headline: Planet Us: Coral Man
text: Ken Nedimyer has started a nursery for staghorn coral in the Florida Keys.

headline: Courting, Fish Fry and All
text: The Democrats’ debate last week offered a prime site for presidential hopefuls to promote their ideas, credentials and, most important, affection for Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina.

headline: Romney Favors Hubbard Novel
text: “What’s your favorite novel?” is a perennial campaign question, the answer to which presumably gives insight into leadership.

headline: 2008 Contenders in the Senate and the War
text: President Bush this week will formally reject the Iraq spending bill, with its timeline for winding down the war. But that will hardly bring the matter to a close for the Democratic presidential hopefuls, especially those in the Senate.

headline: Coachella: View From the VIP Trailer Park
text: Indio, Calif. – If performers are going to come all the way out here, they might as well experience the desert lifestyle, which in this part of California often involves spending time in an RV. Coachella approximates this experience by stowing its artists in a sort of upscale trailer park tucked away on one side of the polo grounds. Virtually every performer, from the co-headlining Red Hot Chili Peppers on down, spends time here, idling between the rows of trailers (they are spruced up with white picket fences and little lawn tables for entertaining guests).

headline: Lonesome George Isn’t Looking So Lonesome
text: Startling news from the Galapagos: Lonesome George could have company. The giant tortoise became an international symbol of conservation as the last surviving member of his species — the “rarest living creature,” according to Guinness World Records. But now it looks as if he’s not the only Pinta island tortoise left on Earth.

headline: Davis Is Face of a Warriors Team Made of Castoffs and Renegades
text: OAKLAND, Calif., April 30 — Baron Davis was hopping, strutting, smiling, almost dancing across the Golden State Warriors’ practice court Monday morning as his teammates waged a half-court shooting contest.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Sesame Street’ Takes On a Role in the Middle East

headline: Sunni Ministers Threaten to Quit Cabinet in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, April 30 — The largest bloc of Sunni Arabs in the Iraqi Parliament threatened to withdraw its ministers from the Shiite-dominated cabinet on Monday in frustration over the government’s failure to deal with Sunni concerns.

headline: The Times Building Is Resold for 3 Times Its 2004 Price
text: Less than three weeks after putting the historic headquarters of The New York Times Company on the block, Tishman Speyer Properties sold the building for $525 million, three times the $175 million it paid in November 2004.

headline: It’s Personal Up in the Stratosphere
text: LONDON, April 30  Nagi Kawkabani, the co-chief executive of Brevan Howard Asset Management, a London-based hedge fund, went on a global road trip to drum up interest in a public offering.

headline: Brooklyn Driver Charged in Bicycle Fatality
text: A Brooklyn man who was arrested Sunday on drunken-driving charges near the scene of a hit-and-run accident that killed a 13-year-old boy riding a bicycle was charged yesterday with vehicular manslaughter, the police said. They said that the boy, Anthony Delgado of Brooklyn, was struck just after midnight on Sunday at the intersection of Palmetto Street and Central Avenue in Bushwick. The man, Melvin Morales, 34, was arrested a short time later, after being stopped for a reason unconnected to the hit and run, the police said. Investigators said that evidence on his sport utility vehicle linked it to the hit and run, and that a surveillance camera had captured images that would provide evidence against Mr. Morales.

headline: A West Coast Orchestra, Distinctly Unmellow
text: The Los Angeles Philharmonic is an exciting orchestra. First, it’s exciting for superficial reasons: it plays in a hot new hall designed by Frank Gehry, and it has just announced its impending transition from one crack former wunderkind conductor, Esa-Pekka Salonen, to another, Gustavo Dudamel, in 2009. But it’s also exciting because of the sound it makes, big and compelling, under Mr. Salonen, who, still boyish and very much in command, showed off the ensemble he has helped to shape on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Uptown, a Company No Longer Plays Nice
text: It was not a major cultural event when the Jean Cocteau Repertory left its longtime home on the Bowery, a few blocks from CBGB, on the Lower East Side. No one protested. For unlike CBGB, which closed to much fanfare in 2006, the Jean Cocteau, which also left that year, was never at the forefront of anything — and perhaps its charm was that it never tried to be.

headline: New York Art College Canceled Deal With Lender After Learning of High Interest Rates
text: Pratt Institute, a New York art and design college, had a deal in 2005 with a student loan company: The lender would provide grant money for needy students if Pratt students over all took out $1 million or more in loans.

headline: Olmert Rebuked by Israeli Panel on Lebanon War
text: JERUSALEM, May 1 — Despite a resounding chorus of calls in Israel for the prime minister, Ehud Olmert, to resign following a report on Monday that excoriated Mr. Olmert for “severe failures” in last summer’s war against the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, his aides insisted today that he had no intention of leaving office.

headline: Baldness and Longevity
text: Q. Is balding an indicator of more rapid aging and a shorter life span?

headline: Bloodlines Worth Their Weight in Gold
text: The dream of Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum to win the Kentucky Derby died this year in the same place it took flight: his desert kingdom, Dubai. His last 3-year-old prospect, a colt named Day Pass, struggled to finish ninth in the U.A.E. Derby.

headline: Protesters Press for Path to Citizenship
text: LOS ANGELES, May 1  Tens of thousands of people pressing for immigrants’ rights demonstrated on Tuesday in dozens of cities. But with advocates splintered over tactics, the crowds paled in comparison with the turnout last year.

headline: In Ducks, War of the Sexes Plays Out in the Evolution of Genitalia
text: LITCHFIELD, Conn. — “This guy’s the champion,” said Patricia Brennan, a behavioral ecologist, leaning over the nether regions of a duck — a Meller’s duck from Madagascar, to be specific — and carefully coaxing out his phallus.

headline: Secularism and Democracy in Turkey
text: The long struggle between Turkey’s generals  the self-appointed custodians of secularism  and the growing popularity of parties rooted in Islam has taken a dangerous turn. Both sides need to step back from the brink for the sake of Turkey’s democracy and its hopes of joining the European Union.

headline: Qaeda Leader May Have Been Killed, Iraqi Official Says
text: BAGHDAD, May 1 — The Iraqi government said today that it was investigating reports from “reliable sources” that the leader of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, the radical Islamist insurgent group, had been killed in an ambush by a rival insurgent faction.

headline: Why Congress Should Embrace the Surge
text: WHEN the civilian hierarchy fails them, soldiers tend to seek solace in Clausewitz’s observation that war is an extension of politics. But in 2005 and 2006 the reverse was true in Iraq: the battle churned in place, steadily eroding the administration’s credibility and America’s psyche, while most politicians stood on the sidelines, content to hurl insults at one another until the battlefield offered a clear political course.

headline: Ivica Racan,  Former Croatian Premier, Is Dead at 63
text: Ivica Racan, the former Croatian prime minister who rebuilt economic and trade ties with Europe after the civil wars of the 1990s, died Sunday in Zagreb, the Croatian capital. He was 63.

headline: In Moscow in 1996, a Doctor’s Visit Changed History
text: It was the fall of 1996, and Boris N. Yeltsin was running for re-election as Russia’s first president in the post-Soviet era. But he faced a crisis far more threatening than any opponent: he was desperately ill.

headline: Dawn Upshaw's Beautiful World of Song
text: “It’s great to be here,” the soprano Dawn Upshaw said on Sunday afternoon at the beginning of her recital at Town Hall. “I mean, really great,” she added, looking misty-eyed, to which the audience responded with a long round of applause and cheers.

headline: A Governor Truly Tightens His Belt
text: SALEM, Ore., April 27 — He swore off beer, had to put the pricey organic bananas back on the supermarket shelf and squeezed four meals out of a single chicken, all in the name of reducing hunger. And this is not even an election year.

headline: BP Chief Resigns Amid Battle With Tabloid
text: Lord John Browne of Madingley, an aggressive but mannered British magnate who transformed BP into one of the most successful, global companies, resigned abruptly on Tuesday in a court battle with a tabloid over details of his personal life.

headline: High Court Puts Limits on Patents
text: WASHINGTON, April 30 — The Supreme Court, in its most important patent ruling in years, on Monday raised the bar for obtaining patents on new products that combine elements of pre-existing inventions.

headline: X Is for Wonderment
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: New York Gambling Treatment Court Stresses Help
text: AMHERST, N.Y. — The docket in front of Justice Mark G. Farrell one recent Tuesday afternoon looked like a routine roster of small-time crime: petty larceny, attempted burglary, check forgery. But the offenders shared a single motivation: money to gamble.

headline: One More Tango for Brando and His Golden Mumble
text: “He was sort of a different type of a person,” ventures Betty Gossell, who went to high school with Marlon Brando in Illinois. A different type of person. That may be the last word on Brando, who died in 2004.

headline: Tommy Newsom, Saxophonist, Dies at 78
text: Tommy Newsom, the good-humored backup bandleader on “The Tonight Show” who earned fame as Johnny Carson’s comical punching bag — and respect among musicians as a composer, arranger and saxophone soloist — died on Saturday at his home in Portsmouth, Va. He was 78.

headline: Torre and Cashman Are Safe, for Now
text: George Steinbrenner made it clear yesterday that he was not ready to fire anybody after 23 games. But with 14 losses already, and a pitching staff that has been exposed as inferior to that of the Boston Red Sox, it is convenient that the Yankees play in Texas this week.

headline: Questions Over Routine Screening for a Leading Cause of Blindness
text: GLAUCOMA, a chronic condition characterized by damage to the optic nerve, is the second-leading cause of blindness in the United States, but routine screening for it is controversial.

headline: Ex-Senator Seen as Rehearsing for Prime Time
text: WASHINGTON, April 30 — When 10 of the declared Republican presidential candidates gather for their first debate on Thursday at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Southern California, Fred D. Thompson, the actor and politician, will not be among them. But he will not be far offstage.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Friday about a new book by George J. Tenet, the former director of central intelligence, gave the incorrect name in some copies for the 2004 award bestowed on him by President Bush. It is the Presidential Medal of Freedom, not the Presidential Medal of Honor.

headline: Citing ‘Rigid’ Deadline, Bush Vetoes Iraq Bill
text: WASHINGTON, May 1 — President Bush vetoed the Iraq-war spending bill this evening, calling it a blueprint for failure and defeat and intensifying a showdown with the Democratic-controlled Congress.

headline: Letters
text: The Mystery of Vanishing Bees

headline: Mets’ Depth Faces Test as 2 Players Go on D.L.
text: By almost all measures, the Mets had an impressive April. On the last day of the month, however, they were confronted with injuries to two prominent players, then were hammered by the Florida Marlins at Shea Stadium.

headline: Philippine Police Close Case in American’s Killing
text: MANILA, May 1 — The Philippine authorities say they consider a case in which an American Peace Corps volunteer was brutally killed to be closed after a suspect confessed to the crime.

headline: The Names Are Vintage, the Touches Modern
text: THEY used to say that life begins at 40. For a familiar advertising character, the lonely Maytag repairman, a new life is beginning at 40 as he gets a major personality makeover.

headline: Torn by University Shootings, Virginia Town Turns Inward to Mend
text: BLACKSBURG, Va., April 28 — In a small yarn shop near the Virginia Tech campus, Molly Heterick sat knitting at a wooden table with her friends this week, looping coarse strands of wool over her needles until a small patch in the colors of the university started to take shape.

headline: Bill on Iraq to Be Delivered 4 Years After Bush’s Words
text: WASHINGTON, April 30 — Democratic leaders in Congress are planning a special ceremony on Tuesday afternoon to send President Bush a bill that sets timetables for troop withdrawal from Iraq.

headline: Ortiz Writes Another Chapter in a Yankees Horror Story
text: It’s a good thing for Joe Torre’s tenuous job security that the Tampa-based George Steinbrenner seldom ventures into Midtown Manhattan anymore. The Boss, already in a blue statement-making mood yesterday, would have had the same visceral reaction that some Yankees fans had on their lunchtime strolls past the Barnes & Noble bookstore on Fifth Avenue.

headline: Israeli Leader Resists Calls to Resign
text: JERUSALEM, May 1 — The newspapers were vituperative, opposition politicians fulminated and a young cabinet minister resigned, but Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel pressed ahead today with what aides called “a normal working schedule,” in the wake of a damning report about his performance in the first few days of last summer’s war against Hezbollah.

headline: Victim Describes 13 Hours of Sexual Torment, and Clues Left Behind
text: She was putting the finishing touches on a Halloween costume from Cheap Jack’s Vintage Clothing store on Oct. 31, 2005, when she heard the pounding at the door of her Chelsea apartment. Through the peephole, she saw thick white smoke and a man in full firefighting gear, a plastic visor obscuring his face, who demanded to be let in.

headline: G.E. Moves Ahead on Removal of PCBs From 2 Rivers, but Frustration Remains
text: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — More than 30 years have passed since Congress banned a broad range of synthetic compounds called PCBs. Yet 2.65 million cubic yards of mud on the bottom of the Hudson River remain contaminated with the chemicals, which are considered neurotoxins and probable human carcinogens.

headline: Officer Testifies Against U.S. Military Jailer in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, April 30  A senior commander in the American military’s main detention center here testified Monday at a military hearing that his predecessor, Lt. Col. William H. Steele, gave computer programs and other gifts to the daughter of a high-value detainee.

headline: Gold Stars and Dunce Caps
text: In this presidential campaign, we need somebody who wants to address the question President Bush once raised: “Is our children learning?”

headline: How to Be More Effective (and Less Annoying and Counterproductive)
text: IT takes both a special mind-set and certain skills to build a successful company.

headline: Satire With the Blessing of Lady Luck Herself
text: Most humor sites begin when some smart-aleck at an old media company begins nagging: “We have to launch a more robust entertainment vertical, guys.” But Black20 has a cool creation myth.

headline: Food Imports Often Escape Scrutiny
text: Early in the 20th century, the safeguarding of food at American ports often amounted to inspectors from the Food and Drug Administration prying open containers of molasses or sugar and examining them for mold or insect parts.

headline: New Orleans Homecoming (for the Lucky Ones)
text: NEW ORLEANS, April 30 — Every so often at this year’s New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival over the weekend, musicians would announce that they were finally back in their old homes after being displaced for a more than a year by Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Administration Proposes New Energy Drilling
text: WASHINGTON, April 30 — The Bush administration proposed on Monday leasing out millions of acres along the coasts of Alaska and Virginia to oil and gas drillers, a move that would end a longstanding ban on drilling in those environmentally sensitive areas.

headline: What's on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) BRANDO “Before Brando, actors acted,” says Michael Winner, who directed Marlon Brando in “The Nightcomers.” “After Brando, they behaved. That is the difference — an extraordinary effect on the history of drama and the history of movies.” This two-part documentary tries to unlock the enigma of Brando (above, in “The Wild One,” from 1953) through interviews with everyone from his former high school classmates to the likes of Al Pacino, Martin Scorsese, Jon Voight, Jane Fonda, Robert Duvall and Dennis Hopper. It also includes film of Brando onstage and on screen, from “Truckline Café,” which first earned him recognition on Broadway, through “A Streetcar Named Desire,” which catapulted him over the top, with stops at “Julius Caesar,” in which he proved he could enunciate; “The Godfather,” his signature work; and the intimate “Last Tango in Paris.”

headline: Court Strikes Law Barring Sale of Drug Data
text: A federal judge ruled yesterday that the pharmaceutical industry could continue to use computerized data showing which doctors are prescribing what drugs.

headline: Depression Raises Risk of Diabetes, Study Finds
text: Depression is associated with an increased risk for diabetes in older adults, even in people who have no other risk factors for the disease, a new study reports.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about plans by the injured New Jersey governor, Jon S. Corzine, to leave a Camden hospital early this week and continue his recovery at Drumthwacket, the governor’s mansion in Princeton, gave an erroneous figure in some copies for the estimated value of his assets, as reported in a 2005 financial disclosure form for the United States Senate, where he served before being elected governor. He said his assets were worth up to $261 million, not up to $61 million. An article about Governor Corzine’s discharge from the hospital yesterday appears today on Page B1.

headline: Senate Takes Up Bill to Change Drug Agency Operations
text: WASHINGTON, April 30 — The Senate began debate on Monday on a bill that could fundamentally change the way the Food and Drug Administration operates by giving it more power and money to ensure that drugs are as safe as advertised.

headline: Abuse Victim Suing Church Testifies He Is Still in Pain
text: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., April 30  The body language may have been as telling as the testimony.

headline: A Meal, a Smile, a Word: Thanks in a Thousand Ways
text: To operate on a patient without receiving a fee is the most satisfying of memories, the greatest of privileges. It leaves a glow, a high — the feeling young doctors must get these days when they go to third-world countries, repair cleft lips and palates, or build hospitals.

headline: Corzine Leaves Hospital After Accident
text: PRINCETON, N.J., April 30 — Gov. Jon S. Corzine apologized to New Jersey residents on Monday as he left the hospital 18 days after being critically injured in a car crash in which he was being driven at 91 miles per hour on the Garden State Parkway while riding without his seat belt.

headline: Even After Two Overtimes, the Rangers Stay Fresh
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., April 30 — On a rink filled with the young players who never miss a practice, optional or not, Rangers forward Jaromir Jagr skated around with a big smile.

headline: Searching for Sleep and Decent Clothing
text: I never wanted to be the poster boy for the bad effects of jet lag. I always had visions of myself as being the archetypal business traveler: one of those folks who arrives at the airport fresh and pressed, and somehow manages to exit the plane looking the same way.

headline: Memo Pad
text: CESSNA DELIVERS VERY LIGHT JET As the very light jet market stirs to life, the Cessna Aircraft Company delivered its first retail Citation Mustang jet last week to Goode Ski Technologies. Goode is currently flying a Cessna 310 twin-engine piston propeller aircraft, and says it bought the Mustang to make it easier to travel to ski locations to test its products. Cessna already has two Mustangs flying for marketing purposes. The $2.5 million, four-passenger Mustang is the latest model of a very light jet to enter commercial service. Eclipse Aviation recently delivered three of its Eclipse 500 very light jets to DayJet, a company that plans to begin on-demand air-taxi service in June and has ordered 239 of the aircraft. Competitors producing very light jets, which are sometimes called microjets, include Adam Aircraft, Honda, Embraer and Piper. A new online magazine, www.verylightjets.com, is devoted exclusively to the new aircraft.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on April 21 about the French film actor Jean-Pierre Cassel omitted some survivors. Besides his son the actor Vincent Cassel, they include another son from his first marriage, Matthias; his second wife, Anne Célérier; and their daughter, Cécile.

headline: Signs of Mourning Follow the Cardinals
text: MILWAUKEE, April 30 — The little boy and the little girl wore St. Louis Cardinals jerseys and caps, stationed themselves by the third-base dugout and held a tribute sign for Josh Hancock. They had drawn a red-and-white uniform with Hancock’s name, his No. 32 and the words “Will Be Missed.”

headline: Newspaper Circulation in Steep Slide Across Nation
text: Newspaper sales continue a steep slide nationally, figures released Monday show, but two New York City tabloids continued to buck the trend, posting the largest gains among major papers.

headline: Elliott Skinner, Scholar and Former Ambassador, Dies at 82
text: Elliott P. Skinner, a former United States ambassador to the Republic of Upper Volta, the West African nation now known as Burkina Faso, and a former chairman of the anthropology department at Columbia University, died April 1 at his home in Washington. He was 82.

headline: Bush Steps Up Effort to Persuade Putin on Missile Defense Plan
text: WASHINGTON, April 30 — President Bush, under pressure from allies in Europe to be more forthcoming about his plans for basing missile interceptors in the region, said Monday that he was intensifying his efforts to persuade Russia to cooperate with the United States on the initiative “so that they don’t see us as an antagonistic force, but see us as a friendly force.”

headline: Recruiting Plankton to Fight Global Warming
text: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 — Can plankton help save the planet?

headline: The Power of Negative Thinking
text: We Americans believe instinctively in the power of positive thinking. Whether one is fighting a cancer, an insurgency or just an unyielding problem at work, the prevailing wisdom is that thinking positive is the key — The Secret, even — to success. But the key, it seems to me, is actually negative thinking: looking for, and sometimes expecting, failure.

headline: Among Chimps and Bonobos, the Hand Often Does the Talking
text: Why is it that when people are yakking away on their cellphones, they often accompany their activity with face and hand gestures, a performance that their distant listener cannot see and does not need?

headline: The Claim: Heat Wraps Ease Back Pain
text: THE FACTS

headline: Interpreting Some Overlooked Stories From the South
text: The gripping black-and-white photographs of civil rights protesters in the South reflect the black-and-white morality tale that generally accompanies them. Hateful, jeering white mobs and attack dogs versus peaceful marchers asking to vote and to walk in the front door.

headline: A New Policy on Iran (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Simple Need, All Too Often Unmet
text: On a recent trip to Sydney, Australia, I discovered the true meaning of civilization — public toilets, lots of them, clean, neat, safe, free of graffiti, working flushes and faucets, and well-stocked with toilet paper, along with paper towels or hand dryers. Most are free (some are automatic pay toilets) and available 24 hours. One free 24-hour toilet under the Darling Harbor Bridge appeared to have just been remodeled with colorful tiles.

headline: How to Halve the Death Rate From Colon Cancer
text: EVEN though screening tests can prevent colorectal cancer or find it early enough to cure, the disease is still the second-leading cause of cancer death in the United States, with nearly 165,000 new cases and more than 52,000 deaths expected this year.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about violence in movies involving college students in the wake of the shootings at Virginia Tech referred incorrectly to “Battle Royale,” which is about ninth graders imprisoned on an island who are forced to kill one another. It was originally a novel, not a video game.

headline: Google Calls Viacom Suit on YouTube Unfounded
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., April 30 — Responding to Viacom’s $1 billion copyright infringement suit over video clips on YouTube, Google said Monday that it would not back off, declaring that the law was on its side.

headline: Morocco Talks Set in Western Sahara Dispute
text: Morocco and the Polisario Front, which are struggling for control of resource-rich Western Sahara, agreed to hold direct talks for the first time under the terms of a unanimously passed United Nations Security Council resolution. Morocco, which annexed the Front in 1979, hopes to incorporate it as an autonomous province with its own regional government. The Polisario Front wants a referendum that will offer the 260,000 residents the choice of autonomy or independence from Morocco.

headline: Amid Bare Breasts and Love Stories, Audience Participation
text: A warning: breasts will be bared in “Exposed: Experiments in Love, Sex, Death and Art,” a new show at Collective: Unconscious in TriBeCa. Since Annie Sprinkle, the pornography star turned performance artist, is a key participant in the proceedings, this is not entirely surprising. But amateur exhibitionists, too, are given a chance to display their wares in one of the evening’s interactive moments, when Ms. Sprinkle and Elizabeth Stephens, her partner in three of the four titular experiences, swarm the audience with digital cameras early on, looking for volunteers to join the party.

headline: Staten Island Borough Has City’s Worst Smog
text: New Yorkers who moved to Staten Island to escape congestion and pollution will be disappointed to hear that while air quality deteriorated in all five boroughs over the past year, it is worst in Staten Island, according to the eighth annual air pollution report by the American Lung Association. The report, which is scheduled to be released today, found that ozone pollution — or smog — is highest on Staten Island. And particle pollution, usually known as soot, has become substantially worse there, as well as in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Louise A. Vetter, chief executive of the American Lung Association of the City of New York, said that among the factors that contribute to Staten Island’s pollution are the heavy volume of vehicular traffic and diesel exhaust from ferries and barges in New York Harbor. Prevailing winds and other meteorological phenomena may also cause pollution from other states to hover over Staten Island, Ms. Vetter said.

headline: This One Will Floor You
text: A new campaign is seeking to take the “hard” out of buying hardwood floors.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 30, 2007

headline: Medicare Advantage (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Washington Wants to Know: Who’s on Escort Service List?
text: WASHINGTON, April 30 — The woman who faces charges of running a prostitution ring in Washington that serviced the prominent and powerful said Monday that she intended to force many of those clients to testify in her behalf.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about a New York subway track worker who was struck and killed by a train at Columbus Circle included erroneous information from the State Transportation Department about an investigation of the accident. New York City Transit is investigating — not the Transportation Department, which investigates only passenger accidents.

headline: Wider Screenings for H.I.V. Are Recommended
text: WHILE the annual number of new H.I.V. infections is sharply lower than in the peak years of the 1980s, the effort to reduce the infection rate further has stalled in the last decade. So the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention now recommends screening for H.I.V. as a routine part of health care, and not just for people in known risk groups.

headline: U.S. Says Some Chicken Feed Tainted
text: CHICAGO, April 30  Government investigators said Monday that byproducts from pet food contaminated with wheat gluten imported from China were used in chicken feed on some farms in Indiana.

headline: Virginia Ends a Loophole in Gun Laws
text: WASHINGTON, April 30  Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia closed a loophole Monday in the state’s gun laws that allowed a mentally disturbed Virginia Tech student to buy the guns used in a shooting rampage that left 33 dead at the university on April 16.

headline: A Day After a Fiery Crash, Bay Area Commuters Enjoy a Surprisingly Easy Ride
text: OAKLAND, Calif., April 30 — A day after a fiery gasoline tanker crash melted and collapsed a critical highway interchange near the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, drivers in the Bay Area enjoyed a relatively painless commute on Monday as an expected rush hour nightmare largely failed to materialize.

headline: 5 Britons Guilty; Tied to 2005 London Bombers
text: LONDON, April 30 — A jury found five British Muslim men guilty on Monday of planning fertilizer-bomb attacks around London, ending a yearlong trial that linked the plotters with two of the four men who blew themselves up on London’s transit system in July 2005.

headline: Japan Wages Fell in March
text: Wages in Japan fell for a fourth month in March, signaling that growth in consumer spending will be limited. Monthly wages, including overtime and bonuses, fell 0.4 percent after dropping 1 percent in February, the labor ministry said. In China, manufacturing activity expanded at the fastest pace in more than two years in April, according to a survey of purchasing managers. The Purchasing Managers’ Index rose to 58.6 from 56.1 in March, the statistics bureau said. That is the highest since the index started in January 2005.

headline: Looking for a Home in the Limbo of Alaska
text: From the moment of his precocious debut in 1988 with “The Mysteries of Pittsburgh,” it was clear that Michael Chabon was an immensely gifted writer and a magical prose stylist. The tales in “A Model World and Other Stories” and “Werewolves in Their Youth” showcased his ability to do wonderful things with words, to conjure everything from the banalities of daily life to the most bizarre of melodrama, just as “Wonder Boys” demonstrated his ability to do slapstick comedy with as much ardor and panache as more serious, emotional material.

headline: Sudan U.N. Peacekeeping Mission Extended
text: The Security Council endorsed a resolution extending by six months the 10,000-member United Nations mission that helps enforce the 2005 peace accord that ended decades of civil war in southern Sudan. The measure expressed “grave concern” over the crisis in Darfur, in western Sudan, but to achieve the unanimous backing of the 15-member Council the United States had to drop language putting pressure on Sudan to accept a proposed United Nations-African Union peacekeeping force there.

headline: Atlanta’s Mayor Defends Chief Against Misconduct Accusations
text: ATLANTA, April 30  Mayor Shirley Franklin defended the city’s police chief Monday against charges by federal prosecutors that a “culture of misconduct” in the Police Department contributed to the shooting death of an elderly woman in a botched drug raid last fall.

headline: Secaucus Turnpike Carjacking Reported
text: Three men posing as police officers pulled over a vehicle on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday afternoon, forced the passengers to the ground and stole the car, the state police said. The victims, who were not identified, told the police that three men in a white Ford Explorer pulled alongside their southbound Toyota Avalon near the Alexander Hamilton rest area on the turnpike, held up silver badges on chains around their necks, and motioned for the driver to pull over, said Sgt. Jeanne Hengemuhle, a spokeswoman for the state police. The men pulled into the rest area, where they were forced out of the car and onto the ground. One of the men from the Ford got into the Toyota, which had a New York license plate, DUU-2791, and both cars sped off, the sergeant said.

headline: Parish Puts Vandalized Statue Back on Its Feet, Again
text: SOMEBODY keeps knocking Jesus off his pedestal outside St. Martin of Tours Church in the Bronx. This time, vandals streaked the face with black marker and wrote “devil” and “666,” and the half-smashed statue spent most of last week propped up against the pedestal as if recovering from a dizzy spell.

headline: S.I.-Linked Murder Suspect Is Returned to Colombia
text: One of the men suspected in last month’s murder and dismemberment of a Staten Island woman in Panama has been returned to his native Colombia by Costa Rica despite being one of Panama’s most wanted men, the authorities in Panama and Costa Rica said yesterday.

headline: Fireproofing of Most Overpasses and Bridges Is Costly and Rare
text: LOS ANGELES, April 30  They are built in most cases to withstand ferocious winds and, here in California, the heaving of earthquakes. But most major highway bridges and overpasses are not fireproof and probably never will be.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption in The Arts on Saturday with an article about Carol Williams, the civic organist for San Diego, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph, of the organ she plays and the pavilion that shelters it, was by Robert Harrington, not Donald MacKenzie.

headline: Views of Parents, Students and Teachers Sought
text: The Department of Education has begun a citywide survey of more than 1.8 million parents, students and teachers concerning their attitudes about the public schools, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced yesterday.

headline: Conduct Costs Some Players More Than Others
text: Perhaps it was fitting that one of the biggest stories of the N.F.L. draft was the acquisition of a player with a long and colorful history of character issues by a team that usually stays away from them. Maybe that player, Randy Moss, will never pretend to moon a bunch of Jets fans. But the New England Patriots were willing to take that risk, one day after they also took one with their first-round pick, Brandon Meriweather, who was prominently involved in an on-field brawl last season only months after he fired his gun when defending his roommate during a robbery attempt.

headline: Instead of Leaping, Sumatran Orangutans Sway From Tree to Tree
text: For animals that spend most of their time in trees, getting around can be costly. Jumping the gap from a thin branch to another tree can be inefficient (not to mention risky), because the bending branch absorbs some of the jump energy. Another option is climbing down one tree and up the other, but this takes energy, too.

headline: Coal’s Energy Potential Is an Engineering Challenge Now
text: WASHINGTON — Coal is so cheap and so widely available that its increased use is inevitable, but clearing the hurdle to burning it on a wide scale — separating the carbon dioxide and sequestering it — could turn out to be one of the great engineering challenges of the century, energy experts say.

headline: Mental Abilities: ‘Sleep on It,’ It Appears, Really Is Good Advice
text: Sleeping on the job is not generally a good idea, but when it comes to the brain it may be another matter.

headline: Turkish Court Blocks Islamist Candidate
text: ANKARA, Turkey, May 1 — Turkey’s constitutional court today supported an effort to block a candidate for the country’s presidency whose background is in political Islam, pitching the country into early national elections and a referendum on the role of religion in its future.

headline: Heated Cross-Examination at the Conrad Black Trial
text: CHICAGO, April 30 — The cross-examination of a crucial witness at the trial of Conrad M. Black grew heated on Monday when a defense lawyer attempted to portray the witness as forgetful or inept.

headline: To Nurture the Next Einstein (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Profit Surges at Loews
text: Loews, a holding company run by the Tisch family of New York, said yesterday that first-quarter profit climbed 42 percent on gains in its insurance, cigarette and oil-drilling units.

headline: Terrorist Attacks in Iraq and Afghanistan Rose Sharply Last Year, State Department Says
text: WASHINGTON, April 30  Terrorist attacks against noncombatants nearly doubled in Iraq from 2005 to 2006 and were up sharply in Afghanistan, with those two countries alone accounting for a 29 percent increase in terrorism worldwide, according to a report released Monday by the State Department.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign misstated the cause of a fire aboard the aircraft carrier Forrestal, which killed 134 of Mr. McCain’s shipmates during his Navy career. It resulted from the explosion of an American rocket on the deck, not an attack.

headline: Report Assails Wal-Mart Over Unions
text: In its first study of how an American company treats its workers, Human Rights Watch asserted yesterday that Wal-Mart’s aggressive efforts to keep out labor unions often violated federal law and infringed on its workers’ rights.

headline: Free Drug Samples? Bad Idea, Some Say
text: Everyone loves freebies, and patients are no exception. So drug company sales representatives try to keep sample cabinets in medical offices well stocked with the latest medications, for doctors to dispense as the need arises.

headline: A Slam-Dunk of a Book Tour Comes to Town
text: George J. Tenet, originally of Little Neck, Queens, returned to his hometown yesterday to peddle a book and, not coincidentally, himself.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Thursday about a reduction in the number of schools that the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation says it can build or rehabilitate with the money it has on hand referred incorrectly to the status of the agency’s previous projects and to their costs. Fifty-six — not zero — projects have been completed in the past five years, including 30 new schools and 26 major renovations. The more than $5 billion spent so far includes $1.25 billion for these projects as well as land acquisition and planning for others; the $5 billion was not spent on land purchases and planning costs alone. (Go to Article)

headline: Trenton Additional Storm Disaster Designations
text: Three New Jersey counties  Camden, Gloucester and Mercer  were added yesterday to President Bush’s disaster declaration in regard to the northeaster of April 15. Last week, the president declared disaster areas in Bergen, Burlington, Essex, Passaic, Somerset and Union Counties, with Hudson, Middlesex and Morris added on Saturday. Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey had requested that the entire state receive the designation, which gives residents access to federal aid. The president also allowed for infrastructure repairs to municipalities in 11 counties.

headline: Coral Is Dying. Can It Be Reborn?
text: TAVERNIER, Fla. — Clouds were moving across the sun and a 20-knot northeast wind was stirring a 3-foot chop as Meaghan Johnson headed her open boat into the Florida Straits.

headline: Shots Against Cancer (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,337 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Outcomes: Study Finds That Cutting Salt Also Cuts Cardiovascular Risk
text: If lowering sodium intake reduces the risk of high blood pressure, and high blood pressure can lead to heart disease, does eating less salt improve the health of one’s heart?

headline: Raise for State Judges Gets Caught in Crossfire Between Spitzer and Bruno
text: ALBANY, April 30 — State judges have gone more than eight years without a pay raise. It appears they may not get one soon.

headline: New DVDs
text: REEL BASEBALL: 1899-1926

headline: A California Max Yasgur for a New Woodstock
text: INDIO, Calif., April 29 — Alexander Haagen III is an unfamiliar figure to the tens of thousands of music fans who converged in the California desert this past weekend for the annual Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival. But more than any rock hero, he wields profound influence here: he is the real estate developer who owns the Empire Polo Club, the gilt-edged grounds where the festival is staged.

headline: Unspent 9/11 Funds Returning to New Jersey Coffer
text: TRENTON, April 30  In 2003, when post-9/11 security fears were still fresh, New Jersey appropriated $23 million to help local governments buy equipment they might need to meet emergencies. But according to the state attorney general, municipalities failed to spend $2.78 million of that money.

headline: Correction
text: An article on Thursday about a reduction in the number of schools that the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation says it can build or rehabilitate with the money it has on hand referred incorrectly to the status of the agency’s previous projects and to their costs. Fifty-six — not zero — projects have been completed in the past five years, including 30 new schools and 26 major renovations. The more than $5 billion spent so far includes $1.25 billion for these projects as well as land acquisition and planning for others; the $5 billion was not spent on land purchases and planning costs alone.

headline: How Does Your Waistline Matter? Let Us Count the Ways.
text: AT age 39, with diabetes and high blood pressure in her family, Linda M. was starting to worry about her weight and its health consequences. She was 5 feet 6 inches tall and weighed 170 pounds, which placed her in the overweight category, according to the standard definition. Although she was not officially obese, she said, “I realized I was not at my ideal weight.”

headline: Post-Minimalist Inspirations, From Bells to Subway Noise
text: The basic elements of Minimalism — tonality, rhythmic regularity, repetition of brief melodic cells — are reasonably easy to summarize. Post-Minimalism is harder to pin down: Composers lumped under this untidy rubric vary widely in style. Just how widely was demonstrated in a program presented on Saturday night by the adventurous new-music ensemble Opus 21, based in Kalamazoo, Mich., at the Leonard Nimoy Thalia Theater at Symphony Space.

headline: Two Stars Push Each Other, and Nets, to New Heights
text: Coming off a two-game tour de force, the Nets stars Jason Kidd and Vince Carter are showing why they may be considered among the N.B.A.’s greatest perimeter tandems. But they are still without a championship, and their place in history remains to be determined.

headline: To: The Temporarily Able-Bodied
text: Just about everyone who works pays taxes into the fund for federal disability benefits. But mercifully, relatively few people ever collect. To qualify, you must be unable to work, and your disability must be of such severity that you’ll be out for at least a year or you’re likely to die from it.

headline: Cambodia Tribunal Clears Procedural Hurdle
text: BANGKOK, May 1 — For a moment, it appeared that $2,700 might be enough to save the mass killers of the Khmer Rouge from going on trial.

headline: For Motherly X Chromosome, Gender Is Only the Beginning
text: As May dawns and the mothers among us excitedly anticipate the clever e-cards that we soon will be linking to and the overpriced brunches that we will somehow end up paying for, the following job description may ring a familiar note:

headline: Senators Question Halliburton Executive About Dealings in Iran
text: WASHINGTON, April 30  A Halliburton executive, facing withering criticism from Democratic lawmakers during a Senate hearing on Monday about the company’s business dealings in Iran, insisted that the firm had not broken any laws.

headline: Don’t Trust Your Ears: This Play Is Not a Musical
text: On a recent evening, the creative team of a new Broadway show were entrenched in a technical rehearsal. A cast of 40 waited onstage for instruction while the show’s composer, Adrian Sutton, consulted with its director, Melly Still, about an element of the sound design. Mr. Sutton then dashed down the aisle to the orchestra pit for a tête-à-tête with the musical director, Constantine Kitsopoulos.

headline: Help, by the Book
text: The State of Washington is looking out for students and their families by passing a law requiring textbook companies to disclose prices and other relevant information when they market books to college professors in the state. Lawmakers hope that professors who learn the costs upfront will opt for reasonably priced textbooks that cash-strapped students can afford.

headline: Magazine Learns to Heed Its Own Advice
text: Business 2.0, the technology-aware magazine published by Time Inc., periodically reminds readers of the importance of backing up computer files. A 2003 article likened backups to flossing — everyone knows it’s important, but few devote enough thought or energy to it.

headline: A Rock Festival Whose Hallmark Is Taste
text: INDIO, Calif., April 30 — The Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival may have to start sharpening its identity.

headline: Court Backs Police in Chase That Hurt Driver
text: WASHINGTON, April 30 — The police did not violate a speeding driver’s rights by ramming his car and causing an accident that left him permanently paralyzed, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday by a vote of 8 to 1.

headline: Arctic Sea Ice Melting Faster, a Study Finds
text: Climate scientists may have significantly underestimated the power of global warming from human-generated heat-trapping gases to shrink the cap of sea ice floating on the Arctic Ocean, according to a new study of polar trends.

headline: Steroids Dealer Testified to the Bonds Grand Jury
text: Kirk Radomski, the former Mets clubhouse assistant who has admitted selling performance-enhancing drugs to dozens of current and former professional baseball players, testified last Thursday in front of a federal grand jury investigating steroid use in sports.

headline: War in the Pacific: It’s Hell, Especially if You’re a Goat
text: PUERTO AYORA, Galápagos Islands — Gripping a semiautomatic rifle, Alonso Carrión, a ranger at Galápagos National Park, recently showed off an impressive arsenal inside a well-guarded complex here.

headline: Chinese E-Commerce Company Said to Plan Public Offering
text: SHANGHAI, April 30 — Alibaba.com, China’s leading e-commerce company, is planning to go public later this year in what could be the biggest initial public offering ever for a Chinese Internet company, according to people briefed on the deal.

headline: Trail Mix Isn’t Just for Hikers
text: As tarmac-sitting stories mount and the Transportation Department investigates the possibility of unrealistic flight schedules, nutrition experts are in agreement: carry-on food is crucial for business travelers.

headline: Revised Genocide Exhibit Opens
text: A United Nations exhibit on the Rwandan genocide that was dismantled three weeks ago after Turkey objected to a reference to the Armenian genocide was opened in revised form by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon. Where the original exhibit had an entry called “What is genocide?” that cited the deaths “following World War I” of a million Armenians “in Turkey,” the revised entry is called “Defining the Crime” and refers to “mass killings of Armenians in the Ottoman Empire during World War I.” Some 1.5 million Armenians were killed by Ottoman Turks, but Turkey says they were victims of war and unrest instead of genocide. The exhibit observes the 13th anniversary of the 100-day slaughter in Rwanda of 800,000 Tutsis by Hutus.

headline: Two Giants Vie for Bank in Chicago
text: Like deep-dish pizza, the Cubs and a mayor named Daley, LaSalle Bank has long been a Chicago institution. But until a few weeks ago, few would have called it a global banking prize.

headline: Wolfowitz Goes on the Attack, but Hints at a Deal
text: WASHINGTON, April 30  Paul D. Wolfowitz defended himself vigorously on Monday, declaring that it would be “unjust and frankly hypocritical” for the World Bank’s board to find him guilty of ethical lapses. But he also hinted that he would discuss whether to resign as bank president if the board cleared him of misconduct.

headline: The Fountain of Youth Is as Near as the Next Party
text: Jules Peimer was a white-capped wave in a sea of staid blue suits. He wore a black velvet jacket, a white silk shirt and a psychedelic tie you might find in the artist Martin Sharp’s closet.

headline: Don’t ‘Robocall’ Me (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Resignation at M.I.T. (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Some Ask if U.S. Attorney Dismissals Point to Pattern of Investigating Democrats
text: WASHINGTON, April 30 — When a jury acquitted Carl J. Marlinga, a former county prosecutor from suburban Detroit, of bribery charges last year, his initial reaction was to write off the episode as a terrible mistake that at least had been corrected.

headline: Costs and Divestitures Cut Verizon's Profit
text: Merger costs and the divestiture of some businesses drove Verizon’s profit down 8.4 percent in the first quarter, but the company continued to have strong growth in wireless and broadband subscriptions.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about a federal investigation of misconduct in the Atlanta Police Department misidentified an officer charged in a botched drug raid whose lawyer is John Garland. He is Jason R. Smith — not Arthur Tesler, another officer charged in the raid.

headline: As Deportation Pace Rises, Illegal Immigrants Dig In
text: NEW BEDFORD, Mass. — The day after his wife was deported to their home country, Honduras, Lilo Mancía grieved as though she had died.

headline: A Pianist With an Ear for Structure
text: The degree to which structure and symmetry matter to the pianist Maurizio Pollini is evident in the two programs he assembled for his Carnegie Hall recitals this season. The first, on Sunday afternoon, balanced two standard repertory composers, Chopin and Debussy, against a modernist, Pierre Boulez. The second, scheduled for May 12, is built similarly, with Beethoven and Schumann from the standard canon, and Karlheinz Stockhausen as the contemporary voice. The composers on the first program all worked in Paris, although one (Chopin) was an immigrant. On the second, the composers are all German, although one (Beethoven) moved to Vienna.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Appeal of Mexican Death Row Inmate
text: WASHINGTON, April 30 — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear an appeal from a Mexican citizen on death row in Texas whose case has embroiled the World Court, the Bush administration and the State of Texas in a conflict that has only deepened in the two years since the justices last considered how to resolve it.

headline: Safety Panel Blames Pilot Error in Lidle Crash
text: WASHINGTON, May 1 — The crash that killed Cory Lidle, the Yankees pitcher, and his flight instructor in Manhattan on Oct. 11 was caused by “inadequate planning, judgment, and airmanship” by the two men, the National Transportation Safety Board concluded today.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a Media Talk report in Business Day yesterday, about an accusation by the magazine Radar that a Chilean publication had plagiarized its article “Toxic Bachelors,” misspelled the surname of a book author who had previously used the title phrase. She is Danielle Steel, not Steele.

headline: Secular Parties Vow to Battle Prime Minister in Turkish Vote
text: ANKARA, Turkey, April 30 — Turkey’s secular political leaders promised Monday to mount a unified challenge to Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan in what are likely to be early national elections. The country’s financial markets, meanwhile, dropped sharply.

headline: Lord Arthur Learns About Love and Death and the Importance of Being Insouciant
text: Oscar Wilde’s short story “Lord Arthur Savile’s Crime” is a clever mystery, written to indict the fate industry — the palmists, spiritualists and telepathists, frauds every one of the them, with whom late-19th-century aristocrats seemed so enthralled. The writer Rob Urbinati has used the story, with its dramatic twists and turns, as a blueprint for his latest theatrical effort, “West Moon Street.” And while it might seem a bit like taking paprika to Hungary, to lighten up Oscar Wilde he has molded the story into a briskly paced comedy of manners true to its author’s greater spirit.

headline: U.S. Says Raids Killed Taliban; Afghans Say Civilians Died
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 30  United States Special Forces said they killed more than 130 Taliban in two recent days of heavy fighting in a valley in western Afghanistan, but hundreds of angry villagers protested in nearby Shindand on Monday, saying dozens of civilians had been killed when the Americans called in airstrikes.

headline: Bloomberg Unveils Plan to Redevelop Willets Point
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled today what he called his master plan to transform the Willets Point section of Queens, an unsightly enclave of junkyards and auto-repair shops near Shea Stadium, into a retailing and entertainment district with new homes and office space.

headline: Octavio Frias, 94, Brazilian Media Executive, Dies
text: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 30 — Octavio Frias de Oliveira, who built one of Brazil’s biggest and most influential media empires, died at his home in São Paulo on Sunday. He was 94.

headline: Business Class to London: Cheaper Than You Might Think
text: HOW about some good news for a change? Business-class fares on trans-Atlantic routes are coming down. Major airlines are improving their international routes and reducing capacity on domestic routes as lower-fare competition becomes more aggressive.

headline: Work Stays on Hold After Deaths in Subway
text: In response to the deaths of two track workers in accidents, transit officials yesterday suspended more than 20 maintenance projects for subway tracks, signals and tunnels for at least two more days.

headline: Law Day
text: President Dwight Eisenhower established May 1 as Law Day to co-opt the biggest day on the socialist calendar. While much of the world marked May Day with critiques of capitalism and parades celebrating working men and women, the United States would honor, President Eisenhower declared, the “national dedication to the principle of government under laws.”

headline: When It Comes to Careers, Change Is a Constant
text: When Ted Greenberg left the field of suicide research to become a stand-up comic, he sent out a mass e-mail that began with the following:

headline: Latest Developments in a Crosstown Rivalry
text: Home plate at Citi Field in Flushing is marked by a patch of Astroturf. In the Bronx, an outcropping of New York schist was leveled by chisel hammers attached to earth movers to clear the land for the future home plate at the new Yankee Stadium.

headline: An Acting Governor’s Balancing Act: Taking the Lead Without Stepping on Toes
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J. — First, there was a vicious northeaster, a deadly, drenching storm that pinwheeled its way across New Jersey, soaking the state with one of its worst water-related disasters in more than a century.

headline: The Wheezing That Could Signal Childhood Asthma
text: LATE last fall, Carrie R., a public relations executive who lives in Riverdale in the Bronx, noticed that her 2-year-old daughter had been suffering from a nagging cough for far too long. She assumed the toddler had caught a cold or was reacting to the change in weather.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Feb. 3 about efforts by Gov. Rick Perry of Texas to require sixth-grade girls to be vaccinated against a virus that causes cervical cancer misstated the length of time over which the vaccine’s three shots are administered. (The error was pointed out after it was repeated in an article on Thursday.) They are given over six months, not eight months.

headline: Nutrition: Shortage of Vitamin D May Weaken the Elderly
text: Too little vitamin D is a common problem among elderly people that may help bring on medical conditions that cause weakness and disability.

headline: Getting the Clearest Look at a Hurting Hip
text: LAST fall, after experiencing a dull ache in his hip for months, Frank Berger felt the pain escalating so much that he couldn’t sleep. Walking became so difficult that Mr. Berger, a 59-year-old accountant in Nantucket, Mass., had to ask his secretary to bring him documents from the printer only 40 feet away.

headline: Heart Scans: Finding More Than You May Need to Know
text: WHEN George Skouras, an investment manager in New York, turned 52, he decided to go for a complete physical exam. He felt perfectly healthy, but wanted to know if there was anything to worry about.

headline: Iraq Puzzle: Getting In, Getting Out (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Patterns: An Upside to Migraines? Less Mental Decline Found
text: Some studies have found that people who suffer from migraines do not seem to lose any of their thinking skills as a result of the headaches. Other studies have found that they do.

headline: Finding Whether Diabetes Lurks
text: MORE than six million Americans are walking around with no idea that they have an insidious disease with the potential to wreak havoc throughout the body.

headline: Blair Indirectly Endorses Brown as Successor
text: EDINBURGH, Scotland, May 1 — Prime Minister Tony Blair offered an indirect endorsement of Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, as his successor today, saying that “in all probability, a Scot will become Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.”

headline: Why Wolfowitz Should Stay
text: Abuja, Nigeria

headline: Fidel Castro Fails to Appear at Parade
text: HAVANA, Cuba, May 1 The throngs were out in the streets with their red shirts and banners, just as they always are on May Day. But Cuba’s holiday honoring workers came and went today without the boss ever showing his face.

headline: Accounting Said to Hide Lender Losses
text: In the spring of 1998, the chief financial officer of New Century Financial, a lender to home buyers with blemished credit, wrote an unusual paper describing a then little-known accounting technique.

headline: N.C.A.A. Cracks Down on Prep Schools and Angers Some
text: The N.C.A.A. quietly passed legislation last week to continue its fight against prep schools that require minimal academic study. In perhaps its most significant move to deter diploma mills, the N.C.A.A. will limit high school students to one core course that would count toward college eligibility after a student’s four-year high school graduation date.

headline: 34 Duke Business Students Face Discipline for Cheating
text: Thirty-four first-year business graduate students at Duke University cheated on a take-home final exam, a judicial board has found, in what officials called the most widespread cheating episode in the business school’s history.

headline: Scientists Look to Vaccines in the War on E. Coli
text: Shousun C. Szu, a scientist at the National Institutes of Health, says the best way to prevent people from being poisoned by deadly E. coli would be to vaccinate all infants against the bacteria.

headline: Consumer Spending Slows, Portending Weaker Economy
text: Personal spending in the United States rose less than forecast in March, a sign that higher gasoline prices and a sagging housing market are chipping away at a mainstay of economic expansion.

headline: Your Comments on my Education Column
text: Please post your comments here on my Tuesday column about education. I particularly welcome comments from teachers or others who have seen these issues first-hand. And if you disagree with me, tell me what you would like to see as school reforms.

headline: Safeguarding Food From Overseas
text: Globalization and new manufacturing capabilities have changed the makeup of the food that Americans put on their table. Food processors in the United States are buying a greater number of ingredients from other countries, becoming more of an assembler in the nation’s food supply chain.

headline: $3 Million Homes
text: Tour a 135-acre Vermont estate, a contemporary home in Sun Valley, Idaho, and a three-bedroom condo on the beach in Malibu, Calif.

headline: A Golden Theater Is Reborn as an Indie Rock Haven
text: An enormous movie theater in Washington Heights has been turned into a major indie music venue, bringing scores of scenesters to 175th street.

headline: Immigrant Rights Rallies Smaller Than Last Year
text: Some of the largest of the demonstrations were in Los Angeles and in Chicago.

headline: Full steam ahead: the French property market
text: The Property Finders, an international buying agency, has extended its service into the French Riviera with the appointment of Martha Saavedra. Ms. Saavedra will be covering the French Riviera from Mandelieu to Menton including St. Tropez and the East-Var.

headline: Dolans Near Deal for Cablevision
text: Cablevision Systems Corporation is near a deal to sell the company to its founding family, the Dolans, for about $10.5 billion in cash, according to people involved in the discussions.

headline: President Bush’s Speech on the Iraq Spending Bill
text: The following is a transcript of President Bush's speech regarding his veto of the Iraq war supplemental spending bill as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

headline: Ex-Westar Executives to Face a Third Trial
text: Two former executives at Westar Energy, David C. Wittig and Douglas T. Lake, will face trial for a third time on criminal charges that accuse them of trying to loot the utility, a federal prosecutor said Monday.

headline: Merrill Lynch Plans Buyback
text: Merrill Lynch said Monday that it would buy back as much as $6 billion of its common stock over time, as the firm looks to return capital that is building up on its balance sheet to investors.

headline: Maker of Yoga Gear to Go Public
text: Lululemon, a Canadian retailer of yoga-inspired apparel, filed with regulators to raise as much as $230 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq and the Toronto Stock Exchange. The company’s backers include private equity firm Advent International and venture capital firm Highland Capital Partners.

headline: I.S.E. Says ‘I Do’ to Deutsche Borse
text: The German stock exchange operator Deutsche Börse said Monday it is in discussions to buy the American options exchange International Securities Exchange Holdings for $2.8 billion. Deutsche Börse said its offer would value the exchange at $67.50 a share, a premium of nearly 50 percent over its closing stock price on Friday. Deutsche Börse said that it had agreed to pay $67.50 a share for the exchange, a 48 percent premium over its closing price on Friday.

headline: Accounting Said to Hide Lender Losses
text: New Century Financial, the subprime lender, has a host of woes at the moment and it seems it can add the use of a certain accounting technique to that list.

headline: For Buyout Firms, Patience Is a Virtue
text: Low interest rates aren’t the only reason that private equity firms are having a buyout bonanza, Derek DeCloet writes in The Globe and Mail. These firms have something that fund managers and the public markets seem to lack: A long-term perspective.

headline: ReVision Sees $25 Million in New Round
text: The optical implant developer ReVision Optics raised $25 million in a Series D financing led by Domain Associates to support clinical trials in its quest to deliver the first commercial implants to replace reading glasses in an aging population.

headline: Delta Air, Out of Bankruptcy, Sports a New Paint Job
text: Delta Air Lines emerged from bankruptcy protection Monday after surviving a hostile takeover bid and cutting billions in costs in a 19-month overhaul. The board will now turn its attention to picking a successor to its chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, and deciding whether to sell or spin off its regional feeder carrier, Comair.

headline: Buyout Shop Scores Big in Deal for Tube Maker
text: Castle Harlan, the private equity firm, will make about two and a half times its money after just a year when it sells the tubing company RathGibson to DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, according to The Deal.com. DLJ Merchant Banking, the private equity arm of the Credit Suisse Group, said Monday that it would pay $440 million for RathGibson.

headline: IMG Picks Up College-Sports Licensing Firm
text: IMG, the sports and media marketing firm led by the financier Theodore J. Forstmann, said Tuesday it would buy the Collegiate Licensing Company, a trademark licensing agency whose clients include the Rose Bowl, the Heisman Trophy and the N.C.A.A. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Interactive Brokers Targets $1 Billion in I.P.O.
text: The Interactive Brokers Group, an electronic broker and market-making firm controlled by Thomas Peterffy, increased the size and price range of a proposed initial public offering on Monday and said it expects to raise about $1 billion.

headline: As ICE’s Bid for C.B.O.T. Rises, Will the Merc Match?
text: The pressure on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to raise its bid for the Chicago Board of Trade intensified on Monday as the premium in the rival offer from the Intercontinental Exchange touched $1.5 billion for the first time, The Financial Times said.

headline: Comcast Takes Stake in Cable Networks
text: Comcast said Monday it would pay $570 million for an interest in two regional cable sports networks, one in San Francisco and the other in New England. In a cash transaction withRainbow Media Holdings, Comcast will purchase a 60 percent interest in FSN Bay Area and a 50 percent interest in FSN New England.

headline: Former Tyco Exec Settles With S.E.C.
text: A former Tyco International executive has agreed to settle civil charges that he helped inflate the company’s profits through sham transactions, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Monday.

headline: Reuters Acquires ClearForest to Enhance Text Searches
text: Reuters announced on Monday that it would acquire a text analytics company, ClearForest, to enhance its advanced search capabilities. Up until this point, ClearForest had primarily marketed its products, text analytics technologies and a tagging platform, to business clients that need to manage and facilitate access to large amounts of information.

headline: BCE Shakes Up Bidding Process
text: BCE, Canada’s largest telephone services provider, said Monday that it intends to attract multiple takeover bids as it considers going private.

headline: V.C.-Backed Pure Digital Aims for YouTube Users
text: Pure Digital, a tech firm with some impressive financial backing, is hoping to piggyback on the success of YouTube and other online video sites with a new, inexpensive camcorder geared to older consumers who may not be as tech-savvy as their kids.

headline: As Triarc Reshuffles, Some See a Future Bid for Wendy’s
text: Adding fuel to the speculation it could be a suitor for Wendy’s, The Triac Companies said Monday that it was selling its controlling stake in the money management firm Deerfield & Company for about $300 million to become a pure play restaurant operator.

headline: D.E. Shaw Mulls Private Equity Fund, Report Says
text: As the line between private equity and hedge funds becomes ever more blurred, The Financial Times reports that D.E. Shaw, the $29 billion hedge fund, is considering setting up a private equity fund into which it could inject some of its existing holdings, potentially including the storied toy shop FAO Schwarz.

headline: Heated Cross-Examination at the Conrad Black Trial
text: The cross-examination of Marie-Josée Kravis, a crucial witness at the trial of Conrad M. Black, grew heated on Monday when a defense lawyer attempted to portray the witness as forgetful or inept. In response, Mrs. Kravis, a former director of Mr. Black’s company, Hollinger International, maintained that she and other directors were misled about millions of dollars in payments Mr. Black and other executives received.

headline: For Silver Lake’s New Fund, Less Is More
text: While most buyout funds are getting bigger, Silver Lake Partners, one of the first heavyweight firms to focus exclusively on technology, is broadening its horizons – by looking at smaller deals, Adam Lashinksy notes in his Go West blog for Fortune.

headline: RBC Capital to Buy Ohio Bond Firm
text: Royal Bank of Canada‘s investment banking arm said it would acquire Seasongood & Mayer, a municipal bond firm based in Cincinnati, for an undisclosed price. RBC Capital Markets said in a news release that the deal, which it expects to close in the second quarter, would bolster its position in the municipal investment banking market in the United States.

headline: Microsoft Is Said to Consider a Bid for 24/7
text: Microsoft has emerged as a contender to buy the online advertising firm 24/7 Real Media in an effort to stay competitive with online rivals Google and Yahoo, The New York Post reported Tuesday. Citing unnamed sources, the Post said that Microsoft is considering a bid of about $1 billion, a hefty premium over the $600 million value that analysts have given the firm.

headline: Lightbulb Wars: It’s Greenpeace vs. Philips in India
text: Campaigners at Greenpeace India this week named the light bulb manufacturer Philips as one of the country’s big contributors to greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Handicapping With Optimism
text: Campaign strategies, endorsements, advertising content and hairdo management. Many factors can influence a political race, and every handicapper has an equation for predicting. Since the late 1980’s, a group of psychologists at the University of Pennsylvania has had a system based on a single factor: optimism.

headline: Alibaba.com of China Said to Plan I.P.O.
text: Alibaba.com, China’s leading e-commerce company, is planning to go public later this year in what could be the biggest initial public offering ever for a Chinese Internet company, The New York Times reported, citing people briefed on the deal. Three Wall Street investment banks, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank, are advising Alibaba on the public offering, which The Times said could raise $1 billion.

headline: Immigration Protests Across U.S.
text: A year ago today, hundreds of thousands of immigrants marched in dozens of cities across the United States. Today, the numbers are expected to be much smaller.

headline: ‘Bad Example’
text: Gov. Jon S. Corzine left the hospital yesterday, with no public events scheduled this week while he recuperates at Drumthwacket, the official residence of New Jersey governors. For the record, here is what he had to say about his failure to wear a seat belt in the crash that led to his serious injuries:

headline: Banking Giants Bring the Fight to Chicago
text: Like deep-dish pizza, the Cubs and a mayor named Daley, LaSalle Bank has long been a Chicago institution. But until a few weeks ago, few would have called it a global banking prize. Now, LaSalle is at the center of what could be the biggest bank deal ever, as a trophy for at least two banking titans: Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: Is Private Equity Riding a Debt Bubble?
text: The chief executive of the private equity firm TA Associates, Kevin Landry, offers a new take on talk of a private-equity bubble. Speaking to The Boston Globe’s Steven Syre about all the private equity cash sloshing around and the unprecedented scale of leveraged buyouts, Mr. Landry said:

headline: Gonzales’s Suspicious Omission
text: “Attorney General Alberto Gonzales signed a highly confidential order in March 2006 delegating to two of his top aides – who have since resigned because of their central roles in the firings of eight U.S. attorneys – extraordinary authority over the hiring and firing of most non-civil-service employees of the Justice Department,” Murray Waas reports in National Journal. “A copy of the order and other Justice Department records related to the conception and implementation of the order were provided to National Journal.”

headline: Report on Al Qaeda Death
text: An Iraqi security official’s announcement today of the death of Abu Ayyub al-Masri, the leader of Al Qaeda’s Iraq operations, prompted a denial from an Iraqi insurgent Web site and cautious responses from the chief spokesman of the Iraqi government and the United States military.

headline: 2008: F. Thompson Looms
text: If you only know him as Arthur Branch, the “Law & Order” district attorney, then you absolutely must read Carl Hulse’s latest on Fred D. Thompson. The Times’s top congressional correspondent outlines the strengths, weaknesses and next steps for the man with the greatest potential to scramble the G.O.P.’s top tier.

headline: Lazard Hires Longtime Perelman Lieutenant
text: Donald G. Drapkin, who had been vice chairman of Ronald Perelman’s investment firm, MacAndrews & Forbes, has taken a position at Lazard, the publicly traded investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein. Lazard said in a news release Tuesday that Mr. Drapkin joined Lazard as of May 1 as vice chairman of its international unit and chairman of its investment committee. Among other things, he will help the firm look for strategic investments and initiatives, Lazard said.

headline: Morgan Stanley C.F.O. to Retire
text: David Sidwell, who as chief financial officer at Morgan Stanley helped guide the firm through a turbulent management shake-up, will retire at the end of the year. He will be succeeded by Colm Kelleher, the head of global capital markets, Morgan Stanley said Tuesday.

headline: Is the Republican Party Committing Suicide?
Where in the World is Eliot Spitzer?
text: The governor is in California today, attending what a spokeswoman, Christine Anderson, described as a series of private fundraising meetings in San Franciso. It is one of his few trips out the state since he became governor.

headline: News Corp. Bids $5 Billion for Dow Jones
text: News Corporation has made an unsolicited bid for Dow Jones that values the publisher of The Wall Street Journal and Barron’s at about $5 billion. Dow Jones, a 125-year-old company controlled by the Bancroft family, said it is evaluating the offer, which may come either as a cash bid or cash and News Corp. stock.

headline: Clinton Campaign Rallies Supporters
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential team is holding a “major supporter briefing” at the Phoenix Park Hotel in Washington this afternoon, followed by a reception at her home this evening, in an effort to engage both new and long-time donors through strategy and policy briefings and rally-the-troops remarks from campaign officials, according to several donors who plan to attend.

headline: News Corp. Bidding for Down Jones, CNBC Says
text: NEW YORK (AP) -- News Corporation, which includes Fox News Channel among its holdings, is offering to buy Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, according to CNBC.

headline: BP Chief Quits as Sex Life Makes Headlines
text: In January, John Browne, chief executive of BP, the British energy company, announced that he would step down in July, more than a year earlier than expected. But he didn’t make it that long: Mr. Browne quit Tuesday as head of the company after a judge lifted a ban on newspaper reports that alleged that he had spent company funds on a Canadian man with whom he had a relationship.

headline: What to Do With a Teenager in Paris in High Summer
text: I am going to Paris in August with my 13-year-old daughter. How can I make the best of perhaps the worst month to go?

headline: The Undisputed Air Polluted
text: The American Lung Association released its rankings of most polluted cities in America, and Los Angeles once again found itself leading the pack.

headline: Newspaper Stocks Feel the ‘Murdoch Effect’
text: Shares of several newspaper publishing companies posted big gains after Dow Jones disclosed that it received an unsolicited takeover offer from News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch’s global media empire. Dow Jones said Tuesday it was considering the proposal but warned that a deal might not happen; nevertheless, investors bid up shares of its peers, apparently hoping that they might also become takeover targets.

headline: Using PowerPoint With Discretion
text: It’s trendy these days to make fun of PowerPoint pitches. “Death by PowerPoint” is a hilarious buzzword that refers to truly awful boardroom pitches in which the speaker dully reads the bullet points off PowerPoint slides.

headline: Bruno Nixes Gay Marriage
text: Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno, the state’s top Republican, said he would not support Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s bill to legalize gay marriage, most likely dooming the measure. This was the expected outcome, which even the governor had predicted.

headline: Cory Lidle's Flight
text: The Safety Board created a video of the flight, combining animation with footage of the impact recorded by a surveillance camera.

headline: Bluebirds, Subarus, Fast Cars and Car Tunes
text: Whenever I take a road trip for more than a few hundred miles, I make a playlist. And while I was putting together some tunes for my Indiana trip last month, I realized I had enough current car songs and songs mentioning cars for a list of their own.

headline: Will $5 Billion Persuade Dow Jones’s Owners to Sell?
text: Rumors that the Bancrofts would sell Dow Jones, the 125-year-old publishing company they control through family trusts, have circulated for years. Usually, they peter out as observers note the family’s loyalty to management and its fealty to the idea that The Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones’s flagship publication, is a public trust and not just an asset.

headline: End of the Road for Park?
