text: If you stumbled upon the beginning of Willie Randolph’s postgame press conference last night, it was pretty easy to tell how displeased he was with Chan Ho Park’s performance.

headline: Delta Ad
text: An advertisement for Delta Air Lines.

headline: If Marlon Brando Had YouTube
text: In “Brando,” the documentary that starts tonight on Turner Classic Movies, there’s an amazing home video made by Brando and Montgomery Clift.

headline: Murdoch’s Bid for Dow Jones: Reading Between the Lines
text: The headline number is eye-catching, but the logic behind Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion offer for Dow Jones & Company may be even more interesting. Mr. Murdoch’s News Corporation already has an array of broadcasting, film, print and Internet assets. What does he want with Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal?

headline: Debating the Wisdom of B-School Ethics Courses
text: A Duke University judicial panel’s determination that 34 M.B.A. students cheated on an exam has some people wondering whether the spate of ethics classes – introduced in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom scandals – are doing any good.

headline: Will the Bancrofts Take the Money and Run?
text: Rupert Murdoch has left the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, in a difficult position.

headline: Bancroft Family Votes Against News Corp. Offer
text: Time for round two in News Corporation‘s quest to win Dow Jones & Company.

headline: Mets Fan Banned From Shea
text: The Associated Press reported that a Mets fan who pleaded guilty Tuesday to shining a high-powered flashlight at two Atlanta Braves players last month will be banned from Shea for three years.

headline: So, How Am I Doing?
text: I always knew I was special. And now research from San Diego State University proves that I am just as unique as everybody else: I and my collegiate peers are 30 percent more narcissistic than the fluffy-haired and spandex-clad college students of 1982.

headline: Easy on the Stirring
text: Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a favorite spring recipe for risotto with asparagus.

headline: For Picnics and Pizza
text: While there’s no recess in the Dining Table Wine School, we do pause now and then for a bit of additional refreshment, which is how I happen to be writing about martinis in my column for Wednesday’s paper. I’m annoyed at myself for even asking this question, but when’s the last time you had a real martini? Not a chocolate cocktail, or watermelon drink or any of the other spurious hangers-on that threaten the integrity of the word martini, but a real honest-to-goodness gin-and-vermouth martini?

headline: Advisers Suit Up for Dow Jones Showdown
text: In a bid as high-profile and potentially contentious as News Corporation‘s $5 billion offer for Dow Jones & Company, it’s only natural that the players in the drama would reach for the big guns. And so they have.

headline: The Brewers Could Be for Real
text: When Tony La Russa, the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, was told that Ned Yost, the manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, said that he would do anything to help them deal with the death of reliever Josh Hancock, La Russa nodded his head in appreciation.

headline: Giuliani on the Immigration Borderline
text: As protesters rally around the country in support of citizenship for undocumented workers, a different group of immigrants and their descendents sat quietly at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington. Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor seeking the G.O.P. presidential nomination, walked a careful line while addressing immigration before the Latino Coalition’s Small Business Economic Conference.

headline: Obama and Clinton Join N.H. Debate
text: California and New York and other big boys can move up their 2008 presidential primaries to influence the nominating contest all they want, but tiny New Hampshire still has political muscle to spare.

headline: Two Students, Four Stars
text: How does a four-star restaurant look through the eyes of a New York teenager eating at one for the first time?

headline: Shh…Thompson Hits New York
text: We were told by spies for The Caucus that Fred D. Thompson was taking his stealth campaign for president  here to New York, the media capital of the world. The venue? The St. Regis Hotel, for an event sponsored by Guggenheim Advisors, the giant hedge fund, where Mr. Thompson and Lawrence B. Lindsey were slated to deliver an “economic policy and national security briefing.”

headline: Bush Vetoes Iraq Bill
text: Just a short while ago, President Bush made good on his promise, and vetoed the war spending bill that included a timeline for troop withdrawal passed by the Democratic-controlled Congress last month. He made his action public in a short announcement, saying the Democrats had approved a plan that set a “rigid and artificial” deadline that “would impose impossible conditions for our commanders and troops in combat.”

headline: Greetings From the House Nolan Built
text: Today is the 16th anniversary of one of those fun days in baseball history, when Rickey Henderson broke the career stolen-base record in the afternoon and Nolan Ryan fired his seventh no-hitter at night.

headline: A Place for Transgender Youth
text: The Rev. Louis Braxton Jr. runs a homeless shelter in Queens for young transgendered men working as prostitutes.

headline: In Nixon’s Tricks, Rove’s Roots and a Blueprint for Bush
text: If you’re a political junkie with Internet access looking for cheap laughs — and if you’re reading this column, you probably are — take a minute, go to YouTube and search for “Nixon” and “Rove.”

headline: A Crossover Helps Ford, but Not Enough to Hold Its No. 2 Spot
text: DETROIT, May 1 — Is the Edge giving Ford the edge it was hoping for?

headline: A Soup With a Difference, Born of Adversity and Error
text: ALL cooks have their share of culinary mishaps and I’m no exception. I’ve made muffins with salt instead of sugar, baked cookies at 450 instead of 350, put on a pot of oatmeal and fallen asleep until the smoke alarm screamed and, one sadly memorable time, braised a brisket in expensive red wine vinegar instead of wine.

headline: Placing Bets on a Strong Manhattan Market
text: SJP PROPERTIES, a commercial real estate firm based in Parsippany, N.J., signed a lease in February for a small office on the 38th floor of The New York Times Building, which is about to open at 620 Eighth Avenue, between 40th and 41st Street, near Times Square.

headline: 5 Tips From ‘Mindless Eating’
text: In “Mindless Eating” (Bantam Books, 2006), the Cornell professor Brian Wansink explains the psychological cues that lead people to overeat. The human stomach isn’t sensitive enough to notice small caloric differences, and it often doesn’t register how much has been eaten until 20 minutes or more after the food has been swallowed. So people instead rely on their eyes, ears and noses to tell them when to stop eating. And they often overeat as a result.

headline: 2 Councilmen Oppose Rise in Water Rates
text: Two city councilmen who oppose a planned 11.5 percent increase in the city’s water and sewer rates announced a proposal yesterday that they said could raise rates no more than 1 percent and keep a lid on future increases for years to come.

headline: Eggplant Sushi and Dubai Duck Add Up in New Arabian Cuisine
text: IF Ingo Maass has anything to say about it, “new Arabian” will become a cuisine worth noticing. Mr. Maass, a cheery 36-year-old German chef, works in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, and with several other chefs he is now on the fast track to modernize the centuries-old, traditionbound food of the Arabian peninsula.

headline: Teaching the Color Printer the Language of Humanity and a Palette of Precision
text: To the human eye, that flower in the photo is reddish orange, that sky is light blue, that sun shines brilliant yellow.

headline: What You Get for ... $3 Million
text: Tunbridge, Vt.

headline: Latin American Companies Make Big U.S. Gains
text: WILTON, Iowa — First came a wave of immigrants from Mexico and elsewhere in Latin America. Next came tortillas and Spanish-language soap operas, made in the United States, for a growing Hispanic audience in this country.

headline: Try Shopping Around for Student Loans
text: In financing his engineering education at Montana State University, Brian D. Zier borrowed the maximum in federally guaranteed loans, with their relatively low, fixed rates. But it was not enough. So he turned to a commercial lender to borrow $30,000 more in private loans, which typically have higher, variable rates.

headline: Recipe: Shredded Fish Tacos
text: Adapted from Patricia Quintana

headline: Utility Is Held Partly to Blame for Fatal Blast
text: A federal investigation into a 2005 gas explosion at a Bergenfield, N.J., apartment building that killed three people has found that Public Service Electric and Gas was partly to blame for the blast.

headline: He Vanished. (Whether He Actually Existed Is Another Story.)
text: An enigmatic and utterly compelling story of incinerated art, unbridled egos and exotic plants, “Missing Victor Pellerin” purports to investigate the 1990 disappearance of Mr. Pellerin, a painter and supposed star of the Montreal art scene. Yet as Sophie Deraspe’s clever debut feature unfolds, the questions about her elusive subject only multiply. Artist or con man? Dead or alive? Real or fictional?

headline: News Corp. Makes a $5 Billion Bid for Dow Jones
text: The News Corporation, owner of the Fox News Channel and The New York Post, has made an unsolicited $5 billion takeover bid for Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: 360 Minutes, 180 Degrees of Difference
text: Only four weeks into the Major League Soccer season, the spotlight is on one team with no past (Toronto F.C.) and one that rarely seemed to have a future (the Red Bulls).

headline: America in Iraq: 10 More Years? (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: No, Really, It Was Tough: 4 People, 80 Martinis
text: HAVE I told you about my 80-martini lunch?

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A listing yesterday of American service members killed in Iraq misidentified the branch of service of Sgt. Michael R. Hullender. It is the Army, not the Marines.

headline: 3 Climate Change Envoys Appointed
text: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon chose three international figures to help him chart a way for the United Nations to take the lead in addressing climate change. The special envoys are Gro Harlem Brundtland, a former prime minister of Norway; Ricardo Lagos, a former president of Chile; and Han Seung-soo, a former foreign minister of South Korea and president of the General Assembly in 2001. Michèle Montas, Mr. Ban’s spokeswoman, said the three would prepare proposals for the opening of the General Assembly in September when national leaders come to New York and for a United Nations conference in Bali, Indonesia, in December. Last month, the first-ever debate on climate change was held in the Security Council.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about the frequency of Jon S. Corzine’s out-of-state travel during his tenure as governor of New Jersey referred erroneously in some copies to the time he has spent outside the state. In the 450 days from his inauguration to his traffic accident on April 12, he was away for all or part of 111 days, not 115, and he spent about a third of February — not half of March — out of state. The article also rendered incorrectly comments on the matter from Zulima V. Farber, then the New Jersey attorney general, in an April 2006 memo. She wrote, “We do not believe that, in the circumstances you describe, an occasional, overnight stay in New York City following a workday in New Jersey and a return to this state in the morning constitutes an absence of the governor that would trigger the devolution of gubernatorial power.” The erroneous version said “circumstance” instead of “circumstances” and omitted the words “and a return.”

headline: Illegal Immigrant and the Right to Wed
text: A federal judge in Pennsylvania ruled yesterday against a county official who denied a marriage license to a couple because the groom-to-be was an illegal immigrant.

headline: Nowitzki and Mavericks Breathe Sigh of Relief
text: DALLAS, May 1 — Infamy shadowed the Dallas Mavericks on Tuesday night. It brushed so close by them that an entire city seemed to feel their shame. Their packed arena was eerily quiet, their fans uncertain whether to cheer or cover their eyes as the evening grew late.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the public debate in Israel over whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert could retain power despite a government report criticizing his leadership in the 34-day Lebanon war misstated the date the war began last year. It was July 12, not June 12.

headline: Israel’s Self-Criticism (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Making a Killing
text: Los Angeles

headline: U.S. Jailer in Iraq Admits Mistakes, Investigator Says
text: BAGHDAD, May 1  A senior commander in the American military’s main detention center here lent prisoners his government cellphone, regularly exchanged e-mail messages with the daughter of a high-value detainee and used public funds to supply Saddam Hussein with hair dye and Cuban cigars, investigators said at a military hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the public debate in Israel over whether Prime Minister Ehud Olmert could retain power despite a government report criticizing his leadership in the 34-day Lebanon war misstated the date the war began last year. It was July 12, not June 12. (Go to Article)

headline: With Ugandan Boy’s Scars, Hidden Woes
text: The standoff near a security checkpoint at Kennedy International Airport on March 20 left passengers agape.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music review on Monday about the premiere of David Carlson’s opera, “Anna Karenina,” by the Florida Grand Opera in Miami, misidentified a work in which Tchaikovsky used the Czar’s Hymn, a variant of which Mr. Carlson uses as a fate motif. In addition to the “1812” Overture it was the “Marche Slav,” not the Fourth Symphony. (Tchaikovsky used a fate motif in that work.)

headline: Letters
text: Not All Food Can Be Local

headline: As Funding Increases, Afghan Forces Range From Ragtag to Ready
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Faizal Karim, a sophomore at the National Military Academy here, stood outside a classroom holding his English-language homework assignment. For a group of cadets nearby, a lecture in physics was ending.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about the identification of new genes connected to the most common forms of diabetes misspelled part of the name of the research organization preparing a report on seven major diseases. It is the Wellcome Trust in London, not the Welcome Trust.

headline: Former World Bank Officials Detail Discord Over Wolfowitz
text: WASHINGTON, May 1  Two former top officials at the World Bank have issued new statements disputing the contention of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank president, that they and others knew about his actions on behalf of his companion, who was employed there when he joined the bank in 2005, according to testimony released Monday night and Tuesday.

headline: Hollinger Money Diverted Improperly, Ex-Director Says
text: CHICAGO, May 1 (Bloomberg News) — Conrad M. Black and other Hollinger International executives improperly diverted more than $15 million to a holding company Mr. Black controlled, former Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois told jurors in Chicago Tuesday.

headline: Upholding a Tradition of Affordable Concerts
text: There is a great tendency to romanticize earlier eras of classical music in New York. But it’s important to remember that when the New School Concerts began in 1957 there was not the abundance of chamber music series that New Yorkers can choose from today. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, for example, did not come along until 1969.

headline: Small Business 101: How to Get Started
text: Take a good look at that store on the corner. There is a 10 percent to 12 percent chance it will not be there next year, according to the Office of Advocacy for the Small Business Administration.

headline: Australian Rate Is Steady
text: SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, May 2 (Bloomberg News)  Australia’s central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Wednesday.

headline: Proxy Adviser Opposes Clear Channel Bid
text: The influential proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services is recommending that shareholders reject a sweetened takeover offer for the broadcasting company Clear Channel Communications, saying the upgraded bid is still too low.

headline: With Indie Rock on 175th St., City’s Reinvention Rolls Uptown
text: In the time it took a traffic light to change, Joshua Sturm and friends explained what they were doing at the corner of 175th Street and Broadway on Monday evening.

headline: Chávez Takes Over Foreign-Controlled Oil Projects in Venezuela
text: SAN FELIPE, Venezuela, May 1 — President Hugo Chávez on Tuesday seized control of the last remaining oil projects in Venezuela controlled by large American and European energy companies. The move to take over the projects, announced in January, is the centerpiece of recent actions aimed at consolidating his government’s control over the economy.

headline: Bruno Opposes Bill to Legalize Gay Marriage
text: ALBANY, May 1  The Republican majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, said on Tuesday that he would not support Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s proposed legislation to legalize same-sex marriage in New York.

headline: Poor Judgment Is Cited in Yankee’s Fatal Crash
text: WASHINGTON, May 1 — The crash that killed the Yankees pitcher Cory Lidle and his flight instructor in Manhattan last October was caused by “inadequate planning, judgment and airmanship” by the two men, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday.

headline: National Magazine Awards Smile on Some and Disappoint Frequent Winners
text: Perhaps more surprising than who won this year’s National Magazine Awards was who didn’t.

headline: And Now, a Sip of History: The Mint Julep, Personified
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Bloomberg Shows Off His Spanish on Mexico Trip
text: On his recent jaunt to Mexico, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg fielded questions from Mexican reporters and, to the surprise of many, responded in Spanish.

headline: Superior Civilizations (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: For One Night, Yankees’ Staff Outdoes Mets’
text: All winter, people questioned whether the Mets had enough starting pitching to contend for the National League pennant this season. The Yankees, on the other hand, had a full rotation, welcoming Kei Igawa to the United States, Andy Pettitte back home and Carl Pavano back to work.

headline: Amid Struggles, Two Players Ease Mets’ Concerns for One Night
text: The struggles of Mike Pelfrey and David Wright have turned Shea Stadium into New York’s roomiest therapist’s couch, with fans loudly wondering just when, oh when, will the troubles end and life be able to return to normal. For one night, at least, the panic subsided and hope was restored.

headline: Curtis Institute’s New Leader Is Set to ‘Clear the Cobwebs’
text: PHILADELPHIA — Leading an orchestra section, “you learn people skills and common sense,” said Roberto Díaz, the violist and new president of the Curtis Institute of Music here. “You learn to navigate tricky situations without making people feel disrespected. ‘Always lead by example’ is a good motto to have.”

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Schoolchildren to Dance With Berlin Philharmonic

headline: Ex-Newsweek Editor to Join NBC as a Senior Vice President
text: NBC, the broadcast network, yesterday named the former editor of Newsweek magazine, Mark Whitaker, as senior vice president for news, a job that will make him the No. 2 executive in the network’s news division.

headline: Brière’s Chance at Stardom Ends in Video Replay
text: It was a star vehicle for the Buffalo Sabres’ A-list player, Daniel Brière: a pivotal playoff game on a stage as rich in history as any on the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer lot. If the Sabres were going to beat the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night and return home with a 3-1 lead in their best-of-seven Eastern Conference semifinal, Brière figured to be in the middle of the action.

headline: China: Tiny St. Lucia Roars for Taiwan
text: St. Lucia, a Caribbean island nation, became the 25th country with diplomatic ties to Taipei instead of Beijing. Liu Jianchao, a Foreign Ministry spokesman in Beijing, denounced St. Lucia for reversing its 1997 decision to recognize Beijing, and said the Chinese ambassador in St. Lucia would lodge a protest. Taiwan has struggled to maintain relations with small countries in Africa, Central America, the Caribbean and the South Pacific, frequently providing them with aid, while larger countries have recognized Beijing as the sole government of all of China, including Taiwan.

headline: A Warning on Risk in Commercial Mortgages
text: Spurred by the collapse of the subprime mortgage market, the leading bond rating agencies are beginning to crack down on what they see as risky lending practices in commercial real estate.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britain’s top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation when it was first made in January. It was made by the Serious Fraud Office — not by Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Saturday about an announcement by the New York State Police that the bullet that killed a trooper during a shootout with a fugitive in a Catskills farmhouse came from the gun of a fellow trooper — not from the fugitive — gave an incorrect surname at one point in some copies for the acting state police superintendent. He is Preston L. Felton, not Mr. Preston.

headline: Better Never Than Late
text: Instead of George Tenet teaching at Georgetown University, George Tenet should be taught at Georgetown University.

headline: After Chirac, a Question Mark on French Foreign Policy
text: PARIS, May 1 — The most dramatic change in France’s foreign policy in a new presidency may not be the arrival of either Nicolas Sarkozy or Ségolène Royal, but the departure of President Jacques Chirac.

headline: Carl F. von Weizsäcker, German Physicist and Thinker, Dies at 94
text: Carl Friedrich von Weizsäcker, whose discoveries helped define nuclear astrophysics and whose work toward developing an atomic bomb for Nazi Germany spurred him to help found his country’s postwar peace movement, died April 28 in the Bavarian town of Starnberg. He was 94.

headline: Barbecue in Brooklyn (Go Thirsty)
text: HERE’S the three-point plan for having the best possible time at Fette Sau, Brooklyn’s newest barbecue peddler:

headline: Fighting to the Finish, the Raptors Stay Alive
text: TORONTO, May 1 — All that the Nets had going for them entering Game 5 — experience, momentum and star power — could not match the Raptors’ most valuable asset: desperation.

headline: Olmert Facing Effort in Party to Oust Him Over ’06 War
text: JERUSALEM, May 1  A mutiny was brewing within Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s party on Tuesday, with a senior official planning to call for Mr. Olmert’s resignation in the wake of a damning report about his performance in last summer’s war against Hezbollah.

headline: A Luscious Taste and Aroma From India Arrives at Last
text: THE first legal shipment of Indian mangoes to the United States in decades landed at Kennedy Airport last Friday, probably the most eagerly anticipated fruit delivery ever.

headline: Manhattan Increased Penalties for Film Piracy
text: Cracking down on video piracy, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law yesterday a measure that increases penalties for unauthorized recordings of public performances to six months in prison, with criminal fines of up to $5,000. The penalties were formerly 15 days in jail, with fines of up to $250. Mr. Bloomberg also announced the start of a marketing campaign to discourage New Yorkers from buying pirated DVDs, which the Motion Picture Association of America estimates cost the city $903 million a year in lost earnings, according to a study released yesterday. The campaign, which includes a trailer-style spot showing very blurry footage from “Happy Feet” that has been rated F for Fake, is to be shown on broadcast and cable stations starting on Monday.

headline: Randolph Gives Slumping Wright a Second Chance
text: David Wright batted second last night for the third time this season. The first two times, he was replacing Paul Lo Duca, who had been given the day off. With Lo Duca in the lineup yesterday against the Florida Marlins at Shea Stadium, this move was more telling.

headline: 2 Turin Gelato Men, Hoping New York Will Melt
text: TURIN, Italy

headline: Albany Republicans Seek Tax Rebate Increase
text: Senate Republicans said yesterday that they would seek to increase by $200 million the school property tax rebate checks that taxpayers 65 and older are eligible to receive, but Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration indicated that it would not support the proposal. Under a budget deal announced in late March, state officials added $1.3 billion to the state’s School Tax Relief Program, making it a nearly $5 billion-a-year program. But the several hundred thousand elderly homeowners who are eligible for higher benefits saw almost no increase when tax exemptions and rebate checks available under the program were taken into consideration. “It’s clear we have the resources available to give seniors greater tax relief,” Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, said in a statement. But Jeffrey Gordon, a spokesman for the governor’s Budget Division, said Mr. Spitzer “will include more relief in next year’s budget” and “will not bust the budget by adding more spending on property tax relief this year.”

headline: Britain: Blair Gives a Nod to Gordon Brown
text: Prime Minister Tony Blair offered an indirect endorsement of Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, as his successor, saying that “in all probability, a Scot will become prime minister of the United Kingdom.” Mr. Blair did not identify Mr. Brown by name when he addressed Labor Party supporters in Edinburgh. Labor is expected to lose ground in regional voting on Thursday, which would help set Mr. Blair’s schedule to resign as party leader.

headline: Owning a Home in the Suburbs of London
text: Alexandra Gilmore’s three-bedroom home in Surrey, a suburban county about an hour southwest of London, could not be more different from the spacious house with a big backyard and lots of storage space in which she grew up just outside Dallas.

headline: Newark Man Convicted in Witness’s Murder
text: A Newark man was convicted yesterday of conspiring in the murder of a witness against him in a drug case, federal prosecutors said. The man, William Baskerville, faces either the death penalty or life in prison without parole, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. The jury in Federal District Court is scheduled to reconvene next week to decide whether the death penalty should be applied, he said. Mr. Baskerville, charged in 2003 with selling crack cocaine to Kempo Deshawn McCray, was convicted of ordering the hiring of a hit man to kill Mr. McCray, who was a cooperating witness, Mr. Christie said. Mr. McCray was shot three times in the head on March 2, 2004.

headline: You Can Almost Eat the Dishes
text: IF we’re not vigilant, who knows what could happen? We could wake up one dark chocolate morning to an East River of cocoa and a Hudson of hot fudge, slices of banana bobbing on its surface. The streets would be paved with bonbons, the skyscrapers bricked with fudge. Calorie counts would skyrocket. And a pox of tooth decay would descend.

headline: Recipe: Mole Blanco
text: Adapted from Carmen Ramírez Degollado

headline: Behind the Voice-Over, a Familiar Screen Face
text: In a studio in Manhattan last Friday, Liev Schreiber was recording the narration of “Brooklyn Dodgers,” a two-part documentary that HBO will show on July 11. He was a few hours from heading uptown to the Longacre Theater, where he is starring in the Broadway revival of “Talk Radio” as Barry Champlain, an abrasive talk show host who loathes his listeners and is losing control of himself just as his program is being syndicated.

headline: Gaza: Demands for BBC Journalist Rejected
text: Palestinian Authority officials said the kidnappers of Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent in Gaza who was abducted March 12, have made specific but unacceptable demands, the first time there has been formal contact. Azzam al-Ahmed, the deputy prime minister, said the demands were “linked with ideology and politics” but refused to detail them. Another security official told a Palestinian newspaper that the kidnappers were known, but that the British had urged that force not be used to free Mr. Johnston, 44, whom Palestinian officials say is alive.

headline: Pet Food Chemical Unlikely to Pose Threat to Humans, Experts Say, as U.S. Continues Inquiry
text: Toxicologists monitoring the American food supply for traces of melamine after it was found in imported ingredients in the contaminated pet food that has killed at least 16 dogs and cats and sickened thousands of others said yesterday that even if there were small amounts of it in the American food supply, it would be unlikely to pose much of a threat to humans.

headline: Revealing the Innovator Behind the Music
text: The rise of the music producer Ahmet Ertegun was more like the intensely groovy embellishment of the lofty status he was born with.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,344 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Off the Menu
text: In Transition

headline: Rupert Murdoch Offers $5 Billion Bid for Dow Jones
text: In a bold move to expand his global media empire, Rupert Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation, has made an unsolicited $5 billion offer to buy Dow Jones & Company, the venerable publisher of The Wall Street Journal, which he has long coveted.

headline: Torre Says He Is Grateful for Steinbrenner’s Support
text: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 1 — Joe Torre called George Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ principal owner, on Monday night to thank him for his latest statement, in which Steinbrenner said he believed in Torre and the rest of the Yankees.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Monday about Mark Halperin, who stepped down as the political director of ABC News and will join Time magazine, misstated his role at both media outlets. He is a political — not a policy — analyst. Because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to John F. Harris who, with Mr. Halperin wrote a book about the 2008 presidential race. Mr. Harris, who was at The Washington Post when the book was published last fall, is now editor in chief of The Politico, which covers national politics.

headline: Iraqi Officials Say Top Qaeda Leader May Have Been Killed
text: BAGHDAD, May 1 — The Iraqi government said Tuesday that it was investigating reports from “reliable sources” that the leader of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, Abu Ayyub al-Masri, had been killed in an ambush by a rival insurgent faction.

headline: In Subways, Safety Course for Workers
text: The curriculum drawn up to give New York City Transit workers an urgent refresher course in safety after two fatal on-the-job accidents last month draws a single, blunt conclusion for avoiding future disasters: “No Short Cuts.”

headline: Yield Documents, Lawmaker Tells White House
text: The chairman of the House education committee asked the White House yesterday to turn over all its communications about the scandal-tarred student loan program and also Reading First, the administration’s $1-billion-a-year reading initiative, which has been besieged by accusations of conflict of interest.

headline: Court Says Congressman Must Pay Damages
text: A federal appeals court in Washington ruled Tuesday that Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, must pay damages to another congressman for giving reporters a tape of an illegally intercepted telephone call.

headline: Recipe: Asparagus Risotto
text: Adapted from Mario Batali

headline: Food Calendar
text: Eating Locally

headline: A Harsh, Healthy Verdict in Israel
text: Israel’s government badly botched the war in Lebanon last summer. But you have to admire the work of the investigating commission that same government appointed to analyze what had gone wrong. In its initial report, the commission pointed to “severe failures” of “judgment, responsibility and prudence” on the part of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert.

headline: Recipe: Rice and Lentils (Kushari)
text: Adapted from “New Arabian Cuisine” by Ingo Maass and Lutz Jäkel (Umschau)

headline: Players Gather Round to Kiss a Music Hall Good Night
text: For those of us born in the 1960s, it is a little unnerving to watch Lincoln Center, another child of the ’60s, being treated for the manifestations of advanced age. As part of the complex’s continuing reconstructive surgery, Alice Tully Hall — the penultimate Lincoln Center edifice to be completed when it opened in 1969 — is getting a complete overhaul in the next 18 months. To send it off into its Brünnhilde-like slumber, a gala concert called “Good Night Alice” was held on Monday night, showcasing most of the hall’s major functions and tenants over the last 38 years. It struck the perfect tone: half festive, half somnolent.

headline: Timing of Fund-Raisers Gives Fuel to Spitzer’s Critics
text: ALBANY, May 1 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer has made tightening New York’s campaign finance laws his principal goal for the rest of the Legislative session, going so far as to mount a statewide tour to attack Senate Republicans who oppose his plan.

headline: A New (Very New) Generation Steps Into Its Shoes
text: The gala for the Youth America Grand Prix, “Stars of Today Meet the Stars of Tomorrow,” has never been a staid affair. Rather, this presentation — the culminating performance of an international dance competition conceived and coordinated by two former Bolshoi members, Gennadi and Larissa Saveliev — moves closer to “So You Think You Can Dance” every year.

headline: Recipe: Plantain and Black Bean Empanadas
text: Adapted from Carmen Ramírez Degollado

headline: Steroid Lugs Grab Midol, Manssieres and Clomid
text: Any baseball lug on a steroid bender can remain in touch with his feminine side but still feel a tad self-conscious when encountering a Midol moment or when shopping for a manssiere in the “Seinfeld” catalog.

headline: Recipe: Fragrant Chicken Soup With Chickpeas and Vegetables
text: Time: 1 hour

headline: Cyberonics Names Chief and Says Marketing Will Shift
text: Cyberonics, the troubled maker of implantable stimulators, said yesterday that it had recruited a senior Boston Scientific marketing executive to become its chief executive and that it would aim to return to profitability by cutting back on efforts to market its device as an antidepression treatment.

headline: Interior Official Steps Down Over Rules Violation
text: WASHINGTON, May 1  A deputy assistant secretary at the Interior Department resigned Monday, a month after the department’s inspector general issued a stinging report that said she violated federal rules by giving industry lobbyists internal agency documents and rode roughshod over agency scientists.

headline: Study of N.B.A. Sees Racial Bias in Calling Fouls
text: An academic study of the National Basketball Association, whose playoffs continue tonight, suggests that a racial bias found in other parts of American society has existed on the basketball court as well.

headline: Easing Swimming Pool Maintenance
text: A sparkling and refreshing swimming pool may be the ultimate symbol of relaxation on a warm weekend, but pools also have a less desirable quality: they can be distinctly high maintenance.

headline: Japanese Gardens Meet American ‘Activities’
text: The Mannes Contemporary Music Festival is presenting a diverse array of modern works over four nights this week, some still hot off the laser printer. The festival began on Monday night with a concert by the ensemble NewMusicMannes, directed by Madeleine Shapiro, in the concert hall of Mannes College the New School for Music. The program held to no overarching theme, but the best of what was offered neatly illustrated the diversity of options available to modern composers.

headline: Uzbekistan: Rights Worker Imprisoned
text: A court in Tashkent sentenced Umida Niyazova, a journalist and human rights worker, to seven years in prison. Amnesty International has called Ms. Niazova a prisoner of conscience. According to local reports, her lawyer was given only 30 minutes warning before the resumption of the trial, in which she was found guilty of smuggling and distributing illegal material. Four days earlier, the authorities had sent a well-known Uzbek doctor, Gulbahor Turayeva, who advocated for patients’ rights, to prison for six years. She was arrested in January when the police said she possessed several banned books.

headline: Turkish Court Blocks Islamic Candidate
text: ANKARA, Turkey, May 1 — Turkey’s highest court on Tuesday blocked a presidential candidate with a background in Islamic politics, pitching the country into early elections and a referendum on the role of religion in its future.

headline: Qwest’s Profit Nearly Triples
text: Qwest Communications, the telephone carrier, reported yesterday that its quarterly profit nearly tripled mostly because of cost cuts and an increase in broadband Internet customers.

headline: Recipe: Fillet of Salmon in a Cinnamon Coating With Cardamom Sauce
text: Adapted from “New Arabian Cuisine” by Ingo Maass and Lutz Jäkel (Umschau)

headline: Violence on the Screen (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Consolation After Thai Coup: Buying  Soccer Club
text: BANGKOK, May 2 — Ousted as prime minister in a coup last September, Thaksin Shinawatra has made a move to console himself with the possible purchase of an English soccer club.

headline: Lacking Alps, Goats Settle in Westchester
text: Few farms remain within an hour’s drive of New York City, and to have one added instead of subtracted is an achievement. In Bedford Hills, N.Y., a Westchester County playground for moguls, Lisa and Mark Schwartz gradually accumulated 35 acres that they turned into Rainbeau Ridge, where they have 24 Alpine goats and make cheese.

headline: Matters of Faith Find a New Prominence on Campus
text: Peter J. Gomes has been at Harvard University for 37 years, and says he remembers when religious people on campus felt under siege. To be seen as religious often meant being dismissed as not very bright, he said.

headline: Driver in Tanker Crash Served a Sentence for Drugs
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1  The driver of a gasoline tanker that overturned early Sunday, sparking a fire that destroyed a vital highway interchange near downtown Oakland, has a criminal record, including a two-year prison sentence for drug possession, the authorities said Tuesday.

headline: Qwest Net Nearly Triples as Costs Fall and Internet Unit Gains
text: Qwest Communications, the telephone carrier, reported yesterday that its quarterly profit nearly tripled mostly because of cost cuts and an increase in broadband Internet customers.

headline: Deciding When Student Writing Crosses the Line
text: AMHERST, Mass.

headline: Turkish Man Arrested After Group Disrupts Book Reading
text: A Turkish native was arrested after he and others disrupted a book reading about the Armenian genocide at a Barnes & Noble store on the Upper East Side last night, the police said.

headline: Icahn Uses Ad in Seeking Seat on Motorola
text: The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn published a letter to Motorola shareholders as a full-page advertisement in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, stepping up his campaign to get a seat on the company’s board.

headline: Cablevision Agrees to Sell Itself to the Dolans
text: Cablevision Systems announced an agreement today to sell itself to its founding family, the Dolans, for more than $10.5 billion in cash.

headline: Questions Linger for Beard Foundation
text: ON Monday the year’s biggest gathering of chefs, food journalists, and other culinary professionals and amateurs will convene at one of the grander locales in New York, Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center, for the James Beard Foundation Awards.

headline: 3 Democrats Suggest Plans for Education in Poor Nations
text: President Bush has made fighting AIDS and malaria in poor nations signature issues, and now the three leading Democratic presidential candidates are laying claim to the theme of educating children in poor countries.

headline: Giuliani’s Tie to Texas Law Firm May Pose Risk
text: For a native New Yorker mounting a first bid for national office, Rudolph W. Giuliani has shown an impressive ability to raise money in Texas, where his Republican presidential campaign collected $2.2 million in the first quarter of the year, far more than any other candidate.

headline: Recipe: Potato and Olive Samosas
text: Time: 1 hour

headline: The Philippines: Charge in Peace Corps Killing
text: The police have filed a murder complaint against a woodcarver who confessed to bludgeoning to death a Peace Corps volunteer who was hiking in the mountains on April 8. They said the woodcarver, Juan Duntugan, 24, told them he had hit the volunteer, Julia Campbell, of Fairfax, Va., with a stick and a rock because he was angry at a neighbor. Asked by an investigator how long he had hit her, The Associated Press reported, he replied: “I think about five minutes. I don’t remember how many times I hit her with that stone.” Ms. Campbell, 40, had worked as a freelance journalist for a number of publications including The New York Times.

headline: Chemotherapy and the Brain (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Election Commission Imposes Fines
text: The campaign of Representative Rick Renzi, Republican of Arizona, agreed to pay a $25,000 fine for underreporting contributions and expenses, the Federal Election Commission said. The Renzi campaign said that the mistake was unintentional. The agency also said that the Democratic National Committee agreed to pay an $82,000 fine for improperly reporting more than $1 million it spent in the 2004 presidential campaign.

headline: Deportation in Narration
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Kent State Tape Is Said to Reveal Orders
text: KENT, Ohio, May 1 — An audio recording of the shootings 37 years ago at Kent State University includes the voices of Ohio National Guard leaders ordering troops to fire into a crowd of students, according to a man wounded in the shootings, who obtained a copy of the recording.

headline: Doubt at Derby After Road That Included Synthetic Surfaces
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 — They will put 20 horses in the starting gate Saturday, evenly matched 3-year-olds in from all corners of the country, none of whom had ever raced at a mile and a quarter. The Kentucky Derby is already the sport’s most difficult handicapping puzzle, and this year there will be a new twist. For the first time, horses that have earned their way into the field after winning major prep races over synthetic racing surfaces will be among the 20 starters. How will they do? No one seems to know.

headline: Israel’s Foreign Minister Says Olmert Should Go
text: JERUSALEM, May 3 — Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s deputy called on him to resign today after a harshly critical government report about his management of last summer’s war against Hezbollah.

headline: From Spare Parts, a Plan to Make Area in Queens a Gem
text: Is Willets Point, the eyesore near Shea Stadium that is known for its auto parts stores, its potholes and its puddles, about to go green?

headline: Bonds Charges Toward Record With a Scandal Close Behind
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 — The San Francisco Giants gave their first public tribute to Barry Bonds before he played his first game with them.

headline: Crosscurrents of Identities: British Soldiers, German Prisoners and a Welsh Barmaid
text: “The Welsh Girl” is a distinguished, beautifully written example of a small but enduring genre. Call it the counterwar novel. Not antiwar, exactly; it lacks the belligerence.

headline: The Hail Mary Pass
text: On Thursday there will be a regional conference in Egypt to discuss stabilizing Iraq, and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice will represent the U.S. President Bush should go instead and give this speech:

headline: A Green Face-Lift for the Governor’s Mansion
text: ALBANY, May 1  The house at 138 Eagle Street here does not immediately seem like a fixer-upper. A stately 20,000-square-foot mansion, home to New York’s governors and their families since 1875, it has a pool, a tennis court and views of the Hudson River.

headline: Like a Politician, Delta Hits the Comeback Trail
text: IT is no coincidence that an ambitious effort by Delta Air Lines to restore luster to its tarnished brand image resembles attempts by elected officials who fall from grace to regain public confidence.

headline: BP’s Chief Quits Over Revelations About Private Life
text: John Browne, an aggressive but mannerly British magnate who transformed BP into one of the most successful global companies, resigned abruptly yesterday after losing a court battle with a London tabloid over details of his relationship with a younger man.

headline: Wolfowitz Gets Chilly Reception in Brussels
text: BRUSSELS, May 2 — Paul Wolfowitz, the embattled president of the World Bank who came to Brussels today to mobilize world governments on education policy in the developing world, was forced instead to dodge questions about an intensifying ethics scandal.

headline: Tom Poston, Virtuosic Comic Actor, Is Dead at 85
text: Tom Poston, an Emmy-winning comic actor whose television characters ranged from the slow-witted Everyman on "The Steve Allen Show" to a cantankerous closet-dwelling clown on the recent sitcom "Committed," died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption in some copies on Sunday with a Sports of The Times column about the PGA Tour’s handling of Tiger Woods given his support among corporate sponsors misidentified the man shown with Woods. He is AT&T’s chairman and chief executive, Edward E. Whitacre Jr. — not Tim Finchem, the PGA Tour commissioner.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary yesterday about Tommy Newsom, the backup bandleader for “The Tonight Show” whom Johnny Carson used as a comical target, misstated part of the name of the Air Force jazz ensemble in which he played. It is the Airmen of Note, not Airman.

headline: New York Marathon to Drop Pacesetters
text: Rabbits will fall by the wayside for the New York City Marathon.

headline: Laid-Back Risotto
text: AS soon as this spring’s vegetables began to appear, I wanted to revisit a favorite dish, a risotto that features asparagus front and center.

headline: Immigrant Rights Rallies Smaller Than Last Year
text: LOS ANGELES, May 1 — Tens of thousands of people pressing for immigrants’ rights demonstrated on Tuesday in dozens of cities. But with advocates splintered over tactics, the crowds paled in comparison with the turnout last year.

headline: Loopholes and More Loopholes
text: Virginia claims that it has closed a loophole that put guns in the hands of a deranged student who killed 32 people at Virginia Tech. But there’s always the next loophole to worry about when it comes to the lack of gun control in this country.

headline: For Most Bush Voters, No Regrets After 2 Years
text: George W. Bush was elected to a second term by a big majority of Republicans, half of political independents and 11 percent of Democrats. Now, more than two years later, the majority of those voters say they are satisfied with the Bush presidency. But some have lost faith, and those who have say it is because they can no longer back Mr. Bush’s support of the war in Iraq.

headline: Dow Offer a Marvel in Its Timing
text: Two years ago, with Dow Jones stock mired in the low 30s — and unhappy members of the controlling Bancroft family selling off some of their shares — Roy A. Hammer, the longtime trustee for the family, quipped to a reporter: “We’d rather sell at $60 a share. If you know any buyers, send them my way.”

headline: A Young Interpretive Palette Filled With Shades of Sound
text: Sometimes beauty of tone is everything, and sometimes it can turn a meaty work into nothing but ear candy. It depends on the music at hand, and a musician’s sense of when to luxuriate in tonal richness and when to let other qualities seize the moment.

headline: Jury Hears Victim’s Terror in 911 Call After Her Ordeal
text: Her demeanor on the witness stand was calm and crisp as she testified on Monday about being dosed with chloroform, stripped and tied to her bed by a masked man on Oct. 31, 2005.

headline: Spying on Americans
text: For more than five years, President Bush authorized government spying on phone calls and e-mail to and from the United States without warrants. He rejected offers from Congress to update the electronic eavesdropping law, and stonewalled every attempt to investigate his spying program.

headline: Recipe: Red Snapper Ceviche With Citrus
text: Adapted from Patricia Quintana

headline: Privacy Laws Slow Efforts on Gun-Buyer Data
text: WASHINGTON, May 1 — Momentum is building in Congress behind a measure that would push states to report their mental health records to the federal database used to conduct background checks on gun buyers.

headline: Lottery Numbers
What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (22, 26) ATLANTIC RECORDS: THE HOUSE THAT AHMET BUILT Ahmet Ertegun, left, was living in Washington when he first heard African-American music in that city’s segregated clubs. The son of a Turkish diplomat, he exported that sound to England, where he merged it with a European sensibility, and then brought it back to the United States, where he started an independent label with Herb Abramson and a $10,000 loan from his dentist. One result was the boogie-based, saxophone-driven “Atlantic Sound,” which changed the face of contemporary American music. Mr. Ertegun’s roster at Atlantic Records included Ray Charles, Ruth Brown, Big Joe Turner, LaVern Baker and the Drifters. In this documentary, Eric Clapton, Aretha Franklin, David Geffen, Mick Jagger, Kid Rock, Henry Kissinger, Jimmy Page, Robert Plant and Jann Wenner, among others, talk about the musical influence of Mr. Ertegun, who died in December.

headline: U.S. Seeks Closing of Visa Loophole for Britons
text: LONDON, May 1 — Omar Khyam, the ringleader of the thwarted London bomb plot who was sentenced to life imprisonment on Monday, showed the potential for disaffected young men to be lured as terrorists, a threat that British officials said they would have to contend with for a generation.

headline: The Power of Money (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: If Your Martini Needs Company, Look to the East
text: A well-made dry martini is a serious, contemplative drink, one that can easily overwhelm anything served with it. But a nibble that offers a touch of fat and salt is always welcome. Good potato chips would be the ticket.

headline: A No-Hit Bid by Hughes Ends With a Leg Injury
text: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 1 — The Yankees were gazing hopefully at their future on Tuesday when the present intervened. It was sudden, it was deflating, and it was cosmically cruel.

headline: Corzine Fined, at His Request, for Not Wearing a Seat Belt
text: TRENTON, May 1 — Gov. Jon S. Corzine voluntarily paid a $46 fine on Tuesday for failing to wear a seat belt, as required by law, on the day when his state vehicle crashed on the Garden State Parkway last month, state officials said.

headline: Staten Island Councilman’s Staff Did Personal Work
text: The city’s Conflicts of Interest Board has found that Councilman Michael E. McMahon, left, had one of his staff members perform personal tasks for him on city time, including helping his 12-year-old daughter with her homework. The inquiry began last year when city officials received an anonymous letter claiming that Mr. McMahon, a Staten Island Democrat, was using his city-paid staff for political campaigning. Mr. McMahon was cleared of that allegation, but investigators found that he had allowed his administrative assistant to type a poem for his daughter while she was visiting his Council office. Mr. McMahon also had his assistant call parents of a youth soccer team he coached to tell them of scheduling changes or that he would be late for games or practices because of Council-related business. Mr. McMahon, who did not dispute the findings, said his staff would no longer perform personal tasks because “that is the strict letter of the rules.” The board recommended no fines or penalties, given the limited nature of the violation. City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said she would refer the findings to the Council’s Standards and Ethics Committee for further review.

headline: Donald P. Lay, 80, Federal Judge Notable in Rights Cases, Dies
text: Donald P. Lay, a former chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit who rigorously defended the rights of women, Native Americans and convicts during his 40 years on the bench, died Sunday at his home in North Oaks, Minn. He was 80.

headline: Are Book Reviewers Out of Print?
text: Last year Dan Wickett, a former quality-control manager for a car-parts maker, wrote 95 book reviews on his blog, Emerging Writers Network (emergingwriters.typepad.com/), singlehandedly compiling almost half as many reviews as appeared in all of the book pages of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution.

headline: Qwest’s Profit Nearly Triples
text: Qwest Communications reported today that its quarterly profit nearly tripled, mainly because of cost cuts and an increase in broadband Internet customers.

headline: Bush Vetoes Bill Tying Iraq Funds to Exit
text: WASHINGTON, May 1 — President Bush vetoed a $124 billion war spending bill on Tuesday, setting up a second round in his long battle with Congressional Democrats who are determined to use the financing measure to force the White House to shift course in Iraq.

headline: The ‘I Forgot’ Syndrome (1 Letter)
text: To the Editors:

headline: Elections in Britain Reveal a Scottish Line in the Sand
text: KIRKCALDY, Scotland, April 30 — Gordon Brown, Britain’s presumed prime minister-to-be, is usually associated with a somewhat dour manner and a mastery of statistics. But here, he displays other skills — a bolt-on smile and a ready handshake to work sparse crowds between the discount stores on the High Street, asking parents with strollers whether their new babies are keeping them awake at night, and inquiring whether the men support the local Raith Rovers soccer team.

headline: No Sign of Fidel Castro on Cuban Holiday
text: HAVANA, May 1 — The throngs were out in the streets with their red shirts and banners just as they always are on May Day, but Cuba’s holiday honoring workers came and went Tuesday without their longtime leader ever showing his face.

headline: Your Plate Is Bigger Than Your Stomach
text: Late last year, a little book called “Mindless Eating” started appearing in bookstores. It was written by Brian Wansink, a Cornell professor who has spent his career doing brilliantly mischievous experiments about the psychology of eating.

headline: After 27 Years, Yonkers Housing Desegregation Battle Ends Quietly in Manhattan Court
text: The federal judge had been on the bench just over a year when the lawsuit first hit his docket; now he is semi-retired. The lawyer for the plaintiffs, now 53, was three years out of law school when he was assigned the case. And the current president of the Yonkers branch of the N.A.A.C.P., which filed the suit on behalf of poor blacks and Latinos living in segregated public housing, was still in her teens at the time the litigation began.

headline: Closing the Claremont Stables
text: Almost nothing captures a sense of the past like the sound of a horse’s hooves on the pavement of Manhattan — nothing, that is, except the smell of a horse. The island was once pervaded by both. Now all that is left of those great urban herds are the carriage horses in Central Park, the police horses in Midtown and, until last Sunday, the horses of the Claremont Riding Academy on West 89th Street.

headline: Now Murdoch Must Persuade the Family
text: Two years ago, with Dow Jones stock mired in the low 30s — and unhappy members of the controlling Bancroft family selling off some of their shares — Roy A. Hammer, the longtime trustee for the family, quipped to a reporter: “We’d rather sell at $60 a share. If you know any buyers, send them my way.”

headline: Rangers Exhale as Victory Goes Straight to Video
text: The Rangers have made an art of games decided by inches, often measured by video review, this time with all the tension of a playoff series resting on goalie Henrik Lundqvist with 17 seconds left in last night’s game against Buffalo.

headline: In a Reversal, U.S. Says Medicare Won’t Cover Stents for Neck Arteries
text: Responding to criticism from surgeons, the government has dropped its previously announced plans to expand Medicare coverage for the use of stents to prop open neck arteries to prevent strokes.

headline: House Fails to Override Bush Veto on Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, May 2 — House Democrats fell far short of overriding President Bush’s veto of the $124 billion war spending bill this afternoon, clearing the stage for negotiations between the president and lawmakers on a new bill.

headline: Iraqi Blocs Concerned Over Oil Bill
text: ERBIL, Iraq, May 2 — Kurdish and Sunni Arab officials expressed deep reservations today about the draft version of a national oil law and related legislation, misgivings that could derail one of the benchmark measures of progress in Iraq laid down by President George W. Bush.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Weekend on Friday about Symphony Space and the various arts programs it presents referred incompletely to the American Symphony Orchestra’s presence in New York City. While the orchestra is moving its annual series of concerts at Miller Theater to Symphony Space, it will continue its annual series of concerts at Lincoln Center.

headline: After Working the Streets, Bunk Beds and a Mass
text: Every Sunday morning in a second-floor apartment in Astoria, Queens, the Rev. Louis Braxton Jr. rouses a half-dozen sleeping bodies from bunk beds in two cramped rooms littered with stiletto heels and skimpy dresses.

headline: Turkish Prime Minister Calls for Early Elections
text: ISTANBUL, May 2 — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan asked the Turkish parliament today to approve early national elections for June 24 and his party began to press for several constitutional changes that would bring it advantages in the coming political battle.

headline: And to My Loyal Feng Shui Adviser, I Leave $3 Billion
Sirius Loss Narrows and Beats Estimates
text: Sirius Satellite Radio, the pay-radio broadcaster that plans to buy XM Satellite Radio Holdings, posted a narrower first-quarter loss yesterday as the company attracted more subscribers than analysts estimated.

headline: 12 Hurt as Car Chased by Police Collides With a School Bus
text: Twelve people, including eight children, were taken to hospitals yesterday after a school bus was struck by a stolen sport utility vehicle that the police were chasing in Queens.

headline: Scottish Nationalists’ Lead Narrows
text: EDINBURGH, Scotland, May 2 — On the eve of crucial regional elections in Scotland and Wales, Britain’s ruling Labor Party registered a last-minute gain in Scotland to make the race too close to call, according to an opinion survey published today in The Scotsman newspaper.

headline: The Matriarchs of Mexican Flavor
text: Mexico City

headline: Tensions Between Russia and Estonia Escalate
text: MOSCOW, May 2 — Diplomatic tensions between Russia and Estonia spilled into the streets today as protesters disrupted a news conference by the Estonian ambassador, harassed diplomats at the embassy and briefly blocked trucks crossing the border near St. Petersburg.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about the success of the trainer Todd Pletcher in horse racing and his efforts to win the Kentucky Derby misstated the length of the Derby and the distance run by 14 Derby winners in preparation for the race. The Derby is a mile and a quarter — not a mile and an eighth, which is the distance those winners had run.

headline: Administration Pulls Back on Surveillance Agreement
text: WASHINGTON, May 1 — Senior Bush administration officials told Congress on Tuesday that they could not pledge that the administration would continue to seek warrants from a secret court for a domestic wiretapping program, as it agreed to do in January.

headline: Cablevision Nears Deal With Dolans
text: Cablevision Systems is nearing a deal to sell itself to its founding family, the Dolans, for more than $10.5 billion in cash, according to people involved in the discussions.

headline: Yum Brands Makes Gains, Mostly in Sales at China Unit
text: Despite back-to-back public relations disasters — first an E. coli outbreak at its Taco Bell franchise, and then a widely publicized rat infestation at one of its restaurants in New York City — Yum Brands yesterday reported strong first-quarter earnings, as surging overseas sales and growth offset reduced business in the United States.

headline: Crossover Vehicle Keeping Ford Sales Afloat
text: DETROIT, May 1 — Is the Edge giving Ford the edge it was hoping for?

headline: 18 Air Force Cadets Exit Over Cheating
text: Fifteen cadets have been expelled and three others have resigned in a cheating scandal at the United States Air Force Academy near Colorado Springs, an Air Force official said yesterday.

headline: Study of N.B.A. Sees Racial Bias in Calling Fouls
text: An academic study of the National Basketball Association found that, during the 13 seasons from 1991 through 2004, white referees called fouls at a greater rate against black players than against white players. A corresponding bias was found in which black officials called fouls more frequently against white players, though that tendency was not as strong.

headline: A Reader’s Small-Plate Suggestion
text: After reading this week's column, a reader named Anne Garcia sent an email to say that Ikea sells 9-inch plates for just 79 cents apiece. The plates are part of the Motto line, and I have no idea how nice they are. But a 9-inch diameter is impressively small for any dinner plate that isn't an antique. I just did a Google search on "small dinner plates," and all of the sizes listed on the first page of results were more than 9 inches. The plates also cost a whole lot more than 79 cents.

headline: Dolans Near Deal for Cablevision
text: Cablevision Systems  is near a deal to sell the company to its founding family, the Dolans, for about $10.6 billion in cash, according to people involved in the discussions. With the addition of debt, the total price tag would come to nearly $23 billion.

headline: DealBook Wins a Webby
text: DealBook was chosen as the Best Business Blog in the 11th Annual Webby Awards, which highlight excellence on the Internet. Other nominees in the category included Bannerblog, paidContent, TechDirt and UX Magazine.

headline: NBC and Citadel Raise Ion Bid, Report Says
text: Under pressure from a group of disgruntled investors, NBC Universal and a hedge fund, the Citadel Investment Group, have again raised their takeover offer for family friendly TV network Ion Media Networks, The New York Post reported.

headline: ChannelAdvisor Tunes in $30 Million in Funding
text: ChannelAdvisor, an 8-year-old maker of on-demand software that helps retailers sell goods through Amazon, Shopzilla and eBay, on Tuesday announced $30 million in fresh funding to expand into new markets.

headline: Sweden Sells $2.9 Billion TeliaSonera Stake
text: Sweden will sell a stake in telephone company TeliaSonera valued at about 19.7 billion kronor ($2.9 billion) to institutional investors, the first sale of a state holding by the new government.

headline: Apollo Revises Countrywide Bid as Rival Rides Again
text: the buyout shop Apollo Management revised its offer for Countrywide, Britain’s largest real estate agency, on Tuesday after an 11th-hour offer by an anonymous bidder threatened to spoil the deal.

headline: Some Supercar Thoughts
text: For a number of reasons, I’ve been falling behind on my magazine reading. And I just got to the April issue of Evo last weekend.

headline: MAF Deal Puts Wind in National City’s Chicago Sails
text: One possible suitor may be out of the battle over ABN Amro‘s LaSalle Bank, the Chicago institution that its Dutch parent agreed to sell to Bank of America for $21 billion.

headline: Hollinger Money Diverted Improperly, Ex-Director Says
text: Conrad M. Black and other Hollinger International executives improperly diverted more than $15 million to a holding company Mr. Black controlled, former Illinois Gov. James R. Thompson told jurors in Chicago Tuesday.

headline: Icahn Vs. Motorola: The Battle Continues
text: The volume went up a notch Tuesday in the ongoing saga between Motorola and the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, who is seeking a seat on the cell phone maker’s board.

headline: Blockbuster Unloads U.K. Chain
text: Bockbuster, the No. 1 U.S. movie retail chain, said on Wednesday it had sold its British video game retailer, Game Station, to Game Group of Britain for $150 million. The move is part of Blockbuster’s ongoing efforts to sell off non-core assets and some international operations, while it heightens Game Group’s presence in the British market.

headline: Virgin Mobile USA Dials Up I.P.O.
text: Virgin Mobile USA, the leading mobile virtual network operator in the United States, plans to raise $100 million in an initial public offering, the company said on Tuesday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Hawaiian Telecom Bids Aloha to Directories Unit
text: Hawaiian Telcom is selling its phone directory publishing business for $435 million and will use the money to pay down debt and make service improvements. The sale to Local Insight Media was announced Tuesday and is subject to approval by the Public Utilities Commission.

headline: Is NYSE Euronext Planning a Run at I.S.E.?
text: A $3 billion loan package secured by the NYSE Euronext has some industry observers speculating that the exchange is plotting to muscle in on Deutsche Börse‘s agreed $2.8 billion deal for the International Securities Exchange.

headline: Green Chemistry Start-Up Gets $15 Million
text: Segetis, a green chemistry company, has raised $15 million from Khosla Ventures. The Minneapolis-based Segetis is one of a number of outfits trying to displace petroleum in household products like countertops, bottles and other items with agricultural-waste products.

headline: Struggles Abound in Sirius-XM Courtship
text: In February, when Sirius Satellite Radio‘s chief executive, Mel Karmazin, announced plans to merge his company with the rival XM Satellite Radio, he pegged the chances of winning approval from regulators at “better than 50 percent.” At the time, many investors and analysts agreed with his math.

headline: Credit Suisse Says First-Quarter Profits Rose
text: Credit Suisse Group said Wednesday that first-quarter net profit rose 5 percent helped by excellent markets for trading stocks and bonds and more commissions from wealthy clients. Credit Suisse, Switzerland’s second-largest bank, said net profit for the three months was 2.7 billion Swiss francs ($2.23 billion), from 2.6 billion francs a year earlier.

headline: Citigroup in Deal for Bisys
text: Citigroup agreed to buy a fund administrator, the Bisys Group, for $1.47 billion. Citigroup will pay $11.85 a share and a special dividend of 15 cents a share at closing, the New York-based bank said today in a statement distributed by Business Wire.

headline: Australia’s Coates Takes Private Equity Callers
text: Shares of Coates Hire, the largest machinery rental company in Australia, rose the most in more than five years after it said it had been approached by buyout firms. Coates hired Macquarie Bank as an adviser and said Tuesday it would review operations, which may take “some months.” Shares in Coates, which is based in Sydney, closed 8.7 percent higher, valuing it at 1.5 billion Australian dollars ($1.2 billion).

headline: What Is Texas Pacific Worth?
text: The Texas Pacific Group is mulling selling a 20 percent stake in itself to a couple of pension funds, in a move that could signal an initial public offering of the private equity group, The Deal.com reported.

headline: I.S.S. Reaffirms Opposition to Clear Channel Deal
text: Things were looking increasingly dismal for the private equity firms bidding for Clear Channel Communications Tuesday as a second proxy advisory firm urged shareholders in the broadcasting company to reject a sweetened offer from Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners.

headline: Will the Bancrofts Sell Dow Jones?
text: Has Rupert Murdoch made the Bancroft family an offer they can’t refuse?

headline: Wolfowitz and the Wages of Hubris
text: Paul Wolfowitz’s failures as a war architect and as a World Bank president flow from the same source, suggests Washington Post columnist David Ignatius: “The lesson of Wolfowitz’s failure is that you can’t change things unless you truly understand them. That was true in Iraq, and it was true at the World Bank.”

headline: The Day Digg Users Revolted
text: Note | 8:59 PM ET: The Times has published an article on the subject, focusing on “How a Number Became the Latest Web Celebrity“

headline: Currents
text: Take home a little piece of Battery Park, a light transportable yurt for today's nomad, playful peel-and-stick art and more.

headline: Personal Shopper
text: The right gear takes some of the dirty work out of seasonal chores.

headline: 2008: Democrats’ Veto Responses
text: The Washington Post’s Dan Balz and David Broder report that Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama encouraged Democrats to continue the fight over the war supplemental bill, which President Bush vetoed because of the included withdrawal timeline, while other contenders called for more drastic steps to end the war. John Edwards’s campaign will tell Democrats, “Don’t back down to President Bush” in ads set to air in Washington, the first of his campaign.

headline: Guantanamo as the Lesser Evil
text: Should liberals want to keep the detention center at Guantanamo Bay open? “[C]losing GTMO would much more [likely] result in more detainees being held in facilities closer to the actual ‘battlefield,’ such as Bagram, rather than in domestic [facilities],” writes Georgetown law professor Marty Lederman at the group legal blog Balkinization. “And that would hardly improve matters from a legal or human rights perspective. Moreover, if GTMO were closed, more of the detainees there might be transferred to nations such as Libya, where there is a real risk that they may be tortured.” He concludes, “A better idea would be for Congress to require that due process and some form of meaningful judicial review be provided at GTMO and at other detention facilities around the globe.”

headline: Now Hughes Is Hurting
text: UPDATE: The Yankees fired strength coach Marty Miller on Wednesday.

headline: Cablevision Accepts $10.6 Billion Buyout Offer
text: The Dolans seem to have finally hit the magic number.

headline: For Most Bush Voters, Few Regrets After 2 Years
text: Fifty-eight percent of President Bush’s voters say their feelings about the administration can best be described as satisfied but not enthusiastic.

text: Recording, With Introduction From Akron Beacon Journal (mp3)

headline: Christians in Pakistan
text: My friend Mukhtar Mai (Mukhtaran Bibi), the Pakistani woman I’ve often written about, is visiting New York for a few days. She has campaigned relentlessly for women’s rights in Pakistan, and as it happens her visit coincides with a report reaching me of another horrific incident:

headline: Further thoughts on my Schools Column…
text: Readers raised several kinds of objections to my education column. You can read the reader comments under the blog entry below. So let me try to summarize and respond to some of the objections.

headline: Paris Is Glowing
text: Images from the various segments of "Paris Je T'Aime."

headline: Dow Jones Bid Puts Pearson in Headlines
text: As deal makers survey the media scene following News Corporation‘s offer for Dow Jones, one name that keeps popping up is Pearson, the British book publisher and owner of The Financial Times. There were lots of scenarios being laid out for Pearson, whose $14 billion market capitalization makes it about three times the size of Dow Jones. It could enter the bidding for Dow Jones. It could itself be a takeover target. It could break itself up.

headline: The Design of Paul’s Dreams
text: After Greg Huddy and I descended from the cherry picker, we all sat down over iced tea to talk about requirements.

headline: How'd That Get Here?
text: How "Frank Stella on the Roof," a show of architectural pieces by Mr. Stella, was installed in the Metropolitan Museum of Art's roof garden.

headline: Ex-M.I.T. Dean’s Secret Degree
text: The saga of Marilee Jones added another layer today when The Boston Globe reported that she indeed had a bachelor’s degree.

headline: Et Voilà, la Vidéo!
text: So it turns out they have the Internet in France! Who knew?

headline: Remaking the Arab World
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s May 2 column, “The Hail Mary Pass.”

headline: Deal Record From AOL-Time Warner Days Is Broken
text: How hot is the mergers and acquisitions market? Consider this: April marked an all-time high for the value of worldwide mergers announced in a single month, lifted in large part by a bidding war that broke out for Dutch bank ABN Amro. Thomson Financial calculates that the combined value of deals announced last month came to $626.3 billion, surpassing the previous record of $518.1 billion set in January 2000, when America Online  announced its $165 billion bid for Time Warner.

headline: Hillary vs. Rudy: A Democratic House Divided
text: The invitation looks pretty normal at first: Rosina Rubin, a donor to Democratic candidates, is hosting a fund-raiser for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign next Tuesday, with former President Bill Clinton as the special guest. The event will be in a New York City suburb at “the home of Rosina Rubin and Jeff Rose,” her husband and another prominent Democratic contributor.

headline: Virginia Tech Roundup
text: Here are a few items on Virginia Tech that we’ve spotted in our travels today around the Web.

headline: 2 Buyout Firms to Acquire Ahold’s U.S. Foodservice
text: Royal Ahold, the Dutch food retailing giant, will sell its U.S. Foodservice business to two United States-based private equity firms for $7.1 billion. Clayton Dubilier & Rice and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed to buy the unit, which was the focus of an accounting scandal that emerged in 2003. U.S. Foodservice is the second-largest food service company, behind Sysco.

headline: TiVo Ad
text: An advertisement for TiVo.

headline: A War of the Quotes for Motorola and Icahn
text: In its proxy fight with billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn, Motorola is giving as good as its getting. One day after Mr. Icahn used a full-page ad in The Wall Street Journal to compare comments by Motorola chief executive Ed Zander to “something straight out of Alice in Wonderland,” Motorola is trying a similar strategy of using its adversary’s words against him.

headline: A Drop in Unsheltered Homeless
text: New York City recorded 3,755 homeless individuals living without shelter according to the latest Homeless Outreach Population Estimate, which the city has conducted each year since 2005.

headline: One Investor’s Dow Jones Dream: $100 Per Share
text: Many Wall Street analysts are still gaping over the $5 billion unsolicited bid that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation made for Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. At $60 per share, it was 67 percent above the company’s recent stock price and represented a multiple of about 16 times Dow Jones’s projected 2007 Ebitda. (Other recent newspaper deals have come in at about eight times Ebitda.) A former financial adviser to the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, has called the bid “absolutely, insanely high.”

headline: Scott Boras’s Yankee Clients
text: Scott Boras, the powerful agent, had a conversation with Yankees’ General Manager Brian Cashman recently about one of his clients who is itching to return and play for New York. But it was not Bernie Williams, the reclusive outfielder. It was Ron Villone, the reliever who is playing in Class AAA.

headline: My Buddy, Bill O’Reilly
text: As readers know, I’ve tangled a few times with Bill O’Reilly, ever since I challenged him to put his passport where his mouth is and travel to Darfur. At the time, I compared him to Father Coughlin, and now we have some research to back up the parallel. An academic study looked at Father Coughlin’s use of various standard propaganda devices versus Bill O’Reilly’s and — you guessed it — O’Reilly uses them on the whole even more than Father Coughlin did. Take a look at the study.

headline: Bully or Nice Guy? Giuliani as a Debater
text: Which Rudolph W. Giuliani will show up Thursday night in California for the debate among 10 Republican presidential candidates? The hard-hitting prosecutor? Or Mr. Nice Guy?

headline:
Register Your Opinions:
A Survey about Reservations
text: One of the topics most frequently covered and debated on this blog is restaurant reservations: the difficulty of getting them, the rules that come with them, the efficiency with which restaurants honor them, the consistency with which diners follow through on them.

headline: Bush: ‘I’m the Commander Guy’
text: WASHINGTON, May 2–And you thought he was still “the decider.”

headline: Stephani Cook
text: Cook is 62 and lives in Pound Ridge, NY. She is an corporate consultant and the author of a memoir, ''Second Life.'' She is a former Ford model. Cook has been married for 22 years.

headline: Crispin Sartwell
text: Sartwell is 48 and lives in Glen Rock, Pa. He is a college philosophy professor and the author of numerous books, including most recently ''Six Names of Beauty.''

headline: Peter Handler
