text: Handler is 59 and lives in Philadelphia. He owns a furniture-making studio. His first marriage ended in divorce after eight years; he now lives with his second wife.

headline: Michael Duszynski
text: Duszynski is 46 and lives in Maplewood, N.J. He is an occupational therapist. He has been married for 18 years and has three children.

headline: Michele Thomas
text: Thomas is 60 and lives in Brooklyn. She teaches English language to international college students. Three years ago, Michele separated from her husband of 20 years. They have one child.

headline: The Flawed Wilsonian Dream
text: Today’s presidential candidates are understandably cautious when it comes to foreign policy, especially about stepping into the minefields of Iraq. But in their remarks, it is possible to discern an assumption about the rightness of American leadership in world affairs – a notion that is the legacy of Woodrow Wilson.

headline: Turning Human Beings Into Monsters
text: It is three years and a few days since CBS News published the first photos documenting the systematic abuse, torture and humiliation of Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison. The Bush administration and the American military have worked hard to firmly establish the “few bad apples” explanation of what happened. Eight low-ranking soldiers were convicted, and Staff Sgt. Ivan Frederick II, who was found guilty of assault, conspiracy, dereliction of duty and maltreatment of detainees, is now halfway through his eight-year prison sentence.

headline: An ‘Insignificant’ Drop in Homelessness?
text: The Coalition for the Homeless, a leading advocacy organization, issued a statement questioning the city’s announcement that street homelessness has declined slightly, according to the Homeless Outreach Population Estimate, a citywide survey conducted annually since 2005. Mary Brosnahan, the coalition’s executive director, called the decline “statistically insignificant and certainly nothing to cheer about.” In a statement, she said:

headline: John Hockenberry
text: Hockenberry is 50 and lives in Brooklyn. He was an award-winning correspondent for NPR, ABC and NBC's ''Dateline'' and is now a freelance journalist and a distinguished fellow at M.I.T.'s Media Lab.

headline: Lyn Neeley
text: Neeley is 57 and lives in Montclair, N.J. She is a high-school biology teacher. Neeley was married for five years. Through her 20s and 30s, she was in long-term relationships with two different women.

headline: Marty Beitler
text: Beitler is 48 and lives in Manhattan. He is a primary-care doctor. He was married for 14 years to a woman he met in medical school. They have a daughter.

headline: Eleanore Wells
text: Wells is 51 and lives in Manhattan. She is a marketing-and-advertising consultant. Before her career in the advertising industry, Wells was a social worker. She has never been married.

headline: Lorraine Landrau
text: Landrau is 46 and lives in the Bronx with her two children. She is a receptionist at a nonprofit legal defense firm and a part-time college student, pursuing a degree in social work.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Waitress'
text: A. O. Scott, Chief Movie Critic of The New York Times, reviews "Waitress."

headline: Bancrofts Are Not United
text: It looks like there are some members of the Bancroft family — the controlling family of Dow Jones — who think it would be a good idea to take the $60 per share offered by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation. And that family split could encourage Mr. Murdoch to keep trying.

headline: The Hurwitz Jurors Explain Further
text: The Hurwitz jurors will not win any popularity contests with the readers of this blog, to judge from the responses to the post quoting the jurors’ reasons for convicting Dr. William Hurwitz. But let me give them a chance to further explain their verdict.

headline: T Style | Hot Links
text: Watch Paul Bertolli, the sausage king, get down to cases.

headline: Another Job Opening for a Yankees Starter
text: I’ve never seen a tornado up close, and I’m quite sure I don’t want to. But there was a tornado warning here in Arlington tonight, and the intense rain washed out the Yankees’ game with the Texas Rangers.

headline: Debate Preview
text: Adam Nagourney narrates a look at what to look for from the Republican presidential debate in Simi Valley, Calif.

headline: Down and Nearly Out, Dallas Turns to Its Star
text: DALLAS, May 2 — The Dallas Mavericks were down by 9 points late Tuesday night, down by 3-1 in their series against the Golden State Warriors and down to their last breath. Anyone in the arena could see the situation was bleak. Except for Dirk Nowitzki.

headline: A Corner Deli With International Appeal
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 2 — On an unseasonably warm Sunday afternoon in mid-March, hundreds of food lovers packed a tent on Detroit Street in front of Zingerman’s Delicatessen here, lining up for samples to celebrate the deli’s 25th anniversary.

headline: Some Access to Student Finance Data Is Restored
text: The federal Education Department announced yesterday that it was restoring some access to a database with personal information on millions of financial aid applicants.

headline: Curing Republican Blues (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Time Warner Lifts Forecast on Growing Cable Earnings
text: Time Warner, the world’s largest media company, raised its 2007 forecast yesterday after surging cable-television earnings helped first-quarter profit beat analysts’ estimates.

headline: Justice Dept. Announces Inquiry Into Its Hiring
text: WASHINGTON, May 2 — The Justice Department has begun an internal investigation into whether a former senior adviser to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales improperly tried to fill vacancies for career prosecutors at the agency with Republicans loyal to the Bush administration, department officials said Wednesday.

headline: G.O.P. Contenders Ponder What to Say About Bush
text: LOS ANGELES, May 2 — As they gather Thursday night at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library for their first debate, the Republican presidential candidates are thrilled at the chance to associate themselves with Reagan. But they may not be able to escape the challenge created for them by the current president.

headline: An Invisible War
text: Paul Rieckhoff looked across the crowded restaurant, which was not far from Times Square.

headline: Small and Smaller
text: LONG among the hottest items in Europe and Asia, ultraportable notebook computers  supercompact, lightweight laptops that slip into briefcases as easily as a legal pad  appear to be finding favor with American tastes. In cafes and corporate boardrooms and on college campuses, the sleek machines are in growing evidence.

headline: Reunited Giants Coaches Seek to Get Most Out of Manning
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 2  Kevin Gilbride was the starting quarterback for Southern Connecticut State in 1971. He was benched after a couple of early losses. Eventually, a third-string senior named Chris Palmer got the job, and the team won its last four games.

headline: Use of Public Funds Is Urged for State Comptroller’s Races
text: State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli called yesterday for giving public matching funds to candidates for comptroller  but proposed allowing much bigger contributions than other jurisdictions with publicly financed elections permit, although far less than the current state limit.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (22) LINCOLN CENTER SPECIAL: A GALA NIGHT FROM ALICE TULLY HALL Good night, Alice — for now. In this “Live From Lincoln Center” production, taped on Monday, performers including Wynton Marsalis, above; Audra McDonald; Philip Glass; Laurie Anderson; and the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center bid temporary adieu to Alice Tully Hall before it closes for renovation. Tom Brokaw is master of ceremonies.

headline: Rapper Charged With Drunken Driving
text: The rapper Busta Rhymes was arrested early this morning and charged with driving while intoxicated after officers stopped his car in Manhattan and smelled alcohol on his breath, the police said.

headline: To Help Cut the Cord, an Internet Handset With a Landline Option
text: Luddites who have been afraid to make the leap to Internet calling can finally get a taste of the 21st century. The Philips VOIP841 acts as a standard landline telephone but can also make calls using the Internet phone service Skype, allowing a switch from Alexander Graham Bell to Buck Rogers in seconds.

headline: Friction Between Estonia and Russia Ignites Protests in Moscow
text: MOSCOW, May 2 — Diplomatic tensions between Russia and Estonia spilled into the streets on Wednesday as protesters disrupted a news conference by the Estonian ambassador, harassed diplomats at the embassy and briefly blocked trucks crossing the border near St. Petersburg.

headline: As Corzine Recuperates Upstairs, Visitors Tour Below
text: PRINCETON, N.J., May 2 — Don Warnock, who has been a docent at Drumthwacket, the New Jersey governor’s mansion, for 14 years, can tell visitors which specific corner of Persia the 1875 Sultanabad rug in the library came from: the northwest.

headline: A Difference of Opinion on a Memoir of Her Mother
text: As a first-time author, Margaret Ajemian Ahnert had hoped that her appearance at a Barnes & Noble store on the Upper East Side would draw attention to her just-published book, “The Knock at the Door,” which deals with the Armenian genocide.

headline: Baltimore Mayor Unveils Strategy to Attack Increase in Gun Crime
text: BALTIMORE, May 2 — With shootings rising sharply here, Mayor Sheila Dixon announced plans Wednesday to form a task force on illegal guns and install a system to track where and when guns had been used in crimes.

headline: A Pool of Ready Capital With  Entrepreneurs in Mind
text: Corporate chief executives may have been the heroes of American business in bygone decades, but these days the entrepreneur is king — or queen. Praised for creating most of the jobs and much of the innovation in the American economy, those who start small businesses are now receiving big money from individual investors in a form called angel capital.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture in some copies with an article on Monday about the funeral and burial of the Russian cellist Mstislav Rostropovich was published in error. It showed a farewell ceremony for the actor Kirill Lavrov, not the burial of Mr. Rostropovich.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: No Hiding From Alice Roi
text: LIKE her brash, unflirtatious designs for urban tomboys, Alice Roi is not coy. Asked what she, a designer with authentic indie stature, intended by blanketing SoHo this week with her name on posters and her little smock dresses in two stores, she came right to the point. She wanted to see whether or not people would actually buy her clothes.

headline: Yankees, Hurting, See Culprit: The Fitness Coach
text: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 2 — With one misstep on Tuesday, Phil Hughes, a Yankees rookie pitcher, lost his chance for a no-hitter. On Wednesday, Marty Miller lost his job.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the inspection of imported foods by the Food and Drug Administration referred imprecisely to the Senate panel on agriculture appropriations that received a letter from Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, warning that the F.D.A.’s resources were overtaxed. It is a subcommittee, not a standing committee.

headline: Obama Placed Under Secret Service Protection
text: Senator Barack Obama, whose crowds at political rallies across the country often have numbered in the thousands, was placed under Secret Service protection yesterday, a spokesman for the agency said.

headline: 66 Workers at Agency Had Records, Inquiry Finds
text: HOUSTON, May 2  An investigation into sexual abuse and mismanagement at the Texas Youth Commission has led to the dismissal of 66 employees with records of felony charges or arrests, including one convicted of homicide and another who had pleaded guilty to attempted murder, the state official leading the inquiry reported Wednesday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Democracy in Nigeria Falters but Is Far From Dead
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — Measured one way, Nigeria’s democracy took a giant step backward in April. Its state and national elections displayed a disastrous mix of fraud and bungling, managing to be worse, by most accounts, than the seriously marred elections in 1999 and 2003.

headline: House Votes to Expand ‘Hate Crime’ Protections
text: WASHINGTON, May 3 — The House of Representatives voted today to extend “hate crime” protection to people who are victimized because of their sexuality. But the most immediate effect of the bill may be to set up another veto showdown between Democrats and President Bush.

headline: For Dedicated BlackBerry Users, a Way to Stay Connected Abroad
text: While there are some export restrictions on precious gems, users of the BlackBerry 8830 — with its shining pearl-like trackball — will have no problem getting through customs, let alone making calls from foreign lands.

headline: Sprint Nextel Posts a Loss Amid Concern About Market Share
text: The Sprint Nextel Corporation, the wireless carrier, reported a quarterly loss yesterday, fueling concern that the company was losing market share to its rivals as it struggles to achieve a turnaround.

headline: Correction: Currents
text: A report in the Currents column last Thursday about the Dutch designer Tord Boontje misidentified the work shown in an accompanying photograph. It was the 7-by-11-inch brass-plated steel panel called “Ivy 1,” which sells for $59, not a curtain made of Tyvek called “Until Dawn.”

headline: Correction: I’d Like to Get Off the Stage Right Now
text: An article last week about technology’s intrusion on celebrities’ privacy misspelled the first name of a divorce lawyer who has represented prominent clients. He is Raoul Felder, not Raul.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: An article in Business Day on Saturday reported that federal prosecutors in Seattle were conducting a criminal inquiry into Quellos Investments, a hedge fund group, over its design and sale of questionable tax shelters. It said that the investigation became public because of a related civil lawsuit.

headline: Toward a Federal Shield Law
text: When the subject of a journalists’ shield law comes up in Congress, as it has this week, the issue is often framed as an attempt by reporters to give themselves special privileges to the detriment of criminal investigations and even national security.

headline: For the Record
text: A letter on Saturday from Newtonville, Mass., about the no-period pill referred incorrectly to the hormone endothelin. It increases blood pressure; it is not an “antihypertensive agent.”

headline: China Food Mislabeled, U.S. Says
text: SHANGHAI, May 2 — A Chinese company accused of selling contaminated wheat gluten to American pet food suppliers avoided inspections partly because it did not correctly disclose its shipping contents to Chinese export authorities, according to American regulators.

headline: History Made Intimate Through Reagan’s Diaries
text: Ronald Reagan’s private diaries, once the subject of argument over whether excerpts would be produced as part of the Iran-contra trial of John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, are being published for all the world to see later this month.

headline: Israel Reveals New Details of Allegations Against Ex-Lawmaker
text: JERUSALEM, May 2 — The Israeli police on Wednesday revealed further details of allegations that they said could result in charges of treason against a former Israeli lawmaker, Azmi Bishara.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to hire 32 more New York City fire marshals misstated the number of fires in 2006 and included an erroneous comparison to statistics from earlier years. There were 27,817 fires in 2006, according to the Fire Department  not 6,023, which was the number of fires investigated that year. In the early 1980s, fire marshals investigated about 13,000 fires a year; that is not the number they fought.

headline: Major Parts Maker in Talks With Auto Unions
text: OTTAWA, May 2  The auto parts maker Magna International, which is considering a bid for Chrysler, is in talks with Canadian and American auto unions about adding Magna’s tens of thousands of workers to their ranks, according to the president of the Canadian union.

headline: Air Disaster Is Linked to Failure of Safety System
text: WASHINGTON, May 2  American air safety investigators on Wednesday attributed a disastrous collision over the Amazon last year partly to cockpit systems’ failure to alert the crew of a business jet that its anti-collision equipment had failed.

headline: A Planet Denser Than Earth
text: Despite being the size of Jupiter and made mostly of hydrogen, a planet around a star 440 light-years away is denser than Earth, astronomers at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass., announced. The astronomers were able to measure the size of the planet, designated HAT-P-2b, because it passes directly in front of the star every 5 days and 15 hours, causing it to dim slightly. HAT-P-2b, in the constellation Hercules, is more than eight times the mass of Jupiter, and the immense gravity crushes the planet down to its relatively small size and Earth-like density.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Lawsuits Compete for Returned Paintings

headline: A Media PC That Can Stand Up Next to the Television
text: Some PCs look great on an office desk, while others are more suited to a home study. The Shuttle X200M, an update to the X100 media PC, looks great next to the TV.

headline: Two Parties, One Law
text: AS a former Justice Department official, I have been inundated lately with questions from friends, family and acquaintances about Attorney General Alberto Gonzales. Should he stay or should he go? To some extent, I think that’s the wrong question.

headline: Protesters Gather to Urge Olmert to Resign
text: TEL AVIV, May 3 – More than 100,000 protesters gathered in Rabin Square here on Thursday night to urge Israel’s prime minister, Ehud Olmert, and his government to resign. The call followed the release of a damning report on the performance of the country’s leadership during last summer’s war in Lebanon.

headline: Iraqi Blocs  Opposed to Draft Oil Bill
text: ERBIL, Iraq, May 2 — Kurdish and Sunni Arab officials expressed deep reservations on Wednesday about the draft version of a national oil law and related legislation, misgivings that could derail one of the benchmark measures of progress in Iraq laid down by President Bush.

headline: Still Hurting, Pavano to Talk to Surgeon
text: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 2  Carl Pavano said he planned to call James Andrews on Thursday to schedule a visit for a recurrence of the tightness in his strained right forearm. Andrews is a surgeon in Birmingham, Ala., who has performed many arm operations on pitchers.

headline: Power-Tool Envy? Read This First
text: ALL nail guns can cause serious injury, said Hester Lipscomb, an associate professor in occupational and environmental medicine at Duke University Medical Center who has studied nail-gun safety. But those with sequential-trip triggers carry half the risk of those with contact-trip triggers, according to her research.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. What’s the secret to creating an appealing bed?

headline: Canada: Earnings Rise at Telephone Giant
text: BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, said first-quarter profit rose 4.6 percent, to 499 million Canadian dollars ($450 million) because of lower restructuring costs and an extraordinary gain. Poor performance in the wireless unit meant that Bell Canada revenue rose just 0.4 percent over the same quarter a year earlier, reaching 3.58 billion Canadian dollars ($3.22 billion). Bell Mobility signed up just 13,000 cellphone subscribers during the period compared with 76,000 a year earlier. Recent price increases by Bell Mobility have not been matched by competitors. BCE said last month that it was in talks with Canadian pension funds and private equity investors that might lead to its going private.

headline: 3 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Baghdad; New Army Reinforcements Arrive
text: BAGHDAD, May 2  Three American soldiers were killed in combat operations in the capital on Wednesday and two were wounded, according to a statement from the military, on a day when thousands more troops arrived in the country.

headline: Climate Panel Reaches Consensus on the Need to Reduce Harmful Emissions
text: The world needs to divert substantially from today’s main energy sources within a few decades to limit centuries of rising temperatures and seas driven by the buildup of heat-trapping emissions in the air, the top body studying climate change has concluded.

headline: Candidates Spar Vigorously as French Vote Nears
text: PARIS, May 2 — He accused her of losing her cool. She accused him of lacking compassion.

headline: Figueiredo Looks to Shift Gears
text: Bia Figueiredo continues her climb through the lower levels of open-wheel racing in the hope of making it all the way to the elite Formula One division. Since PLAY wrote about Figueiredo last November, she finished second in the season’s final race last December and ended up fifth overall in the South American Formula Three division. “After that we started to negotiate my future in Europe, and we are almost closing on it,” she said in a recent e-mail message from her native Brazil. “I am still racing F3, but now I will start to drive the British F3 car in the U.K.” It could lead to an opportunity to race bigger cars, she said, “and I would love to do it.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary yesterday about Donald P. Lay, a federal appeals court judge, gave the incorrect date in some copies for his death. It was Sunday, not Tuesday.

headline: At Trial of Suspect in Sexual Attack, Lawyers Debate Meaning of ‘Normal’
text: To the people who met him in the days before and just after he dressed up as a firefighter and, prosecutors say, sexually molested a former co-worker in her Chelsea apartment, Peter Braunstein seemed perfectly normal, as if he had nothing to hide.

headline: The Republicans’ First Presidential Candidates Debate
text: MSNBC’s Republican presidential debate with candidates: Senator Sam Brownback (R-Kansas);the former Virginia governor James Gilmore (R-Va.); the former New York City mayor Rudolph Giuliani; the former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee; Rep. Duncan Hunter (R-Calif.); Senator John McCain (R-Ariz.); Rep. Ron Paul (R-Tex.); the former Massachusetts governor Mitt Romney; Rep. Tom Tancredo (R-Colo.); and the former Wisconsin governor Tommy Thompson. Moderated by Chris Matthews with questions by John Harris, editor in chief of politico.com and Jim Vandehei, executive editor of politico.com. At the Ronald Reagan Library in Simi Valley, Calif. Transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A books column in Weekend on Friday, about several books on Shakespeare released to coincide with his birthday last month, referred incorrectly to the porter’s actions in “Macbeth.” He opens the gate; he does not knock on it.

headline: AOL Slips to No. 3 on Internet
text: After more than a decade connecting more Americans to the Internet than any other company, AOL has given up its title as the leading Internet service provider, a reflection of changing consumer habits and its own strategic shift.

headline: Democrats Regroup After Veto, Seeking Unity on Iraq Plan
text: WASHINGTON, May 2 — Think of Senators Ben Nelson of Nebraska and Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin as the yin and yang of Democratic views on what to do about the Iraq spending legislation now that President Bush’s veto has been upheld.

headline: The Creator of Thumbelina, and Other Visiting Danes
text: The birthday parties that children attend in Manhattan can be extravagant, if not extraordinary. But even the most jaded young New Yorkers have probably never seen a feast like the one to be presented on Saturday in a building on West 42nd Street:

headline: Vote Sets Tone for Blair’s Anticipated Departure
text: LONDON, May 3 — Across Britain, voters went to the polls today in a mid-term regional vote likely to set the tone for Prime Minister Tony Blair’s expected resignation next week.

headline: Old Sound Brings Out Warm Notes
text: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart with the Off the Charts column in Business Day on Saturday misstated the performance of Merck stock from March 24, 2000, to April 27, 2007. It fell 11.3 percent; it did not rise 37.5 percent.

headline: A Choreographic Duo Take a Final Bow
text: Artistic suicide is an old but enduring game, especially for performers who have manufactured personas that are integral to their work.

headline: Those Star-Crossed Lovers With Sun-Splashed Colors
text: In the ballroom scene of Peter Martins’s new “Romeo and Juliet” for New York City Ballet, each pair of Capulet guests enters by posing dramatically, as if to say, “Do you like the way we’re dressed?” At the gala premiere on Tuesday (attended by Bill Clinton, who took the seat forever associated with Lincoln Kirstein and was greeted with a standing ovation), this certainly rang a bell.

headline: Henry LeTang, Master of Tap, Dies at 91
text: Henry LeTang, a master dancer, teacher and Tony-winning choreographer who for three-quarters of a century taught the leading lights of Broadway and Hollywood how to tap dance, often with show-stopping results, died last Thursday in Las Vegas. He was 91 and was active until shortly before his death.

headline: Easy, Mr. Fix-It
text: THE three Victorian houses James G. Ferreri renovated are gone from his life, but the pain from his falls and injuries lingers on: there’s the arthritis, the atrophy in his right arm, and the back trouble, for which he’s had two surgeries (a third is looming).

headline: Train Hauling NASA Parts Derails on Snakebitten Trip
text: A train hauling segments of the space shuttle’s solid rocket boosters across the country derailed yesterday for the second time in a week.

headline: Officers Gather, 5,000 Strong, to Mourn Fallen Trooper
text: DELMAR, N.Y., May 2  A little more than two and half years ago, a young woman named Barbara Rhodes stood at the front inside Bethlehem Lutheran Church here, just outside Albany, and pledged to have and to hold a young state trooper named David C. Brinkerhoff so long as they both should live.

headline: First Architect, Then Tenant
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: CARE Champions World’s Poor Women With Help From Wealthy Ones
text: In March, Sheila C. Johnson, a founder of Black Entertainment Television and one of the country’s wealthiest women, held a weekend retreat to benefit CARE at her 200-acre horse farm in Virginia.

headline: Afghans Say U.S. Bombing Killed 42 Civilians
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 2 — Aerial bombing of a valley in western Afghanistan several days ago by the American military killed at least 42 civilians, including women and children, and wounded 50 more, an Afghan government investigation found Wednesday. A provincial council member who visited the site independently put the figure at 50 civilians killed.

headline: Making the Transition With a Little Help
text: INTERVAL training is strenuous and involves keeping track of time. Many people prefer having a coach — virtual or real — to tell them when to go and when to rest. For guidance, consider:

headline: Wolfowitz’s Big Mistake
text: Let me offer some advice.

headline: In G.O.P. Debate Today, Which Tack for Giuliani?
On Opening Day, Some Need to Feel Thunder of the Hoofbeats
text: ELMONT, N.Y., May 2 — If betting on horses were the only reason people came to Belmont Park, no one would come. Bettors can gamble over the telephone now, or online. For the companionship of other such enthusiasts, there is Off-Track Betting.

headline: Ousted Thai Premier: Dabbler in Sports, Champ of the Spotlight
text: BANGKOK, May 2 — Ousted as prime minister in a coup last September, Thaksin Shinawatra has made a move to console himself with the purchase of an English soccer club.

headline: Critic of Iran’s Nuclear Policy Is Charged With Spying
text: TEHRAN, May 2  A prominent critic of Iran’s nuclear policies over the past two years was arrested this week on spying charges, the semiofficial Fars news agency reported Wednesday.

headline: Editor’s Note
text: Thanks for taking the time to read this e-mail. We welcome feedback from our readers. Send comments and suggestions to playmagazine@nytimes.com.

headline: After Injuries, Yankees Fire Strength Coach
text: ARLINGTON, Texas – A day after the Yankees’ baffling run of hamstring injuries claimed another victim in Phil Hughes, the team fired its new strength coach.

headline: Walter Reed Should Be Closed as Planned Defense Secretary Says
text: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates embraced recommendations for improving care of wounded soldiers and said Walter Reed Army Medical Center should be closed, as planned. Mr. Gates appeared at a Pentagon news conference with Togo D. West Jr. and John O. Marsh Jr., two former Army secretaries who were co-chairmen of an independent review group appointed in February after disclosures of poor conditions and bureaucratic delays at Walter Reed, the Army’s main hospital for treating soldiers wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan. Some members of Congress have called for reconsidering a Pentagon plan to close the medical center by 2011. But Mr. Gates said it would be “far better to make an investment in brand-new 21st-century facilities.”

headline: In Political Row, Turkey Advances National Ballot
text: ISTANBUL, May 2  Turkish lawmakers on Wednesday set national elections for July 22, four months earlier than planned, and Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s party submitted a package of bills that would bring it advantages in the coming political battle.

headline: A Horse and a Dream (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Year Later, Barbaro’s Doctor Looks Back, and Moves On
text: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., May 1 — A 3-year-old thoroughbred stood in the operating room Tuesday as Dr. Dean W. Richardson removed a bone chip from its lower left front leg. A nurse cradled the horse’s head and the surgical team members wore kneepads, as if laying carpet, as they knelt on the hard floor. The extricated bone fragment was the size of a fingernail clipping. In 15 minutes, the arthroscopic procedure was done.

headline: A Healthy Mix of Rest and Motion
text: SOME gymgoers are tortoises. They prefer to take their sweet time, leisurely pedaling or ambling along on a treadmill. Others are hares, impatiently racing through miles at high intensity.

headline: Florida Legislature to Hold Special Session on Size of Tax Cuts
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 2  Unable to reach agreement on how deeply to cut property taxes, leaders of the Florida Legislature announced Wednesday that they would hold a special session to resolve the issue in June.

headline: After Deaths, Transit Chief Reaches Out to the Union
text: The new head of New York City Transit sent an emotional letter addressed to 47,000 subway and bus workers yesterday, calling for a greater emphasis on safety in the wake of two recent track worker deaths and urging a new, more trusting era of labor-management relations.

headline: Curlin, the Early Derby Favorite, Draws a Difficult Post
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 — Curlin is undefeated and wickedly fast, and on Wednesday he was made the morning-line favorite to win the Kentucky Derby. The untested colt is trying to outrun history and will have to do so from a difficult post: the No. 2 hole.

headline: Citigroup Will Acquire Bisys Group in Cash Deal
text: Citigroup is ramping up a push to serve hedge fund and private equity customers, announcing yesterday that it would pay $1.45 billion for the Bisys Group, which handles mundane back-office tasks for such firms.

headline: Summer on the Ski Slope
text: It’s just about time to head back to the ski areas. Summer is becoming increasingly busy at mountain resorts, which are concocting inventive ways to lure year-round customers and boost the bottom line. At Sugarbush Resort in Vermont, mountain biking returns after a 12-year break; Tahoe’s Northstar Resort, closed to riders last summer, also re-opens its fat-tire trails. For the first time, Jackson Hole in Wyoming will crank up the Bridger Gondola to 9,095 feet for paragliding, rock climbing and backpacking. And Whistler-Blackcomb in British Columbia has the best of both worlds: a new mountain-top yoga session at Whistler and schussing throughout the summer on Blackcomb’s glacier.

headline: He’s Impeachable, You Know
text: Columbia, Mo.

headline: Fight Brews Over Plans to Reinvent Hudson Pier
text: A Hudson River pier built for ocean liners but now used mainly as a parking garage would become home to a large entertainment complex with permanent sites for the Cirque du Soleil and the Tribeca Film Festival as part of a proposal that has encountered significant opposition in Greenwich Village.

headline: Dreamlike, but Nothing at All Unclear
text: “So quiet,” Natasha Khan whispered, and in response Joe’s Pub got a little louder. She grew up in England, spent some of her summers in Pakistan and is now the voice and face of Bat for Lashes, which isn’t quite a solo project or a free-form collective or a band; it’s somewhere in between.

headline: M.I.T. Dean Who Resigned Has a Degree After All
text: In an odd twist to an already strange story, Marilee Jones, the former admissions dean at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who resigned last week after admitting that she had lied about her academic credentials, turns out to have a bachelor’s degree, but not from the institutions she had named on her résumé.

headline: Unwanted Folk
text: Joan Baez sang at Woodstock. If you recognize either name, you probably already knew that. If you don’t, go to Google, then come back and help us puzzle something out.

headline: All About Money for De La Hoya and Mayweather
text: LAS VEGAS, May 2 — Floyd Mayweather Jr. stood in a ring recently but rather than flicking punches, he was flinging cash at the HBO camera that has followed him over the past few weeks for the four-part TV series that concludes Thursday night, “24/7: De La Hoya-Mayweather.”

headline: Degree of Suffering Is Questioned in Abuse Suit
text: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., May 2  A psychiatrist hired by the Roman Catholic diocese on Long Island testified on Wednesday that two sexual abuse victims exaggerated their emotional suffering in suing for multimillion-dollar damages.

headline: Committee Is Likely to Say Wolfowitz Broke Rules
text: WASHINGTON, May 2 — Members of a World Bank board committee investigating the conduct of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank president, are leaning toward finding that he violated the institution’s rules against conflicts of interest when he arranged a pay raise and promotion for his companion, bank officials said Wednesday.

headline: When Love Goes Wrong, Put on the Chicken Suit
text: The best-selling British novelist Penny Vincenzi is poised to fill a gap in the American realm of Cinderella fiction. Ms. Vincenzi writes long, elaborate, mannerly books that aren’t serious literature but aren’t chick-lit either. They unfold at a tea-party tempo for reasons of both etiquette and language. Any of them might be 100 pages shorter if a hardhearted editor chose to delete all use of the words lovely, marvelous, extraordinary, rather, quite, indeed, nicely and Darling.

headline: A Change in Control Could Mean Big Payouts for Executives
text: A deal for Dow Jones & Company could allow thousands of its employees to cash out their stock options for a tidy profit.

headline: More Calls for Olmert’s Resignation; Rally Planned
text: JERUSALEM, May 3 — Politicians from across the political spectrum in Israel called in parliament today for the country’s prime minister, Ehud Olmert, to resign, following the release of a damning report on his performance during last summer’s war in Lebanon.

headline: Rangers’ Old Pros Want to Carry a New Cup
text: In the Stanley Cup playoffs, the old pros are often the best pros. In a moment of crisis, when the young pros might flub an opportunity, the old pros deliver. They know how to win because they’ve won before. Not merely a game or an early-round series, but the Cup itself. And over the years, the Rangers have seldom had two old pros as proven and as productive in the playoffs as 35-year-old Jaromir Jagr and 38-year-old Brendan Shanahan.

headline: I.B.M. to Announce an Advance in Making Chips Faster and More Energy-Efficient
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 — Scientists at I.B.M. have designed a new material that could increase the speed of semiconductors and reduce their energy consumption.

headline: Heavy Options Activity Stirs Suspicions
text: Did word of Rupert Murdoch’s offer for Dow Jones leak out early?

headline: Wall Street Journal Weighs Life Under Murdoch
text: Rupert Murdoch has spent years thinking about what he would do with The Wall Street Journal if he could just get his hands on it. Based on his business history, he often gets what he wants.

headline: In Web Uproar, Antipiracy Code Spreads Wildly
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 — There is open revolt on the Web.

headline: Avoiding Ads With TiVo? TiVo Strikes Back
text: THE holy grail on Madison Avenue these days is to create advertising that is “TiVo-proof” — compelling enough to owners of digital video recorders that they will watch the commercials rather than zip past them when replaying recorded programs.

headline: Frogs Go Bump in the Night
text: COCKEYSVILLE, Md.

headline: Rice Meets Syrian Foreign Minister
text: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt, May 3 — Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice met with her Syrian counterpart here today in the first high-level diplomatic contact between Washington and Damascus in more than two years.

headline: Same Goal, Two Very Different Bankers
text: LONDON, May 2 — The biggest takeover battle in the banking industry, the fight for control of ABN Amro Holding, the largest Dutch bank, brings head to head two very different personalities atop Europe’s banking world.

headline: An Exit Strategy for Guantánamo
text: The five-year-old military prison at Guantánamo Bay, with its indefinite detention rules, lack of judicial review and insufficiently regulated interrogation techniques, is an ugly stain on this country’s long tradition of respect for the rule of law and an endless propaganda bonanza for America’s enemies. Yet it is clear that despite the good advice of friendly foreign leaders, members of Congress and even his own cabinet officials, President Bush has no intention of closing the facility unless Congress forces him to do so.

headline: Theater Companies Learn the Value of Flying Solo
text: Got a hole in your season? Looking for a production that’s simple to assemble? Want to save a few bucks on actors’ salaries? Or maybe just keen to mount something uniquely personal?

headline: U.S. and Guantánamo (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Auction Season of High Estimates, and Even Higher Risks
text: This spring auction houses are touting stunning images by masters like Rothko and Warhol, Bacon and de Kooning. Price estimates are equally stunning, reflecting the fight for market share between the archrivals Sotheby’s and Christie’s. Their competition has never been deadlier, riskier or more expensive.

headline: Corrections
text: Editors’ Note

headline: Sprint Nextel Reports a First-Quarter Loss
text: The Sprint Nextel Corporation reported a first-quarter loss today, fueling concern that the company is losing market share to its rivals as it struggles to achieve a turnaround.

headline: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
text: Stocks have been a great investment in the last 80 years, with an average return of about 10 percent a year. But have investors in the stock market done as well as stocks? Surprisingly, the answer is no. The average dollar invested in the stock market in those years has earned only about 8.6 percent a year.

headline: Connecticut Legislators Approve Contraceptive Pill for Rape Victims
text: HARTFORD, May 2  All hospitals in Connecticut will be required to provide rape victims with emergency contraception under legislation approved overwhelmingly Wednesday by the state’s General Assembly.

headline: Expansion of New Jersey’s Drug Treatment Courts Is Encouraged
text: TRENTON, May 2  A state commission plans to recommend on Friday that New Jersey’s therapeutic drug courts, which allow offenders to avoid jail by getting treatment, be expanded to include people with more than two previous offenses.

headline: A Dollar and a Dream (Bet)
text: The 133rd running of the Kentucky Derby will take place on Saturday, and if it’s the only horse race you bet on all year, as it is for many casual fans, then recent history provides this enticement beyond the simple $2 win bet: the superfecta, in which you select the first four horses in order. It’s difficult, but rewarding: last year, even with Barbaro winning at low odds, it paid $84,860.40. In 2005, when a 50-to-1 horse, Giacomo, won and Closing Argument finished second at 70-to-1, the payoff was a hefty $864,253.50.

headline: No Aston Martin, but a Limo Will Do
text: THE senior class at West Salem High School in West Salem, Ore., will not be able to borrow the “Casino Royale” posters from a local Blockbuster for their James Bond-themed graduation party. An employee at the video store had already reserved them for her child’s 007 graduation party at nearby Cascade High School.

headline: Neon’s Back. Curb Your Enthusiasm.
text: OF all the elements that were essential to the I-Want-My-MTV wardrobe, circa 1981 — and recycled ad nauseam by fashion designers for the I-Want-My-YouTube generation — neon should have been the most glaring candidate to be left behind on the What-Was-I-Thinking scrapheap.

headline: Japan: Fujitsu to Acquire French Company
text: Fujitsu plans to buy GFI Informatique of France for 419 million euros ($569 million) to add computer-services clients and reduce its reliance on Japan. Fujitsu, based in Tokyo, intends to offer 8.50 euros for each GFI share and 3.15 euros for each warrant of the company, a computer consultant based in Paris. The companies have no formal agreement, Fujitsu said.

headline: Ex-Governor Assailed as Inept in Trial of Conrad Black
text: CHICAGO, May 2  Defense lawyers in the trial of Conrad M. Black questioned the memory, business acumen and integrity of the former governor of Illinois, James R. Thompson, on Wednesday as they tried to cast doubt on his oversight of financial decisions at the media giant Hollinger International.

headline: As the Camera Turns, Teams Await Verdicts of the Video
text: The scene has become a fixture in the N.H.L. playoffs — a referee standing outside the penalty box, a phone receiver pressed to his ear. The result of a video review puts the arena crowd, a television audience and two teams in technological purgatory.

headline: Orphans of the Storm, Assailed by Lurid Evildoers
text: What the heck is a “Coram Boy”?

headline: I.R.S. Curtails Many Audits in Tax Havens
text: WASHINGTON, May 2  The Internal Revenue Service is curtailing audits of many people who use offshore tax havens, even when agents see signs of tax evasion, because agents fear they cannot meet a three-year deadline for finishing an examination, Congressional investigators have found.

headline: My Daughter, the Burger-Flipping Penguin
text: MY 9-year-old daughter, Clementine, is working in the food service industry these days.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Fighting for Your Zucchini

headline: The War Bill: Lines in the Sand (9 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pérez Settles in and Makes the Marlins Uncomfortable
text: As Oliver Pérez jogged onto the field to start yesterday’s game between the Mets and the Florida Marlins, he tried to scoop up a baseball resting near the mound. The ball squirted out of his glove and trickled away. For a moment, Pérez looked overmatched. For the rest of the afternoon, however, he pitched with poise as the Mets defeated the Marlins, 6-3, to avoid being swept by Florida in their three-game series at Shea Stadium.

headline: N.C.A.A. Looking Ahead on Poor Academic Progress
text: The N.C.A.A. released its third annual installment of academic progress data yesterday, penalizing few colleges but projecting many more penalties next year.

headline: Creative and Commercial: The Starving Artist Has to Eat
text: When the Bronx Museum of the Arts founded its Artist in the Marketplace program 27 years ago, the business side of an artist’s life didn’t draw the attention it attracts today.

headline: Iraq Reconstruction Is Doomed, Ex-Chief of Global Fund Says
text: OTTAWA, May 2  Reconstruction efforts in Iraq are largely doomed to failure, the former chairman of the International Reconstruction Fund Facility for Iraq said Tuesday in an interview.

headline: Brief Biographies of the ‘Mercury Seven’ Astronauts
text: The death today of Walter Schirra, one of the original “Mercury Seven” astronauts who flew pioneering space missions in the 1960s and 1970s, leaves only two living members of that group, who were as famous as movie stars in the exciting early days of space travel: John Glenn and Scott Carpenter.

headline: Checking Processor Speed
text: Q. I need to add more memory to my computer, but the Web site that sells the memory chips asks what processor and megahertz speed I have. I don’t have the manual anymore, so how do I find this out?

headline: Facing Trial Under Terror Law, Radical Claims a New Outlook
text: TUCSON — Rod Coronado is a celebrity ex-convict in the underground world of environmental and animal rights radicals who advocate burning construction sites and research labs. In 2003, just after giving a speech in San Diego in which he called fire a “cleansing force” and defended its use in strategic property destruction, a woman asked him a question.

headline: Israeli Foreign Minister Calls on Olmert to Resign
text: JERUSALEM, May 2  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s deputy called on him to resign on Wednesday after a harshly critical government report about his management of Israel’s war against Hezbollah last summer.

headline: Obama Placed Under Secret Service Protection
text: Senator Barack Obama, whose crowds at political rallies across the country often have numbered in the thousands, was placed under Secret Service protection yesterday, a spokesman for the agency said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article last Thursday about the burial of Boris N. Yeltsin, Russia’s first democratically elected president, at Novodevichy Cemetery, erroneously included a writer among other Russian notables interred there. Boris L. Pasternak is buried in a writers’ village in Peredelkino.

headline: Let’s End the Nightmare of Peace and Tranquillity
text: “Kindness? Charity? Understanding? When will this hellish nightmare end?” It’s a fair question inside the cynical world created in the Sam & Max adventure game series from Telltale Games. And in Sam & Max Episode 6: Bright Side of the Moon, the two work diligently to end a nightmare of peace and tranquillity.

headline: Your Life, in a Movie of Top Quality
text: “Wow” is typical. “Jeez” is another favorite. “Man, look at that” is a runner-up.

headline: Of Wars, Madness and a Leader of Men
text: Heinrich von Biber’s picturesque “Battalia,” a vivid Baroque work that evokes a pitched battle and the parade of wounded that follows, might have seemed an odd curtain-raiser for a concert by the New York New Music Ensemble. But it deftly set up the twin themes of the ensemble’s program at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday evening.

headline: A Model Modern Musical Marriage
text: If John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey ever stop performing together, God forbid, they could write a handbook called “The New Musical Marriage.” That volume would describe how a man and woman of formidable talent, impeccable taste and acute wit, but opposite temperament, pooled their resources to redefine the canon of pop and jazz music as a no-borders territory.

headline: Calendar
text: Islands in the Bronx

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article yesterday about the News Corporation’s bid for Dow Jones & Company referred imprecisely to the number of paid subscribers to WSJ.com, the online version of The Wall Street Journal. It has 931,000, rather a lot “more than 700,000.”

headline: A Dual-Screen DVD Player, Suited to Separating Feuding Children
text: Nothing beats a portable DVD player for a long trip — except perhaps one with two screens. Designed for those with more than one child, the Disney Dual Screen Mobile DVD Player can simultaneously display a movie or video game on two 7-inch screens.

headline: Boldness That Won Him Wide Attention Costs a Brash Young Mayor His Re-election Bid
text: NEW PALTZ, N.Y., May 2 — Jason West first shocked this funky village of 6,000 residents in 2003, when as a 26-year-old house painter, puppeteer and environmentalist he was elected mayor after two establishment candidates split the vote. He became the first Green Party member to be a mayor in New York State.

headline: No Store Is a Hero to Its Valet
text: THE butler did it. Or — wait — maybe it was the maid. Or maybe, just maybe, it was the scowling doormen who looked me up and down disapprovingly and made me feel like Oprah trying to shop at Hermès.

headline: All His Rooms Are Living Rooms
text: Créteil, France

headline: Gene Links Longevity and Diet, Scientists Say
text: Scientists have identified a gene that makes roundworms live longer when they eat less, a finding they hope could lead to drugs that promote human longevity, but without the pain of strict dieting.

headline: Investor-to-Be in Starrett City Is Bargaining for New Deal
text: Rebuffed by state and federal regulators over his plan to buy Starrett City for $1.3 billion, David Bistricer is now bargaining with the current owner over a lower sale price and devising a plan that he hopes will pass muster with government officials, local politicians and the 14,000 tenants at the vast Brooklyn housing complex.

headline: Canada: Real Estate Concern Plans Spinoff
text: Brookfield Asset Management said it would focus on its real estate holdings, which include the World Financial Center in Manhattan, by spinning off about $1 billion in infrastructure assets to shareholders. The assets, which will be held by a newly created company, Brookfield Infrastructure Partners, include 1.2 million acres of timberlands in Canada and the United States, as well as electrical transmission facilities in Canada, Brazil and Chile. Brookfield Asset, based in Toronto, will hold a 40 percent stake in the new company. Brookfield Asset also said it would split its shares 3-for-2.

headline: Feeling Warmth, Subtropical Plants Move North
text: ATLANTA, May 2 — Like a true belle, this city flounces into bloom when the weather turns, its redbuds, azaleas and forsythia emerging like so much lace on a bodice.

headline: Robert M. Warner, 79, the National Archivist, Dies
text: Robert M. Warner, who built a legislative consensus to wrest the National Archives from political control when he was its director, died on April 24 in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 79. The cause was a heart attack after a yearlong battle with cancer, his son, Mark Warner, said.

headline: Beware the Afterglow
text: YEARS before Ursula Andress, the Swiss actress who was the first Bond girl, emerged from the waves in “Dr. No” with her caramel skin offset by a blindingly white bikini, the tan had taken hold as the abiding fashion image.

headline: F.D.A. Expands Suicide Warning on Drugs
text: The Food and Drug Administration ordered drug makers yesterday to add warnings to antidepressant medications, saying the drugs increase the risk of suicidal thinking or behavior in some young adults.

headline: The Lost Get a Hand From a New Entrant in G.P.S. Devices
text: “Why don’t you pull over and ask for directions?” Portable G.P.S. navigation is helping to cut down on that particular form of nagging. Last year, according to the Consumer Electronics Association, sales of G.P.S. units topped $800 million.

headline: Cablevision Deal Remains Very Much Up in the Air
text: At the Cablevision Systems annual board meeting in Palm Beach, Fla., in March, the company’s founding Dolan family held a private meeting with the board’s special committee — the two men who had rejected previous buyout offers from the family.

headline: The Yester Dressers
text: SNAP-BRIM hats, cool shades and pearls — they are the ingredients of self-invention. Stirred with a pinch of audacity, they yielded a few of the giddy turnouts on parade at the vintage fashion fairs that sprang up last month all around town.

headline: Next Week
text: Carlo Rotella writes about the Mayweather-De la Hoya bout and the current state of boxing.

headline: Mr. Smith Goes to Baltimore
text: Every time a great college football player slides toward the bottom of the N.F.L. draft, I get a feeling like mind erasure. The player’s rejection by the pro teams seems to stand as a repudiation of his college achievements. Wait a second, I think, wasn’t this guy a holy terror on Saturdays?

headline: In the Swirl of Bodies, a Flurry of Emotions
text: Alonzo King and his San Francisco-based Lines Ballet have long been a puzzle. Mr. King has his feet planted in two popular choreographic worlds: African fusion, and the “go nowhere fast” school, though the movement uncharacteristically wells up from the dancers’ bodies rather than being laid on them. So his work is different and his own.

headline: A Radical Idea: Close the Door
text: Peter Kaufman is an unlikely urban guerrilla. Would he toss a bomb? Not a chance. Encourage mass civil disobedience? Hardly his style. Picket government buildings or refuse to pay his taxes? No and no.

headline: Reforming the F.D.A.
text: A bill headed for a vote in the Senate would usher in much needed reforms at the Food and Drug Administration. But it also risks making the agency even more dependent on funds from the industry it regulates.

headline: Bloomberg in Spanish: Now He Can Hold Up His End of the Conversation
text: On his recent jaunt to Mexico, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg fielded questions from Mexican reporters and, to the surprise of many, responded in Spanish.

headline: First the Bid, Now the Jockeying
text: And now for the charm offensive.

headline: Court Rejects Limit on Bids by Convicts for DNA Tests
text: CINCINNATI, May 2  In a unanimous decision, the Ohio Supreme Court overturned on Wednesday the part of a broader 2003 law that required prosecutors’ consent to allow felons who had pleaded guilty to crimes to seek DNA tests that could prove their innocence.

headline: U.N. Says Bosnian Police Officers May Reapply
text: The Security Council has ruled that 700 former Bosnian police officers dismissed by United Nations police trainers after the 1992-1995 civil war for misconduct or alleged involvement in war crimes can reapply for law enforcement work, though not necessarily the same jobs they had. Emyr Jones Parry, the British ambassador to the United Nations, president of the council in April, said in a letter to Bosnian authorities that the country’s standards for recruitment and selection were now acceptable and that individuals could regain police jobs as long as they met those standards. In recent years, 260 of the officers have protested their firings, saying they were guilty only of minor misconduct. Mr. Jones Parry said that his letter should not be interpreted as guaranteeing reinstatement.

headline: Taking Risks for Mideast Peace (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Outing Finds Bush in the Thick of Softball Season
text: WASHINGTON, May 2  President Bush did not leave Washington on Wednesday. But for at least two hours he was transported to a different world, away from inquiries involving the credibility of top aides and questions about the war in Iraq. The place was a hotel ballroom just a couple of blocks from the White House, where he took questions from supporters. It was not so much a grilling as a warming.

headline: Concern Is High and Unity Hopes Are Nil at Talks on Iraq
text: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, May 2 — Four years ago at this Red Sea resort, leaders of Saudi Arabia and Egypt were photographed as passengers in a golf cart driven by President Bush. The symbolism led to taunting headlines in the region’s newspapers.

headline: A Book Full of Tips for Use in the Trenches
text: Mel Colchamiro is a professional bridge player and teacher who lives in Merrick, on Long Island. He has distilled his bridge experiences into a book titled “How You Can Play Like an Expert” (Magnus Books).

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A Sports of The Times column in some copies on Sunday, about the continuing problems with steroids in Major League Baseball, referred incorrectly to the origin of a rule covering “conduct detrimental” to the sport. The top professional leagues included a conduct clause in their governing agreement in 1896, and baseball historians say the notion probably emerged before that. The concept was not created by Kenesaw Mountain Landis, who was elected baseball’s first commissioner in 1920, and who is credited with rigorous enforcement of the conduct clause.

headline: Former Taipei Mayor Nominated
text: The Central Standing Committee of the opposition Nationalist Party nominated Ma Ying-jeou, the former mayor of Taipei, to be the party’s candidate in presidential elections to be held early next year. A full party congress on June 24 is expected to confirm the nomination. Mr. Ma, a Harvard-educated lawyer, has long been seen as the most likely Taiwanese official to bring about a partial reconciliation with the mainland. But he stepped down as party chairman in February after he was indicted for using $339,000 from a mayoral expense account for personal needs; prosecutors have begun a crackdown on the widespread practice among Taiwanese officials of treating expense budgets as part of their personal compensation.

headline: Judges Charge 2 Top Sudanese With Atrocities in Darfur Area
text: PARIS, May 2  Judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague have issued arrest warrants for two citizens of Sudan, the first to be charged with grave atrocities in Darfur, the court said Wednesday.

headline: Arts Library Planned in Brooklyn Hits a Snag
text: The new arts library designed by Enrique Norten that was supposed to rise like the prow of a glass ship near the Brooklyn Academy of Music now seems likely to sink, unrealized, into the pavement.

headline: Common Gene Raises Heart Risk, Studies Find
text: Two rival teams of scientists have discovered a genetic variation that increases the risk of heart disease, the leading cause of death worldwide, by up to 60 percent in people of European descent. They hope a test for the variant will enable physicians to assess patients at risk more accurately and to recommend early intervention.

headline: Qaeda Figure in Iraq Is Killed, U.S. Military Says
text: BAGHDAD, May 3 — American troops killed a senior propagandist for Al Qaeda in Iraq who was involved in kidnapping westerners, including Jill Carroll, the American journalist, American military officials said today. But they denied claims from Iraqi officials that the body was identified as the leader of the group.

headline: A Puck-Crazed Town in Sweden Churns Out N.H.L. Stars
text: ORNSKOLDSVIK, Sweden, April 27  Everyone here seems to agree that Victor Hedman is a hockey prodigy. At 16, he not only has the skills, speed and size  6-foot-5, 215 pounds  to be a great defenseman, but, according to his coach, Hedman also possesses that rare, quiet determination that elevates raw talent into stardom.

headline: Hi-Def Camcorders
text: New camcorders from Sony and JVC give home movies the same kind of clarity as Hollywood releases.

headline: In Web Uproar, Antipiracy Code Spreads Wildly
text: After several Web sites posted a secret code used to prevent piracy of high-definition movies, corporate lawyers demanded that the code be removed. Internet users responded by distributing it even more widely in what was characterized as an exercise of free-speech rights.

headline: On the Web
text: Images from "Spider-Man 3."

headline: The Get
text: Tee-hee towels, the sharpest knives and more.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary yesterday about Carl Friedrich von Weizsäcker, a German scientist and peace activist, misstated the year American troops raided his laboratory and found no evidence of progress toward making a workable nuclear weapon. It was 1944, not 1940.

headline: In-Store | The Hungry Eye
text: Nicole Farhi combines style and sustenance. Sandra Ballentine joins her well-laid table.

headline: The New Collectibles
text: To have and to hold on to.

headline: Strategies for Success
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Trunk Food
text: On the road with beach-blanket favorites.

headline: Excerpts From Previous French Debates
text: Since 1974, the two presidential candidates in the runoff have squared off during a televised debate aired live between the two rounds of the elections. The exception to the rule was in 2002, when incumbent President Jacques Chirac refused to meet Jean-Marie Le Pen, the far right leader who had qualified in an upset by defeating the socialist candidate Lionel Jospin.
For a bunch of big-city aesthetes, Burgenland is their own private paradise.  Maura Egan stops and smells the strudel.

headline: Single Space
text: Bachelor pads that redefine the Alpha male's natural habitat.

headline: Senator Clinton’s Remarks
text: Following is the text of Hillary Rodham Clinton's remarks on legislation to end authority for the Iraq War:

headline: Boomer Babes
text: Five women who defined — and defied — a generation's standards of beauty.

headline: The Ones to Watch
text: Five notable performances from the summer movies season.

headline: Cool Caymans
text: Calico

headline: A Note to Readers: Change to Columnist Schedule
text: The Op-Ed columnists appear on the following schedule.

headline: Letting Go of the Elephant
text: Dulary’s exit from The Philadelphia Zoo this week did not lack for fanfare.

headline: Dow Jones: Well-Timed Options Trades Stir Suspicions
text: Did word of Rupert Murdoch’s offer for Dow Jones & Company leak out early?

headline: Boston Scientific Deal Maker to Step Down
text: Lawrence Best, chief financial officer of Boston Scientific and the architect of the company’s $27 billion Guidant acquisition, will leave his job in July, Boston Scientific said Wednesday. He will be succeeded by Sam Leno, chief financial officer of Zimmer Holdings, a maker of artificial knees, hips, and other orthopedic implants.

headline: Fujitsu Buys French Computer-Services Firm
text: Fujitsu plans to buy GFI Informatique of France for 419 million euros ($569 million) to add computer-services clients and reduce its reliance on Japan. Fujitsu, based in Tokyo, intends to offer 8.50 euros for each GFI share and 3.15 euros for each warrant of the company, a computer consultant based in Paris.

headline: The Same Goal, but Two Very Different Bankers
text: The biggest takeover battle in the banking industry, the fight for control of ABN Amro Holding, the Dutch bank, brings head to head two very different personalities atop Europe’s banking world. The New York Times takes a look at how the distinct styles of the two chieftains affect their deal making and the institutions they run.

headline: Major Parts Maker in Talks With Auto Unions
text: The auto parts maker Magna International, which is considering a bid for Chrysler, is in talks with Canadian and American auto unions about adding Magna’s tens of thousands of workers to their ranks, according to the president of the Canadian union.

headline: Of Big Buyouts and Pink Slips
text: As cash-rich private equity firms continue to buy many of the largest public companies, there is a new focus on one question: Do these big buyouts create jobs or destroy them? The claim that private equity shops are enriching themselves on the backs of employees at their portfolio companies has been circulating in European for some time. Last week, a report by The Service Employees International Union, which represents nearly 2 million United States workers including health care employees and janitors, raised similar concerns.

headline: Cavium Networks Shines in Debut
text: Shares in a networking semiconductor start-up, Cavium Networks rose more than 27 percent in their first day on the Nasdaq stock market Wednesday.

headline: Littlejohn Rolls Up Intertape
text: A buyout shop, Littlejohn & Company of Greenwich, Conn., has struck a deal to take the Intertape Polymer Group,a maker of plastic tape, private for $500 million, including $305 million of debt. Littlejohn has agreed to buy all the company’s common stock at $4.76 a share, valuing the company’s equity at $195 million.

headline: Friendly’s Delays Shareholder Meeting Amid Proxy Fight
text: Friendly Ice Cream, the struggling restaurant chain, postponed next week’s annual shareholder meeting, delaying a showdown with activist investors who are trying to gain more control of the company. Friendly said its executives needed more time for a review of the company’s strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the business, that was disclosed in March.

headline: V.C. Funding to Bring You Ugly Betty’s Ear Muffs
text: An Internet retailer, Delivery Agent, raised $18.5 million in an insider round led by Bessemer Venture Partners to take advantage of partnerships with television networks and other content distributors that steer audiences to its online store to purchase goods featured on the air.

headline: D.E. Shaw Appoints European Private Equity Head
text: D.E. Shaw, the $29 billion hedge fund, announced Wednesday that it had hired Michael Joseph, a former banker at Lloyds TSB, to head its fledgling European private equity unit, D. E. Shaw Direct Capital. Mr. Joseph, a former managing director of structured finance at Lloyds TSB, also served as an investment director at the British buyout shop 3i Group.

headline: Malaysian Billionaire Offers $4.6 Billion for Control of Maxis
text: As expected, Malaysian billionaire T. Ananda Krishnan has offered to buy full control of Maxis Communications, the country’s biggest mobile-phone company, for 15.8 billion ringgit ($4.6 billion) to facilitate its overseas expansion.

headline: N.Y.S.E. and Nasdaq Vie for China’s Offerings
text: As the Nasdaq Stock Market and the New York Stock Exchange battle each other at home and abroad for new listings, China has become a key battleground, BusinessWeek notes.

headline: Blackstone, Carlyle May Bid for Australian TV Network, Report Says
text: The Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group may join forces to bid as much as 2.7 billion Australian dollars ($2.2 billion) for Ten Network Holdings, Australia’s third most-watched television station, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Morgan Stanley Makes China Appointment
text: Morgan Stanley has hired a former banker at Credit Suisse, Carlos Oyarbide, as chief operating officer in China. Mr. Oyarbide, 48, will be a managing director, reporting to Wei Christianson, chief executive of Morgan Stanley’s operations in China. He will start in July, Morgan Stanley said.

headline: Clear Channel Sells Stations as Part of Buyout Plan
text: Clear Channel Communications said on Wednesday it had agreed to sell 362 radio stations for $820 million as it divests assets in accordance with its embattled $27 billion plan to go private. Clear Channel, the nation’s largest radio station operator, did not name any of the buyers.

headline: Cumberland Pharmaceuticals Files for I.P.O.
text: Cumberland Pharmaceuticals intends to raise $115 million in an initial public offering, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The firm, which plans to list on the Nasdaq Stock Market, did not say how many shares it planned to sell, or at what price.

headline: A.G. Edwards Settles Market-Timing Charges
text: A.G. Edwards will pay nearly $4 million for a role in the mutual fund market-timing trading scandal. The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday accused the firm of failing to supervise several brokers who allegedly engaged in illegal market-timing activities.

headline: Burkle Eyes American Media, Report Says
text: Ron Burkle, the Los Angeles billionaire who lost his bid to buy Tribune, is now sizing up the tabloid publisher American Media, according to The New York Post.

headline: Citigroup Took $12 Billion Loan to Seal Nikko Deal, Report Says
text: Citigroup borrowed 1.45 trillion yen ($12 billion) in a syndicated loan to pay for its purchase of Nikko Cordial, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Russia’s Norilsk Launches Rival Bid for LionOre
text: The Russian metals giant Norilsk Nickel said on Thursday it was making an all-cash bid worth 5.3 billion Canadian dollars ($4.8 billion) for LionOre of Canada, trumping an offer from London-listed Xstrata.

headline: Jones Apparel to Unload Moderate Brands
text: The Jones Apparel Group, the owner of Barneys New York and Nine West, said Wednesday that it would close or sell some of its moderately priced apparel brands by year-end, a move that would help reduce its exposure to department stores.

headline: Murdoch’s Next Move: Charming the Bancrofts
text: And now for the charm offensive.

headline: Citi Executive Joins University Pension Fund
text: The University of Texas Investment Management Company, the investing arm of the University of Texas’s pension system, has hired Bruce Zimmerman, former chief investment officer and global head of pension investments at Citigroup, as its new chief executive.

headline: Cablevision Deal Remains Up in the Air
text: Cablevision Systems‘ board said Wednesday it had accepted a $10.6 billion buyout offer from its founding family, the Dolans, but the deal is far from assured. The buyout is subject to approval of more than half of Cablevision’s shareholders, excluding the Dolans and the company’s directors and officers, and analysts and investors are still concerned that the price is too low.

headline: UBS to Close Hedge Fund After Disappointing Returns
text: In a shocking move, UBS said it would scrap its hedge fund, Dillon Read Capital Management, after losses at the unit contributed to a third straight decline in quarterly profit. “We concluded that the DRCM initiative did not meet our expectations,” UBS’s chief executive, Peter Wuffli, said in a statement.

headline: New York Fed Warns On Hedge Funds
text: In what Reuters describes as its “sternest warning to date” on the state of the hedge-fund business, the New York Federal Reserve said Wednesday that the funds could represent the biggest risk for a financial crisis since 1998, when the implosion of Long-Term Capital Management threatened global markets.

headline: Too Manly for His Own Good
text: George W. Bush’s disastrous presidency is linked to the fact that the United States is a country that is “anxiously hypermasculine,” writes Mark Dery on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. “George W. Bush learned an unforgettable lesson about the anxious nature of American masculinity when Newsweek branded his father a ‘wimp,’ a perception Bush 41 never really overcame,” Dery writes. “The resolve never to look like a wimp is the key to Dubya’s psychology.” Dery adds:

headline: Ferrari wins again!
text: But this time, it is the unusual distinction of winning the title of the Best Place to Work in Europe 2007.

headline: Obtaining a Vietnam Visa Outside the United States
text: I am currently traveling throughout SE Asia and would like to add Vietnam to my itinerary. However, Vietnam requires that American tourists obtain a visa through a local consulate prior to arrival. I’m not able to travel to a city that has a consulate and wait two days for my application to be processed. Do you know of any reputable companies that can help expedite the visa for me?

headline: 2008: Debate in the Shadow of Reagan
text: As the G.O.P. contenders gather for their first debate in at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library tonight in Simi Valley, Calif., each will clamor to mount praise on the Gipper. But another Republican president is causing more of a strategic conundrum. The Times’s Adam Nagourney reports:

headline: This Desert Life
text: When I started on the Mets beat in August 2005, my first road trip was an Arizona-San Francisco swing – just like this one. The Mets swept the D-Backs in four games, prompting a few to wonder whether I was a good-luck charm. Then they lost two of three in San Francisco, and that took care of that.

headline: Obama’s Misadventures in MySpace
text: The decision by Barack Obama’s campaign to seize control of a MySpace page created by a (former) Obama supporter has angered many of the activists in the Democratic netroots. “[T]he Obama campaign’s reputation as the most net-savvy of 2008 has taken a big hit,” writes Micah L. Sifry of techPresident. “And MySpace executives have been forced to take extraordinary action to resolve a dispute between two high-profile users of their invaluable site, one a passionate volunteer with a huge network of friends and the other a front-running presidential candidate who has helped make MySpace a new factor in the 2008 contest.”

headline: Safe on the Track?
text: A year ago, some fateful missteps by Barbaro in the Preakness resulted in a fractured right hind leg that eventually led to his being put down in January. But the sad ending appears not to have swayed the thinking of horse racing fans about the inherent safety of the sport. A recent New York Times/CBS News poll of people who said they followed racing showed that 63 percent think the sport is safe for the horses, and only 21 percent said it was too risky. Ten percent said it depends on certain factors like track conditions, and 5 percent said they don’t know.

headline: A Guide to the Republican Debate
text: LOS ANGELES — The Republican presidential candidates are gathering this evening at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library – at the invitation of Nancy Reagan – for their first debate. It begins at 8 p.m. Eastern time, lasts for 90 minutes, and will be broadcast on MSNBC, which is sponsoring it with Politico.com. The moderator is Chris Matthews.

headline: Pogue’s Picks
text: I don't know how the other Times columnists keep up with all their reader e-mail, but I'll tell you how I handle mine: with great difficulty. I try to answer pretty much all of it, thanks to some kind of weird Midwestern sense of obligation.

headline: Sale Could Enrich Top Dow Jones Executives
text: Shareholders of Dow Jones & Company, whose stock price until recently has languished in the mid-30’s, are not the only ones that could see a windfall if the company ends up being acquired by News Corporation at $60 per share. The deal is far from certain: A majority of the Bancroft family, which has a controlling interest in the company, currently stands opposed to Rupert Murdoch’s proposal. Still, The New York Times’s Eric Dash looked through regulatory filings and found that a sale, if it happened, might mean multimillion-dollar paydays for the top managers of Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Storm Over Immigration Protest in L.A.
text: The Los Angeles Police Department is facing public outrage over its officers’ use of batons and nonlethal rubber bullets to disperse an immigrant-rights rally on Tuesday.

headline: Judge Halts Bank Sale in ABN Amro Takeover Duel
text: Hold that deal.

headline: Big Island Bliss
text: Largest and southernmost in the Hawaiian chain, the Big Island of Hawaii is synonymous with stunning landscapes and luxurious retreats.

headline: A Career in Space
text: Walter Schirra was the only man to fly on all three of NASA's early space missions.

headline: Recent Openings
text: New shows in New York include "Coram Boy" and "American Fiesta."

headline: Podcast: Downtown Gender Gap
text: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

headline: Journal Reporters Start Anti-News Corp. Campaign
text: Hoping to fend off the News Corporation‘s $5 billion bid, employees at Dow Jones & Company are pushing back. Jesse Drucker, a Wall Street Journal reporter and representative of the paper’s union, has written an e-mail to his colleagues, asking them to write short letters to three members of the Bancroft family, which controls more than 60 percent of Dow Jones.

headline: On The Market
Memories of Montrachet
text: This happens to be a painful post for me to write because it concerns Montrachet, a formative restaurant for both American wine lovers and for me personally. Montrachet closed last summer with not nearly the ceremony it deserved. In fact, as late as January 2007 Drew Nieporent, one of the owners, still had not acknowledged that the restaurant’s run was over. But if you were still holding out hope, forget it. Next Friday, May 11, Zachys will auction off what it bills as “a significant offering from the cellars of Montrachet.’’

headline: A Push for Cleaner-Fuel Taxicabs
text: If New York City ordered that the nearly 13,000 Ford Crown Victorias be replaced with Kia Rondos — the compact, minivan-like vehicles shown at the Taxi07 exhibition last month — it could potentially save 22.3 million gallons and $66.2 million worth of fuel each year and reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, a leading greenhouse gas, by 88,400 tons per year, according to a new analysis by Consumer Reports.

headline: Pogue’s Picks
text: I don’t know how the other Times columnists keep up with all their reader e-mail, but I’ll tell you how I handle mine: with great difficulty. I try to answer pretty much all of it, thanks to some kind of weird Midwestern sense of obligation.

headline: Unraveling Qaeda Deaths in Iraq
text: Earlier today, the Iraqi interior ministry announced another insurgent leader’s death. This time, it was Abu Omar al-Baghdadi, said to be the leader of an umbrella group, The Islamic State of Iraq.

headline: Compass to Hold $128 Million Offering
text: Compass Diversified Trust, a publicly held private equity firm, said on Thursday that it would hold a $128 million follow-on public offering to repay its corporate debt. In a press release, the firm, which currently holds six middle-market companies in a range of sectors, will sell eight million shares at $16 a share.

headline: Into the Groove with a CIBC Bank Analyst
text: Let’s face it: It’s hard out there for an analyst who wants to stand out from the crowd, especially if you stick to the standard buy-hold-sell script. Last year, a Credit Suisse semiconductor analyst, Mike Masdea, shook things up with a mass voicemail to clients in which he imitated rapper Eminem as he gave his take on the chip business.
