The voicemail made the rounds on Wall Street and was preserved for posterity on Dealbreaker. (“Masdea may want to check himself before he wrecks himself,” one trader quipped to the New York Post.)

headline: M.B.A.’s Dream of Google and Goldman
text: As business school students prepare for graduation, they will face an inevitable barrage of questions from friends and relatives — most prominent among them: So, where are you going to work?

headline: Credit Suisse Shuffles Bankers in Asia and Europe
text: Credit Suisse is moving Paul Raphael from London to Hong Kong to run its investment banking group in Asia, excluding Japan, the firm said in an internal memo. In London, Mr. Raphael was co-head of the European global markets solutions group. Mr. Raphael is taking a role previously held by Joe Gallagher, who becomes Credit Suisse’s head of mergers and acquisitions for the Asia-Pacific region, a new position at the firm. Jim Amine, who had been co-head of European global markets solutions with Mr. Raphael, takes over as the group’s sole head.

headline: Finding Media Buyout Targets in Unlikely Places
text: Private equity firms have historically looked askance at technology companies, whose volatile earnings don’t always mix nicely with heavy debt loads. Which is why the recent findings by Jason Bazinet, a media analyst at Citigroup, are fairly remarkable. Using what he called “fairly conservative assumptions,” Mr. Bazinet screened 100 global media stocks and decided that most of them are not likely to be targets of a leveraged buyout offer anytime soon. Of those that made the cut, however, most were Internet companies.

headline: Oprah Endorses Obama
text: In Chicago, there is no question who carries the title of the Big O. That would be Oprah Winfrey. It’s a safe bet that Senator Barack Obama doesn’t mind playing second fiddle to the talk show icon, particularly when he has her endorsement at his disposal.

headline: Proposed Building Code Overhaul
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the buildings commissioner, Patricia J. Lancaster, today presented a comprehensive overhaul of the city’s building code to the City Council — the first since 1968. The mayor said the rewriting of standards and rules would improve safety, efficiency and environmental sustainability.

headline: Leadership, Republican Style
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s May 3 column, “Wolfowitz’s Big Mistake.”

headline: War? What War?
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s May 3 column, “An Invisible War.“

headline: Clinton: ‘Sunset’ Iraq Authorization
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, on the Senate floor just a few minutes ago, proposed Oct. 11, 2007 as the “expiration date” for the Iraq war.

headline: Lawmaker: Make Gore Mandatory
text: Assemblyman Peter M. Rivera, a Bronx Democrat, said today he plans to introduce a bill that would make “An Inconvenient Truth,” the global warming documentary produced by Al Gore, mandatory viewing for all school age children.

headline: Poll Suggests Manhattan Driving Is Mostly Optional
text: The vast majority of New York City residents who drive in Manhattan on weekdays do not do so because they lack mass-transit options, according to a survey just released by the Partnership for New York City, an influential business group that has prodded Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to support a charge on driving into the city.

headline: New Century to Close Home-Lending Business
text: New Century Financial, the biggest subprime mortgage company to declare bankruptcy, will close its home-lending unit and fire about 2,000 employees after failing to find a buyer. Chief Executive Brad Morrice informed employees of the failed search in a conference call Thursday, said Dan Gagnier, a spokesman for the Irvine, Calif.-based company.

headline: Park Down, Mr. Infinity Up
text: No surprises here: The Mets optioned Chan Ho Park to Class AAA New Orleans today. In his place, however, they summoned the reliever Lino Urdaneta and not, as expected, Jorge Sosa. Willie Randolph will say in a few hours who will replace Park in the rotation, but it is likely that Urdaneta will take over Aaron Sele’s spot, and Sele will pitch Saturday. The Mets may have just added Urdaneta to be available today and tomorrow and then send him back to New Orleans and recall Saturday’s starter.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Away From Her'
text: A.O. Scott reviews "Away from Her," about an aging couple dealing with the ravages of Alzheimer's.

headline: Bullpen Blows Another for Pettitte
text: Jerry Hairston just took Luis Vizcaino into the left-field seats to tie the game here, 3-3. That’s the third time this season the bullpen has blown a potential victory for Andy Pettitte. It’ll be hard for him to reach 200 wins at this rate; he has 187 now.

headline: Gilmore Girls, 2000-2007
text: “Gilmore Girls”: goodbye, sweet princess.

headline: Obama Placed Under Secret Service Protection
text: The decision to assign agents to protect Senator Barack Obama, a full nine months before the Democratic primary, is the earliest the Secret Service has ever issued security detail to a presidential candidate. Russ Knocke, a spokesman for the Department of Homeland Security, said today he could not comment on whether the decision was made in response to a specific threat against Mr. Obama or his family, but that several criteria were taken into account before the authorization was made.

headline: When That Guy Died on My Show
text: “Hey, Dick, I’ll never forget the look on your face when that guy died on your show.”

headline: The First Presidential Decision
text: The first important decision any president makes comes well before taking office: his choice of a running mate at the time of his own presidential nomination, or even before. Presidential nominations now are all but assured well in advance of the party conventions.

headline: Q. and A.: Climate Talks in Bangkok
text: Andrew C. Revkin, an environment reporter at The Times, has spent the week covering talks in Bangkok on the latest report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a U.N.-sanctioned body.

headline: Escape from the Gender Ghetto
text: The very same morning that I began to read the new essay collection: “One of the Guys: Women as Aggressors and Torturers,” which examines the role of women in the Abu Ghraib prison scandal and in other instances of American military abuse, I came upon a man out for a walk with his baby daughter. He was wearing shorts; she was in a sunsuit. He wore a hat; she wore a bonnet. He carried her in a BabyBjörn-like-thing on his chest, and as he reached down for a moment to hike up her bottom (reassuring himself, I imagine, that she was still hanging in there), he looked so blissfully happy, so beatific, in fact, that I had to give him a smile.

headline: Live Blogging the G.O.P. Debate
text: The After-Party: Now that we’ve had a chance to look over the transcript, we’ve caught a couple of moments that are worth going back to. One is that exchange with Mr. Giuliani about Christians. Mr. Matthews asked if the increased influence of Christian conservatives in the Republican party had been good for the party. Mr. Giuliani: “Sure, the increased influence of large numbers of people are always good for us.” Then he used his time to go back to an earlier question and said this: “Neither party has a monopoly on virtue or vice.” His context seemed to be that if the Republicans were going to win, they had to reach out to Democrats, but that was an unusual way to say it.

headline: Down Syndrome
text: Some parents of children with Down syndrome want prospective parents to know the positive side of raising a child with the genetic condtion.

headline: Difficult Diagnosis
text: When their unborn child was diagnosed with Down syndrome, one couple found it difficult to envision their future family. Then they met Troy.

headline: Senators Seek to Provide Aid on Mortgages
text: Three Democratic senators yesterday proposed using $300 million in federal funds to help refinance troubled subprime mortgages and introduced a bill that would require brokers and lenders to act in the interest of borrowers.

headline: Old Kansas, Still Growing Tall
text: THINK all of Kansas is flat? Think again. The Flint Hills, in the eastern part of the state, fan out over 183 miles from north to south, stretching 30 to 40 miles wide in parts, the land folding into itself, then popping up in gentle bumps, with mounds looming far off on the horizon. Seemingly endless, the landscape offers up isolated images — a wind-whipped cottonwood tree, a rusted cattle pen, a spindly windmill, an abandoned limestone schoolhouse, the metal-gated entrance to a hilltop cemetery.

headline: Norway Keeps Nest Egg From Some U.S. Companies
text: OSLO — For a people whose deep national pride is in bestowing the Nobel Peace Prize, Norwegians are developing a reputation for throwing some sharp elbows.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article yesterday about divisions among Republican presidential candidates on how to deal with the record of President Bush incorrectly identified one of the two candidates whose advisers said it was foolhardy to attack Mr. Bush. In addition to the campaign of Mitt Romney, advisers to Rudolph W. Giuliani — not Senator John McCain — made that assertion. The article also misstated the name of the California town where Mr. McCain spent the day Wednesday, preparing for a Thursday night debate. It is Coronado, not Coronado Beach. (Go to Article)

headline: The Fairfax and Balsam Mountain Preserve
text: The Fairfax

headline: Paris as Cinematic Soufflé, From Quartier to Quartier and Director to Director
text: “Paris Je T’Aime,” a mosaic of 18 miniatures, each set in a different location in the City of Light, is a cinematic tasting menu consisting entirely of amuse-bouches. After two hours of such tidbits the palate is sated. But if there is no need for a main course, you still leave feeling vaguely disappointed at not being served one.

headline: N.B.A.’s Denials Overlook a Larger Point
text: So much for the racial dialogue the Imus-Rutgers imbroglio was supposed to provoke.

headline: Europe: Limits on Cellphone Charges Advance
text: Negotiators for the European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Union’s telecommunications ministers agreed to a compromise that could limit mobile phone roaming charges for 450 million European consumers by the end of the summer. The agreement would cap roaming charges at 0.45 euro a minute for outgoing calls, 0.20 euro for incoming and 0.29 for wholesale, excluding value-added taxes.

headline: Superhero Sandbagged
text: If ever a movie had a case of the blues and the blahs, it’s “Spider-Man 3,” the third and what feels like the end of Sam Raimi’s big-screen comic-book adaptations. (Ready or not, the studio is talking about a fourth.) Aesthetically and conceptually wrung out, fizzled rather than fizzy, this latest installment in the spider-bites-boy adventure story shoots high, swings low and every so often hits the sweet spot, but mostly just plods and plods along, as if its heart were pumping tired radioactive blood.

headline: ...Where Orfeo Sings His Way Out of Darkness
text: Typically, plans for a new production at the Metropolitan Opera do not get off the ground until a major singer commits to the project. So it was with Mark Morris’s staging of Gluck’s sublime “Orfeo ed Euridice,” which was to have starred the mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson as Orfeo, the mythic musician and grieving husband whose story has been told in countless operas and dramas.

headline: Olmert Holds on for Now, Despite Huge Public Outcry
text: TEL AVIV, May 3 — More than 100,000 protesters gathered in Rabin Square here on Thursday night to urge Prime Minister Ehud Olmert and his government to resign. The call followed the release of a damning report on the performance of the Israeli leadership during the war in Lebanon last summer.

headline: Bush Warns of Vetoes Over Abortion Issue
text: WASHINGTON, May 3  President Bush told Congressional leaders Thursday that he would veto any legislation that weakened federal policies or laws on abortion.

headline: Florida Acts to Eliminate Touch-Screen Voting System
text: MIAMI, May 3  Florida legislators voted on Thursday to replace touch-screen voting machines installed in 15 counties after the troubled 2000 presidential election here with a system of optical scan voting.

headline: China Now Testing Food for Chemicals
text: SHANGHAI, May 4 — Responding to the sweeping recalls of pet food in the United States and to worries about contamination in its own food supply, China said today that it has begun nationwide inspections to determine whether wheat gluten is being contaminated with chemicals, according to the state-controlled Xinhua News Agency.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article yesterday about divisions among Republican presidential candidates on how to deal with the record of President Bush incorrectly identified one of the two candidates whose advisers said it was foolhardy to attack Mr. Bush. In addition to the campaign of Mitt Romney, advisers to Rudolph W. Giuliani  not Senator John McCain  made that assertion. The article also misstated the name of the California town where Mr. McCain spent the day Wednesday, preparing for a Thursday night debate. It is Coronado, not Coronado Beach.

headline: Wolfowitz Rebuts Critics Over Tempest at World Bank
text: WASHINGTON, May 3  In a new rebuttal to charges that he violated ethics rules at the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz said Thursday that he had helped arrange a generous pay and promotion package for his companion soon after he became bank president in 2005 as “a settlement of her potential claims” if she sued for being relocated against her will.

headline: Epilepsy Drug Can Increase Risk for Newborns, Study Says
text: Doctors reported yesterday that expectant mothers with epilepsy who took a commonly prescribed drug to control seizures were at increased risk of having a child with mental deficits.

headline: Adding Reliever Gives Mets the Option of Recalling Sosa
text: PHOENIX, May 3 — The Mets’ pitching was so thin at one point last season that they granted José Lima four starts, and they were so desperate that they let Geremi González start three times. Their upgraded depth at Class AAA New Orleans allows them to be less tolerant with retreads this season, and after one ineffective start they designated Chan Ho Park for assignment Thursday.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: For the Record
text: A music review on Tuesday of the group Opus 21, at Symphony Space, misspelled the given name of the composer of “Thaw,” a work the group played. He is Mark Dancigers, not Marc.

headline: Sex Charges Against Teacher Put Indian Reservation on Edge
text: SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 3 — Word began rippling through the small Onondaga reservation on the outskirts of the city last fall: a music teacher at the elementary school had been suspended, charged with sexually abusing two of his female students.

headline: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Tuesday with a theater review of “Jump!” and “Realism,” at the Kirk Theater on 42nd Street, misspelled the surname of an actress shown in “Jump!” She is Meredith Zinner, not Ziner.

headline: For the Record
text: A front-page article yesterday about an online revolt against efforts by a trade organization to remove a secret antipiracy code from the Web erroneously included one Web site among those that received requests to remove the code. Wikipedia did not receive such a letter.

headline: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article last Friday about the spouses of the French presidential candidates referred incorrectly to the source of a 1995 quote by Cécilia Sarkozy, wife of the conservative candidate Nicolas Sarkozy, who said: “I don’t see myself as a first lady. That bores me. I am not politically correct.” She spoke in an interview with a French television magazine, not on a television show.

headline: Voices Rise in Mount Vernon Over How to Fight Crime
text: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 3 — After two people were killed and two others were injured in two shootings and a stabbing here last week, local leaders called a meeting at a Baptist church on Tuesday, hoping to calm residents, hear their concerns and offer solutions.

headline: Lamenting the Loss of a Historic Washington Market
text: WASHINGTON, May 3 — Richard Glasgow hoped he could recover the wooden sign that hung above his seafood stall. Chris and Maria Calomiris wanted to salvage the cans of Greek olive oil that had been delivered just days earlier. Mike Bowers wondered if the granite countertop could still be used for his cheese shop.

headline: Dirty Tricks by Phone
text: The phone rings at 3 a.m. You pick it up, and a computerized voice seems to be pitching John Doe’s campaign. You hang up. It calls back 15 more times. Are you going to vote for Mr. Doe? Probably not.

headline: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the reduction in space for book reviews in some newspapers in the United States, and the emergence of Web sites that offer reviews, misstated the title held at Touchstone Fireside, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, by Trish Todd, who commented on the changes. It is editor-in-chief, not publisher.

headline: Reading Russia Right
text: Moscow

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a crackdown on gun violence in Baltimore referred incorrectly to the trend in the rate of violent crime in the city. While shootings are up 36 percent this year compared with last year, violent crime  also including rape, robbery and assault  is down 15 percent. It is not rising.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: U.S. Says Its Troops Killed a Top Iraqi Insurgent Who Aided in the Kidnapping of Westerners
text: BAGHDAD, May 3 — American military officials said Thursday that American troops had killed a senior propagandist for the insurgent group Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia who was involved in kidnapping Westerners, including the American journalist Jill Carroll. But the American officials denied claims from Iraqi officials that other leaders of the group had been killed.

headline: Mother’s S.U.V. Rolls in Bronx, Killing Boy, 1
text: A 1-year-old boy whose father died in Iraq weeks before he was born was killed yesterday afternoon after he was accidentally run over by his mother’s sport utility vehicle near their home in the Bronx, according to the police and relatives.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Newark: New Lawyer for Medical School
text: The embattled University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has hired a new general counsel, Lester Aron. Mr. Aron is a member of the Newark law firm Sills, Cummis, Epstein & Gross. He represents about three dozen New Jersey school districts and serves as a trustee of Kean University. Mr. Aron replaces Vivian Sanks King, who resigned in 2005. A federal monitor is overseeing the operations of the university under an agreement with the United States attorney’s office that allowed the school to avoid federal prosecution for Medicaid fraud. The monitor, Herbert J. Stern, criticized the university in July for its delay in hiring in a new general counsel.

headline: Clinton Proposes Vote to Reverse Authorizing War
text: WASHINGTON, May 3 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed Thursday that Congress repeal the authority it gave President Bush in 2002 to invade Iraq, injecting presidential politics into the Congressional debate over financing the war.

headline: Con Edison Seeks 11.6% Rate Increase
text: Consolidated Edison yesterday asked state regulators today for permission to raise electricity rates substantially in New York City and most of Westchester County, starting next April.

headline: Britain: Bid for Hanson Considered
text: HeidelbergCement, the biggest concrete maker in Germany, said it might bid for Hanson, the world’s largest supplier of crushed rock, setting off a 20 percent gain in Hanson’s stock price. “HeidelbergCement is currently reviewing its options with respect to its interest in Hanson, including the possibility of seeking to acquire the company,” HeidelbergCement said. Acquiring Hanson would increase HeidelbergCement’s revenue by more than two-thirds, add operations in Australia and bolster its range of products like crushed rock, concrete pipes and bricks.

headline: A Veteran Dealer Sheds His Possessions
text: An eclectic offering from the home of British decorator and antiques dealer Keith Skeel and Swedish antiques get hotter.

headline: For $9,000, a Big-Race Competitor
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 — When a bay yearling by the sire Johannesburg entered the sales ring in October 2005, it is doubtful that any of the major players in the industry were paying attention. He was part of a sale, the Fasig-Tipton Kentucky fall yearlings sale, where the leftovers are sold — horses who, because of their pedigrees or conformations or both, cannot make the cut at the big sales frequented by the sport’s wealthiest owners.

headline: In Jihadist Haven, a Goal: To Kill and Die in Iraq
text: ZARQA, Jordan — Abu Ibrahim considers his dead friends the lucky ones.

headline: Walter M. Schirra Jr., Astronaut, Dies at 84
text: Walter M. Schirra Jr., one of the original Mercury Seven astronauts and the only astronaut to fly in all three of NASA’s earliest manned space programs — Mercury, Gemini and Apollo — died yesterday in San Diego. He was 84 and lived in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

headline: Laws Proposed on Use of DNA to Help Prove Innocence
text: ALBANY, May 3  Alan Newton, a former bank teller from the Bronx, was freed from prison in 2006 after serving 22 years for a rape he did not commit. For more than a decade, Mr. Newton had asked the authorities to test his DNA against the physical evidence from the crime scene, only to be told that the evidence could not be found.

headline: A Show Where Candidates Are More Prop Than Player
text: If ever there was an event that cried out for name tags, it was last night’s Republican debate. Which in that long line of white men in bright ties and dark suits supported embryonic stem cell research? And who was it again who called for a flat tax?

headline: China Makes Arrest in Pet Food Case
text: SHANGHAI, May 3 — The general manager of a Chinese company accused of selling contaminated wheat gluten to pet food suppliers in the United States has been detained by the Chinese authorities, according to police officials here and a person who was briefed on the investigation.

headline: Golfers Take Aim With Help of a Rifleman
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 3 — In the past year, several professional golfers have traveled to Flower Mound, Tex., to meet a man trained to shoot a rifle between the beats of his pulse.

headline: Washington: Bush Plans Appointments
text: President Bush said he intended to nominate a federal budget analyst, Kerry N. Weems, to run Medicare and Medicaid. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Weems would become administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, succeeding Dr. Mark B. McClellan, who resigned in October. Mr. Weems, 50, has spent almost half his life at the Department of Health and Human Services. Since early 2005, he has been deputy chief of staff for Michael O. Leavitt, secretary of health and human services. Mr. Bush also announced that he planned to nominate an aide, Tevi D. Troy, as deputy secretary of health and human services. Mr. Troy, 40, was deputy director of policy for the Bush-Cheney campaign in 2004 and now coordinates the president’s Domestic Policy Council.

headline: Welcome, Interstate Satyrs
text: THE yawning atrium of the Holiday Inn in Memphis had been silent all morning, but by noon on a Friday in late March, it began to bustle and hum with the whispering thwip-thwip-thwip of cards being shuffled and the clacking rattle of dice being rolled, with the shouts of victorious adventurers and the death throes of impaled orcs.

headline: Mexico: Drug Dealers Attack the Military
text: Five soldiers were ambushed and killed in the western state of Michoacán late Tuesday during an anti-drug operation, a brazen sign that drug dealers are willing to fight the military as it tries to rid the state of narcotics, the authorities said. Heavily armed men, whom investigators believe to be drug-cartel henchmen, opened fire on the soldiers at 11:30 p.m. as they were driving in pickups through Carácuaro, 85 miles south of the capital, Morelia. One gunmen was also killed in the ensuing exchange of fire. President Felipe Calderón has sent more than 6,000 soldiers into the state as part of a crackdown on drug traffickers that has failed to slow the pace of gangland-style executions.

headline: Big Names, Big Wallets, Big Cause
text: Even in charity, the titans of hedge funds and private equity do nothing small.

headline: Canada and Afghanistan Reach Accord on How to Treat Detainees
text: OTTAWA, May 3 — The government announced Thursday that it had reached an agreement with Afghanistan on the treatment of detainees captured by Canadian troops.

headline: A Question for the G.O.P. (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clear Channel Board Rejects Sweetened Offer From Bidder
text: Clear Channel Communications, the nation’s largest radio broadcaster, said last night that its board had rejected a revised offer by two equity firms that had agreed to buy the company, but are now trying to keep the deal from falling through.

headline: House Votes to Expand Hate-Crime Protection
text: WASHINGTON, May 3  The House of Representatives voted on Thursday to extend hate-crime protection to people who are victimized because of their sexuality. But the most immediate effect may be to set up another veto showdown between Democrats and President Bush.

headline: De La Hoya Reaches Out to Father of Opponent
text: LAS VEGAS, May 3 — The peculiar psychology of Saturday night’s Oscar De La Hoya-Floyd Mayweather Jr. junior middleweight title bout can be summarized with this: Floyd Mayweather Sr., who nurtured his son’s career but is now estranged from him, will attend the fight courtesy of four ringside tickets from De La Hoya, who replaced him as his trainer earlier this year.

headline: A Dose of Funny Ha-Ha From the Good Old ’90s
text: It is a cliché to say so, but “Saturday Night Live” is an institution, kind of like comedy’s Junior League, continually nostalgic for its former cultural significance. Today YouTube makes that sort of self-reflection unnecessary: you can watch Phil Hartman playing John McLaughlin playing Frank Sinatra anytime you want. But NBC, which created retrospectives of “SNL” in the 1970s and ’80s, and produced specials based on the work of individual performers, has now made “Saturday Night Live in the ’90s: Pop Culture Nation,” a compilation of the highs and lows and highs again of the show during the Clinton period. (The program appears on Sunday night.)

headline: Rosneft Buys Yukos Assets, Including Its Oil Refineries
text: MOSCOW, May 3 — Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, acquired 37 subsidiaries of the bankrupt Yukos oil company at an auction on Thursday, expanding Rosneft’s already large footprint in the industry.

headline: Beyond Paintbrush Boundaries: Imagining Structures in 3-D
text: Perhaps Frank Stella should have quit when he was ahead. For some people that was as far back as the mid-1970s, when he began making a succession of increasingly colorful and ornate aluminum reliefs. They were often considered artistic apostasy, blatant betrayals of his ascetic striped paintings of the 1960s, which established his reputation as a wunderkind and premier New York artist, and he became one of the cornerstones of Minimalism.

headline: Labor Party Battered in British Vote
text: LONDON, May 4 — In a historic reversal, the separatist Scottish National Party emerged today as the biggest political force in Scotland, ending 50 years of dominance there by the ruling Labor Party and redrawing Britain’s political landscape.

headline: U.S. Investigators Visiting Pet Food Makers
text: Federal investigators have begun visiting food and pet food makers that use vegetable protein concentrates imported from China to make sure that the additives are not contaminated, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday.

headline: Raptors Are Hurting at Guard Going Into Game 6
text: The status of the Raptors’ two top point guards remained unknown for tonight’s Game 6 against the Nets. The starter, T. J. Ford, left Tuesday night’s Game 5 after he injured his neck in a first-quarter collision with the Nets’ Vince Carter. Ford, who did not practice Wednesday or yesterday, still felt tingling in his arms and was questionable for tonight’s game.

headline: G.M. Turnaround Gains Little Traction
text: DETROIT, May 3 — General Motors has placed all of its bets on its pickup trucks, which are strong enough to pull thousands of pounds through the mud, but from the looks of G.M.’s first quarter, are unable to pull the automaker out of its financial downturn.

headline: Queens Man Arraigned in School Bus Crash
text: A Brooklyn man was arraigned yesterday on charges including burglary and assault in connection with a police chase and bus crash that injured eight children and four adults, prosecutors said. The man, Thomas Hernandez, 43, of De Kalb Avenue, was held without bail after his arraignment in Criminal Court, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. He is charged with crashing into a school bus, which rolled onto its side, on Douglaston Parkway in Little Neck on Tuesday while fleeing the police, Mr. Brown said. The police said officers were pursuing Mr. Hernandez after he burglarized an officer’s house in Flushing and stole his sport utility vehicle.

headline: U.S. Reviews Afghan Claims of Civilian Toll in Airstrikes
text: WASHINGTON, May 3 — The top American commander in Afghanistan said Thursday he was investigating claims that dozens of civilians were killed and wounded recently by American airstrikes in the Western province of Herat.

headline: Gene Identified as Risk Factor for Heart Ills
text: Two rival teams of scientists have discovered a common genetic variation that increases the risk of heart disease up to 60 percent in people of European descent.

headline: Confusion and Deception as a Royal Family Affair
text: Modern-dress minimalism often seems to be the default choice for Shakespeare these days, but it can also be a straitjacket, as the Cheek by Jowl production of “Cymbeline” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater unhappily illustrates. The great tragedies, with their mighty figures and penetrating psychology, can stagger us unadorned. The lively comedies possess a natural effervescence. But the latecoming romances don’t always benefit from a distilled approach.

headline: Secret Service Guards Obama, Taking Unusually Early Step
text: Senator Barack Obama, whose crowds at political rallies across the country have often numbered in the thousands, was placed under Secret Service protection yesterday, a spokesman for the agency said.

headline: Bjork, in Fighting Spirit, Links Church and State
text: The last time Bjork played Radio City Music Hall, five and a half years ago, she was in heaven: dressed in white, accompanied by the harpist Zeena Parkins. But when she returned to the space on Wednesday night, she was somewhere else entirely. The night began with a reddish dress, scorching red flames and pummeling beats: it was clear she had descended into a post-disco inferno.

headline: In a New Space and Time, a Classic Story of Tragic Love
text: When “The Tristan Project” was first presented in Los Angeles, at the end of 2004, it was clear that it would be one of the highlights of Esa-Pekka Salonen’s tenure as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic. At heart, it was a concert opera, but in a multimedia conception that promised to be so ingenious that listeners traveled long distances to catch it, and talked about it for months. The buzz started again when Lincoln Center announced that it would bring the production to New York, and now that it’s here — the first of two performances was on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall — it is a hot topic again, and a hot ticket as well: the performance was sold out, with the best seats priced at $500.

headline: Heart of Hawaii
text: THE Poomau Ditch Trail hugs a mountainside, and we hiked carefully, looking down at the path so as not to take a false step and fall hundreds of feet to eternity. Gnarly ohia lehua trees lined the side away from the chasm, and abrasive blackberry bushes — not native to Hawaii, but thriving here on Kauai like so many other invasive imports — reached out their scratchy canes. Everything around us was green: mountains, canyons, tree canopy.

headline: U.S. Issues Guidelines on Use of Face Masks in Flu Outbreak
text: If a flu pandemic ever emerges, surgical masks “should be considered” by anyone entering a crowd, and thicker industrial masks “should be considered” for anyone taking care of the sick, federal health officials said yesterday as they finally released guidelines for mask use.

headline: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on April 24 about mock elections held in Bhutan as a practice for parliamentary elections next year incorrectly described the status of King Jigme Singye Wangchuck. He abdicated late last year as part of his effort to move the country toward modernity; he did not recently announce plans to do so.

headline: As the Climate Changes, Bits of England’s Coast Crumble
text: BECCLES, England — This winter a 50-foot-wide strip of Roger Middleditch’s sugar-beet field fell into the North Sea, his rich East Anglian lands reduced by a large fraction of their acreage. The adjacent potato field, once 23 acres, is now less than 3 — too small to plant at all, he said.

headline: The (Vintage) Shirt Off Her Back
text: MY name is Annie, and I’m a shopaholic. I love coming home with bags full of clothing, jewelry, vintage collectibles, whatever. The only problem is, I highly disapprove of my own shallow materialism. When most people in the world don’t own a book or a toilet, it seems just a wee bit selfish to buy a wait-listed designer handbag for some astromaniacal sum. So to balance my moral high-mindedness with my base lust for goods, I spend my life scouring thrift shops, estate sales and flea markets; that way I can feel virtuous.

headline: Pope Benedict XVI Meets With Ex-President of Iran
text: ROME, May 4 — Pope Benedict XVI met today with Iran’s former president, Mohammad Khatami, who spoke here earlier in the day about the “very deep” wounds between Muslims and Christians.

headline: In Search of the Master Teacher (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Murdoch on Owning The Wall Street Journal
text: Like any close reader of The Wall Street Journal, Rupert Murdoch has his opinions.

headline: Bloomberg Outlines Plan to Rewrite City’s Construction Codes
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed yesterday overhauling the city’s aged and notoriously byzantine building code by greatly expanding fire safety requirements, encouraging environmentally sound construction and simplifying operations at the Department of Buildings.

headline: 8th-Seeded Warriors Stun Mavericks
text: OAKLAND, May 3 — Mickael Pietrus had never crowd-surfed before.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: A WORD WORTH A SECOND LOOK

headline: Who’s Afraid of Joan Baez? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tiago Tries to Match Champion Sibling
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 — On the day that Giacomo won the 2005 Kentucky Derby, his little half brother, then a yearling, was ambling around the fields of Mill Ridge Farm in Lexington, about 75 miles from the Churchill Downs finish line. No one involved with the yearling could have imagined that two years later he, too, would take aim at horse racing's most coveted prize. The Kentucky Derby is limited to 20 starters and, with roughly 34,000 thoroughbreds born each year in this country, the odds of two horses with the same mother making the race are astronomical.

headline: Republican Candidates Hold First Debate, Differing on Defining Party’s Future
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif., May 3 — The 10 declared Republican presidential candidates met together for the first time here Thursday night in what amounted to a tentative but occasionally vibrant competition to define the party’s ideology and agenda in a post-Bush era.

headline: Court Blocks Sale of an ABN Amro Unit
text: LONDON, May 3 — The sale of LaSalle Bank, a longtime Chicago institution that has suddenly become a pivotal prize in the world’s largest banking takeover battle, was blocked by a Dutch court on Thursday.

headline: For the Record
text: A listing on Wednesday about the amount of money presidential candidates raised in Texas during the first three months of this year omitted two Republican candidates. Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, raised $1,054,050, placing him fourth on a list of 17 candidates. Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, raised $11,225, ranking him 14th.

headline: J. Robert Bradley, 87, Charismatic Gospel Singer, Dies
text: J. Robert Bradley, whose deep, swooping, octave-leaping voice and charismatic presence made him one of the most important figures in gospel music, died yesterday in Nashville. He was 87.

headline: Climate Panel Reaches Consensus on the Need to Reduce Harmful Emissions
text: BANGKOK, May 4 — The world’s established and emerging powers will need to divert substantially from today’s main energy sources within a few decades, to limit centuries of rising temperatures and seas driven by the buildup of heat-trapping emissions in the air, the top body studying climate change has concluded.

headline: Swedish Steel Maker Acquiring Canadian Supplier of Oil Pipes
text: OTTAWA, May 3 — Ipsco, a leading Canadian supplier of steel pipes to the oil and gas industry, agreed to be acquired by a Swedish steel maker, SSAB Svenskt Stal, for $7.7 billion in cash, the two companies said on Thursday.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: U.S. Detains Alleged Smugglers With Ties to Iran
text: American soldiers today detained an alleged cell of smugglers who procured powerful, armor piercing bombs and other weapons from Iran, the military said.

headline: More Troubles for Busta Rhymes
text: In the turbulent world of hip-hop, where the line between art and criminality is sometimes blurred, an arrest for drunken driving would normally attract little attention.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Tenet’s ‘Slam Dunk’ (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Art in Review
text: LAZHAR MANSOURI Portraits of a Village: 1950-70 Westwood 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo Through May 12

headline: Spare Times for Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: The Other Boot
text: As Democrats in Congress and the Bush administration look for common ground on a workable trade policy, it is worth taking a harder look at the capricious system of tariffs that raise the price of goods and are all too often based on outdated political considerations that defy logic and good sense.

headline: Canada: Court Rejects Wal-Mart
text: The Supreme Court of Canada rejected an appeal from Wal-Mart Canada over efforts to unionize another store in Quebec. As is always the case, the high court offered no reasons for its decision. The court’s move appears to open the way for the automatic certification of a store in Gatineau, a city across a river from Ottawa. “We’re disappointed but not surprised, because the Supreme Court rarely hears cases like this,” said Yanik Deschênes, a spokesman for Wal-Mart. Wal-Mart wanted a court order requiring that Quebec’s labor board conduct a secret ballot of employees. The United Food and Commercial Workers has asked for automatic certification under Quebec law based on the number of union membership cards it signed at the outlet.

headline: Behind Bars, Leader of Drug Gang Manages Real Estate Investments, Prosecutors Say
text: It is no small task to pass the time at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility, a maximum security prison in Ossining, N.Y., for male criminal offenders considered among the most dangerous in New York. But for nearly two decades, prosecutors say, one convicted drug kingpin has found a novel use for his time  dabbling in island real estate.

headline: Suit Criticizes Conditions at Mental Hospital
text: A state agency that advocates for mentally ill people has sued New York City in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, alleging that psychiatric patients at Kings County Hospital Center endure squalid conditions and inhumane treatment.

headline: Wind Farms May Not Lower Air Pollution, Study Suggests
text: WASHINGTON, May 3 — Building thousands of wind turbines would probably not reduce the pollutants that cause smog and acid rain, but it would slow the growth in emissions of heat-trapping gases, according to a study released Thursday by the National Academy of Sciences.

headline: Dutch Composer Samples Pop Culture and Gives It a Melody
text: A museum is an appropriate setting for the music of the Dutch composer Jacob Ter Veldhuis, otherwise known as Jacob TV. His work engages in a kind of pop-culture appropriation that has distinct parallels to visual art. On the three-box CD set of his works, to be released today, his orchestral music resembles Jeff Koons in its earnest explorations of kitsch. His boombox pieces, for recorded tape and solo instruments, are analogous to Tom Wesselmann’s slick collages, limning the outlines of larger-than-life American figures in a pop idiom (with digital sampling and D.J.-like repetitions). And there is an overarching element of Henri Rousseau: the bright colors and slightly crude outlines of a folk artist.

headline: Where Words Go to Work and Play
text: AS any aspiring writer knows, sometimes the only route to productivity is escapism. Luckily, there are plenty of workshops and conferences around to supply it — and simultaneously offer not only inspiration but practical advice. Usually held in seaside cities and resort towns or on bucolic college campuses, these writers’ programs can be found year-round. But the summertime crop takes authors to particularly seductive spots.

headline: Plan for Arabic School in Brooklyn Spurs Protests
text: The Khalil Gibran International Academy was conceived as a public embrace of New York City’s growing Arab population and of internationalism, the first public school dedicated to the study of the Arabic language and culture and open to students of all racial and ethnic backgrounds.

headline: Action by Police at Rally Troubles Los Angeles Chief
text: LOS ANGELES, May 3 — Chief William J. Bratton of the Los Angeles Police Department said Thursday that the episode here in which police officers clashed with demonstrators and journalists on Tuesday at an immigration rally was the “worst incident of this type I have ever encountered in 37 years” in law enforcement.

headline: Verizon Vote on Pay Levels to Be Decided in a Recount
text: The shareholder vote on an executive pay proposal at Verizon Communications is too close to call and must go to a recount, the company said after its annual meeting in Pittsburgh yesterday. The results of the recount will be available within two weeks, a company spokesman said.

headline: Seeing No Progress, Some Schools Drop Laptops
text: LIVERPOOL, N.Y. — The students at Liverpool High have used their school-issued laptops to exchange answers on tests, download pornography and hack into local businesses. When the school tightened its network security, a 10th grader not only found a way around it but also posted step-by-step instructions on the Web for others to follow (which they did).

headline: Sometimes You Can Go Home Again
text: When Gene Bauer told his mother he was buying a second home in Williamstown, Mass., in 1998, she couldn’t believe it. Mr. Bauer, a Boston lawyer who graduated from Williams College in 1971, had complained heartily about the frigid, snow-filled winters there when he was a student. “My mother said, ‘You swore you’d never go through another Williamstown winter again,’ ” he recalled recently.

headline: Taking Advantage of the Issue of the Moment
text: Here’s a case that would seem to defy the laws of political science.

headline: Seeking an Edge, Florida Changes Its Primary Date
text: MIAMI, May 3 — Casting more uncertainty over the presidential nominating process for 2008, the Florida Legislature on Thursday moved the state’s primary up to Jan. 29, ignoring the threat of sanctions from the national Republican and Democratic parties.

headline: U.S. Officials Meet Briefly With Iranians
text: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, May 4 — American and Iranian officials spoke briefly today at a regional conference here on the Iraq situation, in a rare direct conversation between representatives of the two antagonistic nations.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Era of ‘Cabaret,’ in Avant-Garde Lines
text: Spurred by its recent architectural makeover, the past-loving Morgan Library & Museum has decided to bring new life to its illustrious collection of works on paper by expanding it into the 20th and 21st centuries. As an early step on its trek to modernity, the Morgan is presenting the small but intense collection bequeathed to it by the Broadway lyricist Fred Ebb (1928-2004).

headline: OSHA’s Enforcement (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Speaking Love With Kurt and Lotte
text: Two luminous, life-infused portraits glow from within a dim, heavy frame at the Biltmore Theater, where “LoveMusik” opened last night. This bio-musical about the marital and professional relationship of the German-born composer Kurt Weill and the actress Lotte Lenya, directed by Harold Prince, is sluggish, tedious and (hold your breath) unmissable — at least for anyone who cherishes stars who mold songs into thrilling windows of revelation.

headline: Should S.E.C. Act Against Lawyers?
text: If you are going to commit fraud, you may need a good lawyer. In some cases, you have to have a lawyer to pull off the fraud at all.

headline: In Victory or Defeat, the 8th-Seeded Warriors Never Go by Unnoticed
text: OAKLAND, Calif., May 3 — The Golden State Warriors are the rare professional basketball franchise that has spent generations just dreaming of being a No. 8 seed.

headline: The Times Names Public Editor
text: The New York Times today named its next public editor, Clark Hoyt, a former Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter and editor who oversaw the Knight Ridder newspaper chain’s coverage that questioned the Bush administration’s case for the Iraq war.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (Disney Channel) HIGH SCHOOL MUSICAL: THE CONCERT More than 100 million children, teenagers and (admit it) parents have watched “High School Musical”  in which a brainiac and a basketball player step out onstage and relegate the drama-club darlings to understudy oblivion  since the movie first hit the Disney Channel in January 2006. Its soundtrack was that year’s top-ranking album, with more than 3.7 million copies sold. And then came the concert tour, above, in which Vanessa Anne Hudgens, Ashley Tisdale, Lucas Grabeel, Corbin Bleu, Monique Coleman and Drew Seeley strutted their triple-platinum stuff. This special ventures behind the scenes with the performers and some of the screaming concertgoing masses.

headline: Rest for the Roses
text: ON one of my first visits to Belmont Park, I saw a fatal breakdown from a few feet away and realized that my enjoyment of horse racing would come with a price. Some people in the sport dismiss the problem by saying that equine breakdowns are “part of the game.” That may be a fact — but that doesn’t make it any more acceptable.

headline: Climate Panel Reaches Consensus on the Need to Reduce Harmful Emissions
text: The world needs to divert substantially from today’s main energy sources within a few decades to limit centuries of rising temperatures and seas driven by the buildup of heat-trapping emissions in the air, the top body studying climate change has concluded.

headline: After a Four-Day Safety Review, Subway Work Is Resuming
text: Transit officials said yesterday that they planned to resume regular maintenance and construction work on subway tracks and tunnels this morning, returning workers to the job after more than four days off for a safety review prompted by the deaths of two track workers struck by trains.

headline: Another Hockeytown
text: BUFFALO, May 3 — In the summer of 2002, one of the few similarities between the Buffalo Sabres and the Detroit Red Wings was that both N.H.L. franchises were located in Rust Belt cities just across a river from Canada — and even that connection was tenuous. While the Red Wings and their fans were celebrating the city’s latest Stanley Cup, the Sabres were in danger of moving out of town.

headline: Mark Morris Descends to the Underworld ...
text: Orpheus, the isolated musician whose sufferings take him to hell and back, is the most potent archetype of the creative artist in Greek mythology, as he has remained for the performing arts since the Renaissance. Onstage we know him in innumerable works, from Monteverdi’s opera to the Stravinsky-Balanchine ballet and a Tennessee Williams play, but none have more enduring dramatic resonance than Gluck’s “Orfeo ed Euridice.” Since Gluck and his artistic collaborators built this opera with extensive dance opportunities in all three acts, it has always attracted eminent choreographers, and three of the greatest have chosen also to direct it: George Balanchine, Frederick Ashton and now Mark Morris.

headline: Hopper’s America, in Shadow and Light
text: BOSTON, April 30 — A certain slant of light was Edward Hopper’s thing. And he made it our thing, hard-wired it into our American brains: white late-morning light scraping across a storefront; twilight, plangent with heat and regret, settling over a city; slabs of late-night lamplight chilling the walls of Lonely Hearts Hotels everywhere.

headline: At Rutgers, 2 Players Complete Little Circle
text: Amid the celebration after the final out of the 1998 Little League World Series, Todd Frazier and Casey Gaynor shared a thought: It does not get any better than this. Nine years after they led Toms River, N.J., to a Little League championship, they are finding out that maybe it does.

headline: Greece: Conviction in C.I.A. Death Upheld
text: A special appeals panel in Athens upheld the 2003 terrorism conviction of Alexandros Yiotopoulos, who led a Marxist terrorist group for 27 years, starting in 1975 with the assassination of the Athens C.I.A. station chief, Richard Welch. The court upheld sentences for 12 other members of the November 17 terrorist organization but cleared two additional suspects because the crimes they were convicted of had fallen outside the statute of limitations. Named after a 1973 student uprising that was crushed by the tanks of a military junta that ruled Greece, November 17 killed 23 people, including American and British diplomats and military officers. It disbanded after a botched bomb attack in 2003.

headline: Next Venture From Stewart: Costco Food
text: The long, fastidious reach of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia extends into the magazine, television, furniture, bedding, paint, glassware, and even home building businesses.

headline: After BP Executive’s Exit, a Fleet Street Debate
text: LONDON, May 3 — Was John Browne, who quit as chief executive of BP after losing a legal battle to keep details of an affair with another man out of the newspapers, the victim of a tabloid press bent on “outing” public figures, or a casualty of his own bad judgment?

headline: Yankees Sweep Rangers in Doubleheader
text: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 3 — The Yankees have won their last 10 games here, including two more in a doubleheader sweep of the Texas Rangers on Thursday. They won a day game, 4-3, and a night game, 5-2, and probably did not want to leave.

headline: Friendlier Skies to a Home Abroad
text: OWNING a second home in Europe is surely many people’s idea of a dream come true. Problem is, the commute can be a nightmare.

headline: Finding Fellowship (Hairy Feet Optional)
text: Fifty-three years ago in The New York Times, the poet W. H. Auden reviewed the first volume of J. R. R. Tolkien’s epic trilogy, “The Lord of the Rings.”

headline: With Pettitte Struggling, Yankees Find Just Enough to Get By
text: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 3 — Each time the Yankees won the World Series in the 1990s, they rolled past the Texas Rangers in the first playoff round, winning all their games at the Rangers’ home ballpark. In this decade, the Yankees have never had a losing record here for a season.

headline: Theater Listings
text: THEATER

headline: 3-Run Homers by Easley and Wright Power Mets in the Ninth
text: PHOENIX, May 3 — Even with them trailing the Arizona Diamondbacks by a run entering the ninth inning Thursday, the Mets had little reason to worry. Due up fourth was their best clutch hitter recently, Damion Easley, and he would bat as long as someone got on base.

headline: Superhero Worship, Gotham to Riverdale
text: There is no better day to visit your neighborhood comic store than tomorrow: Free Comic Book Day, the annual industry promotion in which participating retailers nationwide will give away titles ranging from “Little Archie” and “The Amazing Spider-Man” to “The Lone Ranger” and “Transformers,” a spectrum as wide as the stores that sell them.

headline: Turkish Party Sees Victory in Grass Roots
text: ISTANBUL, May 3 — In the course of a single week, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has taken on Turkey’s Parliament, its highest court, even its military. Then he called for early national elections.

headline: For New Chief, BP’s Problems Range From Rusted Pipes to a Tarnished Image
text: Tony Hayward’s honeymoon is likely to be quite brief.

headline: Monet Arrives and Ripens
text: Seeing a good-sized museum-quality show squeezed into a commercial gallery can sometimes feel like having dinner with a celebrity. A familiar distance falls away; the intimacy startles. So the show of around 60 paintings by Claude Monet at Wildenstein & Company may take getting used to, or it may simply take your breath away. It surveys Monet’s astounding 60-year trajectory in the span of three crowded galleries that would easily fit in one of the coat rooms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Back in U.S., Queen Celebrates Ex-Colony
text: RICHMOND, Va., May 3 — A girl standing with her school marching band said she was on hand on Thursday to see whether the queen of England really waved with a cupped hand.

headline: Yanks Set for 10th Starting Pitcher
text: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 3  Matt DeSalvo had slipped so far down the Yankees’ depth chart that he was taken off the 40-man roster in January to make room for Miguel Cairo. Every team had a chance to claim DeSalvo, but none did.

headline: The U.S. Attorney, the G.O.P. Congressman and the Timely Job Offer
text: There is yet another United States attorney whose abrupt departure from office is raising questions: Debra Wong Yang of Los Angeles. Ms. Yang was not fired, as eight other prosecutors were, but she resigned under circumstances that raise serious questions, starting with whether she was pushed out to disrupt her investigation of one of the most powerful Republicans in Congress.

headline: A Paragon of the Arts, as Both Man and Titan
text: Lincoln Kirstein — patron of the performing, visual, and literary arts; novelist; poet; critic and historian of dance, photography and painting — was one of nature’s titans. He looked the role. Nobody who saw or met him can easily have forgotten the imposing physical impression he made. Tall, strong-browed, massive of shoulders, thorax and head, he might have modeled as Atlas, who in Greek mythology carried the world on his shoulders. His energies were titanic too, as the anthologies and bibliographies of his work have revealed. But what made him exceptional was that he acted as if his main motto were not “I am” or “I do” but “I serve.” He put those shoulders to many wheels, often effacing his own contribution in so doing.

headline: Coordinates of the Rich and Famous
text: WHEN I agreed to represent Gawker, the Web site I co-edit, on an episode of “Larry King Live” last month, I didn’t expect to be shouted at, cut off, talked down to and told that I was going to hell. But as everyone who caught the show — or has seen it since on YouTube — knows, that’s exactly what happened, courtesy of Mr. King’s fill-in, Jimmy Kimmel. If you saw the clip, you probably noticed that I looked sort of stunned. I even rolled my eyes a few times. Here’s why.

headline: Midterm Vote Could Give Blair a Last Hurrah, or a Swift Kick
text: LONDON, May 3  Voters across Britain went to the polls on Thursday in midterm regional elections that are considered likely to set the tone for Prime Minister Tony Blair’s expected departure as prime minister in the coming weeks.

headline: G.M. Profit Down 90% From 2006
text: DETROIT, May 3 — The General Motors Corporation reported a 90 percent decline in first-quarter profit today as losses at its finance arm overshadowed the gains from restructuring its automotive operations.

headline: Ex-Justice Dept. Official Defends Ousted U.S. Attorneys
text: WASHINGTON, May 3 — A former deputy attorney general told the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday that he regarded most of the fired United States attorneys as highly competent prosecutors who should not have been dismissed.

headline: Bill Proposes Climate Study Focused on U.S. Defense
text: WASHINGTON, May 3 — Given the jobs of hunting Al Qaeda, tracking nuclear programs in Iran and North Korea, and monitoring the civil strife in Iraq, American spy agencies are not lacking for work these days. Should they also take on the task of analyzing global warming?

headline: Suspect’s Purchases Are Cast as Window Into Dark Mind
text: Prosecutors say that during the 13 hours Peter Braunstein held a woman captive and sexually assaulted her in her Chelsea apartment in October 2005, he used chloroform, a gun, a military-style mask and other menacing paraphernalia to terrorize her.

headline: From Voice of the Bottle Bill to Keeper of the Green
text: ALBANY

headline: Wall St. Banker Jailed in Trading on 9 Deals
text: Federal authorities arrested an investment banker yesterday and charged him with illegally leaking confidential information on nine deals, including the $45 billion buyout of the Texas energy giant TXU.

headline: Defusing Buffalo Power Play Boosts Rangers
text: A big reason for the Rangers’ success against Buffalo has been their ability to frustrate the Sabres’ power play. In the series, which is tied 2-2, Buffalo has converted only 3 of 25 chances, including 1 of 13 in two losses at Madison Square Garden.

headline: In Iran, Tactics of Fashion Police Raise Concerns
text: TEHRAN, May 3 — Only days after Iran’s annual crackdown on immodest dress began in mid-April, with teams of police officers stopping women in major squares and subway stations to warn them about their attire, the security authorities came under fire.

headline: For the Love of Barbaro and the Love of Money
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Prosecutors Ask Jail For Paris Hilton

headline: Wal-Mart Discloses Some Compensation Details
text: Wal-Mart Stores, which used to closely guard information about its employee’s pay, disclosed yesterday for the first time its annual contributions to workers’ retirement accounts, profit sharing program and stock purchase plan.

headline: Family Values, Betrayed
text: When George W. Bush was running for president in 2000 as a new kind of Republican  the caring kind  he had a ready answer for those skeptical of his moderate views on immigration. “Family values do not stop at the Rio Grande,” he said, again and again. He was standing up for immigrants who come here seeking better lives for their children, and he repeated the message so often that it stuck.

headline: British Bankers Dwell in a Strange Houston Limbo With a Trial at the End
text: HOUSTON, May 3 — “What you have here is a U.S. government brick,” said Giles Darby, as he heaved a bulky global positioning device onto the table in front of him.

headline: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the victim’s testimony in the Manhattan trial of Peter Braunstein, a former magazine writer accused of sexual abuse and kidnapping, misidentified the publication from which the victim, a 36-year-old woman, resigned. It was W, not Women’s Wear Daily.

headline: Inspector of Projects in Iraq Under Investigation
text: A federal official whose investigations of waste and corruption in Iraq have repeatedly embarrassed the Bush administration is now being investigated himself by an oversight committee with close links to the White House and by the ranking Republican on the House Government Reform Committee.

headline: Assemblyman Is Censured for Fraternizing With Intern
text: ALBANY, May 3  An upstate assemblyman was removed from his post as ranking member of the Assembly Committee on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse on Thursday after revelations that he slept at the home of a 21-year-old female intern last month after a night of heavy drinking.

headline: Queens Man Charged With Killing Girlfriend
text: A Queens man has been arraigned on charges of killing his girlfriend in Jackson Heights last month after she tried to break up with him, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Shane Tomlinson, 20, of Springfield Gardens, was charged with second-degree murder in the shooting of Chameka Miller, 18, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Tomlinson shot Ms. Miller April 15 after a confrontation at her home on 77th Street.

headline: Highlights From the IPCC Report
text: “Measures to reduce emissions can, in the main, be achieved at starkly low costs, especially when compared with the costs of inaction,” said Achim Steiner, the executive director of the United Nations Environment Program, which, together with the World Meteorological Organization, established the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change in 1988.

headline: Zimbabwe: Journalists Forbidden to March
text: Police officials barred journalists from marching to commemorate World Press Freedom Day, saying it was prohibited under an emergency decree banning political demonstrations. Journalists had planned 10 separate marches throughout the nation to underscore what they say are increasing restrictions on the news media and a growing number of arrests, jailings and attacks involving journalists.

headline: The Times Names Clark Hoyt as New Public Editor
text: The New York Times yesterday named its next public editor, Clark Hoyt, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter and editor who oversaw the Knight Ridder newspaper chain’s coverage that questioned the Bush administration’s case for the Iraq war.

headline: The Poker’s High Stakes, the Couple’s in Love and the City Is Mostly Sin-Free
text: Cards on the table: I find it hard to dislike a movie that delivers songs by George Jones and Bruce Springsteen within the first five minutes or so. The rest of the music in “Lucky You” is of a similarly high, canonical quality (even when it’s Drew Barrymore rather than Mr. Jones singing “Cold Hard Truth”), but by the time the brand-new, specially commissioned Bob Dylan number plays over the end credits, it feels less like an apotheosis than like a consolation prize.

headline: The Aussie ‘Big Dry’
text: SYDNEY, Australia

headline: Garden City Officer’s Patrol Car Hit
text: A highway patrolman who was parked on the shoulder of the Long Island Expressway was seriously injured early yesterday when his patrol car was struck by another car whose driver was drunk, the police said. The patrolman, Officer Edwin Martinez, suffered head injuries and was taken to Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow, where he was in serious but stable condition last night. Officer Martinez had been patrolling a construction zone on the expressway, near Exit 43 at South Oyster Bay Road in Syosset, shortly after midnight when he pulled over a car driven by Andrew Mericle, 27, of Oyster Bay, for speeding, the police said. A car driven by Yookyung Kim, 19, of Bayside, Queens, rear-ended the officer’s car, which then hit Mr. Mericle’s car, the police said. Mr. Mericle and Mr. Kim were treated for minor injuries at the scene. Mr. Kim was charged with driving while intoxicated and arraigned in First District County Court in Hempstead. Mr. Kim’s license was suspended, and bail was set at $15,000 bond or $5,000 cash.

headline: UBS Closing Hedge Fund; Losses Cited on Mortgages
text: LONDON, May 3 — After turning UBS’s investment bank into one of the elite on Wall Street, John P. Costas gave up the chief executive’s post to run a hedge fund for the company, sensing the opportunity to build another world-class business.

headline: Four-Legged Friends
text: WHO Mary Whitehead, 67, and her husband, Michael Whitehead, 70, a retired structural engineer, from Poway, Calif.

headline: Israel Wary of U.S. Proposals on Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM, May 4 — The United States, seeking doggedly to push along improvements in relations between Israel and the Palestinians, has given both sides a set of modest goals for easing Palestinian travel and bolstering Israeli security.

headline: When Pennies Fail to Pay the Bill, a Bronx Man Pushes for Change
text: Every penny counts. But 10 of them didn’t one recent night in the Bronx, and that’s how the trouble started.

headline: Dia Borrows Space at Hispanic Society
text: DIA BORROWS SPACE

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Wally Schirra, One of the Original Mercury Seven Astronauts, Dies at 84
text: Wally Schirra, one of the original Mercury Seven astronauts and the only astronaut to fly in all three of NASA’s earliest manned space programs — Mercury, Gemini and Apollo — died yesterday in La Jolla, Calif. He was 84 and lived in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

headline: For the Record
text: A picture in the auto sales chart in Business Day on Wednesday was published in error. It showed a Nissan Altima Coupe, which is not on the market yet, rather than the Altima sedan, which had a 12.4 percent drop in sales in April. (The error first occurred in the sales chart on Jan. 4.)

headline: For the Record
text: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about plans to condense versions of “Charlie’s Angels” into three-and-a-half- to five-minute episodes misstated the length of the original program, including one episode in which the cast was shown solving a crime. The program was 60 minutes, not 30.

headline: Lawyer Says Imus to Sue CBS, Accusing It of Breaking Contract
text: The lawyer for the ousted radio host Don Imus said yesterday that he would file a $40 million lawsuit against CBS next week, accusing it of breach of contract.

headline: Loan Inquiry Turns to Deals With Alumni Associations
text: Even as universities are agreeing not to accept cash incentives from student lenders, dozens of college alumni associations are taking payments from loan companies and providing names and addresses of graduates that the companies can use for marketing purposes.

headline: On Oahu
text: Home to Honolulu and Waikiki, Oahu offers visitors and second-home owners a quintessential Hawaiian experience.

headline: Paradise Island
text: The essence of Maui: crystal blue water, big surf, emerald fairways and brilliant sunsets.

headline: The Republican Candidates’ First Debate
text: The first Republican presidential debate between a field of 10 presidential hopefuls highlighted a party in flux as it struggles to figure out how to retain the White House for a third consecutive term. While several of the candidates invoked Ronald Reagan, a few tried to distance themselves from President Bush on Iraq.

headline: Yanks Take Two From Texas
text: It was a long day in Texas, but the Yankees won’t complain. Since that homer by Hairston, they grabbed back the lead to win Game 1, 4-3, and then cruised in the second game, 5-2.

headline: Pulse
text: What I'm wearing now, the platform wedge sandal, Burt's Bees and more.

headline: It’s in the Cards
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Benedict to Face Challenges in Latin America
text: Benedict XVI travels on Wednesday to Brazil, in his first trip as pope to Latin America, home to nearly half the world’s Catholics. He arrives at a time of paradox for the church there. With Catholicism in decline in Europe, the developing world is seen as the future of the church. Yet the church in Latin America faces many challenges – which Benedict is expected to address in his four days in Brazil.

headline: Bid for Hanson Considered
text: HeidelbergCement, the biggest concrete maker in Germany, said it might bid for Hanson, the world’s largest supplier of crushed rock, setting off a 20 percent gain in Hanson’s stock price.

headline: London luxury
text: Coming on the market in two months is perhaps the most state-of-the-art house to ever be built in central London.

headline: Swedish Steel Maker Acquiring Canadian Supplier of Oil Pipes
text: In announcement that took Canada’s financial industry by surprise, Ipsco, a leading Canadian supplier of steel pipes to the oil and gas industry, agreed to be acquired by a Swedish steel maker, SSAB Svenskt Stal, for $7.7 billion in cash, the two companies said on Thursday.

headline: Rosneft Buys Yukos Assets, Including Its Oil Refineries
text: Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, acquired 37 subsidiaries of the bankrupt Yukos oil company at an auction on Thursday, expanding Rosneft’s already large footprint in the industry.

headline: Paper Mill Makes Progress
text: The fate of the Paper Mill Playhouse, which has been struggling with a $2.8 million shortfall, is still very much up in the air, but the theater has been scrambling to raise money from every resource it can find.

headline: The Pre-Trial Limbo of the NatWest Three
text: Since their extradition from Britain in July, three London bankers – known as the NatWest three – have been living in a peculiar limbo, as they await trial in Houston his fall on charges stemming from the collapse of Enron.

headline: Ex-Governor Denies Approval of Payments to Conrad Black
text: Former Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois wrapped up three grueling days on the witness stand Thursday with an emotional denial that he had approved millions of dollars in payments now at the heart of a racketeering and fraud case against the media mogul Conrad M. Black.

headline: Big Names, Big Wallets, Big Cause
text: Even in charity, the titans of hedge funds and private equity do nothing small.

headline: For New BP Chief, Rusted Pipes and a Tarnished Image
text: Tony Hayward’s honeymoon is likely to be quite brief.

headline: Interactive Brokers Prices I.P.O.
text: Interactive Brokers Group late Thursday priced its initial public offering at $30.01 per share, near the high end of the expected range, raising roughly $1.2 billion.

headline: Deadline Looms for Bids on K.K.R.’s Primedia
text: The New York Post notes that Friday is the deadline for Henry Kravis to receive final offers in the wild auction for Primedia Enthusiast Group, a process that has gotten a lot more complicated now that two potential suitors — tabloid publisher American Media and the firm owned by billionaire supermarket mogul Ronald Burkle — are reportedly in merger talks of their own.

headline: Analyzing Love
text: Based on Daniel Menaker's well-received novel of the same title, "The Treatment" is a movie with its heart and head in the right place. Too bad its aesthetic sensibilities and technical coordinates are not as well situated. Directed by Oren Rudavsky, who wrote the intelligently streamlined screenplay with Daniel Saul Housman, the film pivots on a New Yorker, Jake Singer (Chris Eigeman), whose love affair with a newly widowed beauty, Allegra Marshall (Famke Janssen), functions in a curious, sometimes comically bewildering counterpart to his psychoanalysis with the self-described "last Freudian" Dr. Morales (Ian Holm).

headline: ABN Holds ‘Constructive’ Talks With RBS Group
text: A group led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group is in takeover discussions with ABN Amro Holding, after last week saying it may launch a $98 billion hostile bid for the Dutch bank.

headline: Westwood Mulling Sale, Report Says
text: Radio network Westwood One has tapped investment bank UBS to identify potential buyers in anticipation of putting itself on the block next month, The New York Post reported. Westwood One is apparently waiting for shareholder approval for its pending content syndication deal with CBS Radio, tentatively targeted for May 15, before it formalizes an auction.

headline: AMC Brings Curtain Down on I.P.O.
text: It was curtains for AMC Entertainment‘s market debut, as the theater chain’s owners yanked its planned $789-million initial public offering from the stock market Thursday rather than cut the proposed share price in response to tepid investor demand at its asking price.

headline: Qantas Buyout Comes Down to the Wire
text: Macquarie Bank and its partners said shareholders owning 36 percent of Qantas Airways, Australia’s largest airline, have agreed to their A$11.1 billion ($9.1 billion) takeover offer, due to expire Friday. The buyout will fail unless the group reaches 50 percent by 7 p.m. in Sydney Friday. The bidders held about 33 percent of the airline yesterday, they said in a statement.

headline: NBC And Citadel Get Ion Despite Opposition
text: Television broadcaster Ion Media Networks on Thursday approved a takeover offer from NBC Universal and hedge fund Citadel Investment Group, despite three opposing board members and threats from a dissident group of shareholders.

headline: From Scraps of Metal to Biking Medals
text: "A washing machine on wheels" is the derisive description officials of the World Cycling Association give to the revolutionary racing bike designed by the Scottish cyclist Graeme Obree (Jonny Lee Miller) in "The Flying Scotsman." In 1993 Mr. Obree broke the one-hour world record on his homemade contraption, built from scrap metal and washing-machine parts and nicknamed Old Faithful. The powers that be were not amused and frantically invented rules to try to disqualify him.

headline: Frengo Dials Up Funding
text: Fengo, a mobile social network, announced on Thursday that it has raised $5.7 million in its first round of venture capital financing, led by Trilogy Equity Partners. Other investors included Khosla Ventures and Index Ventures.

headline: Starbucks Chairman’s Two-Way Funding Bet
text: Starbucks chairman and founder Howard Schultz, through his venture capital firm, has made a strategic investment decision that is rare, if not unprecedented, The Red Herring reports. He put money into two companies with opposing missions: one that promotes so-called typosquatting, the buying of Internet domain names that closely resemble big brand names, and another that combats it.

headline: Milberg Weiss Lawyer Asks for Dismissal of Fraud Charges
text: A former partner in New York law firm Milberg Weiss & Bershad, accused by the government of paying illegal kickbacks to class-action clients, has asked a federal court in Los Angeles to dismiss the fraud charges against him. The motion could undermine much of the government’s case against Milberg Weiss, The Los Angeles Times noted.

headline: The Debates Within the Debate
text: May 4 - At the Republican debate, many of the running themes provided a window into the party's ideological ferment.

headline: End of a UBS Hedge Fund Is a Blow to Banker
text: UBS‘s announcement Thursday that it would shutter its hedge fund following losses at the unit was an embarrassment both for the bank and for John P. Costas, who gave up his post as chief executive of investment banking to run the hedge fund for the company.

headline: Clear Channel Board Rejects Sweetened Offer From Bidder
text: Clear Channel Communications, the nation’s largest radio broadcaster, said last night that its board had rejected a revised offer by two equity firms that had agreed to buy the company, but are now trying to keep the deal from falling through.

headline: Credit Suisse Banker Jailed in Trading on 9 Deals
text: Federal authorities arrested a Credit Suisse investment banker on Thursday and charged him with illegally leaking confidential information on nine deals, including the $45 billion buyout of the Texas energy giant TXU.

headline: Proposed Tax Levies, State Aid and STAR Rebates in New York School Districts
More Than Friends With Benefits
text: In "Race You to the Bottom," Russell Brown's enervated relationship drama, a pair of thoroughly unlikable 20-somethings explore the possibility of becoming more than friends with benefits. First, however, they must decide what to do about their pesky, live-in boyfriends.

headline: Paranoia in a New Age
text: This initially promising, ultimately irritating psychological thriller recreates the paranoia of the weeks after Sept. 11, when every jet seemed to be flying too low.

headline: CVC and PAI Launch Rival Bid for Altadis
text: CVC Capital Partners and PAI Partners offered 12.8 billion euros ($17.4 billion) for Altadis on Friday, topping Imperial Tobacco Group‘s bid for the Spanish maker of Gauloises cigarettes.

headline: EMI Says Bidders Are Circling
text: British music group EMI, home to Robbie Williams and Coldplay, said on Friday it had received a number of takeover approaches, following a report that private equity firm One Equity Partners had joined the list of suitors.

headline: Murdoch Speaks on Plans for the Journal
text: So what would Rupert Murdoch do if his $5 billion bid to buy Dow Jones comes to pass?

headline: Reuters Receives Takeover Approach
text: There’s another media megadeal in the air.

headline: Deadpan on Ice
text: This debut feature by the filmmaking team of Dominique Abel, Fiona Gordon and Bruno Romy earns two adjectives that rarely go together: breezy and bold. The film charts one woman's journey from dronelike suburban mom and fast-food manager to would-be Arctic explorer. It starts when the heroine, Fiona (Ms. Gordon), is trapped in a restaurant freezer overnight and realizes she enjoyed the experience. She subjects herself to increasingly severe endurance tests and becomes obsessed with images of icebergs, even carving one in her freezer at home (like Richard Dreyfuss creating Devils Tower from mashed potatoes in "Close Encounters of the Third Kind").

headline: Preparations for a Queen
text: In the West Wing, the talk was of negotiations with Syria, but the East Wing bustled with activity in anticipation of a state dinner for Queen Elizabeth II.

headline: 2008: The Reviews Are In, G.O.P. Edition
text: While the candidates were prepping for the debate, the staffs and surrogates were prepping for the debate about the debate that is the spin cycle.

headline: Of Jackals, Bigfoot and ‘Cavemen’
