text: The terrorist known as “Carlos the Jackal” will stand trial once again in France, a judge announced today. This time, he faces charges in attacks that killed 12 people from 1982 to 1983. A European news site reports that one of the three attacks allegedly targeted Jacques Chirac, who was then mayor of Paris. If he’s convicted, the punishment will be a moot point: Carlos is already serving a life sentence.

headline: Plan B – and Plan C
text: When our architects, Greg Huddy and Bill Harris, met with us to review preliminary sketches, they had three designs for us to consider. The first was a two-part house that Paul loved but that was large, expensive to build and, in my view, provided a little too much privacy.

headline: Republican Debate Redux
text: The wide-open nature of the campaign for the 2008 Republican presidential nomination is reinforced by the disparate reactions among conservative journalists and bloggers to last night’s debate.

headline: Wolfowitz Learns That Bosses Are Not All-Powerful
text: The boss is not all powerful, particularly at a proud institution where others have their own power bases.

headline: A Terrorist by Any Other Name …
text: Is Abu Ayyub al-Masri, the leader of Al Qaeda in Iraq, dead or alive?

headline: Comment Zone: On the Mayor’s Mind
text: Updated. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has wrapped up his weekly radio discussion with John Gambling on WABC. They started taking calls near the end — starting with a guy on a cellphone who said he was in (near?) the Holland Tunnel. Subject: cost of the mayor’s congestion pricing proposal. The second and last caller asked if Mr. Bloomberg would support an anti-war protest in the city. Mr. Bloomberg focused on safety and security issues in his reply.

headline: Defying the Laws of Political Science
text: Each party thinks its position on Iraq is a potential winner – at least at the moment.

headline: Damion Easley: Hit Man
text: It happens every spring: The Mets sign a second baseman in the off-season. He struggles early on. And then, because of injury, he slides into the starting role and delivers key hit after key hit. Last year, it was Jose Valentin. Everyone had given up hope on him after his miserable first six weeks. This time around, it is Damion Easley, who replaced the injured Valentin at second base.

headline: The Sharm el Sheikh Kabuki
text: As leaders from about 60 nations gathered at a conference in Sharm El-Sheikh, Egypt, on Iraq’s future, American and Iranian officials have been watched closely for any signs of direct dealings. Those signs have been trickling out all week in the careful language of diplomacy.

headline: A $1 Billion Vote of Confidence for Icahn
text: With the Motorola proxy showdown set for Monday, billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn appears to have a new ally. ClearBridge Advisors, a money manager owned by brokerage firm Legg Mason, said it would support his bid for a seat on the cellphone maker’s board — something the company has adamantly opposed in a series of increasingly hard-edged announcements. “Given recent events at the company, we believe it is in the best interest of all shareholders to have a new representative on the board,” ClearBridge said in a press release. The firm did not say which “events” it had in mind, but Motorola has been struggling mightly in the past few months. In March, it slashed its revenue forecasts announced a management shake-up.

headline: The 8th Fastest Walkers in the World
text: For most out-of-towners fond of a porch swing, a beach blanket or a wandering Sunday stroll, the phrase “New York Minute” has come to mean a peculiarly local delirium of impatience that results in the shrinking of time itself.

headline: Listening in on Customer Service
text: You’re about to meet a guy who’s already had two killer ideas.

headline: Water Rate Increase: A Tax or Not?
text: John Gambling, who plays host to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg every Friday on his WABC talk show, said today that City Council members have called the proposed water rate increase “just another tax.” What did the mayor think of that? Here’s a rough transcript of Mr. Bloomberg’s reply:

headline: The Drunken Father
text: He planted a vineyard; and he drank of the wine, and became drunk, and lay uncovered in his tent. And Taylor, 16, the daughter of Hasselhoff, who once starred on “Baywatch,” saw the drunken nakedness of her father.

headline: A Longer, Better Life
text: Author Sara Davidson talks to two medical scientists about how the body ages and the research on trying to extend our healthy life span.

headline: Con Ed Seeks to Raise Electricity Rates
text: Consolidated Edison today filed an application with the New York State Public Service Commission to raise electricity rates. Starting next April, the typical residential customer would pay 17 percent more, while the typical business would pay 10.7 percent more.

headline: Can Dow Jones’s Board ‘Just Say No’?
text: Rupert Murdoch’s bombshell $5 billion bid for Dow Jones has a lot of legal types talking make-up. More specifically, they’re talking about Revlon, the subject of a 1985 ruling that helped define a corporate board’s duties when a company is up for sale. Dow Jones, like The New York Times Company and the Washington Post Company, has a dual-class share structure that gives majority voting power to its controlling family and insulates it from the whims of Wall Street. But the Bancroft family’s initial resistance to News Corp.’s overture raises questions. What are the board’s responsibilities when a controlling family rejects offers that minority shareholders would jump at? In particular, how do the so-called Revlon duties play into these situations?

headline: Two Years Later, an Ethics Fine
text: About two years ago, the state’s Lobbying Commission settled with Syracuse University over gifts the school had made to various state officials with which it did business. One of those officials was Jeffrey Lovell, at the time a senior policy adviser to then-Gov. George E. Pataki, now an aide to Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, both of them Republicans.

headline: T Style | Living
text: Cover shoot video for the T Style Living Spring 2007 issue.

headline: Drought Brings About a Political Storm
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s May 4 column, “The Aussie ‘Big Dry.'”

headline: A Long, Long Lull at Correspondent’s Dinner
text: Readers respond to Frank Rich’s Apr. 29 column, “All the President’s Press.”

headline: Commander Guy, Redux
text: News flash from the White House: President Bush is not “the commander guy” after all.

headline: The ‘Guidelines on Our Integrity’ from 1999 Are Worth a Look
text: The journalistic standards spelled out in The Times’s 1999 “Guidelines on Our Integrity” are a supplement to the paper’s “Ethical Journalism” handbook of 2004, which is a more complete compilation of ethics rules for news staffers. I think readers may find that the specificity of the 1999 guidelines makes them particularly interesting.

headline: Calm Before D.C. Madam Report, and After
text: [Update | 8:56 AM ET No storm, just calm. No new high-profile names were dropped in a TV interview with a woman accused of running a Washington-area prostitution ring, The Associated Press reported.]

headline: Mayor Calls for Prompt Action on PlaNYC
text: Calling for quick action on enabling legislation for his long-range growth plan for the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today invoked the ill-fated past of the Second Avenue Subway and other major transit projects that did not survive shifts in the city’s political and financial winds.

headline: EN NW PKG RADIO SEGO SARKO
text: EN NW PKG RADIO SEGO SARKO

headline: EN NW PKG DEBAT ADAPT V2
text: EN NW PKG DEBAT ADAPT V2

headline: Mortgages Get Tight
text: Mortgages are suddenly hard to get. And that is why those hoping that the real estate decline is almost over should not take comfort from the fact that mortgage loan applications are strong.

headline: Save Darfur — Somewhere Else
text: I had an interesting note from a woman in Boulder named Rachel who put up a green “Save Darfur” sign on her lawn. Her home-owner association has ordered her to take it down. She sent out an open letter:

headline: Microsoft in Early Talks With Yahoo
text: Microsoft and Yahoo are in talks about a joint venture or some other form of cooperation, according to people briefed on the talks. The discussions are part of a continuing dialogue that the two companies have been holding for more than a year, but are still in preliminary stages, these people say.

headline: Vows: Jennifer and Gregory
text: Jennifer Kohns and Gregory Rathe speak of meeting on motorcycle night at a Chelsea bar, and then riding in a direct line to the altar.

headline: Democrats’ War Release Wars
text: E-mail is cheap and instantaneous, meaning we get deluged with messages about the candidates’ thoughts on just about everything — especially each other. E-mail has become the weapon of choice in the war to win over the netroots and anti-war grassroots.

headline: Manufacturers and Certified Cars
text: Certified used cars have become popular with buyers over the past five years, offering reassurance from manufacturers that consumers won’t get stuck with a lemon. But Christopher Jensen, who wrote about certified pre-owned programs for The Times, found some consumers who discovered that certification did not protect them entirely.

headline: Elephant (Ears) in the Room
text: How must it feel to drive for Honda’s Formula One team? First of all, you’re saddled with the gnarliest livery on the grid, which wouldn’t matter so much if it were fast.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III learns to sell hot dogs at a New York Mets game.

headline: American Album: Spell Utah
text: Kunal Sah, 13, hopes that winning the Scripps National Spelling Bee will bring attention to the plight of his parents, who were deported to India.

headline: Why the Silence from Goldilocks?
text: My colleague Dennis Overbye has started working out the logistics of getting to Gliese 581c, the Goldilocks planet (not too hot, not too cold) that’s the best prospect yet for extraterrestrial life. But could we expect to find intelligent beings there? Since we haven’t detected any electronic signs of life from that neighborhood, are the prospects grim of finding anyone at home?

headline: Thompson, Not Yet a Candidate, Outlines Views
text: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., May 4 — Former Senator Fred Thompson, whose possible bid for the Republican nomination for president could radically alter an already wide open race for the White House, gave a preview of what his candidacy might look like at a speech before a prominent party organization here late Friday night.

headline: How Slow Can It Go?
text: Last week, when the government reported that the economy had slowed to a crawl in the first quarter of the year, any lingering hope for robust employment growth was tempered accordingly. But no one was quite prepared for a job report as weak as the one released yesterday. Only 88,000 jobs were created in April, the smallest gain in nearly two and half years and a sharp deceleration from job growth in the recent past.

headline: Out of Static and Bleeps Can Come, Yes, Melodies
text: Annie Gosfield writes music that ranges from improvisatory and serendipitous to carefully notated. But running through much of her work is a fascination with noise. Her pieces are often about the ways that noise can be manipulated and put to musical use. Sometimes they are about the reverse: the way purely musical sounds can be made into noise, and then turned to expressive use.

headline: Bank of America Files Suit Over Deal to Buy LaSalle
text: Bank of America asked a federal court yesterday to prevent the Dutch bank ABN Amro from selling its Chicago subsidiary, LaSalle Bank, to rival bidders after its $21 billion acquisition of LaSalle was halted by a Dutch court.

headline: Keeping Faith in a Venture Built on Faith
text: “I found the Chapter 11 period exhilarating,” Steven Waldman was saying the other day.

headline: Reuters Approached About a Takeover
text: LONDON, May 4 — Reuters, the 156-year-old news agency and the world’s largest publicly traded provider of financial data, has been approached by the Thomson Corporation of Canada about a takeover, a person close to the situation said today.

headline: The French Abroad Get a Day’s Head Start in Voting
text: Jean Karoubi, a French hedge fund investor who has lived in New York since 1977, plans to spend much of the today at home, “doing my due diligence,” he says. He is going to read a ream or two of recent coverage of the French presidential campaign and, more importantly, telephone a number of friends in Paris in search of insight.

headline: Scottish Nationalists Upset Labor in Elections
text: LONDON, May 4 — In a historic reversal, the separatist Scottish National Party emerged Friday as the biggest political grouping in Scotland, ending 50 years of dominance there by the governing Labor Party and redrawing Britain’s political landscape.

headline: Kentucky Derby Field Screened for Blood-Doping Agent
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4  The 20 horses set to run in Saturday’s Kentucky Derby were tested for the performance-enhancing drug erythropoietin Wednesday, the first surprise prerace test in the Derby’s history.

headline: Riverside Takes On the Task of Rebuilding a Church
text: Around the grand Gothic edifice of Riverside Church in Manhattan, a structure designed to evoke authority and permanence, there rises a scaffolding of tube pipes and raw boards. Its purpose is to allow workers to repoint the building’s stone facade, but it serves also as a handy metaphor for the paradox of Riverside, the capital of a theological movement that has been slowly deteriorating.

headline: Murdoch, Reuters and Scandal. Wait, We’re Not Finished.
text: Rupert Murdoch was the man in the news this week as word got out that he wanted to buy Dow Jones & Company.

headline: A Split Emerges as Conservatives Discuss Darwin
text: Evolution has long generated bitter fights between the left and the right about whether God or science better explains the origins of life. But now a dispute has cropped up within conservative circles, not over science, but over political ideology: Does Darwinian theory undermine conservative notions of religion and morality or does it actually support conservative philosophy?

headline: Construction Accident Kills Laborer at School
text: A day laborer from Ecuador was killed yesterday when an eight-foot-deep trench collapsed at a Brooklyn elementary school, burying him under hundreds of cubic yards of dirt, officials and his employer said.

headline: Mayhem on the Screen (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: BMW Oracle Wins Tight Boat Race
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 4  Arms folded, Larry Ellison looked satisfied, at least for the moment, as he stood on the deck of USA 98 and gazed through his dark glasses at the Italian boat that had not found a way to catch him and his BMW Oracle Racing team.

headline: Prominent Education Reformer to Lead New Orleans Schools
text: NEW ORLEANS, May 4 — Louisiana on Friday picked one of the nation’s most prominent education reformers to run the troubled school district of New Orleans, as schools here continue to grapple with physical and administrative damage from Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Ukraine’s Quarreling Leaders Agree on Early Elections
text: MOSCOW, May 4 — Ukraine’s warring president and prime minister reached an agreement on Friday to hold early parliamentary elections, possibly ending a monthlong political standoff in the former Soviet state but leaving some crucial details unresolved.

headline: N.Y. Schools Seek Higher Taxes Despite Extra Aid
text: John Caruana, an electrician, has been startled by how fast the taxes in his suburban community of North Massapequa have risen since he moved into his small Cape Cod home six years ago with his wife and their three children.

headline: Carlos the Jackal to Be Tried for Role in 4 Bombing Attacks in ’80s
text: PARIS, May 4 — The cold-war-era terrorist known as Carlos the Jackal, already serving a life sentence, will be tried in connection with four bombing attacks that killed 11 people and wounded almost 200 in France in 1982 and 1983.

headline: Judge Orders Release of Police Files on Convention, Pending a Stay to Appeal
text: A federal judge yesterday ordered the New York Police Department to release 600 pages of secret documents related to its security preparations for the Republican National Convention in 2004, but he gave the city a 10-day stay to file an appeal.

headline: Paper Jam at FedEx Kinko’s
text: DALLAS — Tag along and marvel as Kenneth A. May, the chief executive of FedEx Kinko’s, works a roomful of employees.

headline: In French Bid, Immigrant’s Son Battles Reputation as Anti-Immigrant
text: PARIS, May 4 — The possible next president of France is the son of an immigrant with a very un-French name who has done as much, if not more, than any other French official to improve the status of minorities.

headline: Venezuela: A Chill Follows Threat by Chávez
text: Financial markets reacted with concern to a threat by President Hugo Chávez to nationalize the banking system. Mr. Chávez said Thursday that banks should finance industry at a low cost. “If banks don’t agree with this, it’s better that they go, that they turn over the banks to me, that we nationalize them and get all the banks to work for the development of the country and not to speculate and produce huge profits,” Mr. Chávez said. Venezuela’s currency, the bolívar, fell more than 3 percent in unregulated trading to about 3,950 to the dollar, traders said, and investors sold government bonds amid fears that a state takeover of banks could weaken the economy.

headline: The Little Dog Has His Day
text: Miami Beach

headline: First Response to Corzine’s Crash: ‘V.I.P.! Everyone Out Here Now!’
text: TRENTON, May 4 — Shortly before 6 p.m. on April 12, a state police dispatcher assigned to the Garden State Parkway got a frantic call about a major car accident north of the Atlantic City Expressway. “V.I.P.!” came the urgent female voice. “Everyone out here now!”

text: Editors’ Note

headline: Easley Is Saving His Best (and the Mets) for Last
text: PHOENIX, May 4 —Damion Easley’s family left Chase Field a few innings before the end of Thursday’s game. It was getting late, and his four children had to get up early for school the next morning.

headline: Small Businesses’ Premiums Soar After Illness
text: To understand the challenges of insuring the health of the nation’s work force, consider Varney’s Book Store.

headline: Nine Ways to Elect a President
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Evgeny Kissin Warms Up, and He Keeps on Cooking
text: There is a sense of breathless anticipation before some concerts at Carnegie Hall, with people seeking and selling tickets amid the multilingual crowds milling outside. Evgeny Kissin, the Russian pianist, lived up to that excitement at his Carnegie appearance on Thursday night, but mostly after the scheduled program — when he played a marathon 12 encores.

headline: Challenging Saudi Arabia’s Powerful, One Caller at a Time
text: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia

headline: Looking Back at 6 Decades of Subway Worker Deaths
text: One tripped and fell on the third rail. One was walking along an elevated track when a board gave way and he fell to his death. One, walking on the tracks without carrying a light, was run over by a train.

headline: For Queen and First Lady, Bush Will Try White Tie
text: WASHINGTON, May 4 — How does George W. Bush, a towel-snapping Texan who puts his feet on the coffee table, drinks water straight from the bottle and was once caught on tape talking with food in his mouth prepare for a state dinner with the queen?

headline: New Twists and New Bitterness in Suit Over Montana Resort
text: HELENA, Mont., May 4 — Greg LeMond, the champion cyclist who won the Tour de France three times, may have thought his retirement would be quiet and comfortable. But judging from this week’s latest twist in a lawsuit he originally filed last year, Mr. LeMond will be locked in a battle for the edge yet again.

headline: Being Green Doesn’t Mean Buying More
text: IT has never been so trendy to be green. By that I don’t mean that suddenly everyone is installing solar panels at home or making a commitment to reduce, reuse and recycle as many goods as possible. Now you can think of yourself as an environmental champion just by going shopping.

headline: Sabres Steal Victory From Rangers
text: BUFFALO, May 4 — For a while, the Rangers’ locker room stayed nearly empty, except for goalie Henrik Lundqvist, who was encircled by reporters and photographers. He was talking quietly, a blank look on his face, describing the Rangers’ stunning loss to Buffalo on Friday night.

headline: A Beautiful Mine
text: Rowdy, Ky.

headline: Called, Increasingly, to a Somber Duty: Last Respects for the Military’s Dead
text: A gray Dodge Caravan with government plates stopped in a section of St. Raymond’s Cemetery in the Bronx on Tuesday and three young soldiers in dress blue uniforms stepped out. Specialist Rebecca Santana, 23, carried a black case holding a ceremonial bugle. Staff Sgt. Noel Rodriguez, 26, and Specialist Ruben Martinez, 23, walked toward a mound of fresh earth amid narrow rows of well-tended graves. The three were there to serve as official Army representatives at the funeral of a World War II veteran.

headline: Many Detainees at Guantánamo Rebuff Lawyers
text: Many of the detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, are no longer cooperating with their lawyers, adding a largely invisible struggle between the lawyers and their own clients to the legal battle over the Bush administration’s detention policies.

headline: Date Set for Appeal of Jones Suspension
text: Pacman Jones, the troubled Tennessee cornerback, will appeal his season-long suspension from the National Football League on Friday, when he will meet with Commissioner Roger Goodell.

headline: City to Change Taxi Rules After Inquiry Into Bidding
text: New York City will rewrite the rules governing how it auctions off valuable taxi licenses after concerns of collusion were raised in some of the latest auctions, city officials said yesterday.

headline: For the Record
text: A chart yesterday about changes in the dates of Democratic primaries and caucuses from 2004 to 2008 misidentified the time frame for the selection of the District of Columbia’s delegates to the party’s nominating convention. While Washington does hold a primary before the Jan. 14 caucuses in Iowa, the results are nonbinding; the actual delegate selection will not take place until February.

headline: Changing the Cast but Keeping the Quality
text: The Ohio-born tenor Lawrence Brownlee is no newcomer to big-time opera. Last season he sang the role of Count Almaviva in Rossini’s “Barbiere di Siviglia” for his debut at La Scala in Milan.

headline: For the Record
text: A front-page article on April 22 about Russian news coverage misstated the date that a state television network, Rossiya TV, led its newscast with a report about President Vladimir V. Putin’s attending a martial arts competition with the Belgian actor Jean-Claude Van Damme. It was Sunday, April 15, not Saturday, April 14, though an earlier edition of Rossiya’s newscast in St. Petersburg did report on the event that Saturday.

headline: Job Growth Was Slower Last Month
text: Businesses significantly pared back hiring last month, a sign that the job market may be starting to feel the drag of slower economic growth.

headline: Leadership Woes at the World Bank (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Many of the Self-Employed Are Simply on Their Own
text: The small businesses that struggle the most with health insurance may be the smallest of all: those with only one employee.

headline: Jackson Emerges as the Unlikely Leader of the Warriors’ Improbable Run
text: OAKLAND, Calif., May 4  By all rights, Golden State’s Stephen Jackson should have been ejected with 4 minutes 26 seconds left in the third quarter of Game 6.

headline: Fehr Is Standing Strong Against a Raging Tide
text: I don’t know Donald Fehr. Before an hour-long interview in his office Thursday, my only contact with him had been a question at a news conference, or hearing sound bites on TV. I was familiar with his reputation as a ferocious negotiator.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on April 5 about details of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s first New York State budget included erroneous information from a Spitzer aide about the position of fish pathologist for the Department of Environmental Conservation. (The error first appeared on Feb. 5 in the Empire Zone column, about Mr. Spitzer’s first month in office.) The budget adds one position to those that already exist; the fish pathologist to be hired will not in fact be the state’s first.

headline: Can This Patient Be Saved?
text: As a surgeon, I’ve seen some pretty large tumors. I’ve excised fist-size thyroid cancers from people’s necks and abdominal masses bigger than your head. When I do, this is what almost invariably happens: the anesthesiologist puts the patient to sleep, the nurse unsnaps the gown, everyone takes a sharp breath, and someone blurts out, “How could someone let that thing get so huge?”

headline: Winning Goal Comes From Unlikely Source
text: BUFFALO, May 4 — Nobody saw Sabres forward Maxim Afinogenov’s star turn coming Friday night. Not Rangers goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, who was screened on Afinogenov’s game-winning shot in overtime, and certainly not the season-ticket holders in the HSBC Arena sellout crowd who had witnessed Afinogenov’s miserable play here in the first two games of the Eastern Conference semifinal series.

headline: What’s on Saturday Night
text: 9 P.M. (Hallmark) A STRANGER’S HEART (2007) Bring out the tissues. Billed by Hallmark as a “touching story about a second chance at life ... and love,” this feel-good weepy stars Samantha Mathis (above, far left, with Mary Matilyn Mouser) as a magazine reporter who receives a long-awaited heart transplant, only to find that she can’t stop dreaming about a young girl she has never met. Turns out that another heart recipient (Peter Dobson) has the same dreams. Which leads them to ask, “Who is the girl, and what’s her connection to us?” Bet you can guess.

headline: Ida R. Hoos Is Dead at 94; a Critic of Systems Analysis
text: Ida R. Hoos, a prominent critic of assessing technology solely on the basis of mathematical models that failed to take account of societal factors, died on April 24 in Boston. She was 94 and lived in Brookline, Mass.

headline: Many Detainees at Guantánamo Rebuff Lawyers
text: Many of the detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, are no longer cooperating with their lawyers, adding a largely invisible struggle between the lawyers and their own clients to the legal battle over the Bush administration’s detention policies.

headline: On Bulls, Wallace Shows Worth
text: Ben Wallace has a $60 million contract and $15 shoes.

headline: A Young Saxophonist in Good Post-Bop Company
text: Joel Frahm, who has been playing at Sweet Rhythm this week, has established an identity over the last decade as a post-bop tenor saxophonist with a deft and assertive command. He has sharpened his skills alongside members of his peer group, like the singer Jane Monheit and the drummer Matt Wilson. A few years ago he recorded an album of duets with Brad Mehldau, a pianist with a much higher profile, but it was a meeting of equals, and not just because the two musicians had met in their teens.

headline: PBS Supports Ken Burns Against Latinos’ Complaints
text: Public broadcasting executives are defending the right of the filmmaker Ken Burns to tell the history of World War II as he sees fit, in the face of escalating complaints and veiled threats of a boycott from Latinos who say his coming PBS documentary “The War” slights Hispanics’ contributions to the war effort.

headline: Brooklyn School Is Dropped as Site of Arabic Academy
text: The city’s Department of Education abandoned plans yesterday to place the Khalil Gibran International Academy, a fledgling public school that is to be devoted to the study of the Arabic language and culture, in the same building in Park Slope, Brooklyn, that houses Public School 282.

headline: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about the military’s investigation of claims that civilians were killed or wounded by recent American air strikes in Afghanistan misspelled the surname of the top American commander there, who said he is reviewing the incident. He is Gen. Dan K. McNeill, not McNeil.

headline: Woods and Singh Will Meet on First Tee in Last Group
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 4 — Tiger Woods and Vijay Singh are famous for hoarding trophies and burning calories, with each golfer looking for new and interesting ways to do each.

headline: Somehow, Plea for Peace Is a Worry
text: In January 2004, the Police Department’s Intelligence Division, getting ready for the Republican National Convention, found an open letter written by one Jerry Goralnick, who describes himself as a “pacifist anarchist.” It was not a great feat of spy work: Mr. Goralnick had posted his letter in plain sight on the Internet.

headline: Maine Upstages Johnson, and Mets Weather a Scare
text: PHOENIX, May 4 — One of the best starters in the major leagues this season pitched Friday night at Chase Field. Oh, and Randy Johnson pitched, too.

headline: Yanks Pound Out 16 Hits, but Pitchers Give Up More
text: The Yankees’ weekend began with Carl Pavano’s locker vacant, maybe for a day, maybe for longer, maybe forever. Pavano, the chronically injured right-handed starting pitcher, was off to see a doctor about possible elbow surgery.

headline: Weingarten to Unveil Plan to Aid Schools That Falter
text: The president of the New York City teachers’ union, in a speech today, is expected to propose initiatives to attract educators to work in some of the city’s lowest-performing schools, including a reduced course load so teachers can focus on fewer students, and extra pay for teachers who take on special projects like building a parent participation program or developing curriculum units.

headline: Equity Firms Bid for European Tobacco Company
text: MADRID, May 4 — Two private equity groups, CVC Capital Partners and PAI Partners, have made a bid of 12.8 billion euros ($17.42 billion) for Altadis, the maker of Gauloises cigarettes, trumping an earlier offer from Imperial Tobacco of Britain and setting the stage for a bidding war.

headline: Hedging Hedge Funds
text: CAN you hedge a hedge fund?

text: To the Editor:

headline: Nets Advance and Adjust Their Travel Plans
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 4 — Moments after scoring the go-ahead basket on a driving spin move, the Nets’ Richard Jefferson contorted his body in midair again to intercept a pass intended for the Raptors’ Andrea Bargnani, setting off a buzz that had Continental Arena shaking as it rarely has this season.

headline: Every Day, Trainer Has Fight of His Life
text: LAS VEGAS, May 4 — Freddie Roach had an eight-year career as a boxer, mostly as a lightweight, but it was not until two years after he retired, in 1988, that he started feeling the symptoms of Parkinson’s syndrome.

headline: Names Not Worth Mentioning, ABC Decides in Escort Case
text: WASHINGTON, May 4 — In what had become a highly anticipated story about an escort service operating in the capital for the last 13 years, ABC News reported Friday night that the business catered to many men throughout the federal government.

text: To the Editor:

text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,350 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Anglican Church Intercedes as an Episcopal Rift Widens
text: WASHINGTON, May 4 — The archbishop of Canterbury, leader of the worldwide Anglican Communion, has waded into a gathering dispute over efforts by conservative congregations in this country to break away from the Episcopal Church.

headline: Corzine to Resume Duties as Governor
text: HOBOKEN, N.J., May 5 — Gov. Jon S. Corzine plans to take the reins of power again on Monday, more than three weeks after he suffered serious injuries in a car accident on the Garden State Parkway, his spokesman said today.

headline: The Warming Challenge
text: Yesterday’s report on global warming from the world’s most authoritative voice on climate change asserts that significant progress toward stabilizing and reducing global warming emissions can be achieved at a relatively low cost using known technologies. This is a hugely important message to policy makers everywhere, not least those in the United States Congress. Many of them have been paralyzed by fears — assiduously cultivated by the Bush administration — that a full-scale attack on climate change could cripple the economy.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about the tone Rudolph W. Giuliani has taken in political debates misstated the year he became mayor of New York. It was 1994, not 1993.

headline: What Should a Textbook Cost? Do the Math (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Democrats’ Proposals Complicate Deal on Iraq Bill
text: WASHINGTON, May 4 — The aggressive attempts by Democratic presidential hopefuls to shape the war debate are threatening to complicate Congressional efforts to reach a deal on the Iraq spending bill, as the candidates’ calls for accelerating an end to the conflict compete with efforts by legislative leaders to extend financing for the war.

headline: Zambia: Ex-President Told to Repay Stolen Millions
text: A British judge delivered what some experts called a signal verdict against African corruption, ordering the former Zambian president Frederick Chiluba, left, and 19 others to return at least $46 million it said they had stolen while in power in the 1990s and early this decade. The London judge, Peter Smith, ruled that Mr. Chiluba, in power from 1991 to 2001, “was uniquely positioned to stop corruption” in government, but that he elected instead to join in it. Zambia’s government sued in London because it alleged that Mr. Chiluba and his associates had bought assets in Britain and elsewhere in Europe. Mr. Chiluba said in a statement that he did not recognize a British court’s authority in Zambian issues, arguing that the case circumvented Zambia’s justice system. Other African experts said the verdict, the first against a current or former head of state, could set an anticorruption precedent.

headline: Hawking Hot Dogs: Some Are All-Stars and Then There’s ...
text: I HOPPED off the No. 7 subway train at Shea Stadium trying to transform my native Texas twang into Queens-accented English. It was shortly before 11 a.m. on a Saturday in April, about 55 degrees with a chilly northwest wind. The New York Mets were warming up to play the Washington Nationals at 1 p.m., and I was warming up to sell a food item as famously American as baseball and apple pie.

headline: Surprising Finding in Capital Gains Study
text: Capital gains are the most highly concentrated form of income, with just 10,000 or so taxpayers earning a third of all profits from selling investments and only 3 percent of gains going to people who make less than about $50,000.

headline: A Violinist to Listen to, Maybe After a Download
text: One question is sure to arise in any interview with the Dutch violinist Janine Jansen: What’s on your iPod? Readers are presumed to be curious about what musicians listen to during their downtime.

headline: Yankees and Red Sox May Open 2008 in Asia
text: The Yankees and the Boston Red Sox extended their rivalry all the way to Asia in November, when the Red Sox beat the Yankees in their bid to sign the star Japanese pitcher Daisuke Matsuzaka. Next March, Japanese baseball fans could experience the rivalry up close.

headline: Foreign Stars Top M.L.S. Salary Table
text: The Mexican striker Cuauhtémoc Blanco is second only to David Beckham in pay in Major League Soccer, according to the M.L.S. Players Association, which posted a list of players’ salaries on its Web site on Friday.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a picture on the cover of Arts & Leisure this weekend of the dancer Aesha Ash, with an article about the small number of black ballerinas in classical troupes, appeared in mirror image.

headline: U.S. Offers Modest Goals for Israelis and Palestinians to Pursue
text: JERUSALEM, May 4  The United States, seeking doggedly to push along improvements in relations between Israel and the Palestinians, has proposed to both sides a set of modest goals for easing Palestinian travel and bolstering Israeli security.

headline: Proposed Media Deals Signal Upheavals in Financial News
text: The future of financial news may lie in its global reach, supplied by media giants and distributed digitally. If so, there is still the question of which media giants will thrive.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Official’s Aid to Defendant in Boy’s Death Is Criticized
text: Members of a Latino advocacy group and an uncle of a seventh grader who died on March 24 after being struck on the head by a classmate criticized Queens Borough President Helen M. Marshall yesterday for her public show of support for the boy accused of hitting the seventh grader.

headline: How Clean Is Your Carbon Credit?
text: CARBON credits are advertised as a way for polluters to offset the greenhouse gases they produce. Just write a check, and someone else will reduce his emissions, so you can keep driving your Hummer or operating your coal-burning power plant without guilt.

headline: Juggling Several Balls in Real Estate
text: As Gilbert and Sullivan might sing, he is the very model of a modern chief executive. Brett White, who became chief executive of CB Richard Ellis in 2005 — about a year after the company went public for the second time — is tall and rangy, with a broad smile. But looks aside, he has brought the international commercial real estate firm to its present success by following a plan made in 1991.

headline: Do-It-Yourself Eyeglass Shopping on the Internet
text: AN eyeglass frame is little more than bits of plastic and some metal. It is not very high-tech, although frames should be designed and manufactured with precision.

headline: Going Where the Sharks Meet to Eat
text: F. Murray Abraham’s glinty-eyed grandpa persona is perfect for the voice-over of “Sharkland,” the installment of “Nature” that appears tomorrow on PBS. He conjures the dangers of the deep as if for a child on the brink of sleep: he plays nearly every line like Peter Ustinov narrating “Peter and the Wolf”: “Well, Peter, what if you hadn’t caught the wolf? What then?”

headline: Trust in Paper
text: Political experts this week were focused on how the Florida Legislature has advanced its presidential primary to a very early date: Jan. 29, 2008. But the real news, tucked into that same legislation, is that by next summer Floridians should be a lot more confident that whenever they vote, their votes will finally be counted correctly.

headline: Tax to Pay for Health Plan in Illinois Faces Resistance
text: CHICAGO, May 4  Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, a second-term Democrat, decided months ago to push a new health care initiative that would be among the most comprehensive in the country. It would offer not only insurance to everyone in Illinois, but also wellness training, special attention to chronic disease and streamlined administration.

headline: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Thursday about Rupert Murdoch’s strategy to acquire Dow Jones & Company, the parent of The Wall Street Journal, misidentified the university where Lou Ureneck, who discussed the implications of the bid, is chairman of the journalism department. It is Boston University, not Boston College.

headline: Students May Have Paid Cash to Change Grades, College Says
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4  Prosecutors in California are investigating accusations that dozens of students paid hundreds of dollars to have grades changed at a Bay Area community college, college officials say.

headline: Three Wounded in Bronx Shooting
text: Three men were wounded, two of them critically, during a shooting last night in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx, the police said.

headline: Film’s Wall Street Predator to Make a Comeback
text: LOS ANGELES, May 4 — Greed is still good.

headline: Education Councils (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brazil Overrides Merck Patent on AIDS Drug
text: The government, whose spending on AIDS drugs has skyrocketed as more patients have needed costly, patented medicines, overrode the patent held by the pharmaceutical company Merck on the antiretroviral drug efavirenz. The cost of Merck’s drugs has been $580 annually per patient. Brazil said the company had offered a 30 percent discount, but the government opted instead to buy the generic version from India for less than $170. For years, Brazil has considered exercising its rights under international trade rules to make or import generic versions of patented AIDS drugs, but has until now backed away, fearing trade retaliation from the United States. For more than a decade, Brazil has provided universal free access to drug treatment for people with AIDS. Almost one in four patients in Brazil are now taking efavirenz. With the new price, Brazil estimates that it will save $237 million on efavirenz by 2012 when the patent expires. Thailand, which also has an ambitious AIDS treatment program, overrode Merck’s patent on the same drug in November.

headline: U.S. Forces Break Up Arms Smuggling Ring in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, May 4 — American soldiers broke up a weapons smuggling ring on Friday in Baghdad, detaining 16 men who were accused of procuring powerful, armor-piercing bombs and other arms from Iran, the American military said.

headline: Con Ed Seeks to Increase Electric Rates by Up to 17%
text: Consolidated Edison asked state regulators for permission yesterday to substantially raise electricity rates next April  by 17 percent for a typical residential customer and by 10.7 percent for a typical business.

headline: U.S. Now Reaching Out to Those It Shunned
text: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, May 4  After two days of talks aimed at building an international strategy to help bring peace and stability to Iraq, little changed in what many here saw as the crucial factor: relations between Iran and the United States.

headline: Bridle Path in the Park (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kidd Tips Cap to Warriors and Hopes to Match Them
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 4 — Jason Kidd has already received text messages from longtime friends from the Bay Area with an overzealous dream — to see the Nets and the Golden State Warriors face each other in the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Reuters Approached About a Takeover
text: LONDON, May 4 — Reuters, the world’s largest publicly traded provider of financial data, has been approached by the Thomson Corporation of Canada about a takeover, two people close to the situation said today.

headline: Baseball’s Steroid Panel Asks Active Players to Appear
text: The chairman of the special commission set up to examine the use of performance-enhancing drugs in Major League Baseball said for the first time yesterday that he had asked a number of active players to appear before the commission, a move that represents a major turning point in the yearlong investigation.

headline: Iranian Tells Pope of ‘Deep’ Wounds
text: ROME, May 4  Pope Benedict XVI met Friday with Iran’s former president, Mohammad Khatami, who spoke earlier here about the “very deep” wounds between Muslims and Christians.

headline: The High Country Is Ready for Its Close-Up
text: A documentary called “Steep,” which premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival, is the first ski film to use Cablecam technology, the system that allows cameras to swoop over quarterbacks in N.F.L. telecasts.

headline: The New Modern Woman, Ambitious and Feeble
text: It’s time to play the blame game.

headline: Lamoriello Won’t Stay On as Coach
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J., May 4 — Lou Lamoriello, the Devils’ chief executive, president, general manager and interim coach, indicated Friday that he planned to hire another coach after the end of the season, which may come as early as Saturday.

headline: Education Dept. Starts Inquiry Into Possible Loan Conflicts
text: The inspector general of the federal Education Department has opened an investigation into potential conflicts of interest at the agency that may have led to what lawmakers have characterized as lax oversight of the student loan industry.

headline: Inside One Man’s World, Confusion and Physicality
text: At the beginning of the oddly titled “CYP17,” a solo by the Canadian choreographer André Gingras, a man (the superb Kenneth Flak) sits on a chair in the middle of a brilliant, all-white space. Wearing only shiny white briefs, he watches, puzzled and frustrated, as his limbs lash and jerk away from him, independent of his volition and knowledge, in a kind of Tourette’s Syndrome.

headline: Unearthing Real History in the Capital
text: If there’s one figure anxious Washingtonians might consider saluting with a moment of pained silence this week it is Mary Ann Hall, a young entrepreneur who caught the go-go wave of the Civil War when she built and managed one of Washington’s finest bordellos. It was erected a few blocks down from the bustling Capitol, in easier days of righteousness. Then, “prostitute” was an occupation on census lists, and the city’s lobbying arts more routinely extended to sexual quid pro quos. Ms. Hall ran a classic “parlor house,” with Brussels carpets and red plush furniture. It was so fine — “upper ten,” by the Zagat-like ratings of Victoriana — that it was pronounced the best among the 450 brothels the Army provost marshal cataloged like neighborhood boîtes.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: A front-page article on Wednesday about an academic study that detected a racial bias in the foul calls of referees in the National Basketball Association noted that The New York Times had asked three independent experts to review the study and materials from a subsequent N.B.A. study that detected no bias.

headline: Contributors on YouTube May Share Advertising Revenue
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4  Some of the amateur video producers who put clips on YouTube are turning pro.

headline: Big Oil in Tiny Cambodia: The Burden of New Wealth
text: SIHANOUKVILLE, Cambodia, April 27 — Still clawing its way out of the ruins of its brutal past, Cambodia has come face to face with an extraordinary new future: It seems to have struck oil.

headline: Bail Denied for Banker Held for Illegal Trades
text: A former Credit Suisse banker accused of running a $7.5 million insider trading ring from April 2006 until this February was denied bail yesterday at a hearing in federal magistrate court in Manhattan.

headline: The Republican Look (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Underground Veteran Resurfaces in a Basement
text: “I’ve always felt I belonged on the Lower East Side,” the 80-year-old avant-garde theater doyenne Judith Malina said recently as she sat on the terrace of her new apartment on Clinton Street. Several floors below, a half-dozen volunteers were putting the finishing touches on the 100-seat basement space that is the newest incarnation of her baby, the Living Theater. The opening night of “The Brig,” the first show there, was just hours away, but Ms. Malina made time to reminisce.

headline: The City’s Smallest Conservatory Finds Its Voice
text: It’s student opera season in New York, time for the city’s conservatories to mount unusual works in their in-house theaters. The Juilliard Opera Center performs world premieres; the Manhattan School of Music is known for contemporary and recent American opera.

headline: For the Record
text: From Thomas L. Friedman’s column on April 27: Albert Einstein won the Nobel Prize for his “services to theoretical physics and especially for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect,” not specifically for relativity.

headline: Jobs Report Is Weaker Than Expected
text: Employers added just 88,000 jobs in April  the smallest number in more than two years, the Labor Department reported today.

headline: Who Needs Rest When There’s a Big Challenge?
text: Thursday night, the day after Esa-Pekka Salonen had conducted the Los Angeles Philharmonic in a complete concert performance of Wagner’s daunting “Tristan und Isolde,” he might have chosen to give his musicians an extra night off to relax and rest up for the final “Tristan” this afternoon.

headline: Rumors Fly on Microsoft and Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 — Microsoft and Yahoo are discussing a business partnership in their effort to compete with Google, people briefed on the talks said Friday.

headline: At G.O.P. Debate, Candidates Played to Conservatives
text: Thursday night’s debate among 10 Republican presidential candidates encompassed all the usual issues and then some, but some of its most striking moments centered on two topics: abortion and evolution.

headline: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Thursday about the effect of climate change on gardening misidentified the host of a symposium, “Gardening in a Changing Climate.” It was the New York Botanical Garden, not the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: One Story of Taking a Risk, Another of Beating the Odds
text: Bridge is not known for its poignant stories. But one with a happy ending — and a new beginning — concerns Samantha Eisenstein, daughter of the New York bridge expert Glenn Eisenstein. In 1999, while a senior at Brandeis University, Samantha was found to have Ewing’s sarcoma, an aggressive form of bone cancer that required immediate chemotherapy. Two years later, it was discovered that the chemotherapy had given her leukemia. Luckily a bone marrow donor was found in St. Louis, and that operation was a complete success.

headline: Timber (and Its Revenues) Decline, and Libraries Suffer
text: SHADY COVE, Ore. — Business at Book N More has picked up. Louis L’Amour moves quickly. Agatha Christie, too. Never mind the missing covers and coffee stains. People just need the stories, and here in Jackson County there are fewer and fewer places to find them.

headline: For Jockeys, Derby Starts With Choice of Mount
text: LOUISVILLE, May 4 — It has a full field of 20 high-strung 3-year-old horses that are still learning the racing business. They are going a stamina-testing mile and quarter for the first time in their young lives, and doing it before a crowd of more than 100,000 that greets them in the stretch in a full-throated roar.

headline: A Comeback for the S.&P. (If the Yardstick Is Dollars)
text: IT has taken 88 months, or nearly three-quarters of the decade, but the American stock market is finally back to where it ended the last decade.

headline: Lawsuit Accuses M.T.A. of Bias Against Its Black and Hispanic Police Officers
text: Ten current and former members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority Police Department sued the agency yesterday, charging that there was a deeply rooted culture of discrimination against black and Hispanic officers.

headline: Radio Hosts, No Strangers to Controversy, Take on Troopers Union Chief
text: The dispute started where many have: in the radio station studio where the radio hosts called the “Jersey Guys” like to toss their grenades.

headline: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about Secret Service protection provided to Senator Barack Obama referred imprecisely to such protection given to Senators John Kerry and John Edwards in 2004. While they indeed were each provided with the Secret Service detail in February, it was while they were both still seeking the presidential nomination; they were not being protected as the Democratic nominees at that time.

headline: Arts, Briefly

headline: Steep Slopes
text: A documentary called “Steep,” which premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival, uses the technology that allows cameras to swoop over quarterbacks in N.F.L. telecasts.

headline: Comparing Full-Size Pickups
Street Sense's Sweet Victory
text: The colt's performance at the Kentucky Derby was not only dominating, but he did it so effortlessly that jockey Calvin Borel believes that he has yet to see the best of Street Sense.

headline: 2008: First Word From Fred Thompson
text: Finally, we hear from Fred D. Thompson. The former Tennessee senator, current “Law & Order” district attorney and possibly future Republican presidential candidate, spoke to the Lincoln Club of Orange County, Calif., the group that launched Ronald Reagan’s career. The Los Angeles Times has his thoughts on Iraq:

headline: Theater Briefs
text: Prizes of $100,000 each have been won by the librettist Jeremy Desmon and the lyricist Joe Iconis, recipients of the 17th annual Kleban Award for most promising musical theater librettist and most promising lyricist. The prize is given by the Kleban Foundation, established in 1988 under the will of Edward L. Kleban, the lyricist of "A Chorus Line."

headline: Darfur — The Movie
text: One of the most frustrating aspects of trying to get traction on Darfur is the shortage of images, especially on television, to grab the attention of the public and make people care. But last night I saw a new film, “The Devil Came on Horseback,” that conveys the horror of Darfur in a way that I think will move audiences. And, better, galvanize them.

headline: Q & A: A Trail of Poisoned Medicine
text: A poisonous solvent sold by counterfeiters and mixed into drugs has figured in mass poisonings around the world that killed thousands. In many cases, the precise origin of the poison has never been determined. But records and interviews show that in three of the last four cases it was made in China, a major source of counterfeit drugs.

headline: The Panama Syndrome
text: A poisonous solvent sold by counterfeiters and mixed into drugs has figured in mass poisonings around the world that killed thousands.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu
text: You can claim you want to watch George Tenet, the former C.I.A. director, on NBC’s “Meet the Press” in order to better understand the process that led to the Iraq invasion. But if you told us that you have no interest in hearing him his dish on both the Bush and Clinton administrations, we won’t believe you.

headline: Bye-Bye, Burgos
text: To make room on the roster for tonight’s starter, Jorge Sosa, the Mets made the surprising move by sending down Ambiorix Burgos to Class AAA New Orleans while keeping Lino Urdaneta. Burgos had a 4.11 earned run average in 12 appearances and had allowed runs in four of his last five, although he is hardly to blame for Orlando Hudson’s controversial two-run homer last night.

headline: A Tale of Two Cities
text: Among books about the true workings of modern New York, “The Power Broker,” Robert Caro’s monumental biography of the master builder Robert Moses, has long been the bible. But in a strong wave of revisionist thinking, Mr. Caro’s critical portrait of Moses as a man who shaped and misshaped New York has been increasingly challenged by influential historians and planners who praise Moses, saying he allowed the city to flower.

headline: Fred Thompson's Could-Be Campaign
text: At an appearance in California, the former senator offered a preview what his presidential candidacy might look like.

headline: New Tastes From the North Fork
text: The North Fork’s expanding roster of producers has two promising new entries, Clovis Point and Medolla Vineyards. Both have just released their first vintages.

headline: Global Yawning
text: I was running errands the other day when a pleasant young woman with a clipboard tried to stop me. “Do you have a moment for the environment, sir?” she asked.

headline: Barbara Fried, Paul Orland
text: Dr. Barbara Michel Fried and Paul Edward Orland are to be married this morning by Rabbi Jamie Korngold at the Sunrise Amphitheater on Flagstaff Mountain in Boulder, Colo.

headline: The Risk Remains, but So Does the Romance
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

headline: Talk Dirt to Me
text: It’s hard to have a conversation about wine these days without hearing the French word terroir. Derived from a Latin root meaning “earth,” terroir describes the relationship between a wine and the specific place that it comes from. For example, many will say the characteristic minerality of wines from Chablis comes from the limestone beds beneath the vineyards (although, when pressed, they generally admit that they’ve never actually tasted limestone). The idea that one can taste the earth in a wine is appealing, a welcome link to nature and place in a delocalized world; it has also become a rallying cry in an increasingly sharp debate over the direction of modern winemaking. The trouble is, it’s not true.

headline: Correction: Walling Off Your Enemies
text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the use of walls in the history of warfare misstated the length of time the Berlin Wall lasted. It fell after 28 years, not 18, having stood from Aug. 1961 to Nov. 1989.

headline: August
text: AUGUST

headline: Jennifer Kohns and Gregory Rathe
text: IN August 2005, Jennifer Kohns was enduring what she calls her “Job-ian” period. Unlike the Biblical figure, Ms. Kohns, a restaurateur, said her suffering was a result of her separation from a 10-year marriage and the closing of Lunchbox Food Company, a West Village diner of which she was an owner.

headline: Faith Confronted, and Defended, Downtown
text: PERFORMANCE SPACE 122, the East Village center known for telling heart-on-its-sleeve theater to take a hike, is undergoing a religious conversion of sorts, with two new shows on Christian themes. “Church,” written and directed by Young Jean Lee, is being performed until next Saturday. It’s an unorthodox contemporary worship service, complete with sermon, praise dancing and a gospel choir. The playwright and director Lear DeBessonet upends Brecht’s “St. Joan of the Stockyards” in a revival that begins June 15, transplanting the dark Joan of Arc story to 1920s Chicago, with bluegrass music by the singer Kelley McRae and handouts of warm bread.

headline: Defending Goliath: Hollywood and the Art of the Blockbuster
text: SUMMERTIME and the viewing is lousy and noisy and deedle-dee dumb, or so the received wisdom has it. It is our season of stupidity, summertime, that interminable stretch when adults surrender the nation’s theaters to hordes of popcorn-chugging, sugar-jonesing, under-age nose-pickers for whom the cinematic experience means nothing more than recycled big, bigger, biggest bangs. It is the season of mass distraction, of the tent pole, the event movie, the blockbuster.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

An article on April 22 about five composers who were asked to write the music for a Roman Catholic Mass referred incorrectly to a difference between that Mass and the Greek Orthodox one — a difference cited by the composer Ivan Moody. The word filioque (“and from the son”), which appears in the Catholic liturgy but not in Orthodox liturgy, occurs in the Credo section, not the Sanctus.

headline: Bronx Man Dies on Subway Platform
text: A Bronx man died early yesterday after he was found motionless and bleeding at the Bowling Green subway station in Lower Manhattan, the police said.

headline: Midlife Vehicle Administration
text: My little white Hyundai died a couple of years ago at 75,000 miles, died beyond repair or resuscitation. I was sad to see it go, towed away one day before I even had the chance to clean it out. I bought it brand-new and pearl white for what seemed like a huge sum, back then — $4,000. That car carried me through my 30s and into my early 40s. With it went a lot of time, a lot of ideas dreamed up behind its sticky wheel, a lot of babies crying and late-night fights, a lot of conversations with my sister.

headline: Local Forecast: Bad
text: THE recent heavy storms that left downtown Manville, N.J., under 10 feet of water; filled the basements of Mamaroneck, N.Y.; and flooded rivers and downed power lines in Connecticut may have provided a glimpse of our future. Climate change is accelerating, and the prognosis for the region is alarming, as it is for the rest of the world. No matter how effectively we begin to curb our greenhouse-gas emissions now, we are destined to see significant climate changes because these gases remain in the atmosphere for a long time. We cannot delay planning for the environmental and human calamities that lie ahead.

headline: Plan B? Let’s Give Plan A Some Time First
text: Kuwait

headline: Denial and Democracy in Egypt
text: In recent weeks, Egypt’s government has further trampled the rights of its citizens, closing several branches of the Center for Trade Union and Workers’ Services, which provides much needed legal assistance to workers. This comes at a time when a growing number of government critics have been thrown in jail and on the heels of constitutional amendments that restrict rights and weaken standards for arrest and detention.

headline: That ’70s Showdown
text: The challenge: to transform a distressing culinary relic like Ladies’ Seafood Thermidor or Bologna Biscuits With Vegetables into a dish you’d proudly serve your food-snob friends. This is the stated objective of the Betty Crocker Card Game. The unstated objective is to amiably enact what we’ve long known to be true: that every dinner party is an unspoken competition with your guests, i.e., I see your beef Wellington and raise you a cassoulet. The B.C.C.G. allows you to compete openly over ludicrously time-consuming food, and for prizes.

headline: I’ll Take It! (and the Sofa, Too)
text: THE way homes for sale are being dressed up, or “staged,” these days can provoke an overwhelming love-at-first-sight, I-want-it, I-want-it-all kind of fervor in certain buyers, real estate sales agents are noticing.

headline: A Drastic Cure for Procrastination
text: I STUMBLED over the accordion in the basement, its case already as deep in water as I was — water pouring in from foundation crevices, billowing up through floor tiles into the fringed magenta rug and, more repulsively, backing up from the street through the sewer cap that we had opened in a feeble attempt to drain away the flood. The April northeaster had hit New Jersey, and we were in its path.

headline: In Florida, a Home Market Still in Flux
text: FOR several years, the defining images of Florida’s frenzied real estate boom were crowded open houses and speculators flipping preconstruction condominiums. But since the market sputtered in mid-2005, as sales fell and inventories soared, property auctions and price cutting have become commonplace.

headline: Free-Agent Pitchers Come at High Cost, Most With No Payoff
text: Jason Marquis pitched so poorly last September that he won none of his five starts, lost four of them, compiled a 7.25 earned run average, didn’t appear in the St. Louis Cardinals’ first playoff series against San Diego and was left off the roster for the league championship series and the World Series.

headline: Emily Gregory, Daniel Hopkins
text: Dr. Emily Flora Gregory, the daughter of Rona H. Gregory of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Joel W. Gregory, who lived in Montreal, is to be married today on Cape Cod to Daniel Jacob Hopkins, a son of Dr. Alice S. Prince of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Dr. B Smith Hopkins III. Rabbi Barbara Penzner officiated at the vacation home of the bridegroom’s mother in Orleans, Mass.

headline: Big Bird Meets the Big House
text: When Greg Scheinman and his wife, Kate, moved to Houston four years ago, they were expecting their first child.

text: Conclusion: On Following the Road to One's Destiny, With the Usual Intrusions of Violence and Grace

headline: Manchester United Closes in on a Title
text: Manchester United goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar saved a penalty kick yesterday to help his team defeat host Manchester City, 1-0, and close in on its first English Premier League title since 2003.

headline: Correction: Comparative Literature
text: A statistical report on April 15 about the international book market misspelled the surname of the author of “Measuring the World,” a top international fiction best seller for 2006. He is Daniel Kehlmann, not Kellman.

text: Saddle River

headline: Wang Keeps Demeanor Calm and Sinker Low
text: Chien-Ming Wang’s audition for the Yankees took place in a gymnasium in Taiwan seven years ago. It rained that day, so Wang’s workout was moved indoors. Wang threw for about a half-hour before he was offered a $1.9 million signing bonus. He accepted.

headline: A Two-Wheeled Option (With a Battery) for Commuters
text: JEFF BAUM has a breathtaking daily commute. He travels 10 miles each way from his home in Frisco, Colo., to his office in Breckenridge — up and down winding roads that eventually climb to 9,800 feet in the Rockies — to his job as the executive director of the Breckenridge Music Festival.

headline: Correction: Caption in ‘The Grand Surprise’ Review
text: A picture caption on April 22 with a review of “The Grand Surprise: The Journals of Leo Lerman,” misspelled the given name of the actress shown with Lerman in 1952. She is Luise Rainer, not Louise.

headline: Not Hot Just Yet, but Newark Is Starting to Percolate
text: NEWARK, May 2 — You live where?

headline: Promiscuities
text: The protagonist of Lynn Stegner’s stunning new novel is a self-destructive hussy who isn’t above locking her child in a car for several hours while she amuses herself with an afternoon tryst. Kate Riley needs to be desired — constantly, achingly, even violently desired — in order to feel truly alive. Lunging from one sensual high to the next, she leaves a crowd of broken people in her wake.

headline: Propaganda Fear Cited in Account of Iraqi Killings
text: Recently unclassified documents suggest that senior officers viewed the killings of 24 Iraqi civilians in Haditha in late 2005 as a potential public relations problem that could fuel insurgent propaganda against the American military, leading investigators to question whether the officers’ immediate response had been intentionally misleading.

headline: A Scandal That Keeps Growing
text: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales declared recently, while batting down bipartisan calls for him to resign, that he had many things to do and “can’t just be focused on the U.S. attorneys situation.” It’s not surprising that Mr. Gonzales wants to change the subject. At best, the firing of eight United States attorneys, most of them highly respected, is an example of such profound incompetence that it should cost Mr. Gonzales his job. At worst, it was a political purge followed by a cover-up. In either case, the scandal is only getting bigger and more disturbing.

headline: From Arabic to Hebrew
text: One day in 10th-century Baghdad a visiting foreign student named Dunash Ben Labrat showed his teacher, the revered scholar Sa’adia Gaon, a poem he had composed in a novel style. Sa’adia handed the poem back with the comment “Nothing like it has ever been seen in Israel.” This dubious compliment, which all teachers of creative writing might wish to employ, failed to discourage Dunash. He took himself, and his new poetry, back home to Muslim Spain. There, despite the dismay his mediocre verses prompted in other aspiring Hebrew poets, his style caught on. Within a few decades, from these unpromising origins, a brilliant and original body of Hebrew verse began to take shape. Virtually stagnant since late Biblical times, Hebrew poetry and the language itself would be transformed by a succession of poets of genius and their imitators. In Peter Cole’s rich new anthology, the extent of their astonishing achievement is fully revealed for the first time in English.

headline: Increased State Aid or Not, Districts Seek Higher Taxes
text: DESPITE record increases in state aid for next school year, most districts on Long Island and in other New York City suburbs have also proposed property tax increases well over the inflation rate. District officials say they are handcuffed by big annual increases in teachers’ salaries and the rising costs of pensions and health insurance, as well as higher energy prices.

text: UPTON

headline: Vivaldi Arrives Fashionably Late
text: IN fashion, everything old eventually becomes new again. No matter how old.

DeScherer of New York, is to be married today to Edwyn Patrick Ossa, the son of Patricia Stypula of Newark, Ohio, and the late Julio E. Ossa. The ceremony will be at the William Aiken House, a 19th-century mansion in Charleston, S.C. Richard A. Brown, the Queens County district attorney and a friend of the bride and her family, is to officiate by a special order of the Probate Court of Charleston County.

headline: Annsley Rosner, Gregory Slawsky
text: Annsley Elin Rosner, the daughter of Krista Berneike Hart of Woodbridge, Conn., and Robert A. headline: Certified? Yes. Satisfied? Not Always.
text: GETTING halves of two cars was not what Paulette Day expected when she bought a red 2004 Chevrolet Monte Carlo that year from a dealership near Detroit for $22,000. The car was used, but it was a “G.M. certified” car, meaning it had supposedly passed a rigorous inspection by the dealer. As General Motors says in its marketing material, buying a certified car means “the reliability of new and the affordability of used.”

headline: Dear S.E.C., Reconsider Arbitration
text: ARGUING that it is wrong to force investors into arbitration when resolving disputes with their brokers, two prominent United States senators have asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to ban the Wall Street practice of requiring customers to sign away their rights to bring their grievances to court.

headline: Mr. Spitzer’s Gold Rush
text: In a case of particularly bad timing, Gov. Eliot Spitzer flew to California last week to raise campaign funds. Rushing to California to raise money is not illegal or even uncommon for a New York politician. But Mr. Spitzer’s trip came while he has been chastising legislators back home for failing to reform the state’s shameful campaign fund-raising system.

headline: After the Horrors of War, a Helping Hand at Home
text: WHEN soldiers from the Connecticut Army National Guard returned from Afghanistan two weeks ago, barricades could not stop their families and friends from greeting them as they got off planes at the Army Aviation Support Facility in Windsor Locks.

headline: Giving the Last Laugh to Life’s Losers
text: schlub U.S. slang. A worthless person, a “jerk,” an oaf. — Oxford English Dictionary

headline: A Winning Producer Chronicles a Broadway Season on Film
text: ONE opening night has come and gone, leaving mostly big smiles in its wake. But for Dori Berinstein, one of the three leading producers of “Legally Blonde,” which opened on Broadway April 29, the anticipation has just begun. On Friday she will make her debut as a film director when “ShowBusiness: The Road to Broadway,” a full-length documentary that she also produced, opens in Manhattan.

headline: Raise You One
text: Odds are, you won’t be competing at Wimbledon this year. Nor will you be sporting an Olympic medal, a Super Bowl ring or the Masters’ green jacket anytime soon. And given that others spend their lives training for these things and you don’t, that seems only fair. But as Anthony Holden points out in his engaging new book, “Bigger Deal,” lack of experience needn’t prevent any of us from participating in — and possibly winning — the world’s largest, most lucrative sports competition: the World Series of Poker. In 2006, 44,500 entrants vied for a prize pool of more than $150 million, and the $12 million title event was won by a Hollywood producer taking time off from filming a reality show called “America’s Hottest Mom.” In 2005, the title came down to a head-to-head between two mortgage brokers. At the W.S.O.P., amateurs compete with pros and regularly trounce them. So why not you? Or me? Or Holden?

headline: Marcia Yablon, Geordie Zug
text: Marcia Anne Yablon, a daughter of Joan and Charles M. Yablon of New York, is to be married today to Charles Gordon Zug IV, the son of Sara G. Zug of Gladwyne, Pa., and Mr. Zug III of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Kayelily Middleton, a nondenominational minister, is to officiate at Fearrington House, a restaurant and inn in Pittsboro, N.C., with Rabbi Andrew V. Ettin taking part.

headline: When a Kiss Is More Than a Kiss
text: RICHARD GERE, while not the first person you’d think most likely to invoke the wrath of a conservative religious mob by kissing somebody in public, was at least a passably recognizable symbolic target for Hindu demonstrators last week, when they burned his figure in effigy in cities across India.

headline: A Close Call, and a Sign of a Thriving Animal World
text: MIDDLETOWN

headline: A Young Playwright Gets Her Say, and Teenagers Their Day
text: SEVERAL teenagers from New Haven will be visiting Yale this month, and it won’t be for early orientation. “The Wendy Play,” written by Amy Herzog, a third-year playwright at Yale Drama School, will feature young actors from the Educational Center for the Arts (E.C.A.) run by ACES, Area Cooperative Educational Services.

headline: Antiwar Groups Use New Clout to Influence Democrats on Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, May 4 — Every morning, representatives from a cluster of antiwar groups gather for a conference call with Democratic leadership staff members in the House and the Senate.

headline: Mets’ Gamble on Sosa Pays Off for One Night
text: PHOENIX, May 5 — Last seen in spring training: A right-handed pitcher named Jorge Sosa, about 6 feet 2 inches, who spent a good portion of his time watching balls sail over the fence. Seen at Chase Field on Saturday: A guy who looked like Sosa, same height and build and fastball, who spent a good portion of his night watching zero after zero pile up next to ARI on the center-field scoreboard.

headline: Laid-Back Labor
text: The $140 Homemade Scarf

headline: For a Small Slaughterhouse, a Dash of Local Glory
text: About a dozen speckled Plymouth Rock hens sat at the front of the poultry section. They and their neighbors — hundreds of Rhode Island hens, Muscovy drakes and other fowl — warbled quietly in their pens. Lambs and goats munched alfalfa grass in a roomier wing next door.

headline: Invisible Palestinians Exist in Legal Limbo in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5 — Three generations of the Hamdallah family have lived in Lebanon. And for three generations not a single member of the family has been allowed to graduate from school, legally marry, or hold a job, or even set foot outside of the rundown camps that have been home to generations of Palestinians.

headline: Beer-Soaked Myths, Boarded Up for Now
text: BY early last week, the word seemed to have gotten out about Chumley’s. The former speakeasy and literary haunt in Greenwich Village, closed since its chimney collapsed on April 5, was still boarded up, and even tourists with their noses buried in guidebooks passed by without looking up.
