text: Storms Prompt Bill on Buying Flood Properties

headline: Laugh Lines: Jay Leno, David Letterman and Conan O’Brien
text: JAY LENO

headline: An Indie Star Whose Life Is an Indie Film
text: AFTER a breakfast interview with Parker Posey in the East Village in March that careered through yoga, Mel Gibson and how not to play the Hollywood game, it was time to go. She offered to walk a reporter toward the subway, stopping at her apartment to get her little fluffy white dog, Gracie. Ms. Posey smiled to herself as she came down the steps with Gracie in a floral shoulder bag, then pointed to a small stuffed Snoopy in the tree above us.

headline: Sex, Drugs and Hot Tubs
text: People of a certain age will remember Esalen, the famous (or infamous) spa in Big Sur on the California coast, founded in the 1960s as a center of the human potential movement. In his book “Esalen: America and the Religion of No Religion,” Jeffrey J. Kripal describes it as “a utopian experiment creatively suspended between the revelations of the religions and the democratic, pluralistic and scientific revolutions of modernity.” In 1990, someone painted graffiti (unprintable in its entirety here) at the entrance: “Jive ... for rich white folk.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,353 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: The Rangers Bury the (Immediate) Past With Optimism
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., May 5 — From the looks of the Rangers’ practice, with players laughing and joking, trash-talking with the backup goaltenders during drills, Saturday seemed like a normal day.

headline: The New Staples
text: According to Peppadew lore, a man referred to only as J. S. discovered an unusual pepper plant a decade ago near his home in South Africa. Delighted by the fruit’s sweet and spicy kick, he began a global marketing campaign. Pickled, the pepper has since become a fixture at restaurants like Little Giant in New York, where the bartender whips up this Peppadew martini.

headline: Julie Katz, Brian Karp
text: Dr. Julie Ann Katz and Dr. Brian James Karp are to be married this afternoon at the View on the Hudson, an events space in Piermont, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua Z. Gruenberg is to officiate.

headline: The Guy Who Picks the Best Places to Live
text: EVERY so often, a report comes out listing the best (or worst) cities to live in, the most romantic, the most child-friendly or the most affordable.

headline: The Older Woman
text: Q: Despite your reputation as a seriously witty journalist, screenwriter and director, you’ve recently emerged as the poster girl for a whole new wrinkling and sagging population, thanks to your essay collection “I Feel Bad About My Neck: And Other Thoughts on Being a Woman.” How old are you, exactly? I’m 65 going on 66, as we used to say when we were 12.

headline: Where Are All the Black Swans?
text: IN 1933 Lincoln Kirstein wrote a passionate 16-page letter to his friend A. Everett Austin Jr., the director of the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, introducing a man named George Balanchine and a dream: to remake ballet for America. The plan, as Kirstein wrote, was to have “four white girls and four white boys, about 16 years old, and eight of the same, negros.”

headline: What’s on Sunday Night
text: 9 P.M. (NBC) SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE IN THE ’90s: POP CULTURE NATION This was the decade in which “S.N.L.” went from being named a national institution by the Peabody Awards to being derided as “Saturday Night Dead” to being resurrected with the addition of new cast members including Will Ferrell. This special traverses the decade’s highs and lows through interviews with Lorne Michaels, Dana Carvey (above right), Mike Myers (above left), Jimmy Fallon, Mr. Ferrell, Tina Fey, Darrell Hammond, Norm Macdonald, Tim Meadows, — take a breath — Kevin Nealon, Cheri Oteri, Chris Rock and Molly Shannon, among others, as well as a little insight from two of its most frequent hosts, John Goodman and Alec Baldwin.

headline: Walking on the Wild Side of a Montana University
text: MISSOULA, Mont.  The University of Montana is a wild place.

headline: Against Moderation
text: It’s odd the books people get asked to review. Take this one, a carefree history of our long love affair with drinking. I have no training as a historian, just some slight experience on both sides of bars. And perhaps an exaggerated reputation for disparaging today’s ubiquitous alcohol-free business lunches. Barbara Holland, though, might empathize. She reminds us that in 1787, two days before their work was done, the 55 delegates to the Constitutional Convention “adjourned to a tavern for some rest, and according to the bill they drank 54 bottles of Madeira, 60 bottles of claret, 8 of whiskey, 22 of port, 8 of hard cider and 7 bowls of punch so large that, it was said, ducks could swim around in them. Then they went back to work and finished founding the new Republic.” Note the 55 delegates and 54 bottles of Madeira. Which founder was slacking?

headline: Correction: 36 Hours in Dublin
text: The 36 Hours column on April 22, about Dublin, misstated the location of the Fashion and Design Market there. It is on Cow’s Lane, not Cow’s Land.

headline: Hatland
text: A new gilded age was in full bloom at the 25th anniversary lunch of the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy last Wednesday. Extravagant hats are always a signature of the event. This year the favorite colors were white, ivory, beige and black etched in white. Attended by 1,240 guests, the lunch raised $2.3 million. Over the years, the committee has raised more than $28 million.

headline: In Praise of General Tso
text: IF there is a song of the lazy, unmarried man in New York, the words and music can be found most often in that pile of yellowed and stained takeout menus on top of his fridge.

headline: A Victory for Open Space
text: In a state as densely populated and developed as New Jersey, even a small victory for preserving open land is worth celebrating. A unanimous appeals court ruling last week gave conservationists exactly that by saying that owners enrolled in the state’s farmland preservation program must allow the state to buy the land even it does not exactly match a developer’s offer.

headline: But Would Thoreau Have Lived Here?
text: EAST LYME

headline: ‘MST3K’: The Final Frontier
text: WHEN “Mystery Science Theater 3000” was canceled after 11 seasons in 1999, 146 distraught fans bought a full-page advertisement in Daily Variety urging another network to continue the show. But the series was not revived, and today devotees cannot even tune in to reruns because its premise — a host and his two robot pals mock B movies — required securing those movies’ broadcast rights, which expired after the show’s demise.

headline: Inside the List
text: BIG IN BERLIN: J. R. Moehringer’s memoir “The Tender Bar” (2005), about how the author, as a boy, found a family of sorts in a Long Island saloon, was a best seller in the States — it spent four weeks on our hardcover list and seven more in paperback. Interestingly, the book has found an enthusiastic audience as well in Germany, where it was recently No. 3 on Der Spiegel’s best-seller list. The Book Review’s “Bad for You” issue seemed like an occasion to explore why this beer-soaked memoir is selling so well there, and we reached Moehringer by phone at a hotel room in Berlin, where he’s still touring for his book. “I wish I knew why it’s doing so well,” he said. “But it is interesting to discuss theories. I suspect it’s a combination of a bunch of things.” Here, in Moehringer’s words, are what some of those things may be.

headline: A Tale of Two Cities
text: THE question trails Robert Caro like a fly, buzzing in his ear. Over and over, at cocktail parties and museum receptions in the past few years, he hears variations on the same query.

headline: Grill Seekers
text: Outdoor cooking used to be so easy. You’d douse briquettes in petrochemicals, overcook meat in the kettle grill from the hardware store and drink too much canned beer. But no more: like sports and deodorant, grilling has gone extreme. Interest in the nuances of grilling and barbecue has skyrocketed. Guys list the grills they own in barbecue chat rooms, while charcoal brands are rated at Nakedwhiz.com (sample: “Whole Foods charcoal is mostly flooring scrap”). These people are not just spending too much time thinking about outdoor cooking. They’re spending too much money too: Kalamazoo Outdoor Gourmet, the leader in meticulously manufactured and conspicuously expensive grills, has discontinued production of its $1,600 entry-level model since orders for its custom outdoor kitchens (starting at $20,000) have shot up from 5 percent of its business three years ago to 40 percent today.

headline: Prison Made of Type
text: While incarcerated in a madhouse in mid-18th-century England, Christopher Smart scribbled a poem suggesting that God was “punching” words onto the blank page of his imagination. Two centuries later, William S. Burroughs imagined the Soft Typewriter, a demiurge that writes each of us into being and controls our behavior. In “The Iron Whim,” Darren Wershler-Henry insists that, until quite recently, the act of typewriting exercised a sinister influence over our lives. Just because Smart and Burroughs were paranoid, he suggests, it doesn’t mean their typewriters weren’t out to get them.

headline: A Medicare Program (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Claire Israel and Oren Silverstein
text: Claire Deborah Israel and Oren Benjamin Silverstein were married last evening at Cupid’s Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The Rev. John Langford, a Pentecostal minister, officiated. The couple plan to have a Jewish service on June 9 at Nana restaurant in Brooklyn. Rabbi Dan Bromstein is to officiate.

headline: Stella Mellas, Scott Hadfield
text: Dr. Stella Mellas and Scott William Hadfield are to be married today at Christ Church Warwick in Paget, Bermuda. The Rev. T. Alan W. Garrity, a minister of the Church of Scotland, will officiate. Afterward, the Rev. Demetrios Kehagias, is to perform a Greek Orthodox ceremony.

headline: High Hopes for This Season. After That, Who Knows?
text: OCEANPORT

headline: Hyatt Promises ‘Homey’ Feeling in New Chain
text: The Global Hyatt Corporation is hoping the word Andaz will soon be a brand name as well known to consumers as, say, Hyatt. Meaning “personal style” in Hindi, the name is being given to a to the renovated Great Eastern Hotel in London’s financial district. This first Andaz is to open this fall and be followed in late 2008 by a second Andaz in New York at 75 Wall Street and a third, the following year, on Fifth Avenue across from the New York Public Library.

headline: Stocks Rise as the Media Sector Is Rediscovered
text: Buoyed by reports of possible mergers and acquisitions, stocks surged last week, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to another record close on Friday.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Music and Dance

headline: Another Way to Go Green
text: With plenty of seats on hand and swift counter service, the Stand Cafe and Juice Bar would seem to be misnamed. But it’s not time on your feet that the name is meant to evoke. Instead it’s the wholesome image of a fruit or vegetable stand, said the owners, Carissa Dellicicchi and Michael Hvizdo, who by opening this vegan vegetarian eatery last December, also felt they were taking a stand.

headline: Wearing a Hat and Wanted in 3 Counties
text: UNION

headline: Iraqi Courts Seek to End Sunni’s Immunity
text: BAGHDAD, May 5 — Iraq’s top judicial authority has asked Parliament to lift immunity for a prominent Sunni lawmaker, possibly clearing the way for his arrest on charges of provoking sectarian violence.

headline: G.O.P. Leader Says Results Needed in Iraq by Fall
text: WASHINGTON, May 6 — The House Republican leader, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, warned today that unless progress is evident in Iraq by early fall, many Republican lawmakers would begin losing patience.

headline: Get Happy
text: So far as I know, Attila the Hun had nothing to say on the subject of happiness. In this, he appears to be unique among notable (and not so notable) figures from antiquity on down to the present day. He’s absent from those lists of quotable happiness quotes that litter self-help books and the Web, and he isn’t among the many dozens of sources cited — from Ecclesiastes to Thomas Jefferson to Willy Wonka — in Jennifer Michael Hecht’s new book, “The Happiness Myth: Why What We Think Is Right Is Wrong.”

headline: State Using Green Funds to Buy Parcel in Arrow Park
text: TO some, the $1.98 million is a good start. To others, it is simply not enough.

headline: A Longer, Better Life
text: Sara Davidson talks to two medical scientists about how the body ages and the research on trying to extend our healthy life span. Participants: Lenny GUARENTE, PH.D.: Novartis professor of biology at M.I.T. and author of “Ageless Quest: One Scientist’s Search for Genes That Prolong Youth.”; Robert N. BUTLER, M.D.: Founding director of the National Institute on Aging, a founder of the Alzheimer’s Disease Association and winner of a Pulitzer Prize in 1976 for “Why Survive? Being Old in America.” He heads the International Longevity Center.; SARA DAVIDSON: Author, most recently, of “Leap! What Will We Do With the Rest of Our Lives?”

headline: Jockey Wins Four on Derby Undercard
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5  When they hit the far turn in the 133rd running of the Kentucky Derby, Elizabeth Jones Valando could not have asked for more: Nobiz Like Shobiz was moving quickly toward the leader, Hard Spun.

headline: Tracy Rohrlich, Jonathan Badner
text: Tracy Lynn Rohrlich and Jonathan Harris Badner were married last evening by Rabbi Norton D. Shargel at the St. Regis in New York.

headline: University President Placed on Suspension
text: BATON ROUGE, La. (AP), May 5 — The nation’s largest historically black university system suspended its president with pay Saturday and ordered him to cooperate with an investigation into the way sexual harassment charges against a fellow administrator were handled.

headline: It’s the Truth, but Not the Whole Truth
text: AN Ohio judge will decide on Friday whether to approve the settlement of a class-action suit against Carfax in which consumers could receive coupons worth about $20 and the lawyers representing them $566,000.

headline: Make Cupcakes, Not War
text: A limited-edition T-shirt from Johnny Cupcakes is one of the few things that can’t be bought in Manhattan. Cupcakes (a k a John Earle) and his upcake-and-crossbones logo took Boston by storm last year when he and his dad outfitted a storefront on tony Newbury Street to look like a bakery, with antique refrigerators, baking racks, a hulking 1930s dough mixer and a cast-iron wood-burning oven from the 1890s. The T-shirts have a Magnolia Bakery-like following: In October, more than 500 aficionados lined up to buy Cupcakes’ $55 monster tees. “People like what no one else has,” Earle says. “That’s why I number my shirts and don’t repeat my designs.” Earle has also cooked up day-of-the-week undies and skateboard decks, available at his store as well as online. Go to www.johnnycupcakes.com.

headline: Juilliard Recasts the Role of Mentor
text: JAMES HOUGHTON first auditioned for John Houseman in 1986. A young San Franciscan, barely out of the Meadows School of the Arts at Southern Methodist University, he won a coveted spot in Mr. Houseman’s elite classical theater group, the Acting Company.

headline: Dear Anne, Not Ready to Kill You Yet
text: You watch “The Tudors” for the history the way you read Playboy for the articles. So far, five weeks into this popular Showtime series about a young, buff and lusty Henry VIII, there’s a lot more off-with-your-velvet-frock than off-with-your-head. But not — yet — between two of history’s most famous lovers, Henry Tudor and Anne Boleyn. (Henry does seem to sleep with everyone else, with the possible exception of his wife, while Anne sleeps with no one, with the possible exception of her brother.)

headline: Renting Out Your Vacation House
text: FOR many, a vacation house is a personal oasis that offers a snug refuge from the world and its worries. For others, a vacation home is basically a cash cow.

headline: A Shore Menu That’s Long on Value
text: GEMÜTLICH is the word that springs to mind (my mind at least) on entering the White Peach Restaurant in Gaylordsville (northwest of New Milford, on the road to Kent). The exposed log ceiling, posts, wood floors and handful of tables all evoke the coziness and congeniality that the German word suggests.

headline: Knives on the Streets
text: ON March 26, as students poured out the front doors of the High School for Arts and Business in Corona, Queens, one 16-year-old boy frantically headed in the other direction, trying to reach the safety of the school lobby.

headline: Trunk Food
text: Watermelon Juice

headline: The Week in Connecticut
text: Towns Seek Flood-Prevention Solutions

headline: And Now, a Few Words in Defense of Nostalgia
text: A FEW days before the start of the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in California last week, fans of the reunited — and legendarily unpredictable — British group Happy Mondays got an unhappy surprise. The band would be playing its first American concert in 15 years without one of its best-loved members. Mark Berry, better known as Bez, had been denied a visa and wouldn’t be appearing.

headline: What to Do When Rupert Calls?
text: I DON’T regularly watch the Fox News Channel, but when I do, I hardly think it is “fair and balanced.” I confess to reading The New York Post, but more as a delicious treat than a trusted news source. When I lived in London, I picked up The Times of London on my way to work every morning, but felt that the once-august publication had moved a bit down-market.

headline: Fat Chance
text: If you had to choose, would you rather be fat or blind? When a researcher asked that question of a group of formerly obese people, 89 percent said they would prefer to lose their sight than their hard-won slimness. “When you’re blind, people want to help you. No one wants to help you when you’re fat,” one explained. Ninety-one percent of the group also chose having a leg amputated over a return to obesity.

headline: Detroit Closes In on Conference Finals
text: DETROIT, May 5 (AP) — Pavel Datsyuk and Henrik Zetterberg each had a goal and two assists for the Detroit Red Wings on Saturday in a 4-1 victory against the San Jose Sharks in Game 5 of their Western Conference semifinal series.

headline: Self-Nonmedication
text: Seven years ago, not long after my father died, with my editing job lost, my finances frail, my 26-year marriage failing, a child in college and a mortgage to pay, my brain seemed to lose its way. Sometimes it could barely think at all. Sometimes it tortured a single thought for hours. And sometimes, in desperation and without aim, it released a barrage of anger upon itself.

headline: Oops, It May Be Time to Rebalance That Portfolio
text: AS stock indexes flirt with previous highs — or forge ahead of them — many investors have no urgent need for celebration.

headline: When Words Speak Louder Than Actions
text: AGAIN this week, the key task for Federal Reserve policy makers will be to decide what to say, not what to do. Few people expect the central bankers to nudge interest rates up or down, but the usual language in the statement that accompanies the rate decision could be due for some tweaking, one analyst predicts.

headline: Winning Isn’t Everything. Check the Periphery.
text: COLLABORATION can be a powerful driver of innovation when it is done thoughtfully. But thoughtfulness can be hard to achieve in a traditional corporate or academic setting, where getting the best of others — whether by winning a sale or an argument — tends to be rewarded.

headline: Reinventing Middle Age
text: Quick, what does the following list suggest to you: Lamaze classes; baby showers; “parenting skills”; preschool anxiety all the way up to college; transitional phases; timeouts; chronic credit-card debt; the indiscriminate wearing of athletic garb; political correctness; anti-political correctness; midlife crises; couples therapy; divorce mediation; Botox; dermatological fillers; cosmetic surgery; the new-and-improved menopause; wearing sunglasses in winter even though you’re not famous; comb-overs; an obsession with the daily lives of the celebrated and merely notorious; real estate as a means to an end; a debilitating reliance on takeout dinners; a preference for esoteric coffee beans; an aversion to butter; an uneasy feeling of identification with Bob Dylan; a denial of death; cilantro, cilantro, cilantro; framing every photograph you’ve ever taken; the belief that your dog/cat is you; an excessively personalized vision of retirement; older single mothers; grandfatherly second-time fathers; a fear that you’ve become your mother or father; a free-floating feeling of grievance that you’ve failed to make obscene amounts of money as a hedge-fund manager; a gut instinct that immortality might be just around the next technological bend. If you still haven’t figured out that I’m talking about the so-called baby-boomer generation, you might consider the possibility that the reason you are having difficulty making out the fine print of any given subtext is because you need reading glasses.

headline: Kelly Mason, Benjamin Unger
text: The Rev. Kelly Murphy Mason and Dr. Benjamin Daniel Unger were married last evening in the chapel at Union Theological Seminary in New York. The Rev. Catherine Torpey, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated, with Rabbi Ronald Broden taking part.

headline: Lauren Bisordi, Don Lepore
text: Lauren Constance Bisordi and Anthony Donald Lepore III were married yesterday at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel O’Reilly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: From Great Lake Swimmers All the Way to Timberlake
text: THE Tel Aviv-born Keren Ann Zeidel is a singer-songwriter who infuses her spare, poetic lyrics with subtle, complex and sometimes lush compositions. Her self-titled “Keren Ann” (Metro Blue) comes out Tuesday, her third album to be released in the United States. Raised in Paris, Ms. Zeidel, 33, speaks Hebrew, French, English and Dutch. While on tour in Europe (she moves on to the United States beginning next month), Ms. Zeidel spoke late at night with Winter Miller by phone as her bus rolled along the French countryside toward Brest in Brittany. “We wake up in a different town every day, sometimes in a different country,” she said. Here is what she’s listening to and why.

headline: Not Boring or Blah Here, but Classics in a Cozy Spot
text: EVERY town should have a restaurant like Julianna’s. This cozy eating spot, subtitled “an American bistro,” is a terrific addition to the northwest side of the county, where there is a paucity of fun, informal places serving thoughtfully prepared food. The co-owners — Michael Carrozza, the talented chef, and Derek Palmisano, who handles the front of the house — are from the area and certainly have hit upon what this remote residential neighborhood needed.

headline: Losing Her Accent
text: In the introduction to “Shakespeare’s Kitchen,” Lore Segal’s charming novel disguised as a book of short stories, the author offers an apology for not writing a more conventional narrative. Describing a meeting with a film producer who tells her that “in a good plot nothing happens that is not the result of what happened before or the cause of what happens next,” she says, “I like reading stories like that, but I don’t write them because that’s not how life happens to me or to the people I know.” It’s an illuminating point, but less about the book than about Segal herself.

headline: Chief Justice to Retire. Who’s Next?
text: TRENTON

headline: A Nervous Case
text: 1. Symptoms

headline: Net Worth
text: At sunset on a clear June evening, Andrea Fariello steered his small boat to a chosen location two miles from shore. By day Fariello — tall, with rough, sun-stained skin, an unkempt beard and a few blackened teeth from years of smoking — tends his bar along the main strip of Marina di Pisciotta, a sleepy village about 70 miles south of Italy’s Amalfi coast. At night he is one of Marina di Pisciotta’s anchovy fishermen. What sets him apart from the other anchovy fishermen along the Mediterranean coast is that he is among the few who still use the menaica, a net dating to the ancient Romans.

headline: The D.J. Rocked, and TV Shook
text: ALTHOUGH it was never meant to be the stuff of conventional entertainment, too much rock ’n’ roll has become just that. Rock stars are featured in reality shows and tabloids; previously sacrosanct Led Zeppelin and Nirvana songs are plugged into commercials and soundtracks; “American Idol” has devoted an entire evening to cluelessly sung renditions of British Invasion hits. The refrain of a Pink Floyd classic, “Welcome to the Machine,” has never stung more.

headline: Dine by Diagram
text: Recipics may be an answer to today’s cacophony of culinary chatter. Influenced by the field of instructional design and airplane-emergency-card instructions, the Australian graphic designer Lauren Bugeja began to create recipes using virtually text-free pictograms for a student project at the University of Technology in Sydney. Recently, she teamed up with designers to develop a Web site for sharing recipes and creating recipics (www.coo.kz), which will launch this month. Bugeja says recipics will appeal to visual learners and could also be useful for translating recipes across languages. While steps such as duration, measurement and actions can be diagramed relatively easily, Bugeja acknowledges the occasional stumbling block: “The ingredients are still a work in progress,” she said. “For example, it’s hard to explain the difference between flour, baking powder, anthrax and cocaine without words.”

headline: A Crime in the Graveyard, Motive Unfathomable
text: As robberies go, it was no jewel heist. The stolen items included a clown doll with a porcelain face, a stuffed bear won at a fair, three small containers filled with the ashes of pet dogs that had died, a ceramic angel and an album of letters from grateful students.

headline: Fresh-From-the Sea Fish Emporium
text: In the two years since Joe DiMauro, the owner of Mount Kisco Seafood, moved his business up the street to its present location, this once vest-pocket seafood operation has evolved into an emporium. “We quadrupled our space, and we now have enough parking,” he said, with a hint of wistfulness for the old place mixed with pride in the new. In the back of the shop is a big sleek kitchen; in front are luxuriously long ice-filled cases displaying the freshest-tasting seafood in the area.

headline: D’oh! They’re Still Tinkering With Homer
text: OBSESSIVE fans of “The Simpsons” — and really, is there any other kind? — may remember an early episode of the show in which the denizens of Springfield brace themselves for the debut of a movie starring the cartoon cat-and-mouse pair Itchy and Scratchy. As the film’s premiere draws closer, the hype surrounding it becomes unavoidable, promotions and merchandising spin out of control and rabid moviegoers gather outside theaters in lines that stretch beyond the horizon.

headline: French Voters Pick Sarkozy to Be President; Turnout High
text: PARIS, May 6 — Nicolas Sarkozy, an immigrant’s son who had the French presidency in his sights for three decades, won a decisive victory in the election on Sunday, keeping the right in power for the next five years.

headline: Paranoids, Grab Your Raid Cans
text: IN William Friedkin’s new film, “Bug,” paranoia is an infection that spreads from one character to another and eventually in the general direction of the viewer. A lurid psychological thriller with an acute case of the jitters and a nasty sense of humor, it does not exactly seem like the work of a mellowed old-timer, let alone that of a Hollywood veteran who made his most popular films when Richard M. Nixon was president.

headline: A Crystal Ball Would Have Been Nice
text: IF they could have predicted the future, Julie and Neil Weintraub would have bought a one-bedroom co-op, not a two-bedroom, for their first home.

An article on April 22 about a DVD of the first season of the television series “Maude” misstated the date a two-part episode about abortion was broadcast. It was a few months before the Supreme Court’s decision in Roe v. Wade in January 1973, not after.

headline: Village People
text: RECENTLY, after decades of stalling, my sisters and I divided up our grandfather’s diaries, 43 boxes chronicling in alarming detail a life that started on a Kansas farm in 1893, made a 12-box detour to Ohio and ended in 1988, at age 95, in his beloved Manhattan.

headline: Torn From Parents, a Top Speller Vents His Anger, Letter by Letter
text: GREEN RIVER, Utah — Great spellers come in all types, from egotistical showoffs to loners who find sanctuary in the forest of words.

headline: Comings and Goings
text: Call it plane travel, unplugged. Pared-down flights at super-cheap rates, which have been all the rage in Europe for years, will show up in the United States when Skybus Airlines (www.skybus.com) starts domestic operations on May 22. For budget-minded passengers, the compromise seems minimal; reservations must be made through the Web site (no customer relations phone number exists) and there are extra fees for services that are usually part of the fare — like bag check ($5 each for two bags, $50 for additional ones), soft drinks and seating requests. But the flights are cheap. Really cheap. One-way fares start for as little as $10, with a top one-way walk-up fare of $330 (all flights must connect in Columbus, Ohio). Skybus is not serving the New York area, but is flying to nine other cities, including Richmond; Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Greensboro, N.C.; San Francisco; and Seattle. ... Tourists who want a break from the slot machines now have the option of bowling in Las Vegas 24 hours a day. Last month, Red Rock Casino, Resort and Spa, about 10 miles off the Strip (www.redrocklasvegas.com), opened a 72-lane bowling center (below). The center has a pro shop, an arcade, meeting rooms, a deli, a lounge and bar, dart boards, billiard tables, a shuffleboard table, plasma televisions and, surprise, slot and video poker games. There is also a 12-lane, nightclub-like V.I.P. suite, which can be subdivided into four or eight lanes for private parties. Three-hour V.I.P. rates range from $1,500 to $4,500; catered food and bottle service are available. Regular rates start at $3 per adult per game. ... All Holiday Inn hotels — nearly 1,000 — will begin serving Rainforest Alliance certified coffee to guests by June. At least 30 percent of the beans used to make the coffee will be grown on farms that have met strict environmental and social standards on issues like worker protection and biodiversity conservation (www.rainforest-alliance.org).

headline: The Empire Skate: New York Producing Players
text: There is something unusual about several of the key players in this spring’s big hockey tournaments: they come from New York State.

headline: Immigration, Legal and Illegal; There’s More to Life Than the Ivy League (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Week Ahead: May 6 - 12
text: THEATER

headline: The World Is Changing, and With It, This Corner
text: I AM moving. It is not the kind of move where you have to pack a single box, which is fortunate, because I have been known to disintegrate into a puddle when it comes to actual relocation. This particular move is from one section of this newspaper to another.

headline: Now Pouring | Rhum Agricole
text: Lately, the most interesting rum to surface in the States is from the French island of Martinique. Unlike most rum, which is made from molasses, Martinique’s rhum agricole is made exclusively from fresh sugar-cane juice. In addition to the sugary aroma, a tinge of herbal, floral or vegetal flavors evoke the island’s rain forest. Depaz, Rhum Clément, Rhum JM, Neisson and La Favorite are labels offering clear, unaged rhum blanc and amber, wood-aged rhum vieux. Don’t bother using rhum agricole in your mojito, though; it doesn’t work. Try a Ti Punch (short for “petit”) instead.

headline: Perfect Party Mix
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: A Parish Rallies and, After Many Delays, a Church Is Built
text: IN a happy ending to a torturous tale, Long Island’s newest Roman Catholic church, St. Therese of Lisieux in Montauk, has thrown open its doors after a construction project that would have tried the patience of, well, saints.

headline: When Picasso Went Down to Georgia
text: THE birth of Cubism may not seem like standard fodder for a graphic novel. But the painting breakthrough is at the heart of “The Salon,” by Nick Bertozzi, which quickly moves from art history to murder mystery with the help of a magical blue absinthe. Along for the ride are early-20th-century Modernist heavies like Braque, Picasso and Satie. And just as those artists provoked controversy in their day, the graphic novel has led to a skirmish about its depiction of nudity.

headline: Matchmakers Know Superstars Need Love, Too
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Pocahontas II
text: Americans have been very, very bad. Gluttonous, warmongering, nonenvironmentally conscious bad. In Matthew Sharpe’s strange and strained “Jamestown,” set in the post-apocalyptic future, everything is ruined, even the country, even the people. Brooklyn and Manhattan are fighting each other; the Indians have, inexplicably, retaken the South. The East River is goopy (or goopier). The Chrysler Building is rubble. Hares stalk the dead landscape biting off the heads of rodents. If Sharpe’s book had come out in the ’90s, Kevin Costner would be looking to direct.

headline: Johnson Is and Isn’t Where He Wants to Be
text: PHOENIX, May 5 — For those Yankees fans feeling disconnected from their favorite (or least favorite) 6-foot-10 scowling left-hander, they could have done the unthinkable and tuned in to the Mets’ game against the Diamondbacks on Friday night.

headline: A Young Man With an Eye, and Friends Up a Tree
text: IN the beginning Ryan McGinley was known for pictures of his young downtown Manhattan friends. By day he photographed them running, skateboarding, moving, always in motion. By night they were partying, having sex, taking drugs, living fast.

headline: France Heads to the Polls After a Scorching Finale
text: PARIS, May 5 — She apocalyptically predicted that France would blow up if he were elected. He dismissively scoffed that she was too moody to run the country.

headline: The Many Perils of Unqualified Hypocrisy
text: In Michael Vick’s version of HBO’s “Entourage,” he is scolded for the actions of a posse that runs an alleged dog-fighting ring out of a mansion he owns but supposedly never visits.

headline: Breaking Through
text: Alicja Bachleda-Curus

headline: Devils Score First, but Ottawa Won’t Let Series Last
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 5 — The Devils closed their 25-year run at Continental Arena on Saturday night, but most of the sellout crowd that showed up early and had been in such a boisterous mood was unwilling to stick it out to the very end.

headline: The Young and the Restless
text: When did teenage angst and arrogance begin? Many baby boomers, still fighting over the legacy of the 1960s as they lurch toward retirement, think of themselves as products of the rock ’n’ roll rebellion that shattered the bourgeois proprieties of the 1950s. Chronicled in song and witnessed by the new electronic media, the impudent saga of the ’60s counterculture seemed unique.

headline: Have vs. Have-Not, in Jail (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: College Rival Welcomes Another Shot at Woods
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 5  On the soggy grounds of the Quail Hollow Club, where pine needles gathered in bunches and fans did likewise, a cluster of golfers spent a gray Saturday afternoon stirring up shouts and knocking down flagsticks.

headline: Patricia Gross, Gavin Franklin
text: Patricia Jane Gross and Gavin Richard Franklin are to be married today on the Brooklyn Bridge by Shivaun Manley, a friend of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

headline: Rupert Murdoch, Once the Outsider
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Transit Chief’s To-Do List: No. 1, New Hudson Tunnel
text: NEWARK

headline: The Week in Westchester
text: 2nd Missed Name to Be Added to 9/11 Memorial

headline: Mr. Bad Example
text: “I got to be Jim Morrison a lot longer than he did,” the wild-man Southern California singer-songwriter Warren Zevon liked to brag in his abbreviated later years. So we learn from Carl Hiaasen’s foreword to this effusive, seamy — effusively seamy? — oral biography assembled by Zevon’s ex. Short on perspective it may be, but  “I’ll Sleep When I’m Dead”  definitely piles up enough horrendous behavior to back the title’s claim.

headline: Going Where Toyota’s Never Gone Before
text: LAST year, when Nathalie Guiraudet heard that Toyota was making the next-generation Tundra much bigger, she began to fret about her vehicular future.

headline: Final Thoughts About My Tenure and The Times’s Future
text: AS I conclude my tour of duty as the second public editor of The New York Times, here are some final thoughts and concerns about the paper and its journalism that flow from what I’ve observed over the past two years from my perch outside the newsroom.

headline: Victoria-Rong Shi and Christopher Kennedy
text: Victoria-Rong Shi and Christopher J. Kennedy were married last evening in New York. The Rev. Kevin D. Bean, an Episcopal priest and the vicar of St. Bartholomew’s Church, performed the ceremony there.

headline: A Cook’s Companions
text: There are, in my experience, two kinds of cooks: those knowledgeable enough to make it up as they go along, and those who wouldn’t dream of setting out without a road map. Sadly, I am among the latter. It’s no coincidence that I like to bake: I find precision reassuring. Just give me instructions, and I’ll carry them out, to the letter.

headline: 200 Teas? That’s De-Lovely
text: Ours may be a coffee-drinking society, as Robert Scott, owner of the Montclair teahouse Cha-Ma-Gu-Dao, readily concedes. But that doesn’t mean the typical coffeehouse, all that foam and caffeine notwithstanding, can come close to serving up the sensuous, multitiered and occasionally mind-expanding experience a thoughtfully appointed tea spot can.

headline: The Year of the Large Caps? This Time, Don’t Laugh
text: LONG-SUFFERING blue-chip stocks are finally back.

headline: Shortchanging Judges
text: A $141,000 salary seems generous, but for judges in New Jersey it is unrealistically low. Unless the Legislature acts soon to raise it substantially, the state’s judiciary, which legal scholars have long rated as one of the nation’s best, will decline in stature as fewer and fewer top lawyers will be interested in serving.

headline: Changes to Cheer About. Really.
text: IF you ask most people what comes to mind when they hear the word “Rahway,” the first answer is likely to be the state prison. A second response might have something to do with Rahway’s role as a major stop on the New Jersey Transit lines leading into New York City.

headline: Following Matsuzaka on the Emerald Isle
text: The legend of Daisuke Matsuzaka was born in Japan and is taking shape in the United States now that he is pitching for the Boston Red Sox. Matsuzaka’s tale has even trickled to at least one spot in Ireland, a country that did not have a legitimate baseball field until 1998.

headline: Thats Amari
text: If you’ve ever entered a caffè bar in Italy, you can’t help but notice all the splashy, unfamiliar bottles with labels as luridly colorful as old Cinecittà movie posters. Five years ago you were hard-pressed to find any of these amari in America, but bars and restaurants are waking up to the bitter reality.

headline: The Case of the Dwindling Dunes
text: SEA GATE, the gated community on the western tip of the Coney Island peninsula, is shielded from the rest of Brooklyn by a guardhouse and a long fence along West 37th Street. But in recent years, the neighborhood has been under siege along its exposed southern flank — from the sea itself.

headline: Learning the Language of the Drum
text: RIVERHEAD

headline: A Family Torn Apart by Deportation (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chicken Coops to Give Way to Animal Refuge
text: ASHFORD

headline: Taste Maker
text: Innovative design and delicious food meet at Proef, Marije Vogelzang’s design studios/restaurants in Amsterdam and Rotterdam. Weekend visitors can participate in her oddball creations, such as salads whose ingredients were grown in the dark. Vogelzang became interested in food as a material while studying industrial design. She now creates “food concepts” for events for clients ranging from Hermès to Nike. (For a Dutch lingerie launch, she placed beribboned hors d’oeuvres on swaying rods to mimic a swarm of butterflies.)

headline: The Gipper as Diarist
text: Anyone hungering for historical disclosure and nuance in Ronald Reagan’s presidential diaries will have to settle for a prosaic and amiably unrevealing drone in the daily ruminations of the private Reagan. There’s a wisp of tidy news headline reader that summons Reagan the heartland radio announcer. And a tone of that’s-the-way-life-goes utterances worthy of the “Our Town” stage manager, whom the actor Reagan could intuitively play. “A haircut & then over to the Soviet embassy to sign the grief book,” the Great Communicator notes of the passing of Konstantin Chernenko as Kremlin ruler.

headline: Not All Donations Are Created Equal
text: Those seeking a lesson in how to shake people up for money may want to take a page from the playbook of Hilary M. Weston, who has led fund-raising efforts for the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto.

An article last Sunday about the film actress and director Sarah Polley referred incorrectly to the setting of “Avonlea,” the Canadian television series in which she starred. It was set on Prince Edward Island, not the prairie.

headline: Planning, and Policing, Prom Night
text: THIS spring, there will be about 65 proms in Westchester, and there is a flurry of planning all over the county. First, there is the matter of securing a date, which can be filled with as much drama and tension as any episode of “24.” Then there are the dress shopping and tuxedo fittings, hair and manicure appointments, limousine rentals and plans for the “after-prom,” the celebration after the dance that can last anywhere from a few hours to a long weekend.

headline: Forget Who’ll Win in France. Change Is a Loser.
text: PARIS

headline: In Search of the Real Flamenco
text: STEPPING into the almost hidden doorway of the flamenco bar La Soleá in Madrid, one enters a smoky L-shaped room, its walls adorned with blue and white tiles. Well after midnight on a recent Thursday the place was packed with Gypsies and Madrileños, all in thrall to the rhythmic, heartfelt music produced by a Gypsy guitarist and a singer, both dressed in black pants and white shirts. Soon, they were joined by a woman with flowing black hair. Luckily for the customers, she was a master of cante jondo, or deep song, and for the next hour, her voice rose and fell, as she sung a tale of lost love — a favorite flamenco theme.

headline: Long Island’s Land Rush
text: “On Course for Failure” is the unpleasantly blunt title of a report by the Long Island Pine Barrens Society about what it calls the unacceptably slow pace of open-space preservation in these parts. The organization argues that at the rate we’re going, when the final buildout of Long Island occurs — the day in 2015 when there is no land left to develop or preserve — we will be left with far too many malls and McMansions and much too little farmland and open space, and no chance ever again to correct the imbalance.

headline: The (Not So) Eagerly Modern Saudi
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia

headline: An Ancient Coda to My 21st-Century Divorce
text: I WAS finally getting married. That’s what I kept telling people. I didn’t say I was finally getting married “again,” because bringing up a first marriage during the planning of a second is a major buzz kill for everyone involved.

headline: Gin Joint
text: Today’s typical Chicago saloon has Old Style in the can, the Cubs on the tube and video poker in the corner. Weegee’s Lounge, in the Logan Square neighborhood, has none of these. “We like to think of ourselves as the kind of bar you would have found in Chicago in the ’40s,” says Alex Huebner, who, with his wife, Lynne Marrs, opened Weegee’s last June. This means jazz on the stereo and a cocktail repertory featuring classics like the Pink Squirrel, the grasshopper and the Knickerbocker. Huebner licensed the fabled crime-scene shutterbug’s name thinking that Weegee would have found the still-gritty area stimulating. No doubt. 3659 W. Armitage Ave.; (773) 384-0707.

headline: First World, Third World (Maybe Not in That Order)
text: WOULD you risk part of your children’s college fund or your retirement in third-world equities? You may already have.

headline: Lela and Deedie Rose | Designer and Philanthropist
text: Mother Deedie supports the Dallas Museum of Art and the Dallas Center for the Performing Arts with her glittering benefits; her designing daughter, Lela, dresses many of the high-profile guests, as well as her own coterie of followers in Manhattan, where she lives.

headline: Giuliani, Speaking at the Citadel, Calls for a Bigger Army
text: CHARLESTON, S.C., May 5 — Rudolph W. Giuliani called on Saturday for a large-scale increase in the overall troop strength of the Army and the creation of a special force to specifically handle post-combat operations.

headline: Protecting Against the Dread ‘What If?’
text: AS summer approaches and travelers plunk down nonrefundable deposits to secure their vacation plans, many will inevitably be pressed — or at least invited — to purchase travel insurance. But is it really worth it? Some travelers don’t think so, having taken trip after trip without any problems, or, because of some exclusion, found out they weren’t covered when they thought they were. Others have been relieved to be reimbursed for their lost airfare and hotel fees when illness or some other misfortune unexpectedly kept them home.

headline: Up Front
text: Is everything good bad for you? Probably not. In the extreme, maybe. Yet “bad” things can form the basis of some interesting — and amusing — books.

headline: Is Condi Hiding the Smoking Gun?
text: IF, as J.F.K. had it, victory has a hundred fathers and defeat is an orphan, the defeat in Iraq is the most pitiful orphan imaginable. Its parents have not only tossed it to the wolves but are also trying to pin its mutant DNA on any patsy they can find.

headline: Gay Art: A Movement, or at Least a Moment
text: MAYBE it doesn’t signal the arrival of a major arts movement and maybe it is just a symptom of another consumer-driven microtrend, but it would seem that something is afoot in the contemporary art world and it concerns what you could call, for lack of more comprehensive terminology, a burgeoning of gay male art.

headline: Republicans Add Their Two Cents
text: State budgets are cobbled together not only by people who can count to 10 but also by those who can factor in political gains and losses. There has been plenty of political adding and subtracting in the General Assembly, especially by the minority Republicans. They proposed a budget of their own late last month — and in so doing effectively abandoned their Republican leader, Gov. M. Jodi Rell.

headline: His Friends: A Who’s Who. Him: Just ...Who?
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: A Bowling Ball With Snap (and Scent)
text: A MYRIAD of odors permeates American bowling alleys: nacho cheese, stale beer and the mineral oil that coats the lanes. The delicate scent of orange ginger, however, is not one typically associated with the pursuit of spares and strikes.

headline: Molto Mochi
text: It’s been eaten by Japanese noblemen for centuries; it contains phytins, which are thought to prevent cancer; and it’s said to be impervious to the Heimlich maneuver.

headline: After a Long Journey, a Jets Safety and His Mother Are in a Better Place
text: On the second day of the N.F.L. draft last week, Erik Coleman and his mother, Cynthia Bracey-Coleman, sat side by side on the sofa in his apartment in Westbury, N.Y., counting their blessings as they did on the same Sunday three years earlier after Coleman was drafted in the fifth round by the Jets.

headline: Bhutan Lets the World In (but Leaves Fashion TV Out)
text: THIMPHU, Bhutan — “Explore the World,” promised the signboard outside.

headline: Where Feuds Never Die
text: Tarrytown

headline: You Do the Math
text: Do birthday parties held in restaurants give you a palm-dampening, heart-palpitating anxiety attack? You’re not alone.

headline: An Extra Story
text: To the Editor:

headline: Street Sense Wins Derby Despite Field’s Head Start
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 — Calvin Borel had Street Sense in 19th place and about a half a block behind the leaders as the field hit the backstretch in the 133rd running of the Kentucky Derby. Was he worried? Hardly. He had the agile colt next to his beloved rail, and they don’t call the jockey “Bo-Rail” here at Churchill Downs for nothing.

headline: Once-Feared Serbian Hard-Liners Fade Into Shadows
text: KRUSEVAC, Serbia, May 5 — Hard-line nationalists gathered Saturday in this city with a plan to “save Kosovo” as a part of Serbia. But they were a shadow of the paramilitary groups that had caused untold trouble in the 1990s.

headline: Eastward Ho
text: After eight decades of false starts, the Second Avenue subway line may finally become a reality, but it will be years before the line runs through the East Village. In the meantime, these restaurants will attract diners arriving by cab, car, bus and, of course, foot.

headline: The Talk
text: salumi / n. / the generic Italian term for salt-cured pork and beef products, such as salame, prosciutto, coppa, lardo and bresaola, e.g., “People used to make fun of Mario’s lardo pizza, but now every Italian restaurant has a $20 platter of salumi from Fra’ Mani”; the name of the Seattle restaurant run by the salumi-making side of the Batali family.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Music and Dance

headline: What to Do About Wanderlust
text: Q. You are comfortably settled in a career, and making good money. But you don’t feel fulfilled, and you think you may want to move to a completely different field. Should you even consider such a change?

headline: Businesses Try to Make Money and Save the World
text: ALTRUSHARE SECURITIES is a brokerage firm, engaged in the sort of things you might expect of a Wall Street outfit, like buying and selling stock, and providing research on companies. Unlike its peers, however, the firm is majority-owned by two charities that each control about one-third of it.

headline: Hot Links
text: Americans have been high on the hog lately. Thanks to the reintroduction of heritage breeds, humble pork cuts like belly, neck and Boston butt have gained entree status at restaurants of every caliber, and bacon is suddenly suitable as a gift. If you want to outclass your competitive eating friends this summer, may we suggest bringing homemade sausage to the table?

headline: 36 Hours in Istanbul
text: THE Turks have changed tactics. For centuries, the sultans of Istanbul sent forth their armies, seizing territories across Europe, the Middle East and North Africa. This time, it's a style offensive. And the spoils of the conquests are everywhere. Downbeat neighborhoods have re-emerged as artist and night life enclaves. Medieval Ottoman motifs are winding up on T-shirts and design products. Plain kebabs are getting epicurean makeovers, and Old World hammams are being converted into jet-setters' spas. With architecture from the Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman periods as a backdrop, Istanbul is now the rare place where readers of Archeology and Wallpaper magazines can clink glasses with equal zeal.

headline: Vogue Plays Fairy Godmother
text: A WEEK before the Costume Institute party at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the actress Elizabeth Banks, needing a gown for the event, arrived at the offices of Vogue. Editors had assembled a rack of eight dresses, and Ms. Banks tried each one on, had it pinned around her slender frame and posed for a Polaroid camera.

headline: June
text: JUNE

headline: Stress on Troops Adds to U.S. Hurdles in Iraq
text: The detailed mental health survey of troops in Iraq released by the Pentagon on Friday highlights a growing worry for the United States as it struggles to bring order to Baghdad: the high level of combat stress suffered during lengthy and repeated tours.

headline: Rome: Bassetti Tessuti
text: Bassetti Tessuti is more than Rome's largest fabric store. It's a secret world in a nondescript palazzo that is the textile superstore for many of Italy's top designers, dressmakers and debonair businessmen alike.

headline: When Carbon Is Currency
text: AMID steadily increasing carbon emissions, and a federal government hesitant to take the lead on climate legislation, 10 states have joined to create the first mandatory carbon cap-and-trade program in the United States. They aim to reduce emissions from power plants by 10 percent in 10 years.

headline: Bad Behavior Within Reason
text: The novel in stories is the Rube Goldberg contraption of the literary world, fiction that works in wondrous and roundabout ways. While the short story pauses to explore an illuminated moment, and the novel chugs toward a grand conclusion, the novel in stories moves in spirals and loops, a corkscrewing joy ride. Read the chapters in any order, and the overall narrative experience often remains virtually the same. For this reason alone, the novel in stories may be the most tuned-in form of contemporary storytelling. Nothing is lost in setting one’s reading on shuffle.

headline: Why the Movies Keep Digging Into TV’s Bottomless Dustbin
text: SAMUEL JOHNSON notoriously compared a woman preaching to “a dog walking on its hind legs.” “It is not done well,” he mused, “but you are surprised to see it done at all.” Johnson’s view of animal behavior may be as dated as his ideas about women. At least in movies, the spectacle of a dog walking, talking, dancing and flying does not seem especially surprising.

headline: Hyatt Promises ‘Homey’ Feeling in New Chain
text: The Global Hyatt Corporation is hoping the word Andaz will soon be a brand name as well known to consumers as, say, Hyatt. Meaning ”personal style” in Hindi, the name is being given to the renovated Great Eastern Hotel in London’s financial district. This first Andaz is to open this fall and be followed in late 2008 by a second Andaz in New York at 75 Wall Street and a third, the following year, on Fifth Avenue across from the New York Public Library.

headline: Correction: Adventures in Low-Cost Travel
text: An article April 22 about budget airlines in Europe misstated the number of airports in the London area. There are five (Heathrow, Gatwick, Luton, Stansted and London City), not four.

headline: Helena Yu and Anthony Yu
text: Helena Alexandra Yu, the daughter of Choon E. Yu and Dr. Young J. Yu of Lewiston, N.Y., was married yesterday to Anthony Francis Yu, a son of Carmen Yu and Dr. Guan-Hiok Yu of Dix Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Rex T. Stewart, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Youngstown, N.Y.

headline: The Heel Is Rising
text: WE were bound for a farmhouse, and I had my doubts.

headline: Life Comes Full Circle While Driving on an Oval
text: RICHMOND, Va., May 5  Strands of gray have crept into Jeff Gordon’s stylish sideburns, betraying the youthful, metrosexual image that has helped sell watches, cologne, clothing, food, drink and Nascar to the masses.

headline: A Secret Garden of Golf (Mind the Jungle)
text: FIVE years ago, after a hiatus of nearly three decades, I began swinging the driver again in Indonesia.

headline: Hail to the Analysand
text: “WHEN a pretension to free the world from evil ends only in a new proof of the danger of a fanatic to the commonweal, then it is not to be marveled at that a distrust is aroused in the observer which makes sympathy impossible.”

headline: With Move Into 2nd Round, Nets Leave Struggles Behind
text: By the time Richard Jefferson secured the Nets a spot in the Eastern Conference semifinals late Friday night, the perils of a rocky regular season seemed to be but a scuff on their shoes.

headline: Halfway Humanity
text: “In your discussion of the term age-appropriate,” writes Prof. Erik Smith of Concordia University, Montreal, “you identified Harrison Ford as ‘middle-aged.’ Mr. Ford is 64. If he were literally middle-aged, then he could expect to live to 128. By describing themselves as middle-aged, are not those in their 60s and even 70s guilty of some rather overoptimistic math?”

headline: Austro Turf
text: Burgenland unfurls like a long ribbon through eastern Austria, nudging up against Hungary, Slovenia and Slovakia. Here the Alps loom farther in the background; the land is somewhat flat, a patchwork of sunflower fields, farmsteads and small, scraggy-looking vineyards perched on hills. Until 1989, when the Iron Curtain came down, a high chain-link fence crisscrossed the border between Burgenland and Hungary. “No one wanted to come here,” explained Gerhard Kracher, a third-generation vintner whose family has been producing prestigious wines here for decades. “It was the end of the world, but there was great weather and world-class sweet wines.”

headline: The Short Supply of Competitive Balance
text: Last Thursday the Golden State Warriors eliminated the Dallas Mavericks. That was a shock, since it was the first time since the N.B.A. went to a best-of-seven format in the first round of the playoffs that the lowest- seeded team in a conference defeated the top seed.

headline: Now Mowing | No-Impact Sheep
text: Don Watson raises some of the best milk-fed lambs on the planet. The ones that don’t make it to Chez Panisse are rented out as lawn mowers in Northern California. Watson says his Wooly Weeders can digest noxious plants and manage steep hillsides and tightly spaced vineyards while leaving behind rich fertilizer. Vintners, like the Mondavi family, have hired them to snack on leaves that drain nutrients from grapes. Others use them to prevent brush fires. Guarantees Watson, “Five hundred sheep will turn 10 grassy acres into a golf course, overnight.”

headline: F.A.A. Downgrades Indonesian Air System
text: Anyone jetting off to Jakarta, Bali or the other islands of Indonesia, take note: On April 16, the United States Federal Aviation Administration announced that it had changed Indonesia’s air safety oversight category from a 1 to a 2, because of “serious concerns” over safety.

text: Dwindling Funds Jeopardize Immigrant Center

headline: Increased State Aid or Not, Districts Seek Higher Taxes
text: IN spite of record increases in state aid for next school year, most districts in Westchester and other New York City suburbs have proposed property tax increases well above the rate of inflation. District officials say they are handcuffed by big annual increases in teachers’ salaries and the rising cost of pensions, health insurance and energy.

headline: Correction: DJ AM: His Life, Times, Shoes		fashion
text: An article last Sunday about DJ AM, a leading party D.J., misspelled the surname of the editor of Us Weekly, which chronicled his relationship with Nicole Richie. She is Janice Min, not Minn.

Karrh Sr. of Swainsboro, Ga. Msgr. Michael J. Dempsey, a cousin of the bride, officiated at St. Andrew’s Roman Catholic Church in Bluffton, S.C.

headline: Samantha Miller, David Noever
text: Samantha Elizabeth Miller and David Anthony Noever were married on Friday at St. Mary of the Visitation Church in Huntsville, Ala. The Rev. Glen Sayers, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony with Robert Tracy, a Roman Catholic deacon and an uncle of the bride, participating.

headline: At Religious Preschools, Worries About Others Looking Over Their Shoulders
text: The city’s health code spells out hundreds of regulations governing preschools and day care centers, ranging from the urgent (rooftop play areas must be fenced; teachers must get inoculations and pass background checks) to the comparatively minor (one toilet per 15 children, and 30 square feet of space per child; no television for children under 2; no whole milk for children over 2).

headline: Correction: The Amis Inheritance
text: An article on April 22 about the writers Kingsley and Martin Amis omitted a word in a quotation from Kingsley’s biographer, Zachary Leader. He referred to Kingsley as “the finest British comic novelist of the second half of the 20th century,” not the finest comic novelist.

headline: Tobacco Road
text: It is a familiar exchange: I step up to the counter at a convenience store and order my daily ration of Camel cigarettes, which I have been smoking since the Reagan administration and, as it happens, am smoking as I type this. Sliding the pack across the counter, the clerk — female clerks, typically; male clerks are more laissez-faire — sighs and says to me, “You know you need to quit.” My response, well honed over the years, goes like this: “I know I should quit,” I say, “but there’s one problem. I enjoy it.” On rare occasions, the clerk startles and smiles — that’s how it played out this morning — as if tickled by this forbidden admission. Far more frequently, however, I find myself at the receiving end of a uniformly bemused, pitying and faintly disgusted stare. I cannot possibly mean what I have just uttered, the stare says to me. The victim cannot confess to the crime. The cash register rings its tinny ring as the clerk slides the drawer shut and sadly wags her head.

headline: Keypad Economics: Why Talk When You Can Type?
text: Talking is starting to seem so old school to many cellphone users.

headline: Wizards in the Studio, Anonymous on the Street
text: THE songwriting session was so fresh that the aroma of the evening’s chicken wings still lingered. Behind the vast mixing board of a dimly lighted Manhattan recording studio, two producers and their co-writer greeted a record executive who had come to hear their work. With the press of a button, the room filled with sound: somber guitar arpeggios over a slow, sleek hip-hop beat, with layers of falsetto harmonies leading to a big, glittery, instantly memorable chorus. It was pure candy — sweetly melodic, but just funky enough to have a dance groove.

headline: Suicide Attacks and Gunfight in Afghanistan Kill 10 Police Officers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 5 — A wave of suicide attacks in four provinces of Afghanistan on Saturday killed two police officers and wounded a NATO soldier and two other Afghan policemen, and eight other Afghan police officers were killed in a gun battle with the Taliban, officials said.

headline: The Silver Lining to Impending Doom
text: ACROSS the world, doomsayers are smiling. The mounting signs of climate change have forced onto center stage the challenges of reducing carbon emissions and quickly adapting human activities to thrive in higher temperatures and more unpredictable weather.

headline: Sex Changes
text: My wife of 30 years and I are in our 60s. A few years ago she asked that we no longer engage in sex. “It’s not such a big deal anymore,” she said. She would not see a doctor or consider other help. I began an affair with a widow. Recently my wife found out and went ballistic. If she can casually renounce sex, can’t I seek it elsewhere?  name withheld, Massachusetts

headline: Trying to Discourage Draws That Please Players, Not Fans
text: Imagine going to a big tennis match and watching the players hit a few balls, shake hands and split the prize money. Of course, this is impossible in tennis, but something like this has gone on in chess for decades.

headline: One Plate the Ceramist Doesn’t Throw
text: YOU would think that ceramists like Adam Silverman would be grateful to Jonathan Adler for bridging the earnestness of pottery and the glibness of postmodern fashion. Mr. Adler’s peppy aesthetic revived interest in what had become an almost embarrassingly sincere form of craft.

headline: Ah, the Days of Spectacle and Bad Taste
text: IF there was any doubt that songs and sketches from classic Broadway revues could be reintroduced to the stage almost a century later, the director Jerry Zaks may have been feeling it.

headline: New Hawaii Ferry Is Set for July
text: Island hopping, at least from Oahu to Kauai and Maui, will be easier starting in July, when the Hawaii Superferry catamaran begins daily service from Honolulu. After six years of planning and more than a few battles with environmentalists, the ferry (below) has been cleared to operate between the three islands, which are now linked only by commercial airliner service.

headline: The Details Are in the Beauty
text: To a certain extent, the abstract style known as Color Field painting is a one-shot deal: what you see is what you get. Natvar Bhavsar, an Indian-born artist who has lived in New York since the 1960s, is trying to do something else with this fairly straightforward genre, as a stimulating retrospective of his work at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick seeks to show.

headline: New Aging Medicine
text: Here’s a sampling of innovations being developed by medical researchers to combat conditions and diseases associated with aging. Some are close to becoming reality; others are farther out on the horizon. — JOHN GLASSIE

headline: Now Registering | Wine Is Thicker Than Porcelain
text: For the New York investment banker Said Armutcuoglu, wedding gifts don’t get much better than the case of wines he got from Premier Cru. “We didn’t need another bowl,” he acknowledged. Although the bowls arrived anyway, the starter cellar that Armutcuoglu received ranged from Mouton to the rare Quintarelli amarone. Of course, not everyone has such generous friends, but that doesn’t affect the growing trend of registering for wine. “People want to be different,” said Carley Roney, the editor in chief and co-founder of the bridal magazine The Knot Weddings. “They’re getting married later and already have the espresso machine.” The process often starts with a consultation. Nicole Serle, in charge of wedding registries at Vino in New York, advises requesting an assortment of everyday bottles as well as wines that will appreciate in 5-, 10- and 15-year increments (proper storage is key). Stores like Kermit Lynch in Berkeley, Calif., and Sherry-Lehmann in New York are preparing for summer-wedding requests.

headline: Busted at the Regal
text: The mission was a botch. We debriefed over Chinese. Cherkis speared a piece of vegetarian black-pepper chicken and jabbed it in my direction.

headline: Spunky Nancy Drew Faces Her Hardest Case: Hollywood
text: ASK a healthy sampling of American women under 100 about Nancy Drew and chances are they will remember three things: the girl detective’s titian hair, her chums Bess and George and her blue roadster. The totemic automobile made its debut in 1930 in the first sentence of the first Nancy Drew mystery, “The Secret of the Old Clock.” In the years — and books, films, television shows and computer games — that followed, it morphed into a blue convertible, a red Mustang and a blue hybrid. Now the roadster is back, as blue and distinctive as ever, in “Nancy Drew,” which Warner Brothers will release on June 15.

headline: Other Reasons Borrowers Falter
text: FOR housing economists, the best gauge of whether borrowers will repay their mortgages is their job status. When unemployment jumps, foreclosures are not far behind.

headline: First Twenty20 Title Event Challenges World Cup
text: Cricket’s World Cup, which ended in farcical conditions after seven weeks of scant drama, could be upstaged by the inaugural championship in the sport’s shortest version, officials and players said.

headline: The Older-and-Wiser Hypothesis
text: In 1950, the psychoanalyst Erik H. Erikson, in a famous treatise on the phases of life development, identified wisdom as a likely, but not inevitable, byproduct of growing older. Wisdom arose, he suggested, during the eighth and final stage of psychosocial development, which he described as “ego integrity versus despair.” If an individual had achieved enough “ego integrity” over the course of a lifetime, then the imminent approach of infirmity and death would be accompanied by the virtue of wisdom. Unfortunately for researchers who followed, Erikson didn’t bother to define wisdom.

headline: The Pursuit of Dreams and a Harvard Degree; Call for a Watchman of the Waterways (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: It’s the Truth, but Not the Whole Truth
text: AN Ohio judge will decide on Friday whether to approve the settlement of a class-action suit against Carfax in which consumers could receive coupons worth about $20 and the lawyers representing them $566,000.

headline: Alyssa Qualls, John McCormick
text: Alyssa Anne Qualls and John Patrick McCormick were married yesterday at the First Unitarian Church of Providence in Rhode Island. The Rev. Charles F. Flagg performed the ceremony.

headline: 3 Are Arrested in Shootings; 1 More Sought
