Lubow of New York, was married last evening to Edward Necarsulmer IV, the son of Terry O’Toole Necarsulmer and Mr. Necarsulmer III of Quogue, N.Y. The Rev. Robert J. Verrigni, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York.

headline: From China to Panama, a Trail of Poisoned Medicine
text: The kidneys fail first. Then the central nervous system begins to misfire. Paralysis spreads, making breathing difficult, then often impossible without assistance. In the end, most victims die.

headline: How Cars Rate in Saving Our Necks
text: WHEN the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety recently rated 2007 cars for rear-impact protection, it found that almost two out of three did not do a good job protecting occupants from neck injuries.

headline: A Season of Events for Auto Lovers
text: AS the days grow warmer, a car lover’s cup runneth over. Whether it’s a concours or a swap meet, or some of the world’s most prestigious races, spring brings more than enough activities to keep an auto enthusiast happy — and busy.

headline: Where Their Heads Are in the Clouds
text: THE rain fell steadily from an impenetrable gray sky on a recent weekday morning, and an unseasonably cold wind whipped around the corner of 34th Street and Fifth Avenue. But nothing seemed to deter the raincoat-clad, umbrella-clutching line of figures wending their way into the lobby of the Empire State Building, not even the conspicuous sign bearing the words “Zero Visibility. No View.”

headline: Iced Storm
text: Unless you’re familiar with coffee concentrate, New Orleans iced coffee is a puzzling ritual. The first time I had it, I watched skeptically as a friend’s mother filled a plastic Mardi Gras cup with ice, poured in an inch of inky coffee from a mayonnaise jar, then topped it off with milk. It was as smooth as a milkshake but had a rich coffee flavor and packed a caffeinated punch. It was easily the best iced coffee I’d ever had, yet another thing that tastes better in New Orleans.

headline: Turning the Familiar Into Something Novel
text: MOKSHA is a good restaurant, with several dishes that have spoiled me for lesser versions. But one of my favorite things about it is inedible: the rough white washcloth handed to each patron that, when unrolled and used to clean one’s hands, sends up rose-scented steam all around. It helped us make the transition from the rainy gantlet of traffic and road construction along the way.

headline: As a Big Landowner Plans to Sell, Mouths Begin to Water
text: In the lobbies of some of the buildings near the Brooklyn waterfront owned by the Watchtower Bible and Tract Society, visitors can pick up plastic-wrapped packets of postcards depicting the organization’s various properties. On one, an aerial view of Brooklyn Heights, it seems as if nearly every third building is a Watchtower dormitory.

headline: Corzine to Resume Duties as Governor on Monday
text: HOBOKEN, N.J., May 5 — Gov. Jon S. Corzine plans to return to office on Monday, three and a half weeks after he suffered serious injuries in a car accident, his spokesman said Saturday.

headline: Secrets and Lies
text: “When they asked me why I lied, I lied,” confesses Steve Geng, small-time crook, sometime actor, drug addict and drunk. (Or is he lying and was he, in fact, telling the truth?) At the time, Geng was living at the Daytop Village rehab facility on Staten Island, wearing a “Pinocchio nose” and a can labeled “A Can of Lies” to remind him of his predilection. You’ve gotta love the literalness of recovery programs.

headline: A Beach Resort That’s Quiet Enough for a King
text: AS the late afternoon sun bathes the horizon in purple and crimson, I wander slowly down the long, curving beach. Though rocks mar part of the five-mile-long stretch, most of the waterfront is covered with white sand. On the southern end of the beachfront, a towering, slim golden Buddha statue peers out over the sea, and I can see small white and yellow shrines cut into the rocks of a nearby mountain fringed with low mist.

headline: Tea-Totalers
text: Teatime and cocktail hour have finally collided. Witness the Beijing Peach, made with jasmine-green-tea-infused vodka, served at the Flatiron Lounge in New York; the Mate Mojito (yerba mate tea, mint, rum and soda) served at the Camellia Lounge in Portland, Ore.; and the Po’my Leng from the Poleng Lounge in San Francisco.

headline: Does It Even Matter if the U.S. Has a Cold?
text: FOR the last several decades, the United States has functioned as the main engine of growth in a global economy that has been moving with synchronicity.

headline: Joanna Bloom, Brett Lindenbach
text: Joanna Faye Bloom and Brett David Lindenbach were married at the Municipal Building in New York on Friday by Blanca Martinez, a marriage officiant in the City Clerk’s office.

headline: Secret San Sebastian
text: Regulars at Aloria Berri — recently named the best bar in Spain by the prominent guidebook Gourmetour — used to tease its owner, José Ramon Elizondo, that they had to cross the desert to eat his alta cocina en miniatura. Actually, just a river. His place is a short walk from San Sebastian’s Old Quarter, on the other side of the Urumea River, in the emerging neighborhood of Gros. Once the province of working families and car-repair shops, Gros has become a draw for locals looking for an alternative to the city’s popular pintxo (tapas) bars. And besides, “everyone knows the best pintxos are in Gros,” says Elizondo, whose txirristra de mar (an architectural concoction of mackerel, vegetables and foie gras) took first prize in the National Tapas Competition in 2006.

headline: Passing the Bucket
text: Across Tokyo, snooty barkeeps who practice molecular mixology have held on to at least one tradition: an old-fashioned ice bucket made by hand. These smooth-hewn caddies are shaped from Sawara wood, a cypress native to central Japan. It’s a superb natural insulator that keeps ice drier and less slushy than a metal strainer or bowl. Although Sawara trees are now protected by a government quota, prices are still reasonable: expect to pay about $160 (www.edocraft.com), while a stylish take on the traditional, made from another type of cypress, is $353 (www.b-zenjapan.com).

headline: Emily Lasner, Nicholas Brod
text: Emily Anne Lasner and Nicholas David Brod were married last evening at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington. Dr. Rodney Mariner, a rabbi, officiated.

headline: Lessons From the Diamond
text: I’M a pretty good baseball player and a really terrible guitarist. What I’ve learned from baseball has had a great impact on the kind of manager I’ve become, but it was the guitar that landed me my first technical job.

headline: On a Quiet Lane, an Unsettling Discovery
text: THE scene outside the Whitestone Lumber shop on April 26 did not entirely shatter the reputation of this Queens neighborhood as a quiet place: No shots were fired. But less than two weeks after a gunman at Virginia Tech killed 32 people and himself, the arrest of a Whitestone couple in their apartment above the store prompted residents to reflect on their own vulnerability.

headline: What Counts Most in College Admissions; Sound Barriers Make Perfect Sense (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taking the Long View
text: UNLIKE Fifth Avenue, whose mansions and museums keep a walker’s attention near to the ground, Central Park West is a skyscape, a panorama of tops and towers best seen from a distance. Now each end of this legendary street is anchored by modern architecture: at 106th Street, the 2004 condominium building and, just this year, 15 Central Park West, at 61st Street, an urbane mega-tower designed by Robert A. M. Stern to display a rich tapestry of historical allusion.

headline: Stupid and Contagious
text: Until I received the assignment to review Everett True’s “Nirvana,” I hadn’t listened to the band much in recent years. In this I suspect I’m like most of us who were in our late teens or early 20s when Nirvana’s singer, songwriter and guitarist, Kurt Cobain, died in April 1994, hardly two and a half years after the release of “Nevermind.” There was so much hype — inevitable word — over Nirvana and its demise that the music later seemed somehow buried beneath the ephemera it occasioned. It became almost embarrassing to listen, in one’s dorm room, to Cobain’s strangely sarcastic and inviting voice, when journalists had called him the voice of our generation. And the band’s tortured ambivalence over its tremendous popularity grew to seem sadly quaint. When “Nevermind” came out, the marketing of the Persian Gulf war as a blockbuster action film was a fresh outrage, as was the recruitment of the Beatles’ song “Revolution” as an advertising jingle; we were not yet thoroughly familiar with the emotional indecency of commercialization. We are now four years into the gulf war’s skillfully marketed sequel, while Cobain’s widow, Courtney Love, has recently licensed her husband’s song “Breed” for use by a manufacturer of video games. How to listen to the anthems of the early ’90s in what are already the late ’00s? What does “Smells Like Teen Spirit” sound like when you’re in your 30s, as Kurt Cobain, dead at 27, of course will never be?

headline: Hamas Rejects U.S. Proposals as ‘Terrorist’
text: JERUSALEM, May 5 — Hamas, which leads the government of the Palestinian Authority and dominates its legislature, on Saturday poured scorn on American proposals to increase Palestinian movement and Israeli security.

headline: Who Can Use Co-op’s Roof?
text: Q How can a shareholder in a co-op determine if the owner of the penthouse has exclusive use of the roof? At the annual meeting a few years ago, the board president suggested making a roof garden. I later found out that the owner of the penthouse threatened to sue the board if the issue was pursued.

headline: Wang’s Bid for Perfection Couldn’t Come at Better Time
text: Chien-Ming Wang of Tainan, Taiwan, is a talented and polite Yankees pitcher who has little to say in two languages. But Wang came close to giving the baseball world and 51,702 witnesses something special to talk about yesterday at Yankee Stadium.

headline: With Ryan Getzlaf
text: Anaheim center Ryan Getzlaf has had 7 points in 10 playoff games as the Ducks have advanced to the N.H.L.’s Western Conference finals. Getzlaf, who turns 22 on Thursday, said he would spend his free time golfing as Anaheim awaited the winner of the Detroit-San Jose series. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

headline: Shock Radio Shrugs at Imus’s Fall and Roughs Up the Usual Victims
text: Almost two weeks after CBS Radio fired Don Imus for his racially and sexually demeaning remarks about the Rutgers women’s basketball team, Nick Di Paolo opened his talk show on another CBS station in New York by mocking a manual that, he said, one of his bosses had given him that morning.

headline: Home in the Range? Who Can Sing What
text: IN 1998 Luciano Pavarotti canceled an appearance at the Grammy Awards at the last minute, and Aretha Franklin stepped in to perform the famous tenor aria “Nessun dorma” from Puccini’s “Turandot.” A friend of mine, a pop music writer, was agog at the feat. “Isn’t this a very difficult aria to sing?” he asked. “Isn’t it amazing that she could do it?”

headline: Immigrants’ Hopes, and Their Fears, Change a Westchester Town
text: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 4  For Alex Gregorio and Aydee Romero, these are good times in Mount Kisco.

headline: Mayweather Wins Decision Over De La Hoya
text: LAS VEGAS, May 5 — Floyd Mayweather Jr. had just defeated Oscar De La Hoya in their superwelterweight title bout in a split decision Saturday night when a controversy threatened to delay, if not upend, his victory.

headline: Energy and Safety
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has now added his voice to the chorus of New York lawmakers imploring the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to conduct a thorough, independent safety inspection at the Indian Point nuclear plant in Buchanan — not the routine maintenance and oversight that the commission insists is all that’s needed, but a special, meticulous, top-to-bottom review that includes experts from outside the region and input from the state.

headline: Mariners Reliever Mateo Is Charged With Assault
text: Julio Mateo, a relief pitcher for the Seattle Mariners, was arrested yesterday after an early-morning incident in which, the police said, he struck his wife in a Midtown Manhattan hotel room.

headline: My Warming Garden
text: Gardeners are used to change. No two summers are alike, and what one year offers in rainfall is withdrawn the next in drought. In many gardeners — especially in the North — there is also a resignation to the limits of their growing seasons. But those are changing, and more quickly than anyone could imagine. The National Arbor Day Foundation has published a new hardiness zone map, based on climate data from the past 15 years, that clearly shows the warming trend across the country.

headline: Get Back to Work
text: Imagine a shy, observant American girl, born in the middle of the last century. For years, her mother comes home from her job as an editor and puts in a second shift cooking, cleaning and supervising homework while Dad dozes in front of the TV. Gradually, the girl realizes that something is very wrong. When she is 13, her mother gives her a newly published book and says, “Read this,” and her life begins to change.

headline: In a Tangled Family Drama, the Son Grasps for a Role
text: There’s a broad spectrum of feeling and behavior buried within the deceptively simple words “family drama”; the term can cover everything from “Agamemnon” to “Hamlet” to “The Sopranos.” But mostly we tend to think of such plays as smaller in scale, more personal and less cosmic — even when they are masterpieces, like “A Doll’s House” or “Long Day’s Journey Into Night.”

headline: Edward F. Boyd Dies at 92; Marketed Pepsi to Blacks
text: Edward F. Boyd, who as a young sales executive parlayed his assignment to promote Pepsi-Cola to fellow blacks into a war against white racism and black stereotypes, meanwhile selling oceans more soda, died on April 30 in Los Angeles, PepsiCo announced. He was 92.

text: JUDITH A. JACOBS, the presiding officer of the Nassau County Legislature, removed her deputy, Roger Corbin, last month, the latest flare-up between the two Democratic leaders. But Mr. Corbin may be able to resume his leadership position.

headline: A New Style of Hotel Where Work Meets Play
text: SIMON SINEK is a communications consultant who lives in Manhattan — at least when he’s not traipsing around the country on business. In just one month, he will have traveled to five different cities, from Atlanta to Seattle, and spent a considerable amount of time in hotels.

headline: In a Return to Normal in Trenton, Sniping Over Ethics in Budgeting

Corzine’s life-threatening injuries from his traffic accident three weeks ago seemed to suck much of the oxygen from the everyday political battles here  except for a few stray elbows thrown among the staffs of the governor and his stand-in, Senate President Richard J. Codey.

headline: Putting the ‘Avant’ in Avant-Garde
text: AS Lila del Corte Hirschfeld was about to turn 1, her mother was feeling slightly frantic. Like many New York parents, Jenny 8 del Corte Hirschfeld (the numeral is her middle name) had a vision for her daughter’s birthday party, though hers was more Dalí than Disney. In place of balloons and goody bags, this one had a working title — “El Ataque de los Trapos” (“The Attack of the Cleaning Cloths”) — and would be filmed using seven movie cameras, all borrowed for the occasion.

headline: Muscular Metaphor
text: Posit Science Brain Fitness Program

headline: Why Not the Worst?
text: Last year, I stumbled upon a remarkable book called “The Talisman of Troy.” Written by Valerio Massimo Manfredi, “The Talisman of Troy” chronicled the adventures of Diomedes, a second-tier hero in the “Iliad,” after the fall of Troy. Bristling with sentences like “Anchialus shuddered: in that boy was the awesome power of the son of Peleus, but not a crumb of his father’s piety, nor his hospitable manners,” the novel advanced the theory that Helen of Troy had not really been abducted by Paris, son of Priam, but had deliberately gone to Asia Minor in order to get her hands on a sacred totem — the talisman of Troy — that would enable women to rule the world. The book is thus one of life’s unalloyed pleasures: an uncompromisingly stupid novel in a world filled with stupid novels that do make compromises. And, by virtue of its faux Hellenic inanity and all-purpose Delphic hootiness, it is also a powerful weapon in the hands of those of us who work night and day to resist the tyranny of the good.

text: FOR me the defining moment of Paul Kellogg’s 11-year tenure as general and artistic director of the New York City Opera came on Saturday, Sept. 15, 2001. Four days after 9/11 the company opened a delayed season with new productions of Wagner’s “Flying Dutchman” in the afternoon and Gilbert and Sullivan’s “Mikado” in the evening.

headline: U.S. Bishop, Making It Official, Throws in Lot With African Churchman
text: WOODBRIDGE, Va. May 5  The Anglican archbishop of Nigeria, Peter J. Akinola, on Saturday installed Bishop Martyn Minns of Virginia as the new leader of a diocese that would take in congregations around the country that want to leave the Episcopal Church. In doing so, Archbishop Akinola rejected requests by leaders of the worldwide Anglican Communion and the Episcopal Church to refrain from taking part in the ceremony.

headline: Cape Town Wants Visitors to Feel Safe
text: Some three million visitors are expected in Cape Town and the Western Cape in 2010, when Cape Town will be one of nine host cities in South Africa for the soccer World Cup. In anticipation of this influx, Cape Town Tourism (www.tourismcapetownco.za), in partnership with other city organizations, has implemented a safety plan it hopes will create a more secure environment — though it seems in some ways to be less about prevention than helping the latest victims.

headline: Statue of Limitations
text: Historical mysteries often convey a sense of yearning for people and places irretrievably lost in time. That feeling surfaced in Mark Mills’s haunting first novel, “Amagansett,” as a lyrical lament for a Long Island fishing community whose traditional way of life was doomed by the booming prosperity of postwar America. Although a keen sense of loss and longing also suffuses Mills’s second novel, THE SAVAGE GARDEN (Putnam, $24.95), the youth of its protagonist and the thrill of his exploits as an amateur sleuth keep depression at bay in this romantic and gracefully executed literary puzzle.

headline: Ellen Hayes, Robert Friedman

text: FOR many New Yorkers, familiarity with nature comes mainly in the form of extravagant salads, but for Steve Brill, extravagant salads come from his familiarity with nature. He has been living off the bounty of the city’s parks for 25 years, feasting on wild edibles and leading foraging tours twice a week.

headline: Lessons of the Game
text: JUST before the start of a T-ball game last summer, my son Christopher threw me a curve.

headline: Paris: The Five Hôtel
text: THE BASICS The Five Hôtel, open for about seven months now, aims to compete with the new boutique hotels now scattered about Paris. The interior design is so striking it can be fatiguing — especially in the red-leather paneled hall. The tiny lobby — warmed with a red-painted gas fireplace — is filled with purposefully mismatched geometric shaped chairs in black and white patterns. Every room has a different color scheme — gray wallpaper accented with teal velvet; stripes of blood red and orange; black and taupe. All feature tiny white lights that create a planetarium effect.

headline: A Liberal Case for Gun Rights Sways Judiciary
text: In March, for the first time in the nation’s history, a federal appeals court struck down a gun control law on Second Amendment grounds. Only a few decades ago, the decision would have been unimaginable.

headline: A Scoop, Topped With Politics
text: Residents of the West Village may debate whether scrappy political activism, once a staple of the neighborhood, is still alive and well in this quaint maze of tree-lined streets or finally has given way to a shameless pursuit of the sumptuous life. But Adam Riff, a legislative aide to State Senator Thomas Duane, has found an unlikely way to marry the two currents.

text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5 — Angel Cordero Jr. has ridden his last horse race. Or maybe he hasn’t. He can’t decide.

text: In a sea of church ladies with wide white hats and deacons in dark suits sat 120 broad-shouldered men wearing orange-and-yellow reflective vests, transit workers come to bid goodbye to one of their own.

headline: Sarkozy Wins the Chance to Prove His Critics Wrong
text: PARIS, May 6 — Arrogant, brutal, an authoritarian demagogue, a “perfect Iago”: the president-elect of France has been called a lot of unpleasant things in recent months and now has five years to prove his critics wrong.

headline: Book of Revelations
text: If there’s such a thing as boomer cuisine, it can be found in the pages of “The Silver Palate Cookbook.” With its chirpy tone and “Moosewood”-in-the-city illustrations, the book, published in time for Mother’s Day in 1982, gave millions of home cooks who hadn’t mastered the art of French cooking the courage to try sophisticated dishes like escabeche, wild mushroom soup and that new thing called pesto. Years later, mothers sent their grads into the world with their raspberry-vinaigrette-stained copies. And now, with the 25th-anniversary edition, a new generation will try dishes like chicken Marbella, which once seemed as risky (capers! prunes!) as the East Village.

text: Los Angeles

headline: Torre Suspects Pavano Is Gone for Year

headline: A Generation of Strivers Sits for Its Portrait
text: More than 40 years after their first days in Kew Gardens, Queens, the children from Public School 99 came together again last week — older, grayer, more distinguished, maybe a little shorter. They had met up in the past, of course, sharing rugelach on a walk through the neighborhood or chatting across the world on the phone, but Monday night was different. This time, they would be on film.

headline: Ice-Cream Capades
text: Mister Softee meets his match when Heartschallenger rolls into the Big Apple this month. The powder-pink trucks are stocked with ice cream and global treats served up by Leyla Safai, an L.A.-based artist, and her musician beau, Ben Pollock, who wrote a collection of modern melodies to accompany their arrival (think Good Humor with an electro-pop twist). The couple, who also perform as the band Heartsrevolution, travel wherever the truck is hired to enliven weddings, birthday parties, even film festivals. Heartschallenger also collaborates with local artists across the country to curate curbside exhibitions, show films, play music and share sweets like the artist Gary Garay’s ice pops shaped into peace signs. Next stops: England and France. Go to www.heartschallenger.com.

headline: States Ponder Laws to Keep Web Predators From Children
text: HARTFORD, May 4  Nearly every American teenager, it seems, has a Web page displaying his or her life details. And nearly every parent has nightmares that someone might visit those pages, easily discovering where the children live and what they like.

headline: Creatures on the Knife’s Edge
text: IT’S almost like old times in the northern Rockies of western Wyoming and Montana. Gray wolves are hunting elk. Grizzlies are eating berries, elk and anything else they can find. Bald eagles are no longer a rare sight.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: Death on the Tracks
text: The deaths of two subways workers, each hit by trains in separate accidents in the last two weeks, reminds us that maintaining New York’s subway tracks is necessary and dangerous work. The system is vital to hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, requiring expeditious repair when things break down; it is also a century old, with many original and near-original components that need constant attention or replacement.

headline: Stop and Smell the Barrenwort
text: ADRIAN BENEPE, New York City's parks commissioner, boasts that when it comes to gardens, New York City is “comparable with Paris.”

headline: Whose Secrets?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Roughaging It
text: Agritourism takes the bed-and-breakfast model one step further, providing a rural respite on working farms, where travelers can pick berries for breakfast and learn to milk a cow. At MaryJanesFarm (www.maryjanesfarm.org/bb) in Moscow, Idaho, visitors sleep in walled tents (above) equipped with antique propane ranges and outdoor showers. Weatherbury Farm (www.weatherburyfarm.com) in Avella, Pa., offers suites in a renovated livery stable overlooking its cattle-grazing meadow.

headline: Letters
text: A Good Provider Is One Who Leaves

headline: You’ve Got Trouble
text: A few years back, when my son was in college, he had to mail a letter. I don’t remember the specific reason, but I do remember having a conversation with him in which he complained bitterly about the amount of work involved — finding a place where he could purchase a stamp, figuring out what kind of stamp he needed, actually writing the letter, locating an envelope, putting the letter into the envelope, having to physically leave his dormitory room to mail the envelope and so on. I grew exhausted just listening to him describe this series of arduous tasks, one coming right after another. I was glad, for my son’s sake, that he never had to live in a world — as I once did — where the only way to change channels was to walk all the way to the TV set and manually turn a knob.

headline: ‘Consumed’
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Prince of Pulp, Legit at Last
text: ALL his life the science fiction writer Philip K. Dick yearned for what he called the mainstream. He wanted to be a serious literary writer, not a sci-fi hack whose audience consisted, he once said, of “trolls and wackos.” But Mr. Dick, who popped as many as 1,000 amphetamine pills a week, was also more than a little paranoid. In the early ’70s, when he had finally achieved some standing among academic critics and literary theorists — most notably the Polish writer Stanislaw Lem — he narced on them all, writing a letter to the F.B.I. in which he claimed they were K.G.B. agents trying to take over American science fiction.

headline: TV’s Silver Age
text: TV Land, that cable network repository of pop-culture comfort food, knows how to put on a splashy marketing event. The current resting place for series like “The Andy Griffith Show,” “Bewitched” and “Little House on the Prairie,” TV Land transformed a restaurant in Times Square into the Bat cave, complete with Adam West and Julie Newmar prowling the premises and the Batmobile parked outside, to celebrate its fifth anniversary in 2001. On a rainy afternoon in March, however, the network forsook its usual irreverent shout-outs to television’s past glory. Instead, for its latest effort to woo advertisers and media buyers, TV Land hired Bill Clinton to speak soberly about the future of the planet.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: THE TRAIN OR THE PLANE?

headline: The Future of P.E. (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Glass House Full of the Past Opens to the Present
text: On Dec. 12, 1948, The New York Times published an article about crowds “in holiday mood” blocking traffic in an old Connecticut village of stately colonial homes. Nearing completion on Ponus Ridge in New Canaan, Conn., was the ultramodern, all-glass house of the flamboyant modernist architect Philip Johnson. Nothing like it had been seen in these conservative, well-heeled parts.

headline: Going Up
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tony Blair Prepares for a Subdued Exit
text: LONDON, May 5 — It began with an effusive exuberance as Britain’s Labor party came in from 18 years of opposition in 1997 in a landslide won by a bright and young politician called Tony Blair. Nothing seemed impossible. He spoke of a new dawn. The party’s campaign song declared, “Things can only get better.”

headline: Bridgeport: Stop Litigating
text: Bridgeport owes at least $2 million in legal fees and millions more in interest incurred during its six-year effort to avoid paying a contractor, C. R. Klewin Northeast, for its work on the Arena at Harbor Yard in 2001.

headline: It Slices. It Dices...
text: The Cuisinart food processor was the right machine at the right time for Sheila Lukins and Julee Rosso. ‘‘When we started the Silver Palate in 1977, we didn’t have a real kitchen,’’ Rosso says of their gourmet takeout shop and catering business on New York’s Upper West Side. ‘‘The health department demanded it, so we opened one around the corner with three used refrigerators and three brand-new Cuisinarts.’’

headline: ‘Esalen’
text: Esalen is on the edge. Located in Big Sur, California, just off Highway 1 on approximately one hundred and fifty acres of stunning natural beauty, Esalen is, geographically speaking, a cliff suspended about one hundred feet above the crashing surf and kelp-congested tides of the Pacific Ocean. By all measures, it is a stunning place, replete with natural beauty and a certain physical paradox, partly produced by the proximate presence of mountains and ocean; indeed, the rocky heights seem to drop directly into the watery depths here or, more true to the place's primeval geological history, it is as if the heights rise up out of the depths. Henry Miller called Big Sur "a religion where extremes meet." Indeed. The physical paradox of the land is deepened further by a simple, but somehow profound, historical and geographic fact: these, after all, are grounds that both constitute the very edge of the American frontier and look due west to see the East. Certainly Walter Truett Anderson had it right when he wrote, "If a place can have charisma, then surely this one has it."

headline: ‘Later, at the Bar’
text: That winter there were two snowstorms. The first one was expected. Born in Florida and galvanized by the damp winds of the Pennsylvania mountains, it was strong as a wildcat by the time it reached upstate New York. The YMCA closed early and so did the library. The mayor declared a state of emergency, which it was. There were three head-on collisions on Route 19 and a teenager froze to death after falling into one of the gorges on the north end of town. Hank Stevens, who owned Hank's Diner, couldn't get out of his driveway and had to stay at home with his children. ("No," he said all afternoon. "Daddy cannot go outside and build a fort. Daddy doesn't own snow pants.")

headline: ‘Send’
text: Bad things can happen on email. Consider Michael Brown, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, who committed the following thoughts to email during the very worst days of Hurricane Katrina.

headline: ‘The Happiness Myth’
text: Know yourself. This is the key to all philosophy, the center of all wisdom, the one thing that decides if you are the actor in a tragedy or a comedy. This chapter points out three major interpretations of this singular injunction. The first is the Socratic, and it has to do with knowing what you believe. The second is Freudian and has to do with knowing who you are. The third is lonely and has to do with training yourself to take your intellect as your own companion.

headline: ‘Bigger Deal: A Year Inside the Poker Boom’
text: In 1978, the year I first visited Las Vegas for the World Series of Poker, Bobby "the Owl" Baldwin beat a record field of forty-two players to the title of world champion and a handsome first prize of $270,000. A decade later, in 1988, the first time I played in the main event myself, there were all of 167 starters and the title was worth $700,000. By 2005, when I take part again at the beginning of this book, the field has risen to nearly six thousand. The first prize is $7.5 million and all nine players who reach the final table become dollar millionaires.

headline: ‘The Joy of Drinking’
text: Here on my scruffy, untamed mountainside in northern Virginia, if you stand on the kitchen steps and pitch a rotten peach into the woods, in a few years you will have a fine peach tree. In years when May doesn't spring a sharp freeze and the squirrels don't, for reasons inscrutable, harvest the unripe crop, you will have more peaches than anyone can possibly eat or freeze.

headline: ‘I’ll Sleep When I’m Dead’
text: Warren's father, William Rubin Zivotofsky, was born in Kiev, Ukraine, in 1903. His father, Rubin, left for New York in 1905, and the Zivotofskys of Ukraine became the Zevons of Brooklyn.

headline: ‘Thick as Thieves’
text: One of these days that kid's gonna get his tit in a wringer. It was the voice of an old, familiar ghost, and it spoke to me as I stumbled through waist-high drifts in the blizzard of '96. According to newscasters, this was the worst snowstorm to hit New York in decades. Parked cars on Tenth Avenue were visible only as little bumps on the white, silent landscape. And still it came down, big wind-whipped flakes that nipped my cheeks and scrambled my senses. I wasn't exactly homeless, but some instinct had been driving me through the streets, hunched into the storm. There was little refuge back where I'd come from.

headline: ‘Rethinking Thin’
text: If you met Carmen J. Pirollo, you might not realize that he has a weight problem. He's a square-jawed, animated man, who talks in exclamation points, favors preppy clothes, and-the big hint that he's a bit self-conscious-sometimes doesn't tuck in his shirts. Yet while you may notice his abdomen under that shirt, he is not what you might think of as obese. He does not seem to have any trouble moving, and when he sits down, he does not spill out of his chair. He's not like one of the subjects in those insulting, deliberately humiliating photos that show up in magazine articles or on television programs to illustrate the horrors of the obesity epidemic-those familiar images of round-faced, double-chinned people captured stuffing hamburgers into their mouths or of a fat family lumbering past fast food restaurants, dipping into bags of popcorn or licking ice cream cones.

headline: It’s the Truth, but Not the Whole Truth
text: AN Ohio judge will decide on Friday whether to approve the settlement of a class-action suit against Carfax in which consumers could receive coupons worth about $20 and the lawyers representing them $566,000.

headline: A Greener IPCC?
text: Last week in Bangkok, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change announced that the world’s nations would have to divert their reliance on fossil fuels in the next few decades to avert a climate change catastrophe.

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: EDITH WHARTON, by Hermione Lee. (Knopf, $35.) This meticulous biography shows Wharton’s significance as a designer, decorator, gardener and traveler, as well as a writer.

headline: Paperback Row
text: EVERYMAN, by Philip Roth. (Vintage International, $13. ) A nameless protagonist grapples with aging, physical decline and impending death in this slender, elegant novel. Roth begins with Everyman’s end: the novel opens at his funeral, and goes back in time as he ponders his middleclass New Jersey boyhood, his successful advertising career on Madison Avenue, his three failed marriages and a series of increasingly frequent health crises. “Everyman” won the 2007 PEN/Faulkner award for fiction. “Roth takes the writer’s free acknowledgment of many literary modes,” Nadine Gordimer wrote in the Book Review, “while unceasingly experimenting with his own.”

headline: State of the Rotation
text: The Yankees' starting rotation has struggled through injuries and ineffectiveness early in the season.

headline: Neon's Back.
text: Acid colors flicker back to life. Don't get way excited.

headline: Gear Test With Mark Hagen, Cyclist
text: Cyclists need clothing versatile enough to handle vast fluctuations in conditions — especially wind and sudden showers.

headline: Smiles and Flowers
text: Takashi Murakami's show at Gagosian Gallery includes paintings of the founder of Zen Buddhism and smiley-faced flowers.

headline: Photos: Clemens’s Career Continues
text: At age 44, Roger Clemens will resume his pitching career by returning to the Yankees.

headline: French Voters Pick Sarkozy
text: Nicolas Sarkozy earned a decisive victory over Ségolène Royal, keeping the right in power for another five years.

headline: Correction: Varmints!
text: The On Language column on April 22, about "varmint," misstated the magazine in which President Bush used the word in 2004. It was Field & Stream, not Outdoor Life.

headline: 36 Hours in Istanbul
text: A weekend in a city best described as venerable and youthful, holy and avant-garde.

headline: Fabulous fairways
text: Gorgeous

headline: Around the neighborhood
Why We Travel
text: "It’s at the bottom of a sandstone ravine, surrounded by gum trees — a really quiet place. I was just thinking how good it was to be back home again, to be with my family, to be back in the bush.”

headline: My New Column Days
text: Anybody looking for my column today, Sunday, will be puzzled. That’s because we’re all switching days. My new column days are Mondays and Thursdays….

headline: Sunday Sampler Platter
text: The biggest news from the Sunday talk shows was probably the declaration of doubt  by the Republican leader of the House, Representative John Boehner, about whether his fellow Republican lawmakers would continue to support President Bush on Iraq if no progress is evident by early autumn.

headline: Who Said Anything About ‘War Powers’?
text: Since the founding of the Republic there have been 12 major wars in 12 generations, and the ultimate result has been a steady rolling back of the ideas that guided the men who wrote the Constitution. On almost any reading it is clear that the framers expected Congress, not the president, to be the dominant element in American government.

headline: Iraq War Poetry Contest
text: In 2004 I held a contest for poetry about the war in Iraq and published the best of it. Three years later, with the war grimmer than ever, I’m now holding a second such contest.

headline: Your Comments on my Hillary Clinton Column
text: Please post your comments below on my Monday column about Hillary Rodham Clinton, the new aristocracy, and the presidency.

headline: Musings from Chase Field
text: It is days like this that I recall something Omar Minaya told me before last season. As much as he enjoys pursuing big-name free agents and working the phones to swing trades, Minaya says he has more fun assembling his bench.

headline: The All-Spin Zone
text: When Aristotle comes to the topic of style and persuasion in Book 3 of his “Rhetoric,” he draws back in distaste from a subject he considers “vulgar” and “unworthy.” The only reason I am talking about this stuff, he says, is because men are so susceptible to artfully devised appearances. In the best of all possible worlds we would “fight our case with no help beyond the bare facts,” for after all, “nothing should matter except the proof of those facts.”

headline: California's Impact on the Campaign
text: The effects of California moving up its primary to February 5 are being felt far and wide, not just in campaign tactics but in the very dialogue of the contest.

headline: American Twist
text: For all those awake in the world tonight, Liz Claiborne is acquiring Narciso Rodriguez. The deal in all its wild details will be in Monday’s paper. But, as I’ve been negligent with posts — and I’m sorry — I wanted to put the news up here first.

headline: The Rocket Lands in the Bronx
text: Brian Cashman has always believed that when you bring in Roger Clemens, you bring in more than just the winningest pitcher alive. You bring in an attitude, a presence, a drill sergeant and a guiding hand.

headline: Olmert Survives Three No-Confidence Motions
text: JERUSALEM, May 7 — Israel’s prime minister, Ehud Olmert, survived three no-confidence motions against his government today, following a harsh report on the performance of the country’s leadership during last summer’s war with Hezbollah in Lebanon.

headline: Counting Radio Listeners Stirs Controversy
text: A few weeks ago, Philadelphia became the first city in the United States to abandon the pen-and-ink diary system of collecting radio ratings data. Instead, Philadelphians who are being surveyed by Arbitron, the ratings measurement service, now wear pager-size devices that register hidden audio tones in nearby radio sound. Arbitron calls the devices Portable People Meters, or P.P.M.’s.

headline: Clemens Returns, and So Does Hope for Yankees
text: It was a news bulletin delivered before 52,553 fans on a glorious spring day at Yankee Stadium, where the season is suddenly alive with hope again. The man with more victories than any living pitcher was holding a Yankees microphone, addressing the crowd with a splash of the high drama that has punctuated his career.

headline: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the fraud trial of Conrad M. Black misspelled the given name of the former director of Mr. Black’s company who testified that she and other directors were misled about millions of dollars in payments to Mr. Black and other executives. She was Marie-Josée Kravis, not Marie-José.

headline: Appetite for Destruction: A Messianic Monster, Trained in Pain
text: Chuck Palahniuk’s new novel, “Rant,” takes its title from the noise made by children as they retch and vomit. The beautiful anatomical drawing on the book’s cover depicts a heart, since a cow’s heart appears in the novel as something used to make kids throw up. Details like these add up to an automatic deal breaker for anyone who has been tantalized from afar by Mr. Palahniuk’s visceral fiction and wondered if “Rant” was the place to start.

headline: Relocate the Stables (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

Because of a production error, the continuation of a front-page article yesterday about a rethinking of interpretation of the Second Amendment was omitted in some copies. The complete article is reprinted today on Page A18. It is also online: nytimes.com/national.

headline: Newfangled Silent Movie With a Bit of Old Barnum
text: For the Canadian filmmaker Guy Maddin, who has lately been testing the limits of both autobiography and movie nostalgia, his latest feature represents a double apotheosis.

headline: Throngs Attend Speech by Pakistan’s Suspended Justice
text: LAHORE, Pakistan, May 6 — The chief justice of Pakistan’s supreme court, suspended by the government after he investigated some of its practices, received an emotional welcome here on Sunday from thousands of supporters.

headline: Clash at U.N.-Run Gaza School Wounds 6
text: JERUSALEM, May 6 — A clash outside a United Nations-run school in the southern Gaza town of Rafah on Sunday left one Palestinian dead and six wounded, witnesses and Palestinian security officials said.

headline: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Rangers Fall Too Far Behind to Stay Alive
text: The emotions in Madison Square Garden bounced up and down as if on a spring throughout the third period of yesterday’s game: from disappointment to hope to dejection, back to hope again. It seemed as if the Rangers played their entire season in those final 20 minutes, finally falling just short.

headline: Cellphones Tailored for Any Organization
text: FOR decades, consumers have been able to choose a credit card based on its affiliation with a particular group — a college alumni association, for example, a sports team or a retailer that offers reward points.

headline: ‘Spider-Man 3’ Box Office Bodes Well for Summer
text: LOS ANGELES, May 6 — In Hollywood summer is supposed to open with a box-office bang, and if all goes well keep on popping through the next three months.

headline: Obama Criticizes Automakers on Fuel Economy
text: DETROIT, May 7 — Senator Barack Obama of Illinois criticized American auto companies today for doing too little to lessen the nation’s dependence on foreign oil and said the United States must adopt a more aggressive energy policy.

headline: Panel to Find That Wolfowitz Broke Rules, Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON, May 6  The World Bank committee investigating misconduct charges against Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank president, failed to complete its review on schedule this weekend, but bank officials said the panel would eventually find that he violated bank rules barring conflicts of interest.

headline: Afghan Soldier Said to Have Shot U.S. Military Trainers
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 7 — The man who shot and killed two American military trainers on Sunday, and wounded two others, was a soldier of the Afghan National Army, the Afghan Ministry of Defense confirmed today.

headline: Ottaways Deplore Bid by Murdoch
text: Two members of the Ottaway family, a minority partner in Dow Jones & Company, released scathing statements yesterday saying that a takeover by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation would ruin Dow Jones and its crown jewel, The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Devils Face Changes From Top On Down
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 6  Not long into what probably was Lou Lamoriello’s final postgame news conference as the Devils’ coach, the subject shifted abruptly from the game to Lamoriello’s decision to fire Claude Julien on April 2.

headline: Nets Wilt and Cavaliers Blossom in Final Minutes
text: CLEVELAND, May 6 — LeBron James bumped off Jason Kidd, drove to the basket and elevated for a runner that fell with a deft bounce off the glass.

headline: After the Pet Food Contamination
text: The purchase of toxic pet food ingredients from China is a chilling warning about the weakness of the nation’s defenses against tainted imported foods. Reports from pet owners indicate that the contaminated protein concentrate may have killed thousands of dogs and cats; it has also been found in farm animals.

headline: A Program of Five Ballets: Some Fluid, Others Formal
text: The American Repertory Ballet has been performing and teaching ballet in its home state, New Jersey, for half a century. But the dancing looked surprisingly pushed, particularly by the women, on Friday night at Symphony Space. The one exception among the program’s five pieces was Melissa Barak’s “Danzantes.”

headline: For the Record
text: A report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about a Congolese military tribunal clearing an opposition politician of inciting armed insurrection misspelled the name of the city in which the tribunal met. It is Kinshasa, not Kinshasha.

headline: Crispin Porter Acquires Radar Communications
text: Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, part of MDC Partners, has acquired and absorbed Radar Communications in Boulder, Colo., a consulting company specializing in market research that seeks to better understand consumer behavior. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Chávez Rattles Takeover Saber at Steel Company and Banks
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 6 — President Hugo Chávez is deepening efforts to assert greater control over the economy by dictating changes to the operations of a large Argentine-controlled steel maker and threatening to nationalize banks controlled by financial institutions from the United States and Spain.

headline: The Warhol of Japan Pours Ritual Tea in a Zen Moment
text: The unmistakable aroma of incense wafted through the Gagosian Gallery on Madison Avenue one afternoon last week. It wasn’t the only hint that business was not as usual. Instead of chicly dressed gallery assistants, demure Japanese ladies in colorful kimonos greeted visitors.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on April 21 about the removal of a mechanical ventilator from Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey eight days after he was seriously injured in a vehicular crash misstated the title of Dr. Ken Rodriguez of Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston, who discussed milestones for patients who have been removed from ventilators. He is the chief of orthopedic trauma, not orthopedic medicine.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,355 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Saturday:

headline: Methods Used by Insurers Are Questioned
text: WASHINGTON, May 6 — Insurance companies have used improper hard-sell tactics to persuade Medicare recipients to sign up for private health plans that cost the government far more than the traditional Medicare program, federal and state officials and consumer advocates say.

headline: As Pope Heads to Brazil, a Rival Theology Persists
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, May 2 — In the early 1980s, when Pope John Paul II wanted to clamp down on what he considered a dangerous, Marxist-inspired movement in the Roman Catholic Church, liberation theology, he turned to a trusted aide: Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger.

headline: In Domestic Abuse, Digital Photos Can Say More Than Victims
text: Her body was crisscrossed with his rage. And after she slipped off her clothes, wincing, the police officer photographed every welt. The bruises marbling her upper arm. The places where her skin broke. Her striated back, which looked as if it had been flogged with a cat o’ nine tails.

headline: Hendrick Team Dominates in Car of Tomorrow
text: RICHMOND, Va., May 6 — Nascar officials hoped to improve competition this year when they rolled out the Car of Tomorrow in the Nextel Cup series. So far, it has done wonders for the battle among Hendrick Motorsports drivers.

headline: When the Entrepreneur Has 2 Faces
text: Q: I have a split life — doing a few kinds of work that might not make sense to everyone. What is the best way to handle multiple lives that do not necessarily relate to one another?

headline: Chosen by David Bowie, Shows That He’d Attend
text: David Bowie has been a rock god, a philosopher of the pop avant-garde, an actor, a fashion plate and a talent scout. But he has a little trouble taking seriously the job description for his newest gig: curator of the first High Line Festival.

headline: An Ugly Number Adds Up to a Series Loss
text: When the news that Roger Clemens was a Yankee again circulated throughout Madison Square Garden yesterday during the Rangers-Sabres showdown, the logical reaction was that Mark Messier would surely be skating in the third period.

headline: Bulgaria Invites Guests for a Day of Intense Democracy
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria — With food, wine and ripples of laughter, more than 200 guests gathered for dinner at a Communist-era hotel on the edge of this capital for what seemed like a wedding party. Heckles pierced speeches, and the alcohol flowed.

headline: A Guru Offers Help on Credit Scores, but No Longer Makes Any Promises
text: Suze Orman, the telegenic personal finance guru, offers myriad ways for fans to soak up her wisdom — on her QVC show, her CNBC show, her Web site and in her best-selling books.

headline: A Bit of Thin Skin Peeks Out of the Robes
text: When judges talk about threats to judicial independence, which is constantly, they sometimes make important points about the value of the rule of law in a democracy. Other times they are looking for a pay raise.

headline: Sarkozy Wins in France and Vows Break With Past
text: PARIS, May 6 — Nicolas Sarkozy, the passionate, pugnacious son of a Hungarian immigrant, was elected president of France on Sunday, promising a break with the past, a new style of leadership, and a renewal of relations with the United States and the rest of Europe.

headline: Queens Man Fatally Stabbed
text: A 20-year-old man was fatally stabbed during a fight in Jamaica shortly after midnight yesterday, the police said. The man, whose name was not released by the police, was stabbed at Las Playitas, a restaurant at 170-03 Jamaica Avenue, the police said. He was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. There were no arrests yesterday.

headline: Where Pigeons Rule the Sky, Troublemakers Foul the Nest
text: AMMAN, Jordan — The conquest of the skies over Amman begins every afternoon at 3:30, sharp.

headline: Violence, Role Playing and a Writer’s Creativity (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taking Violence to a New, Technological Absurdity
text: MANY people go to YouTube to look at video clips. But what they really want to do is direct.

headline: For the Record
text: An obituary on Friday about Walter M. Schirra, Jr., an early United States astronaut, misstated the publication date for “The Real Space Cowboys,” which he wrote with Ed Buckbee. It was 2005, not 1971.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) TELL ME NO LIES (2007) A mother suspects that her increasingly rebellious teenage daughter is in trouble when she steals and then wrecks the family car. But the mother has no idea how big the problem is until she discovers evidence about something else that happened that night. Kelly Rutherford and Kirsten Prout, above, star in this made-for-television suspense thriller.

headline: Bach’s Captains and Foot Soldiers of Musical Industry
text: BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 5 — Few would have guessed, say 25 years ago, that among the central pillars of this city’s storied tradition the Bethlehem Bach Festival would prove sturdier than Bethlehem Steel. But the steel mill, shut down in 1998, now stands as perhaps the most spectacular ruin of the American rust belt. And the annual Bach festival is alive, well and celebrating its 100th outing here, 85 miles west of New York City.

The complete article is reprinted today on Page A18. It is also online: http://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/06/us/06firearms.html.

headline: Tech Investors Cull Start-Ups for Pentagon
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 — The nation’s military, in its search for the next surveillance system, bioterror vaccine or robot warrior, has decided to take a peek into the garage.

headline: In Iraq, the Play Was the Thing
text: Washington

headline: Want to See That Shot Again? Download It for $3
text: DESPITE the many treasures posted online, sports fans still can’t find videos of the first Yankee game they saw with their fathers, or download all of Pete Maravich’s behind-the-back passes.

headline: About.com Buys ConsumerSearch.com
text: About.com, a Web information service owned by The New York Times Company, plans to announce today that it has bought ConsumerSearch.com, a Web site that compiles reviews of consumer products, for $33 million in cash.

headline: 2 Car Bombings in Iraq Kill 25
text: BAGHDAD, May 7 — Two car bombs exploded near a police checkpoint just north of Ramadi today, killing 25, including six police officers, and wounding 51 others, according to Col. Iaria Yusuf, the Iraqi security supervisor in the Anbar province.

headline: Bidding War for ABN Amro Division Intensifies
text: LONDON, May 6 — A group of three banks led by the Royal Bank of Scotland submitted a $24.5 billion offer on Saturday for LaSalle Bank, the American unit of the Dutch bank ABN Amro, that would top an earlier bid from Bank of America, a person familiar with the bid said. But the offer was contingent on its successful takeover of all of ABN Amro, this person said.

headline: World Bank Panel Finds Wolfowitz at Fault; Aide Resigns
text: WASHINGTON, May 7 — A committee of World Bank directors has formally notified Paul D. Wolfowitz that they found him to be guilty of a conflict of interest in arranging for a pay raise and promotion for Shaha Ali Riza, his companion, in 2005. The findings stepped up the pressure on Mr. Wolfowitz to resign.

headline: Whistle-Blower on Student Aid Is Vindicated
text: WASHINGTON — When Jon Oberg, a Department of Education researcher, warned in 2003 that student lending companies were improperly collecting hundreds of millions in federal subsidies and suggested how to correct the problem, his supervisor told him to work on something else.

headline: Misty Watercolor Memories, Anyone?
text: It is comforting to be able to assure someone, even a fictional character, that her greatest fear is unfounded. In “Deuce,” the flimsy excuse for a comedy by Terrence McNally at the Music Box Theater, Leona Mullen, a tennis player in her early 70s, worries that old age is turning her into the sort of woman that people look right through. “I am not invisible,” she says.

headline: Trying to Make a Hearty Meal From a Political Food Fight
text: It was hard not to feel a little sorry for the moderators of the Republican presidential debate in California last week. There they stood for 90 minutes on a stage with 10 different candidates clamoring for an equal share of camera time.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to redevelop the Willets Point business district in Queens misstated the given name of the owner of the Crown Container Company, one of the businesses in the area, who opposes the plan. He is Jerry Antonacci, not Joey.

headline: They Sacrifice. We Go Shopping. (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Dangerous Loophole? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Boss at Opera, Emphasis on the New
text: No “Carmens,” no “Bohèmes,” at least for the first year.

headline: Rasner Baffles Mariners as  Clemens Prepares to Return
text: Darrell Rasner baffled the Seattle Mariners for much of yesterday afternoon. The Yankees may respond by sending him to the minors.

headline: Immigration Questions, 20 Years Old but Current
text: A wife gets a job offer in another city; her husband is reluctant to follow her. Furthermore the couple is Puerto Rican; the job is in Texas.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Mirren Sends Regrets to the Queen

headline: For the Record
text: A theater review on April 20 about “The View From K Street Steak,” at Altered Stages in Chelsea, referred incorrectly to the setting at the start of the play. While the first scene is titled “Reno,” the play is set, according to the program, at a political retreat at a Hilton Head spa and resort “and similar expense-account playgrounds.” The retreat is not in Reno, Nev.

headline: Turkish Candidate Withdraws, as Voting Stalls
text: ISTANBUL, May 6 — A Turkish presidential candidate with a background in Islamic politics withdrew his candidacy on Sunday, ending several weeks of struggle that has sharply divided Turkish society and reshaped the political landscape.

headline: Everything Goes at the Casino, and Some Finally Win Big
text: ATLANTIC CITY, May 6 — Doug Neal and two of his friends nearly knocked over a casino executive as they made their way through the lobby of the old Sands hotel over the weekend, hauling a king-size bed, complete with mattress, box spring and leather headboard, taken right from the Hollywood Suite.

headline: All in the Families
text: Before I get to the “but,” let me say that Hillary Rodham Clinton would make a terrific president.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Clemens Returns in a Save Situation
text: In a dapper striped tie and blazer, with all eyes on his Aqua Velva-fresh face, Roger Clemens wore the look of a groom’s best man when he took the mic at Yankee Stadium yesterday to deliver what ended up as a toast to himself.

headline: After All These Years, a New Twist in Defense
text: Bridge has been around in one form or another for well over 100 years. But new plays are still being discovered. The diagramed deal, which was sent to me by Mel Colchamiro, arose on April 27 during a duplicate at the Franklin Bridge Center in Franklin Square, on Long Island. It features a defensive coup I have not seen before — perhaps because it has never occurred to anyone. Sitting West was Mitchell Pollenz, whose partner was Emmett Pollenz, his uncle.

headline: Steinbrenner’s Sons Are Part of Process
text: The Yankees’ internal discussions about signing Roger Clemens provide a glimpse into the changing power structure at the top of the organization.

headline: In Forgotten New Orleans, Life and Hope Stir at the Bottom
text: New Orleans

headline: Violent Protests Greet Sarkozy’s Election in France
text: PARIS, May 7 — Violent protests against the election of Nicolas Sarkozy as president of France ended early today with hundreds of people arrested, hundreds of cars gutted and hundreds of windows smashed in several cities across in France.

headline: In the Fine Print, a Raise of More Than 20%
text: ALBANY — Speaker Sheldon Silver and fellow Assembly Democrats quietly introduced legislation late last month that would grant lawmakers a raise of nearly 21 percent, increasing their base pay to the second highest in the nation among state legislators.

headline: For Tafel, Finally a Derby Wrapped in Roses
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 — Jim Tafel will never forget his first Kentucky Derby, the one he watched on television 50 years ago. He was at the home of his friend Lew Worsham, the golfer who won the 1947 United States Open. Right outside his door, Worsham had a patch of mint. He fetched some, cut it and fashioned it into a mint julep.

headline: California Gains Clout With Earlier Primary
text: LOS ANGELES, May 4 — When Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, finished a speech on foreign policy recently in Northern California, he was surrounded by reporters who wanted to ask about another topic: global warming and how it was contributing to the state’s water shortage.

headline: Players With No Conductor and, Increasingly, With No Fear
text: The Danish composer Poul Ruders wrote “Trapeze” for a European orchestra that, following the example of the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, performs without what he calls “the safety net of a conductor.” Like a daredevil trapeze artist performing ever riskier moves, Orpheus has recently branched into riskier repertory, including Romantic concertos and symphonies, which require larger forces and whose rubato and interpretation can be harder to coordinate without a conductor than Baroque or Classical repertory.

headline: A Liberal Case for the Individual Right to Own Guns Helps Sway the Federal Judiciary
text: In March, for the first time in the nation’s history, a federal appeals court struck down a gun control law on Second Amendment grounds. Only a few decades ago, the decision would have been unimaginable.

headline: Girl, 12, Injured by Gunfire Outside a Party in the Bronx
text: A 12-year-old Bronx girl was shot and critically injured shortly before 3 a.m. yesterday when a dispute broke out and gunfire erupted in the street, according to the police and witnesses.

headline: Quotes From, and About, Nicolas Sarkozy
text: THE KÄRCHER

headline: Police Say Girl, 15, Left Baby in Closet
text: A 15-year-old Queens girl placed her newborn son in a plastic bag and hid him in a closet in her home, where he remained until her mother, looking for the source of an odor, discovered his body yesterday morning, a law enforcement official said.

headline: An Empty Place Where a Kansas Town Once Stood
text: GREENSBURG, Kan., May 6 — The crows awoke on Sunday to an all but lifeless landscape in this farming town on the rolling plains, cawing from denuded trees into the silent rubble field below.

headline: A Boston Newspaper Prints What the Local Bloggers Write
text: While most newspapers are trying to stake bigger claims online, one new publication is pulling material off the Internet to be printed in ink.

headline: Mayweather Wins, but Now What?
text: LAS VEGAS, May 6 — Floyd Mayweather Jr. fulfilled his vow to defeat Oscar De La Hoya to become the World Boxing Council superwelterweight champion on Saturday night. Now, the fight’s slogan, “The World Awaits,” could apply to whether the bout will provide any short- or long-term momentum for a sport that is only occasionally relevant.

headline: Goalie Sticks Out Elbow and Knocks Rangers From the Playoffs
text: The puck came off the stick of defenseman Michal Rozsival with seven seconds remaining in the third period yesterday. Hoping it would be the shot that extended the Rangers’ season, the crowd at Madison Square Garden rose as one to follow its path, with fans in the back rows straining to see over the people in front of them.

headline: Webber’s Return Is an Opportunity for Reconciliation
text: Auburn Hills, Mich.

headline: Two Men Struck by Trains
text: Two men were struck and injured by trains late Saturday and early yesterday, one by a subway in Brooklyn and one by a commuter train in Queens, the police said. The first man, 26, was found on the L train tracks near the Grand Street station in East Williamsburg shortly before 11:30 p.m. on Saturday, the police said. He had been struck by a train and critically injured and was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center. It was unclear how he had come to be on the tracks, but criminal activity was not suspected, the police said. The second man, identified as Eduardo Zenteno, 19, of Brooklyn, was on the Long Island Rail Road tracks between the Woodside and Shea Stadium stations when a westbound train struck him about 4:30 a.m. yesterday, according to Susan McGowan, a spokeswoman for the railroad. He was in serious but stable condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center yesterday, she said.

headline: Beam It Down From the Web, Scotty
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Sometimes a particular piece of plastic is just what you need. You have lost the battery cover to your cellphone, perhaps. Or your daughter needs to have the golden princess doll she saw on television. Now.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Astronomers Report Biggest Stellar Explosion
text: Kaboom, indeed.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: EYES ON INTEREST RATES The main news of the week is likely to be the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve (Wednesday). The committee is expected to hold interest rates steady at 5.25 percent. The European Central Bank is also scheduled to issue a decision on rates (Thursday).

headline: Hollywood Loves the Tiny Screen. Advertisers Don’t.
text: LOS ANGELES, May 6 — Superman has the power to leap tall buildings. But leaping onto a cellphone screen is proving a little trickier.

headline: Trial and Error for Winning Trainer
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6 — Long before laying eyes on Street Sense, the trainer Carl Nafzger proved that he knew how to win the Kentucky Derby. The Preakness and the Belmont have been the races that have tripped him up. But this year, Nafzger may have the right horse for the demanding weeks ahead.

headline: Book Not Ready for Print? You Can Whip Up an Audiobook for a Podcast for Now
text: When you are a budding author and you appear on television, it is sure to enhance book sales.

headline: M.T.A. Chairman to Step Down
text: Peter S. Kalikow, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said today that he intended to step down as soon as his successor is approved.

headline: An English Village Bedeviled by Ideas Out of This World
text: Anyone fortunate enough to have stumbled across the exceedingly odd British comedy series “The League of Gentlemen” when it found its way to Comedy Central a few years ago was introduced to Royston Vasey, a fictional English town where the goings-on were so bizarre as to almost defy description. (Typical scene: a woman, played by a man, suckling a pig.) Now the archaeologists at the Actors Company Theater have unearthed the literary forerunner of Royston Vasey. It’s the town that is the setting for “The Sea,” a funny-in-that-British-way play by Edward Bond from 1973.

headline: Critic Says Levee Repairs Show Signs of Flaws
text: Some of the most celebrated levee repairs by the Army Corps of Engineers after Hurricane Katrina are already showing signs of serious flaws, a leading critic of the corps says.

headline: Fashion Industry Rallies to Aid Designer in Trouble
text: Few dresses have glamorized bare flesh more than the silk slip that Carolyn Bessette wore to marry John F. Kennedy Jr. in 1996. It blotted from the mind the schoolgirl roundness of Diana, it stoked the copy kings and it gave an unknown designer, Narciso Rodriguez, a very nice push.

headline: Queens Woman Killed in Crash
text: An 18-year-old woman was killed when the car in which she was riding skidded off the Grand Central Parkway shortly after 1 a.m. yesterday, the police said. The accident occurred near Roosevelt Avenue when the car hit a center barrier, struck a tree and caught fire, the police said. The 18-year-old driver and two other passengers, a 16-year-old boy and an 18-year-old woman, were injured and were in stable condition at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens, the police said.

headline: Bush and Queen Celebrate Common Values
text: WASHINGTON, May 7 — President Bush welcomed Queen Elizabeth II to the White House today with remarks that celebrated the values that have bound the United States and Britain across the Atlantic and across the centuries.

headline: For the Record
text: A picture in some copies on Friday with the Public Lives column, about Judith Enck, deputy secretary for the environment for Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York, was published in error. The picture was of Carol Ash, the new state parks commissioner  not Ms. Enck.

headline: A Former P.O.W., Now Sentenced to Loneliness
text: One of the strongest elements of Tom Cipullo’s opera “Glory Denied” is the use of supertitles as a visual element, an integral part of the proceedings. The words spread across the stage behind the singers like concrete poetry. Sometimes they are repeated to form a kind of verbal screen; sometimes they are in different colors; sometimes they are words the singers aren’t even singing but tell a part of the story. Sometimes they are grievously misspelled too, but whether one ascribes that to Mr. Cipullo or to the students of the Brooklyn College Opera Theater, led by Richard Barrett, which gave the opera its first complete staging this weekend, this is a creative use of titles, weaving them into the fabric of the piece rather than taping them across the proscenium as a barrier between the viewer and the action on stage.

headline: Time Learns That Popular Taste Can Vary a Lot With the Test Market
text: Last year Time magazine declared “You” the person of the year, paying homage to everyone who had blogged or contributed to sites like YouTube, MySpace and Wikipedia.

headline: Still Best in Show
text: It has been difficult to reconcile the blockbuster profits at investment banks and the rising share prices on stock exchanges in the United States with the doom-and-gloom pronouncements — and predictions of a mass exodus from Wall Street — by business interests intent on rolling back the post-Enron financial regulations.

headline: New CDs
text: BONE THUGS-N-HARMONY “Strength & Loyalty” (Interscope)

headline: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the first debate of the Republican candidates for president referred incorrectly in some copies to Duncan Hunter, one of the 10 participants. He is a current  not former  congressman from California.

headline: For the Record
text: An article and picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday about efforts to re-establish coral reefs referred incorrectly to the networks of pipes on which coral is grown in the Mote Marine Laboratory in Florida. The pipes are made of PVC, not iron. The article also carried an incomplete list of American territories where corals occur. Besides Florida, Hawaii, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, corals also grow in warm and cold water in several other areas, including American Samoa and the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Louisiana and Texas.

headline: Brooklyn Man Killed Outside Lounge
text: A man was stabbed and shot to death during a fight outside a club in Bushwick yesterday morning, the police said. The fight occurred shortly after 3 a.m. at the Groove Lounge, the police said. Patrons spilled outside the club, and witnesses said they heard several gunshots. The victim, Luis Ruiz, 24, of Clinton Hill, a single father who worked in Manhattan in computer graphics, had visited the club for the first time that night, said Noemi Galletti, his landlord and friend. “Someone called him to come over because they were having a party there,” she said. Another man was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center with a head injury, but he was in stable condition yesterday, the police said. There were no arrests yesterday.

headline: For the Record
text: A map on Tuesday with an article comparing two PCB-removal projects by General Electric  one on the Hudson River in New York and the other on the Housatonic in Massachusetts  misspelled part of the name of a city near the G.E. factory in Hudson Falls, N.Y. It is Glens Falls, not Glen Falls.

headline: Students Search for the Words to Go With Their Cultural Pride
text: CLOSTER, N.J. — Last summer, watching Al Jazeera’s reports of the war in Lebanon between Israel and Hezbollah, Fidele Harfouche was startled to realize that in addition to understanding the Arabic spoken by the anchors, she could, for the first time, read some of the words marching across the bottom of the screen.

headline: A Big Stretch
text: I GREW up watching my father stand on his head every morning. He was doing sirsasana, a yoga pose that accounts for his youthful looks well into his 60s. Now he might have to pay a royalty to an American patent holder if he teaches the secrets of his good health to others. The United States government has issued 150 yoga-related copyrights, 134 patents on yoga accessories and 2,315 yoga trademarks. There’s big money in those pretzel twists and contortions — $3 billion a year in America alone.

headline: Paying Dearly in Desperation
text: It’s Roger Clemens’s ball, and he can throw it wherever he wants. Beginning June 1, he’ll throw it for the Yankees.

headline: Studying Religion in Today’s World (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Flooding Forces Evacuations in Plains
text: Two more bodies were discovered today in Greensburg, Kan., raising the death toll in the little town that was devastated by a tornado on Friday night to 10. Weather officials estimate that the storm’s winds blew at over 200 miles an hour as it all but leveled the town.

headline: Only 4 Coffins, but 265 Victims Are Mourned at Mass in the Bronx
text: Red roses in hand, about 45 mourners emerged yesterday from a Spanish-language Mass and walked a quarter-mile to a majestic mausoleum at Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx. For some of those being mourned, it was a second or even third funeral.

headline: Mets Come Up Empty in Their Bag of Tricks
text: PHOENIX, May 6  Mike Pelfrey and John Maine were sitting around the Chase Field clubhouse Thursday reminiscing about the bad old days. The conversation centered on last July, when Maine fell to 0-3 with a loss to the Florida Marlins but had pitched well enough to think he had reached a turning point in his season. In his next start, Maine threw a shutout that started his 26-inning scoreless streak.

headline: Epidemic Is Killing Pigs in Southeastern China
text: HONG KONG, May 7 — A mysterious epidemic is killing pigs in southeastern China, but international and Hong Kong authorities said today that the Chinese government is providing little information about it, or about the contaminated wheat gluten that has caused deaths and illnesses in other animals.

headline: Victory Challenge Still Has Chance at America’s Cup Semifinals
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 6 — Eighteen months ago, the crew and support staff of Victory Challenge were on the verge of unemployment.

headline: N.J. Governor Ready to Resume Duties
text: PRINCETON, N.J., May 7 — Saying that his prolonged absence from a job that he loves was driving him “stir crazy,” Jon S. Corzine resumed his official duties as Governor of New Jersey this morning, three and a half weeks after sustaining serious injuries in a car accident.

headline: With Sarkozy, Bush May Find a Close Friend in France
text: PARIS, May 7 — Two days before the first round of the presidential election last month, Nicolas Sarkozy donned a red checked shirt, jeans and cowboy boots, mounted a small white horse named Universe and rode around the Camargue country in France’s deep south. A gaggle of reporters and cameramen followed him in a cart pulled by a tractor. The black bulls on the nearby pasture stayed away.

headline: Once Again, Murdoch’s Siren Song
text: Rupert Murdoch, the thrill-ride version of the modern media mogul, delivered a particularly head-snapping jolt last week when the News Corporation said it intended to buy The Wall Street Journal and the rest of Dow Jones & Company for $5 billion. Now that some of the commotion has eased, it might be worth a few minutes to examine the proposal bearing in mind Mr. Murdoch’s unique business DNA.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Sept. 30 about a lawsuit to force the Department of Veterans Affairs to add the Wiccan symbol to the list of approved emblems for headstones included erroneous information from the suit about a Pentagon survey of Wiccan participation in the military. (The error was pointed out after it was repeated in an article on April 23 about the suit’s settlement.) There were more than 1,800 Wiccans in the Air Force, not in all of the armed forces. (The Pentagon did not survey the entire military.)

headline: Rumpled Sheets and Notions Among Strange Bedfellows
text: An unlikely affair is the most likely thing imaginable in a romantic comedy, but the match in “An Octopus Love Story,” Delaney Britt Brewer’s drama that comes on strong before settling into the rhythm of a sitcom, does have an unusual twist.

headline: Afghan Media Face Threat of Controls
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 6 — Afghanistan’s government, competing with the Taliban for public support and trying to fend off accusations that it is corrupt and ineffective, is moving to curb one of its own most impressive achievements: the country’s flourishing independent news media.

headline: Journalists Intend to Sue Hewlett-Packard Over Surveillance
text: In an unusual step for the news media, three journalists whose private phone records were scrutinized by investigators working for Hewlett-Packard intend to sue the company for invasion of privacy.

headline: The Fishing Is Canceled, but Kayakers Are Buoyant
text: Kayak fishing is a sport still obscure enough that just about anyone who shows up for a tournament quickly finds that there are no strangers.

headline: Beyond Books: Oprah Winfrey’s Seal of Approval Goes Presidential
text: It’s usually pretty easy to quantify what Oprah Winfrey’s stamp of approval can mean: her book club catapults titles to the top of best-seller lists, and her nods at other products send consumers racing to buy them.

headline: With Game Deserting Him, Woods Manages to Hold On
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 6 — There have been tidier victories to come out of the golf bag of Tiger Woods, but he has even mastered making the stressful and dramatic look like expressions of himself.

headline: Rough Alliance Built on Commandeered House in Anbar
