text: JUWAYBA, Iraq — Nearly every day, the sheik stops by the villa that was once his home but is now an American garrison. Sometimes he comes with tips about the insurgency, or with news of political developments in this rural village near the Euphrates River.

headline: The Soft Bigotry of Iraq
text: Whether out of blind loyalty or blind denial, most Congressional Republicans are prepared to back up President Bush’s veto of the Iraq spending bill. It is now essential that the revised version not back away from demanding that Iraq’s prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, finally deliver on the crucial national reconciliation measures he has spent the last year dodging. And it must make clear that American support for his failures  and Mr. Bush’s  is fast waning.

headline: Getting Their Faces Done but Not Their Brains
text: For well over a decade now it has been fashionable to think of adolescent girls as the gender wars’ neediest casualties. Their self-esteem, we are told, is siphoned off by a culture that mutes their instincts. Girls go underground. Their voices are sublimated; they eat too much or they eat too little. Unable to express themselves, they become what they buy, succumbing to commercial demands about what girlhood should look like.

headline: Reviews and Success for Movies
text: “Spider-Man 3″ set box office records this weekend despite getting mostly luke-warm reviews. “300” and “Wild Hogs,” which were both surprise hits for the movie industry, also managed to be hot at the box office without critical acclaim.

headline: Lawyers, Guns and Meaning
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: A Royal Visit
text: President Bush welcomed Queen Elizabeth II to the White House with remarks that celebrated the values that have bound the United States and Britain across the Atlantic and across the centuries.

headline: Crispin Porter Acquires Radar Communications
text: Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, part of MDC Partners, has acquired and absorbed Radar Communications in Boulder, Colo., a consulting company specializing in market research that seeks to better understand consumer behavior. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: About.com Buys ConsumerSearch.com
text: About.com, a Web information service owned by The New York Times Company, plans to announce Monday that it has bought ConsumerSearch.com, a Web site that compiles reviews of consumer products, for $33 million.

headline: V.C.’s Dial Up $10 Million for Mig33
text: A start-up, Mig33, has snagged $10 million in funding for its mobile Internet telephony and instant-messaging services, the Red Herring reported. The funding, led by Accel Partners and RedPoint Ventures, and which included Technology Venture Partners, is expected to be announced Monday, the publication said.

headline: May Could Bring a Sweet I.P.O. Market
text: Start-ups preparing to go public and the bankers backing them are hoping for a merry, merry month of May. The Red Herring notes that bankers are hoping to raise $1.4 billion this week with six new stocks coming to market, and have $1.3 billion lined up for the following week.

headline: Wells Fargo Gobbles Up Greater Bay Bancorp
text: In the eat-or-be-eaten world of banking, Greater Bay Bancorp‘s network of Bay Area community banks became a snack Friday for giant Wells Fargo. Wells Fargo agreed to pay about $1.5 billion in stock for the East Palo Alto, Calif., holding company, which is better known to most customers for its individual banks, including Santa Clara Valley National Bank, Mid-Peninsula Bank, Peninsula Bank of Commerce and Mount Diablo National Bank.

headline: Netgear Bulks Up with Infrant Buy
text: Netgear, a Santa Clara, Calif. maker of equipment that lets customers set up household Internet networks, agreed to buy closely held Infrant Technologies for $60 million to gain access to its data storage products. Additionally, Netgear may pay as much as $20 million in cash over three years if Infrant meets revenue goals, Netgear said Thursday in a statement.

headline: Losses Narrow at Trump Casinos, but Buyers Remain Elusive
text: With its three Atlantic City casinos being eyed by potential buyers, Trump Entertainment Resorts said Thursday that its first-quarter loss shrank, despite increasing competition from slot-machine parlors in Philadelphia and New York. Perhaps more worrisome news is that potential white knights have yet to materialize.

headline: ABN Amro Rejects $24.5 Billion Bid for Lasalle Bank
text: The Dutch bank ABN Amro, the subject of one of the largest takeover battles in history, said Monday it had rejected a $24.5 billion offer for its Lasalle Bank subisidiary from a group including the Royal Bank of Scotland, finding it “did not constitute a superior proposal” to a previous bid from Bank of America. Nevertheless, ABN said it would allow shareholders to vote on the competing bid and others, as required by last week’s ruling in an Amsterdam court.

headline: Sears Chairman Eyes Possible Deals
text: With more than $2 billion in cash to burn, Sears Holdings‘ chairman Edward Lampert told shareholders Friday the retail giant is considering numerous possibilities for acquisitions or investments.

headline: Activist Shareholders Hit a Hot Streak
text: As activist investors like Carl Icahn, who is currently waging a proxy war with Motorola to gain a seat on its board, become more determined, the companies’ boards are apparently getting softer.

headline: Safeway Won’t Shop Dominick’s, C.E.O. Says
text: Dominick’s, the Chicago-area grocery chain, is not for sale, the chief executive of Safeway, its parent company, told The Chicago Tribune. But at the same time, Safeway is not going to rapidly expand the size of the chain, which was cut to 83 stores earlier this year when it closed 14 “underperforming” stores, said the executive, Steven Burd, who engineered Dominick’s acquisition in 1998 in a deal then valued at $1.9 billion.

headline: Alliance Boots Buyers Must Pay Into Pension Fund
text: The trustees of the pension fund at Alliance Boots, the British drugstore chain, are demanding that the private equity bidders planning to take over the company commit 1 billion pounds ($2 billion) to its pension plan.

headline: Carlyle Eyes British Submarine Dock
text: The Carlyle Group is one of two bidders expected to put in final offers to buy the Devonport submarine dockyard near Plymouth in Britain this week. Final offers for the Devonport Management Limited, the company that runs the submarine refueling and maintenance yard, are due on Tuesday following a first round of bidding that valued it at about 350 million pounds ($697 million).

headline: Alcoa to Bid $33 Billion for Alcan
text: Alcoa, the world’s No. 1 aluminum company, said Monday it would make an unsolicited bid it valued at $33 billion for Alcan, a Montreal-based rival. Alcoa said the proposed bid came after lengthy negotiations between the two aluminum giants failed to produce a mutually agreed deal. “This offer follows almost two years of discussions between our companies regarding a variety of potential business combination transactions, including unsuccessful board-level discussions of a merger transaction last fall,” Alcoa’s chief executive Alain J.P. Belda said in a statement. “We are very disappointed that those efforts did not result in a negotiated transaction — a conclusion we would have strongly preferred.”

headline: 3 Buyout Firms to Battle for EMI, Report Says
text: A takeover battle for the EMI Group, the British music company, may be in the offing, but Warner Music, which has been interested in EMI for years, will not be among the bidders.The Financial Times reported that three private equity firms in the United states — Fortress, Cerberus and One Equity — are set for a 3 billion pound ($5.98 billion) takeover battle during the next two weeks for control of EMI, the world’s third-biggest music group.

headline: Buffett Talks About Succession and Big Deals
text: Berkshire Hathaway‘s Warren Buffett said he would “love” to find a $40 billion acquisition and would “figure out a way” to come up with $60 billion for the right deal, Bloomberg News reported. Speaking at his company’s annual shareholder meeting in Omaha over the weekend, he also suggested that he might hire up to four people as chief investment officers when he steps down.

headline: Goldman Runs Numbers on Buyout Candidates
text: Predicting the next buyout target has become a cottage industry on Wall Street, with analysts seeming to churn out lists of suggestions — usually based on a screening of stocks according to set criteria — on a weekly basis. Dan Primack of PEHub said he has gotten ahold of one such leveraged buyout model produced by Goldman Sachs for its institutional clients, and it apparently offers some intriguing candidates that private equity funds might be considering.

headline: KPMG Resigns as New Century Auditor
text: KPMG has quit as auditor of the bankrupt subprime lender New Century Financial, which has hired forensic accountants to investigate how the company valued its stake in mortgage-backed bonds.

headline: Debate Escalates Over Hedge Fund Fees
text: Are hedge fund managers fees getting too rich for investors’ blood? While managers of these regulated investment pools are getting richer — they took home an estimated $14 billion last year — there are grumblings among some investors that their returns are not worth the fees.

headline: ABN Amro Rejects Rival Bid for LaSalle
text: ABN Amro rejected a $24.5 billion offer for its LaSalle Bank unit from a group led by the Royal Bank of Scotland Group, as the biggest takeover battle in the financial-services industry intensified.

headline: Clear Channel Bidders Said to Consider Changing Offer
text: Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners discussed possible changes to their bid for Clear Channel Communications over the weekend, The Financial Times reported, citing undisclosed sources. A price increase was unlikely, the newspaper said, but other terms could change ahead of Tuesday’s shareholder vote on the proposal.

headline: Qantas Bid Is Up in the Air
text: The investment group whose bid of 10.8 billion Australian dollars ($8.9 billion) for Qantas collapsed over the weekend said Monday it might make a new bid for the airline, as regulators sought clarification that the old offer was indeed dead.

headline: BAE in in Talks for Armor Holdings, Report Says
text: In a possible transAtlantic combination of defense contractors, Britain’s BAE Systems is in final negotiations for the $3.5 billion purchase of Armor Holdings, a United States maker of military and heavy vehicles, Humvee armaments and soldier body armor, according to The Wall Street Journal. The deal with BAE would pay Armor Holdings shareholders about $88 a share, or a 7 percent premium to the company’s closing price Friday of $82.15 a share, the report said.

headline: Bail Denied for Banker Held for Illegal Trades
text: A former Credit Suisse banker accused of running a $7.5 million insider trading ring from April 2006 until this February was denied bail yesterday at a hearing in federal magistrate court in Manhattan. Magistrate Judge Theodore H. Katz said that the banker, Hafiz Muhammad Zubair Naseem, a Pakistani citizen, met “virtually every criteria” as a flight risk.

headline: In Chasing Dow Jones, What Does Murdoch Want?
text: Synergies aside, is Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company really about the media mogul’s desire to acquire the patina of respectability that has eluded him as he built his News Corporation empire?

headline: Not Reading the Fine Print
text: State Senator Antoine M. Thompson of Buffalo, a freshman Democrat, made a fiery speech on the Senate floor last week, denouncing a bill to increase legislators’ salaries when it came up for a vote in his chamber. He cited the lack of raises for Buffalo city workers, police officers, teachers and sanitation workers, and said, “I can’t in good conscience vote for myself, or anyone else, a raise.”

headline: A New Investing Tactic: Hedging Hedge Funds
text: Can you hedge a hedge fund? An investment currently being marketed to the rich is trying in essence to do just that, and the approach is bound to be offered to the rest of us soon, The New York Times reports.

headline: Tech Investors Cull Start-Ups for the Pentagon
text: The nation’s military, in its search for the next surveillance system, bioterror vaccine or robot warrior, has decided to take a peek into the garage. Through a program that recently emerged from an experimental phase, the Defense Department is using some of the nation’s top technology investors to help it find innovations from tiny start-up companies, which have not traditionally been a part of the military’s vast supply chain.

headline: A (Fictional) Wall Street Predator to Make a Comeback
text: Greed is still good.

headline: In Congress, Working on ‘Plan B’
text: Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, had a clear message for the White House Sunday – the clock is ticking.

headline: AT&T Mergers Chief to Step Down
text: A week after AT&T‘s chief executive said he would step down, the head of the telecommunication company’s mergers and acquisitions team announced he also will retire. James Kahan, the senior executive vice president for corporate development who helped spearhead $200 billion in deals, including the acquisition of BellSouth, will step down on June 30, the company announced Saturday.

headline: Apparently, Rudy Can Fail
2008: New Primary Focus
text: The Times’s Adam Nagourney looks at how California, armed with an early primary, is changing presidential politics:

headline: A C.E.O. Pitches Universal Health Care
text: Thirty-six companies have decided to join forces in a push to extend health insurance to all Americans, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

headline: Sarkozy’s Lesson for Republicans
text: Jacques Chirac leaves office after two terms as France’s president, largely deemed a failure. He gets credit in France for standing up to President Bush over Iraq, but on the domestic front it was a time of drift, with efforts on reform collapsing as soon as protesters took to the streets. Voters rejected the European Union constitution he supported. He decided against seeking a third term only when polls made clear he could not win.

headline: Trying to Make a Feast From a Political Food Fight
text: In his Web-only column, Adam Nagourney writes about the challenge of moderating and reporting on the political debates.

headline: M.T.A. Chairman Is Resigning
text: Peter S. Kalikow, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority since 2001, announced this morning that he would resign when Gov. Eliot Spitzer names his replacement, after six eventful years at the helm of the nation’s biggest and busiest mass transit system.

headline: Rove in Limbo
text: The revelation — dropped by Christopher Hitchens in an interview with New York magazine — that Karl Rove is an atheist has enabled the Bush administration to, at long last, deliver on its 2000 campaign promise to “change the tone” in Washington. Exhibit A: “I’ve never said this before, and never will again, but I’m with Karl Rove,” writes The American Prospect’s Ezra Klein on his personal blog. (Hitchens told New York, “Karl Rove is not a believer, and he doesn’t shout it from the rooftops, but when asked, he answers quite honestly. I think the way he puts it is, ‘I’m not fortunate enough to be a person of faith.’ “)

headline: Insurer Liberty Mutual Acquires Ohio Casualty
text: The Liberty Mutual Group, a home and auto insurer based in Boston, said Monday it had agreed to buy the Ohio Casualty Corporation for $2.7 billion.

headline: Celestial Snapshots
text: Pictures from the flyby of Jupiter by the New Horizons spacecraft.

headline: When We Blew It
text: In retrospect, it’s clear that we in the news media let the public down in the run-up to the Iraq war. This was the point of Bill Moyers’ recent documenary, “Buying the War.” Michael Getler, as experienced and savvy a journalist as any, has a thoughtful take on the documentary, and I recommend it. Getler writes in part:

headline: Patina to Take Smith & Wollensky Off the Menu
text: In what may be the end of a months-long battle for the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, the national steakhouse chain said on Monday that it has agreed to a sweetened $94.6 million buyout offer by the Patina Restaurant Group. Patina’s newest bid, which raised the cash per share to $11 from $9.25, bested a rival $84 million proposal by the Landry’s Restaurant Group.

headline: The Nice Little Steamroller
text: While J. Christopher Callaghan, the former candidate for state comptroller, stole the show at the 107th Legislative Correspondents Association dinner over the weekend, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s video had its moments.

headline: A Set-Top Box for the Junk Heap
text: I was never very impressed with Akimbo, the set-top box that was going to give you access to any TV show ever aired, on demand, via the Internet. The problem wasn’t the concept; it was that they couldn’t get the rights to any decent shows.

headline: Dissolving and Consolidating
text: Perhaps in advance of the just-announced Assembly oversight hearing at which they will be appearing tomorrow, officials at the Empire State Development Corporation issued a press release today announcing the consolidation of some of its many, many subsidiary development corporations.Of all the state’s hundreds of public authorities, the development corporation is one of the biggest and most sprawling and controls some of the biggest pots of money. According to the release, it is dissolving 13 subsidiaries and collapsing 25 others into a single holding company “to promote good corporate governance and ease oversight burdens.”

headline: Tornado Chasing on the Web
text: What’s left behind after most natural disasters is usually death, destruction and a lingering curiosity about what could have caused it.

headline: Hostile Bid for Alcan May Chafe in Canada
text: Alcan, the Montreal-based aluminum giant, had a relatively low-key public reaction Monday to Alcoa’s surprise $33 billion hostile bid, saying in a short press release that it would “consider the proposal.” Canadian politicians may not be so measured. The uninvited offer from Alcoa, which is based in Pittsburgh, is likely to rekindle a national debate in Canada about the recent surge in foreign takeovers of large Canadian companies and whether it represents a threat to the country’s economic prestige — not to mention a potential loss of lucrative underwriting, accounting and legal work for the nation’s financial professionals.

headline: Clear Channel Delays Vote as Bid Talks Continue
text: It’s the buyout deal that wouldn’t die.

headline: Stupid Restaurant Tricks
text: After tipping over a glass filled with red wine because — for the gazillionth time — I caught the sleeve of my jacket on the edge of one of those paper tablecloth tops, my next blog came into sharp focus: annoying restaurant practices.

headline: Investors Place Their Bets in Motorola Match-Up
text: Motorola chief executive Edward Zander and activist investor Carl Icahn have been at each other like “antsy pugilists trying to work the media for a prefight edge,” writes Roger O. Crockett in BusinessWeek. And Monday is fight day: Motorola’s annual shareholder meeting in Chicago.

headline: Monday Motorsports
text: In Nascar, Jeff Gordon started on pole in Richmond, his third straight pole, but faded in the final 15 laps to finish fourth. His Hendrick Motorsports teammates, Jimmie Johnson and Kyle Busch, finished one-two. Hendrick drivers are four-for-four in Car of Tomorrow races. ESPN takes a closer look at the team’s domination.

headline: Lawmaker Plays Down Private-Equity Tax Chatter
text: Private equity chiefs worried about a much bigger tax bite can take some comfort — though it’s unclear just how much — from Senate Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus. The Democratic lawmaker from Montana told the National Press Club on Monday that his committee is “nowhere close” to drafting a bill that could affect the amount of tax that private equity funds and hedge funds have to pay. Mr. Baucus called recent reports that such legislation is already being drafted “pure speculation,” according to Bloomberg. “People need to keep their shirts on here.”

headline: More Woes for Wolfowitz
text: Even before a top aide’s resignation was announced this afternoon, Paul D. Wolfowitz was facing a fresh wave of doubt that he’d survive turmoil at the World Bank over his handling of a companion’s pay raise.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III learns to sell hot dogs at a New York Mets game.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III takes on a well-prepared opponent at the Fencer's Club in Chelsea.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III attempts a specially choreographed 15-second routine with a ballerina from the New York City Ballet.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: The Times's Harry Hurt III heads to the Shawangunk Mountains to try his hand at rock climbing. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: The Times's Harry Hurt III learns how to defend himself in a class on ki chuan do. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt quarterbacks three plays as a "Paper Jet." He didn't run for daylight, but he didn't fumble either.

headline: Bloomberg: A Thousand Times No
text: At a news conference this afternoon announcing the results of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s self-evaluation of his progress in keeping campaign promises (Surprise! He’s doing really well, with 91 percent kept), the subject turned, as it so often does, to his presidential prospects.

headline: Fox Interactive Nears Deal to Buy Photobucket
text: Photobucket, a four-year-old, rapidly growing Web company, is in advanced talks to be acquired by Fox Interactive Media, a division of the News Corporation, reports Brad Stone of The New York Times.

headline: Springtime for Spitzer. For Real?
text: Relations between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and members of the Legislature have been notably more sour during the last few weeks, as the governor butted heads with lawmakers over campaign reform, school districts, and other issues.

headline: A Thousand Times No
text: Diane Cardwell, The Times’s City Hall bureau chief writes in our sibblog, The Empire Zone, that a news conference this afternoon announcing the results of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s self-evaluation of his progress in keeping campaign promises, the subject turned, as it so often does, to his presidential prospects.

headline: When Order Creates Itself
text: An anonymous commenter, responding to my previous column, suggested that my title “Our Lives as Atoms” is “more than a little puzzling,” and wondered “Where will all this lead us?” I’ve written about the amplified polarization of opinion in the political blogs, and about the abuse at Abu Ghraib prison, which had a disturbingly eerie resemblance to famous experiments at Stanford University 36 years ago. What does any of this have to do with atoms? Fair question. I’d like to start my answer by telling you about a strange phenomenon in Spitsbergen.Spitsbergen is a Norwegian island in the Svalbard archipelago. It has spectacular mountains, abundant glaciers and desolate tundra, where stones are littered over a flat and mostly featureless terrain. In places on this tundra, the stones are arranged in a remarkable way; they lie not in a chaotic, haphazard jumble but in an ordered array of hauntingly beautiful, nearly perfect circular piles. You really have to look at a photo to believe it.

headline: Pardon Me? A Congressional Pardon?
text: The power to pardon traditionally belongs to the president. But Representative Duncan Hunter, who is seeking the 2008 Republican nomination, isn’t waiting for Inauguration Day.

headline: Almost There
text: When we met with Greg Huddy and Bill Harris, our architects, the next day for breakfast, I wasn’t expecting much.

headline: Wrestling With God at the Public Library
text: The New York Public Library is hosting a debate tonight between the author Christopher Hitchens and the civil rights leader the Rev. Al Sharpton. The question: Is God great?

headline: By the Numbers: Clinton, Obama and Iraq
text: Senator Hillary Clinton’s current opposition to the war in Iraq is enough to satisfy members of her overwhelmingly anti-war party, despite her support for the invasion four years ago. While three quarters of Democrats in a New York Times/CBS News poll last month said the United States should have stayed out of Iraq, seven in 10 of them still expressed a favorable opinion of Mrs. Clinton. The poll was conducted before Mrs. Clinton’s call last week to deauthorize the war.

headline: The Peace Presidents
text: On Feb. 8, 2004, George W. Bush proudly proclaimed to Tim Russert on “Meet the Press,” “I am a war president.” Like an 8-year-old playing with toy soldiers, Bush, an Air National Guard dropout, looked at war with vicarious enthusiasm. Contrast the attitude of the nation’s “peace presidents” – supreme commanders who led the nation to victory in the greatest wars the country faced: men who had experienced the grim reality of battle and wanted no part of it.

headline: The End of Cocaine the Beverage
text: The short life of a highly-caffeinated beverage known as Cocaine has come to an end.

headline: He’s Off to See the Doctor … Again
text: Matt DeSalvo is wearing No. 14 tonight in his major league debut for the Yankees. Maybe they should have given him No. 45.

headline: Hitchens, Sharpton and Faith
text: You could tell from the background music that played beforehand – alternating recordings of James Brown and Gregorian chant – that this was going to be an unusual debate.

headline: Speaking Presidential at Graduation
text: It is cap-and-gown season, and for the presidential candidates, that means the opportunity to spend May weekends delivering speeches at colleges and universities that are carefully selected to fit a strategic purpose.

headline: Clinton Stumps in Obama’s Backyard
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York has been battling Senator Barack Obama of Illinois for primacy in the Democratic field of presidential hopefuls, and now she is taking the battle to Chicago — his home turf and her former hometown.

headline: Eve? Lonesome Suzie? Old Weird Alice? Name Lonesome George’s Mate
text: If they finally find a mate for Lonesome George, what should she be called? I suggest Eve in my Findings column about George, the famous giant tortoise from Pinta Island in the Galapagos. For decades, he was thought to be the last of the Pinta species, but biologists now think there’s probably at least one more mixed in with the tortoises on another island. They hope to find one next year, preferably a female they could take back to George’s pen.

headline: The Genetics of Obesity
text: In an article in today’s Science Times, Gina Kolata reports on research showing that obesity is largely determined by genetics, a message that is at odds with popular conceptions of weight loss. What does that say about society’s obsession with dieting?

headline: The Best Park in Baseball (Not Chan Ho)
text: For those of you who love baseball and have never watched a game here, I say only this: Do not pass Go, do not collect $200, get thee here as fast as you can. If God were an architect – and who knows, He could be – I’m convinced that He designed AT&T Park. Just finished taking a lap around the main concourse, which, between the foul lines, is uncovered and allows fans to gaze at the Bay Bridge, the Bay and dozens of souvenir shops/tasty concession stands (I’m eating one of these  right now)

headline: Johnson & Johnson Won’t Seek Approval for a Heart Stent
text: Johnson & Johnson’s hopes for an early return on its recent $1.4 billion acquisition of Conor Medsystems have been dashed by the failure of Conor’s heart stent design in a pivotal medical trial comparing it with a Boston Scientific stent.

headline: Flying This Summer? Fasten Your Seat Belt
text: REMEMBER the summer of 2000, when delays, cancellations and work slowdowns by pilots sometimes brought the air travel system to near collapse?

headline: Jupiter Gets Its Close-Up
text: On the way to Pluto, the New Horizons spacecraft has provided planetary astronomers their first close-up look in several years at Jupiter and its moons.

headline: Manhattan: Viacom Moving Downtown
text: After nearly a year of negotiations, Viacom, the giant media company, signed a 15-year lease yesterday with Trinity Real Estate for about 400,000 square feet for offices and production facilities at 345 Hudson Street, the real estate company said. The annual rent was believed to average in the mid-$40 range per square foot over the life of the lease. Early next year, Viacom plans to relocate some 1,000 employees from several buildings in Midtown, including its MTV Networks Entertainment Group, which includes Spike TV, Comedy Central and TV Land.

headline: Astronomers Report One for the Record Books
text: Kaboom indeed.

headline: In World Skyscraper Race, It Isn’t Lonely at the Top
text: SHANGHAI — When work began on the Shanghai World Financial Center in 1997, in the headiest days of China’s economic takeoff, Shanghai was already a city that was hard to impress.

headline: Sarkozy Sets a New Course for Relations With U.S.
text: PARIS, May 7 — Two days before the first round of the presidential election last month, Nicolas Sarkozy donned a red checked shirt, jeans and cowboy boots, mounted a small white horse named Universe and rode around the Camargue country in France’s deep south. A gaggle of reporters and cameramen followed him in a cart pulled by a tractor. The black bulls in the nearby pasture stayed away.

headline: Germany: No Pardons for 2 in Terrorism Gang
text: President Horst Köhler turned down a politically contentious request for clemency by a terrorist from the far-left Red Army Faction, also known as the Baader-Meinhof gang. Mr. Köhler met last week with the man, Christian Klar, who has served 24 years of a life sentence for the murder of a German prosecutor in 1977. The meeting drew protests from conservative politicians, who said Mr. Klar had shown no remorse for his crimes. Speculation that he might be freed rose after a fellow gang member, Brigitte Mohnhaupt, was released in March after serving 24 years in prison for murders in the 1970s. The president also denied clemency to another member, Birgit Hogefeld.

headline: Sounds of Silence in Northern Ireland
text: IT was summer 1975 when the chilling report filtered through to our suburban Dublin kitchen: there’d been another killing in Northern Ireland. Members of a well-known music group, the Miami Showband, had been driving home to Dublin after a gig in County Down. They were stopped at a false checkpoint 30 miles south of Belfast by members of the paramilitary Ulster Volunteer Force. As one of the terrorists tried to plant a bomb in the back of the band’s van, it exploded. In the confusion, three of the musicians who had been lined up along the side of the road were executed.

headline: Cesium Time
text: Q. Why is cesium used in atomic clocks?

headline: Stomping Through a Metaphoric Jungle, Parasols at the Ready
text: Of all the worlds left to explore, the only one completely forbidden to mankind’s prying eyes has always been the future. In an amusing revival of Eric Overmyer’s “On the Verge,” by the Phoenix Theater Ensemble, three Victorian-era American ladies set out for an unspecified virgin territory.

headline: Former Associate Testifies Black Was Kept Informed
text: CHICAGO, May 7  The star witness in the criminal case against the former media baron Conrad M. Black, F. David Radler, took the stand Monday and portrayed himself as a close partner of Mr. Black who did not make a major move without talking with him.

headline: A Met Gala for Feathered Friends and Acquaintances
text: Early yesterday afternoon, a peahen  a female peacock  escaped from a 20-foot-high gilded bird cage that had been constructed inside the main entrance of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, causing a brief stir as organizers of the annual Costume Institute gala clumsily chased her about the Great Hall. The bird, an indentured guest with pristine white feathers, seemed to be setting a tone for the untamed evening that was to come.

headline: Skiers Dive Into a Sport, and Soar Back Up Again
text: LA GRAVE, France — François Bon, a 34-year-old from Les Arcs, France, is a pioneer in a sport that is so new that it has not even settled on a name.

headline: New DVDs
text: CHINA DOLL

headline: Medicare Privatization Abuses
text: It seems that outrageously high government subsidies aren’t enough to satisfy the private plans that participate in Medicare. Some of these Medicare Advantage plans have been caught using hard-sell tactics to pressure elderly Americans into signing up for policies that may leave them worse off than they would be with traditional Medicare coverage. The unscrupulous sales pressure is one more argument for removing the subsidies that are the only crutch allowing many of these plans to survive.

headline: China Tells Little About Illness That Kills Pigs, Officials Say
text: HONG KONG, May 7 — A mysterious epidemic is killing pigs in southeastern China, but international and Hong Kong authorities said Monday that the Chinese government was providing little information about it or the contaminated wheat gluten that has caused death and illness in pets in the United States.

headline: 6 Arrested in Plot to Attack Fort Dix
text: Six people have been arrested in a plot to fire grenades and kill scores of soldiers at a New Jersey Army installation, the United States attorney’s office in New Jersey said at a news conference today. Four of them were born in the former Yugoslavia, one was born in Turkey and one in Jordan, said a spokesman for the office, Greg Reinert.

headline: Brooklyn Firefighters Find Homicide Victim
text: A 31-year-old Bedford-Stuyvesant woman whose body was found by firefighters after a fire broke out in her home early yesterday died of strangulation, the city medical examiner’s office said last night, adding that the death had been ruled a homicide. The police said the woman also had puncture wounds to her torso. Firefighters were called to the home, on Rochester Avenue, about 1:30 a.m. and discovered the body of the woman, who was identified by acquaintances as Wanette Douglas. The woman’s 5-year-old daughter, T’kyha Douglas, was treated for smoke inhalation, the authorities said.

headline: Letters
text: Saving Coral Reefs

headline: Swedes Stay Alive With Victory in Louis Vuitton
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 7  To the uneducated observer, clarity can be hard to come by in an America’s Cup race as 17 men and the occasional woman crouch, scurry and lean on the deck of their cutting-edge yacht and try to read the invisible wind.

headline: Steakhouses Accept Offer
text: The Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, the New York-based steakhouse chain, said yesterday that it agreed to be bought by the Patina Restaurant Group for $94.6 million, topping a rival proposal from Landry’s Restaurants.

headline: HBO Chief Takes Leave After Assault Arrest
text: The chairman and chief executive of HBO, Chris Albrecht, announced this afternoon that he was taking a leave of absence after being charged with assaulting a girlfriend in a Las Vegas parking lot early Sunday. .

headline: Rookie Gives the Yankees a Lift Before They Fall
text: Twenty years from now, Matt DeSalvo said, the image that will stand out most from his major league debut is the first one he saw from the mound last night.

headline: Suicide Bombers Kill 25 Near Ramadi, Dealing Blow to Recent Gains Against Insurgents
text: BAGHDAD, May 7 — Two suicide car bombs killed 25 people near Ramadi on Monday, the provincial security chief said, dealing a blow to a city recently considered a showcase for the strategy of integrating former insurgents into the Iraqi security forces.

headline: Pavano Visiting Doctor; Igawa Packs for Class A
text: The Yankees planned for Carl Pavano and Kei Igawa to hold down spots in their rotation this season. Yesterday, both were making plans to leave town.

headline: Japanese Premier Makes Gift to War Shrine but Does Not Visit
text: TOKYO, Tuesday, May 8 — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan made a ceremonial offering to a controversial Tokyo war shrine last month but did not go himself, a shrine official said Tuesday.

headline: Senate Vote Upholds Drug Import Limits
text: WASHINGTON, May 7 — The Senate voted on Monday to preserve current restrictions on the importing of lower-cost prescription drugs from Canada and other countries, fearing that such imports could pose risks to consumers, even with new safeguards.

headline: Report on Child Deaths Finds Some Hope in Poorest Nations
text: The rate at which young children perish has worsened most disastrously over the past 15 years in Iraq, hard hit by both sanctions and war, and in Botswana, Zimbabwe and Swaziland, devastated by AIDS, according to a report released yesterday by Save the Children. But researchers also found against-the-odds progress in some of the world’s poorest nations.

headline: Liberty Mutual to Buy Ohio Casualty
text: The Liberty Mutual Group, one of the largest business insurers in the United States, agreed yesterday to buy a competitor, the Ohio Casualty Corporation, for $2.7 billion in cash to increase its sales through independent agents.

headline: Watching Kids Behind Bars as They Ripen Into Adults
text: A cheap and easy critical approach to a crime documentary is to look at the opening scene. Try this at home: If a program opens on a rough, hot city block with torn chain link and kids hanging out, the film is probably going to have a bleeding heart. In its long and loving look, misty as a bobby-soxer’s gaze at James Dean, we get the picture. These are the neglected toughs who might be rehabilitated by the gentle hand of a social worker or a Brown-educated filmmaker.

headline: Manhattan School Survey Pushed Back
text: The Department of Education has extended a deadline for surveys measuring satisfaction in the schools from May 18 to June 1, officials said. The surveys, for parents, teachers and students from grades 6 to 12, are part of a $2 million city effort. The Education Department’s Web site said the auditing giant KPMG, which produced the survey, was not able to send out all copies on time, but promised all parents should receive them sometime this week. A spokesman for KPMG said the “extended deadline ensures the broadest possible participation.” Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the project last week, calling it “the most extensive effort in the history of American education to solicit a community’s ideas and views about their public schools.”

headline: Manhattan Drug Research Benefits University
text: New York University received $650 million Friday from Royalty Pharma, a privately held New York company, for rights to a portion of its royalties from the drug Remicade, an anti-inflammatory agent used to treat rheumatoid arthritis. Jan Vilcek and Junming Le, researchers at N.Y.U.’s School of Medicine, helped develop the monoclonal antibody that led to the drug, in collaboration with Centocor, a biotechnology company. Since Remicade came to market in 1998, the university has received about $365 million in royalties from it, including about $90 million last year. In 2005, Dr. Vilcek, a professor of microbiology, pledged to give N.Y.U.’s medical school $105 million. The Remicade royalties have helped place N.Y.U. among the universities collecting the most royalties annually.

headline: In Return to Work, Corzine Agrees to Take Things Gradually
text: PRINCETON, N.J., May 7 — Saying that his absence from a job that he loves was driving him “stir-crazy,” Gov. Jon S. Corzine resumed his official duties on Monday morning, three and a half weeks after sustaining serious injuries in a car crash.

headline: Obama Criticizes Automakers on Fuel Economy
text: DETROIT, May 7 — Senator Barack Obama of Illinois delivered a stern message to Detroit auto companies on Monday, saying they had done little to lessen the nation’s dependence on foreign oil and needed to improve the fuel efficiency of their vehicles.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Thursday about negotiations between the White House and Congress over a new war-spending measure carried an inaccurate transcription by the White House for a comment by President Bush, who had criticized Congress for trying to use an Iraq spending bill to mandate troop withdrawal. Mr. Bush said, “I’m a commander guy,” meaning he was siding with military commanders, not politicians. He did not say, “I’m the commander guy.” The White House issued a corrected transcript on May 4 after reviewing a recording. (Go to Article)

headline: More Hotel Rooms May Temper Rate Rises
text: With many new hotel rooms planned in the next couple of years, the industry is clearly optimistic that it will have little problem filling them.

headline: Plan B for Iraq Exists, Like It or Not (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Turkey With All the Trimmings in Pakistan
text: There is nothing easy about business travel. Nothing. And I should know. I’m traveling about two weeks a month, both domestically and internationally. Ten countries and 10 states in 10 weeks is my personal record.

headline: Where History Reigns
text: Although as a child I had turtles named Disraeli and Gladstone, I was never invited to sip Champagne with the queen until yesterday. Although I’ve been an Anglophile all my life, I was never able to participate in a fawning orgy of Albion worship until the British ambassador’s party for the monarch yesterday afternoon.

headline: A White-Tie Dinner for Queen’s White House Visit
text: WASHINGTON, May 7  Presidents come and go, but for more than half a century, the queen has always been the queen.

headline: President of Jewish Congress Resigns After 3 Years’ Turmoil
text: The World Jewish Congress, the tiny nonprofit organization that won billions of dollars for Holocaust survivors, said yesterday that Edgar M. Bronfman Sr., the billionaire liquor magnate who is its largest patron, had resigned as its president.

headline: Find a Penny: This Is a Real New York Story (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Why Wall St. Journal Editors Held News of Murdoch Bid
text: One of the trickiest things for a news organization to do is cover itself.

headline: British Bachelor-Partiers Are Taking Their Revels East
text: PRAGUE — By midnight, wearing nothing but his socks, Paul Roe had crawled the length of a strip club catwalk here, led on a leash by one barechested blonde woman while another whipped him with a belt.

headline: Official Who Oversees Gulf Oil Drilling to Retire
text: Johnnie Burton, the top federal official overseeing Gulf of Mexico oil and gas drilling, will retire, effective at the end of this month, Dirk Kempthorne, the interior secretary, said yesterday.

headline: Guests at the State Dinner
text: WASHINGTON, May 7  Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, were the guests of honor Monday at a state dinner at the White House.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9:30 P.M. (Sundance Channel) ART FROM THE ARCTIC  Between 2003 and 2005 David Buckland, a British filmmaker, organized three sailing expeditions to the high Arctic as part of his Cape Farewell project, a collaboration among artists, educators and scientists created to focus attention on climate change. This film follows those expeditions as artists like the sculptors Max Eastley and Rachel Whiteread, the photographer Alex Hartley and the writer Ian McEwan are inspired by the otherworldly sights and sounds. Above, an installation by Heather Ackroyd and Dan Harvey.

headline: Board Urges Modest Range for Rises in Stabilized Rents
text: The board that regulates rents for New York City’s one million rent-stabilized apartments proposed tentative increases last night of 2 to 4.5 percent on one-year lease renewals and 4 to 7.5 percent on two-year leases, which could mean smaller increases than last year’s when the board holds a final vote next month.

headline: Doing Good on Company Time
text: Companies have been using off-site meetings and retreats to foster a sense of camaraderie among employees for decades, but obstacle courses or golf tournaments are becoming as dated as guaranteed frequent-flier upgrades to first class. Today, more corporations are turning to hands-on volunteer projects to get their people motivated and working as a team.

headline: Deal Is Offered for Chief’s Exit at World Bank
text: WASHINGTON, May 7  Leading governments of Europe, mounting a new campaign to push Paul D. Wolfowitz from his job as World Bank president, signaled Monday that they were willing to let the United States choose the bank’s next chief, but only if Mr. Wolfowitz stepped down soon, European officials said.

headline: Stamping Out Diverse Voices
text: Postal rate increases are an unwelcome fact of life for every magazine publisher. But it seems the steep new increases for periodicals, scheduled to begin on July 15, will inflict undue hardship on small independent magazines that do much to inform the national discourse on politics and culture. They will be required to pay a much higher percentage increase than some of the largest magazines.

headline: HBO Chairman Held in Dispute With Girlfriend
text: Chris Albrecht, the chairman of HBO, was charged with domestic assault and battery after an altercation with a girlfriend Sunday morning, a Las Vegas police spokesman said yesterday.

headline: A Misunderstanding, and a Simple Life Descends Into a Nightmare
text: The heroine of Richard Flanagan’s stunning new novel is an Australian pole dancer known as the Doll, and like Cary Grant or Jimmy Stewart in a Hitchcock movie, she finds herself being mistaken for someone else and falling, abruptly, down a black rabbit hole, her identity stolen, her daily life torpedoed, her most fundamental expectations about life blown to smithereens.

headline: Russell W. Kruse, Auctioneer of Classic Autos, Dies at 85
text: Russell W. Kruse, whose sonorous voice auctioned off everything from funeral parlors to castles, but who achieved fame for thinking up and building the business of auctioning classic cars, including ones owned by the pope and Al Capone, died Friday, in Fort Wayne, Ind. He was 85.

headline: Inquiry Into Man’s Death Fuels Unease in Mount Kisco
text: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 7  At 10:47 p.m. on April 28, a homeless Guatemalan man known to roam the streets, plucking cans and bottles from trash cans and causing trouble when he was drunk, dialed 911 from the pay phone at a Laundromat here.

headline: Brooklyn Woman Found Dead After Fire
text: The police and the city medical examiner said yesterday they were investigating the death of a 31-year-old Bedford-Stuyvesant woman who was burned when a fire broke out in her home, but who also suffered puncture wounds to the front and back of her torso. Firefighters were called to 39 Rochester Avenue about 1:30 a.m. and found the woman, who was identified by acquaintances as Wanette Douglas. Her 5-year-old daughter, T’kyha Douglas, suffered smoke inhalation and was treated at Kings County Hospital Center, the authorities said.

headline: House Democrats May Seek Short-Term Financing of War
text: WASHINGTON, May 7 — House Democrats may push ahead this week with a new war spending bill that would provide money for combat operations through midsummer, with the rest of the funds sought by President Bush withheld until commanders in Iraq provide a report on conditions there.

headline: EADS Hoping to Increase Military Work for the U.S.
text: TOULOUSE, France, May 7 — The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company wants to expand its military activities in the United States, and friendly governments in both France and Germany could help further that goal, the company’s co-chief executive said on Monday.

headline: East Coast Money Lent Out West
text: AGOURA HILLS, Calif.  Visitors to Ownit Mortgage Solutions’ offices here are met by an abandoned reception desk and three dying potted plants that appear to have gone months without water.

headline: Baseball Ignores a Problem More Deadly Than Steroids
text: Alcohol last week killed one more major league baseball player than steroids ever have.

headline: Couple Expected to Plead Guilty to Insider Trading This Week
text: A former Morgan Stanley compliance officer and her husband are expected to plead guilty this week to charges stemming from an insider-trading case that prosecutors say was part of the largest such scheme on Wall Street since the 1980s.

headline: A Lonesome Tortoise, and a Search for a Mate
text: It is a truth universally acknowledged, at least among humans, that a giant tortoise in the possession of the last sperm of his species must be in want of a wife. But what if the tortoise prefers a different lifestyle?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A theater review yesterday about “Bad Blood” (“Malasangre”), at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater on West 47th Street, misspelled the surname of the actor who plays Don Augusto. He is Felipe Javier Gorostiza, not Corostiza.

headline: New Bid for Energy Concern
text: The Macquarie Bank, Australia’s largest securities firm, made a new takeover offer for the energy transmission company Alinta to challenge Alinta’s agreement to be acquired for 7.4 billion Australian dollars ($6.1 billion) by Babcock & Brown and Singapore Power. Alinta, based in Perth, Australia, is seeking further information on the revised offer. Macquarie, based in Sydney, said its proposal included three options, one of them an all-cash bid. Macquarie did not disclose further details. Both Macquarie and Babcock plan to break up the utility, which has a nationwide network of gas and power lines, and generates electricity at five plants. Alinta rejected Macquarie’s earlier offer on March 30.

headline: Study Suggests Meditation Can Help Train Attention
text: In meditation, people sit quietly and concentrate on their breath. As air swooshes in and out of their nostrils, they attend to each sensation. As unbidden thoughts flutter to mind, they let them go. Breathe. Let go. Breathe. Let go.

headline: How the Inca Leapt Canyons
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Conquistadors from Spain came, they saw and they were astonished. They had never seen anything in Europe like the bridges of Peru. Chroniclers wrote that the Spanish soldiers stood in awe and fear before the spans of braided fiber cables suspended across deep gorges in the Andes, narrow walkways sagging and swaying and looking so frail.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Earnhardt Becomes the Latest Driver to Turn Against the Car of Tomorrow
text: CONCORD, N.C., May 7  After four races in the Car of Tomorrow, Dale Earnhardt Jr. said he had had enough. On Monday, Earnhardt, the sport’s most popular driver and among the most influential, joined the list of critics of the new racecar, which is being phased into the Nextel Cup series this season.

headline: U.S. Debates Deterrence for Nuclear Terrorism
text: WASHINGTON, May 7 — Every week, a group of experts from agencies around the government — including the C.I.A., the Pentagon, the F.B.I. and the Energy Department — meet to assess Washington’s progress toward solving a grim problem: if a terrorist set off a nuclear bomb in an American city, could the United States determine who detonated it and who provided the nuclear material?

headline: France Under New Leadership
text: The French (like many Americans) have grown increasingly tired of their cranky and ineffective president, Jacques Chirac. With Nicolas Sarkozy they’ve certainly gotten a very different sort of leader. A graduate of a non-elite university, and the son of a Hungarian immigrant, he won this week’s election promising sweeping change to voters impatient with their country’s long economic and diplomatic decline. But to succeed, Mr. Sarkozy will need to keep his own impatience, and his destructive penchant for divisive rhetoric, under firm control.

headline: Ukraine Gas Pipeline Hit by Blast
text: An explosion destroyed a section of a pipeline in Ukraine carrying Russian natural gas to Europe. No injuries were reported, and technicians quickly rerouted the gas to other pipelines. In a telephone interview, Ihor I. Kroll, a spokesman for the Ministry of Emergency Situations, played down the possibility of sabotage. But later in the day, the minister for transport, Mykola Rudkovsky, said on Ukrainian television that the pipe might have been sabotaged as “part of a planned attempt to destabilize” the country, the Interfax news agency in Russia reported. Russia provides about a quarter of Europe’s natural gas, 80 percent of which is pumped through aging pipes on Ukraine’s territory. Gazprom, the Russian natural gas company, said its customers in Europe would not be affected.

headline: Special of the Day: Peace of Mind
text: WATCHUNG, N.J.

headline: Isabella Blow, Flamboyant Discoverer of Fashion Talent, Dies at 48
text: Isabella Blow, a British fashion editor, aristocrat and aesthete whose gift for identifying and promoting new talent was occasionally overshadowed by her own Surrealist plumage, died yesterday in Gloucestershire, England. She was 48.

headline: The Struggle to Move Beyond ‘Why Me?’
text: Six days after my husband and I returned from a trip to Aruba — our first real vacation without our children — my doctor told me I had breast cancer. I had felt a lump in my breast before the trip, but decided to wait to have it checked. I’d had lumps before, and they had always turned out to be nothing. But this one wasn’t nothing. It was Stage 2 invasive ductal carcinoma.

headline: For Democrats, New Challenge in Age-Old Rift
text: WASHINGTON, May 7  Almost nothing rouses as much passion, anger or history for the Democrats as the issue of trade.

headline: Liquor Maker Ups the Ante a Bit in Discouraging Young Drinkers
text: THERE was another round yesterday in the continuing sparring over alcohol advertising, as Beam Global Spirits and Wine — which makes brands like Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark bourbon and Canadian Club whiskey — announced it would voluntarily adopt stricter rules to keep messages away from young people.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: The Advertising Club, New York, presented the 2007 International Andy Awards for campaigns that appeared in 2006. For the first time, the Best of Show Award, known as the Grandy, was presented to a digital campaign. The winning agency, R/GA, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was honored for work for Nike Plus, the running shoe that comes with an iPod Nano. The campaign also won another award, sponsored by Yahoo, called the Big Idea Chair. Offices of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, won the most Andys, 14, followed by offices of Leo Burnett Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, with 10. The honor for best in show for public service advertising, known as the Richard T. O’Reilly Award, went to the “Truth” anti-smoking campaign created by Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas, and Crispin Porter & Bogusky, Miami, part of MDC Partners.

headline: Yankees Rein in Expectations of Clemens
text: The Yankees have gotten the headlines and the hope. They will have to wait several weeks to see if the signing of Roger Clemens actually gets them much-needed victories.

headline: In the Desert, a Festival of Country and Its Kin
text: INDIO, Calif., May 7  What does country music sound like in 2007? Well, around 3:15 on Sunday afternoon here in the California desert it sounded like a Chinese folk song struggling to be heard over a Guns N’ Roses medley.

headline: At Risk: Study Shows Flu Season Increases Heart Ailments
text: Heart attacks and chronic heart disease both increase sharply during flu season, according to a large new study based on autopsy reports in St. Petersburg, Russia.

headline: Pakistan Court Halts Inquiry of Top Judge
text: The Supreme Court suspended proceedings against Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, Pakistan’s suspended chief justice, before a five-judge panel known as the Supreme Judicial Council. The council began hearing accusations of misconduct and abuse of power against Mr. Chaudhry after President Pervez Musharraf suspended him in March. Mr. Chaudhry, meanwhile, went to the Supreme Court to challenge the council’s authority and impartiality. In addition to halting the council inquiry, the Supreme Court also recommended that Mr. Chaudhry’s complaints be heard by the full Supreme Court. The decision followed a mass rally in support of Mr. Chaudhry over the weekend.

headline: ‘Top Chef’ Dreams Crushed by Student Loan Debt
text: Rick Park started working at a Jack in the Box in Austin, Tex., when he was 18. He moved on to sub shops, pizza parlors and chain restaurants, turning out hundreds of meals during a shift.

headline: U.S. Trainers’ Killer Was Afghan Soldier
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 7 — The man who shot and killed two American military trainers and wounded two others on Sunday was a soldier in the Afghan National Army, the Afghan Defense Ministry confirmed Monday.

headline: Tapes Capture Bold Claims of Bronx Man in Terror Plot
text: “You really want to learn how to rip somebody’s throat out?” Tarik Shah asked the man he thought was a terrorist. It was March 2004, and Mr. Shah did not know that the man was recording him for the government.

headline: Manhattan Challenge for Metal Bat Law
text: Several baseball bat manufacturers, baseball coaches, parents and players filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking to overturn New York City’s recent ban on metal bats in high school baseball games. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, claims the new law “unjustifiably prohibits the use of bats that are preferred by the vast majority” of players, coaches and teams and that are already regulated by national high school sports officials. The City Council, which approved the ban last month over Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s veto, said baseballs fly off metal bats faster than they do off wooden ones, making them more dangerous. Officials of the city Law Department said they would evaluate the lawsuit thoroughly.

headline: Child Care: Regular Television Time Starts for Many at 3 Months
text: For many families, apparently, it is never too early to watch television. Researchers reported yesterday that 40 percent of infants are regular viewers of television or videos by age 3 months, and 90 percent are watching regularly by age 2.

headline: Cuomo Announces Inquiry Into Conflicts Under Hevesi
text: ALBANY, May 7  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that his office was investigating “very troubling, serious, systemic conflicts of interest” in the way the comptroller’s office has managed the state’s $145 billion pension fund.

headline: Political Progress in Iraq as Violence Continues
text: BAGHDAD, May 8 — The threat of a walkout by Iraq’s leading Sunni Arab bloc in Parliament and the Cabinet seemed to subside Tuesday after a meeting between Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a Shiite, and Tariq al-Hashimi, the Sunni vice president.

headline: Pavlovic’s Offense Is No Longer His Defense
text: CLEVELAND, May 7 — Sasha Pavlovic insisted he was trying to make a joke. Perhaps it was lost in translation, considering Serbian is his first language.

headline: The Claim: Aspirin Can Reduce the Risk of Alzheimer’s Disease
text: THE FACTS

headline: Quebec Separatist Leader Resigns
text: QUEBEC, May 8 — The leader of the separatist Parti Québécois, André Boisclair, resigned today, further destabilizing a sovereignty movement that was left in shambles after a third-place finish in provincial elections in March.

headline: Congress and the Student Loan Scam
text: Republicans in Congress have generally defended corporate welfare for companies involved in the student loan business: lenders that collect billions of dollars in federal subsidies in return for issuing government-backed loans that represent no real risk to the companies themselves. But support for these wasteful subsidies is waning in both parties, thanks to recent revelations showing just how corrupt and costly the program has become.

headline: Romeos and Juliets: Young, Impetuous, ‘for Real’
text: New York City Ballet’s new “Romeo and Juliet” begins with a bit of mood-creating romantic spontaneity for Romeo: two or three arabesque poses alone, then, when his chums Mercutio and Benvolio join him, he waxes more poetic with a few richly dimensional pirouettes. As a solo, it at first looks piffling. But Peter Martins, this production’s choreographer and the company’s ballet master in chief, is giving audiences a choice of four Romeos and four Juliets, and that sketchy opening dance demonstrates how he has encouraged his Romeos to find their own voices.

headline: ABC Sets Spring 2010 as the End for ‘Lost’
text: LOS ANGELES, May 7  ABC announced on Monday that it would broadcast three more seasons of its hit castaway mystery, “Lost,” ending the show in 2010 after a run of six seasons.

headline: From DNA Analysis, Clues to a Single Australian Migration
text: Geneticists re-examining the first settlement of Australia and Papua-New Guinea by modern humans have concluded that the two islands were reached some 50,000 years ago by a single group of people who remained in substantial or total isolation until recent times. The finding, if upheld, would undermine assumptions that there have been subsequent waves of migration into Australia.

headline: Power Sharing Begins in Northern Ireland
text: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 8 — Paying tribute today to the thousands of victims in one of Europe’s bloodiest sectarian conflicts, the leaders of Northern Ireland drew a formal line under decades of hostility and strife, re-establishing a power-sharing local authority of once implacable foes.

headline: Deciphering the Results of a Prostate Test
text: After his annual physical, a middle-age man is told that his PSA level has jumped to 2.3 after having been stable for years at 1.5. Should he be alarmed?

headline: Waiters Claim Harassment at Mr. Chow
text: Michael Chow, a flamboyant artist, entrepreneur and owner of two elegant Chinese restaurants in Manhattan, does everything with singular flair, so it was hardly surprising that when three waiters sued him yesterday, it was in no way a run-of-the-mill lawsuit.

headline: Los Angeles Punishes Police Official Over Clash at Demonstration
text: LOS ANGELES, May 7 — The city’s mayor and its police chief said Monday that one of the highest-ranking officials in the Police Department would be demoted and transferred in the wake of a violent confrontation between officers and demonstrators at an immigration rally last week.

headline: Genes Take Charge, and Diets Fall by the Wayside
text: It was 1959. Jules Hirsch, a research physician at Rockefeller University, had gotten curious about weight loss in the obese. He was about to start a simple experiment that would change forever the way scientists think about fat.

headline: Sun Plans Version of Java for Web-Linked Cellphones
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 — Sun Microsystems plans to revamp its Java software in an effort to compete more effectively in the fast-growing market for Internet-connected mobile phones.

headline: More Than Just Talk
text: New Orleans

headline: Carving Out Havens and Facing Down the Skeptics
text: Enforcement officers from the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation sat in two cars and guarded the locked gates of Hunts Point Riverside Park in the South Bronx last Wednesday.

headline: Foes Wary of Street Sense in Preakness
text: Street Sense seems to have some trainers thinking twice about taking him on in the Preakness Stakes on May 19 in Baltimore. From the Derby field, only the runner-up, Hard Spun, has been committed to the Preakness, the second leg of the Triple Crown.

headline: Beating by Guards Fails to Stop Voting, Iranian Students Say
text: TEHRAN, May 7  Students at Amir Kabir University fended off club-wielding university security guards on Monday and went ahead with elections for a pro-democracy association.

headline: Shanahan and Rangers Left With Questions to Ponder
text: Of all the sadness, disappointment and heartbreak in the Rangers’ locker room Sunday after they were eliminated from the playoffs, forward Brendan Shanahan wore his most acutely. As the Rangers’ oldest player, a 38-year-old forward in a younger man’s sport, he could not find a minute’s solace in the team’s hopes for next season.

headline: Brooklyn Firefighters Find Homicide Victim
text: A 31-year-old Bedford-Stuyvesant woman whose body was found by firefighters after a fire broke out in her home early yesterday died of strangulation, the city medical examiner’s office said last night, adding that the death had been ruled a homicide. The police said the woman also had puncture wounds to the front and back of her torso. Firefighters were called to the home, at 39 Rochester Avenue, about 1:30 a.m. and discovered the body of the woman, who was identified by acquaintances as Wanette Douglas. The woman’s 5-year-old daughter, T’kyha Douglas, was treated for smoke inhalation, the authorities said.

headline: Manhattan Court Upholds School Cellphone Ban
text: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that New York City’s rule prohibiting students from bringing cellphones to public schools was “rational,” rejecting an effort by parents who had sought to overturn the ban. In a 50-page decision, the justice, Lewis Bart Stone, said the court could decide only whether the rule was a reasonable way to prevent students from using cellphones in school and that he could not suggest a different rule, even if he preferred one. “The court finds that banning possession in the school is not an irrational method to accomplish such goal,” he wrote. Justice Stone also rejected a claim that the rule violated students’ and parents’ constitutional rights. “Neither the state nor federal constitutions include any express constitutional right to bear cellphones,” he wrote. Norman Siegel, above, a lawyer for the parents, said they were considering an appeal. “We will not rest until the ban is lifted,” he said. David Cantor, a spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, said the city was pleased with the decision.

headline: Judge’s Libel Victory Against Paper Is Upheld
text: BOSTON, May 7  The highest court in Massachusetts upheld a $2 million libel verdict on Monday against The Boston Herald and one of its reporters for articles that said a Superior Court judge had made disparaging comments about crime victims and that he was lenient with criminals.

headline: A Producer and a Studio Stay Close Despite Split
text: LOS ANGELES, May 7 — Some couples get along better after the divorce. But few stay quite as intimate as Paramount Pictures and its erstwhile producing partner Scott Rudin.

headline: Electronic Voting May Be Ready by Fall ’08, Official Says
text: Despite earlier predictions to the contrary, New York State could well replace its aging voting machines by September 2008, a co-chairman of the New York State Board of Elections said yesterday.

headline: A Sheik and His Uninvited ‘Guests’ Mirror Uneasy Iraq-U.S. Ties
text: JUWAYBA, Iraq  Nearly every day, the sheik stops by the villa that was once his home, but is now an American garrison. Sometimes he comes with tips about the insurgency, or with news of political developments in this rural village near the Euphrates River.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Paris Hilton Rolls a Head

headline: Kalikow’s Departure Brings Assessments of His Six Turbulent Years as Chairman of the M.T.A.
text: When Peter S. Kalikow announced yesterday that he would be stepping down as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, it marked the end of six eventful and turbulent years, including a bitter transit strike, a bookkeeping scandal and the start of the first major expansion of the city’s transit system in decades.

headline: Study Links Rescuers’ Lung Ailment to Trade Center Collapse
text: In the first clinical study to clearly link World Trade Center dust to serious and sometimes fatal diseases, doctors have found that the number of New York City rescue and recovery workers with a rare type of lung-scarring condition soared in the year after the trade center collapsed.

headline: A Saucy Way to Get Noticed
text: A new campaign for a popular brand of pasta sauce is taking a humorous tack in an effort to stir the pot in a sleepy category and gain the attention of grocery shoppers.

headline: New Coalition of Christians Seeks Changes at Borders
text: WASHINGTON, May 7  A new coalition of more than 100 largely evangelical Christian leaders and organizations asked Congress on Monday to pass bills to strengthen border controls but also give illegal immigrants ways to gain legal residency.

headline: No Objections to Immunity Grant
text: Justice Department officials said they would not object to a Congressional grant of immunity to a former senior aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales who played a central role in the dismissals of federal prosecutors. The decision appeared to increase the likelihood that the aide, Monica Goodling, will soon appear before a Congressional panel, under a grant of immunity, to answer questions about last year’s firings of eight United States attorneys.

headline: 50 Years Later, Little Rock Can’t Escape Race
text: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — Fifty years after the epic desegregation struggle at Central High School, the school district here is still riven by racial conflict, casting a pall on this year’s ambitious commemorative efforts.

headline: For India’s Airlines, Passengers Are Plentiful but Profits Are Scarce
text: NEW DELHI, May 7 — Emergency landings, chronic delays and millions of dollars in losses — and that is just the month of April.

headline: Smithsonian Search Committee Named
text: The Board of Regents at the Smithsonian announced the members of the search committee charged with finding a new secretary of the institution. The chairman of the committee is Alan G. Spoon, a regent and managing general partner of Polaris Venture Partners. Other members are Representative Xavier Becerra, Democrat of California; L. Hardwick Caldwell, chairman of the institution’s National Board; Anne d’Harnoncourt, a regent and director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art; Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont; Walter E. Massey, president of Morehouse College in Atlanta; Jeffrey Minear, administrative assistant to Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.; and Roger W. Sant, chairman of the regent executive committee.

headline: Answering Al Qaeda
text: Washington

headline: Fox Interactive Nears Deal to Buy Photobucket
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7  Photobucket, a four-year-old, rapidly growing Web company, is in advanced talks to be acquired by Fox Interactive Media, a division of the News Corporation, a person briefed on the negotiations said Monday.

headline: U.S. Apologizes to Families for Killing Afghan Civilians
text: WASHINGTON, May 8 — An Army commander apologized and paid compensation on Tuesday to families of Afghan civilians killed by marines after a suicide attack in March, marking the first formal acknowledgment by American authorities that the killings were unjustified.

headline: Chevron Seen Settling Case on Iraq Oil
text: Chevron, the second-largest American oil company, is preparing to acknowledge that it should have known kickbacks were being paid to Saddam Hussein on oil it bought from Iraq as part of a defunct United Nations program, according to investigators.

headline: Hundreds Are Arrested in Post-Election Riots Across France
text: PARIS, May 7  Violent protests against the election of Nicolas Sarkozy as president of France ended early Monday after hundreds of people were arrested, hundreds of cars gutted, and hundreds of windows smashed in several cities across France.

headline: Stealth Killer Puts Doctor on Mission With N.F.L.
text: The long ago quarterback and retired heart surgeon was 58 when he discovered how much he knew about human frailty, just not his own.

headline: Relationship Counseling, With Hand Signs for ‘Sex’ and ‘Cry’
text: It’s hard to write a comedy that’s funny in more than one language. Christopher Durang can congratulate himself. More than a quarter-century after he wrote “Beyond Therapy,” it is still very funny in a language not generally mentioned in discussions of the translator’s art: American Sign Language.

headline: Revisiting, and Revising, a Very Familiar Legend
text: She was bright and curious, probably between 10 and 14. He was a cocky adventurer, short and hairy, about 28 when they met.

headline: Errors Lead to Giants’ Big Inning and Doom Mets
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 — The Mets spent so much time in the field during the fifth inning of Monday’s game that they could have counted how many fans were sitting in Section 108. Anything to distract them from Giants stampeding around the bases. In all, 12 came to the plate, and surprise, surprise, Barry Bonds played only a minor role as his teammates tagged the Mets for nine runs in their 9-4 victory.

headline: Nigerian Bishop Criticizes Episcopal Church
text: In a letter to the archbishop of Canterbury, the Anglican Archbishop of Nigeria, Peter J. Akinola, harshly criticized the Episcopal Church for what he called an “insulting and condescending” response to demands by primates of the worldwide Anglican Communion to establish a parallel oversight structure for disaffected congregations and dioceses in the United States. Archbishop Akinola arrived in Virginia late last week to install a new bishop for one such structure, rejecting requests to cancel his trip from the archbishop of Canterbury, the leader of the communion, and the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, the American branch of Anglicanism. Archbishop Akinola dismissed concerns that he was exacerbating tensions over a longstanding dispute regarding the church’s liberal stance on homosexuality, blaming instead the Episcopal Church for the crisis.

headline: Adolescence: No Link to Promiscuity Found in Youths Using Condoms
text: A new study has found that adolescents who use condoms the first time they have intercourse do not go on to have more sexual partners than others, and that they have lower rates of sexually transmitted diseases than those who do not use condoms the first time.

headline: Albany: New Rules for Tuition Loans
text: Both houses of the State Legislature passed legislation yesterday to sharply restrict the relationships between colleges and the companies that make tuition loans to their students. The legislation follows an investigation by Andrew M. Cuomo, the state attorney general, into hundreds of colleges, lenders and alumni associations that have admitted to or are suspected of steering loans to prospective students in exchange for gifts, trips or payments from lenders. The bill, which Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to sign, prohibits colleges from soliciting or accepting any gifts or money from lenders in exchange for recommending them to students, and prohibits lenders’ staff members from working out of college financial aid offices, among other provisions.

headline: Alcoa Makes a Hostile Bid for Alcan
text: MONTREAL, May 7 — The success of Alcoa’s hostile $27 billion takeover offer for the rival Alcan of Canada may rest as much with politicians as investors.

headline: Boy, 1, Dies and 3 Are Hurt in Brooklyn Basement Fire
text: A 1-year-old boy was killed and three of his relatives were critically injured yesterday morning when a fire broke out in an illegal basement apartment in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

headline: A Moment of Revelation, Preserved in a Test Stick
text: If I ever manage to assemble a baby book about my son, here are some of the things I’ll put in it: the tiny onesie I bought when I was just a few weeks pregnant, and the first ghostly ultrasound print my husband and I received. (We named it “Reclining Nude.”)

headline: Clear Channel Postpones Vote, Giving Suitors’ Bid More Time
text: Clear Channel Communications, owner of the largest network of radio stations in the nation, yesterday postponed a shareholder vote on a revised buyout offer by two private equity firms.

headline: Soaring for the Most Important Women in Their Lives
text: Mother’s Day is hardly a red-letter event in the modern-dance world. But for Urban Bush Women, who open tonight at the Joyce Theater, it seems only natural that the company would celebrate the holiday in a performance this Sunday afternoon.

headline: Jury Is Still Out on Gluten, the Latest Dietary Villain
text: Brandi Walzer, a 29-year-old cartographer in Savannah, Ga., loves bread, not to mention pizza and beer. But she tries to avoid them, because they contain gluten — a substance she says upsets her stomach, aggravates her arthritis and touches off depression.

headline: Consumer Borrowing Increased in March by Most in 4 Months
text: WASHINGTON, May 7 (Bloomberg News) — Consumer borrowing increased in March by the most in four months as Americans charged more purchases to their credit cards and took out more car loans, Federal Reserve figures show.

headline: Laptops in School: Boon or Bane? (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Alcoa Makes a Bid for Alcan of Canada
text: MONTREAL, May 7  Alcoa made an unsolicited $27 billion offer today for rival Alcan of Canada, which would propel it to the top spot in the aluminum industry, a position it surrendered just months ago.

headline: Ramapo Man Arrested After Gunfire in Courtroom
text: A 60-year-old man was arrested last night after he fired a .22 caliber rifle in a village courtroom in Rockland County, the police said. No one was injured when, the Ramapo Police Department said, Leo Lewis, a party in a civil case in the village court in Sloatsburg, pulled out the rifle and fired a single shot toward the front of the courtroom. Mr. Lewis had been scheduled for a hearing around 6 p.m. at the Sloatsburg courthouse, which also serves as the village hall. The police said it was unclear if Mr. Lewis was aiming at anyone. They said he ran out of the courtroom after the shot, and a Sloatsburg court officer and Ramapo police officer gave chase. The Ramapo officer fired one shot during the chase, but it did not hit anyone, the authorities said. A civilian outside the building helped the officers catch Mr. Lewis. No charges had been filed as of late last night.

headline: Cheering Change at the Élysée, and in Neighbors’ Attitudes
text: All in all, the French who live and work in New York had reason to feel chipper yesterday. In even greater percentages than their compatriots back home, they had voted strongly for Nicolas Sarkozy to be France’s next president. On Sunday, their jour de gloire arrived.

headline: Across the Sea Under Power From the Sun
text: So far, the five Swiss sailors aboard the sun21 have not run into trouble the way Giovanni da Verrazano did.
