headline: Memo Pad
text: AIR TRAVEL DELAYS ARE UP Delays on domestic flights rose in the first quarter, with 25.25 percent of flights arriving late, compared with 21.35 percent in the first quarter of last year, the Bureau of Transportation Statistics said yesterday. The number of lost or otherwise mishandled checked bags rose in March  to 7.71 per 1,000 passengers compared with 5.81 per 1,000 passengers in March 2006.

headline: Bonds Is Doing His Talking With a Bat in His Hands
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 — Barry Bonds has averaged a home run once every three games this season. So, entering Monday night’s game against the Mets needing 12 home runs to break Hank Aaron’s record of 755, it stands to reason that Bonds is more than capable of coming to Shea Stadium in three weeks with a chance to make history. Wouldn’t that be fun?

headline: 20 Years Later, Again Assigned to Fight Climate Change
text: Gro Harlem Brundtland is back on the case.

headline: Monroe Township: Minor Injuries in School Bus Crash
text: Twenty-two elementary school students sustained minor injuries yesterday morning when two school buses collided in central New Jersey, the authorities said. A driver of one of the buses was also hurt in the crash, which occurred about 9 a.m. in Monroe Township. The authorities said the collision, near the intersection of Buckelew Avenue and Schoolhouse Road, occurred when a bus that had stopped to pick up children was rear-ended by another bus. The students, some of whom were removed on backboards and wearing neck braces, were treated at four area hospitals. The injuries included facial cuts and complaints of back and neck pain. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: People
text: People

headline: An Irish Taste for Real Estate in Manhattan
text: They live an ocean away, but that has not stopped the Irish from lining up to buy condominiums in Midtown Manhattan, often years before they are built.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,361 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Icahn Appears to Fall Short at Motorola
text: CHICAGO, May 7  The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn came to Chicago on Monday to attend Motorola’s shareholders meeting, with some expectation that he would get elected to the board.

headline: Sale of Carbon Credits Helping Land-Rich, but Cash-Poor, Tribes
text: LAPWAI, Idaho — On the Nez Perce reservation here, land that was cleared in the 19th century for farming is being converted back to forest, in part to sell the trees’ ability to sequester carbon.

headline: ABN Amro Rejects $24.5 Billion Bid for LaSalle
text: LONDON, May 7  ABN Amro on Monday rejected a $24.5 billion bid from the Royal Bank of Scotland Group and two partners for its American unit, the LaSalle Bank  putting the fate of the Dutch bank, which is at the center of a large and complex takeover battle, more in the hands of shareholders.

headline: Virginia Lacrosse Team Finds  Reluctant Leader
text: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 3 — Ben Rubeor rolls up his sleeve to show the underside of his left forearm. The raised scars that are scattered from his wrist to his elbow are pinkish now, but for a long time they were almost purple.

headline: Clemens, Redux (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Museum for Artifacts of the News Media’s Hunters and Gatherers
text: WASHINGTON  Time magazine’s armored truck from the Balkans, pockmarked with bullet holes, has been hoisted into place. The laptop used by Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter murdered in Pakistan in 2002, has arrived. So has the vest that Bob Woodruff of ABC was wearing last year when he was wounded by a roadside bomb in Iraq.

headline: Patterns: Early Menarche Linked to Heavier Children
text: The younger a woman is when she has her first period, the more likely her children are to be overweight, a new study suggests.

headline: Israeli Premier Survives Votes in Parliament
text: JERUSALEM, May 7 — Israel’s prime minister, Ehud Olmert, survived three no-confidence votes against his government on Monday, part of the political fallout from a harsh report on the country’s leadership during last summer’s war in Lebanon.

headline: Abortion Rises Anew for Giuliani
text: WASHINGTON, May 7  Rudolph W. Giuliani told a gathering of conservatives Monday that his campaign could be boiled down to two major themes: national security and economic security.

headline: Mozart’s ‘Figaro,’ With a Cast in First-Marriage Age Bracket
text: Mozart’s “Nozze di Figaro” often has an added resonance when performed by a cast of young, eager singers who have fresh memories of adolescent crushes and romantic stirrings. This was true of the production by Mannes Opera on Sunday afternoon in the Kaye Playhouse of Hunter College. (The performance was the second of two.) The likable, well-schooled and endearing cast had both undergraduates and students in the master’s programs at Mannes College the New School for Music, so the average age was the early 20s.

headline: Devil Rays Tempting Fans With a Field Trip
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 3 — Under the dome of Tropicana Field, Carlos Peña hit a pop-up that never came down. It lodged in the ceiling for a foul ball. Next time up, in the 10th inning, Peña hit another pop-up that caromed off a catwalk and landed for a single behind the confused Minnesota infielders.

headline: It’s Still Dark Out, So Why Are the Birds Singing Away?
text: Being the divas that they are, songbirds don’t like noise. Urban birds have been known to alter their songs to be heard above the racket — making them shorter, higher pitched or louder, or changing their patterns.

headline: Lost on Metro-North, but Most Likely Found
text: It is not too much of a stretch to say that Mike Nolan has seen just about everything there is to see in his line of work, from commuters searching for their false teeth to Pete Seeger’s banjo to thousands of dollars in cash tucked into a pair of socks.

headline: Pavano Says He Has Elbow Tear
text: Carl Pavano talked after the game and said he would meet with Dr. Frank Jobe on Wednesday in California. A couple of writers reminded him he was actually seeing Dr. Lewis Yocum.

headline: ‘Top Chef’ Dreams Crushed by Student Loan Debt
text: Many would-be top chefs face a challenge that most lawyers, engineers or nurses do not: few jobs in their chosen field pay enough for them to retire their student loans. As a result, as many as 11 percent of graduates at some culinary schools are defaulting on federal student loans. The national average for all students last year was roughly half that, at 5.1 percent.

headline: Tread Lightly
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Replacing Kyoto
text: More than 1000 Delegates from more than 160 nations began meeting today in Bonn to decide what kind of treaty should replace the 10 year old Kyoto Protocol, which expires in 2012. That program, which sets targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in developed nations, was never signed by the United States (the worlds largest emitter) and did not apply to China and India (two other major polluters) because they are developing nations.

headline: The Exodus
text: Millions of Iraqis have fled their country, creating the largest Mideast refugee problem since 1948.

headline: Trouble in paradise — or not
text: A rash of alarming headlines regarding the Spanish property market in recent weeks are enough to give anyone the impression that the market is on the verge of collapse. The event that inspired the doom-and-gloom articles was a share price correction of property companies quoted on the Madrid stock exchange. But, according to one expert, falling stock market confidence is not the same as a housing market crash.

headline: Zurich Capital Settles Probe into Market-Timing
text: Zurich Capital Markets agreed to pay $16.8 million to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of alleged market-timing of mutual funds. The S.E.C. said that between 1999 and 2003, Zurich Capital, a unit of Zurich Financial, made $11 million by helping four hedge funds that were defrauding mutual funds through illegal market timing.

headline: Macquarie Fires Up New Alinta Bid
text: The Macquarie Bank, Australia’s largest securities firm, made a new takeover offer for the energy transmission company Alinta to challenge Alinta’s agreement to be acquired for 7.4 billion Australian dollars ($6.1 billion) by Babcock & Brown and Singapore Power.

headline: Buyout Group Abandons Qantas Bid
text: The buyout group bidding for Qantas Airways of Australia on Tuesday declared its offer of 11 billion Australian dollars ($9 billion) had lapsed after deciding not to pursue a legal case to keep the takeover alive. The group, Airline Partners Australia, said it believed “that Qantas shareholders need more certainty and, accordingly, it has determined that its bid should be treated as having lapsed on May 4, 2007.”

headline: BAE Buys Armor Holdings for $4 Billion
text: The military contractor BAE Systems said it had agreed to buy Armor Holdings, a maker of armored vehicles for the United States military, for $4.1 billion. BAE Systems, based in London, agreed to pay $88 a share for Armor Holdings, a 7 percent premium over its closing price Friday. BAE is also assuming $388 million in debt.

headline: Fund With Rinker Stake Backs Cemex Offer
text: The largest shareholder of the Rinker Group, an Australian building company, said it had approved a $14.25 billion bid from Cemex, the Mexican cement company. Perpetual, a fund manager in Sydney that owns a 10.5 percent stake in Rinker, said it would accept Cemex’s amended offer.

headline: Subprime Mortgages: A Cross-Country Blame Game
text: What used to be a profitable partnership between subprime lenders and Wall Street banks has degenerated into a cross-country blame game. Lenders in California say big investment banks encouraged and pushed them to make risky loans. On Wall Street, bank executives say mortgage lenders became sloppy and did not pay enough attention to fraud.

headline: Could BHP Be the First $120 Billion Buyout Target?
text: BHP Billiton once considered a possible suitor for Alcoa, which began a hostile bid of its own for Alcan, may become a target itself.

headline: Icahn Appears to Fall Short at Motorola
text: The billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn came to Chicago on Monday for Motorola‘s shareholders meeting, with some hope that he would be elected to the board. But by late in the day, as the politics played out, Mr. Icahn conceded that he had lost his proxy fight and had failed to garner enough support from large funds to become a director.

headline: Theater Awards Are Announced
text: The New York Drama Critics' Circle has named "The Coast of Utopia" by Tom Stoppard the best play of the 2006-7 season.

headline: J.P. Morgan’s Dimon Talks Deal Making
text: Following comments last year by James Dimon that J.P. Morgan Chase was ready to do some deal making, the bank’s chief executive provided a few more details on the subject, but still appeared to be hedging his bets.

headline: Jerry Mathers Joins the Cast of ‘Hairspray’
text: Jerry Mathers, best known for his portrayal of Theodore (Beaver) Cleaver in the 1950s family comedy "Leave it to Beaver," will be joining the cast of "Hairspray" on June 5.

headline: Deutsche Sells 60 Wall St. for $1.1 Billion
text: Deutsche Bank said Friday that it is selling its North American headquarters in Manhattan for $1.18 billion to the Paramount Group, a real estate firm. Deutsche, the latest company to take advantage of a sizzling commercial real estate market, bought the 1.6 million-square-foot 60 Wall St. from J.P. Morgan Chase in July 2001.

headline: Couple Expected to Plead Guilty to Insider Trading
text: A former Morgan Stanley compliance officer and her husband are expected to plead guilty this week to charges stemming from an insider-trading case that prosecutors say was part of the largest such scheme on Wall Street since the 1980s.

headline: Judge Rules Broadcom Suit Can Proceed
text: A judge Monday denied a request by the Broadcom founders Henry Nicholas and Henry Samueli and other company directors to dismiss a lawsuit filed by investors accusing them of improperly backdating stock options. Judge Manuel Real of United States District Court in Los Angeles made the ruling without further comment. Judge Real last month denied a similar motion by the company to dismiss the case for lack of merit.

headline: Liz Claiborne Dresses Up with Narcisco Rodriguez Deal
text: Few dresses have attained the glamour than the dress that Carolyn Bessette wore to marry John F. Kennedy Jr. in 1996. But its designer, Narcisco Rodriguez, has since fallen on hard times. In a rare move in the fashion world, however, he asked for help.

headline: Clear Channel Postpones Shareholder Vote on Buyout
text: Clear Channel Communications, owner of the largest network of radio stations in the nation, on Monday postponed a shareholder vote on a revised buyout offer by two private equity firms.

headline: London Stars Join ‘George’ on Broadway Next Year
text: The Olivier Award winners Daniel Evans and Jenna Russell will reprise their starring roles when the Menier Chocolate Factory of London production of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine's Pulitzer Prize-winning musical "Sunday in the Park With George" opens next year in New York.

headline: Portola Raises $70 Million to Prep for I.P.O.
text: Vascular anticoagulant drug developer Portola Pharmaceuticals raised $70 million in a third round of venture financing from a deep-pocketed group of hedge fund and crossover investors. The firm will use the cash to fund late stage clinical trials, and prepare for an initial public offering in its next capital call.

headline: Solar Power Start-Up Absorbs $27 Million
text: Solaicx, a developer of solar wafers, said on Tuesday it had received an additional $27.1 million in funding, giving it the funds it needs to increase production. The firm said it had developed a new process for making single-crystal silicon wafers-designed specifically for solar panels-more efficiently and cheaply.

headline: Marsha Mason at Playwrights
text: The four-time Academy Award nominee Marsha Mason will star when Playwrights Horizons presents the world premiere of "A Feminine Ending" next fall.

headline: S.E.C. to Consider New Proxy Rules
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission will float a proposal this summer to address controversy over shareholder democracy and hopes to have new rules in place by fall, in time for corporate annual meetings in 2008, the agency’s chairman, Christopher Cox, said Monday.

headline: A Deal To-Do List for Warren Buffett
text: After Warren Buffett said would “love” to find a $40 billion acquisition, BusinessWeek has put together its list of possible targets for the Berkshire Hathaway chieftain.

headline: Wall Street Journal Editors Held News of Murdoch Bid
text: One of the trickiest things for a news organization to do is cover itself.

headline: Are Heavyweight Investors Turning on Private Equity?
text: The balance of power between institutional investors, like Fidelity Investments and T. Rowe Price, and buyout deal makers such as Henry Kravis, David Bonderman and Leon Black, is beginning to shift, says Bloomberg News.

headline: Thomson in Talks to Buy Reuters for $17.6 Billion
text: Big-time deal making has officially hit the media market.

headline: Former Associate Testifies Black Was Kept Informed
text: The star witness in the criminal case against the former media baron Conrad M. Black, F. David Radler, took the stand Monday and portrayed himself as a close partner of Mr. Black who did not make a major move without talking with him.

headline: Arcelor Mittal Is Said to Eye AK Steel
text: Deal making in the metals sector is flourishing. The Financial Times’s Alphaville blog reported Tuesday that Arcelor-Mittal, the steel empire run by Lakshmi Mittal, is considering a deal for AK Steel, a smaller Ohio-based rival. Arcelor-Mittal may offer as much as $4.5 billion, or $40 a share, Alphaville said. Shares in AK jumped 3.5 percent to $32 in New York on Monday as news of the impending deal appeared to emerge.

headline: Deutsche Bank 1st-Quarter Profit Rises 30%
text: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest bank, said first-quarter profit rose 30 percent on record earnings from its securities unit. The bank outpaced European rivals UBS and Credit Suisse Group as record revenue from sales and trading spurred investment banking earnings.

headline: Muzzling All to Hush a Few
text: CBSNews.com has been getting so many vitriolic comments about Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, that it has taken the unusual step of blocking all reader comments on its stories about Mr. Obama.

headline: LVMH Plans to Spend on Belle’s I.P.O.
text: France’s LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the world’s largest luxury goods group, plans to buy $30 million worth of initial public offering shares in China’s Belle International Holdings, according to a deal prospectus. Belle, which is China’s largest retailer of women’s shoes, intends to raise up to $1.1 billion to add about 1,000 outlets a year in China.

headline: Australia’s Publishing & Broadcasting to Split Gaming, Media Assets
text: Australia’s richest man, James Packer, will split his Publishing & Broadcasting empire into two listed gaming and media companies and return 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.7 billion) to shareholders, sending the firm’s stock up 6 percent, Reuters reported Tuesday. Mr. Packer, who took control of Publishing and Broadcasting following the death of his father, said he would separate the company’s fast-expanding gaming and casino operations from its traditional businesses of television and magazines to raise the stock price and pursue growth.

headline: Virtuosos and Storytellers
text: Photographs from the inaugural Stagecoach country music festival in Indio, Calif.

headline: The Year of Who Knows When
text: For years, there’s been an annual happening on sites like Chowhound, where, for months before it actually happens, people eagerly inquire if the Red Hook Ball Fields – the city’s top spot for pan-Latin street eats – are open for business yet.

headline: How to Make the Debates Worth Watching
2008: Abortion and the G.O.P. Primary
text: A report by Politico.com Monday evening that Rudolph W. Giuliani donated $900 to Planned Parenthood, an abortion rights advocacy group and provider, adds a new wrinkle to the former New York mayor’s efforts to persuade conservatives to look past his social views. Speaking in Iowa Monday, Senator John McCain said it would be “tough” for a candidate who supports abortion rights to win the G.O.P. nod.

headline: Gilles Villeneuve, Zolder, 8 May 1982
text: Trying to figure out what could be the best way for me to say something about the 25 year anniversary of Gilles Villeneuve’s death at the Belgian Grand Prix, I realized that probably the best thing I could do was to avoid my usual verbose approach to blogging, and simply set up some links. But these links are the things that come to my mind.

headline: How Ronald Reagan Is Killing the Republican Party
text: “No mortal fares well when compared to a saint, which is how Republicans view Reagan,” writes Time Washington bureau chief Jay Carney at Swampland. “But a party more focused on its grand past than its promising future is a party in deep trouble.” Carney continues:

headline: Killing Time in Barcelona
text: My family will be flying overnight to Barcelona this summer, arriving around 9 AM. Hotel check in is not until 2 PM or so. Any suggestions for places to rest, relax and put up one’s feet in that transition time?

headline: Lost, Then Found: Herod’s Tomb
text: For decades, archaeologists looking for the tomb of King Herod have focused on one site in particular, based on an account in the first volume of “The Wars of the Jews,” written by the first-century historian Flavius Josephus.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: The Times's Harry Hurt III tries his hand at sailing. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

headline: Casa Hyder
text: Tour the Hyder family's labyrinthine 10-bedroom, 11-bathroom second home in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III pursues lost youth by taking up surfing. (Producer: Erik Olsen)

headline: $1,600,000 Homes
text: A 46-acre equestrian property near Charlottesville, Va., a Santa Fe-style stucco house in Scottsdale, Ariz., and a Victorian home in San Luis Obispo, Calif.

headline: Constructions of a Cultural Legend
text: More images from “The Sculpture of Louise Nevelson: Constructing a Legend,” now at the Jewish Museum.

headline: Poiret’s Descendents
text: Paul Poiret, the subject of the new costume exhibition at the Metropolitian Museum of Art, was one of the worldliest of the worldly, at least as the world looked right after the First World War. He was as famous for his elegant, Oriental dresses as he was his dazzling costume parties, including one, “La Mille et Deuxième Nuit,” that featured live monkeys and parrots, as well as actors hired to play beggars and rug merchants as 300 guests dined on lobsters, goose liver and 900 liters of Champagne. Poiret sat on a throne.

headline: Citadel Gets Active With Networking Firm 3Com
text: Kenneth Griffin doesn’t shy away from unloved assets. As the market for subprime mortgages — loans to homeowners with weak credit histories — began to fall apart this year, his $13.5 billion fund, the Citadel Investment Group, snapped up assets in the industry. Now, Citadel is putting a chunk of money into a beaten-down technology company. Citadel has spent $135 million to buy an 8.4 percent stake in 3Com, a maker of networking equipment that was a Wall Street darling in the 1990’s, before it spun off its Palm subsidiary and the technology boom subsided. Times have changed, and 3com’s stock has lost about half its value since early 2004.

headline: Joe Perella Gets His Headline Deal
text: Since it was founded a year and a half ago with a roster of brand-name investment bankers, Perella Weinberg Partners has left many on Wall Street wondering when it would get its first marquee deal — the kind of blockbuster transaction that involves well-known companies and lots of zeroes in the price tag. On Tuesday, the doubters seemed to get their answer: The boutique investment bank, led by Joseph R. Perella, is a co-lead adviser to the Thomson Corporation, alongside Bear Stearns, in its negotiations to acquire the Reuters Group for 8.77 billion pounds ($17.5 billion).

headline: Real Estate Notes From All Over
text: Notes from higher end real estate:

headline: Washington’s Tax Talk Turns to Ivory Towers
text: Some top universities may be getting caught up in a wide-ranging congressional examination of the tax treatment of hedge funds and private equity firms. The scrutiny from Washington has been a prime concern for many buyout chiefs, who fear that cherished tax loopholes may be closed. (PEhub, writing about the topic Tuesday, poked some fun at such concerns, noting “the horror of being filthy rich instead of obscenely rich.”) On Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported that, in addition to looking at how private equity and hedge funds are taxed, the Senate Finance Committee also discussed offshore investments of pension funds, foundations and universities including Harvard, Yale and Stanford.

headline: Alli Ad
text: An advertisement for Alli by GlaxoSmithKline.

headline: Alli Ad
text: An advertisement for Alli by GlaxoSmithKline.

headline: Lazard’s 1st-Quarter Profit Falls Short of Estimates
text: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said Tuesday that its first-quarter profit grew 5 percent from last year, helped by gains in its asset management business. Revenue from the firm’s core financial advisory work, which includes helping to arrange mergers, remained essentially flat from a year ago.

headline: The Fat Woman of YouTube
text: In mid-March, a harangue by a proud 224-pound woman named Joy Nash appeared on YouTube.

headline: Clinton Warning Signs in Iowa
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign sent supporters an email last night calling attention to a recent blog entry by a key backer of hers, former Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa, describing “Hillary’s strong organization in Iowa and office openings across the Hawkeye State.”

headline: Blogtalk: Tuesday Link Mania
text: Sharpton vs. Hitchens

headline: Let the Sharing Begin in Ulster
text: To get a sense of the extraordinary optimism in Northern Ireland today, look no further than a self-deprecating joke credited to the “reliably intransigent” Rev. Ian Paisley.

headline: The Yin and Yang of Supervoting Shares
text: Supervoting shares can be either good or bad for ordinary investors. Or they can be good at first, and bad later. Or vice versa. Given the potential hazards, should investors accept these kinds of dual-class share structures, in which not all shareholders are created equal, and some essentially call the shots?

headline: The Next Exchange Takeover?
text: The world’s exchanges cannot seem to buy each other fast enough. The latest example of the global consolidation is last week’s $2.8 billion offer by Deutsche Borse of Germany for the International Securities Exchange, a New York-based options exchange.

headline: Crazy Is O.K., But Don’t Lie to Google
text: A hint for start-ups hoping to be acquired by Google (and what start-up doesn’t?): Don’t try to bamboozle the Internet giant. The warning came from Google’s acquisitions chief, Salman Ullah, during a conference for venture capitalists in Monterrey last week. The Red Herring’s Scott Martin wrote about the event Tuesday on the magazine’s blog.

headline: 2 Accused of Insider Trading in Dow Jones Stock
text: Well, that was fast. Less than a week after Dow Jones confirmed receiving a $5 billion takeover bid from News Corporation, a Hong Kong couple stands accused of insider trading in Dow Jones shares before the approach was made public. In a civil complaint filed Tuesday in New York, the Securities and Exchange Commission said the couple spent $15 million to engage in “highly profitable and highly suspicious” trades in Dow Jones shares from April 13 to April 30. When the bid was announced on May 1, Dow Jones’s shares shot up by 58 percent.

headline: Frankie Avalon’s Long Tail
text: With news about the music industry getting worse every day, the National Association of Recording Merchandisers met last week to, as the Chicago Tribune put it, “figure out how to halt a slide in CD sales while providing music fans with new reasons to shop at a store.”

headline: Times Square vs. Eiffel Tower
text: Times Square makes up only 0.1 percent of New York City’s area, but accounts for 5 percent of the city’s jobs and 10 percent of the city’s economic output — more than the combined gross domestic products of Bolivia and Panama — and is far more popular around the world than the Eiffel Tower in Paris, at least as measured by Google hits.

headline: Grasso Wins Round in Lawsuit Over Pay
text: Richard Grasso’s retirement may have just gotten a bit more pleasant. The former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange won a partial legal victory on Tuesday when an appeals court threw out four rulings against him in a suit over his $190 compensation package. The reversal was on technical grounds, The Associated Press said; Bloomberg News reported that the state of New York can still go to trial against Mr. Grasso on other claims. A spokesman for New York Governor Eliot Spitzer, who, as New York’s attorney general, first sued Mr. Grasso to seek the return of the money, said the state planned to appeal Tuesday’s decision. But the final decision on an appeal will be up to New York’s current attorney general, Andrew Cuomo.

headline: Wine School, Take Two
text: The first session of the Dining Table Wine School is nearly finished, and I’m about to declare recess. But before we pack up the glasses — “close up your books, get out of your seat, down the halls and into the street’’ — I have just a few things to add.

headline: More on Hillary Rodham Clinton
text: Plenty of readers disagreed furiously with my Monday column about Senator Clinton’s candidacy, warning that we should be wary of keeping the White House in any one family. You can see (or add to) the reader comments if you scroll down a bit and hit the comment tab.

headline: Worthy of Adulation, If Not Imitation
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s May 8 column, “Where History Reigns.”

headline: Powerful Poverty Policy
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s May 8 column, “More Than Just Talk.“

headline: More Details on the Fort Dix Suspects
text: Following are some details from reports around the Web to complement The Times’s lede:

headline: Insider Trading?
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission today persuaded a federal judge to freeze the profits of a Hong Kong couple who made $8 million by buying stock in Dow Jones from April 13 to April 20, and then selling it last Friday. The 415,000 shares they bought accounted for 3 percent of the volume during the period.

headline: The G.O.P.’s French Connection
text: Among Republicans, making fun of the French seems to always be en vogue. But while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign has worked to quell comparisons to Ségolène Royal, the socialist candidate who lost Sunday’s French elections, some Republicans are suddenly eager to associate themselves with the French.

headline: No Love Lost
text: It’s long been clear to me that working in a restaurant is tense and grueling. For one thing, I’ve waited tables. For another, I sit in restaurants almost every night, and I can see how servers hustle and, if the kitchen is open to view, how cooks sweat.

headline: My First Time in New York City
From Apple, a Welcome Reminder
text: Holy cow. I just got this e-mail from Apple’s iTunes store:

headline: Sitting Out the Tennessee Waltz
text: Despite two crowded fields of presidential aspirants, voters remain unhappy. Each party lacks a candidate with the ability to unite and excite its diverse factions—while also projecting the electability needed for the fall 2008 race. So we’re now hearing wistful talk that two Tennessee senators-turned-Hollywood-stars might join the race: Fred Thompson for the Republicans, Al Gore for the Democrats. Neither man, alas, can answer his party’s prayers.

headline: Raw Deal?
text: Speaking of public authorities and economic development, a labor-backed group called New York Jobs With Justice has taken a closer look at another, especially convoluted and under-examined kind of authority: Local business-promotion agencies known as industrial development authorities. IDAs, as they are known, account for more than half of all the authorities on state books, according to this handy list put out by the state comptroller’s office. In a nutshell, IDAs are set up, usually with the consent of state lawmakers, to support the development of everything from manufacturing facilities to hotels to horseracing tracks. The deal is, the IDAs give developers a tax break, or financing through tax-exempt bonds, in exchange for the promise of creating jobs and economic activity.

headline: Dancing With The Tundra
text: When I was young, my parents, Frank and Bernice Maynard, and my godmother, Maxine P. Clapper, were determined to groom me into a fine lady.

headline: Yankee Doodle Andy
text: The last time Andy Pettitte played for the Yankees, he kept a back page of The New York Daily News taped to the side of his locker. It had Pettitte’s black-and-white picture on it with the headline: TIRED ACT.

headline: Kitchen Starter Kit
text: Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, outfits a kitchen with the basics for less than $300.

headline: Massachusetts Proposes Stem Cell Research Grants
text: BOSTON, May 8 — Gov. Deval Patrick on Tuesday unveiled a $1.25 billion proposal intended to help the state maintain its status as a pre-eminent place for stem cell research and other life sciences.

headline: Treasury Chief Supports Delay for Wolfowitz
text: WASHINGTON, May 8 — Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. on Tuesday endorsed the request by Paul D. Wolfowitz, the World Bank president, for more time to defend himself against charges of misconduct, seeking a delay that could also give the Bush administration time to negotiate his voluntary resignation.

headline: Kiwanuka Revisits His Past and Pursues a New Dream
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 8  The biggest off-season change for the Giants’ Mathias Kiwanuka did not come with word that he was moving from defensive end to linebacker.

headline: Dining Briefs: Spotlight Live and Pio Pio Salon
text: NEW PLACES

headline: Recipe: Extra-Sharp Leeks Vinaigrette
text: Time: 25 minutes

headline: Six Ordinary Lives That Took a Detour to a World of Terror
text: These are the suspects arrested in connection with a plot to attack Fort Dix.

headline: Gates Discusses Software, but Talk of a Yahoo Deal Persists
text: SEATTLE, May 8 — Bill Gates, Microsoft’s chairman, spoke to hundreds of marketers and advertising agencies here on Tuesday amid rumblings about his company’s struggle to compete against Google in online advertising and about its efforts to court Yahoo for some sort of partnership.

headline: Players Championship Shifts Date; Island Green Stays
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., May 8  The Players Championship is the PGA Tour’s most eccentric child, a tournament dug from swampland and topped with an island green.

headline: When Images Take on Lives of Their Own
text: This documentary by Hans Pool and Maaik Krijgsman about four World Press Photo contest winners defines icon to mean a still image so searing that it supplants memories of the event it was supposed to record.

headline: Peddling Fear (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Sweet So Sour: Kool-Aid Dills
text: Greenville, Miss.

headline: Look to Airbus for Clues to Sarkozy
text: TOULOUSE, France, May 7 — For those trying to predict how France’s newly elected president, Nicolas Sarkozy, will lead his country’s economy, one of the first critical tests is likely to come here, at the home base of Airbus, the proud but ailing European plane maker.

headline: Cheers in Valencia as Spain’s Boat Backs Into Semifinals
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 8 — Matt Wachowicz has been a Harvard student, an aspiring professional high hurdler, a molecular biologist and an anxious military spouse.

headline: Clinton Foundation Announces a Bargain on Generic AIDS Drugs
text: Former President Bill Clinton announced yesterday that his foundation had negotiated deep price reductions for generic versions of costly, second-line AIDS drugs needed when the original medicines fail, as well as for less toxic, easier-to-use first-line medicines combined in a pill that can be taken once a day.

headline: Brooklyn: Deal Offered in Case of Fake Veterinarian
text: A man charged with operating on animals without a license was offered a deal yesterday to avoid prison time by completing a psychiatric program, prosecutors said. The man, Steven Vassall, 29, was accused of botching an operation on a Boston terrier named Burt. Prosecutors deployed a so-called undercover cat, known as Fred Wheezy to his family and Detective Fred to his public. Fred was not harmed in the course of duty, but he later ran into traffic and was killed. Mr. Vassall was offered a deal to plead guilty to felony charges of practicing unlicensed veterinary medicine and scheming to defraud. Under the deal, he must complete a three-year outpatient mental health program and refrain from working with animals or children or in health care, prosecutors said. Mr. Vassall was given until May 22 to decide.

headline: Firefighting Efforts at Georgia Swamp Shift to Fire-Steering
text: RACE POND, Ga., May 8 — Tuesday was a red-flag day in southeast Georgia, meaning that a continuing drought had turned low, scrubby underbrush into the ideal fuel for fires.

headline: House Democrats Push Plan to Finance Iraq War in Stages
text: WASHINGTON, May 8  House Democrats moved quickly Tuesday to try to build support for a two-stage war spending proposal that would provide $30 billion for combat operations in Iraq through midsummer, but require a second round of Congressional votes in July on beginning a troop withdrawal or continuing the war.

headline: Behind the Dow Chemical Firings, a Tangled Corporate Drama
text: On March 23, Andrew N. Liveris, the chief executive of Dow Chemical, wrote a scathing performance review about one of his top lieutenants.

headline: The Wizard Drops the Curtain
text: Omaha

headline: Rights Groups Object to Serbia’s Leading Council of Europe
text: PARIS, May 8 — Human rights groups are objecting to Serbia’s taking over the presidency of a major European political organization this week at a time when Belgrade is in violation of the international Genocide Convention.

headline: 2 Accused of ‘Suspicious’ Trading in Dow Jones Bid
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a complaint today against a Hong Kong couple, accusing them of “highly profitable and highly suspicious” trading of stock of Dow Jones & Company ahead of the announcement last week that the News Corporation had offered $60 a share for the company.

headline: As Pope Heads to Brazil, Abortion Debate Heats Up
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, May 9 — Hours before Pope Benedict XVI arrived here on his first pastoral trip to Latin America, a heated dispute broke out today between the Roman Catholic Church and the Brazilian government about abortion policy.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Active Authority, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., an online community for baby boomers, named the Fort Lauderdale office of Marc USA as its first agency of record. Spending has not been determined.

headline: New York Makes a Strong Showing at the James Beard Awards
text: THE James Beard Foundation’s new regime spiffed up its awards for restaurants, chefs and food books Monday night. Starting at the red carpet entrance, there was little argument that the event at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center had more class than the previous ones in ballrooms at the Marriott Marquis.

headline: Meeting May Lessen Threat of a Sunni Boycott in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, May 8 — The threat of a walkout by Iraq’s leading Sunni bloc in Parliament and the cabinet seemed to subside Tuesday after a meeting between Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a Shiite, and Vice President Tariq al-Hashimi, a Sunni.

headline: Unable to Solve Woes, Nets Are in a Real Fix
text: CLEVELAND, May 8 — This was supposed to be a second-chance game for the Nets. Instead, the replay flashed before their eyes and opportunity fell through their hands.

headline: Learning to Empathize With a Suicide Bomber
text: To study the unsettled emotional weather on the face of Luisa Williams, the intense, dark-eyed star of “Day Night Day Night,” is to be reminded of Norma Desmond’s famous boast, “We had faces then.”

headline: Yahweh ben Yahweh, Leader of Separatist Sect, Dies at 71
text: Yahweh ben Yahweh, who, as the charismatic leader of a religious, black separatist sect in the Miami area was convicted of conspiring to murder white people as an initiation rite, died on Monday night or early yesterday in Miami. He was 71.

headline: Clean Power That Reaps a Whirlwind
Angola: U.S. Advised to Strengthen Ties to Stabilize Oil Supply
text: A report sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations, the nongovernmental, nonpartisan organization with headquarters in New York, said the United States should devote significant resources and diplomatic effort to developing ties with Angola, the second largest oil producer in sub-Saharan Africa after Nigeria, and strategically important for ensuring a steady supply of oil and the stability in the oil-rich Gulf of Guinea region. It noted that Angola had one of the world’s fastest-growing economies but remained one of the world’s least-developed countries. “Cronyism and the labyrinthine bureaucracy that businesses must navigate to turn a profit frighten away all but the most courageous investors,” the report said.

headline: The Latest in Shutters for Storm Protection
text: Andrea Tsakanikas, who owns a property management company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., saw homeowners’ attitudes toward hurricane preparation change dramatically after severely damaging storms hit the state in 2004 and 2005.

headline: After Arrest, HBO Chief Takes Leave of Absence
text: The chairman and chief executive of HBO, Chris Albrecht, announced yesterday that he was taking a leave of absence after being charged with assaulting a girlfriend in a Las Vegas parking lot early on Sunday.

headline: Brazil Greets Pope but Questions His Perspective
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, May 8 — Pope Benedict XVI arrives here Wednesday for his first foray into Latin America, hoping to stanch the church’s steady loss of followers in the region. But some of the faithful frankly wonder whether an 80-year-old pontiff from Germany can speak to their needs.

headline: Former Credit Suisse Banker to Be Freed on $1 Million Bail
text: A former Credit Suisse banker charged with masterminding a $7.5 million insider trading ring will be released on $1 million bail today, after a federal magistrate judge questioned the strength of the government’s case.

headline: Senate Approves New Power for F.D.A. on Drugs
text: WASHINGTON, May 9 — By a vote of 93 to 1, the Senate passed a bill this afternoon that gives the Food and Drug Administration sweeping new power to police drug safety, order changes in drug labels, regulate advertising and restrict the use and distribution of medicines found to pose serious risks to consumers.

headline: Telling Dieters a Pill Works Only if They Work, Too
text: FOR decades, the beauty industry was described as — or accused of — selling “hope in a jar.” Now, a marketing blitz with a budget estimated at more than $150 million in the first year will try to persuade dieters to seek hope in a pill bottle despite widespread skepticism about the grandiose promises of diet pills, plans and potions.

headline: Tennessee, After Review, Sets Execution
text: NASHVILLE, May 8  Philip R. Workman’s execution date has come and gone five times in the quarter-century since his conviction for shooting a Memphis police officer. On Tuesday, he awaited his death once again at the Riverbend prison on the industrial outskirts of this city.

headline: Bleak Reality on Film (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Longtime Partner at Hollinger Testifies He and Black Conspired to Divert Millions
text: CHICAGO, May 8  Conrad M. Black’s longtime business partner, F. David Radler, testified Tuesday at Mr. Black’s criminal fraud trial that the two men conspired to divert millions of dollars of payments for assets of the newspaper company Hollinger International.

headline: Where the Homework Is a Pleasure
text: WITH wine, as with so many wonderful things in life, you can never know it all.

headline: Congregations to Give Haven to Immigrants
text: Recalling a movement that challenged United States policy in Central America in the 1980s, several religious congregations in New York and other cities will announce a campaign Wednesday to provide sanctuary to illegal immigrants who face deportation.

headline: A Lavish Home in San Miguel de Allende
text: When Martha and Elton Hyder of Fort Worth began building a vacation home in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, in 1959, people there still got their water from an ancient spring, and telephones were scarce.

headline: In a Diary, Attacker Brags About a ‘Buffet of Crime’
text: A former Women’s Wear Daily writer accused of holding a former colleague captive and sexually tormenting her for 13 hours wrote a personal manifesto and mused in a diary about why New Yorkers were so captivated by the crime, according to testimony at his trial yesterday.

headline: Shots in a Village Court Raise Security Issues in the Statewide System
text: SLOATSBURG, N.Y., May 8  Shots fired in a tiny village court on Monday evening certainly caught the attention of people in this unassuming semirural community in Rockland County. But the reverberations have spread farther, underscoring the vulnerability of the 1,250 village and town courts across New York at a time when the state has just begun to address their security needs.

headline: Court Rules for Grasso in Pay Case
text: Finally, some good news for Richard A. Grasso.

headline: In the Rush to Progress, the Past Is Never Too Far Behind
text: An elegy whispers beneath the energy that animates “Radio Golf,” the last play by August Wilson. The production that opened last night at the Cort Theater, directed by Kenny Leon, has the crackle of a bustling comedy crossed with an old-fashioned melodrama, in which scenes end with surprise revelations or personal declarations of war.

headline: A Life Made Out of Wood, Metal and Determination
text: Consider the dark-horse career of Louise Nevelson as an antidote to the youth-obsessed art world. Born in Russia, she was 42 before she had her first solo show, and her big break came at 60, when her monochrome found-wood constructions were included in “Sixteen Americans” at the Museum of Modern Art in 1959. That show was also a launching pad for Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly, Robert Rauschenberg and Frank Stella — all younger than Nevelson’s son.

headline: A Chef With Swagger Can Nurture, Too
text: HE’S a showboat, that’s for sure. You don’t sign up for three seasons of the reality TV show “Top Chef” unless you relish the glow of the spotlight. And on some points he’s dogmatic. You don’t insist on roasting your steaks when everybody else is grilling or broiling theirs unless you’re convinced you’ve found the one true path.

headline: Share Prices in China Hit Record High
text: SHANGHAI, May 9 — After another feverish day of buying in this country’s amazing bull run, share prices in China broke records again today, sending the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index past the 4,000-point milestone for the first time.

headline: Lightning Cited in Sago Mine Report
text: BUCKHANNON, W. Va., May 9 — The spark that set off the Sago Mine explosion that trapped 13 miners in West Virginia last year, killing all but one of them, was most likely caused by a lightning bolt that shot through a cable connected to a pump cable inside a sealed section of the mine, a report by the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration has concluded.

headline: Chinese Company Linked to Deaths Wasn’t Licensed
text: BEIJING, May 8 — China’s drug regulation agency has confirmed that the company linked to counterfeit medicine that caused at least 100 deaths in Panama was not licensed to be engaged in the pharmaceutical business, the Foreign Ministry said Tuesday.

headline: Another Chemical Emerges in Pet Food Case
text: SHANGHAI, May 8 — A second industrial chemical that American regulators have identified as a pet food contaminant may have been intentionally added to animal feed by producers seeking larger profits, according to interviews Tuesday with chemical industry officials.

headline: District of Columbia Set Back in Fight Over Its Gun Law
text: A federal appeals court in Washington refused yesterday to revisit a March decision striking down parts of a gun control law there. The development brought the case one step closer to possible Supreme Court consideration of the Second Amendment’s meaning.

headline: The G.O.P., Abortion and 2008
text: It is one of the enduring features of the modern Republican Party: Since the rise of Ronald Reagan and the empowerment of the social conservatives, the party has formally stood in firm opposition to the constitutional right to abortion and the Supreme Court decision that established it.

headline: Wrestling Nuclear Genies Back Into the Bottle, or at Least a Can
text: It has been more than three weeks since North Korea missed the deadline to shut down its nuclear reactor at Yongbyon, but we’ve heard only mild protests from the White House. President Bush, who once declared that he loathed North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-il, isn’t eager for another fight these days. Still, the North Koreans have a way of making even patient people apoplectic.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about a White House inquiry into possible misconduct by Stuart W. Bowen Jr., a federal official whose investigations of fraud and waste in Iraq reconstruction work have embarrassed the Bush administration, misstated the name of the office that is conducting the inquiry. It is the President’s Council on Integrity and Efficiency, not the President’s Council on Integrity and Excellence. (Go to Article)

headline: New ‘Law & Order’ Episodes May Move to TNT From NBC
text: The future of the long-running drama “Law & Order” may not be on NBC.

headline: The Yankees Hit Away, and Mientkiewicz Is Happy to Help
text: Doug Mientkiewicz spoke at length about his hitting before the Yankees played the Texas Rangers last night. Mientkiewicz, the Yankees’ first baseman, explained the nuances of his swing, his mind-set and his health. Then he simplified it.

headline: Los Angeles Mayor Says Wildfire Is Under Control
text: LOS ANGELES, May 9 — A stubborn brush fire burned nearly a fifth of Griffith Park, among the largest municipal parks in the country before firefighters brought the blaze under control today.

headline: Cultural Collisions in the Slow Lane to Modernity
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Mansour al-Atayan sat at a table in one of the Starbucks that are as ubiquitous here as they are in Manhattan and explained how unhappy he was with the social changes occurring in his country. He said he thought that it would be better if women were not allowed to work in his office at all.

headline: Hot, Hotter, Hottest: Fire From France
text: AMONG all the comestibles a person could lug home from a trip to France — handmade Alsatian quince jam and fancy Provençal lavender honey; walnut oil, freshly pressed by a tiny producer in the Midi; or, say, a big bag of brown-edged butter cookies from Poilâne — my friend Alice always makes room for a few jars of cheap mustard from the supermarket.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: New York Critics’ Circle Names Its Favorites

headline: Going to War Wasn’t the Answer (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush. Clinton. Bush. Clinton? (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Lazard Posts Higher Profit, but Misses Estimates
text: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit increased 5 percent from the quarter a year ago, helped by gains in its asset management business.

headline: Staten Island: Men Sentenced in Deaths of Officers
text: Two men were sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to 15 years to life in prison for their roles in the murders of two undercover police detectives in 2003. The men, Mitchell Diaz, 22, and Jessie Jacobus, 21, members of a robbery ring prosecutors called the Stapleton Crew, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder charges within days of the killings. Both testified at the trial of Ronell Wilson, who was convicted on federal capital murder charges and sentenced to death for shooting the detectives, Rodney J. Andrews and James V. Nemorin. Mr. Diaz confessed to providing the gun, and Mr. Jacobus confessed to accompanying Mr. Wilson to rob the detectives.

headline: Sosa and Palmeiro Cited in Steroid Investigation
text: Investigators of steroid use in baseball are seeking medical records from at least two of the game’s premier sluggers over the past dozen years, Sammy Sosa and Rafael Palmeiro, along with records from dozens of other players suspected of using performance-enhancing drugs, a baseball official with direct knowledge of the request said.

headline: After Years in Wait, a Lab Is Born
text: Five years after a similar project was announced but never built, ground has finally been broken on a $145 million biomedical laboratory for research on cancer and other diseases at Landmark at Eastview, an office park straddling the towns of Greenburgh and Mount Pleasant in Westchester County, N.Y.

headline: Brooklyn: Woman’s Defense in Baby’s Death
text: A woman accused of killing her newborn daughter was unaware of her pregnancy and has no memory of giving birth, her lawyer said in State Supreme Court yesterday. The woman, Laura Sergio, 25, has been charged with second-degree murder. The police found the baby, who was said to have died of hypothermia and asphyxiation, on the back porch of the family home in Bay Ridge on April 7. In an interview, a lawyer for Ms. Sergio, Thomas Cascione, described the case as “a classic neonaticide,” a term used to describe the killing of a baby by the mother within 24 hours of birth. In such cases, the mother is generally in denial of her pregnancy. Ms. Sergio was ordered held without bail.

headline: The Bicycle in New York, From an Artistic Viewpoint
text: To look at nearly any bicycle — from graceful racers with inch-thick tires to the clunky, rusted workhorses of food delivery fleets — is to behold a union of form and function that has existed for nearly two centuries. Bicycles, after all, have been transporting people at least since 1817, when Baron Karl von Drais invented a contraption in Germany that operated without pedals and required riders to push against the ground with their feet to propel themselves.

headline: About-Face as Nash Helps Suns Knot Series
text: PHOENIX, May 8  Steve Nash did not need to wear 20 gauze pads, 10 Band-Aids and a box full of steri-strips just to make a point.

headline: Manhattan: Mayor Opposes Limits on Gun Trace Data
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg released a letter yesterday urging Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to reconsider limits on the use of gun trace data compiled by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The limits bar the bureau from releasing gun-trace data except to police officials and prosecutors working on a particular crime. The mayor sent a copy of the letter to members of Congress. He wrote that although the chief argument supporting the limits concerns protecting the anonymity of undercover officers, no one “has been able to identify a single instance when trace data compromised the anonymity of an officer or the integrity of an investigation.” Erik Ablin, a Justice Department spokesman, said the limits were in keeping with the bureau’s “longstanding policy of disclosing firearms trace results only to the law enforcement agency that recovered the crime gun.”

headline: Prim but Satisfying, Venerable Sweets From Milan
text: Chocolates for Mother’s Day can come in an elegant navy blue silk faille box, like this assortment from Cova, a chocolatier in Milan that has been in business since 1817, first next to La Scala opera house, and since 1950 on the chic Via Montenapoleone.

headline: Mets Getting Their Heads Together
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 — As his teammates shuffled into the clubhouse bathroom, Shawn Green sat in front of his locker running his fingers through his hair for the final time. After much prodding and teasing, Green surrendered to the peer pressure and let Carlos Beltrán, the Mets’ center fielder/resident barber, pare his brown locks into a crew cut.

headline: Love, Honor, Cherish and Buy
text: Gazing upon the Custom Liquid booth at the Great Bridal Expo, where the half-liter water bottles picture a bride and a groom on the label ($48 a case, plus shipping), Rebecca Mead announced, “This is a new one on me.”

headline: Kansas Tornado Renews Debate on Guard at War
text: CHICAGO, May 8 — For months, Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas and other governors have warned that their state National Guards are ill-prepared for the next local disaster, be it a tornado, a flash flood or a terrorist’s threat, because of large deployments of their soldiers and equipment in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Scrutiny Seen of Trading in Dow Jones
text: Federal regulators are expected to examine the role of a Dow Jones director in the possible leak of inside information to a Hong Kong couple, who were accused yesterday of making millions of dollars from trading shortly before news of Rupert Murdoch’s takeover offer.

headline: Tennessee Carries Out First Execution Since Lethal Injection Review
text: NASHVILLE, May 9 — Philip R. Workman's execution date has come and gone five times in the quarter-century since his conviction for shooting a Memphis police officer. Early Wednesday, he was finally executed at the Riverbend prison on the industrial outskirts of this city.

headline: In a Quiet Part of Florida, a Bid to Bring in the Crowds
text: PANAMA CITY, Fla. — This corner of the Florida Panhandle already has an airport, but it is sleepy, with a runway too short for the heavy jets that bring well-heeled crowds. Tourists come for the quartz-sand beaches, but most make the trip by car from Alabama, Georgia and Tennessee.

headline: The Five-Second Rule Explored, or How Dirty Is That Bologna?
text: A COUPLE of weeks ago I saw a new scientific paper from Clemson University that struck me as both pioneering and hilarious.

headline: Fidelity Units Settle Complaints Over Military Fund Sales
text: Two Fidelity brokerage units have agreed to pay $400,000 in fines to settle regulatory complaints accusing them of producing misleading sales materials for two archaic Fidelity mutual funds that were sold almost exclusively to military consumers.

headline: Official Takes Case to U.S., but Skeptics Don’t Budge
text: WASHINGTON, May 8 — Mowaffak al-Rubaie, the national security adviser to Iraq’s prime minister, undertook on Tuesday what may have been his most challenging mission yet: trying to persuade American lawmakers who have all but run out of patience that still more patience is required.

headline: Ending Speculation, Gov. Spitzer Says He’ll Back Clinton for President
text: ALBANY, May 8 — After sitting on the fence for months, Gov. Eliot Spitzer said on Tuesday that he had decided to endorse Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, his fellow New York Democrat, for president.

headline: When Tranquillity Trumps Equality
text: The libbers for lob equality once risked their wood Wilsons so prize purses for women would mean more than a nice clutch bag, so gender equity would include the right to a shared pot.

headline: Senators Reach Outline on Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, May 8 — Key senators said Tuesday that they had agreed on the outlines of a bipartisan bill that would toughen border enforcement and provide a path to legal status for illegal immigrants.

headline: Food Calendar
text: Wine in Brooklyn

headline: Officer Says Civilian Toll in Haditha Was a Shock
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 8 — The only Marine Corps officer who was in Haditha, Iraq, when American troops killed 19 civilians in their homes in 2005 testified at a military hearing on Tuesday that he was “shocked” to find only unarmed people, including women and children, among the dead. But he said the marines had not violated any law of war.

headline: Working in the Sewers Is a Dirty Job, but Someone’s Got to Win
text: A sewer is a slippery workplace. Water can move at the speed of oncoming traffic, even when it is not laden with tree branches, two-by-fours and the waste products known in the business as “turtles.” A single footstep in the water can stir up enough gas to knock a man unconscious. And then there is the smell.

headline: Prominent Iranian-American Academic Is Jailed in Tehran
text: Haleh Esfandiari, an Iranian-American academic who is prominent in Washington, was imprisoned yesterday in the Iranian capital of Tehran after being barred from leaving the country four months ago, said the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars.

headline: Burress Shows Up at Camp; Shockey Stays Away
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 8  A spring ritual for the Giants is trying to lure receiver Plaxico Burress and tight end Jeremy Shockey from Florida to Giants Stadium for workouts that are officially voluntary but viewed as nearly mandatory.

headline: Canada: Quebec Separatist Leader Quits Party After Election Loss
text: André Boisclair, left, the leader of the separatist Parti Québécois, resigned, further destabilizing an independence movement that was left in shambles after a third-place finish in provincial elections in March. “The current conditions don’t allow me to do this anymore,” he said. The party was poised to have a strong showing in the elections, with some even predicting a win for the separatists, who want Quebec to be a nation. But instead they had their worst showing in decades. When he was elected party leader in November 2005, Mr. Boisclair, 41, made headlines for being openly gay and for admitting to having used cocaine while a cabinet minister. His relative youth also marked a departure from previous sovereignty leaders, most of whom traced their roots to the party’s founding in the late 1960s. He fought back tears as he announced his resignation, ending it with a familiar rallying cry among separatists: “Vive le Quebec!”

headline: Councilman Seeks a Top Job in Brooklyn
text: City Councilman Charles Barron said yesterday that he would run for Brooklyn borough president in 2009 and would not challenge Representative Edolphus Towns next year for his Congressional seat, as had been widely expected.

headline: Clumsy Tools to Aid a Family After the Death of a Son
text: In one of the most virtuosic monologues of the theater season, Christina Kirk, the rangy grande dame of the downtown stage, encapsulates an entire marriage in a series of declarative statements and hackneyed phrases. The poetic high point of Jenny Schwartz’s “God’s Ear,” a formally inventive and superbly performed drama about how the death of a son shatters a family, this ode to love, loss and the routines of life has the economy and dry wit of a Sondheim love song.

headline: Queens: Ferry to Rockaways
text: New York City hopes to expand private ferry service from Manhattan to the Rockaways in Queens as a way to relieve traffic congestion and provide quicker commuting for residents in one of the most remote areas of the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The city’s Economic Development Corporation will ask private ferry operators to propose service for one or more routes that would, at a minimum, run weekdays during peak commuting hours. Operators will have about six weeks to submit responses. The price for the service will depend on the proposals, but officials said they hoped it would cost about the same as express bus service, about $4 each way.

headline: Pupil Needs Shape Budget for Schools in New York
text: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein released next year’s budgets for New York City’s more than 1,400 public schools yesterday, using a new financing system that will drive far more money to schools serving low-achieving students, children from low-income families and those who speak limited English.

headline: Classic Book About America’s Indians Gains a Few Flourishes as a Film
text: LOS ANGELES, May 8 — When the historian Dee Brown published “Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee” in 1971, it became an instant sensation. In an age of rebellion, this nonfiction book told the epic tale of the displacement and decline of the American Indian not from the perspective of the winners, but from that of the Indians.

headline: A Cruise, and in Turn, Perhaps a Loan?
text: Oh, to be a university financial aid administrator on the loose in Manhattan.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To Love a Martini

headline: A Man, a Woman and a Day of Terror
text: No writer has been as prescient and eerily prophetic about 21st-century America as Don DeLillo. His novels, from “Players” and “White Noise” through “Libra” and “Mao II” and the remarkable “Underworld,” not only limned the surreal weirdness of the waning years of the 20th century, but somehow also managed to anticipate the shock and horror of 9/11 and its darkly unspooling aftermath.

headline: Ethics Panel Clears Corzine in Labor Talks
text: TRENTON, May 8 — There was no conflict of interest in Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s conduct during labor negotiations with a union led by a woman with whom he once had a romantic and financial relationship, an ethics panel reported on Tuesday.

headline: Marks Mysterious and Foundlings Sad: O, Tangled Web!
text: Guy Maddin’s “Brand Upon the Brain!” takes place in an orphanage where tiny tots earn their keep by the sweat of their brows and adults exact a savage price on their tender souls. A baroque entertainment with one foot in silent cinema and the other gingerly toeing the sound waves, the film centers on a man who, in visiting the now-emptied foundling home, journeys deep into his childhood. There, amid secrets and lies, open wounds and monstrous parental narcissism, he discovers what made him tick and why, and how between his mother’s terrifying love and his father’s sadism he learned all the cruel tricks of desire.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Says Quarterly Results Will Top Forecast
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 — Hewlett-Packard said Tuesday that its earnings for the quarter just ended would be higher than previously forecast, largely because of strong worldwide sales of personal computers. The announcement pushed the company’s stock to its highest point in more than six years.

headline: A No-Frills Kitchen Still Cooks
text: THE question I’m asked more often than any other is, “What kitchen equipment should I buy?”

headline: Negotiating a Shadow World, With Bumps
text: The tight-lipped protagonist of Christoffer Boe’s film “Allegro” is a familiar type found in Scandinavian movies: an Olympian talent — in this case a concert pianist named Zetterstrom (Ulrich Thomsen) — cut off from his own emotions in his drive for perfection.

headline: Glavine Wins His 294th, but the Buzz Is About the Hair
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 — Tom Glavine arrived at AT&T Park on Tuesday afternoon to find that the Mets’ clubhouse had turned into a barbershop. As he walked toward his locker, he glanced around and saw a bald Mike Pelfrey, a buzzed Joe Smith and a flat-topped David Wright, and then peered into the bathroom to see Carlos Beltrán wielding an electric razor.

headline: Mets’ Wright Begins to Show Frustration Over His Slump
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8  It was just David Wright’s luck. In his first three at-bats Monday night, he broke his bat against Barry Zito, whose fastball hardly resembles Mariano Rivera’s vaunted cutter. After selecting a new bat for the third time, in the sixth inning, Wright missed a good pitch to hit and lofted a fly ball to left.

headline: Disney Profit Up on ‘Wild Hogs’
text: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that its quarterly profit rose 27 percent on the surprise hit movie “Wild Hogs” and higher advertising rates at ABC television.

headline: Agency Affirms Mandates for Driver’s Licenses
text: WASHINGTON, May 8  The Homeland Security Department said Tuesday that it would plow ahead with national standards for driver’s licenses, despite a highly unusual level of activity by state legislatures opposed to the idea, and substantial second thoughts in Congress.

headline: Federal Student Loan Official Is Resigning
text: Under criticism that it has been lax in policing the $85 billion student loan industry, the Education Department announced yesterday that the chief official responsible for overseeing the loan program was stepping down.

headline: Creating a Fable for Our Times, Based on Very Thin Evidence
text: In a world dominated by machines and awash in paper, it is little wonder that a discarded, computer-printed bar receipt could end up being one man’s ticket to bedlam. That, at any rate, is the premise behind “The Receipt,” a clever and funny show concocted by Will Adamsdale and Chris Branch and being presented at 59E59 Theaters as part of the Brits Off Broadway festival.

headline: 4 Arrested in 2005 London Transit Bombings
text: LONDON, May 9 — British police today arrested three men and the widow of a suicide bomber involved in the terror attack on the London transit system in 2005 on suspicion they helped in the atrocity that killed 52 people.

headline: Norway: Police Hold Suspect in Bosnia War Crimes
text: The police arrested a 40-year-old native of Bosnia, now a Norwegian citizen, on suspicion of committing war crimes against Bosnian Serbs while serving in an ethnically Croatian military unit in 1992. The man, who in keeping with Norwegian police practice was not identified, faces up to 21 years in a Norway prison if convicted on charges of assault, rape and illegal detention at a prison camp during the wars over the former Yugoslavia. The police have said they are investigating 70 immigrants to Norway who are suspected of war crimes in a number of countries. The arrested man arrived in Norway with his family in 1993 and received citizenship in 2001.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A theater review on Thursday about “Coram Boy,” at the Imperial Theater, misstated the definition of the term Coram boy. It refers to a child abandoned by his parents, not an orphan. (It is derived from the name of Thomas Coram, who in the 18th century established the Foundling Hospital to care for abandoned children in London.)

headline: Cheney Presses Iraqi Leaders to Act Decisively
text: BAGHDAD, May 9 — After a day of talks here with Iraq’s fractious political leaders, Vice President Dick Cheney said Wednesday that he detected “a greater sense of urgency” among them in tackling a list of divisive issues that the Bush administration sees as the key to any sustained progress against the country’s insurgent and militia groups.

headline: U.S. Pays and Apologizes to Kin of Afghans Killed by Marines
text: WASHINGTON, May 8 — An Army commander apologized and paid compensation on Tuesday to families of Afghan civilians killed by marines after a suicide attack in March, in the first formal acknowledgment by the American authorities that the killings were unjustified.

headline: Practice in the Poconos: U.S. Details How Men Prepared
text: It was a terror plot that hinged, in no small part, upon a map snatched from a New Jersey pizzeria. The plotters honed their shooting skills on semiautomatics at the firing range, though they also spent time conducting what the authorities called “tactical training” by playing paintball in the woods.

headline: Pentagon Tells 35,000 Troops They May Be Deployed to Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, May 8 — The Pentagon said Tuesday that it had informed an additional 35,000 soldiers that they were likely to be heading to Iraq by December, a move that would allow the Army to maintain heightened American troop levels into next year.

headline: Fine Season Leaves Rangers Wanting to Stay Rangers
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., May 8  Two days after they were ousted from a promising playoff run, the Rangers had their traditional breakup day, but it did not include much talk of breaking up.

headline: Putin Cites Third Reich in Veiled Criticism of U.S.
text: MOSCOW, May 9 — President Vladimir V. Putin obliquely compared the foreign policy of the United States to the Third Reich in a speech on Wednesday commemorating the 62nd anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany, apparently in an escalation of anti-American talk within the Russian government.

headline: A Trashy Tupperware Lady With a Man’s Touch
text: Meet Dixie Longate. She’s so excited to be here tonight, she could just throw up blood! But Miss Dixie Longate, queen bee of the one-woman show “Dixie’s Tupperware Party,” has bigger things on her mind, like selling the audience some of her plastic junk: the kiwi- green and tangerine-orange and mixed-berry plastic ware that decorates the stage at Ars Nova, a tiny Off Broadway theater.

headline: Doctors Reap Millions for Anemia Drugs
text: Two of the world’s largest drug companies are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to doctors every year in return for giving their patients anemia medicines, which regulators now say may be unsafe at commonly used doses.

headline: National Study Gives Gateway Park Low Marks
text: Gateway National Recreation Area, the sprawling waterfront park that stretches from Jamaica Bay to Sandy Hook in New Jersey and is home to several threatened species, is in the worst condition of any national park surveyed by an advocacy group, according to a report to be released today.

headline: Author and Surfer to Share in Proceeds of Waves Book
text: For writers of narrative nonfiction, one of the biggest challenges is getting access to sources and events that they might not otherwise see.

headline: 6 Men Arrested in a Terror Plot Against Fort Dix
text: CAMDEN, N.J., May 8 —Six Muslim men from New Jersey and Philadelphia were charged Tuesday with plotting to attack Fort Dix with automatic weapons and possibly even rocket-propelled grenades, vowing in taped conversations “to kill as many soldiers as possible,” federal authorities said.

headline: The Democrats’ Pledge
text: Last year, Congressional Democrats allowed the Bush administration to ram through one of the worst laws in the nation’s history  the Military Commissions Act of 2006. This year, the Democrats pledged to use their new majority to begin repairing the profound damage the law has done to the nation’s justice system and global image.

headline: Cisco Systems Says Quarterly Earnings Soared 34%
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8 — Cisco Systems, the network equipment maker, reported a 34 percent gain in quarterly profit on Tuesday that it attributed to strong demand for high-speed networking, particularly in international markets.

headline: Prenatal Test Puts Down Syndrome in Hard Focus
text: DETROIT — Sarah Itoh, a self-described “almost-eleven-and-a-half,” betrayed no trace of nervousness as she told a roomful of genetic counselors and obstetricians about herself one recent afternoon.

headline: The Arab Commission
text: Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, made a remarkable statement last week. He praised Israel for conducting an inquiry into last year’s war with Hezbollah — an inquiry that accused Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of “serious failure in exercising judgment, responsibility and prudence.”

headline: Archaeologist Says Remnants of King Herod’s Tomb Are Found
text: JERUSALEM, May 8 — After a long quest in search of King Herod’s tomb, an archaeologist announced Tuesday that he had found what appear to be the ornate remnants of the Roman-era king’s burial site on the edge of the Judean Desert.

headline: Science Fiction Sneaks Up
text: Make your own spatula or SpongeBob key ring. That is the promise of the 3-D printers that may soon be gracing your kitchen or family room.

headline: Josephine Baker Unfit for the Mail? (It Wasn’t Even a French Postcard)
text: On the endless march toward liberty and justice for all, a new cause has joined the parade: postcards featuring the breasts — clad, unclad, and pretty much clad — of Josephine Baker, famous long ago and dead these many years.

headline: Jurors Seated in Terror Trial of Padilla and 2 Others
text: MIAMI, May 8  A jury was seated Tuesday for the trial of Jose Padilla, the American who was initially designated an enemy combatant but was then moved to the criminal justice system to face terrorism conspiracy charges with two co-defendants.

headline: Get Off the Chaise Longue
text: Paris

headline: War Shrine Gift by Japan Leader Prompts Concern
text: TOKYO, Wednesday, May 9  China and South Korea made subdued expressions of concern on Tuesday after disclosures that Japan’s prime minister had presented an offering to a Tokyo war shrine, as officials in Tokyo tried to play down the gift’s significance.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) STAGE DOOR (1937) Turner Classic Movies continues its salute to Katharine Hepburn on the centennial of her birth with four of her best-known films, starting with the Academy Award-nominated “Stage Door” (1937), about a society beauty with Broadway dreams who moves into a boardinghouse full of actresses, played by Ginger Rogers, Lucille Ball, Eve Arden and Ann Miller, then largely unknown. Starting at 10, Hepburn joins forces with Cary Grant in three classic comedies: “Bringing Up Baby” (1938), above, about a scatterbrain who uses her pet leopard to catch the attention of a starchy paleontologist; “Holiday” (1938), in which a freethinker engaged to a millionaire’s daughter decides that her sister just might be a better match, at 1:15 a.m.; and “The Philadelphia Story” (1940), about an ice princess socialite on the verge of remarrying who is forced to rethink everything, at 3. At midnight there’s Hepburn’s first television interview, on “The Dick Cavett Show,” from 1973.

headline: A Master of Song, Operating at Full Power
text: If there is one quality that distinguishes Matthias Goerne’s singing — apart from the rich, large sound of his baritone — it is his ability both to create and to inhabit the emotional world a song describes. In his recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, Mr. Goerne worked his magic quickly: within a bar or two, he sounded fully at home in a song, and he maintained an interpretive suppleness that kept his expressive moves fresh and unpredictable.

headline: English Language Learners as Pawns in the School System’s Overhaul
text: Let’s call this the mystery of the missing ELLs. An ELL, you need to know, is the abbreviation for English Language Learner. These students, immigrants or their children, are legally entitled to special classes intended to make them fluent readers, writers and speakers of their new language.

headline: To Regain His Thump, Abreu Is Bumped to 7th
text: Nearly every time he is asked about Bobby Abreu, Joe Torre calls him the perfect No. 3 hitter in the Yankees’ lineup. Abreu is among the most patient hitters in baseball, forcing pitchers to throw strikes and allowing teammates to see many pitches.

headline: Opposition Splits While Zimbabwe Slips
text: JOHANNESBURG, May 8 — The last couple of years have been exceedingly tough for the Movement for Democratic Change, the only opposition political party of any note in authoritarian Zimbabwe. Party officials have been beaten with stones and logs; their cars have been hijacked; their posters have been methodically stripped from street poles. In one memorable instance, thugs tried to toss the party’s director of security down a sixth-floor stairwell at its headquarters.

headline: Get a Dog From a Shelter (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Driven by International Bidders, Prices Soar at Sotheby’s Sale With No Blockbuster
text: “It’s a new world,” said Tobias Meyer, the auctioneer conducting Sotheby’s sale of Impressionist and modern art last night, as his hammer pounded the rostrum like a loud exclamation mark. After an intense war between two telephone bidders, a canvas by the Expressionist painter Lyonel Feininger had just sold for $23.2 million, more than two and a half times its high estimate and a record for the artist at auction.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Confronting Questions of Faith With a Few New Responses
