text: People of faith are often treated as either jokes or villains in the downtown theater scene, but that may be starting to change. Les Freres Corbusier was evenhanded in “Hell House,” and the Civilians, a company not known for being dogmatic, is working on a new docudrama about evangelicals.

headline: Two Former Enemies Are Sworn in to Lead Northern Ireland’s Government
text: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 8 — Paying tribute to the thousands of victims in one of Europe’s bloodiest sectarian conflicts, the leaders of Northern Ireland on Tuesday drew a formal line under decades of hostility and strife, re-establishing a power-sharing local authority of once implacable foes.

headline: Thomson Confirms Offer for Reuters
text: OTTAWA, May 8 — Thomson, the Canadian electronic information company, said today that it was offering $17.5 billion in cash and shares for the Reuters Group, the financial and general news service.

headline: In Los Angeles, the Accidental Pizza Maker
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Positions Available: $12,900 to Start, Advancement Possible
text: The Major League Soccer players union released salary information last week that showed that the league’s more than 90 developmental players each earn less $20,000. That stands in stark contrast to the salaries of the league’s marquee players, some of whom make 50 times that or more.

headline: Diego Corrales, Fighter and Victim of Motorcycle Crash, Dies at 29
text: Diego Corrales, who once held four world boxing championships and was remembered most for a pair of brutal lightweight bouts two years ago, died Monday night in a motorcycle accident on the outskirts of Las Vegas. He was 29.

headline: Saving, Not Victimizing, Children
text: Sexually exploited children can be helped by the law or victimized by it, depending on where they are from. An Eastern European child smuggled into this country as a sex slave is offered protection under the federal Trafficking Victims Protection Act. An American child who flees abusive parents and ends up selling her body on the streets is labeled a criminal and sent to the juvenile equivalent of prison.

headline: Combined Thomson-Reuters Would Challenge Bloomberg
text: OTTAWA, May 8 — Thomson, the Canadian electronic information company, on Tuesday sketched out the broad details of its $17.5 billion offer for the Reuters Group, the financial and general news service.

headline: Telling Bogus From True: A Class in Reading News
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — It was early in the morning, but the class was lively. Perhaps it had something to do with the news article the professor had just handed out for the students to read.

headline: Glimmers of a Turnaround in Springfield, Mass.
text: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. — Late last century, this once-thriving New England city, like many of its neighbors, fell victim to a causal chain of events — mills closed, jobs disappeared, crime rose and residents left.

headline: Moving Day for the Devils, in More Ways Than One
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 8  As a woman mopped the aisles and as the ice at both ends began to melt, the Devils posed for their last team photograph Tuesday at empty, forlorn Continental Arena. Even Lou Lamoriello sounded wistful.

headline: Maryland Is First State to Require Living Wage
text: Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland signed the nation’s first statewide living wage bill yesterday, giving fresh momentum to a movement that seeks to raise wages through legislation.

headline: Lesotho: 39 Die in Bus Crash
text: At least 39 people died late Monday when a bus carrying 103 textile workers collided with a tractor-trailer truck in northern Lesotho, a police spokesman said. The accident occurred while the bus, traveling between Maputsoe, a garment-making center on the South Africa border, and Fobane, a village about 15 miles south, was on a winding road. One or both vehicles may have been speeding, the police said.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.6 Million
text: Keswick, Va.

headline: Germany Conduct Raids Ahead of G-8 Summit
text: FRANKFURT, May 9 — Four weeks before leaders of the world’s big industrial nations are to gather at a Baltic Sea resort in northern Germany, the police conducted sweeping raids on Wednesday on the offices and homes of left-wing campaigners whom they suspected of planning to disrupt the meeting.

headline: Corrections
text: A list of gins with an article last Wednesday about the best gins for martinis misstated the strength of the alcohol in Junipero, made by Anchor Distilling. It is 98.6 proof, not 86.

headline: Doctors Getting Paid to Prescribe Drugs
text: Two of the world’s largest drug companies are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to doctors every year in return for giving their patients anemia medicines, which regulators now say may be unsafe at commonly used doses.

headline: No More Freedom Fries?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Cape Town With Kids
text: Cape Town's beaches, parks and gardens are a perfect playground for children and families.

headline: Brazilians Focusing on Pope’s Arrival
text: It is always remarked that Latin America is the most Roman Catholic part of the world, with nearly half the world's one billion Catholics living in the region. But in the same way that Indonesians are said to follow a more relaxed version of Islam than their brethren in the Arab world, Catholicism in Latin America is often more informal than that practiced elsewhere: many Latin Americans who describe themselves as Catholics either don't attend mass, or, as is often the case here in Brazil, mix Catholicism with African or Indian rites.

headline: Personal Shopper
text: The modern slipper chair, as distinctive as ever.

headline: London lures Purple Prince
text: Pop star Prince has confirmed that he’ll be looking this summer for a house to buy in London, where he will kick off a 21-concert tour on Aug. 1st.

headline: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Racing Shoes
text: Purists don’t dare race in trail running shoes. Enter trail racing shoes with stickier, firmer soles and less weight than everyday trail running shoes.

headline: Fine Points | No Hands
text: The fanny pack: it's not just for Michelin guides.

headline: Currents
text: Dressing rooms in the Hamptons, reimagining cardboard, far outside the box, rare rugs and more.

headline: Tyco Reports Lower Earnings Ahead of Break-Up
text: Tyco International, which plans to split into three companies in coming weeks, reported lower quarterly earnings Tuesday as revamping costs reduced earnings but a low tax rate helped results beat Wall Street expectations.

headline: Warner’s Loss Widens Amid Fading Deal Hopes
text: The Warner Music Group posted a wider quarterly loss Tuesday and said it would cut about 400 jobs as it shifts resources to increase digital distribution of music and video. The announcement comes as Warner’s hopes for a deal with its British rival, the EMI Group, are fading in the face of private equity bids for EMI.

headline: Gates Discusses Software, but Talk of a Yahoo Deal Persists
text: Bill Gates, Microsoft‘s chairman, spoke to hundreds of marketers and advertising agencies in Seattle on Tuesday amid rumblings about his company’s struggle to compete against Google in online advertising and about its efforts to court Yahoo for some sort of partnership.

headline: Fidelity Units Settle Complaints Over Military Fund Sales
text: Two Fidelity brokerage units have agreed to pay $400,000 in fines to settle regulatory complaints accusing them of producing misleading sales materials for two archaic Fidelity mutual funds that were sold almost exclusively to military consumers.

headline: Longtime Hollinger Partner Says He Diverted Millions
text: Conrad M. Black’s longtime business partner, F. David Radler, testified Tuesday at Mr. Black’s criminal fraud trial that the two men conspired to divert millions of dollars of payments for assets of the newspaper company Hollinger International.

headline: BNP Paribas Reports 25% Jump in 1st-Quarter Profit
text: BNP Paribas, the French bank, reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter profit on higher corporate and investment bank earnings and gains from asset sales. The shares rose to a record.

headline: Hedge Fund Targets Movie Gallery
text: An activist hedge fund, Schultze Asset Management, vowed Tuesday to press Movie Gallery to take steps to increase shareholder value.

headline: KBW Chief Casts Skeptical Eye on Private Equity
text: The chief executive of the boutique investment bank Keefe Bruyette & Woods, adding his voice to the growing chorus of those warning of the dangers of the current buyout boom, said that the private-equity frenzy could end as badly for investors as the technology-stock bubble did.

headline: Former Credit Suisse Banker to Be Freed on $1 Million Bail
text: A former Credit Suisse banker charged with masterminding a $7.5 million insider trading ring will be released on $1 million bail Wednesday after a federal magistrate judge questioned the strength of the government’s case.

headline: Rumors of BHP Bid for Rio Tinto Send Shares Soaring
text: Days after an analyst’s report suggested that BHP Billiton, the Australian mining company, could become a target for private equity buyers, speculation surfaced that the company is considering a bid for a rival, the Rio Tinto Group.

headline: Proenza Schouler Close to Financing Deal, Report Says
text: A New York design house, Proenza Schouler, is close to scoring a much-needed cash injection from a European luxury firm, The New York Post reported. While Proenza Schouler’s founders, Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, have experienced an almost meteoric rise in fashion circles, they have been looking for additional financing after buying out a German venture capitalist, Markus Hofels, last year, The Post said.

headline: OakTree Swings Deal for Taiwan’s Fu Sheng
text: Oaktree Capital Management, a buyout firm with $40 billion of assets, plans to take over Fu Sheng Industrial of Taiwan, the world’s biggest maker of golf-club heads, for 28.3 billion Taiwan dollars ($851 million).

headline: Bank of Montreal Puts 2 Commodites Bankers on Leave
text: Bank of Montreal, which said last month that it would report a pretax loss of as much as 450 million Canadian dollars ($407 million) from trading natural gas, placed two New York bankers on leave. A natural gas trader, David Lee, and Bob Moore, executive managing director of commodity products, are on leave as Bank of Montreal conducts an “external review,” a spokesman, Ralph Marranca, told Bloomberg News.

headline: Grasso Ruling Makes State’s Case Tougher
text: The ruling by a court of appeals Tuesday dismissing some of the claims brought against Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, is likely to make it more difficult for the state of New York to force him to return the bulk of his pay package.

headline: Fresh Buyout Rumors Dog Countrywide
text: The share price of Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage lender in the nation, jumped Tuesday on renewed speculation of a buyout. The stock climbed $2.77, or 7.2 percent, to $41.28 after rising as high as $42.19.

headline: Strong Demand Seen for Secondary Buyout Funds
text: Goldman Sachs and Coller Capital are among the firms raising secondary buyout funds, that acquire private equity portfolios rather than portions of companies as appetite for these kinds of investments seems to be hitting a high. Financial News cites estimates that $15 billion has been raised this year for secondary funds, more than the amount raised in the last two years combined.

headline: Wildfire in Los Angeles
text: A raging fire in Griffith Park has forced evacuations of homes and city landmarks.

headline: Regulators Are Said to Examine Role of Dow Jones Director in Leaks
text: Federal regulators are expected to examine the role of a Dow Jones director in the possible leak of inside information to a Hong Kong couple, who were accused Tuesday of making millions of dollars from trading shortly before news of Rupert Murdoch’s takeover offer.

headline: Morgan Stanley May Sell Korean Unit, Report Says
text: Morgan Stanley is in talks with foreign money managers, including the ING Group, to sell its South Korean asset management firm in a deal local media valued at up to $220 million, Reuters reported.

headline: SAP Buys OutlookSoft to Advance in Battle Against Oracle
text: The German software maker SAP said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy OutlookSoft, a planning, budgeting, forecasting, and consolidation software maker that competes with Oracle.

headline: Taking Stock of EMC’s Software Spinoff
text: VMware, EMC‘s fast-growing virtualization software unit, plans to offer 10 percent of its stock in an initial public offering. But a report from The 451 Group asks: If VMware’s newly enriched founders should leave the company, will the juggernaut they created keep its momentum? Though comparisons with similar publicly traded companies is difficult, analysts at The 451 Group estimate that VMware could be valued at $7 billion or more once its shares begin trading.

headline: Buyout Suitors Said to Pay a Call on Alltell
text: The rural wireless telecom service provider Alltel is being courted by at least three groups of private-equity buyers about a potential purchase, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Jana Urges Alcoa to Be Prey, Not Predator
text: A hedge fund that has a stake in Alcoa wants the company to drop its $33 billion hostile bid for its Canadian rival Alcan so that it can be bought instead.

headline: Fortress Buys Florida East Coast
text: The Fortress Investment Group is taking Florida East Coast Industries private in a deal valued at $3.5 billion. The buyout agreement follows Fortress’s announcement that it has closed on the first $2.8 billion of a new $5 billion private equity fund.

headline: Dimon Was the Only Source for Dow Chemical Firings
text: The story behind the firing of two Dow Chemical executives for allegedly being “involved in unauthorized discussions with third parties about the potential acquisition of the company” became even more bizarre – and clouded – as the two men sued Dow Chemical, contending that they were defamed. The company, in turn, has sued both men.

headline: Intercasting Nets New Funding
text: Once narrowly focused on a mobile blog publishing application, Intercasting of San Diego now hopes to be the largest intermediary between mobile phone carriers and social networking sites. Its investors have shown their support for the second time, providing $12 million in new capital to support Intercasting’s growth initiatives. Venrock Associates, the venture capital vehicle of the Rockefeller family, led the new round.

headline: Meet the Bancrofts
text: Who does Rupert Murdoch need to win over in his $5 billion bid to acquire Dow Jones? To answer that question, The New York Observer drew up a family tree of the Bancrofts, who control the publishing company through a special class of stock. Family members include a champion power-boat racer, a retired American Airlines pilot and the head of a Texas private equity firm.

headline: The Moss Model
text: Storekeepers praise the Moss model even as they turn away from it.

headline: Citi’s Consumer Arm Loses Senior Managers
text: Citigroup‘s consumer operations have lost nearly half of their senior management in the last 18 months, The Financial Times reported. Several of these high-level employees have left for J.P. Morgan Chase, while three others joined Brysam Global Partners, a private equity firm co-founded by Bob Willumstad, a former chief operating officer at Citi.

headline: Another Call for Habeas Corpus
2008: Second Chances with Conservatives
text: In the wake of less-than-stellar reviews of his speech last week, Fred D. Thompson is working on “Stump Speech 2.0” for a second shot this weekend, report Jonathan Martin and Mike Allen at Politico.com. “Friends working on the speech say it will include more of a call to arms than the entertaining but unfocused after-dinner address Thompson gave to an eagerly expectant audience Friday night at the Balboa Bay Club and Resort in Newport Beach, Calif.,” they write. Mr. Thompson is slated to appear in Northern Virginia on Saturday before the Council for National Policy, an organization of conservative leaders.

headline: One Reason Drug Prices Are So High
text: Why are prescription drugs so expensive? One reason is that the system does not encourage price competition.

headline: Republicans and the Abortion Issue
text: Robin Toner’s Web-only column today looks at the question of whether the G.O.P. is ready for more flexibility on the issue.

headline: Deadline: Iraq
text: It’s not Walter Cronkite, but still…: National Review White House correspondent Byron York questions the “article of faith in Republican circles that Congress should not impose deadlines on the U.S . troop presence in Iraq.” He writes at The Corner:

headline: Mob Hits and Misses
text: Mafia clans are known to fight over turf, but credit for a double murder? F.B.I. documents cited by The Associated Press today recount a conversation between two rival families.

headline: Design Stores
Cravath Woos Skadden Partner for Restructuring Group
text: Cravath Swaine & Moore, the New York law firm, is putting its white shoe firmly in the bankruptcy business. The firm, which frequently counsels companies in multibillion-dollar mergers, said Wednesday it has formed a corporate restructuring and insolvency group and hired Richard Levin, a former partner at Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom, to lead it. The move comes as Skadden and other law firms with established restructuring practices have been recruiting new talent, anticipating that the long lull in large corporate bankruptcies might be nearing an end.

headline: For Poverty Lesson, Edwards Enrolled at a Hedge Fund
text: John Edwards has made poverty a top issue as he stumps for the Democratic Presidential nomination. So his connections to Fortress Investment Group, a highly profitable hedge fund and private equity firm with several executives on Forbes’ latest billionaires list, have provoked quite a bit of interest from campaign watchers. Asked about his decision to join Fortress as a senior adviser in 2005, Mr. Edwards told The Associated Press on Tuesday that he did it “mainly in order to learn about the relationships between financial markets and poverty.”

headline: A Refresher Course in English
text: Oh, lordy, how long I’ve been waiting for this!

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The On Education column yesterday about Columbus High School, misstated its location. The principal says the Bronx school considers Pelham Parkway to be its home. The school is not in Pelham Bay.

headline: Spitzerisms, Lt. Gov. Edition: ‘Dialectic’
text: In which your correspondents track the unusual verbiage of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a highly precise public speaker who often uses words or phrases that rarely alight upon the ears in normal conversation, and occasionally Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson, who appears to be picking up some of his boss’s habits.

headline: 24/7 Natalie Portman?
text: Imagine that there was a way to know what Natalie Portman was doing all the time. Would indulging in that be … weird? Would you do it anyway?

headline: The Gore Reunion
text: There were campaign-style buttons passed around last night at a gathering of former Al Gore donors in Washington, but they did not augur a presidential run by Mr. Gore (to the disappointment of some). “Al Gore Reunion 2007,” they read.

headline: A Rally Turns Tragic in Macedonia
text: A week ago, there was a disastrous crash on the Gumball 3000, an annual rally through Europe that advertises itself as “3,000 miles of adventure with the most eccentric group of thrill-seekers imaginable, partying every night with the who’s who of international society and pop culture.” As you would expect, most of the participants drive exotic cars.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III tries his paws at dog sledding.

headline: Dairy Queen Ads
text: Dairy Queen Ads

headline: Dairy Queen Ads
text: Dairy Queen Ads

headline: Dairy Queen Ads
text: Dairy Queen Ads

headline: Scene from 'Cellular'
text: A.O. Scott describes the movie "Cellular" as "a minor, highly enjoyable recent addition to the canon of Los Angeles crime films." This scene takes place on the Santa Monica Pier.

headline: Wednesday at the ZOPA Cabana
text: That’s ZOPA, as in Zone of Potential Agreement, a term Senate Minority Leader Malcolm A. Smith picked up in a Harvard seminar, and Cabana, as in the place where deals get made, according to the song Mr. Smith and his fellow Senate Democrats sang in a skit at last weekend’s Legislative Correspondents Association dinner

headline: Falling Dow: Doubts Grow About Murdoch’s Bid
text: If Rupert Murdoch is feeling anxious about the fate of News Corporation‘s $5 billion bid for Dow Jones, he didn’t let on at Tuesday night’s Alexander Hamilton dinner in New York, organized by the Manhattan Institute. According to DealBreaker, Mr. Murdoch told the audience a joke, or tried to:

headline: Network Chipmaker Xelerated Lands $23 Million
text: Xelerated, a maker of processors for network routers and switches, has landed $23 million in financing from a group of investors led by Sixth Swedish National Pension Fund.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III tries his paws at dog sledding.

headline: Teamsters Pan Zell’s Buyout Plan for Tribune
text: Is Tribune‘s unusual buyout plan a coup for labor groups seeking a piece of the private equity pie?

headline: Hezbollah Faces Harsh Consequences of War
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s May 9 column, “The Arab Commission.”

headline: Homeland Circuit City Dept.
text: Circuit City confirmed today that one of their employees tipped off authorities to the Fort Dix suspects in January 2006. The employee works at the Mount Laurel, N.J., branch, but has yet to step forward.

headline: The Morning After
text: The day after the Mets played bald, Carlos Beltran, “the Barber of Sheaville” (that was the New York Post’s back page headline when Rey Sanchez received a haircut during a game), walked around the clubhouse with a digital camera. He stuck the camera about two feet away from John Maine, today’s pitcher, who was sitting on the couch. The usually unflappable Maine burst out laughing.

headline: Randolph Notches 200th Win as Manager
text: Barry Bonds hit his 745th home run last night. Tom Glavine won his 294th career game. Feeling left out, Manager Willie Randolph accomplished his own milestone, winning his 200th game as Mets manager. For those interested, he ranks seventh on the franchise’s all-time list and is pretty much assured of sliding into sixth within the next few months and all the way up to fourth early next year.

headline: ‘Best Eyes I’ve Ever Seen’
text: In recent years, Barry Bonds has not made it a habit of playing in day games after night games, but he is in today’s lineup.

headline: My Times News
text: Dear My Times Beta tester,

headline: The Best-Laid Plans
text: A nanosecond is one-billionth of a second.

headline: Murdoch’s Cricket Murder Ruling
text: There’s been no shortage of theories as the investigation continues into the death of Bob Woolmer, the Pakistani cricket coach who died hours after his strongly favored team lost to a neophyte squad from Ireland.

headline: Audio: Giuliani on Ingraham’s Show
text: As we mentioned earlier today, Rudolph W. Giuliani appeared on Laura Ingraham’s talk radio show yesterday and discussed his stance on abortion and answered questions about his previous donations to Planned Parenthood.

headline: More About Mozza
text: For my story in today’s newspaper about Pizzeria Mozza, I talked to several of its ardent fans, and a theme that came up repeatedly in their comments — comments that didn’t wind up working their way into the story — was that Mozza seemed more like a New York restaurant than a Los Angeles one. These fans stressed that the two cities’ restaurant cultures were very different.

headline: Romney and Sharpton on Mormons
text: FORT DODGE, Iowa — Mitt Romney criticized today comments made by the Rev. Al Sharpton about Mormonism and his candidacy, calling the remarks “bigoted” and proof that “bigotry still exists in some corners.”

headline: Clinton as First Spouse
text: Bill Clinton plans to be a First Husband for the 21st century: A post-modern, post-ego presidential spouse who doesn’t earn an income of his own, but rather pays the bills from family savings and does what he can to help the missus down in the Oval Office.

headline: Crash Inquiry Concludes in Brazil
text: An criminal inquiry in Brazil has concluded that two Americans were responsible for piloting a private jet into a collision with a commercial airliner in September 2006, according to O Globo, a Brazilian newspaper.

headline: Ann Romney’s Planned Parenthood Donation
text: Mitt Romney’s campaign confirmed to ABC News today that his wife, Ann Romney, donated $150 to Planned Parenthood in 1994. The news comes just two days after reports resurfaced that Rudolph W. Giuliani donated $900 to Planned Parenthood during the 1990’s—and the day before Mr. Romney is scheduled to receive a “Political Leadership Award” form Massachusetts Citizens for Life.

headline: An Endless Tug of War With Congress
text: In the dying days of the Bush presidency, it looks as though Congress and the president are engaged in one of their repeated tussles over control of foreign policy. The Constitution has always provided the potential for conflict, of course. Dividing up powers means that neither branch of government likes what they get. But it usually takes a dramatic event or a catastrophe (you can decide which of those the current occupation of Iraq is) to stir up the conflict.

headline: The Roots of Ethnic Violence
text: One week ago, the International Criminal Court in The Hague issued arrest warrants on charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity for Ahmad Muhammad Harun, Sudan’s former interior minister who oversaw the Darfur Securty Desk, and Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, a leader of the Janjaweed militia. Mr. Harun is now Sudan’s minister of humanitarian affairs. The two men seem to be rather small fry compared to Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the Sudanese president, but it’s a step in the right direction. Too little, too late, of course, for the hundreds of thousands who’ve been tortured, raped and murdered in the Darfur region over the past four years.

headline: Back On With the Show
text: Pardon my modest blush while I do something here that may appear uncomfortably self-serving. A recurrent theme in your replies to these columns has been how much people miss my old show(s) and how they wish they could see them now. A recent commenter confessed to a life-long “crush” on Katharine Hepburn and just learned that I did two full shows with her on my ABC late-night show. Another writer, Hepburn-smitten, would “give anything” to see them. You, sir (as I recall), can give considerably less than that. And you could probably see them today. Another writer suggested that DVDs of the shows would be a good idea. I don’t know which of us should be embarrassed but DVDs are already out here.

headline: Your Comments on My Column about Genocide and Psychology
text: So what do you think? Can a puppy save Darfur? My column benefited tremendously from this journal article, and I encourage you to look it up.

headline: Suggested Reading
text: Dave Anderson, who covered Muhammad Ali throughout his career, knows a big fight, and a big fight night, when he sees one. Here he recalls the first Ali-Frazier fight in 1971 and wonders whether boxing can recover the majesty and energy of nights like that. From PLAY’s suggested reading list:

headline: Curing the System
text: The American health insurance system is a slow-creeping ruin, damaging people and increasingly the employers that hire us. Yet there is another truth as well: the vast majority who have decent coverage are happy with the care we get  I am writing this, for instance, as I sit with my 11-year-old son waiting for an M.R.I. to check the cardiac repair that has saved his life for a decade. So most have resisted large-scale change, fearing that it could make some lives worse, even as it makes others better.

headline: Some Other Takes, From Coast to Coast, on Contemporary Design
text: The Conran Shop

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Economic Scene column in Business Day last Thursday, about research into the discrepancy between stock market returns and individual investors’ returns, misstated the average yearly dollar-weighted return for a hypothetical investor who bought 100 shares of a company at $10 a share, then a year later bought 100 more shares when the share price was $20, then sold all 200 shares when the price fell to $10 a share at the end of that second year. The investor’s average yearly return was a negative 26.8 percent, not a negative 16.8 percent.

headline: Silence on Guns
text: The tragedy of our runaway gun culture can only deepen now that it’s clear the new Democratic Congress operates in fear of the gun lobby’s well-practiced demagoguery and rich campaign treasury. A collective silence descended on the Capitol after the pro forma expressions of outrage over the Virginia Tech gun massacre.

headline: Extra! Extra! Now the Post Doesn’t Cost That Extra 25 Cents
text: To recap New York City’s tabloid price war: the tabloid costing 25 cents went to 50, so the one at 50 went to 25, but it will return to 50 soon. And now, the one that just went to 50 has gone back to 25. Got that?

headline: Sarkozy’s Achievement (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: International Bidders Raise Prices at Art Auction
text: “It’s a new world,” said Tobias Meyer, the auctioneer who conducted Sotheby’s sale of Impressionist and Modern art on Tuesday night, as his hammer pounded the lectern like a loud exclamation mark. After an intense war between two telephone bidders, a canvas by the Expressionist painter Lyonel Feininger had just sold for $23.2 million, more than two and a half times its high estimate and a record for the artist at auction.

headline: Tennessee Inmate Executed
text: The convicted killer Philip R. Workman was executed, the first execution in the state since the release of new state procedures for administering lethal injections. Mr. Workman, who had been on death row since 1982, was executed after the United States and Tennessee Supreme Courts refused to issue a stay. Mr. Workman’s last-minute appeals included challenges to the state’s revised lethal injection protocols. The protocols were released last week after a 90-day review and moratorium on executions.

headline: Europe’s Satellite Navigation System Will Miss a Deadline
text: BERLIN, May 9 — The European Commission is abandoning plans to build a satellite navigation system in partnership with private industry after the consortium chosen for the project became mired in disputes about financing, jobs and management structure, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: At the Stadium, Stay Put When the Music Plays
text: The most patriotic moments at Yankee Stadium can also be the most confining.

headline: Harvard Task Force Calls for New Focus on Teaching and Not Just Research
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8 — Joshua Billings, 22, says he did not come to Harvard for the teaching.

headline: The Yoga Therapist Will See You Now
text: FOR three years after a car crash left her with chronic pain, Deanna Adams searched high and low for relief. Mrs. Adams, 41, a stay-at-home mother in West Palm Beach, Fla., consulted a physical therapist, a chiropractor, two doctors (a pain specialist and a neurologist) and an acupuncturist — to no avail.

headline: Mayweather Victory Sets Pay-Per-View Mark
text: Floyd Mayweather’s split decision against Oscar De La Hoya in Saturday night’s superwelterweight title fight generated 2.15 million pay-per-view buys — eclipsing the 10-year-old record for the second Evander Holyfield-Mike Tyson fight.

headline: Verizon Drops Pop Singer From Ads
text: Many music fans know that Pete Wentz, the bassist for the rock band Fall Out Boy, found himself overexposed last year when sexually explicit pictures of him surfaced on the Internet. Many also know that Keith Urban, the country superstar, recently endured a stint in rehab.

headline: East Patchogue: Man Found Dead in Yard
text: A 3-year-old boy was found lying unharmed next to his father’s body on Tuesday afternoon near their house in East Patchogue, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The father, Carlton Shaw, 38, had been shot in the chest and was found in a yard next to his house on Amsterdam Avenue about 4:45 p.m., the police said. The shooting was under investigation yesterday.

headline: U.S. Attorneys, Reloaded
text: As the United States attorney scandal grows, so does the number of prosecutors who seem to have been pushed out for partisan political reasons. Another highly suspicious case has emerged in the appointment of Bradley Schlozman, a controversial elections lawyer, to replace a respected United States attorney in Missouri. From the facts available, it looks like a main reason for installing Mr. Schlozman was to help Republicans win a pivotal Missouri Senate race.

headline: Whose Face Is It, Really?
text: IS a face one of a kind, an original like a snowflake and of such fragile beauty that its uniqueness perishes when tampered with? Or is a face malleable, like dough, the easier to mold into identical cookie-cutter shapes?

headline: Cheney Visits Baghdad and Presses Leaders on Political Progress
text: BAGHDAD, May 9 — After a day of talks here with Iraq’s fractious political leaders, Vice President Dick Cheney said Wednesday that he detected “a greater sense of urgency” among them in tackling a list of divisive issues that the Bush administration sees as the key to any sustained progress against the country’s insurgent and militia groups.

headline: 2 Arrested in Jailhouse Plot to Kill Queens Police Officer
text: A police officer who broke up a fistfight in front of his Queens home in August became the target of a murder plot, the authorities said yesterday, when a man he arrested that day tried to hire a hit man from his Rikers Island jail cell.

headline: The Collarbone’s Connected to Slimness
text: LET’S say a woman clocked a few hundred crunches a day, Stairmastered her bottom into a replica of J. Lo’s and avoided carbs so assiduously that the waiters at her regular restaurants knew not to bother with a breadbasket. If no one could see results of all of this exertion and deprivation, would it count?

headline: Giuliani to Support Abortion Rights
text: After months of conflicting signals on abortion, Rudolph W. Giuliani is planning to offer a forthright affirmation of his support for abortion rights in public forums, television appearances and interviews in the coming days, despite the potential for bad consequences among some conservative voters already wary of his views, aides said yesterday.

headline: Senate Approves Tighter Policing of Drug Makers
text: WASHINGTON, May 9 — By a vote of 93 to 1, the Senate passed a bill on Wednesday that would give the Food and Drug Administration new power to police drug safety, order changes in drug labels, regulate advertising and restrict the use and distribution of medicines found to pose serious risks to consumers.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with the Advertising column about cellphones affiliated with particular organizations carried an incorrect credit. The photograph was by Evan J. Thomas  not Michael Caulfield/Wire Image.com for CNN.

headline: Earnhardt Could Take a New Turn
text: Dale Earnhardt Jr., Nascar’s most popular driver, has scheduled a news conference for 11 a.m. today amid speculation about his future with the race team Dale Earnhardt Inc.

headline: Afghans Say U.S. Airstrikes Killed 21 Civilians
text: HERAT, Afghanistan, May 9 — Afghan officials said Wednesday that airstrikes called in by American Special Forces against Taliban fighters in Helmand Province had killed 21 civilians, the latest in a series of claims of noncombatant casualties that have strained relations with the Afghan government.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the arrests of six men in New Jersey on charges of plotting to attack the Fort Dix Army base referred imprecisely to the relationship between three suspects  the brothers Eljvir, Dritan and Shain Duka  and a fourth, Mohamad Shnewer. Mr. Shnewer’s sister is married to Eljvir Duka, so only Eljvir  not all three Duka brothers  is legally Mr. Shnewer’s brother-in-law.

headline: Frustration Ends for Delgado and Wright
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9  Atop their division is probably not where one would expect to find the Mets with Carlos Delgado and David Wright mired in season-long slumps. But that is where the Mets sit after Delgado and Wright, partners in frustration, redeemed themselves Wednesday with clutch doubles in consecutive innings to boost the Mets to a 5-3 victory against the San Francisco Giants at AT&T Park.

headline: In Churchill’s Rise to Power, a Rough Path of Rebellion
text: Historical memory, like a skilled film editor, compresses the past. In the mind’s newsreel of the late 1930s Neville Chamberlain steps off the plane from Munich, declaring “peace in our time,” the camera quickly pans over German troops on the march, and in the next instant Winston Churchill strides toward 10 Downing Street flashing the V-for-victory sign, ready to lead Britain at war.

headline: The Netherlands: Stiffer Sentence for Iraq Poison Gas
text: An appeals court raised the 2005 prison sentence of a Dutch businessman, Frans van Anraat, to 17 years from 15 for selling chemicals to Saddam Hussein. The chemicals were used in poison gas weapons in the 1980s and against Kurdish villagers. Prosecutors had demanded a conviction for complicity in genocide, but the appeal judges rejected that, saying Mr. van Anraat was driven not by genocidal intent but by greed.

headline: Brooklyn: Illegal Steroids Seized
text: More than $100,000 worth of illegal steroids were confiscated from a pharmacy yesterday by the New York State Bureau of Narcotic Enforcement, officials said. The authorities were led to a Lowen’s Pharmacy in Brooklyn as part of an investigation by the Albany County district attorney. The investigation so far has led to the prosecution of at least 20 people. Christopher Baynes, an assistant district attorney for Albany County, said that investigators found large amounts of Chinese growth hormone and testosterone that had not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration at Lowen’s Pharmacy. As of last night, no charges had been filed, Mr. Baynes said.

headline: Save the Darfur Puppy
text: Finally, we’re beginning to understand what it would take to galvanize President Bush, other leaders and the American public to respond to the genocide in Sudan: a suffering puppy with big eyes and floppy ears.

headline: Mubarak Meets Israel’s Foreign Minister
text: CAIRO, Egypt, May 10 — President Hosni Mubarak met with Israel’s foreign minister, Tzipi Livni, today and agreed that a team of Arab officials would soon visit Israel to discuss a peace proposal initiated by Saudi Arabia and endorsed by all members of the Arab League.

headline: New Zealand Goes Right, and Grabs the Advantage
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 9  So who is the heavyweight challenger now?

headline: Romney Accuses Sharpton of a Bigoted Remark
text: FORT DODGE, Iowa, May 9  Mitt Romney said Wednesday that a comment by the Rev. Al Sharpton about Mr. Romney and his Republican presidential candidacy was proof that “bigotry still exists in some corners.”

headline: Olmert’s Testimony on War Is Made Public
text: JERUSALEM, May 10 — In confidential testimony on last summer’s war with the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said that the Israeli killing of a group of civilians in the town of Qana in late July was a turning point that delayed a diplomatic resolution.

headline: Defense Attacks Credibility of Black’s Former Associate
text: CHICAGO, May 9  A defense lawyer in Conrad M. Black’s criminal fraud trial attacked the credibility of the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler, on Wednesday by pointing out the numerous times Mr. Radler had lied before he cut a deal with federal prosecutors.

headline: A Site Where Virtual Barbies Can Compare Their Makeovers
text: Barbie dolls collide with Web 2.0 with the release of BarbieGirls.com, a free online community which Mattel hopes will pull young girls away from competitors like Ty Girlz, Neopets and Webkinz. Once children pick a screen name and password, they can dress up their own Barbie avatar, a fun process of mixing and matching hairstyles, clothing items and shades of lipstick. There’s no bad hair; in fact, every creation looks like a slightly different beauty queen.

headline: Manhattan: Gay Festival in Jeopardy
text: The organizers of PrideFest, the gay-themed street fair that generally accompanies the city’s gay pride parade on the last Sunday in June, voted on Tuesday night to tell city officials that they would cancel this year’s festival unless they could find a better location. The members of Heritage of Pride, which organizes the festival and the parade, have said that the previous site, in the West Village, was cramped and dangerous, and that they wanted to move to Chelsea. On April 27, city officials denied permission for the change and urged the organizers to keep the event at the original site. The city’s comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., has sent the mayor a letter urging the city to reconsider.

headline: The Real Owner of All Those Planes
text: LOS ANGELES — When Steven Udvar-Hazy was a teenager in New York City, he would often head after school to Idlewild Airport, as Kennedy International was known then, to watch planes take off and land.

headline: Chefs Topped With Debt
text: The chef behind your light soufflé may be bending under the weight of heavy debts. The servitude of student loans extends well beyond college and graduate programs and straight into the culinary schools, where many aspiring young Mario Batalis and Daniel Bouluds take on tens of thousands of dollars in debt that they will spend years struggling to pay back if they don’t quite make the big leagues.

headline: Elevated Levels of Chemical Found in Queens Drinking Water
text: Slightly elevated levels of an industrial chemical have been found in the water supply of as many as 64,000 Queens residents, prompting officials to recommend the use of bottled water for drinking and cooking until the source is determined.

headline: Fire Chars Part of Major Los Angeles Park
text: LOS ANGELES, May 9  A stubborn brush fire burned nearly a fifth of Griffith Park, among the largest municipal parks in the country, before firefighters brought the blaze under control on Wednesday.

headline: Religion Guided 3 Held in Fort Dix Plot
text: PHILADELPHIA, May 9 — The three Duka brothers — Eljvir, Shain and Dritan — not only prayed here at the Al Aqsa Islamic Center, but also recently began repairing its roof.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,365 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Disillusioned Diva With Glimmers of Soul
text: Amy Winehouse is a tease. The songs on her second album, “Back to Black” (Universal Republic), revive the sound of 1960s and 1970s soul with tales of plunging into temptation and toughing out the consequences. She drinks, she cheats, she falls for the wrong guys, she cries; she refuses rehab with a magnificently simple refrain, “I said no, no, no.”

headline: Earbuds for Fashion and Sound That Adjust So They Don’t Fall Out
text: It’s called T.E.S.  tiny ear syndrome. No, it’s not a new medical malady but the problem many people have with the earbuds that ship with portable music players. They don’t always fit comfortably and sometimes pop out unexpectedly.

headline: Seizing the Moment
text: DIGITAL cameras are amazing. Even compact digital cameras selling for less than $100 take photographs with great resolution.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on April 28 about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britain’s top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation. Also, because of an editing error, a correction in this space on May 2 misstated the month the announcement was made. The Serious Fraud Office made the announcement, not Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general. The announcement was made in December, not January. (Go to Article)

headline: For Clemens, Leg Work Is the Key to Success
text: When Roger Clemens was a Yankee in his previous life, Mel Stottlemyre was his pitching coach. Stottlemyre is retired now, playing golf and fishing among the fir trees and lakes of Washington State, but if he were monitoring Clemens’s new life as a Yankee, he would be concerned more with the strength in Clemens’s legs than in the arm with 348 career victories, the most of any active pitcher and eighth on the career list.

headline: Calendar
text: All Irises

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on April 28 about American diplomatic protests over the cancellation of a British government inquiry into bribery by BAE Systems, Britain’s top military contractor, to secure contracts in Saudi Arabia, misattributed the announcement of the cancellation. Also, because of an editing error, a correction in this space on May 2 misstated the month the announcement was made. The Serious Fraud Office made the announcement, not Lord Peter Goldsmith, the attorney general. The announcement was made in December, not January.

headline: A Top Russian Marathoner Fails a Drug Test
text: Lyubov Denisova, a 35-year-old Russian who has finished in the top 10 in the New York City Marathon four times, has tested positive for an elevated testosterone level.

headline: As Top Seeds Dominate in East, Fans Head West
text: Vince Carter has settled for fadeaway after fadeaway after fadeaway in Cleveland, and the empty thud of his misses has echoed the Nets’ playoff plight.

headline: Faster Fashion, Cheaper Chic
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: South Korea: Big Plans for Solar Energy
text: South Korea plans to break ground for the world’s biggest solar power plant as it tries to diversify its power sources and use cleaner energy, the government and developers said. The $170 million plant, being built in Shinan, near the southwestern tip of South Korea, is part of an effort to seek new and renewable energy sources and is scheduled to be completed by late 2008. The plant will produce more than 27,000 megawatt-hours of electricity a year, enough to supply 6,000 to 7,000 households, said Kim Ji Hun, president of the Korean subsidiary of SunTechnics, the German solar power company that will build the plant. It will be operated by Dongyang Engineering and Construction.

headline: House Passes Ban on Gifts From Student Lenders
text: WASHINGTON, May 9 — The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly Wednesday to ban gifts and payments by student loan companies to universities, showing bipartisan resolve to clean up the $85 billion industry.

headline: Irvington: Sergeant Charged With Theft
text: A police commander and the owner of an auto yard were arrested yesterday and charged with stealing items from vehicles that had been seized, the Essex County prosecutor’s office said. Sgt. Barry Halpern, 51, of Kenilworth, a 24-year veteran of the Irvington Police Department and commander of the auto squad unit, was charged with second-degree official misconduct and third-degree theft. Mark Minett, 51, of Tinton Falls, the owner of MTS Towing in Irvington, was charged with third-degree theft, said the prosecutor, Paula T. Dow. An inquiry began in January 2006 after several people reported items like laptop computers and power tools missing from their cars. Sergeant Halpern is being held in $50,000 bail and Mr. Minett is being held in $30,000 bail.

headline: Britain Arrests 4 Suspected of Ties to 2005 Transit Bombings
text: LEEDS, England, May 9  The British police on Wednesday arrested three men and the widow of a suicide bomber involved in the terrorist attack on the London transit system in 2005 on suspicion that they helped in the atrocity, which killed 56 people, including the 4 bombers.

headline: A Family’s Films, Like No Home Movies You’ve Seen
text: Like father, like son? That question hovers evocatively over the nine-title program, Generation Garrel, that opens today at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s BAM Rose Cinemas. Dedicated to three male members of the same filmmaking family — the actor Maurice, his director-son Philippe and actor-grandson Louis — the program’s relative modesty doesn’t justify sweeping claims about how the ties that bind can lead to a life in the movies. But it does suggest that all three Garrels share a cinematic culture of experimentation and provocation and offers hard proof that together and alone they have done exceptional work.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies yesterday about the six suspects in the Fort Dix case misstated which two of the suspects are brothers-in-law. Eljvir Duka and Mohamad Shnewer are related, not Mr. Duka and Agron Abdullahu. The article also misstated the number of Mr. Shnewer’s sisters. He has five, not two.

headline: Facing the New Motherhood, Cutthroat and Neurotic
text: In Amy Wilson’s new solo comedy, “Mother Load,” she tackles a subject that has suffered inadequate attention perhaps only on Jupiter. A mother of two, Ms. Wilson is addled by the whole neurotic culture of modern parenthood. The pressures! The lactation consultants! The baby rice cakes!

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in the special Personal Health section on May 1, about sexually transmitted diseases, misidentified the viruses that cause herpes, the most common sexually transmitted disease in the United States. They are strains of H.S.V., or herpes simplex virus  not H.P.V., or human papillomavirus.

headline: Italy: Profit Rises 12% at Utility
text: Enel, an Italian utility, said first-quarter profit unexpectedly rose 12 percent, fueled by increased foreign sales and cost cuts. Net income climbed to 943 million euros ($1.28 billion), or 16 cents a share, from 842 million euros, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Enel, which is bidding for the Spanish utility Endesa, sold power in Eastern Europe and Russia in the period to make up for falling electricity demand at home. Costs were reduced by 7.2 percent, helping offset a drop in Italian sales. Sales declined 5.1 percent, to 9.73 billion euros. The bid for Endesa values the company at 43.7 billion euros and will give Enel access to another 22 million customers. The deal will create a platform to sell electricity across borders when the EU energy market opens to competition on July 1.

headline: A Sensible Solution to Thin Traffic, and One for Easing Concerns About Fairness
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg recently proposed charging a fee to motorists who enter Manhattan south of 86th Street on weekdays. Drivers of cars would face a daily charge of $8 from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m., while the fee would be $21 for driving commercial trucks.

headline: France: Profit Up 25% at BNP Paribas
text: BNP Paribas, the French bank, reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter profit on higher corporate and investment bank earnings and gains from asset sales. Income climbed to 2.51 billion euros ($3.4 billion), from 2.01 billion euros a year earlier, BNP Paribas said. Revenue rose 21 percent, to 8.21 billion euros. Profit beat the 2.06 billion euros expected by analysts. BNP Paribas’s stock rose 3.65 euros, to 91.15 euros. Pretax profit at the corporate and investment bank rose 12 percent. Earnings at the French branch network declined 2.2 percent, while pretax profit at BancWest, a unit based in Hawaii, slipped 20 percent. Excluding Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, earnings at BNP Paribas’s international retail bank decreased 5.3 percent.

headline: Legislators Ask to Revise Plan for Hospitals
text: ALBANY, May 9  The Republican and Democratic leaders of the State Legislature said Wednesday that they wanted Gov. Eliot Spitzer to reconsider a plan approved last year to close, merge or shrink dozens of hospitals across the state.

headline: A Spaniard With a Taste for Drama
text: When the Spanish singer Martirio performed the slow bolero “Si Te Contara” on Tuesday night at Joe’s Pub, her backing trio narrowed to only a plucked bass, and her physical emphasis moved to the areas beyond her wrists: the swivel of her hands, the tense arcs of her fingers.

headline: Chemicals Found in Queens Water Since 2003, Reports Say
text: The area of New York City where officials this week found industrial chemicals in the drinking water has had problems with contamination by the same chemicals for several years.

headline: Correction: Currents
text: A report in the Currents column last Thursday gave an incorrect telephone number to order the Butch & Harold line of wall decals. The number is (212) 712-0616.

headline: All-in-Ones: Bring on the Tiny Purse
text: NO strangers are we to multitasking; it was only a matter of time before we demanded our makeup do the same. These days, sticks, pencils and compacts can perform multiple beauty duty without dominating the purse — or the wallet.

headline: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
text: Boston

headline: Yankee Rings Become Issue for Giuliani
text: With his official interlocking “NY” cap, shiny team jacket and seats near home plate, Rudolph W. Giuliani has often looked as if he might just bleed pinstripes if his beloved Yankees lost a game.

headline: A BlackBerry for Collars of All Colors
text: As a human being, you’re pretty much stuck with the features you had on the date of manufacture. Very few adults ever become substantially taller, faster or more artistic.

headline: Arabic School Finds Temporary Home in Brooklyn
text: The Department of Education has found a temporary site for the Khalil Gibran International Academy, a public school devoted to the study of Arabic language and culture that is scheduled to open in September.

headline: A Player Who Never Found His Stage
text: London

headline: Room to Improve
text: A. Simplicity goes a long way toward making a bathroom feel as if it is from another time. The most difficult part of the job may be undoing old decorating. Before you bring in new fittings, fixtures or furniture, take stock of what you have and remove ill-conceived flourishes. Vinyl flooring or carpet? Rip it out. Jaunty wallpaper? Tear it off.

headline: House Panel Considers Cuts for Missile Defense
text: WASHINGTON, May 9 — The Bush administration’s proposal to construct two American missile defense bases in Europe has roiled relations with Russia and provoked sharp questioning even in NATO capitals, where critics ask: With the system still unproven and, under the best of circumstances, years from completion, why rush construction now?

headline: G.O.P. Moderates Warn Bush Iraq Must Show Gains
text: WASHINGTON, May 9 — Moderate Republicans gave President Bush a blunt warning on his Iraq policy at a private White House meeting this week, telling the president that conditions needed to improve markedly by fall or more Republicans would desert him on the war.

headline: Indictment in ’65 Killing That Inspired March
text: NEW ORLEANS, May 9 — A grand jury in Alabama handed up an indictment on Wednesday in an obscure killing that helped inspire the historic Selma-to-Montgomery march in 1965. The case is the latest in a series of belated prosecutions of crimes from the civil rights era.

headline: Manhattan: Notification of Building Permits
text: The City Council passed legislation yesterday requiring the Buildings Department to notify the Fire Department when alteration permits are issued for buildings. The bill was submitted after a 2006 Bronx fire in which two firefighters were killed when a floor collapsed in a building that had undergone renovations, though the cause of the collapse is still under investigation. The bill passed 51 to 0, and the mayor is expected to sign it.

headline: Germany Conducts Raids Ahead of G-8 Summit
text: FRANKFURT, May 9 — Four weeks before leaders of the world’s big industrial nations are to gather at a Baltic Sea resort in northern Germany, the police conducted sweeping raids on Wednesday on the offices and homes of left-wing campaigners whom they suspected of planning to disrupt the meeting.

headline: Alan Lowenstein, 93, Lawyer, Is Dead; Revised Newark Government
text: Alan V. Lowenstein, a prominent New Jersey lawyer who headed the commission that drafted the restructuring of Newark’s government in the 1950s, allowing for the direct election of the mayor, and who also led one of the nation’s early attempts at employee ownership of a major company, died Tuesday at his home in Maplewood, N.J. He was 93.

headline: European Buyers Enjoy Weak Dollar at Art Auction
text: A sea change in the art market was stunningly apparent last night at Christie’s sale of Impressionist and Modern art, where most of the buyers spending millions of dollars on everything from stark Giacometti sculptures to dreamy Signac landscapes were mainly Europeans taking advantage of the weak dollar.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on May 1 about an accounting technique used by New Century Financial misstated the year that the company’s chief financial officer, Edward F. Gotschall, stepped down from that job. It was 2004, not 2006. (Mr. Gotschall is still with the company as a vice chairman.)

headline: 2 Convicted of Leaking Memo on Bush-Blair Talk
text: LONDON, May 9  A British court found a civil servant and a legislator’s aide guilty on Wednesday of breaking the Official Secrets Act by leaking a classified memorandum concerning a conversation at the White House between Prime Minister Tony Blair and President Bush.

headline: Ways to Speed an Exit From Iraq (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Blair Says He Will Leave Office in June
text: LONDON, May 10 — After months of coy hints and fevered speculation, Prime Minister Tony Blair announced today that he would leave office on June 27 after a decade in power in which he sacrificed his popularity to the war in Iraq and struggled at home to improve schools, policing and hospitals.

headline: The Hague: Bosnian Serb Wins Genocide Appeal
text: An appeals court of the United Nations war crimes tribunal overturned a 2005 conviction for complicity in genocide against a former Bosnian Serb officer, Vidoje Blagojevic, saying it had no proof that he had known of the “genocidal intent” of the perpetrators of the 1995 massacre of Muslims at Srebrenica and provided only logistical support. The court reduced his prison sentence to 15 years from 18, and upheld several related war crimes charges.

headline: Missouri Prosecutor Says He Was Pushed to Resign
text: WASHINGTON, May 9  The former United States attorney in Kansas City, Mo., said Wednesday that he was pushed to resign last year after disagreements with the Justice Department over politically sensitive cases. That would make him the ninth federal prosecutor forced out by department officials in Washington.

headline: Toyota Profit Robust, Forecast Cautious
text: TOKYO, May 9 — Toyota reported another year of record profit today but signaled a slowdown in the current year because of weakness in North America and increased spending.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary by The Associated Press on Saturday about Gordon Scott, an actor who played Tarzan in the 1950s, misspelled his surname at birth. He was Gordon W. Werschkul, not Werschkull. The obituary also misspelled the given name of his surviving brother. He is Rafield Werschkul, not Rayfield.

headline: Nothing Like the Suns, Thomas Mixes It Up
text: PHOENIX, May 9  If the Phoenix Suns ran a footrace against one another in practice, Kurt Thomas might well finish last.

headline: Microsoft to Invest in CareerBuilder Web Site
text: SEATTLE, May 9 — Microsoft said Wednesday that it would take a small equity stake in CareerBuilder, a popular job recruitment site operated by three big media companies. The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising.

headline: Magna Chairman Confirms an Offer for Chrysler
text: OTTAWA, May 9  Frank Stronach, the chairman of the auto parts maker Magna International, confirmed Wednesday that his company and Onex, a Canadian investment company, have made a bid for Chrysler, the struggling American unit of DaimlerChrysler.

headline: Queens: Woman Admits Fatally Beating Father
text: A woman yesterday admitted fatally beating her father with a hammer in a November 2004 attack, prosecutors said. The woman, Laura Martin, 46, of Long Island City, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to first-degree manslaughter, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Ms. Martin admitted repeatedly striking her father, John Martin, 67, in the head in their apartment. She had told the police that he had been killed in a break-in, Mr. Brown said. In exchange for her plea, Ms. Martin will be sentenced to 20 years in prison, Mr. Brown said.

headline: On the High-Definition Front: A Laptop With Blu-ray
text: The war between the HD-DVD and Blu-ray formats rages on, but it is still quite difficult to find PCs and laptops that can handle either of the new standards for high-definition video.

headline: Growing Numbers on L.I.R.R. Ride Against Commuter Tide
text: As city residents continue to take more jobs in the suburbs, the number of reverse commuters during the morning rush on the Long Island Rail Road has jumped 76 percent since 1998, according to a study to be released today.

headline: From a Nevada Tournament, Defense by the Textbook
text: The Cavendish Invitational tournament started yesterday at the Green Valley Ranch Resort in Henderson, Nev. The main events are the John Roberts Teams and the Cavendish Invitational Pairs, with a secondary competition, the World Bridge Productions Pairs, also scheduled. Details: cavendishinvitational.com. Play can be seen live at www.bridgebase.com.

headline: The Role of an F.B.I. Informer Draws Praise as Well as Questions About Legitimacy
text: It was August 2006 when one of the young Muslim men accused of plotting to kill soldiers at Fort Dix first broached the idea, according to the authorities. Talking to an informer who was secretly taping the exchange, the young man said that he thought he could round up six or seven other men willing to take part, and that a rocket-propelled grenade might be the most effective weapon, the authorities said.

headline: Bush Threatens Veto
text: The House approved legislation that proposes $39.8 billion for the Homeland Security Department next year. President Bush has threatened to veto the measure over its pro-union provision. The measure, which passed 296 to 126, would strike a provision in the 2002 legislation creating the department that allowed the president to waive collective-bargaining rights for department workers.

headline: As Mayor Says No to ’08 Bid, Revived Web Site Fuels Skeptics
text: Does the mayor protest too much?

headline: The Incredible Flying Granny Nanny
text: ANGELA KIM spends two days a week baby-sitting for her 2-year-old grandson, Noah, while her daughter, Andrea, a doctor, works nine-hour hospital shifts.

headline: A New Attitude for the Hip
text: IN Australia, they call it a “bum bag.” In France, it’s “le banane.” Apparently much of the world regards the fanny pack, that belted pouch often seen around the enlarged waists of unsophisticated travelers, as little more than a gag item.

headline: Battle of Britain’s Free Newspapers
text: LONDON — British tabloids typically send out paparazzi to poke into the lives of the royals, soccer coaches and supermodels. Lately, however, two free newspapers fighting a circulation battle on the streets of London have turned the cameras on each other.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Picture captions in The Arts yesterday with a theater review of “Radio Golf,” at the Cort Theater, reversed the identities of two actors. In the picture on the cover of the section, the actor on the right was James A. Williams, not John Earl Jelks. In the picture with the continuation of the review, the actor on the left was Mr. Jelks, not Mr. Williams.

headline: Order and Chaos in a Single Heartbeat
text: Los Angeles

headline: Pope Opens Trip With Remarks Against Abortion
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, May 9 — Benedict XVI arrived in Brazil on Wednesday, starting his first papal trip to Latin America with strong words against abortion, and roiling a Catholic continent increasingly divided by the issue.

headline: Curtis Harrington, Director of Horror Films, Dies at 80
text: Curtis Harrington, who dived under his seat while watching his first horror film as a child, then went on to be a filmmaker known for his elegant, edgy cinematic forays into the macabre, died on Sunday at his home in the Hollywood Hills section of Los Angeles. He was 80.

headline: Japan: G.E. Buys Rest of Sanyo Credit
text: The General Electric Company said today that it had paid 126.3 billion yen or $1.05 billion for the Japanese leasing company Sanyo Electric Credit Company. G.E. paid 3,250 yen a share for 97 percent of Sanyo Credit’s stock, the company said in a statement. The company bought the shares from Sanyo Electric and two Goldman Sachs units. G.E. is focusing on lending to companies after the Japanese government tightened consumer credit rules.

headline: The Morning Line on Tony From Jersey
text: A certain gent in New Jersey is hereby urged to call this number before his life spins totally out of control: 1-800-522-4700. That is a national help line for problem gamblers, open 24 hours a day.

headline: From Intel and A.M.D., Rival Boasts of Technology
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 — The fierce rivalry between the chip makers Intel and Advanced Micro Devices is ratcheting up as both companies claim superiority in technology used for notebook computers.

headline: Iran Frees Former Atomic Negotiator on Bail
text: TEHRAN, May 9  A former nuclear negotiator who was arrested over a week ago was released Wednesday after a hefty bail was paid for him, the ISNA news agency reported.

headline: Taking Suggestions While Searching
text: Q. I recently did a Web search with Google on my daughter’s computer. When I entered the information, a drop-down menu appeared with suggested Web addresses and additional words. How can I get my own computer to suggest words and Web sites?

headline: Manhattan: Database for Birth Statistics
text: The public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, introduced legislation yesterday that would require the city’s health department to create an online database of birth statistics, including the number of delivery procedures, like Caesarean sections, performed at hospitals. She said the database would help expectant parents choose a hospital. State law requires hospitals to provide women with maternity information, but surveys by Ms. Gotbaum in 2005 and 2006 found that many were not in compliance.

headline: PGA Tour Caddies Finally Take a Load Off Their Shoulders
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., May 9 — There was a tip jar on the 17th tee at the T.P.C. Sawgrass filled with golf balls, coins and crinkled dollar bills.

headline: Reyes Keeps His Head, and Hair
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 — Carlos Beltrán, bald as a cue ball, walked around the clubhouse Wednesday admiring his handiwork. He went from Jorge Sosa to John Maine to David Newhan, snapping photos with his digital camera, before stopping in front of José Reyes, who was seated at a table. Beltrán shook his head.

headline: Prominent in Hong Kong and, Perhaps, in the Dow Jones Inquiry
text: HONG KONG, May 9 — Like David Rockefeller in the United States and a succession of Rothschilds in Europe, David K. P. Li has long received the accolades that come to aristocratic bankers who combine wealth, political influence and public service.

headline: U.S. Report Cites Lightning and Old Cable in Mine Blast
text: BUCKHANNON, W.Va., May 9  A lightning bolt was the likely cause of the Sago Mine explosion last year that killed 12 miners, a 16-month federal investigation has concluded.

headline: Toyota Posts Another Record but Warns of Slowdown
text: TOKYO, May 9 — Toyota reported another year of record profit on Wednesday but signaled a slowdown in the current year because of weakness in North America and increased spending.

headline: Death Penalty Sought in a Fatal Wildfire
text: LOS ANGELES, May 9  The Riverside County district attorney has decided to seek the death penalty against a man accused of starting a wildfire last year that killed five firefighters.

headline: Uneasy Rider: Insuring Clemens a Big Risk
text: Between now and the time that Roger Clemens joins their roster, the Yankees will search for a disability policy to insure him against a season-ending injury. It is not certain they will get one, or that it will be affordable.

headline: Windows Upgrade for Smartphones Improves Search and E-Mail Features
text: You’ll never be able to buy a boxed version of Microsoft’s latest mobile operating system, but who needs boxes? Windows Mobile 6, a considerable upgrade to the company’s operating system for smartphones and P.D.A.’s, is now available as a free download for owners of the T-Mobile Dash. Versions will soon be released for other smartphones, old and new, from multiple carriers.

headline: Manhattan: Deal for Marine Terminal Lease
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey reached a $51 million deal yesterday to allow one of its tenants, Orient Overseas International Ltd., which is based in Hong Kong, to sell its lease of a Staten Island marine terminal to the board of the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, which is buying the lease as an investment. In return for signing off on the $470 million transaction, the authority will receive $16 million in cash, up to $5 million to cover construction costs and a commitment from the pension board to invest $30 million in the Howland Hook terminal.

headline: Two Special Elections Later, New Councilman Takes Oath
text: With his hand on a Bible and his family at his side, Mathieu Eugene was sworn into the City Council yesterday, apparently putting to rest questions about his residency.

headline: Roundabout to Fill a Brand-New 89-Year-Old Theater
text: If everything stays on schedule, the number of Broadway theaters will increase by one in the fall of 2008, with the opening of Henry Miller’s Theater, behind an 89-year-old facade of old Broadway on 43rd Street that will be surrounded by the glass modernity of the new 54-story tall Bank of America Tower.

headline: Next Week
text: Rob Weintraub looks ahead to the N.B.A. draft lottery and how the presence of two super freshmen, Greg Oden and Kevin Durant, could affect the dynamics of the decision making. Gretchen Reynolds examines a new study on hydration.

headline: Correction: Up, Up and ... Never Mind
text: An article on April 26 about efforts to encourage people to learn to fly referred incorrectly to a new category of airplanes, light sport aircraft. They are indeed being built.

headline: Group Seeks Trade for Captive BBC Journalist
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank, May 9  The Palestinian Authority information minister, Mustafa Barghouti, said Wednesday that there had been “very important developments in the last 24 hours” concerning the kidnapped BBC journalist Alan Johnston.

headline: Short Route to the Races
text: The triathlon season is in full swing, but it's not too late to start training to compete in one, even if you’re starting from the couch. First-timers should focus on the sprint events, such as the popular "short course" race at the Life Time Fitness Triathlon in Minneapolis on July 14. It features a 0.4-mile swim in Lake Nokomis, 15 miles on a bike, and then a 3-mile run around the lake. Seasoned triathletes seeking a more rigorous challenge can compete that day in Olympic-distance races that roughly triple the short-course lengths. For an extensive list of triathlon coaches, local clubs and events, visit the USA Triathlon Web site.

headline: Parents and District Settle Dispute on Teacher’s Religious Remarks
text: The Kearny Board of Education in New Jersey and the parents of Matthew LaClair, a 17-year-old junior at Kearny High School, settled their dispute on Tuesday night about a teacher who proselytized in class.

headline: It’s Her World, We’re Just Buying It
text: KATE MOSS pondered the question for a moment. Her shoulders heaved forward to hold up a wisp of fabric in a print of white barbed wire that could qualify as a dress only on her. She gestured beyond the colossal security guards in three-piece suits, the scruffy entourage, the D.J. girls with the cropped platinum hair wearing her little dresses, the waiters clearing the detritus of broken Champagne glasses left in their wake and the sea of gawking news-media types whirling in the background with notepads in hand. Then she said what she wanted:

headline: Poisoned Medicines (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column last Thursday about lawsuits over the ownership of the 16th-century diptych “Adam and Eve,” by Lucas Cranach the Elder, misstated the name of the organization that now owns it. It is the Norton Simon Art Foundation, not the Norton Simon Foundation. The report also misstated the painting’s history. The foundation bought it in the mid-1960s directly from an heir to the Stroganoff dynasty of Russia. It did not buy it at auction.

headline: Neither Rain Nor Love, Till a Guy Promises Both
text: Is it possible for a performance to be too good? Audra McDonald brings such breadth of skill and depth of feeling to the Roundabout Theater Company revival of “110 in the Shade” that she threatens to burst the seams of this small, homey musical. Ravishing of voice and Olympian of stature, she’s an overwhelming presence in an underwhelming show.

headline: Yanks Work Through Problems to Get Back to .500
text: In the American League East, the second-place Yankees remain closer to last place than to the first-place Boston Red Sox. But a sense of stability has returned to the Bronx, and it was evident last night in a methodical 6-2 victory over the Texas Rangers.

headline: Legal Victory by Militant Cuban Exile Brings Both Glee and Rage
text: MIAMI, May 9  An elderly exile linked to deadly bombings in Cuba and on a Cuban airliner was on his way back to Miami as a free man on Wednesday, his indictment on charges of immigration fraud dismissed by a federal judge in Texas.

headline: Heel Injury Forces Giambi to Sit as Lineup Shuffles
text: Jason Giambi, often the designated hitter and sometimes the first baseman, was out of the starting lineup because of a bone spur in his left heel last night when the Yankees played Texas in the second game of a three-game series at Yankee Stadium.

headline: New York City Renters Cope With Squeeze
text: Like the legions of aspiring poets, tap dancers and musicians who came before her, Nina Rubin, a 29-year-old graduate of Wesleyan University, has struggled to find halfway decent housing in New York. Earlier this year, she ended up in her most unusual home yet: an office.

headline: Mamet to Return to Theater of Politics
text: The last time David Mamet dipped his sharp pen into presidential politics was in 1997, when he was a co-author of the screenplay for “Wag the Dog,” about a — ahem — fictional president who tries to stage a fake war to distract from a damaging sex scandal.

headline: Visiting Troops, Cheney Gives Sober Case for Iraq War
text: BAGHDAD, May 10 — Vice President Dick Cheney spoke to American troops stationed near former Iraqi President Saddam Hussein’s birth place today, but the visit was far from a victory lap.

headline: Aspiring to the Throne
text: LAST Friday afternoon, Jamie Gray, the owner of the Brooklyn design boutique Matter, stood in an empty storefront in Lower Manhattan, scraping away at a stubborn plastic UV filter that covered the front window. The work was punishing — “hopefully there won’t be any scratches or blood loss,” he said, though he ended up calloused and bleeding — and very time consuming, considering he had less than two weeks left until the opening of Matter’s new Manhattan branch. A lot of problems remained to be dealt with, including glass doors he had trouble mounting on the display cases, and the important shipment of Established & Sons furniture stuck in customs limbo.

headline: In Guilty Plea, OxyContin Maker to Pay $600 Million
text: ABINGDON, Va., May 10 — The company that makes the narcotic painkiller OxyContin and three current and former executives pleaded guilty today in federal court here to criminal charges that they misled regulators, doctors and patients about the drug’s risk of addiction and its potential to be abused.

headline: Mahler Supplies the Emotions, Yet There Are No Guarantees
text: For an ensemble like the Philadelphia Orchestra, dazzling an audience with Mahler’s Second Symphony should be an easy night’s work. This orchestra has all the ingredients: the highly polished string sound that has traditionally been its strength; the solid, gleaming brass playing it has cultivated more recently; woodwinds that convey shapeliness and lyricism; and percussionists who aren’t afraid to play at full throttle.

headline: No Nook Unbuttered, No Slice Unturned
text: THE ideal breakfast consists of a cup of coffee, the newspaper and a toasted English muffin. All three should be consumed in silence.

headline: Pier 40’s Fields of Dreams (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sergeant Urinated on Body in Haditha
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 9  A marine sergeant testified on Wednesday that he urinated on the bloody remains of one of five unarmed Iraqi men whom his squad leader had fatally shot in late 2005 moments after a roadside bomb had killed one of their comrades in Haditha.

headline: Fed Leaves Key Interest Rate Unchanged
text: WASHINGTON, May 9  The Federal Reserve acknowledged today that the economy is slowing but offered little hint that it is ready to lower interest rates anytime soon.

headline: HBO Chief Executive Resigns After His Arrest
text: Time Warner announced this evening that Chris Albrecht, the chairman and chief executive of its Home Box Office unit, had agreed to resign at the company’s request, three days after he was arrested and charged with assaulting a girlfriend in a Las Vegas parking lot.

headline: Still Making Waves
