text: Shirtless and barefoot in his living room two summers ago, Kelly Slater was demonstrating the bodyweight movement inside a radical surf maneuver. I was interviewing Slater about his ongoing rivalry with Andy Irons for an article that ran in PLAY last summer, and Slater radiated balance and calm as he flowed across his floor like a tai chi master. This season, on surfing’s 2007 World Tour, Slater is showing the same form. Two competitions have been completed, with Irons finishing last in the first one and second in the next — typically erratic. Slater, meanwhile, landed a respectable third and then a fifth, putting him right on target for what many expect to be a slow, steady march to a ninth world title.

headline: Visas and Security (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Take Me to Your Designer
text: IN anticipation of commercial space tourism, which has been promised by several companies now busily competing to develop aircraft for suborbital flights as soon as 2009, this may be an appropriate moment to ask, what does one pack for space travel?

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: Sometimes Rock Belongs to the Quiet and the Shy
text: On Tuesday night at Town Hall, Ben Gibbard thanked his fans for coming to see him, and then he went further. “I know there’s a lot of stuff going on in town, especially with the Arcade Fire show tonight,” he said. For a moment, one of indie-rock’s most popular singer-songwriters sounded a little bit like a flight attendant: He knew we had our choice of concerts, and he thanked us for choosing his. (Somehow he refrained from wishing us a pleasant stay in New York, or wherever our final destination might be.)

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Henry and Eliza, Back on Broadway

headline: Some Leeway for Wolfowitz, Who Gets a Good Word From Rice
text: WASHINGTON, May 9 — Bowing to pressure from the Bush administration, the World Bank board agreed Wednesday to give Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank’s president, slightly more time to defend himself against charges of misconduct before the board decides his future.

headline: Death Finds a Crack in the Life of the Guys at the Social Club
text: Two old men in baseball caps sat in two old chairs in front of an old building under a warm sun. A passer-by on Classon Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant might have thought they were having a lovely and peaceful Monday, but that would have been way off.

headline: Putin Is Said to Compare U.S. Policies to Third Reich
text: MOSCOW, May 9 — President Vladimir V. Putin seemed to obliquely compare the foreign policy of the United States to the Third Reich in a speech on Wednesday commemorating the 62nd anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany.

headline: Bill Clinton Ponders a Role as First Gentleman
text: Bill Clinton plans to be a first gentleman for the 21st century: a post-modern, post-ego presidential spouse who does not earn an income of his own, but rather pays the bills from family savings and does what he can to help the missus down in the Oval Office.

headline: Straight From the Heart
text: Personal heart-rate monitors, which read your pulse and send the number to a wrist-watch-like display, were once balky and pricey. They’re now inexpensive, (starting around $50), reliable and featherweight. One sportswear company, Numetrex, is developing a workout shirt with heart-rate monitoring capabilities woven into the fabric. But does your average athlete need so much data? “Sure,” says Lindsay Hyman, a coach with Carmichael Training Systems who works with elite and professional athletes. “Heart rate helps you refine your training and track your fitness.” Most sporting goods stores sell monitors. To learn how to train with one, click around the Internet. The Tri-eCoach.com site has an estimable overview, as does the Flora London Marathon, which also, for $2.38, offers a downloadable heart-rate monitor guide.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Rhododendrons in Distress

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on April 16 about airline food in the special Business Travel section incorrectly attributed comments about a private-jet company, New York Aviation, and about business travelers in general. The comments, “We’ll go into the city and get dinner at Le Cirque if people want it,” about the services New York Aviation provides, and “As long as there’s booze on board, they’re happy,” referring to business travelers, were by Jack Gentile, founder of New York Aviation  not by Hector Adler, senior vice president for customer experience at Eos Airlines.

headline: I.B.M. Effort to Focus on Saving Energy
text: I.B.M. is beginning a $1-billion-a-year investment program intended to double the energy efficiency of its computer data centers and those of its corporate customers.

headline: Scot With Baggage Readies for Leader’s Role
text: LONDON, May 9 — With Prime Minister Tony Blair expected to announce Thursday his plans to step down as leader of the Labor Party, Britons seem set to trade the Great Communicator for the Great Puzzle — Mr. Blair’s likely successor, James Gordon Brown.

headline: Shortchanging the Census
text: The Bush presidency will be history in 2010, the year of the next nationwide census. But the administration’s influence on the count could nevertheless be profound — and not, it seems, for the better.

headline: The Minotaur and the Muse: Picasso’s Carmen Fixation
text: PARIS, May 9 — Mistresses and wives successively served as Pablo Picasso’s muses, but they were not enough. He also sought inspiration from fictional women. And who better than Carmen to personify the themes of sex, love, violence, tragedy and death that run through so much of his work?

headline: A Workers’ Compensation Fraud Case, on Tour in Europe
text: The bus driver was a drummer in a rock band.

headline: Fed Gives No Signal of Rate Shift
text: WASHINGTON, May 9 — The Federal Reserve acknowledged Wednesday that the economy was slowing, but offered little hint that it was ready to lower interest rates anytime soon.

headline: Text of the Fed’s Statement on Interest Rates
text: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed’s monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged.

headline: For Cycling Around Town, a Three-Speed Automatic
text: If you’ve walked into a bike shop recently, you’ve probably noticed how complicated bicycles have become. In an era of carbon fiber, 27 or more speeds and disc brakes, riding a bike is not the playful pastime it once was.

headline: Chief Agrees to Resign From HBO After Arrest
text: Time Warner announced last night that the chairman and chief executive of its Home Box Office unit, Chris Albrecht, had agreed to resign at the company’s request, three days after he was arrested and charged with assaulting a girlfriend in a Las Vegas parking lot.

headline: Gonzales Is Said to Seem Confident He Will Stay
text: WASHINGTON, May 9 — Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales appears increasingly confident that he will survive the crisis over the dismissal of federal prosecutors, as White House aides who view him as a liability see little point in trying to persuade President Bush to push him out, administration officials and Republican allies said.

headline: The Woman No Hat Could Tame
text: ISABELLA BLOW, the English eccentric and sorcerer of talent who died this week, was a completely implausible figure. You could not explain her and you could not reason with her. She was incredibly bright on the subject of fashion and rarefied tastes, a fact she wore on her sleeve and on her head. She loved a bustle, a corseted waist and a spectacular hat. And not for her the mushy-pea variety, the Ascot bonnet.

headline: China: Virus Suspected in Pig Deaths
text: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said Chinese officials had informed it that a pig epidemic was under control in Laosi, in southeastern Guangdong Province. China’s Ministry of Agriculture is conducting tests to determine if the disease is porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome, a viral disease that began attacking North American and European swine farms in the late 1980s and is the costliest virus for swine herds in the United States. The disease does not infect humans, the United Nations agency said. China reported a similar epidemic of the pig disease to the agency in September.

headline: Lottery Numbers
It Takes a Hammer to Grow This Salad
text: IF you love fresh greens, there is no reason not to grow them yourself, even if you have only a tiny terrace or handkerchief lawn.

headline: In Court, Details of Sex Play With Suspect
text: The beauty editor of W magazine testified yesterday about fantasy role-playing with Peter Braunstein, her boyfriend at the time, that foreshadowed his attack on another woman, in which he dressed as a firefighter, stripped her and put high heels on her while sexually molesting her.

headline: Aiming for a Drug-Free Workplace
text: There is no shortage of reasons employers test their workers for drugs. At one company, an employee high on marijuana forgot to lock the wheels on his forklift and it dropped five feet off a loading dock, while employees at another built a crystal meth lab in the back of a truck.

headline: As We Try to Foil Another 9/11 (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stomp, Sneeze, Grunt, Gasp and All That Body Language
text: The movement in David Parker’s new “Hour Upon the Stage,” as seen at Dance Theater Workshop on Tuesday, is on several cusps at once: between basic and virtuoso, between modern dance and ballet, between generating self-made rhythm and responding to other rhythms. The central gimmick is that the eight dancers (the Bang Group) themselves make most of the sounds: They slap, click, grunt, gasp, all in rhythmic patterns. But they don’t try to make a serious rhythmic accompaniment for one another.

headline: Trying to Connect Dots in Notorious Killing
text: For nearly 15 years it has endured among the more bizarre mysteries in Mafia lore, a competitive field if ever there was one: When a young couple from Queens  armed with an Uzi, a Mercury Topaz and a dream  ventured out to rob social clubs run by the mob, how exactly were they expecting things to end?

headline: Helping Immigrants, and a Town, Move Ahead
text: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y.

headline: Bush Says He’s Open to Iraq Bill With Benchmarks
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — President Bush offered his first public concession to try to resolve the impasse over Iraq war spending today, as he confronted new pressure from his own party over the conflict and House approval of a plan that would provide money for combat operations only through midsummer.

headline: House Democrats Raise New Criticism of Gonzales
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales endured new criticism on Capitol Hill today as House Democrats questioned his leadership of the Department of Justice and his personal candor.

headline: Ottawa, East Finalist, Asks: Canada, Where’s the Love?
text: When the Ottawa owner, Eugene Melnyk, told a local chamber of commerce gathering last week that he believed all of Canada should be rooting for the Senators because they were the last Canadian team left in the Stanley Cup playoffs, he was exercising a bit of wishful thinking.

headline: After a Museum Is Bombed, the Real Trouble Begins
text: In television’s war on terrorism you’re either with us or a wrongly accused pawn set up by a sinister, high-placed conspiracy.

headline: China Stocks, Rising Steeply, Test New Highs
text: SHANGHAI, May 9 — After another feverish day of buying in this country’s amazing bull run, share prices in China broke records again Wednesday, sending the benchmark Shanghai composite index past the 4,000-point level for the first time.

headline: Three Writers of Nonfiction Are Honored
text: Writing narrative nonfiction is grueling, lonely work haunted by the question of whether anyone will read the finished book. “You’re always worried, ‘Am I just banging my head against the wall?’ ” said Robert Whitaker, who on Tuesday night was awarded the J. Anthony Lukas Work in Progress Award for “Twelve Condemned to Die: Scipio Africanus Jones and the Struggle for Justice That Remade a Nation,” to be published by Crown.

headline: Bush Tours Tornado-Ravaged Town in Kansas and Promises Governor Help in Rebuilding
text: WASHINGTON, May 9  With memories of his administration’s flat-footed response to Hurricane Katrina still lingering, President Bush visited a tornado-wrecked patch of Kansas on Wednesday to pledge administration vigilance in recovery efforts.

headline: Boxing’s Big Night: What Was It We Saw?
text: The long estrangement between boxing and mainstream sports culture has made the actual fighting in a so-called superfight almost irrelevant. When a matchup catches the attention of the general sporting public and press, most casual observers are so out of practice at evaluating boxing that there’s almost no consideration of substance to offset the hype.

headline: Apolitical Justice Dept.? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Legal Advice Is a First Step in Setting Up Screening
text: Business owners interested in setting up a drug screening program should consult a lawyer first, as rules vary by state.

headline: Psychiatrists, Children and Drug Industry’s Role
text: When Anya Bailey developed an eating disorder after her 12th birthday, her mother took her to a psychiatrist at the University of Minnesota who prescribed a powerful antipsychotic drug called Risperdal.

headline: Accumulate This
text: IN 1947, the bodies of the reclusive, eccentric Collyer brothers were discovered in their Harlem brownstone, amid tons of newspapers, musical instruments, sofas, chandeliers — the fruits of 40 years of obsessive collecting.

headline: Feeling the Burn, and the Triumph, After Some Gritty Labors
text: When the members of Urban Bush Women took their bows at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night after “Walking with Pearl ... Africa Diaries,” they did not look like performers, though all are powerful dancers.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (BBCA) INNOCENT This British import from the producer of “State of Play” follows a team of law students as they re-examine the cases of those they believe wrongly convicted of serious crimes. Lloyd Owen (above, far left) plays their leader, Professor Jon Ford, a champion of the underdog who has established a legal center for those with nowhere else to turn. His team: the idealistic Adam (Luke Treadaway); the passionate Beth (Ruth Bradley); Nick (Oliver James), a charmer; Sarah (Christine Bottomley), who harbors a wealth of useless information; and Andrew (Stephen Graham), on sabbatical from a police department, who just might help the others grow up.

headline: Blogging for Truth and Beauty
text: MOST bloggers have never met a beauty product or treatment they didn’t love. The fill their columns with wildly enthusiastic prose about the latest blush, the newest procedure or research that they laud as cutting-edge.

headline: Child’s Play (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Radical Solutions for Paying the Rent in New York
text: With very low vacancy rates for apartments in New York, real estate brokers say radical solutions among young, well-educated newcomers to the city are becoming more common. Some new arrivals have even made homes in unoccupied office space.

headline: Pope Steps to the Microphone
text: Pope Benedict XVI gave the first substantial press conference of his two year papacy, 35,000 feet above Algeria (on a plane that was still 4,600 miles from his destination, Sao Paulo). He did not fail to make news, as he seemed to raise the possibility of excommunication for Catholic politicians who support abortion laws. The Vatican quickly issued clarifications, saying that the pope did not mean to make new policy: Now, as before, the question of whether a pro-choice Catholic politician receives communion rests with his or her individual conscience.

headline: Excerpts From 'Stuck in the Middle'
text: Selections from an anthology subtitled "Seventeen Comics From an Unpleasant Age."

headline: Here Comes the . . . Bill
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: YOO!
text: YOOMexico

headline: Henry and Eliza, Back on Broadway
text: The persnickety professor Henry Higgins and the courageous Cockney Eliza Doolittle will be at each other's throats once again in September, when the Roundabout Theater Company opens its 2007-8 season with a new production of George Bernard Shaw's "Pygmalion."

headline: Energy Investors Look to Private Equity Partners
text: Venture investors are searching for a new model for alternative energy deals, and partnerships with private equity funds may be part of the solution, The Deal reports. These investors want to get high returns on early developments so they are not diluted when the time comes for raising capital for building production facilities. Volatile energy prices only add to the uncertainty. “It’s a very difficult balancing act for venture capital investors in energy right now,” the head of the energy ventures group at Portland, Ore.-based law firm Stoel Rives tells The Deal.

headline: Rags to Royalty
text: Images from "Poiret: King of Fashion" at the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute.

headline: G.E. Buys Rest of Japan’s Sanyo Credit
text: General Electric said Wednesday that it had paid 126.3 billion yen ($1.05 billion) for the Japanese leasing company Sanyo Electric Credit. G.E. paid 3,250 yen a share for 97 percent of Sanyo Credit’s stock, the company said. The company bought the shares from Sanyo Electric and two Goldman Sachs units. G.E. is focusing on lending to companies after the Japanese government tightened consumer credit rules.

headline: Morgan Stanley Will Pay $8 Million to Settle Fraud Case
text: Morgan Stanley agreed Wednesday to pay nearly $8 million to settle federal fraud charges stemming from its reported failure to get retail stock investors the best prices possible on more than a million over-the-counter transactions.

headline: Supporting the King of Fashion
text: Photos from the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute Benefit Gala "Poiret: The King of Fashion."

headline: Microsoft to Invest in CareerBuilder Web Site
text: Microsoft said Wednesday that it would take a small equity stake in CareerBuilder, a popular job recruitment site operated by Tribune, Gannett and McClatchy. The deal deepens an existing partnership in a lucrative category of online classified advertising.

headline: Magna Chairman Confirms an Offer for Chrysler
text: Frank Stronach, the chairman of the auto parts maker Magna International, confirmed Wednesday that his company and Onex, a Canadian investment company, have made a bid for Chrysler, the struggling American unit of DaimlerChrysler.

headline: TomoTherapy Stock Makes Healthy Debut
text: Shares of TomoTherapy, a venture-backed maker of medical devices, rose 20 percent in their first day on the Nasdaq. It was the year’s second-largest initial public offering of a life-sciences company.

headline: Pressed by Police
text: Recent criminal cases have shown just how far the Japanese authorities will go in securing confessions.

headline: Defense Attacks Credibility of Black’s Former Associate
text: A defense lawyer in Conrad M. Black’s criminal fraud trial attacked the credibility of the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler, on Wednesday by pointing out the numerous times Mr. Radler had lied before he cut a deal with federal prosecutors.

headline: Rosneft Buys More Yukos Assets
text: A subsidiary of Russia’s state-controlled oil company Rosneft bought the remaining production and refining assets of bankrupt Yukos on Thursday at an auction for 165.5 billion rubles ($6.42 billion).

headline: 3i Has Record Year
text: 3i, the publicly listed British private equity firm, reaped a record 2.4 billion pounds ($4.8 billion) in sales proceeds from its investments in the past financial year, but expects returns from assets disposals to slow.

headline: UniCredit Sizes Up Societe Generale and Capitalia
text: UniCredit, Italy’s biggest bank, is on the hunt and has Societe Generale and Capitalia in its sights. The bank, which just 18 months ago shelled out $21 billion to take over the HVB Group of Germany, said it is considering making a move either on the French bank or the Italian lender, which is controlled by a group of investors including ABN Amro.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Leads $65 Million Round for CVRx
text: CVRx raised $65 million in a fourth round of funding as the company is poised to launch a pivotal clinical trial to win approval for the first implantable device for modulating high blood pressure. The deal brings total funding in the six-year-old company to $125 million.

headline: Freshly Launched Joost Scores $45 Million
text: That was fast. The online video site Joost, the latest venture by the founders of Skype, has raised $45 million in funding from four venture capital and media groups, just a week after introducing the service.

headline: Biotech on an M&A Tear
text: The pace of mergers and acquisitions in the biotechnology industry is expected to continue at a torrid pace through 2007, said panelists at the Biotechnology Industry Organization conference in Boston on Wednesday. The bullish forecast was issued after a recent Ernst & Young report found that biotech deals in the United States were valued at a record $23 billion in 2006 while high premiums drove the value of acquisitions to the second highest level in history.

headline: At Tribune Meeting, a Passing of the Torch
text: The torch, it seems, has been passed. During an annual meeting that The Chicago Tribune notes was more noteworthy for its symbolism than its substance, Tribune‘s chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, welcomed the Chicago billionaire Sam Zell to the Tribune board on Wednesday and all but said goodbye to its largest, most antagonistic shareholder, California’s Chandler family.

headline: Depite Mixed Results, I.P.O.’s from China Tempt Investors
text: In its IPO Report, MarketWatch.com notes that public offerings from Chinese companies listing in the United States are being well-received on Wall Street, although two new listings last week had mixed results.

headline: BlackBerry Curve
text: May 10 - The Curve is a pleasant and logical descendant of the Pearl.

headline: Northwest Creditors Approve Reorganization Plan
text: Taking another step toward leaving bankruptcy, Northwest Airlines said a majority of its creditors has approved its reorganization plan. Based on its unofficial count, 97 percent of the creditors that voted approved Northwest’s plan, the airline said.

headline: Dow Jones Inquiry Could Be Awkward for Hong Kong
text: Many in Hong Kong were surprised to learn that a local aristocrat and business magnate, David K.P. Li, may come under scrutiny in relation to stock trading ahead of Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion for Dow Jones. But the investigation by American regulators into the possible leak of confidential information could have wider effects, potentially damaging the city’s attempts to shake its reputation for financial regulations that are weaker than the West’s, The New York Times reports. Hong Kong only made insider trading a criminal offense in 2003, and has not yet brought any prosecutions under the statute.

headline: Amaranth Settles S.E.C. Charges
text: Amaranth Advisors, the hedge fund that collapsed last fall losing some $6 billion, has agreed to pay more than $716,000 to settle charges of violating securities rules, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday.

headline: S.E.C. to Weigh in On ‘Merrill Lynch Rule’
text: Wall Street brokerage firms are on edge awaiting a decision next week by the Securities and Exchange Commission’s chief, Christopher Cox, that could put nearly $300 billion of their client’s money in limbo.

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
text: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: The $1 C.E.O.: Narcissist or Everyman?
text: In an era of skyrocketing pay for chief executives and growing shareholder angst about it, a handful of C.E.O.s are opting to draw a $1 paycheck or none at all. Seven C.E.O.s in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index were paid $1 or less in 2006, including Apple‘s Steven P. Jobs and Google‘s Eric Schmidt.

headline: ABN Amro’s Finance Chief to Step Down
text: ABN Amro, the Dutch bank at the center of one of the biggest bidding wars in history, said Thursday that its chief financial officer, Hugh Scott-Barrett, would resign in August. News of Mr. Scott-Barrett’s departure came as ABN is trying to fend off an unsolicited $98 billion takeover approach so it can be acquired in a friendly deal by Barclays of Britain. ABN said late Wednesday it would appeal a decision in a Dutch court that halted the sale of the LaSalle Bank, its Chicago subsidiary, to the Bank of America. That side deal was widely seen as an attempt to drive off the rival bidding group, led by the Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: Is Alltel Out of Private Equity’s League?
text: Following a report that Alltel, a rural wireless telecom service provider, is being courted by a slew of private equity firms, TheDeal.com suggests that the company might be too healthy to be a viable candidate for a leveraged buyout.

headline: From Murdoch, Sweet Words, Not a Sweetened Bid
text: Rupert Murdoch, the chief executive of the News Corporation, on Wednesday defended his unsolicited offer for Dow Jones, which has run into opposition from the Bancroft family, the company’s controlling shareholders, and from Dow Jones employees.

headline: The Broad Scope of Broadway
text: The documentary "ShowBusiness" follows four Broadway musicals from rehearsal through the 2004 Tony Awards: "Caroline, or Change," "Taboo," "Avenue Q" and "Wicked." On top of the usual challenges (fund-raising, rewrites, tryouts, marketing), they all had to endure scrutiny by a Greek chorus of theater critics and gossip columnists. (The rogues' gallery includes Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood, critics for The New York Times, and The New York Post's dapper scorpion of a theater columnist, Michael Riedel.)

headline: Inverness Raises Bid for Biosite
text: In the continuing battle over Biosite, a maker of laboratory medical tests, Inverness Medical Innovations has raised its bid to $92.50 a share, topping a rival bid by Beckman Coulter. Biosite said Thursday that it had received a letter from Inverness, which already holds a stake of about 5 percent in the company.

headline: Apple Shareholders to Vote on Compensation Proposals
text: Even as its stock is riding high off the success of the iPod and anticipation of the iPhone, Apple will face some restive shareholders at its annual meeting Thursday, TheStreet.com reported. Labor unions who own Apple shares through pension funds, have put up proposals that require options to be priced on the day they are granted to eliminate the practice known as backdating; that give investors a nonbinding vote on executive compensation, known as “say on pay”; and that tie executive bonuses to the company’s stock performance.

headline: Cutting Hair and Cutting Remarks
text: In "The Salon" the normally vivacious Vivica A. Fox seems as artistically depleted as her surroundings: an urban beauty shop where cutting hair and cutting remarks go hand in hand. As Jenny, the beleaguered owner of a Baltimore beauty shop catering primarily to African-American women, Ms. Fox plays moderator to a relentless stream of high drama and low wit.

headline: Beats With a Meaning
text: Giving "inspirational" a good name, Matt Ruskin's vibrant and soulful documentary "The Hip Hop Project" sets its universal message to an inner-city beat. Named for the New York City youth program founded in 1999 by Chris Rolle, known as Kazi, a Bahamian orphan forced to grow up on the streets of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the movie follows his efforts to encourage at-risk teenagers to express themselves in verse rather than violence.

headline: Disney v. Hamas
text: An illegal Hamascot? The Los Angeles Times editorial page encourages Disney to sue Hamas over “Farfur, a Mickey Mouse clone that until recently hosted ‘Tomorrow’s Pioneers,’ a kids’ television show on Hamas’ Al Aqsa TV station.” The editorial quotes the “cartoon rodent” as saying, “We will liberate Al Aqsa, inshallah; we will liberate Iraq, inshallah; and we will liberate the Muslim countries invaded by murderers.” Could Disney’s ferocious army of copyright lawyers bring down a sponsor of international terrorism? Maybe:

headline: A Sense of Purpose Takes Flight
text: Nic Bettauer's low-budget "Duck" is going for that warm-and-feathery feeling generated by the best of the human-bird love stories, movies like "Fly Away Home" and "Paulie." But it doesn't come within quacking distance, partly because it tries too hard and partly because, frankly, ducks aren't all that endearing.

headline: The Cold Male Gaze
text: "Casting About," from the documentary filmmaker Barry J. Hershey ("The Empty Mirror"), is a record of casting calls for lead actresses in a dramatic feature that Mr. Hershey wrote but has yet to direct: a seemingly Hemingwayesque drama involving a wounded combat photographer, a nun, a dancer and a painter's model. From its opening montage of head shots through its fragments of auditions and between-performance chatter, "Casting About" is a solid documentary about how art is made.

headline: Rock Off the Radar
text: See the churches, lofts, galleries, museums and silos where you can hear music, far from New York's madding clubs.

headline: Blair Says He Will Leave Office in June
text: Prime Minister Tony Blair has announced that he will leave office on June 27 after a decade in power in which he sacrificed his popularity to the war in Iraq and struggled at home to improve schools, policing and hospitals.

headline: The Pillar: Isabella Blow
text: Her arrival at a fashion show usually set off a current of excitement: “Ah, there’s Isabella. What’s she got on?” It could be a McQueen couture dress, corseted and padded, so as to show off her figure. She wore McQueen better than anyone else; the clothes were realized on her in a way they were not on other women, and probably because she understood their entire aesthetic history. The meeting of Izzy Blow and Lee McQueen must have been one of those moments when you would have gladly consented to be a fly, just to observe the action. How would he have reacted to this woman? Knowing Izzy, she would have been smoking, the red lipstick stain going well up the paper. She would have almost certainly been wearing one of Philip Treacy’s hats; she had already recognized his talents. And her enthusiasm and energy would have been limitless, and a little terrifying.

headline: 2008: Giuliani’s Political Science Experiment
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani is about to test decades of Republican precedent. Rather than walking the abortion tightrope (“hate it” personally, support choice as public policy, but would nominate “strict constructionist” judges), Mr. Giuliani plans to forthrightly express his support for abortion rights in upcoming appearances, report The Times’s Adam Nagourney and Marc Santora. Will his strategic primary choices and post-9/11 leadership image be enough to help him clear this traditional hurdle?

headline: Orbitz Shoots for $750 Million I.P.O.
text: Back so soon?

headline: Giambi Sidelined but D.L. Not in Sight
text: Last night’s Yankees’ lineup had a slightly different look. Jason Giambi was not in it for the game against Texas at Yankee Stadium due to a bone spur on his left heel.

headline: Day of the Dead Tours in Mexico
text: I would like to travel to Oaxaca, Mexico and experience the festival of Día de los Muertos at the end of October/early November this year. Which groups offer good tours for this event?

headline: Asterisk or No Asterisk?
text: By MARJORIE CONNELLY

headline: Bulking Up in Baghdad
text: Strategies to stem Iraq’s insurgency can be debated, but few would disagree that no matter what tack is taken, the violence there is not about to come to a halt anytime soon. So the United States is taking steps to try to save more lives when the enemy lands a blow.

headline: Asking the Crowd to Spread the News
text: "Web 2.0," as I understand it, refers to Web sites whose contents are supplied by us, the people. What would Flickr be without its photos, YouTube without the videos, Craigslist without the ads, eBay without the auctions, TripAdvisor without people's travel reviews? These mega-sites would be only empty white pages if the audience didn't supply their materials.

headline: Carry On, Blair
Remembering a Plutonium Scare
text: The discovery of slightly elevated amounts of tetrachloroethylene, an industrial chemical also known as perc, in the water supply in Hollis, Queens, dredges up memories of past scares about the safety of the city’s water supply.

headline: Long Term Capital Alumni Form New Fund
text: Nine years after the math whizzes at Long Term Capital Management found themselves on the brink of a market-rattling collapse — which they narrowly averted thanks to a huge bailout by a consortium of banks — some of the hedge fund’s former employees are having a reunion of sorts. Bloomberg reports that Eric Rosenfeld, one of Long Term Capital’s co-founders, has joined with the fund’s former chief financial officer, Robert Shustak, and its former controller, Bruce Wilson, to open Quantitative Alternatives, which Bloomberg describes as a hedge fund that “uses computers to pick investments.” The fund apparently uses humans too: The Rye Brook, N.Y.-based firm is currently hiring research analysts and traders.

headline: Asking the Crowd to Spread the News
text: “Web 2.0,” as I understand it, refers to Web sites whose contents are supplied by us, the people. What would Flickr be without its photos, YouTube without the videos, Craigslist without the ads, eBay without the auctions, TripAdvisor without people’s travel reviews? These mega-sites would be only empty white pages if the audience didn’t supply their materials.

headline: Blair to Step Down
text: British Prime Minister Tony Blair announced that he would leave office on June 27 after a decade in power.

headline: Recent Openings
text: New shows in New York include "Deuce" and "God's Ear."

headline: Harvey Pitt on Insider Trading, Then and Now
text: The speed with which the Securities and Exchange Commission identified and took action against alleged insider trading in Dow Jones stock this week was “a phenomenal achievement,” Harvey Pitt, the S.E.C.’s former chairman, declared in an interview with The Wall Street Journal’s Law Blog. Mr. Pitt, who served from 2001 to 2003, said that “in the old days, it took a while to figure out who knew what, when and where. I would say enforcement is alive and well.”

headline: Goldman Unit Seeks to Sell Power Plants
text: Cogentrix Energy, an electricity producer owned by the investment bank Goldman Sachs, has put 14 power plants up for sale, the energy industry Web site SparkSpread reported Thursday. Cogentrix itself, which Goldman acquired in 2003 for $115 million, is not up for sale, the Web site said.

headline: Ferrari’s Surprise Move
text: Just when everyone expected to arrive at the first European race of the season – notice I avoid using that phrase “the start of the European season,” since this particular European season will only last two races before the circus moves on for the start of the North American season?! – and everyone expected to see all sorts of new motor homes representing various states of team dreams of grandeur…and when everyone expected that the most ostentatious display of the motor home art would likely come from McLaren, it turns out that the greatest example of motor home decadence yet to appear in the paddock comes from the team one least expected to see it come from: Ferrari. (That run-on Jamesian sentence, by the way, would be accept nowhere else today outside this blog…. My apologies.)

headline: At Last, Hope for Lonesome George
text: In the great quest to name Lonesome George’s new mate, I think the most promising new suggestions have come from those who know him best: the biologists who’ve been studying him. But readers also came up with some excellent nominations.

headline: Hamas, Fatah and Mickey Mouse
text: Last night, a Palestinian minister appeared to answer a torrent of outrage when he announced the suspension of a children’s television show starring a Mickey Mouse clone who spouts Islamist slogans.

headline: Better Than the First Time
text: Wil Nieves, the backup catcher for the Yankees, broke an 0-for-22 streak Wednesday night when he singled during the Yankees’ 6-2 victory over the Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Giambi Out Again
text: For the second consecutive game, Jason Giambi was not in the Yankees lineup due to a bone spur on his left heel. Manager Joe Torre said Giambi had a 10:30 a.m. appointment with a foot specialist but was expected back in time for this afternoon’s game with Texas.

headline: Two New Guilty Pleas in Insider Trading Case
text: A former Morgan Stanley compliance lawyer and her husband pleaded guilty to insider trading in federal court Thursday, the latest pleas in a wide-ranging investigation that has touched employees at some of Wall Street’s top firms.

headline: Budget: $123.9 billion
text: Time for The Empire Zone’s budget minute, where we distill a new 205-page budget analysis [pdf] from the comptroller’s office into four bullet points.

headline: There’s Going to Be a Ballpark There
text: Yankee Stadium’s upper deck has a classical sweep. Despite the remodeling of the 1970s, the look is traditional, with three rows of lights above the highest rows of seats and only the sky above the lights. On most days.

headline: Another Couple, Another Pair of Insider Trading Arrests
text: We’ve begin to think they might want to add a few words to the traditional wedding vow: ” ‘Til death — or insider trading charges — do us part.”

headline: About a World Bank Girl
text: With Paul D. Wolfowitz today getting more time to respond to charges that he mishandled his companion’s reassignment and pay package, it seemed like a good time to take a look at the woman in question, Shaha Ali Riza.

headline: A Private Equity Defender With a Taste for Mystery
text: Facing criticism from unions and lawmakers, the private equity industry has found a passionate champion on the Internet. The only problem is that it’s unclear who that person is. Percywalker.com, a financial blog of murky provenance, has entered the debate on the taxation of “carried interest,” a big source of fees for the people who run private equity funds. The blog claims to be written by a billionaire named Percival X. Walker, but when contacted last year by Forbes magazine — which failed to find any mention of Mr. Walker in public documents — the operator of the blog said: “I lack the desire to establish that I even exist.”

headline: Podcast: Zane Grey’s Manhattan Frontier
text: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

headline: 24/7 Media Confirms Hiring Investment Bank
text: The online marketing firm 24/7 Media on Wednesday disclosed that it has hired Lehman Brothers to help it assess “strategic alternatives,” adding credence to rampant speculation that the company is up for sale. The New York Post reported this week that both WPP Group, the London-based advertising and marketing group, and software gaint Microsoft were “leading contenders” to buy 24/7, which has a market capitalization of about $560 million.

headline: Posada Ever So Briefly Leads the A.L. in Hitting
text: When Jorge Posada batted for the Yankees in the fourth inning, the message beside his picture on the scoreboard said that he led the American League with a .360 batting average.

headline: Spitzer Camp: DiNapoli report ‘Misleading’
text: The Empire Zone weighs in with more news from the sizzling debate over the state budget. Is it $121 billion? Is it $123.9 billion?

headline: At Mogul’s Trial, Lies! Lies!! Lies!!!
text: F. David Radler must have known that testifying against his boss of 30 years wouldn’t be easy. But did he think it was going to get as heated as it did today?

headline: 'City of Trash' Ad
text: Items collected from California's freeways and shoulders are shown in this public service announcement.

headline: … And Yet MORE on Mozza
text: Following the publication Wednesday of my article on Pizzeria Mozza, I received several e-mails from readers that represented the kind of discussion — quibbles, observations, suggestions — that should be seen by more eyes than just my own. It’s the kind of discussion encouraged by, and often present on, this blog.

headline: Terroir
text: If you want to start an argument in the wine world – and believe me, it’s not hard to do – all you have to do is mention the word terroir. It is one of the most overused, overworked, misunderstood and misrepresented clichés in wine, though it does have some stiff competition.

headline: A Conspiracy So Vast
text: Overstock.com, which has a huge short position, has drawn my attention a few times in the past. (For blogs, see here. For columns, see here, here, here, and here.) I am attracted to the story because Patrick Byrne, the chief executive, has engaged in what he called a jihad against naked short sellers, who sell the shares without borrowing them, and has had some political success. I am more impressed by his jihad-making activity than by his corporate management, but he is certainly different from your average chief executive. He has sued an analyst firm, a hedge fund and most of the major Wall Street firms. An S.E.C. investigation is pending.

headline: Sustainability for Rich and Poor
text: Rich and poor countries are deeply divided on many fronts, but perhaps none more so than on the question of who should do what about human-caused global warming.

headline: Frank Torre Back in Intensive Care
text: Joe Torre, the Yankees manager, said Thursday that his brother, Frank, has returned to the intensive care unit of an area hospital due to an infection that followed a recent kidney transplant.

headline: Movie Minutes: '28 Weeks Later'
text: A. O. Scott, the Chief Movie Critic of the New York Times, reviews "28 Weeks Later," the sequel to the 2003 film "28 Days Later."

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Sleep Alone'
text: A. O. Scott, the Chief Movie Critic of the New York Times reviews "I Don't Want to Sleep Alone," set in the slums of Kuala Lumpur.

headline: Candidates Live, From MySpace to Yours
text: MySpace has it out for Iowa and New Hampshire. First, the social networking site announced that it would hold the first primary of 2008, letting its users pick their favorite candidate throughout the first two days of January. Now it’s trying to break the early primary states’ monopoly on intimate, unrehearsed meetings with the candidates by offering all 66 million of its unique monthly visitors the chance to participate in town hall forums with the presidential candidates.

headline: Giuliani’s Tough Week
text: First came the revelation that Rudolph W. Giuliani had given repeatedly to Planned Parenthood, furthering angering conservatives upset about his abortion stance. Then the Village Voice raised questions about whether he got a discount on four diamond rings commemorating the Yankees’ recent World Series rings. Could the week get any tougher for Mr. Giuliani?

headline: High Line Festival
text: Melena Ryzik of The Times hits the the opening night party of the High Line Festival.

headline: A White Tie Kind of Guy
text: So President Bush, it seems, confounded expectations and managed to keep it together for Queen Elizabeth II’s state visit this week. He didn’t slobber, chug-a-lug from an Evian bottle, spew bits of buttered roll or engage in any impromptu shoulder massages.

headline: Perils of an Ideological Presidency
text: That great pipe-puffing philosopher of the Nixon presidency, John Mitchell, once famously observed: “Watch what we do, not what we say.” In other words, forget the rhetoric and pay attention to the more telltale actions of what eventually became a disgraced administration.

headline: Mia, the Gold Medalist
text: Sports Illustrated has a terrific column about Mia Farrow, the champion of the campaign to pressure China to behave better in Darfur. Mia has been relentless on Darfur and has used her megaphone to back the “genocide Olympics” campaign. The idea isn’t to boycott the Olympics, but to make China realize that its Olympic dream will be marred if it continues to underwrite genocide in Sudan.

headline: The Real Darfur Puppy!
text: After my column Thursday lamented the lack of a photogenic puppy that could focus public sympathy on the Darfur genocide, I had this remarkable email from an American who until recently worked in Sudan. Call ABC News — finally they’ll cover the story!

headline: Mayweather Tries Broadcasting, but Ponders His Future
text: Floyd Mayweather would make a good boxing commentator.

headline: Facebook to Offer Free Classifieds
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 — Facebook, the social networking Web site, is adding free classified ad listings, putting it into competition with dozens of established companies like Craigslist and many newspapers.

headline: A Neighborhood of Colonials and Palm Trees
text: ANYONE who still considers St. Petersburg, Fla., the last stop before checking into a nursing home may be shocked by the transformation of this once sleepy Gulf Coast city. Construction cranes pierce the sky, topping off a series of new high-rise condominiums. Closer to the ground, daytime visitors tarry between art museums, a farmer’s market and the waterfront park, while young professionals pack restaurants and clubs at night.

headline: Realism, Both Magic and Downright Mean
text: Aside from the presence of a few cars and a biplane, the setting of “Disappearances” — Kingdom County in Vermont during the closing days of Prohibition in 1932 — might as well be 1870s Deadwood in the Black Hills of the Dakota Territory. In some ways life in rural New England was even more hardscrabble.

headline: Shareholders Give Ex-Chief the Blame for Ford Woes
text: WILMINGTON, Del., May 10  A group of Ford Motor shareholders took turns blaming the company’s executive chairman, William Clay Ford Jr., at the annual meeting Thursday, criticizing every decision he made as the former chief executive except one. That was his decision last September to hire a Boeing executive, Alan R. Mulally, as his successor.

headline: Romney Works to Put Skeptics’ Doubts to Rest
text: AMES, Iowa, May 10 — Bart Pals, a county chairman for Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign, had been given talking points to use when he introduced the former Massachusetts governor at an event in northern Iowa on Wednesday.

headline: Never Too Late to Vote
text: LAST month, Gov. Chet Culver of Iowa signed a bill authorizing Election Day registration, which allows previously unregistered voters with proper ID the opportunity to cast a ballot that day. This is a powerful tool to promote voting and, as secretaries of state of two states that already have this policy in place, we welcome Iowa in joining our ranks.

headline: Sabbatini’s Goal Is to Win Tournaments, Not Friends
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., May 10 — In a sport light on trash talk and heavy on backslapping, Rory Sabbatini is an anomaly in an oversized belt buckle.

headline: Juvenile Injustice
text: The United States made a disastrous miscalculation when it started automatically trying youthful offenders as adults instead of handling them through the juvenile courts. Prosecutors argued that the policy would get violent predators off the streets and deter further crime. But a new federally backed study shows that juveniles who do time as adults later commit more violent crime than those who are handled through the juvenile courts.

headline: Nature, Nature, Burning Bright (High-Def Cameras Frame Thy Fearful Symmetry)
text: When it comes right down to it, there are precious few DVDs of television series that a modern gentleman or lady absolutely must buy, bind and emboss, and shelve for all time. These include “My So-Called Life,” the British “Office,” the soon-to-be complete “Sopranos,” VH1’s “I Love New York” and “Friday Night Lights.” (That last acquisition should be made this summer, the minute the DVDs of that drama’s great first season — the first of many great seasons, surely — goes on sale.)

headline: A Loving Look at a Cinematic Tough Guy: Gangster, Hit Man, Gunslinger
text: Lee Marvin moved across the screen like a shark coming in for the kill. Long and lean, with shoulders that looked as wide as his hips and hair as silver as a bullet, he seemed built for speed. He roamed across genres, excelling at gangsters and cowboys. Romance was not his thing. He could make you laugh, at times uneasily, but it’s his bad men that stick in your head. They are scary as hell, sometimes seductively so, because their every punch and twist of the knife seems delivered not in the heat of violence but in its chill.

headline: Brewers Off to a Fast Start
text: He used to be one of them. Craig Counsell grew up a Milwaukee Brewers fan in Whitefish Bay, Wis., partly because of location, and partly because his father, John, worked for the team’s community relations department.

headline: Fisher Is a Father First, and a Jazz Player Later
text: OAKLAND, Calif., May 10 — Derek Fisher had 30 minutes Tuesday morning to decide whether to remove his daughter’s left eye.

headline: Because It’s Good for You, That’s Why
text: There are many ways for a writer to tell you to eat your vegetables: earnestly, humorously, scientifically, self-righteously, instructively or so voluptuously that the page practically reeks of fertilizer. Barbara Kingsolver’s way is both folksy and smart. While she is cogent and illuminating about serious matters of nutrition, Ms. Kingsolver also finds ways to convey what it’s like to be showered with friends’ plants as birthday gifts, regard a full supply of potatoes as “homeland security,” and fend off the amorous attention of a lovesick turkey hen.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about an ethics panel report clearing Gov. Jon S. Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey, of conflicts of interest in conducting state labor negotiations with a union led by a woman with whom he once had a romantic relationship referred incorrectly to The Times’s efforts to reach the governor’s office for comment. The reporter sent an e-mail message to a Corzine spokesman; he did not place phone calls. (The message was never delivered because of technical problems, but the reporter was not aware of that until the next day.)

headline: A Ski Community Where There’s No Such Thing as Too Much
text: THE homes at the Yellowstone Mountain Club would never be confused with the simple log cabins that once dotted the Old West.

headline: The Art of Political Damage Control
text: Is Senator Barack Obama mastering the art of political damage control?

headline: Blair Endorses Gordon Brown as His Successor
text: LONDON, May 11 — A day after announcing that he would step down in June, Prime Minister Tony Blair offered a fulsome if long-delayed endorsement today of Gordon Brown as his successor, calling him “an extraordinary and rare talent.”

headline: Electric Pulses, Instead of Shocks, Can Help Heart Patients
text: DENVER, May 10 — Many heart patients who believe that their lives have been saved by shocks from implanted defibrillators could have survived without a jolt from the devices, according to research presented here today at a meeting of heart specialists.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,371 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Republicans in Congress Press Bush for Sanctions on Sudan
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — In the latest attempt to exert pressure on Sudan over the killing in the Darfur region, a group of conservative to moderate Republicans in Congress demanded Thursday that President Bush impose sanctions against the government for its failure to rein in the violence.

headline: Ramos-Horta Wins East Timor’s Presidential Election
text: HONG KONG, May 11 — José Ramos-Horta won a decisive victory in East Timor’s presidential election this week, a significant move toward creating genuine multi-party democracy in the country and breaking the dominance of the political organization that largely led its struggle for independence, analysts and election observers said today.

headline: Earnhardt Drops Team Built by His Father to Become a Free Agent
text: MOORESVILLE, N.C., May 10 — Dale Earnhardt Jr., the son of a legend and the most popular driver in Nascar, has put himself on the open market for 2008. His free agency will send ripples throughout the sport, potentially affecting driver salaries, merchandise sales and even television ratings, not to mention the balance of power among race teams.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: NBC Orders Five Dramas for Next Season
text: NBC took the first steps toward rebuilding its prime-time schedule yesterday by ordering five new hours of drama programs, which will be part of the fall schedule the network plans to announce to advertisers on Monday.

headline: In Defense of the Right to a Defense
text: The distance from West 44th Street in Manhattan to Guantánamo Bay in Cuba is roughly 1,400 miles as the crow flies, assuming no grand detours by the crow. Metaphorically speaking, the distance between West 44th Street and Washington seems far greater right now.

headline: For the Record
text: A theater review on Monday about “Beauty on the Vine,” at the Harold Clurman Theater, referred incorrectly to the play’s sponsorship. Donna Karan contributed one costume and Lancôme made a small financial contribution. The play is not sponsored by “various cosmetic and fashion companies.”

headline: U.N. Security Council to Review Draft on Kosovo Independence
text: UNITED NATIONS, May 10  The United States and its European allies will circulate a draft Security Council resolution Friday to endorse a plan granting Kosovo supervised independence, Zalmay Khalilzad, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said Thursday.

headline: In Houston, Giuliani Defends Abortion Stance
text: HOUSTON, May 11 – Rudolph W. Giuliani directly challenged Republican Party orthodoxy on Friday, asserting that his support for abortion rights, gun control and gay rights should not disqualify him from winning the party’s presidential nomination and that Republicans need to be tolerant of dissenting views on those issues if they want to hold the White House.

headline: A Cheerleader for Brooklyn’s Treasury of Books
text: IF keeping intelligent tabs on the Brooklyn Public Library’s $92 million operating budget, 60 libraries, 1,100 full-time employees, five million circulating and reference items, and nearly 1.1 million cardholders — she thinks of them as shareholders in the New Age knowledge bank — is what passes for bookish these days, then Dionne Mack-Harvin is a consummate librarian.

headline: Punishing Court Day for Black’s Ex-Deputy
text: CHICAGO, May 10  F. David Radler, the chief witness against the media baron Conrad M. Black, endured more withering cross-examination on Thursday, and was again called a liar before a federal jury hearing the case against Mr. Black and others accused of stealing millions from the publishing company Hollinger International.

headline: The Somber Sound of Nondenominational Mysticism
text: Stretching time and collapsing space: That’s what Lisa Gerrard was up to when she performed at the Concert Hall at the New York Society for Ethical Culture on Wednesday night.

headline: Channeling Group Dynamics Fueled by the Power of Funk
After Scandal, Cycling Struggles for Sponsors
text: PARIS — With the Tour de France approaching this summer, the sport of cycling is taking brutal spills in corporate suites, where deals are made to sponsor competitions with little attention to return on investment.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (Sundance) MUTUAL APPRECIATION (2005) This “wonderful independent film” directed by Andrew Bujalski “looks like something that just came out of a time capsule, but there’s nothing dusty about it,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, comparing its “artfully artless, low-fi vibe” to the French New Wave and the East Village film scene of the late 1970s. Alan (Justin Rice, above), a musician whose band has just broken up, arrives in New York in pursuit of a rock ’n’ roll career. Seung-Min Lee, at his left, plays Sara, a radio D.J. who would like more from Alan than he wants to give; Mr. Bujalski is Lawrence, Alan’s best friend; and Rachel Clift is Ellie, Lawrence’s girlfriend — and the woman Alan would take, if he could. “It’s the sort of unassuming discovery that could get lost in a crowd or suffer from too much big love, and while it won’t save or change your life, it may make your heart swell,” Ms. Dargis wrote. “Its aim is modest and true.”

headline: Inquiry on New Jersey Prostitutes’ Deaths Slows, Frustrating Families
text: Nearly six months after the bodies of four prostitutes were found in a ditch on the outskirts of Atlantic City, tips have slowed to a trickle. The task force investigating the deaths, which used to gather every day after the gruesome discovery, now meets only twice a week.

headline: Awaiting Rock-Eating Beast, L.I.R.R. Tunnel Is Poised to Finish Trip to Grand Central
text: All the parts needed to build a mammoth tunnel-boring machine are crossing the Atlantic Ocean on a boat from Italy and are due to arrive tomorrow at the port in Newark.

headline: Bristol-Myers Agrees to Plead Guilty in Plavix Case
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb, the drug company, will plead guilty to criminal charges that it made false statements to the government — the same crime that landed Martha Stewart in prison — to end a federal antitrust investigation of its botched efforts to preserve a lucrative monopoly for the anti-clotting medicine Plavix.

headline: JetBlue’s Leader Is Giving Up Chief Executive Title
text: Everyone takes things personally, but David G. Neeleman is that rare corporate executive who admits to those feelings.

headline: U.S. Queries Filmmaker on Cuba Trip for Movie
text: LOS ANGELES, May 10 — Michael Moore, the provocative filmmaker who has made a career out of skewering automakers, gun enthusiasts and the Bush administration, is being investigated by the Treasury Department over a trip he made to Cuba for his new film, “Sicko.”

headline: Shots Fired at Residence of Aide to Pakistan’s Ousted Chief Judge
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 10 — Shots were fired early Thursday at the home of a lawyer for the suspended chief justice of Pakistan’s Supreme Court, government officials said.

headline: Toasting the Neighbors
text: WHO Ralph Erath, 45, an information technology help desk manager from Kennewick, Wash.

headline: What to Wear to a Revolution
text: “Poiret: King of Fashion,” the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s sumptuous survey of the designs of the French couturier Paul Poiret (1879-1944), will transform your understanding of the origin of modern fashion. Its radiant hand-painted silk backdrops may also increase your appreciation of the art of set design; they magically create an immersive beauty out of almost nothing.

headline: Britain: Fashion Legend Drank Weed Killer
text: Isabella Blow, the colorful and influential British fashion editor, talent spotter and aristocrat who died in a hospital in Gloucestershire on Monday, ended her life by drinking the herbicide paraquat, The Times of London reported on its Web site. It said that at the opening of an inquest into her death yesterday, the deputy Gloucestershire coroner, David Dooley, reported that after Ms. Blow, 48, was “found in a poorly state” on Saturday and taken to the hospital, “she told doctors she had taken paraquat, and tests proved positive for this liquid.” Further toxicological tests are to be done before a full inquest in October.

headline: Blair Choreographs End to a Stewardship Dogged by Iraq
text: LONDON, May 10 — He announced the end with much the same flourish as, 10 years ago, he initiated a decade in power that became known as his era. By turns pensive, boastful and humble, Tony Blair made a final pitch to his followers on Thursday to accept that, whatever else, he did what he thought was right.

headline: Corrections
text: The Shanghai Journal article on Tuesday, about competition among developers in Shanghai and elsewhere to construct the world’s tallest building, misidentified the builder of a 2,300-foot skyscraper in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, which will be the record-holder when completed. The skyscraper, called the Burj Dubai, is under construction by an international team that includes the Samsung Corporation of South Korea, the main contractor; Turner Construction International of New York; Skidmore, Owings and Merrill LLP, the Chicago-based architecture firm; and Emaar Properties, the Dubai-based developer that owns the property. The team does not include relatives of Osama bin Laden. (The Saudi Binladin Group, a construction company owned by Mr. bin Laden’s relatives, was a finalist in the bidding to build Burj Dubai but lost to the Samsung team).

headline: Duke Lacrosse Team Uses Work Ethic to Fix Image
text: DURHAM, N.C., May 9 — These are heady times for the Duke men’s lacrosse program. The Blue Devils earned their first top seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament, which begins Saturday. The team earned a cumulative 3.45 grade-point average during the fall semester, and by Sunday, its 13 seniors will have graduated.

headline: On Carrier in Gulf, Cheney Warns Iran
text: BRUSSELS, May 11 — Vice President Dick Cheney used the deck of an American aircraft carrier just 150 miles off Iran’s coast as the backdrop today to warn the country that the United States was prepared to use its naval power to keep Tehran from disrupting off oil routes or “gaining nuclear weapons and dominating this region.”

headline: Passage of Drug Safety Bill Was Common Goal for Two Very Different Senators
text: WASHINGTON, May 10  Legislation to beef up drug safety, passed by the Senate this week with only one dissenting vote, grew out of an extraordinary pact between two senators and a frantic effort by the pharmaceutical industry to avoid any disruption in the approval of new drugs.

headline: Correction: Old Kansas, Still Growing Tall
text: An article last Friday about the Flint Hills Scenic Byway in eastern Kansas misspelled the name of an anti-alcohol campaigner who was active a century ago in the area. She was Carry Nation, not Carrie, although she and others sometimes used that spelling.

headline: The Human Community
text: The conventional view of Tony Blair is that he was a talented New Labor leader whose career was sadly overshadowed by Iraq. But this is absurd. It’s like saying that an elephant is a talented animal whose virtues are sadly overshadowed by the fact that it’s big and has a trunk.

headline: Germany: Protests Over Raids
text: More than 5,000 people poured into the streets of several cities to protest a crackdown on leftist groups before a Group of 8 meeting in the city of Heiligendamm next month. The police in Hamburg clashed with demonstrators there, arresting eight people. Some opposition leaders criticized the raids, saying the police were trying to intimidate legitimate opponents of the meeting.

headline: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts yesterday about winners of the Lukas Prize Project Awards, which recognize excellence in nonfiction writing, misspelled the name of the foundation that jointly administers the prizes with the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. It is the Nieman Foundation for Journalism at Harvard University  not Neiman.

headline: U.S. Charges a Leading Chicago Political Figure With Fraud and Bribery
text: CHICAGO, May 10 — A powerful former alderman who in the 1980s led a bitter rebellion of white politicians against the city’s first black mayor was indicted Thursday on federal charges of fraud and bribery.

headline: Wildfire Threatens a California Resort Island
text: Firefighters struggled early today to prevent a wildfire from reaching homes on the edge of Santa Catalina Island’s main town, as residents and visitors fled the resort island off the Southern California coast.

headline: A Slow, Steady Approach to Governing in Corzine’s First Week Back
text: TRENTON, May 10 — When Mayor Jerramiah T. Healy of Jersey City listened to his messages last week, he was surprised to hear a 90-second one related to an environmental issue from someone who had just been released from the hospital: Gov. Jon S. Corzine.

headline: British Officers Won’t Be Disciplined Over Shooting
text: LONDON, May 11 — An official police oversight body ruled on Friday that 11 officers involved in the fatal shooting of a 27-year-old Brazilian electrician they allegedly mistook for a terrorist would not face disciplinary hearings.

headline: California: Ill Woman Is Dropping Marijuana Battle
text: A terminally ill woman who sued the United States government over the right to use medical marijuana, as state law allows, said she was dropping her five-year legal battle. The woman, Angel M. Raich, 41, of Oakland, said in a statement that she had decided to concentrate on radiation therapy to treat a brain tumor, rather than appealing a federal court ruling that she was not immune to federal prosecution despite California law. “I’m not a quitter, so this was a hard decision,” said Ms. Raich, who has never been prosecuted. She said she intended to take her battle to Congress.

headline: Civil Liberties Advocate Named Ombudsman for Texas Youth
text: HOUSTON, May 10  A leading civil liberties advocate was named Thursday as the first ombudsman of the Texas Youth Commission, after a sexual abuse scandal.

headline: Police Officer Accused of Killing His Girlfriend
text: A 37-year-old police officer was arrested last night in connection with the fatal shooting of his girlfriend on a Queens street after she broke up with him, the police said.

headline: The Sarkozy of the Future Jousts With the Chirac of the Past
text: PARIS, May 10 — Repentance for the sins of the past has come easy to President Jacques Chirac. He will be remembered as the first French leader to recognize the country’s crimes against Jews in World War II and to commemorate formally its complicity in African slavery.

headline: A Nobel for the Sandman
text: Minneapolis

headline: Puffing Away That PG Rating
text: LOS ANGELES, May 10 — WARNING: Smoking may be hazardous to your movie rating.

headline: Turkish Parliament Approves Direct National Vote for President
text: KONYA, Turkey, May 10 — The Turkish Parliament approved a constitutional amendment on Thursday that would allow the president to be elected in a direct nationwide vote.

headline: City Tests Idea of Building Apartments by Brooklyn Jail
text: City officials have devised what may be the ultimate test of demand for housing in New York: They are asking developers if they want to build apartments pressed up on the side of the Brooklyn House of Detention.

headline: Retailers Issue Gloomy Sales Report for April
text: It was, in a word, dismal.

headline: Senators Score Late and Often in Taking an Early Series Lead
text: BUFFALO, May 10 — For a player who has struggled to find a home in Ottawa’s lineup since the Senators traded for him in late February, Oleg Saprykin found himself in the perfect spot Thursday night to become the Senators’ most unlikely star.

headline: Carter Comes Close to Blaming Himself
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 10  Vince Carter had his entire arsenal going Thursday: the dismissive smirk, the practiced nonchalance, the mildly defensive monotone.

headline: Foiling a Ft. Dix Plot: Gumshoes, Not War (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sowing the Substance of Life
text: Living where we do, it can be hard to tell how ordinary our Sun is, shining dimly in our ordinary galaxy. Then comes something to remind us. This time it is a colossal supernova, called SN 2006gy, the brightest ever recorded. A supernova is an exploding star. This one, first observed last September, lies about 240 million light-years from us in the constellation Perseus. The explosion was perhaps 100 times more powerful than an ordinary supernova, and the star that exploded may have been 150 times the Sun’s mass, “freakishly massive,” as one astronomer put it. A photograph of SN 2006gy shows that it vastly outshines the entire galaxy in which it is located. This takes some imagining.

headline: Revisiting the True Story of a Battered Wife’s Revenge
text: With its tone of unremitting gentility “Provoked” may be the most restrained wife-beating drama ever to grace a movie screen. Based on the true story of Kiranjit Ahluwalia (played by the Bollywood star Aishwarya Rai), a London housewife from Punjab who killed her sleeping husband in 1989 using a homemade cocktail of gasoline and caustic soda, the movie is tasteful to a fault. Unfortunately, in keeping its inflammatory subject matter at arm’s length, “Provoked” does exactly the same to its audience.

headline: Elmira: Company Fined for Dumping
text: Kennedy Valve, an Elmira-based company that has been manufacturing fire hydrants since the 1890s, pleaded guilty yesterday in Chemung County Court to illegally dumping more than two tons of lead-contaminated waste from 2001 to 2004 in a county landfill that was not licensed to handle hazardous material. Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said the company claimed the material was not hazardous when it applied for a dumping permit. Samples of the waste were subsequently sent for analysis to laboratories that confirmed that it contained lead, Mr. Cuomo said. The company was fined $300,000 for unlawful dealing in hazardous wastes and agreed to pay $1.5 million to finance a lead removal program for children. Kennedy Valve is a division of McWane Inc., a manufacturer that has been convicted of safety and environmental violations in several states.

headline: U.S. Backs Off Limits on Guantánamo Lawyers
text: The Justice Department yesterday withdrew one of its proposals to tighten restrictions on lawyers representing detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, but said it would continue to press a federal appeals court for a series of other limits on the lawyers.

headline: Yankees Overwhelmed by Texas Rangers
text: In a decisive defeat, like the 14-2 loss the Texas Rangers handed the Yankees yesterday afternoon at Yankee Stadium, it might be an overstatement to cite one botched play as a turning point.

headline: Theater Listings
text: GAYFEST NYC June is Gay Pride month, so we can expect the usual variety of special events around the city leading up to the Pride Day march on June 24. But since this is New York, we don’t have to wait till next month — there’s fabulous gay entertainment whenever we want.

headline: Heading Toward Reform of the F.D.A.
text: The Senate passed a bill to reform the Food and Drug Administration this week by such an overwhelming margin  93 to 1  that some much needed changes now seem likely to gain full Congressional approval and become law. The downside is that an amendment to allow the import of safe and inexpensive prescription drugs from abroad had to be eviscerated to get a veto-proof majority.

headline: Manhattan: Change at Downtown Alliance
text: Eric J. Deutsch, president of the Downtown Alliance since 2005, will leave the organization for a private-sector job, the alliance announced this week. Mr. Deutsch, former president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation, will leave the Downtown Alliance, a business improvement district, on June 1 and become managing director at the Clarett Group, a real estate development company. The alliance did not announce a replacement yesterday.

headline: Give the Arab Peace Initiative a Chance
text: Beirut

headline: Afghans Say Civilian Toll in Strikes Is Much Higher Than Reported
text: HERAT, Afghanistan, May 10 — The toll of civilians killed in bombing by coalition forces on Tuesday night was much higher than the official figure of 21, and may be as high as 50 or even 80, residents reached by telephone said Thursday.

headline: People
text: Richard Levin, formerly of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, is joining Cravath, Swaine & Moore as a partner to head the firm’s new restructuring and insolvency practice. Mr. Levin was one of the principal authors of the 1978 federal bankruptcy code.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Seeks Limits on Cancer Patient Drugs
text: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 10  Bowing to safety concerns, government medical advisers urged on Thursday that additional restrictions be put on the use of drugs that treat anemia in cancer patients.

headline: In Monterey, Where Sea Lions and Children Are at Play
text: IT'S doubtful the Spanish explorer Juan Cabrillo was thinking “family friendly” when he spotted Monterey Bay in 1542. But these days it's hard to visit the relaxed seaside city of Monterey, about 120 miles south of San Francisco, and think anything else.

headline: A Tough Fight Still Looms, Cheney Warns G.I.’s in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, Friday, May 11 — Vice President Dick Cheney spoke Thursday to American troops stationed near Saddam Hussein’s birthplace, Tikrit, telling them in somber tones that they were the front line in the fight against global terrorism and making no promise that an end was in sight.

headline: Omaha’s Own (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Musical World Traveler Who Likes to Mix Things Up
text: Anat Cohen’s quartet was playing jazz at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, and it was jazz that imported elements from the Middle East and South America and the language of early-20th-century classical music. That’s impressive, but not so surprising; those elements have all become moving parts in a jazz composer’s vocabulary. More curiously, it was jazz that behaved like pop  determined, encased in strong melodies and played at medium-full projection  and the musicians were articulating every note.

headline: A Nuclear Reactor Reborn
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to reopen its Browns Ferry 1 nuclear reactor this month — 22 years after it was shut for safety reasons and 5 years after extensive renovations began.

headline: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the producer Scott Rudin referred incorrectly to the release date of his movie “The Manchurian Candidate.” It was released in July 2004; it was not among his movies that were released near the year-end holidays that year.

headline: Pope Addresses Brazil’s Youth and Meets With the President
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, May 10 — The 80-year-old pope, Benedict XVI, filled a stadium here on Thursday with 30,000 or more young Brazilians, whom he called “the future of the church and of humanity.”

headline: Blissful and Benighted: Dispatches From the War of the Sexes
text: Whatever wars may capture the headlines, the one that still fires the greatest passions is the battle of the sexes. In “Couples,” an evening of eight one-acts being presented at the WorkShop Theater Company, Rich Orloff offers brief updates on several skirmishes in that never-ending conflict.

headline: New Mayor but Familiar Issues on Dallas’s Horizon
text: DALLAS — The $69 margarita at N9NE Steakhouse in Ross Perot Jr.’s $3 billion Victory Park development is not the most expensive drink in town, but it is one way of toasting the better times that some see ahead for a long-struggling Big D.

headline: Movie Ratings Panel Will Assess Smoking
text: LOS ANGELES, May 10 — WARNING: Smoking may be hazardous to your movie rating.

headline: Conviction Is Vacated After 22 Years, but Murder Suspect Is Not Free to Go
text: Carmine Carini’s cousins were assassins. Prosecutors and Mafia defectors have credited them with numerous killings. One time they were ordered to kill a federal prosecutor but instead they killed his father, an administrative judge who handled parking tickets. They were killed for their blunder.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: The Making of Mayberry on the Outer Banks
text: WHEN asked whether he and his wife had been accepted into the tightknit community of Manteo, N.C., Fountain Odom chuckled.

headline: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Tuesday about the heavy debt incurred by culinary students who rely on student loans misstated the name of the California school attended by a student who returned to New York to help pay her bills. It is the California Culinary Academy, not the California Culinary Institute. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the format of the ShawGuides to culinary schools. It is published online; it is no longer a book.

headline: $350 Liquor? Just Spreading the Wealth
text: Steve Leuthold, a money manager out of Minneapolis, told his clients last month that he was appalled by something he had read in The New York Times.

headline: Government in Secret(1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Out of Chaos, Order. Or So Google Says.
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., May 10  Over the years, Google has carefully cultivated the image of a zany company in which innovation and new products  lots of new products  emerge from a bit of chaos.

headline: Bush and Democrats in Accord on Labor Rights in Trade Deals
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — The Bush administration and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, breaking a partisan impasse that had dragged on for months, reached an agreement this evening on the rights of workers overseas to join labor unions.

headline: Albany: Dispute Over Budget’s Size
text: State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli issued a report yesterday that said the state budget is $2.9 billion larger than previously thought, but Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s budget director, Paul E. Francis, responded that the comptroller’s numbers were inaccurate because he counted capital spending items not traditionally included in the budget. The governor’s office has estimated the budget at $121 billion, while the comptroller’s estimate is $124 billion, leading to a dispute over how much the state is spending. “The next step toward budget reform has to focus on spending restraint,” said Mr. DiNapoli, above. Mr. Spitzer opposed Mr. DiNapoli’s appointment to the comptroller’s office after the resignation of Alan G. Hevesi, saying that Mr. DiNapoli, then a Democratic assemblyman, did not have the knowledge of finance necessary for the job, but recently he has been more conciliatory.

headline: Lesley Blanch, 102, a Writer and Traveler, Dies
