text: Lesley Blanch, an English writer and traveler best known for “The Wilder Shores of Love,” a biography of four 19th-century women who cast aside convention to seek adventure and romance in the East, died on Monday in Menton, in the South of France. She was 102 and had lived in Menton for many years.

headline: Israel’s Foreign Minister Meets Egypt’s Chief; More Talks Set
text: CAIRO, May 10 — President Hosni Mubarak and Israel’s foreign minister, Tzipi Livni, met Thursday and agreed that a team of Arab officials would soon visit Israel to discuss a Saudi peace proposal endorsed by the members of the Arab League.

headline: Icon Vallarta and Pronghorn
text: Icon Vallarta

headline: JetBlue’s Founder Is Stepping Aside as Chief
text: JetBlue Airways said today its founder, David Neeleman, is stepping aside as chief executive officer and will be succeeded in that role by David Barger, Mr. Neeleman’s long-time No. 2 executive.

headline: In Support of Sex Attacker’s Insanity Plea, a Look at His Brain
text: Armed with rainbow-colored slides of Peter Braunstein’s brain, his defense lawyers yesterday presented what they said was scientific evidence that his transformation from witty, successful media writer at Women’s Wear Daily to sex abuse and kidnapping suspect was due not to criminality but to schizophrenia.

headline: Panel Seeks End of New Jersey’s Death Penalty
text: TRENTON, May 10  A State Senate committee passed a bill on Thursday that would make New Jersey the first state to abolish the death penalty since states began reinstating their capital punishment laws more than three decades ago.

headline: 6 Former Workers at a Day Trading Firm Are Acquitted
text: A federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday acquitted two former stockbrokers and four former employees of the A. B. Watley Group, a day trading firm, of securities fraud in what became known as the “squawk box” case.

headline: President Open to Benchmarks in Iraq Measure
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — Hours before the House approved a plan on Thursday to finance the Iraq war only through midsummer, President Bush offered his first public concession to try to resolve the impasse on war spending, acknowledging rising pressure from his own party and the public.

headline: Narcotic Maker Guilty of Deceit Over Marketing
text: ABINGDON, Va., May 10 — The company that makes the painkiller OxyContin and three of its current and former executives pleaded guilty Thursday in federal court here to criminal charges that it had misled doctors and patients when it claimed the drug was less likely to be abused than traditional narcotics.

headline: Manhattan: Police Clerk Charged With Theft
text: A civilian employee of the Police Department and two of his friends were charged yesterday with stealing about $30,000 worth of property that belonged to defendants and crime victims, prosecutors said. The employee, Kevin Byrd, 36, of Springfield Gardens, Queens, faces charges including grand larceny, forgery and criminal possession of stolen property, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. Mr. Byrd was the evidence and property control specialist for the 28th Precinct, in Harlem, Mr. Morgenthau said. He said that from October 2006 until January, Mr. Byrd forged vouchers for property and cash, and stole personal items, including a dead man’s wedding ring. Mr. Byrd’s friends  James Goorahoo, 37, of Springfield Gardens, and Jermal Williams, 36, of Laurelton, Queens  were also charged with grand larceny. Pretending to be crime victims, they exchanged the fake cash vouchers for checks at Police Headquarters, then split the money with Mr. Byrd, prosecutors said.

headline: For Life, Sometimes (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Vendors’ Removal Brings a Venezuelan Gem Back to Life
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 10 — “They made Caracas into Calcutta,” the Venezuelan writer Fausto Masó lamented in the epilogue of a recently reissued memoir of bohemian exploits in the 1970s and 1980s along Sabana Grande, the boulevard that once symbolized this city’s effervescent intellectual life.

headline: Laptops in the Classroom (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Restoring an Old House and Putting Down Deeper Roots
text: BOB Weinstein was happy in Sag Harbor, in the little gray house on Suffolk Street he had owned for a decade. It was a quiet second home on a lot thick with old-growth trees, away from the busiest parts of the roughly 260-year-old former whaling village on the South Fork of Long Island, but a short walk from a downtown lined with restaurants and small shops.

headline: Marine Says His Staff Misled Him on Killings
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 10 — The general who led a division in charge of the marines who killed 24 Iraqi civilians in Haditha in 2005 testified Thursday that he was kept from weighing accusations that the killings were illegal because his subordinate officers withheld information for nearly three months.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Ken Burns and Hispanic Groups Reach Agreement

headline: Purdue Will Reinvestigate Its Professor Who Claimed Desktop Fusion
text: Three months after it cleared him of research misconduct, Purdue University has begun a new inquiry into a professor who claims to have generated nuclear fusion in a desktop experiment, the university acknowledged yesterday.

headline: The Demimonde Doesn’t Vanish, It Just Changes Location
text: Here is information about some of the places mentioned:

headline: Drug Maker to Plead Guilty to Making False Statements
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that it would plead guilty to criminal charges that it made false statements to the government, a move meant to end a federal antitrust investigation of the drug maker’s botched efforts last year to preserve a lucrative monopoly for the anti-clotting medicine Plavix.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: For the Record
text: A report in the National Briefing column in some editions on Tuesday, about the Smithsonian Institution’s search for a new secretary, referred incorrectly to the status of Walter E. Massey, a member of the search committee. His reappointment to the board of regents is pending before Congress; he has not been a regent since his term ended in March. The report also misstated the title of Roger W. Sant, also on the search committee. He is chairman of the regent executive committee, not chairman emeritus.

headline: Bush Expected to Renew Term of Chairman of Joint Chiefs
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — President Bush is expected to nominate Gen. Peter Pace of the Marines for a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, opting for continuity during a critical phase in the Iraq conflict, two Defense Department officials said on Thursday.

headline: Corrections
text: The Shanghai Journal article on Tuesday, about competition among developers in Shanghai and elsewhere to construct the world’s tallest building, misidentified the builder of a 2,300-foot skyscraper in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, which will be the record-holder when completed. The skyscraper, called the Burj Dubai, is under construction by an international team that includes the Samsung Corporation of South Korea, the main contractor; Turner Construction International of New York; Skidmore, Owings and Merrill LLP, the Chicago-based architecture firm; and Emaar Properties, the Dubai-based developer that owns the property. The team does not include relatives of Osama bin Laden. (The Saudi Binladin Group, a construction company owned by Mr. bin Laden’s relatives, was a finalist in the bidding to build Burj Dubai but lost to the Samsung team). (Go to Article)

headline: Trade Deficit Hits a Six-Month High
text: Rising oil prices and a surge in pharmaceutical imports contributed to a significant widening of the nation’s trade deficit in March, the government said today.

headline: National Guard to Patrol PATH Stations
text: Up to 40 National Guard troops will begin patrolling 13 PATH stations in New York and New Jersey starting next week, similar to programs already under way at Penn Station and Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Mother Nature’s Helpers
text: IF you love the outdoors but are bored just lying in the sun, try traipsing the wilderness as a citizen scientist — no degree required. Summer is high season for the kind of naturalists’ adventures that pair amateurs with researchers to collect information and restore wild areas. On one level, it’s volunteer work — making a contribution to scholarship or cleaning up an environment. On another, it’s a good time in the outdoors with like-minded people.

headline: Guggenheim Foundation Takes Steps to Preserve Its Artistic Legacy
text: As the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation gears up for its 70th anniversary next month, its officials have been pondering its legacy. To preserve the collection that the foundation got from Solomon R. Guggenheim, a copper mining magnate who died in 1949, it has designated 620 works by more than 60 artists as the Solomon R. Guggenheim Founding Collection. Each will be noted on its wall label.

headline: Quest for a Title Pulls Them Back In
text: The Yankees didn’t look much like the “anything else is a failure” championship team yesterday that will eventually justify the enormous expenditure for a certain 44-year-old, six-inning starting pitcher soon to rejoin them.

headline: Lottery Numbers
State Closes Coal-Fired Plant That Failed to Limit Emissions
text: STONY POINT, N.Y., May 10  Four years ago, a company that owns two local power plants settled a lawsuit with New York State by agreeing to install $100 million worth of pollution control technology at one of them, its coal-fired plant here, or shut it down.

headline: Art in Review
text: MYRON STOUT  Washburn Gallery 20 West 57th Street, Manhattan Through June 29

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

headline: In the Big House ... Just Visiting
text: A FEW blocks from the Philadelphia Museum of Art, a massive, crumbling building rises up like a medieval castle over blocks of modest, middle-class homes mixed with brownstones. Complete with ivy-covered walls, a tower and corner battlements, it casts a forbidding shadow over the city — as it was meant to. Built in 1829, this hulking pile of stone was Pennsylvania's Eastern State Penitentiary, a cautionary landmark for nearly a century and a half, the place nobody wanted to go.

headline: Latin Food at Yankee Stadium. Now, How About That!
text: In the Bronx, Latin food has always been easy to find. But not in Yankee Stadium. It has been one place in the majority-Hispanic borough where the only thing that came close to qualifying as authentic Latin fare was an order of nachos.

headline: Manhattan: Firefighters Ratify Contract
text: New York City’s largest fire union announced yesterday that its members had voted to ratify a 24-month contract that gives raises totaling 8.16 percent. The union, the Uniformed Firefighters Association, said the vote was 4,037 to 3,115 to approve the deal, which raises starting pay by $9,900 to $35,000 and increases base salary after five years on the job to $68,475. The deal is retroactive to Aug. 1, 2006 and runs through July 31, 2008. To help finance the raises, the agreement calls for new firefighters to receive lower night differential pay and six fewer paid holidays each year during their first five years on the job.

headline: For the Record
text: A music column on May 1 about the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival referred incorrectly to a song performed by Bonnie Raitt, “God Was in the Water.” It is by Randall Bramblett and Davis Causey, not by Ms. Raitt.

headline: Guilty Pleas and Charges Filed in 2 Couples’ Insider Cases
text: What is it about married couples and insider trading?

headline: Pressed by Police, Even Innocent Confess in Japan
text: SHIBUSHI, Japan — The suspects in a vote-buying case in this small town in western Japan were subjected to repeated interrogations and, in several instances, months of pretrial detention. The police ordered one woman to shout her confession out a window and forced one man to stomp on the names of his loved ones.

headline: Bidding War Expected for Earnhardt Jr.’s Services
text: MOORESVILLE, N.C., May 10 - Dale Earnhardt Jr., the most popular driver in Nascar, announced Thursday he will leave the race team his father built and will listen to all offers as he looks for a new team to drive for in 2008.

headline: Queens: Officer Arrested in Slaying
text: An off-duty police officer was arrested for fatally shooting his 22-year-old girlfriend in the head last night on a Queens street, according to Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman. The girlfriend reportedly wanted to break up with the officer, investigators said. Witnesses said they saw the officer and his girlfriend fighting on the street, near the intersection of Atlantic Avenue and 82nd Street, shortly before 8 p.m. The woman broke away from the conversation, then the man took out his gun, ran up to her and shot her in the head, according to witnesses. She was declared dead at the scene. It was unclear last night what the charges against the officer would be. The police were not releasing the names of the officer or the woman.

headline: Israel’s Bombing of Civilians Extended War, Olmert Told Panel
text: JERUSALEM, May 10 — In confidential testimony on last summer’s war with the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said that the Israeli killing of a group of civilians in Qana in late July was a turning point that delayed a diplomatic resolution.

headline: For the Record
text: A report in the Sports Briefing column yesterday about the College Football Hall of Fame’s newest inductees misidentified the university affiliation of Herb Deromedi, a coach who will be enshrined. He coached at Central Michigan, not Eastern Michigan.

headline: New London: Threat on Chalkboard Investigated
text: The police are investigating a threatening message found on a Connecticut College chalkboard Wednesday that seemed to make reference to the recent deadly rampage at Virginia Tech. Discovered at 6:34 a.m. by a campus security officer, the chalked message said, “V.T.” and “I can kill more than that.” Eric Cardenas, a spokesman for Connecticut College, said the New London police and the campus safety department were investigating. “At this point, our best assessment is that it was a very ill-advised prank, but we’re taking it seriously,” he said. Classes at the private four-year college end this week, but Mr. Cardenas said the Fanning Hall classroom, where the message was found, would not be used again this semester. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: From Wales, Tales of Berlin Then and Bethlehem Now
text: That historic cry “The British are coming!” could be used these days as a fanfare to herald each new Broadway season. British plays, British directors, British actors — even British productions of American classics — are such a familiar feature of the landscape that it was hardly surprising when Richard M. Nixon, that scowling gray ghost of American history, arrived on Broadway this year carrying a British passport, in the London-born “Frost/Nixon.”

headline: Chasing an Old Flame, Taking No Prisoners
text: It may look like heaven, but the spacious loft that houses Sunburst Communications — the new-age Ohio advertising agency where much of the comic mischief in “The Ex” is hatched — is a viper’s nest.

headline: California: Plan to Privatize Lottery
text: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger will propose privatizing the state’s lottery as a way to generate money to pay down debt and finance his public works spending and health care proposals, a spokesman said. Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican, will detail the lottery proposal on Sunday when he revises his budget for the coming fiscal year, said the spokesman, Adam Mendelsohn. Under the plan, the state would lease the lottery to a private company in exchange for as much as $37 billion in either a lump sum or in payments.

headline: You Go to a Fight, and a Boston Pops Concert Breaks Out
text: It was Lockhart on the mound, Gigi at the plate and Folds on deck. Play was halted when fans started fighting in the upper deck of Fenway Park. Wait, make that Symphony Hall, the buttoned-down bastion of proper Bostonians.

headline: Dairy Council to End Ad Campaign That Linked Drinking Milk With Weight Loss
text: A national advertising campaign that associates dairy products with weight loss will be curtailed because research does not support the claim, according to the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: Kirstein’s Lust for Art and Artists
text: Tucked away on the top floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art is another centenary tribute, in a season of them, to the man who brought George Balanchine to the United States. Lincoln Kirstein (1907-1996) is best remembered for founding with Balanchine the New York City Ballet and the School of American Ballet. But as a friend of his put it, he had “more arms than Shiva.”

headline: To Raise a Down Syndrome Child (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pope Canonizes Brazil’s First Native-Born Saint
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, May 11 — After canonizing Brazil’s first native-born saint and receiving a bracing dose of Brazilian-style religious fervor at an outdoor mass here today, Pope Benedict XVI called for more forceful evangelization efforts throughout Latin America to counter growing conversions to Pentecostal Protestant groups.

headline: Citing Lighter Penalties, Titan Is Appealing Ban
text: When Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones was suspended last month for the 2007 season, an appeal of the punishment seemed unlikely.

headline: Highway Debris, Long an Eyesore, Grows as Hazard
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 — It was just another California rush hour. On eastbound Interstate 580 near Pleasanton recently, a rocking chair brought traffic to a near-standstill, while on southbound I-680 near Walnut Creek, a trampoline blocked two left lanes, wreaking havoc on the morning commute. Bagged loaves of sourdough bread blocked U.S. 101, near Petaluma. The highway patrol had to be dispatched.

headline: $45 Million Invested in Internet TV Venture
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10  Joost, a start-up that delivers television programming over the Internet, said Thursday that it had received $45 million in financing from venture capitalists and content partners including CBS and Viacom.

headline: Feliciano Uses Guile to Aid the Mets
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 — When Pedro Feliciano played a season in Japan, he had a daily routine. He threw. Then he threw some more. After throwing, he would throw and then throw again.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Monday about two minority partners in Dow Jones & Company who criticized a takeover attempt by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation referred incorrectly to the ownership of Dow Jones’s Class B stock, which has 10 times the voting power of a regular share. The Ottaway and Bancroft families are the largest owners of Class B shares, they are not the sole owners. (Shareholders were given Class B shares in the 1980s.)

headline: Washington: Whistle-Blower Ordered to Be Reinstated
text: The federal Merit Systems Protection Board has ordered the Smithsonian Institution to reinstate a whistle-blower fired in 2002. The board rejected an appeal from the Smithsonian, ruling Wednesday that “the administrative judge made no error in law or regulation” in finding that the whistle-blower, Michael D. Cross, had been fired for reporting illegal activities at the National Air and Space Museum, specifically that supervisors had told employees to do work outside their official duties.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Theodore Maiman, 79, Dies; Demonstrated First Laser
text: Theodore H. Maiman, a physicist who on May 16, 1960, demonstrated the world’s first laser, a device small enough to fit in his hand, died on May 5 in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 79.

headline: Some Unrest Is Bubbling Beneath the Top Tier
text: VENTURE capitalists are enjoying growing prominence and swelling investment coffers, and they are taking and receiving credit for considerable job and wealth creation.

headline: Spellings Rejects Criticism on Student Loan Scandal
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — With scandal rattling the $85 billion student loan industry, Education Secretary Margaret Spellings argued at a House hearing on Thursday that she lacked legal authority to clamp down on many abuses.

headline: Hey, California Girl, Don’t Mess With Grandma
text: “Georgia Rule,” in which Jane Fonda washes Lindsay Lohan’s mouth out with soap, might easily have been a tepid, sudsy puddle of easy sentiment and soft comedy. Three generations of women  Ms. Fonda and Ms. Lohan are Georgia and Rachel, grandmother and granddaughter, with Felicity Huffman in between them as Lilly, Georgia’s daughter and Rachel’s mom  fuss, fail to communicate and, in the end, forgive one another. Small-town values triumph over flashy, big-city California relativism, as happens exclusively (and frequently) in Hollywood movies. You’ve seen it all before.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: ‘MISS NELSON HAS A FIELD DAY’ Some children are lucky enough to have a Miss Nelson: a sweet, sympathetic elementary school teacher who guides them gently over the rough spots in their paths toward higher education. Others must confront a Miss Swamp: an unforgiving, terror-inducing martinet whose tone and manner are as sharp and stinging as a rap across the knuckles with a ruler.

headline: Queens Man Charged With Robbing Bishop
text: A St. Albans man was arraigned Wednesday night on charges of robbing the bishop of a Queens church and later assaulting a woman and an off-duty police officer at a restaurant, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Oluwafemi Olowofela, 25, of 194th Street, was charged with robbery, burglary and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Olowofela is accused of robbing the Rev. Melvin Artis, 67, at gunpoint on Tuesday afternoon inside the Greater Universal Highway Deliverance Church on Linden Boulevard. He is also charged with attacking a 43-year-old woman later that day, and fighting with Officer Malik Kirkland, who came to her aid and apprehended him, Mr. Brown said.

headline: Europeans Press Wolfowitz to Quit as Bank Chief
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — European leaders have told the Bush administration that Paul D. Wolfowitz must resign as president of the World Bank in order to avoid a vote next week by the bank’s board declaring that he no longer has its confidence to function as the bank’s leader, European officials said Thursday.

headline: Mixed Mood on Campus at Va. Tech Graduation
text: BLACKSBURG, Va., May 11 — Commencement at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute was supposed to be a moment for parents to watch their children take a symbolic step. From a youthful safe haven, students would graduate into a larger and less predictable world.

headline: Hamas, Fatah Gunfight Leaves 10 Wounded
text: JERUSALEM, May 11 — In the worst factional violence in nearly two months, Hamas and Fatah gunmen shot at each other today in the Gaza Strip, wounding at least 10 people and putting new strains on the Palestinian “unity” government in which both parties participate.

headline: ABN Amro Executive Resigns
text: LONDON, May 10 — ABN Amro, the Dutch bank that is the target of one of the world’s largest takeover battles, said Thursday that Hugh Y. Scott-Barrett, its chief financial officer, had handed in his resignation, amid other departures from the bank.

headline: Man Convicted in 1993 Restaurant Killings
text: CHICAGO, May 10  A man was convicted Thursday of murdering seven people at a restaurant in 1993, a crime that shook a quiet suburb and stumped investigators for years.

headline: Iraq Petition Presses for Withdrawal of U.S. Troops
text: BAGHDAD, May 11 — A majority of Iraq’s parliament has signed a petition for a legislative timetable governing a withdrawal of American troops from Iraq, several parliamentarians said today.

headline: Bush and Democrats in Accord on Trade Deals
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — The Bush administration reached agreement on Thursday with the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and other Democrats to attach environmental and worker protections in several pending trade accords, clearing the way for early passage of some pacts and improving prospects for others.

headline: Qaeda Presence in Pakistan Worries Britain
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, May 10 — A senior British diplomat said Thursday that his government was greatly concerned about the continued ability of leaders of Al Qaeda hiding in Pakistan’s northwestern tribal region to direct terrorist operations across the world.

headline: Note From Guantánamo (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: At Vonage, Sales Increase as Litigation Clouds Future
text: Vonage said yesterday that its quarterly loss narrowed and sales rose 64 percent amid a fierce legal battle with Verizon Communications that has left its future in question.

headline: Mr. Bush Alone
text: The difference between mainstream hawks and mainstream doves on Iraq seems to have boiled down to two months, with House Democrats now demanding visible progress by July while moderate Republicans are willing to give White House policies until September, but no longer, to show results.

headline: We Are New Orleans (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, the NYC column last Friday  about Peter Kaufman, who takes action against air-conditioned commercial buildings that waste energy by keeping their doors open in the summer  referred incorrectly in some copies to comments from Robert W. Walsh, New York’s commissioner of small business services, on proposed legislation that would fine violators. His comments  that before resorting to bans and fines, the city should educate the wastrels about the harm they do  should have been rendered as a paraphrase, not as a direct quotation.

headline: Vonage Narrows Loss and Increases Sales
text: Vonage said today that its first-quarter loss narrowed and that sales rose 64 percent despite a fierce legal battle with Verizon Communications that has left the company’s future in question.

headline: Panel to Look at Conflicts in Consulting
text: Members of Congress are looking into the potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do other lucrative work for the companies whose pay they help devise.

headline: Sotheby’s and Its Landlord Battle Over Building’s Sale
text: It sure looked like a perfect match in 2002.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: VALUED, BUT NOT SO VALUABLE

headline: Intimate Nooks Filled With Unexpected Treasures
text: Once again the International Fine Art Fair is filling the Seventh Regiment Armory with booths of swanky art from the 14th century through the 20th. Organized by the Londoners Brian and Anna Haughton, it is surprisingly intimate as far as art fairs go. The booths are decorated to resemble European period homes and palace parlors. The invitation-only top-shelf dealers  60 this year  from Europe, America and Japan all specialize in painting and drawing. There is some sculpture floating about too, but in no way does it match the quality and intensity of the artwork on the walls.

headline: Democrats Push Gonzales on Attorney Dismissals
text: WASHINGTON, May 10 — House Democrats pressed Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales at a hearing on Thursday to provide specifics about why federal prosecutors had been dismissed, but he stuck to his past assertions that, although ineptly handled, the dismissals were justified and appropriate.

headline: Contaminated Water in Queens Is a Repeat Performance
text: The area in Queens where city officials found an industrial chemical in the drinking water last week has had problems with contamination by the same chemical for several years.

headline: Relatives Noticed Changes in Accused Plotters
text: PHILADELPHIA, May 10  Ramiz Duka said his three cousins started to change two to three years ago. Three young men who had grown up with more American friends than fellow ethnic Albanian immigrants began to lecture other Muslims about religion.

headline: 6 Charged in Fort Dix Plot Held Without Bail
text: CAMDEN, N.J., May 11 — Six Muslim men from New Jersey and Philadelphia charged with plotting to attack Fort Dix with automatic weapons were ordered held without bail today by a federal magistrate here.

headline: Canadian Pension Funds Becoming Buyout Players
text: TORONTO, May 10 — Public pension funds have long been big investors in private equity. Now, some big Canadian pension funds are taking a page from the private equity playback and taking the lead in buyouts.

headline: Retail Sales Fell Sharply Last Month
text: From department stores to discount chains, sales were dismal last month, suggesting that rising gas prices and the flagging housing market are starting to weigh on American consumers.

headline: The N.F.L. Loses a Cable Ruling
text: A Manhattan Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Comcast, the nation’s largest cable operator, can carry the NFL Network on a digital sports tier. The decision could roil the channel’s goal to be carried on the levels of digital distribution that would give it the greatest number of subscribers.

headline: Off the Beaten Beat
text: ON Monday night inside the GlassLands Gallery, a converted warehouse in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 100 or so people, alerted by MySpace pages and music blogs, gathered for a concert by the Yeah Yeah Yeahs. For an hour, the singer Karen O yelped and shrieked and pranced around a makeshift stage in a paint-splattered gold bodysuit, often wading into the audience a few feet away. At the end of the night the band took requests; to close the set, as her band mates played on, Ms. O paraded most of the crowd toward an alley behind the building, a musical moment as intimate as a reigning rock star can have.

headline: Bronx: Shooting Leaves One Dead and One Hurt
text: One man was fatally shot and another was critically wounded yesterday afternoon in an apartment building at 1143 Noble Avenue, the police said. The men, who were not identified by the police, were found in a hallway of the building at 2:42 p.m. One of the men, who had been shot in the head, was declared dead on arrival at Jacobi Medical Center. The other man, shot in the torso, remained in critical condition last night at Jacobi.

headline: Rate in Europe Held Steady; Currency Rise Stirs Concern
text: FRANKFURT, May 10  The European Central Bank on Thursday signaled that it would lift borrowing costs as early as June to prevent a robust European economy from stoking inflation, even as the surging euro begins to crimp corporate profits and slow exports.

headline: From Little Clubs to Big Halls, an Indie Band Evolves
text: “There’s only about four security guards,” said Win Butler, near the end of Arcade Fire’s show at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night. And so, he added, if fans wanted to rush toward the stage, “it’d be pretty easy.”

headline: Harlem’s Cultural Anchor in a Sea of Ideas
text: YOU could almost see the ghosts among the new furniture and modern recessed lighting. It was a few days before the staff at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, at 135th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard in Harlem, finished hanging two exhibitions and stripping the paper off the doors at its bigger, brighter new entrance. Amid the sounds of hammers and drills, they prepared for tomorrow’s public celebration of the center’s two-year, $11 million renovation.

headline: The Glittering A-List of Black History
text: “Let Your Motto Be Resistance: African American Portraits” at the International Center of Photography is a praise song in pictures, a shoutout to history. It’s also a fancy-dress inaugural party for the yet-to-be-built National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington. As such, it is a little too fancy, too heavy on glitz, too short on grit. Still, what a party it is.

headline: Puffing Away That PG Rating
text: The Motion Picture Association of America on Thursday said portrayals of smoking would be considered alongside sex and violence in assessing the suitability of movies for young viewers. Films that appear to glamorize smoking will risk a more restrictive rating, and descriptions of tobacco use will be added to the increasingly detailed advisories that accompany each rated film.

headline: Want to live next to Tony Blair?
text: Exterior

headline: Decades of Drama
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: It’s All About My Mother
text: If you’re lucky, you inherit more than just the fashion gene.

headline: Vatican and Brazil at Odds
text: In public, the meetings between Pope Benedict XVI and President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva have been all handshakes and smiles during the pontiff's first pastoral visit to Brazil. But behind the scenes, the Vatican and the Brazilian government seem to be at an impasse in their efforts to negotiate a new accord that would regulate the Roman Catholic Church's status and presence in the country that has the largest Catholic population in the world.

headline: Clinton Campaign Video
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign has recently filmed this five-minute video of former President Bill Clinton talking about his wife's accomplishments and lavishing praise on her. The video has been sent to several hundred Clinton donors and supporters.

headline: Can Religious Symbols Be Publicly Displayed?
text: Q I live in a two-family house in which both apartments are rented. One family is Catholic, and the other is Jewish. Is it permissible for a tenant to display a religious symbol in the window — a cross or a menorah — that is visible from the outside?

headline: What Rules Apply on Bicycle Spaces?
text: Q I own a Manhattan co-op and have paid for a bicycle space through the end of the year. I have moved, and I have been told by the building's management company that I cannot sublet my bike space and that I cannot get a refund. This doesn't seem right to me.

headline: Pulse | Dresses That Do Mean a Thing
text: This season, dresses are a swinging affair, with silhouettes that float far from the body and high above the knee.

headline: An Uncertain Future
text: Salifou Yankene, a former child soldier from Ivory Coast who is seeking asylum in the United States, faces a long road to healing.

headline: Theater Briefs
text: Works by Stephen Adly Guirgis and Neil LaBute, among others, will be in "Marathon 2007," Ensemble Studio Theater's 29th festival of new one-act plays, from May 31 through June 30 at the theater.

headline: Russian Bank VTB Raises $8 Billion in I.P.O.
text: VTB, Russia’s second-largest bank, raised about $8 billion in its initial public offering, which drew heavy interest from the country’s institutional and retail investors. The bank sold a 22.5 percent stake in what was the largest I.P.O. of the year and Russia’s third-largest stock sale ever.

headline: Law Firm Preps for Private Equity Flameouts
text: Amid concerns that the recent buyout boom could take an ugly turn, yet another law firm is gearing up to be in the right place at the right time if and when it does. O’Melveny & Myers said Thursday that it hired a trio of bankruptcy specialists and the co-chair of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan‘s restructuring practice in preparation for portfolio company blowups involving its private equity and distressed-debt fund clients.

headline: For Tyco, Breaking Up Just Got Harder to Do
text: The American International Group has filed a bondholders’ lawsuit against Tyco International to stop the conglomerate’s planned bond tender offer, accusing Tyco of trying to buy back its debt on the cheap.

headline: Punishing Court Day for Black’s Ex-Deputy
text: F. David Radler, the chief witness against the media baron Conrad M. Black, endured more withering cross-examination on Thursday, and was again called a liar before a federal jury hearing the case against Mr. Black and others accused of stealing millions from the publishing company Hollinger International.

headline: Ex-Comverse Lawyer Going to Jail in Options Backdating Plan
text: The former top lawyer at the software maker Comverse Technology was sentenced Thursday to a year and one day in prison for his role in a stock options backdating scheme, becoming the first corporate executive to be sentenced for options-related crimes.

headline: Some Unrest Beneath V.C.’s Top Tier
text: Venture capitalists are enjoying growing prominence and swelling investment coffers, and they are taking and receiving credit for considerable job and wealth creation.

headline: Investment Bank JMP Group Goes Public
text: JMP Group, a San Francisco-based investment bank, sold nearly 8 million shares at $11 apiece in its initial public offering. The shares represented a stake of about 38 percent in the company, according to its prospectus.

headline: No Deal for Ford as Company Struggles to Regain Footing
text: Those hoping for transformative merger for the Ford Motor Company were disappointed Thursday when the troubled automaker poured cold water on the notion that it might be considering a deal.

headline: Auction of American Golf Tees Off, Report Says
text: American Golf, the country’s largest golf course owner and operator, is on the block and may fetch more than $1 billion, according to The Deal.com. The company, which manages more than 160 courses, is owned by private equity affiliates of Goldman Sachs and prominent real estate investment business Starwood Capital Group.

headline: In Another Blow for Macquarie, Alinta Backs Babcock Bid
text: The board of Australian energy company Alinta on Friday recommended shareholders accept an A$8 billion ($6.64 billion) takeover offer by investment bank Babcock & Brown and Singapore Power, potentially ending a bidding war with Macquarie Bank.

headline: Canadian Pension Funds Becoming Buyout Players
text: Public pension funds have long been big investors in private equity. Now, some big Canadian pension funds are taking a page from the private equity playback and taking the lead in buyouts.

headline: Texas Pacific and Warburg Team Up for British Retail Bid
text: In an era of mammoth buyouts, private equity firms Texas Pacific Group and Warburg Pincus  are apparently determined to exercise control in their bid for British retail chain New Look.

headline: Turn-of-the-Century Charm
text: The well-kept turn-of-the-century houses in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, charmed Darcey Steinke.

headline: Regulators Examine Suspicious Sallie Mae Trades
text: The SLM Corporation, the student loan provider better known as Sallie Mae, on Thursday said two regulators are probing trading in its stock prior to its April 16 announcement that it would be taken private in a $25.2 billion deal.

headline: Banks Rush for South Korean Asset Managers
text: A flurry of banking deals in South Korea’s asset management sector are in the offing, as a law that allows banks to bring asset management under the same roof as other financial services is expected to go into effect.

headline: Penthouse Settles Fraud Allegations
text: Penthouse International settled charges of accounting fraud and financial reporting violations, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Thursday. Former Penthouse executive Charles Samel and former shareholder Jason Galanis also agreed to each pay $60,000 to settle accounting fraud charges, the S.E.C. said.

headline: Whole Foods Deal Raises Regulatory Concerns
text: Whole Foods Market has confirmed that antitrust regulators appear have serious issues with the company’s planned $700 million cash purchase of rival grocery store chain Wild Oats Markets.

headline: NeuroVista Scores Second Round
text: NeuroVista, a Seattle medical device company developing treatments for epilepsy, has raised $33.8 million in a second round of funding led by Advanced Technology Ventures and Delphi Ventures.

headline: Apple Shareholders Question Jobs on Options
text: Apple chief Steven P. Jobs faced a barrage of questions from shareholders about the company’s handling of stock option grants and its policy of executive compensation, during a an annual meeting Thursday. But Mr. Jobs, with his typical flair for showmanship, elicited laughs and applause during the meeting despite rankling questions.

headline: Oaktree to List on New Goldman Market, Reports Say
text: Private investment firm Oaktree Capital Management is set to be the first firm to list on Goldman Sachs‘s new private market set to launch this month, according to press reports.

headline: China Allows Banks to Buy Stocks Abroad
text: China will allow the country’s commercial banks to buy stocks abroad, in a move that may release some of the nation’s 35 trillion yuan ($4.6 trillion) of savings on overseas equity markets for the first time.

headline: Historic Old Northeast
text: Scenes from the Historic Old Northeast neighborhood of St. Petersburg, Fla., a front-porch kind of place close to downtown.

headline: Former Day Traders Acquitted in ‘Squawk Box’ Case
text: A federal jury in Brooklyn on Thursday acquitted two former stockbrokers and four former employees of the A. B. Watley Group, a day trading firm, of securities fraud in what became known as the “squawk box” case.

headline: Panel to Look at Conflicts in Consulting on Executive Pay
text: As the hew and cry over rich executive pay intensifies, members of Congress are looking into the potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do other lucrative work for the companies whose pay they help devise.

headline: Hedge Fund Tells Wendy’s to Sell Itself
text: The largest institutional shareholder of Wendy’s International is urging the hamburger chain to sell itself to the highest bidder, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Terra Firma Flies Off With Pegasus
text: Terra Firma, the private equity group run by British financier Guy Hands, doubled the size of its aircraft leasing business on Friday with the acquisition of San Francisco-based Pegasus Aviation Finance for $5.2 billion.

headline: Google C.E.O. On Dealmaking Strategy
text: Google, which last month announced a deal to buy online ad firm DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, said that while it has become more comfortable doing big acquisitions, it still sees small technology deals as its primary thrust for buying businesses.

headline: Is JetBlue a Takeover Play?
text: David G. Neeleman, the founder of JetBlue Airways, reluctantly agreed to step aside as the company’s chief executive Thursday. The move marked a turning point in the short history of the upstart airline, but it also gave new life to recent speculation that the low-cost carrier might be a candidate for a takeover. JetBlue’s shares rose 4.7 percent after the move was announced.

headline: Latest Shock Jock Outburst
text: Opie and Anthony, who ended up on satellite radio after being fired from a New York radio station for mixing transgressive sex and religion, have sparked a new uproar. This time, it is over mixing transgressive sex and politics.

headline: Carlyle Said to Plan Publicly Traded Fund
text: Carlyle Group, the private equity giant, plans to file to list its first publicly traded fund by the end of June, BusinessWeek.com’s Deal Flow blog reported, citing people familiar with the transaction. The Washington-based firm will list a leveraged finance fund made up primarily of mortgage-backed securities on the Euronext.

headline: Are ‘Wacky’ Climate Solutions Worthwhile?
text: The more we hear about climate change, the more we hear about how business, government and green-minded consumers are going to collaborate to create a low-carbon economy. Politicians and chief executives say these initiatives could get us there within two or three decades.

headline: Out of Brooklyn, Endlessly Blogging
text: Certain neighborhoods in Brooklyn seem to have become the most blog-rich areas of the United States, according to a recent informal survey by the blog Outside.in. So where better to take the pulse of this rapidly growing community of writers, thinkers and observers than the second annual Brooklyn Blogfest?

headline: Former BP Chief Quits Goldman’s Board
text: Goldman Sachs said Thursday that John Browne, who quit as chief executive of BP on May 1 after it emerged that he had lied during legal proceedings about how he met a former lover, had resigned from the Goldman board. Mr. Browne, who helped build the London-based BP into one of the largest oil companies in the world, had been a Goldman director since the investment bank went public in May 1999.

headline: KB Home Receives Offer for Stake in French Home Builder
text: KB Home, the fifth-largest homebuilder in the United States, received an offer worth 580 million euros ($782 million) for its 49 percent stake in Kaufman & Broad, the biggest home builder in Paris and the surrounding region.

headline: Giuliani Trips in the Abortion Minefield
text: The Wall Street Journal editorial page thinks Rudy Giuliani’s decision to run as a pro-choice presidential candidate will damage whomever emerges as the eventual Republican nominee in 2008: “As if Republicans don’t have enough problems, their presidential candidates and interest groups seem eager to re-stage a fight over abortion the American public doesn’t want to hear. Blame both Rudy Giuliani and his conservative critics, but

headline: Thomson Slims Down as Reuters Talks Continue
text: As Thomson lays the groundwork for a blockbuster merger with Reuters, the Canadian company said Friday it will sell its education and career units to two private equity funds for about $7.75 billion in cash.

headline: 2008: Romney’s Media Weekend
text: The Times’s Michael Luo assesses the state of Mitt Romney’s candidacy, detailing hurdles such as skepticism about his ideological shifts and Mormon faith, as well as strengths including a proven fund-raising capacity and even greater skepticism about his chief rivals, Senator John McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani (who, as Katharine Q. Seelye pointed out Thursday, has been having a rough week).

headline: Romney Elaborates on Evolution
text: DES MOINES, May 11 — Mitt Romney expanded on his belief in evolution in an interview earlier this week, staking out a position that could put him at odds with some conservative Christians, a key voting bloc he is courting.

headline: Sex Trafficking in India
text: Last month I visited India and wrote about the horrific sex trafficking situation there, through the story of a woman named Meena who had been imprisoned in a brothel herself, was bred, and then had her daughter prostituted as well. Meena is an incredibly gutsy woman, and she was able to rescue her teenage daughter, Naina.

headline: Chicago Merc Raises Bid for CBOT
text: Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings sweetened its all-stock offer for CBOT Holdings, the parent company of the Chicago Board of Trade, in hopes of fending off a competing bid from the IntercontinentalExchange. The revised offer, announced early Friday, values CBOT at about $9.2 billion, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Mixed Mood at Virginia Tech Graduation
text: As thousands of parents arrived for graduation ceremonies, it was hard to tell the tears of joy from those of sadness.

headline: Google Draws a Line With Thailand
text: Two months after Thailand blocked YouTube over video clips it said insulted the King, a response emerged from its owner, Google, in a letter released by the nation’s communications minister. Google has not commented so far.

headline: Heidfeld’s Nurburgring ride nearly dominates the Friday press conference
text: The Friday press conference returned to a discussion of Nick Heidfeld’s drive on the Nordschleife last month. That is significant. The questions came not only from the official FIA interviewer, but from journalists and…another driver.

headline: Drug Maker to Plead Guilty to Making False Statements
text: Bristol-Myers Squibb said Thursday that it would plead guilty to criminal charges that it made false statements to the government, a move meant to end a federal antitrust investigation of the drug maker’s botched efforts last year to preserve a lucrative monopoly for the anti-clotting medicine Plavix.

headline: When Looks Deceive
text: “I thought it would be much, much bigger,” said one of my companions.

headline: As SunTrust Rises, Takeover Talk Heats Up
text: In their search for the next takeover candidate, analysts and investors seem to be casting an eye on SunTrust Banks. Part of the reason is a recent comment from James Dimon, the chief executive of J.P. Morgan Chase, who said on a conference call Monday that his firm is ready to buy a domestic regional bank. Speculation immediately turned to SunTrust, which has a major presence in the Southeast, a market that J.P. Morgan may be targeting for growth.

headline: $350 Liquor
text: My column today, arguing that such things as clubs charging $350 for a bottle of booze are simply ways that money is redistributed from the wealthy, provoked a telephone call from a reader who told me I “write like a Republican.” He did not mean it as a compliment, but did seem to take for granted that Republicans would be the kind of people to patronize such establishments.

headline: Orbitz Prospectus Gets Mixed Reviews
text: The online travel site Orbitz Worldwide “isn’t a bad company,” Kevin Kelleher writes on GigaOM.com. It is nevertheless a contender for “the worst I.P.O. candidate of the year,” he concludes.

headline: Pakistani Banker Named in Insider-Trading Suit
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday accused a prominent investment-banking executive in Pakistan of taking part in a $7.5 million insider trading ring along with a former banker at Credit Suisse. In an amended complaint filed in federal court in Illinois, the S.E.C. said Ajaz Rahim, the country head of investment banking at Faysal Bank Limited of Pakistan, with making about $5 million in illegal profits by trading in TXU options before the Texas utility announced its $45 billion sale to two private equity firms.

headline: Fried Frank Adds M&A Partner
text: Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobson, one of the law firms advising Dow Jones as it considers a takeover bid from News Corporation, said Friday it hired a new corporate partner for its mergers and acquisitions practice. John E. Sorkin, previously a partner at Latham & Watkins, joins Fried Frank in its New York office.

headline: Of Hedgehogs and Courtroom Moles
text: Like fedora-sporting reporters in old movies, hedge fund employees lately have been known to jump up from their courtroom seats as rulings are issued to get breaking news back to headquarters. But they’re not rushing to the bank of payphones in the lobby (which probably aren’t there anymore anyway). “These guys are texting the hedge fund, so they can short the stock” of whatever company just lost a patent suit, Ron Laurie, of Inflexion Point Strategy, an intellectual-property investment bank, told the trade publication IP Law and Business.

headline: The Significance of paul99503
text: YouTube is magnetic. The average user spends nearly 30 minutes there, just hanging out. Part of the draw is the thick, lush, humid comments section. It’s like a rainforest in there with, yeah, tons of bugs and some predators, but also plenty of dense and fascinating flora.

headline: Mistakes Happen
text: Jeff Zeleny takes a look at Barack Obama and the art of political damage control.

headline: What’s So Funny ‘Bout Peace, Love and Understanding?
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s May 11 column, “The Human Community.”

headline: Giuliani in Houston
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani began his effort today to show a more consistent, if liberal, persona on the campaign trail, telling a conservative crowd in Houston that he favored abortion rights, gay rights (domestic partnerships but not marriage) and certain restrictions on guns.

headline: Is Greenwich, Conn., Obama Country?
text: Considerable amounts of ink and pixels have been devoted lately to characterizing Barack Obama as the presidential candidate of the hedge-fund set. A Financial Times article last month quoted an anonymous United States businessman as saying, “The whole of Greenwich is backing Obama” — a reference to Greenwich, Conn., the leafy suburb that many hedge fund managers call home. (That breezy statement turns out to be quite untrue, as we will see later.)

headline: The Day the Union Jack Got Beat Back
text: The good ol’ days of rebellion were back today in Delhi, India, where the 150th anniversary of India’s first revolt against British rule was celebrated.

headline: Going Underground
text: Physicists are putting the final touches on the biggest and most expensive scientific experiment on Earth.

headline: Decoding 'Code Monkey'
text: How Jonathan Coulton's song became a viral hit.

headline: A Cabrera by Any Other Name
text: In case you thought the Yankees had somehow traded for Miguel Cabrera from the Florida Marlins without anyone noticing, there’s a friendly reminder on your Times box score page nearly every day.

headline: Asking the Obvious
text: With thanks to reader Ricardo B. for expressing something we’ve all thought at one time or another:

headline: The Flight From Iraq
text: Nir Rosen reports on the refugee crisis at Al Tanf on the Syrian border with Iraq.

headline: The Good News, and the Bad
text: As we sat waiting in Sarasota Airport for our flight, I was riding a roller coaster of emotions. One moment I was elated that we had made extensive progress on our house plans, the next I was depressed that the plans weren’t perfect.

headline: Clinton Campaign Video
text: Former President Bill Clinton narrates a short biographical film about Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Oleg the Cab Driver
text: Fox's Advertising Experiment

headline: A Long Tryout for First Lady
text: As she spends more time on the campaign trail, Michelle Obama is appearing in support of her husband but is also campaigning for herself.

headline: The Flight From Iraq
text: Photographer Joachim Ladefoged speaks about his work with Iraqi refugees in Damascus.

headline: A Prominent Iraqi Blogger Flees
text: A young Iraqi woman who chronicled the daily struggles of life in Baghdad is fleeing with her family.

headline: More Problems Redeeming Miles and Using Miles on Partner Airlines
text: I recently called up Lufthansa Miles & More to reserve a flight using my miles from the program. Lufthansa said that I had enough miles for the flight, but that there were no seats available. I was able to make online bookings for the seats I wanted — as long as I paid for them. Is this a typical problem? Why am I storing up all these miles if I can’t use them?

headline: One More Thing About the Size of the Tundra…
text: Tooling around Texas, I noticed that not only is the new Tundra much bigger than a Prius (as Micheline Maynard pointed out in her last post), but it’s also bigger than a Tundra. Check it out. The truck on the right is a first-generation Tundra.

headline: More on the Gumball 3000; and the Art of the Pitstop
text: While reading through the comments on the Gumball 3000 post, I was surprised to find a few from participants, recent and past — at least they said they were.

headline: From City Hall to Property Development
text: Jay L. Kriegel, who was Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff’s right-hand man in the city’s unsuccessful effort to secure the 2012 Olympics, starts work on Monday as a senior adviser to The Related Companies, a major property developer, and its chairman and chief executive, Stephen M. Ross.

headline: A Wealth of Poverty
text: I wrote an extended essay about poverty, at home and abroad, for the latest New York Review of Books. Read it and comment below.

headline: Odds and Ends From Safeco Field
text: A little of this, a little of that from a lovely night in the Emerald City:

headline: Do U Txt Whl Drvng?
text: Gov. Christine Gregoire of Washington State signed the nation’s first law Friday to ban “D.W.T.” — driving while texting with a cellphone, BlackBerry or other mobile device. New Jersey is considering similar legislation, which would make drivers who text and drive subject to fines.

headline: A Father’s Pain and an Empty Pizzeria
text: COOKSTOWN, N.J., May 11 — After the third death threat of the day, Muslim Tatar decided on Thursday to telephone a sign maker. He had an assistant dictate precisely how he wanted the big new banners to read: “Under New Management.”

headline: The Millions Left Out
text: The United States may be the richest country in the world, but there are many millions — tens of millions — who are not sharing in that prosperity.

headline: Motive No. 1 in Washington: The Will to Power (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Romney Aides Say His Worth Is at Least $260 Million
text: Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential hopeful, has assets estimated at $260 million to $350 million, his campaign advisers said yesterday in discussing his personal financial disclosure statement.

headline: 5 Dead After Attack on U.S. Patrol in Iraq; 3 Still Missing
text: BAGHDAD, May 12 — A coordinated attack on seven American soldiers and an Iraqi Army interpreter early this morning south of Baghdad left five of them dead and three missing, the United States military said.

headline: Alfred D. Chandler Jr., a Business Historian, Dies at 88
text: Alfred D. Chandler Jr., an economic historian who revolutionized the writing of business history, shunning the old debate about whether tycoons are good or bad, and instead arguing persuasively in almost two dozen books that it was the emergence of professional management that propelled modern capitalism, died on May 9 in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88.

headline: U.S. Won’t Limit Detainees’ Visits With Attorneys
text: The Justice Department yesterday withdrew one of its proposals to tighten restrictions on lawyers representing detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, but said it would continue to press a federal appeals court for other limitations on the lawyers.

headline: A New Style for Portugal’s Old Fado, but the Songs Are Still Full of Emotion
text: When Dulce Pontes started a song with the words “meu amor” (“my love”) at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, she flooded them with emotion: longing, seductiveness, bravado, desperation, strength. It was quintessential Portuguese fado singing, with long-breathed swoops and tempestuous dynamic surges, simultaneously abandoned and refined.

headline: East Timor Figure’s Victory Is Seen as Cause for Hope
text: HONG KONG, May 11  The decisive victory of José Ramos-Horta in East Timor’s presidential election was a significant move toward creating genuine multiparty democracy and breaking the dominance of the political organization that largely led the struggle for independence, analysts and election observers said Friday.

headline: Reyes Resists a Buzz Cut but Could Be Wavering
text: José Reyes was the busiest man in baseball yesterday afternoon.

headline: Spy Chief Backs Study of Impact of Warming
text: WASHINGTON, May 11  Stepping into the middle of a partisan debate on Capitol Hill, the United States’ top intelligence official has endorsed a comprehensive study by spy agencies about the impact of global warming on national security.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on the Street Scene pages of Business Day on April 6 about a program geared toward training female lawyers to become directors of companies misstated the percentage of Fortune 500 companies that have women on their boards. It is 88.4 percent, not 14.6 percent. (Women held 14.6 percent of the board seats on Fortune 500 companies in 2006.) Catalyst, the research company that compiled the statistics, pointed out in an e-mail message this week that the article had misstated the findings.

headline: For the Record
text: An article in some copies on Tuesday about proposed tentative rent increases for New York City’s one million rent-stabilized apartments included an outdated schedule for the board’s final vote. It is now expected June 26, not June 22. The article also misstated the number of public hearings to be held on the increases. (The same error appeared in an article on April 25 about reports that building owners’ costs and revenues rose in the last year.) There will be two hearings, not three.

headline: Tears Are Mixed at Virginia Tech Commencement
text: BLACKSBURG, Va., May 11 — Commencement at Virginia Tech was supposed to be a moment for parents to watch their children take a symbolic step. From a youthful safe haven, students would graduate into a larger, less predictable world.

headline: Bloomberg Calls for National Energy Reforms
text: HOUSTON, May 11 — Sounding a lot like a presidential candidate, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg laid out the framework for a national energy policy on Friday and accused Washington lawmakers of “passing the buck” on meaningful energy reforms.

headline: In Los Angeles, Where the Police Were Unable to Contain Themselves
text: Los Angeles

headline: Child Care Workers Get Right to Unionize
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed an executive order yesterday that gives 60,000 home-based child care providers the right to unionize, opening the door to one of the largest organizing drives in decades in New York State.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a Hong Kong couple accused of insider trading in connection with a bid for Dow Jones & Company by the News Corporation referred imprecisely to the actions taken by Dow Jones. While the company is gathering information internally and is cooperating in an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission, it is not conducting an internal investigation focusing on a director, David K. P. Li.

headline: An Impressive Run in the Southeast Regional
text: John Diamond and Jim Krekorian of New York City were the most successful pair at the Southeastern Regional in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., last month. In five events they had two firsts, two seconds and a tie for third.

headline: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about public financing of stem cell research in Massachusetts referred incorrectly to financing plans in New York. Although Gov. Eliot Spitzer at one time proposed spending $1 billion, a budget agreement with the Legislature in March reduced the figure to $600 million.

headline: Value of an Afghan Life (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Asian Growth Offsets U.S. Slump to Prolong Industrial Metals Rally
text: “Every boom,” it used to be said, “has a copper roof.”

headline: Thomson to Sell Educational Group
text: OTTAWA, May 11 — Thomson, the Canadian information company that hopes to buy Reuters, said today that it would sell its textbook and educational materials to two funds for $7.75 billion.

headline: The Baby Sitter With Frequent Flier Miles (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bad Medicine, Sneaking In
text: As I read about the melamine-tainted pet food, and about the hundreds in Panama killed by phony glycerin from China, I remembered a patient I once saw. She was a dancer in her 40s who had hobbled into the emergency room one October night with a painful, bulging mass in her groin. I gently put my fingers to it. It was beet-sized and firm. When I placed my stethoscope on it, I heard gurgling. This was, I told her, a strangulating hernia  a rent in her abdominal wall had trapped a loop of intestine. The swelling was the knot of bowel; the gurgling, the fluid inside.

headline: Earnhardt Free Agency Echoes Through Nascar
text: DARLINGTON, S.C., May 11 — Dale Earnhardt Jr. was back in a racecar Friday, a welcome relief after the week he has been through. It did not seem to matter that he was driving the Car of Tomorrow, the Nascar-designed car that he has roundly criticized.

headline: Mining a Rich Vein of Sequins in Revues
text: Encores! has built its own jukebox, and it gleams like gold. “Stairway to Paradise,” which runs through Monday at City Center, is an anthology of truly olden oldies, songs the theatergoing masses heard in musical revues in the first half of the 20th century. And yes, I know, it all sounds too quaint and camp and, well, dusty, for words.

headline: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about events in Iraq, including closing arguments in a trial of six colleagues of Saddam Hussein in attacks that killed as many as 180,000 Kurds in the 1980s, misstated the date of Mr. Hussein’s execution. It was Dec. 30 of last year, not in January.

headline: Canada: Court Delays Terrorism Suspect’s Deportation
text: The Federal Court said the government may not deport an Algerian accused of having ties to Al Qaeda until it revised its law on detaining foreign-born terrorism suspects. The Algerian, Mohamed Harkat, was arrested in Ottawa in 2002 and became one of five Muslim men held without charges or a trial under the detention measure, the security certificate system, introduced late in 2001. In February, the Supreme Court found the measure unconstitutional and gave the government a year to change it. Mr. Harkat was released under restrictive conditions after the ruling as the government continued his deportation process.

headline: Talking Again of Middle East Peace (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Price of a Stamp Continues Its Upward March
text: The Postal Service’s new rates take effect Monday. The cost of a first-class stamp, which covers letters weighing up to one ounce, will increase to 41 cents from 39 cents, while the cost of each additional ounce will decrease to 17 cents from 24 cents. Items placed in mailboxes after Saturday’s pickup must reflect the new prices. Also available will be the Forever Stamp, currently 41 cents, which covers the one-ounce letter rate regardless of any future increases. More information on pricing for domestic mail and new international rates can be found at www.usps.gov.

headline: Hot-Shooting Warriors Cool Off Jazz
text: OAKLAND, Calif., May 11 — The Golden State Warriors have turned this year’s N.B.A. playoffs into the world’s biggest pickup game.

headline: A Congressman Faces Foes in Japan as He Seeks an Apology
text: SAN JOSE, Calif.

headline: Rates Hold Fast, and Movie Smoking Takes a Hit
text: Policy makers in Washington kept their eyes on inflation, but held rates steady. In Hollywood, the Motion Picture Association of America tossed smoking into its ratings system.

headline: Making Sure the Negative Can Be Heard
text: “If my attorneys knew I was here, they would be here with a hook,” joked David A. Rocker a few weeks ago, looking out at a sea of people some 1,600 strong.

headline: Battle to Acquire the Chicago Board of Trade Heats Up
text: CHICAGO, May 11 — The Chicago Mercantile Exchange raised its bid to acquire its crosstown rival, the Chicago Board of Trade, by 16 percent on Friday, closing the gap with the surprise offer by the Intercontinental Exchange two months ago.

headline: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about mounting pressure on world leaders to help bring an end to the violence in Darfur misspelled the given name of a film director who has tried to step up pressure on Sudan’s government. He Steven Spielberg, not Stephen.

headline: Spotlight Has Dimmed, but LeBron Still Shines
text: In the box score, LeBron James can be

headline: Edwards to Ask Antiwar Stand of Americans
text: Stepping up his antiwar stance, John Edwards said yesterday that he would call for Americans to “raise their voices” on Memorial Day against the Iraq war and would say that patriotism required supporting the troops by bringing them home.

headline: In Rematch, Mariners Top Rasner and Yanks
text: SEATTLE, May 11 — Joe Torre fields dozens of questions before every game, most about his own team, and some about the opposition. In the dugout at Safeco Field on Friday, Torre was asked about Jarrod Washburn, the starter for the Seattle Mariners.

headline: Thomson Agrees to Sell Educational Group
text: OTTAWA, May 11 — Thomson, the Canadian information company that hopes to buy Reuters, said Friday that it would sell its textbook and educational materials to two funds for $7.75 billion.

headline: Radio Hosts Lose a Sponsor After a Routine About Rape
text: A representative for Trojan condoms said yesterday that the company would no longer advertise on the “Opie & Anthony” show on a CBS-owned FM station in New York after a guest on another version of the show, on XM satellite radio, mused about sexually assaulting Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, leading to a vulgar discussion.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on the Street Scene pages of Business Day on April 6 about a program geared toward training female lawyers to become directors of companies misstated the percentage of Fortune 500 companies that have women on their boards. It is 88.4 percent, not 14.6 percent. (Women held 14.6 percent of the board seats on Fortune 500 companies in 2006.) Catalyst, the research company that compiled the statistics, pointed out in an e-mail message this week that the article had misstated the findings. (Go to Article)

headline: Damaged Shuttle Tank Is Called Ready for Flight
text: NASA officials said that the hail-pocked tank for the next shuttle mission had been repaired and that they expected to be ready for the shuttle Atlantis to blast off by the proposed launching date of June 8. A hailstorm in February left more than 4,000 dings in the foam insulation on the external tank while the shuttle sat on the launching pad. Analysts are confident that pieces of foam big enough to damage the shuttle during ascent — the problem that doomed the shuttle Columbia and its crew of seven astronauts in 2003 — will not fall off the repaired tank, said N. Wayne Hale, Jr., the shuttle program manager. “Our goal is zero, and our testing indicates it will be zero,” Mr. Hale said.

headline: Getty Moves Closer to Returning an Ancient Statue to Italy
text: LOS ANGELES, May 11 — The J. Paul Getty Museum inched a step closer to relinquishing ownership of one of its most prized artifacts, a 2,400-year-old statue of a goddess claimed by Italy, at a conference of international experts to discuss the artifact this week, its director said.

headline: War on Terror Takes a Detour
text: With “Delta Farce,” his second movie vehicle, the Southern-fried comedian Larry the Cable Guy takes ever greater risks to advance his career.

headline: Giuliani Takes On G.O.P. Orthodoxy on Social Issues
text: HOUSTON, May 11 — Rudolph W. Giuliani directly challenged Republican orthodoxy on Friday, asserting that his support for abortion rights, gun control and gay rights should not disqualify him from winning the party’s presidential nomination.

headline: Suits Alleging Pay Violations at Restaurants
text: Restaurant owners in Manhattan have long had plenty to worry about, like soaring rents and exacting customers, but now they face a new and costly problem: a record number of lawsuits accusing them of stealing tips and cheating on wages.

headline: Classic Jazz With No Frills or Preening
text: The jazz singer Karrin Allyson has added a new instrumental ingredient to her music with the introduction into her band of the vibraphonist Steve Nelson. As he swapped solos with the guitarist Rod Fleeman on Thursday’s early show at Birdland, where Ms. Allyson is appearing through tonight, his shimmering blues-charged lyricism gave the music a mild percussive kick. It lent songs, several of which are found on her 2006 album, “Footprints” a discreet element of exoticism that suggested a dramatic indigo sky in a painting of a cornfield. (Ms. Allyson is from Kansas City.)

headline: Guard Troops Will Assist in Protecting PATH System
text: Up to 40 National Guard troops will begin patrolling 13 PATH stations in New York and New Jersey next week, similar to programs under way at Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central Terminal.

headline: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the role of genes in weight gain misstated the publication date for an article in the journal Science describing the biological controls over body weight. The article was published in 2003, not 2000.

headline: In His Own Words
text: Following are excerpts from a speech delivered Friday by Rudolph W. Giuliani at Houston Baptist University, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: No Tribunal for 11 Officers Tied to Killing of Brazilian in Britain
text: LONDON, May 11 — A police oversight body ruled Friday that 11 officers involved in the fatal shooting of a 27-year-old Brazilian electrician, whom the police had said they mistook for a terrorist, would not face disciplinary hearings.

headline: Soft Sounds, Subtle Shadings: What Would Have Been on Louis XIV’s iPod
text: The viola da gamba virtuoso Jordi Savall runs a remarkably efficient musical enterprise. In addition to the three ensembles he directs, Mr. Savall has his own record label, Alia Vox, to document his adventures in (mostly) unusual corners of the early-music repertory. Mr. Savall’s ensembles produce a luxurious sound, and in recent seasons he has brought one or more of them to New York.

headline: Anarchist’s Head Is Finally Buried, but Outcry Arises Over Timing
text: ROME, May 11 — The anarchist Giovanni Passannante is becoming a cause célèbre 97 years after his death.

headline: The Rings of Giuliani
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani, who after deep reflection has concluded that he is the best qualified person in America to be president, now owns four gold World Series rings, which, if hit hard enough with a hammer, would yield about 100 diamonds, some of them a half-carat in size.

headline: When Failure Is a Good Thing
text: QUIZ time: What percentage of dot-com start-ups have failed?” an article in Strategy + Business asks.

headline: For the Record
text: A listing on Thursday of American service members killed in Iraq erroneously included two servicemen who died recently. James W. Harrison Jr., 47, a colonel with the United States Command and General Staff College, and Wilberto Sabalu Jr., 36, a master sergeant with the United States Military Police School, were killed in Afghanistan, not Iraq.

headline: World View Podcast
text: Calvin Sims and Alan Cowell discuss Tony Blair

headline: Colleagues Cite Partisan Focus by Justice Official
text: WASHINGTON, May 11 — Two years ago, Robin C. Ashton, a seasoned criminal prosecutor at the Department of Justice, learned from her boss that a promised promotion was no longer hers.

headline: Despite Upset, Nowitzki Will Be M.V.P.
text: Dirk Nowitzki, who led the Dallas Mavericks to a 67-victory season but failed to lead them out of the first round of the playoffs, will be named the N.B.A.’s most valuable player next week, two team officials confirmed.

headline: Hamas-Fatah Gunfight Worsens Factional Strife in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, May 11 — In the most severe factional violence in nearly two months, Hamas and Fatah gunmen shot at each other on Friday in Gaza, wounding at least 10 people and putting new strains on the Palestinian unity government in which both parties take part.

headline: Brown Strikes a Note of Change for Britain
text: LONDON, May 11 — Bolstered by a long-awaited endorsement from Tony Blair, Gordon Brown, Britain’s prime minister-in-waiting, moved quickly on Friday to stake out distinctive new ground, acknowledging “mistakes” in Iraq and promising “a new leadership for this new time.”

headline: Crisis in Pakistan Over Judge Turns Violent
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 12 — At least 27 people were killed and more than 100 were injured in Karachi today in clashes set off by the arrival of the chief justice of Pakistan’s Supreme Court, suspended by President Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani officials said.

headline: Mobster Guilty of Racketeering, but Not Murder
text: The Gambino crime family conspired to kill a Queens couple for robbing Mafia social clubs in the early 1990s, a federal jury decided yesterday in a split verdict that assigned no culpability for carrying out the murders.

headline: Artificial Sweetener Makers Reach Settlement on Slogan
text: The makers of Equal and Splenda reached an undisclosed settlement yesterday over Splenda’s contested slogan “made from sugar, so it tastes like sugar,” ending a monthlong trial in which, just moments earlier, a jury had reached a verdict.

headline: It’s Not ‘American Idol,’ but Subway Station Auditions Draw Crowd in Washington
text: WASHINGTON, May 11  Some came bearing musical instruments of all kinds, from guitars and banjos, to electric keyboards and trumpets, to traditional African drums and gourd rattles.

headline: Booker to Endorse Obama, Calling Him a ‘Voice for Change’
text: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark said yesterday that he would endorse Senator Barack Obama for president on Monday.

headline: Tough Sell: An American Yogurt in Paris
text: The Danone Group has enjoyed great success by selling French yogurt to Americans. Now the company is turning to an American to introduce organic yogurts in Europe, starting in France, a country that doesn’t normally look across the Atlantic for culinary advice.

headline: Online Ads vs. Privacy
text: FOR advertisers, and in many ways for consumers, online advertising is a blessing. Customized messages rescue advertisers from the broad reach of traditional media. And consumers can learn about products and services that appeal directly to them.

headline: Billions in Oil Missing in Iraq, U.S. Study Says
text: Between 100,000 and 300,000 barrels a day of Iraq’s declared oil production over the past four years is unaccounted for and could have been siphoned off through corruption or smuggling, according to a draft American government report.

headline: Majority of Iraq Lawmakers Seek Timetable for U.S. Exit
text: BAGHDAD, May 11 — A majority of Iraq’s Parliament members have signed a petition for a timetable governing a withdrawal of American troops, several legislators said Friday.

headline: Mum Is the Word in Steroid Inquiry
text: Earlier this week Commissioner Bud Selig issued a directive to officials of the 30 major league clubs telling them to quit talking about George J. Mitchell’s steroid investigation.

headline: Officer Is Arraigned in Companion’s Killing
text: A police officer accused of fatally shooting his estranged companion while off duty was formally charged yesterday with second-degree murder during an arraignment at Queens Criminal Court.

headline: Studying the Majors, With 200 Books to Go
text: SEATTLE, May 11 — Matt DeSalvo sat in silence at his Yankee Stadium locker before his major league debut on Monday, buried in the written word. It is his most comfortable position.

headline: Incredible Shrinking Packages
text: Marketers usually boast about what they have added to their products. Increasingly, though, they are bragging about what they are taking out — by cutting down on packaging and its impact on the environment.

headline: In Investing, Passive Beats Active
