text: THEY say you get what you pay for, but mutual fund investors often get less. Actively managed stock portfolios find it hard to achieve the returns of low-cost index-tracking funds, and that was especially true last year.

headline: Burglary Charge Is Costly for Rutgers Class President
text: The senior class president at Rutgers University’s Livingston campus in Piscataway, N.J., will not be graduating with her classmates next week, university officials said yesterday, after being charged with burglary in the dormitory where she was a resident adviser.

headline: Woods Saves His Best Shot for Sabbatini
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., May 11  Tiger Woods had just signed his scorecard when the name of his newest adversary was uttered.

headline: A Slap Echoing Beyond the Stage
text: At each performance of New York City Ballet’s new “Romeo and Juliet,” numerous members of the audience gasp aloud in shock at the moment when Lord Capulet knocks his daughter to the ground with a highly audible slap. The slap occurs onstage; then, like an echo, the gasp occurs in the auditorium.

headline: Pentagon Opens Inquiry of Troop-Support Group
text: WASHINGTON, May 11 — The Pentagon is looking into complaints that Defense Department officials charged with building public support for troops in Iraq and Afghanistan might have engaged in improper fund-raising and unauthorized spending, officials said Friday.

headline: Middle School Manages Distractions of Adolescence
text: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y. — At Briarcliff Middle School, almost any minute of any day can become a lesson in weathering the turmoil of adolescence.

headline: Visit by Bush Tests Beliefs and Hospitality of Students at a Catholic College
text: LATROBE, Pa., May 11 — Ordinarily, there would be nothing notable about the chancellor of a small Roman Catholic college in a reliably Republican county telling President Bush, as he did on Friday, “Know, Mr. President, that you are very welcome on this campus.”

headline: Town Spared, but Wildfire Still Burns on Catalina
text: LONG BEACH, Calif., May 11 — The second major Southern California brushfire this week continued to burn Friday on the resort island of Santa Catalina. But Avalon, the island’s major town, appeared to have been spared, and some of the thousands of people who had been evacuated began returning from the mainland.

headline: For the Record
text: A picture credit on Tuesday with an article about the 50th anniversary of desegregation in Little Rock, Ark., misspelled the surname of the photographer in some copies. He is Michael Stravato, not Stavato.

headline: Alcatel Posts Loss on Merger Costs
text: Alcatel-Lucent, the telecommunications equipment maker, posted a first-quarter loss yesterday, hurt by costs and accounting changes related to the merger that created the company last year.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,376 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans this week:

headline: Iran’s American Prisoner
text: This past week Iran’s capricious and dangerous government jailed the Iranian-American scholar Haleh Esfandiari. Her unjustified arrest came after authorities barred her from leaving the country and after weeks of harassment clearly intended to intimidate one of the United States’ most distinguished analysts of Iranian politics.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Aspen Isn’t Laughing

headline: In Utah, Roles Are Reversed, but a Relationship Perseveres
text: OAKLAND, Calif., May 11 — When Deron Williams pulled up on Wednesday with 2.3 seconds left and took the jump shot that would decide the game, his mother was nowhere to be seen.

headline: In New Hampshire, Soft Sell Eases Vaccine Fears
text: CONCORD, N.H. — A vaccine for a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer may be creating controversy across the country, but in New Hampshire physicians say so many people want it that they cannot satisfy the demand.

headline: Live From Washington, Opera for the College Crowd
text: Students wandering into some college auditoriums on Sept. 23 may receive a few unexpected lessons on subjects like the nature of Bohemian love, consumptive heroines and life in a garret.

headline: Last Big Piece of Russian Oil Giant Is Sold
text: MOSCOW, May 11 — A last big piece of the Yukos oil company, once Russia’s largest company, was sold at a bankruptcy auction on Friday. And like much else about the dismembering of the company, the sale raised more questions than it answered.

headline: Hoping to Shorten Suspension, Jones Meets With Goodell
text: Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones met yesterday with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell, hoping to persuade Goodell to reduce the season-long suspension he levied last month on Jones for his off-field conduct.

headline: Mets Finally Solve the Brewers’ Suppan
text: The last time the Mets faced Jeff Suppan, an October chill was in the air and the stakes were high. It was Game 7 of the National League Championship Series at Shea Stadium, and Suppan allowed one run in seven innings for the St. Louis Cardinals, spoiling the Mets’ hopes of reaching the World Series.

headline: Prosecutors Drop All Charges in Boston Terrorism Scare
text: BOSTON, May 11  Prosecutors on Friday dropped criminal charges against two men who set off fears of terrorism by placing electronic advertisements for a cartoon in and around Boston.

headline: U.S. Fugitives Worry About a Cuba Without Castro
text: HAVANA — These are uneasy times for a man on the lam in Havana.

headline: Leonard Eron, 87, Is Dead; Researcher on TV’s Tie to Violent Conduct
text: Leonard D. Eron, a psychologist whose pioneering studies of youth violence led him to conclude that television had a significant role in prompting destructive behavior in later life, died on May 3 at his home in Lindenhurst, Ill., near Chicago He was 87.

headline: At 80, He’s Hardly Done Talking, or Performing
text: “I’m always ashamed about repeating things I’ve written, but occasionally you have to,” Charles Rosen said with a laugh. “I’m running short of ideas.”

headline: She Carries Weapons; They Are Called Words
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 — Mohja Kahf, an Arab-American writer, draws sharp, funny, earthy portraits of the fault line separating Muslim women from their Western counterparts. At times she captures the breach in a single title, like her poem built around respecting prayer rituals, called “My Grandmother Washes Her Feet in the Sink of the Bathroom at Sears.”

headline: At Commencement, a Call for Religious Literacy
text: And so, members of the graduating class of 2007, we’ve come almost to the end of this commencement ceremony and of these brief commencement remarks.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bringing a Touch of Jazz Even to Familiar Pop Songs
text: The pristine and lightly quavering sound of Kate McGarry’s voice doesn’t send up any flares identifying her as a jazz singer. But she certainly deserves the designation, as she confirmed with a well-rounded performance at the Jazz Standard on Thursday night.

headline: Hands on the Wheel, Not on the BlackBerry Keys
text: Do u txt whl drvng?

headline: Amid Burst of Fervor, Pope Canonizes a Brazilian
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, May 11 — After canonizing Brazil’s first native-born saint and receiving a bracing dose of Brazilian-style religious fervor at an outdoor Mass, Pope Benedict XVI called Friday for more forceful evangelization throughout Latin America to counter growing conversions to Pentecostal Protestant groups.

headline: Paint by the Numbers (When Your Canvas Is the Bathroom Wall)
text: It is time to paint the bathroom again. Cracks are showing up on the door and the ceiling — well, you don’t want to know about the ceiling.

headline: Suspects in Army Base Terror Plot Are Held Without Bail
text: CAMDEN, N.J., May 11  The six men charged in connection with a plot to attack the Fort Dix military reservation were ordered held without bail on Friday by a federal magistrate.

headline: Suspicious Trading on the Rise
text: On Wall Street, it feels like the 1980s all over again. Investment banks and private equity firms are minting money on a binge of deal making. Buyouts are not only back, but bigger than ever. Billionaire titans of finance are feted at huge, glittering parties. Even leggings are back in style.

headline: Recruits Say Joining Police Force Is a Test of Wills and Wallets
text: There are days when Wilfredo Gonell fantasizes about not having to steer his dates to the dollar menu. Or when Michael Ferrari, who is 27, recalls his life before peanut butter and jelly sandwich lunches, and before he had to become a roommate with his mom.

headline: The Mayor Strikes a Nerve
text: We might ask why Virginia’s Legislature has decided to protect some of its shadier gun dealers from being unmasked. But, unfortunately, we already know the answer: more craven service to the all-powerful gun lobby.

headline: A Charm School Teaching a Lot More Than Manners
text: Is strength charming? And by strength I don’t mean traps and lats, or even that elusive “strength of character” that no one has probably had since 1963, if anyone ever had it.

headline: Mexico: Troops Moving Into Eighth State
text: The government said it would send federal troops to an eighth state, Veracruz, on the Gulf Coast, to battle drug traffickers. The announcement came after gunmen from a suspected drug gang killed four bodyguards for family members of Gov. Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico State vacationing in Veracruz.

headline: For the Record
text: The Saturday Interview in Business Day last week, with Brett White, the chief executive at the real estate company CB Richard Ellis, referred incorrectly to acquisitions the company made in the 1990s. It bought investment management and commercial mortgage brokerage firms, not a pension fund and a commercial bank.

headline: The Psychiatrists and Drug Makers (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Contrarian on Retirement Says Wait
text: Come retirement, it will finally be time to get back the money that has been extracted from your paycheck your entire working life.

headline: The Commissioner of Baseball Is on Deck
text: MILWAUKEE, May 11 — Bud Selig, the commissioner of Major League Baseball, slowly turned the desk chair in his 30th-floor corner office toward a panoramic view of Lake Michigan. Few could see him here, but Selig knows the eyes of the nation’s baseball fans are watching him.

headline: As Kennedy Traffic Rises, So Do Worries About Delays and Heavier Runway Use
text: Traffic at the New York area’s busiest airport, Kennedy International, has jumped about 25 percent in the last year, aviation officials say. The increase raises concerns about serious flight delays as summer approaches and is pushing the Federal Aviation Administration to consider major changes in runway operations.

headline: Sabres Happy to Be Here, or to Be at All
text: BUFFALO, May 11 — The most popular of the Buffalo Sabres may not be the clutch-scoring forward Chris Drury, or the elastic goalie Ryan Miller, or even the scowling coach with the fitting surname, Lindy Ruff.

headline: For the Record
text: A front-page article last Saturday about a dispute among some conservatives over whether Darwinian theory undermines or supports conservative principles erroneously included one social Darwinist among Victorian-era social Darwinists who adopted evolutionary theory to justify colonialism and imperialism. Herbert Spencer opposed both.

headline: Hepburn, Revisited
text: Palm Springs

headline: A Feeble Performance
text: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales has reportedly begun telling friends and associates that he has weathered the storm over the firing of nine United States attorneys and that his job is safe despite widespread calls for his resignation. We can only hope he is wrong. Not only is the purge of the attorneys extremely serious, it is part of a long chain of evidence that Mr. Gonzales does not have the ability or the moral compass to do his vitally important job.

headline: Cheney, on Carrier, Sends Warning to Iran
text: Vice President Dick Cheney used the deck of an American aircraft carrier just 150 miles off Iran’s coast as the backdrop yesterday to warn that the United States was prepared to use its naval power to keep Tehran from disrupting oil routes or “gaining nuclear weapons and dominating this region.”

headline: Brahmin Vote Helps Party of Low Caste Win in India
text: NEW DELHI, May 11 — In the age-old caste divisions of India, a new political calculus has emerged.

headline: Medical Gear That Rarely Makes News
text: Becton, Dickinson & Company may well be the most invisible of the nation’s publicly traded medical device giants. Its revenue, which topped $5.7 billion last year, comes from the sale of syringes, diagnostic kits, lab equipment and related gear widely used at home and overseas in doctors offices and hospitals.

headline: For the Record
text: The Sports of The Times column yesterday, about the significance of Roger Clemens’s signing with the slow-starting Yankees, referred incorrectly to the timing of a pivotal play in the team’s 14-2 defeat on Thursday by the Texas Rangers. The Rangers took the lead when the Yankees failed to execute a rundown in the fifth inning, not the fourth inning.

headline: In the Gauzy Glow of the Mayfly
text: STARLIGHT, Pa., May 6 — Just as spring follows winter, the annual progression of mayfly hatches on Eastern rivers provides a boost to the spirits of trout fishermen.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) AMERICAN DREAMZ (2006) This comedy directed by Paul Weitz (“In Good Company” and, with his brother, Chris, “About a Boy”), in which a bumbling American president (Dennis Quaid) signs on to judge a television talent show in an effort to boost his popularity, appears just as the “American Idol” season is nearing its climax. Above: Hugh Grant plays the Simon Cowell-esque host; Mandy Moore is the contestant-next-door with the voice of an angel who’s hiding some arsenic under all that lace. And Willem Dafoe, doing his best Dick Cheney impersonation, is the president’s chief of staff, who thought up the publicity stunt in the first place.

headline: Built to Last, and Lasting
text: NEWBERN, Ala., May 6 — They used to serve the hog whole at the annual pig roast here in Hale County, in central Alabama. The architecture students who gathered to honor another year of designing and constructing buildings would slice their own fatty hunks of pork to pile on paper plates, alongside fried catfish, shredded coleslaw and hush puppies.

headline: A Searchable List of Religious Earmarks
A Peek Inside a Beautiful Home
text: A look at one Chappaqua couple who agreed to allow scores of strangers into their home to benefit the local historical society.

headline: Pope Warns Drug Dealers of Punishment From God
text: GUARATINGUETA, Brazil, May 12 -- Aiming to underline the church's concern for poverty and other social problems in Brazil, Pope Benedict XVI declared on a visit to a drug rehabilitation center here Saturday that God would punish drug dealers.

headline: The Birds of Summer
text: Some pretty rare birds have been spotted this spring at ball parks around the country.

headline: 2008: Abortion and Taxes
text: On Thursday at Houston Baptist College, Rudolph W. Giuliani tried out his new political strategy of confronting head on his departures from the traditional G.O.P. platform. The Times’s Marc Santora and Adam Nagourney report that the speech “appeared to reflect two calculations by his campaign.”

headline: And Then There Was Only Aaron Sele…
text: Jose Reyes finally relented. No more hair. He emerged from the players’ lounge this morning rubbing his newly-smooth head with an I-told-you-so grin on his face. He wasn’t resisting, he said, and it had nothing to do with his 14-game hitting streak ending last night; he was just waiting until the day after he shot footage for a reggaeton video. Didn’t want to look silly for that. So he came in this morning and asked the team’s regular barber, Jordan, (and not the higher-priced Carlos Beltran or Carlos Delgado), to buzz off his curls for the first time in about five years. It took about 10 minutes.

headline: Senna Mania!
text: It was an absolute zoo after the GP2 race in Barcelona today as Bruno Senna, Ayrton’s nephew, won the race in only his third GP2 race and with not quite three years of car racing behind him. He moves to third place in the series, which is a Formula One support race, and a final stepping stone to the highest level of racing. I wrote a little about Bruno after the first GP2 race in Bahrain, so I thought I should continue with the theme. In fact, I could not avoid the theme this time.

headline: The More You Know
text: Went into the Brewers clubhouse this morning to catch up with outfielder/fellow unabashed Eagles fan Kevin Mench, who I covered in Dallas two years ago. On the way out, I couldn’t help but notice that photographs of the umpiring crew, along with short biographies underneath, were stuck to the back of the door.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu
text: Imagine this Sunday’s breakfast menu as a rather limited buffet. You can take huge, belly-busting helpings of presidential politics, but you might have to scrape at the bottom of the tray to get much of anything else.

headline: Derek Jeter Outlasts Them All
text: I wrote a story for the Sunday paper about Derek Jeter, who’s leading the A.L. in batting average and hits. Doug Mientkiewicz compares Jeter to his former teammate, Paul Molitor, who finished with 3,319 hits. Jeter has 2,200 hits, with no end in sight.

headline: Fred Thompson’s Just-Secret-Enough Meeting
text: Fred D. Thompson, the “Law & Order” star and subject of much speculation about his presidential ambitions, is practically above our head right now, speaking to a secretive group of conservative heavyweights and activists.

headline: The Courage of Mel Stottlemyre
text: Mel Stottlemyre spent the afternoon at the incomparable Elliott Bay Book Co. in Seattle’s Pioneer Square, meeting fans and signing copies of his autobiography, Pride and Pinstripes, written with John Harper. Then Stottlemyre, the former Yankees pitcher and pitching coach, came by Safeco Field to see his old team for the second day in a row.

headline: The Empire in the Mirror
text: The only sure thing that can be said about the past is that anyone who can remember Santayana’s maxim is condemned to repeat it. As a result, the danger of not understanding the lessons of history is matched by the danger of using simplistic historical analogies. Those who have learned the lessons of Munich square off against those who have learned the lessons of Vietnam, and then they both invoke the bread-and-circus days of the overstretched Roman empire in an attempt to sound even more subtle and profound.

headline: Traffic Cones, Missing in Action
text: LITTLE seemed unusual outside Public School 24 in Riverdale on Wednesday morning, as a parade of buses, S.U.V.’s and sedans discharged children in scuffed sneakers in front of the two-story red brick school on West 236th Street.

headline: Forget the Lamborghini. He’d Rather Drive a V-8.
text: SHEIK MARWAN AL-MUALLA has a new V-10 Lamborghini Gallardo that he has driven only once. Ditto for his new Ferrari.

headline: Surprised? Maybe You Shouldn’t Be
text: FOR weeks now, corporate earnings reports have outstripped analysts’ expectations, contributing in no small part to the fizzy mood on Wall Street. But here’s a sobering thought: those expectations were way too low in the first place.

headline: This Season’s Must-See Criminal Trial
text: “Sex and the City,” meet “Law & Order.”

headline: When Children Fly Alone, Who’s in Charge?
text: YOUR children are going to camp far from home this summer, but you can’t get off work or justify the expense of an extra plane ticket just to fly them there. Should you trust the airlines to take care of them if they fly alone?

headline: A Proposal for Mini-Spaces: Mini-Soccer
text: West Harlem is swarming with real estate speculators these days, so a worldly bystander might not have been surprised to see Irv Smalls Jr. looking covetously the other day at a trash-strewn lot on 114th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard.

headline: Giants Both Hopeful and Wary of One Rookie’s Potential
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 12  It was the first N.F.L. practice for most of the 50 players at Giants Stadium. When it ended, about noon Saturday on the first day of the rookie minicamp, the new Giants wandered quietly around the locker room or ate lunch, getting used to unfamiliar surroundings and introducing themselves to one another.

headline: Brief Histories of Time
text: In Berkeley, Calif., where Liza Dalby lives, the traditional notion of four seasons, each constituting a quarter of the year, is falsified daily. Dalby is an anthropologist — her first book chronicled her experience, in the mid-1970s, inside the “flower and willow world” of the Kyoto geisha (remarkably, she became one herself) — and here she adapts an ancient Chinese almanac whose division of the year into 72 five-day periods has influenced not only the Japanese concept of time but also her own. In 72 short essays, with lowercase titles like “dormant creatures start to twitch,” “chrysanthemums are tinged yellow” and “magpies nest,” Dalby meditates on the changes under way in her garden, tells stories from her years in the field and contemplates etymologies and linguistic puzzles.

headline: A Downtowners’ Club for Poets on a Curfew
text: IN the annals of New York’s postpunk, polysexual downtown bohemia, celebrated haunts are best known by their memorable evenings. The night at the Pyramid in 1984, when the Red Hot Chili Peppers first played the East Coast and shocked the dive’s drag queens with wardrobes limited to artfully placed socks. Or the final marathon, in December 2000, of the cult party Jackie 60, which reigned on Tuesdays in the 1990s at Mother, the club-cum-salon in the meatpacking district.

headline: Not Yet in High School, but Focused on College
text: White Plains

headline: Writing the Book on Hating the Sox
text: Jerome from Maine is a Yankees fan.

headline: At the Pleasure
text: Pleasure is a beautiful word. That s in the middle, pronounced like the z in azure, a word favored by lyric poets, gives a little thrill to the mouth. The meaning in the noun alone — “happy satisfaction or enjoyment; delight, gratification” — runs 26 printed-out pages in the Oxford English Dictionary Online, including “the indulgence of physical, especially sexual, desires or appetites” specifically to take one’s pleasure, a lazily elegant way of saying “to have sexual intercourse.”

headline: The Odd Couple
text: Visionaries or cynics? Peacemakers or warmongers? Few individuals in recent times have provoked as much controversy as Richard Nixon and his partner in foreign affairs, Henry Kissinger. Admirers laud the two men for dramatically easing the cold war and sensibly recognizing the limits of American power to shape the world. Critics castigate them as Machiavellians who undertook reckless policies in the third world, often throwing American power behind brutal tyrants in elusive quests for international stability.

headline: Melissa Holsinger, John-Paul Anderson
text: Melissa Costiere Holsinger, a daughter of Lorraine and John R. Holsinger of Hackensack, N.J., is to be married today to John-Paul Ryan Anderson, a son of Sandra and H. Charles Anderson of Boise, Idaho. The Rev. John J. Ranieri, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Queen of All Saints Church in Brooklyn.

headline: Stirring Up Support for Those That Walk, Fly, Swim and Slither
text: Darien

headline: My First Lesson in Motherhood
text: I SAW the scar the first time I changed Natalie’s diaper, just an hour after the orphanage director handed her to me in a hotel banquet room in Nanchang, a provincial capital in southeastern China.

headline: Plenty to Admire (Punctuation Aside)
text: THE arrival of Michaels’ at the Boardwalk has made Riverhead a dining destination. The restaurant, which opened in late March, is a beauty that would fit right into the Hamptons or Manhattan. In fact, it is the younger sibling of Michaels’ at Maidstone Beach in East Hampton, which dates from 1984 and was taken over in 2005 by Debra and Rich Gherardi. They breathed new life into the place, but kept the name with its misplaced apostrophe.

headline: Yfat Reiss, Bradley Gendell
text: Yfat Miri Reiss and Bradley Howard Gendell were married last evening by Rabbi Sol Greenberg at the Wheatleigh, a hotel in Lenox, Mass.

headline: Music, Love and Fatalism: How Irish
text: DON’T get John Carney, the Irish-born director of “Once,” started on the topic of movie musicals. “I like ‘Guys and Dolls,’ ‘Singin’ in the Rain’ and ‘A Star Is Born,’ ” he said in a recent interview in New York. “When it works, a musical is an amazing thing. But it rarely works.”

headline: After Years of Turmoil, Miller Quits U.S. Team
text: Bode Miller, the former Olympic medalist and World Cup champion, announced his departure from the United States ski team yesterday, a day after his cousin Liko Kenney had a violent confrontation with a New Hampshire police officer that left the officer and Kenney dead.

headline: The Year of the Dog
text: One of the tenderest, least self-interested love scenes to have graced a page in a decade or so pops up a little more than halfway through Cathleen Schine’s latest novel, “The New Yorkers,” when Everett, a gruff, divorced 50-year-old chemist who has been conducting a lazy affair with a 26-year-old named Polly (she lives in his building), is bowled over by a wave of bliss. As Everett sits in his apartment, reading the paper and sipping a martini, a pair of warm eyes unexpectedly meets his, and his world turns from blasé to rosé. “Everett experienced an unfamiliar sensation,” Schine writes. “He was suddenly, intensely aware of the room around him, of the soft order of his furnishings and his life, of the soft order outside where day was giving way to night, of the TV sounds and the cold wet of the martini glass, of the smudgy feel of newsprint on his fingers, but mostly he was aware of joy — the wild, clattering joy of being alive. ‘Howdy,’ he whispered.”

headline: Beethoven in a Barn, and More
text: Arizona

headline: The Week on Long Island
text: New Prosecutors Will Fight Drunken Driving

headline: Cloudy, With a Chance of Golf Balls
text: THE sun was finally out last week, and on a clear Wednesday afternoon, group after group of golfers stood on a grassy hill at the southern edge of Brooklyn, across the street from the leafy grounds of the Poly Prep Country Day School, and peered down the ninth fairway of the city-owned Dyker Beach Golf Course.

headline: Nascar Teams Line Up to Make a Pitch for a Big Catch
text: DARLINGTON, S.C., May 12  The suitors are beginning to line up for the chance to talk Dale Earnhardt Jr. into driving for their race team next season.

headline: An Appeal to Look East
text: MARC deVENOGE grew up in Manhasset, a wealthy enclave on the North Shore of Nassau County, but spent summers sailing and cycling on the North Fork at the East End of Long Island.

headline: The What? Committee
text: The question surrounding New Jersey’s legislative ethics committee is whether it is for ethics or against them. In the 34 years of its existence, a period marked by one Trenton scandal after another, the committee has imposed sanctions on only four legislators: three simple reprimands and a small fine.

headline: Correction: Taking the Long View
text: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about residential towers on Central Park West, gave an incorrect cross street for the apartment building at 1040 Fifth Avenue, which is cited as an inspiration for the design of 15 Central Park West. It is East 85th Street, not 84th Street.

headline: On the Snake River, Dam’s Natural Allies Seem to Have a Change of Heart
text: LOWER GRANITE DAM, Wash. — The wheat Bryan Jones grows in Eastern Washington begins its journey to Asia on barges along the lower Snake River. The river, once a wild, muscular torrent, was made barge friendly a quarter-century ago by four of the nation’s most controversial hydropower dams.

headline: Monica Yang and Michael Tai
text: Monica Ina Yang, a daughter of Joung Sook Yang of Studio City, Calif., and the late Dr. Soon Chung Yang, was married yesterday to Michael Wei-kwun Tai, the son of Kay and Jackson P. Tai of Greenwich, Conn., and Singapore. The Rev. Dr. Stuart H. Hoke performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in New York.

headline: Caught in the Headlights
text: AS the Upper East Side braces for the commotion and transformation that will undoubtedly mark the first phase of construction of the Second Avenue subway, a very few of the neighborhood’s residents face a more dramatic change. To make room for subway stations and other components of the system, some buildings and the people who live in them will have to go.

headline: Homes for $1? Sure, but They’re Real Fixer-Uppers
text: NORWICH

headline: House Tours: Inviting Outsiders In
text: Chappaqua, N.Y.

headline: Antique Horror Show
text: As a literary form, pastiche has its pleasures, often witty ones, as the career of Arthur Phillips proves. His first novel, “Prague,” doesn’t immediately read as an imitation, since it tells the contemporary tale of young expatriates in Budapest, loosely based on the author’s own experiences in Hungary. But what about that anomalous section in the middle, a 70-odd-page history of a Hungarian printing family? As if to acknowledge the pleasures of such research, Phillips’s follow-up novel, “The Egyptologist,” dispatched with a contemporary setting and fully embraced historical detail, this time more boldly, recreating the fantasia of 1920s Tut-mania, complete with desert brigands.

headline: Floating Away
text: Several years ago, I worked as a student chaplain at a children’s hospital for six months. While there, I often heard that children were “better” at dying than adults. The idea that children have an innate understanding of death that adults lack is indeed compelling. But personally, I never saw it. The death I saw was painful. It was hard.

headline: Getting Better All the Time
text: It should be said: Kevin Henkes is a genius. Not that he needs me to point this out. And not that it will be news to the many fans of his 37 books or the judges who have made him the rare author-illustrator to have received both a Caldecott Medal (the picture-book prize) and a Newbery Honor (the runner-up children’s fiction prize). And yet he isn’t quite the household name that Dr. Seuss and Maurice Sendak are, though he should be.

headline: The Week in Westchester
text: A Month After the Flood, Aid Requests Continue

headline: Correction: Tell Them Seth Sent You
text: The Weekend in New York column on April 29 about former speakeasies referred incorrectly to the attention that one bar, Bill’s Gay Nineties, has received from guidebooks. It is included in the Zagat New York City night life guide; it has not been overlooked by Zagat.

headline: Parkway Expansion Plan Draws Opposition
text: WHEN Gilmore Clark, the landscape architect who worked on many New York-area highways for Robert Moses, came to New Jersey to design the Garden State Parkway in the early 1950s, he held to certain principles to keep it both beautiful, like Connecticut’s Merritt Parkway, and efficient, like the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

headline: Earnings and Reports Give the Dow a Lift
text: The Dow Jones industrial average rose again last week on strong corporate earnings and economic reports that sustained Wall Street’s hopes for lower interest rates.

headline: Charles Dickens’s Books Are Basis for New Park
text: Charles Dickens’s 19th-century characters are about to be brought to life in a decidedly 21st-century manner — as animatronic figures in a new theme park based on the author’s books and life. Opening May 25, Dickens World (www.dickensworld.co.uk), in Chatham, Kent, England (where Dickens spent most of his childhood), will introduce visitors to life in Dickensian times — from the architecture and street scenes to the smells and sounds.

headline: Lauren Berger, Stuart Ruderfer
text: Lauren Rachel Berger, a daughter of Marjorie Berger and Dr. Neil Berger of Penn Valley, Pa., was married last evening to Stuart Benjamin Ruderfer, the son of Jill Ruderfer and Irwin Ruderfer of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Geoffrey Spector officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: COMEDY

headline: Courtney Young, Laurin Penland
text: Courtney Brummett Young and Melinda Laurin Penland, both involved in the construction business, affirmed their partnership yesterday. Sara Smolik, a friend of the couple, led a commitment ceremony on the beach at Wrightsville Beach, N.C.

headline: Deirdre Cahill, John Swagerty
text: Deirdre Anne Cahill, a daughter of Sheelagh and William T. Cahill of Bangor, Pa., was married yesterday to John Fitzgerald Swagerty, a son of Ann and Terry C. Swagerty of Roseburg, Ore. The Rev. Robert Beloin, the Roman Catholic chaplain at Yale University, officiated at St. Charles Borromeo Church in Brooklyn.

headline: ‘Warehoused’ Apartments
text: Q I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a seven-unit building in Manhattan. The landlord has emptied the four apartments above me, and he lives in two apartments below me. For the last three years, he has warehoused the upstairs apartments, which had been rent-stabilized, but has allowed friends and religious students to stay there rent-free. Is he allowed to do this?

headline: Hey, Pop Idol, Surrender My Name!
text: HOW do you compete with an Angel?

headline: Love’s Deity
text: It has always been convenient to see John Donne (1572-1631) as the St. Augustine of English letters, made priestly and pure in his own good time, and not too soon to have produced the brainy carnal thrustings of his early love poems. Donne himself made things misleadingly neat for posterity by drawing his own contrasts between “Jack Donne” and “Dr. Donne,” dean of St. Paul’s Cathedral, and by setting “the Mistresse of my youth, Poetry,” against “the wyfe of mine age, Divinity.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Hard Race From Backstretch to White House
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 10 — There was the hug from President Bush, and small talk with Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., and the introduction to Queen Elizabeth II. Calvin Borel blushed as he recounted the fairy tale evening at the White House, a grin cracking across a face as well worn as an old saddle.

headline: A Good Summer to Leave the Car in the Garage
text: The summer forecast for gasoline prices is out. Quick summary: you may want to stay home for your vacation and ask your boss about telecommuting.

headline: No Muggings in New Dorp, and Game Fans Are Miffed
text: Imagine, if you will, that you are Niko Bellic, the main character of Grand Theft Auto IV, a video game due out in October. With free rein in Liberty City, a meticulously rendered stand-in for New York, you can carjack a hot rod in Dumbo and zoom down the Manhattan Bridge at 140 miles per hour. If you’re short on cash, you can mug a tourist in Times Square or stick up a group of workers on the Red Hook piers.

headline: A Joke Inspires a Hall of Fame That’s No Joke
text: Commack

headline: Civilian Deaths Undermine Allies’ War on Taliban
text: ZERKOH, Afghanistan, May 9 — Scores of civilian deaths over the past months from heavy American and allied reliance on airstrikes to battle Taliban insurgents are threatening popular support for the Afghan government and creating severe strains within the NATO alliance.

headline: Voters in Dallas Suburb Back Limit on Renting to Illegal Immigrants
text: DALLAS, May 12 — Voters in a Dallas suburb approved a contentious proposal Saturday to ban landlords from renting apartments to most illegal immigrants.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An entry in the hardcover advice best-seller list on Page 32 of the Book Review today, for “The Loved Dog,” omits the name of the writer with whom Tamar Geller collaborated on the book. She is Andrea Cagan.

headline: A Mall Plan, a Call to Arms, a Plot of Land Still Empty
text: SYOSSET, N.Y.

headline: Spangles All Around
text: WITH ink-black hair and silver-streaked eye shadow, Camille Wojtasiak, 47, is a dancer who inspires women to dip and swoon and men to take notes on her technique. As she confidently leads a swift fox trot or a gliding waltz, the only thing belying her calm is a pesky trickle of sweat.

headline: Earth to G.O.P.: The Gipper Is Dead
text: OF course you didn’t watch the first Republican presidential debate on MSNBC. Even the party’s most loyal base didn’t abandon Fox News, where Bill O’Reilly, interviewing the already overexposed George Tenet, drew far more viewers. Yet the few telling video scraps that entered the 24/7 mediasphere did turn the event into an instant “Saturday Night Live” parody without “SNL” having to lift a finger. The row of 10 middle-aged white candidates, David Letterman said, looked like “guys waiting to tee off at a restricted country club.”

headline: Keeping Precious Artwork Safe
text: STEALING a painting, according to the artist Scott Richter, is a lot easier than you’d imagine. Perhaps not from major museums, which have sophisticated alarms and guards in every room. But after 30 years working as a painter, sculptor and teacher , Mr. Richter has learned that lesser institutions can rarely afford such tight security.

headline: Dinosaurigami
text: Big is beautiful — and it leaps directly off the page at you with teeth and claws bared in “Encyclopedia Prehistorica: Mega-Beasts.” This intricate pop-up book is billed as the third and final entry in Robert Sabuda and Matthew Reinhart’s “Prehistorica” series, following “Dinosaurs” and “Sharks and Other Sea Monsters.” Like the previous volumes, the book is filled with elaborately engineered paper creatures that burst forth in all their 3-D glory, no funky cardboard glasses required.

headline: Nicole VanDernoot, Jared Hirsch
text: Nicole Ruth VanDernoot and Jared Brett Hirsch were married last evening at Boston Harbor Hotel in Boston. Cantor Jodi Sufrin officiated.

headline: An Open, Sunlit Space at 7 World Trade Center
text: WHEN Mansueto Ventures bought the magazines Inc. and Fast Company from the German publisher Gruner & Jahr two years ago, it immediately began polishing the two titles. The paper quality was improved, staff changes were made and the editorial content was sharpened, according to Mansueto, the new owner. The company also wanted its new offices in New York to project the same retooled image, by emphasizing that the magazines were no longer part of a huge global stable of mainstream publications on subjects ranging from politics to parenting to decorating.

headline: Jennifer Merzon, Christopher Evans
text: Jennifer Lee Merzon and Christopher Michael Evans were married last evening by the Rev. James L. Burns at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan. The Right Rev. Andrew St. John, the vicar of the Church of the Transfiguration in Manhattan, participated in the ceremony.

headline: We Don’t Need 169 Fiefs
text: Connecticut is an old state; many towns have been part of the landscape for more than 350 years. That provides residents with a rich history. It also carries a significant downside. Communities’ boundaries were set centuries ago, and so was the manner in which they raise money. Beginning in colonial times, Connecticut’s towns and cities have come to rely heavily — too heavily — on property taxes to meet their civic needs.

headline: Lauren Kelley, Martin Koopman
text: Lauren Hawkes Kelley, a daughter of Marcia Eve Kelley and Dr. William E. Kelley Jr. of Richmond, Va., was married there yesterday to Martin Julius Koopman, the son of Peggy Koopman-Boyden of Hamilton, New Zealand, and John Koopman of Christchurch, New Zealand. The Rev. James Glass, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Bridget’s Catholic Church.

headline: Kelly McMenamin, Frederick Wang
text: Colleen Cara McMenamin and Frederick William Wang were married yesterday at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: A Wished-For House With a Hideaway Nook
text: ON her fourth birthday, Abbie Hornburg made a wish on a party balloon as it floated up into the sky.

headline: How the West Side Was Won
text: Q On the East Side of Manhattan the names of avenues, like First or Park, continue unchanged north of 59th Street, while on the West Side the names change. Ninth becomes Columbus, for instance. Why? ... Herb Dooskin, Manhattan

headline: Venturing Out of the City and Into Creation
text: TIVOLI, N.Y.

headline: Religious Groups Reap Federal Aid for Pet Projects
text: St. Vincent College, a small Benedictine college southeast of Pittsburgh, wanted to realign a two-lane state road serving the campus. But the state transportation department did not have the money.

headline: ‘Bigger Than Life’
text: To the Editor:

headline:
Nuclear Physics: Not Just for Men; Interfaith Preparation for Climate’s Hazards; What I Expect
From Poetry (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Natalie Lui, Stephen Duncan
text: Chunghymn Natalie Lui and Stephen M. Duncan were married yesterday at the Seminary Chapel at the Virginia Theological Seminary in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Dr. M. Craig Barnes, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: In New Role, Senator Clinton’s Strategist in Chief
text: Bill Clinton’s connections, and his endless supply of chits, only begin to capture his singular role in his wife’s presidential candidacy, advisers and friends of the couple say. He is the master strategist behind the scenes; the consigliere to the head of “the family,” as some Clinton aides refer to her operation; and a fund-raising machine who is steadily pulling in $100,000 or more at receptions.

headline: Heart of a Company, and a Family
text: Irvington

headline: The Charming Gadfly Who Saved the High Line
text: FOR all the giddiness surrounding the transformation of the High Line, the city’s favorite elevated railway, into a linear park running from the meatpacking district to Hell’s Kitchen, nearly one-third of it remains in danger of being torn down. The stretch between 30th and 34th Streets, where the High Line loops gracefully around parts of the railyards between 10th and 12th Avenues, is shaping up as the last battleground for the innovative project.

headline: Babymoon: Getting Away, While There Are Just Two of You
text: AT 20 weeks pregnant, Courtney Monardo, a 40-year-old processor for a mortgage company in Scottsdale, Ariz., was — to quote Madeleine Kahn in “Blazing Saddles” — “so tired.”

headline: The Alchemy of Violence
text: The intellectual thriller, dripping with blood and erudition, was invented by Poe, refined by Borges and Umberto Eco, and eventually attained its popular apotheosis in “The Da Vinci Code.” By now, its cogs and pulleys are so familiar that seasoned readers don’t flinch at time travel, cryptography, a famous ghost or two and the rest of the shopworn gadgetry of the genre. Rebecca Stott’s intricately plotted “Ghostwalk” begins in the orthodox fashion, with a corpse, a clue and an armchair detective. But it also has a scholarly authority and imaginative sparkle all too rare in upscale pulp — or, for that matter, any kind of writing.

headline: Soft Market? What Soft Market?
text: WHEN it comes to transactions in the New York City real estate market, April is the sweetest month, at least for the sellers of co-ops and condominiums and those hard-working brokers who count on the commission checks handed over at closing.

headline: Back Home, the Nets’ All-Stars Return to Life
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 12 — LeBron James took his first loss of the 2007 playoffs Saturday, but he set aside his disappointment long enough to appreciate the way it was delivered.

headline: Evelyn Hsieh, Joseph Donroe
text: Dr. Evelyn Joyce Hsieh and Dr. Joseph Anthony Donroe were married Friday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The Rev. Paul M. Mayer, a priest associated with the Federation of Christian Ministries, officiated.

headline: What Kind of History Is Bonds Making?
text: As he hits his way inexorably to baseball’s career home run record, Barry Bonds has even his fellow major leaguers confused. What should they think and how should they view him? Have all of his home runs been legitimate, or have they been chemically aided? Does it matter, especially if he was hitting them against pitchers whose fastballs and curveballs were chemically aided?

headline: Correction: Beware the Siren Lebanon
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the history of Israel’s difficulties in Lebanon referred incorrectly to a commission that issued a scathing report on Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s handling of the war with Hezbollah last summer. It was a government commission, not a parliamentary committee.

headline: The Whole Empire
text: Melville

headline: Something There Is That Loves a Wall
text: IT was a quiet Sunday afternoon in Chelsea, but all three branches of the Perry Rubenstein Gallery were buzzing as assistants uncrated and positioned sculptures — including a green soap bicycle, a gold-plated spade and a silver abalone shell filled with coins — by the South African artist Robin Rhode. Yet the most intense interchange involved the artist himself, who was arguing quietly with his dealer, Mr. Rubenstein, about a drawing he had executed earlier that day directly onto a gallery wall.

headline: Improving Gateway National Park by Design
text: GATEWAY NATIONAL RECREATION AREA, a 26,607-acre national park along the Atlantic coast that strings together a dozen separate and diverse parcels from New Jersey to the Nassau County border, allows visitors a wide variety of activities, some atypical for a protected area.

headline: Russia to Get Central Asian Pipeline
text: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, May 12 — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia brokered an agreement on Saturday with two Central Asian countries to build a new gas pipeline to Russia, delivering a major setback to continuing American efforts to send Central Asian natural gas exports directly to Europe.

headline: Adult Themes
text: Before “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” and “Veronica Mars” — but not before “Rebel Without a Cause” and the Shangri-Las — there was “The Outsiders” (1967), a novel by S. E. Hinton that cut to the heart of teenage anxiety and confusion as no other book had. Written in language whose rhythms felt true to the way kids talked, from the point of view of Ponyboy Curtis, a bright, idealistic 14-year-old who veers dangerously close to ending up on the wrong side of the law, “The Outsiders” had the vitality and the audacity of rock ’n’ roll — partly because Hinton was a teenager herself when she wrote it.

headline: Tilting at a Digital Future
text: IN Rupert Murdoch’s world, two things are certain: the sun never sets on the kingdom, and a TV is always on in the background.

headline: Don’t Touch the Water
text: St. Louis

headline: Eliza Harrington, Minor Myers III
text: Dr. Eliza Weil Harrington and Minor Myers III were married in Washington last evening at Anderson House, the home of the Society of the Cincinnati, an association of the descendants of officers in the American Revolutionary War, of which the bridegroom is a member. Peter W. Hall, a judge for the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York, officiated.

headline: Assorted Mysteries of Economic Life
text: THERE are many mysteries in the world of economics. The subject is in good measure terra incognita even now, 231 years after publication of “The Wealth of Nations,” Adam Smith’s free-market bible.

headline: Sister Has Seat of Power as Earnhardt Drives On
text: As Dale Earnhardt Jr. sat before the cameras and rows of reporters Thursday trying to explain his shocking decision to leave the Nascar team founded by his father, there was a mostly quiet presence beside him.

headline: In-Town Living in Morristown
text: MORRISTOWN

headline: Comings and Goings
text: The Zagat Survey, known for rating hotels, restaurants and hot spots in cities like London, Shanghai and Paris, now covers Disney World, too. The Zagat Walt Disney World Insider’s Guide (www.zagat.com; $15.95), rates and reviews Disney’s six Orlando theme parks in categories that include hotels, rides and attractions, golf, shopping and dining. ... Robin Pope Safaris (www.robinpopesafaris.net), which operates out of South Luangwa National Park in Zambia, is offering family-friendly safaris at three of its facilities: Nkwali Camp, Robin’s House and the Luangwa Safari Houses. Children observe animals in their natural habitat and participate in guided nature walks. They also visit a local school. Rates for Nkwali Camp start at $240 a night for ages 12 to 16 and $160 a night for ages 7 to 11. Adult rates start at $380 a person. Rates at the Luangwa Safari houses start at $1,040 a night for a family of four. ... Families visiting Waterville Valley, N.H., might be interested in visiting the Margret and H. A. Rey Center (www.reycenter.org) and the Curious George Cottage, once the summer home of the creators of the celebrated children’s book series about the curious monkey (right). It offers nature walks, writers’ workshops, art shows and activities for children. Three times a month, the center has astronomy nights. On Aug. 10 and 11, the Curious George Cottage Family Festival will include nature walks, lunch with Curious George characters, games, tethered hot air balloon rides, a croquet tournament and a clambake (www.waterville.com). ... Grande Isle Resort on Great Exuma, Bahamas (www.grandisleresort.com), offers the Junkanoo Kids Club. Each two-hour session (twice a day, five days a week), costs $20 a child, and includes pirate-inspired arts and crafts for ages 3 to 12. Villa rates start at $380.

headline: Prescribed Reading
text: Medicine engages life’s existential mysteries: the miraculous moment of birth, the jarring exit at death, the struggle to find meaning in suffering. But medicine is practiced in the mundane world and involves concrete issues like the imbalance of power between physician and patient; the role of quackery, avarice and ego in molding a doctor’s behavior; and the demand for perfection in the face of human fallibility. No insight into its more existential aspects is found in clinical textbooks, properly devoted to physiology, pharmacology and pathology. Rather, it is literature that most vividly grapples with such mysteries, and with the character of physician and patient.

headline: Portuguese Favorites, and Steak With a Twist

And you probably are not familiar with “steak on a rock,” the house specialty of Santos’ Restaurant — perhaps even “invented” there — and more Japanese than Portuguese in spirit. For my money, this is the best $16 steak in the state, or maybe in the country.

headline: Sex, Drugs and Updating Your Blog
text: Jonathan Coulton sat in Gorilla Coffee in Brooklyn, his Apple PowerBook open before him, and began slogging through the day’s e-mail. Coulton is 36 and shaggily handsome. In September 2005, he quit his job as a computer programmer and, with his wife’s guarded blessing, became a full-time singer and songwriter. He set a quixotic goal for himself: for the next year, he would write and record a song each week, posting each one to his blog. “It was a sort of forced-march approach to creativity,” he admitted to me over the sound of the cafe’s cappuccino frothers. He’d always wanted to be a full-time musician, and he figured the only way to prove to himself he could do it was with a drastic challenge. “I learned that it is possible to squeeze a song out of just about anything,” he said. “But it’s not always an easy or pleasant process.” Given the self-imposed time constraints, the “Thing a Week” songs are remarkably good. Coulton tends toward geeky, witty pop tunes: one song, “Tom Cruise Crazy,” is a sympathetic ode to the fame-addled star, while “Code Monkey” is a rocking anthem about dead-end programming jobs. By the middle of last year, his project had attracted a sizable audience. More than 3,000 people, on average, were visiting his site every day, and his most popular songs were being downloaded as many as 500,000 times; he was making what he described as “a reasonable middle-class living” — between $3,000 and $5,000 a month — by selling CDs and digital downloads of his work on iTunes and on his own site.

headline: The Right Stuff, but Usually the Wrong Stuff
text: AT 10 o’clock one morning not long ago, 14 men waited in a brightly lighted corridor of Access Self Storage in Long Island City, Queens, a company that shares a drab stretch of Review Avenue with a strip club, electrical generators and warehouses. The men were there to bid on the foreclosed contents of the first storage locker up for auction — essentially panning for gold. Inside every sealed cardboard box is the possibility of a jewelry collection, a Civil War relic or a first-edition Superman comic book. Far more frequently, though, they find themselves the owners of items like photo albums and sex toys that are worthless — at least to them.

headline: Hunger and Food Stamps
text: If you think people do not go hungry in America, you’re wrong. At last count in 2005, 35 million low-income Americans — about a third of them children — lived in households that cannot consistently afford enough to eat. Since 2005, the situation has most likely become worse. Last year, real wages for low-income workers were still below 2001 levels. This year, job growth is slowing and prices are rising.

headline: Addicted to L-U-V
text: ABOUT three years ago, I stumbled onto something called Scrabble Blitz. It was a four-minute version of Scrabble solitaire, on a Web site called Games.com, and I began playing it without a clue that within 24 hours — I am not exaggerating — it would fry my brain. I’m no stranger to this sort of thing: one summer when I was young, I became so addicted to croquet that I had a series of recurrent dreams in which I was whacking my mother’s head through a wicket.

headline: Tulip Mania

headline: Mountain People
text: Lisa Alther’s raucous novel “Kinflicks” (1976) was all the rage among my high school set for its lurid paperback cover (nude female back, gilt lettering) and its frank talk of erections and lesbian hook-ups. Revisiting the novel 30 years later, it’s clear the packaging sold the contents short: Alther’s best-known book is a witty coming-of-age tale in which a tart-tongued protagonist named Ginny wanders her way through an identity crisis, mostly against a classic counterculture background (soybeans feature prominently).

headline: Cops and Rabbis
text: “Don’t get wistful on me,” says a sly old man in Michael Chabon’s sly new novel, his first big serious one since the best-selling, Pulitzer Prize-winning “Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay,” seven long years ago. “God knows I’ve had my fill of wistful Jews, starting with myself.” Chabon, starting with himself as writers should, seems determined in “The Yiddish Policemen’s Union” to stave off wistfulness by any means, even if it requires him to turn the story of the endless, endemic disappointment of the Jews — their millenniums-old-and-counting wait for the Messiah — into a screwball, alternative-reality, hard-boiled mystery, set, for maximum incongruity, in Alaska. The impressively wacky premise is that after the Holocaust, large numbers of Jews were relocated to Sitka, where by statute they were allowed to make their home for the next 60 years, at the end of which the town would revert to the control of Alaska. Israel, it appears, didn’t work out: the Jewish settlers there were ejected “with savage finality” in 1948. “The Holy Land,” the novel tells us, “has never seemed more remote or unattainable than it does to a Jew of Sitka.” The godforsakenness of the place is something more than a figure of speech.

headline: The Bankable Siren Call of the Misty Isles
text: ABOUT a year ago I started to notice something odd on those evenings when I was channel surfing. When I passed through PBS, I often caught sight of a bunch of impeccably groomed women in shiny gowns singing gorgeous harmonies with great sincerity. Every once in a while a tiny, buxom fiddler would cavort across the stage, tossing her white-blond mane. They induced in me a spacey, Groban-esquestupor. They were Celtic Woman.

headline: Ocean Blues
text: Not long ago, inside the residence of Hawaii’s last queen, Laura Bush stepped to a lectern and carefully pronounced the word “Papahanaumokuakea.” A cheer went up, the Halau Pua Ali’i ’Ilima dancers chanted and Honolulu’s important people took turns praising the first lady’s pronunciation of the new name for the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands Marine National Monument, the largest protected marine area in the world and George W. Bush’s only act of unabashed environmentalism. But amid the easy island music and Laura Bush’s descriptions of the Laysan albatross (“who mate for life”), the significance of the monument felt buried. More than a native Hawaiian cultural heritage site, more than a nesting area for endangered albatrosses, Papahanaumokuakea represents something unique in U.S. conservation history: the first large-scale territorial victory of fish over fishermen.

headline: Correction: Moses and the Co-op City Site

headline: Bucking a Trend, More Houses Sell
text: IN the context of the depressed housing market nationwide, Westchester looks good. The number of sales has been rising since the start of the year, not falling. Prices, however, are down slightly over all, although not in every town — Rye, for instance, has seen a substantial increase in prices.

headline: Sausage Secrets? They’ll Never Tell
text: Contrary to what its name suggests, La Molisana Italian Sausage is not devoted entirely to wurst. But homemade sausage is indeed its primary focus, as is evident from the heady aroma of seasoned meat that engulfs you on entering the pocket-size storefront, located on the ground floor of a two-story residence a few blocks from the center of Waterbury.

headline: Faster Than a Flying Pumpkin
text: WHEN the curtain goes up Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, all vestiges of the opera season that ended two nights before will have disappeared. The marquis’s palace from “Turandot”? Gone. The barge from “Il Trittico”? Headed to storage. Replacing them will be things like shock-absorbent flooring, different lights and even a flying pumpkin for the American Ballet Theater’s spring gala, the start of its 67th season.

headline: The Flight From Iraq

headline: A Festival of Favorite Foods
text: The food at Mardi Gras, a takeout and catering shop in Verona, is perfect party fare: elegant soups, salads, hors d’oeuvres and main dishes. And even when the meal is for one — you, at your desk at lunchtime — the food impresses.

headline: Pope and Bishops Set Thorny Agenda for Talks
text: APARECIDA, Brazil, May 12 — On Sunday, Pope Benedict XVI will shift his attention from the specific issues facing the church in Brazil to the challenges in the whole of Latin America, as he concludes his first pastoral visit to the Western Hemisphere at a conference of the region’s bishops here in this center of religious devotion.

headline: The Secret in the Old Attic
text: I was never as enraptured by Nancy Drew as other girls I knew were. For me the Nancy mysteries, with their odd citron-colored spines, were on a par with Brownies craft projects or board games. Fun in a pallid way, but kind of “what’s the point unless you’re sick in bed?” I was slightly more interested in Nancy’s life than in the cases she solved, where anyone with bad grammar and ragged clothes tended to be guilty. What was it like having a full-time housekeeper always in your face? Did Nancy own any jeans? Why wasn’t she in college?

headline: Cool Reception for Plan to Let Elderly Ride Free
text: STAMFORD, Conn, May 11  To many commuters in Connecticut, the state’s overworked mass transit system would be vastly improved by an infusion of new rail cars providing more seats and new bus routes to cover more ground.

headline: Welcome to Start From Scratch, U.S.A.
text: AT least the meteorite survived. “The world’s largest pallasite meteorite,” that is, or so it is claimed. “The world’s largest hand-dug well” survived too, although it was smothered with debris by the tornado that walloped Greensburg, Kan., a little over a week ago.

headline: The Cape Town Area’s Endless Possibilities
text: A toddler squeals with delight alongside a jumble of boulders, plunking herself thigh high into a sloshing emerald pool within inches of dozens of honking African penguins that squirt in and out of the water like large self-propelled watermelon seeds.

But Ms. Smith, this year’s juror, has done so judiciously. The show is fresh, entertaining and lively, though still very much a community event.

headline: Correction: Who Needs Venice When Zagreb (or Bruges . . .) Beckons?
text: An article April 22 on alternatives to popular European vacation destinations referred imprecisely to beer brewing in Bruges, Belgium. Although beer brewed elsewhere in Belgium by Trappist monks is widely available in Bruges, Trappist monks do not brew beer in the city.

headline: Citing New Admission, Lawyers Seek Murder Case’s Dismissal
text: Lawyers for a man who was convicted of killing a bouncer at the Palladium nightclub in 1990 but who faces a second trial after the conviction was set aside have asked to have the case dismissed based on a prosecutor’s admission that he did not personally believe the man was guilty.

text: BAGHDAD, May 13 — About 4,000 American ground troops supported by surveillance aircraft, attack helicopters and spy satellites swept towns and farmland south of Baghdad on Sunday, searching for three American soldiers who disappeared on Saturday after their patrol was ambushed, military officials said.

headline: Good Enough to Buy by the Tub
text: Baci Gelato in Albertson opened last September, but many people who live nearby have only recently discovered this sweet spot, tucked away on a commercial stretch of Willis Avenue. A cheerful dessert cafe with orange walls, a blue-tiled floor and a half-dozen tables with chairs in rainbow colors, it seems ready made for summer crowds looking to cool off.

headline: Stormy Weather
text: What do you tell a child when a natural disaster darkens the news? “Things like that don’t happen here.” “The grown-ups in charge have it under control.” And when it does happen here, and the grown-ups in charge haven’t a clue, there’s Plan C: “Scientists are working on it.”

headline: From Start to Finish, Pitching Fails Mets
text: In evaluating his pitchers, Manager Willie Randolph says that one of the last things he examines is their records. Too many times, he says, a victory can obscure a poor performance and a loss can cloak a strong one. So what to make of Mike Pelfrey, who fell to 0-5 yesterday when the Mets lost, 12-3, to the majors’ best team, the Milwaukee Brewers, at Shea Stadium?

headline: O’Hair Closes With Flourish and Climbs Into Lead
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., May 12 — On a sticky afternoon near the northeast tip of Florida, a 24-year-old with a precocious manner emerged from the shade for his latest bold endeavor.

headline: Jailhouse Flock
text: The women-in-prison genre, even at its most blatantly exploitative, can’t escape the political. The collective female experience, what we’re allowed and what we’re forbidden, is distilled into the image of rows of women behind bars doing time for crimes that often seem to be entangled in questions about gender and power — the much-beaten woman who finally kills the abusive husband or boyfriend, the prostitute, the drug mule for male gangsters, the mother who inexplicably murders her own children, the teacher who sleeps with her 13-year-old male student. Like a funhouse mirror, prison reflects and distorts the darkest impulses of women, and of the culture in which they maneuver. If your husband cheats on you, again, is it O.K. to run him over with your car a few times? If the tall boy in the junior high math class you teach says he loves you and you really, really love him, too, can you have his baby? If you’ve been repeatedly raped by your stepfather since you were 7, is it any surprise that you grow up to be murderously psychotic?

Schulz and Albert J. Schulz of Osterville, Mass. The Rev. Davis Chappell performed the ceremony at Duluth First United Methodist Church in Duluth, Ga., with the Rev. Gary E. headline: Dance Fever
text: My son Elijah’s teacher recently announced that his preschool class would be having a “music unit.” She informed us of the music unit as she did many things: by posting a sign-up sheet asking for our help. Two dads stepped up to the volunteer plate. One fronts a successful local folk-rock band for kids, and the other is a film scorer who used to be in the indie-rock band Screaming Trees. As for me, I complained.

headline: Going Deep, Before Bonds and Aaron and Ruth
text: There’s no law that says Bud Selig has to show up when Balco’s favorite customer, Barry Bonds, breaks the home run record one of these weeks. After all, other commissioners were not on the premises the last two times the career record was broken.

headline: Summer Camps Take Teenagers Around World
text: If the thought of a traditional summer camp — complete with canoeing and marshmallow roasts — makes your teenager yawn, why not try a more adventuresome approach? According to Peg Smith, chief executive of the American Camp Association, there has been a 59 percent increase in travel camp programs since 2000.

headline: Michele Molfetta, Carolyn Wolpert
text: Michele Molfetta and Carolyn Wolpert affirmed their partnership last evening at Martha Clara Vineyards in Riverhead, N.Y. Patricia Bruder Debrovner, the leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, led the commitment ceremony.

headline: London: Walton Street
text: Walton Street, once known for attracting London's most sophisticated women with its art galleries, designer boutiques and elegant cafes, is now catering to another, more single-minded crowd — mothers willing to pay sky-high prices for their children's pint-sized garments.

headline: Sugar and Spice
text: César Aira is a 6-year-old Argentine girl whose first taste of strawberry ice cream is tainted with cyanide. “I was a devoted daughter,” she says as she lifts the spoon to her lips. “Dad could do no wrong in my eyes.” After she retches, though, her father flies into a rage and murders the ice cream vendor, and the child collapses into a monthlong toxic delirium. She wakes in a hospital bed to a doctor who asks, “And how are we today, young Master César?” Lucky to have been one of the survivors of an unexplained wave of food poisoning, César still has one big, though unstated, problem: she is a precocious little girl trapped in the body of a boy.

headline: Shareholders Benefit When Managers Have a Serious Stake
text: IF you own stock in a company that is ripe for takeover, you should hope the company isn’t acquired by a private equity firm.

headline: Army Career Behind Him, General Speaks Out on Iraq
text: ROCHESTER, May 10 — John Batiste has traveled a long way in the last four years, from commanding the First Infantry Division in Iraq to quitting the Army after three decades in uniform and, now, from his new life overseeing a steel factory here, to openly challenging President Bush on his management of the war.

headline: For Oksana Baiul, a Role Close to Life

headline: Forever Huggy
text: TO Uncle Sam, he’s Isaac Liev Schreiber. To his mother, he’s Huggy Buggy Pinchy Winchy, Huggy for short.

headline: Top Taliban Commander Is Killed in Clash
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, May 13 — The Taliban’s foremost operational commander, Mullah Dadullah, was killed in a joint operation by Afghan security forces and American and NATO troops in Helmand Province, Asadullah Khaled, the governor of the neighboring Kandahar Province, said Sunday.

headline: For Bright Beacons, a Murky Future
text: For decades, they floated over Second Avenue near East 12th Street like twin stars guiding tipsy East Villagers home: “Jade Mountain” in glowing pink bamboo-style letters, and above it, in rosy neon, a smaller, two-sided sign bearing the words “Chow Mein.”

headline: Jordan’s King in West Bank to Discuss Peace Efforts
text: JERUSALEM, May 12  King Abdullah II of Jordan will meet with the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Sunday in the West Bank in an attempt to push along Israeli-Palestinian talks about peace. It will be the king’s first visit to the occupied territory, which Jordan ruled until 1967, in seven years.

headline: 36 Hours in St. Petersburg, Russia
text: BACK when foreigners in Leningrad were treated almost like interlopers, shunted into dormitory-like hotels and pummeled with propaganda about the primacy of Soviet Man, the city was an improbable destination for families. No longer. Rechristened as St. Petersburg, the former Russian capital has recaptured much of its glamour and offers an enchanting landscape not only for lovers of culture but for their children as well. Adults can walk in the footsteps of Pushkin and Dostoevsky, Tchaikovsky and Shostakovich. But the city also has a slew of fantastical palaces, a rousing circus, one of the world's deepest subways and natives who eat pancakes for dinner. What child wouldn't be smitten by that? And if you visit during the summer, the sun barely sets, so there's plenty of time to play. Here's the only rub: getting the little ones to bed when there's still daylight.

text: The Confessor

headline: In Corzine’s Recovery, Doctors Cite Grit and Luck
text: CAMDEN, N.J. — Dr. Steven E. Ross was about to perform an appendectomy shortly before 7 p.m. on a routine Thursday when a nurse paged him to say the governor of New Jersey had suffered an open femur fracture and severe chest injuries and was about to land on the helipad atop Cooper University Hospital here.

headline: Top Taliban Commander Is Killed in Clash
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Sunday, May 13 — Afghan government officials showed the body of Mullah Dadullah, the top operational commander for the Taliban insurgency, to reporters here Sunday morning, saying he had been killed in a joint operation of Afghan and coalition forces.

headline: On Film: Hollywood Shows Its Good Side. Its Bad Side, Too.
text: IT almost goes without saying that the best way to see Hollywood is in the movies, since for obvious reasons the greater Los Angeles area has probably been the setting and subject of more motion pictures than any other American metropolis. The city’s sprawling geography and stark social divisions have given rise to a number of distinctive subgenres, from California noir to show-business satire. The following is a highly selective list of favorites — some classics, some curiosities, not all of them necessarily suitable for family viewing — that have colored, for better or for worse, my own fantasies about Hollywood and its environs. All are available on DVD.

headline: Pop Quiz: Did the Tax Cuts Bolster Growth?
text: POLITICIANS from the president on down have lately been saying that the tax cuts passed in 2001 and 2003 were responsible for the quick growth of the economy starting in mid-2003. That growth has since tapered, but as Republicans lobby to make the tax cuts permanent, it’s worth asking — are they right?

headline: The Greatest Mystery: Making a Best Seller
text: WHEN Shana Kelly, a literary agent at the William Morris Agency, submitted Curtis Sittenfeld’s first novel, “Cipher,” to book publishers in 2003, she had high expectations. She contacted nearly two dozen high-ranking editors at major publishers, expecting every one to make offers for her client’s coming-of-age story set at a boarding school.

headline: Jessica Luterman, Brendan Naeve
text: Jessica Danielle Luterman and Brendan French Naeve were married last evening by Rabbi Jill Hausman at the University Club in Manhattan.

headline: In God, Distrust
text: Observers of the Christopher Hitchens phenomenon have been expecting a book about religion from him around now. But this impressive and enjoyable attack on everything so many people hold dear is not the book we were expecting.

headline: Today’s Face of Abortion in China Is a Young, Unmarried Woman
text: QINGDAO, China — At an abortion clinic in this seaside city, a young woman sat in the recovery room with an IV drip in one hand and a cellphone in the other. She was 22 and worked as a nurse. Her boyfriend, an information technology specialist, sat nearby. They both knew the routine: It was her second abortion in 18 months.

headline: Formula, for Disaster
text: IN case you’re one of the roughly 340 women who will give birth today in New York City — on Mother’s Day no less — I have some news for you: hospitals are no longer mom-friendly. That’s right, in an effort to encourage breast-feeding, what the American Academy of Pediatrics has deemed the healthier food source for newborns, 11 public hospitals in the city have decided to stop giving free formula samples to new mothers.

headline: Commander Visits China to Increase Ties With U.S.
text: BEIJING, May 12  The new commander of United States military forces in the Pacific said Saturday that America wants to continue building closer ties with Chinese forces and he called for more extensive and sophisticated military exchanges and joint exercises between the countries.

text: RAMALLAH, West Bank, May 13 — A rare visit to the West Bank by King Abdullah of Jordan was called off at the last minute today because of bad weather, Palestinian officials said, as serious factional fighting continued in Gaza.

headline: Acura MDX: If It Looks Like a Duck...

text: THE names of the bands Goat, Ashes Are Nutritious and Stringbean and the Stalkers may not mean much to you. But if you follow rock music in New Jersey, chances are at least one of the 157 other acts on the bill will.

headline: To Land a High-Paying Job, Some Try an Executive Coach
text: AFTER more than 20 years in corporate marketing, Chip Perry was ready for a change, so he turned to an executive coach to help him decide exactly what to do.

headline: Not There Yet, in Albany
text: In the strange world of New York State politics, it is sometimes possible to take the wrong step in the right direction. If that makes no sense elsewhere, it is perfectly understandable in Albany. There, the new comptroller, Thomas DiNapoli, has proposed a plan to begin public financing of state campaigns, starting with the race for comptroller in 2010.

headline: A Troubling Death
text: Poor immigrants die in our suburbs all the time and people barely take notice. They fall sick or get hurt doing jobs that are strenuous and unsafe. In January, an Ecuadoran immigrant, the father of six, was killed at a recycling plant in West Babylon, N.Y., when his son accidentally ran over him with a payloader. On a freezing night in February, a young Honduran man went to sleep, drunk, in a tent in some woods near the Long Island Rail Road tracks and never woke up.

headline: Native Daughter
text: Q: You just won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry for your third collection, “Native Guard.” The title refers to a regiment of African-American soldiers who fought on the side of the Union in the Civil War. Is this a well-known chapter of history? Not really. I’ve been interested in historical erasure and historical amnesia for a long time, those things that get left out of the record.

headline: Nassau and Suffolk Rate Poorly on Air Quality
text: WHEN it comes to ozone and other air pollution, Long Island has problems, according to the American Lung Association. In its eighth annual State of the Air report, the association said the Island’s air quality was declining because of the increased presence of ozone and particulates or soot.

headline: Watergate Warrior
text: Howard Hunt, who died in January at the age of 88, was among the last living members of the clandestine service created as part of the Central Intelligence Agency in the late 1940s. Hunt wanted to believe he fit the popular image of the C.I.A.’s founders — the American aristocrats, the tough young veterans of the last good war, the daring amateurs who set out to save the world.

text: BAGHDAD, May 12 — The Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, one of the country’s most powerful Shiite parties, announced Saturday that “revolution” would be dropped from its name and that Iran’s top cleric would cease to be the party’s dominant spiritual leader.

headline: Kristen McAuliffe and John Timken
text: Kristen Leigh McAuliffe, the daughter of Donna Dee McAuliffe and David McAuliffe of Forest Hill, Md., was married last evening to John Henry Timken, a son of Polly Morgan Timken and John Marter Timken Jr. of Old Saybrook, Conn. headline: High Anxiety
text: Is it so bad to grow up Asian in America? One might be forgiven for asking upon encountering “American Born Chinese,” a graphic novel that, with its dark exploration of Asian-American adolescence, won last year’s Michael L. Printz Award for young adult literature and was also a finalist in its genre for a National Book Award.

headline: Only Halfway There
text: I’m glad Democrats are keeping the pressure on President Bush for a withdrawal date from Iraq. It’s the only way to keep him and Iraqis focused on the endgame. But if Democrats really want to be taken seriously on foreign affairs, they need to recognize that they have only half a policy on Iraq. And it’s the easy half.

headline: Her Secret, Smashed Garden
text: FOR the last 15 years, the people of 21st Street in Long Island City, Queens, have often visited a community garden tucked into a corner of Murray Playground.

headline: In Sam Adams Land, This Pinot’s for You
text: Barcibo Enoteca, a four-month-old wine bar on Broadway and West 69th Street, was quietly buzzing. Local residents were packed elbow to elbow on the wooden stools and benches, and patrons in low-key pairs or trios chatted quietly in a space defined by high marble tables, neutral tones and soft lighting.
