headline: Up Front
text: This week’s special Children’s Books section features poetry, Al Gore’s young adult version of “An Inconvenient Truth” and comics for teenagers. But it’s a picture book for the youngest readers that elicits some of the warmest praise. The book is “A Good Day,” by Kevin Henkes. And our reviewer, Bruce Handy, calls it “almost perfect.”

headline: Jennifer Nordin, Srinivasan Soundararajan
text: Jennifer Marie Nordin was married to Srinivasan Soundararajan yesterday in Minneapolis. The Rev. Daniel C. Nordin, an uncle of the bride and a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at Lake of the Isles Lutheran Church.

headline: Cradle of a Sport Has Crossed the Gender Line
text: On the Onondaga Nation near Syracuse, Jeanne Shenandoah adores lacrosse. All eight of her brothers played it. She scours the papers for scores of the local indoor team. But when it comes to women playing the game that her Iroquois forefathers originated centuries ago, the conversation turns tense.

headline: At Least 27 Die as Violence Flares in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 12 — At least 27 people were killed and more than 100 injured in Karachi on Saturday in some of its worst political violence in years, Pakistani officials said.

headline: For Wright, Promise Is Fulfilled
text: When most fans watch David Wright, they see a talented third baseman who is a cornerstone of the Mets. They see a player who is an All-Star, a player who made that nifty barehanded catch in shallow left field and, temporarily, a player who is almost bald.

headline: Behind Many of the Elite Events, a Patron Who Has Deep Pockets
text: The United States Chess Championship begins Tuesday in Stillwater, Okla., but if not for Frank K. Berry, a local resident who put up $50,000, it might not be happening at all.

headline: Band Takes Quick Trip From a Nassau Basement to a Texas Stage
text: USUALLY a Long Island garage band makes its out-of-state debut in a dingy bar in New Jersey or, maybe, in a pub in Connecticut. But for Post Roman it was at a concert at the Backyard, an amphitheater in Austin, Tex., organized by MTV Networks and attended by more than 4,000 ticket holders.

headline: Sweet Pleasures, French Style
text: As France debates the wisdom of its state-mandated 35-hour workweek, Patrice Yvon, a native of Angers, France, and owner of L’Anjou Pâtisserie in Mount Kisco, displays a work ethic that could put the French economy back on its feet. He begins baking at 5 a.m. and shutters his shop between 7 and 7:30 p.m.

headline: Family Ties Bind Philippine Government
text: MANILA, May 12 — When Julian Resuello, the mayor of San Carlos City in the northern Philippines, was killed by gunmen at a campaign rally on April 28, his brother quickly stepped into his shoes.

headline: Judith Lynn and Joel Levy
text: Judith W. Lynn and Joel M. Levy were married on Tuesday by Rabbi Joel Levine at the Four Seasons Resort in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: He Puts Lids on His Excitement
text: THE artist Toland Grinnell cannot pinpoint exactly what it is about a good container that gets his motor revving. “Maybe it has something to do with containment,” he theorized. “Life is supercomplicated, and if you’re a Type A person, you want containment, to have, you know, control, whether it’s an illusion or reality.”

headline: Students See the Future, and It’s Elderly People
text: DANCING to the driving beat of 1960s twist music, the three high school students tried to rouse the spirits of the 50 people in front of them. Some in the audience swayed slightly in their chairs or wheelchairs, or clapped or nodded with the rhythm. Others simply watched; a few dozed despite the high decibels from the live singer and his synthesizer.

headline: And Let’s All Hope for a Long Run
text: DANIELLE BOBISH, a freelance wedding coordinator with a musical-theater background, makes no bones about it: “All weddings technically have a show value to them.”

headline: Less ‘Precious’ Than the Slope? Certainly Cheaper
text: SOMETHING about Park Slope seemed not quite right to Samantha Davidson Green and her husband, Jordan Green, who moved there last September from Los Angeles with their 2-year-old son, Duncan. The couple, who rented an apartment on First Street, liked the neighborhood well enough, feeling reassured by the reputation of its schools and enjoying Prospect Park right next door. There was also the never-ending parade of shops and restaurants to try.

headline: Reviving a No Man’s Land Along the Tennessee River

headline: School Openness
text: A foundation hired me to start and help run a philanthropy club at the high school where I am a junior. We raise money for women’s health in Mexico. None of the other members are paid. Am I ethically wrong not to tell them (or colleges or future employers) that I am paid for work they might assume is voluntary? — Anna Akullian, Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Clothes Don’t Make the Dance (but They Sure Can’t Hurt)
text: WHEN Angel Corella steps out on the Metropolitan Opera stage on Tuesday at the end of Act I of “La Bayadère,” his Solor will sparkle a little more than usual. And it won’t be his personality or a lighting trick. It will be his new tunic.

headline: Erika Mikkelsen, Michael Halford

headline: 5 Killed and 3 Missing in Attack on American Patrol South of Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, May 12 — A coordinated attack on seven American soldiers and an Iraqi Army interpreter Saturday morning south of Baghdad left five of them dead and three missing, the United States military said.

headline: Drive to Cut Emissions Creates Jobs Engine
text: THE challenge of global warming is moving from rhetoric to the workplace, creating jobs as governments, businesses and environmental groups create markets aimed at reducing greenhouse gases.

headline: Style Questions: Grab or Go? Pass or Punch?
text: This year’s Stanley Cup semifinal round is as thick with subplots and coincidences as an episode of “Lost.” But the most important subtext is the clash of styles each semifinal represents.

text: Re “Final Thoughts About My Tenure and The Times’s Future” (May 6):

headline: Old-Fashion Fizz
text: WALTER BACKERMAN, who is more commonly known as Walter the Seltzer Man, is a third-generation deliveryman of seltzer water, which he dispenses door-to-door in spray bottles made of thick green and cobalt glass, some of which date back to when his grandfather made his rounds through the Lower East Side in a horse-drawn wagon.

headline: Sexy? No. But There Are Other Kinds of Appeal.
text: THE funny thing about Tom Hanks and Peter Scolari in the 1980s cross-dressing sitcom “Bosom Buddies” is not how much they look like women. It’s how much they don’t.

headline: Still Invitation Only, but Jets Widen Door for Camp
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., May 12  The Jets coach who was conducting the position meeting Saturday kept referring to Will, Mike and Sam, and every time he did, Cole Konrad felt more lost, like someone trying to follow a conversation about Tony, Paulie and Christopher despite having never watched “The Sopranos.”

headline: A Bare Stage, a Bit of Magic, and a Transfixing ‘Henry V’
text: Let’s begin by stating the obvious: David Conrad is no Kenneth Branagh. As Henry V in the 1989 film version of the Shakespeare play, Mr. Branagh was nothing short of magnificent.

headline: Officer Arrested in Queens
text: An off-duty police officer was arrested in Queens early yesterday after he moved his car while his former companion was trying to remove their 2-year-old daughter from the back seat, the police said.

headline: Couples Enter New Terrain in Push for Gay Marriage in Connecticut
text: HARTFORD, May 11  When the Connecticut legislature approved civil unions three years ago, gay rights advocates viewed it as only a half-victory, a kind of pit stop in their quest for same-sex marriage.

headline: ‘Second Tier’ City to Rise Fast Under India’s Urban Plan
text: NAGPUR, India — A year ago, this relatively small, forgettable city in the heart of India did not have an air-conditioned cinema. In the sweltering heat of summer, the rich would fly one hour to Mumbai, India’s financial hub, to see a movie and stock up on Levi’s jeans, Domino’s Pizza and other big-city treats that they could not find at home.

headline: Writing in the Dark
text: “To our joy or to our misery, the contingencies of reality have a great influence on what we write,” says Natalia Ginzburg in her book “It’s Hard to Talk About Yourself,” in the chapter in which she discusses her life and her writing in the wake of personal disaster.

headline: The World at Their Feet
text: California

headline: When a Child Outgrows the Safety Net
text: LAST year, when my son Sean was 12, he started to shoot baskets, watch too much television and have his first major crush. He said “my bad” after forgetting homework and plunged his size-seven feet into sneakers before bolting without a jacket.

headline: Sandya Magge and Ketan Jhaveri
text: Sandya T. Magge and Ketan P. Jhaveri were married yesterday at the Pittsburgh Marriott City Center. Samudrala V. Charyulu, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Basketball Sees Potential in China, and Vice Versa
text: I was in the N.B.A. players union office last week for an important occasion — the signing of a memorandum of agreement between the union and the Citic Guoan Group, mainland China’s largest state-run investment company. The agreement is called Bridges to China, a partnership meant to develop business opportunities in China for the union’s membership and to take the N.B.A.’s individual star power to China.

headline: Lincoln MKX: Beyond the Edge
text: WHILE Cadillac has staged a respectable revival of late, times are still tough for Lincoln, the other venerable American luxury line.

headline: John K. Lattimer, Urologist of Varied Expertise, Dies at 92
text: John K. Lattimer, a prominent urologist, ballistics expert and collector of historical relics who treated top-ranking Nazis during the Nuremberg war crimes trials and was the first nongovernmental medical specialist allowed to examine the evidence in President John F. Kennedy’s assassination, died Thursday at a hospice near his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 92.

headline: Calendar of Events
text: Music and Dance

headline: Did That Power Dad Get His Hands Dirty?
text: Some executives are much more hands-on than others. That was made clear last week during a panel discussion titled “Power Couples — How They Live and Work” at the 92nd Street Y in New York.

headline: Robyn Fried, Brian Greene
text: Robyn Elizabeth Fried, the daughter of Cathy Katz of Short Hills, N.J., and Mitchell Fried of Hoboken, N.J., was married last evening to Brian Ross Greene, a son of Dory Greene and Dr. Andrew Greene of Warren, N.J. Rabbi Michael S. Friedman officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: When the Wheels Come Off a Sport
text: TOMORROW, the American cyclist Floyd Landis, the would-be heir to Lance Armstrong, steps before an arbitration panel in California to rebut the charge that his come-from-behind victory last year in cycling’s most celebrated race was a fraud.

headline: Pamela Karle, Thomas Frame
text: Pamela Alyce Karle and Thomas Crawford Frame are to be married today. The Rev. Dr. Larry H. Ellis, a Presbyterian minister, is to perform the ceremony at the Village Chapel in Pinehurst, N.C.

text: DAVID LETTERMAN

text: MONTVALE, N.J.

headline: What Gets Left Behind
text: FOR many people, moving is a deeply taxing combination of high anxiety, brute labor and loose ends. Perhaps that’s why moving on doesn’t always mean completely moving out.

headline: Rx for Mother of Twins: Pampering
text: SCARSDALE

headline: Afghan Legislators Vote Out Foreign Minister
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 12  Afghanistan’s foreign minister, Rangin Dadfar Spanta, lost a no-confidence vote in Parliament on Saturday after he was unable to stop the expulsion of tens of thousands of Afghan refugees and illegal workers from Iran in the last three weeks.

headline: Clearly, Frankly, Unabashedly Disabled
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: A Managable Dose of Cruising With Kids
text: If the thought of being trapped on a boat with your kids for a week is horrifying, but a day cruise and one-night island stay sounds about right, check out Discovery Cruise Line’s special family offer (www.discoverycruiseline.com).

headline: White and Hot From Spain
text: America’s imports of albariños from northwestern Spain leapt to one million liters in 2006 from 755,000 in 2005. The charming, appetite-whetting 2006 Martín Códax, from Rías Baixas, on the Atlantic in Galicia, shows why these dry whites’ popularity is on the rise.

headline: Alone
text: In her first three novels, including her marvelous debut, “Dreaming in Cuban,” Cristina García amply demonstrated her literary gifts, delineating fine gradations of love and hatred, madness and obsession, while juggling multiple narratives. Although she demonstrated a fondness for excess and magic, her stories remained firmly grounded in the insistent claims of the body — and in the recent history of her native country, Cuba. Her characters — whether good or bad, in exile or in Havana — also remained strongly linked to that small island nation.

headline: Staring Down Risk
text: MY great-grandfather Montague is my inspiration. He was a slave in Virginia who had superior math skills. When the slave owner conducted business, he took Montague along to do calculations.

headline: No One Says ‘9/11.’ No One Needs To.
text: ON Tina Fey’s NBC sitcom “30 Rock,” recently, her character, the fictional NBC producer Liz Lemon, settles in with friends to watch the network’s “Salute to Fireworks” in Rockefeller Plaza. As marching-band music plays, they see explosions and smoke rising over a monolithic high-rise tower in New York. “Oh boy,” Liz says dryly, “that’s going to scare a lot of people.”

headline: Friends Older and New
text: The restaurant scene that has thrived for years in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, remains vibrant. Three of these newer places have opened in the past year.

headline: The Family Vacation, Reinvented
text: IT seems that a one-week trip to the shore, with days spent digging for clams and nights spent camping under the stars, has long ago ceased to be enough of a diversion for families planning their summer getaways. Now, the options range from cooking lessons in Italy (with even toddlers getting some kitchen time) to marionette-making courses in Prague to “volunteer vacations” that include trips to orphanages in China.

headline: ‘American Spy’
text: By the summer of 1943, the tides of World War II seemed to be turning ever so slightly to the Allies' side. Earlier in the year, Hitler had been forced out of Stalingrad and Tunisia. The Allies landed in Sicily, bombed Rome, sent German troops scurrying out of Italy, and arrested Mussolini. But it was a tug of war. Hitler countered by invading Allied-occupied Italy, where he rescued Mussolini in the middle of September. If we were going to win this war, Uncle Sam needed every man he had, but I was twiddling my thumbs as a briefer to a paper-pushing general in sunny Orlando, Florida.

headline: ‘God Is Not Great’
text: If the intended reader of this book should want to go beyond disagreement with its author and try to identify the sins and deformities that animated him to write it (and I have certainly noticed that those who publicly affirm charity and compassion and forgiveness are often inclined to take this course), then he or she will not just be quarreling with the unknowable and ineffable creator who-presumably-opted to make me this way. They will be defiling the memory of a good, sincere, simple woman, of stable and decent faith, named Mrs. Jean Watts.

headline: ‘The Big Girls’
text: Sloatsburg Correctional Institution, a walled complex of seven large stone buildings, sits on the west bank of the Hudson River. An hour north of Manhattan by train, it was built in the late nineteenth century as a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients. Buildings A, B, and C hold five hundred prisoners of the federal government, all of them women. The remaining buildings are used for clinics, schoolrooms, the chapel, and administration as well as for the laundry, kitchens, library, and machine shop. There is a large plot of land behind Building A where the prisoners grow beans. A high brick wall with two wooden watchtowers occupied by men with rifles surrounds the prison on three sides. The river runs parallel to Building C on the east. There are no guardhouses along the river, which causes me to wonder. Do they think that black women can't swim?

headline: ‘The Yiddish Policemen’s Union’
text: Nine months Landsman's been flopping at the Hotel Zamenhof without any of his fellow residents managing to get themselves murdered. Now somebody has put a bullet in the brain of the occupant of 208, a yid who was calling himself Emanuel Lasker.

headline: ‘How I Became a Nun’
text: MY STORY, THE STORY of "how I became a nun," began very early in my life; I had just turned six. The beginning is marked by a vivid memory, which I can reconstruct down to the last detail. Before, there is nothing, and after, everything is an extension of the same vivid memory, continuous and unbroken, including the intervals of sleep, up to the point where I took the veil.

headline: ‘Nixon and Kissinger’
text: In the nearly twenty years following his resignation from the presidency in 1974, Richard Nixon struggled to reestablish himself as a well-regarded public figure. He tried to counter negative views of himself by writing seven books, mostly about international relations, which could sustain and increase his reputation as a world statesman. Yet as late as 1992, he complained to Monica Crowley, a young postpresidential aide: "'We have taken ... ever since-insulted by the media as the disgraced former president.'"

headline: ‘The New Yorkers’
text: We'll begin our story with Jody. She had lived on the block in her studio apartment since college, a luxurious accommodation at the time, certainly when compared to the dorm room she was leaving. After twenty years, the one room no longer struck her as luxurious, but the morning light was still lovely, the stabilized rent remained artificially low, and the large room with its beautiful bay window, high ceiling, and molding in the shape of twisted rope continued to be her home.

headline: ‘A Handbook to Luck’
text: Enrique Florit climbed the stairs to the roof of his apartment building, which was eye level with the top of the street's jacaranda trees. It had rained that afternoon and dark puddles stained the cement and the peeling tar paper. When Enrique opened the doors of the wire-mesh cages, the doves fluttered to his shoulders and outstretched arms. Five months ago, he and his father had bought the doves and dyed their feathers a rainbow of pastels. Now Enrique poured their daily seed, freshened their water, listened to the low blue murmurings in their throats.

headline: ‘Ghostwalk’
text: Over the last two years, as I have tried to tease out the truths from the untruths in that series of events that seeped out through Elizabeth's death, like lava moving upwards and outwards through salt water from a tear in the seabed, I have had to be you several times, Cameron Brown, in order to claw myself towards some kind of coherence. Sometimes it was-is-easy to imagine the world through your eyes, terribly possible to imagine walking through the garden that afternoon in those moments before you found your mother's body in the river. After all, for a long time, all that time we were lovers, it was difficult to tell where your skin ended and mine began. That was part of the trouble for Lydia Brooke and Cameron Brown. Lack of distance became-imperceptibly-a violent entanglement.

headline: ‘Angelica’
text: I suppose my prescribed busywork should begin as a ghost story, since that was surely Constance's experience of these events. I fear, however, that the term arouses unreasonable expectations in you. I scarcely expect to frighten you of all people, even if you should read this by snickering candle and creaking floorboards. Or with me lying at your feet.

headline: ‘Kinfolks’
text: My younger brother bill is clutching his teddy bear, the noose still knotted around its neck. My older brother John and I sit on a carpeted step in the front hallway as the gray-haired babysitter with crooked brown teeth informs us that the Melungeons will get us for having hung the bear from the upstairs landing, just out of Bill's reach in the downstairs hall.

headline: Kevin Henke's Drafts for 'A Good Day'
The Mother of All Holidays
text: In an illustrated slide show, Bruce Handy and Barbara deWilde tell the story of Anna Marie Jarvis, the "mother of modern Mother's Day."

headline: A Reading List for Future Doctors
text: Freshman Seminar Program, Harvard College

headline: In a Stadium or in a Pool, Bands Galore
text: California

headline: Paperback Row
text: ABSURDISTAN, by Gary Shteyngart. (Random House, $13.95.) One of the Book Review’s top 10 books of 2006, Shteyngart’s exuberant second novel introduces Misha Vainberg, the rap-music-obsessed, grossly overweight son of the 1,238th-richest man in Russia. After attending college in the United States and falling for a Bronx-bred woman named Rouenna, Misha is now stuck in St. Petersburg, scrambling for an American visa that may never arrive. He heads for Absurdsvanï, an oil-rich former Soviet republic, hoping to buy a Belgian passport, and gets tangled up in local politics. “Compared with most young novelists his age,” Walter Kirn wrote here, “Shteyngart is a giant mounted on horseback. He ranges more widely, sees more sweepingly and gets where he’s going with far more aplomb.”

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: BECAUSE A FIRE WAS IN MY HEAD, by Lynn Stegner. (University of Nebraska, $24.95.) Stegner’s protagonist is a self-destructive hussy who leaves a crowd of broken people in her wake.

headline: Senna Day II
text: I just had to do a little follow-up on the Senna mania, since the GP2 series holds the main race on Saturday and a secondary race on Sunday. In the second race the top eight finishers of the previous day start in reverse order on the grid.

headline: A victory for Honda?  Ask Hamada-san
text: He is a Japanese comedian and presenter on Fuji TV. The last time he came to a Formula One race was at Budapest last year and Honda won the race. So that is why the Super Aguri team, with the Honda engine, placed a representation of a Japanese Stone God outside its motor home welcoming this god man, Hamada-san, to Spain.

headline: Civilian Losses in Afghanistan
text: Deaths from U.S. and allied airstrikes are threatening support for the Afghan government and straining the NATO alliance.

text: A family weekend in Hollywood, a tourist destination that is at once wide-open and hermetic.

headline: Why We Travel
text: "My mom held my kite and I started running and she let go. It goes up really high. I got it up like six times, twice for a long time, and the other times just for a minute."

headline: Around the neighborhood
text: Real estate in the news:

headline: Safeco Field Is Baseball Paradise
text: Safeco Field is the best ballpark in the major leagues. There, I said it.

headline: Giuliani’s Courtship of Nathan
text: Judith Giuliani has been a constant companion to Rudolph W. Giuliani at least since early 2000, when Mr. Giuliani, then mayor of New York City, launched a short-lived Senate campaign. At first, few people seemed to know for sure if Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Giuliani were a romantic item. But in the summer of 2001, almost a year after he publicly announced his divorce from his second wife, Donna Hanover, the relationship was made public in a cover story on People magazine.

headline: Sunday Sampler Platter
text: Rudolph Giuliani was literally sweating his position on abortion during an interview with Fox News aired on Sunday.

headline: Cerberus Is Said to Be Close to Winning Chrysler
text: DaimlerChrysler appears ready to sell a controlling interest in the struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management, people with direct knowledge of the discussions told The New York Times on Sunday.

headline: Triumphs of the White House Spouse
text: Everyone has heard of the office of the president, but there is also an official office of the first lady, which has increased in size and importance as the presidency has grown.

headline: A Dangerous Move
text: If you want to move four million gallons of gasoline from a refinery in New Jersey to gas stations in Baltimore, you’ll need a 400-foot-long double-hulled barge and a 5000-horsepower tugboat to push it. Then to pilot the load, you’ll need a crew of people willing to be away from their families for two weeks at a time while working six-hour shifts around the clock. And you’ll need about a billion dollars worth of liability coverage.

headline: Welcome to the Gambit Chess Blog
text: This blog is starting today to coincide with the United States Chess Championship in Stillwater, Okla., which runs through May 23. The field of 36 players includes last year’s champion, Alexander Onischuk, and Hikaru Nakamura who won the 2005 championship at the age of 16, becoming the youngest champion since Bobby Fischer.

headline: Suddenly, the Yankees Can’t Hit
text: When the Yankees scored in the sixth inning against the Mariners on Sunday, they became the first American League team to score 200 runs this season. That’s about the best thing they can say about their offense.

headline: The “Other Kristof” in the “Other Times” on Darfur
text: Kathy Kristof, no relation I think, writes about how investors can fight the Darfur genocide in her personal finance column in Sunday’s Los Angeles Times.

headline: Your Comments on my Latest Darfur Column
text: My Monday column is about Darfur — through the lens of Daoud Hari, right, who had been my interpreter last year and has just resettled here as a refugee, after a harrowing experience being imprisoned in Sudan. Daoud is an incredible guy, and you can see little bits of him in this video from that same trip with him. He’s the tall Sudanese in the edge of some scenes.

headline: Who Killed Kennedy? One Man’s Answer
text: LOS ANGELES, May 13 — The prosecutor who put Charles Manson behind bars now wants to solve another crime — a really simple one, he insists. So simple that it takes only 1,612 pages to prove his case.

text: Spidey Hangs Tough in a High Place

headline: Music Radio on the Internet Faces Thorny Royalty Issues
text: PARIS, May 13 — Since Pandora.com closed its box of digital musical delights this month to users outside the United States, the complaints have been pouring in from Dubai to Patagonia.

headline: For Virginia Tech Grad, Focus Is With the Jets
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., May 13  Jesse Allen was in a classroom at Weeb Ewbank Hall at Hofstra this weekend when he was supposed to be collecting his college diploma from Virginia Tech. A rookie free agent, Allen passed up his graduation ceremony Saturday to try to win a job with the Jets.

headline: Bank Files May Undercut Wolfowitz, Critics Say
text: WASHINGTON, May 13 — Documents circulating at the World Bank suggest that Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank president, understood that his role in ordering a pay increase and promotion for his companion in 2005 might be seen as a conflict of interest but insisted on proceeding anyway, bank officials who are critics of Mr. Wolfowitz said Sunday.

headline: With Duncan as Model, Suns Look to Regroup
text: SAN ANTONIO, May 13  Tim Duncan was spinning the Phoenix Suns on their heels, muscling his way to the basket and finishing his turnaround jump hooks with angles off the backboard that only he knows.

headline: Rising Exports Putting Dent in Trade Gap
text: Over half of the 9.1 million vehicles General Motors produced last year were sold in foreign countries. More KFC fast food restaurants are opening in China now than in the United States.

headline: Educating the Education Secretary
text: “It’s not our fault.” That’s what Education Secretary Margaret Spellings seemed to say while testifying before Congress last week about her department’s failure to halt the payoffs, kickbacks and general looting of the public treasury by a lending company that collected nearly $300 million in undeserved subsidies. But that doesn’t track with the federal Higher Education Act, which clearly authorizes the secretary to disqualify from federal programs lenders who employ payoffs, kickbacks and unethical practices like those that have been found to be commonplace in the college lending business.

headline: Chrysler Group to Be Sold for $7.4 Billion
text: STUTTGART, Germany May 14 — DaimlerChrysler confirmed today that it would sell a controlling interest in its struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management of New York, a private equity firm that specializes in restructuring troubled companies. The price being paid is $7.4 billion, mostly in the form of capital that Cerberus will put into Chrysler.

headline: Web Videos Let Car Buyers Survey Their Many Choices
text: ONE of the most dreaded buying decisions is becoming still tougher. Auto manufacturers now sell about 280 different cars in the United States, up from 208 at the start of the decade. In five years that number is expected by market researchers to reach 340.

headline: New York Plan for DNA Data in Most Crimes
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is proposing a major expansion of New York’s database of DNA samples to include people convicted of most crimes, while making it easier for prisoners to use DNA to try to establish their innocence.

headline: In Native Alaskan Villages, a Culture of Sorrow
text: BETHEL, Alaska, May 10 — The older brother hanged himself. The younger one used a gun. They died 38 days apart.

headline: The Nation’s Borders, Now Guarded by the Net
text: Andrew Feldmar, a Vancouver psychotherapist, was on his way to pick up a friend at the Seattle airport last summer when he ran into a little trouble at the border.

headline: The Witness Next Door
text: One of the most unusual people in New Jersey these days is a tall 34-year-old black man named Daoud Hari. Others may lose their tempers at traffic jams on the turnpike, but he’s just glad he’s no longer being tortured.

headline: Three Women on the Verge of a Life-Changing Moment
text: “Betrothed” is a lovely and uneven work of theater. On the one hand, it’s a literally moving meditation on matrimony: not quite dance, not quite drama, weaving together three stories from very different sources (Jhumpa Lahiri, Anton Chekhov and S. Ansky) about women who are looking forward to marriage. Rachel Dickstein, the show’s inventor and the founder of the company Ripe Time, has developed a distinctive stage language, simple yet effective, overlapping words with movement, poetic image with sound (the score is by the jazz pianist and composer Vijay Iyer). From the opening tableau of three women half-suspended within rectangular openings in the back wall, bathed in a haze of sepia light, while the cellist Greg Heffernan and the flutist Natacha Diels gently feel out lines of electronically enhanced music, it’s clear this is going to be a sensual, beautiful evening.

headline: Maximalism, Minimalism and a Few Narratives Askew
text: Anyone who wanted a crash course in downtown dance currents could have spent several profitable evenings attending the recent “La MaMa Moves!” festival, where some 50 companies and choreographers have been presented over the last two weeks.

headline: Violence Reported in Philippines Elections
text: MANILA, May 14 — Voters went to the polls in the Philippines today to elect senators, congressmen and local officials, amid reports of election-related violence and allegations of fraud.

headline: Rock, Scissors, Pay-Per-View?
text: LAS VEGAS, May 13 — As if it were necessary to further whip up a ballroom filled with raucous people already giddy on free-flowing beer, Matti Leshem was on the microphone Saturday afternoon trying to imbue some more excitement.

headline: Georgetown Sends Princeton Packing With a Goal 21 Seconds Into Overtime
text: WASHINGTON, May 13 — Moments after scoring in overtime to give his team a 9-8 victory against Princeton Sunday in an N.C.A.A tournament first-round game, Georgetown attackman Brendan Cannon removed his jersey.

headline: Dallas Suburb Votes to Allow Land Sale for a Bush Library
text: UNIVERSITY PARK, Tex., May 13 — The prospect of the George W. Bush Presidential Library’s being built on the campus of Southern Methodist University received a lift over the weekend when voters in this Dallas suburb passed a proposition that paves the way for the city to sell a piece of parkland to the university.

headline: At Journal, Slim Margins Open Door to Murdoch
text: Does The Wall Street Journal make money? The question might seem silly. The chronicler of capitalism, the bible of business: of course The Journal turns a profit, right?

headline: On the Canals, a Woman Paddles Against the Tide
text: VENICE — For more than a thousand years, Venice has had gondolas but never a female gondolier. But now there is Alexandra Hai.

headline: Antiwar Iraqi in Washington Has a More Sectarian Agenda at Home
text: WASHINGTON, May 13 — As Congress and the White House continue to spar over war plans, Iraqis representing all sides in the conflict are turning up in the halls of power here to press their views.

headline: Cerberus’s Strategic Plan May Finally Be Paying Off
text: If Cerberus Capital Management winds up owning the controlling interest in Chrysler, it would be a first for Detroit’s three automakers: Never before has one of them been outside the control of another major automotive company.

headline: Web Fight: Blocking Ads and Adding Art
text: There has long been a cat-and-mouse game between Web advertisers, which pay to place their messages on sites where people view content, and ad-blocking services, which let people hide those messages from their browsers.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A listing of credits on Wednesday with a film review of “Day Night Day Night” included incorrect information from the film’s distributor about several people who worked on the movie. Benoit Debie was the sole director of photography; he was not joined by Michael Taylor. The editors were Julie Loktev and Mr. Taylor  not Ms. Lotkev and Leslie Shatz, who was the sound designer. The production designer was Kelly McGehee  not Rabiah Troncelliti, who was the costume designer.

headline: Less Risk Seen in Purchasing Clothes Online
text: Maybe Americans don’t need dressing rooms after all.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Search for 3 G.I.’s Abducted in Iraq Continues
text: BAGHDAD, May 14 — The search for three missing American soldiers abducted after an attack south of Baghdad continued Monday as the Al Qaeda group that claimed responsibility for the ambush said the soldiers would never be found.

headline: University of Texas Fires Director of Financial Aid
text: The University of Texas announced today that it had fired the director of financial aid at its Austin campus for improper conduct, saying that he had more ties to a student loan company than were previously known and had begun recommending the lender to students a few months after he purchased stock in its parent company.

headline: A New Curator Casts a Fresh Eye on Architecture’s Past at MoMA
text: Stepping into the large shoes of Philip Johnson, the founding curator of MoMA’s architecture department, might have seemed challenge enough for Barry Bergdoll, who took on the position in January. But he also had to contend with a weighty anniversary: the department turns 75 this year.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article last Monday about Victory Challenge’s performance in the America’s Cup challengers series referred incorrectly to a past Cup competitor that was used as the model for a prized yacht of Jan Stenbeck, the founder of Victory Challenge. Endeavor, on which the prized yacht Sophie is based, challenged for  but did not win  the America’s Cup in 1934.

headline: Amid Friction, Plans for U.S.-Iran Talks on Iraq
text: CAIRO, May 13  The diplomatic tussle between Iran and the United States intensified Sunday as leaders from both countries toured Middle Eastern capitals seeking to shore up relationships, even as signs of new cooperation over Iraq emerged between them.

headline: Divided Over Trade
text: Nothing divides Democrats like international trade policy. That became clear last week, when the announcement of a deal on trade between Democratic leaders and the Bush administration caused many party activists to accuse the leadership of selling out.

headline: Boy Killed as Overloaded Van Hits Pole in Northern Manhattan
text: The driver of an overloaded minivan lost control of the vehicle early yesterday on the Harlem River Drive in northern Manhattan, the police said, and one of 10 people on board, a 14-year-old boy, was killed when it hit a light pole.

headline: U.S. Asks Europe to Ensure Continued Access to Air Passenger Data
text: VENICE, May 13 — In order to reduce the odds that terrorists will enter the United States, the Bush administration is asking the European Union to lift its objections to the sharing of airline passenger information with American intelligence agencies, said the secretary of homeland security, Michael Chertoff.

headline: Dancemakers’ Urgent Visions Echo in a Harlem Landmark
text: Part of the pleasure of E-Moves 8, which opened on Friday night at Harlem Stage at the Gatehouse, was the setting, a sensitively restored 1890 pumping station whose theater space and staff are instantly welcoming. But pieces like Ayo Janeen Jackson’s “Where Unicorns and Demons Play” and Camille A. Brown’s “Evolution of a Secured Feminine” would probably look terrific even performed on a subway platform.

headline: A Nod to Journalistic Integrity Is Seen in an Editor’s Return
text: Who says industry magazines are cozy with their advertisers?

headline: More Than Advocacy (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hotel Chain Compromises With Publisher After Rejecting Book Over Language
text: The Ritz-Carlton chain is known for offering many fine services to its guests, and now it may be time to add book censorship to the list.

headline: Pérez Close Enough to Perfect for the Mets
text: When Mets Manager Willie Randolph strode toward the mound yesterday, the crowd at Shea Stadium booed every slow step. He took the baseball from his starter, Oliver Pérez, who was only two outs from the end of a brilliant game, and no one wanted to see Pérez go.

headline: Renewed Violence Limits Oil Production in Nigerian Region
text: The violence that has gripped Nigeria’s main oil region for the last year is again on the rise after weeks of an uneasy truce.

headline: He’s Taut of Style and Light of Foot
text: When Lee Child toured Britain early this spring for the release of his latest monster hit, “Bad Luck and Trouble,” certain fans were awarded reproductions of the folding toothbrush featured in the novel. It would take a hard-core fan to appreciate the humor in this. But there are many of those fans, for good reason.

headline: Take a Class, Tweak Your Career
text: ON a typical Tuesday night at the Jewish Community Center on Manhattan’s Upper West Side, I sit at a table in what is normally a pre-school classroom with a psychologist, an interior designer, a nonprofit administrator, a few mothers eager to return to the work force and the requisite handful of lawyers looking to leave their law practice.

headline: Is It the Woman Thing, or Is It Katie Couric?
text: The numbers are stark. Eight months into Katie Couric’s job as the first woman to anchor a network newscast on her own, her “CBS Evening News” has not only settled back into its long-held position of last among the evening news broadcasts, but also regularly falls short of the newscast that Ms. Couric replaced.

headline: Matz’s Chelokee Not Expected to Run in Preakness
text: The trainer Michael Matz said it was unlikely that Chelokee would compete in the Preakness Stakes on Saturday. Instead, Matz said his colt would run in the Barbaro Stakes, which is part of the undercard at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore.

headline: TV Viewing, Through the Lens of Politics
text: Viewers of the Fox News Channel were significantly more likely than the general population to call themselves Republicans, according to data released last week by Scarborough Research, the consumer research firm.

headline: Mylan Labs in Deal to Buy German Generic Drug Unit
text: Mylan Laboratories has agreed to buy the generic drug unit of Merck, the German drug maker, for 4.9 billion euros ($6.7 billion) in cash.

headline: Japan Sets Referendum on Pacifist Constitution
text: TOKYO, May 14 — The Japanese government took an important step toward revising its pacifist Constitution today when the country’s parliament endorsed a national referendum on the issue.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A dance review on April 16 about the Boris Eifman Ballet, at City Center, misstated the history of Mr. Eifman’s new ballet, “The Seagull.” Its American premiere was in March at the University of California, Berkeley  not at City Center in April.

headline: Offensive Struggle Catches Up to the Yankees
text: SEATTLE, May 13 — The Yankees have fallen so far behind the Boston Red Sox that every game seems to take on urgency, even this early in the season. That is what made their Sunday so discouraging.

headline: Going Nine for Nine in Nevada on the Way to a Teams Title
text: The John Roberts Teams opened the Cavendish Invitational tournament that began on Wednesday at the Green Valley Ranch Resort in Henderson, Nev., and ended yesterday. The winners ended with a perfect record of played nine, won nine. They were Drew Casen of Las Vegas; Neil Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y.; John Diamond and Jim Krekorian of New York; Gaylor Kasle of Boca Raton, Fla.; and John Schermer of Seattle.

headline: Bowen’s Defense Earns Him More Scrutiny
text: SAN ANTONIO, May 14 – Bruce Bowen has made a career of frustrating opponents with his tenacious defense while provoking their suspicion -- if not outrage. In three games of this testy Western Conference semifinal series against the Phoenix Suns, the Spurs forward has managed to do both, but has yet to incur a major penalty from the N.B.A.

headline: Sitcoms Are Dead! Long Live Sitcoms!
text: NETWORK television isn’t dead.

headline: G.O.P. May Be Losing Patience With State Chairman’s Scarcity
text: ALBANY — Discontent is rising with Joseph N. Mondello, the state’s Republican Party chairman, ahead of the party’s New York City fund-raiser on Thursday featuring John McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: Battle Over Same-Sex Marriage Reaches Connecticut’s Highest Court
text: HARTFORD, May 14 — The battle over same-sex marriage reached Connecticut’s highest court today, with judges confronting two basic questions during oral arguments: Does the state law that provides for civil unions for same-sex couples create a fundamentally inferior status for gays and lesbians, compared with marriage? And do homosexuals constitute a class of people with special protection against discrimination under state law?

headline: Papá y Yo, Speaking Our Rebel Minds
text: Most people don’t know their parents as well as they think they do, partly because children must rely on eyewitnesses to help them understand those crucial, early years. But more important, there’s the issue of critical distance, which is why family members don’t always make the best biographers. In “Daughter of a Cuban Revolutionary,” at DR2 Theater, Marissa Chibas, who also stars in this standard-issue solo show, at least has the benefit of a fascinating family.

headline: Manhattan: Motorcyclist Killed
text: A motorcyclist was thrown to the pavement and killed yesterday after she struck a man who had run into traffic on the West Side Highway at 56th Street in Manhattan, the police said. The woman, whose name was not released but who was said to be in her 30s, was traveling north on the highway shortly after 9:30 a.m. when the crash took place, the authorities said, even though she applied her brakes and swerved to try to avoid a collision. The man suffered a broken leg, the police said. The police did not release the pedestrian’s name.

headline: 2 Sides Give Opening Arguments in Padilla Trial
text: MIAMI, May 14 — The trial of Jose Padilla and two co-defendants charged with conspiring to support terrorism opened today with government lawyers describing what they called a calculated plan to provide money, equipment and recruits to Al Qaeda and, in Mr. Padilla’s case, train to become a terrorist.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: ECONOMIC INDICATORS Reports this week will provide data on consumers. The government releases its consumer inflation report, and the Labor Department reports the Consumer Price Index for April (Tuesday) and weekly jobless claims (Thursday). The University of Michigan releases its consumer sentiment index on Friday.

headline: Key Taliban Leader Is Killed in Afghanistan in Joint Operation
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, May 13 — The man who probably was the Taliban’s foremost operational commander, Mullah Dadullah, was killed in a joint operation by Afghan security forces, American forces and NATO troops in Helmand Province, Governor Asadullah Khaled of the neighboring Kandahar Province said Sunday.

headline: NBC Will Bring Back All Three ‘Law & Order’ Shows
text: NBC Universal has made a last-minute deal to retain all three of its long-running “Law & Order” series, shifting one, “Law & Order: Criminal Intent,” to its entertainment cable channel, the USA Network, for the first run of new episodes.

headline: Coldwell Banker Selects National Creative Agency
text: Accounts

headline: Last Call in Baseball Clubhouses, but Few Players Seem to Mind
text: There are two glass-door refrigerators in the narrow visitors’ clubhouse at Yankee Stadium. One is filled with bottled water and juices, while the other has a more varied selection: sports drinks, protein shakes, soda, diet soda, lemonade and chocolate milk.

headline: College Outside the Class: Advanced Studies in Tharp
text: The eagerly anticipated “College Showcase: Works by Tharp,” presented Saturday afternoon at the Joyce Theater, provided a fascinating look into 1970s choreography by Twyla Tharp and her style and compositional methods. The afternoon also suggested a few things about programming and the high level of university dance training today, seen here in students from Barnard, Hunter, Marymount Manhattan and Sarah Lawrence Colleges, as well as the Juilliard School’s student professionals. The urge to include all four of the colleges was understandable, but having two segments of “The Fugue” was overkill.

headline: A Fresh Start on Energy
text: Congress’s last effort to craft a decent energy strategy, in 2005, was largely disappointing. But at the risk of getting our hopes up once again, we call attention to two promising bills making their way to the Senate floor. Stapled together, they could make a constructive start toward reducing this country’s dependence on oil imports and its emissions of greenhouse gases.

headline: Obama Says He’d Roll Back Tax Cuts for the Wealthiest
text: WASHINGTON, May 13 — If elected president, Senator Barack Obama said Sunday, he would seek to repeal President Bush’s tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans and use the money to pay for health care, but he did not suggest he would raise other taxes to pay for expanded services.

headline: Psychoanalyzing Our Leaders (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Pope Denounces Capitalism and Marxism
text: APARECIDA, Brazil, May 13 — In a major speech on Sunday, Pope Benedict XVI condemned capitalism and Marxism as “systems that marginalize God” and urged the Latin American clergy to feed people’s spiritual hunger as the way to ease poverty and halt the Roman Catholic Church’s steady decline in the region.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,377 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of following American on Friday:

headline: A Virtuoso of Imagination Glories in Connected Dots
text: Every distinguished artist who has been chosen to present a series of Perspectives concerts at Carnegie Hall has used the opportunity to make connections among music of different styles and eras. But no one has taken this kind of exploration to the exhilarating extremes of the brilliant French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard this season at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Palestinian Interior Minister Resigns
text: GAZA CITY, Gaza Strip, May 14 — The Palestinian interior minister, Hani al-Qawasmeh, resigned today, as four more Palestinians were killed in fierce factional gun battles.

headline: Briton Bullish on Buying Small Newspapers in Europe
text: LONDON, May 13 — As Rupert Murdoch trains his sights on Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, another veteran of the British newspaper wars is betting on the future of lower-profile print publications.

headline: Engine Woes Fail to Slow Hendrick Team’s Streak
text: DARLINGTON, S.C., May 13 — From week to week, California to Carolina, the locations change, but the story lines continue to repeat themselves in Nascar’s one-sided Nextel Cup series.

headline: A Bedrock of Fairness (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Violence Puts More Pressure on Musharraf
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 13 — A day after political clashes claimed 39 lives in Karachi, analysts said the violence — and accusations that the government had done little to stop the killings — had put renewed pressure on the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.

headline: For This Troop, No Battles but Plenty of Brass
text: Joseph N. Mondello, the chairman of New York State’s Republican Party, was a corporal in the United States Army when he was honorably discharged in 1958. But now, in the New York Guard, he is a two-star general.

headline: Ground Zero Illnesses Clouding Giuliani’s Legacy
text: Anyone who watched Rudolph W. Giuliani preside over ground zero in the days after 9/11 glimpsed elements of his strength: decisiveness, determination, self-confidence.

headline: Mets’ Pelfrey Is Sent to the Minors
text: The Mets sent the right-handed starter Mike Pelfrey to Class AAA New Orleans yesterday, in hopes that he will be able to resume throwing his fastball much lower in the strike zone and can rummage up some lost confidence.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Wednesday with an art review of “The Sculpture of Louise Nevelson: Constructing a Legend,” at the Jewish Museum, reversed the credits. The photograph of “First Personage” was from the Brooklyn Museum, and the picture of “Mrs. N.’s Palace” was from the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Jordan’s King Calls Off Visit to the West Bank
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank, May 13  A rare visit to the West Bank by King Abdullah II of Jordan was called off at the last minute on Sunday because of bad weather, Palestinian officials said, and in Gaza, serious fighting between Palestinian factions continued.

headline: Giving Players a Choice and a Chance to Play
text: Two hours before his Detroit Pistons were scheduled to take on the Chicago Bulls in the fourth game of their Eastern Conference semifinal series, Amir Johnson stood in the middle of the Pistons’ locker room trying to hold a telephone conversation. You could sense the excitement in Johnson’s voice. Although he wouldn’t be in uniform, he is living the life and the dream of an N.B.A. player. At age 20 (he celebrated his 20th birthday on May 1), Johnson has seen much of the underside of the N.B.A., and a glimpse of the glory.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the annual New York City sewage workers’ competition misstated part of the name of an organization of wastewater professionals that founded a national competition, the Operations Challenge, to which New York State’s winners will progress. It is the Water Environment Federation, not Foundation.

headline: Trying to Keep the Viewers When the Ads Come On
text: As the big agencies get ready for the biggest week of the year for the biggest advertising medium, changes are coming that can only be called, well, big.

headline: Torre Hustling Home to Spend Day Off With Ailing Brother
text: SEATTLE, May 13  Joe Torre will spend the Yankees’ day off Monday at New York-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital with his brother Frank, who is recovering from a kidney transplant.

headline: Strike to Protest 39 Deaths Shuts Down Karachi
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 14 — Opposition parties shut down the southern port city of Karachi and slowed commerce in other parts of the country with a strike on Monday to protest the deaths of at least 39 people in political violence over the weekend.

headline: The Danger in Drug Kickbacks
text: The explosion in the use of three anti-anemia drugs to treat cancer and kidney patients illustrates much that is wrong in the American pharmaceutical marketplace. Thanks to big payoffs to doctors, and reckless promotional ads permitted by lax regulators, the drugs have reached blockbuster status. Now we learn that the dosage levels routinely injected or given intravenously in doctors’ offices and dialysis centers may be harmful to patients.

headline: Atomic Agency Concludes Iran Is Stepping Up Nuclear Work
text: VIENNA, May 14 — Inspectors for the International Atomic Energy Agency have concluded that Iran appears to have solved most of its technological problems and is now beginning to enrich uranium on a far larger scale than before, according to the agency’s top officials.

headline: Mickelson Is Star Pupil at Players Championship
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., May 13 — The transformation of Phil Mickelson began away from microphones and cameras, on deserted driving ranges and under the eye of new management.

headline: Got Reggae: Marley and Marley (and Marley, Too)
text: For brand recognition, the best family name in popular music may well be Marley. Bob Marley’s reggae hits are instant singalongs for multiple generations of listeners worldwide — feel-good music that lets fans equate dance grooves and ganja smoke with political and spiritual righteousness.

headline: U.S. Forces Search Iraq Area for 3 Missing Soldiers
text: BAGHDAD, May 13 — About 4,000 American ground troops, supported by surveillance aircraft, attack helicopters and spy satellites, swept towns and farmland south of Baghdad on Sunday, searching for three American soldiers who disappeared Saturday after their patrol was ambushed, military officials said.

headline: Accused of Plagiarism, Magazine Withdraws Issue
text: After being accused by Radar magazine of stealing an article, the Chilean magazine Cosas said it had been hoodwinked by a reporter and had withdrawn the issue from newsstands.

headline: Germany’s Governing Coalition Suffers Losses in Regional Election
text: BERLIN, May 13 — Germany’s governing coalition of conservatives and Social Democrats suffered big losses on Sunday in a regional election in the northern port of Bremen, as three opposition parties, particularly the new Left Party, made significant gains.

headline: Coming Together With the Sound of Electric Clippers
text: Do these Mets appreciate their opportunity to be one of the most memorably nicknamed teams in baseball history?

headline: A Producer and an Ex-Prosecutor in a Trial by TV
text: The most disturbing spectacle at the trial of Phil Spector isn’t the wizened and peculiar defendant slumped in the courtroom dressed in a 1970s-style leisure suit and blond pageboy wig. It’s the parade of attractive, mature women shown on Court TV testifying that not so long ago they too were willing, even eager, to spend time with the once-legendary record producer.

headline: A Mom Running to Lead the Mommy Party
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton chose to mark Mother’s Day a couple of days early this year, on Friday in New Hampshire, at an event with families to decry the lack of health insurance for millions of American children.

headline: Chrysler on Verge of Sale to a Private Firm
text: FRANKFURT, May 13 — DaimlerChrysler appears close to selling the struggling Chrysler Group to a private equity firm that specializes in restructuring troubled companies, unwinding a 1998 merger that was meant to create a trans-Atlantic automotive powerhouse, people with direct knowledge of the discussions said on Sunday.

headline: Teaching at Harvard (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Deaths of Skier’s Cousin and Officer Divide a Town
text: FRANCONIA, N.H., May 13 — The skier Bode Miller is a proud member of the Kenney clan, which has populated this rugged mountain valley for three generations. The family is famous in the region for questioning authority, and Miller’s rise to the top of his sport extended the family’s outlaw mystique.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (CBS) THE KING OF QUEENS In this two-part series finale, the Heffernans teeter on the brink of disaster after Doug (Kevin James, above) discovers that Carrie (Leah Remini, above) didn’t get rid of her apartment in the city after all. But then they receive a phone call that will change their lives.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A theater entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Gayfest NYC, which presents the works of emerging gay playwrights, misstated the middle initial of one of the festival’s producers. He is Jack W. Batman, not Jack R.

headline: Mayor Denies Political Bid but Fuels Talk With Actions
text: Last week, Michael R. Bloomberg, the New York City mayor, stood on a sunny public school terrace in Queens and told reporters that he was not running for president.

headline: Foreigners Praise Conduct of Armenian Elections
text: MOSCOW, May 13 — Parliamentary elections in Armenia largely complied with international standards, Western election observers said Sunday, in the first positive assessment of an election in the former Soviet republic since it gained independence in 1991.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR Diary:

headline: Discouraged Young Chefs (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kidd’s Numbers, Like Clockwork, Give Nets Hope
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 13 — Jason Kidd had a triple-double on Saturday, an occurrence so common for him that it sounded like old news before the sentence had even been typed.

headline: Mosques Are Shaken by Ties to a Plot
text: PHILADELPHIA, May 11  On the southern wall of the Al-Aqsa Islamic Society here is a mural painted by local schoolchildren. In 18 different languages  from Arabic to Swahili  it depicts the world’s various ways of saying “love,” “hope” and “peace.”

headline: U.S. Soldier Shot to Death in Pakistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 14 — An American soldier was shot dead and four other Americans were wounded in Pakistan today after a meeting among Afghan, Pakistani and NATO officials at the Afghan-Pakistan border Afghan and NATO officials said. The meeting had been called to try to resolve recent clashes between the two neighboring countries

headline: Consumers Take a Break
text: Consumer spending has been the powerful and dependable engine of the current economic expansion. Americans have continued to shop through boom-time borrowing, high oil prices, on-and-off job growth, uncontrolled medical costs, rampant trade deficits, hurricanes and war.

headline: Smoke From Fires Closes 2 Highways
text: LAKE CITY, Fla., May 13 (AP)  Interstates 75 and 10 in north Florida were briefly reopened on Sunday before dense smoke from wildfires led the authorities to close them again.

headline: Deputy Attorney General Resigns His Post
text: WASHINGTON, May 14 — Paul J. McNulty, the deputy attorney general whose Congressional testimony in February provided a spark that turned a smoldering issue over the firings of federal prosecutors into a raging inferno, announced his resignation this afternoon.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the annual New York City sewage workers’ competition misstated part of the name of an organization of wastewater professionals that founded a national competition, the Operations Challenge, to which New York State’s winners will progress. It is the Water Environment Federation, not Foundation. (Go to Article)

headline: A Performance Operatic in Its Scope (Opera Not Included)
text: Deborah Voigt’s recital at Carnegie Hall on Friday was operatic, even with no opera on her program. Ms. Voigt, the American soprano, and her pianist, Brian Zeger, offered among other items Mozart’s mouthful “Die Ihr des Unermesslichen Weltalls Schöpfer Ehrt.” Later came Strauss’s “Lied der Frauen” and some Verdi, too.

headline: Passaic: 2-Year-Old Left in Car Overnight
text: The father of a 2-year-old was charged yesterday with endangering the welfare of a child after he left his son locked in a parked car overnight, the police said. The father, Daniel Ribot, 32, took the boy, Adonis, to his second birthday party on Saturday night in Paterson. About 2:30 a.m. yesterday, the man placed the sleeping child inside his black Lexus parked at a gas station lot in Passaic, not far from the party, said Lt. Luis Guzman of the Passaic Police Department. When Mr. Ribot woke up in his Clifton home at 11:30 a.m., he realized he was missing both his child and his car, Lieutenant Guzman said. Mr. Ribot called the police in Clifton, who called the police in Passaic. The Passaic police found the car with Adonis screaming inside it, Lieutenant Guzman said. The police said they were still investigating and Mr. Ribot could face further charges.

headline: Music in Review
text: MUSICIANS FROM MARLBORO Metropolitan Museum of Art

headline: Deng Stays in Game, and Bulls Stay in the Series
text: CHICAGO, May 13  Continuing his effective play during the playoffs, Luol Deng played a major role Sunday in saving the Chicago Bulls’ season.

headline: Hagel ‘Not Happy’ With Republican Party
text: WASHINGTON, May 13 (Bloomberg News) — Senator Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican, said Sunday that his party had “been hijacked by a group of single-minded, almost isolationist insulationists, power-projectors.”

headline: Many Cuts and Crises at a Paper
text: MINNEAPOLIS, May 13 — Last Thursday afternoon, more than a hundred employees of The Star Tribune in Minneapolis took to the small park across the street, many of then dressed in black or wearing black armbands in what they said was an act of mourning.

headline: New CDs
text: LINKIN PARK  “Minutes to Midnight” (Warner Brothers)

headline: Grief, and Mystery, Over Immigrant’s Killing
text: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y.  Fourteen years ago, when Rene Javier Perez decided to leave his impoverished hometown in eastern Guatemala in search of a more prosperous life in the United States, his parents mortgaged the plot of land where they lived to raise $3,000 he needed for a smuggler to lead him across the border.

headline: Party Like It’s 1992 or ’84 or ’76 or ’68!
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: See You in September, Whatever That Means
text: Progress by September — that was the latest mandate from some nervous Republicans to President Bush over the war in Iraq. However, nobody in Washington seems to agree on what progress actually means — or how, precisely, it might be measured.

headline: Chrysler Group to Be Sold for $7.4 Billion
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., May 14 — DaimlerChrysler reached an agreement early today to sell the struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management, a private equity firm that specializes in restructuring troubled companies, for $7.4 billion.

headline: Hits and Misses
text: A look at the critical hits and misses from the 2006-2007 Broadway season.

headline: Briton Bullish on Buying Small Newspapers in Europe
text: As Rupert Murdoch trains his sights on Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, another veteran of the British newspaper wars is betting on the future of lower-profile print publications.

headline: Chrysler’s Real Price: Less Than Zero
text: DaimlerChrysler confirmed Monday that it would sell a controlling interest in its struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management of New York, a private equity firm that specializes in restructuring troubled companies. The price being paid is $7.4 billion, mostly in the form of capital that Cerberus will put into Chrysler. Of that sum, DaimlerChrylser itself will receive only $1.3 billion, and the German automaker said Monday that the transaction will actually result in a “net cash outflow” of about $678 million.

headline: From Obi-Wan to ‘Othello’
text: Ewan McGregor, who makes millions from playing Obi-Wan Kenobi in the "Star Wars" films and other screen roles, will take the minimum wage — $790 week — when he returns to the stage this fall as the villainous Iago at the Donmar Warehouse in London in a new production of Shakespeare's "Othello," The Associated Press reported.

headline: ‘Lion King’ in South Africa
text: "The Lion King" is going home.

headline: A New C.E.O. Means an Exit for Many Lieutenants
text: Seasoned managers know one of the coldest truths of corporate life: A new chief executive means a scramble for survival in executive suites.

headline: Buyout Shop Swallows Sam’s Wine and Spirits
text: Family control of Sam’s Wines and Spirits has ended with a deal announced Friday to sell 80 percent of the third-generation business to a Chicago private-equity firm. The deal with buyout shop Arbor Investments provides Sam’s with access to capital that would allow it to expand at a time when Internet sales are putting pressure on wine-and-spirits stores.

headline: Russian Billionaire Buys Stake in Lyondell Chemical
text: News that a Russian-born billionaire is buying a stake in Houston’s Lyondell Chemical fueled an 11 percent surge in shares of the company on Friday in anticipation of a possible takeover.

headline: The Mystery Poet of Science
text: Writers sometimes praise the poetry of science, but they haven’t composed many memorable verses on the topic. As an inspiration for odes, the lab is no match for love. But there are exceptions, and here’s one of them.

headline: Compass Sells Vending Unit to Allianz
text: Stockholders of Compass, the catering company, are to receive a further 500 million pound ($991 million) payout as a result of the company’s sale of its Selecta vending business for 772.5 million pounds to the private equity arm of Allianz.

headline: Indian Beer Magnate Sets Sights on Scottish Whiskey
text: The Scottish whiskey distiller Whyte & Mackay is about to become the latest target of India’s growing global aspirations. Vijay Mallya, the Indian beer magnate, is expected to sign a deal to buy Whyte & Mackay this week, according to The International Herald Tribune.

headline: The Large Hadron Collider
text: Scientists are putting the final touches on a 17-mile-long particle accelerator that will attempt to create forces and particles that existed shortly after the Big Bang.

headline: Tesla Revs Up With $45 Million
text: Tesla Motors, the Silicon Valley electric-car start-up, said Friday that it had raised an additional $45 million – from a venture capital firm as well as its chairman. Buzz surrounding the surrounding the company, which will start producing its first vehicle, a zero-emissions, two-seat roadster, later this year, is already deafening, with a list of high-profile buyers already lining up to snag a model.

headline: Defending the Orbitz I.P.O.
text: A number of analysts and industry watchers are predicting that Orbitz Worldwide‘s $750 million initial public offering will end in tears, as DealBook noted Friday. Among the reasons that detractors think the online travel site’s I.P.O. will flop are its complex financial arrangements with its parent, Travelport, as well as the company’s history of losses.

headline: A Four Seasons bid to float your boat
text: SkyBar

headline: More Criminal Charges May Surface Over Options Backdating
text: More company executives may face criminal charges as a result of ongoing federal investigations into stock-option backdating, the Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman, Christopher Cox, said Friday. “We have a substantial number of investigations under way [including] cases that are maturing to the point of potential criminal action,” Mr. Cox told reporters at a securities conference.

headline: Everquest I.P.O. Highlights Bear Stearns’ Subprime Bets
text: The initial public offering of Everquest, a fledgling financial-services company, is a blatant attempt by Bear Stearns to unload its mortgage bets on unwitting retail investors, argues BusinessWeek’s Matthew Goldstein.

headline: Citigroup Scores a Private Equity Director
text: Citigroup said Friday that it had hired Chris Gammons from a rival, Deutsche Bank, to be its managing director focused on covering Asia’s fast-growing private equity firms, which have become big fee-payers in the region.

headline: Cold Stone and Kahala Team Up to Take on Buyout Shops
text: As deal making in the fast-food industry continues to heat up, an ice cream maker, the Cold Stone Creamery, and a fast-food operator, Kahala are teaming up to form a holding company they hope will be able to compete with private equity firms for a greater share of the sector.

headline: Trial Highlights Black’s Rift With Lieutenant
text: The trial of Conrad M. Black has brought to the surface the simmering tensions that grew between the publishing magnate and his former partner, F. David Radler. The New York Times’s Richard Siklos notes that it has also provided a reminder that, for the modern media mogul, a good No. 2 is hard to find.

headline: A Deal (and Perhaps an Unveiling) for a Fake Steve Jobs
text: Guessing who’s behind The Secret Diary of Steve Jobs, a satirical blog by an anonymous writer calling himself the Fake Steve Jobs, has become a parlor game in Silicon Valley, with several journalists, former Apple employees and even Steve Jobs himself topping the list of suspects.

headline: CBOT-Merc Merger Faces Renewed Opposition
text: Despite the Chicago Board of Trade’s formal rejection of the Intercontinental Exchange‘s bid, following a higher offer from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, investors were betting that the battle for control of the Chicago derivatives exchange wasn’t over.

headline: Telefonica Unloads Endemol for $3.5 Billion
text: Spain’s Telefonica has reached a deal to sell the Dutch TV company Endemol, creator of the “Big Brother” show, for 2.63 billion euros ($3.55 billion) to a consortium including the Mediaset media empire controlled by the family of the former Italian Premier Silvio Berlusconi, Mediaset said in a statement.

headline: As Hedge Fund Scrutiny Increases, So Does Political Spending
text: As lawmakers continue to scrutinize the hedge fund industry, a recent surge in the hiring of lobbyists and stepped-up contributions to political action committees by managers in the $1 trillion hedge fund industry and top officials of private-equity groups probably comes as no surprise.

headline: CBS Is Reportedly in Deal to Buy WallStrip
text: WallStrip, the online television show that strives for a mix of “Squawk Box” and “Saturday Night Live,” is reportedly in talks to be bought by CBS for about $5 million, according to New York media blog Jossip. The blog said that as part of the deal, which is expected to be announced this week, WallStrip’s presenter, Lindsay Campbell, will become “the next Amanda Congdon: frontin’ for CBS’ Web initiatives.”

headline: Mylan Labs in Deal to Buy German Generic Drug Unit
text: Mylan Laboratories has agreed to buy the generic drug unit of Merck, the German drug maker, for 4.9 billion euros ($6.7 billion) in cash. The acquisition will make Mylan the world’s third-largest maker of copycat versions of drugs, after Teva Pharmaceuticals of Israel and Novartis of Switzerland.

headline: RBS Alliance Publishes Details of ABN Amro Bid
text: The consortium that wants to buy and break up ABN Amro on Monday published confidential details of its offer, which the Dutch bank rejected last week. The consortium, which includes Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander, and Fortis, said their proposal had “lower execution risk” than an agreed deal between ABN and Britain’s Barclays Bank and was worth more.

headline: Private Equity Eyes Valentino Fashions
text: The Valentino Fashion Group said Friday that it had been approached by several private equity firms interested in buying a stake in the Italian fashion house, but said it had not received a formal offer. The chairman, Antonio Favrin, who made the comments at the company’s annual shareholders meeting Friday in Milan, did not name any of the potential suitors for the firm, which controls Hugo Boss.

headline: Alexandra Investment Gets a New Partner
text: A hedge fund, Alexandra Investment Management, said on Friday it was hiring John Hock as president and partner.

headline: The Dirty 30
text: Steam rises from the cooling towers of Schwarze Pumpe power plant, Germany. Jockel Finck/AP

headline: Former Times C.F.O. to Join Buyout Firm
text: Leonard Forman, the former chief financial officer of The New York Times Company, is joining a media-focused investment firm Veronis Suhler Stevenson in another sign that private equity continues to lure retired public company executives, the New York Post reported Monday. Mr. Forman plans to join Veronis’s board of advisers, which already has nine former industry and government leaders, to help the firm identify deals in the specialty media sector.

headline: Ford Family Said to Consider Trimming Stake
text: Members of the family that founded Ford Motor are discussing the possibility of selling some of their controlling stake in the company, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people with direct knowledge of the talks. Bloomberg said that Bill Ford, Ford’s chairman, told the company’s directors about the family members’ views before last week’s annual shareholder meeting in Wilmington, Del. As has been previously reported, some family members have sought to hire an investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners as an outside financial adviser.

headline: In Congress, Seeking a Compromise War Bill
text: Congressional Republicans evidently have found an Iraqi withdrawal plan they can accept.

headline: Some Bancrofts Open to Meeting With Murdoch, Report Says
text: Some Bancroft family members want to meet Rupert Murdoch to discuss his $5 billion offer for Dow Jones but they face stiff opposition from other relatives, The Financial Times reported. Mr. Murdoch has been pressing for a meeting with the Bancroft family, which controls the publishing company through a special class of stock, since they rejected his $60-per-share offer for the company and its flagship Wall Street Journal nearly two weeks ago.

headline: Brazil’s Wine Country
text: Wine is now being made in nontraditional areas like Brazil’s desert, challenging centuries-old grape myths.

headline: Pentagon Blocks MySpace and YouTube
text: The Defense Department has decided to make it impossible to reach 13 Web sites from its network, citing an overabundance of “recreational traffic.”

headline: Will the Pope’s U.N. Speech Be Green?
text: – Tobin Harshaw

headline: 2 Former Siemens Executives Are Convicted of Bribery
text: Two former executives at Siemens were convicted Monday of bribery and assisting bribery for their involvement in multimillion-dollar payments to officials at an Italian utility. The verdict came in the first trial over a series of scandals at the company.

headline: Churning the Bottom
text: Satellite photos from around the world show the impact that fishing trawlers are having on the ocean bottom.

headline: Meeting of the Minds
text: Last week Mr. Bruno and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver bumped into each other in the Capitol, and the two men, who cannot resist pushing each other’s buttons, took a moment to discuss a New York Post story that said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was mulling a bid for governor in 2010.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Investigations Editor Matthew Purdy
text: Matthew Purdy, The Times's investigations editor, answered reader questions May 14 through May 18, 2007.

headline: Primedia to Sell Magazines to Burkle for $1.2 Billion
text: Primedia agreed on Monday to sell about 70 magazines, including Motor Trend, Hot Rod and Surfer, to Source Interlink, a company controlled by the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle, for about $1.2 billion in cash.

headline: Monday Morning Motorsports
text: In Formula One, Felipe Massa started from pole in his Ferrari and survived a first corner charge from Fernando Alonso of McLaren to win the Spanish Grand Prix. Lewis Hamilton continued to impress, finishing second, well ahead of his McLaren teammate. He now leads the championship by two points. Here’s the back story on Hamilton. Nothing we haven’t heard before, but a pretty good timeline of his rise to Formula One. At 22, Hamilton admits that he’s an accidental role model. He said, “You just need that wall knocking down and then you can have other people coming through. It hasn’t been my plan, but I hope that it does that.”

headline: Notes on 5/14 Column, “Divided Over Trade”
text: A few notes on trade and wages.

headline: Law Firms Help Drive Chrysler Deal
text: The winner of the auction for Chrysler, Cerberus Capital Management, is widely refered to as a private equity shop these days. But the firm’s longtime legal adviser, Schulte Roth & Zabel, reflects Cerberus’s roots as a hedge fund — and one that knows its way around a bankruptcy courtroom. Schulte Roth, which counseled Cerberus in the Chrysler negotiations, is known as one of the top legal advisers to hedge funds, and it claims to represent more than one half of the 100 largest hedge funds listed in Institutional Investor. On many occasions, it has advised Cerberus when it bid for assets of bankrupt companies (or when Cerberus’s portfolio companies tumbled into bankruptcy protection themselves).

headline: Abandon Cruise Ship
text: Good Samaritans in the great state of Alaska are helping passengers escape their cruise ship, which is stuck and listing after running aground 15 miles southwest of Juneau.

headline: Amid a Flood of Buyouts, Signs of Leakage
text: Is it coincidence that the boom in leveraged buyouts is being accompanied by a surge in suspicious pre-deal trading activity and a rise in insider-trading cases? Some research by FinancialWeek suggests there may be a connection between the two trends.

headline: A Mom Running to Lead the Mommy Party
text: For Hillary Rodham Clinton, the race for the Democratic nomination is about likeability as well as toughness.

headline: 2007 Tony Award Winners
text: A list of winners of 2007 Tony Awards (denoted with a

headline: TV Upfronts: Baby, Can We Start Fresh?
