text: We’re off to the prime-time prom: this week New York is host to the upfronts, where the networks roll out their new prime-time schedules for advertisers.

headline: Scientologists Ambush the BBC
text: A 41-second video of a BBC reporter shouting at someone in rather unhinged fashion was posted on YouTube late last week as part of a campaign to discredit a documentary the British network is preparing about The Church of Scientology.

headline: How Can Chrysler Get Back Its Vroom-Vroom-Vroom?
text: One of the classic scenes on the international auto show circuit took place in 2003, when Chrysler’s then-president, Wolfgang Bernhard, roared onto the stage in Detroit astride a thundering, gleaming-silver motorcycle called  the Tomahawk.

headline: Take My Company, Please
text: The most amazing aspect of Daimler’s giveaway of Chrysler is that it is considered good news by all. Ford and General Motors shares are up, despite the fact that Chrysler is deemed essentially worthless. Daimler bonds are up on the news, and the company’s bond rating may be increased, despite the fact that it no longer will have Chrysler assets available to help provide the money to repay the bonds.

headline: Obama’s Sunday Debut
text: Although it may seem as if Barack Obama has been running for president ever since his big speech at the 2004 Democratic National Convention, yesterday in fact marked his first appearance on the Sunday gabfest circuit since his official announcement. He talked with George Stephanopoulos on ABC’s “This Week.” So how did the “rookie” do?

headline: TV Upfronts: Getting the 8206492 on Alec Baldwin
text: News about Alec Baldwin … breaking …

headline: Facing Reality
text: When all else fails, face the facts. And the fact was we needed to build a smaller house.

headline: TV Upfronts: Waiting for NBC
text: Big happy Radio City. I’m sitting next to an ad man, whose 16-year-old son’s favorite shows are “Friday Night Lights” and “Entourage.”

headline: TV Upfronts: The Search for More Mass
text: Tina Fey, in a low low cut black dress, is onscreen in a little movie. She’s so good at pushing the digital stuff and the product integration without not being funny.

headline: Give Us Your Snakecharmers, Your Fakirs, Your Frauds
text: Nasdijj, the make-believe American Indian and perpetrator of what the LA Weekly exposed as the Navahoax, is back. Remember him? Remember “The Blood Runs Like A River Through My Dreams,” and the Esquire article that made him a National Magazine Award finalist?

headline: Should Alcan Turn the Tables on Alcoa?
text: As aluminum giant Alcan considers how to react to the hostile $27 billion from Alcoa, an analyst at Prudential Equity Group has a suggestion that harkens back to the era when legwarmers were the height of fashion (though we hear they are making a comeback). The analyst, John C. Tumazos, is floating the idea that terms of the deal could be flipped so that Montreal-based Alcan buys New York-based Alcoa. Such a tactic first gained currency in the 1980’s, when it became known as the Pac-Man defense, after the popular video game in which the player could change roles and go after his or her pursuers.

headline: TV Upfronts: Everybody’s a Detective
text: Applause at the “news” that NBC is keeping “Friday Night Lights.” Cool. (The news is not as good for fans of Aaron Sorkin’s “Studio 60″ — NBC plans to burn off the remaining episodes this summer. It’s doomed for next year.)

headline: TV Upfronts: ‘That One’s Got Me’
text: Or so says the sweetheart ad salesman next to me of “Journeyman,” the weepie new NBC show about a time traveler with two wives. Or something.

headline: TV Upfronts: The Too-Big Bed
text: “Lipstick Jungle,” the new Candace Bushnell cocktail, contains at least one effective sight gag: a giant, god-size bed, a visual sendup of all the too-big things that rich people outfit their houses with.

headline: Lining Up for Clinton in Albany
text: Senator Hillary Clinton appeared just after noon today on the lofty steps of the state Capitol wearing a magenta jacket and surrounded by a phalanx of seven men in dark suits.

headline: TV Upfronts: Better Than She Was Before
text: “Bionic Woman.” McG directed the pilot. This is the show that’s said to be presold, because we remember its name from Lindsay Wagner days.

headline: TV Upfronts: ‘Bionic Woman’ contd.
text: Completely goofball reality pilots, but I’m still thinking about “Bionic Woman.” It looks a bit like “Buffy,” though I know it’s a risk to say that. What I love about the idea is that — as Kevin Reilly said earlier — NBC is following what its sister channel Sci-Fi did with “Battlestar Galactica”: taking a dopey camp show and making it into something serious and intense.

headline: TV Upfronts: Jerry Seinfeld’s Here … and He’s Funny!
text: Jerry Seinfeld is here! Jerry Seinfeld is here! Save us, Jerry Seinfeld!

headline: TV Upfronts: Tinisodes
text: So Jerry Seinfeld has produced a bunch of short videos for NBC about the making of “Bee Movie,” his animated movie for DreamWorks. I’m not crazy about what I saw. Hammy and sketchy and overproduced. I would have liked to have seen Mr. Seinfeld being kind of self-important in his new executive role, or just tired, like he was in “Comedian,” the documentary.

headline: TV Upfronts: Wrapping Up NBC
text: While the hoarse, bulked-up sports guys are throwing footballs into the balcony — I actually love this stunt — I should mention “Life,” which has a title that rivals “Heroes” for lameness, and which is certainly expected to draw the same crowd. It’s more spooky-sci-fi stuff. There’s also “Chuck,” which looks like “My Name Is Earl” meets “Heroes,” and thus like a big miss, which relies too much on Zachary Levi, its forgettable-seeming star.

headline: The Clinton Pull
text: Dubious about the power that Bill Clinton has to woo Democrats to support his wife’s presidential campaign? The Empire Zone’s Danny Hakim reports on how Bill Clinton’s powers of persuasion were on display up in Albany today, as Gov. Eliot Spitzer and others endorsed Senator Clinton’s candidacy.

headline: The Buyout Discount, or Why Private Equity Pays Less
text: If you own shares in a takeover target, you might want to pin your hopes on a public company being the buyer. That is because these kinds of acquirers usually pay more in an acquisition than private equity firms do, according to a study cited by Mark Hulbert in The New York Times. The study, conducted by finance professors and called “Why Do Private Acquirers Pay So Little Compared to Public Acquirers?”, found that, on average, target shareholders receive 55 percent more if a public company instead of a buyout shop (or shops) is paying the bill.

headline: At NYSE Euronext, a Franco-American Pay Chasm
text: When it comes to executive pay on both sides of the Atlantic, Jean-François Théodore is probably not shouting “vive la difference.” Financial News points out that Mr. Theodore, who was head of Euronext and is now deputy chief executive of the newly merged NYSE Euronext, was paid less than one-fifth what his new boss, John Thain, earned last year.

headline: F.D.R.’s Rough Road to Nomination
text: Presidential candidates now jockeying for position might take comfort when they recall Franklin D. Roosevelt’s perilous route to the Democratic nomination. Even F.D.R., one of America’s most successful presidents, had to work long and hard to get his party’s support for the job. And the last night of that effort was the longest and hardest of all.

headline: Bias as Usual or Foul Play?
text: David Stern, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, isn’t too happy with the recent revelation that N.B.A. referees appear to have a racial bias in the way they call fouls. He’s questioned the validity of the statistical analysis by Justin Wolfers, an assistant professor of business and public policy at the Wharton School, and Joseph Price, a Cornell graduate student in economics, which suggests that white and black referees call fouls preferentially against players of the opposite race. The N.B.A. insists that its own analysis (of different data) reveals no such bias, although other experts who’ve seen both analyses say that the Wolfers and Price study is more convincing.

headline: Law School Classmates Criticize Gonzales
text: Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, who has been under fire from politicians in both parties, was assailed today by several dozen of his classmates at Harvard Law School, Class of 1982.

headline: If You Think Oswego’s Cold, Try New Hampshire in January
text: We caught up with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on his way out of a meeting with Gov. Eliot Spitzer about the mayor’s plans to make the city more livable and evironmentally sound. (He needs the governor’s help for some of it, especially congestion pricing.) Mr. Bloomberg was mum about his plan’s reception — “I’m optimistic we’ll that find a ways to get his support, but his staff wants to look at it first” he said — but he did take another swing at the question of whether he would consider running for governor in 2010.

headline: Johnson Prepares for Senate Return
text: Senator Tim Johnson of South Dakota is preparing for a return to the Senate after a brain hemorrhage in December, and fellow Democrats say they fully expect Mr. Johnson to be a candidate for a third term next year.

headline: Television Upfronts: NBC
text: The Times's Bill Carter reports from Radio City Music Hall, where NBC presented its 2007 fall lineup.

headline: Welcome Back, Cliff
text: Not to take any words out of my colleagues’ mouths (or blogs), but I can safely say that the one player we miss most around here is Cliff Floyd, who returns to Shea for the first time tonight as a member of the Chicago Cubs. A few days before players were scheduled to report to spring training, a few other beat writers and I were walking around the Mets clubhouse and I recall having a moment of silence in front of Cliff’s corner locker that was then occupied by David Newhan.

headline: Clinton Keeps Corporate Adviser
text: Add another consultant to the list of those advising Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton: John Kao, a corporate communications consultant who is based in San Francisco and advocates using the techniques of musical improvisation to get the creative juices flowing and leave competitors in the dust.

headline: Harnessing the Large 2008 Field
text: When 10 Republican presidential candidates assemble on a stage Tuesday night in South Carolina for their second debate, viewers will get a reminder of how the sheer size of the field in both parties limits the opportunities for probing questioning.

headline: Basic Instinct Politics
text: From the politics-meets-art/weirdness file: The Italian artist Francesco Vezzoli has hired the top campaign ad gurus for President Bush and Senator John Kerry from 2004, but this time to square off again as part of his installation in the upcoming Biennale in Venice.

headline: Unseating the Border Patrol Chief
text: David V. Aguilar, the chief of Border Patrol, has managed to steer clear of the critics dogging other Bush administration officials these days. Instead, he has a union calling for his head.

headline: Life After the Airline Industry
text: Members of the Schalk family of Oceanside, N.Y., talk about their jobs as airline mechanics and why they made a change.

headline: Is Amputee Sprinter Too-Abled?
text: Oscar Pistorius of South Africa, who had both legs amputated below the knee when he was 11 months old, wants to be the first amputee runner to compete in the Olympics.

headline: For ABC, Dramas Fill Out the Lineup
text: ABC will continue to be the most aggressive of the networks with its lineup of new shows for the next television season, ordering at least 11 new series, when it officially announces its fall schedule to advertisers today.

headline: Napa Valley? Bordeaux? No, but Still Wine Country
text: RIO de JANEIRO, May 14 — When the Portuguese winemaker João Santos first viewed his company’s new vineyard in Brazil, he was crestfallen. How could he ever produce wine anywhere nearly as good as that made in Europe? The trouble was the palm trees.

headline: Japan: Trade Surplus Rises to a Record
text: Japan’s current account surplus widened to a record in March, as exports to Asia and Europe helped counter slower growth in shipments to the United States. The surplus expanded 36.9 percent, to 3.32 trillion yen ($28 billion) from a year earlier, the ministry of finance said. In other economic news, Japan’s machinery orders fell unexpectedly for a second month in March. Non-government orders excluding shipping and utilities dropped 4.5 percent from a month earlier after declining a revised 4.9 percent in February.

headline: Clinton and Obama Visits Suggest New Clout for Two States
text: New York and New Jersey have often been bit players in the presidential nominating process, with their primaries typically occurring after the nominees have been settled upon.

headline: Swiss Investigating BAE in Money Laundering Case
text: PARIS, May 14 — Law enforcement authorities in Switzerland confirmed Monday that they had opened a criminal investigation into possible money laundering at BAE Systems, adding to the international scrutiny of the company, the top British military contractor.

headline: Guantánamo Detainees’ Suit Challenges Fairness of Military’s Repeat Hearings
text: WASHINGTON, May 14  The military system of determining whether detainees are properly held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, includes an unusual practice: If Pentagon officials disagree with the result of a hearing, they order a second one, or even a third, until they approve of the finding.

headline: What’s on Sale There? Confusion, but It’s Cheap
text: A humble sign on the window of a new storefront in Lower Manhattan yesterday encouraged passers-by to take a trip, one that could be long or quite brief depending on the traveler: “Explore Your Inner Self.”

headline: At Least 7 Killed in Gaza Fighting
text: NAHAL OZ, Israel, May 15  Fighters from the military wing of Hamas, one of the two main Palestinian political factions, attacked Palestinian Authority security forces loyal to the rival Fatah faction at a location in Gaza near the border with Israel today, killing nine people, according to Fatah officials.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (CW) GILMORE GIRLS Lorelai (Lauren Graham), center, and Rory (Alexis Bledel), right, that bantering mother-daughter duo, move on with their lives in the series’s final episode. Rory lands her dream job as a political reporter, and Luke (Scott Patterson) throws her a graduation party attended by all of Stars Hollow, including Emily (Kelly Bishop) and Richard (Edward Hermann). They are on hand to hear Rory thank Lorelai for giving her a such great start in life. And then she’s off!

headline: Scientists Back Off Theory of a Colder Europe in a Warming World
text: OSLO — Mainstream climatologists who have feared that global warming could have the paradoxical effect of cooling northwestern Europe or even plunging it into a small ice age have stopped worrying about that particular disaster, although it retains a vivid hold on the public imagination.

headline: Nigeria: Election Body Must Produce Evidence, Court Says
text: An election tribunal ruled that the government must produce evidence that supports its declaration of a winner in last month’s presidential election, delivering an early victory to efforts to challenge the balloting in court. A tribunal judge said that electoral officials must allow Atiku Abubakar, the vice president and third-place finisher in the presidential contest, to examine the ballot papers, tally sheets and other materials used in declaring Umaru Yar’Adua, the candidate of the governing party, the winner. A European Union observer mission declared the voting “not credible,” and Nigerian observers demanded a rerun. Mr. Yar’Adua is set to be inaugurated on May 29.

headline: Britain: Blair and Bush to Meet
text: Prime Minster Tony Blair plans to visit Washington this week and meet with President Bush to discuss issues related to the Group of 8 meeting in Germany next month. Mr. Blair’s spokesman, who customarily speaks in return for anonymity, said the discussions would also cover climate change, Iraq and the Middle East. The Washington trip is being billed as part of Mr. Blair’s farewell schedule before he leaves office on June 27.

headline: U.S. Soldier Is Shot Dead in Ambush in Pakistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 14  An American soldier was shot dead and four other Americans were wounded in Pakistan on Monday after a meeting of Afghan, Pakistani and NATO officials at the border to try to resolve recent clashes between the neighboring countries, Afghan and NATO officials said.

headline: One Secret to Middle School Success: Class Size (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Operas on the Horizon: Tantalizing Glimpses of Adventurous Productions
text: The New York City Opera has become savvy about promoting its Vox series as a hip and adventurous event. The purpose of this invaluable showcase is to present excerpts from new or unperformed operas by American composers in free concert tryouts with the City Opera Orchestra and strong casts of singers.

headline: Bloomberg Pushes Green Plan, but Many Want to Talk of ’08
text: ALBANY, May 14 — Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came to the Capitol on Monday to pitch his plan for reducing traffic congestion in Manhattan to state lawmakers and Gov. Eliot Spitzer, but there is no apparent sense of urgency in Albany to move on the mayor’s complex environmental proposals.

headline: Gonzales’s Deputy Quits Justice Department
text: WASHINGTON, May 14 — Paul J. McNulty, the deputy attorney general whose Congressional testimony in February provided a spark that turned a smoldering issue over the firings of federal prosecutors into a raging inferno, announced his resignation on Monday.

headline: On the Web, an Advanced Carbon Calculator for Personal Use
text: A new Internet tool to help individuals and communities curb their role in adding global-warming carbon emissions will be announced today at a conference in New York of mayors from around the world, said a person who built the Web technology.

headline: White House Shifts Course on Wolfowitz
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — The Bush administration, shifting strategy in the face of mounting opposition to Paul D. Wolfowitz, opened the door today to him resigning voluntarily as World Bank president if the bank board drops its drive to declare him unfit to remain in office.

headline: Here Is New York: A Gallery’s Album of 25 Years of City Life
text: In the early 1970s, when few art galleries showed photography, the Midtown Y Photography Gallery was a rare pioneer devoted to the medium. An exhibition at the New York Public Library revisits the gallery’s 25-year history and the role it played as photography moved into the art world.

headline: Fort Dix Background Checks Proposed
text: A congressman from New Jersey said yesterday that he would propose a bill that would require all visitors to military installations to undergo federal background checks. The proposal comes in the wake of the charges filed last week against six men accused of planning an attack on soldiers at Fort Dix. The congressman, Representative Jim Saxton, a Republican whose district includes Fort Dix, said his bill would require the background checks for all visitors, including contractors, delivery people and civilians. The authorities have linked the six terrorist suspects to a pizzeria that frequently delivered to the base.

headline: The Familiar and the New, With Gusto
text: James Levine conducts seated these days. And at least a few of his performances in recent years have seemed apathetic. But on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall the lively and satisfying concert he gave with the Met Orchestra was a picture of robust good health.

headline: Stuck on the Runway, Thinking Rebellious Thoughts
text: THE other day I asked G. Bruce Hedlund, a pilot for a major domestic airline who has about three decades in the air, when he was going to be able to retire.

headline: The Right to Paid Sick Days
text: It sounds reasonable: seven paid sick days a year. Why should you have to lose a couple of days pay, or maybe even your job, because you had the misfortune to catch the flu?

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: SOLDIER’S IRAQ BLOG BECOMES PRIZE-WINNING BOOK

headline: Central Asians Chase Jobs, and Endure Exploitation
text: JIBEK JOLY, Kazakhstan, May 14 — Dressed in ratty sport coats and dirty T-shirts, Uzbek men clutching yellow job contracts squeezed recently into packed buses heading for cities to the north in fast-urbanizing Kazakhstan and on up to Russia.

headline: Jerry Falwell, Leading Religious Conservative, Dies
text: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, the fundamentalist preacher who founded the Moral Majority and helped bring the language and passions of religious conservatives into American politics, died today shortly after he was found unconscious in his office at Liberty University in Lynchburg, Va. He was 73 years old.

headline: A Corporate Divorce on the Cheap
text: STUTTGART, Germany, May 14 — Nine years after they exchanged vows at a huge, lavishly choreographed news conference in London, Daimler and Chrysler signed their divorce papers Monday at a sparsely attended briefing in an auditorium at an aging Mercedes-Benz factory here.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on May 7, about yoga patents, misstated the responsibilities of the United States Patent and Trademark Office. It does not register copyrights; that is the job of the United States Copyright Office.

headline: Words That Help When Life Is All Drama, No Comedy
text: ISARIS BAEZ is 11 and waiting for heart surgery. It gets a little boring being in a hospital all day. So she was happily surprised last Wednesday when she learned that there was to be a screening of “TMNT,” the latest Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movie, followed by a poetry jam. Pizza! Popcorn! Poems!

headline: Military Gives Details of Iraq Ambush of 7 G.I.s
text: BAGHDAD, May 15 — The seven American soldiers involved in a deadly weekend ambush south of Baghdad were from the 10th Mountain Division, based in upstate New York, military officials announced today, as thousands of troops continued an intensive search for three of the soldiers, who disappeared and are presumed to have been kidnapped by Sunni Arab insurgents.

headline: Letters
text: The Root of Obesity

headline: Qaeda Group Calls Hunt for Soldiers Pointless
text: BAGHDAD, May 14 — The search for three missing American soldiers abducted after an attack south of Baghdad continued Monday as the Qaeda group that claimed responsibility for the ambush said the soldiers would never be found.

headline: New York Welcomes Floyd Back to Town
text: Cliff Floyd could rattle off a list of 100 reasons why he signed with his hometown Chicago Cubs in January, starting with more day games and more time with his family.

headline: In Deal, a Test for the U.A.W.
text: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., May 14 — Can private equity investors fix Chrysler for good, and can they avoid a confrontation with the United Automobile Workers union?

headline: Mammograms in Decline
text: After years of going to their doctors in rising numbers to get annual mammograms, American women have begun skipping the procedure. The small, but significant decline — reported yesterday by researchers from the National Cancer Institute — is disturbing because it means that more women will fail to get the early detection that increases their chances of survival.

headline: In Hive or Castle, Duty Without Power
text: I never much cared for royalty, although I admit that, for reasons my family and I are still struggling to understand, I named my first cat “Princess Bubbles.”

headline: Look Back in Chagrin: A Rocker’s Progress
text: A portrait of the artist as a confused young black man emerges in vivid colors in the fresh, exuberant and bitingly funny new musical “Passing Strange,” which opened last night at the Public Theater. The biography of a songwriter on a wayward journey of self-discovery, this bracingly inventive show introduces an exciting new voice to contemporary musical theater, a witty wordsmith, composer and performer who goes by the single name Stew.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend on Friday about the exhibition “Lincoln Kirstein,” at the Whitney Museum of American Art, misstated the name of the ballet school Kirstein founded with George Balanchine. It is the School of American Ballet, not the American School of Ballet.

headline: Lawyers Argue Legal Status of Gay Unions
text: HARTFORD, May 14 — Connecticut’s highest court became the first in the nation on Monday to hear arguments over whether the establishment of civil unions created a fundamentally inferior status for gays and lesbians. But in pondering a new appeal for same-sex marriage, the State Supreme Court’s seven justices also focused on another fundamental question: whether laws that make distinctions based on sexual orientation, like those governing marriage, merit scrutiny similar to that given laws that discriminate based on race or gender.

headline: Science in the Court Room
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Marathoner Joins Central Park Race
text: Khalid Khannouchi, who has twice broken the world record in the marathon, yesterday joined the field for Saturday’s Healthy Kidney 10-kilometer run in Central Park. He has never raced in the park.Khannouchi, 35, was born in Morocco, moved to Brooklyn in 1993 and lives in Ossining, N.Y. He became an American citizen in 2000. He set world marathon records of 2 hours 5 minutes 42 seconds in Chicago in 1999 and 2:05:38 in London in 2002. He has been slowed by foot injuries in recent years.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Correction: For the Record
text: An article and picture caption in some copies on Friday about the killing of the New York police officer’s estranged girlfriend misidentified the Queens neighborhood where it occurred. It was Woodhaven, not Woodside. The article also gave an incorrect spelling from the police for the given name and surname of the victim. She was Guiatree Hardat, not Guyatree Hartati.

headline: One Misstep and They’re Out the Door
text: Misbehaving executives, take note: before you have your day in court, you may already be out of a job.

headline: Broadway’s Year of Tepid Hits
text: All right, to recap:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about the arraignment of a New York police officer on murder charges in the killing of his estranged girlfriend misspelled the surname of the assistant Queens district attorney who spoke in court. She is Annette Almazan, not Almaza.

headline: Oklahoma Chides Insurer in Medicare Marketing Case
text: WASHINGTON, May 14 — In the first major investigation of Medicare marketing, the Oklahoma insurance commissioner has documented widespread misconduct by agents working for Humana and has ordered the company to take corrective action to protect consumers against high-pressure sales tactics.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a bid by the equity group Cerberus Capital Management to buy a controlling interest in Chrysler referred imprecisely to the timing of Chrysler’s acquisition of Jeep. It was added in 1987 with Chrysler’s purchase of American Motors; Jeep was not part of Chrysler when it received a federal bailout in 1979.

headline: In Divided New Orleans
text: When President Bush spoke to the nation soon after Hurricane Katrina, he was resolute that the city would be rebuilt. “We will do what it takes,” he said. We — the federal, state and city governments; elected officials and the citizens who hire them — have failed spectacularly. Homes and schools remain empty or imaginary; evacuees and survivors wait in cramped trailers, unable to return or rebuild. A huge silence still hangs over the Lower Ninth Ward, a place every American should see, to witness firsthand how truckloads of promises have filled New Orleans’s vast devastation with nothing.

headline: Giants’ Kicking Hopes Rest on Untested Legs
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 14  The Giants have two place-kickers on their roster. One, Josh Huston, spent most of last fall with the odd job of cleaning junk out of foreclosed houses. He had his appendix removed last week and will probably not kick again until June.

headline: Iraqi Military Faces Hurdles in Its Quest to Take Charge
text: KIRKUSH BASE, Iraq, May 9 — The heat of the day was just beginning as Brig. Gen. Dana J. H. Pittard greeted Lt. Gen. Ali Ghaidan Majid, commander of ground forces in Iraq, and the two boarded a helicopter for Diyala Province, one of the most violent areas of the country.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about the decision by a powerful Shiite party, the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, to drop the word “revolution” from its name omitted the party’s new name. It is the Iraqi Islamic Supreme Council.

headline: Two Kinds of Oxygen
text: Q. I am a veterinarian. The last time I went to my supplier for medical oxygen, only industrial oxygen was available. What is the difference between the two products? Does industrial oxygen have harmful contaminants? I have heard that it is sometimes recommended for emergency use in third-world countries.

headline: After 5 Years, Padilla Goes on Trial in Terror Case
text: MIAMI, May 14 — The trial of Jose Padilla, the American convert to Islam charged with conspiring to support terrorism, opened Monday with federal prosecutors describing what they called a calculated plan to provide money, equipment and recruits to Al Qaeda.

headline: Marine Refused Staff’s Advice on Iraq Deaths, Major Testifies
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 14 — A Marine Corps officer testified Monday that a commander in Iraq rejected recommendations from two subordinates that he investigate accusations that marines in his battalion deliberately killed a group of civilians in Haditha in late 2005.

headline: Suns See a Dirty Player Where the Spurs See a Winner
text: SAN ANTONIO, May 14  The physical evidence has been quite obvious in the Western Conference semifinals.

headline: Queens Worker Injured Chasing Shoplifters
text: A Jamaica clothing store employee who tried to stop two shoplifters was struck by their vehicle as they fled, the police said. The employee, whom the police identified only as a man in his 50s, saw a man and a woman take merchandise from the store, Pretty Girl, at 162-21 Jamaica Avenue about 1:20 p.m. and chased them. When the shoplifters got into a waiting minivan, the employee grabbed a door handle but was struck as the vehicle drove off, and received a head injury, the police said. He was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was in critical condition. The police said late yesterday that no suspects had been arrested.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,382 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:

headline: Nutrition: A Cardiovascular Argument for Eating Whole Grains
text: It is hard to escape the message that whole grains are good for you. But few Americans put it into practice.

headline: Posada Is One Yankee That Can’t Be Replaced
text: Only four catchers in major league history have spent more games behind the plate than Tony Peña. For 18 seasons, Peña squatted behind hitters, cajoled pitchers, absorbed foul tips and collided with charging runners. He is an expert on longevity at baseball’s most rigorous position.

headline: Stanley Holden, 79, a Dancer and Prominent Ballet Teacher, Is Dead
text: Stanley Holden, whose Chaplinesque blend of wistfulness and wit made him one of the finest character dancers in Britain’s Royal Ballet before he settled in Los Angeles and became one of the area’s most popular ballet teachers, died on Friday in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 79.

headline: New DVDs
text: CLASSIC WESTERN ROUND-UP: VOLUME 1

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about an agreement between Russia and two Central Asian countries for a new gas pipeline to Russia rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Vice President Dick Cheney on a visit to Kazakhstan in 2006. He said that Russia wields its energy supplies as “tools of intimidation or blackmail,” not “tools for intimidation and blackmail.” It also misstated the timing of his visit. It was May of last year, not last summer. The article also misstated the price Russia pays Turkmenistan for gas and the price for which it resells the gas to European customers. It buys the gas for $100 per 1,000 cubic meters and resells it for $250 per 1,000 cubic meters — not $100 and $250 “per cubic meter.”

headline: Bush Calls for Work for Higher Fuel Efficiency
text: WASHINGTON, May 14 — President Bush announced on Monday that he had directed his administration to begin the long process of establishing higher fuel efficiency standards for new cars.

headline: Transit Chief Plans to Ask Riders to Grade Subway and Bus Lines
text: Griping about subway service is practically a vocation for many New Yorkers. Yet it often goes hand in hand with the conviction that no matter how much they complain, no one is ever likely to listen.

headline: The Pesthouse
text: An unspecified war or series of wars has dragged the world back into a harsh, preindustrial existence. In what was the United States, its cities gone and its population vastly reduced, the survivors live meagerly off the land, using the most rudimentary of tools. A crude social structure has sprung up in isolated local communities; bandits maraud through stretches of countryside; and life has been reduced to the Hobbesian state: nasty, brutish and short.

headline: In Study, College-Prep Classes Left Many Unready
text: Only one-quarter of high school students who take a full set of college-preparatory courses — four years of English and three each of mathematics, science and social studies — are well prepared for college, according to a new study of last year’s high school graduates released today by ACT, the Iowa testing organization.

headline: Cowboys Camp Is Peaceful, at Least for Now
text: IRVING, Tex., May 14  Terrell Owens stood in front of his locker on Monday  the final day of the Dallas Cowboys’ minicamp  and described the difference between playing for Wade Phillips, the new coach, and Bill Parcells, who rarely spoke to Owens or even mentioned him by name.

headline: The Conservative Path (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Who Should Run Your Company After You?
text: When it comes to succession, a typical chief executive has one person in mind. That’s simply not the way to go, says Barry S. Cain, managing director for the Family Business Center at Blackman Kallick, an accounting and consulting firm.

headline: Palestinian Minister Quits, as Factions Battle On
text: GAZA, May 14 — The Palestinian interior minister, Hani al-Qawasmeh, resigned Monday, and four more Palestinians were killed in fierce factional gun battles.

headline: Sharing Values: Who Gets to Decide? (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: HPV Vaccine: Few Risks, Many Benefits
text: What is it that some parents don’t understand about the HPV vaccine, licensed last summer in hopes of preventing most cases of genital warts and cervical cancer?

headline: Cerberus Goes Where No Firm Has Gone Before
text: In the last year, private equity firms have broken the mold over and over again. They have bought technology and finance companies, previously thought unsuitable for buyouts. The deals have gotten bigger; the financing more creative.

headline: ‘Spring Awakening’ Gets 11 Tony Nominations
text: In a season rich with contenders, “Spring Awakening,” a dark rock musical based on a 19th century German play about sexually anguished teenagers, led the field of Tony Award nominations this morning with 11, including chances at awards for best musical, director and best actor for two of its cast.

headline: Plucking at Strings
text: What will the new Large Hadron Collider at Cern have to say about string theory, the alleged theory of everything that describes nature as composed of tiny wriggling strings?

headline: Three Detectives Accused in Death of Sean Bell Seek Evidence
text: Lawyers for the three detectives charged in the shooting death of Sean Bell complained yesterday that prosecutors are withholding evidence they say they are entitled to — including eyewitness accounts — that could help their clients.

headline: Britain: Pearson Acquires an Educator
text: Pearson, the education publisher, agreed to buy eCollege.com for $538 million to add online degree courses in the United States. Shareholders of eCollege will receive $22.45 a share, Pearson said, an 8.9 percent premium over its closing price on Friday. ECollege, founded in 1996 and based in Chicago, works with about 180 United States colleges and universities to offer degree, certificate and diploma programs.

headline: Teaching vs. Research (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Paper Mill Playhouse Announces Multifeatured Plan for Survival
text: The financially floundering Paper Mill Playhouse announced a plan yesterday that it said would allow it to finish its season on schedule and continue operating next year. The plan is a mixed bag that includes administrative restructuring, a sizable bank loan and help from the government of Millburn, N.J., where the theater is situated.

headline: Ghosts of Chocolate Cigars to Waft Over Hungry Minds
text: Even seasoned New Yorkers may be unfamiliar with Jersey Street. It’s more alley than avenue, tucked between Mulberry and Crosby Streets like a quaint movie-set reminder of old Manhattan. But those who do know the block’s history will tell you that No. 10 was where the Hawley & Hoops candy factory churned out chocolate cigarettes and cigars starting in the late 19th century.

headline: Family Holds Discussion of Dow Bid by Murdoch
text: The far-flung family that controls Dow Jones & Company met by phone yesterday to discuss a pledge by Rupert Murdoch to give them a seat on the board of his News Corporation if it buys Dow Jones, and to guard the independence of the Dow Jones trophy property, The Wall Street Journal.

headline: A Bang, a Cloud, a Delay
text: There was a bang and then a cloud of dust.

headline: Opposition Parties Paralyze Pakistan’s Financial Hub
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 14 — Opposition parties shut down the southern port city of Karachi and slowed commerce in other parts of the country with a strike on Monday to protest the deaths of at least 39 people in political violence over the weekend.

headline: Memo Pad
text: GRIDLOCK AHEAD? With 750 million domestic passengers expected to fly this year, “the air transportation system is stretched thin,” the Federal Aviation Administration said in a report. It called for increased financing for "major technology upgrades and capacity-improvement projects at major airports" to avoid what the agency said would be aviation “gridlock.” Last year, the F.A.A. said, airline delays were “the worst in history.” DELTA HELICOPTER SHUTTLE  US Helicopter, which operates helicopter shuttles with 325 flights a week to Kennedy International and Newark airports and Bridgeport, Conn., is now flying into Delta Air Lines Terminal 3 at Kennedy, rather than American Airlines Terminal 9. One-way fares for the eight-minute trip from Manhattan to Kennedy or Newark start at $159. At Newark, the shuttles land next to Continental Airlines Terminal C.

headline: White House Names General to Be ‘War Czar’
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — The White House said this afternoon that President Bush ended his lengthy search for a “war czar” to carry out Iraq and Afghanistan policy by offering the job to an active duty three-star Army general who said in his interview that he had been skeptical of the troop buildup in Iraq.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about an agreement between Russia and two Central Asian countries for a new gas pipeline to Russia rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Vice President Dick Cheney on a visit to Kazakhstan in 2006. He said that Russia wields its energy supplies as “tools of intimidation or blackmail,” not “tools for intimidation and blackmail.” It also misstated the timing of his visit. It was May of last year, not last summer. The article also misstated the price Russia pays Turkmenistan for gas and the price for which it resells the gas to European customers. It buys the gas for $100 per 1,000 cubic meters and resells it for $250 per 1,000 cubic meters — not $100 and $250 “per cubic meter.” (Go to Article)

headline: Patterns: Moderate Drinking May Ease Effects of ‘Bad’ Cholesterol
text: Researchers have long known that people who drink moderate amounts of alcohol appear to be less likely to develop heart disease. Much of the benefit has been attributed to the higher levels of HDL cholesterol — often referred to as the “good” cholesterol — found in moderate drinkers. The lipoproteins in this kind of cholesterol are believed to help the body fight off heart disease.

headline: NBC, Tired of Last Place, Turns to Sci-Fi and Fantasy
text: NBC, in a slump and eager to regain its winning ways, is hoping to attract advertisers and viewers with a fall schedule that plays it safe by trying to learn from recent mistakes and build on recent strengths.

headline: Landis Takes Doping Case to Court, Hoping to Keep Title
text: MALIBU, Calif., May 14  The hearing that will determine whether Floyd Landis keeps his 2006 Tour de France title started Monday with legal maneuvering, dense scientific testimony and an unusual photo for the family album.

headline: Friend or Faux?
text: Dreux, France

headline: Creator of ‘Big Brother’ and ‘Deal or No Deal’ Is Being Sold
text: LONDON, May 14 — A group of investors led by John de Mol, one of the founders of Endemol, which pioneered reality television series like “Big Brother” and game shows like “Deal or No Deal,” agreed Monday to buy a controlling stake in the company from Telefónica, the Spanish telecommunications company.

headline: Japan to Vote on Modifying Pacifist Charter Written by U.S.
text: TOKYO, May 14 — The Japanese Parliament passed a bill on Monday calling for a national referendum on amendments to the country’s pacifist Constitution.

headline: Doctors Who Wield the Pen to Heal the Profession
text: Like the racket of dozens of birds on a clothesline, the sound of doctors is filling the air.

headline: Rock Star Still Hasn’t Found the African Aid He’s Looking For
text: With less than a month to go before the leaders of the Group of 8 nations gather at a Baltic Sea resort in Germany for their annual summit meeting, Bono, the rock star and antipoverty campaigner who helped sweet-talk, cajole and otherwise persuade them to make commitments to double aid to Africa, says most of them have fallen behind on their promise.

headline: Writes Thrillers, Flies a Cessna
text: I GREW up in Buffalo, and my dad used to take me out to the airport to watch the planes. I knew then that someday I was going to learn to fly. I’m a former United States Air Force captain. There are a lot of great things about the service, but one of the best is that you can take flying lessons pretty inexpensively with the Air Force-supervised civilian-run aero clubs on base. I took my first lesson in high school, but really learned to fly from these guys.

headline: A Chief With Union Roots Enters a Proving Ground
text: He comes from a long line of unionized autoworkers, but Thomas W. LaSorda’s collar is unmistakably white.

headline: Mexico: Chief of Drug Intelligence Shot and Killed
text: Gunmen killed José Nemesio Lugo, a veteran government intelligence officer and the new chief of the National Center for Analysis, Planning and Information to Combat Crime, a unit of the attorney general’s office that gathers and analyzes intelligence on organized criminal organizations, including drug traffickers. He was appointed to the post just a month ago.

headline: Pentagon Blocks 13 Web Sites From Military Computers
text: Members of the military will not be allowed to use military computers to communicate through Web sites like YouTube and MySpace under restrictions that the Pentagon imposed yesterday.

headline: Deaths and Fraud Reports Mar Philippine Vote
text: MANILA, May 14 — Voters went to the polls in the Philippines on Monday to elect their senators, representatives and local officials, amid reports of election-related violence and allegations of fraud.

headline: Texas: 4 Suspended in Youth Agency Scandal
text: Superintendents of four detention centers of the troubled Texas Youth Commission have been suspended with pay pending investigations. The suspensions, on charges of failing to report a sexual assault, inappropriate use of state resources, mistreatment and interfering with reporting or investigating incidents, involve centers in Edinburg, Harlingen, Crockett and Roanoke. The latest actions bring to 93 the number of agency employees disciplined since accusations of a cover-up of sexual abuse of juveniles by staff members and other inmates. Earlier, 8 employees were arrested and 81 were dismissed or are in process of termination.

headline: Uzbekistan: Europe Eases Sanctions
text: European Union foreign ministers meeting in Brussels removed four names from a list of 12 high-ranking Uzbek officials who have been denied visas as a part of the sanctions imposed on Uzbekistan after the government violently crushed an uprising in the city of Andijon in 2005. An arms embargo remains in effect.

headline: How a Vast Ice Sheet Put the Squeeze on Earth (and Its Gravity)
text: To use a very unscientific term, the earth is squishable. Put a heavy weight on it and the crust will deform. Remove the weight and the crust will rebound.

headline: Trenton: Increased Penalties for Gas Price Gouging
text: A bill to increase penalties for gasoline price gouging unanimously passed the Assembly Transportation Committee yesterday. The measure, which has passed the Senate, increases fines for a first violation to $1,500 from $50 and for subsequent violations to $3,000 from $200. The previous fines were set nearly 70 years ago. The measure grew out of a rash of violations after Hurricane Katrina, which disrupted oil industry operations in the Gulf of Mexico, sent gasoline prices soaring in 2005. The measure will now go to the full Assembly.

headline: A New York Institution Gets a Network Reprieve
text: The honchos at NBC Universal made it official yesterday, announcing that they were not consigning a well-known New York institution to the dustbin of history.

headline: A Human Capital Agenda
text: In 1998, the Republican Party was in disarray. “G.O.P. Train Careens Out of Control,” was the headline on one George Will column. The folks at National Review surveyed the wreckage of the Republican Revolution and asked, “What Went Wrong?”

headline: Justices’ Vote in Death Case Is Close Again, but Differing
text: WASHINGTON, May 14 — For the fourth time in a row, the Supreme Court on Monday decided a death penalty case by a vote of 5 to 4. But this time, contrary to the court’s overturning of three Texas death sentences last month, a narrow majority went the other way and reinstated the death sentence of an Arizona man who argued that his lawyer had failed to discover or present crucial evidence that could have persuaded the jury to spare his life.

headline: Kazakhstan: Mass Deaths of Seals Linked to Virus
text: The government said distemper appeared to be a cause in the wave of deaths of seals this spring in the Caspian Sea. At least 933 dead seals have washed ashore in Kazakhstan in recent weeks, most of them pups. The deaths have raised concerns about seals in the sea, which contains extensive industrial pollution and is a major transit route for oil and the site of a network of oil-pumping platforms. Laboratory tests confirmed the presence of the distemper virus, the Environmental Protection Ministry announced, according to the Russian news agency Interfax. Environmentalists have warned for years that exposure to oil and heavy metals in the sea had weakened the seals’ immune systems.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Saturday about the economic historian Alfred D. Chandler Jr. misspelled part of the name of the place of residence of his daughter Mary (Mimi) Chandler Watt. It is Dinas Powys, Wales, not Dina.

headline: U. of Texas Fires Officer Over Tie to Loan Company
text: The University of Texas fired the director of financial aid at its Austin campus for improper conduct yesterday, reporting that he had more ties to a student loan company than had been known and had begun recommending the lender to students a few months after he bought stock in its parent company.

headline: Barely in Office, but G.O.P. Rivals Are Circling
text: MILFORD, N.Y. — The furniture has yet to arrive for one of the offices that Kirsten Gillibrand, a freshman Democrat in Congress, recently opened here. But the list of Republicans angling to challenge her next year is already growing.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the arrest of two Rutgers University seniors on burglary charges referred incorrectly to their campus. It is the Livingston campus, and it is in Piscataway, N.J. — not in Livingston.

headline: Chrysler Workers Surprised After Union Backs Sale
text: WARREN, Mich., May 14 — Chrysler workers were warned a few weeks ago by union officials that a private equity owner would be the worst thing that could happen to them. So many were as surprised as anyone Monday to learn that the sale of Chrysler to Cerberus Capital Management had their leaders’ support.

headline: Bombing Kills at Least 22 in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, May 15 — Twenty-two people were killed and 30 wounded here today when a suicide bomber struck a crowded restaurant in a busy part of the old city, police and hospital officials said.

headline: The New French President’s Roots Are Worth Remembering
text: ALATTYAN, Hungary

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption last Tuesday with an article about disciplinary action against Los Angeles police officials after a clash at an immigration rally referred incompletely to a scene at the rally, where officers used force to break up the crowd. The man pictured on his knees with police officers standing over him was a photographer for KCAL-TV in Los Angeles, Carl Stein — not one of the people who the police said had tried to provoke them.

headline: Intellectual Property Is on the Block at a German Auctioneer
text: BERLIN, May 13 — Webasto, an auto parts maker based in a Munich suburb, has spent millions over the last decade negotiating licenses for its products to automakers like Mercedes-Benz, Volvo, Opel, Volkswagen and Audi.

headline: Chrysler Group to Be Sold for $7.4 Billion
text: STUTTGART, Germany, May 14 — DaimlerChrysler announced today that it will sell a controlling interest in its struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management, a private equity firm that specializes in restructuring troubled companies, for $7.4 billion, mostly in the form of capital that Cerberus will put into Chrysler.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about “Patina du Prey’s Memorial Dress, 1993-2007,” at Artists Space in Soho, misidentified the Artists Space Web site. It is artistsspace.org.

headline: Case Highlights Sex Abuse at Church, Beyond Priests
text: Beginning in sixth grade and lasting several years, Claudia Vercellotti said she was sexually abused repeatedly by the chief of youth ministries for the 19-county Roman Catholic Diocese in Toledo, Ohio. She said she later found four others who said they were victimized by the same man, although he denied wrongdoing.

headline: Delgado Caps Mets’ Rally With Walk in the Ninth
text: It was one of those delightfully far-fetched situations that, considering the moment, did not seem all that bizarre. With the score tied and two on and two out in the bottom of the ninth inning, the Chicago Cubs intentionally walked Carlos Beltrán to pitch to ... Carlos Delgado?

headline: Strapping on the Toe Shoes to Push at Ballet’s Borders
text: Deborah Lohse’s “Lucy Poems” is an example of a phenomenon that crops up every now and again: someone has the worthy thought that he or she will make ballet look contemporary. The most successful practitioner of this genre is Karole Armitage, whose “Drastic Classicism” — frenzied ballet to an ear-splitting rock score — shocked and thrilled audiences in 1981. (Twyla Tharp and William Forsythe had used rock music for ballet companies well before that, but their subject was not primarily how classical dance inhabits the modern world.)

headline: A Giant Takes On Physics’ Biggest Questions
text: 300 FEET BELOW MEYRIN, Switzerland — The first thing that gets you is the noise.

headline: As Demand for Donor Eggs Soars, High Prices Stir Ethical Concerns
text: Samantha Carolan was 23 and fresh out of graduate school when she decided to donate eggs to an infertile couple. Ms. Carolan concedes that she would never have done it if not for the money, $7,000 that she used to pay off some student loans.

headline: Ceridian Executive Is Fired
text: The Ceridian Corporation said yesterday that it had fired a top executive, accusing him of disclosing confidential information to Pershing Square Capital Management, a hedge fund that is trying to oust the company’s board.

headline: Testimony About Delusions With ‘Cosmic Proportions’
text: To the prosecution, it was a sinister crime that a troubled but calculating man committed against one terrified woman. But to a defense psychologist, Peter Braunstein’s attack on a former colleague in the fashion press was a symbolic attack on the hypocrisy of the fashion industry and of American society.

headline: U.S. Tries to Stem Afghan Opium Trade, Belatedly
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a walled compound outside Kabul, two members of Colombia’s counternarcotics police force are trying to teach raw Afghan recruits how to wage close-quarters combat.

headline: Uncle Sam Has His Eye on You: Government Surveillance Today
text: Something about being in government or law enforcement must bring out the Peeping Tom in people. Every couple of decades the amount of Big Brothering being practiced in the United States — by J. Edgar Hoover, for instance, or the Watergate crowd — bubbles to the surface. And once the furor has subsided, we are left with the uneasy sense that such shenanigans are probably the rule rather than the exception.

headline: Port Authority Plans to Study Cashless Tolls
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will consider in a few weeks a proposal to remove all toll booths on the bridges and tunnels it operates to reduce traffic and usher in a new pricing system, the authority’s executive director, Anthony E. Shorris, said today.

headline: How to Define Progress in Iraq (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Considering How Best to Play a Playmaker
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: U.S.-Russia Bond Is Far Better Than Before, Rice Says
text: MOSCOW, May 14  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Monday that while Russia and the United States were going through a period of uneasy relations, the problems fell far short of those of the cold war and that the two countries continued to cooperate in a number of important areas.

headline: Giuliani and the G.O.P. (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chicago Is Piniella’s Kind of Town
text: Before Lou Piniella left home for spring training in February, he had lunch with an old friend.

headline: Red Cross Report Says Israel Disregards Humanitarian Law
text: JERUSALEM, May 14 — The International Committee of the Red Cross, in a confidential report about East Jerusalem and its surrounding areas, accuses Israel of a “general disregard” for “its obligations under international humanitarian law — and the law of occupation in particular.”

headline: Bear Stearns Will Write Down $225 Million
text: Bear Stearns, the securities firm, will write down $225 million in the value of its specialist business as the switch to automated trading at the New York Stock Exchange reduces the need for floor traders.

headline: William Becker, 85, Creator of Concept of Motel 6 Chain, Dies
text: William Becker, who after enduring rundown, though not particularly cheap, motel rooms on a cross-country trip in 1960 got the idea for the Motel 6 chain, charging $6 a night for a spare but clean room, died April 2 at his ranch outside Kingman, Ariz. He was 85.

headline: Inspectors Cite Big Gain by Iran on Nuclear Fuel
text: VIENNA, May 14 — Inspectors for the International Atomic Energy Agency have concluded that Iran appears to have solved most of its technological problems and is now beginning to enrich uranium on a far larger scale than before, according to the agency’s top officials.

headline: Bob Barker, 50 (on TV), Is to Be in Two Specials
text: LOS ANGELES, May 13 — When Bob Barker got out of the Navy at the end of World War II, he thought about becoming a flight instructor. But he had heard about an opening at a radio station and thought it sounded interesting. He had also heard that the station manager liked airplanes.

headline: Bank’s Report Says Wolfowitz Violated Ethics
text: WASHINGTON, May 14 — A World Bank committee charged Monday that Paul D. Wolfowitz violated ethical and governance rules as bank president by showing favoritism to his companion in 2005. In response, the Bush administration mounted a last-ditch global campaign to save Mr. Wolfowitz from being ousted from office.

headline: Afghan War, Unfinished (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gonzales Pressed Ailing Ashcroft on Spy Plan, Aide Says
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — On the night of March 10, 2004, a high-ranking Justice Department official rushed to a Washington hospital to prevent two White House aides from taking advantage of the critically ill Attorney General, John Ashcroft, the official testified today.

headline: 2 Suspended for School Prank That Scared Pupils in Tennessee
text: MURFREESBORO, Tenn., May 14 — A teacher and an assistant principal were suspended Monday for a prank in which sixth graders on a sleepover trip were told that a gunman was prowling nearby and were ordered to hide in silence.

headline: Now, Parents in Boerum Hill Raise Objections to an Arabic School
text: The Department of Education stood on the firing line last night at a contentious PTA meeting attended by more than 100 Brooklyn parents whose schools are set to share space with the Khalil Gibran International Academy, a new dual-language school that will teach Arabic language and culture.

headline: Details Emerge on Battles With Law by Miller’s Cousin
text: FRANCONIA, N.H., May 14  Liko Kenney, a cousin of the champion ski racer Bode Miller, had at least two confrontations in 2003 with Bruce McKay, the local police officer he killed Friday night in a shooting that left both men dead.

headline: The Claim: Darker Skin Protects Against Skin Cancer
text: THE FACTS

headline: House Democrats Set to Move on New Fund-Raising Rules
text: WASHINGTON, May 14  House Democratic leaders, against stiff resistance in their caucus, have decided to advance a measure to require federal lobbyists to disclose the campaign contributions they collect and bundle for federal political candidates, officials involved in their deliberations said.

headline: Utah: Voters Will Decide on Voucher Program
text: State voters will decide in November the future of the nation’s first statewide school voucher program, which would provide families with $500 to $3,000 per child for private school tuition. The Legislature narrowly adopted the program in February. Opponents, including teachers’ unions, the National PTA and the N.A.A.C.P., said the program would harm public schools and gathered more than 124,000 signatures to force Utah’s first referendum since 1974. Gov. Jon Huntsman Jr., a Republican who initially recommended combining the referendum vote with the primary election on Feb. 5 to save money, signed an executive order last week setting the vote for Nov. 6. The governor has asked legislators to provide money to help local governments pay for the election.

headline: Charities Settle Dispute on Split of Surprise Gift
text: A dispute over a $264 million trust that pitted the Salvation Army against Greenpeace was settled last week.

headline: After Ordnance Scare, Beachgoers Told to Dig With Care
text: SURF CITY, N.J., May 14 — Sun worshipers coming to this Jersey Shore town should be happy that the closed beaches will soon be reopening. But they might want to rethink what they bring.

headline: Movement With and Against Music, but Bracingly
text: The Divine Sarah is what they used to call Sarah Bernhardt. The Divine Sara is what some New York dancegoers began to call Sara Rudner in the 1970s. Ms Rudner is one of those rare artists who embody the art form they practice: a born dancer, sensuous and infinitely expressive, with a fluent body gifted in feats of multiple coordination, intense focus and effortless control over long, complex phrases of movement. To borrow the brilliant title of the dance historian Sally Banes’s definitive history of the New York 1960s generation of experimentalists, Ms. Rudner is Terpsichore in sneakers.

headline: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
text: ST. LOUIS, May 14 — Miles and miles of bigger and stronger levees have been built along the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers since the deadly floods of 1993, and millions of dollars have been spent on drainage improvements.

headline: U.N. Official Says He’s Been Denied Access to U.S. Immigrant Jails
text: A United Nations human rights official said he was barred from visiting an immigration detention center in New Jersey yesterday. It was the second time he was denied access to an American immigration jail on a weeklong monitoring tour.

headline: Poor Shooting Night Puts Nets’ Backs to the Wall
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 14 — Vince Carter had the ball in his hands, a roaring crowd on its feet and, it seemed, an entire franchise on edge.

headline: An Amputee Sprinter: Is He Disabled or Too-Abled?
text: MANCHESTER, England, May 14 — As Oscar Pistorius of South Africa crouched in the starting blocks for the 200 meters on Sunday, the small crowd turned its attention to the sprinter who calls himself the fastest man on no legs.

headline: States Fault MySpace on Predator Issues
text: Some of the country’s top law enforcement officials are charging that the online social network MySpace has discovered thousands of known sex offenders using its service, but has failed to act on the information.

headline: A Scholar of the Master Distills Beethoven’s Details
text: When considering an intersection of the pianist Charles Rosen with the late piano music of Beethoven, an old cliché comes to mind: Mr. Rosen has forgotten more about Beethoven than most people will ever know. The temptation to use that expression is best avoided. Mr. Rosen’s 80th-birthday recital at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday afternoon, in which he played Beethoven’s last three sonatas, made it clear that he has forgotten nothing.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music review and a picture caption yesterday about the pianist Maurizio Pollini, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the date of the recital. It was Saturday, not Friday.

headline: Cable Operators Score Points in Battle With N.F.L.
text: It’s been a long time since anyone viewed the National Football League as marginal in any way. Market muscle and viewership explain why the N.F.L. gets more television money than any other league and why the NFL Network was conceived as having nearly limitless appeal.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A television review last Tuesday about “When Kids Get Life,” a “Frontline” documentary on PBS, misstated the number of times the voice of the filmmaker, Ofra Bikel, can be heard in the documentary. It is several times, not just in one scene.

headline: Oracle Falls as Challenger Semifinals Open
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 14 (AP)  Emirates Team New Zealand and the Italian boat Luna Rossa earned victories Monday in the first of the Louis Vuitton Cup semifinal races. The semifinals are best-of-nine series.

headline: Nash Shows Some Fire, and Suns Show Some Life
text: SAN ANTONIO, May 14 — All night, Steve Nash played with his eyes peering out from behind his bandaged nose as he furiously tried to lift his Phoenix Suns from behind and into a tie in their series with the San Antonio Spurs.

headline: An Example of the ‘Soft Sell’
text: It is not often that consumers want marketers to waffle. When it comes to treats, though, they certainly seem to, if you consider the success of chains like Cold Stone Creamery and MaggieMoo’s, which sell ice cream in waffle cones and bowls.

headline: Trenton: Agency Approves 1 Billion for Tunnel
text: The North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority yesterday approved a proposal by Gov. Jon S. Corzine to spend $1 billion in federal highway funds over 10 years on a new commuter rail tunnel under the Hudson River. The tunnel is expected to cost $7.5 billion to build, and officials have raised $3 billion of that, including the funds approved yesterday. Supporters say the tunnel will double rail capacity between New York City and New Jersey and will reduce highway congestion. New Jersey will also apply for funds from the Federal Transit Administration for the project. Construction of the two-track tunnel is expected to begin in 2009 and end in 2016. To make up for the diverted federal highway funds, New Jersey will use $1 billion from its Transportation Trust Fund on state road work.

headline: Prestigious Private Schools Settle Rights Suit by a Non-Hawaiian
text: The private Kamehameha Schools in Hawaii announced yesterday that they had settled a civil rights lawsuit brought against them by a student denied admission because he did not possess Hawaiian ancestry. The settlement avoided the possibility of a decision by the United States Supreme Court on the status of Native Hawaiians.

headline: Satellites Show Harvest of Mud That Trawlers Leave Behind
text: Scientists have known for years that when fishing trawlers drag nets and gear across the ocean bottom they trap or kill almost all the fish, mollusks and other creatures they encounter. And the dragging destroys underwater features like reefs, turning the bottom to mud.

headline: 2 Former Siemens Officials Convicted for Bribery
text: A German court convicted two former Siemens executives of bribery yesterday and ordered the company to pay a fine of 38 million euros ($51.4 million), the first verdict in a widening corruption scandal that has engulfed the German engineering and electronics giant.

headline: Kate Webb, War Correspondent, Dies at 64
text: Kate Webb, a brave, no-nonsense correspondent during the Vietnam War who was erroneously reported to have been captured, killed and cremated in Cambodia — only to emerge from the jungle alive —died on Sunday in Sydney, Australia. She was 64.

headline: Hotel as Lifestyle
text: What Starbucks did for coffee and JetBlue did for air travel, a growing number of new hotel brands is trying to do for the overnight stay: create an experience that offers something different from the status quo, then replicate it around the globe.

headline: Turkish City Counters Fear of Islam’s Reach
text: KONYA, Turkey, May 12 — In the not too distant past here in Turkey’s religious heartland, women would not appear in public unless they were modestly dressed, a single woman was not able to rent an apartment on her own, and the mayor proposed segregating city buses by sex.

headline: Cameras in the Courts
text: Anybody who has been in a working courtroom knows that a real trial is a long way from “Law & Order.” But even though trials are often dry, unglamorous events, they are so vested in public interest that the founders required that they be open to the public. Today, the best way to give the public access is to allow court proceedings to be televised. New York has been among the slowest states to allow cameras in, but that could be about to change.

headline: A Vibrant Vucciria
text: Every day but Sunday, Palermo's Vucciria market fills with fishermen, shopkeepers and merchants who have come to peddle their goods.

headline: Bit of advice
text: For those seeking property in a crazy city like London, where someone told me there are 100 buyers for every house on the market, here’s a bit of advice from Cliff Gardiner, head of London buying for professional home-buying service The Buying Solution:

headline: 36 Hours in Baltimore
text: A harbor makeover, Colonial history and emerging art galleries give the city reasons for out-of-towners to visit.

headline: For Sale: Designer House
text: Christie’s will offer a small aluminum-paneled house built in 1951 by French designer Jean Prouvé.

headline: The New Atlantic City
text: With its combination of casinos, beaches, upscale shopping and fine dining, Atlantic City has one of the hottest real estate markets on the Jersey Shore.

headline: Greener Acres
text: When it comes to designing buildings that are good for the environment, Europe gets it.

headline: Pearson Acquires an Educator
text: Pearson, the education publisher, agreed to buy eCollege.com for $538 million to add online degree courses in the United States. Shareholders of eCollege will receive $22.45 a share, Pearson said, an 8.9 percent premium over its closing price on Friday. ECollege, founded in 1996 and based in Chicago, works with about 180 United States colleges and universities to offer degree, certificate and diploma programs.

headline: Regulators Expand Biovail Inquiry
text: Biovail, a Canadian drug maker, said regulators in the United States had expanded their investigation into questionable accounting and possibly misleading financial disclosures. The company said it had received a so-called Wells notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to its 2003 accounting, a 2002 acquisition, and how it accounts for revenue.

headline: Cardinal Health Acquires Device Maker
text: The medical products and services company Cardinal Health said on Monday that it would buy the medical technology company Viasys Healthcare for $1.42 billion, an acquisition that would help Cardinal expand in international markets.

headline: Swiss Investigating BAE in Money Laundering Case
text: Law enforcement authorities in Switzerland confirmed Monday that they had opened a criminal investigation into possible money laundering at BAE Systems, adding to the international scrutiny of the company, the top British military contractor.

headline: G.E. Kicks Off Soccer Partnership
text: General Electric said that its commercial finance division has teamed up with Hermes Sports Partners, a sports finance advisory boutique in London, to help finance soccer club buyouts and other deals related to the sport. G.E. has already helped the Texas oil magnate Malcolm Glazer finance his 790 million pound ($1.6 billion) acquisition in 2005 of Manchester United.

headline: Continental Resources I.P.O. Prices Below Expected Range
text: Continental Resources, an oil and natural gas exploration and production company, priced its initial public offering late Monday at $15 per share, below the expected range of $16 to $18. The company sold 8.85 million new shares and Harold G. Hamm, its chairman, sold 20.65 million of his shares in the offering, according to the prospectus.

headline: Conrad Black’s Wife Accused of Stealing Chandeliers
text: As her husband, Conrad Black, stands accused of stealing millions from the publishing company Hollinger International at a fraud trial under way in Chicago, Barbara Amiel is having some legal trouble of her own.

headline: Ex-Merrill Executive’s Enron Appeal Is Denied
text: A former executive at Merrill Lynch whose Enron-related fraud and conspiracy convictions were overturned last year by an appeals panel will remain a felon on two other counts. On Monday, the Supreme Court declined, without comment, to review the 2004 convictions of perjury and obstruction of justice in a jury trial against the executive, James Brown.

headline: Xstrata Raises Bid for LionOre
text: Xstrata, a Swiss mining company, increased a cash offer for LionOre Mining International by 35 percent, to 6.2 billion Canadian dollars ($5.6 billion), to top a bid from Russia’s Norilsk Nickel.

headline: Jott.com Gets First Taste of Funding
text: Jott.com, a phone-in service that converts voice messages into text messages that can be e-mailed, said it had raised $5.4 million in its first equity financing. The company, founded last year by John Pollard and Shree Madhavapeddi, said the round was led by Bain Capital Ventures.

headline: Latin America’s eBay Says Hola to Nasdaq
text: Investors will get a chance to bid on a Latin American online auctioneer, MercadoLibre, after the company, which is backed by eBay, filed to raise as much as $100 million in a proposed initial public offering.

headline: Another Tough Day in Court for Former Black Lieutenant
text: Former Chicago Sun-Times Publisher and Hollinger International President F. David Radler spent a third day fending off harsh questions and assertions that he is a liar, as his cross-examination in the criminal fraud trial of ousted Hollinger Chief Executive Conrad Black continued Monday.

headline: One Misstep and They’re Out the Door
text: Misbehaving executives, take note: before you have your day in court, you may already be out of a job.

headline: Buyout Battle for EGL Rages On
text: The battle for EGL continued over the weekend, with a company backed by Apollo Management offering $1.95 billion, or $46 a share, Saturday, to top a sweetened management-led buyout proposal for the company.

headline: ‘Private Equity Can Go Anyplace’
text: Chip makers. Student lenders. Giant regulated utilities. In the last year or so, private equity firms have repeatedly broken the mold, acquiring companies previously thought unsuitable for buyouts. And on Monday, they moved into virtually uncharted territory again, as Cerberus Capital Management agreed to take a majority stake in Chrysler, marking the first time an investment firm has sought control of a Detroit automaker.

headline: Swedish Green Tech: Silicon Valley’s Next Big Thing?
text: On a recent trip to Silicon Valley, Michael Wood, the United States ambassador to Sweden, pitched 30 Swedish green tech companies to 18 venture capitalists during a meeting at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: IAC In Deal for Front Line Stake, Report Says
text: In a bid to expand its already-considerable influence in the live-music industry, Ticketmaster’s parent, IAC/InterActiveCorp, is acquiring a significant stake in one of the biggest artist-representation businesses, Front Line Management, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Pershing Square Battles With Ceridian Over Fired Executive
text: A battle for control of Ceridian is heating up between the company’s management and Pershing Square Capital, an activist hedge fund that owns 14.2 percent of the provider of payroll and human resources services.

headline: Forget Wall Street: Bankers Head to Moscow for Big Pay
text: In Moscow, within a mile of the tomb of Vladimir Lenin, who vowed to destroy capitalists, investment bankers are now earning double the pay of their counterparts anywhere else. Deal makers from banks like UBS and Lehman Brothers are now commonly offered between $7 million and $10 million a year in Moscow, industry recruiters said.

headline: British Lobbying Group Defends Private Equity
text: Despite recent slamming by public shareholders, labor unions and lawmakers, it seems that private equity still has one ally.

headline: HSBC USA Reports Lower Profit
text: HSBC USA, a unit of British bank HSBC Holdings, said on Monday profit fell 11 percent in the first quarter, hurt by rising credit losses. Net income for the New York-based unit fell to $273 million from $308 million, HSBC USA said in its quarterly report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: HeidelbergCement to Buy British Rival for $15.8 Billion
text: Germany’s HeidelbergCement said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy a British rival, Hanson, for 8 billion pounds ($15.8 billion) in a deal that will create the world’s second-largest construction materials group.

headline: Societe Generale Denies Imminent Deal
text: The chief executive of Société Générale, the French bank that has been at the center of takeover speculation for weeks, denied Monday any immediate plans for a merger. But he left the door open for a future deal as banks in Europe look to consolidate across borders.

headline: Bear Stearns Will Write Down $225 Million
text: Bear Stearns will write down $225 million in the value of its specialist business as the switch to automated trading at the New York Stock Exchange reduces the need for floor traders.

headline: Bancrofts Hold Discussion of Revised Bid by Murdoch
text: The far-flung family that controls Dow Jones & Company met by phone on Monday to discuss a pledge by Rupert Murdoch to give them a seat on the board of his News Corporation if it buys Dow Jones and to guard the independence of the Dow Jones trophy property, The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Another Couple’s Sweet Nothings Lead to Insider Trading Charges
text: In the latest crackdown on illicit pillow talk, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday accused a former Oracle vice president of improperly profiting from his wife’s knowledge about two deals engineered by her boss, Oracle’s chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison.

headline: Carlyle Confirms Its Next Fund Will Be Publicly Traded
text: The Carlyle Group confirmed Monday that it would offer shares of an affiliate, Carlyle Capital Corporation Limitedm on Euronext Amsterdam in the second or third quarter of the year. Carlyle Capital is seeking to raise $400 million in the offering, giving the private equity shop’s affiliate a total capitalization of about $1 billion following the listing, the buyout shop said.

headline: Thomson and Reuters Agree to $17 Billion Merger
text: Reuters Group and the Thomson Corporation said Tuesday that they had agreed to a $17.2 billion combination that will create one of the world’s largest financial news providers. The announcement came less than two weeks after the two companies said they were in talks about a possible merger. The deal is not without obstacles, however. Antitrust regulators, and especially those in the European Union, are likely to take a close look at the transaction and its effects on competition. An analyst in London told Bloomberg News there was a “75 percent chance” the deal would go through.

headline: Tyco to Pay Nearly $3 Billion to Settle Lawsuits
