text: Tyco International agreed on Tuesday to pay $2.98 billion to settle investors’ lawsuits accusing the company of artificially inflating revenue, a move that helps clear the way for the firm to split into three companies. The agreement will resolve securities-fraud suits alleging that the company overstated its income by more than $5 billion under its former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski.

headline: Evercore Says Adjusted Income Doubled
text: Evercore Partners said Tuesday that its net income fell 84 percent to $4.2 million in the first quarter. But after factoring in the effects of last year’s initial public offering and other accounting adjustments, Evercore’s profit more than doubled from a year earlier to $16 million, lifted by strength in its merger advisory business, the investment bank said.

headline: 2008: G.O.P. Rumble in Columbia
text: Republican candidates gather tonight in Columbia, S.C. for their second debate. Sponsored by the state’s Republican party and  Fox News, the event can be seen on the network at 9 p.m. On FoxNews.com, the network’s Griff Jenkins will talk with students from the University of South Carolina before, during and after the debate.

headline: The Future of New York’s Past
text: A walk through Lower Manhattan yields scant evidence of the 17th century Dutch and English settlements. Many of the buildings now seen as timeless masterpieces, like the Flatiron Building (1902) and Grand Central Terminal (1903), are very young by Old World standards. In a city where change is the only constant, is there sufficient respect for the past?

headline: Hagel-Bloomberg: A Threat to Which Party?
text: While Barack Obama’s TV appearance got the most attention over the weekend, Republican Senator Chuck Hagel may have made the most interesting splash, telling “Face the Nation” that he is interested in a third-party run for president, likely paired with Mayor Mike Bloomberg: “It’s a great country to think about – a New York boy and a Nebraska boy to be teamed up leading this nation.”The conservative blogger John Hinderaker at Power Line doesn’t find this to be much of threat to the G.O.P., however: Maybe people at NPR are yearning for a candidate like Hagel; I know some Republicans who are yearning for a new candidate, but it isn’t Hagel: it’s Fred Thompson or Newt Gingrich.Which brings us to the question: if Hagel runs, will he hurt the Republican candidate, or the Democrat? I find the suggestion that Hagel’s run would hurt a Republican presidential candidate, which I’ve seen in a couple of places, rather ludicrous. Hagel is widely despised within the party, and the last poll I saw had him at 1% among Republicans. My guess is that a large majority of those “yearning” for a Hagel candidacy would otherwise vote for the Democrat.

headline: Che’s Fans in Iraq
text: Che Guevara may not live, as one of the latest installments in his T-shirt line claims, but he still has fans leading South American nations, and now, starting insurgent groups in Iraq.

headline: Charming Cape May
text: Cape May, N.J., offers families a traditional Jersey shore experience, restored Victorian homes and ample outdoor recreation.

headline: Seattle's Mix Master
text: For the design guru Brian Balmert, Seattle is equal parts laid-back and luxe.

headline: Point Pleasant Beach
text: A destination for family-friendly seaside recreation, Point Pleasant Beach is located at the top of the Intercoastal Waterway in Ocean County, N.J.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand May Sell Bobcat Unit
text: Ingersoll-Rand, the industrial conglomerate, said on Tuesday that it is exploring strategic alternatives for its Bobcat farm equipment and construction units, including a possible sale or spinoff. The move was announced alongside an expansion of the company’s share-repurchase plan to $4 billion from $2 billion.

headline: Yahoo Hires Thomas Weisel Co-founder as Finance Chief
text: Even as rumors swirl that Yahoo might be heading for some kind of deal with Microsoft, the Internet giant has picked a technology deal maker as its next chief financial officer. Yahoo announced Tuesday that it had hired Blake J. Jorgensen, a co-founder of the technology-focused investment bank Thomas Weisel Partners, as its finance chief. He will succeed Susan L. Decker, who took control of the company’s advertising operations in December amid mounting competition from its archrival Google.

headline: Paris — Travel Basics
text: THE AIRPORT: Jet-lagged visitors may not notice, but Charles de Gaulle International Airport – familiarly known as Roissy for the nearby town -– was explicitly conceived as an architectural entry point to France.

headline: Greek Islands for 20-somethings
text: My daughter and 3 female friends (22-23 years old) would like to spend aweek in the Greek islands this summer. They would like to take a boat from Athens and return there. They would like to meet other young peoplebut also enjoy the history and culture.

headline: Discovering Modern Marvels
text: Last Thursday, I served as one of the judges for the Modern Marvels Invent Now Challenge.

headline: $600,000 Homes
text: A two-bedroom condo in Boston, a house on Wisconsin's Door County Peninsula and a two-bedroom stucco home in Taos, N.M.

headline: From Behind the Scenes to Behind the Wheel
text: As the business world continues to examine every nook and cranny of the $7.4 billion acquisition of Chrysler, many are wondering about the driving force behind the deal: Cerberus Capital Management. The hedge fund and private equity firm has many reputations, including that of hard-charging negotiator and behind-the-scenes operator, loath to step into the spotlight. Both qualities could be said to apply to Cerberus’s founder, Stephen A. Feinberg, a Drexel Burnham Lambert alumnus, Princeton graduate and former Army paratrooper.

headline: Republican Presidential Debate in South Carolina
text: The following is a transcript of the Republican presidential primary debate at the University of South Carolina on May 15, 2007, as recorded by the Federal News Service:

headline: Tony Nominations: Plays
text: A look at the 2007 Tony Award nominations for best play and best revival of a play.

headline: Bangkok — Travel Basics
text: AIRPORTS: For years flying into Thailand meant stepping into the charmless, somewhat crusty hallways of Don Muang airport. It was a quick and dirty experience but surprisingly efficient. Now things are more complicated. If you’re on an international flight you’re likely to arrive at the sprawling new airport, Suvarnabhumi (airport code BKK), which is east of the city. Don Muang carries the airport code DMK and is used mainly for domestic flights. Study your tickets carefully, especially if you’re changing planes (it takes at least an hour to travel between airports). Here’s the most important thing to know about Suvarnabhumi: it’s pronounced Sawana-phoom. If you pronounce it the way it’s spelled, no one will understand you. Peak time for international flights at Suvarnabhumi is the evening. Check-in lines, especially for Thai Airways, which now uses the single check-in line system, can be very long. This system apparently saves Thai Airways money, but at peak times you can wait an hour or longer.

headline: Tony Nominations: Musicals
text: Photos of the 2007 Tony Award nominees for best musical and best revival of a musical.

headline: Rome — Travel Basics
text: The Colosseum. (The Associated Press)

headline: A Normandy Dream Home
text: 18th-century Château de Livry in Normandy.

headline: South America’s Next Big Thing
text: Cartagena has beaches, architecture and never sleeps.

headline: The Tonys: ‘Spring Awakening’ Leads the Field
text: In a season rich with contenders, “Spring Awakening,” a dark rock musical, led the field of Tony nominations.

headline: Hong Kong — Travel Basics
text: THE AIRPORT: The Hong Kong International Airport, also known as Chek Lap Kok, (www.hongkongairport.com) is organized and fast, with clear English signage. On good days, I’ve made it from plane to taxi in less than half an hour. (Tip: Though others say the exchange rate is better in town, I usually do the most convenient thing and change my money right after leaving customs). Facilities, including toilets, are wheelchair-friendly, and there are services for the hearing- or seeing-impaired.

headline: Is the Key to Dow Jones in the Bancrofts’ Wallets?
text: Given his repeated entreaties to the Bancroft family and his recent promises to shield The Wall Street Journal’s newsroom from his own meddling as owner, News Corporation chief Rupert Murdoch seems almost desperate to buy Dow Jones. He has written three letters to pitch his proposal and offered to hold tetes-a-tetes with the family members, who have a controlling stake in the company — all this on top of the rich premium contained in his $5 billion offer. But there is something else the media mogul can do, according to Breakingviews: Throw more bags of money at the Bancrofts, while leaving common shareholders with his current offer.

headline: Mediterranean Style
text: Fashion inspired by the hidden gems of the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: Berlin — Travel Basics
text: Berlin’s main train station. (Associated Press)

headline: London — Travel Basics
text: AIRPORTS: This is a good introduction to London, as it will get you used to the idea that everything seems to cost more, take more time and be more complex here than elsewhere. For starters, London has five airports, so pay attention to where you’re landing!

headline: A Tour of South African Wineries
text: The town of Tulbagh is at the forefront of the country’s wine revolution.

headline: WELCOME TO OUR WORLD!
text: Globespotters is a new site where International Herald Tribune reporters and editors (and readers too!) can share up-to-the-minute tips and recommendations about what’s happening in the places they live and visit. Let Globespotters help you get the most out of the world’s great cities.

headline: NoSpace at the Pentagon
text: In what borders on news of the weird, YouTube.com, MySpace.com and 11 other Web sites have been banned by the Department of Defense.

headline: Joshua Tree National Park and Beyond
text: The man-made outcroppings in the California desert.

headline: Angry Giuliani Aide Lashes Back
text: The other day on Fox News Sunday, Rudolph W. Giuliani blamed a former aide for the decision to put the city’s emergency command center at 7 World Trade Center, where it was destroyed on 9/11. Now the aide, Jerome M. Hauer, the former director of emergency management, has fired back, giving Lloyd Grove of New York magazine a February 1996 memo that shows he argued for a Brooklyn location. He says the mayor overruled him.

headline: The Super Bowls of Tokyo
text: A trip across Japan's culinary universe.

headline: The Sources of Pakistani Chaos
text: Before Mullah Dadullah, one of the Taliban’s top commanders, was killed over the weekend, he was able to leave a warning behind for his enemies.

headline: War Games in Taiwan
text: Taiwan’s military is testing out some new moves this week in drills meant to prepare for the possibility of a Chinese attack. Today, six fighter jets landed on a highway for a scenario that left official runways destroyed in the fighting.China and Taiwan, which split in 1949 after a civil war, appear to be far from conflict, although there are plenty of political frustrations over Taiwan’s attempts to be recognized as an independent nation. China has threatened invasion if Taiwan goes too far on that count.

headline: Bargain Spotting in the Software Sector
text: Media deals may be all the rage these days, but some analysts are seeing fodder for potential takeovers in the software industry as well. Kirk Materne and Daniel Cummins of Bank of America ran the numbers and found eight big software companies with low-enough stock values to make them attractive takeover candidates, even if the acquirer shelled out a 25 percent premium to the current price. The analysts emphasized they had no reason to believe a specific deal for any of them was in the works, but they also argued that consolidation in the software industry looked “inevitable.”

headline: TV Upfronts: Second Thoughts on NBC
text: Manhattan is steaming up as the weather prepares, maybe, for ABC’s presentation at 4 p.m. in tony Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.

headline: Rev. Jerry Falwell, Moral Majority Founder, Dies at 73
text: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, who founded the Moral Majority and built the religious right into a political force, has died. Rev. Falwell credited his Moral Majority with getting millions of conservative voters registered, electing Ronald Reagan and giving Republicans Senate control in 1980.

headline: For Blackstone Co-Founder, a Deal With Park Views
text: When Peter G. Peterson retires at the end of next year, he will be able to relax in some luxurious digs. The co-founder of private equity giant Blackstone Group has just shelled out $37.5 million to buy media mogul David Geffen’s 12-room duplex penthouse on Fifth Avenue in New York, city records show. The New York Observer, which noted the deal on its real estate blog, points out that Mr. Geffen bought the apartment last year for $31.5 million. That’s a 19 percent markup in a year — a respectable return even in private equity circles.

headline: Bruno’s Upstate Plan
text: Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno rolled out a lengthy plan to revitalize the upstate and used the occasion to tweak Gov. Eliot Spitzer for not doing likewise.

headline: More on Chrysler
text: Perusing the comments from Micheline Maynard’s last post on the Chrysler sale, I noticed three recurring themes. Two of them dealt with Chrysler’s poor interior design and reliability. But by far, most of the comments mentioned something about the hybrid issue.

headline: Fixing Our Economy By Fixing Up Our Workers
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his May 14 column, “Divided Over Trade.”

headline: ’04 Wiretapping Talks at Hospital
text: An extraordinary meeting in March 2004 in the hospital room of Attorney General John D. Ashcroft has been reported before. Today, Mr. Ashcroft’s deputy, James B. Comey, recounted the meeting for the first time.

headline: Clues to Watching Tonight’s G.O.P. Debate
text: Republicans are gathering in Columbia, S.C. today for what will be their second debate. It begins at 9 p.m. Eastern time, and is being broadcast on Fox News Channel. We’ve learned long ago not to try to make predictions about what can happen in these very free-for-all events, but there are a few things to watch for.

headline: Inventions That Make Life Easier
text: I mentioned earlier today that I’d be describing some of the good ideas that made the finals in the Modern Marvels Invent Now competition. Later this week, I’ll describe a few of them in more detail, but here’s a quick sweep to show you the kind of brilliance that was on display:

headline: Zambrano (No, Not That One) to the Mets?
text: The ace of the Mets in 2008 could be pitching at Shea Stadium tonight. Not John Maine, although he is certainly pitching like one. We’re talking about Carlos Zambrano, the Cubs’ burly right-hander who, if he cannot work out an extension with Chicago, will become the most coveted pitcher on the free-agent market come November.

headline: A Not-So-Fond Farewell for Falwell
text: In the good old days when print was king, nobody spoke ill of the dead, and if someone did, nobody else would know about it until the obituaries came out the next day. As we all know, with the rise of the blogosphere things have changed; still, the death of Jerry Falwell today seems to have set new heights in terms of both haste and venom. Here is a sampling:

headline: Limited Sells Stake in Express, Explores Sale of Chain
text: Limited Brands announced Tuesday that it was selling its 67 percent stake in Express for $548 million and that it would weigh a sale of its Limited Stores business. With the sale to the private equity firm Golden Gate Capital, the company will focus on its Victoria’s Secret and Bath & Body Works businesses, among others. The streamlining plan was announced as the company also lowered its guidance for the first quarter. In afternoon trading, Limited shares were down 4 percent.

headline: TV Upfronts: Help Change … What, Exactly?
text: ABC’s upfront is different right off the bat. Exit the subway at 66th Street and someone pleads “Help change TV!” and gives anyone with hands a card with many mixed messages on it: a duct-taped girl, the word “help!” and then some advocacy about — ah, the absence of Latinos on TV. The George Lopez thing.

headline: A New Direction for Republicans
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s May 15 column, “A Human Capital Agenda.”

headline: TV Upfronts: “Bachelor” Spoiler Alert
text: The big black ABC ball has iron filings spinning off it, and the montage of ABC’s triumphs just showed Officer Andy kissing Tessa. And if you don’t know what that means — the embrace — ignore it; but if you do, you’re a very loyal ABC fan, and yes it was a spoiler. At least I assume it was. Sorry about that.

headline: Sick Pay, Right or Privilege?
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s May 15 column, “The Right to Paid Sick Days.“

headline: TV Upfronts: The Black Ball, contd.
text: They’re crows, ravens, littles birds of death, flying off the ABC black ball. It’s too cold in here. Why is this horrible? I hate this upfront. I’m seriously disturbed by the logo stuff, which is not incidental. I know that someone designed this “Blair Witch” thing thinking that the little, um, “items” might call to mind the digital extensions that shows now offer. But if ABC sees those as evil little sick viral — ugh, they just turned seborrheic white!! — they’re either not getting it, or the future looks deranged.

headline: XM Suspends Opie and Anthony
text: And on the fifth business day, the satellite transmitted its punishment.

headline: TV Upfronts: A Little Girlie Beauty
text: It’s water. Definitely water. A “Lost” reference?

headline: TV Upfronts: Regular Dopes and a Heche Knockoff
text: “Carpoolers,” about four regular dopes who drive to work in the morning, looks like “King of Queens.” That’s high praise. I’m in.“Sam I Am” stars Christina Applegate, who now styles herself a little like Anne Heche.

headline: Ron Gettelfinger’s Radio Days
text: When Ron Gettelfinger speaks, Detroit listens. And when Mr. Gettelfinger has something to say, where does he speak? Most frequently, on the radio.

headline: TV Upfronts: The Sadness of Jimmy Kimmel
text: Jimmy Kimmel:

headline: TV Upfronts: Thank You, Your Oprah Majesty
text: Stephen McPherson, the boss here, just thanked Oprah Winfrey in the humble kiss-the-ring way for her first prime-time reality show, “Oprah’s Big Give.”

headline: TV Upfronts: It’s Getting All Emo in Here (and Really Cold)
text: The tearjerking — hey, are the droplets tears? — band the Fray plays its “How to Save a Life” live over another montage of ABC dramas, and I’m kind of losing the point of things here.

headline: TV Upfronts: Jerky Guys, Meet Career Women
text: There’s Dr. Addison Montgomery’s new “Grey’s Anatomy” spinoff show, “Private Practice.” It looks too antic. Kate Walsh’s lab-perfected red hair dominates every frame.

headline: Spitzer: Déjà Vu on Senate Plan
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer was not pleased to hear Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno claiming that the Senate’s new upstate revival plan is the first such plan offered this year.

headline: TV Upfronts: Upscale and Down
text: The next show is about “the price you pay for having it all,” so I guess the upscale peeps of ABC really are worried about something.

headline: TV Upfronts: Must. Move. Fingers.
text: Something is wrong with me, and it’s frostbite from air conditioning, but I’m drawn to “Big Shots,” an old man’s answer to “Entourage,” right here on ABC. I can already see the cancellation notice for it on zap2it.com, but with my frozen fingers it is my pleasure to type these words: I plan to watch the pilot.

headline: TV Upfronts: The Last Word on ABC (and It’s ‘Bingo’)
text: Maybe the stuff is confetti, which fell in torrents for the girl who won “Bingo,” and with it a 70-inch plasma TV. Jeez.

headline: Giuliani, 9/11 and the Emergency Command Center, Continued
text: Joseph J. Lhota, who was a deputy mayor and top aide during Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani’s two terms, said this afternoon that it was preposterous for Jerome M. Hauer to deny responsibility for the recommendation to place the city’s emergency operations center in 7 World Trade Center, which was destroyed on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: How Bush Stayed True to Conservatism
text: For years now, Sen. Chuck Hagel, a Nebraska Republican, has been generating admiring news stories by publicly distancing himself from the Bush administration. Sunday morning he did it again by inching still further away from the hapless president.

headline: Giuliani and the Bunker, Re-examined
text: Before Rudolph W. Giuliani became a national symbol of the fight against terrorism, he had his own expert overseeing the New York City’s emergency preparedness, including readiness for terrorist threats. Now that former city official, Jerome M. Hauer, is in a heated battle with the Giuliani campaign over whether the Mayor – or Mr. Hauer – was responsible for the decision to place the city’s emergency command center near the World Trade Center towers before 9/11.

headline: Good News From Bordeaux
text: Relatively quietly, reports on the 2006 Bordeaux vintage have filtered in and the reviews, while somewhat mixed, are pretty good. Last year, if you recall, the limits of hype were tested daily as wine pundits competed to see who could froth at the mouth most excessively in praise of the 2005’s.

headline: Falwell’s 2008 Shadow
text: Back in 2000, when he was trying to appeal to moderates, Senator John McCain positioned himself against the religious right. His chief targets were Jerry Falwell and Pat Robertson, whom he described as “agents of intolerance.”

headline: Murdoch and the Wall Street Journal
text: In the debate over Rupert Murdoch’s bid for The Wall Street Journal, one obvious question is how a Murdoch purchase would affect the Journal’s excellent coverage of China. Seven Journal reporters in China just weighed in on this, telling the Bancroft family: Don’t sell!

headline: Planet Us: Born Again Green
text: Ray Anderson is a carpet-tile maker on a quest to reduce his global footprint.

headline: BlogTalk: Falwell’s Passing
text: The Rev. Jerry Falwell’s status as one of America’s most polarizing figures has been confirmed in the wake of his death by the speed and intensity of vitriol directed at him in the blogosphere, especially on the left. We’ve waded through most of that to find more thoughtful analyses of the Moral Majority leader’s legacy (as in, you’ll have to look elsewhere if you want the vitriol).

headline: Shrimp Deviled Eggs
text: Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The  Minimalist, prepares deviled eggs with a twist.

headline: American Ballet Theater Gala
text: Melena Ryzik of The Times reports on the American Ballet Theater's opening gala.

headline: When Auditors Get Too Close
text: It was not that long ago that auditing firms sometimes seemed to think they were part of the team — not independent gatekeepers truly representing the users of the financial statements they audited.

headline: Television Upfronts: ABC
text: The Times's Bill Carter reports from Lincoln Center in New York, where ABC presented its 2007 fall lineup.

headline: Live Blogging the G.O.P. Debate
text: The After-Party The candidates seemed to mix it up more in this debate than in the previous one in California. They were certainly more willing to challenge each other, while some candidates seemed to vanish from the conversation. The willingness of the candidates to criticize each other and of the debate moderators to give more airtime to the top tier could presage some dropping out in the near future. Or they could be a prelude to even sharper disputes in the debates ahead.

headline: The Mystery Poet Revealed
text: Some astute detectives have solved our poetic mystery. (You can try it yourself here, but don’t read any further here unless you want to know the answer.)

headline: Your Ideas for China Columns
text: I’m leaving at the crack of dawn for a two-week trip to China, from south to north (taking two of my kids, age 13 and 9, heaven help me!).

headline: Rain Delay Theatre in Chicago
text: So I’m waiting out a rain delay here in Chicago, finishing up a meal in the press dining room, when I head for the elevator and bump into… George Steinbrenner’s daughter, Jenny Swindal. She was quite pleasant, as she’s always been the times I have seen her. Apparently it’s just a social visit with some friends. No sign of her soon-to-be ex-husband, Steve Swindal, who remains a general partner but has lost his power within the organization. She still calls herself Swindal, by the way.

headline: Television Upfronts: ABC
text: The Times's Bill Carter reports from Lincoln Center in New York, where ABC presented its 2007 fall lineup.

headline: U.S. Championship, Day 1: No Real Surprises
text: Form held almost perfectly in the first round of the championship, which is taking place in Stillwater, Okla. Although a few lower ranked players held their opponents to draws, there were no major upsets as happened last year when Hikaru Nakamura, the 2005 champion, lost in the first round to Joshua Friedel. Nakamura got a measure of revenge this year by beating Friedel in the first round in a titanic struggle. The games can be seen live or be replayed here  at Monroi.com.

headline: The Mets See How Effective a Zambrano Can Really Be
text: So, this must have been what the Mets envisioned when they pictured a No. 38-wearing right-handed pitcher from Venezuela with the surname Zambrano mowing down hitters from the Shea Stadium mound.

headline: Thousands Flee New Jersey Wildfire Ignited by Flare From F-16
text: A flare dropped by an F-16 fighter jet at a bombing range in southern New Jersey ignited a wildfire yesterday that burned thousands of acres of brush and pine forest, closed highways, forced thousands of residents to flee and damaged some homes, state officials said.

headline: Doubts Arise on How a Cricket Coach Died
text: PROVIDENCIALES, Turks and Caicos, May 15  Was it enraged gamblers who strangled the coach? Or vindictive players? Or a fan with a grudge?

text: Time: 30 minutes

headline: Falwell’s Legacy in the Pulpit and Politics
text: At his death yesterday, the Rev. Jerry Falwell, the founding father and long the public face of the religious right, left behind a university, a megachurch and a movement that are likely to carry on his legacy.

headline: End of the Affair
text: It is tempting to look at the dissolution of the ill-starred union of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler and chalk it up to an irreconcilable clash of cultures and question the very tenability of trans-Atlantic mergers. But that would be the wrong lesson.

headline: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
text: Hedge funds have been very good to institutions like Yale. On its 2005 tax forms, the university reported annual income of $149 million from its hedge fund investments.

headline: Hamas Attacks Against Fatah Kill 14 and Add to Gaza Chaos
text: NAHAL OZ, Israel, May 15 — Members of the military wing of Hamas attacked Palestinian Authority security forces loyal to Hamas’s rival, Fatah, on Tuesday, killing nine, according to Fatah officials.

headline: Hocus-Pocus, and a Beaker of Truffles
text: A TRUFFLE by any other name may smell as sweet, but what if that name is 2,4-dithiapentane? All across the country, in restaurants great and small, the “truffle” flavor advertised on menus is increasingly being supplied by truffle oil. What those menus don’t say is that, unlike real truffles, the aroma of truffle oil is not born in the earth. Most commercial truffle oils are concocted by mixing olive oil with one or more compounds like 2,4-dithiapentane (the most prominent of the hundreds of aromatic molecules that make the flavor of white truffles so exciting) that have been created in a laboratory; their one-dimensional flavor is also changing common understanding of how a truffle should taste.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,387 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Strong Winds May Spread New Jersey Wildfire
text: A wildfire sparked by a flare that an F-16 jet dropped over southern New Jersey on Tuesday afternoon continued to burn through thousands of acres of brush and pine forest today, fueled by strong gusts of wind that fire officials worried might pick up throughout the day.

headline: Adoptions From Guatemala Face an Uncertain Future
text: After successfully adopting a child from Guatemala two years ago, Mary Vertin and Mark Huepfel are trying to adopt another from the country. This time around, though, the process has been fraught with uncertainty.

headline: Recipe: Asparagus Frittata
text: Adapted from Lidia Bastianich

headline: After Rice and Putin Meet, Russia Agrees to Soften Language
text: MOSCOW, May 15  Russia agreed Tuesday to tone down the harsh language its senior officials have used against the United States in recent months, but the two countries remained at an impasse on several issues that have strained relations.

headline: Greenspan Finds a Client in Bond Management Firm
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman whose pronouncements continue to jolt world markets, has signed a consulting deal with Pimco, the giant bond management firm.

headline: Manhattan: Judgment Against Police Is Overturned
text: A state appeals court has dismissed a civil judgment against the Police Department that stemmed from a 1992 altercation between police officers and demonstrators in Orchard Beach, in the Bronx. The original verdict, in which a jury awarded $81 million to seven plaintiffs, was reduced by the trial judge in 2004 to $635,000, city officials said. In a ruling released yesterday, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court found that videotapes of the confrontation did not support the contention that the police had acted improperly. After reviewing the tapes, the judges said that the police were justified in their belief that the protest could escalate and that officers “appropriately tried to quell a quickly unfolding, potentially explosive situation.” Mark Kressner, the plaintiffs’ lawyer, said they would appeal on the grounds that the trial jury made the correct decision after carefully reviewing the evidence. “The jury had the opportunity to see those tapes over a three-week period in slow motion, with explanation of what occurred off camera,” he said.

headline: Mets Expect Hernández Back Soon
text: Ever so slowly, Orlando Hernández is nearing a return to the Mets. He threw about 60 pitches yesterday in a simulated game at Port St. Lucie, Fla., and he is on track to pitch one more before rejoining the team in Miami next weekend, when the Mets play the Florida Marlins.

headline: Suspensions Have Suns Crying Foul
text: SAN ANTONIO, May 15 — With one hip check and a forearm shiver, San Antonio’s Robert Horry did more than send Steve Nash of Phoenix crashing to the floor. He altered the tenor of the rest of the Western Conference semifinals.

headline: Art Dealers Scramble for Space in Chelsea
text: The contemporary art auctions at Sotheby’s and Christie’s this month are among New York’s colorful rites of spring. Art dealers say they expect the spring sales to be especially bountiful this year, thanks in no small part to the record bonuses on Wall Street in December.

headline: An Amputee Olympian? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Earnhardt and Team Penalized for Changes
text: Nascar officials yesterday issued severe penalties to Dale Earnhardt Jr., his race team and his crew chief after his car failed an inspection before a Nextel Cup race last weekend.

headline: In Istria, Fresh From the Land and the Sea
text: PULA, Croatia

headline: Will There Be an ‘Obama Effect?’
text: In high-profile contests where one of the major party candidates is black, pre-election telephone polls have often been wrong, overstating the strength of the black candidate. In polling circles this is known as the “Bradley effect” or the “Wilder effect” or the “Dinkins effect.” Will it also be known as the Obama effect?

headline: MySpace Gives Details of Its Plan to Reveal Known Sex Offenders
text: MySpace, an online social network popular with teenagers, said in two statements yesterday that it was prepared to work with state attorneys general who have requested the identities of MySpace members who are known sex offenders.

headline: Robert S. Oelman, 97, Chief Who Led NCR to Automation, Dies
text: Robert S. Oelman, who was chief executive of the NCR Corporation for 17 years and moved in the circles of leaders of business, politics and golf, died in Delray Beach, Fla., last Thursday. He was 97.

headline: At Mayors’ Summit, Bloomberg Campaigns for Clean Air
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg thrust himself onto an international stage yesterday as a champion of the environment, telling a roomful of leaders from this country and overseas that the solution to global warming lay with the world’s mayors.

headline: Terror Attack Scenario Exposes Deep Differences Among G.O.P. Hopefuls
text: The scenario presented to the 10 Republican presidential candidates was chilling: Three American shopping malls had been bombed, producing scores of casualties. Terrorists with detailed Fknowledge of another imminent and deadlier attack had been captured and taken to Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Breaking Our Addiction to Oil (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Now Departing: Airline Careers
text: OCEANSIDE, N.Y. — Workers at many airlines have been forced to take huge pay cuts in recent years, and they have watched 100,000 or so of their colleagues lose their jobs.

headline: A Timeless Tale of True Love in Digital Video
text: Watching the director Jay Stern’s microbudget digital video adaptation of the 1622 play “The Changeling” is much like watching a straightforward theatrical production of any play hailing from any century: you have to imagine a more detailed world beyond the bare-bones visuals.

headline: Lebanon: U.S. to Introduce Resolution for U.N. Tribunal
text: Zalmay Khalilzad, the American ambassador to the United Nations, said a resolution would be introduced this week calling on the Security Council to create a tribunal to judge the killers of Rafik Hariri, the former prime minister who was assassinated in a Beirut car bombing in 2005. The action was in response to a request from Fouad Siniora, the current prime minister, whose government is locked in a struggle with pro-Syrian forces that are against an international court. A United Nations investigation has linked the assassination to the Syrian security services. Saying he endorsed the decision to act now, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said, “I am of the view that there should be no impunity for the perpetrators of political assassinations.”

headline: Citing Waste, Albany Seeks to Rein in Public Authorities
text: For almost a century, public authorities have been the universal solvent of New York politics, burning through legislative or bureaucratic gridlock to build ambitious public works projects, from subways to hospitals to public housing.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about a speech by Rudolph W. Giuliani in Houston misstated the name of the academic institution where the speech took place. It is Houston Baptist University — not Houston Baptist College, which changed its name in 1973.

headline: A Purple Passion for Pinot Noir
text: SINCE the movie “Sideways” came out in 2004, America has carried on a passionate affair with pinot noir. Restaurants can’t keep it in stock, wineries can’t make enough of it and consumers show no signs of loosening their embrace of it.

headline: Documents From Vast Nazi Archive to Be Made Available to Scholars
text: BERLIN, May 15 — Electronic copies of documents from a closely guarded Nazi archive will start flowing to several countries for the first time since World War II, following an agreement announced Tuesday by the 11 countries that govern the archive in central Germany.

headline: In Normandy, Buying and Restoring
text: It seemed like déjà vu all over again when John Rossant and his Italian wife, Antonella Caruso, stumbled on the 18th-century Château de Livry in Normandy.

headline: Iraq Attacks Stayed Steady Despite Troop Increase, Data Show
text: Newly declassified data show that as additional American troops began streaming into Iraq in March and April, the number of attacks on civilians and security forces there stayed relatively steady or at most declined slightly, in the clearest indication yet that the troop increase could take months to have a widespread impact on security.

headline: Cavalier Seeks Players’ Support for Darfur
text: CLEVELAND, May 15  Ira Newble was not politically active until he read about Eric Reeves. Reeves was not a fan of professional basketball until he received a flurry of e-mail messages from Newble.

headline: Terror Suspect Testifies of Torture in Custody
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — A former Baltimore resident, who was transferred last fall from secret C.I.A. custody to detention in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, denied to a military hearing that he was an extremist and asserted that he had been tortured while in government custody, according to a transcript the Pentagon released Tuesday.

headline: Settlements Under Student Loan Inquiry
text: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, has reached agreements with two more universities under which they will adopt a code of conduct governing relations they may have with student loan companies. Mr. Cuomo’s office found that Drexel University, in Philadelphia, was due to receive more than $250,000 from a loan company. That money will now be distributed to students who borrowed from that lender, according to Mr. Cuomo’s office. The investigation also found that Timothy Lehmann, the director of financial aid at Capella University, an online institution based in Minneapolis, received more than $12,000 as a consultant to one lender. Twenty-four colleges and universities have adopted Mr. Cuomo’s code of conduct.

headline: Agency Might Replace Bridge and Tunnel Tollbooths With Cashless System
text: The backup at the tunnel — a phrase as familiar to New York and New Jersey drivers as rubbernecking delays — will never go away. But it may be used less frequently if the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has its way.

headline: Nigerian Oil Production Falls After a Pipeline Hub Is Overrun
text: NDJAMENA, Chad, May 15  Young protesters have overrun an oil pipeline hub in the volatile Niger Delta, the authorities said, helping to cut Nigeria’s oil production by about 30 percent as the country weathers a period of instability after a deeply flawed election last month.

text: To the Editor:

headline: XM Radio Takes Two Hosts Off the Air for 30 Days
text: XM Radio, the satellite provider, announced yesterday that it had imposed 30-day suspensions on the hosts known as Opie and Anthony after the pair participated in an on-air discussion last Wednesday that imagined sexual assaults on Condoleezza Rice and Laura Bush.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE PRICE IS RIGHT MILLION DOLLAR SPECTACULAR Come on down! After 50 years in television and 35 years as host of “The Price Is Right,” Bob Barker, left, who is leaving the show next month, makes his final prime-time appearance in this special episode in which contestants can spin the wheel for $1 million. Tomorrow night at 8, Mr. Barker will reminisce about all those squeals, hugs and grateful kisses in “Bob Barker: A Celebration of 50 Years on Television.”

text: To the Editor:

headline: Pakistan Suicide Blast Kills 22 Near Afghan Border
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, May 15  A suicide bomber struck a restaurant in the congested part of the old city here around lunchtime on Tuesday, killing 22 people and wounding 30, the police and hospital officials said. Two women and a child were among the dead.

headline: The ‘Capital’ of the World
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: At a Film Festival, France Is Again Center of the World
text: CANNES, France, May 15 — Standing in the lobby of the Hôtel Splendid, just a few blocks from the center of the Cannes Film Festival, Pierre Rissient, a kind of cinematic ambassador without portfolio and something of a local institution, paused to critique the festival’s official souvenir bag.

headline: Sony Expects Recovery After Big Losses
text: TOKYO, May 16 — Sony posted its worst quarterly loss in four years today, but said strong television sales and hit movies like “Spider-Man 3” will put it back on course to recovery this year, when it expects a record profit.

headline: Thomas Curry, 74, Officer Hit in Infamous Shooting, Dies
text: Thomas Curry, one of two New York City police officers who were seriously wounded by machine-gun fire in 1971 while guarding the Manhattan district attorney’s home, died on Monday in the Bronx. He was 74.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Books of The Times review yesterday, about “The Pesthouse,” by Jim Crace, misstated the name of one character at several points. As noted elsewhere in the review, he is Franklin, not Francis. The review also misspelled the surname of a writer who was described in the review as part of “the crowning trio of living British writers,” along with Mr. Crace and Barry Unsworth. He is Ian McEwan, not McEwen.

headline: Rothko Breaks a Record for Contemporary Art
text: The Rockefeller name worked its magic last night at Sotheby’s sale of contemporary art, where a mysterious bearded collector in a skybox outbid five other contenders for Rothko’s “White Center (Yellow, Pink and Lavender on Rose).” The $72.8 million he paid, far above the painting’s $40 million estimate, set records for both the artist and for any contemporary work at auction.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A listing of credits last Wednesday with a film review of “Day Night Day Night” included incorrect information from the film’s distributor about several people who worked on the movie, and a correction in this space on Monday misstated the given name of one of the film’s editors and misspelled her surname at one point. She is Julia Loktev, not Julie Lotkev. (Others working on the movie: Benoit Debie was the sole director of photography; he was not joined by Michael Taylor, who was an editor along with Ms. Loktev. Leslie Shatz was the sound designer, not an editor. And the production designer was Kelly McGehee — not Rabiah Troncelliti, who was the costume designer.)

headline: Unity Fractures as Palestinians Battle in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, May 16 — Gaza City was shuttered on Wednesday as gunmen took over rooftops and top-floor apartments. Most everyone else huddled fearfully indoors on the fourth day of factional Palestinian fighting that is drawing in the Israeli military.

headline: 11 Tony Nods for ‘Spring Awakening’
text: In a season rich with contenders, “Spring Awakening,” a dark rock musical based on a 19th-century German play about sexually anguished teenagers, led the field yesterday with 11 Tony nominations, including chances at best musical and director and recognition for two actors.

headline: Brooklyn: Cobble Hill Firehouse Will Not Be Sold
text: The city has agreed not to sell a vacant firehouse in Brooklyn, ending a four-year battle between the Bloomberg administration and community activists and local leaders. Engine Company 204 on Degraw Street in Cobble Hill was one of five units closed or relocated during budget cuts in 2003, leaving their firehouses empty. The changes set off emotional debates over the future of the buildings, whose communities prized their distinctive structures and histories. Yesterday, Councilmen Bill de Blasio and David Yassky, both of Brooklyn, and the borough president, Marty Markowitz, announced that the city had agreed to put the Degraw Street building up for lease for a community use to be determined. The City Council’s land use subcommittee approved the deal and the potential sale of three of the other firehouses, with a provision that the buildings be used to benefit their communities. The fifth closed firehouse, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, has been approved for sale to the Henry Street Settlement for moderate-income housing.

headline: Letters
text: Kosher, Not Kool-Aid

headline: Bush Nominee to Get Payment From Old Job
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — A senior lobbyist at the National Association of Manufacturers nominated by President Bush to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission will receive a $150,000 departing payment from the association when he takes his new government job, which involves enforcing consumer laws against members of the association.

headline: Reality Overtakes the Illusion of Unity in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, May 15 — A third day of deadly clashes between Hamas and Fatah fighters suggests that the Palestinian unity government, put together under Saudi auspices at the end of March, is something of a fiction.

headline: Auto Union Leader Finds Comfort Level
text: DETROIT, May 15 — Ron Gettelfinger, president of the United Automobile Workers union, is a man of few words, so it is never easy to be sure what he is thinking.

headline: Loving, Fighting, Sulking, Dancing, Betraying
text: PARIS

headline: Pace U. Leader, Beleaguered, Will Step Down
text: Pace University’s embattled president, David A. Caputo, is stepping down on June 3.

headline: Time for Iced Tea and Summer Internships
text: THIS is the month when businesses compete for the best summer workers, from a pool of students and older people.

headline: Massachusetts: Labor Law Violations Claimed in Suit
text: A federal lawsuit was filed claiming violations of wage and overtime laws at a New Bedford leather company where an immigration raid took place in March. The suit asserts that workers were denied overtime pay and wages for unpaid time spent in the factory. The suit, filed by Greater Boston Legal Services, also asserts that employees who worked a shift for Michael Bianco clocked out for 15 minutes and then returned for a second shift working the same job, but for Front Line Defense, a company the suit says is headed by the wife and daughter of Michael Bianco’s owner, Francesco Insolia. Mr. Insolia and his family could not be reached for comment.

headline: Britain’s Prince Harry Will Not Be Heading to Iraq
text: LONDON, May 16 — He had been cast as the warrior prince, the royal who, like a Shakespearean namesake, would lead his troops “unto the breach” of southern Iraq.

headline: From Africa to Queens Waterfront, a Modernist Gem for Sale to the Highest Bidder
text: For anyone still looking for a house for the summer, something very exclusive is about to come up in Queens.

headline: Some New Friends for the Humble Egg
text: IF you grew up eating deviled eggs, they are probably a favorite comfort food, something you don’t think too hard about.

headline: Reuters Trustees Say Sale Won’t Hurt Journalism
text: LONDON, May 15 — The trustees charged with overseeing the integrity and independence of the Reuters Group endorsed the sale of the company to the Thomson Corporation of Canada on Tuesday, but the speed with which they acquiesced has upset some employees, who fear that the merger could undermine the quality of Reuters’s journalism.

headline: Correction: New York Makes a Strong Showing at the James Beard Awards
text: An article last Wednesday about the James Beard Foundation awards misstated the status of the Manhattan restaurant Xing, which won an award for best restaurant design. It is open, at 785 Ninth Avenue (52nd Street); (646) 289-3010. It has not closed.

headline: Senators Report Progress on a Complicated Bill on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — With the new Congress poised to take its first vote on immigration, senators from both parties stepped up the pace of negotiations on Tuesday in hopes of cutting a deal on a comprehensive bill that would increase enforcement at the border and offer legal status to millions of undocumented workers.

headline: Recipe: Pasta With Chicken Sauce
text: Adapted from Restaurant Gina

headline: Sometimes in War, You Can Put a Price on Life
text: Washington

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times yesterday about the construction of particle detectors under parts of France and Switzerland misstated the weights of the Atlas detector and the Eiffel Tower. Each one weighs about 7,000 tons, not pounds.

headline: A Band Struts Again, Under an M.B.A. Baton
text: AT 6-foot-7 and shod in size 16 two-tone cowboy boots, it’s hard to picture anything halfway about Ray Benson, the guitarist and leader of the western swing band Asleep at the Wheel. But Mr. Benson admits that for all his success as a musician — nine Grammys’ worth — he wasn’t the all-around businessman he aimed to be.

headline: Canada:  Iamgold’s Profit Falls as Costs Rise
text: The Iamgold Corporation, a Canadian gold producer, said first-quarter net income fell 43 percent on losses from derivatives and higher mining costs. Profit declined to $11.3 million from $19.9 million a year ago, Iamgold said. Profit per share fell to 4 cents, from 13 cents, as Iamgold issued shares to pay for its acquisition last November of its rival Cambior for $1.1 billion. Sales more than tripled, to $146.4 million. Iamgold’s cash cost of producing an ounce of gold rose 54 percent, to $416, from a year ago on higher labor and fuel costs.

headline: Tyco to Pay $3 Billion to Settle Investor Lawsuits
text: Tyco International, whose two top executives were imprisoned for fraud, has agreed to pay almost $3 billion to settle class-action lawsuits brought by investors, the company announced yesterday.

headline: Poppy Fields Are Now a Front Line in Afghan War
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a walled compound outside Kabul, two members of Colombia’s counternarcotics police force are trying to teach raw Afghan recruits how to wage close-quarters combat.

headline: We Try Harder (but What’s the Point?)
text: Seattle

headline: Culinary Institute Receives $35 Million
text: PACE picante sauce, one of the first salsas sold commercially, made Christopher Goldsbury a billionaire. Now the salsa fortune will pay for a push to deepen the United States’ relationship with food from Latin America, and help restaurant workers move ahead in the kitchen.

headline: Bush Picks General to Coordinate War Policy
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — The White House said Tuesday that President Bush ended his lengthy search for a so-called war czar to carry out Iraq and Afghanistan policy by offering the job to an active duty three-star Army general who said in his interview that he had been skeptical of the troop buildup in Iraq.

headline: Jerry Falwell, Moral Majority Founder, Dies at 73
text: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, the fundamentalist preacher who founded the Moral Majority and brought the language and passions of religious conservatives into the hurly-burly of American politics, died yesterday in Lynchburg, Va. He was 73.

headline: Among the Rich, a New Dispute Over Air Rights
text: It’s not the war against third world debt, but still.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports graphic yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about Oscar Pistorius, a South African athlete who wants to be the first amputee runner to compete in the Olympics, carried incorrect renderings in some copies of the “take-off” phase of running. A corrected version can be found online.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Donna Murphy Healing

headline: Clemens Readies Arm While Others Pick His Brain
text: TAMPA, Fla., May 15 — The young pitchers gathered around the mound like ducklings to see and hear Roger Clemens, who obliged them with a tutorial that took more time than he planned.

headline: New Motorola Phones Aim at High-End Market
text: Motorola, the mobile phone giant, is hoping to revive its business prospects with some slick new phones and a little celebrity gloss.

headline: Proxy Fights More Muted, for Most Part
text: Fireworks have so far been rare at annual shareholder meetings this year. With stock indexes near their record highs, investor anger, not surprisingly, has been muted.

headline: Web Site May Be Liable for Some User Postings
text: A Web site that matches roommates may be liable for what its users say about their preferences, a fractured three-judge panel of the federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled yesterday.

headline: Death-Squad Scandal Circles Closer to Colombia’s President
text: CALI, Colombia, May 15 — President Álvaro Uribe, the Bush administration’s closest ally in Latin America, faces an intensifying scandal after a jailed former commander of paramilitary death squads testified Tuesday that Mr. Uribe’s defense minister had tried to plot with the outlawed private militias to upset the rule of a former president.

headline: U.N. Emissions Program (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Soccer: Right Coach Is Right Here
text: With national soccer coaches, the job is always interim. Coaches can win the World Cup and still turn back the job, weary of the entire country camping on their doorstep, critiquing their choice of midfielders.

headline: Shares of Anemia Drug Makers Slide as Medicare Threatens to Cut Reimbursement
text: Amgen shares were battered again yesterday after Medicare proposed to sharply curtail reimbursement for the company’s biggest selling product, the anemia drug Aranesp.

headline: Soviet Architects and Their Edifice Complex
text: The nonprofit Storefront for Art and Architecture has been around for a quarter-century now. A tiny wedge-shaped space on a noisy street at the edge of Chinatown, it built its reputation on managing to work its many limitations to its advantage. Its best shows, typically thrown together on a shoestring budget, had a raw immediacy that the bigger art institutions can rarely match.

headline: Inflation Tame Despite Rising Gas Cost
text: The slowing economy helped tone down inflation last month, even as rising energy prices threatened to send it higher.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about the resignation of Paul J. McNulty, the deputy United States attorney general, misstated the given name of another Justice Department official, the former director of the executive office for United States attorneys, who left his job over the department’s handling of the firings of several federal prosecutors. He is Michael A. Battle, not William.

headline: Handling House Calls in a Managed-Care World
text: THE day when doctors treated patients at home disappeared decades ago in most of America as house calls gave way to more cost-effective office visits. But a small company that devised a way to charge for doctors’ house calls could encourage a return to the practice — not just as a service for the rich, but as the most economical way for Medicare and private insurers to care for their frailest patients.

headline: A School Frees Low-Income Boys From the Pressures of the Streets
text: Where are the boys?

headline: Bush Opens Door to Wolfowitz’s Resigning
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — The Bush administration, shifting strategy in the face of mounting opposition to Paul D. Wolfowitz, opened the door Tuesday to his resigning voluntarily as World Bank president if the bank board dropped its drive to declare him unfit to remain in office.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The About New York column on Saturday, about the relationship between the New York Yankees and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, misspelled the surname of a Yankees spokeswoman in some copies. She is Alice McGillion, not McGillon.

headline: A Little Company May Help Some Big Ones Grow Bigger
text: AESOP’S mouse, who chewed away the ropes binding a lion to set him free, proved that powerful beasts sometimes benefit from having small friends. Cambridge Heart, a tiny maker of heart stress test equipment, may be living out a similar story.

headline: France: Vivendi Profit Increases 32
text: Vivendi said its first-quarter profit rose 32 percent, spurred by demand for its World of Warcraft video game and subscriber growth at the pay-television unit. Net income rose to 932 million euros ($1.27 billion) from 707 million euros ($957.5 million) a year earlier, Vivendi said. First-quarter sales rose 5.3 percent, to 5.02 billion euros ($6.8 billion) from 4.77 billion euros ($6.47 billion) a year earlier. Profit at Vivendi Games surged to 107 million euros ($145 million) from 23 million euros ($31.1 million) a year earlier. The unit sold almost 2.4 million copies of the expansion pack to World of Warcraft the first day it went on sale in January. Profit at the pay-television unit Canal Plus jumped fivefold, to 164 million euros ($222.1 million). Profit at the mobile phone unit SFR, Vivendi’s largest business, slipped 3.5 percent, to 643 million euros ($871 million). Profit was down at the Universal Music Group, hurt by falling CD sales.

headline: After Rainout, Yankees Need Another Starter
text: CHICAGO, May 15 — The Yankees, who have already used 10 starting pitchers, are searching for a starter again. A rainout here Tuesday night leaves an open spot in the rotation for Sunday night’s game against the Mets.

headline: Cust Finally Gets a Chance to Show He Hits for Power
text: OAKLAND, Calif., May 15  (AP) — Jack Cust had the reputation of a power hitter for almost a decade, impressing scouts with his ability to wait for his pitch and drive it over the fence with ease.

headline: Of Spring and Fair Harbors
text: Everyone has a ritual to shake off winter, a gesture to prove to ourselves that the bleak days of biting wind are over for now. For some, it’s baseball practice, or buying bathing suits. Others just itch to turn over the warm earth and rake off the detritus of leaves and branches from already-forgotten February storms. Yardwork that seems like a chore in autumn has a liberating feel, a necessary rite to welcome the warmer months.

headline: Workshop ‘Hamlet’: Free, Indoors, Uncut (He’s Still Angry)
text: It seems to take a gimmick to stage Shakespeare these days. For the last 15 years Gorilla Rep’s has been to offer free outdoor productions around New York City: “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” in Washington Square Park; “Macbeth” in Fort Tryon Park. The company’s next project is an outdoor “Hamlet,” scheduled for 2008, and it is now holding indoor workshops of it at the Times Square Arts Center.

headline: Afghanistan: Afghan Soldiers Die in Ambush
text: A joint Afghan and American patrol was ambushed in eastern Nuristan, the most remote province, leaving seven Afghan soldiers dead, four missing, and five American and three Afghan soldiers wounded, NATO said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Personal Health column in Science Times yesterday, about the vaccine for human papillomavirus, misstated a condition caused by two variants of the virus. They cause 90 percent of cases of genital warts, not genital herpes.

headline: It’s Not Just Honey
text: ONE Friday last month, thousands of New York City commuters on their way home from work stopped to sample fruity-smelling hand lotions and macadamia body butter inside a big yellow tent next to Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Couple Held Two Servants Captive for Years, U.S. Says
text: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y., May 15  Federal prosecutors charged a wealthy Long Island couple on Tuesday with keeping two Indonesian domestic workers as virtual prisoners in their home for more than five years under conditions they called “modern-day slavery,” beating one severely and paying them very little.

headline: From Maine, Small Business Stories to Inspire
text: STATISTICS can suggest trends, but they can’t tell stories. They cannot, for instance, describe Carolann Ouellette’s mashed-potato issue. They cannot convey the odd pleasure that Jane Barron felt when she realized someone was probably stealing her work. They cannot follow the unlikely trail that Lisa Burns and Karen King blazed when they bought a tractor.

headline: Germany: Concrete Maker Buys a Supplier
text: HeidelbergCement, a German concrete maker, has agreed to buy Hanson, a British supplier of building materials, for £7.85 billion ($16 billion). HeidelbergCement will pay £11 ($21.80) a share for Hanson, a premium of 29 percent over Hanson’s share price on May 2 when HeidelbergCement first said it might bid. With the purchase, HeidelbergCement will increase its revenue by two-thirds, expanding in the United States and bolstering output of aggregates, pipes and bricks. “The companies are a perfect fit and overlaps are minimal,” HeidelbergCement’s chief executive, Bernd Scheifele, above, said in a conference call with analysts. “Hanson strengthens our operations in the U.S., U.K. and Europe and adds a business in Australia.” Hanson has 26,000 workers in 14 nations and derives half its sales from North America.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A map of Central Asia yesterday with the Jibek Joly Journal article, about the large number of Uzbek migrants who pass through the Kazakhstan border town of Jibek Joly to seek work, misidentified the country in the lower left corner, bordering Afghanistan and Turkmenistan. It is Iran, not Iraq.

headline: C.I.A. Officer Testifies He Was Given Qaeda ‘Pledge Form’ Said to Be Padilla’s
text: MIAMI, May 15  A covert officer in the Central Intelligence Agency, apparently using a false name and partial disguise, told the jury in the trial of Jose Padilla on Tuesday how the government acquired a document in Afghanistan that it later identified as Mr. Padilla’s application to train at a camp run by Al Qaeda.

headline: Gliding Through the Classics With a Sample of What’s Ahead
text: I come from centuries-old agricultural stock. Why do I mention this when starting to review the Monday night gala that opened American Ballet Theater’s spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House? I once groaned, “I’ve got to go to a gala,” to my brother, who had then been specializing in pigs for 15 years. He replied, “You said that in just the same tone as I use when I say, ‘I’ve got to clear the pig slurry.’ ”

headline: Your Ad Goes Here
text: THE Internet search engine is an indispensable tool of modern life and an advertising gold mine for Google, the favorite first stop on the Web.

headline: Hedge Fund Proposal
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 (Dow Jones)  Hedge fund advisers would be required to register with the Securities and Exchange Commission under a bill intended to give regulators new tools to oversee the fast-growing industry.

headline: Giving Morels the Caviar Treatment
text: AS anyone with a hard-core shopping habit knows, there’s a moment after you’ve zeroed in on your object of desire when all reason ebbs. It doesn’t matter that those strappy sandals are a little too tight, a little too high-heeled and a lot too expensive. A euphoric cloud obscures common sense, especially if they’re on sale.

headline: Sometimes, What’s Needed Is a Nudge
text: I was walking through the intensive care unit of a San Francisco hospital earlier this year when I noticed a jarring sight. Most of the patients in the unit were sitting up in their beds. Some of them were gravely ill, drifting in and out of consciousness, but their mechanical beds were still propped up, much as the bed of an alert patient receiving visitors might be.

headline: Bush Intervened in Dispute Over N.S.A. Eavesdropping
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — President Bush intervened in March 2004 to avert a crisis over the National Security Agency’s domestic eavesdropping program after Attorney General John Ashcroft, Director Robert S. Mueller III of the F.B.I. and other senior Justice Department aides all threatened to resign, a former deputy attorney general testified Tuesday.

headline: Bringing Lobbyists to Heel
text: It’s crunch time for House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to deliver on the Democrats’ vow to rein in power lobbyists who sully Congress by purchasing privileged access with outsized campaign donations. There are worthy remedies, but members are balking. If the House resorts to mere cosmetic changes, the Democrats will risk the same voters’ ire that cost the Republicans control last year.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Off the Menu
text: Looking Ahead

headline: Germany: Big Expansion for Nursery Schools
text: The government agreed on a $16 billion plan that will triple the number of day care centers for children under age 3 to 750,000 by 2013. Germany now lags behind its neighbors in providing day care, with just 13.5 percent of toddlers under 3 in nursery schools, compared with the European average of 35 percent.

headline: A Swedish Band With a Yen for the Olden, Golden Days
text: Between Mando Diao’s set and its encore at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night, the band members went backstage, shook up their beer bottles and returned to spray them across the stage and their closest fans. That was the kind of old-school boisterousness they also showed in their songs, which embrace 1960s garage-rock as if it might grow up to be punk.

headline: Vornado Goes Both East and West for a Deal
text: Steven Roth’s hopes of establishing a beachhead on the West Coast were dashed earlier this year when he lost the high-stakes contest to acquire Equity Office Properties and its nationwide portfolio of prime office buildings to the Blackstone Group, a private equity firm.

headline: Who’s Watching What We Eat?
text: ELIZABETH ARMSTRONG did not give the Food and Drug Administration much thought until her children became ill from eating contaminated bagged spinach.

headline: Gauging Viewer Tastes: A New Dose of Escapism
text: ABC is joining the other broadcast networks in lightening up for the 2007-8 season.

headline: London May Be Baby Step for N.F.L.
text: Steve Tisch, one of the Giants’ owners, said the team’s October game against the Miami Dolphins in London  the first N.F.L. regular-season game to be played outside North America  would serve as a litmus test for the league’s plan for more international games.

headline: Judge Lifts Seal on Secret Police Convention Files
text: A federal judge today lifted a stay that paved the way for the release of about 600 pages of secret documents relating to police preparations for the 2004 Republican National Convention, held in New York.

headline: The Unkept Promise on Voting
text: Congress has done a terrible job of regulating electronic voting: It allowed A.T.M.-style voting machines to proliferate without requiring them to produce a paper trail that can be audited to ensure that the results are accurate. That has meant wasted time and money for the states, confusion for voters, and questionable election results. Fortunately, the nation’s delinquent lawmakers have a chance to set things right — through a bill introduced by Representative Rush Holt, Democrat of New Jersey, that would finally impose a paper trail requirement. There are some details that need fine-tuning, but Congress should move quickly to pass it.

headline: Wolfowitz Said to Be Working on Deal for His Resignation
text: WASHINGTON, May 16 —After six weeks of fighting efforts to oust him as president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz began today to negotiate the terms of his possible resignation, in return for the bank dropping or softening the charge that he had engaged in misconduct, bank officials said.

headline: Oracle Uses Late Charge to Tie Series
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 15 (AP)  BMW Oracle Racing, the only entry from the United States in the Louis Vuitton Cup, rallied to defeat Luna Rossa of Italy on Tuesday to tie their best-of-nine semifinal series after two flights.

headline: How an ‘Invisible’ Man Was Seduced by His Visibility
text: In June 1933 Ralph Ellison, riding the rails like a hobo, traveled to the Tuskegee Institute in search of a new life. Left fatherless at 3, he gravitated toward authority figures in a position to help him, but at Tuskegee he received a cold reception from a man he idolized, a composer named W. L. Dawson, who kept him at arm’s length. He would later describe his trip to Tuskegee as a journey into the heart of darkness, adding, “My Kurtz was W. L. Dawson: the artist corrupted by his environment.”

headline: Greek Again, With Even More Passion
text: ONE of the real pleasures of dining in New York over the last few years has been keeping tabs on Michael Psilakis, whose path to success hasn’t been conventional and whose goal — a quest, really — isn’t ordinary. And one of the real pleasures of his newest restaurant, Anthos, is its affirmation of how far he’s come and how fast he’s done it.

headline: CBS Lineup to Offer Vampires and a Mystery With Singing Casino Workers
text: CBS will follow its stated goal of taking its prime-time schedule in unexpected directions with fall series hopefuls exploring unusual themes like vampires, swingers and even singing casino workers.

headline: The Men Are in Leotards, but Don’t Call It Dancing
text: ST. PAUL, May 14 — At the end of “The Baron,” a play about old-school professional wrestling currently running at the History Theater here, the eternal question that is as much a part of the sport as heels and bad accents is finally raised.

headline: Democrats Signal End to Impasse on War Spending
text: WASHINGTON, May 16 — Congressional Democratic leaders signaled today that they were ready to give ground to end an impasse with President Bush over war spending after the Senate soundly rejected a Democratic plan to block money for major combat operations in Iraq beginning next spring.

headline: Defense Links Sex Attack to Contempt for Firefighters
text: The heroism of firefighters on 9/11 has been etched into the memories of most New Yorkers. But not for Peter Braunstein, a defense psychologist testified at his trial yesterday.

headline: Study Finds College-Prep Courses in High School Leave Many Students Lagging
text: Only a quarter of high school students who take a full set of college-preparatory courses — four years of English and three each of mathematics, science and social studies — are well prepared for college, according to a study of last year’s high school graduates released yesterday by ACT, the Iowa testing organization.

headline: A Team Player, Once It’s Off the Vine
text: Pinot noir demands much of both vine grower and winemaker,” wrote Jancis Robinson in “The Oxford Companion to Wine.” But as challenging as the grape may be, once it is in the bottle, it often becomes the most forgiving of wines.

headline: Fatah Official’s Home Stormed in Gaza Clashes
text: JERUSALEM, May 16 — The combat in Gaza appeared to intensify today, with an Israeli air strike on what officials called a Hamas command center and a Hamas raid on the home of a senior Palestinian security official from the rival Fatah faction.

headline: Devil Rays 4, Rangers 3
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla., May 15 (AP)  The night was already a success for the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. Brendan Harris’s game-winning hit made the team’s debut at Disney World that much sweeter.

headline: Strong Tax Figures Improve Prospects for Corzine’s Budget
text: TRENTON, May 15  Legislative analysts reported on Tuesday that there had been unexpected growth in corporate income taxes over the past two months, buoying chances for passage of Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s proposed $33 billion budget.

headline: Analysis Finds Large Antarctic Area Has Melted
text: While much of the world has warmed in a pattern that scientists have linked with near certainty to human activities, the frigid interior of Antarctica has resisted the trend.

headline: In N.B.A., for Some Actions, There’s an Overreaction
text: With a man of David Stern’s worldliness — as a Johnny Appleseed on an odyssey to sprinkle the N.B.A. throughout the planet — it is remarkable how Global Dave just ignored climate change.

headline: Parents of Dan Snyder Forgive but Can’t Forget
text: ELMIRA, Ontario, May 10 — Dany Heatley was playing hockey about two hours down the road and across the border. One of the best players in the N.H.L., a top scorer in the playoffs, Heatley helped the visiting Ottawa Senators to a playoff victory over the Buffalo Sabres on Thursday. HSBC Arena was sold out, and millions across the continent saw the game on television.

headline: DNA in Murders Frees Inmate After 19 Years
text: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 15 — A man who served 19 years in prison for the sadistic murders of his companion’s two children walked out of the Union County Courthouse flanked by his family members after a judge vacated his convictions on Tuesday.

headline: Both Sides Claim Victory in Long Case of Failed Film
text: LOS ANGELES, May 15 — A knock-down, drag-out trial over the failed big-budget movie “Sahara” mercifully ended on Tuesday after three and a half months. But it had an unsatisfying Hollywood ending.

headline: Inflation and Wages Show Slower Growth
text: Businesses kept a lid on prices again last month, and wage gains were scant for most working Americans, signs consistent with an economy in the midst of a slowdown.

headline: Some Gay New Yorkers Gain in Ruling on Marriages
text: BOSTON, May 15  A little-noticed resolution to a case involving same-sex couples from New York will allow dozens of them to be considered legally married in Massachusetts, and apparently in their home state as well.

headline: Good Medicine, Under Attack (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Turkey: Erdogan Urges Sarkozy to Drop ‘Prejudices’
text: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said he hoped that Nicolas Sarkozy, who takes over as France’s president today, would drop his opposition to Turkey’s joining the European Union. Mr. Sarkozy, who argues that Turkey is culturally not a part of Europe and that most of its territory is in Asia, vehemently opposes Turkey’s membership. “This approach of Mr. Sarkozy comes from prejudices,” Mr. Erdogan said, addressing a media conference in Istanbul. “Mr. Sarkozy has to overcome these prejudices.” Mr. Erdogan’s remarks were the first to directly address the implications of Mr. Sarkozy’s election for Turkey. “Turkey’s E.U. membership is the peace project of the 21st century,” Mr. Erdogan said, “an alliance of East and West.”

headline: Recipe: Octopus and Potato Stew
text: Adapted from Martin Pescator

headline: $72.8 Million for a Rothko
text: Mark Rothko’s “White Center (Yellow, Pink and Lavender on Rose),” a dreamy abstract painting from 1950, sold for $72.8 million — more than three times the previous auction record for the artist — at Sotheby’s major spring auction of contemporary art last night.

headline: G.I.’s Who Were Ambushed Were Based in New York
text: BAGHDAD, May 15 — The seven American victims of a deadly weekend ambush south of Baghdad were soldiers from the 10th Mountain Division, based in upstate New York, military officials said Tuesday, as thousands of troops continued an intensive search for three of the men, who were presumed captured by Sunni Arab insurgents.

headline: Deadly Day of Violence Wracks Much of Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, May 16 — Sprawling street battles between militia gunmen and Iraqi security forces erupted in three cities in Iraq on Wednesday on a day of wide-ranging violence that underscored the grave security situation across much of Iraq.

headline: Obama and Clinton Back Ending Iraq Combat by March 31
text: WASHINGTON, May 15 — Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton said for the first time on Tuesday that they would support legislation to curtail major combat operations in Iraq by March 31, 2008, cutting off financing for all but a limited mission of American forces.

headline: Germany: Report on Africa Aid Disputed
text: The Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development disagreed with the contention of Bono and his antipoverty advocacy group, DATA, that Germany has gone off track in meeting its promise to double aid to Africa by 2010. The ministry said the group’s decision to exclude debt relief as a form of aid was “factually unjustified.” It said the debt relief it provided had helped African governments put more children in school and improve health. France, too, has disputed the organization’s exclusion of debt relief.

headline: Ivy League Crunch Brings New Cachet to Next Tier
text: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — Lehigh University has never been as sought after as Stanford, Yale or Harvard. But this year, awash in applications, it churned out rejection letters and may break more hearts when it comes to its waiting list.

headline: Philadelphians Pick Nominees for Mayor
text: PHILADELPHIA, May 15 — Michael Nutter, a former member of the City Council, won the Democratic primary for mayor Tuesday, effectively guaranteeing him the position in a city that has not had a Republican mayor since 1952.

headline: A Bluestocking Route From Gridiron to Commerce
text: AT 33, Lance Johnstone is hardly old, but his days are numbered — playing days, that is. As he enters his 12th season with the National Football League, he knows that soon he will need to make a living beyond professional sports.

headline: Thomson Adds Reuters in $17 Billion Bid to Be Giant
text: TORONTO, May 15 — In the information age, content may be king. But the real power lies in what you can do with it.

headline: Wiccans Keep the Faith With a Religion Under Wraps
text: DUMFRIES, Va. — Above the woman’s fireplace hangs her wedding picture, taken in a Lutheran church years ago. Below it, on the mantelpiece, is a small Wiccan altar: two candles, a tiny cauldron, four stones to represent the elements of nature and a small amethyst representing her spirit.

headline: Former Soldier, Now a Professor, Loses His Only Son to a War He Actively Opposed
text: BOSTON, May 15 — The father, a longtime military man, from West Point to Vietnam to the first Persian Gulf war, became an early public critic of the war in Iraq, writing frequently and potently about its causes and effects.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A map of Central Asia yesterday with the Jibek Joly Journal article, about the large number of Uzbek migrants who pass through the Kazakhstan border town of Jibek Joly to seek work, misidentified the country in the lower left corner, bordering Afghanistan and Turkmenistan. It is Iran, not Iraq. (Go to Article)

headline: A Choreographer Goes Video, Featuring a 99-Year-Old Star
text: These days lots of choreographers are trying their hands at video — lots more, unfortunately, than are good at it or even seem to know what it’s about. Those artists might consider ambling over to the Kitchen, where Ralph Lemon’s quiet but richly layered video installation is the central element in “(The efflorescence of) Walter.” Organized by guest curators, Anthony Allen and Claire Tancons, this mixed-media exhibition is his first solo show in New York, and a graceful public foray into visual art.

headline: Manhattan: Former Interfaith Official Charged
