text: The former office administrator of the Interfaith Center of New York, a nonprofit educational organization, was charged yesterday with stealing more than $55,000 from the group by charging personal expenses to business credit cards, prosecutors said. Denyce Norment, 58, of Brooklyn, was charged with grand larceny, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, and she pleaded not guilty at her arraignment. Prosecutors said Ms. Norment charged personal expenses, including a cruise and tickets to a Beyoncé concert, to Interfaith credit cards from April 2000 until October 2004. The bills were discovered after Ms. Norment was laid off in 2004, Mr. Morgenthau said. Ms. Norment’s lawyer, Frederica L. Miller, said yesterday that some of the charges were approved by Interfaith and that documentation concerning some of the bills was lost when the office changed locations. “She is absolutely not guilty,” she said. “I am confident the charges will eventually be dismissed.”

headline: Food Calendar
text: Wine Tastings

headline: 3 Suspects Freed in London Transit Attacks
text: LONDON, May 15 — The British police on Tuesday released three of four people arrested a week ago in connection with the London bombings of 2005, including the widow of one of the bombers.

headline: Plan for Middle-Class Homes on Queens Bank of East River Prompts Ideas and Protest
text: Stephen M. Ross wants some of the wealthiest developers in the city to come together to build 5,000 apartments for nurses, teachers, firefighters, construction workers and other middle-class employees on the bank of the East River — at no profit.

headline: Failing by Example
text: If you want to know why we are losing in Iraq, go back and read this story that ran on the front page of The Times on Saturday. It began like this:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on May 3 about plans to redevelop Pier 40 on the Hudson River into an entertainment complex misstated the year the pier was built as a commercial shipping terminal for the Holland America Line. It was 1963, not 1954.

headline: Health Insurance and Other Benefits: A Primer
text: BUSINESS owners who want to offer benefits like health insurance and tax-deferred retirement plans for themselves and their employees face two daunting hurdles: high costs and complicated federal laws intended to prevent plans from discriminating in favor of top employees.

headline: Microsoft to Release New Version of Halo Video Game on Sept. 25
text: Microsoft plans to announce today that the third installment of Halo, the company’s biggest video game franchise, will be released on Sept. 25.

headline: Kennedy Airport, Dining Destination
text: Delta Airlines has provided new food options at Terminal 2 at Kennedy Airport. A Balducci’s satellite, the store’s first such outlet, has self-service units with salads and first-rate sandwiches (including smoked salmon on baguette and smoked chicken and avocado), as well as yogurts, small containers of seasoned couscous and cold Asian noodles, pastries and fruit. Balthazar croissants are sold, and breakfast egg specialties and hot pressed sandwiches can be ordered at the service counter. But on a recent morning a well-stuffed hot corned beef and pastrami sandwich that needed more mustard was not heated through. Salads and sandwiches are mostly $6.49 to $7.49. A Todd English Bonfire steakhouse is to open in the terminal next month.

headline: Bronx Man Convicted of Killing Girl
text: A Bronx man who opened fire at a crowded playground two years ago has been convicted of fatally shooting a 10-year-old girl during the attack, prosecutors said yesterday. Rene Bonilla, 22, was convicted of murder and attempted murder on Friday in State Supreme Court for killing the girl, Naisha Pearson, and wounding Leonardo D’Eaza, 19, during a Labor Day block party on Sept. 5, 2005. Prosecutors said that Mr. Bonilla went to the playground in Mott Haven to kill Mr. D’Eaza because Mr. D’Eaza had beaten him in front of Mr. Bonilla’s girlfriend. After Mr. Bonilla started firing  striking the girl once and hitting Mr. D’Eaza five times  a crowd chased Mr. Bonilla to the roof of a building, where he was arrested, prosecutors said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day yesterday about the daily closing of the stock market misstated the given name of a strategist at JPMorgan Private Bank who discussed factors that could affect the performance of shares. He is Jack Caffrey, not James.

headline: Modest Gains Seen in U.S. Students’ History Scores
text: Federal officials reported today that students in fourth, eighth and 12 grade showed modest increases in test scores in history, although more than half of the nation’s high school seniors still showed poor command of even basic facts like the impact of the cotton gin on the slave economy or the causes of the Korean War.

headline: Unkind Cut for Janitors at Hilfiger
text: On Thursday, Gloria Coreas took the subway from Jackson Heights, Queens, to 23rd Street, then a crosstown bus to the western edge of Manhattan, and spent her usual eight hours cleaning the office at the Tommy Hilfiger company.

headline: Warding Off Diseases, Many Vaccines at a Time
text: DARREN E. HIGGINS wants to help your immune system in a hurry and on the cheap.

headline: Keeping Out the Wildlife
text: Every summer, it’s the same battle: Gardeners will try almost anything to keep nibbling wildlife out of their gardens. And for second homeowners, keeping prized gardens away from voracious critters can be a constant battle — one fought with fences, stinky sprays and odd home concoctions.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Bid4Spots, Encino, Calif., which operates a reverse-auction for radio commercial time, is expanding to Britain. Plans call for its first auction to be held in the third quarter and continue weekly thereafter. RadioWorks, a company specializing in the British radio market, will advise Bid4Spots and Paul Mitchard, the operations manager at RadioWorks, will manage the Bid4Spots British operation.

headline: What You Get for ... $600,000
text: Boston

headline: In China, It’s Not Always Clear for Whom the Booth Tolls
text: CHEN VILLAGE, China — Few motorists in any country brighten at the sight of tollbooths ahead. In China, which is building more toll roads than any other country in the world, legions of drivers are trying almost anything to avoid them.

headline: California Addresses Death Penalty Concerns
text: LOS ANGELES, May 15  State officials said Tuesday that they had addressed the plethora of serious concerns raised by a federal district judge last year over how California executed condemned inmates by lethal injections.

headline: Taking Office, Sarkozy Vows to Bring Change
text: PARIS, May 16 — Nicolas Sarkozy was officially inaugurated as France’s 23rd president today, vowing to bring far-reaching change, but also order and authority, to his country. He then left for Germany to meet with German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

headline: Recipe: Black Cod on Wilted Radicchio
text: Time: 45 minutes

headline: Billions of Dollars Pledged to Cut Urban Energy Use
text: A coalition of 16 of the world’s biggest cities, five banks, one former president and companies and groups that modernize aging buildings pledged today to invest billions of dollars to cut urban energy use and releases of greenhouse gases linked to global warming.

headline: The Taco Truck That Delivers
text: UNTIL 6 on weeknights, 96th Street and Broadway looks like so many other New York intersections, home to yet another Rite Aid, another Citibank, another McDonald’s. The northernmost exits of the 96th Street subway station belch out a batch of commuters every few minutes; they reach for cellphones above ground like snorkelers headed underwater reach for masks.

headline: This Elephant Asks, What’s Your Dosha?
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Rhett, Scarlett and Friends Prepare for Yet Another Encore
text: It’s taken 12 years, three authors and one rejected manuscript, but tomorrow will be another day when “Rhett Butler’s People,” the second sequel to Margaret Mitchell’s “Gone With the Wind,” is published this fall.

headline: PGA Tournament With a View of the New York City Skyline
text: The Barclays golf tournament, a fixture at Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y., since 1967 and the inaugural PGA Tour playoff event, will move to Liberty National Golf Club in Jersey City in August 2009, bringing professional golf closer to Manhattan for at least one year.

headline: Making Calls, Cheaply
text: WITH the prospects for Vonage, the pioneering Internet phone service, cast into doubt by an unfavorable ruling in a patent infringement lawsuit, now is a good time to look at other options for Internet business calls.

headline: Hooked on S-c-r-a-b-b-l-e? You’re Not Alone (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Sunday with a sports article about the Nets’ 96-85 playoff victory on Saturday against the Cleveland Cavaliers gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the player going up for a layup. He was Jason Kidd of the Nets, not his teammate Richard Jefferson. In other copies and on NYTimes.com, the caption to a different picture correctly identified Jefferson.

headline: Suit Contending Bribery in China Is Settled
text: The information technology unit of the Fidelity National Financial Corporation has settled a lawsuit with a company in Taiwan that accused it of breaching a contract to secure business with a Chinese bank and of bribing bank officials.

headline: More than he bargained for…
text: A homebuyer in Spain came across a nightmarish find this week.

headline: Ivy League Crunch Brings New Cachet to Next Tier
text: Twenty-five to 40 colleges that have traditionally been perceived as being a notch below the most elite have seen their cachet climb because of the astonishing competitive crush at the top.

headline: Under attack…
text: Starting June 1, 2007, a change in British law means that every property seller will have to produce a Home Information Pack at a cost of several hundred pounds. The packs are aimed at giving buyers more information from the outset so they can make an informed decision early on in the purchase. The goal is to reduce the number of aborted transactions that take place. All packs must contain evidence of title, standard searches, an energy performance certificate, among other information.

headline: A Beer Pilgrimage
text: A journey from Berlin to Bamberg in search of Germany's elusive home brews.

headline: A New Mexican Consulate
text: The new consulate in Little Rock, Ark., is one of several opened or planned in recent years where immigration from Mexico has soared.

headline: Currents
text: The National Design awards, hotel-quality flowers, nightspots in Los Angeles, a “Global Warming Action Kit” and the Design on a Dime auction.

headline: Stoppard’s ‘Rock ‘n’ Roll’ Comes to Broadway
text: Stars of the London production of Tom Stoppard's "Rock 'n' Roll" will reprise their roles when the prizewinning play opens on Broadway in the fall.

headline: Beauty and Brio
text: Images from “Material Journeys” at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and from “African Vision” at the National Museum of African Art in Washington.

headline: Kitchen, Bath and Beyond
text: This season's trends in appliances, fixtures and design.

headline: A Health Care Warranty
text: A hospital group is trying a radically new method to avoid costly mistakes, charging a flat fee that includes follow-up care.

headline: Lighting Up Summer Nights
text: Whether romantic or not, evenings on a patio or terrace are more enjoyable with appropriate lighting. Some suggestions to set the mood for summer.

headline: Gear Test With Pablo Airaldi
Donna Murphy Healing
text: So, other than being nominated for a Tony Award yesterday, what's happening with Donna Murphy?

headline: UniCredit and Capitalia Confirm Merger Talks
text: UniCredit and Capitalia, two of the largest Italian banks, confirmed Tuesday for the first time that they were in merger talks, but said no accord had been reached. The shares of Capitalia, which is considered by investors as the takeover target in any deal, rose 40 cents, or 5.3 percent, to 7.91 euros, valuing the company at 20.5 billion euros, or $27.8 billion.

headline: Older and Better
text: Smarter looks for older women.

headline: Russian Suitor Is Shocked by LionOre Break-Up Fee
text: The Russian nickel giant stalking LionOre Mining International is not retreating, but said it is outraged that the company agreed to such an unusually large break-up fee as part of a sweetened takeover bid of 6.2 billion Canadian dollars ($5.6 billion) from Xstrata.

headline: MySpace in Deal for Flektor, Report Says
text: MySpace is buying Flektor, a new service that allows users to create widgets from photos, video and text, according to TechCrunch. The report follows the announcement last week that MySpace, which is own by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, is acquiring Photobucket for between $250 millon and $300 million.

headline: Asthmatx Gets $50 Million Injection
text: Forgoing earlier plans for an initial public offering, a medical device maker, Asthmatx, said it has taken on $50 million in new funding from a strategic investor, Olympus Medical Systems, to fund regulatory approval and commercialization of catheter-based products to treat asthma. Olympus joins previous venture investors including Polaris Venture Partners and Menlo Ventures.

headline: Visa Names Chief Ahead of I.P.O.
text: Visa hired Joseph W. Saunders to find a chief executive for the company as it prepares for an initial public offering and he found — drum roll, please — himself.

headline: Oracle Buys Agile Software in Arms Race With SAP
text: The business software maker Oracle made yet another acquisition on Tuesday with a $495 million deal to buy Agile Software, which specializes in software that helps companies manage crucial products.

headline: Investors Push Insulet Up in Debut
text: Stock in Insulet, a diabetes treatment developer that became the second diabetes-focused health care company to go public in the past few days, rose in its first-day of trading Tuesday.

headline: 3i to Float Fund on L.S.E.
text: A London private equity firm, the 3i Group, said Tuesday it plans to list its specialist-quoted private equity investment business on the London Stock Exchange, raising at least 400 million pounds ($793 million) for growth capital investments in publicly traded companies in Britain and Europe.

headline: Fiery Meeting Expected at American Airlines
text: Fireworks have so far been rare at annual shareholder meetings this year. With stock indexes near their record highs, investor anger, not surprisingly, has been muted. But Wednesday’s annual meeting of shareholders of AMR, the parent of American Airlines, may be an exception.

headline: With New Hire, Yahoo Sends Out Deal Vibe
text: By hiring a veteran investment banker, Blake Jorgensen, as its chief financial officer, Yahoo sent out signals that there is deal making in its future, but analysts and industry observers seemed unable to decide what kind.

headline: Buffett Discloses More Railroad Stakes
text: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway on Tuesday revealed stakes in Norfolk Southern and Union Pacific. — five weeks after the billionaire said he had invested in three railroad companies but would not disclose the names of two.

headline: Sitcoms Based on Commercials
text: A new ABC sitcom follows in the footsteps of Max Headroom.

headline: Vornado Goes East and West for a Deal
text: Steven Roth’s hopes of establishing a beachhead on the West Coast were dashed earlier this year when he lost the high-stakes contest to acquire Equity Office Properties and its nationwide portfolio of prime office buildings to the Blackstone Group.

headline: Greenspan Finds a Client in Bond Management Firm
text: Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman whose pronouncements continue to jolt world markets, has signed a consulting deal with Pimco, the giant bond management firm.

headline: A Home That Heats and Cools Itself
text: This week, on my blog, I've been writing about the inventions I saw at last week's Modern Marvels/Invent Now finals. About 25,000 inventors from all walks of life entered this annual contest, which is run by the History Channel and the National Inventors Hall of Fame. I was among the six judges who were asked to declare a winner from among the 25 finalists still standing.

headline: Proposal for Hedge Fund Registration Resurfaces
text: Hedge fund registration is back on the menu.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Jockeys for Air Canada Division
text: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has emerged as one of three foreign front-runners bidding for a piece of Air Canada Technical Services, battling against the lone Canadian contender in the top four, Gerald Schwartz’s Onex, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: A First for Private Equity as Fortress Reports Results
text: The Fortress Investment Group became the first American hedge fund and private equity firm to report quarterly earnings Tuesday, and the disclosures highlighted the difficulties the public markets have in dealing with businesses whose income streams are volatile and difficult to predict.

headline: Lampert Fund Takes Stake in Citigroup
text: Chuck, meet Eddie.

headline: Wendy’s Hires Banks, But Is It Really For Sale?
text: Wendy’s International, the fast-food chain that put itself up for sale last month, hired J.P. Morgan Chase and Lehman Brothers for advice on evaluating potential buyers.

headline: Permira Slips into Valentino Fashion Group
text: Permira Advisers, Europe’s biggest leveraged buyout fund, agreed to buy 29.9 percent of the Valentino Fashion Group from Marzotto family members in a deal that values the Italian fashion company at 2.6 billion euros ($3.5 billion).

headline: BofA Appeals Dutch Ruling on LaSalle Sale
text: The Bank of America filed an appeal with the Dutch Supreme Court on Tuesday over a ruling this month that froze the company’s $21 billion purchase of the LaSalle Bank from ABN Amro. “We’re confident that the Dutch Supreme Court, when presented with all the facts, will overturn the decision” of the Amsterdam Superior Court, Scott Silvestri, a Bank of America spokesman, told The Associated Press.

headline: 2008: Southern Discomfort
text: After a week of news dominated by abortion on the G.O.P. side, security has come back into the fore. As they said they would, Fox News producers tried to drive a substantive debate, and differences among the candidates were especially stark, and sometimes emotional, on the question of interrogation techniques. From The Times’s Adam Nagourney and Marc Santora:

headline: In Deal for Reuters, Thomson Continues Its Evolution
text: The Thomson Corp.’s $17.2 billion acquisition of the Reuters Group, the global news and financial data service, comes in the middle of an information revolution as easy distribution over the Internet has turned news and data into a commodity. Media companies, including newspapers, cable companies and financial publishers, are all struggling to turn their content into new services that their customers are willing to pay for.

headline: Bausch & Lomb to Go Private in $4.5 Billion Deal
text: Sometimes, unsubstantiated deal chatter is right on the money.

headline: Should Goldman Have Defended John Browne?
text: When John Browne, the former chief executive of BP, resigned from Goldman Sachs‘s board of directors last week, it was hard to escape the conclusion that Goldman had inadvertently contributed to a nasty episode of homophobia, Matthew Lynn writes in a Bloomberg News column.

headline: Merrill’s Co-Head of Investment Banking to Leave
text: Merrill Lynch said that Dow Kim, executive vice president and co-president of its global markets and investment banking group, will leave this year to start his own investment firm. Merrill said it expects to be a client of Mr. Kim’s new firm.

headline: And the Winner Is . . . Nobody
text: Who won Tuesday night’s Republican presidential debate? Pretty much everybody, according to the blogosphere. The bad news: pretty much everybody lost, too.

headline: Icahn Takes Stake in Anadarko
text: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, has purchased a big stake in Anadarko Petroleum, according to regulatory filings, suggesting the billionaire investor is betting on further consolidation in the oil services sector. Icahn Management, one of Icahn’s investment vehicles, took a stake of about 3.1 million shares in Anadarko, worth about $133.5 million as of March 31, the filing said Tuesday.

headline: Judge Declines to Appoint Bankruptcy Trustee for New Century
text: The judge overseeing the bankruptcy case of New Century Financial, the subprime lender, rejected the federal government’s effort to oust its management on Tuesday but agreed to appoint an examiner to review its accounting.

headline: Union Takes Aim at Blackstone I.P.O.
text: The simmering tensions between organized labor and the United States private equity industry may be coming to a boil.

headline: Arcelor Mittal Shareholders Protest New Share Offer
text: Arcelor Mittal, the world’s largest steelmaker, angered Arcelor minority shareholders with buy-out terms below the current market price on Wednesday after announcing its first-quarter results, Reuters reported. Arcelor Mittal, formed by Mittal Steel’s takeover of Arcelor, said it would offer eight Arcelor Mittal shares for seven Arcelor shares, or an exchange ratio of 1.143, for the 6 percent of Arcelor it did not already own.

headline: Will There Be an ‘Obama Effect?’
Deal Reached on Human Trafficking
text: A source close to the Spitzer administration says that a deal has been reached between the governor and Legislative leaders on legislation to make human trafficking a felony in New York state.

headline: Fresno State Ads
text: Fresno State has just concluded a campus competition to create video clips that are meant to appeal to potential applicants as well as stir feelings of pride among students.

headline: Fresno State Ads
text: Fresno State has just concluded a campus competition to create video clips that are meant to appeal to potential applicants as well as stir feelings of pride among students.

headline: Three for the Road
text: What the future may hold for the next incarnation of Chrysler is certainly open to speculation. But there is no argument the company could certainly use some new product. A.S.A.P., please.

headline: Time to Think (Again) About Selling Time Inc.?
text: Time Warner may have fended off Carl Icahn’s calls for a four-way breakup of the company, but that doesn’t mean the media conglomerate isn’t still considering some major changes. An analyst at Bear Stearns thinks a sale of Time Inc., the world’s largest magazine company, is high on the list of restructuring moves under consideration.

headline: Thompson’s Quick Video Attack
text: Fred Thompson is impressing some in the blogosphere with his quick and pointed video response to the filmmaker Michael Moore, who asked the not-quite presidential candidate to debate health care.

headline: Fishing Under the City
text: Our recent post about the future of historic preservation in New York City elicited a fascinating comment from Dr. Mark Klein* who offered this intriguing recollection:

headline: Luxury on the Cheap
text: “I’m absolutely crushed,” a reader wrote in today, saying he had just read the article in the Dining section about the speciousness of truffle oil. “What a shock and disappointment.”

headline: Limiting the Decibels, and Hearing Loss
text: Yesterday, I wrote about my experiences as a judge in the Modern Marvels Invent Now competition.

headline: Bourdais test observation
text: Sebastien Bourdais again tested the Toro Rosso, today at the Paul Ricard circuit in the south of France. Like his last test, it was pretty difficult to compare his times to other Toro Rosso drivers. Scott Speed drove the car yesterday at the same track, and he had some mechanical problems and ran only 53 laps, setting a fastest time of 1m08.143. Today, Bourdais set a fastest time of 1m07.743, but he ran 142 laps and encountered no mechanical problems.

headline: How Buyouts Affect Workers: Lots of Ideas, Little Data
text: What has the recent run of private equity megadeals meant for the United States economy, the middle class and income inequality? It’s hard to say for sure — at least that was the sense we got from watching the witnesses who testified Wednesday before the House Financial Services Committee. Still, that didn’t stop both lawmakers and some of the witnesses from offering their opinions on the matter, which has come into focus as labor organizations have raised questions about buyout funds, which acquire public companies in hopes of selling them after an operational or financial overhaul, and whether they are good for United States workers.

headline: The War at Home: Senate Votes
text: Roll call votes in the Senate typically transpire with little fanfare and are filed away in the Congressional record, seldom to be dusted off ever again.

headline: Rosie O’Donnell’s 9/11 Question
text: The debate over the third building that collapsed at ground zero on Sept. 11, 2001, is back.

headline: The Power of the Darfur Movement
text: Fidelity Investments has generally behaved disgracefully in the context of Darfur. It has large holdings in PetroChina (which in turn buttresses the Sudanese government), yet it has refused to hold any dialogue with the divestment movement. There are legitimate arguments Fidelity could make (Berkshire-Hathaway has tried to make them), but Fidelity has essentially stonewalled. That’s one reason for the movement to boycott Fidelity.

headline: Fresno State Ads
text: Fresno State has just concluded a campus competition to create video clips that are meant to appeal to potential applicants as well as stir feelings of pride among students.

headline: Fresno State Ads
text: Fresno State has just concluded a campus competition to create video clips that are meant to appeal to potential applicants as well as stir feelings of pride among students.

headline: Why Blackstone Is, or Isn’t, an Investment Company
text: Yet again, carried interest is at the center of controversy. The carry, as it is called, is essentially the portion — usually 20 percent — of private equity funds’ investment profits that flow to the funds’ managers as a kind of performance fee. Some people, including lawmakers and labor groups, have recently questioned whether the carry deserves to be taxed at the lower capital gains rate (as it usually is) or whether it should be taxed as ordinary income (which the private equity industry naturally thinks is an awful idea).

headline: A Clear Favorite
text: Interesting Q-and-A on the Wine Spectator web site with Robert Bohr, the wine director at Cru restaurant in Manhattan. Robert has many sensible things to say, but among his points I find this statement particularly interesting:

headline: Partisan Politics, Bad Precedent
text: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedman’s May 16 column, “Failing by Example.”

headline: Dizzying Spin On the Latest Wiretap Revelations
text: Congressional testimony is great fun for journalists, both those who wear press passes and those who wear pajamas. Given the bare-bones style of Capitol grillings and the disjointed manner of recorded testimony, anyone who wants to analyze the event can feel free to give the commentary his or her personal little spin. Yesterday’s stunning comments by James Comey, the former deputy attorney general, were of course no exception. For the sake of argument, let’s use this New York Times news report as a neutral baseline against which we can judge the blogospheric reaction:

headline: Dubai Takes a Stake in Deutsche Bank
text: Deutsche Bank has become the latest western financial institution to attract interest from a Middle Eastern investor after Dubai’s International Financial Center built a significant stake in the German bank, the Financial Times reported. In a statement on Wednesday, DIFC Investments, the center’s investment arm, said it had acquired a 2.2 percent stake in Deutsche Bank, becoming one of the bank’s largest shareholders.

headline: Giuliani Calls on Democrats to Debate on Fox
text: When Fox News tried to set up a Democratic presidential debate with the Congressional Black Caucus, it watched its effort crumble after bloggers and liberal groups complained that Democrats should not appear on a network that, they said, had a history of belittling Democrats and promoting Republicans on its airwaves.

headline: Democratic Party Debate Calendar
text: Mark these dates. The Democratic National Committee today released the days, sponsors and locales of the six debates it is sanctioning this year, one a month beginning in July.

headline: Fishing, in Iraq and Back Home
text: You can take the man away from the Minnesota Fishing Opener, but you can’t take the Minnesota Fishing Opener away from the man.

headline: Changing Direction
text: Through our own fault, our architect had designed a house too big and too expensive — just plain too much.

headline: TV Upfronts: Gil Schwartz = CBS
text: Before the CBS presentation begins at Carnegie Hall, I have to say a word about Gil Schwartz. Gil Schwartz has something to do with CBS; his awesome, double-wide, “Sopranos”-cast face is almost always the first one I see at any CBS event. This time he was pacing around the back corridors of Carnegie Hall, which — like everything secretive and powerful — he seemed to know intimately.

headline: TV Upfronts: Second Life, the Executive Edition
text: Cool cool cool — JoAnn Ross, CBS’s president of network sales, is onscreen in avatar form. Her reason for trying the stunt? “Size 4, baby.”

headline: TV Upfronts: CBS Fansubs Itself
text: Quincy Smith, the president of CBS Interactive, promises tons of “non-nose ring” people who are turning sudoku into rocket ships. He’s wearing sneakers, and talking about wikis and stealth, not the quarterback jargon from 1980 that NBC’s Kevin Reilly was throwing around on Monday.

headline: Spitzer and Leaders Meet, Fight
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders gathered in the Red Room of the Capitol today for their second public meeting since the budget was passed six weeks ago.

headline: TV Upfronts: Jokes :(
text: “We sort of wrapped up the sex portion of the marriage” is a big deadpan line in “Rules of Engagement.”

headline: TV Upfronts: SPF
text: Does anyone but me worry so much about David Caruso’s rosacea in Florida that they can’t watch “CSI: Miami”?

headline: American Dreamin’
text: I was sitting with Alix Browne of the Times Magazine the other night at the Dior resort show at 7 World Trade Center when I had the thought that John Galliano’s clothes were not really about India or Marrakech at all. Rather, they were about the American West and the Middle West of Arkansas and Oklahoma. There was a great vibrant redneck couture quality about the clothes — and those of you who follow Galliano’s work know he has a taste for raw country. Remember the trashy Dior shows of few years back? Anyway, that’s what I saw in the show, a kind of couture sensibility that never made it to Dallas or Fort Worth but maybe got as far as Oklahoma. All those turquoises, and lemon yellows, and pinks done in a kind of corn-haired babe stiffness.

headline: TV Upfronts: The Tiffany Show Titles
text: Because it goes third, CBS is the only network to post its schedule against the other Big Three schedules, ABC’s and NBC’s. And it’s true that its clinical-sounding show names (“NCIS,” “The Unit”), which sound sterile on their own, become somehow dignified and even governmental when set against “Dirty Sexy Money,” “Scrubs” and “Ugly Betty.”

headline: TV Upfronts: Eye Teeth
text: The vampire show, “Moonlight,” which has been cited as very un-CBS, looks thin. For one, the protagonist is Casper the Friendly Vampire, it seems. For another, the star, Alex O’Loughlin, appears to be the only Australian actor in the history of Australia who can’t pull of an American accent.

headline: Kyoto Goes Local in the U.S.
text: The United States, the world’s largest emitter of greenhouse gasses, never signed the Kyoto Protocol, the program by which most developed nations pledged to reduce emissions. Now the nation’s governors and mayors are promising to do what their national government has avoided.

headline: TV Upfronts: CBS, Ugly All the Way to the Bank
text: CBS shows are ugly. It’s a signature CBS thing. If someone told me that CBS broadcasts with fewer brush strokes — or lines or aesthetic IQ points or whatever — and that that was decreed in the days of Bill Paley, I’d believe it. The shows look greenish and slightly unwell, as though the colors have been badly mixed and then soaked in dirty water.

headline: The Prosecutor’s Fallacy
text: Later this month – or it could be next month – a group of three judicial “wise men” in the Netherlands should finally settle the fate of a very unlucky woman named Lucia de Berk. A 45-year-old nurse, de Berk is currently in a Dutch prison, serving a life sentence for murder and attempted murder. The “wise men” – an advisory judicial committee known formally as the Posthumus II Commission – are reconsidering the legitimacy of her conviction four years ago.

headline: A Trove of N.Y.P.D. Surveillance Files
text: Jim Dwyer wrote a lengthy and comprehensive article in March detailing the extensive and secretive surveillance conducted by the Police Department, starting more than a year before the 2004 Republican National Convention.

headline: Clinton Seeks a Theme Tune
text: Some days we just can’t resist a challenge, especially when it comes to music. Today’s one of them.

headline: An Author’s Nightmare
text: “You should sue your publisher.”

headline: Crucial Facts About Stroke
text: Stroke is the third leading cause of death in the United States, but many strokes that could be successfully treated are not.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Once'
text: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Once," about a Dublin street musician and the Czech woman he falls for.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Golden Door'
text: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Golden Door," about a poor Sicilian crossing the Atlantic at the turn of the century.

headline: Minor Relief From Major Problems
text: With the Yankees these days, it’s really best to look at the minor league affiliates.

headline: Land Wars in Venezuela
text: President Hugo Chavez's ambitious land reforms have injected the poor with optimism, and brought dread to the wealthy.

headline: Television Upfronts: CBS
text: The Times's Bill Carter reports from Carnegie Hall, where CBS presented its 2007 fall schedule.

headline: Television Upfronts: CBS
text: The Times's Bill Carter reports from Carnegie Hall, where CBS presented its 2007 fall schedule.

headline: Design Helps H.P. Profit More on PCs
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 16  Hewlett-Packard’s effort to transform its personal computers from low-margin commodities into more stylish devices has started to pay off.

headline: The Paris Review
text: PARIS HILTON, through no fault of her own, appears on the covers of two fashion magazines hitting newsstands this month. One is a straightforward friendly endorsement of Ms. Hilton’s celebrity: the June issue of Harper’s Bazaar, where she appears with erstwhile best friend Nicole Richie, both in Chanel tweed coats. The other cover, on the esoteric quarterly aRude, is a far more poisonous statement about the cultural fascination with Ms. Hilton, that which ostensibly justifies her appearance in Harper’s Bazaar.

headline: Four Killings in the City in 12 Hours
text: Four people were killed in unrelated cases in less than 12 hours Tuesday night and early yesterday, the police said. The figure is unusually high for a year in which an average of less than one homicide per day has occurred, though Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly pointed out yesterday that “one day doesn’t make a trend.” In the first killing, Donnell McFarland, 18, of Brooklyn was shot in the head at 7:30 p.m. at the corner of Linden Street and Knickerbocker Avenue in Bushwick, the police said; James Kelly, 16, of Linden Street has been arrested. In the second, a young man of 18 who was not identified by the police was shot in the back shortly before 11 p.m. on Tuesday in front of 570 Blake Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn. Three hours later, Emrand Hossain, 19, of Queens was stabbed in the chest at the corner of 28th Street and Hoyt Avenue in Astoria. And shortly before 3 a.m., a man of 19 was shot on University Avenue in the Bronx. There were no arrests as of last evening.

headline: Sarkozy Picks Fillon as Prime Minister
text: PARIS, May 17 — Nicolas Sarkozy named Francois Fillon as prime minister today, an appointment that France’s new president hopes will smooth the introduction of his ambitious reform program.

headline: Charles Gibson Enjoys a Second Wind on ABC
text: The retirement date had already been set: Charles Gibson was scheduled to leave ABC News on June 22, 2007, after a 32-year career.

headline: The Finance of Business (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Just a Ride in the Park
text: Single-track mountain-biking trails have long been a fixture of the backwoods. But a push for trails closer to home has prompted municipalities like Seattle, Minneapolis, Pittsburgh, Tucson and Salt Lake City to legitimize the sport in parks within city limits. In New York, $100,000 in government financing built four miles of single-track path in Highbridge Park in upper Manhattan, where a grand opening will be celebrated this Saturday. “The face of the sport is changing,” said Chris Bernhardt, a consultant with the International Mountain Bicycling Association. “Urban terrain is receiving more attention than traditional wilderness trails in some areas.” At Highbridge, New York City’s first legal mountain-biking area, twisting trails, jumps, banked turns and stunts occupy woods formerly famous for homeless encampments and used hypodermic needles.

headline: Iraqis Admit Ambush Roles as U.S. Searches for 3 G.I.’s
text: YUSUFIYA, Iraq, May 16 — Four days into a huge manhunt for three American soldiers abducted in an ambush a few miles from here, military officials said Wednesday that they had detained several local residents who confessed to taking part in the attack and that they had recovered equipment that might have belonged to the missing soldiers.

headline: Suns Are Not Counting Themselves Out
text: PHOENIX, May 17 — Like a can of soda that had been dropped and then shaken over the past two days, the undermanned Phoenix Suns exploded at the opening tip of Game 5 Wednesday night, their adrenaline surging against the visiting Spurs.

headline: Manhattan: Harlem Food Shops Chided
text: A report released yesterday by the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene found that residents in East and Central Harlem have far less access to healthful food in stores than their nearby counterparts on the Upper East Side. The report, based on a survey that department researchers conducted in 2005, found that stores in Harlem were half as likely to stock low-fat dairy products and seven times less likely to sell common vegetables, said Andrew Tucker, a Health Department spokesman. Mr. Tucker said city officials were working with store owners to encourage them to offer more healthful foods.

headline: Democrats Seek No-Confidence Vote on Gonzales
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales’s standing in Congress became even shakier today as Senate Democrats called for a vote of no confidence in him, and the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee and others predicted that the furor over Mr. Gonzales’s leadership of the Justice Department would end with his resignation.

headline: Orthodox Jews Come to a Well-Worn City, Pleased to Find a Piece of Paradise
text: WATERBURY, Conn. — The 7-Eleven on Cooke Street in this central Connecticut city now offers kosher Slurpees. A deli offering Shabbat specialties like cholent and kishke sits on a blighted street where the police frequently block off vandalized homes. An abandoned synagogue that was nearly sold to a church about seven years ago is now a bustling yeshiva where 200 young men study the Talmud.

headline: Fast, Loud and Savage: Hey, Hey, They’re Arctic Monkeys
text: Alex Turner always acts as if he’s trying hard to stave off boredom and barely succeeding. Onstage at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Tuesday night with his band, Arctic Monkeys, he glanced at the heaving crowd and said, “Nice to see you’re on your feet.” Nice, maybe, but not surprising: there are no chairs on the main floor.

headline: Bausch & Lomb Accepts $4.5 Billion Takeover Bid
text: Bausch & Lomb, a troubled leader in the eye care industry, said yesterday that it had accepted a $4.5 billion takeover offer from investment groups controlled by Warburg Pincus, a private equity firm known for backing a wide range of health care companies.

headline: In Bid for Better Care, Surgery With a Warranty
text: What if medical care came with a 90-day warranty?

headline: Street Battles in Iraqi Cities Point to Dire Security Status
text: BAGHDAD, May 16 — Sprawling street battles between militia gunmen and Iraqi security forces erupted in three cities on Wednesday on a day of wide-ranging violence that underscored the grave security situation across much of Iraq.

headline: Newly Released
text: Judging by some of this month’s new books, the transition from childhood to the adult world remains as rich a vein for writers as it was when Holden Caulfield first wandered around New York (and one of the authors goes the ducks one better by giving his protagonist a job at the Central Park Zoo). In these books, children are beset by their parents, by demons and by first love, among other things. Elmore Leonard, on the other hand, writes strictly about adults.

headline: Pros and Cons of Web-Based Mail
text: Pros and Cons

headline: Bausch & Lomb Accepts $4.5 Billion Takeover Bid
text: Bausch & Lomb, a troubled leader in the eye care industry, said today that it had accepted a $4.5 billion takeover offer from investment groups controlled by Warburg Pincus, a private equity firm known for backing a wide range of health care companies.

headline: Deal Is Reached in Senate on Immigration
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — Senators from both parties announced an agreement this afternoon on immigration-reform legislation that would bring illegal immigrants and their families “out of the shadows and into the sunshine of American life,” as Senator Edward M. Kennedy put it.

headline: In Time for Summer Parties, an Amplifier Geared for MP3
text: Ion Audio’s mission, it seems, is to bring old-school technology into the 21st century. For those with a collection of vinyl records, it has turntables that connect directly to computers to digitize tracks from the likes of Jefferson Airplane and the Ohio Players.

headline: Resignations Leave Trenton’s Pension-Investment Board at Quorum Plus One
text: A flurry of resignations has left the board that oversees New Jersey’s pension investments perilously close to not having enough members to conduct its business.

headline: With Bad Suit Splits, Go With No-Trump
text: The fifth and final session of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs, which took place last Sunday in Henderson, Nev., turned into a close race. The Norwegians Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness had led after the fourth session but suffered a couple of disasters and dropped to fifth. The Americans Bobby Levin of New York City and Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y., who had been in front after the second session, moved up steadily on the rail, putting their noses in front near the end and holding off the challengers. Second were Drew Casen and Mike Passell of Las Vegas, with Bruce Rogoff of Upper Grandview, N.Y., and Louk Verhees from the Netherlands third.

headline: Chrysler Sale Unavoidable, Chief Says
text: STUTTGART, Germany, May 16  On Monday evening at Chrysler’s offices in Auburn Hills, Mich., Dieter Zetsche held what is likely to be his last, and most poignant, session of “Ask Dr. Z.”

headline: Pennsylvania Voters Reject Tax Plan to Finance Schools
text: PHILADELPHIA, May 16  Pennsylvania voters overwhelmingly rejected a plan to reduce property taxes in return for higher local income taxes as a way of financing school districts, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Clash of Hope and Fear as Venezuela Seizes Land
text: URACHICHE, Venezuela — The squatters arrive before dawn with machetes and rifles, surround the well-ordered rows of sugar cane and threaten to kill anyone who interferes. Then they light a match to the crops and declare the land their own.

headline: Dollar Coin of John Adams Is to Be Released Today
text: The second design in the presidential one-dollar coin series, featuring John Adams, is to be released today by the United States Mint.

headline: Why Is Income Inequality in America So Pronounced? Consider Education
text: The most commonly cited culprits for the income inequality in America  outsourcing, immigration and the gains of the super-rich  are diversions from the main issue. Instead, the problem is largely one of (a lack of) education.

headline: Psychiatrists and Drugs (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Judge Orders Police Department Files on Preconvention Surveillance Opened
text: A federal magistrate judge yesterday released about 600 pages of secret documents relating to police preparations for the 2004 Republican National Convention, held in New York.

headline: Met Opera to Expand Simulcasts in Theaters
text: He is no Spider-Man, but Papageno held his own at the movies this season.

headline: Amazon to Sell Music Without Copy Protection
text: Amazon.com, the biggest online seller of CDs, is joining the movement against copy-protection software for digital music. It plans to sell songs that can be freely copied to any computer, cellphone or music player, including the iPod from Apple.

headline: Storms Knock Out Power for Thousands
text: Heavy thunderstorms across the region last night caused nearly 30,000 customers in Westchester County to lose power, Consolidated Edison officials said. The hardest-hit towns were Cortlandt, New Castle, Bedford, Ossining and Mount Vernon. In northern New Jersey, Public Service Electric and Gas reported that about 7,000 customers lost power.

headline: For Wolfowitz, a 2nd Chance Dissolves Into Failure
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — Paul D. Wolfowitz was ready to move on from the Pentagon in early 2005. But he had been thwarted in his effort to become defense secretary or national security adviser. The war in Iraq, meanwhile, had deteriorated. So when the World Bank presidency came open, he jumped at the opportunity.

headline: Ooh, That Face! It’s Model Behavior, Online
text: Kate Moss was discovered by a modeling scout as she waited for a plane at Kennedy International Airport. Twiggy was noticed in a suburban London hair salon. Claudia Schiffer began modeling after she was spotted dancing in a Düsseldorf nightclub.

headline: Danger: Plant Sales Ahead
text: LANCASTER, Pa.

headline: Older, Better, but Harder to Dress
text: AT the start of any fashion writer’s career there is, waiting at the end, the dreaded article about older women and how they can never find clothes appropriate for their age. I swore on a stack of Vogues I would never write such a piece. It was totem journalism, predictable, worked at. Even the term “appropriate” has always seemed to me old hat, with violets on top.

headline: Awaiting Defining Pitchers
text: Pressed and spotless, their uniforms hang neatly in the clubhouses at Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium, but neither pitcher is there. Their lockers are as empty as the slots in their teams’ rotations. And until Roger Clemens and Pedro Martínez each reappear, neither the Yankees nor the Mets will really know how high (or how low) they can go this season.

headline: Investors Plan New Monorail Linking Soweto to Johannesburg
text: JOHANNESBURG, May 16  A Malaysian investor pledged on Wednesday to link central Johannesburg to its famous suburb, Soweto, via a 27-mile, $1.7 billion monorail to be built and operated entirely with private money.

headline: Psychiatrist Says Defendant in Sex Case Wanted to Die
text: A psychiatrist said yesterday that Peter Braunstein, a writer accused of sex abuse, was suicidal after his arrest. She said he told her he did not care how his trial turned out because he was going to kill himself anyway.

headline: Inconspicuous Drama, Now Playing at the World Financial Center
text: All the world’s a stage, as two uniformed police officers discovered yesterday. For about 30 seconds at the World Financial Center, Officer John Monteforte and Officer Jason Lagnese were walk-ons in a play called “Remembrance.”

headline: Needing to Win in the Worst Way, the Nets Do It
text: CLEVELAND, May 16 — Late-game pratfalls put the Nets on the edge of playoff elimination, and a disastrous fourth quarter should have ended their season Wednesday night. Only a strange brew of stout defense, good mojo and striking ineptitude by the Cleveland Cavaliers saved them.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about the extensive medical care that Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey received at Cooper University Hospital in Camden after a traffic accident on April 12 misstated the date of Mr. Corzine’s release in some copies. It was April 30, not May 1.

headline: Blair Bids Farewell to Bush in Bittersweet Meeting
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — The poignancy of Prime Minister Tony Blair’s final White House news conference was perhaps summed up best today when a British reporter asked President Bush, his own time in office winding down, whether he was partly responsible for Mr. Blair’s leadership ending sooner than either man might have liked.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some copies yesterday about the debate by the 10 Republican presidential candidates at the University of South Carolina in Columbia referred incorrectly to support for the war in Iraq among the candidates. One of them, Representative Ron Paul of Texas, opposes it; they do not all support the war. The article also misidentified the home state of another candidate, Representative Tom Tancredo, in some copies. It is Colorado, not Arizona.

headline: Taller, Faster Officers on Patrol as Police Dept. Gets 10 Segways
text: A city already patrolled by police horses and bicycles, police speedboats and helicopters, and all manner of cars, vans and armored vehicles bearing the emblem “NYPD,” now has a new crime-fighting tool: the rolling lollipop known as the Segway.

headline: Mr. Gonzales’s Incredible Adventure
text: There were many fascinating threads to the testimony on Tuesday by the former deputy attorney general, James Comey, who described the night in March 2004 when two top White House officials tried to pressure an ailing and hospitalized Attorney General John Ashcroft into endorsing President Bush’s illegal wiretapping operation.

headline: A Defense We Just Don’t Need (Yet)
text: Washington

headline: Paying More for a Printer, but Less for Ink
text: In some ways, the world of electronics is a great big game of Us vs. Them, filled with imbalances of power that the little people can’t do anything about. Through learned helplessness, we’ve come to accept that the gadget we buy today will be passé in a year — period. Calling technical support is going to be a nightmare — tough rocks. Buying cartridges for an inkjet printer will cost twice as much as the printer itself — each year.

headline: Energy Standards Needed, Report Says
text: Energy saving opportunities in American homes are immense with current technology, but new product standard mandates will be needed, according to a study by the McKinsey Global Institute.

headline: Senate Rejects Iraq Troop Withdrawal
text: WASHINGTON, May 16 — Congressional Democratic leaders signaled on Wednesday that they were ready to give ground to end an impasse with President Bush over war spending after the Senate soundly rejected a Democratic plan to block money for major combat operations in Iraq beginning next spring.

headline: Wealth Is a Common Factor Among 2008 Hopefuls
text: WASHINGTON, May 16 — Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, who just six years ago told a divorce court he had only $7,000 in assets under his control, has amassed a net worth of more than $30 million, much of it from paid speeches.

headline: Coalition to Make Buildings Energy-Efficient
text: A coalition of 16 of the world’s biggest cities, five banks, one former president and companies and groups that modernize aging buildings on Wednesday pledged investments of billions of dollars to cut urban energy use and releases of heat-trapping gases linked to global warming.

headline: Belarus Blocked From Membership in U.N. Human Rights Council
text: UNITED NATIONS, May 17 — Belarus, one of the world’s most repressive states, was blocked from gaining membership on the United Nations Human Rights Council today after being outvoted in favor of Bosnia, a late entry.

headline: Doctors, Drugs and the Poor
text: It’s one of those questions no one tells you about when you enter medical practice. What do you do when patients come who can’t pay? Some doctors decline to see them. I have expenses to pay and a family to feed, they’ll argue.

headline: Driving While Distracted (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Baby, Boss Comes Calling
text: AMY STEPNOWSKI spent 12 years as a banker specializing in Latin America. Which means she spent the better part of 12 years on airplanes. While pregnant with the second of her three children, she decided that that kind of globetrotting didn’t allow her a family life, so she left JPMorgan Chase & Company in 2002. In the years that followed she “didn’t have time to think about work, or going back to work, or actually much of anything at all that didn’t involve children,” she says.

headline: Fixing the Student Loan Mess
text: Colleges that have been caught steering students to loan companies in exchange for kickbacks and goodies have often blamed financial aid officers, insisting they were violating school policy. Congress, which clearly knows better, is fashioning bills that would explicitly outlaw collusion between lenders and schools while closing loopholes that the two have routinely used to enrich themselves at the expense of students.

headline: Giuliani’s Abortion Figures Are Compared to National Trend
text: In the first two Republican presidential debates, Rudolph W. Giuliani has addressed questions about his stand on abortion by citing figures showing that abortions declined when he was mayor of New York, while adoptions increased.

headline: A Pair of Creepy, Yet Cerebral, Action-Adventures
text: “My name is Philip. If we are lucky, then by the time you receive this, I will be dead.”

headline: Actor, Star, Singer, Raconteur: Baby, It’s Crowded Inside
text: Peter Gallagher has the gift of gab. This New York actor, born into the Irish storytelling tradition, spins amusing yarns with an ease that turns the kind of polished after-dinner remarks usually accompanied by brandy and cigars at a black-tie function into yarns swapped by regular guys over beers in the local pub.

headline: Lawmakers Near Agreement on New Immigration Rules
text: WASHINGTON, May 16  Senators from both parties said Wednesday that they were close to agreement on a new system of selecting immigrants that would give greater weight to education and to job skills deemed helpful to the economy.

headline: Mother and Daughter, Each Coming Into Her Own
text: On Tuesday night “Gilmore Girls” ended its seven-season run, and its departure, I predict, will in some small way serve to boost the collective self-esteem of a certain population of American parents.

headline: Selima Optique
text: 59 Wooster Street (Broome Street);

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Stoppard’s ‘Rock ’n’ Roll’ Comes to Broadway

headline: Bronx: Probation for Charter School
text: The Department of Education has placed a turbulent Bronx charter school on probation to address problems of teacher turnover, a department spokeswoman said yesterday. The International Leadership Charter School, a high school on Exterior Street in Kingsbridge, is under investigation by its trustees after complaints that resulted in a student walkout last week. Since the school opened in September, all eight of its original teachers have resigned or been fired. All have been replaced. The principal, Elaine Ruiz Lopez, was removed from management duties last week and is currently handling “long-term projects” like fund-raising, a school spokesman said. The Department of Education oversees 31 publicly financed but privately managed charter schools in the city. Twenty-seven other charter schools are authorized by the state or the State University of New York.

headline: When the Small Nations Get the Biggest Weapons
text: William Langewiesche begins “The Atomic Bazaar” with a reference to Hiroshima and a chilling, methodical description of exactly how a nuclear blast destroys a city. Literally and figuratively this is overkill. He did not need such a drastic way of attracting attention to his book’s true subject: the illicit and unstoppable spread of nuclear weapons to some of the world’s most volatile nations. His book insightfully examines the perils created by this leveling of the global playing field.

headline: Manhattan: Developer for Hospital Site
text: The Rudin family has been selected as the developer for a site on Seventh Avenue owned and occupied by St. Vincent’s Hospital, which is relocating, hospital officials announced yesterday. Under the plan, the hospital will move from its current location, on Seventh Avenue between 11th and 12th Streets, to Seventh Avenue between 12th and 13th Streets, said Michael Fagan, a hospital spokesman. He said a modern hospital would replace the current collection of buildings. Once the new building is open, the current site will be redeveloped and the Rudins will pay St. Vincent’s an amount to be determined in part by the type of project approved by the city, Mr. Fagan said. He said the money would go toward the cost of the new hospital, estimated at $650 million.

headline: Norman Frank, 82, Public Relations Adviser, Dies
text: Norman Frank, the public relations executive who in 1966 devised the strategy by which New York City’s police union turned back Mayor John V. Lindsay’s attempt to create a civilian complaint review board, died Friday near his home in Miami. He was 82.

headline: A Collision Course for Physics
text: Excitement is building among high-energy physicists as construction in Europe of a huge new particle accelerator nears completion, with the first experiments scheduled for next year. It will be the purest exercise of pure science with researchers spending billions of dollars pursuing knowledge with no practical use, but that could add to our understanding of the universe’s fundamental constituents.

headline: Why Women Avoid Mammograms (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Reluctant Daffodils

headline: Gay Youths Find Place to Call Home in Specialty Shelters
text: DETROIT — One girl said she started living on the streets after her mother beat her for dressing like a boy. Another said she ran away from home after her father pulled a gun on her for hanging around with so many “tomboys.” A third said she left home after a family acquaintance raped her because she was a lesbian and he wanted to “straighten her out.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A theater review in Weekend on Friday about “Couples,” a group of eight short plays at WorkShop Theater Company on West 36th Street in Manhattan, misidentified the actors in “Right Sensation” and misidentified a character. The actors are Jacqueline M. Raposo and Michael Anderson  not Cailin McDonald and Anthony Aibel, who appear in “Invisible Woman.” The character played by Ms. Raposo is Paula  not Susanne, a character in “Invisible Woman” that is played by Ms. McDonald.

headline: The Lower (Far) East Side
text: ST. Marks Place and neighboring Ninth Street, long a mecca to punkers of every stripe, has become a magnet to a new generation of hipsters. Pouring into this grotty swath of Manhattan from cities as far-flung as Tokyo, Singapore and Seoul, they take time to sample local confections like green tea tiramisù and to show off a style that is largely defined by wild-child hair and incongruously fancy footgear.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about plans for three Tintin movies misspelled the given name of one of the filmmakers. He is Steven Spielberg, not Stephen.

headline: Watching a Show Live, With 72 Hours to Do It
text: AS the big broadcast networks complete a week of previews for Madison Avenue of their schedules for the coming season, the same words are on everyone’s lips: not the title of an appealing new series or the name of a promising young star, but the phrase “live plus three.”

headline: East Orange: Ex-Clerk Is Sentenced
text: A former clerk at the State Motor Vehicle Commission office in East Orange has been sentenced to five years in state prison for selling drivers’ licenses to unauthorized people, Attorney General Stuart Rabner announced yesterday. The clerk, Lawrence McCross, 29, of East Orange, pleaded guilty last June to conspiring to commit official misconduct. He admitted to issuing about 25 licenses to people who did not present any of the required identification documents, for an average fee of $2,500.

headline: With Help From Hypnotist, St. John’s Goes to Regional
text: In his first time on a golf course this year, after two weeks of winter hibernation, George Zolotas shot a 61 for St. John’s. That pleased the team’s sports hypnotist because Zolotas, his prize pupil, had stayed calm during and after a stretch of eagle-birdie-eagle-birdie.

headline: Decades Later, a Guilty Plea in 3 Murders in the Buffalo Area
text: BUFFALO, May 16  A 49-year-old factory worker pleaded guilty Wednesday to murdering three women, effectively closing a case that involved at least a dozen rapes dating back about a quarter century and the wrongful imprisonment of another man for more than two decades.

headline: As the Networks Order New Shows, Fox Moves to Consolidate Its Gains
text: With its prime-time lineup in its strongest position ever, the Fox network has ordered a new slate of programming intended to consolidate recent overall gains and shore up the network’s weak point, the early months of the television season.

headline: 2 Russian Churches, Split by War, Reuniting
text: MOSCOW, May 16 — The atmosphere was tense, laced with nearly a century of mistrust and bitter feelings, when President Vladimir V. Putin met in New York in 2003 with leaders of an émigré church that had broken with the Russian Orthodox Church after the Bolshevik Revolution. The breakaway church had vowed never to return as long as the “godless regime” was in power.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some copies yesterday about primary voting for mayor of Philadelphia misstated the last year the office was held by a Republican. It was 1952, not 1948.

headline: Yolanda King, 51, Actor and Dr. King’s Daughter, Dies
text: Yolanda King, the eldest child of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. who melded her father’s message of racial equality and nonviolence with her own calling as an actor and a motivational speaker, died on Tuesday in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 51.

headline: Korean Train Crossing Seen as Sign of Progress
text: MUNSAN, South Korea, May 17 — Trains crossed the border between North and South Korea today for the first time in 56 years, in what was hailed by both countries as a key step toward reconciliation on the divided Korean Peninsula.

headline: A Bright Future in Shades
text: LIKE pens and umbrellas, I usually buy sunglasses in the $20-or-less range because I know I will lose or destroy them. The last pair I had were plastic shades from a farmacia in Mexico. I sat on them, they cracked, the end.

headline: For ’08 Résumés, Don’t Ask Them to Fill in Blanks
text: WASHINGTON, May 16 — Stealing a page from the Soviet playbook, the current crop of presidential candidates has taken to eliminating whole chapters of their histories.

headline: Dubai Investment Unit Acquires a 2.2% Stake in Deutsche Bank
text: DIFC Investments, the investment arm of the Dubai International Financial Center, has become one of the largest shareholders in Deutsche Bank with a 2.2 percent stake, Dubai officials said yesterday.

headline: Wolfowitz Said to Push for Deal to Quit
text: WASHINGTON, May 16  After six weeks of combating efforts to oust him as president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz began Wednesday to negotiate the terms under which he would resign, in return for the dropping or softening of the charge that he had engaged in misconduct, bank officials said.

headline: Israel Strikes at Hamas Compound
text: JERUSALEM, May 17 — Israel continued its attacks on Hamas today with three airstrikes, killing at least three Palestinians, while five more Palestinians died in factional fighting despite a new cease-fire between the Hamas and Fatah factions.

headline: Sarkozy Gets Off to a Fast Start as President of France
text: PARIS, May 16 — Nicolas Sarkozy is proud of his reputation as an impatient politician driven by big ambitions and limitless energy, and on his first day as president of France, it was not enough to step back and savor the moment.

headline: Waiting for Thabo Mbeki
text: Will Robert Mugabe’s outrages never stop? For months he has been jailing and brutalizing opposition leaders and trampling the rule of law in order to guarantee himself another rigged victory in next year’s presidential elections.

headline: Amazon to Sell Music Without Copy Protection
text: After years of industry speculation, Amazon.com is getting into the digital music business.

headline: Wolfowitz to Resign From World Bank
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — Paul D. Wolfowitz this evening ended weeks of furor over charges of favoritism toward a bank employee who is his female companion and announced his resignation as president of the World Bank, effective June 30.

headline: New Demographic Racial Gap Emerges
text: With the number of nonwhite Americans above 100 million for the first time, demographers are identifying an emerging racial generation gap.

headline: A Vigorous Art Sale Makes Auction History
text: Buyers from all over the world spent millions of dollars at Christie’s last night as if it were play money. Together they made auction history: the most successful sale of postwar and contemporary art ever. Records were set for 26 artists, including Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns, Gerhard Richter and Damien Hirst.

headline: Magazine Suspends Its Run in History
text: After more than 50 years American Heritage, the magazine that furnished not just the minds but, in its original hardcover format, the dens of generations of American history buffs, is suspending publication, its editor, Richard F. Snow, said last week.

headline: For New Transit Chief, Is Frost on the Pumpkin?
text: The new boss man of subways and buses, Howard H. Roberts Jr., is said to be partial to the poetry of Robert Frost. Not a bad choice of a muse, even if Frost was a rural type who may have thought — assuming he dwelt on the matter at all — that BMT was shorthand for a kind of sandwich.

headline: Brown to Take Labor Nomination Unopposed
text: LONDON, May 17 — Opening a new era in British politics, the ruling Labor Party confirmed today that Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, had emerged as the sole candidate to assume the party leadership and thus succeed Tony Blair as prime minister when he steps down in June.

headline: The President and Wolfowitz
text: As Paul Wolfowitz is to the World Bank, the U.S. is becoming to the world.

headline: With Suspensions, Series Gains Another Layer of Heat
text: PHOENIX, May 16  Throughout this series, the Phoenix Suns have been the smaller, quicker younger brothers eager to be recognized by the N.B.A. hierarchy.

headline: Mets Minor Leaguer Barred 50 Games for Drug Violation
text: Lino Urdaneta, a minor league pitcher who was on the Mets’ 25-man roster two days ago, tested positive for a performance-enhancing substance and was suspended for 50 games, Major League Baseball said yesterday.

headline: Two Old Masters, Partnered Perhaps With New Ones
text: To find any ballet that brings tears to the eyes is cause for celebration, but in New York City Ballet’s quadruple bill “Four Voices” I find two. Not that these are tearjerkers. If tears come at all here (and doubtless I am in a minority), then they do so in a spontaneous sense of emotional recognition. A feeling we have known in life is happening again onstage, writ large to music.

headline: Democrats Agree on a $2.9 Trillion Budget
text: WASHINGTON, May 16  House and Senate Democratic leaders reached agreement on Wednesday on a $2.9 trillion budget for 2008 that envisions a return to budget surpluses by 2012 and assumes that some of President Bush’s tax cuts will be allowed to expire.

headline: For Teen Pitcher, New Team, Same Dream
text: On a nationally prominent team of 12-year-old baseball sensations, Jarrod Petree was the kid with the golden arm. When PLAY visited with him last year in Apopka, Fla., Jarrod and his travel-ball team, the Central Florida Express, were midway through what would be a stellar season, ending with 60 wins and just 6 losses. Jarrod would go 14-0 on the mound and hit .412. Yet the pile of victories was not enough to convince the overworked volunteer head coach, Ben Nichols, to take the Express into another year. The team dissolved last fall, but has been mostly reconstituted for 2007 under the leadership of Tim Petree, Jarrod’s dad, and Joe Winker, the father of a talented outfielder named Jesse, who is Jarrod’s best friend.

headline: Stretching, Sliding, Bonding: A Multitasking Mix
text: BOUNCE-N-SLIDEThe Fitness Guru, 77 Front Street, Brooklyn;www.fitnessgurunyc.com. $25 for a single class.

headline: Executive Pay Proposals Rejected at AMR
text: FORT WORTH, May 16 — Shareholders of AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, rejected at the annual meeting on Wednesday two proposals aimed at setting controls on executive pay.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about an investigation by Swiss authorities into a money laundering case linked to the military contractor BAE Systems referred incorrectly to a report in The Guardian, the British daily, about a Syrian financier, Wafic Said, a potential witness in the case who the newspaper said might have acted as a middleman for payments. The Guardian said the authorities “will be able to examine” the accounts of Mr. Said, not that they were already doing so.

headline: Highway Peril (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Legacy of Jerry Falwell (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Share Your World With the World by Pressing a Button
text: Pure Digital Technologies has modified its low-cost Flip Video camcorder for all those impatient exhibitionists out there, adding one-button instant uploading to video-sharing Web sites.

headline: Long Hidden, Stories Clash Over Killing Tied to Mob
text: “Incredulous” was one word the judge used. Another was “flabbergasted.”

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE OFFICE They may have survived the beach trip, but the employees of Dunder-Mifflin may still go their separate ways as Michael, Jim (John Krasinski, left) and Karen go to New York to interview for a job at corporate in the finale. Back in the office things get hairy when Dwight becomes the new sheriff in town.

headline: Internet Meets Large Screen
text: ROBERT SOREL, a trombonist from Woonsocket, R.I., keeps his PC in his basement media room, where, hooked up to his other components, it acts as a jukebox for his music and video collection.

headline: With Coaches on Move, Top Recruits May Wait
text: When the high-profile college basketball coaches Tubby Smith, Bob Huggins, Billy Gillispie and John Beilein left their teams for new jobs this spring, speculation was widespread about the reactions of the players who had signed national letters of intent with the universities they were leaving.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with the continuation of an article about a decision by members of the Schalk family to find alternatives to their jobs as airline mechanics gave incorrect identifications in some copies for three Schalk brothers at a family get-together. They are from left: Glenn, Chuck Jr., and Greg.

headline: Johnson Is Latest to Face Goodell
text: Chicago Bears defensive tackle Tank Johnson met yesterday with Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, making Johnson the latest player to face discipline for his off-the-field behavior.

headline: Collect-Me-Nots
text: Iowa City

headline: Lawyers on Haditha Panel Peer Into Fog of War
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 16  On its face, the military hearing that ended here Tuesday concerned just one issue: whether an inexperienced Marine lawyer’s failure to question the killing of Iraqi civilians in Haditha 18 months ago constituted a criminal dereliction of duty.

headline: A Fishing Hole Turns Into a Morass
text: MAHWAH, N.J.

headline: Myer Shark, Lawyer Who Fought Utility, Is Dead at 94
text: Myer Shark, a Minnesota consumer lawyer whose last case sought to recover $300 million of taxes that electric customers paid a utility but that federal and state governments never received, died yesterday in a suburb of Minneapolis, days after filing the final papers in the case. He was 94.

headline: Google’s One-Stop Search to Yield Text and Images
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., May 16  Google said on Wednesday that it was changing its approach to Internet searches by combining results from its established Web search service with offerings that help users find videos, images, maps and other content.

headline: Unity Fractures as Palestinians Battle in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, May 16 — Gaza City was shuttered on Wednesday as gunmen took over rooftops and top-floor apartments. Most everyone else huddled fearfully indoors on the fourth day of factional Palestinian fighting that is drawing in the Israeli military.

headline: Sderot Residents Evacuate to Escape Rocket Attacks
text: SDEROT, Israel, May 17  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert paid an unannounced visit to this border town on Thursday night to show solidarity with its residents after days of rocket fire from the nearby Gaza Strip.

headline: A Point-and-Shoot Camera That’s Quicker on the Shutter
text: Some pocket point-and-shoot cameras may skimp on extras, especially when compared with pricier models aimed at professionals, but Canon’s new PowerShot SD850 IS Digital Elph packs in quite a few features.

headline: South Koreans Jostle to Take an English Test
text: SEOUL, South Korea, May 16  Thailand has its attractions for foreign visitors: its famed temples, seaside resorts, tom yum soup. But what drew Oh Sun-yee to Bangkok recently for a three-day stay was something considerably less recreational. Like an increasing number of South Koreans, Ms. Oh went to take the Test of English as a Foreign Language, or Toefl.

headline: Parallel Paths Diverging Sharply
text: On a hot evening this week in the Museum of Modern Art’s garden, Marie-Josée Kravis, the museum president, and her husband, Henry, played host to more than 900 guests who mingled near two giant Richard Serra sculptures. Her presence was cool and reserved, and her outfit of a shimmering sequin top and dark slacks struck a conservative tone amid the sun-fired skin and tummy-hugging gowns that the wives of other moguls favored.

headline: Spain: Madrid Bombing Suspects on Hunger Strike
text: Nine defendants in the Madrid train-bombing trial began a hunger strike, joining four others who stopped eating last Thursday to protest the trial, the prison authority and a lawyer for the suspects said. Javier Gómez Bermúdez, the presiding judge, ejected two of the original hunger-strikers from the Madrid courtroom yesterday after they slumped to the floor, apparently weak from dehydration. He said he would authorize prison officials to force-feed them, if necessary. He added that the trial would “not be suspended under any circumstances.” The 13 men, mainly Moroccans, are among 29 suspects who have been on trial since Feb. 15 on charges connected to the bomb attacks on Madrid commuter trains that killed 191 people in 2004.

headline: Fans Cram Into Disney Bandbox for a Major League Attraction
text: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., May 16 — At Boston’s Fenway Park, the Green Monster is a tall, hard wall in left field. At The Ballpark, in Disney’s Wide World of Sports complex, the big green thing in left field is a soft, grassy hillside rising from the fence to a row of bushes and a grove of trees.

headline: Loyal to Bush but Big Thorn in Republicans’ Side
text: WASHINGTON, May 16  For a loyal George W. Bush Republican, James B. Comey has made a remarkable amount of trouble for the White House.

headline: Sosa Pitches Mets Past Cubs After Long Wait
text: The start of the Mets’ game against the Chicago Cubs last night was delayed because of rain for 3 hours 7 minutes. The first pitch was thrown at 10:17 p.m., and the last out was made at 12:53 this morning.

headline: Albany Agrees on Law Against Sexual and Labor Trafficking
text: ALBANY, May 16  State lawmakers and Gov. Eliot Spitzer said Wednesday that they had agreed to make labor- and sex-trafficking felonies, breaking a deadlock on an issue many thought should have been resolved long ago.

headline: Pieces Come Together Slowly for the Yankees
text: CHICAGO, May 16 — When the Yankees evened their record last week, they hoped it would be the start of their climb. Instead, they have played so unevenly that a .500 record was a mirage by Wednesday afternoon.

headline: New Research on Athlete Hydration
text: As they sweat and drip through a summer workout, few athletes fret about overdrinking. (They’re probably more concerned about parched shriveling.) But even in hot weather, some people develop hyponatremia — or water overload. During the London Marathon, held on an unseasonably warm day in April, the lone fatality was due to brain swelling from overdrinking.

headline: Traveling Light, but Still Pretty
text: LISA HOFFMAN’S line, Night & Day 24 Hour Skincare, packages products in sizes that can probably pass muster with even the most ornery airport security agents. Other brands that help skirt the roadblocks of modern travel:

headline: Financial Angels Band Together
text: Two weeks ago, 40 successful businesspeople sat around a horseshoe table in a university lecture hall firing questions at four aspiring entrepreneurs. The aspirants were giving 20-minute presentations about their start-up companies to the Los Angeles chapter of Tech Coast Angels, a group that invests in new businesses.
