headline: High, Low and in Between
text: THIS year’s Kitchen and Bath Industry Show, held last week in Las Vegas, brought together more than 1,000 manufacturers from around the world, but the wares they showed were playing to very different audiences.

headline: As Giuliani Strays From G.O.P. Base, He Sticks to 9/11
text: WASHINGTON, May 16 — The most striking moment of the Republican presidential debate on Tuesday night may not have been the back-and-forth on abortion or immigration. It was arguably when Rudolph W. Giuliani won resounding applause for rebutting another candidate’s suggestion that American policies might have helped incite the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report by The Associated Press in the Metro Briefing column on Monday, about the arrest of a man from Glen Cove, N.Y., on homicide charges in connection with a fatal six-car crash on Long Island, gave the incorrect name in some copies for the town where the crash occurred. It is Old Brookville, not Old Brookfield.

headline: Hardly Shocking, Derby Winner Street Sense Is Favorite
text: BALTIMORE, May 16  There is a field of nine signed on for the 132nd running of the Preakness Stakes, but eight horses are running for second-place money behind the Kentucky Derby winner, Street Sense. Or at least that is what the trainers and owners here at the post-position draw were suggesting Wednesday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about the Maison Tropicale, a small house built in 1951 by the French designer Jean Prouvé that is on display in Long Island City, Queens, pending an auction in June, referred incorrectly to another Maison Tropicale at the Centre Pompidou in Paris. It is in fact already on exhibit; the exhibition is not pending.

headline: A Suspected Serial Arsonist Rattles Nerves in Newport
text: NEWPORT, R.I., May 16 — Volunteers are spending nights patrolling the grounds of the 281-year-old Trinity Episcopal Church here. The Hill Association, a neighborhood group, is urging residents to watch for suspicious people in the shadows. Bruce Rader now makes sure to keep a light on in his backyard.

headline: Higher Taxes Rejected in Oregon, and Counties Will Trim Services
text: SEATTLE, May 16  Voters in southwestern Oregon on Tuesday rejected proposals to increase local taxes to offset the loss of federal subsidies.

headline: Big Storm Helps Shrink New Jersey Wildfire
text: A powerful thunderstorm that drenched much of the Northeast last night helped shrink a huge wildfire that has burned through 14,000 acres of pine forest in southern New Jersey since Tuesday.

headline: Computer Sales Lead H.P. to Strong Revenue
text: Led by surging computer sales, Hewlett-Packard reported a 12.8 percent increase today in its quarterly revenues.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: Afghans Say Gunfire From NATO Soldiers Wounded 5 Civilians
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, May 16 — NATO soldiers driving through this southern city shot and wounded five civilians late Tuesday, local residents and police officials said Wednesday. The spokeswoman for the NATO forces, Lt. Col. Angela Billings, said, though, that they had no information that such shootings had occurred.

headline: U.S.  Ambassador to Iraq Ready to Talk to Iran
text: BAGHDAD, May 17 — The United States ambassador to Iraq said today that he was “ready to sit down” any time with Iranian officials for talks on ways of stabilizing Iraq.

headline: Pants in a Twist? Try Some Knickers
text: URBAN cyclists can’t win. Snug-fitting Lycra shorts offer a padded chamois and seams that don’t chafe, but lack style. Regular pants with rolled-up cuffs may be more fashionable but can become clammy for anything longer than a short ride.

headline: For Ochoa, Being a Role Model Comes With the Territory
text: CLIFTON, N.J., May 16  When Lorena Ochoa left Mexico seven years ago to attend college in the United States, she gave up a cocoon of familiarity for long bouts of homesickness.

headline: Mr. Right, It Turns Out, Does Not Take Classes
text: AFTER more than two years of disheartening online dating, Charlotte Kullen resolved to spend less time pursuing men and more time pursuing her hobbies. She plunged into tennis, running, sailing, horseback riding, fitness boot camp and scuba diving classes, assuming that somewhere between the situps and the strapping on of fins she might meet some eligible prospects.

headline: A Fire-Breathing Laptop Powered Up for Entertainment
text: If you nickname your company’s new laptop the Dragon, it had better be impressive. The Hewlett-Packard Pavilion HDX lacks wings and scales, but it does have a 20-inch screen and can handle HD DVD discs and HDMI video.

headline: Britain: Brown’s Only Challenger Pulls Out
text: Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, cemented his bid to replace Tony Blair as Labor Party leader and prime minister when he steps down next month. Mr. Brown, left, the party’s overwhelming favorite, had faced the outside possibility of a symbolic challenge from John McDonnell, a leader of the left wing. Late yesterday, Mr. McDonnell conceded that he had been unable to muster sufficient backing from party lawmakers for his challenge, leaving Mr. Brown as the only candidate. The final tally of support for Mr. Brown among the Labor Party legislators is to be announced today.

headline: Cuban Music, Good for Dancing, and for Thinking About as Well
text: Cuban music can withstand endless revisions, and the singer-songwriter Jose Conde is taking his turn, as he suggested at Joe’s Pub on Tuesday night. Born in Miami to Cuban parents, Mr. Conde has been working in New York for the last 10 years, slowly formulating a kind of Afro-Cuban music with an enlarged frame. It now brings together son, guajira, guaracha with New Orleans funk, Nigerian Afrobeat, South American cumbia, James Brown rhythms, Haitian compas, Brazilian afoxe, New York City boogaloo and even jam-band stuff predicated on electric guitars as much as hand drums.

headline: Fire Spotlights Concerns of Living Near Fighter Jets
text: As hundreds of firefighters battled for the second day to control a huge wildfire touched off by a flare at a military firing range on the edge of the Pine Barrens in southern New Jersey, some of those who live near the blaze questioned yesterday whether more safety precautions should be put in place.

headline: New Producer at ‘Nightly News’ Seeks to Regain NBC Dominance
text: Alexandra Wallace, who got the equivalent of a battlefield commission when she was named executive producer of “NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams” two months ago, keeps her plans for the broadcast on a to-do list streaked with tight scribbles from a black, felt-tip marker. She calls it her “crazy person list,” and she is continually cutting and pasting it, as if it were a worn map to buried treasure. (Mr. Williams has another analogy: “It’s like her blankie,” he says.)

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Tuesday about clashes between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza referred incorrectly in some copies to the unidentified Palestinian shown standing in the burned offices of Fatah in Gaza City. The person is a woman.

headline: Pakistan Judicial Crisis Adds to Pressure on Media
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 16 — Legal and political wrangling over the suspension of the chief justice of Pakistan’s Supreme Court by President Pervez Musharraf appears to be leading to new pressures on the media, news organizations and media advocacy groups say.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. How can I minimize the risk of lead poisoning from old painted furniture?

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,390 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans this week:

headline: Secret Ingredients: Their Husbands
text: JO WOOD, wife of the Rolling Stones guitarist Ron Wood, spent 30 years touring with the band, and apart from being a mother, her only occupation was helping to dress her husband for his shows. Now that their children are out of the house, she has launched Jo Wood Organics, a line of oils, creams and candles that she sells in New York at Bergdorf Goodman.

headline: Feeling Short of Real Heroes, Thus Fond of a Fake One
text: PLZEN, Czech Republic — Zdenek Sverak, dressed in a professorial gray suit with a red club tie, nodded a greeting to the sold-out crowd in a theater here and began his lecture about Jara da Cimrman, the greatest Czech of all time.

headline: Brooklyn: Principals Ratify Contract
text: The union representing New York City school principals and assistant principals voted overwhelmingly yesterday to ratify a contract deal with New York City. The new contract provides raises of more than 23 percent and also establishes a new executive principal position that will pay bonuses of up to $25,000 a year to principals who agree to work for up to three years in a troubled school. The union, the Council of School Supervisors and Administrators, said that the ratification vote was 3,633 to 266. The deal, which is retroactive to July 1, 2003, and runs through March 5, 2010, will increase the starting salary of elementary school principals to $123,456 from $100,242. The maximum base pay for high school principals will rise to $154,295 from $125,282. Starting salaries for assistant principals who work all year rather than just the 10 months that schools are in session will rise to $108,869 from $88,398, and their maximum salary will be $130,100, up from $108,869.

headline: Bradley Takes Reins as Coach of U.S. Team
text: Bob Bradley  tall, slender and plain talking  shrugged off the long process that ultimately led to his selection yesterday as the head coach of the United States men’s national soccer team. And he said his style would remain unchanged as he took charge through the 2010 World Cup.

headline: Gas May Have Harmed Troops, Scientists Say
text: WASHINGTON, May 16 — Scientists working with the Defense Department have found evidence that a low-level exposure to sarin nerve gas — the kind experienced by more than 100,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf war of 1991 — could have caused lasting brain deficits in former service members.

headline: Unfriendly Views on U.S.-Backed Arabic TV
text: WASHINGTON, May 16 — Toward the end of a Congressional hearing on Wednesday on American efforts to win more popular support in the Arab world, Representative Gary L. Ackerman, Democrat of New York, got sidetracked.

headline: Leaving Her Mark, Sometimes With Tape
text: The art industry requires that at least one young artist be shot into the stratosphere every few years. The painter Dana Schutz was the choice in 2002, when she was in her mid-20s and barely out of school. She’s been producing and selling like mad ever since. Last year she had a museum career retrospective. It covered four years.

headline: Yankees Are Working on a Settlement With Swindal
text: CHICAGO, May 16  The Yankees are negotiating a buyout of the general partner Steve Swindal in which the team would pay him about $5 million for what he is owed contractually in exchange for his leaving the organization.

headline: Follow the Bouncing Ball — to Oden or Durant?
text: It’s time for the N.B.A. draft lottery, when the dregs of the league gaze to the heavens — and watch the Ping-Pong balls flutter — in hope of a quick fix. For this go-round, coming on Tuesday, one question hovers over the proceedings: Greg Oden or Kevin Durant? A dominating big man or a perimeter wizard who can also excel inside?

headline: Sony Expects Recovery After Big Quarterly Loss
text: TOKYO, May 16 — Sony posted its worst quarterly loss in four years on Wednesday, but said strong television sales and hit movies like “Spider-Man 3” will put it back on course by year-end when it expects a record profit.

headline: 19th-Century Vision of India, With Room for Two Ballets
text: There is nothing quite like “La Bayadère.” That may be a good thing, given the foolishness that jostles for predominance with exquisite classicism in this spectacle of late-19th-century ballet. That American Ballet Theater chose the work to open its spring season proper on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House can be seen as a statement of belief. That is, for all the adventurousness of its repertory over the years, Ballet Theater has been one of the world’s great classical troupes. “La Bayadère” provides a bridge from the narrative-heavy extravaganzas of the mid-19th century to the pure-dance choreography of George Balanchine, an heir, after all, to Russian ballet tradition through his early training.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Monday with a sports article about the reaction of a community in New Hampshire to the deaths of a police officer and a cousin of the ski racer Bode Miller in a violent confrontation misspelled the cousin’s given name. It was Liko Kenney, not Leko. The error also appeared in the article in some copies.

headline: Soup Up Your Everyday Computer With a Blu-ray Drive
text: PCs, like automobiles, can become something entirely different with just a few tweaks and additions. Take the Pioneer BDC-2202. Today your PC is just a DVD-playing, file-storing computer. Tomorrow, with the help of this Blu-ray drive, it becomes a high-def hot rod.

headline: Racecourse Experience Could Decide Preakness
text: BALTIMORE, May 16 — Mario Pino knows almost everything about Pimlico Race Course. He knows every nook, cranny, nuance and trick to get into the winner’s circle, something he has done quite often in the 28 years he has been around Maryland racing.

headline: All Cooped Up in a Manhattan Co-op
text: LET me explain why my 12-year-old had a chicken coop in her bedroom.

headline: With Hussein Gone, Other Iraqi Trials Lose Impact
text: BAGHDAD, May 16 — When the man Iraqis know as Chemical Ali made a final plea of innocence to the Iraqi High Tribunal last week, the court’s public galleries were all but empty, and there was not a single Iraqi or foreign reporter on hand.

headline: Sales Practices at Dell Draw New York Suit
text: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, announced yesterday that his office had filed a lawsuit against Dell Inc. and its Dell Financial Services unit, accusing them of deceptive business practices and of failing to provide adequate customer service.

headline: Biggest Building Site in Manhattan Up for Auction
text: It is the largest building site left in Manhattan, 26 acres on the Far West Side, where the Bloomberg administration envisions the equivalent of five Empire State Buildings rising on $1 billion worth of concrete columns over bustling railyards.

headline: Students Gain Only Marginally on Test of U.S. History
text: Federal officials reported yesterday that students in 4th, 8th and 12th grades had scored modestly higher on an American history test than five years earlier, although more than half of high school seniors still showed poor command of basic facts like the effect of the cotton gin on the slave economy or the causes of the Korean War.

headline: Shimmering Anthems to the Apocalypse
text: Everything blurred when the Silversun Pickups played a sold-out Webster Hall on Tuesday night. Brian Aubert’s guitar playing was a haze of tremolo strumming, distortion and reverb, while his voice was high and hoarse, all frayed edges. Nikki Monninger’s bass lines stayed low, providing as much rumble as tone, and Joe Lester’s keyboards were usually just a looming, amorphous texture. The songs’ direction was set by clear, terse melodies, and their momentum came from Christopher Guanlao’s drumming, with his hefty beat topped by washes of cymbals.

headline: Queens Man Arraigned in Guard’s Injury
text: A Springfield Gardens man was arraigned in Queens Criminal Court yesterday on charges that he robbed a clothing store on Monday and critically injured a security guard during the getaway, prosecutors said. The man, Philip J. Zabriskie, 53, of 133rd Avenue, was charged with first-degree robbery and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Zabriskie is charged with robbing the Pretty Girl clothing store in Jamaica on Monday afternoon, Mr. Brown said. When Mr. Zabriskie and two accomplices tried to flee, a guard, Awali Khouroupra, tried to stop them by holding onto the hood of their minivan, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Zabriskie is charged with knocking Mr. Khouroupra to the pavement as he drove off, causing a severe head injury. Mr. Khouroupra is on life support.

headline: Daimler and Cerberus to Invest $1.2 Billion in Pension Fund at Chrysler
text: DETROIT, May 16 — DaimlerChrysler and Cerberus Capital Management, which is buying the Chrysler Group, have agreed to invest $1.2 billion in the pension fund of Chrysler workers under terms of the sale, the United Automobile Workers union said Wednesday.

headline: G.M. May Sell a Unit
text: General Motors may sell its midsize truck business as it focuses on making profits from cars and light trucks.

headline: China Urges U.S. Not to Punish All Food Exporters
text: SHANGHAI, May 16  China has urged the United States not to take punitive action against this country’s exporters of agricultural goods even though Chinese officials have determined that two Chinese companies intentionally contaminated American pet food ingredients with an industrial chemical.

headline: Perhaps for God, England and St. George, but Not Harry
text: LONDON, May 16  He had been cast as the warrior prince, the royal who, like a Shakespearean namesake, would lead his troops “unto the breach” of southern Iraq.

headline: A Reality Show Confronts the Reality of Real Estate
text: LOS ANGELES, May 16 — So, like, after Daddy died and things stayed rocky with Mom, it was definitely time for a change: new husband, new baby, new business! And why not put it on TV!

headline: A: The Theater at the Garden. Q: What Is a WaMu, and Where Is It Found?
text: What would a man of letters  Nabokov, say  make of it?

headline: The Dream of Absolute Quiet
text: JONATHAN PRAGER is a 40-something Manhattan comedian and singer whose life experience and worldview, like those of many other comedians, are semitragic. Certainly, his quest to find a quiet home has been laced with pathos.

headline: Correction
text: An entry in the Skin Deep column last week, about “Beauty on the Vine,” a play about plastic surgery, referred incorrectly to an annual list of the celebrity features most in demand among the patients of Drs. Toby G. Mayer and Richard W. Fleming, surgeons in Beverly Hills. Jessica Alba’s nose and Scarlett Johansson’s lips were among this year’s three most popular for each of those facial features; neither was the most popular.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Tuesday about clashes between Hamas and Fatah in Gaza referred incorrectly in some copies to the unidentified Palestinian shown standing in the burned offices of Fatah in Gaza City. The person is a woman. (Go to Article)

headline: U.S. Championship, Day 2: Three Take the Lead
text: Although it is still early, grandmasters Ildar Ibragimov, Alexander Shabalov and Alexander Stripunsky hold the lead in the Frank Berry United States Championship being played in Stillwater, Okla. Each player has two points after winning their second round games. The games can be seen live or replayed  here  at Monroi.com.

headline: A Win in the Windy City
text: Well, the Yankees won the nightcap, 8-1, and all is well again… for the moment. They’re 18-20, and as Derek Jeter said, their next game starts “in about 45 minutes.”

headline: Art Reflecting Life
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

text: Additional images from "Shrek the Third," including new characters.

text: Chalet

headline: Luc Besson Movie Posters
In Bid for Better Care, Surgery With a Warranty
text: Taking a cue from the makers of TVs, washing machines and other products, Geisinger Health System in central Pennsylvania essentially guarantees its workmanship with a 90-day warranty.

headline: Everyday America
text: Images from "Biographical Landscape: The Photography of Stephen Shore, 1969-79" at the International Center of Photography.

headline: Text: Statements by World Bank and Wolfowitz
text: Following is the text of statements released by the World Bank's executive directors and Paul D. Wolfowitz announcing his resignation.

headline: The Goal Is Superimmunity; The Status, Almost There
text: Green tech may capturing all the headlines in venture capital deals these days, but a broad renaissance in vaccine research and development is nonetheless capturing the attention (and cash) of V.C.’s and big-name charities like the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

headline: Walgreen to Buy Operator of In-Store Health Clinics
text: Walgreen said Wednesday that it planned to buy Take Care Health Systems, which operates in-store health clinics, as it moves to offer more patient services in its drugstores. The terms of the all-cash deal, which is expected to close next week, were not disclosed.

headline: ValueAct Prevails Over Acxiom
text: Acxiom, a data-management company, is being acquired by two investment firms and will be taken private, the chief executive of Acxiom, Charles D. Morgan, announced Wednesday. In a deal worth $2.25 billion, a partnership being formed by the equity firms ValueAct Capital and Silver Lake Partners will pay $27.10 a share in cash, Mr. Morgan said.

headline: Executive Pay Proposals Rejected at AMR
text: Shareholders of AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, rejected at the annual meeting on Wednesday two proposals aimed at setting controls on executive pay. The Allied Pilots Association had sponsored a resolution to give stockholders an advisory vote on executive compensation each year. Votes representing about 59 percent of AMR’s shares went against the proposal.

headline: Canadian Pension Fund in Chilean Water Deal
text: The Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan said it agreed to buy into two water supply and distribution companies in Chile, in what it called its first infrastructure investments in South America. Financial terms were not disclosed. Teachers’ will acquire Aguas Nuevo Sur Maule and a 50 percent stake in Empresa de Servicios Sanitarios del Bio-Bio.

headline: Edwards Discloses Income From Work for Hedge Fund
text: Presidential contender John Edwards earned $479,512 in 2006 for his work advising Fortress Investment Group, a hedge fund and private equity firm, and sold several million dollars in assets to personally invest in Fortress funds, according to personal financial disclosure forms released Wednesday by the Federal Election Commission.

headline: Financial Angels Band Together
text: While the sums that angel investors typically provide to hopeful start-ups may be dwarfed by the investments that their later-stage colleagues drum up, their returns are far from bite-sized. In particular, one group of angel investors — individuals who put up seed money for fledgling companies based on a smile and a shoeshine — is seeing its numbers and importance growing.

headline: J.P. Morgan Axes China Fund Manager
text: J.P. Morgan‘s asset management joint venture in China announced on Wednesday that it had fired a senior fund manager who is under investigation by a Chinese regulator for allegedly manipulating share prices. China International Fund Management, which is 49 percent owned by J.P. Morgan Asset Management, said in a statement on Wednesday that it had dismissed Tang Jian, the manager of one of the company’s main equity funds.

headline: Plaza Owner Buys Las Vegas Casino
text: The owner of New York’s Plaza hotel announced plans Wednesday to buy the New Frontier hotel-casino on the Las Vegas Strip and replace it with a $5 billion multiuse complex.

headline: Regulators Serve Biovail Founder
text: Just days after the Securities and Exchange Commission hit Canadian pharmaceutical company Biovail with a so-called Wells notice, the company’s embattled founder, Eugene Melnyk, revealed Wednesday that he also received one.

headline: Ex-Goldman Head Calls Wall St. Pay ‘Shocking’
text: This is bound to be creating some buzz down on 85 Broad: John C. Whitehead, who retired as co-chairman of Goldman Sachs in 1984, called current compensation levels at the giant securities firm “shocking” and said he was “appalled” at Wall Street pay in general. In an interview with Bloomberg News, Mr. Whitehead, 85, urged his former employer to curb bonuses, even if it means losing some valued employees. “I would take the chance of losing a lot of them and let them see what happens when the hedge fund bubble, as I see it, ends,” he told Bloomberg earlier this week.

headline: G.M. May Dump Midsize Trucks
text: General Motors may sell its midsize truck business as it focuses on making profits from cars and light trucks. And, according to The Flint Journal, Navistar International might be interested in a deal for the unit. “We are considering options for our medium-duty truck business to better position the unit for growth,” a spokeswoman, Melisa Tezanos, told Bloomberg News.

headline: New Century Unit Receives Second Bid
text: New Century Financial, the largest subprime lender in bankruptcy, received another offer for its loan-servicing unit that tops the initial $133.3 million bid by Carrington Capital Management, a lawyer said. Company attorney Suzzanne Uhland told Bankruptcy Court Judge Kevin J. Carey in Wilmington, Del., that the new offer makes it possible to hold an auction for the unit, considered New Century’s most valuable asset.

headline: Boston Scientific in Talks to Settle Guidant Suit, Report Says
text: Boston Scientific is in talks to settle 1,350 product liability suits it inherited when it bought Guidant last year, the Wall Street Journal reported. The suits allege that Guidant sold several models of implantable defibrillators after learning of defects in the devices that caused them to fail, the paper said.

headline: A Rosy I.P.O. for Belle International
text: Belle International Holdings and shareholders raised HK$8.7 billion, or $1.1 billion, in the largest initial public offering abroad by a Chinese consumer company, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
text: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Like Buffett, Icahn’s Working on the Railroads
text: Carl C. Icahn has bought a $122 million stake in CSX, joining Warren Buffett and TCI Fund Management in purchasing railroad shares. Mr. Icahn held 2.68 million shares of Jacksonville, Fla.-based CSX, the nation’s third-largest railroad, as of March 31, according to filings Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway and hedge fund TCI also detailed their purchases in the industry, which they disclosed in the past month.

headline: Investors Bet That More Bidders Will Eye Bausch & Lomb
text: Will more bidders emerge for Bausch & Lomb, the troubled eye care firm that said Wednesday it had accepted a $4.5 billion takeover offer from Warburg Pincus?

headline: Funds Seek Break-Up of Britain’s Prudential
text: Yet another group of hedge fund shareholders is on the move, this time urging Prudential Chief Officer Mark Tucker to break up Britain’s second-biggest insurer. New Star Asset Management Group, Jupiter Asset Management and Canada Life of London, which together oversee about $91 billion, say Prudential’s British division is dragging down faster-growing units in Asia and the United Sates. Earnings in Britain fell 7.9 percent in 2006, while profit in Asia jumped 20 percent, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Kodak Printers
text: It's war in the world of inkjet printers and cartridges as Kodak gets into the business.

headline: Carlyle to Offer Rival Valentino Bid, Report Says
text: The Carlyle Group is planning to go head to head with European rival Permira Advisers for control of Valentino Fashion Group, the Italian company that controls Hugo Boss, according to Reuters.

headline: Clinton on Climate Change
text: Bill Clinton talked to Andrew C. Revkin after announcing his new plan to fight climate change at the Large Cities Climate Summit in New York last May.

headline: S.E.C. Poised to Set Course on Business
text: In the coming weeks, the Securities and Exchange Commission must decide a series of critical issues worth billions of dollars to the business community, from how far to cut back accounting rules to whether it should side with investment banks or shareholders in a Supreme Court case.

headline: Daimler, Cerberus to Invest $1.2 Billion in Chrysler’s Pension Fund
text: DaimlerChrysler and Cerberus Capital Management, which is buying the Chrysler Group, have agreed to invest $1.2 billion in the pension fund of Chrysler workers under terms of the sale, the United Automobile Workers union said Wednesday.

headline: Chrysler Sale Unavoidable, Zetsche Says
text: On Monday evening at Chrysler’s offices in Auburn Hills, Mich., Dieter Zetsche held what is likely to be his last, and most poignant, session of “Ask Dr. Z.” Mr. Zetsche, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, became famous last summer as that affable German fellow with a walrus mustache, who answered questions about cars on a Chrysler Web site.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
text: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Is Alwaleed Sizing Up InterContinental?
text: When Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal hits New York to check up on his Citigroup stake, he might have another investment to consider. The Telegraph reported Wednesday that Saudi billionaire was rumored to be making a takeover play for InterContinental Hotels Group, whose stately New York flagship, The New York Post notes, is just steps from the Park Avenue headquarters of Citigroup.

headline: For Black and Kravis, Parallel Paths Diverge Sharply
text: Until recently, Marie-Josee Kravis, the economist, charity fund-raiser and wife of private equity bigwig Henry R. Kravis, and Conrad Black, the one-time chief of Hollinger International, on whose board Ms. Kravis once sat, pursued a similar path.

headline: Quattrone Raises Profile With Museum Post
text: He’s back.

headline: 2008: When Elephants Attack
text: It doesn’t take a brilliant strategist to suggest that candidates try to gloss over unfavorable parts of their pasts, but “one of the striking features of the 2008 campaigns is the pungency of the various elephants in the various rooms” of the leading candidates, writes The Times’s Mark Leibovich.

headline: Inspecting the Generals
text: – Tobin Harshaw

headline: Rolling Into History on the Rails of Korea
text: The two Koreas took a long-planned step towards reconciliation today when trains crossed the demilitarized zone for the first time since the armistice that ended the fighting in the Korean War and created the zone in 1953.

headline: Masters of the Brush
text: Images from "Ike Taiga and Tokuyama Gyokuran: Japanese Masters of the Brush" at the Philadelphia Museum.

headline: Blackstone to Acquire Alliance Data
text: Blackstone Capital Partners said on Thursday it would buy Alliance Data Systems, a provider of transaction, credit and marketing services, for $7.8 billion including debt. It will pay $81.75 per share in cash, which it said was a premium of about 30 percent over Alliance Data’s closing share price of $62.96 on May 16 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Sarbanes-Oxley Compliance Costs Drop 23%, Study Finds
text: The costs of complying with Sarbanes-Oxley governance regulations dropped 23 percent last year to $2.9 million for big companies, the second large decline in a row, the Financial Times reported, citing a survey by Financial Executives International of 200 companies.

headline: Blackstone to Buy Alliance Data in $7.8 Billion Deal
text: Alliance Data Systems, which administers credit card programs for major retailers, said Thursday it agreed to be acquired by Blackstone Group in a deal it valued at $7.8 billion, including assumed debt. Blackstone will pay $81.75 in cash for each share of Alliance Data, about 30 percent more than the stock’s Wednesday closing price. If approved by shareholders, the buyout would end Alliance’s six-year run as a public company and put it back in the hands of a private equity firm. Alliance was formed in 1996 by Welsh Carson Anderson Stowe, which combined two businesses it bought from J.C. Penney and Limited Brands.

headline: Does Pitching Need a Hand?
text: The cry from major league teams for pitching help has rarely seemed so full-throated. Out of necessity, teams must rely on journeymen and young, untested prospects — like the Mets did with Mike Pelfrey, now in the minors after going 0-5 with the big club. At PLAY, we were talking about how serious a problem the dearth of quality pitching is for Major League Baseball, and whether officials need to somehow address it.

headline: Family Thanksgiving Trip in the Caribbean
text: My brother turns 40 in a few months and we’d like to take a collective vacation to a not-too-expensive Caribbean beach spot during the week of Thanksgiving. Can you recommend a place that is not too hard to get to (parents in their 70s, so not a plane to small plane to ferry, please) and can deal with little kids (mine, ages 11, 9, 6)? None of us require organized activities. We might enjoy the option to take a day trip or two, if there’s a town or jungle nearby. Mostly, we just want a beautiful, relaxing beach place where we can enjoy each other. My parents live in Jacksonville, FL, my family lives in Brooklyn, and my brother and girlfriend are in Albuquerque, NM.

headline: Simplifying Diabetes Shots
text: I’ve been writing this week about the inspirational finalists in the Invent Now competition for amateur inventors. Turns out the second-prize winner ($10,000) was born, as so many inventions are, out of a real-world need.

headline: TV Upfronts: CW Takes the Stage
text: The Pussycat Dolls are tramping it up onstage at Madison Square Garden; the ad girls in their DVF wraps are sucking on buckets of Jamba Juice; and various chipper kids in white are wearing “free to be helpful” T-shirts, just begging to show you to your seat.

headline: TechTarget Raises $75 Million in I.P.O.
text: TechTarget, a venture-backed company that produces technology-focused Web sites, magazines and conferences, priced its initial public offering late Wednesday at $13 per share, in the middle of the expected range. The 7.7-million-share offering, representing a stake of about 20 percent in the company, included 6.4 million new shares and 1.3 million sold by existing shareholders. The company said it expected to raise about $75.2 million in the stock sale.

headline: Your Comments on my Bush-Wolfowitz Column
text: I’m sorry I’m late putting this up — I’ve been in a plane flying to Hong Kong all these hours, and I forgot to put this up before I got in the plane. But, in any case, please post your comments on my Thursday column about the way the U.S.’s position in the world community is beginning to resemble Wolfowitz’s position at the World Bank.

headline: Reactions to R.N.C. Surveillance
text: The Web is abuzz with reactions today to the release yesterday of 600 pages of documents detailing Police Department surveillance before and during the 2004 Republican National Convention. The Times, which has an article today on the release, has prepared an index with PDF images of all the released records.The response to the new records has varied greatly. Some samples:

headline: Advertising Group WPP Takes 24/7 Real Media
text: A week after confirming that it hired an investment bank to explore “strategic alternatives,” 24/7 Real Media has decided that a sale is the way to go. The company, which provides online marketing services, said it agreed to be bought by advertising and marketing firm WPP Group for $11.75 per share in cash, or about $649 million net of cash acquired. The sale of 24/7 is just the latest in a string of deals involving online advertising companies: Google recently bought DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, and Yahoo  paid $680 million for the part of Right Media that it didn’t already own.

headline: Green Isn’t Clean In the Laundry Room
text: In the battle against global warming, there is no more beloved phrase in Washington than “energy efficiency.” Mandating energy-efficient appliances costs nothing in the budget and sounds painless to voters. Who could be in favor of energy inefficiency? Congress is working on legislation now to tighten standards further — and touting all the money that consumers will save.

headline: Monitor on L.A.P.D. and Protests
text: Of all the opinions raised by the Los Angeles Police Department’s handling of an immigration protest early this month, one carries particular weight.

headline: Recent Openings
text: New shows in New York include "Passing Strange" and "Memory."

headline: Deal Makers Expect to Stay Busy, Survey Says
text: Last year’s record for global deal activity could be a short-lived one, if the predictions of a group of deal makers surveyed by Mergermarket turn out to be correct. Many of the bankers, buyout professionals and chief executives said in the survey that they expect to see continued strength in 2007 in both mergers and acquisitions and leveraged buyouts. In fact, more than half of the respondents are looking for another increase this year in M&A among large-cap companies. Most of the rest believe the level of deals will remain about the same as last year’s. Just four percent said they expect deal activity to recede.

headline: TV Upfronts: America’s Next Top Avatar
text: Dawn Ostroff, the CW’s president of entertainment, announces the pickup of “The Search for the Next Pussycat Doll.” She’s in shiva black and pearls, though she also appears on the screen, turned via photoshop into an ab-proud Pussycat dancer. This is the second time that a CBS-linked network has turned a female executive into a centerfold using tech wizardry. The idea that you might live a separate virtual existence as a size 4 or 0 — without having to forfeit the pleasures and advantages of actual flesh-and-blood life — might, I’m not kidding, be enough to draw female viewers to the CW, with its sexy modelly gossipy shows.

headline: TV Upfronts: Come Back, Marissa, All Is Forgiven
text: The “O.C.” of N.Y.C., “Gossip Girl,” is on the big screen. The kids are rich and mean, and they party and steal each other’s boyfriends.

headline: Venture Capitalists: Our Carried Interest is Different
text: Carried interest works in the venture capital business pretty much the same way it works in private equity. But as Congress reconsiders how this income source is taxed, venture capitalists are insisting that for them, it’s a world apart. It’s all part of an effort “to escape taxation,” Adam Lashinsky writes in Fortune magazine.

headline: A Home That Heats and Cools Itself
text: This week, on my blog, I’ve been writing about the inventions I saw at last week’s Modern Marvels/Invent Now finals. About 25,000 inventors from all walks of life entered this annual contest, which is run by the History Channel and the National Inventors Hall of Fame. I was among the six judges who were asked to declare a winner from among the 25 finalists still standing.

headline: TV Upfronts: What the Internet Is
text: Dawn Ostroff, who’s running a brisk show, gets into digital. It’s all O.K.: content wraps, avatars, shows to which viewers contribute video. (“Content wraps”? Whatever.)

headline: TV Upfronts: The CW on Safari
text: I’m excited about “Life Is Wild,” because I loved “The Wilderness Family” and the grim “Mosquito Coast,” and I basically just love freaky dads who take their families off the grid.

headline: TV Upfronts: The Lessons of the Raj
text: “Aliens in America” looked lousy until Adhir Kalyan appeared, and stole a scene — and seemingly the whole pilot (remember, we only see a clip here). As a Pakistani exchange student, he brooks the responses of random American kids to his ethnicity and religion when a wonderfully unctuous middle-school teacher coordinates a “discussion” of their anger at him for 9/11. As a set piece, it’s an almost perfect send-up of classrooms’ being used as encounter groups, as well as the frank contempt that public-school teachers often have for exchange students.

headline: TV Upfronts: Geeks and Sweeps
text: Press conference. “Nerds are really in right now,” Dawn Ostroff is saying, by way of explaining why “Big Bang Theory” on CBS, which is about two geeks and a girl, won’t “dilute the power” of Ashton Kutcher’s reality show, “Beauty and the Geek,” on the CW.

headline: Opie and Anthony Fans Bite Back
text: Unhappy with XM Radio’s decision to suspend Opie and Anthony, fans are canceling subscriptions by the hundreds, smashing satellite radio receivers and posting tons of angry comments. There are also a reports of companies pulling ads.

headline: TV Upfronts: “Gilmore Girls” R.I.P.
text: We’re now talking about the “Gilmore Girls” finale. Ms. Ostroff mentions “Lauren and Alexis,” and how great they are, and I always feel like whatever you think of the war — the direction of the show and its vision — everyone always says they support the troops, Lauren and Alexis, Lorelai and Rory.

headline: Ouch!  That’s Speedy!
text: Anyone want to speculate on how Scott Speed is taking all this talk about him being rejected from the Toro Rosso team and replaced by a Sebastien or a Sebastian? (Bourdais or Vettel.) Just check out his time at Paul Ricard today. It cannot be compared with the times of the previous two days as the track configuration was changed. But here are the results:

headline: Questions and Answers: Immigration
text: [ From the editors: The 681 comments and counting, posted in response to an item on illegal immigration, leave no doubt that readers of The Lede have strong opinions on the subject.

headline: Content May Be King, but the King Is Also Content
text: Today we visit the realms where YouTube is banned, or at least kept on a very short leash:

headline: Charges May Loom in Stock-Loan Investigation
text: Federal prosecutors may soon charge “a number” of current and former employees of prominent securities firms with taking part in a kickback scheme involving loans of stocks and bonds to short sellers, according to BusinessWeek, which cites undisclosed sources. If they do, it could shed some light on a shadowy but profitable corner of Wall Street. BusinessWeek’s Matthew Goldstein writes that the securities-lending business generates about $10 billion in fees for investment banks each year.

headline: Greetings From Winter Haven, Err, Shea Stadium
text: Bleary-eyed, the Mets reported to Shea Stadium this morning not long after they left. On his way in, Billy Wagner tapped Jason Vargas, today’s starter, on the shoulder and said, “Eight and two-thirds” innings. Everyone, I’m sure, would agree with him.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Stock Market?
text: Dwindling polar ice caps are a good reason to worry. But should the declining number of publicly traded U.S. companies be cause for concern?

headline: Podcast: Three Little Words
text: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

headline: ‘Yippie’ Denies Pie-Throwing Intent
text: Aron Kay, a k a “Yippie Pie Man,” is not surprised that he was among the many individuals and groups monitored by the Police Department in the months before the Republican National Convention in 2004.

headline: Immigration Scuffle
text: The Senate has reached a compromise on immigration reform. The blogosphere, naturally, has not.

headline: Obama on Clinton’s War Views
text: In polite but direct remarks, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois took on the Clintons over Iraq this morning, delivering the sort of punch that might always tempt the famous bare knuckles of Clinton operatives. But, by mid-afternoon today, the Clinton camp was responding coolly.

headline: Pin the Tail on Iraq
text: Readers respond to Frank Rich’s May 6 column, “Is Condi Hiding the Smoking Gun?.”

headline: McCain in New York
text: It was an uptown/downtown day of Manhattan fundraisers for Senator John McCain – with a jaunt back down to Washington in the middle of the day, as the Senate reached an agreement on the contentious immigration bill.

headline: In Hindsight, Reagan Not So Worthy
text: Readers respond to Frank Rich’s May 13 column, “Earth to G.O.P.: The Gipper Is Dead.”

headline: Bank Street President Resigning
text: Augusta Souza Kappner, who has been president of the Bank Street College of Education since 1995, will step down at the end of the 2007-08 academic year.Dr. Kappner, known almost universally as Gussie, was the lone mayoral appointee on the Panel for Education Policy three years ago to vote against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to end social promotion — and distributed research to other panel members showing that, despite their political popularity, policies requiring struggling student to repeat a year do not help their educational outcomes.

headline: TV Upfronts: Let’s Start Fox’s Family Feud!
text: “The following takes place between 4 and 5pm.”

headline: Obama Videos Get Closed-Captioning
text: Web video is helping all sorts of people get connected to the political process — but some have still been left out. For the deaf and hard-of-hearing, YouTube hasn’t really done a whole lot of good — until now.

headline: TV Upfronts: Sisters and ‘Starting Over’
text: Amy Sherman-Palladino, who made the late “Gilmore Girls” for the late WB, now springs “The Return of Jezebel James” on us. It’s about sisters. One needs, I guess, a surrogate to have a baby for her; the players are Parker Posey and Lauren Ambrose. Oh how I want to say it looks good. But it does not.

headline: From the High Court to the Ivory Tower
text: Clerking for the Supreme Court is not part of the traditional career path to become a college president. But when Stephen J. Friedman becomes interim president of Pace University in June, he will join at least two other university presidents in New York who have traveled that route.

headline: TV Upfronts: Turning Down the Razzle-Dazzle
text: Fox upfront. Last year’s at the Armory was a bust: hot, glitchy and loud with scary, bad jokes. (Hi Brad Garrett!)

headline: Third M-Tel Masters: Second Half Begins With Three Decisive Games
text: While most of the country’s best players have been competing in the Frank Berry United States Championship, Gata Kamsky has been in Sofia, Bulgaria, playing in what has become one of the elite events on the calendar: The M-Tel Masters.

headline: TV Upfronts: The Search for the Next Karen Black
text: With Robert Altman no longer with us, it’s time to remake “Nashville” as fluff — except that Fox’s reality series “Nashville,” by the big minds and hearts behind MTV’s “Laguna Beach,” looks pretty great.

headline: TV Upfronts: Selling Soap
text: “K’ville” is a PG “Wire,” just as “Cane” on CBS is a PG “Sopranos.” Film actors, cops and bad neighborhoods with a down-and-out, Tom Waits-style soundtrack. But “redemptive.” And shot in New Orleans, so it’s got that highly pleasurable guilt-trip factor. Looks like a possible hit.

headline: McCain Stops By the Senate
text: John McCain made an appearance in the Senate today. Yes, at least on Capitol Hill, this is a newsworthy item.

headline: Lack of Healthy Food in Harlem
text: Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson just issued a statement urging the Legislature to act on the Healthy Schools Act proposed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer.

headline: Vows: Jessica and Emile
text: Jessica Rodriquez and Severiano Emile Lisboa IV met while dancing the night away at the South Street Seaport in New York.

headline: Succeeding Wolfowitz
text: In the past few days, the Paul D. Wolfowitz Question turned from if he would step down at the World Bank, to when and how. And the answer came this evening.

headline: Who’s Worse, Nixon or Bush?
text: WASHINGTON — A favorite pastime of political scientists and pollsters is compiling lists of the best presidents. The results vary widely, as the judgments of history conflict with contemporary sentiments. Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln and F.D.R. always finish high on the lists, with more controversial choices like Truman and Reagan often thrown in.

headline: Television Upfronts: Fox
text: The Times's Bill Carter reports from City Center, where Fox presented its 2007 fall schedule.

headline: A Warm Welcome for ‘Dad Lit’
text: Back in 2002 when I was in the thick of conducting interviews with groups of mothers for my book “Perfect Madness,” I began to think that it would be a great idea to turn the tables and interview groups of dads. After all, I was listening almost daily to mothers venting (in the nicest possible way) about their lazy, self-indulgent, oversexed, under-involved husbands; there had to be, I thought, another side to the story.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts by Paul D. Wolfowitz to retain his job as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly in some copies to a critic of Mr. Wolfowitz’s who has accused him of favoritism. The critic, Robert Daniño, is a former general counsel at the bank, not the current general counsel.

headline: Germany: Ex-C.I.A. Detainee Held in Arson Attack
text: The police arrested Khaled el-Masri, the German citizen of Lebanese descent who says he was subjected to the Central Intelligence Agency’s practice of extraordinary rendition, on suspicion of setting a fire at a market in the Bavarian town of Neu-Ulm that caused an estimated $675,000 in damage, his lawyer said. A judge ordered him held in the psychiatric ward of a local hospital. The lawyer, Manfred Gnjidic, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Masri, who says he was seized while on vacation in Macedonia in 2003 and flown to Afghanistan, where he was questioned about ties to terrorist groups and beaten, had had a dispute with the store and that his action was a result of not having received the psychological counseling he had sought. “I have asked several times from the beginning for psychological help, but without any luck,” Mr. Gnjidic said. “The very ironic thing is that he will get psychological help now, after he committed a crime, and as a torture victim didn’t get it before, when he asked for it.”

headline: Democrats Balk Over Pledge of Tighter Rules on Lobbying
text: WASHINGTON, May 17  House Democrats wavered Thursday in their vow to tighten Congressional ethics rules as their leaders scrapped a campaign pledge to double the current one-year ban on lobbying by departing lawmakers and senior staff members.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Thomson Corporation’s acquisition of the Reuters Group misspelled the name of the Ontario town where Thomson was founded. It is Timmins, not Timmons.

headline: 22-Foot Pipe Falls 35 Floors Into Firehouse Near 9/11 Site
text: The long-delayed demolition of the former Deutsche Bank building across from ground zero suffered another setback yesterday when a 22-foot metal pipe fell from its 35th floor and crashed through the roof of a firehouse across the street.

headline: Dance Listings
text: NEW YORK CITY BALLET/AMERICAN BALLET THEATER Sure, the blossoms and longer days are all right, but for some New Yorkers, spring means opera glasses, Champagne at intermission and having to choose between New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater, which are performing next door to each other at Lincoln Center.

headline: En Route to a Mountain Peak, a Stop at the Hudson’s Source
text: MOST New Yorkers take the Hudson River for granted. It’s simply a fact of life, like alternate-side parking and the Yankees’ making the playoffs each season. Most only have the vaguest sense of where the river begins. If you told some New Yorkers that the Hudson’s source was a hose left running outside someone’s chalet in the Canadian Rockies, a few of them just might believe you.

headline: The Troubles: A Walking Tour
text: Belfast

headline: Calls to Remove CVS/Caremark Director
text: An investment advisory firm is calling for the board of CVS/Caremark to remove a director, Roger L. Headrick, amid concern that his re-election was aided by “phantom votes,” or votes cast without guidance from shareholders.

headline: Russia Sues U.S. Bank; Laundering Case Cited
text: The Federal Customs Service of Russia is seeking $22.5 billion in damages from the Bank of New York Company over accusations of money laundering in the 1990s.

headline: Bush Asked to Reconsider Safety Nominee
text: WASHINGTON, May 17  Senate Democrats urged President Bush on Thursday to withdraw his nomination of a top lobbyist from the National Association of Manufacturers to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission, saying the candidate was unqualified and the appointment posed insurmountable conflicts of interest.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Appointed Hobblers of Government
text: Across six years, the Bush administration has mocked all standards of conflict of interest by choosing private industry zealots for high regulatory posts  where they worked to roll back hundreds of rules on transportation, workplace and mine safety, the environment and other issues. The latest in this subversive chain must surely take the fox-in-the-henhouse statuette: President Bush has nominated Michael Baroody, lobbyist for the powerful National Association of Manufacturers, to lead the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

headline: Hunt for 3 G.I.’s in Iraq Slowed by False Trails
text: RUSHDIMULLAH, Iraq, May 17 — The stories have come in by the dozens.

headline: A Renaissance of Charm in a Hub of the Surfing World
text: IF you had walked down Avenida del Mar in San Clemente, Calif., 10 years ago, you would have found a down-at-the-heels beach town that didn’t seem to have much going for it. It had a smattering of intriguing boutiques, a longtime surf shop and an excellent deli and a Jamaican restaurant, but many shops along Del Mar stood empty.

headline: Mosque Bombing Kills Seven in India
text: NEW DELHI, May 18 — A crude bomb exploded during Friday prayers at a 17th-century mosque in Hyderabad, a major city in southern India. At least seven people were killed, and about 35 more were wounded.

headline: They Are Inauthentic, Yes, but Beautiful
text: It could have fooled me, as it fooled others. The exquisitely detailed sculpture of St. Michael battling the dragon of the Apocalypse, in half-human scale, wrought in gilt silver with semiprecious stones, is a gorgeous thing, showing the saint looking down in triumph as his lance pierces a loathsome creature writhing at his feet. For a long time it was thought to be an original medieval work, so well regarded that it was once part of a Rothschild collection.

headline: Theater Listings
text: ‘KING KONG’ “Why, in a few months, it’ll be up in lights on Broadway: ‘Kong — the Eighth Wonder of the World,’ ” Carl Denham (Robert Armstrong) said in the 1933 film. King Kong did go on to make a Broadway debut in the movie, before he grabbed Ann Darrow (Fay Wray) and bolted to the top of the Empire State Building.

headline: Violence Continues in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, May 18 — Israel struck more targets of the Palestinian faction Hamas today, while forces from the group’s Palestinian rival, Fatah, fired mortar shells at Hamas’s Islamic University and exchanged gunfire with fighters inside.

headline: Torre Won’t Start Wang, So Another Rookie Looms
text: CHICAGO, May 17 — Tyler Clippard was pulled after striking out the side in the first inning Thursday for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre, a strong indication that Clippard will start for the Yankees on Sunday. Manager Joe Torre said he would not use Chien-Ming Wang on short rest for that game.

headline: Hilfiger Janitors Back on Job After Abrupt Layoffs
text: A week after they were told that they were being replaced by workers earning far lower wages, nine workers who clean the offices of the Tommy Hilfiger clothing company were hired by a different contractor yesterday and went back to work.

headline: Army Punished 2 Officers in ’06 After Failures in Iraq Ambush
text: An Army general relieved a company commander and a platoon leader of their commands last year after enlisted men were ambushed and killed by insurgents at an isolated observation post south of Baghdad in June 2006, Army officials said yesterday.

headline: Financier Says He Is Not Target of Swiss Arms Investigation
text: PARIS, May 17 —A Syrian-born financier who helped broker a $79 billion arms contract between BAE Systems and Saudi Arabia two decades ago said Thursday that he was not a target of a money-laundering investigation opened this week by the Swiss authorities.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: The Insurgent Advantage
text: The war on terror has shredded the reputation of the Bush administration. It’s destroyed the reputation of Tony Blair’s government in Britain, Ehud Olmert’s government in Israel and Nuri al-Maliki’s government in Iraq. And here’s a prediction: It will destroy future American administrations, and future Israeli, European and world governments as well.

headline: Networks Know That All Rivalries Aren’t Viewed Equally
text: Interleague play begins today, and guess which two teams Fox and ESPN are featuring this weekend? The Yankees and the Mets. It doesn’t matter if they’re at Shea Stadium or at Yankee Stadium, or if both teams are great.

headline: Relent on Missile Defense (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: At Cannes, Blueberry Nights and Romanian Days
text: CANNES, France, May 17 — As a first course the 60th Cannes Film Festival served its audiences dessert.

headline: In Deal for Chrysler, Snow’s Role Extends a Trend
text: At a news conference this week in Stuttgart, Germany, the usually secretive private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management was in the spotlight, announcing an agreement to take control of Chrysler.

headline: President Bush to Replace Wolfowitz Quickly
text: WASHINGTON, May 18 — The Bush administration promised today to find someone quickly to succeed Paul D. Wolfowitz as president of the World Bank, and bring management skills to the job of healing an institution battered by the turmoil over Mr. Wolfowitz’s tenure.

headline: Puns, Not Potshots, as Mayor Faces an Ex-Rival
text: It was a meeting that felt more like a Catskill comedy routine than a reunion of two formerly bitter political rivals:

headline: Paradise Preserved in a Restless Continent
text: “Gabon: The Last Eden,” tonight on the National Geographic Channel, is an example of a currently popular genre that could be called enviroporn. Born from the union of global warming mania and the increasing ease with which anything, anywhere can be photographed in brilliantly colorful detail, it proliferates on outlets like National Geographic, the Discovery Channel and PBS.

headline: Rescuers Try to Lure Lost Whales With Sound
text: WEST SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 17 — Anxious to save two injured wayward whales, a team of marine rescuers on Thursday played recorded humpback songs, hoping to lure the stranded mammals from the Sacramento River back to the sea.

headline: Turnaround Effort Is Challenging at Airbus, a Stew of European Cultures
text: TOULOUSE, France, May 17 — Louis Gallois is fed up with flags. When he took over as chief executive of Airbus in October, an early edict was to ban the use of national symbols in PowerPoint presentations.

headline: Denis Kuhn, 65, Dies; Restored New York Landmarks
text: Denis G. Kuhn, an architect who oversaw many major restoration and reuse projects in New York City, including the transformation of the Alexander Hamilton Custom House into the Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Indian and the conversion of the old Police Department headquarters in Little Italy into elegant apartments, died on May 10 in the Dominican Republic while touring a project site. He was 65 and lived in Manhasset, N.Y.

headline: Battling Evildoers From Worldwide Headquarters in Woodside, Queens
text: “You’re a good woman, Fay,” declares Jallal (Anatole Taubman), an Osama bin Laden surrogate. “Someday when all this is over and we have destroyed Western civilization. ...” he continues, without finishing the sentence.

headline: Louisiana: Wage Laws Cover Foreign Workers, Judge Says
text: Foreign workers brought into the United States by companies facing labor shortages are covered by federal minimum wage laws, a judge in New Orleans ruled May 15. In what he said appeared to be the first federal ruling on this issue, which could affect thousands of workers nationwide, the judge, Eldon E. Fallon of Federal District Court, found that workers hired by Decatur Hotels in New Orleans had the right to sue their employer under the Fair Labor Standards Act. The workers are seeking to be reimbursed for thousands of dollars in travel and other costs to get the hotel jobs, arguing that the company’s failure to do so left them working for less than minimum wage.

headline: Crisis at Justice Over Wiretapping (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Memories of the ’Hood and the Mob
text: “Brooklyn Rules,” the story of three buddies growing up in a mob-infested blue-collar neighborhood, makes you realize how high the bar has been set by “The Sopranos.” However authentic and heartfelt this film’s depiction of life on the meaner streets of the Northeast corridor may be, it doesn’t begin to match “The Sopranos’ ” epic vision of violence, class struggle and upward mobility in a barbarous culture.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: A Grumpy Green Giant Who Would Not Be King
text: For all I know, there may be an endless supply of “Shrek” sequels in the pipeline. That DreamWorks ogre’s skin is the color of money after all. But there is nonetheless a feeling of finality about “Shrek the Third,” a sense that the tale has at last reached a state of completion. In the first movie Shrek (voiced by Mike Myers) met and wooed his lady love, Fiona (Cameron Diaz); in the second he got to know the in-laws. The current installment finds him faced with impending fatherhood and something of a career crisis. Will he take over his father-in-law’s business or remain true to his vocation of bellowing and smashing things?

headline: Congress and Bush Striving for Compromise on War Funds
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — Congressional leaders and the White House began what they said they hoped were the final talks on an Iraq war spending bill on Thursday as Democrats braced for potential defections by lawmakers leery of any compromise with President Bush.

headline: Promises to Keep and Miles to Go for Transit Chief
text: The new boss man of subways and buses, Howard H. Roberts Jr., is said to be partial to the poetry of Robert Frost. Not a bad choice of a muse, even if Frost was a rural type who may have thought — assuming he dwelt on the matter at all — that BMT was shorthand for a kind of sandwich.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (CBS) THAT’S THE WAY IT IS: CELEBRATING CRONKITE AT 90 He led the country in mourning when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated, pushed the story of the civil rights movement, publicly expressed his opinion of the Vietnam War and helped to send the United States’ space program soaring. No wonder Walter Cronkite, above, with George Clooney, became the nightly news anchor to watch. In this hourlong special colleagues including Katie Couric, Barbara Walters, Brian Williams, Charles Gibson, Dan Rather, Ted Koppel and Diane Sawyer as well as friends like Bill Clinton and Mr. Clooney discuss Mr. Cronkite’s legacy in honor of his 90th birthday.

headline: Movie Listings
text: SAM FULLER This retrospective devoted to the work of the tabloid reporter and crime novelist turned director should really be titled “Sam Fuller!” to reflect both his fondness for appending exclamation points to his titles (“Fixed Bayonets!,” “Verboten!”) and his filmmaking, which is so loaded with huge close-ups and percussive editing that Jean-Luc Godard once called it “ciné-fist.” This program at the Museum of the Moving Image in Queens features most of Fuller’s major films in hard-to-find 35-millimeter archival prints.

headline: Zimbabwe: Inflation Hits 3,714 Percent
text: Zimbabwe’s hyperinflation reached a record annual rate of 3,714 percent in April, the government-run newspaper The Herald reported, a 1,500 percentage-point increase over the March rate. Steep increases in the cost of fuel, food and power drove the rate higher, the Central Statistical Office was quoted as stating. The new rate effectively means that average prices in Zimbabwe rose 36-fold between April 2006 and April 2007.

headline: Life That Brings Out the Beast in Humanity, and a War That’s Far From Civil
text: The rustics in the French director Bruno Dumont’s fourth film, “Flanders,” are tragic beasts. Farmers who live a hardscrabble life surrounded by animals, woods and muddy fields, they are elemental beings ruled by primal emotions they can barely express and would never dream of analyzing.

headline: Life Beyond the ‘Lux et Veritas’ Zone (8 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jazz Listings
text: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

headline: Canada: Bank of Montreal Revises Trade Loss
text: Bank of Montreal, stung by a huge loss from natural gas trading, said the debacle would cost at least 50 percent more than originally forecast and started an investigation into potential irregularities. Bank of Montreal said it would record pretax losses of 680 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from the trades, compared with an April 27 forecast of 350 million to 450 million Canadian dollars. Two New York-based bankers involved in the trades have left the firm. The bank said the losses were bigger than it originally forecast after it adopted a different pricing model to better assess the value of its natural gas options contracts. The revision also reflects “increased concerns” about the reliability of quotes from its main broker.

headline: Republican Renewal: A Long Road Ahead (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ordinary People, in the Flesh and on the Screen
text: How on earth to watch Doug Varone’s “Dense Terrain”? Running 75 minutes without a break at the BAM Harvey Theater, this numbingly tedious and relentlessly earnest show (a New York premiere) passed like an ice age. Dense terrain? Deserts are more varied and vivacious.

headline: Lukas, Still Active, Could Play the Spoiler
text: BALTIMORE, May 17 — D. Wayne Lukas does not want to hear about how he is in the twilight of an unparalleled career as a horse trainer. He is 71 but still looks good in a cowboy hat and jeans or a $3,000 bespoke suit. He no longer has hundreds of horses in his charge, but he still pops up and wins important races.

headline: Monsoon Rains Could Moderate Drought in Southwest
text: Federal forecasters said the extreme drought in the Southwest, just one step from the top of the scale, could moderate in Arizona in July as monsoon rains build but is likely to persist in Southern California into the fall. The similarly intense drought in the Southeast, partly set up by the lack of hurricanes last summer, is unlikely to break any time soon except in Florida, where increasing thunderstorm activity later this month could moisten vegetation, but add to wildfire risks through more lightning strikes. More information is at www.drought.noaa.gov.

headline: G.E. Nears a Deal to Sell Plastics Unit
text: General Electric is close to reaching an agreement to sell its plastics division for about $11 billion to Saudi Arabia’s largest public company, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation, according to people briefed on the negotiations.

headline: $11.45 Million Awarded in N.Y. Church Abuse Case
text: A jury in State Supreme Court in Nassau County today awarded $11.45 million to two people who said they had been abused by the youth minister at a Roman Catholic church on Long Island during the 1990s.

headline: Mets’ Makeshift Lineup Jells in Ninth
text: After hearing that the Mets’ starting lineup did not include José Reyes, Carlos Beltrán, David Wright or Paul Lo Duca, the thousands of children who crammed the upper decks of Shea Stadium might have asked their teachers, “We missed school for this?”

headline: Labor Party Picks Brown to Succeed Blair in Britain
text: LONDON, May 17  Opening a new era in British politics, the governing Labor Party confirmed on Thursday that Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the Exchequer, had emerged as the sole candidate to assume the party leadership and thus succeed Prime Minister Tony Blair when he steps down in June.

headline: Not Just Any Port for Migrating Snowbirds
text: WHEN Albert Gallatin, the United States Treasury secretary under Thomas Jefferson, first dreamed up what would become, more than a century later, the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway, he envisioned a series of linked rivers, canals, bays and deep-water channels that would provide an easy way to transport cargo and troops back and forth between the North and the South.

headline: For Fairer Trade Deals (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Colombia: Escaped Hostage Says Americans Are Alive
text: Emerging from 17 days in the jungle after fleeing from guerrillas, Jhon Frank Pinchao, a police officer, stunned Colombians with his tale of escape after more than eight years in captivity. Mr. Pinchao, left, looking rawboned, said he shimmied off his chains, waded through rivers and endured dehydration, sunburn and insect bites before stumbling across a police patrol. He also offered news of three Americans held hostage by the guerrillas, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia for four years — Marc Gonsalves, Thomas Howes and Keith Stansell — as well as of Ingrid Betancourt, kidnapped in 2002 while running for president. All are still alive, Mr. Pinchao said.

headline: People
text: People

headline: Fed Chief Addresses Foreclosures
text: The Federal Reserve does not foresee a broader economic impact from the growing number of mortgage defaults and home foreclosures, its chairman said yesterday. And he cautioned that heavy-handed regulation of lenders could have the unintended effect of adding to the strain on the troubled housing market.

headline: Man Held in Midtown Killing Is Implicated in Chicago Death
text: A New Jersey man arrested this week on charges of strangling a companion in a Midtown hotel in the summer of 2003 and stuffing her body into a suitcase is wanted in another grisly death: the killing of a college student in Chicago nine days ago, the authorities said.

headline: How to Survive in Cambodia: For a Turtle, Beneath Sand
text: SAMBOR, Cambodia — With the self-confidence of tens of millions of years of instinct, 12 tiny turtles raced down a mud bank of the Mekong River on a recent day, plopped into the water and disappeared with a wriggle under the sand.

headline: Olmert Visits Israeli Town Where Residents Flee Rocket Fire
text: SDEROT, Israel, May 17 — Prime Minister Ehud Olmert paid an unannounced visit to this border town on Thursday night to show solidarity with its residents after days of rocket fire from the nearby Gaza Strip.

headline: ‘E-stonia’ Accuses Russia of Computer Attacks
text: MOSCOW, May 18 — The computer attacks, apparently originating in Russia, first hit the Web site of Estonia’s prime minister on April 27, a day the country was mired in protest and violence. The Estonian president’s site went down, too, and before long so did those of several other government departments, in a wired country that is proud of its paperless government and likes to call itself E-stonia.

headline: In Game of Games, Wii Outshoots PlayStation
text: The sales gap between the Nintendo Wii video game console and Sony’s competing PlayStation 3 widened during April, according to industry performance figures released yesterday.

headline: In Search for a New Sheriff, One Stands Out
text: As New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer won national attention by becoming the new sheriff in finance, taking on Wall Street and mutual funds and the insurance industry.

headline: Bill Would Increase Health Spending in Poor Countries
text: Senators Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, introduced a bill to sharply increase spending on child and maternal health in poor countries to $600 million next year and $1.6 billion by 2011 from $350 million a year. A companion bill was introduced with bipartisan support in the House last week. Save the Children, the U.S. Fund for Unicef and the Campaign to Make Poverty History, co-founded by the rock star Bono, are supporting the legislation. A recent Save the Children report found that some of the world’s poorest countries have sharply reduced child deaths with practical, inexpensive solutions, but that progress globally has slowed. More than 10 million children die every year before their fifth birthdays, most of them from preventable causes.

headline: Mets Say Reliever’s Demotion Wasn’t Based on Positive Test
text: When the Mets sent reliever Lino Urdaneta to Class AAA New Orleans on Tuesday, they had been told that he had tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs. General Manager Omar Minaya said that he was notified last Friday, but Major League Baseball delayed the announcement until Wednesday because of the minor league appeals process.

headline: Wolfowitz Resigns, Ending Long Fight at World Bank
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — Paul D. Wolfowitz, ending a furor over favoritism that blew up into a global fight over American leadership, announced his resignation as president of the World Bank Thursday evening after the bank’s board accepted his claim that his mistakes at the bank were made in good faith.

headline: Manhattan: Budget Increases for New Subway
text: The construction budget for the first phase of the Second Avenue subway crept over $4 billion this month after the Federal Transit Administration asked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to add $160 million to a reserve fund for unexpected costs. At the request of the federal agency, the authority also pushed back its projected completion date for the long-awaited subway project to 2014 from 2013. The revised budget and timeline were included in material distributed to the authority’s board members this week. The changes came about in response to a risk assessment of the construction costs and schedule prepared by the federal agency. The federal government is expected to provide $1.3 billion in financing.

headline: Dozens in School Are Sickened After Free Drink Is Distributed
text: Dozens of sixth and seventh graders in the Lakeland Central School District in northern Westchester County reported becoming sick on Wednesday after many of them drank free samples of fortified milk drinks given out during lunchtime, school officials said yesterday.

headline: Bronx: Man Slain Outside His Restaurant
text: A Bronx man was shot and stabbed to death yesterday outside a restaurant he owned, the police said. The man, Douglas Mills, 36, was killed about 2:30 p.m. outside the D&R Jamaican and American Restaurant at Morris Avenue and East 151st Street. The police said they did not know what led to the killing, adding that an investigation was under way. John Mills, Mr. Mills’s father, said his son was one of 17 siblings, only 12 of whom are still alive. “People raise their kids so they can take care of you when you’re old, not so you can take care of them and bury them,” he said.

headline: A Gallery of Gamblers, Each With an Unlucky Number to Be Called
text: “Even Money,” a scare movie about gambling addiction, is as grim and lurid as any in the recent spate of films about the evils of crystal meth. Once you’re hooked, it suggests, you’re a goner. The zombie face of Kim Basinger, her vacant eyes glued to a slot machine, tells you all you need to know. The elusive quest of her character, Carolyn Carver, for a cascade of jangling silver soon leads to roulette, blackjack and high-stakes bets placed with a murderous bookie.

headline: Qantas Chairwoman Decides to Retire
text: Margaret A. Jackson, the chairwoman of Qantas Airways, who was one of the proponents of a failed attempt to take the airline private, will retire, a company spokesman said. Ms. Jackson, 54, told the board that she would not seek re-election at the airline’s annual meeting in October, said Simon Rushton, a spokesman for Qantas. The buyout attempt, led by the Macquarie Bank and TPG, collapsed two weeks ago when investors rejected a cash offer of 5.45 Australian dollars a share as too low. The buyout group says it will not make another bid. Ms. Jackson joined the board in July 1992 and was appointed chairwoman in August 2000.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A “What’s on Tonight” television listing on May 5 about the film “The Day of the Jackal” misidentified the actor who played the French detective who pursues the Jackal. He was Michael Lonsdale (also known as Michel Lonsdale), not Terence Alexander, who played Lloyd in the film.

headline: Passing Mile Markers, Snapping Pictures
text: In 1973 Stephen Shore set out from New York to photograph the United States for what became a book called “Uncommon Places.” He shot his motel room in Idaho Falls. He shot a pancake breakfast at the Trail’s End Restaurant in Kanab, Utah. He shot a rainbow arching over a rain-soaked parking lot in Lovell, Wyo.

headline: Three Sculptures Sell for Record Prices and Warhol Stars Again at Phillips Auction
text: Three sculptures — one fashioned from a dozen African masks, a dead deer cast in bronze, and a ball of painted and chromium-plated steel mangled as if hit by a truck — by some of today’s most popular artists brought record prices last night at Phillips de Pury & Company. After a week of records at the auction giants Christie’s and Sotheby’s, the contemporary-art sale at Phillips, the Chelsea-based boutique firm, had a mix of lower-priced works. Still, the lust to collect continued.

headline: Not for Kids Only: Seeking Buccaneer Bliss
text: BLUE BAYOU, Anaheim, Calif.: Caroline Treadwell, 34, stepped gingerly into a boat, then was launched into the bayou darkness to the soothing sounds of crickets, bullfrogs and the distant strumming of a banjo.
