It seemed like a nocturnal paradise. But avast! Around the next bend Ms. Treadwell’s boat was sucked into a subterranean waterfall only to emerge in a blue-lighted grotto inhabited by skeletons. Somewhere out there, a drunken chorus was singing, “Yo ho, yo ho, a pirate’s life for me.”

headline: Senators in Bipartisan Deal on Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — Senate negotiators from both parties announced Thursday that they had reached agreement on a comprehensive immigration bill that would offer legal status to most of the nation’s 12 million illegal immigrants while also toughening border security.

headline: Manhattan: Slight Increase in Unemployment
text: New York City’s unemployment rate edged up to 4.4 percent in April, from 4.3 percent in March, the state’s Department of Labor reported yesterday. The city’s jobless rate, which is adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, was lower than the national rate of 4.5 percent but higher than the rate for the rest of the state, which was 4.1 percent. Statewide, the number of private-sector jobs declined for the first time since July, dipping by 7,900, or 0.1 percent, to 7.18 million.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Principals Act in Plan to Reduce Bureaucracy
text: More than a third of New York City’s public school principals embraced a challenge from Chancellor Joel I. Klein to free themselves as much as possible from outside oversight under a new reorganization and become full stewards of their individual schools, the city said yesterday.

headline: For Nets, Winning Ugly Looks Pretty Good
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 17 — After testing the limits of basketball aesthetics, and the tonal quality of their opponents’ rims, the Nets returned home Thursday and considered their good fortune again.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts by Paul D. Wolfowitz to retain his job as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly in some copies to a critic of Mr. Wolfowitz’s who has accused him of favoritism. The critic, Robert Daniño, is a former general counsel at the bank, not the current general counsel. (Go to Article)

headline: What’s Happened to the Lawyers Who Worked for Spitzer?
text: After reining in Wall Street analysts, curbing mutual fund trading abuses and corralling some of the biggest insurance companies in the industry, what do you do for an encore?

headline: Life Resettles for Survivors of Bronx Fire
text: A 7-year-old girl played with a construction-paper butterfly. Her 5-year-old cousin came and went from the kitchen, trying to distract her mother as she fried potato wedges on the stove. A teenager focused on a homework assignment, sitting in front of the computer in the living room.

headline: Goshen: Cleanup for Orange County Landfill
text: The United States Military Academy at West Point, the City of New York and 74 other municipalities, organizations and corporations in the region have agreed to pay nearly $5 million to help clean up hazardous waste in an Orange County landfill. The agreement was part of a consent decree filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan and announced yesterday by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. Orange County operated the landfill, situated on 300 acres in Goshen, from 1974 to 1992. The landfill was declared a hazardous waste site and was capped in the late 1990s under an agreement with the state in which those responsible for disposing of the waste would eventually help pay for the cleanup. The defendants agreed to contribute toward the cleanup costs, even though they deny wrongdoing.

headline: A Tenderhearted Introvert, Crooning in Eclectic Company
text: Two-thirds of the lineup made obvious sense at the Highline Ballroom show on Wednesday night, which was curated by David Bowie. Daniel Johnston, the headliner, and the Legendary Stardust Cowboy, who opened, are two Texas characters with longtime cult followings.

headline: An Export Boom Suddenly Facing a Quality Crisis
text: SHANGHAI, May 17 — Weeks after tainted Chinese pet food ingredients killed and sickened thousands of dogs and cats in the United States, this country is facing growing international pressure to prove that its food exports are safe to eat.

headline: Manhattan: Port Authority Urged to Cut Emissions
text: The chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Anthony R. Coscia, called on his agency yesterday to reduce carbon emissions at its ports and airports by 80 percent over the long term. That goal, he said, could be met by using geothermal energy to heat and cool buildings, installing fuel cells and harnessing wind and solar energy. Equipment used to service aircraft at airports could use electricity and alternative fuels. The strategy, said Mr. Coscia, above, would help reduce global warming and benefit the renewable energy industry.

headline: Park Feels Right at Home Among Sybase Leaders
text: CLIFTON, N.J., May 17 — On an L.P.G.A. Tour rife with translators and passports, Angela Park may have the most diverse background of all.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Lottery Numbers
No Sleep Is Part of the Ordeal
text: BLAME Mark Burnett, the reality-television producer best known for “Survivor.” In the mid-’90s, he created the Eco-Challenge race and accompanying TV series, and an exotic new sport called adventure racing was stamped on the American consciousness. Today, hundreds of adventure races are attended by thousands of Eco-Challenge wannabes each year, on wilderness courses in the mountains and deep woods from Maine to Alaska.

headline: Obelisk Mobility in Central Park
text: OBELISK MOBILITY

headline: The Tyranny of the 2nd Home
text: IN his book “Acres and Pains,” S. J. Perelman recalled his notion of becoming a country squire in Bucks County “with nothing but a high heart, a flask of citronella and a fork for toasting marshmallows.” But after 15 years of part-time rusticating, he ended up with “a superb library of mortgages, mostly first editions, and the finest case of sacroiliac known to science.”

headline: A Game Show, and Bingo Is Its Name-O
text: There is at least one game of chance loaded with particularly hateful hazards. Players are rapt, tingling with hope and growing confidence, and then across the room a complete stranger stands up and ruins everything. Bingo.

headline: In West Oakland, a Second Freeway Collapse Threatens a Fragile Recovery
text: OAKLAND, Calif., May 17 — To get a sens0e of the problems in West Oakland, a rough-and-tumble corner of a city known for having a few, you need look no farther than places like 14th Street, where a house floats in midair.

headline: Citigroup Works Both Sides of Distiller Deal
text: DELHI, India, May 17 — Bankers at Citigroup may celebrate the latest Indian cross-border takeover with a few extra drams of Scotch.

headline: WPP Group to Acquire Online Ad Company
text: In an effort to catch up with Google’s fast-growing online advertising business, the WPP Group, the advertising holding company that owns traditional ad agencies like JWT and the Grey Global Group, agreed yesterday to pay about $649 million to acquire 24/7 Real Media, an advertising network and technology company.

headline: Colleges Offering Campuses as Final Resting Places
text: RICHMOND, Va. — Want to recapture those undergraduate years? Colleges and universities are offering the chance — for eternity.

headline: Obama Disputes Claim of Sharing Clinton’s Stance on War
text: Senator Barack Obama yesterday directly challenged former President Bill Clinton’s assertions that Mr. Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton hold the same essential positions on the Iraq war.

headline: When a Crocodile Eats the Sun
text: The title of Peter Godwin’s haunting and beautifully written new memoir, “When a Crocodile Eats the Sun,” comes from an African tribal belief, which holds that an eclipse of the sun occurs when a crocodile eats it: “This celestial crocodile, they say, briefly consumes our life-giving star as a warning that he is much displeased with the behavior of man below. It is the very worst of omens.” At the turn of this millennium, Mr. Godwin reports, two total eclipses occurred within less than two years, something no one he knows can recall, “even in the stories handed down through the generations.” People are saying that “the celestial crocodile must be truly furious to be back so soon, threatening us again with perpetual darkness.”

headline: Russian Police Detain Opposition Leaders
text: MOSCOW, May 18 — The police detained more than a dozen opposition leaders and journalists here on Friday, preventing them from flying to a provincial city to take part in anti-Kremlin protests. The action followed a wave of harassment of the protest’s organizers.

headline: Democrats and White House Remain at Odds on Iraq Bill
text: WASHINGTON, May 18 – Congressional Democrats and the White House remained at odds over a war spending measure Friday after a crucial negotiating session ended with both sides expressing disappointment and accusing the other of being intractable.

headline: Making Fast Work of a Second Chance
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., May 14 — The open-heart surgery did not frighten her, Kayleigh Lotti said. But three weeks later, when she tried to throw a softball again, the ball fell out of her hand because there was no muscle strength to lift her arm. Then she cried.

headline: Online Invitation to ‘Help Yourself’ Surprises the Stuff’s Owner
text: SEATTLE, May 17 — The offer had sure seemed strange. Then again, it appeared on Craigslist, the online marketplace that has made its name by upending conventional classified advertising.

headline: Those Hard-Luck Ranch Hands, After 70 Years
text: This is the 70th anniversary of John Steinbeck’s novella “Of Mice and Men,” and the play he adapted from it, also in 1937, is being honored in a tiny theater on a West Side street where drunks and derelicts roam. Perhaps in some way that suggests the book’s diminished status in the American canon.

headline: A Charming Slacker Fights the Power in a Retirement Home
text: Venture capitalist: that’s the misleading job description preferred by the title character of the slight and silly “Wendell Baker Story.” Wendell (Luke Wilson), a cheerful Texan slacker, runs a profitable operation on the Tex-Mex border selling fake driver’s licenses to illegal migrant workers.

headline: Soldier’s Smallpox Inoculation Sickens Son
text: A 2-year-old boy spent seven weeks in the hospital and nearly died from a viral infection he got from the smallpox vaccination his father received before shipping out to Iraq, according to a government report and the doctors who treated him.

headline: Senate Democrats Plan a Resolution on Gonzales
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales’s standing in Congress weakened further on Thursday as Senate Democrats arranged to hold a no-confidence vote and the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee predicted that the furor over Mr. Gonzales’s stewardship would end with his resignation.

headline: Boston’s Early-Music Hegemony, Reasserted
text: New York early-music performers get terribly exercised when reviewers suggest that Boston has more period-instrument activity than New York. And Boston’s musicians, happy to drive the point home, have established the Boston Early Music Festival series at the Morgan Library & Museum as a New York outpost. To some extent, this is sleight of hand: The festival itself is held in Boston every other spring (this year’s runs from June 11 to 17), but its administration also presents concerts during the season by both Boston and international ensembles, some of which make their way to the Morgan series as well. To be fair, New York presenters like Music Before 1800 do the same.

headline: Private Equity Goes Prime Time
text: Ready or not, it’s time for private equity’s close-up. The announcement earlier this week that Cerberus Capital Management was taking control of Chrysler has made the clubby, backroom industry the center of attention like never before.

headline: Family Income and Brain Development
text: Children develop most of their basic verbal, memory and abstract reasoning skills from ages of 6 to 10, and the effect of family income on these abilities may be smaller than previously thought, scientists are reporting. The findings, which appear online in The Journal of the International Neuropsychological Society, are from a large, continuing government study tracking changes in cognitive abilities and brain structure. The difference in I.Q. scores between low-income and high-income was about 10 points, when youngsters with learning disabilities were excluded; previous studies have found differences of 15 to 20 points. “The purpose is to provide a large, public database of healthy, normal brain development,” said the lead author, Dr. Deborah P. Waber, a pediatric researcher at Children’s Hospital Boston and Harvard University.

headline: 8 Israeli Airstrikes in Gaza Kill at Least 7
text: JERUSALEM, Friday, May 18 — Israel moved a small number of tanks and soldiers over the Gaza border and hit Hamas with eight airstrikes on Thursday and early Friday, killing at least seven Palestinians, while five other Palestinians died in factional fighting despite a new cease-fire.

headline: Mexico: Economic Growth Rate Slips in Quarter
text: Mexico’s economy grew in the first quarter at its slowest rate in more than a year as construction fell and automobile output declined on slumping demand in the United States. Gross domestic product grew 2.6 percent from a year earlier, the government reported. A growth rate of less than 3 percent suggests Mexico is failing to reduce dependence on exports to the United States, the destination for about 80 percent of the country’s sales abroad. Last year’s 4.8 percent growth, Mexico’s fastest in six years, was driven by strong United States demand, while the weakening economy last quarter similarly tracked the United States slowdown.

headline: A Fired Boss Seeks His Revenge
text: If a chief executive is fired for fraudulently taking travel money from the company, and then turns out to have been involved in backdating options grants, should his fellow shareholders let him pick new directors to replace those who ousted him?

headline: 3 Department Store Chains Exceed Estimates
text: J. C. Penney, Kohl’s and Nordstrom reported first-quarter profits yesterday that surpassed analysts’ estimates, and they increased their full-year earnings forecasts.

headline: Making Some Waves
text: WHO Michael Morgan, 44, a physician, from Odessa, Fla.

headline: A Town That Has a Way With Words
text: IN the 19th century, Concord, Mass., was a peaceful country village and home to best-selling writers. In the 21st, Concord is a bustling, upscale Boston suburb and still home to best-selling writers.

headline: Different Challenges for Yankees and the Mets
text: You begin to see the makings of something seismic over the next few days, with the Yankees at Shea Stadium this weekend before going home to play the Red Sox. Tonight, it’s the soaring Mets against the slumping Yankees, the commencement of a Subway Series that is always a crush of impassioned, impossible humanity, but is perfectly timed this season to match irresistible force against movable object.

headline: Ads That Are Too Fast for a Fast-Forward Button
text: A BROADCAST network will soon offer advertisers two more ways to try holding the attention of viewers throughout those commercial breaks that consumers love to hate.

headline: From Out of the Shadows, Whistle-Blowers Convene
text: WASHINGTON, May 17  The whistle-blower, a species in Washington’s peculiar zoology as well established now as the talk-show pundit or the campaign consultant, is enjoying an unusual spell in the sunshine. It is Whistle-Blower Week, so declared by a coalition of advocacy groups, and there is unusual acclaim for those whose leaks make possible Congressional hearings and newspaper exposés.

headline: Publisher and Authors Parse a Term: Out of Print
text: When is a book out of print?

headline: ‘Second Chance’ at Career Goes Sour for Wolfowitz
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — Paul D. Wolfowitz was ready to move on from the Pentagon in early 2005. He had been thwarted in his effort to become defense secretary or national security adviser. And the war in Iraq had deteriorated. So when the World Bank presidency came open, he jumped at the opportunity.

headline: U.N. Rejects Belarus for Seat on Its Rights Panel
text: UNITED NATIONS, May 17  Belarus, one of the world’s most repressive states, was blocked Thursday from gaining membership on the United Nations Human Rights Council after being outvoted in favor of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a late entry.

headline: Utah Mall Shootings Lead to Indictments
text: SALT LAKE CITY, May 17  Four men are accused of helping a teenager illegally obtain weapons that were used in a shooting rampage on Feb. 12 at a Salt Lake City mall, the United States attorney for Utah said Thursday.

headline: Michelle Obama Adds New Role to Balancing Act
text: It was a triumphant moment for Barack Obama: He was walking through the Capitol for the very first time as a United States senator in January 2005, trailed by photographers, hangers-on, and finally, his amused wife. Rolling her eyes as she pulled a reporter aside, Michelle Obama said, “Maybe one day, he will do something to warrant all this attention.”

headline: G.M.’s Advertising Chief to Step Down
text: General Motors said yesterday that its North American marketing and advertising chief, Mike Jackson, would leave the company June 15.

headline: Brooklyn: Atlantic Yards Suit Filed in Wrong Court
text: A judge yesterday dismissed a lawsuit filed by tenants challenging the Atlantic Yards construction project, saying they had filed their suit in the wrong court. The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, accused the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency that shepherded the project to approval, of condemning two apartment buildings on the project site without permission from state housing officials to cancel the tenants’ rent-stabilized leases. Justice Walter B. Tolub said the suit should have been filed directly in the Appellate Division of Supreme Court. A. J. Carter, a spokesman for the development corporation, said the agency was pleased with the decision. George Locker, a lawyer for the tenants, said he would file his suit in the appellate court even though he believed the Supreme Court had jurisdiction.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article on Tuesday about the success of Yankees catcher Jorge Posada referred incorrectly to the career standing of the former catcher Tony Peña, the Yankees’ first-base coach, who spoke favorably about Posada’s potential longevity in baseball. Four catchers in major league history  not three  have spent more games behind the plate than Peña. (Iván Rodríguez of the Detroit Tigers passed Peña on the career list earlier this season; the others are Carlton Fisk, Bob Boone and Gary Carter.)

headline: Rudeness, Realism and Russia
text: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and the German foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, held back-to-back meetings with Vladimir Putin on Wednesday to try to calm overheated East-West tensions. The Russians obliged with soothing pronouncements, including an agreement that mutual recriminations should be toned down.

headline: Wartime Furniture Draws Unusual Attention
text: WARTIME FURNITURE

headline: Union Plans Advisory Tool for Young Workers
text: Helped by start-up money from the Rockefeller Foundation, the Service Employees International Union has created a nonprofit organization that plans to help young workers who lack health insurance and are saddled with debt.

headline: The Reclusive Rich Neighbor and Her Report of Intruders
text: SOUTH KENT, Conn. — The road to Anne Bass’s country estate here in the northwest corner of Connecticut overlooks spectacular vistas of clear ponds, rolling hills and fields of wildflowers. It is as picturesque and unspoiled a setting as one is likely to find within two hours’ drive from Manhattan.

headline: Stalemate Appears Broken in Dispute Over Dredging the Delaware Channel
text: CAMDEN, N.J., May 17 — Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania announced on Thursday that he and Gov. Jon S. Corzine had agreed on a plan to deepen the Delaware River shipping channel in a $300 million effort to rejuvenate the once-thriving maritime industry in Philadelphia and South Jersey. The agreement would end a contentious stalemate that had lasted more than 16 months.

headline: Rose Garden Charade
text: Confronted with soaring gasoline prices, a Congress growing more restless by the day about oil dependency and a Supreme Court demanding executive action on global warming emissions, President Bush stepped before the cameras in the Rose Garden the other day and said, essentially, nothing.

headline: North and South Send Trains Across the Korean Frontier
text: MUNSAN, South Korea, May 17 — Trains crossed the border between North and South Korea on Thursday for the first time in 56 years, an event both sides described as a milestone for reconciliation on the divided Korean Peninsula.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A music review in The Arts yesterday about Peter Gallagher’s nightclub debut, at Feinstein’s at the Regency, misstated the closing date of his engagement. It ends June 2, not tonight.

headline: The Suns Forge Ahead Without Stopping for Pity
text: PHOENIX, May 17  Steve Nash was not about to blame the Phoenix Suns’ last-minute loss to the San Antonio Spurs in Game 5 on bad luck or missing players.

headline: Illinois Mass Murderer Is Spared Execution
text: CHICAGO, May 17 — A convicted murderer was spared the death sentence on Thursday, instead receiving life in prison without parole for killing seven people in 1993 at a suburban restaurant.

headline: Fox to Try Fixing Fall Woes and ‘24’; CW Adding 6 Shows
text: The Fox network, emphasizing its position as the network leader in reaching audiences that most advertisers want to reach, announced a prime-time schedule yesterday aimed at solving its chronic problems in the fall, while maintaining its strength in the winter and spring.

headline: Forbidden Games: My Two Sons, My Ex-Husband, My Lover and Me
text: No one bleeds on screen like Isabelle Huppert. I’m talking metaphorically, of course, though given her trembling ferocity, the way this pale sliver of a woman seems to pierce the screen with her absolute commitment to the moment at hand, to the radiance and anguish and bile, it’s hard not to think that she has already sacrificed bits and pieces, gnawing off an arm in one film, opening her veins in another. Watching her in Michael Haneke’s “Piano Teacher” or “Private Property,” a slow-boiling film from the young Belgian Joachim Lafosse, you wonder how much more she can afford to give, how much she has left.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

headline: Mexico: 15 Dead in Police Shootout With Drug Gang
text: The police killed 15 suspected members of a drug gang that had kidnapped and killed five other policeman in Sonora State, just south of Arizona, state officials said. They said the gunmen also killed two civilians. It was the bloodiest gunfight yet in President Felipe Calderón’s five-month offensive against drug cartels, which has been met with almost daily attacks on police officers and soldiers.

headline: Auditing Rule Is Put at Risk by Texas Bill
text: Texas lawmakers are on the verge of rejecting a requirement that state and local governments disclose the cost of the health care they have promised to retired employees.

headline: Equal Parts Myth and Foam, Carefully Melded
text: JERSEY CITY — “This is my first dragon,” Matt Mikas said as he shaped the right foreleg of a 17-foot-long beast he was carving from plastic foam. A plume of fine fuzz rose as he attacked the creature with a wood rasp. “At a certain point the dragon will start speaking. There’s always a time when the image begins to come out of the foam.”

headline: Don’t Blame Bush
text: I’ve been looking at the race for the Republican presidential nomination, and I’ve come to a disturbing conclusion: maybe we’ve all been too hard on President Bush.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article yesterday, about collecting relics, misstated Napoleon’s fate at Waterloo. He formally surrendered a month after the battle; he was not captured there.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about a new branch of the New York Public Library on Jersey Street on the edge of SoHo referred imprecisely to the street. It runs from Mulberry Street past Lafayette Street to Crosby Street  not just from Mulberry to Lafayette, the block where the library is located.

headline: Struggling Yankees Could Use a Close Shave
text: CHICAGO, May 17 — Jason Giambi took out his razor after Thursday’s game and shaved the days-old scruff from his face. He stopped at his upper lip, keeping the beginnings of a mustache, the same look he wore last summer when the Yankees were soaring.

headline: Evacuees Start to Assess Fire Damage in New Jersey
text: BARNEGAT, N.J., May 17 — Two days after fleeing 20-foot flames that licked at their backyards here, residents began returning to their mobile homes Thursday, though some came back to piles of charred rubble where their homes once stood.

headline: Wacky Love, in Translation
text: Anyone who has gone off to Europe with a partner to try to perk up a flagging romance, or dreamed of a happy future with an Italian met on vacation, has had a chance to learn that a change of scenery, or even of language, does not necessarily alter the underlying terms of a relationship.

headline: Paid Sick Leave (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Wednesday about a dispute over fireplace smoke at a Manhattan co-op, the San Remo, that involves Bono, the lead singer of U2, and another rocker, Billy Squier, gave an erroneous age in some copies for Mitch Miller, another resident and the host of the 1960s show “Sing Along With Mitch.” He is 95, not 96.

headline: Fed Chairman Sees Mortgage Damage as Limited
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, helped soothe concerns that problems in the subprime mortgage market would spread, saying today that the Fed sees “no serious broader spillover.”

headline: And as the Abused Heroine, a Pop Princess
text: As someone who has remained immune to the addictive attractions of “American Idol,” I was steeling myself to greet the arrival of Fantasia on Broadway with the kind of hand wringing that proud partisans of the theatah often reserve for despised interlopers from television and pop. O the outrage! O the crass commercialism! O the lack of discipline and proper vocal training!

headline: Giorgio Cavaglieri, Urban Preservationist, Dies at 95
text: Giorgio Cavaglieri, an architect who took his fascination with how buildings and cities change over time from his native Italy to New York, where he helped start and define the city’s preservation movement, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Unlikely Comrades Share Parting Moment
text: WASHINGTON, May 17 — There was a moment, as Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Bush stood together in the bright sunshine on Thursday for their last joint appearance in the Rose Garden, when the shouts of antiwar protesters gathered outside the gates of the White House threatened to drown out their words.

headline: Manhattan: Man Found Dead in Apartment
text: A 70-year-old man was found dead in his Murray Hill apartment Wednesday, having suffered blunt trauma to the head and compression of the neck, Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the chief medical examiner, said yesterday. The man, identified by the police as Jose Prieto, though neighbors knew him as Raul, was a retired graphic designer for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and had lived in the building on East 35th Street for more than 30 years. The police said the death was under investigation.

headline: French Leave Resort and Montesoro
text: French Leave Resort

headline: In Rare Turn, U.S. and Iran Schedule High-Level Security Talks in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, May 17  The United States and Iran on Thursday announced plans to hold rare face-to-face talks this month about Iraqi security, and the police in Mosul made mass arrests after a wave of bombings.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Paris Hilton Sentence Cut

headline: Proof That Things Are People Too (Well, Almost)
text: What do objects want?

headline: Sarkozy Chooses Campaign Aide as New French Premier to Help Smooth Way for Reform Plan
text: PARIS, May 17 — President Nicolas Sarkozy of France on Thursday named François Fillon to be his prime minister in a move intended to smooth the enactment of an ambitious reform program.

headline: Art in Review
text: KELLI CONNELL

headline: In Japan, When Word Was Wed to Image
text: The 18th-century painter and calligrapher Ike Taiga was something like the Pablo Picasso of Japan. The comparison, while superficial, is hard to resist as you wade into the dazzling, almost daunting retrospective of Taiga’s work at the Philadelphia Museum of Art and begin to absorb the many sides of his achievement.

headline: Seasoned Look at Latest in Police Transport
text: Oh, the toys that grownups have these days. Back in the 20th century, when Officer Wilton Sekzer kept the peace on the blistering Coney Island Boardwalk, he actually had to use his feet to propel himself from one end to the other.

headline: Going Like 60 (Tick Tick Tick)
text: George J. Tenet accuses the White House of bungling the Iraq war and setting him up (“slam dunk”) to take the fall. John McCain says he shopped peacefully in a Baghdad market, then cameras pull back to show him in body armor surrounded by armed guards. John and Elizabeth Edwards explain why her cancer won’t stop his run for the presidency. In a prison interview, L. Dennis Kozlowski, Tyco’s former C.E.O., answers questions about his $6,000 shower curtain.

headline: Correction: The Making of Mayberry on the Outer Banks
text: An article last Friday about Manteo, N.C., misspelled the given name of the former director of the school of landscape design at North Carolina State University who worked on in a recent 20-year plan for the town. She is Achva Stein, not Achba.

headline: WPP Group to Buy 24/7 Real Media, an Online Ad Company
text: In an effort to catch up with Google’s fast-growing online advertising business, the WPP Group, the advertising holding company that owns traditional ad agencies like JWT and Grey Global Group, agreed today to pay about $649 million to acquire 24/7 Real Media, an advertising network and technology company.

headline: Votes on Troop Withdrawal Highlight House and Senate Differences
text: It’s a given that the House and Senate are different legislative and political animals.

headline: Sharing the Thrill, and the Heartbreak on the Racetrack
text: The Little Red Feather Stables horse racing syndicate gathered April 20 to watch its 3-year-old filly Guts Game, a 6-5 favorite, in a $44,000, one-mile race at Aqueduct Race Track. Mets catcher Paul Lo Duca was there, as were Kenny Mayne of ESPN and Bob Brittingham, a partner in Afleet Alex, who won the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes in 2005.

headline: Rising Star Knows What, Not Who, Is Cooking
text: IT is late afternoon, and Momofuku Ssam Bar in the food-fixated East Village is idling in self-service mode waiting for the cocktail crowd — pretty much indistinguishable from the pierced and tattooed waiters — to saunter in.

headline: U.S. Championship, Round 3: Some Fireworks on the Top Boards
text: Imaginative attacks ruled the day on the top boards at the Frank Berry United States Championship which is being played in Stillwater, Okla. Alexander Shabalov surged into the lead with his third straight victory, but only a half point behind sit a quartet of strong grandmasters, including Hikaru Nakamura, Alexander Onischuk, Jaan Ehlvest and Gregory Kaidanov. The games can be seen live or replayed  here  at Monroi.com.

headline: Big Oil, BP, and Berkeley
text: Robert Malone, BP America Chairman, speaks at Berkeley, California. Paul Sakuma/AP

headline: London luxury
text: View

headline: Pulse
text: What I'm wearing now, Gola sports shoes, Noko baby clothing and more.

headline: ‘Journey’s End’ to End; ‘Moon’ Turns Green; New Address for the Grinch
text: "Journey's End," the critically acclaimed World War I drama, could take home as many as six Tony Awards on June 10, including one for best revival of a play.

headline: Theater  Briefs
text: It will be "110 in the Shade" for a couple of weeks more. The Roundabout Theater Company announced yesterday that its revival of the musical starring Audra McDonald has been extended for two weeks, through July 29, at Studio 54.

headline: Russian Developer Plans $2.2 Billion I.P.O.
text: The PIK Group, a Russian residential property developer, said on Friday it planned to raise up to $2.2 billion through an initial public offering in London and Moscow that would value the group at up to $14.1 billion. The I.P.O., which would be one of the largest to date by a European property developer, has been priced at between $25 and $31 a share.

headline: Ferrovial to Sell Majority Stake in Naples Airport, Report Says
text: Grupo Ferrovial, the Spanish builder that spent $19 billion buying the British airport operator BAA, is preparing to sell its 65 percent stake in Naples International Airport, Bloomberg News reported. Ferrovial this week asked investment banks to bid for a contract to handle the sale of the stake, which has a value of at least 300 million euros ($409 million), Bloomberg said.

headline: Venture-Backed Amicus Sets I.P.O. Price
text: A biopharmaceutical company, Amicus Therapeutics set its planned initial public offering on Thursday at 5 million shares for an estimated $14 to $16 each. Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch, J.P. Morgan, Lazard Capital Markets, and Pacific Growth Equities are underwriting the I.P.O., according to an amended filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Calls to Remove CVS/Caremark Director
text: An investment advisory firm is calling for the board of CVS/Caremark to remove a director, Roger L. Headrick, amid concern that his re-election was aided by “phantom votes,” or votes cast without guidance from shareholders.

headline: Does Blackstone Want the Best of Everthing?
text: Blackstone Group‘s proposed initial public offering has become a focal point for criticism, in part because its structure gives the impression that the private equity firm wants to have its cake and eat it, too, The Financial Times’s Lex column writes. It seems to be pushing the boundaries in order to get favorable tax treatment while seeking to avoid undesired regulatory restraints. There are good reasons for the firm to go public, Lex writes, but the question is on what terms.

headline: Institutional Venture Partners Raises $600 Million for Late-Stage Deals
text: A Silicon Valley venture firm, Institutional Venture Partners, raised $600 million in the largest venture fund in its 26-year history, double the size of its previous fund, as it shifts its focus to late-stage investments.

headline: Phillips Sells $2.5 Billion in Taiwan Semiconductor Shares
text: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe’s largest consumer electronics maker, sold $2.56 billion of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing shares as part of a plan to shed its entire stake in the chipmaker within three years.

headline: G.E. Nears $11 Billion Deal to Sell Plastics Unit
text: General Electric is close to reaching an agreement to sell its plastics division for about $11 billion to Saudi Arabia’s largest public company, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation, according to press reports.

headline: Russia Sues Bank of New York Over Money Laundering
text: The Federal Customs Service of Russia is seeking $22.5 billion in damages from the Bank of New York over accusations of money laundering in the 1990s.

headline: Ex-Chief of Chip Maker May Lose Proxy Fight
text: The former chief executive of Atmel, George Perlegos, appears unlikely to win back control of his company on Friday when his plan to replace five board members goes before shareholders, according to The San Jose Mercury News.

headline: Chilean Retailers in $3.7 Billion Deal
text: SACI Falabella, the biggest operator of department-stores in Chile, agreed to buy a supermarket owner, Distribucion Y Servicio D&S, for $3.7 billion to form one of the biggest retailers in Latin America and to expand internationally.

headline: Motorola Rings Up Deal for Modulus
text: Motorola agreed to acquire closely held Modulus Video, a maker of video coding compression systems, for an undisclosed price. Motorola said the Modulus acquisition will complement the company’s recent purchases of four other companies involved in the creation and delivery of “an integrated, end-to-end video delivery system for multiple network architectures.”

headline: After Failed Bid, Qantas Chairwoman Decides to Retire
text: Margaret A. Jackson, the chairwoman of Qantas Airways, who was one of the proponents of a failed attempt to take the airline private, will retire, a company spokesman said Thursday. Ms. Jackson, 54, told the board that she would not seek re-election at the airline’s annual meeting in October.

headline: 2 Banks See Departures at Hedge Fund Businesses
text: Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers have both experienced high-level departures in their hedge-fund-related businesses, the Financial News reported. The turnover comes as investment banks have been trying to capture more business from these private pools of capital. Bear Stearns’s co-head of prime brokerage, Leonard Feder, left the firm for personal reasons, while Lehman lost Jin Park, deputy chief investment officer of its fund of hedge funds unit.

headline: Ex-Ahold Official Sentenced
text: A former marketing executive of the American-based food distribution unit of the Dutch food retailer Ahold was sentenced to seven years in prison by a federal judge yesterday for his role in an $800 million accounting fraud.

headline: Financier Says He Is Not Target of Swiss Arms Investigation
text: A Syrian-born financier who helped broker a $79 billion arms contract between BAE Systems and Saudi Arabia two decades ago said Thursday that he was not a target of a money-laundering investigation opened this week by the Swiss authorities.

headline: KB Home in Talks to Sell Stake in French Homebuilder
text: Los Angeles-based KB Home said Thursday it was in exclusive talks to sell its controlling stake in a French homebuilder for 600 million euros ($813 million) to a European buyout shop. Moving quickly to sell an operation that is outperforming its activities in the United States, KB Home said it is in talks to sell the 49 percent stake in the French unit, Kaufman & Broad, for 55 euros a share to PAI Partners, a Paris-based private-equity firm.

headline: Bank of America’s Private Banking Chief to Step Down
text: The Bank of America, which expects to complete its $3.3 billion purchase of Charles Schwab‘s U.S. Trust private banking arm this fall. said Thursday that its private banking chief, Jane Magpiong, plans to leave the company.

headline: BP and Rio Tinto Team Up for Venture
text: The Rio Tinto Group, a mining company that is a major producer of coal, will join BP to develop power generation plants that will pump their carbon dioxide emissions underground to help curb global warming. The companies said Thursday that Rio would pay BP $32 million for a 50 percent stake in a new company, to be called Hydrogen Energy. BP will fold its carbon capture and storage operations into the new entity.

headline: Citigroup Works Both Sides of Distiller Deal
text: Bankers at Citigroup may celebrate the latest Indian cross-border takeover with a few extra drams of Scotch. The bank played a leading role on both sides of the deal, the buyout of a 163-year-old Scottish distiller by one of India’s most aggressive acquirers.

headline: Is EMI’s Offer-Soliciting Just a Tease for Warner?
text: With indications pointing toward the European Union’s likely approval of both the SonyBMG merger and the Universal Music Group‘s purchase of BMG Music Publishing, London-based EMI Group has moved into full sale mode, the New York Post reported citing unidentified sources.

headline: In Search for a New Financial Sheriff, One Stands Out
text: As New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer won national attention by becoming the new sheriff in finance, taking on Wall Street and mutual funds and the insurance industry.

headline: Iacocca: Hard on Daimler, Cautious on Private Equity
text: Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler‘s former chairman and cigar-chomping pitchman, is not mincing words on what led to what he calls Chrysler’s “desperation sale to Cerberus Capital Management.”

headline: A Fractured Heart and a Filthy Mouth
text: A Michael Keaton outing is always cause for celebration, no matter how ramshackle the vehicle ("First Daughter," anyone?) or paper-thin the role. He's an actor who works on the balls of his feet, forever poised for flight or the next reckless opportunity. Unpredictability is his game, and when he's on top of it, he can make you forget that there's a script.

headline: Fishing for a Buyer, Trump Entertainment Gets Some Nibbles
text: Trump Entertainment Resorts, the casino company controlled by Donald J. Trump, has received preliminary offers from possible buyers, although details on who the potential suitors might be were not disclosed.

headline: The 24/7 Real Media Sale: A Story of ‘Frenemies’
text: With the purchase of 24/7 Real Media, WPP Group‘s chief executive, Martin Sorrell, who called Google a “frenemy” last fall, is hoping to become a frenemy himself.

headline: The Breakdown of a Breakdown
text: Movie audiences hoping to spend a cheery couple of hours with Alzheimer's disease this week will have a choice, as Yukihiko Tsutsumi's "Memories of Tomorrow" joins Sarah Polley's "Away From Her" in theaters. But while Ms. Polley maintains a cool, respectful distance from her victim's suffering, Mr. Tsutsumi would like us to experience every symptom for ourselves.

headline: Cerberus May Put Together Bid for BCE, Report Says
text: Cerberus Capital Management, fresh from signing its $7.2 billion deal for Chrysler, is courting Shaw Communications and CanWest Global Communications to join a possible buying group for one of Canada’s biggest companies, BCE, according to The Globe and Mail.

headline: Cadbury’s Drinks Unit Attracts a Dozen Bidders, Report Says
text: Britain’s Cadbury Schweppes has received about a dozen expressions of interest in its United States drinks business, Reuters reported.

headline: What’s Happened to the Lawyers Who Worked for Spitzer?
text: After reining in Wall Street analysts, curbing mutual fund trading abuses and corralling some of the biggest insurance companies in the industry, what do you do for an encore? For the lawyers who worked under Eliot Spitzer in the New York attorney general’s office, the options have ranged from law firm partnerships to state agency heads, The New York Times found.

headline: Germany Stands Alone in Battle to Rein in Hedge Funds
text: Germany will make a last-ditch effort Friday to persuade the world’s top economic powers to tighten their grip on hedge funds and private equity firms. But even before these countries’ finance ministers convened at a Group of 8 meeting, the push was being written off as futile, illustrating Germany’s isolation in its desire to rein in the booming industry.

headline: Bernanke’s Buyout-Lending Blues
text: The struggling United States housing market is not the only thing worrying Federal Reserve Chairman Ben S. Bernanke. Speaking at a conference Thursday in Chicago, Mr. Bernanke sounded his first public warning about potential dangers for banks that are helping to finance the recent run of leveraged buyouts. Eager for the lucrative business brought by private equity deals, many banks have been going the extra mile to make loans on friendly terms.

headline: UniCredit May Announce Capitalia Deal, Report Says
text: UniCredit, Italy’s biggest bank, may be close to announcing plans to acquire a smaller competitor, Capitalia, Bloomberg News reported. Shares were halted for the day on Friday pending news, a Milan stock exchange spokeswoman said.

headline: In Deal for Chrysler, Snow’s Role Extends a Trend
text: At a news conference this week in Stuttgart, Germany, the usually secretive private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management was in the spotlight, announcing an agreement to take control of Chrysler.

headline: 2008: Spouses and Race
text: The Times’s Jodi Kantor and Jeff Zeleny profile Michelle Obama, calling hers “the trickiest of political performances.” A part of that trickiness is the ambiguity of race’s role in the election. The Washington Post reports on the split loyalties that many black lawmakers are grappling with when choosing their favorite candidate:

headline: Dead-End Jobs
text: Ever since Bram Stoker gave Count Dracula a Transylvanian lineage, Eastern Europe has been a familiar setting for horror tales. "Severance" continues the tradition by turning a corporate retreat in a Hungarian forest into a bloody game of whack-a-mole. (Team building and paintballing are so last year.)

headline: Microsoft Pays Up for Online Advertising Firm aQuantive
text: Microsoft said Friday it would buy aQuantive, an online advertising firm, for $66.50 a share in cash. The deal, valued at $6 billion, was easily Microsoft’s largest acquisition ever and the price represented an eye-popping 85 percent premium to aQuantive’s closing price Thursday.

headline: Reflections in Super 8
text: The premise of "Rolling Like a Stone" makes it sound like a Christopher Guest comedy: members of the 1960s Swedish rock bands the Namelosers and the Gonks and some of their friends and groupies pore over Super 8 snippets from a 1965 party they attended with the Rolling Stones, trying to remember the event and their lives at that time.

headline: The Life of a Trust Fund Punk
text: There may be a point to "The Boy Who Cried Bitch: The Adolescent Years," a purportedly fact-based psychodrama about the teenage evolution of a future serial killer. But the film is so clumsily written and directed, and the performances so one-note, that any potential for enlightenment is suffocated.

headline: Closer to War
text: What "Six Days" is doing in theatrical release rather than on the History Channel isn't quite clear; the film, about the 1967 war in the Middle East, is a standard-issue documentary, and a rather plodding one. But at least it makes for an interesting compare-and-contrast exercise.

headline: A Whiter Shade of Green
text: Van Jones, writing at the Huffington Post, has an unusual criticism of the environmental movement: that it presents itself as being as white as the polar ice caps it’s trying to save. “I see a disturbing pattern of exclusivity that is starting to set in,” Jones writes. “And that kind of elitism can sow the seeds for a very dangerous, populist backlash, down the line. To see what I mean, just flip through the pages of Vanity Fair’s recent green issue (the one with Leo DiCaprio and that cute polar bear cub on the cover) … Now, count the non-white Americans in the whole magazine. Okay. Now try to find the working-class environmentalists, the ones trying to protect their kids from pollution at the fence-line?” Vanity Fair, elitist? Say it isn’t so …

headline: Who’s the New Sheriff?
text: The Empire Zone’s colleagues in the business section ponder who has filled the gap among state attorneys general as the new ‘Sheriff of Wall Street,’ as Gov. Eliot Spitzer was often called in his previous job.

headline: The War on Terror Weakens Our Foundations
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s May 18 column, “The Insurgent Advantage.”

headline: Survey Says…
text: About two and a half weeks ago I provided a link from this blog to a survey that Sherri Kimes, a professor at Cornell University, is doing. The survey concerns diners’ attitudes and behavior when it comes to making reservations at restaurants and dealing with the reservation policies that restaurants have. I described it in that blog post, where I also said that from time to time, Professor Kimes would fill me in — and I would in turn fill you in — on bits and pieces of what the survey was showing.

headline: Teaching a Door New Tricks
text: I’ll wrap up my coverage of this year’s Modern Marvels Invent Now competition with one more of my favorites.

headline: In Cycling, a Race to the Bottom
text: On Thursday, a sports blog called Off Wing Opinion posted a preview of a big day at the trial of Floyd Landis, the Tour de France champion who is accused of doping on his way to the 2006 title.

headline: Dance of a Billion Veils
text: Diane Cardwell listened in yesterday as Mark Green, in his new non-politician role, interviewed his former opponent, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, on Air America radio for a program to be broadcast next week. (WNBC has video).

headline: Clear Channel Accepts Revised Takeover Bid
text: Clear Channel Communications is hoping that an extra 20 cents a share, plus the option to own a piece of the company, will finally clear the way for its controversial buyout to go through. The radio broadcasting giant said Friday that it had agreed to amend the terms of the buyout to include $39.20 in cash for each Clear Channel share, up from $39, and a provision allowing shareholders to take stock in the post-takeover company instead of cash. The “stub equity,” as the stock portion is commonly called, would be limited to 30 percent of Clear Channel’s equity and would not be listed on any exchange, Clear Channel said in a press release.

headline: The Rent Went Up $2,100, but Was the Increase Legal?
text: Q I moved into an apartment that a previous tenant lived in for more than 20 years. The rent history I dug up shows that rent was $400 a month and that the apartment was rent-stabilized. I was never told that the unit was stabilized and wasn't provided with any information as to why the rent was increased to $2,500. Do I have any options?

headline: Before the aQuantive Deal, Lots of Well-Timed Trades
text: Whether it was because of sheer luck or an inside tip, options traders made some big bets on aQuantive on Thursday — just in time to cash in on the company’s $6 billion deal to be acquired by Microsoft. Trading in aQuantive’s options has been active for weeks, driven in part by the rampant takeover speculation surrounding many independent Web advertising firms since Google‘s $3.1 billion deal for DoubleClick in mid-April. But according to Jon Najarian, co-founder of OptionMonster, activity in aQuantive’s call options went through the roof on Thursday, with a volume of 9,363 contracts, or more than five times the average volume on the previous five days.

headline: McCain-Giuliani Fan-Fest
text: Love was in the air when Senator John McCain and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani spoke before New York Republicans last night.

headline: The Cure for Road Rage?
text: In his weekly call-in radio show on WABC, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said his congestion pricing proposal received a cordial reception in Albany earlier this week but he hinted at a long fight ahead.

headline: The People, They Are a-Changin’
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Bloomberg on the Guest Worker Deal: ‘Totally Impractical’
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has been a staunch advocate of easing immigration restrictions, offered harsh words for the guest-worker provision in the immigration deal struck Thursday between senators and the White House.

headline: Treasure Hunt Inc.
text: A company that has made a business out of finding and picking over shipwrecks and then selling the booty announced today that it had a whole lot more booty to sell.

headline: The House and the Senate on Iraq
text: It’s a given that the House and Senate are different legislative and political animals.

headline: More Hellfire From Ford Boycotters
text: Is the Ford Motor Company the “top pro-homosexual sponsor” on all of network television? That’s what the American Family Association said this week.

headline: Microsoft: Tight-Fisted No More?
text: Microsoft had about $28 billion in cash and short-term investment on March 31, an amount the CIA World Factbook tells us is more than twice the gross domestic product of Iceland. But despite its riches, the software giant has shied away from large acquisitions, especially in the past five years or so. That is part of the reason Friday’s $6 billion cash bid for online advertising company aQuantive was so surprising. (The 85 percent premium it agreed to pay was something of a shock as well.)

headline: Bruno, Steaming
text: Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno spoke after Rudolph Giuliani and before Senator John McCain last night at a Manhattan fund-raiser for the state Republican Party.

headline: For Chrysler Workers, Private Equity May Cut Both Ways
text: When United Auto Workers president Ron Gettelfinger annouced Monday that his union supported the sale of Chrysler to Cerberus Capital Management, it case caused whiplash for many industry observers. Before the deal was announced, the U.A.W. had publicly opposed selling the beleaguered auto maker to a buyout firm, citing the potential for waves of layoffs that may follow.

headline: Making a Case for Congestion Pricing
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg faces huge hurdles in getting the State Legislature to go along with his congestion pricing proposal, but there were indications at a forum this morning that local officials are sympathetic to his position.

headline: For One Hedge Fund, April Was the Cruelest Month
text: For all the talk about how hedge funds are raking in cash and earning double-digit returns all the time, it’s helpful to remember that they can lose — and lose big. Witness the letter that Jurg Buhler, managing director of Dighton Capital, recently sent to investors in his small ($34 million) fund registered in the Cayman Islands.

headline: Weekend Reading: The State of Investment Banks
text: The Economist this week offers a huge package on investment banks, tracing their history and all the “thrills and spills” along the way to the highly profitable present and the highly uncertain, risk-laden future. According to the magazine, while buyout firms and hedge funds are getting most of the attention, glory and money these days, investment bankers don’t mind. When “bankers discuss the fabulous fortunes accruing to these firms’ founders, they do so without envy,” The Economist writes.

headline: The Immigration Debate
text: Long before the immigration deal was announced on Thursday, candidates in the 2008 presidential field and indeed, the down-ballot field, had faced a lot of questions inside and outside the border states over the nation’s policies.

headline: The Battle for New York
text: We’re about four hours from first pitch here at frigid Shea Stadium. Note to fans planning to attend tonight’s game against the Yankees: dress warmly. You’ll thank me later.

headline: Final Call
text: On the Mediterranean island of Lampedusa, a canine traveler rushes to make his flight.

headline: The Beauty of Green
text: Where luxury living meets eco-friendly construction. A video tour.

headline: Two Steps Forward, One Back
text: There was lots of good news to be found in the new plans.

headline: McCain's "Drunken Sailor"
text: John McCain invokes "Drunken Sailor" at a recent Republican primary debate. (source: FOX News Channel)

headline: Lining Up Behind Giuliani
text: Last night, Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, was effusive in his praise of both Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain at a state Republican Party fundraiser in Manhattan.

headline: Tabloid’s Pre-emptive Strike
text: The New York Post came out swinging today against charges made by a former staffer.

headline: Next Up at the World Bank
text: Well, we no longer have Paul Wolfowitz to kick around any more, so who’s next?

headline: A New Campaign Media Entry
text: Come fall, campaign junkies will have yet another way to get their political news, one that will rely largely on ordinary citizens, not political reporters or media pundits.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Seeking the Real in a Desert City Known for Artifice
text: Dubai is place that caters to the super-wealthy, but savvy travelers can find a few welcome bargains if they look hard enough. Do you have tips and suggestions how to enjoy Dubai cheaply? Share your suggestions here.

headline: Yankee Math
text: Even if they lose tonight, the Yankees can’t fall another full game behind the Boston Red Sox. That’s because the Red Sox have already been rained out.

headline: What Precautions Are Necessary for a Safari in Kenya?
text: I am planning a photo safari to Kenya and am told I need vaccinations and malaria protection. My tour guide tells me to see my doctor; Condé Nast Traveler magazine tells me to see Johns Hopkins Travel Medicine; the Department of Health and Human Services refers me to Passport Health travel clinics; my doctor refers me to a Centers for Disease Control Web site (www.cdc.gov/travel) and tells me to look up a member of the International Society of Travel Medicine. Please help; there are too many choices.

headline: Third M-Tel Masters: The Race Tightens
text: The M-Tel Masters is proving to be very competitive. Krishnan Sasikiran of India, who surged into the lead in round 7, was beaten in round 8 by the American Gata Kamsky. (The game can be replayed here.) Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu of Romania also won, beating Michael Adams of England. (Click here to replay the game.) So with two rounds to play, Sasikiran still leads with 4.5 out of 8, followed by Kamsky, Nisipeanu, Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria and Shakhriyar Mamedyarov of Azerbaijan, all with 4, and Adams with 3.5.

headline: As Losses Mount, Torre Praises the Effort
text: The first thing I heard Joe Torre say as I wedged my way into the visiting manager’s office at Shea Stadium tonight was this: “Everyone’s on the top rail. Everyone’s pulling for everyone else. That’s all we have to hang on to right now.”

headline: Childress Racing and D.E.I. Plan to Merge Engine Shops
text: CONCORD, N.C., May 18 — Richard Childress Racing and Dale Earnhardt Inc., two high-profile Nascar Nextel Cup teams, announced Friday that they would consolidate their engine shops in a move to remain competitive with Ford, Toyota and Hendrick Motorsports.

headline: Eviction Notice Is Latest Russian Move Against Journalists
text: MOSCOW, May 18 — The largest society of independent journalists in Russia, long critical of the Kremlin’s curtailment of the independent news media, defied a government eviction notice on Friday, saying it would try to remain in its offices in spite of state pressure.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Online Ad Company
text: Microsoft said today that it would buy the online advertising company aQuantive for $66.50 a share, or approximately $6 billion. It is Microsoft’s largest acquisition ever, and the latest in a flurry of deals for online advertising firms by big Internet and media companies.

headline: Atmel Shareholders Vote Down Fired Chief’s Plan to Oust Board
text: Shareholders in the Atmel Corporation rejected a proposal yesterday by the former chief executive, George Perlegos, to remove five directors after the company promised to add two new directors and focus on its semiconductor unit.

headline: One Composer, Two Choreographers, Three Geniuses
text: I cherish an old cartoon that depicts an all-Tchaikovsky concert at which cygnets (“Swan Lake,” of course) are being thwacked by cannonballs (the “1812 Overture”). A Tchaikovsky’s Greatest Hits evening will always draw. But what makes New York City Ballet’s new program, “Three Masters — Tschaikovsky, Balanchine, Robbins,” fascinating (yes, City Ballet spells the composer’s name with an “s,” as in “Tsch ... You know who”) is that it’s a strong triple bill made up of works that, except among balletgoers, aren’t among the composer’s best known or most generally admired.

headline: Gómez Is Making a Name With His Attacking Style
text: Carlos Gómez has spent less than a week in the major leagues. He has 15 at-bats. He lives in a hotel a few blocks from Shea Stadium.

headline: BMW Oracle Falls Further Back
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 18 (AP)  After dominating the early rounds of the Louis Vuitton Cup, BMW Oracle Racing has stumbled at the worst possible time.

headline: Evolution Opponent Is in Line for Schools Post
text: The National Association of State Boards of Education will elect officers in July, and for one office, president-elect, there is only one candidate: a member of the Kansas school board who supported its efforts against the teaching of evolution.

headline: Fishing on a Belizean Island and Enjoying a Nice Day
text: PLACENCIA, Belize — The fertile reefs and flats of this Central American nation may be the best place for a flyfisher to score a grand slam, which consists of catching a bonefish, a tarpon and a permit on a fly, all in the same day. But when you are on a family vacation instead of on a mission, and staying in a pleasant, sleepy seaside village instead of Fort Flyfisher, it’s wiser to set aside those dreams of angling immortality, shove a few beers into the cooler, and just kick back and see what the day brings.

headline: New in New York: A Bus Ride on the Hudson River
text: Until this week, tourists in Manhattan who wanted to go for a cruise on the Hudson River had to find the river first. Now, they can simply hail a boat in Times Square.

headline: Clemens Takes First Step in His Return to the Mound
text: TAMPA, Fla., May 18 — For two innings Friday night, it seemed preposterous to think Roger Clemens could be ready by the end of the month to pitch for the Yankees. As he pitched for the Class A Tampa Yankees, his two-seam fastball had no life and he was throwing curveball after curveball, as if he had nothing else to offer.

headline: British Girl Vanishes in Portugal, and Her Country Grieves
text: LONDON, May 18 — For 15 days, the wide eyes and waiflike features of a child of 4 have stared out at Britons from television screens and newspaper front pages, T-shirts and posters with a simple message: find me.

headline: For Ballet’s Shifting Casts, a Big Question: Who Will Lift It to the Realm of Poetry?
text: There was lush beauty in the arch of Diana Vishneva’s resilient back and in her ethereal arms as she portrayed the doomed temple dancer Nikiya in American Ballet Theater’s “Bayadère” on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. And the hungry passion of her fleeting first-act encounter with Solor, danced by Ethan Stiefel, made his eventual betrayal even more surprising.

headline: Language and Diplomacy (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ochoa Conquers Course and Moves Into a First-Place Tie at Sybase
text: CLIFTON, N.J., May 18 — Stuffed in the middle of Lorena Ochoa’s golf bag is a light-blue head cover with a Superman logo. It was gift she received before her freshman year of college, and it has been protecting her driver since.

headline: Open House at Mosque of Suspects Proves Tense
text: PALMYRA, N.J., May 18 — The man sat in the back row of the mosque, his arms folded, unsure whether his hard opinions would change.

headline: Pérez Shows Up the Yankees in a Crowd Pleaser
text: In the Mets’ clubhouse, Oliver Pérez is about as invisible as anyone 6 feet 3 inches can be. The rare times he is at his locker, Pérez sits staring spellbound at his cellphone or portable video game player.

headline: Sarkozy’s Top Diplomat: Undiplomatic Opposite
text: PARIS

headline: Veterans of Storm Find Relief in Combat
text: HARVEY, La., May 16 — For Brett Hughes, the best way to cope with the stresses of life after Hurricane Katrina turned out to be flipping another guy over onto the floor, choking off his blood supply and threatening to mangle his limbs.

headline: Shoppers Are Holding Back, but Billionaires Are Buying
text: A PRIVATE equity fund and some well-known billionaires were in acquisitive moods this week. Less affluent shoppers  consumers, that is  were more restrained, as the results of retailers showed, but Amazon hopes to tempt them with music. Tyco is still bleeding.

headline: Estonia Computers Blitzed, Possibly by the Russians
text: MOSCOW, May 18 — The computer attacks, apparently originating in Russia, first hit the Web site of Estonia’s prime minister on April 27, the day the country was mired in protest and violence. The president’s site went down, too, and soon so did those of several departments in a wired country that touts its paperless government and likes to call itself E-stonia.

headline: Don’t Finance Anyone Over 27
text: THE environment for today’s entrepreneurs is far different in a number of ways from the boom of the late ’90s, Steven Levy noted this week in Newsweek.

headline: Macho Meets the Mystical in a Himalayan River Trek
text: The tiny kingdom of Bhutan was ranked the eighth-happiest country on earth in a study last year by a British scientist at the University of Leicester in England. It is probably no coincidence that the Bhutanese do not go in for white-water kayaking. Leave it to the West to import this perilous activity and make a documentary about it.

headline: A Television Revolution? Not Shown at Upfronts
text: This year’s television upfront presentations, where the networks open giant briefcases and introduce samples from their fall lineups to advertisers, came and went with whimpers.

headline: The Grace and Humor of the Body Imperfect
text: Lawrence Goldhuber has made a career of defying expectations. He weighs, by varying reports, 300 to 350 pounds, unusual, to say the least, for a dancer. But Mr. Goldhuber had a memorable nine-year career with Bill T. Jones’s company before establishing a reputation as a witty, touching dance-maker.

headline: Their Master’s Voice
text: In March 2004, the acting attorney general distrusted Alberto Gonzales so much that he wouldn’t meet with him at the White House without a witness. Eight months later, President Bush promoted Mr. Gonzales from White House counsel to attorney general, the top law enforcement job in the land. The president is still standing by his man, ignoring Mr. Gonzales’s efforts to mislead Congress, his disregard for the Constitution and his gross neglect of even basic bureaucratic duties.

headline: Say-on-Pay Gets Support at Verizon
text: A proposal to give Verizon Communications’ shareholders a voice in its executive pay practices passed with 50.18 percent of the vote, the company said yesterday — the clearest sign yet of investor irritation over chief executive compensation.

headline: China Will Allow Its Currency to Fluctuate More
text: HONG KONG, May 18 — China’s central bank announced late today that it would begin allowing the country’s currency to fluctuate more during each day’s foreign exchange trading but again rebuffed demands from the United States and Europe for a sustained rise in the currency’s value.

headline: ’08 Candidates Weighing Consequences as They Take Sides on Immigration Plan
text: The bipartisan immigration proposal being taken up by Congress is putting pressure on the leading presidential candidates to take a position on the issue, which could set them up for confrontations with influential constituencies within the two parties.

headline: Mediate Co-op Disputes (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: State Attorney General Investigating Manhattan Real Estate Practices
text: New York State is investigating Manhattan real estate practices, seeking information about whether brokers pressured appraisers to inflate property values as prices doubled in the last five years.

headline: Witness Describes Training Padilla Reportedly Received
text: MIAMI, May 18  Despite vigorous defense efforts to bar his testimony, a cooperating witness in the case against Jose Padilla was allowed on Friday to describe a Qaeda training camp that prosecutors say Mr. Padilla attended.

headline: The Life of a Marine Sergeant, and His Sacrifice in the Field
text: The war in Iraq may be complicated and confusing, but the Memorial Day story from it told in “Act of Honor,” tonight on the History Channel, is as basic and noble as war stories get: one soldier chooses to die so that his comrades can live.

headline: 2 Activists Are Under House Arrest and Barred From Leaving China
text: BEIJING, May 18  A young Chinese couple who have promoted a variety of delicate social and political causes were barred from leaving the country on Friday and placed under house arrest, the couple said.

headline: A Bountiful Undersea Find, Sure to Invite Debate
text: MIAMI, May 18 — Explorers for a shipwreck exploration company based in Tampa said Friday that they had located a treasure estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars in what may be the richest undersea treasure recovery to date.

headline: In an Era of Revelation, Even a Dynasty Is Questioned
text: There are certain go-to benchmarks of a baseball epoch in which the hope chest of nostalgia has been looted by steroid suspicions:

headline: You Want a Simple Life? It’ll Cost You
text: WHEN my family and I moved full time to a small village in the Catskills a few months ago, I was amazed by how cheap everything seemed to be.

headline: The Cavendish Wasn’t the Only Game in Town
text: The World Bridge Productions Pairs was run alongside the late stages of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs, held outside Las Vegas last weekend. This was a much smaller affair. Only 28 pairs entered the three-session World Bridge event, for which the entry fee was $750 a pair.

headline: Recalling the Music and the Spirit of a ‘Mother of Many’
text: The musical and the spiritual were inseparable during the Alice Coltrane Ascension Ceremony, a memorial held on Thursday night at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. In a lengthy but carefully organized program, a succession of musicians and speakers attested to a life of devotion. From a screen beside the altar, her projected image cast a beatific gaze.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about a case before the Connecticut Supreme Court that questions whether civil unions for same-sex couples fulfill the state’s constitutional obligation to treat individuals equally misidentified the legal standard that would be applied if the court found that gay men and lesbians were a “suspect class,” a status, like membership in a racial minority, that makes laws that categorize on that basis suspect. The standard is “heightened scrutiny,” which requires the state to prove that discrimination against gay men and lesbians is related to an important or compelling government interest; it is not “rational basis,” a more relaxed standard in which the state is required to show only that it had such a basis for making a distinction between single-sex and heterosexual couples.

headline: A Candidacy That May Test a Friendship’s Ties
text: Consider the pros and cons for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton:

headline: Rally by Suns Falls Short, as Does Their Season
text: SAN ANTONIO, May 18 — Steve Nash tried to fend off elimination as well as thoughts of “what if” by staging one last desperate rally for the Phoenix Suns.

headline: Bus Kills Man on Bicycle After Robbery
text: A thief was killed by a city bus in the South Bronx yesterday as he fled across a busy intersection on a bicycle after stealing a gold chain from a jewelry store, the police said.

headline: Manipulating Kids (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rabbi’s Campaign for Kosher Standards Expands to Include Call for Social Justice
text: MENDOTA HEIGHTS, Minn.

headline: Con Ed Will Inspect Its Grates
text: Consolidated Edison plans to inspect all 18,000 of its grates in the city and in Westchester County, a spokesman said yesterday, one day after a woman fell through a sidewalk grate in Midtown.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Two Million Little Dollars

headline: A ‘Straddling’ Governor Worries Environmentalists
text: TRENTON, May 18  As a United States senator, and as a governor, Jon S. Corzine has cultivated a reputation in New Jersey as an ally of environmentalists.

headline: China Slightly Loosens the Reins on Its Currency’s Market Fluctuation
text: HONG KONG, May 18 — China’s central bank announced Friday that it would begin allowing the country’s currency to fluctuate more during each day’s foreign exchange trading, but again rebuffed demands from the United States and Europe for a sustained rise in the currency.

headline: Immigration Deal: A Step Forward? (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: World View Podcast
text: CALVIN SIMS. Welcome to The New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe. I’m Calvin Sims of The Times. I spent 10 years as a foreign correspondent for the paper.

headline: Psychologist Says Attacker Exaggerated Signs of Illness
text: A former fashion writer had already planned to carry out a crime spree when he sexually abused a onetime co-worker in 2005, a psychologist for the prosecution testified yesterday.

headline: Internet Giants Vie to Snap Up Web Ad Firms
text: It’s a good time to be an Internet advertising company.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture in The Arts on Tuesday with an article about the Broadway season was published in error. The photograph, of a scene from “Grey Gardens,” showed the Off Broadway production, not the one on Broadway. The actress on the left, Audrey Twitchell, is not in the Broadway production.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article yesterday about the role that Barack Obama’s wife, Michelle, is playing in his presidential campaign rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Valerie Jarrett, a friend of the Obamas who commented on their decision that he would run. She said in a telephone interview, “Barack and Michelle thought long and hard about this decision before they made it”  not that they “fought” long and hard.

headline: U.S. Forces Seize 6 Linked to Armor-Piercing Bombs
text: BAGHDAD, May 18  American soldiers on Friday captured six men in northeast Baghdad suspected of involvement in smuggling materials for deadly armor-piercing bombs, the military said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about the rising number of abortions among unmarried women in China gave the incorrect location in some copies for Qingdao, a city where a nongovernmental abortion clinic opened in 2003. It is on the Yellow Sea, not the Bohai Sea.

headline: Hunt for Fugitive Beset by Confusion, Report Says
text: The biggest manhunt in state history — the five-month search for Ralph J. Phillips last year in the backwoods of western New York — was thwarted time and again by communications problems, command confusion, troopers’ misjudgments and over-reliance on an elite mobile unit, a state police report says.

headline: Sobered by Its PlayStation 3’s Tumble, Sony Shows Its New Toys With a Soft Pitch
text: SAN DIEGO, May 16 — Don’t envy Jack Tretton. As the new chief executive of Sony Computer Entertainment America, Mr. Tretton may have the toughest job in the video game business (with the possible exception of his boss, Kazuo Hirai, who is taking over Sony’s global game operation).

headline: At a University in India, New Attacks on an Old Style: Erotic Art
text: NEW DELHI, May 18 — It’s a heady time for Indian contemporary art. Never before has it fetched such extravagant prices and acclaim abroad. Never before have Indians at home been so prosperous as to support a proliferation of galleries, exhibitions and even investment funds devoted to art.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about a partnership of Vornado Realty Trust and Donald J. Trump, which controls two buildings in New York and San Francisco, misstated the role of David H. Pikus in mediation proceedings involving Mr. Trump and his former partners in a development on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Mr. Pikus is the special discovery master, in charge of working out discovery schedules and procedures  not the mediator, who is Simeon H. Baum, president of Resolve Mediation Services Inc.

headline: Putting Aside His Past Criticisms, Teamsters’ Chief Is on Mission to China
text: SHANGHAI, May 18 — Three years ago, the head of the Teamsters union, James P. Hoffa, derided China as xenophobic. He said that China did not believe in free trade and that the United States was losing jobs because China was unwilling to buy American goods.

headline: Shock Therapy to Resuscitate Rite-Aid Chain
text: Mary Sammons joined Rite-Aid as president and chief operating officer in 1999, part of a team brought in to save the company, the third-largest drugstore chain, from bankruptcy. The former chief executive, Martin L. Grass, eventually went to jail because of an accounting scandal that overstated earnings by $1.6 billion — leading to what was at the time a record profit restatement.

headline: 2 Raped by Minister Are Awarded $11.45 Million
text: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., May 18  In one of the largest judgments in a child sexual abuse suit against the Roman Catholic Church, a Long Island jury on Friday awarded a total of $11.45 million in damages to a young man and woman who were repeatedly raped by a youth minister as teenagers starting in the late 1990s.

headline: 3 Months of Tense Talks Led to Immigration Deal
text: WASHINGTON, May 18 — Hours before a bipartisan deal on immigration policy was to be announced Thursday, a tenuous compromise was threatening to unravel, and tempers flared once again.

headline: N.Y.P.D.’s New Ride (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about concerns in Congress that Al Hurra, an American-financed television channel in the Middle East, was broadcasting the views of militant groups referred incorrectly to comments by Joaquin F. Blaya, a Hurra executive, about the criticism. He said it was ironic that the government was seeking to promote values like democracy and a free press while trying to censor  not censure  what was shown on the station.

headline: Clinton Offers Steps to Ease Hurricane Aid
text: NEW ORLEANS, May 18 — After touring empty homes that still bear the scars of Hurricane Katrina, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said Friday that bureaucratic red tape was “strangling people” trying to rebuild here, and proposed steps to speed money to current and former residents of the city.

headline: Donald M. Ginsberg, 73, Expert in the Working of Superconductors, Is Dead
text: Donald M. Ginsberg, a physicist who became a leading expert on the production and functioning of superconductors, died on May 7 at his home in Urbana, Ill. He was 73.
