headline: Thousands of Buildings Lack Required Water Valve, New York Records Show
text: As many as 85,000 large residential and commercial buildings in New York City lack special valves on their water connections that could prevent hazardous substances from being sucked into the public water system, according to city records.

headline: Forget the Pitching Woes. It’s Hitting That’s Giving the Yankees Problems.
text: The season is teetering on disaster, so it was no surprise that Joe Torre knew the details of Roger Clemens’s minor league start only moments after the Yankees’ loss last night.

headline: New Routes and New Risk, as More Haitians Flee
text: PROVIDENCIALES, Turks and Caicos, May 16 — There is no conceivable way to get from this island to Miami by bus. But the traffickers who ply Haiti’s northern coastline in search of those willing to risk their bleak lives for better ones abroad tell some tall tales to fill their rickety boats.

headline: After Another Early Playoff Exit, the Rockets Let Van Gundy Go
text: SAN ANTONIO, May 18 — On the day that the Houston Rockets fired him as their coach, Jeff Van Gundy was back preparing for a playoff game — once again working as a television broadcaster.

headline: Much Muscle, Less Meaning
text: Vasco Wellenkamp, the co-artistic director of Companhia Portuguesa de Bailado Contemporâneo, uses a lot of aggressive movement. Sometimes he uses really aggressive movement. If he’s feeling especially wild, he throws in a languid pause or two.

headline: Great Space, Glass Floor-Through, Canyon Views
text: GRAND CANYON WEST, Ariz. — A visitor to these stark and imposing lands of the Hualapai Indians on the western rim of the Grand Canyon knows what sensation is being promised at the journey’s climax. After driving for a half-hour over bone-jolting dirt roads some 120 miles from Las Vegas, you take a shuttle bus from the parking lot, not far from where helicopters are landing, and construction is proceeding. You deposit all cameras at a security desk, slip on yellow surgical booties and stride out onto a horseshoe-shaped walkway with transparent sides and walls that extends 70 feet into space, seemingly unsupported.

headline: White House Says It Will Move Quickly to Replace Wolfowitz
text: WASHINGTON, May 18 — The Bush administration promised Friday to find someone quickly to succeed Paul D. Wolfowitz as president of the World Bank and bring management skills to the job of healing an institution battered by the turmoil over Mr. Wolfowitz’s tenure.

headline: Giants Fill Scouting Vacancy
text: The Giants named Marc Ross as their director of college scouting yesterday, filling a vacancy created when Jerry Reese was promoted to general manager in January. Ross, 34, was 27 when the Eagles made him the N.F.L.’s youngest college scouting director in December 2000. He spent the past three seasons as the national college scout for the Buffalo Bills.

headline: California: Appeal Fails in Terror Case
text: Hamid Hayat, a Lodi man convicted last year of providing material support for terrorism by attending a training camp in Pakistan, lost his appeal for a new trial and will be sentenced Aug. 10. Mr. Hayat, 24, faces up to 39 years in prison, after Judge Garland E. Burrell Jr. of Federal District Court in Sacramento denied the motion for a new trial Thursday. In the appeal, Mr. Hayat’s lawyer said the trial was unfair because the jury foreman hid a prejudice against Pakistanis. The lawyer also objected to the way testimony from an F.B.I. informant and several expert witnesses was handled.

headline: Gangly Exultation, With Punctuation
text: There was a crash course in disco-punk groove construction on Wednesday night, when !!! began its sold-out show at the Bowery Ballroom. First came a beat, kick-started by the no-nonsense drummer Jerry Fuchs. Next, a bass line, audaciously played by Justin Van Der Volgen. Then there were some washy keyboard noises, just a few, before the addition of the singer Nic Offer, who immediately shared a secret of the trade: “Only takes a little bit, a gleam or a glimmer/Only just a little bit, a shake or a shiver.”

headline: Even When Pavano Is Gone, His Presence Is Felt
text: The Yankees are back in New York. Their $39.95 million pitcher is also in New York. But that pitcher, Carl Pavano, did not come to Shea Stadium last night to see his teammates. According to General Manager Brian Cashman, the visitors’ clubhouse is too small.

headline: On Third Time Around, Clear Channel Accepts Takeover Bid
text: For the two bidders for Clear Channel Communications, the third time may be the charm.

headline: G.M.’s Mr. Horsepower Has an Electric Conversion
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 18 — Robert A. Lutz, vice chairman at General Motors, has long been considered one of Detroit’s ultimate “car guys,” for whom no vehicle could be big enough, powerful enough or fast enough.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,393 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:

headline: Houseguests Who Pay, and Pay Well
text: Soaring real estate prices, taxes and the associated costs of living in a tourist destination can be an expensive endeavor. A small but growing number of intrepid homeowners, however, have figured out a way to make their prime locations pay.

headline: Long Journey After Hope of Crown Faded
text: UPPERVILLE, Va., May 15 — Bert and Diana Firestone will not be at the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, but they will be watching, and more intently than most. This is the time of year when their memories of the 1980 Triple Crown campaign and their terrific filly Genuine Risk come flooding back.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on Thursday about the Pioneer BDC-2202 computer drive incorrectly described its capabilities. The drive can read Blu-ray discs and can read and record on CDs and DVDs; it cannot record on Blu-ray discs.

headline: Israel Continues Airstrikes Against Hamas, as Rival Palestinian Factions Battle in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM, May 18 — Israel struck more targets of the Palestinian faction Hamas on Friday, while forces from the group’s Palestinian rival, Fatah, fired mortars at Hamas’s Islamic University and exchanged gunfire with fighters inside.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Thursday about Norman Frank, the spokesman for the New York City Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association in the 1960s, misspelled his surname at birth. It was Fetbrod, not Fetrod.

headline: Work, Money and Regret
text: HERE’S something to think about the next time you find yourself staring at the office clock waiting for the workday to end: a survey of 1,500 British retirees found that a substantial amount of the regret they had about their life revolved around work and finances.

headline: Marathon Legend Is Up for a Run in the Park
text: In some ways, Khalid Khannouchi is the Dr. Phil of long-distance running. When Khannouchi trains in Central Park, which he often does, people invariably recognize him and ask for advice. He has offered tips on everything from shin splints to sprint finishes.

headline: Where the Guys Are (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Giambi Not Discussing His Comments on Steroids
text: Jason Giambi of the Yankees tossed a piece of gum into a clubhouse garbage can yesterday, welcomed reporters to his locker, then refused to talk about comments he made Wednesday that could be interpreted as an admission of steroid use. Giambi spoke to USA Today about being “wrong for doing that stuff,” words that may create new problems for him with the commissioner’s office and the Yankees.

headline: Picking a World Bank President
text: For decades, the World Bank has lectured borrowers on the virtues of competitive bidding, merit selection and transparent procedures. Yet when it has come to choosing the bank’s leadership, Washington has never accepted those principles.

headline: Favored in Preakness by Odds, Less So by History
text: BALTIMORE, May 17 — Carl Nafzger is not a gambler. He is a horse trainer, a celebrated one these days after Street Sense won the Kentucky Derby. He could not care less that his colt is the 7-5 favorite to win the 132nd running of the Preakness Stakes.

headline: Let’s Talk About Sex
text: One statistic seems to me to give the lie to all the rhetoric about abortion, and it’s this: one in three women under the age of 45 have an abortion during their lifetime. One in three. All politicians — Democrat and Republican — say they want to make abortion at least rare (as Giuliani did in Wednesday’s debate). On, this they could reach agreement. But it’s clear they haven’t been serious; the U.S. has 1.3 million abortions a year.

headline: The World Bank After Wolfowitz (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Privacy and Data Mining (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tips for Renting a Home
text: People considering renting out their primary home to strangers should not just hand over the keys. Here are a few things to ponder before you take out an ad:

headline: One Catch by Chávez Leads to Many Opportunities
text: Endy Chávez’s final encounter with baseball anonymity came in October, less than two hours after the St. Louis Cardinals had bounced his Mets from the playoffs.

headline: Americans Put Their Weakening Dollars to Work Overseas
text: American investors, having seen the dollar weaken and foreign stock markets consistently outperform the American market, are putting record amounts of money into overseas securities.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about the Army’s decision to relieve a commander and platoon leader of their commands in Iraq in June 2006 after enlisted men were ambushed and killed misidentified the news organization that first reported the story. It was The Houston Chronicle, not The Associated Press.

headline: Elimination May Break Up Nets’ 3 Best Players
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 18 — Thousands of pinkish seats had been vacated by the time Jason Kidd, Vince Carter and Richard Jefferson walked off the court late Friday night.

headline: Russia Detains Opposition Leaders Until They Miss a Protest
text: MOSCOW, May 18 — The police detained more than a dozen opposition leaders and journalists here on Friday, preventing them from flying to a provincial city to take part in anti-Kremlin protests. The action followed a wave of harassment of the protest’s organizers.

headline: Corzine Talks of New Outlook: ‘Seize the Moment’
text: PRINCETON, N.J., May 18  Saying that his recent brush with death had prompted him to “seize the moment,” Gov. Jon S. Corzine disclosed on Friday that he planned to select a chief justice of the State Supreme Court who was young enough to leave an indelible stamp, and that his decision would be made public no later than June 4.

headline: Can Cities Save the Earth?
text: The mayors of some of the world’s biggest cities have every reason to feel especially anxious about climate change. Their populations are the biggest polluters but also among the most vulnerable to weather-related catastrophes. And they are far ahead of their national governments in giving urgency to global warming. So, for the second time since 2005, the leaders of dozens of cities, representing 400 million people, have stepped up. Meeting in New York this week, they produced a plan that should shame G-8 leaders into at least saying something about the issue at their meeting next month.

headline: Singer at the End of Time: The Video Diary of Lisa Lopes
text: A series of disappointments and misunderstandings.

headline: A Return to the Land, for Fuel
text: LAHAINA, Hawaii — Here on the West Side of Maui, where lush mountainsides and the warm waters of the Alalakeiki Channel juxtapose increasingly crowded roadways and a spate of new luxury hotels, the push for renewable energy has found an unlikely advocate: the chief executive of one of the most aggressive developers on the island.

headline: They Come in Peace, Surrounded by Extension Cords
text: New Yorkers do impatience like pros. Boredom, not so much; the city’s denizens are far too overstimulated and attention-fractured to approach anything like the drifty languor of this underestimated state.

headline: Schubert and Two 20th-Century Surprises
text: The final concert of the season at the 92nd Street Y’s chamber music series, on Wednesday evening, was devoted to works for strings and included a duo, a trio, a quintet and a sextet. But instrumental combinations aside, the most striking aspect of the program was the way warm-toned, comfortably familiar music was juxtaposed with early-20th-century works that had sharper and more ragged edges.

headline: Right Time, Wrong Publicity
text: Burgers and alcohol have been an unlucky combination for David Hasselhoff, even more than we knew. First came the leaked video of him that flooded television and the Internet a couple of weeks ago: he sits on the floor, slurring words as he talks to his teenage daughter, so drunk he can’t get a burger into his mouth. Now comes this revelation from his just-published autobiography, “Don’t Hassel the Hoff.” After a couple of stints in rehab, one that included a nighttime escape from Betty Ford, he started drinking again and craved a midnight snack.

headline: Poetry Holds the Stage for a Whole Day
text: It was not, O worshipers of words, the 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee but rather the 35th Annual Spring Poetry Festival. And 9-year-old Gabriel Nazir Mejia was waxing, yes, poetic — about writer’s block.

headline: Italian Banks Said to Be Near a Merger
text: LONDON, May 18  UniCredit, Italy’s biggest bank, is expected to announce this weekend that it has agreed to buy a rival, Capitalia, to bolster its business at home after years of expanding abroad.

headline: A New Reality in Washington, but Can It Last?
text: WASHINGTON, May 18 — Six months after Republicans lost control of Congress, President Bush is learning the rules of a game that, for six years, he seemed to have forgotten: the Capitol Hill edition of “Let’s Make a Deal.”

headline: Poisoned Toothpaste in Panama Is Believed to Be From China
text: Diethylene glycol, a poisonous ingredient in some antifreeze, has been found in 6,000 tubes of toothpaste in Panama, and customs officials there said yesterday that the product appeared to have originated in China.

headline: Kazakhstan: President Voted In for Life if He Likes
text: Parliament voted to exempt President Nursultan Nazarbayev from a provision in the Constitution limiting presidents to serving two terms. The vote effectively clears the way for Mr. Nazarbayev, a former Communist Party official who has led Kazakhstan since its independence from the Soviet Union, to become president for life. Mr. Nazarbayev has never been elected by a poll judged free or fair by Western election monitors and has long been dogged by corruption allegations and complaints of crackdowns on the opposition and the news media. But Kazakhstan, which gave up its abandoned Soviet nuclear arsenal after independence, has been spared the wars, terrorism, personality cults and much of the disorder of other Central Asian states. Many of Mr. Nazarbayev’s critics say he has significant popular support.

headline: A Trade by French Brothers, Made for Love, Bien Sûr
text: In the 19 years since Yves Abel started L’Opéra Français de New York to explore the French opera canon, he has become a master at wringing magnificent performances from the most modest materials. For the company’s performance of Rameau’s “Castor et Pollux” at the French Institute Alliance Française on Thursday evening, Mr. Abel had no scenery to speak of, but he made do with a table, a few chairs and a small props collection.

headline: Walking Slowly and Carrying a Big Stick
text: I CRAWLED out of bed on all fours, nursing and cursing the second toe on my left foot. Outside my bedroom window, the early morning Manhattan sky loomed dark and foreboding like an ancient oracle. As the inevitable rain began to fall, I recalled the riddle of the Sphinx from a high school course in Greek mythology:

headline: Page Six, Staple of Gossip, Reports on Its Own Tale
text: Page Six, The New York Post’s free-swinging showcase for gossip about canoodling celebrities and cheating spouses, ran a tell-all item yesterday about a subject it does not usually cover in eye-popping detail: itself.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Perlman, ‘American Pieces’ and the Sweet Spot in Tone
text: Sometimes it seems as if brand-name performers feel there is no need to put in unnecessary blood, sweat and tears when they are practically guaranteed an ovation (and enormous fees) for just showing up.

headline: What’s on Saturday Night
text: 9 P.M. (Starz) PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN: DEAD MAN’S CHEST Johnny Depp, left, continues to channel Keith Richards as Capt. Jack Sparrow, the rockingest swashbuckler to sail the seven seas, in the second “Pirates” installment. (The third, “Pirates of the Caribbean: At World’s End,” opens next weekend.) Keira Knightley, above, and Orlando Bloom return as Elizabeth Swann and Will Turner, his valiant sidekicks, whose wedding day is torpedoed in the opening scene. And Bill Nighy plays the undead, squid-faced mariner Davy Jones.

headline: Putting More Profit Before Education
text: The United States Department of Education has been rightfully drawn (but not yet quartered) in Congress for failing to prevent the kickbacks, payoffs and self-dealing recently uncovered in the student loan business. Now it turns out that the department also mismanaged the federal Reading First initiative, the cornerstone of the No Child Left Behind Act, which requires states to improve reading instruction in exchange for federal education dollars.

headline: Contractor Deaths in Iraq Soar to Record
text: WASHINGTON, May 18 — Casualties among private contractors in Iraq have soared to record levels this year, setting a pace that seems certain to turn 2007 into the bloodiest year yet for the civilians who work alongside the American military in the war zone, according to new government numbers.

headline: Clinton Quiet on Her Past Role at Wal-Mart
text: In 1986, Sam Walton, the founder of Wal-Mart, had a problem. He was under growing pressure from shareholders — and his wife, Helen — to appoint a woman to the company’s 15-member board of directors.

headline: Talks, but No Breakthrough, on Iraq War Spending Measure
text: WASHINGTON, May 18 — Congressional Democrats and the White House remained at odds over a war spending measure on Friday after a crucial negotiating session ended with both sides expressing disappointment and accusing the other of being intractable.

headline: Giuliani Endorsement Expected
text: Joseph L. Bruno, majority leader of the New York State Senate, and his fellow Senate Republicans are expected to endorse Rudolph W. Giuliani for president on Tuesday in Albany. The announcement is significant because the Senate is the Republican Party’s last statewide power base and because the state’s elective influence was bolstered when New York officials recently moved the 2008 primary date to Feb. 5 from March 4. “He’s coming up Tuesday and we’re looking forward to doing some very positive things with him at that time,” Mr. Bruno said of Mr. Giuliani.

headline: Chief of EGL Raises Buyout Bid Yet Again
text: The chief executive of EGL, James R. Crane, has raised his buyout offer for the company to $46.25 a share, competing with a $46-a-share offer from the Ceva Group.

headline: Mary Scheier, 99, Creator of Elegant Pottery, Is Dead
text: Mary Scheier, a pioneer of the modern studio pottery movement known for the lightness of her forms, died on May 14 in Green Valley, Ariz. She was 99 and had lived in Green Valley for many years.

headline: Lloyd Alexander, Author of Fantasy Novels, Is Dead at 83
text: Lloyd Alexander, a National Book Award-winning author of fantasy novels for young people whose work was noted for its romantic locales, complex characters and barely concealed allegorical depictions of the struggle against tyranny, died on Thursday at his home in Drexel Hill, Pa. He was 83.

headline: Couple Learn the High Price of Easy Credit
text: YPSILANTI, Mich. — On a recent evening, Christine Moellering, 40, sorted through the plastic laundry basket where she keeps the family bills, statements and coupons.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about the rising number of abortions among unmarried women in China gave the incorrect location in some copies for Qingdao, a city where a nongovernmental abortion clinic opened in 2003. It is on the Yellow Sea, not the Bohai Sea. (Go to Article)

headline: Destroying Dow Jones to Save It
text: So let’s see. We’re now into week No. 3 of the business world’s favorite new soap opera, “Mr. Murdoch Lusts After Dow Jones.” And what a strange week it’s been.

headline: Israeli Army Strikes Gaza Rocket-Launching Cell
text: JERUSALEM, May 19 — The Israeli army struck a Palestinian rocket-launching cell near Beit Hanoun in the northern Gaza Strip today, first with tank shells and then from the air, killing one, an army spokesman said.

headline: Young, Ill and Uninsured
text: Fourteen-year-old Devante Johnson deserved better. He was a sweet kid, an honor student and athlete who should be enjoying music and sports and skylarking with his friends at school. Instead he’s buried in Houston’s Paradise North Cemetery.

headline: Karen Hess, 88, Dies; Culinary Historian Who Challenged Standards
text: Karen Hess, an American culinary historian who brought an academic rigor to the study of recipes, cooking techniques and ordinary American kitchen practices, died Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 88.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about the pitching situation for the Mets and the Yankees as they approached this weekend’s interleague series, referred incorrectly to the timing of an injury sustained by the Yankees’ Phil Hughes. He pulled his left hamstring while taking a no-hitter into the seventh inning of his second start, not his debut.

headline: In Queens Fire, Pet Rescue Takes a Turn for the Wild
text: Every so often a deer will appear in the 190th Street subway station. Or a 2,000-pound bull will escape from a rodeo and gallop along the streets of Long Island City. A man might arrive at an emergency room in need of stitches, bitten, it turns out, by the 500-pound pet wild tiger that lives in his apartment in Harlem.

headline: F.D.A. Is Delaying Approval of Anemia Drug From Roche
text: The Food and Drug Administration has delayed approval of Roche’s new anemia drug, as concerns mount about the safety of drugs in its class.

headline: Randolph Finds That Familiarity Pays Off
text: Endy Chávez had tried to bunt Andy Pettitte’s first pitch, which was the sensible strategy with a runner on second base and no outs. Manager Willie Randolph figured Pettitte might expect Chávez to try to bunt again and simply throw him a fastball. So Randolph signaled for Chávez to swing away.

headline: The Battle Over an Ecological Biosphere
Some Racy Alternatives to the Audi R8
U.S. Championship, Round 4: Shabalov Takes the Lead
text: Alexander Shabalov, a grandmaster who lives in Pittsburgh, is putting on quite a show at the Frank Berry U.S. Championship in Stillwater, Okla. In Round 4, he beat Hikaru Nakamura, the highest ranked player in the tournament. All of the games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.

headline: State Aid in Connecticut Municipalities
Tax Increase and Budget Vote Results in New York School Districts
Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article by The Associated Press yesterday about the arbitration hearing for the cyclist Floyd Landis referred incorrectly to the results of tests for a substance banned in cycling. The tests indicated that Landis had used synthetic testosterone — not Greg LeMond, a three-time Tour champion, who testified at the hearing.

headline: Sky High
text: Images of the Grand Canyon Skywalk.

headline: Excerpts of interview with Alexandra Guarnaschelli
text: Alexandra Guarnaschelli, the executive chef of Butter, the New York restaurant, whose marriage to Brandon Clark is featured in Vows this week, explained how and why she became a chef in an interview with the column's author, Devan Sipher. She also discussed some highlights from her wedding menu. Below are excerpts from that interview along with a link to the menu:

headline: Seeking a Tech-Savvy President
text: Is America ready for its first tech president? Tech-types here are calling for the presidential candidates to catch up with their global counterparts, both on the campaign trail and in their campaign platforms.

headline: Wedding Menu
text: Brandon Clark and Alexandra Guarnaschelli April 29, 2007

headline: Photos: Down to the Finish
text: Curlin and Street Sense in a thrilling finish to the 132nd Preakness Stakes.

headline: Africa’s Universities in Crisis
text: The decrepitude of Africa’s colleges is depriving dozens of nations of the homegrown expertise that could lift millions out of poverty.

headline: 2008: Immigration and the Trail
text: The immigration deal in the Senate is putting pressure on the leading presidential candidates to take a position on the issue. Many of the candidates released statements about the Senate plan, (You can see what they’ve said previously on the issue here), but Mitt Romney took it one step further with an ad that begins running this weekend that highlights his call for a secure border and an “employment verification system.”

headline: The Preakness Stakes: Moment by Moment
text: A graphical look at the 132nd Preakness Stakes in Baltimore.

headline: A Tale of Two Nine-Pitch At-Bats
text: Oliver Perez pitched an excellent 7 2/3 innings last night. Billy Wagner finished off the Yankees in the ninth, getting Jason Giambi to chase a slider on the ninth pitch of the at-bat to wrap up the victory. So, what happened to the other 1/3 of an inning?

headline: Third M-Tel Masters: A Day of Draws, so Tomorrow Will Decide the Winner
text: All three games in round 9 of the M-Tel Masters in Sofia, Bulgaria, ended in draws today. So the standings remain the same with Krishnan Sasikiran of India leading by a half-point over Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria, Shakhriyar Mademyarov of Azerbaijan, Gata Kamsky of the United States and Liviu-Dieter Nisipeanu of Romania. With the field so tightly bunched, and with Sasikiran playing Topalov, the tournament will be decided tomorrow in the last round. Games from the tournament can be replayed here at the tournament’s Web site.

headline: Rasner Breaks His Index Finger
text: I was talking in the clubhouse yesterday with Darrell Rasner, who improbably would be making his sixth start of the season today. Only Andy Pettitte has made more.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, May 20
text: With the halls of Congress abuzz this week about the Big I’s—immigration and Iraq— not to mention new revelations about Attorney General Alberto Gonzales’s term as White House counsel, the legislative branch takes center stage on tomorrow’s talk shows.

headline: China’s Labor Movement
text: In Hong Kong I had breakfast with an old friend and a man I greatly admire, Han Dongfang. He also makes me a little optimistic about China’s evolution.

headline: An Update on Hasina
text: In March I wrote about a woman in Pakistan whose daughter had been raped and murdered — and then her problems really began. The authorities, at the behest of feudal leaders, arrested some innocent poor people and drove the Hasina away when she protested. It’s a reminder of just how feudal rural Pakistan can be.

headline: Tony Blair for the World Bank?
text: Looking at the possibilities for the presidency of the World Bank, I like the idea of Tony Blair.

headline: U.S. Championship, Round 5: Shabalov Remains Unstoppable and Unbeaten
text: Alexander Shabalov, who was already leading by a full point, continued his fine play, chalking up a win against Gregory Kaidanov in the fifth round of the Frank Berry U.S. Championship in Stillwater, Okla. Shabalov, who is now a perfect five for five, leads a pack of six grandmasters by 1.5 points with only four rounds to go. All the games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.

headline: How Would You Fix the Yankees?
text: Joe Torre referenced 1951 after the game tonight. For Torre, who grew up a New York Giants fan, that year has powerful resonance. The Giants came storming back from a huge deficit to beat the Brooklyn Dodgers in a classic pennant race.

headline: Last Shot
text: I was feeling a little more blue than usual. I was sitting in my second-story office looking down at the street. I wasn’t thinking of jumping, but I was thinking about thinking of jumping. I found myself having Edgar Allan Poe-type thoughts.

headline: No Edit
text: As a high-school English teacher, I am frequently asked to proofread and make rewriting suggestions for students’ college-application essays. I decline on the grounds that admissions officers assume that these essays accurately represent the students’ work. Other teachers argue that our students lose the editing advantage many students receive. Is it ethical for me to read student essays? — name withheld

headline: The Truth and Nothing but the Truth. Or Not.
text: IN many towns across Connecticut, the local newspaper publishes a “police blotter,” a sometimes surprising, often amusing, occasionally juicy list of various transgressions — crimes small and large, from driving into a tree on an icy road to bashing your neighbor over the head with a shovel — that occur in a given jurisdiction.

headline: ... As Ice Cream Trucks Tune Up With Songs That Madden or Gladden
text: It was a slow Wednesday afternoon at A Selinger Enterprises, a distribution company for ice cream truck drivers in the Pelham Bay neighborhood of the Bronx. Showers were predicted, and Tommy Metropoulos, the company’s 32-year-old president, leaned back in his chair, nervously drumming a pencil against the desk.

headline: Domestic Disturbances
text: Helen Simpson’s short stories read like cautionary tales about the ravages of parenthood, harrowing dispatches from the front lines of middle-class family life. Her previous collection, “Getting a Life,” dissected modern British domesticity, the tenderness included, with a mordant wit. In her new collection, “In the Driver’s Seat,” child-rearing is still a marathon of compromise and exhaustion — and now illness, as her characters get older. If they remain wry and indomitable, it might be that death is no match for someone who’s faced the daily car pool.

headline: Bombs Imperil U.S. Troops Searching for Captured Comrades
text: LATAFIYA, Iraq, May 19 — The thousands of American soldiers searching for their three comrades who were captured a week ago have been dogged by a deadly threat: bombs buried far from roads that strike them as they fan out to cover the area’s rural terrain.

headline: A Solution to Crawling City Traffic? Not So Fast
text: WHEN Michael Bloomberg talks about congestion pricing for New York, he refers to London and the success that city has had with the program. Indeed, he’s based his pilot on the London plan. Should the mayor be permitted his pilot? Absolutely. He just has to monitor it very carefully, casting a skeptical eye on all assertions of success until he’s sure the details are right.

headline: Ottoman Rules in Istanbul
text: Istanbul, the city that once commanded an empire (and was called Constantinople, New Rome and Byzantium), embodies centuries' worth of East-meets-West history. But that's all water down the Bosporus. A new generation is creating a vibrant cosmopolis that bridges two continents, and cultures, in style.

headline: South Africa’s Valley High
text: Late in the evening of Sept. 29, 1969, in the bloom of the antipodean spring, an earthquake struck the quiet community of Tulbagh, some 75 miles northeast of Cape Town. Boulders glowing like hot coals tumbled down the nearby mountain of Saronsberg. Downtown on Church Street, textbook examples of thatched-roof Cape Dutch architecture were reduced to rubble. “I was convinced they’d dropped an atomic bomb on Cape Town,” is how Nicky Krone, whose family owns the local winery Twee Jonge Gezellen, describes it. Krone spent that night pulling the children of his black workers out from under the remains of collapsed buildings. Two perished.

headline: Lebanese Troops Clash With Islamic Militants
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, May 20 — Fierce clashes erupted between Lebanese Army soldiers and Islamic militants tied to Al Qaeda in the northern Lebanese town of Tripoli on Sunday, leaving 23 Lebanese soldiers and 17 militants dead and dozens injured in one of the most significant challenges to the army since the end of Lebanon’s bloody civil war.

headline: Fifty, Finned and Fabulous
text: Each age is a dream that is dying, or one that is coming to birth,” the poet Arthur O’Shaughnessy wrote. The year 1957 was just such a time.

headline: Nadal and Federer Rally and Gain Final

text: ST. PAUL, May 16  John Berns and John Benson were swept into the Minnesota State Legislature last fall in a midterm election that promised an end to the state’s polarized partisan politics.

headline: With Keith Bulluck
text: As an N.F.L. linebacker, Keith Bulluck has known only one home, with the Tennessee Titans, who drafted him in the first round out of Syracuse in 2000. But when Bulluck was 12 he was abandoned by his mother. He would have wound up a ward of the state if Linda Welch, the mother of a friend, had not taken him in. Bulluck has made foster children the focal point of the charity he started in 2003. This weekend, he returns to Rockland County as the host of a softball tournament featuring his Titans teammate Vince Young, with proceeds going to the Rockland County Parent Aid Fund. KAREN CROUSE

text: IT is one of the most dreaded driving maneuvers: getting a car into a tight parking space. It requires not only practice, but also finesse and some guesswork, primarily because drivers cannot see exactly where they are going.

headline: Robert N. Buck Dies at 93; Was Record-Setting Aviator
text: Robert N. Buck, a distinguished pilot who in the 1930s crossed the continent at record speed, flew a light plane higher than anyone had done before and photographed ancient ruins of the Yucatán from the air for the first time — all by the age of 20 — died on April 14 in Berlin, Vt. He was 93 and had continued to fly gliders into his late 80s.

The effort to transform a tiny island in Fiji into a sustainable, democratically run community, is now a year old and has grown to 1,160 “tribe” members from 35 countries.

headline: Making the Maestro Collaborator in Chief
text: MANY musicians of high school age have devoted teachers whom they respect and depend on. But only at a conservatory or a university music school do young hot-shot musicians typically encounter teachers of awesome stature like the cellist Janos Starker and the pianist Leon Fleisher. Music students develop transformational relationships with these inspiring, sometimes intimidating masters, more so, in my experience, than students in the visual arts, acting, writing and other creative fields.

headline: Condos Tighten the Rules
text: EVERYONE knows that buying a condominium in New York City is supposed to be much easier than buying a co-op. More expensive maybe, but definitely easier.

headline: Visible Man
text: Ralph Ellison burned out as an artist under excruciating circumstances. His failure to complete a second novel after his landmark book, “Invisible Man,” exploded onto the scene in 1952 was already a source of pain just six years later, when he wrote to Saul Bellow about having a “writer’s block as big as the Ritz.” His suffering intensified as the years rolled by and contemporaries like Bellow (Ellison’s onetime housemate), John Cheever and Bernard Malamud all capitalized on their talents and moved on into prolific maturity. His predicament was worsened by the feeling that he had failed not only himself but the broader black society whose aesthetic he had hoped to champion in a great book that would rival “Moby-Dick.”

headline: Correction: Moyduh, He Watched: Commissioner Turns Critic

headline: Putting the Skinned Knees Back Into Playtime

headline: Up Front
text: DEBBY APPLEGATE was an undergraduate at Amherst College when she was asked to put together an exhibit on famous Amherst alumni. Applegate, class of 1989, soon discovered Henry Ward Beecher, class of 1834, who became something of an obsession for her. She went on to write a seminar paper about him, then a senior thesis, then a Ph.D. dissertation at Yale, then a Pulitzer Prize-winning biography. Beecher, she said in an e-mail message, is “a bit like the Forrest Gump of the 19th century, popping into all the great debates of the era, from the noble, like the antislavery or woman suffrage movements, to the frivolous, like whether women should wear bloomers.” Applegate doesn’t have a new project in mind yet. “In some ways, finishing a book after spending 20 years on a subject is like breaking up with a longtime boyfriend — you need a little breather before jumping back into a new relationship,” she said. But she was delighted to write about a book on the art-collecting Clark family because “I’ve always secretly wished that I’d become an art critic.” This week, she reviews Nicholas Fox Weber’s “Clarks of Cooperstown.”

Turn your lamp low! We in trouble now. Aunt Ester died!”

headline: Conspiracy?
text: Within minutes of learning of President John F. Kennedy’s murder on Nov. 22, 1963, Robert F. Kennedy was working the phones, looking for answers to how his brother had died. “There’s so much bitterness,” he told a colleague that day. “I thought they would get one of us.” But who were “they”? Robert Kennedy gravitated immediately to a shadowy nexus of forces he believed were at odds with the policies of his brother’s administration. Was it the C.I.A.? he asked John McCone, the director of central intelligence. Was the assassination the work of anti-Castro Cubans? Was it the American Mafia? Or was it — since there were hidden but important connections among these groups — a combined effort by them all? Before he had ever heard the name Lee Harvey Oswald, Robert Kennedy was considering scenarios that would eventually become the foundation of the myriad conspiracy theories that have haunted the American imagination for more than 40 years; according to David Talbot, he continued to explore those scenarios until his own death in 1968, even while publicly denying his belief in a conspiracy.

headline: After Bronx Crash, Minivan Driver Is Fatally Shot by Off-Duty Officer

headline: Fantasy Baseball
text: A switch-hitting country boy with phenomenal power and a killer smile, Mickey Mantle symbolized the New York Yankees’ dominance in the 1950s. But he was also a womanizer and an alcoholic who could injure himself in battles with water coolers and golf clubs. (He died at 63, a victim of cancer and his own careless lifestyle.) Like Joe Namath, that other swinger who took New York a decade later, the Mick possessed an endearing fragility that became a part of his resonance. “We didn’t just root for him, we felt for him,” the broadcaster Bob Costas said at Mantle’s funeral, in 1995. “He was our guy.”

headline: Flooding by the Numbers
text: The Federal Emergency Management Agency measures disasters in a way that only a statistician could love. It turns out that the agency does not simply assess damage the storm inflicted on, say, each town. It estimates the cost of the damage per capita on the population of each county. If the figure does not reach $3.05 per capita, counties are out of luck in attaining the coveted federal disaster rating that would help pay for damage.

headline: Bilking the Elderly, With a Corporate Assist
text: The thieves operated from small offices in Toronto and hangar-size rooms in India. Every night, working from lists of names and phone numbers, they called World War II veterans, retired schoolteachers and thousands of other elderly Americans and posed as government and insurance workers updating their files.

headline: Breathless, Buoyant
text: THE last practice I remember was during the period between summer and fall, before summer had entirely faded and before autumn had entirely set in. The leaves had just begun to litter the back hills of the cross-country course of Van Cortlandt Park. We had been sent out to run six miles, past the hole in the fence, past the fruit market just outside the park, past the big oak tree; we all knew this was going to be a long run.

headline: Kill, Pray, Love
text: Early one morning in 1540, while a 12-year-old Saxon boy, Mattias Tannhauser, is tempering a dagger at his father’s forge, marauding Turks descend on his village in the Carpathian Mountains. Renegade foot soldiers bash his sister’s head in and rape and kill his mother. Amid the many victims of this carnage, young Mattias is fortunate only because he can put his new dagger to immediate use — and in doing so he inadvertently shows a Turkish captain that he has a natural gift for the arts of war. Abbas bin Murad spares the boy’s life, carrying Mattias out of the village and into a life of adventure, amply documented in this first book of a projected trilogy by Tim Willocks. The summer reading season has officially begun.

headline: Can a Cousin’s Daughter Share a Co-op?
text: Q My cousin’s daughter needs a place to stay while she goes to college, and I offered her some space in the three-bedroom co-op I recently bought. Is this permissible?

headline: What’s Bad?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cornell Remains Undefeated and Advances to the Final Four
text: PRINCETON, N.J., May 19  Cornell midfielder Max Seibald spent a majority of the past week in the Big Red’s training room. For about four hours every day, Seibald put his sprained left ankle through a combination of ice, whirlpool and electrical stimulation.

headline: Duke Lacrosse Is Focal Point Again, This Time for the Good
text: Two seasons ago, when the Duke men’s lacrosse team reached the N.C.A.A. tournament championship game for the first time in the team’s history, its achievement went largely unnoticed.

headline: French Revolution in Paris
text: The closest thing to a tourist attraction in the Paris neighborhood of Belleville is a small plaque commemorating the birth of Edith Piaf, posted on a drab apartment building on a busy street. “On the steps of this house,” the inscription reads, “was born on 19 December 1915, in the greatest destitution, Edith Piaf, whose voice would later turn the world upside down.” The story isn't quite true — in fact, Piaf was born in a nearby hospital — but it's a charming myth that evokes both Piaf's legendary rise from street urchin to international stardom and the hard-boiled mystique of her childhood quartier.

headline: Gargoyle Man
text: IN 1973, a shy 13-year-old named Randall Dana was biking through the deteriorating landscape of the Lower East Side when he stumbled upon an awesome sight. A trove of architectural ornaments lay before him like ancient ruins: busts of Neptune, fierce lions, chimera, gargoyles and griffins. Embedded in the facades of 19th-century buildings, these victims of decades of neglect were headed into the hands of demolition crews, landfills and certain extinction.

headline: The Nuclear Threat
text: One need read only the first three pages of “The Atomic Bazaar” to be reminded of William Langewiesche’s formidable talent as a journalist whose cool, precise and economical reporting is harnessed to an invigorating moral and intellectual perspective on the world he describes. In a single paragraph, he lucidly explains the basic physics of the uranium-based atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima. Once a professional pilot, and the author of “Inside the Sky,” Langewiesche then leads the reader inside the “pressurized, well-heated” cockpit of the Enola Gay, flying at 31,000 feet in “smooth air,” piloted by the young Colonel Paul Tibbets, and vividly reconstructs the evasive maneuver taken by the B-29 as it banks steeply to minimize the coming shockwaves, while the bomb, named Little Boy, falls for 43 seconds before igniting several miles below, lighting the sky with “the prettiest blues and pinks that Tibbets had ever seen.” Tibbets’s subsequent career, from Air Force general to Internet purveyor of autographed souvenirs of that momentous flight, is adroitly sketched. The bombing of Nagasaki three days after Hiroshima, with a plutonium device, is handled in brisk but sufficient detail. Langewiesche counts the total killed in the two attacks (around 220,000), then delivers his own one-sentence bomb: “The intent was to terrorize a nation to the maximum extent, and there is nothing like nuking civilians to achieve that effect.”

headline: Jennifer Gellmann, Raul Rothblatt
text: Jennifer Stacy Gellmann and Raul Rothblatt are to be married today in Brooklyn. Rabbi Hara E. Person is to officiate at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios, a film production complex at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

text: THE Bloomberg administration’s proposal to charge cars and trucks to enter Manhattan below 86th Street will help reduce air pollution and improve the health of some New Yorkers, but not all. Indeed, it is likely to worsen the health of many New Yorkers, particularly the poor.

headline: Home of the Bronx Roar
text: HIGH BRIDGE, folded into a valley in the southwestern Bronx, welcomed its first wave of Manhattanites in the 1920s; developers promised them more room for less money.

headline: Heart in Israel, Home (Court) in New York
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y., May 18 — Shay Doron waited for her life’s dream to unfold last month at the W.N.B.A. draft.

headline: A Coastline Smorgasbord
text: The old towns along the North Shore of Staten Island, with their Victorian and Colonial houses, retain some of their charm from the days before the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge ushered in waves of development. The restaurant scene, meanwhile, has taken on a life its own, with a diverse mix of 15-year standbys like Aesop’s Tables and newcomers like Nürnberger Bierhaus, open a little more than a year.

headline: Trieste, Italy: Buffet da Pepi
text: Among experienced travelers, Trieste is widely considered a town barely worth visiting. I don't get it. With the central square and a broad canal right on the Adriatic, the eclectic architecture, the converging cultures ... O.K., it's not Venice, but neither is it Bridgeport.

headline: At the Mall, Mariachi Instead of Muzak
text: ON a sunny day in early May, more than 12,000 people descended on the Plaza Fiesta Mall in Atlanta for a Cinco de Mayo festival celebrating Mexican heritage. Fourteen bands played mariachi; reggaetón, a sort of Latino rap; and banda, which is traditional Mexican brass music. There were carnival rides, and tortillas sizzled on grills.

headline: Two Officers Tried to Rob Drug Suspect, Officials Say
text: Two New York City police officers have resigned after being accused of trying to rob the apartment of a suspected drug dealer in New Jersey, a law enforcement official said yesterday.

headline: It’s a Sleeper (and a Keeper): Small but Big in Choices
text: CHEF Luis on the main shopping street in New Canaan is such a sleeper that several friends begged me not to review it. “It’s too small, too much business will spoil it.”

headline: A Smooth and Meaty Malbec
text: Macari Vineyards in Mattituck has successfully turned malbec, long a secondary blending grape on the North Fork, into a full-scale wine.

headline: Calling Mr. Green
text: Q: As an architect and designer who helped pioneer environmentally sustainable buildings in the ’80s and was nicknamed the Green Dean during your tenure at the University of Virginia in the ’90s, what is your top priority these days? I am very focused on large-scale deployments of renewable power and how we’re going to get this done. Imagine our military bases covered with solar thermal collectors that could generate steam and electricity.

headline: Correction: In-Town Living in Morristown
text: The “In the Region” article in New Jersey copies last Sunday, about residential developments in downtown Morristown, misidentified the developer of DeHart Place, a project of nine Victorian-style town houses. The developer is Lennar Urban — not Roseland Property, which is serving as DeHart Place’s “designated master redeveloper.”

headline: When Hitting Is More Important Than Pitching
text: Nobody ever says that pitching is 35 percent of baseball.

headline: The Once and Future Pee-wee
text: IN the 1985 movie “Pee-wee’s Big Adventure,” the title character turns to a friend and murmurs darkly, “There are a lot of things about me, things you wouldn’t understand, things you couldn’t understand, things you shouldn’t understand.”

headline: Catching Up on a Little Light Reading
text: IN the 1930s the paperback made its appearance. Readers in Germany, Britain and the United States responded enthusiastically to the idea of a small-format book that could be slipped into the pocket and read on the bus or train. What a novelty it seemed, a streamlined leisure product fitting for a scientific age.

headline: Emily Sheehy, Reed Carey
text: Emily Jean Sheehy, the daughter of Theresa Towle of Plaistow, N.H., and John Sheehy of River Vale, N.J., was married on Friday to Robert Reed Carey, a son of Roberta and John Carey of Easton, Md. The Rev. Kevin D. Bean, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Bartholomew’s Church in New York.

headline: So, Did You Pack the Ticket for the Air Ambulance?
text: WHEN Christopher Peabody, 60, of Laguna Beach, Calif., suffered life-threatening intestinal problems in Morelia, Mexico, last month, her son, Wyatt, flew to her side from Los Angeles. Although he speaks Spanish fluently and calls Mexico “a second home,” he was horrified when he saw the hospital.

headline: Correction
text: A review on May 6 about “I’ll Sleep When I’m Dead: The Dirty Life and Times of Warren Zevon,” by Crystal Zevon, misspelled the surname of the writer who contributed the book’s foreword. He is Carl Hiaasen, not Hiassen.

headline: What Exactly Is a Condop?
text: PEOPLE often wonder what exactly a condop is.

headline: Gettysburg’s Martial Plan
text: This summer may be your last opportunity to see the Cyclorama Center, the 1962 visitors’ center designed by Richard Neutra and Robert Alexander overlooking the battlefields of Gettysburg in Pennsylvania. The building is scheduled for demolition within the next two years. A new visitors center will occupy a structure designed to simulate a round barn from “ye olde days” — an oddly Virginian conceit for a site where General Lee’s army went down to bloody defeat.

headline: A Basket Case in North Carolina
text: The old Appalachian ballad “Lord Daniel” is a bracing dose of adultery and murder at 7:45 a.m. Not that we need extra stimuli. Sleeping in is the province of the young, and the average age at John C. Campbell Folk School hovers somewhere around . . . well, to employ the equivalent of describing certain political candidates as clean and articulate, the students do seem to be a spry lot. Easily 80 of us have gathered in the community room to hear Jan Davidson, the director of the school, lead us in our first session of MorningSong, the half-hour of music and stories that starts our day.

headline: Spread the Wealth of Spousal Rights
text: WHEN the poet Elizabeth Barrett Browning wrote, “How do I love thee? Let me count the ways,” little did she know that a century and a half later the list would extend into the thousands — at least for married couples. As of 2005, the Government Accountability Office had identified more than 1,000 legal rights and responsibilities attendant to marriage. The era of big government is clearly not over when it comes to family policy.

headline: Seeking the Real in a Desert City Known for Artifice
text: IN many ways, this brunch was like a million others I’d had before: poached eggs with hollandaise sauce, fresh orange juice, coffee, buttered toast. The sun was glowing somewhere over the comfy outdoor sofas, and no one seemed in a hurry to finish up and get home.

headline: As a Director, Clinton Moved Wal-Mart Board, but Only So Far
text: In 1986, Sam Walton, the founder of Wal-Mart, had a problem. He was under growing pressure from shareholders — and his wife, Helen — to appoint a woman to the company’s 15-member board of directors.

headline: To Palm Springs via ‘Dawson’s Creek’
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: The Soviet Pianist Who Wasn’t All Thunder
text: LISTENERS who regularly make their way along the main roads and side streets of New York music know that it won’t be long before they come across another young pianist from the former Soviet Union. One hardly needs to open the program. Correct Mozart or Beethoven will be offered as a duty fulfilled. There will be high-powered Chopin or Liszt played with staggering competence.

headline: They Eat Horse Sashimi in Tokyo, Don’t They?
text: An American chef I know told me about a dream he had in Tokyo after an intense bout of professional eating. Dinner had been an exhausting affair, during which every creature of the sea appeared at the table. The feast ended after 4 a.m. with the entire restaurant staff lined up on the street outside, waving good night. My friend woke in his hotel room later with a vivid memory and an unsettling lump in his gut: he dreamed he'd swallowed his camera.

headline: Erin Love, Lawrence Strauss
text: Erin P. Love and Lawrence C. Strauss were married yesterday at the Berkshire Botanical Garden in Stockbridge, Mass. Judge Paul Perachi, the presiding judge of the Berkshire juvenile division of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts trial court system, officiated.

headline: The Zero-Energy Solution
text: Mike Strizki’s house, the house of the future, the revolutionary house that might very well change our lives forever, is an unremarkable two-story, 3,000-square-foot, white colonial-style kit home in front of which, one rainy day last November, were parked no fewer than seven trucks and cars, a pair of Jet Skis, a speedboat on a trailer, several golf carts, a small tractor, a couple of vans and an old dump truck rusting in the middle of the woods, like a major reworking of a Robert Frost poem. There was nothing odd, or futuristic, or exotically “eco” about the house — no solar panels to be seen, no giant arrays of thermopane windows passively drinking up light and heat; yet here, I’d been told, in the Sourland Mountains in New Jersey, an hour from Manhattan, was a house that had the potential — not long from now, not 20 years from now, but maybe within 5 to 10 years — to help turn millions of American homes into fully self-sustaining power plants, each one capable of producing hydrogen to fuel cars as well.

headline: Mr. What-If Is Circling Around My Marriage
text: MY wife and I have been married 27 years, but her first husband still wants her back. When we’re together at family functions, he tells everyone that he’s just waiting for me to die so he and Julie can remarry. He acts like he’s joking, but he means every word of it.

headline: Unoriginal Quips Ahoy!
text: There he goes again.

headline: Sail of the Century in Valencia
text: The best reason yet to jump on the boat-shoe trend: the 32nd America’s Cup yacht race in Valencia, Spain. This summer, the regatta returns to Europe after 150 years — and to one of its buzziest cities. Here’s how to join in the maritime mania.

headline: A Dangerously Depleted Guard
text: The tornado that suddenly destroyed Greensburg, Kan., earlier this month was another reminder of why Americans need to be concerned that so much of the National Guard and its equipment is now deployed far from home — in Iraq, Afghanistan and along the Mexican border.

headline: Correction: Breaking Through
text: An article on May 6 about the actress Nikki Blonsky included incorrect information from the actress and her director, Adam Shankman, about the circumstances of her casting in the film “Hairspray.” Morgit Management, which represented her at the time, sent New Line Cinema an e-mail message with a Web link to a copy of her audition tape. She won a tryout as a result of that e-mail message, not a copy of the tape she sent separately by mail. In addition that taped audition was made with the help of the management company, not solely by Ms. Blonsky.

headline: For the Mugs of Brooklyn, the Bus to Bling

text: BAGHDAD, May 19  An American Special Operations unit has killed a Shiite militant suspected of organizing a sophisticated attack on a government compound in January that left five American soldiers dead, several senior military officers said Friday.

headline: A Great Idea Lives Forever. Shouldn’t Its Copyright?
text: Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Ghosts Wail as Cambodians Plunder Killing Field Graves
text: SRE LEAV, Cambodia — Researchers are examining a long-unknown killing field in Cambodia with the graves of thousands of victims of the Khmer Rouge from the 1970s.

headline: Nicole Hauptman, Cory Siegel
text: Dr. Nicole Esther Hauptman, a daughter of Madeline Hauptman and Dr. Allen Hauptman of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married today to Dr. Cory Daniel Siegel, a son of Karen Siegel and Stanley Siegel of Massapequa, N.Y. Rabbi Lester Bronstein is to officiate at the Coveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y.

headline: The Bull Market That’s Missing Something
text: SO far, this bull market has benefited from several tailwinds, including the resilient economy, reasonably low interest rates, better-than-expected corporate profits and, most recently, a flurry of merger-and-acquisition activity. But one missing ingredient has been the willingness of investors to pay higher prices for earnings.

headline: Abbey Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation
text: "I HAD a chance to be myself, and I was,” Abbey Lincoln said one recent afternoon, in a corner parlor of her spacious but unassuming ground-floor apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. This 76-year-old jazz legend was summing up her new album, “Abbey Sings Abbey” (Verve), but she could have been describing the central theme of her long and colorful career. On the walls around her were dozens of artifacts — photographs of her with jazz greats, plaques from politicians and family portraits she painted — attesting to the fullness of that story. Dominating the room was a piano, the instrument with which she wrote many of her symbolically charged and self-reflective songs.

headline: Where the Rebel Meets the Road in Joshua Tree
text: For all its desert toughness, the Joshua tree is a delicate creature. With a fibrous, almost hairy trunk and elbowed limbs crowned with spearlike leaves, it bears the solemn dignity of the truly freakish. It can live for nearly half a millennium — no one knows for sure, as it has no real bark, and hence no ring structure by which to count the years — but can survive only at certain altitudes and within a narrow band of climatic variation. It is sorrowfully inept at reproducing.

headline: Hail to the Victors of $5.4 Million
text: JetBlue’s new chief executive, David Barger, is loyal to more than just the blue in the airline’s logo. He also is a big supporter of the maize and blue — the University of Michigan, that is.

headline: Looking at the Subway From Every Angle
text: There was a time — before the automobile, the airplane and the rocket — when the transcontinental train was rich with romance, a miracle emerging from tons of steam and steel.

headline: From Russia With Nostalgia
text: Back before there was television — or radio, cellphones and the Internet — people must have devoted an enormous amount of concentration to studying one another’s appearance, deducing from physiognomy the sort of meaning a seer reads into a tarot-card spread. Oracles debated the significance of small hands or large earlobes, and authors assumed their audiences would read character into physical features. Why else would Dostoyevsky take such pains describing the examining magistrate in “Crime and Punishment?”

headline: In Palermo, Life Vibrates in a Fading Market
text: THE Vucciria, in the heart of Palermo's historic old city, opens early. By 4 a.m., fishermen are hauling in the day's catch; by 5 a.m., vendors are setting out crates of fruit and vegetables; and by 6 a.m., the place is bustling with shoppers. It's a tradition that's gone on, more or less the same way, for the last 700 years.

headline: In the ‘24’ World, Family Is the Main Casualty
text: THE frenetic, labyrinthine, exhausting counterterrorism drama “24” concludes its sixth year on Monday night with its ratings slipping and its fans in revolt. With each season of the series transpiring over a single day, this one, detractors lament, has felt like 70. The producers themselves have acknowledged the challenges of maintaining the story line’s intensity and focus. Recently in his blog on “24,” the humorist Dave Barry expressed a wish for Congressional hearings into the show’s crimes against narrative cohesiveness.

headline: The Native Builder
text: Having lived to testify, I can assure you that Glenn Murcutt is not as bad a driver as everyone says he is. Not quite, anyway. On a sunny afternoon toward the end of the Australian summer, he piloted his wife’s MG down from Sydney through the New South Wales countryside, where several examples of his architecture — a few houses and a small arts center — lie scattered about the countryside like so many jewels in the grass. “I’ve had a number of accidents, but I’ve never wiped the car out,” he said, and in truth, the ride was less frightening than exhausting. But it was a trial, an erratic wending through a lovely green landscape, full of sudden accelerations and stops, tight turns and lane dodges, lost directions and carefree distractions, all of it magnified by his tendency to stay in third gear whether we were going 10 miles an hour or 50, to drum his thumbs on the steering wheel and to talk about everything, all at once.

headline: Where Nature and National Pastime Compete
text: Jersey City

headline: The DNA 200
text: DAVID VASQUEZ was a janitor of borderline intelligence when he confessed to the 1984 rape and murder of a young woman in Arlington, Va. He was sentenced to 35 years in prison and spent 5 years there, before DNA evidence from a series of similar rapes and murders committed after he was jailed convinced the police that Mr. Vasquez was innocent.

headline: Cracking Down on Corruption
text: When a corrupt public official goes to prison, it defies common sense to reward him with a government pension for holding the job that he abused. Such a situation robs taxpayers twice: once when they pay the salary of a dishonest official who uses his job to break the law and again when they pay for his retirement.

headline: Inside the List
text: RALPH AND WRIGHT: “I wish I’d written that.” It’s a thought everyone has a couple of times a year, upon reading something particularly great. In the winter of 1952, the Book Review asked 12 writers with new books in stores to single out another book, published that year, that they wished they’d written. The answers bordered on the bizarre. John Steinbeck praised Al Capp’s dialogue in his “Li’l Abner” cartoons. Tallulah Bankhead said she envied Adlai Stevenson’s campaign speeches. Edna Ferber singled out her own novel “Giant.” (C’mon, people.) Then there was Ralph Ellison, whose first novel, “Invisible Man,” had been published earlier that year. The book Ellison said he wished he’d written was Wright Morris’s novel “The Works of Love.” This made a certain amount of sense; Morris was a forceful and worthy, if ultimately minor, writer. Ellison’s pick made even more sense if you recalled that Morris had effusively reviewed Ellison’s own novel in the Book Review, calling it “a resolutely honest, tormented, profoundly American book.” As lit-crimes go, Ellison’s back-scratching was barely a misdemeanor. But for more on Ellison’s rough edges, see Brent Staples’s review of Arnold Rampersad’s new biography.

headline: Purple Haze
text: It was a wisteria-like moment in the city last week, even before you could see the mauve blossoms dripping from a pergola, or engulfing a Victorian house at 91st Street and Lexington as if it were Sleeping Beauty’s lair. At the parties, there were women in diaphanous chiffon, a man in a mauve shirt and bowtie, a hat encircled with purple blossoms and a couple watching the sunset through the wisteria vines behind the Naumburg Bandshell.

headline: While You Were Out
text: “The Descendants” is a Pandora’s box-style tragicomedy in which a swirl of emotional debris is flung at the narrator, who is smashed and pounded and yet each time rises to be smashed and pounded again. Matt King, a wealthy Honolulu attorney, has had a grave shock: his wife, Joanie, has been injured in a boat-racing accident and now lies in the hospital in a vegetative state. In the painful depths of this crisis, King tries to repair his relationship with his two daughters, then struggles with the revelation that before her accident his wife had been in love with another man.

headline: Back in the Day
text: “A couple of expressions keep popping up in classrooms all over,” says Karen Tolchin, assistant professor of English at Florida Gulf Coast University, “looking back to what they think of as a previous era, which to us was not very long ago. One is back in the day — as in, ‘back in the day when I had the old iPod.’ The other is ‘I like to kick it old school,’ meaning they like the ‘classics’ — songs or books or films of only a few years ago. This imbues old expressions with what seems to us a wholly different time sense.”

headline: The Police Are Overdue
text: At a time when New York City is enjoying one of the biggest budget surpluses it has ever seen, when business is healthy and crime low, the men and women of the city’s police department continue to collect the stingiest paycheck around — less than police on Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey, less even than Port Authority cops. This is deeply unfair and it must be corrected.

headline: Building the Duke, Film by Film
text: JOHN WAYNE was born 100 years ago this month —“born ready,” presumably, because that’s what the men he played in the movies liked to say, and those men never lied. The whole point of the character Wayne embodied in something like 150 pictures, the overwhelming majority of them westerns and war movies, was that there was no mystery to him at all: What you saw was what you got, and if you didn’t like it, tough.

headline: A Borough’s Wise Men, in Search of a New Salon

Said friendly joint will allow up to 10 men, most of them aging and Bronx to the bone, to gather five or six times a year to eat lunch, schmooze, booze (just a little), exchange friendly insults and tell innocent off-color jokes.

headline: Trans-Atlantic Bargains Begin

Zoom Airlines, which has been operating low-fare flights from Britain to Canada for three years, is starting service between London and New York on June 21. The company will offer daily flights between Gatwick and J.F.K., with 25 percent of the seats sold for as little as as $199 each way, plus taxes.

headline: Getting to Know Mold
text: THERE are 800 to 1,000 identified molds, according to L. Claire Macdonald, laboratory manager at SanAir Technologies Laboratory, a microbial testing firm in Richmond, Va. “When you actually see mold with the naked eye, it’s just a bunch of spores stuck together,” she said. “It’s kind of known in the industry that you can’t tell by looking at it what species a particular mold is.”
