It was the worst attack against German soldiers in four years.

headline: Lee and Ochoa Pull Away on Soggy Day at Sybase
text: CLIFTON, N.J., May 19  On a drizzly Saturday at Upper Montclair Country Club, where umbrellas were large and puddles were everywhere, Lorena Ochoa and Sarah Lee played golf in a warm and comfortable cocoon.

headline: Stocks Cheap? Private Equity Thinks So
text: A LIGHT economic calendar and a winding-down of earnings announcements may keep traders focused on deal-making this week. The proliferation of mergers and acquisitions, especially by private equity funds, appears to be accelerating, and one market strategist views it as confirmation that stocks have further to rise.

headline: Medical Decisions Law (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bend, but Don’t Break
text: WHILE soaring skyward, a pole vaulter never wants to hear a loud snap — a sign that the fiberglass pole has shattered and that a rough landing may be in the cards. Such accidents, unfortunately, are an unavoidable part of the sport.

headline: When Grease Is the Way You Are Feeling
text: Gloriously greasy food is a big winner, in culinary terms, on game days. But even those who are not tuning in to sports will want to try the wings, cheese steaks and pizza at Padonno’s in Union.

headline: Assaulted, in Broad Daylight; Baby Formula at Hospitals (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Funny, You Don’t Look Dancerish
text: THE press kit is a crucial weapon in the arsenal of any media-savvy choreographer. A sort of all-purpose calling card, it includes photographs, biographical information and favorable reviews. As a popular choreographer in the middle of his career, David Dorfman has no problem supplying rave notices. But one year, fed up with a certain pattern of description, he flirted with the idea of using less flattering press descriptions: those calling him chunky or stocky, or — his favorite — saying that he looks like the owner of a hardware store.

headline: Parks for All New Yorkers
text: Among former Gov. George Pataki’s pet projects were the parks in and along the state’s waterways, especially the Hudson River Park in Manhattan and historic Governors Island in New York Harbor. For reasons that are not entirely clear — envy, perhaps, or lack of interest — Gov. Eliot Spitzer has shown nowhere near the same enthusiasm, despite the environmental credentials he earned as Attorney General.

headline: Sarah Atwood, George Recine Jr.
text: Sarah May Atwood, a daughter of Justice John R. Atwood of Newcastle, Me., and the late Patricia S. Atwood, was married yesterday to George M. Recine Jr., a son of Karen Recine and Mr. Recine Sr. of Easton, Conn. The Rev. William H. Murdoch, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the First Parish Church in York, Me.

headline: The Scent of Lilacs
text: I am writing from a mile high in a small Wyoming town on the edge of the Wind River range. The snow on the nearby buttes — the gift of late April — has finally melted, and the creek bottoms and pastures and hayground are an unhoped-for green. The drift of cotton from the cottonwoods is almost over, but the lilacs are still in high bloom. The town is nearly damp with their scent. When I come inside and can no longer smell it, I try to picture it in my mind. It is two scents really, a floral dissonance, a sweet astringency. There is a dark, grating baritone of sorts, which is veiled by a lighter, more liquid perfume — a second soprano, I suppose. I find myself wondering how a scent so strangely unsettled can also feel so homely.

headline: Correction: April 29 and May 6 Country Indexes
text: The Country Indexes table on the DataBank page on April 29 and May 6 carried incorrect data from FTSE International for the performance of foreign stock markets. Corrected tables are online at nytimes.com/business/yourmoney.

headline: Living Larger, and Drawing Fire
text: LIKE the many Eskimo words for snow, a multitude of nicknames exist for the oversize houses commonly referred to as McMansions, and they mirror the uneasiness over the spread of the homes.

headline: Israeli Army Strikes Cell in Northern Gaza as Palestinian Factional Fighting Persists
text: JERUSALEM, May 19 — The Israeli Army struck a three-member Palestinian rocket-launching cell near Beit Hanoun in the northern Gaza Strip on Saturday, first with tank shells and then from the air, an army spokesman said.

headline: Flour Power
text: On a recent afternoon, I met Maury Rubin, a baking impresario best known for serving hot chocolate with marshmallows the size of children’s blocks and tasty, oddball pastries like the pretzel croissant, at Birdbath, one of two “green” bakeries he recently opened in New York — this one appropriately in Greenwich Village. (The original Birdbath is located in the East Village.)

headline: Dijon’s Toy Story
text: In his TriBeCa art studio, the painter John Currin holds hostage a three-legged rhinoceros. Before recounting how the beast came to lose an ear, a foot and its entire right hind leg, Currin promises that this is not a Rosebud story, even though the object does relate to his California childhood. “Come to think of it, maybe it is a Rosebud,” he admits. “When I was a little boy, I went driving with my mom around Santa Cruz, and we stopped at a roadside toy store. I found this cheap stamped-metal fire engine, and I wanted it really bad. My mom wouldn’t buy it for me. She wanted me to get this carved wooden rhinoceros. I threw a temper tantrum, and the result was, I got nothing.”

headline: Africa’s Storied Colleges, Jammed and Crumbling
text: DAKAR, Senegal, May 19 — Thiany Dior usually rises before dawn, tiptoeing carefully among thin foam mats laid out on the floor as she leaves the cramped dormitory room she shares with half a dozen other women. It was built for two.

headline: Slaves of Long Island
text: A small act of kindness by workers at a doughnut shop early last Sunday has opened a window into a horrifying story of exploitation and cruelty. The accusations highlight the serious need for New York State to crack down on the trafficking of people for sex and labor, and arose, coincidentally, just as a deal was being reached in Albany on a bill to do that.

headline: Repeat Offenses
text: Tana French promises two whodunits for the price of one in her harrowing first novel, IN THE WOODS (Viking, $24.95),  by linking the contemporary homicide of a 12-year-old girl from a small town near Dublin with the misadventures of three children who vanished while playing in the same wooded area 20 years earlier. While French resolves only one of these twinned mysteries, the intricate design of her storytelling is something of its own reward — although that might not appease readers who, having been lured into these thickets, find themselves hanging from a limb.

headline: Yanks’ Trauma Is Beyond Flesh and Bone
text: The Mets had a newly anointed doctor in their dugout at Shea Stadium yesterday, but it was the Yankees who needed a doctor  an orthopedist most definitely, but maybe a psychiatrist, too.

headline: Comings and Goings
text: A new blog, uwishunu.com (you wish you knew) is promising to put the hip side of Philadelphia back on the map. A project of the Greater Philadelphia Tourism Marketing Corporation, the blog is written by city dwellers about where to eat, drink and enjoy the arts. The corporation is also using the site to promote a Philly Like a Local package, which includes a one- or two-night stay at one of eight hotels, late check-out, a guide and a CD featuring Philadelphia musicians. Rates for a one-night package start at $209. Participating hotels include the Four Seasons, the Rittenhouse Hotel and the Westin Philadelphia, which has also volunteered for another uwishunu.com-inspired project: the Hip Hotel Room Makeover. More than 25 local artists and designers were recruited to create a unique hotel room by May 31. The starting rate for the redesigned room is $239. ... Get that holiday card out of the way this summer with the Marco Island Marriott Beach Resort’s Family Beach Portrait Package. Available through Sept. 29, the package includes accommodations and a professional photo session on the beach. Rates start at $169 (www.marriott.com/mrkfl; enter promotion code PR5). On June 6, Fairmont Hotels and Resorts (www.fairmont.com) will add another jewel to its crown: Fairmont Le Montreux Palace, in Switzerland. Situated on Lake Geneva, the resort, above, now owned by Raffles, opened in 1906, and has 235 rooms, 5 restaurants, 2 bars and a spa. Fairmont is offering a three-nights-for-two promotion from June 6 to July 6 and from July 22 to Sept. 5. Nightly rates start at 515 francs, about $420 at 1.24 francs to the dollar. ... Starting Aug. 14, Qantas Airways (qantas.com/us) will offer daily service from New York to Sydney through Los Angeles. The flights are scheduled to depart J.F.K. airport every evening; round-trip fares start at $1,320. ... Avis customers planning to travel in Canada who make a reservation online for an intermediate vehicle or larger for at least five days can save $30 if they rent between now and June 27 and mention Avis Worldwide Discount number G026400 at the time of the reservation (www.avis.com/canada).

headline: 9th Graders Reach Out to Sudan, With Cash
text: Mamaroneck

headline: How’s My Driving? Dial My License Plate
text: IN “American Graffiti,” the character played by Richard Dreyfuss spends much of the movie pursuing a mysterious woman played by Suzanne Somers, who drives a white Ford Thunderbird.

headline: Celebrating Great Writing, in Short
text: ELIZABETH RICHEBOURG REA remembers her husband, Michael M. Rea, who died in 1996, always having his bedside table stacked high with short stories.

headline: Holy Satire! Faith-Based Mockery
text: THE Crusades took place during the Dark Ages, which was a very pious and righteous time during our history,” explains a teacher on a recent episode of the religious family satire “Moral Orel.” “Then the Renaissance came along and ruined everything when artists started taking the clothes off all their paintings.”

headline: Correction: Girth and Nudity, a Pictorial Mission
text: An article last week about the photography of Leonard Nimoy referred imprecisely to his acting career. He had some minor roles beginning in 1991; he did not stop acting in 1990.

headline: Family Fare, Family Affair
text: TASTE OF CHINA, a modest little takeout place in Maspeth, Queens, is destined to be one of the childhood places that Eric Lam, 4, will forever revisit, not only in dreams and memories but in person as well.

headline: Le Cinéma du Blockbuster
text: ON the sliding scale of Frenchness, “Angel-A” — a low-budget black-and-white romance in which a desperate couple travel the streets of Paris, alternately running from and chasing after a gangster as they debate the nature and meaning of existence — would seem at first glance to register pretty high. Unless you were a member of the French cinematic elite, in which case your animus toward the writer-director, Luc Besson, long the most Hollywood of French filmmakers, might make you suspect its authenticity. When it opened in Paris in December 2005, critics were predictably hostile: Under the headline “Besson Stupid and Talkative,” the reviewer for the newspaper Libération sneeringly wrote, “Besson thinks he can buy himself the title of auteur, but all he attains is a parvenu’s vulgarity.”

headline: A Great American City, Suffering (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Alexandra Guarnaschelli and Brandon Clark
text: THE hardest thing for me is restraint,” Alexandra Guarnaschelli says. “I see fresh beans and ramps and I start to quiver.”

headline: Two Opposites, Neither Perfect
text: AS far as buildings are concerned, I’m of two minds. I love the old ones where architectural details — arched windows, Corinthian columns and rough-hewn stone — are reminders of everything solid and true about old New York. But I also get excited about glittering structures with lots of glass that seem to promise a better life — with luck, on a high floor with outdoor space.

headline: Housing Plan Turns Disney Grumpy
text: Anaheim, Calif.

headline: Nearly 60 Years and Counting, Working on the Art of Theater
text: As acting techniques go, the Handman is probably not as famous as, say, the Stanislavsky or the Strasberg. But perhaps it should be.

headline: Get Your Niacin Here
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sleep French, Eat Caribbean
text: THERE are plenty of reasons to spend an evening in the Bronx, but the subway ride back to Manhattan isn't one of them. Alas, unlike the other four boroughs, the Bronx's tourist-friendly hotels exist only as the figments of politicians' and developers' imaginations.

headline: Falling Down Green
text: When my wife and I first began making yearly springtime pilgrimages to our old log cabin in the woods of Quebec, there was nothing particularly pure about our intentions. No declarations of getting back to the land, melding with nature, going green. “Wickerby” — so named by my wife’s mother after a local shrub called the “wicopy” in hope of lending it the air of an English country manor — was pretty much an uninhabitable wreck when it was first acquired in the early 1960s: a nearly two-century-old, hand-hewn spruce cabin thrown into the original 90-acre land purchase at no extra cost. The place did yield my wife and her cousins some fond childhood memories. But in the wake of various divorces and moves, the cabin was soon abandoned, allowed to go to such utter ruin that by the mid-80s, only the equivalent collapse of our Brooklyn neighborhood into drug-related violence would prompt us to think of a rundown cabin as idyllic.

headline: Amanda Plotkin, Daniel Weisenfeld
text: Amanda Jill Plotkin, a daughter of Janet and Fred Plotkin of Weston, Conn., was married last evening to Daniel Malen Weisenfeld, a son of Nancy Weisenfeld of Fremont, Calif., and the late Barry Weisenfeld. Rabbi Alysa Mendelson Graf officiated at the Essex House in New York.

headline: When Tennis Elbows Are Sharp
text: The relatively genteel sport of tennis has become the surprising focus of an impassioned war in an unassuming corner of TriBeCa.

headline: Cuomo’s Inner Circle
text: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has been praised for attracting experienced lawyers and prosecutors to his staff. They include:

headline: Lessons Well Learned, at the Academy for Anything
text: CASS CALDER SMITH spent much of his childhood with his mother on a commune in Northern California, where their house was made of surplus lumber.

headline: Cures for Some Ailing Cars
text: MECHANICAL problems can baffle even the best repair shops, in part because of cars’ increased complexity and reliance on electronic controls. Technical service bulletins from automakers, known as T.S.B.’s, can provide solutions for some recurring ailments.

headline: T-Rex to Car of Tomorrow: Hendrick Stays Ahead
text: CONCORD, N.C., May 18 — Hendrick Motorsports was at the height of its dominance of Nascar in the late 1990s when the driver Jeff Gordon showed up for the annual all-star race here with the T-Rex racecar.

text: FOR three long decades, Judith Rodgers lived in a one-bedroom rent-stabilized apartment on West 86th Street. All around her, life moved on.

headline: Clinton Accepts Aid From a Divisive Figure
text: NEW ORLEANS, May 19 — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York, who has cast herself as an ally of African-Americans in rebuilding this city, this weekend accepted fund-raising assistance from a family friend who is controversial with many black and white victims of Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Prado Grows; Vermeer Gets a Museum
text: Art aficionados heading to Spain and Holland have new spaces to enjoy.

headline: Stranded
text: If people were as obsessed with books and writers and “lost” manuscripts in the real world as they are in a certain kind of novel, we’d be living in a literary boom time. But maybe it’s the very fact of our declining book culture that compels writers like Sheridan Hay to fashion a world in which books are objects of desire.

headline: The City’s Turkish Delights
text: Come summer, the Bosporus is the only place to be. The city's main waterway separates Europe from Asia — and a noisy old city on the left bank from more tranquil shores on the right.

headline: Only 6 Districts’ Budgets Fail in Low Turnout
text: TURNOUT in school budget voting last week was low, and that was probably a good thing for Long Island’s school districts. Low turnout, superintendents say, means low levels of tax unrest among voters.

headline: Bohos in Paradise
text: At Vik-Hum’s, a late-night dive on Harbour Island in the Bahamas, the writing is on the wall — literally. Were it not for the fact that nearly every inch, including the ceiling, is covered with the signatures of beautiful people like Naomi Campbell, it would be hard to believe that this shabby frump attracts the caftan-wearing beau monde.

headline: On the Q.T.:  Grant Thatcher
text: Among the jet set, Luxe City Guides have achieved a near cult status for their exacting, opinionated and deliciously bitchy takes on cities including Hanoi, Rome and, next month, New York. The Hong Kong-based founder and editor Grant Thatcher took the T Travel Questionnaire.

text: Joachimsthal, Germany

text: Summerland, Calif.

headline: Bois Sec Ardoin, Musician and Nurturer of Creole Tradition, Dies at 91
text: Alphonse Ardoin, a Louisiana Creole accordionist and singer nicknamed Bois Sec whose music stalwartly sustained South Louisiana tradition, died Wednesday of natural causes in Eunice, La., where he had been living in a nursing home, said his son Morris. He was 91 years old.

headline: The Gates of Hell
text: This year Britain, whose empire was, until 1807, the world’s biggest slave power, is marking the bicentenary of its abolition of the slave trade. The commemoration has ranged in tone from presenting a part of the country’s past as indeed something somber, even shameful, to celebrating its role in bringing human trafficking to an end.

headline: Dina Hasiotis, Timothy McEvoy
text: Dina Evangeline Hasiotis and Timothy Graham McEvoy were married yesterday by the Rev. George Daskalakis at the Annunciation Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Boston.

headline: Hooked on News
text: I PLAYED forward on the junior varsity basketball team my first year in high school. A few weeks after the season started, the varsity team played a game against Tamaqua Area High School. I was also a stringer for The Easton Express. One of my earliest stories was about the victory. I was hooked from the get-go.

headline: A Stylish Rosé of South Africa
text: Mulderbosch’s floral 2006 cabernet sauvignon rosé from Stellenbosch, in the heart of South Africa’s wine industry, combines a white’s zip and a red’s oomph. Deeply chilled, this stylish pink rosé is a tangy aperitif.

headline: Colombian Gold in Cartagena
text: You’re probably still a bit gun-shy about visiting Colombia, put off by the country’s long history of cocaine-fueled mayhem. Travel qualms diminish or subside entirely, however, when you’re the guest of a trusted local who assures you that Pablo Escobar is dead and buried. Which may explain why a class of well-connected travelers has recently been alighting in the Caribbean port city of Cartagena and raving about the place upon their return.

headline: Alicia Kirk, Ben Fritz
text: Alicia Kirk , a daughter of Florence Kirk of Manlius N.Y., and the late Eugene Kirk, was married yesterday to Ben Fritz, the son of Elise Godfrey of Ossining, N.Y., and Bruce Fritz of Westport, Conn. Isaac Reed, a friend of the couple who was named a deputy marriage commissioner by Los Angeles County for this event, officiated at Saddlerock Ranch in Malibu, Calif.

headline: The Geisha-and-Houseboy-Liberation Theater
text: NEW YORK is a graveyard of bankrupt theater companies and broken dreams. But Tisa Chang’s Pan Asian Repertory Theater, with an annual budget of less than $1 million, is improbably celebrating its 30th anniversary.

headline: Bowa Hopes Canó’s Errors Are Part of Maturing
text: Larry Bowa keeps close watch on Robinson Canó, working with him constantly, cajoling him, yet supporting him. Canó, the Yankees’ second baseman, forged a bond with Bowa by calling him before last season when Bowa was named the infield coach.

headline: Hiring Outlook Shows There Is  Life After Finals
text: As the strains of “Pomp and Circumstance” dissolve into the past and the latest batches of college graduates issue forth into the work world, they can expect a warm welcome from the nation’s employers. Some companies might view these new graduates as “cheap labor,” but in general it is more polite to use the term “entry-level workers.”

headline: Extreme Mulching
text: THE surest way to scatter my family is to mention, oh so casually, that the mulch delivery is imminent. For the last few years, since our teenage son got buff enough to wield the oversize shovel used to spread the small mountain delivered every spring, he and his dad have approached the task with the verve and good cheer of chain gang conscripts.

headline: High-low | Riviera Restaurants
text: MIRAZUR

headline: Jangled by a Jingle, He Writes His Own ...
text: The familiar jingle of Mister Softee is a bit less ubiquitous on city streets these days, and not just because soggy weather gave the company its slowest April in history. Eighteen months ago, when the city was cracking down on noise, the company promised that the jingle would be played only when its ice cream trucks were on the move. Now, the bouncy little melody faces yet another challenge, this time from a Brooklyn songwriter.

headline: In Praise of Translators
text: To the Editor:

headline: Erin Neary, Erdal Dere
text: Erin M. Neary, a daughter of Helen Neary Pryor of Weston, Conn., and the late Martin E. Neary, was married yesterday to Erdal Dere, a son of Aysel Dere and Selim Dere of Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. George M. Witt performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

headline: Reaping Results: Data-Mining Goes Mainstream
text: RODNEY MONROE, the police chief in Richmond, Va., describes himself as a lifelong cop whose expertise is in fighting street crime, not in software. His own Web browsing, he says, mostly involves checking golf scores.

headline: Another Dow Record, and S.& P. Comes Close
text: It was another strong week for the stock market, and it ended with the Dow Jones industrial average reaching another record close and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index tantalizingly near a record of its own.

headline: Mixed (Media) Messages
text: “Tremendous World” is the apt title of Lesley Dill’s exhibition now at the Neuberger Museum of Art, where extremely large, dramatic works cover the walls of the gallery, some of them up to 60 feet long and 20 feet high. The show is not a retrospective, but it does chronicle ideas and themes that the Brooklyn-based, Bronxville-born artist has been working with throughout her career.

headline: ‘Doors Open’
text: Doors Open: Chapter 2: At the Gallery

headline: Under Oath, Landis Denies Having Used Testosterone
text: MALIBU, Calif., May 19  After five days of dense scientific testimony, revelations of sexual abuse and accusations of blackmail, Floyd Landis finally spoke at his own hearing.

headline: Sophia Chaknis, Joseph Levy
text: Sophia Ruth Chaknis and Joseph Daniel Levy were married yesterday in the Old State House in Boston. The Rev. Mark D. W. Edington, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the nondenominational ceremony.

headline: Where the Club Boys Are
text: IT was Friday night, and a petite writer named Caroline was the only woman in sight at the Joiner's Arms, a crowded bar in the East London neighborhood of Shoreditch that was recently immortalized in a song by the band Bloc Party. But that's not to say she was the only person in a dress.

headline: Spitzer Is Said to Be Weighing a Track Overhaul That Would Close Aqueduct
text: Aqueduct, the blue-collar racetrack in Queens, could be closed under a plan reportedly being floated by Gov. Eliot Spitzer to overhaul racing at three New York thoroughbred tracks.

headline: Anime Dreams, Transformed Into Nightmares
text: THE parade always starts like this: A sofa, a refrigerator, a microwave oven and a vacuum cleaner dance and twist their way down a confetti-covered street. Right behind them come the frogs playing trumpets; a group of tipsy raccoons, clutching bottles of sake; and a band of friendly cats, raising their paws in greeting.

headline: Village Vanguard in Tiradentes, Brazil
text: There was much excitement in the village of Tiradentes when Ana Maria Parsons, the proprietor of the Solar da Ponte inn in the center of town, recently installed a soapstone bathtub in one of her guest rooms. The tub weighs more than 1,000 pounds and required six burly men using three car jacks to hoist it in place.

headline: 36 Hours in Baltimore
text: BALTIMORE is sometimes the forgotten middle child among attention-getting Eastern cities like Washington and New York. But a civic revival, which began with the harbor's makeover 27 years ago, has given out-of-towners reason to visit. Yes, there are wonderful seafood restaurants, Colonial history, quaint waterfronts and other tourist-ready attractions. But Baltimore's renaissance has also cultivated cool restaurants with innovative cuisine, independent theaters that showcase emerging talent and galleries that specialize in contemporary art. In other words, Baltimore is all grown up, but it's still a big city with a small-town feel.

headline: Denver’s Mile-High Style
text: When Jennifer Roberts opened Composition (1) in 2003, a modern design store was a hard sell in Denver. The city was still driven by outdoor sports; few went looking for Karim Rashid piggy banks. “I was a few years too early,” says Roberts of her shop (7180 W. Alaska Drive, Belmar; 303-894-0025). But, with Daniel Libeskind's museum complete, one by David Adjaye on the way and a handful of major hotels scheduled to open in the next three years, Denver is emerging as a style-conscious city with great shopping. Along with the three-year-old fashion boutique Skye (2) (1499 Blake Street; 303-623-0444), still the only game in town for avant-garde labels like Alexandre Herchcovitch and Heatherette, there's the Fabric Lab (3105 East Colfax Avenue; 303-321-3604) and Fancy Tiger (1 South Broadway; 303-733-3855). Both cater to hipsters interested in reworked vintage clothes and printed tees from local labels like Potential Fashions and Hecklewood. And in the fast-gentrifying downtown, the high-end sneaker shop the 400 (3) opened a second Denver location (2445 Larimer Street; 303-292-2646), near the former Brooklynite Paul Hardt's gallery and furniture shop, P Design Gallery (4) (2590 Walnut Street; 720-259-2516), which has introduced Coloradans to the likes of Tobi Wong and FredriksonStallard.

headline: Matthew’s Vindication
text: Some stories have good endings. Take, for example, the case of Matthew LaClair, the Kearny student who last year had the courage to speak up when his 11th-grade history teacher told students that the theory of evolution was scientifically unsound and that only Christians had a place in heaven.

headline: This Old, Organic House
text: The house that I live in is an exquisitely tuned, environmentally sensitive machine — or at least it was when it was built, back when Thomas Jefferson was president, more than two centuries ago. Light, temperature and air circulation were regulated by an elaborate technology of window sashes, louvered or paneled shutters, flues, curtains and doors. A long central hallway drew breezes through, offering relief from steamy Maryland summers. Sometimes, I can still almost hear the ghosts of the original owners, offering advice born of long experience: On a hot July morning, close the front shutters, open the hall doors at both ends, raise the upstairs sashes to catch the southerly breeze. My house’s walls were built of bricks fired on the spot from the same clayey soil that had been dug out to form the cellar, so that I think of it as something like a sand castle, sculptured from its surrounding earth. It is as “organic,” in its homely 19th-century way, as the pounded-dirt floors that are apparently all the rage now in certain parts of Mendocino County.

headline: For Oracle, the Race Is Almost Over Before It Begins
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 19  In a battle for survival, the United States team, BMW Oracle Racing, lost another duel with the Italian team Saturday, sending the Americans to the brink of losing a pricey, four-year quest for the America’s Cup sailing trophy.

headline: Conductor, Dismissed After a Stroke, Sues Ridgefield Symphony
text: FOR more than 30 years, Sidney Rothstein made his living as a music conductor, beckoning orchestras with the wave of his right hand. Then, on Dec. 19, 2005, he had a stroke and awoke unable to use the arm that earned him a living.

headline: Celebrating, and Quarreling Over, Frogs
text: ANGELS CAMP, Calif., May 17  Every May, they come. Thousands of slimy little athletes, primed for the biggest event of their careers, the World Series of competitive frog jumping: the Calaveras County Fair and Jumping Frog Jubilee.

headline: Immigrants Reject Quebec’s Separatists
text: VERDUN, Quebec — As cultural coordinator for a resource center for new Quebecers, Gabriel Garcia is leading an effort to bridge the gap between the growing number of immigrants here and the mostly French-speaking society into which they have moved.

headline: Résumé of Doom
text: Paul Wolfowitz may be out of a job soon, but think of what an amazing résumé he’ll be shopping around:

headline: An Undersea Feeling in a Landlocked Space
text: AT Opah Grille, deft decorating creates the uncanny sensation of dining underwater. The recessed ceiling, deep-sea blue, is echoed in the window awnings visible from inside. Two fish tanks are focal points, with constant, undulating movement: spanning the entryway to one large dining room, and dominating a wall in another.

headline: Mlicki Still Savors Success Against Yanks
text: When Dave Mlicki first glanced at the Mets’ schedule before the 1997 season, his eyes darted to mid-June. That was when the Mets would play the Yankees for the first time in a regular-season game. Mlicki, a starting pitcher, immediately began forecasting the future.

headline: Wrapping His Arms Around the Red Wings

headline: Mommy Woes

The classrooms inside the 1876 schoolhouse where her daughters Jordan, 6, and Olivia, 2, spent their day were warm and brightly decorated, and the rooms’ corners were each devoted to a particular field of discipline: science, art, numbers and reading.

headline: The Road to Curitiba
text: On Saturday mornings, children gather to paint and draw in the main downtown shopping street of Curitiba, in southern Brazil. More than just a charming tradition, the child’s play commemorates a key victory in a hard-fought, ongoing war. Back in 1972, the new mayor of the city, an architect and urban planner named Jaime Lerner, ordered a lightning transformation of six blocks of the street into a pedestrian zone. The change was recommended in a master plan for the city that was approved six years earlier, but fierce objections from the downtown merchants blocked its implementation. Lerner instructed his secretary of public works to institute the change quickly and asked how long it would take. “He said he needed four months,” Lerner recalled recently. “I said, ‘Forty-eight hours.’ He said, ‘You’re crazy.’ I said, ‘Yes, I’m crazy, but do it in 48 hours.’ ” The municipal authorities were able to accomplish it in three days, beginning on a Friday night and installing paving, lighting, planters and furniture by the end of the day on Monday. “Being a very weak mayor, if I start to do it and take too long, everyone could stop it through a juridical demand,” Lerner went on to explain. “If they stop the work, it’s finished. I had to do it very fast, at least in part. Because we had discussed it a great deal. Sometimes they have to have a demonstration effect.”

headline: Playing the Hand We’ve Dealt
text: Last week, President Bush appointed a “war czar,” Lt. Gen. Douglas Lute, to oversee everything we’re doing in Iraq and Afghanistan — which raises the question: Who was doing this job up to now? The answer, amazingly, is no one. We’re like a fine restaurant that has decided five years after it’s opened — and has lost most of its customers — that it might be good to hire a head chef. Better late than never. General Lute comes advertised as smart and tough. Good. I hope his first memo to the president starts like this:

headline: Grand Old Lessons in a Bright Blue Borough
text: It looked like an exam room for an S.A.T. A week ago Saturday, in a small conference room in a hotel in Bayside, Queens, rows of tables stood covered with neatly laid-out papers. The type of people filing into the room, however — mostly middle-aged and older — suggested otherwise.

headline: The Reverend Falwell’s Heavenly Timing
text: HARD as it is to believe now, Jerry Falwell came in second only to Ronald Reagan in a 1983 Good Housekeeping poll anointing “the most admired man in America.” By September 2001, even the Bush administration was looking for a way to ditch the preacher who had joined Pat Robertson on TV to pin the 9/11 attacks on feminists, abortionists, gays and, implicitly, Teletubbies. As David Kuo, a former Bush official for faith-based initiatives, tells the story in his book “Tempting Faith,” the Reverend Falwell was given a ticket to the Washington National Cathedral memorial service that week only on the strict condition that he stay away from reporters and cameras. Mr. Falwell obeyed, though once inside he cracked jokes (“Whoa, does she look frumpy,” he said of Barbara Bush) and chortled nonstop.

headline: Home of the Brave
text: “Presidential historians” seem to be everywhere these days. Doris Kearns Goodwin, Douglas Brinkley and Richard Norton Smith, all of whom are commonly defined as such, appear frequently on television talk shows and write for op-ed pages. They are consulted when former presidents die, around election time or on the occasion of any notable episode involving the executive branch. Yet no one goes to college or graduate school to study “presidential history.” Universities do not offer courses in the subject. So: who or what created “presidential history”?

headline: In Final Strides, Curlin Ends Bid for the Crown
text: BALTIMORE, May 19 — As Street Sense angled out of the final turn past Hard Spun, much as he did two weeks ago in the Kentucky Derby, Carl Nafzger, the colt’s trainer, nudged Jim Tafel, his owner, and tight, satisfied smiles spread across their faces. Street Sense was en route to the Belmont Stakes with a chance to sweep the Triple Crown.

headline: U.S. Pays Pakistan to Fight Terror, but Patrols Ebb
text: WASHINGTON, May 19 — The United States is continuing to make large payments of roughly $1 billion a year to Pakistan for what it calls reimbursements to the country’s military for conducting counterterrorism efforts along the border with Afghanistan, even though Pakistan’s president decided eight months ago to slash patrols through the area where Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters are most active.

headline: In Wary Era, Nanny State of Our Own Making

headline: Lottery Numbers
A New Adventure Across the River
text: ELIZABETH STRIBLING, a high priestess of sorts for pricey Upper East Side real estate, has decided to move out of her town house — with its beloved rear garden — on East 84th Street near York Avenue. She is moving, not to a swanky Fifth Avenue duplex or an exclusive Park Avenue co-op listed by her firm, but (gasp!) across the East River to a condominium penthouse just south of the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: 1940s Communal Living in a Wright-Planned Utopia
text: In photographs and drawings, Usonia’s houses look like early 20th-century geometric abstractions, or even Constructivist sculpture. Visiting the buildings on a pristine tract of 97 acres overlooking the north end of Kensico Reservoir in Mount Pleasant is an entirely different experience, for they are so sympathetic and well integrated that they blend inconspicuously into the leafy environment, echoing the contours of the land and frequently utilizing local natural materials like wood and stone.

headline: Outrageous Fortune
text: Near the end of Henry James’s career, Edith Wharton reproached him for repudiating the novels of Gustave Flaubert. Why, she asked, was Anna Karenina a better subject than Madame Bovary? “Ah,” James replied, “but one paints the fierce passions of a luxurious aristocracy, the other deals with the petty miseries of a little bourgeois in a provincial town.”

headline: Or No Conspiracy?
text: I have no idea what book wears the crown of longest nonfiction title ever published. Whoever holds the record, it is about to be challenged by Vincent Bugliosi, whose new work, “Reclaiming History,” a cellular-level re-examination of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, clocks in at 1,612 pages. That’s not a typo. One thousand six hundred and twelve pages. Plus notes. On a CD-ROM. Bugliosi, best known as the prosecutor of Charles Manson and a co-author of the best seller “Helter Skelter” three decades ago, writes that his new offering, if chopped into books of 120,000 words each, would fill 13 full volumes. Note to editor: You owe me big time.

Despite the cold and intermittent rain, dancers from all over New York, New Jersey and Long Island turned out in skimpy spangled tops, floor-sweeping skirts and zoot suits.

headline: Al Gore Has Big Plans
text: One afternoon in February, Al Gore was waiting to board a commercial flight from Nashville to Miami, where he was to deliver the slide show that forms the basis of “An Inconvenient Truth,” his Academy Award-winning documentary on global warming. Gore was telling me about Ilya Prigogine, a Belgian chemist who won a Nobel Prize in 1977 for his insights into the thermodynamics of open systems, an intriguing subject that has very little to do with global warming. Every minute or so he flashed a microgrin at a passer-by without interrupting his oratorical flow. We had moved on to complexity theory, which Gore would really immerse himself in if only he had the time, and then to the concept of nested systems, which of course had been developed by the late psychologist Uri Bronfenbrenner, when a woman in a blazing orange shirt emerged from her flight, did a double take and cried, “Isn’t that AL GORE?!” There was no ignoring this fan. As she came over to thank Gore for trying to save the planet, I saw that my bags were in the way. “I’ll move them,” I said; and Gore, before he could think, said, “No, don’t.”

As I got out of the taxi, I collapsed onto the street.

headline: Why Are They Greener Than We Are?
text: The headquarters of the federal environment agency in Dessau, Germany, occupies a low-slung building on the edge of an abandoned gasworks. Dessau, a center for munitions production during the war, was virtually obliterated by Allied bombs. Over the next 50 years, East German factories saturated the soil with chemical and industrial waste. Yet both the agency building and its location might be said to embody a new, ecologically sensitive Europe.

headline: The Immigration Deal
text: The immigration deal announced in the Senate last week poses an excruciating choice. It is a good plan wedded to a repugnant one. Its architects seized a once-in-a-generation opportunity to overhaul a broken system and emerged with a deeply flawed compromise. They tried to bridge the chasm between brittle hard-liners who want the country to stop absorbing so many outsiders, and those who want to give immigrants — illegal ones, too — a fair and realistic shot at the American dream.

headline: My Dear Fellow Species
text: THE Origin of Species” is almost 150 — a fit survivor of the science canon even if not everyone has seen fit to jump from the Ark to the Beagle on the matter of evolution (three Republican presidential candidates, for example). But Darwin himself was slow to come to his ideas, and slower still to disclose them to a skeptical public. Last week, the Darwin Correspondence Project, based at Cambridge University, put about 5,000 letters to and from Darwin, some of them previously unpublished, online at darwinproject.ac.uk, with thousands more to follow. The searchable database lets anyone track the painstaking development of his research and thinking — on all kinds of topics, personal and professional, and with a huge array of correspondents. MARY JO MURPHY

headline: In Hell’s Basement
text: THE bimonthly parties held in the squat basement of St. Paul the Apostle, a church on Columbus Avenue, are not your typical Manhattan affair.

headline: The Accidental Environmentalist
text: One late evening in March, Shigeru Ban, dressed as always in black, left his office, a large recycled-paper tube structure about the size of a subway car temporarily wedged onto the top floor of the Pompidou Center in Paris. Mimicking the shape of the glass escalator tubes on the building’s outside, the office blends imperceptibly enough into the architecture that nobody on staff at Georges, the trendy rooftop restaurant with a big glass window facing Ban’s studio, even knew it was there.

headline: What’s on Sunday Night
text: 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS With the help of the C.T.U. (Counter Truancy Unit), Bart, left, and Lisa race against time to stop a gang of bullies from releasing a near-toxic stink bomb at the school’s annual bake sale. Agents Jack Bauer (voiced by Kiefer Sutherland) and Chloe O’Brian (Mary Lynn Rajskub) take a break from the live action of “24” to help Bart and Lisa save Springfield’s olfactory nerves. In the second half of this hourlong season finale  the 400th episode of the series  Kent Brockman swears during his newscast and loses his job.

headline: Point of Order
text: Like Webster’s Dictionary and “Hints From Heloise,” Robert’s Rules of Order is a powerful brand name and an American classic. Since it first appeared in 1876, Robert’s has become the go-to guide for conducting parliamentary-style meetings, used by everyone from the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee to the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, as well as countless local governments and corporate boards.

headline: The Lavender Hill Mob
text: It’s Washington in 1953, and the senator from Wisconsin has the gavel in his hand. The city is full of muck and fear and the naming of names, but red isn’t the only color the McCarthyites claim to abhor. There’s lavender too, though the question remains the same: “Are you now or have you ever been. ...” At the State Department, the forces of decency work in the Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs, an office whose name sounds to Hawkins Fuller “like a C.I.A. front: the little publishing house in Vienna, the art dealer in Rome.” At Fuller’s own interrogation, he’s asked to walk across the room, then read aloud from Somerset Maugham. But there’s nothing swishy about this Navy veteran, and when the lie detector is brought out his pulse holds steady.

headline: Roadside Bombs Kill 7 U.S. Soldiers in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, May 20 — Seven American soldiers were killed by roadside bombs, including six who died in one attack in western Baghdad, the military said today.

headline: Corina Wilder, Michael Davis
text: Corina Anne Wilder, a daughter of Gail L. Wilder and Darrel R. Wilder of Johnson City, Tenn., was married on Friday to Michael Clayton Davis, a son of Nancy L. Davis and Dennis K. Davis of State College, Pa. John G. Laurie, a retired judge of the Circuit Court of Cook County in Chicago, performed the ceremony at the Joseph Bond Chapel of the University of Chicago.

headline: Matz and Chelokee Honor Barbaro With a Victory
text: BALTIMORE, May 19  Chelokee, a colt trained by Michael Matz, captured the first running of the Barbaro Stakes, named for last year’s Kentucky Derby winner who made a catastrophic misstep in the opening yards of last year’s Preakness Stakes.

headline: New Chef Enhances a Proven Crowd Pleaser
text: A YEAR and a half ago, Four Food Studio and Cocktail Salon opened to raves in Melville. The place has been packed from Day 1, as those in search of a sleek, sophisticated spot found they no longer had to trek to Manhattan. At lunch the restaurant attracts office workers from the nearby Route 110 corridor; in the evenings it seems as though the entire population of single Long Islanders aged 20 to 50 is in the bar.

headline: Market Forces
text: The Grand Bazaar is the mother of all shopping districts, a 550-year-old warren of more than 3,600 shops and 60 streets. It’s a must-see for visitors but can also be a nightmare: lots of dross, rapacious salesmen and the hassles of bargaining. Local entrepreneurs have recently set up shop alongside some worthwhile stalwarts, creating relaxed spaces with quality merchandise that are drawing even Turks to the old town. Most of these are in the bazaar’s central area around Fes Cafe.

headline: The Week Ahead: May 20 - 26

headline: An Eco-House for the Future
text: Diller Scofidio + Renfro have made a building out of a cloud of atomized lake water, designed a museum for the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston that literally opens onto the harbor and devoted an entire multimedia exhibition to the American lawn. Their recent projects include remaking Lincoln Center and transforming New York’s High Line — an abandoned elevated railroad line that runs from Midtown Manhattan to the meatpacking district — into a park. On this and the following pages, in collaboration with the environmental-design firm Atelier Ten, they imagine a guilt-free, sustainable luxury house that thrives on excess, and the couple, M. and J., who live in it.

headline: ‘The Atomic Bazaar’
text: Hiroshima was destroyed in a flash by a bomb dropped from a propeller-driven B-29 of the U.S. Army Air Corps, on the warm morning of Monday, August 6, 1945. The bomb was not chemical, as bombs until then had been, but atomic, designed to release the energies that Einstein had described. It was a simple cannon-type device of the sort that today any number of people could build in a garage. It was bulbous and black, about ten feet long, and weighed ninety-seven hundred pounds. It fell nose-down for forty-three seconds and, for maximum effect, never hit the ground. One thousand nine hundred feet above the city it fired a dull gray plug of highly enriched uranium down a steel tube into a receiving lump of the same refined material, creating a combined uranium mass of 133 pounds. In relation to its surface area, that mass was more than enough to achieve "criticality" and allow for an uncontrollable chain of fission reactions, during which subatomic particles called neutrons collided with uranium nuclei, releasing further neutrons, which collided with other nuclei, in a blossoming process of self-destruction. The reactions could be sustained for just a millisecond, and they fully exploited less than two pounds of the uranium atoms before the resulting heat forced a halt to the process through expansion. Uranium is one of the heaviest elements on earth, almost twice as heavy as lead, and two pounds of it amounts to only about three tablespoonfuls. Nonetheless the release of energy over Hiroshima yielded a force equivalent to fifteen thousand tons (fifteen kilotons) of TNT, achieved temperatures higher than the sun's, and emitted light-speed pulses of lethal radiation. More than 150,000 people died.

headline: ‘The Clarks of Cooperstown’
text: The person whose amassing of a fortune made all the collecting and high living possible was Edward Cabot Clark. Edward's grandsons-Sterling and Stephen and their brothers, Edward and Ambrose-would not have been who they were without the wealth they acquired thanks to Edward's phenomenal business success. They reaped the rewards of their grandfather's financial acumen, legal expertise, and common sense; and Sterling and Stephen, if not the other two, also felt the imprint of Edward's personality. While on the surface Edward, a Sunday-school teacher as well as a lawyer, was a man of traditional bearing who comported himself with conservative demeanor, he was intensely strong-willed, determined, and uncompromising, as well as crafty. Even if their own father, Edward's son Alfred, was a bird of a different feather, Edward's triumph in the world of commerce gave Sterling and Stephen their mettle and sense of entitlement.

headline: ‘In the Driver's Seat’
text: Up at a Villa

headline: ‘The Secret of Lost Things’
text: I was born before this story starts, before I dreamed of such a place as the Arcade, before I imagined men like Walter Geist existed outside of fables, outside of fairy tales. My time at the Arcade would have gone very differently but for him, for his blindness. His eyes were nearly useless when I met him, and were it not for his condition, I would never have known about Herman Melville's lost book. Walter Geist's blindness is important, but it's my own, with regard to him, that remains a lasting regret. It's the reason for this story. If I start with my own beginning you will understand how I came to the Arcade, and how it came to mean so much to me.

headline: ‘Fellow Travelers’
text: September 28, 1953

headline: ‘Presidential Courage’
text: A Speedy Death to General Washington!

headline: ‘The Descendants’
text: The sun is shining, mynah birds are chattering, palm trees are swaying, so what. I'm in the hospital and I'm healthy. My heart is beating as it should. My brain is firing off messages that are loud and clear. My wife is on the upright hospital bed, positioned the way people sleep on airplanes, her body stiff, head cocked to the side. Her hands are on her lap.

headline: ‘Einstein’
text: When Albert Einstein woke up on November 7, 1919, a wintry gray Friday morning, in his apartment on Haberlandstrasse 5 in Berlin, his life had been transformed. The forty-year-old had no idea at this point what the next few weeks and months-and the rest of his life-had in store for him. His quest to "sneak a look at God's cards" brought him about as close to the essence of nature as anyone had ever been. Even so, on the day of his "canonization" in the temple of science, he could scarcely envision the direction his life was about to take.

headline: ‘The Religion’
text: Sunday, May 13, 1565 Castel Sant'Angelo-The Borgo-Malta

headline: ‘Ralph Ellison’
text: Decades after the blazing hot afternoon in June 1933 when Ralph Ellison, in his first and last outing as a hobo, climbed fearfully and yet eagerly aboard a smoky freight train leaving Oklahoma City on a dangerous journey that he hoped would take him to college in Tuskegee, Alabama, his memories of growing up in Oklahoma continued both to haunt and to inspire him. For a long time he had suppressed those memories; then the time came when he began to crave them.

headline: ‘Einstein: His Life and Universe’
text: "I promise you four papers," the young patent examiner wrote his friend. The letter would turn out to bear some of the most significant tidings in the history of science, but its momentous nature was masked by an impish tone that was typical of its author. He had, after all, just addressed his friend as "you frozen whale" and apologized for writing a letter that was "inconsequential babble." Only when he got around to describing the papers, which he had produced during his spare time, did he give some indication that he sensed their significance.

headline: Dubai on a Budget
text: In the emirate synonymous with over-the-top artifice, the Frugal Traveler gets by on $250 a day.

headline: Paperback Row
text: GUESTS OF THE AYATOLLAH: The First Battle in America’s War With Militant Islam, by Mark Bowden. (Grove, $15. ) In “Black Hawk Down,” Bowden recounted the fiasco that led to the death of 18 Army Rangers in Somalia in 1993. Here he reconstructs in minute detail the seizure of the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979, and the 444-day ordeal that followed. Bowden includes thumbnail sketches of the participants — from the hostages and their student captors to the aggressive new military unit called Delta Force — and a heart-stopping account of Desert One, President Jimmy Carter’s near- suicidal rescue operation. Our reviewer, James Traub, called “Guests of the Ayatollah” a story of “mutual incomprehension” and a “case study in how ordinary men and women cope with the stupefying tedium, the rage and the gnawing despair, of long confinement.”

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: GHOSTWALK, by Rebecca Stott. (Spiegel & Grau, $24.95.) Stott’s first novel, a mesmerizing intellectual thriller, connects a 17th-century alchemical cabal in Isaac Newton’s Cambridge with outbreaks of post-9/11 violence.

headline: Excerpts and Audio: The Pellicano Case
text: Following are excerpts of calls between the private eye Anthony Pellicano and several Hollywood players, as transcribed and edited by The New York Times. The digital recordings of the calls were turned over last year by prosecutors to defense lawyers as part of the discovery process. Prosecutors said the recordings were recovered from Mr. Pellicano's computers. Mr. Pellicano has pleaded not guilty to charges of wiretapping and racketeering.

headline: Haunted Dreams
text: Images from Satoshi Kon's anime film, "Paprika."

headline: Third M-Tel Masters: Topalov, the Comeback Kid, Wins Again
text: Veselin Topalov of Bulgaria won the M-Tel Masters yet again by beating Krishnan Sasikiran of India in the last round. In what is becoming a trademark for him, Topalov once again came from behind by staging a second-half surge to overtake his rivals. Games from the tournament can be replayed here at the tournament’s Web site.

headline: Sunday Sampler Platter
text: This could be the week when Attorney General Alberto Gonzales finally resigns –- at least if the Sunday-morning predictive powers of Senator Arlen Specter prove accurate.

headline: Looking for a Few Stand-Up Men
text: What the military needs now is a number of senior generals and admirals who are willing and able to debate the president and the secretary of defense — and a president and secretary of defense who are big enough to accept disagreement and even learn from it. This would re-establish a tradition that gave the armed services their greatest commanders and America a history of military victory.

headline: The Beauty of the Oil Market
text: It’s busy season for gas station attendants — with prices for a gallon of regular unleaded bopping around $3.11 nationally, they need to change their signs at least once a day. Many drivers hate these price changes, and I see their point: Not only are rising gas prices a financial burden; they also function as a sort of emotional baseball score — an index of American economic health. When prices are high, anxiety rises.

headline: Your Comments on my Health Column
text: Please post your comments here on my Monday column about reforming the health care system. Thanks.

headline: New York Republicans, Pining
text: State Republicans are pining for a 2008 ticket with the name Rudolph W. Giuliani at the top.

headline: Emphasis Shifts for New Breed of Evangelicals
text: The evangelical Christian movement, which has been pivotal in reshaping the country’s political landscape since the 1980s, has shifted in potentially momentous ways in recent years, broadening its agenda and exposing new fissures.

headline: Emphasis Shifts for New Breed of Evangelicals
text: The evangelical Christian movement, which has been pivotal in reshaping the country’s political landscape since the 1980s, has shifted in potentially momentous ways in recent years, broadening its agenda and exposing new fissures.

headline: At Marymount Graduation, a Centennial, and a Farewell
text: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 20 — Mother and daughter strutted hand in hand on Sunday along a dais erected on the edge of the bucolic Marymount College campus here, on a knoll overlooking the Hudson River.

headline: Death by Veganism
text: WHEN Crown Shakur died of starvation, he was 6 weeks old and weighed 3.5 pounds. His vegan parents, who fed him mainly soy milk and apple juice, were convicted in Atlanta recently of murder, involuntary manslaughter and cruelty.

headline: In Boston Clubhouse, No Comfort in a Fast Start
text: BOSTON, May 20 — Because his current perspective is from high atop the American League East, Boston Red Sox Manager Terry Francona was asked whether he felt any sympathy for or empathy with Joe Torre, his rival as manager of the Yankees.

headline: 2 Free New York Newspapers Are Doing Battle on Web Sites as Well as in Subways
text: New York City’s two free daily tabloids usually compete by seeing how many papers they can shove into the hands of subway riders. Now they are going head-to-head on a different platform — a digital one.

headline: Exploiting a Convenient Truth: There’s Profit in Eco-Disaster
text: After a wild night at a rave Gabriel (Tom McClane), a banker with a guilty conscience, makes his move on a pretty artist, Ellen (Sophie Hunter). He flirts and she smiles, and as the sexual tension rises conversation turns to — what else? — global warming. “The sea’s been rising by the same amount for centuries, but now with the ice caps melting, it’s out of control,” Ellen says, with a glint in her eye. After some passionate banter about storm surges and low-pressure systems, the attractive couple, high from all this talk of the end of the world, jump into the sack.

headline: Tough Territory in the World of Experimental Music
text: A lot of the sounds heard over the weekend at the Hook in Red Hook, Brooklyn, came with the force of an assault. There were whipsaw screeches, scorching blasts, solar-plexus-socking rumbles. Also ominous whorls and scabrous wails. It was all part of the fourth annual No Fun Fest, a transnational summit on the state of extreme experimental music, mostly electronic in origin and industrial in tone.

headline: U.S. Sues New York for Bias Over Firefighters Test
text: The United States Department of Justice filed a civil rights lawsuit against New York City over the Fire Department’s written multiple-choice test, which black and Hispanic candidates fail at much higher rates than whites.

headline: Much Ado About Apple’s iPhone
text: PARIS, May 20 — Few mobile phones have created more buzz before becoming a reality than Apple’s iPhone — even in Europe and Asia, which will not see the talked-about handset for many months.

headline: White House Says Carter Criticism of Bush Is ‘Sad’
text: CRAWFORD, Tex., May 20  It is a relatively genteel club, with a membership that has dwindled to four in number: Those who know, firsthand, the pressures and challenges of being the leader of the free world.

headline: Eye-Opener: A Blind Man’s Rare Opportunity to See
text: With his first book, “Shadow Divers,” Robert Kurson told the endlessly interesting story of how divers discovered a mysterious sunken submarine off the coast of New Jersey, a find that would lead them to solve the mysteries of how the sub got there and why its fate had gone undocumented. “Shadow Divers” also had the human-interest elements of the divers’ bravado and the sub disaster’s casualties to explore. Mr. Kurson set a very high bar for his next nonfiction endeavor.

headline: Second CD by Maroon 5 Faces Great Expectations
text: LOS ANGELES, May 20 — Even an ardent fan could be forgiven for wondering just how Maroon 5 would sound on “It Won’t Be Soon Before Long,” the follow-up to its wildly successful debut album, “Songs About Jane,” from 2002. After all, on its long journey to stardom this band abandoned its post-grunge roots for a radio-friendly pop-soul sound, even while dabbling in hard rock. (At the height of its success from that first album Maroon 5 closed live shows with a cover of AC/DC’s “Highway to Hell.”)

headline: Political Questioning (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pfizer’s Head of Research Is Departing
text: Pfizer’s head of research, John L. LaMattina, said yesterday that he was leaving the company, five months after Pfizer was abruptly forced to cancel development of torcetrapib, a heart medicine that was its highest-profile drug candidate.

headline: Immigration Bill Clears Its First Hurdle in Senate
text: WASHINGTON, May 21 — A comprehensive immigration bill cleared its first hurdle this afternoon as the Senate voted to start work on the legislation, which would offer legal status to most of the nation’s 12 million illegal immigrants.

headline: Two Boys Shot by Gunmen Outside Party in Harlem
text: Two teenage cousins were hospitalized after being shot early yesterday by hooded gunmen while waiting to go into a party at a Harlem housing project, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Hollywood Diet: Cutting Back on the Big Parties
text: HOLLYWOOD, May 20 — The premiere of the Will Ferrell hit comedy “Blades of Glory” here in March could not have been more fabulous. Photographers crowded the red carpet at Grauman’s Chinese Theater, snapping pictures of celebrities like Ben Stiller and Brooke Shields. The ice skating stars Nancy Kerrigan and Dorothy Hamill mingled with eager fans.

headline: Outsider Picked to Run Siemens
text: FRANKFURT, May 20 — The German engineering giant Siemens on Sunday appointed Peter Löscher, an Austrian-born outsider from the pharmaceutical industry, to lead the scandal-scarred company starting July 1.

headline: Zipf’s Law, or the Considerable Value of Being Top Dog, as Applied to Branding
text: What do consumers have in common with earthquakes? Both, researchers say, broadly conform to patterns described by a formula known as Zipf’s law.

headline: 2 Candidates to Roll Out Domestic Proposals
text: Two presidential candidates plan to unveil significant domestic policy proposals today, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton calling for a $5 billion plan for universal prekindergarten classes and Senator John McCain urging more efficiency and ethics in government.

headline: Global Art: Talismans, a Phantom and a King
text: You think art fairs aren’t sexy? The New York International Tribal & Textile Arts Show is out to prove you wrong. Just inside the entrance to the Seventh Regiment Armory’s drill hall you’ll find a peppery display of Burmese pornographic drawings. And smack in the middle of the show, bristling like a cactus garden, is a cluster of carved-wood Thai phalluses.

headline: Publisher to Let the Public Have a Vote on Book Projects
text: When predicting which candidate is likely to win an election, what a movie will make at the box office or how much the price of oil will fluctuate, the guesses of a crowd can be remarkably accurate.

headline: Anthony M. Brooks, Undercover Foe of Nazis, Dies at 85
text: Anthony M. Brooks, who led a network of saboteurs who delayed German reinforcements for weeks after the Normandy invasion, died on April 19 in London. He was 85.

headline: Self-Assessment and the Usual Foolishness
text: Everyone knows a gear buff — a deluded beginner who buys the hottest skis or the most advanced camera, but is clearly too inexperienced to use such sophisticated items properly.

headline: Aw, Shucks! Provocateur Takes On Health Care
text: CANNES, France, May 20 — Three years after conquering the Cannes Film Festival and winning the Palme d’Or for “Fahrenheit 9/11,” Michael Moore has returned the amour big time with “Sicko,” his most fluid provocation to date. A persuasive, insistently leftist indictment of the American health care system, as well as a funny valentine to all things French — and many things Canadian, British and Cuban — the film shows that while Mr. Moore remains a radical partisan, he has learned how to sell his argument with a softer touch. He’s still the P. T. Barnum of activist cinema, but he no longer runs the entire circus directly from the spotlight.

headline: Amid Dow Bid, Murdoch Family Comes Together
text: Last August, a management conference for senior executives of the News Corporation in Pebble Beach, Calif., featured a range of attention-getting speakers, like Prime Minister Tony Blair, former President Bill Clinton and the rocker-humanitarian Bono.

headline: Magician at the Table Makes a Sure Trick Vanish
text: Thomas Carmichael of Kennesaw, Ga., and Joel Wooldridge of Buffalo finished second in the World Bridge Productions Pair event, held alongside the Cavendish Invitational Pairs near Las Vegas two weeks ago. They did well on the diagramed deal, Board 11 of the second session, which has been rotated to make South the declarer.

headline: Birth Control Measures Prompt Riots in China
text: BEIJING, May 21 — An intensive campaign to enforce strict population-control measures prompted violent clashes between the police and local residents in southwestern China in recent days, witnesses said, describing the latest incident of rural unrest that has alarmed senior officials in Beijing.

headline: Mortgage Fraud Is Up, but Not in Their Backyards
text: ATLANTA — The three women call themselves the All-Broad Fraud Squad.

headline: Equity Firms to Buy Alltel in $27.5 Billion Deal
text: Alltel, the wireless phone company, agreed last night to be sold to a consortium of private equity firms for $27.5 billion, marking the largest buyout ever in the telecommunications industry.

headline: Fear of Eating
text: Yesterday I did something risky: I ate a salad.

headline: UniCredit to Buy Capitalia for $29.5 Billion in Stock
text: LONDON, May 20 — The Italian bank UniCredit agreed Sunday to buy a rival, Capitalia, for 21.8 billion euros, or $29.5 billion, in an all-stock deal that would create Europe’s second-biggest bank behind HSBC Holdings.

headline: Attack on Idaho Courthouse Kills Policeman
text: MOSCOW, Idaho, May 20 — A gunman went on a shooting rampage in this quiet college town late Saturday night, killing a police officer and wounding a sheriff’s deputy and a civilian before taking refuge in a church.

headline: Why This Scandal Matters
text: As Monica Goodling, a key player in the United States attorney scandal, prepares to testify before Congress on Wednesday, the administration’s strategy is clear. It has offered up implausible excuses, hidden the most damaging evidence and feigned memory lapses, while hoping that the public’s attention moves on. But this scandal is too important for the public or Congress to move on. This story should not end until Attorney General Alberto Gonzales is gone, and the serious damage that has been done to the Justice Department is repaired.

headline: Italy Bests U.S. in America’s Cup Semifinals
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 20 — The United States’ quest for the America’s Cup ended Sunday in a humiliating defeat for BMW Oracle Racing to Luna Rossa of Italy, which won the sixth race of the Louis Vuitton Cup semifinals to clinch the best-of-nine series, 5-1.

headline: For States, It May Be Worth It to Wait
text: By now, you have no doubt read endless speculation about the political implications of the shifts in the 2008 presidential primary calendar. New Hampshire and Iowa have been marginalized. No, New Hampshire and Iowa are going to be more powerful than ever. California is the new Iowa. Both parties will have nominees by the time polls close on Feb. 5, as voters in a score of states participate in primaries. The race will go undecided right into the party conventions.

headline: Electricity Crisis Hobbles an India Eager to Ascend
text: GURGAON, India — This suburb south of New Delhi is where the fruits of India’s economic advance are on full display: sprawling malls, skyscrapers housing India’s acclaimed software companies, condominiums with names as fanciful as Nirvana Country.

headline: Goodbye Cingular, Hello to the New Bell, AT&T
text: AT&T is finally saying goodbye to Cingular for good.

headline: Manhattan: Appeal of Church Ruling
text: More than two dozen members of Mary Help of Christians Roman Catholic Church, whose parish is to fold into that of a nearby church under the New York Archdiocese’s realignment plan, announced yesterday that they would file an appeal to the Vatican this week in hopes of keeping their East Village parish alive. Their first appeal, which they said was filed April 10, was denied by Cardinal Edward M. Egan. The parishioners said they feared that the church, at 440 East 12th Street, would be sold to developers, as some other historic churches in the neighborhood have been. A spokesman for the archdiocese said that it had no plans to sell the church, and that for now, priests from Immaculate Conception Church, on 14th Street at First Avenue, would conduct two Masses there each Sunday, one in English and one in Spanish.

headline: One-Ounce Belgian Idols Vie for Most Tweets Per Hour
text: WAREGEM, Belgium — The timekeeper waves a large red flag. Spectators wait in hushed anticipation. The nearly 50 featherweight rivals — including Rambo and Duracel — are surrounded by nervous trainers.

headline: Will Gentrification Spoil the Birthplace of Hip-Hop?
text: Hip-hop was born in the west Bronx. Not the South Bronx, not Harlem and most definitely not Queens. Just ask anybody at 1520 Sedgwick Avenue — an otherwise unremarkable high-rise just north of the Cross Bronx and hard along the Major Deegan.

headline: Deal to Merge 2 Health Firms Aimed at Women
text: Patrick J. Sullivan, the chief executive of the Cytyc Corporation, and Jack W. Cumming, the chief of Hologic Inc., like to joke about their companies splitting the geography of the female body. Hologic, a leader in breast cancer diagnostics, focuses on the top half, while Cytyc, a leader in diagnostics for cervical cancer, focuses on the bottom half.

headline: Staten Island: Teenager Fatally Shot
text: A Brooklyn teenager was found fatally shot in the head in a Park Hill apartment complex yesterday morning, the authorities said. The teenager, Wayne Kennedy, 17, of Morgan Avenue in East Williamsburg, was shot in a building at 280 Park Hill Avenue about 7:30 a.m., the police said. Neighbors in the six-story brick building said they heard an argument, followed by gunfire. Mr. Kennedy was found on the third-floor landing in a stairwell. It was unclear yesterday why he was at the building, the police said.

headline: Making Industry Efficient (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Stamford, a Plan to Rebuild an Area and Build an Advantage
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — By Fairfield County standards, the South End here is about as run-down as it gets. Abandoned factories, reminders of an industrial past, abut rows of homes where some of the city’s poorest residents live. The neighborhood represents a sharp contrast to the bank towers and condominium high-rises on the other side of Interstate 95.

headline: G.O.P. Is Spelling Victory With a G, for Giuliani
text: ALBANY  State Republicans are pining for a 2008 ticket with the name Rudolph W. Giuliani at the top.

headline: Targeting Human Trafficking
text: After years of shameful recalcitrance, New York will take the lead in the nation’s effort to combat sex and labor trafficking with a new law that targets this modern form of slavery. The issue is an urgent one. Each year, thousands of people are brought into the United States  often through New York  to be used for forced sex or labor. Yet New York has lagged behind at least two dozen states in enacting laws to go after the traffickers and help their victims.

headline: Dozens Slain as Lebanese Army Fights Islamists
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, May 20 — Fierce clashes erupted between Lebanese Army soldiers and Islamic militants in the vicinity of a Palestinian refugee camp here on Sunday, leaving 22 Lebanese soldiers and 17 militants dead and dozens injured in one of the most significant challenges to the army since the end of Lebanon’s bloody civil war.

headline: Israel and Militants Trade Deadly Attacks in Gaza
text: GAZA, May 21 — The Israeli Air Force continued its airstrikes in Gaza today, killing four members of Islamic Jihad who the Israeli Army said were preparing to launch rockets against Israel.

headline: Steinbrenner Gives Torre a Message of Support
text: The last time the Yankees struggled against a prominent rival, at the end of April, they were losing badly to the Boston Red Sox and the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, was considering whether to fire Manager Joe Torre. Not so this past weekend.

headline: For Opera, the Longest Day, Crammed in a Smallish Space
text: Four hundred years of opera in 13 hours. Symphony Space outdid itself with this year’s ambitious entry in the lists of its annual Wall to Wall marathons. The event usually focuses on the work of a single composer; this year it took the whole of opera, from Monteverdi’s “Orfeo” (1607) to Tarik O’Regan’s work in progress based on Conrad’s “Heart of Darkness.” Along the way, it involved 276 people — 94 singers, 149 musicians, et al. — and became an endeavor that Isaiah Sheffer, artistic director of Symphony Space, compared at least twice in the course of the day to the invasion of Normandy.

headline: Survivors Must See the Holocaust Files (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Short American Life
text: How’s this for a glimpse into America’s health care mess:

headline: Positive He’s a Killer; Less Sure He Should Die
text: CHICAGO

headline: Magazine Postal Rates (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: New CDs
text: THE USED “Lies for the Liars” (Reprise)

headline: In Court Files, Hollywood’s Mr. Fix-It at Work
text: LOS ANGELES, May 20 — Just hours after a raft of articles suggesting the impending collapse of his business hit the papers on April 11, 2002, Michael S. Ovitz did what Hollywood moguls had done for a generation: He called Anthony Pellicano.

headline: Trials on TV? No Thanks (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bad Hair Days Lead Pair to Web Incubator and Venture Capital
text: FOR many entrepreneurs in the first dot-com boom, the name of the game was “portal-matic.” Spin a wheel, pick a niche interest group, build a comprehensive Web portal aimed at that group’s needs and cash a venture capitalist’s check.

headline: U.S. Bid to Win the America’s Cup Ends
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 20 — The United States’ quest for the America’s Cup ended Sunday in a humiliating defeat for BMW Oracle Racing. It lost to Luna Rossa of Italy, which won the sixth race of the Louis Vuitton Cup semifinals to clinch the best-of-nine series, 5-1.

headline: Hold the World Bank to Account
text: Washington

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) DEAL OR NO DEAL Wesley Autrey Sr., the New York construction worker who jumped on the subway tracks in January to save the life of a stranger, plays for the $1 million top prize in this special episode. (Mr. Autrey is left above, with the show’s host, Howie Mandel.)

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,397 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the weekend:

headline: Two Are Killed and 32 Hurt in Crash of Bus Bound for Chinatown
text: Two people were killed and 32 injured yesterday when a bus bound from Chicago to Chinatown in New York City crashed in the early morning on a rainy interstate in western Pennsylvania, the authorities said.

headline: Final Homecoming
text: Once upon a time, sweatshirts and pennants sufficed as markers of school spirit. And while more than a few Fighting Irish fans would be happy to have their final resting place under the 50-yard line at Notre Dame Stadium, most university devotees have understood the difference between a college and a cemetery. But the line is beginning to blur.

headline: 8 Killed as Israel Hits a Hamas Politician’s Gaza Home
text: JERUSALEM, May 20 — The Israeli Air Force struck the home of a Hamas Parliament member in Gaza on Sunday night, killing eight people, Palestinian hospital officials said. The Parliament member, Khalil al-Hayya, was not in the house at the time.

headline: A Lifeline for the Parks
text: We have had our quarrels with Dirk Kempthorne, the interior secretary, on policy questions involving endangered species as well as other issues. But when it comes to the national parks, he has brought good ideas and real follow-through to an administration that has been long on promises to the parks and annoyingly short on results.

headline: Pitching Change Intended to Save Young Players’ Arms
text: Toeing the pitching rubber, 10-year-old Anthony Service glared toward home plate for a sign from his catcher in a tense one-run game this month in the Valley Stream Little League on Long Island. He did not get the signal he wanted. Anthony was coming out of the game because he had already thrown 75 pitches, the limit for him under Little League rules introduced this year.

headline: Mozart for Instruments, Voices and Bodies
text: In an age of electronic scores and purposefully pedestrian movement, there are certainly moments when one pines for live music and actual steps. But if Christopher Caines’s new program proves anything at all, it’s that live music and ballet steps are no guarantees of success.

headline: Steinbrenner Gives Torre Message of Support
text: The last time the Yankees struggled against a prominent rival, at the end of April, they were losing badly to the Boston Red Sox and the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, was considering whether to fire Manager Joe Torre. Not so this past weekend.

headline: Manhattan: Fire Ruins Midtown Pizzeria
text: A fire destroyed a Midtown pizzeria yesterday morning, sending five firefighters and one civilian to the hospital with minor injuries, the Fire Department said. The fire was reported at 11:29 a.m. in a building housing Abitino’s Pizzeria, on First Avenue near 52nd Street. When firefighters arrived, the first three floors of the five-story building were ablaze, and it took them about an hour to put out the fire, Deputy Chief Thomas McKavanagh said. Dominick Abitino, one of three brothers who opened the restaurant in 1992 along with their father, said, “It’s a family business, and we’re all sad here.”

headline: Finding His Footing on Clay, Federer Ends Nadal’s Run
text: HAMBURG, Germany, May 20 (AP) — Roger Federer had the perfect response to questions about his status as the world’s top-ranked player: He ended Rafael Nadal’s 81-match winning streak on clay.

headline: From Beaches to Pine Barrens, a Study Puts Values on New Jersey’s Natural Assets
text: The New Jersey Pine Barrens are known for a lot of things: ghostly legends of a bat-winged Jersey Devil; weekend canoeing among mossy bogs; a place where Tony Soprano and company like to dump their dead.

headline: Pitch by Pitch, the Yankees’ Mood Brightens
text: The tower atop the Empire State Building will glow blue and orange for a few hours this evening. The Mets earned that honor by winning the first two games of their series against the Yankees, but their supremacy in the city is not quite complete.

headline: Honduran Diplomat Assails Police in Shooting of Unarmed Bronx Man
text: Appearing at a sidewalk memorial for an unarmed driver shot dead by an off-duty officer in the Bronx, the senior Honduran diplomat in New York criticized the police yesterday, saying, “We are not going to let this go by unnoticed.”
