headline: One Catch Has Changed Everything for Chávez
text: Endy Chávez’s final encounter with baseball anonymity came in October, less than two hours after the St. Louis Cardinals bounced his Mets from the playoffs.

headline: To the Glee of South Korean Fans, a Game’s Sequel Is Announced
text: Much of South Korea and gamers around the world spun into a tizzy over the weekend as Blizzard Entertainment, perhaps the world’s most successful video game company, announced that it was developing a sequel to its popular computer strategy game StarCraft.

headline: Supreme Court Rules on Education Lawsuits
text: WASHINGTON, May 21  The Supreme Court ruled today that parents of children with disabilities need not hire lawyers if they want to sue public school districts over their children’s special-education needs.

headline: A Musical Star Plucked From the Underground
text: In “Passing Strange,” an idiosyncratic and vibrant new musical that opened last week at the Public Theater, an ensemble of stunning young actors is almost overshadowed by the mesmerizing stage presence of a chubby, bald, moon-faced, middle-aged performer named Stew.

headline: Wife of Idaho Gunman Is Found Dead
text: The wife of the gunman who killed two people and wounded others before killing himself in a shooting rampage in Moscow, Idaho, over the weekend has been added to the casualty list. Her body was found in their home, police said, according to broadcast and online news reports from local news media and reports by the Associated Press.

headline: G.O.P. Senator Says Gonzales Might Quit
text: WASHINGTON, May 20  Senator Arlen Specter, the senior Republican on the Judiciary Committee, said Sunday that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales might resign rather than face a potential no-confidence vote in the Senate.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: CHINA TRADE TALKS A high-level delegation from China visits the United States this week for a second round of talks aimed at easing trade tensions. The meetings on Tuesday and Wednesday will be the second session of the Strategic Economic Dialogue, which the two countries began in December in Beijing. The Chinese delegation will be led by Vice Premier Wu Yi, right.

headline: Street Sense and Curlin May Not Meet Again Until Travers
text: The first two legs of the 2007 Triple Crown are in the books, and the races left horse enthusiasts with little to complain about. In the Kentucky Derby, Street Sense exploded down the stretch for a victory that validated his credentials as a champion. In the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, he made a similar move, only to be run down by a colt named Curlin in a heart-pounding stretch drive.

headline: After Aiding Bill on Immigration, Employers Balk
text: WASHINGTON, May 20 — Employers, who helped shape a major immigration bill over the last three months, said on Sunday that they were unhappy with the result because it would not cure the severe labor shortages they foresee in the coming decade.

headline: Wayward Humpback Pair Moves Toward Ocean
text: WEST SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 20 — The pilgrimage, for some, begins at dawn. They travel by foot, bicycle, scooter and even wheelchair to camp along a dusty riverbank facing a homely industrial port.

headline: A Battered Siemens Names a New Chief
text: MUNICH, May 20 (Bloomberg News) — Siemens, Europe’s largest engineering company, named Peter Löscher, an executive of the American drug maker Merck, as its chief executive, to succeed Klaus Kleinfeld, who resigned after less than three years because of a bribery investigation on his watch.

headline: Different Uniform, but Same Cheers for Dr. Williams
text: The graduates had filed into the Theater at Madison Square Garden, and as the screech of bagpipes accompanied the procession of Iona College’s administration and faculty members toward the flower-rimmed stage yesterday, Bernie Williams, with that familiar shy smile and taller than most in a black robe and with a gold tassel swinging from his black mortarboard, returned to public life for about two hours.

headline: Reliever’s Spirits Sink After Best Pitch Doesn’t
text: Next week, Scott Schoeneweis’s wife and three children will join him for the summer, and he can’t wait to see them.

headline: Growing Pains Galore for Toyota in First Year
text: Whatever exuberance Toyota and its teams brought to Daytona International Speedway in February for the season-opening race is long gone. So is the fear that Toyota, the first foreign brand to compete in Nascar’s premier series since the 1950s, would come into the Nextel Cup this year with an open wallet and buy its way into victory lane.

headline: In a Time of High Anxiety, a Sedative of the Occult
text: The coming television season looks as if executives at the big broadcast networks might have turned over the creation of their schedules to the Munsters, the Addams family and Rod Serling — with an assist from Darrin, the adman on “Bewitched.”

headline: Visitors From San Francisco Burnish a European Patina
text: Europeans like to call American orchestras brilliant and heartless and their own warm and cuddly. In places like Chicago and Cleveland clichés like this are embraced and transcended, with precision of gesture transformed into exquisite musicality. Visitors from the old country, on the other hand, might feel right at home in San Francisco, where the San Francisco Symphony under Michael Tilson Thomas has come to sound something like a high-end voice from across the sea. Capital cities in Central Europe might be happy with Americans like these to call their own.

headline: Page Six Covers Itself, a Bit Painfully
text: If you were a member of the Bancroft family in the midst of deciding whether to sell Dow Jones & Company to Rupert Murdoch, reading Friday’s New York Post might have made you choke on your bagel.

headline: Return to the Final Four a Family Affair for Duke
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 20  When Duke’s 19-11 victory against North Carolina in an N.C.A.A. tournament quarterfinal was complete, Blue Devils attackman Matt Danowski made a beeline toward his father, Coach John Danowski, and wrapped him in a bear hug. The father patted his son’s head and smiled as the Duke fans among the 10,438 at Navy-Marine Corps Memorial Stadium celebrated.

headline: Gay Britons Serve in Military With Little Fuss, as Predicted Discord Does Not Occur
text: LONDON, May 20 — The officer, a squadron leader in the Royal Air Force, felt he had no choice. So he stood up in front of his squad of 30 to 40 people.

headline: A Splash of Photo History Comes to Light
text: At first glance the two pictures seem to be gorgeous anachronisms, full-color blasts from the black-and-white world of 1908, the year Ford introduced the Model T and Theodore Roosevelt was nearing the end of his second term.

headline: 7 U.S. Soldiers Die in Iraq, 6 in Sweep of Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, May 20 — Six American soldiers and their interpreter were killed by a roadside bomb in western Baghdad on Saturday, the military said Sunday, in one of the deadliest single attacks against American troops in the capital in recent months.

headline: Ochoa Gets a Victory to Match Her Ranking
text: CLIFTON, N.J., May 20 — On her drive to Upper Montclair Country Club, Lorena Ochoa said she saw sunshine and blue skies. She faced a two-shot deficit going into the final round of the Sybase Classic, but she said she was happy.

headline: Ducks’ Last-Minute Goal Leads to Overtime Win
text: DETROIT, May 20 (AP) — The Anaheim Ducks were within a minute of losing a game that could have led to the end of their season.

headline: Only Hope Is That It’s Not Too Late in the Bronx
text: The Yankees never ask for sympathy, and in many places they do not get it. Even the interleague schedule works against them, having put them up against the Mets when they could least afford it.

headline: Those Mischievous Looks Are Not at All Deceiving
text: A note to future concertgoers: When Devin the Dude promises to do one “for the ladies,” don’t expect a love song. Expect instead a laundry list of impertinent anatomical questions, shyly delivered by a skinny, smiley, bug-eyed rapper who loves to sing. Somehow a dirty joke from Devin is much more charming than your average love song, and he proved it on Friday night at the Knitting Factory.

headline: Lebanon Pounds Refugee Camp; Fighting Kills 60
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, May 21 — Lebanese tanks and artillery pounded a Palestinian refugee camp in this northern Lebanese city for the second straight day on Monday, trying to trap members of a radical Islamist group and raising concerns for thousands of Palestinians inside the camp.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR Diary:

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 10 at Market in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 20  At least 10 people were killed and 32 were wounded Sunday when a suicide bomber struck at a crowded market in the southeastern province of Paktia, the provincial police chief said. News agencies said the death toll later rose to 14, quoting doctors at the local hospital.

headline: Tick-Tock and Other Pulses of the West
text: Back in the days of the early Middle Ages when sand and water and shadow were used to tell time, before there were mechanical clocks or eyeglasses or great cathedrals or steam engines, China was the world’s leading technological culture, able to best the provincial Europeans by nearly any measure. Three of the most important new materials that made their way into Europe from the 13th to the 15th century were paper, cast iron and gunpowder, each of which had probably been invented in China, each of which also was a fundamental resource for the development of Western civilization.

headline: Virginia and Guns (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Legends of Life and Art, Stravinsky and Balanchine
text: If wealth of choreography is your main criterion, New York City Ballet should be the envy of the world this spring. By any standard except perhaps its own, the density with which it keeps adding ballets to its repertory is staggering.

headline: Firefox and the Anxiety of Growing Pains
text: IF the open-source software movement were an upstart political campaign, Chris Messina would be one of its community organizers — the young volunteer who decamps to New Hampshire, knocking on doors, putting up signs.

headline: Ex-Vice President’s Review Is ‘Full of Heart’
text: When it comes to journalism, the former vice president Dan Quayle would probably rather be known for his family’s onetime publishing empire than for his orthography (remember the potato incident). Now he can add the title of book reviewer to his résumé.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Shrek’ Reigns

headline: Magical Night for Rookie Pitcher
text: Tyler Clippard spent Saturday night at a hotel in New Jersey, and he planned to arrive at Shea Stadium at 4 p.m. yesterday. He expected snarled highways, and a car service picked him up at 2:30.

headline: Buyout to Form Big Company to Train and Treat Prisoners
text: A company based in New Jersey that provides training and treatment programs to prison inmates is announcing today that it has bought a similar Massachusetts company, creating one of the largest correctional services companies in the country.

headline: China to Buy a Stake in Blackstone
text: The Chinese government said yesterday that it would acquire a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, in the country’s first effort to diversify its $1.2 trillion in foreign-exchange reserves beyond United States Treasury bills and into commercial enterprise.

headline: A Paper Trail for Electronic Voting (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Verizon Consolidates Agencies and Adds Wireless Assignments
text: In one of the largest recent account consolidations, Verizon Communications is combining duties for its consumer and business services with assignments for Verizon Wireless to increase effectiveness and efficiency. Verizon, which spends about $1.9 billion a year on advertising, will reduce its agency roster to 10 from more than 20.

headline: NATO Chief and Bush Meet at Ranch
text: CRAWFORD, Tex., May 20  President Bush welcomed the NATO secretary general to his home here on Sunday for two days of meetings focusing on holding together the fragile coalition fighting in Afghanistan and on dealing with new tensions with an assertive Russia.

headline: Treasury Auctions Scheduled for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Richardson Formally Enters Race for President
text: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico formally kicked off his bid for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination today, highlighting his Hispanic roots and wealth of experience and issuing a forceful call to end American involvement in Iraq.

headline: End-of-Life Decisions (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Confident Spurs Show Jazz What It Is Missing
text: SAN ANTONIO, May 20 — Jerry Sloan, who has never had any use for excuses in his 19 years as the coach of the Utah Jazz, spit out a terse halftime speech that made no allowances for his players being young or afraid in the face of the San Antonio Spurs.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page picture caption yesterday with an article about the crisis faced by Africa’s finest universities because of mismanagement, neglect and policies that favor basic education referred incorrectly in some copies to the broken piece of equipment being used by a chemistry student. It is a graduated cylinder, not a test tube. (Go to Article)

headline: No Sign of Murdock or B.A. Baracus
text: Anyone watching the opening to Fox’s telecast yesterday noticed that David Wright introduced the Mets’ starting lineup with a little flair. He assigned nicknames to everyone but himself: Carlos “Mr. GQ” Beltran, Shawn “I Miss My Hair” Green, Carlos Delgado – “The Puerto Rican Mr. T,” and so on. In case you were all wondering, yes, Wright thought of all of them himself. And he was pretty proud of them, too.

headline: Relax, Breathe … the Yankees Win the Finale
text: First of all, thanks to everyone who responded to the last entry on how to fix the Yankees. Great insights, and a lot of funny ones, too. Keep those comments coming.

headline: U.S. Championship, Round 6: Shabalov Express Is Derailed, but He Still Leads
text: Well, Alexander Shabalov will not win every game in the Frank Berry U.S. Championship. He won’t even go undefeated. Alexander Onischuk, the defending champion, beat Shabalov and moved into second place, a half point out of the lead. Most of the other games on the top boards were drawn so there is a pack of seven players with 4 points, a point behind Shabalov. The games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about American adoptions from Guatemala incorrectly described the accreditation process for adoption service providers. The State Department contracts the process out to the Council on Accreditation; it does not itself accredit them.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about a transcript of a military hearing for Majid Khan, a terror suspect held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, gave an incorrect number in some copies for the times that Mr. Khan said he cut and chewed an artery in his arm because he was so desolate. It was twice, not three times.

headline: All You Need Is (the Summer of) Love
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Woven Together
text: Photographs from the New York International Tribal & Textile Arts Show.

headline: No Man's Land
text: Other cities in Colombia have become secure and prosperous enough, but Buenaventura is a different story.

headline: Chrysler Finds Itself in Phonetic Purgatory
text: Q: How do you pronounce DaimlerChrysler in German?A: Daimler. The Chrysler is silent.

headline: Alltel’s $27.5 Billion Buyout Creates Static
text: Alltel‘s agreement to go private in a $27.5 billion deal — the largest leveraged buyout ever in the telecommunications industry — is not sitting well with some of the other private equity firms who lined up to bid for the wireless phone company. The deal to be acquired by a consortium including the Texas Pacific Group and a unit of Goldman Sachs effectively short-circuits the auction process, in which other groups, such as the Blackstone Group with Providence Equity Partners, and the Carlyle Group with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, had hoped to participate.

headline: Fancy a fractional?
text: Floresta

headline: Hedge Funds to Manage Part of Illinois Teachers’ Pension
text: The Illinois Teachers’ Retirement System said Friday it would allocate more than $1.6 billion of its $39.7 billion pension fund to hedge funds strategies and $425 million to private equity firms as part of a new fund manager mix. Among those chosen to help manage the funds were the hedge funds Bridgewater Associates and AQR Capital Management as well as fund-of-fund groups K2 Advisors and Grosvenor Capital Management.

headline: Bad Hair Days Lead to Venture Capital Funding
text: For many entrepreneurs in the first dot-com boom, the name of the game was “portal-matic.” Spin a wheel, pick a niche interest group, build a comprehensive Web portal aimed at that group’s needs and cash a venture capitalist’s check.

headline: Bank of America Faces Discrimination Suit
text: Five black current and former employees of Bank of America have filed a lawsuit that accuses the bank of racial discrimination by steering lucrative clients to their white counterparts. The complaint, filed Thursday in the Federal District Court in Boston, contends that the bank discriminates against African-Americans in pay, promotions, training and support services.

headline: Tourists Ogle a Less-Frenetic N.Y.S.E.
text: The Empire State Building, Times Square and now the floor of The New York Stock Exchange. The New York Post reports that the trading floor, once home to 5,000 traders, is now a tourist destination, as electronic trading has substantially cleared the floor of traders and given those who remain more time to give tours to customers.

headline: Traffic, Heavy Traffic and Statistics
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was in Albany last week lobbying state lawmakers on his PlaNYC, a raft of measures — many needing state aid and approval — to ensure that New York City grows in an environmentally sustainable way. Legislators were treated to a PowerPoint presentation in which Mr. Bloomberg showed slides depicting a dire future of street traffic and overloaded subways, and he asked for new daytime fees for driving in much of Manhattan, new subway construction and other measures.

headline: V.C.’s Help Build Gorilla Nation
text: As the Internet advertising frenzy continues, the online ad and marketing firm Gorilla Nation Media said Friday that it had secured a $50 million equity investment from Great Hills Partners, which will take a substantial minority position.

headline: Sneaker Brands Seen as Ripe for Buyouts
text: Footwear brands Skechers USA and Genesco, which has retail brands such as Lids and Journeys in its stable, are emerging as two leading targets to be taken private in the retail and footwear sectors, according to Women’s Wear Daily. In April, Genesco rejected an unsolicited $1.2 billion bid from Foot Locker, saying it undervalued the company.

headline: In Congress, Plenty of Work Before Recess
text: Nothing typically motivates a member of Congress like the approach of a recess. Majority Democrats better hope that the impending Memorial Day break is a highly potent incentive given the amount they hope to accomplish in the next few days.

headline: Siemens Names New Chief
text: The German engineering giant Siemens on Sunday appointed Peter Löscher, an Austrian-born outsider from the pharmaceutical industry, to lead the scandal-scarred company starting July 1. The announcement ends uncertainty over who will run the biggest engineering and technology company in Europe after the current chief, Klaus Kleinfeld, said he would step down after less than three years running the company.

headline: S.E.C. Gets Monthly Briefing from C.I.A.,Report Says
text: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is being briefed monthly by the Central Intelligence Agency about terrorists and other criminals active in global stock markets, according to Barron’s, which called them the first regular intelligence briefings in S.E.C. in history. S.E.C. Chairman Christopher Cox told Barron’s that he and four other commissioners are briefed each month by the CIA, offering the S.E.C. a “somewhat sharper focus” to an “underworld of murky, illegal dealings that threaten the world capital markets.”

headline: Spitzer, Nixon and Gonzales
text: As one might expect, Eliot Spitzer, the former New York attorney general turned governor, has some opinions about Attorney General Alberto Gonzales. As one might expect, they are not kind.

headline: Too Old to Innovate?
text: The environment for today’s entrepreneurs is far different in a number of ways from the boom of the late ’90s, Steven Levy noted this week in Newsweek. It is “dramatically cheaper to start a company now,” he wrote, so it is substantially easier to build a business, sometimes without needing venture capital. “Software tools, which used to cost hundreds of thousands, are now largely free,” while computer equipment and bandwidth are much less expensive.

headline: M&A Extends Markets’ Bull Run
text: Corporate takeovers helped spur the Dow Jones industrial average to its 24th record close this year on Friday, even as the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index came within striking distance of its record high. The latest takeover news, including deals involving marquee names like General Electric and Microsoft, signaled that the enormous amount of liquidity that has lubricated global stock markets in recent months is still in good supply. “The M.& A. activity and earnings seem to be holding up better than expected. I think you’re going to see more of this,” Bill Dwyer, chief investment officer at MTB Investment Advisors, told The Associated Press.

headline: Acer May Be Hunting Smaller Game
text: Acerchairman and chief executive J.T. Wang made headlines recently when he said his rapidly expanding PC company planned to make a meaningful acquisition soon. But according to a report from The Deal.com, Acer is far more likely to strike a modest deal outside the U.S.

headline: Bill Richardson's Candidacy
text: As he officially declares his candidacy, Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico discusses his run for the White House.

headline: Arlington’s Main Line Takes Radio One
text: Radio One has agreed to sell 10 radio stations to Main Line Broadcasting for about $76 million cash. Main Line, a portfolio company of Washington private equity firm Arlington Capital Partners, is buying four stations in Dayton, Ohio, and six in Louisville, Ky.

headline: First Stop: Hong Kong
text: Nicholas D. Kristof visits Hong Kong for the first time since the handover.

headline: Training Ground for Democracy
text: Images related to the Christoph Büchel exhibit at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art.

headline: Goldman and SBI Team Up for Japan Venture
text: Goldman Sachs Group and Japanese venture capital firm SBI Holdings have agreed to form a joint venture to provide growth capital to mid-sized companies Japan and overseas. SBI said Goldman would buy a 40 percent stake in its subsidiary SBI Capital for an undisclosed sum, and the venture would aim to manage 100 billion yen ($825 million) in assets within three years.

headline: When Book Reviews Coincide With Deal-Making
text: Former Vice President Dan Quayle’s byline appeared in this weekend’s issue of The Wall Street Journal over a chatty, first-person review on the latest book on golf by John Feinstein. And it just so happens that, in what The New York Times describes as an “interesting quirk of timing,” the review appeared on the same weekend that Cerberus Capital Management — the private equity and hedge fund firm where Mr. Quayle works — was sewing up its landmark deal to buy Chrysler.

headline: Hologic’s $6.2 Billion Deal Cytyc Deal Aimed at Women
text: Patrick J. Sullivan, the chief executive of the Cytyc Corporation, and Jack W. Cumming, the chief of Hologic, like to joke about their companies splitting the geography of the female body. Hologic, a leader in breast cancer diagnostics, focuses on the top half, while Cytyc, a leader in diagnostics for cervical cancer, focuses on the bottom half.

headline: Collins Stewart to Buy CE Unterberg, Report Says
text: British broker Collins Stewart, continuing its push into the U.S. market, is buying CE Unterberg, Towbin, the privately owned New York-based investment bank, for $44 million, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Monday Morning Motorsports
text: In the WRC, Sebastien Loeb made a rare mistake and crashed out of the Rally d’Italia Sardenga on the morning of the third leg. Marcus Gronholm took advantage of the miscue, leading his Ford teammate, Mikko Hirvonen, to a one-two finish as the rally championship series approaches the season’s midpoint. Loeb said he had pace issues from the start and pushed a little too hard. “I had a wheel slightly on the verge,” he said. “I tried to bring the car back in line, but then I hit a big rock with my front left wheel.” The win puts Gronholm seven points in front of Loeb in the championship.

headline: China to Take Stake in Blackstone
text: The Chinese government said Sunday it would acquire a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, the private equity firm, in the country’s first effort to diversify its $1.2 trillion in foreign-exchange reserves beyond United States Treasury bills and into commercial enterprise.

headline: For Hedge Funds, Treasure Ahoy
text: A number of hedge funds that have significant stakes in Odyssey Marine may reap the rewards of sunken treasure after the company recently gained title to a colonial-era shipwreck.

headline: Deal to Form Big Company to Train Prisoners
text: A company based in New Jersey that provides training and treatment programs to prison inmates is announcing today that it has bought a similar Massachusetts company, creating one of the largest correctional services companies in the country. The two companies – Community Education Centers of Roseland, N.J., and CiviGenics of Marlborough, Mass. – are trying to capitalize on the growing number of inmates and tight financing for new prisons that have led federal, state and local governments to contract out more of their operations to private businesses.

headline: Does Lehman Need a Big Deal?
text: Lehman Brothers‘ stock price and revenue growth have been lackluster over the last year, helping to drive speculation of a potential merger or even a sale of the giant securities firm, Breakingviews writes. It suggests that a merger with UBS‘s banking operations or a Cazenove-style venture with HSBC could make sense.

headline: Germany Calls for Voluntary Hedge Fund Rules
text: Germany has switched tactics in its efforts to police the fast-growing global hedge fund industry, hoping to overcome skepticism by other Group of Eight member countries by encouraging the industry itself to compile a voluntary code of conduct.

headline: As Murdoch Pitches Dow Jones, a Gossip Scandal Heats Up
text: If you were a member of the Bancroft family in the midst of deciding whether to sell Dow Jones & Company to Rupert Murdoch, reading Friday’s New York Post might have made you choke on your bagel, The New York Times’s David Carr declares.

headline: APN Asks Shareholder to Express Itself on Buyout Bid
text: Australia’s APN News and Media said Monday it wants the fund manager Perpetual, APN’s second-largest shareholder, to clarify its position on a planned takeover of APN by a group led by an Irish newspaper publisherIndependent News and Media.

headline: Prosecutors Seek to Freeze Nacchio Assets
text: Federal prosecutors have asked a judge to immediately freeze the assets of Joseph Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, who was convicted last month of making $52 million from insider trading. In a motion filed Friday in Denver federal court, prosecutors said Mr. Nacchio and his wife, Anne Esker, have assets derived from the sales of Qwest stock worth “more than $100 million,” which is subject to forfeiture under federal law.

headline: UniCredit to Buy Capitalia for $29.5 Billion
text: UniCredit, the Italian bank, agreed Sunday to buy a rival, Capitalia for 21.8 billion euros, or $29.5 billion, in an all-stock deal that would create Europe’s second-biggest bank behind HSBC Holdings. The merger also would strengthen the position of Italian lenders as consolidation in Europe’s banking industry gathers pace.

headline: Yahoo Said to Consider Bid for Britain’s Bebo
text: Yahoo is working on a takeover offer for Bebo, the most popular social networking Web site in Britain, and is willing to pay up to $1 billion to seal the deal, according to The Telegraph.

headline: G.E. to Sell Plastics Unit for $11.6 Billion
text: General Electric said Monday it had agreed to sell its struggling GE Plastics business to Riyadh-based chemicals company Saudi Basic Industries in an $11.6 billion cash deal. G.E. said it would receive net after-tax proceeds of about $9 billion, which would be primarily put toward the company’s current stock buyback.

headline: Buyout Firms Said to Consider Virgin Media Bid
text: Providence Equity Partners is leading a group that is considering a $15 billion bid for Virgin Media, the cable company in which Sir Richard Branson is the largest shareholder, The Observer reported Monday. The United States-based private equity firm is said to be speaking with its partners, including Blackstone, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Cinven, about the possibility of making an approach in the coming weeks.

headline: In Iraq, Violence as Propaganda Tool
text: Daveed Gartenstein-Ross files a couple of interesting dispatches from Baghdad for the Counterterrorism Blog. The first is on the increasing deadliness of insurgents’ mortar attacks inside the “IZ” or Green Zone in the capital. The second is on the increasing number of journalists killed of late.Gartenstein-Ross feels the two trends are linked. “Just as the mortar targeting of the IZ seems clearly part of the militants’ propaganda war, so too is the targeting of journalists.” he writes. “If journalists believe the country is falling apart, and feel that their profession places them in constant danger, that pessimism will be reflected in their writing. And just as Iraqi translators who work with U.S. troops need to be disguised while in the field, it has reached the point where Iraqi reporters with strong American sources need to be disguised too.”

headline: Stages of Cutty Sark Grief
text: They say that grief follows an orderly sequence over a prudent amount of time: denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance. On the Web, they can all happen within hours of an event, and in no particular order.

headline: Bush Is Just Following Party Orders
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his May 18 column, “Don’t Blame Bush.”

headline: Blackstone I.P.O. Could Reach $4.75 Billion
text: Blackstone Group pulled back the veil a little further on its closely watched initial public offering on Monday, as it filed an amended prospectus with regulators. The major addition was the terms of its planned $3 billion investment from China, but the financial aspects of the offering were fleshed out as well. The private equity giant said that it planned to offer 133.3 million units at a price of $29 to $31 each and was giving underwriters the option of selling 20 million more. At the maximum, the I.P.O. could raise a whopping $4.75 billion (an amount that doesn’t include the $3 billion infusion from China’s investment arm).

headline: Top of the Charts for Escaped Gorilla
text: Along with the usual smattering of scantily clad ladies, a gorilla named Bokito is dominating the YouTube charts today with four of the six most-watched video clips of the day.

headline: ‘Coast of Utopia,’ ‘Spring Awakening’ Honored at Drama Desk Awards
text: "The Coast of Utopia," the Tom Stoppard trilogy about 19th-century Russia, won seven honors, including the accolade for outstanding drama, at the 2006-7 Drama Desk Awards last night at La Guardia Concert Hall at Lincoln Center.

headline: Is Murdoch Getting Ready to Walk?
text: Richard Greenfield of Pali Research says he doesn’t have any inside knowledge on the matter, but he is speculating that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation is likely to abandon its closely watched effort to acquire Dow Jones — at least for the moment.

headline: For States, It May Be Worth It to Wait
text: In today’s Web column, Adam Nagourney offers some unsolicited advice to any state still considering joining the rush to vote on Feb. 5 or earlier: Don’t. At this point, your best chance for wielding real influence over the nominating process is to go later, not earlier.

headline: Misery Chastain Cannot Be Dead!! Or, A Way to Save “Jericho”
text: Every compelling story produces its own brand of fans, with their own distinct style of story-worship.

headline: A Boomtown Revisited
text: In his first stop on the Chinese mainland, Nicholas Kristof meets up with the Communist Party official he first profiled 20 years ago.

headline: Merrill Lynch Takes Hedge Fund Stake
text: Merrill Lynch said Monday it would buy a minority interest in GSO Capital Partners, a hedge-fund firm with about $8 billion in assets under management. GSO was founded in July 2005 by Bennett Goodman, Tripp Smith and Doug Ostrover, all of whom had previously been at Credit Suisse.

headline: EMI Accepts $4.7 Billion Bid From Terra Firma
text: The EMI Group, the British music giant that has drawn heavy takeover interest in the last year, said Monday it had agreed to be bought by Terra Firma, the private equity firm led by the financier Guy Hands. EMI, whose recent talks with another buyout firm, Permira, ended without a deal, said it was recommending Terra Firma’s offer to its shareholders. The bid values EMI at 2.4 billion pounds ($4.7 billion).

headline: American Album: Spell Utah
text: Kunal Sah, 13, hopes that winning the Scripps National Spelling Bee will bring attention to the plight of his parents, who were deported to India.

headline: Saturday in Flushing
text: We went because we had to. Every once in a while, a need, a want, a hunger, wakes from its slumber and demands immediate and full satiation.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page picture caption yesterday with an article about the crisis faced by Africa's finest universities because of mismanagement, neglect and policies that favor basic education referred incorrectly in some copies to the broken piece of equipment being used by a chemistry student. It is a graduated cylinder, not a test tube.

headline: Video: Hong Kong
text: Nick started his journey across China with a stop in Hong Kong. It was his first trip to the city since the British handed the colony back to the Chinese in 1997. Back then he wrote an article called “Year of the Trojan Horse.”

headline: At Carlyle, a Taste for Designer Goods
text: Carlyle Group seems to have an eye for couture — in more ways than one. Even as the private equity shop vies with Permira Advisors to buy Valentino Fashion Group (which controls the Hugo Boss line), one of the firm’s employees is getting prominent play in New York magazine for her high-end taste in accessories. The magazine’s “Look Book” features an interview with Natasha Mitra, who is described as a private equity associate. (Her firm isn’t identified, but Ms. Mitra’s name appears on Carlyle’s Web site.) The interview begins with a question that isn’t really a question: “Such big accessories!”

headline: We’re Paying What in Taxes?
text: If we had been wavering about the need to reduce the construction costs of our dream home, a letter from the Manatee County Taxing Authorities eliminated all doubt.

headline: Top Law Firms Look Farther Afield for Recruits
text: As they compete for fresh legal talent, some of the biggest law firms in mergers and acquisitions are apparently looking in some unusual places — like Brooklyn. So says a recent article by Bloomberg News, which uses the New York City borough as a kind of proxy for the so-called “second tier” law schools (loosely defined as any school not in the top 10) that are getting increased attention from the major firms.

headline: Capitalia and the Lone Banker
text: With some companies hiring as many as seven advisory firms to help with one transaction, investment bankers by now must be used to sharing clients. Not so Claudio Costamagna, the former chairman of European investment banking at Goldman Sachs in London.

headline: Kurds Fleeing Northern Iraqi City
text: Conflict between Arabs and Kurds is intensifying in Mosul, adding another dimension to Iraq's civil war.

headline: To the Editor: Please See Wiki
text: Our colleagues on the opinion side of The New York Times receive about 1,000 letters a day, many seeking to address remarks that “should not be suffered to pass unnoticed,” as one put it in 1851.

headline: MTV Ad
text: An ad for MTV.

headline: MTV Ad
text: An ad for MTV.

headline: Revving Gore’s P.R. Machine
text: Al Gore – who recently described himself as an “unlikely, but not impossible” candidate for president in 2008 – is starting a publicity tour this week for his new book, exposing himself to the intensifying questions about his political plans.

headline: McCain’s Way With Words, Still Intact
text: Fresh from his dustup with Republican Senate colleague John Cornyn last week, John McCain used a conference call with bloggers today to take on a more obvious intra-party rival, Mitt Romney. Ryan Sager of The New York Sun’s Latest Politics blog gives us the details: ” ‘Maybe I should wait a couple weeks and see if it changes,’ Mr. McCain said of Mr. Romney’s position on immigration this week. ‘Maybe he can get out his small varmint gun and drive those Guatemalans off his yard.’ ”

headline: Cell Phone Tip: Use It As a Silent Alarm
text: In a note from my friend Bill Ginsberg, president of the New York PC users’ group, he passed a long a tip from a buddy of his, a psychology PhD candidate who’s writing his dissertation on his Treo smartphone!

headline: End of an Era, Captured on Tape
text: Online Videos by Veoh.com

headline: A Real Food Fight
text: Paul Krugman responds to readers’ comments on his May 21 column, “Fear of Eating.”

headline: Another Needless Death
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s May 21 column, “Young, Ill and Uninsured.“

headline: High Crimes and Chocolate
text: Relenting after pressure from vegetarians and those who keep Kosher, Masterfoods has flip-flopped on the issue of using animal products in British chocolate bars.

headline: Has Kerkorian Put MGM Mirage in Play?
text: Kirk Kerkorian said this afternoon that he planned “to pursue strategic alternatives” for his controlling stake in MGM Mirage, the giant hotel and casino company. Mr. Kerkorian also said that he planned to enter talks to buy Bellagio Hotel and Casino and City Center properties from MGM Mirage. The brief, three-sentence statement from Mr. Kerkorian’s holding company, Tracinda, has caused a lot of head scratching at DealBook about his intentions, but that hasn’t stopped investors from bidding up shares of MGM Mirage by more than $9, or 15 percent, in after-hours trading. It is unclear whether he plans to put his controlling stake up for sale or whether he is considering buying up the outstanding public shares, either himself or with a partner.

headline: Richardson and the Hispanic Factor
text: In spite of his decidedly Anglo-sounding name, Bill Richardson, speaking in Spanish and English, made a big deal out of his Hispanic roots in announcing his presidential bid in Los Angeles today. And thanks to a decision by his father — an American born overseas — there is no question about Mr. Richardson’s ability to run for president.

headline: Civics Lessons in Albany
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders met in their third public meeting in a month to see what issues they could resolve before the regular legislative session ends on June 21. Not much tangible progress was made.

headline: A Good Day at the Office for Citigroup
text: Monday was a big deal for dealmaking. It may have been an even bigger day for Citigroup. Citi’s investment bank had a role in all the big headline deals of the day — more than $80 billion worth — which propelled it into first place, ahead of Goldman Sachs, in the worldwide merger advisory league tables compiled by Thomson Financial. Among the recent deals in which Citi had a hand were Alltel‘s $27.5 billion sale to TPG and Goldman Sachs; General Electric‘s sale of its plastics division to Saudi Basic Industries for $11.6 billion; EMI‘s 3.5 billion pound sale to Terra Firma; UniCredit‘s $29 billion acquisition of Capitalia; Banca Popolare di Milano‘s purchase of Banca Popolare dell’Emilia Romagna for $7.6 billion.

headline: The Golden Rule in the Human Jungle
text: News of the past few days and weeks suggests a rather dismal view of humanity. Israelis and Palestinians are again firing rockets at each other. On the streets of Karachi, just over a week ago, Pakistani security forces stood by while 42 people were killed and many more injured at a rally for Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, deposed Chief Justice of the Supreme Court and opponent of President Pervez Musharraf. In the United States, a company compiling data on consumers is making money by helping criminals steal the savings of thousands of retired Americans.

headline: When Government Was the Solution
text: For more than a generation, Americans have been told that government is the problem, not the solution. The mantra can be traced back to Barry Goldwater’s presidential bid in 1964. It provided the mind-set for the Reagan administration, and it has come to ultimate fruition during the presidency of George W. Bush.On college campuses and at think tanks across the country, libertarian scholars stoke the urge to eliminate government from our lives. This thinking has led to the privatization of vital government functions such as the care of disabled veterans, the appointment to regulatory commissions of members at odds with the regulations they are sworn to enforce, the refusal of the Environmental Protection Agency to protect the environment, and the surrender of the government’s management of military operations to profit-seeking contractors.

headline: A Democratic Drive to War?
text: In an appearance on the “Late Show with David Letterman” that will air later tonight, Rudolph W. Giuliani said he believes America might have gone to war in Iraq even if George W. Bush had not been President.

headline: Signals From Our Statues
text: When lighting strikes a holier-than-most location like the Mother Cabrini Shrine in Golden, Colo., only small quantities of faith and/or imagination are needed to see the possibilities for divine actions. After all, she was the first American citizen canonized as a Roman Catholic saint.

headline: McCain’s Choice Words for Romney
text: It does not look much like there’s a McCain-Romney ticket is in the offing. Consider Senator John McCain’s latest riposte to Mitt Romney, who has been attacking him lately for his support of the Senate’s new accord on immigration.

headline: Graphic: The Third Way
text: Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, mentioned the possibility of running on an independent presidential ticket with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York last week. Although independent candidates did not win a presidency in the last century, they have changed the dynamic of many races. Party control changed in many elections when there was support for third-party candidates.

headline: Ron Paul’s Web of Support
text: Representative Ron Paul, the Texas Republican who is running for president, may be barely registering in public opinion polls, but his supporters are making their presence known on the Internet. They were particularly energized after the second Republican debate, held last week in South Carolina.

headline: “Geek” Schedule
text: This past weekend marked the broadcast debut of my Science Channel show, “It’s All Geek to Me.” Thanks to everyone who tuned in! (*Especially* those of you with Nielsen meters.)

headline: Telling Bloopers: Oops! I Didn’t Mean for You to Find Out This Way
text: In my Findings column, I inveigh against spam from friends. Now it’s your turn to rail against what Dan Ryan calls violations of “notification norms.”

headline: Fund-Raising Adds to a Democratic Advantage
text: Senate Democrats have raised twice as much money this year as have their Republican counterparts, adding more difficulty to the electoral equation for Republicans next year.

headline: Florida’s Primary Penalty
text: Signing into law a contentious plan to move up his state’s presidential primary, Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida said yesterday that he might lobby the national Republican and Democratic Parties to bend their “byzantine” rules so the state will not be penalized.

headline: We’re Goin’ Streaking!
text: Well, not really. But two wins in a row is something. The Yankees have not done that since May 8 and 9. They beat the Red Sox tonight, 6-2, and a win on Tuesday will give them three in a row, matching their longest winning streak of the year.

headline: Onetime Giuliani Insider Is Now a Critic
text: As Rudolph W. Giuliani runs for president, his image as a chief executive who steered New York through the disaster of Sept. 11 has become a pillar of his campaign. But one former member of his inner circle keeps surfacing to revisit that history in ways that are unflattering to Mr. Giuliani: Jerome M. Hauer, New York City’s first emergency management director.

headline: Legal Victory for Families of Disabled Students
text: WASHINGTON, May 21 — A Supreme Court decision on Monday gave parents of children with disabilities the right to go to court without a lawyer to challenge their public school district’s individualized plan for their child’s education.

headline: Transition Leader Is Named for Ailing Roosevelt Schools
text: State education officials have asked a veteran school administrator who is a former president of the New York State Council of School Superintendents to oversee a transition period for the troubled Roosevelt Union Free School District on Long Island.

headline: Bloomberg Proposes Energy Efficient Taxi Fleet
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced today a plan to replace the city’s entire yellow cab fleet with environmentally friendly hybrid vehicles over the next five years.

headline: Idaho Gunman Also Killed Wife, Police Say
text: MOSCOW, Idaho, May 21 — The gunman who killed a police officer, a church sexton and then himself in this quiet northern Idaho town over the weekend also apparently shot and killed his wife in the moments before his sniperlike shootings, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: For at Least a Night, Wang and the Yanks Have Control
text: Hitters usually know just what to expect from the Yankees’ Chien-Ming Wang: heavy sinkers begging to be topped into the dirt. David Ortiz, the Boston Red Sox slugger, has faced Wang many times, but he did not quite recognize him last night at Yankee Stadium.

headline: California: Wayward Whales Balk
text: Two wayward injured humpback whales were nearly halfway toward the Pacific Ocean after a detour that started on May 13 and took them 90 miles up the Sacramento River. Escorted by the Coast Guard and a 21-vessel flotilla, the whales traveled 30 miles in 20 hours since leaving the Port of Sacramento on Sunday, the authorities said. The two stopped again yesterday and circled a river channel near Rio Vista, apparently hesitant to swim under an open drawbridge, the authorities said. The whales, injured by a boat propeller, have passed the bridge several times, but always retreated upstream. Jim Milbury of the Fisheries Service of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said the whales faced threats like pylons, a series of delta islands and sloughs that could ground them.

headline: Film Offers New Talking Points in Health Care Debate
text: Few of them may become Michael Moore fans. But some insurance industry officials and health policy experts acknowledged yesterday that the film documentary “Sicko,” Mr. Moore’s indictment of health care in this country, taps into widespread public concern that the system does not work for millions of Americans.

headline: Network Shuffle Leaves N.H.L. Out in the Cold
text: This just shouldn’t happen to a major sport during its playoffs.

headline: Critics in Senate Vow to Alter Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, May 21 — As the Senate began work on a comprehensive immigration bill, lawmakers from both parties demanded substantial changes in the legislation on Monday and forced Senate leaders to extend debate beyond the Memorial Day recess.

headline: 2 Firms Tied to Phone Lists Will Review Their Policies
text: Two companies accused by state and federal regulators of doing business with suspected telemarketing thieves released statements yesterday pledging to examine and change their business practices.

headline: Letters
text: The Rewards of Acceleration

headline: Iran Accuses American of Revolution Plot
text: The Islamic Republic of Iran yesterday accused a prominent American academic it imprisoned two weeks ago of conspiring to foment a velvet revolution there.

headline: Paying for College
text: One of the ways the rich are different is that their children are much more likely to attend college. Nearly 80 percent of high-income high school graduates went directly to college in 2004, versus some 60 percent of middle-income graduates and about half of those who are low income. Inadequate financial aid is not the only reason for such disturbing discrepancies. But it’s a significant one  and one that Congress can do something about this year.

headline: New DVDs: Gary Cooper
text: GARY COOPER

headline: Mexican Workers Provide a Resort Island’s ‘Backbone’
text: AVALON, Calif., May 16 — The flames and smoke are gone, the tourists are coming back and the Rufino, Campos and Hernandez families, part of the Latino immigrant work force keeping things running here, are again receding into the background of this island known more for its bison and bungalows than as a center of immigration.

headline: Web Sites Listing Informants Concern Justice Dept.
text: There are three “rats of the week” on the home page of whosarat.com, a Web site devoted to exposing the identities of witnesses cooperating with the government. The site posts their names and mug shots, along with court documents detailing what they have agreed to do in exchange for lenient sentences.

headline: China Investigates Contaminated Toothpaste
text: DANYANG, China, May 21 — Chinese authorities are investigating whether two companies from this coastal region exported tainted toothpaste as more contaminated product, including some made for children, has turned up in Latin America.

headline: Correction
text: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Friday about the dismissal of a lawsuit challenging the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn misidentified the suit in question. It accused the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency that shepherded the project to approval, of condemning two apartment buildings on the project site without permission from state housing officials to cancel the tenants’ rent-stabilized leases. A separate lawsuit accusing the agency of offering an unfair relocation plan to those tenants is still pending.

headline: Trade Talks With China at a Juncture
text: WASHINGTON, May 21 — In recent weeks, the Bush administration has negotiated furiously with China to secure some eye-catching new agreements to unlock Chinese markets for American goods. China, in response, has told the United States that it plans new purchases of $30 billion — a shopping spree that dwarfs any China has gone on previously.

headline: Commercial-Free TV, With Sponsorship in Show
text: Commercial-Free TV,

headline: On an Icy Moon of Saturn, Gravity Causes Plenty of Moving and Shaking
text: When baking a potato, the smart cook pierces the skin in several places. That allows water vapor to escape as the potato heats, avoiding a potentially explosive situation.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary by The Associated Press on May 14 about Bernard Gordon, a blacklisted Hollywood screenwriter who eventually had some film credits restored, misstated the relationship of the stars of “Hellcats of the Navy,” a film for which he was later credited. Ronald Reagan had already married Nancy Davis when the film was made in 1957; she was not his “future wife.”

headline: Top Directors See the Future, and They Say It’s in 3-D
text: LOS ANGELES, May 21 — If some prominent Hollywood directors and an Irish rock band have their way, moviegoers en masse will soon be heading back to the future, wearing newfangled 3-D glasses.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Friday about Denis G. Kuhn, an architect and preservationist, gave an erroneous credit for the master plan for a proposed suburban community in Gaithersburg, Md. The project was overseen by Matthew J. Bell of Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn Architects, not by Mr. Kuhn. The obituary also misstated the reopening date of the Alexander Hamilton Custom House on Bowling Green in Lower Manhattan, vacated in the 1970s, which Mr. Kuhn turned into the Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Indian. The building reopened in 1987, when the Federal Bankruptcy Court moved into two floors — not in 1994, when the museum opened on three additional floors.

headline: New York’s Annual Estimate of Homeless Is Challenged
text: A Columbia University professor hired by the city to help conduct an annual estimate of homeless people has disavowed the project, saying its methods cause the number to be understated.

headline: New Train Station for Stadium
text: A Metropolitan Transportation Authority committee yesterday approved a $91 million plan to build a Metro-North Railroad station that would serve the new Yankee Stadium, which is under construction in the Bronx. The station is expected to open in June 2009, about two months after the Yankees are scheduled to begin playing in their new home. The station will operate as a regular stop on Metro-North’s Hudson line and will have added service for baseball games, M.T.A. officials said. The transportation authority and the city are to share the cost of building the station, which is meant to handle up to 12,000 passengers after a game. The full board of the M.T.A. is expected to approve the plan tomorrow.

headline: A Century and a Half Later, a Novel Inspires an Opera
text: Vivid adventure novels like “The Three Musketeers” and “The Count of Monte Cristo” made the French author Alexandre Dumas père one of the best-selling writers of the 19th century. He turned some of his books into plays, and adaptations of works like those must have been a tantalizing prospect for ambitious opera composers. Yet despite attempts to work with Bellini and Meyerbeer, Dumas neither produced nor inspired a libretto of lasting importance. (His son, Alexandre Dumas fils, far less a man of the theater, wrote “La Dame aux Camélias,” the novel on which Verdi based “La Traviata.”)

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Cannes Journal article in The Arts yesterday, about new movies at the Cannes Film Festival, referred incorrectly to text at the start of “Terror’s Advocate,” a documentary about Jacques Vergès, a French lawyer. It says that the film’s view of the protagonist may not correspond with his own, not that it may correspond.

headline: Governor and Lawmakers in 3rd Round of Public Talks
text: ALBANY, May 21 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders met on Monday for their third round of public negotiations in as many weeks to see which issues they could resolve before the legislative session ends a month from now.

headline: At the End, a Duty to Bear Witness
text: It was nighttime when I first met Madeline and Shana. I knew I had an agenda that night, and I needed to establish trust, to bear witness and not to be thrown out of the room.

headline: Baghdad District Is a Model, but Only for Shiites
text: BAGHDAD, May 18 — Ice cream shops in the Shiite stronghold of Kadhimiya are flush with sweet-toothed customers. Hospitals have new supplies. Rents have tripled as displaced Shiites flock to the historic district’s spacious homes, while pilgrims stream to the golden-domed shrine at its heart.

headline: Rated PG, With No Dirty Dancing
text: WANTAGH, N.Y., May 20  Talk about a bait and switch. Surely some of the young people who came to see Gwen Stefani and Akon at Jones Beach on Sunday night had seen the infamous video online. The one that depicted Akon in Trinidad, bumping and grinding and dragging a female fan  a minor, it turned out  all over the stage. The one that inspired a loud chorus of “Harrumph!” from the harrumphers. The one that spooked Verizon so much that it withdrew its sponsorship of this tour.

headline: Phone Company Deal Irks Would-Be Bidders
text: The Alltel Corporation’s agreement to go private in a $27.5 billion deal, the largest leveraged buyout ever in the telecommunications industry, is not sitting well with some other private equity firms that were lined up to bid for the company.

headline: An Old Steel Mill Retools to Produce Clean Energy
text: LACKAWANNA, N.Y., May 21 — Empty grain elevators and dormant railroad tracks line the Buffalo River to the east and Lake Erie to the west, interspersed with empty fields overgrown with gnarled shrubbery. Test wells that monitor decades of buried industrial waste dot the landscape. A passenger ship, rust overtaking its aqua paint, sits beside a decaying mill.

headline: Where Have You Gone, Gary Sheffield?
text: Where is Gary Sheffield when the Yankees need him? He plays for the Detroit Tigers these days, courtesy of the Yankees. General Manager Brian Cashman traded Sheffield to the Tigers last November rather than give him a contract extension and trade another high-priced right fielder instead.

headline: Commissioner Leaves for Port Job
text: Gov. Jon S. Corzine yesterday appointed Susan Bass Levin, left, to the post of deputy director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Ms. Levin, 54, has served as the state’s commissioner of community affairs since 2002 under three Democratic governors, except for a brief period in late 2005, when she worked for Mr. Corzine’s campaign for governor. She succeeds James P. Fox, a former chief of staff to Gov. James E. McGreevey. Mr. Fox is forming a transportation and economic development consulting firm with George D. Warrington, the former head of New Jersey Transit, and Eric Shuffler, a former top aide to Mr. McGreevey.

headline: Success at Career Colleges (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Study of History Isn’t Helped by Testing (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Media Equation column in Business Day yesterday, about a disclosure by The New York Post that its staff had accepted money from a restaurant in return for favorable coverage, included incorrect information in some copies about the amount of money and the recipients. The amount was $1,000 — not $3,000 — and it went to the editor of Page Six, Richard Johnson. No money was given to two other Page Six staff members, Jeanne MacIntosh and Sean Gannon, now the business editor. (The money was spent on an afternoon of drinking by the staff.)

headline: Ensure Low-Cost Housing, Meadowlands Panel Is Told
text: NEWARK, May 21  A New Jersey appellate court ruled on Monday that the state Meadowlands Commission is responsible for ensuring that low-income housing is included in the development of 21,000 acres it oversees just west of Manhattan.

headline: Ad Limits Seen as Way to Curb Youth Smoking and Drinking
text: Price-cutting and other marketing strategies widely used by the tobacco and alcoholic beverage industries are highly effective in encouraging children and teenagers to smoke and drink, according to two new studies.

headline: MySpace to Share Data With States on Offenders
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 21  MySpace and the 50 state attorneys general appear to have made peace.

headline: Memo Pad
text: MAJOR AIRPORT INVESTMENT URGED Airports need to spend more than $87 billion for infrastructure and other improvements by 2011 to accommodate increasing passenger and air-cargo demand, according to a study by the Airports Council International North America. “Anyone traveling by air today knows that aviation is already stretched to the breaking point,” said Greg Principato, president of the council. In a statement, the group said that “2007 is stacking up to be similar to and in some instances worse than 2000, a year which until now had the dubious distinction of being the peak year for air-travel delays.” Most airport improvement projects — for runways, terminals, gates and the like — are paid for by the so-called passenger facility charge added to the price of airline tickets. That charge has been capped by Congress at $4.50 since 2000, but the council said Congress should increase the cap.

headline: With an Immigration Compromise Committed to Paper, the Time for Scrutiny Begins
text: The debate over a sweeping bipartisan immigration bill got off to a fiery but confused start yesterday, since few lawmakers, and even fewer people around the country, had seen the full text of the proposal.

headline: Cocaine Wars Make Port Colombia’s Deadliest City
text: BUENAVENTURA, Colombia, May 15 — Visitors to this city can be forgiven for thinking no place is safe here. Gunfire often echoes through the slums surrounding its port, the country’s most important on the Pacific coast. As larger cities have calmed, Buenaventura has emerged as the deadliest urban center in Colombia’s long internal war.

headline: Outcomes: Alcohol Is Tied to Lower Risk of One Type of Kidney Cancer
text: Scientists have discovered yet another reason that alcohol might be good for you. Using pooled data from 12 studies and more than 750,000 subjects, researchers found that moderate alcohol consumption — about a drink a day — is associated with a decreased risk of renal cell carcinoma, one type of kidney cancer.

headline: Torre Says Abreu Is Close to Climbing Out of Slump
text: Maybe it was the giddiness of simply winning a game, but Yankees Manager Joe Torre was emphatic when speaking about Bobby Abreu after Sunday’s victory. “Abreu is back,” he said.

headline: Attacks in Sunni Areas in Baghdad Kill at Least 29
text: BAGHDAD, May 22  A truck laden with explosives detonated near a market in southwest Baghdad today, killing 25 and wounding more than 100 in the latest in a series of devastating attacks that have set back the American-led effort to stabilize the capital.

headline: As the Grapevine Withers, Spam Filters Take Root
text: Thanks to the sociologist Dan Ryan, I’m coming to terms with my need for spam filters against my friends’ e-mail.

headline: The Show Will Go On, but the Art Will Be Shielded
text: You enter through a place that looks like the very last picture show, an old movie theater with soda-stained carpet and a busted popcorn machine. Sleeping bags and clothes are scattered around, as if the theater has served as a shelter from some unnamed danger outside its doors.

headline: Eighth Graders in N.Y. Show Gains in Reading
text: The number of New York state eighth graders reading on grade level climbed impressively this year for the first time since 1999 when the state adopted tougher educational standards and its modern testing system, according to scores released today from this year’s statewide English exam.

headline: Landis Waits Another Day to Testify
text: MALIBU, Calif., May 21  Floyd Landis, who has waited 10 months to argue his case against the United States Anti-Doping Agency, had to sit and stew for one more day.

headline: Supreme Court to Address State Tax Breaks for Bonds
text: WASHINGTON, May 21  In a case with the potential to rattle, if not reshape, the market for state and municipal bonds, the Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether states can continue to exempt interest on their own bonds from their residents’ taxable income, while taxing the interest on bonds issued by other states.

headline: Executive on a Mission: Saving the Planet
text: VININGS, Ga. — What Ray Anderson calls his “conversion experience” occurred in the summer of 1994, when he was asked to give the sales force at Interface, the carpet tile company he founded, some talking points about the company’s approach to the environment.

headline: Figuring the Next Field for the Mayor
text: This just in:

headline: Raising the Room Temperature With Three Brahms Sonatas
text: The violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg has said she feels possessed when she plays. A recital on Sunday with the pianist Anne-Marie McDermott demonstrated that neither the electric spark nor the eccentricity of her playing has mellowed since she won the Naumburg International Violin Competition in 1981.

headline: Fighting in Lebanon Dashes Cease-Fire Hopes
text: NAHR EL-BARED REFUGEE CAMP, Lebanon, May 22 — Fierce fighting continued for the third straight day in northern Lebanon today, as the Lebanese Army continued battling militants holed up in a refugee camp on the outskirts of Tripoli, ending a brief cease-fire with a barrage of shelling and gunfire that hampered rescue and aid efforts and raised political tensions in other parts of the country.

headline: Study Cites Safety Questions About Diabetes Drug
text: An article released today by The New England Journal of Medicine raised safety questions about the widely-used diabetes pill Avandia. An analysis of clinical trials concluded that the drug might significantly increase the risk of heart attacks.

headline: Audit Finds Subway Track Work Safety Violations
text: City transit officials found dozens of safety lapses during spot checks of track work on the subway system just weeks after the deaths of two track workers, officials said yesterday.

headline: When Former Presidents Assail the Chief
text: WASHINGTON, May 21 — Nothing rattles Washington quite like a good violation of unwritten rules, especially when the violator and the violated are both presidents (past and present, respectively).

headline: No Helmet, No Pads, No Escape
text: LAKE FOREST, Calif., May 16 — When Johnnie Morton finished playing wide receiver in the National Football League, he carefully reviewed his retirement options: be host of a talk show, expand his real estate profile, maybe work on his golf game.

headline: Side Deals in a Gray Area
text: Global deal making is on a tear, accompanied by a surge of insider trading cases.

headline: The Immigration Debate, in Full Cry (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Knicks Expected to Miss a Shot at Oden or Durant
text: When the N.B.A. has its draft lottery tonight, the team with the ninth-best chance of winning will be the Knicks. But their logo will be absent from the proceedings and their seat on the stage will be filled by a man they have probably never met.

headline: EMI Accepts $4.7 Billion Buyout Offer
text: The EMI Group, the world’s third-largest record company, said today that it would recommend to shareholders that they accept a $4.7 billion buyout offer from a private equity firm, Terra Firma Capital Partners.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A map on Friday of the site of two freeway collapses in Oakland, Calif., incorrectly located the site of the 1989 collapse of Interstate 880. The highway was about 3,500 feet east of Maritime Street, not at its present location, about 2,000 feet east of Maritime.

headline: China: Formula One Chief Fired in Graft Inquiry
text: The head of Shanghai’s new Formula One racing track lost his job as part of an investigation into corruption in the city government. Yu Zhifei, the official, was fired and expelled from the Communist Party, state news media said. He oversaw the introduction of the racing circuit in 2005. The track and related infrastructure cost the city more than $1 billion to develop.

headline: A Race for Jobs in Police Depts. on Long Island
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — At John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan, as soon as fliers advertising the police academy entrance exams on Long Island are posted, they are routinely ripped down, presumably by applicants for the tests who do not want the word to spread.

headline: Darkness With the Light, Inspired by a Buddhist Chant
text: Change is hard. Classical music likes its status quo: the same great music in the same great halls. So the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s move to a new location for its final concert of the season on Sunday afternoon — since Alice Tully Hall has closed for renovations — seemed to throw some audience members a curve. Just finding the Frederick P. Rose Hall in the Time Warner Center was evidently a challenge to many, including two couples who stood on the sidewalk, peering anxiously through the glass doors of the mall as if not daring to go in and look around.

headline: Harnessing Methane, Cutting Waste, Recycling Tiles
text: LaGRANGE, Ga. — The urge to conserve is obvious at the Interface Corporation, from slogans painted on the factory floor (“One Planet/Zero Harm”), to prize parking spots reserved for car-poolers, to packing boxes so relentlessly recycled that they sit, wrinkled and battered, festooned with the remains of previously applied masking tape (bought from Germany, because the extra adhesive in American masking tape causes more wear and tear).

headline: Macho Mistakes at Ground Zero
text: As more and more workers who inhaled the dust at ground zero fall ill, it has become increasingly clear that much of the problem can be traced to the Giuliani administration’s failure to insist that all emergency personnel and construction workers at the site wear respirators.

headline: America’s Admissions System
text: Harvard is tough to get into. To be admitted to a school like that, students spend years earning good grades, doing community service and working hard to demonstrate their skills. The system has its excesses, but over all it’s good for Harvard and it’s good for the students beginning their climb to opportunity.

headline: Harsh Birth Control Steps Fuel Violence in China
text: BEIJING, May 21  An intensive campaign to enforce strict population-control measures, including forced abortions, prompted violent clashes between the police and local residents in southwestern China in recent days, witnesses said Monday, describing the latest incident of rural unrest that has alarmed senior officials in Beijing.

headline: To Lead the Jazz Ahead, Boozer Reaches Back to the Past
text: The last time Carlos Boozer of the Utah Jazz struggled in the opening game of a playoff series, he called a friend for solace and advice.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Stallone Fined for Hormone Imports

headline: An Energetic Pianistic Program With Wine as Accompaniment
text: Nostalgia for the vanished tradition of salon concerts appears to be on the rise. Two years ago a series of piano recitals at the Rainbow Room put listeners at dinner tables with glasses of wine, and the Baryshnikov Arts Center and Lincoln Center (in its post-Mostly Mozart concerts) has been doing the same. Last year Arium, a hybrid restaurant, gallery and concert space on Little West 12th Street in the West Village, began presenting recitals for which the ticket price included a glass of wine, hors d’oeuvres before the performance and dessert afterward.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A headline in Business Day on Friday with an article about the sale of 24/7 Real Media, the advertising network and technology company, to the WPP Group misstated the price of the deal. As the article noted, it was $649 million, not $64 million.

headline: Richardson Officially Enters ’08 Democratic Presidential Race
text: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico formally kicked off his bid for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination yesterday, highlighting his Hispanic roots and wealth of experience and issuing a forceful call to end American involvement in Iraq.

headline: General Electric to Sell Plastics Division
text: General Electric agreed today to sell its plastics division for $11.6 billion to the largest public company in Saudi Arabia, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation.

headline: Eugen Weber, Authority on Modern France, Dies at 82
text: Eugen Weber, the Romanian-born, English-educated American historian who was one of the world’s foremost interpreters of modern France and an authority on modern Europe, died Thursday at his home in Los Angeles, where he had taught at U.C.L.A. and was a former dean of its College of Letters and Science. He was 82.

headline: Marine Is Used to Fighting for His Life
text: When asked to assess his state of mind before stepping into a steel cage for a fight, Brian Stann provides a matter-of-fact reply that also stands as a stark warning.

headline: Cleveland to Cairo, in Coach? Ways to Outwit the Body Clock
text: Anyone who has flown across several time zones for business or pleasure has no doubt experienced jet lag — that days-long feeling that all body functions are out of sync with the new environment. And as soon as you become adjusted, you return home and have to go through it again. It’s enough to prompt some people to stay home.

headline: A Mezzo-Soprano Steps In, With a Wild and Woolly Berlioz
text: I am running out of good things to say about the Met Orchestra and its music director, James Levine. If there is someone out there with a new repertory of complimentary adjectives suitable to this exquisite marriage of taste and heart, I would be glad to give way.

headline: Student Sentenced in Hate-Crime Attack
text: A college student from Little Neck was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years of probation for his role in an attack on two Asian-American teenagers last year, prosecutors said. Paul A. Heavey, 21, pleaded guilty in March to third-degree assault as a hate crime, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Heavey admitted punching and kicking the two men — John Lu and Reynold Liang, both 19 at the time and both from Little Neck — during an August 2006 altercation in Douglaston, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Heavey’s co-defendant, Kevin M. Brown, 19, of Auburndale, was sentenced in March to three and a half years in prison after he admitted beating one of the men with a metal steering wheel lock, prosecutors said.

headline: Taking a Dim View
text: Q. Does wearing someone else’s prescription glasses for a short time do any damage to a child’s eyes?

headline: Carnegie Hall Plans Major Expansion, Without Its Tenants
text: The curtain may finally be falling for dozens of tenants of Carnegie Hall, whose studios helped form a Bohemia on 57th Street because of the many musicians, dancers, painters and other artists who lived in them.

headline: Comments Make Giambi a Target of Investigators
text: When Major League Baseball investigates Jason Giambi’s tacit admission that he used steroids, there is no guarantee that Commissioner Bud Selig will meet with him. Selig is planning first to have one of his chief labor executives conduct an interview with Giambi soon.

headline: Defendant Pleads Not Guilty in Abduction of Boy
text: POTOSI, Mo., May 21  A man accused of kidnapping, armed criminal assault, forcible sodomy and attempted murder in the abduction of a boy from Richwoods in 2002 quietly asserted his innocence on Monday before a circuit judge here, 56 miles southwest of St. Louis.

headline: Putin Prompts Split in German Coalition
text: FRANKFURT, May 21  Germany’s relations with Russia were never likely to be as cozy under Angela Merkel as under her predecessor, Gerhard Schröder, who adopted a 3-year-old Russian girl and, on his 60th birthday, invited President Vladimir V. Putin home to celebrate.

headline: Worker Program Stays in Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, May 23 — The Senate this afternoon endorsed the concept of allowing up to 600,000 temporary workers a year to enter the United States under a broad immigration-reform bill, rejecting an amendment that would have scrapped the worker program.

headline: Heart Attack Risk Seen in Drug for Diabetes
text: An article in a leading medical journal yesterday raised serious safety questions about the widely used diabetes pill Avandia and renewed skepticism about the vigilance of federal drug regulators.

headline: At the Dentist’s: Vicious Cycle of Gum Disease, Bone Loss and Cancer
text: The bone loss caused by gum disease is associated with an increased risk for tongue cancer, and the more the bone loss, the greater the risk, researchers report.

headline: Group Offers a Simple Fix for Alternative Minimum Tax
text: A levy originally intended to ensure that the richest investors cannot live tax-free is taking back a much larger portion of the Bush tax cuts going to those who make less than $100,000 than to those who earn more than $1 million, according to a new analysis by the Joint Committee on Taxation.

headline: Kerkorian in New Move in Las Vegas
text: Last month Kirk Kerkorian, the 89-year-old billionaire who buys and sells large positions in corporations like few others on Wall Street, offered $4.5 billion to buy Chrysler from DaimlerChrysler, only to lose out to another bidder.

headline: The Rich and Faithful in Africa. Discuss.
text: NEW HAVEN, May 19 — It says much about “The Unmentionables,” a new play by Bruce Norris at the Yale Repertory Theater, that the most likable character in it, an easygoing African doctor, admits he occasionally feels a temptation to plant a tomahawk in the middle of somebody’s forehead. Given the company he’s surrounded by in this acidic satire of bourgeois venality and hypocrisy, you are tempted to sympathize with this confession.

headline: Iran’s Centrifuges
text: For a U.N.-baiting, diplomacy-bashing crowd, the Bush administration has shown unexpected patience in trying to persuade the Security Council to punish Iran for its nuclear misbehavior. And for a foot-dragging, conflict-averse crowd, the Security Council has moved with alacrity in imposing two sets of sanctions on Iran just since December.

headline: Bank Robbery in Chicago Leaves 3 Injured
text: A gunfight broke out during a robbery in a Chicago bank this morning, injuring a security guard, a bank employee and a customer, officials said. The bank employee later died of his injuries.

headline: Dame Mary Douglas, 86, a Wide-Ranging Anthropologist, Is Dead
