text: Dame Mary Douglas, an anthropologist whose influence ranged beyond the traditional questions of her field to examine areas as diverse as kosher diets, consumer behavior, environmentalism and humor as she described how humans work together to find shared meaning, died Wednesday in London.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (Fox) ON THE LOT Sixteen aspiring filmmakers compete for their big break — in the form of a $1 million development deal with DreamWorks — in this new reality series with Mark Burnett and Steven Spielberg as executive producers. Carrie Fisher and Brett Ratner, above, as well as Garry Marshall and Jon Avnet are judges for the audition rounds tonight and Thursday. The competitors try their hands at a pitch meeting, then shoot and edit a short film in 24 hours. The series moves into its regular times, Mondays and Tuesdays at 8 p.m., next week.

headline: China: Road Accident Kills 20 Farmers
text: Twenty female farmers were killed when the three-wheeled vehicle they were riding overturned on a mountainous road in Liaoning Province. State news media said they were returning from a day of picking herbs and were crowded onto a trailer towed behind the vehicle. China’s roads are the most dangerous in the world, with 90,000 people losing their lives in accidents in the first quarter of 2007 alone, according to official estimates.

headline: Marketers Struggle to Get Folks to Stay Put for the Commercials
text: TO many people, the commercial break is when you use the restroom, change the channel or grab a snack.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,407 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Columbia Fires Its Director of Student Aid
text: Columbia University dismissed its financial aid director yesterday after the release of documents showing he promoted a student loan company in which he had a stake, sending letters to parents and alumni on three occasions praising the lender.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article in the Week in Review section on Sunday about the conservative movement misstated the outcome of impeachment proceedings in 1998 against President Clinton, whose character conservatives made the focus of the 2000 election. The House of Representatives did indeed impeach him. (The Senate did not convict him of the impeachment charges.) (Go to Article)

headline: Supporters Urge Pakistan Leader to Shift Course
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 21 — After a series of political blunders in the last two months, Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, is being advised by his political supporters to make a dramatic change of course or risk losing power amid more chaos and bloodshed.

headline: A Move for Birth Certificates for Stillborn Babies
text: Last summer, three weeks before her due date, Sari Edber delivered a stillborn son, Jacob. “He was 5 pounds and 19 inches, absolutely beautiful, with my olive complexion, my husband’s curly hair, long fingers and toes, chubby cheeks and a perfect button nose,” she said.

headline: Rival Books on Hillary Clinton Play Leapfrog on Debut Dates
text: In the latest round of publishing one-upmanship, the two publishers of rival biographies of Hillary Rodham Clinton have moved up their on-sale dates once again.

headline: Lebanese Army and Islamists Battle for 2nd Day
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, May 21 — Lebanese tanks and artillery pounded a Palestinian refugee camp in this northern Lebanese city for the second straight day on Monday, battling members of a radical Islamist group and raising concerns for thousands trapped inside.

headline: Is Your Career a Kayak or an Ocean Liner?
text: I normally pay a lot of attention to people striking out on their own. But lately I’ve been noticing those who swim against the tide of self-employment. You know, the ones who ditch all that flexibility and autonomy for the life of a steady paycheck, defined hours, in-person colleagues and a bundle of benefits. Put it that way and it doesn’t sound so bad after all, does it?

headline: Democrats Avoid Vote on Reprimanding Murtha
text: WASHINGTON, May 22 — House Democrats flexed their new majority today and avoided having to vote on whether one of their own, Representative John Murtha, a crusty ex-marine from coal-and-steel country, had besmirched the dignity of the chamber through bare-knuckled politics.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A headline on Saturday with the obituary of the physicist Donald M. Ginsberg misidentified his area of expertise. It was superconductors, not semiconductors.

headline: General Electric to Sell Plastics Division
text: General Electric agreed yesterday to sell its plastics division for $11.6 billion to the largest public company in Saudi Arabia, the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation.

headline: Wealth as a Clue in Running
text: The initial financial disclosure required of the presidential candidates is already shedding light on important questions of wherewithal looming beyond the glare of televised debate. As voters sort through the crowd, which includes 10 millionaires, they should find their finances useful in sizing up the contenders and whom and what they actually work for.

headline: Justice Dept. Sues New York City, Citing Bias in Hiring Firefighters
text: The United States Department of Justice filed a civil rights suit against New York City yesterday over the Fire Department’s written entrance exam, which black and Hispanic candidates fail at much higher rates than whites. The suit claims that the city has never proved a link between test scores and performance as a firefighter.

headline: $4.7 Billion Private Equity Buyout Wins Support at EMI
text: The music company EMI Group, which has been the subject of takeover speculation since the 1990s, said yesterday that its board supported a new $4.7 billion offer from a private investor, Terra Firma Capital Partners.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the National Briefing column on Saturday about an appeal by Hamid Hayat, a Lodi, Calif., man convicted in a terror case, referred incorrectly in some copies to his lawyer. The lawyer, Wazhma Mojaddidi, is a woman.

headline: For Less Crowding on L Train, Think 2010, Report Says
text: Riders on the crowded L subway line, who at peak hours frequently have to wait for two or more trains to pass at some stations before squeezing aboard, will have to keep on squeezing for at least a few more years, according to a report released yesterday.

headline: In New Role, Myers Is Good News for Phillies
text: Since an ugly off-the-field incident last season, Philadelphia Phillies pitcher Brett Myers has experienced a lot of change — some in private, some in the open.

headline: China Says It Made Blackstone Investment to Raise Returns
text: HONG KONG, May 21 — From the outside, the Chinese government’s $3 billion purchase of a nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group might look like a prelude to a broader campaign for control of foreign companies.

headline: Six Dead in Baltimore Fire
text: Six people died and five others were injured early today as a fire swept through a two-story rowhouse in the northeast section of Baltimore.

headline: Alienated Europeans, Through a Cold Lens
text: CANNES, France, May 21 — One of the most fertile subjects of contemporary European cinema is the desolation of contemporary European life. The extravagance and high spirits outside the Cannes screening rooms thus frequently stand in jarring contrast to the misery displayed within them, where stories of privation, disconnection and violence hold up a corrective mirror to a continent that likes to present itself to the rest of the world as prosperous, unified and at peace.

headline: Kidd Will Understand if Carter Leaves the Nets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 21  Three summers ago, Kenyon Martin was a free agent chasing a big payday. The Nets balked, and Jason Kidd fumed.

headline: Democrats Drop Troop Pullout Dates From Iraq Bill
text: WASHINGTON, May 22 — Congressional Democrats relented today on their insistence that a war spending measure sought by President Bush also set a date for withdrawing troops from Iraq. The decision to back down, described by senior lawmakers and aides, was a wrenching reversal for some Democrats, who saw their election triumph as a call to force an end to the war. A Democratic effort to include timelines prompted Mr. Bush’s veto of the original bill last month, producing a political impasse.

headline: Correction
text: Because of an editing error, an article in the Week in Review section on Sunday about the conservative movement misstated the outcome of impeachment proceedings in 1998 against President Clinton, whose character conservatives made the focus of the 2000 election. The House of Representatives did indeed impeach him. (The Senate did not convict him of the impeachment charges.)

headline: Al Gore Speaks of a Nation in Danger
text: In “The Assault on Reason” Al Gore excoriates George W. Bush, asserting that the president is “out of touch with reality,” that his administration is so incompetent that it “can’t manage its own way out of a horse show,” that it ignored “clear warnings” about the terrorist threat before 9/11 and that it has made Americans less safe by “stirring up a hornets’ nest in Iraq,” while using “the language and politics of fear” to try to “drive the public agenda without regard to the evidence, the facts or the public interest.”

headline: Mets Look to Future and See the Braves
text: Tom Glavine is many things. A future Hall of Famer, golf nut and the Mets’ conscience, yes. A soothsayer, probably not. But when Glavine, still an authority on all things Atlanta after five years in a Mets uniform, peers a few months ahead to October, toward the playoffs, he sees two things: the Mets and the Braves.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in some copies on May 13 about a request to dismiss a murder case stemming from the killing of a bouncer outside the Palladium nightclub in Manhattan in 1990 referred imprecisely to David Lemus, who was convicted in the case in 1992. That conviction was set aside in 2005 and Mr. Lemus is now awaiting a second trial on the same charges. He is not merely “accused” of the crime or otherwise being treated as only a suspect.

headline: Test Case in Charges That Gas Stations Imperil Water
text: PLAINVIEW, N.Y., May 21 — When Paul Granger, the water district superintendent here, came to work one morning in 2000, he spotted a rig test-drilling for pollution at a gasoline station across the road from two wells that pump up to 1.7 million gallons of drinking water a day.

headline: Give Them a Break
text: TALKING heads and lawmakers in Washington have a new reason to be exercised about the situation in Iraq — as if any were needed. They’re in an uproar that the Iraqi Parliament, the Council of Representatives, is planning to take a two-month recess starting on July 1. This is being represented as evidence that the Iraqis would prefer to go off to the seashore rather than try to save their country.

headline: Palestinian Militants and Israel Carry Out Deadly Attacks
text: GAZA, May 21 — The Israeli Air Force continued its strikes in Gaza on Monday, killing four members of Islamic Jihad who the Israeli Army said were preparing to launch rockets against Israel, and one member of Hamas at what it said was a bomb-making factory.

headline: On Search for Comrades, a Bomb Wreaks Havoc
text: MAHMUDIYA, Iraq, May 22 — The ground exploded under an ashen sky at dawn. Dust, dirt, blood and military equipment filled the air, clearing after several seconds to reveal a frenzied scene of horror.

headline: Patterns: Treatment of Depression May Lead to Longer Life
text: Treating depression in older adults may be a life-saving intervention, a new study suggests.

headline: Israel and Militants Trade Deadly Attacks in Gaza
text: GAZA, May 22 — The Israeli Air Force mounted three more attacks on Gaza today, as an Israeli woman killed by rocket fire from Gaza on Monday was buried in Sderot, Israel.

headline: The Claim: Microwave Ovens Kill Bacteria in Food
text: THE FACTS

headline: Ethiopia Detains Times Journalists for Five Days
text: Three journalists for The New York Times were arrested by the Ethiopian military on May 16 in the Ogaden region of Ethiopia, held for five days and interrogated at gunpoint, and then released on Monday without any charges being lodged against them, The Times said today.

headline: Ex-Brokers Face Retrial in Eavesdropping Case
text: Three former brokers for Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers face a second trial on charges that they conspired to commit fraud by allowing day traders to eavesdrop on orders on internal “squawk boxes.”

headline: Britain Charges Russian in Poisoning Case
text: LONDON, May 22 — The British authorities said today that they would seek the extradition of a Russian businessman, Andrei Lugovoi, to face trial for the murder of Alexander Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. agent who died last November in London of radiation poisoning caused by a rare isotope, polonium 210.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on May 13 about the decision by a powerful Shiite party, the Supreme Council for the Islamic Revolution in Iraq, to drop the word “revolution” from its name omitted the party’s new name, and a correction in this space on May 15 incorrectly rendered the English version of the new name. It is the Supreme Islamic Iraqi Council, not the Iraqi Islamic Supreme Council.

headline: Bush Scorns Proposed Vote on Gonzales as Theater
text: CRAWFORD, Tex., May 21  President Bush said on Monday that any effort by Congress to hold a no-confidence vote on Alberto R. Gonzales, his embattled attorney general, amounted to the “kind of political theater that has caused the American people to lose confidence in how Washington operates.”

headline: Culinary Adventures in the Customs Lane
text: For our Fairway Market here in New York, I import cheeses, olives, oils and lots of other wonderful stuff from more than a hundred little companies, most of them in Europe.

headline: This Is Your Life (and How You Tell It)
text: For more than a century, researchers have been trying to work out the raw ingredients that account for personality, the sweetness and neuroses that make Anna Anna, the sluggishness and sensitivity that make Andrew Andrew. They have largely ignored the first-person explanation — the life story that people themselves tell about who they are, and why.

headline: Boards More Likely to Oust Underperforming Chief Executives, a Study Finds
text: A new study examining turnover among top executives has found that corporate boards were nearly three times as likely to pull the trigger on failing chief executives than they were a decade ago.

headline: McCain Counters Romney With a Three-Way Riposte
text: It doesn’t look much like there is a McCain-Romney ticket in the offing.

headline: American Cities and the Great Divide
text: A public high school teacher in Brooklyn told me recently about a student who didn’t believe that a restaurant tab for four people could come to more than $500. The student shook his head, as if resisting the very idea. He just couldn’t fathom it.

headline: The Politics of Eurovision
text: Oxford, England

headline: Meet Your Clothes at the Hotel
text: The luggage shipping business has found a convert in Murray Grenville, who runs an investment valuation company in New York and has not flown with bags on business trips in almost a year, even when he goes to the West Coast.

headline: Forget Spartacus, I Am Fresno State
text: For the last couple of years, Madison Avenue has been embracing an idea called user-generated content, encouraging consumers to create advertising, promotional video clips and other marketing messages that were once produced solely by professionals. Among the blue-chip marketers taking part in the trend are Chevrolet, Frito-Lay, Geico, Heinz ketchup, KFC, Mr. Clean, the National Football League and Verizon Communications.

headline: How to Fight the Insurgents (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gunmen Kill 5 in Ambush of Minibus in Diyala Province on Day of Scattered Violence in Iraq
text: ERBIL, Iraq, May 21 — Gunmen ambushed a minibus passing through a troubled area of Diyala Province on Monday and killed five passengers, including a child, an Interior Ministry official said.

headline: Diverse Fashions, Same Statement: Police
text: During the 24 years that Wilfredo Vega Jr. has been working behind the counter of a police equipment shop on East 21st Street in Manhattan, he has made countless sales to veteran officers of the New York Police Department and to the cadets who attend classes close by at the Police Academy.

headline: War Proposal Still Stymied Despite Talks
text: WASHINGTON, May 21  Facing a self-imposed weekend deadline, Congressional Democrats said Monday that they remained uncertain how they would shape a war spending measure that has been the center of a political and policy battle with President Bush.

headline: A Flute With a Beat, and You Might Dance to It
text: GREG PATTILLO may be the best person in the world at what he does. He may also be the only person in the world who does what he does.

headline: Children’s Health Care (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nutrition: A Healthy Diet May Keep Chronic Lung Disease at Bay
text: A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, fish, poultry and whole grain foods may offer protection against chronic lung disease, a new study suggests, in addition to the other benefits of such a regimen.

headline: Paintings From Germany, With a Wink and a Sneer
text: Painting may go in and out of fashion, but its many lifesaving graces always keep it afloat. One is its capacity for what might be called beautiful sarcasm, a sly self-parody while still looking good that is cultivated by many young painters today.

headline: Judge Says Oneida Indians Deserve a Chance for Redress
text: A federal judge yesterday rejected claims by the Oneida Indian Nation to land in upstate New York, but agreed with the tribe that it deserved a chance to prove it is owed some compensation for property that the state bought 200 or more years ago at unfairly low prices.

headline: 2 Ex-Officers Plead Not Guilty in New Jersey Break-In
text: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 21 — Two former New York City police officers accused of trying to rob a reputed drug dealer in New Jersey were each ordered held in $1 million bail on Monday after pleading not guilty in State Superior Court here.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Friday about the resignation of Paul D. Wolfowitz as president of the World Bank referred incorrectly to the pay package for the job. It was the previous World Bank president — not Mr. Wolfowitz — who was paid a salary of $302,470 and expenses of $141,290 in 2004. (Mr. Wolfowitz, who did not arrive at the bank until 2005, was paid an after-tax salary of $391,440 beginning July 1, 2005. )

headline: The Attack of the Exhibits, Starring a Spooky Piano
text: BOSTON, May 20 — In January the choreographer Mark Morris gave us a world premiere to Bach’s “Italian” Concerto in his own Brooklyn dance center. On May 2 the full production he staged and choreographed of the three-act Gluck “Orfeo ed Euridice” opened at the Metropolitan Opera. Now this irrepressible artist has knocked off another world premiere, for the new Institute of Contemporary Art, memorably located on the waterfront here.

headline: Conviction in Fatal Stabbing
text: A Jamaica man was convicted of murder yesterday in State Supreme Court for fatally stabbing a man during a fistfight two years ago behind a public school in Briarwood, prosecutors said. Dwayne Morrison, 26, stabbed Miguel Restituyo, 23, on July 30, 2005, after Mr. Restituyo began to get the upper hand in the fight, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said that after someone in the crowd tossed Mr. Morrison a knife, Mr. Restituyo raised his hands in a gesture of surrender, and Mr. Morrison stabbed him.

headline: New Directions From the AAA: Go to the Web, Then Print
text: YOU remember all those predictions about how technology was going to usher in the paperless office?

headline: Convicted Murderer Is Freed in Wake of Tainted Evidence
text: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 21 — “It’s like landing on a new planet,” said Curtis E. McCarty, who was freed from death row this month after two convictions for the same murder, and 22 years in prison, 16 of them on death row.

headline: In Bubbles and Metal, the Art of Shape-Shifting
text: The next time you stare into a beer, contemplate the bubbles.

headline: 19th-Century Looks That Belie a Three-Century Range
text: Dressed in black and crowned by a flowing raven mane, the violinist Nemanja Radulovic looked the part of a dashing 19th-century Romantic virtuoso when he took the stage of Weill Recital Hall on Friday night. Mr. Radulovic, born in the former Yugoslavia and now based in France, came to Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the Rising Stars series, having been nominated by the Cité de la Musique in Paris. His accompanist was Susan Manoff, a New York-born pianist who teaches at the Paris Conservatory.

headline: Channeling Spirits From the Good Old Days, When Love Songs Were Love Songs
text: When the indefatigably romantic cabaret performer Andrea Marcovicci turns the tables on herself and waxes cynical, her infatuation with old Hollywood and classic glamour snaps into focus. That’s when you have to ask yourself: Where would you rather live? Inside her Fred and Ginger, Noël and Cole dream world, or somewhere closer to reality?

headline: Under the Sea
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Mysteries to Behold in the Dark Down Deep: Seadevils and Species Unknown
text: When, more than 70 years ago, William Beebe became the first scientist to descend into the abyss, he described a world of twinkling lights, silvery eels, throbbing jellyfish, living strings as “lovely as the finest lace” and lanky monsters with needlelike teeth.

headline: Legal Status Brings Security to Some Same-Sex Marriages
text: Officially speaking, same-sex couples who live in New York State cannot be married. Nancy Goldstein and Joan Hilty, a Brooklyn couple who celebrated their third wedding anniversary on Saturday, are an unusual exception.

headline: Cancer Care Seeks to Take Patients Beyond Survival
text: As a growing number of Americans are learning, surviving cancer can mean slipping into a rabbit hole of long-term medical problems — from premature menopause and sexual dysfunction to more debilitating side effects of chemotherapy and radiation, like heart disease and even new cancers.

headline: Voice of Experience Knows It’s Too Soon for Yanks to Panic
text: Ron Guidry is available for counseling, willing to double as pitching coach and staff shrink, one on one or group sessions, no charge for the multimillionaires in the Yankees’ clubhouse.

headline: Abortion Foes See Validation for New Tactic
text: WASHINGTON, May 21 — For many years, the political struggle over abortion was often framed as a starkly binary choice: the interest of the woman, advocated by supporters of abortion rights, versus the interest of the fetus, advocated by opponents of abortion.

headline: Aeroflot Seeks Loan to Deal for Alitalia
text: MOSCOW, May 21 — The Russian airline Aeroflot is seeking up to 900 million euros ($1.2 billion) in loans to finance its bid for all or part of the Italian national airline, Alitalia, in its first merger or acquisition effort outside the former Soviet Union.

headline: Afghanistan: Parliament Ousts Leading Critic
text: The lower house of Parliament suspended an outspoken member from Farah Province, Malalai Joya, over a recent interview she gave to a local television station in which she compared Parliament to a stable of animals. Ms. Joya, who has often branded many of her fellow legislators as warlords and war criminals, said that while a cow can give milk and a donkey can carry a load, the lawmakers do nothing.

headline: For Pan-Am Games, the Big Race Is to the Starting Line
text: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 21 — At the edge of Copacabana Beach, a giant electronic display is counting down the days to the start of the Pan-American Games here. Whether the organizers and all of the venues will be ready on July 13, when the clock strikes zero and the 17-day competition starts, is another matter altogether.

headline: Google Proposes Innovation in Radio Spectrum Auction
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 21  Google filed a proposal on Monday with the Federal Communications Commission calling on the agency to let companies allocate radio spectrum using the same kind of real-time auction that the search engine company now uses to sell advertisements.

headline: Web Sites Expose Informants, and Justice Dept. Raises Flag
text: Web sites like whosarat.com expose the identities of witnesses cooperating with the government and provide their names and mug shots.

headline: U.S. Championship, Round 7: Two Share the Lead
text: Alexander Onischuk knocked off Hikaru Nakamura today to join Alexander Shabalov in the lead of the Frank Berry U.S. Championship while Sergey Kudrin beat Ildar Ibragimov to get to 5 points, only a half point back. Another seven grandmasters were at 4.5, so with two rounds to play, the championship has become wide open with many players still with a chance to win. The games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.

headline: Dashing in Dublin
text: Living

headline: Seadevils and Species Unknown
text: Images from a world even stranger than the one Beebe described seven decades ago after the first look into the abyss.

headline: Those Friendly Iranian Mullahs
text: An Iranian friend sent along this photo. It was taken in Hafteh Tir square when a mother and a daughter were beaten for taking pictures of the vice police treating women badly. Some 2000 people gathered in protest.

headline: J.W. Childs Duo Said to Launch New Firm
text: Two senior partners of J.W. Childs Associates are leaving the Boston private equity shop to start their own firm, according to The Deal.com. Dana Schmaltz and Ted Yun each joined J.W. Childs shortly after its founding by John W. Childs in 1995. Mr. Schmaltz, who now serves as president, joined in 1997, while Mr. Yun, a partner and chairman of the investment committee, came on board in 1999. Their departure is expected at the beginning of June, sources told The Deal.

headline: A New Twist in Merrill’s Hedge Fund Deal?
text: With its deal to buy a 20 percent stake in the New York hedge fund GSO Capital Partners, Merrill Lynch appears to be buying a piece of the “nascent competition,” The Financial Times’ Alphaville blog concluded Monday.

headline: New Date for Lonergan Play
text: "The Starry Messenger," a play written and directed by Kenneth Lonergan and starring Matthew Broderick, was scheduled to open on Broadway last month. But Hollywood intervened, specifically Mr. Lonergan's movie "Margaret," which took longer than expected, pre-empting a pre-Broadway tryout at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego.

headline: China Says Blackstone Deal Is All About Returns
text: The Chinese government’s $3 billion purchase of a nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group appears to be a move to pounce on a strategy many foreign banks have adopted in China: buy into a company just before it begins its initial public offering. That strategy has given many banks, like Bank of America and Goldman Sachs, significant initial gains, at least on paper, on their early investments, The New York Times writes.

headline: An ‘Addams Family’ Musical
text: A musical of "The Addams Family" is in the works, with a planned premiere on Broadway in the 2009-10 season.

headline: More on Health
text: Lots of interesting and thoughtful comments below from readers about health care. A few took a swipe at Leana Wen, the winner of my win-a-trip contest. I had used Leana as an example in my column of someone without health coverage. She posted her comments as No. 133. Here are excerpts:

headline: Lawmakers Cut Funding to Army’s V.C. Arm
text: The House of Representatives has cut funding for the Army’s venture capital affiliate from the 2008 defense appropriations bill amid questions about fees and return on investment, The Red Herring reported. Specifically, a $10 million allocation to OnPoint Technologies from the Army was removed from the bill after Tennessee Representative Jim Cooper raised objections over management fees.

headline: Ex-Brokers in ‘Squawk Box’ Case Face Retrial
text: Three former brokers for Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers face a second trial on charges that they conspired to commit fraud by allowing day traders to eavesdrop on orders on internal “squawk boxes.” Four current and former executives at the day trading firm A.B. Watley Group will also be retried on charges that they had a role in the scheme, the United States attorney’s office in Brooklyn said Monday.

headline: Senior Executives Quit Proxy Firm
text: Two senior executives have quit the proxy advisory firm Glass Lewis & Company amid questions over whether its China-based parent, Xinhua Finance Media, withheld unfavorable information about its former chief financial officer. Barron’s reported on Sunday that the prospectus of Xinhua Finance Media, controlled by Xinhua Finance, based in Tokyo, withheld details about business dealings of the finance chief, Shelly Singhal.

headline: Citadel’s European Energy Head Resigns
text: Kenneth Griffin’s $13.5 billion hedge fund, the Citadel Investment Group, said Monday that Karl Robijns, the company’s head of European energy trading, had resigned. “He’s no longer with the firm,” Bryan Locke, a spokesman for Citadel, told The Chicago Tribune. Mr. Robijns joined Citadel in 2005 to begin the company’s European energy trading, according to SparkSpread, an energy and commodities news service.

headline: Residential Capital Plans $12.5 Billion Debt Offering
text: Residential Capital, a real estate finance company that is part of GMAC, filed with regulators on Tuesday to periodically sell up to $12.5 billion in senior debt securities and subordinated debt securities. In November, a group of investors led by Cerberus Capital Management acquired a majority stake in GMAC from General Motors for $14 billion.

headline: Behind Oracle’s Play for Agile
text: Agile Software had already seen two of its largest rivals snatched up before Oracle acquired it for $495 million. The Agile deal brings Oracle head-to-head with SAP in the manufacturing-related ERP software arena, The 451 Group wrote in a report. Back in August, when Agile’s stock was in the low $5 range, The 451 Group said that it expected the company to be acquired. Earlier this month, Oracle agreed to pay $8.10 a share for Agile.

headline: Kerkorian’s Vegas Moves Ignite Talk of MGM Deal
text: What is Kirk Kerkorian up to now?

headline: With $10 Million in Hand, Evergrid Goes to Market
text: Evergrid, a data center software developer, received $10 million in new third-round venture funding, which it will use to bring its first product to market. The latest investors including first-time backer Menlo Ventures and return investor Acartha Group.

headline: Tesla Motors Gets Battery Deal
text: Tesla Motors, the electric car start-up that has piqued the interest of stars like George Clooney, announced Tuesday that it had created a new division, the Tesla Energy Group, to sell batteries, and that it has received a $43 million order. Think, a Norwegian maker of electric cars, will buy lithium-ion battery packs from Tesla Energy. The deal, reported in the San Jose Mercury News, will bring Tesla $3 million this year and $40 million in 2008.

headline: Aeroflot Seeks Loan for Alitalia Bid
text: The Russian airline Aeroflot is seeking up to 900 million euros ($1.2 billion) in loans to finance its bid for all or part of the Italian national airline, Alitalia, in its first merger or acquisition effort outside the former Soviet Union.

headline: Cisco Spies Deal in Surveillance Software Maker
text: The networking equipment maker Cisco Systems said Tuesday it would buy privately-held BroadWare Technologies, a provider of Internet-based video surveillance software. Financial terms were not disclosed. The company said BroadWare’s software allows users to monitor, manage, record and store audio and video online, and helps customers gain access to live and recorded surveillance video for faster investigation response.

headline: Chevron Plans Offering of Dynegy Stake
text: Chevron, the oil behemoth, intends to sell what amounts to a stake of about 12 percent in the energy company Dynegy through a public stock offering. Chevron U.S.A. will offer 96.9 million Class A Dynegy shares in a sale that will be managed by Goldman Sachs.

headline: Boards More Likely to Oust Failing Chiefs
text: Corporate boards are nearly three times as likely to push out failing chief executives than they were a decade ago, a new study examining turnover among top executives has found. Nearly one of three chief executives who departed last year were either fired or forced out for performance-related reasons, according to the analysis by the global management consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton. That compared with roughly one in seven departing executives ousted in 1996.

headline: Paul Weiss Adds to Investment Funds Group
text: Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton & Garrison said it hired Jennifer A. Spiegel as counsel in its corporate department. Ms. Spiegel, previously of Debevoise & Plimpton, will be part of Paul Weiss’s investment funds group, which advises on fund organization, registration and compliance as well as the buying and selling of investment advisers. The investment funds group has grown to more than 20 lawyers, Paul Weiss said.

headline: Electronic Arts Takes Stake In Chinese Game Firm
text: In a deal that has been rumored for some time, Electronic Arts announced Monday that it is investing about $167 million to buy a 15 percent stake in The9, a Chinese video game company. As part of the deal, The9 acquired an exclusive license to publish E.A.’s “FIFA Online” soccer game in China.

headline: In Acxiom Deal, It’s Hedge Fund vs. Hedge Fund
text: When an activist hedge fund makes headlines, it’s generally raising a ruckus over a company’s poor management decisions. But now, two activist hedge funds seemed to poised to go head to head over a deal for software company Acxiom. MMI Investments, Acxiom’s second-largest shareholder, is objecting to the sale of the company to Acxiom’s largest shareholder, ValueAct, and the private equity firm Silver Lake.

headline: Headwinds for Home Depot’s Supply Auction?
text: Is Home Depot having trouble selling its supply unit? According to The New York Post, the softening housing market and other complications are creating challenges for Home Depot as it tries to find a buyer for its professional supply business.

headline: Unimpeachable Bravery
text: The legacy of the concentration camp survivor and Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal is one of unimpeachable bravery, but "I Have Never Forgotten You," a new documentary, is a suspect monument to his courage.

headline: British Airways Signs Onto Iberia Bidding Group
text: British Airways said Tuesday it had joined a consortium led by a private equity firm, the Texas Pacific Group, that is considering a bid for Spain’s Iberia airline. British Airways is Iberia’s largest shareholder, with a 10 percent stake, and some analysts saw the move as an attempt to retain some influence over Iberia.

headline: Buyout Bid for Outback Steakhouse Is Raised
text: OSI Restaurant Partners, which runs the Outback Steakhouse chain, said Tuesday a group including Bain Capital, Catterton Partners and OSI’s founders have raised their buyout offer by 3 percent to about $3.18 billion.

headline: 2008: Immigration Draws Out McCain
text: As he faces criticism from members of his own party over his immigration stance, Senator John McCain has begun to stress the differing positions of one of his chief G.O.P. rivals. For example, Michael Cooper reported on a three-pronged jab he took at Mitt Romney on the issue. Mr. McCain may also be feeling the competition from Mr. Romney, whose performance in polls in Iowa and New Hampshire is starting to match his stellar fund-raising capacity.

headline: Fighting Spam, Artistically
text: This isn’t usually a blog about art, let alone “installations.” But I thought you’d get a kick out of this one from artist Bill Shackelford.

headline: Graveyard Travels
text: As Americans choose cremation in record numbers, cemeteries are repositioning themselves for the afterlife: their own.

headline: Cooler Climate for NIMBYs?
text: Wind turbines next to a farm house in Kansas, U.S. Lawrence Journal/AP

headline: The Meaning of ‘Democrat’ in Montana
text: If any state symbolizes the new Democratic Congressional majority, it might be Montana: a former Republican bastion that now has two Democrats, Max Baucus and Jon Tester, in the Senate. Matt Singer at Left in the West however, is beginning to have qualms about the sort of Democrats that get elected in conservative states. He considers the two Montanans’ votes against the Reid-Feingold bill, which would have put a timeline on funding for the war in Iraq, to be partisan treason. There’s a couple problems with this — first and foremost, it’s misleading. As a staffer from one of their offices told me himself, there’s this whole false understanding that passing Feingold-Reid would literally mean that tanks in Iraq would start running out of gas and the like. That’s simply not true — and it’s not how our government actually operates. Our Senators shouldn’t perpetuate myths.Second, they’re both using common right-wing attacks to undermine progressive Democratic leadership. They could have both simply said, “My position is that the President and the Pentagon need to come up with a plan. This bill doesn’t accomplish that.” Instead, they threw in a gratuitous, “Leading members of my own party want to ‘pull out the rug’ on our troops in a way that ‘I believe compromises the safety and security of our troops on the ground.'” Those are Mitch McConnell’s talking points.

headline: A Week Among the Sites of Andalusia
text: A friend is providing a resort condo for 7 days in Malaga! There are 3 of us and we have a car with a GPS, but there is so much to choose from in the neighboring cities, towns & beaches. Please recommend an ideal itinerary to see the best of the best while we are in Andalusia. A few great restaurant recommendations would be much appreciated too.

headline: State Tax Discrimination
text: Taxing the other guy — not the locals who can vote in local elections –has obvious appeal to politicians. It helps to explain the widespread use of discriminatory taxing of municipal bond interest. If you live in New York, bonds issued by that state, and its cities and other agencies, are not subject to state income tax. But those issued by other states are.

headline: Wall Street Likes Kerkorian’s Odds
text: Whatever happens at MGM Mirage, it looks like Kirk Kerkorian will walk away a winner. That is what several analysts suggested Tuesday as they pondered Monday’s short but highly suggestive announcement by Tracinda, Mr. Kerkorian’s investment vehicle, that it would begin negotiating to buy two Las Vegas properties from MGM Mirage and consider alternatives for its majority stake in MGM. Mr. Kerkorian has already hit the jackpot, at least on paper. Shares of MGM Mirage surged 26 percent in early trading Tuesday to $79.32. As a result, the value of Mr. Kerkorian’s 56 percent stake in the casino company grew by $2.6 billion overnight.

headline: Siam meets Las Vegas
text: I’m not normally a fan of “cultural shows,” but Siam Niramit, a huge production of acrobatics and special effects (the producers somehow figured out how to recreate a tropical downpour onstage) is worth the trip. It’s sort of Thai culture meets Las Vegas.

headline: Life in the Fast Lane
text: Charlie LeDuff interviews Gloria Castillo during her shift at a Burger King in Dallas.

headline: Third Man in Russian Poisoning Case
text: Alexander V. Litvinenko, Andrei K. Lugovoi and Dmitri V. Kovtun met in London on Nov. 1. Within hours, Mr. Litvinenko would fall seriously ill, dying later that month from radiation poisoning. The other two would soon become a focus of the investigation.

headline: Fremont Sells Commercial Lending Arm
text: Fremont General, a California lender stung by recent weakness in the subprime mortgage market, said Tuesday it had agreed to sell its commercial lending business to iStar Financial for about $1.9 billion, leaving the company to focus on its retail operations. Fremont also said that it would sell a minority stake in the entire company to an investor group led by Gerald Ford, the former chief executive of Golden State Bancorp, who will become its new chairman.

headline: Is Jeff Immelt Done With Deal Making?
text: Speaking words that are bound to disappoint a few investment bankers, Jeffrey Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, said the giant conglomerate is likely to avoid big deals for the time being. Interviewed by The Financial Times after the announcement that a Saudi Arabian company would buy G.E.’s plastics business for about $11.6 billion, Mr. Immelt said, “I like the company in the current position. We will remain tough-minded about opportunities, but the sale of the plastics business is consistent with our strategy.” Instead, he indicated that the company will look to return excess cash to shareholders and expand its current lines of business.

headline: Making New Yorkers Stay Put
text: Silda Wall Spitzer, the governor’s wife, said this morning that she would hold a public meeting to examine why young people are leaving the state, particularly upstate. The “I Live New York” conference will take place on Sept. 19 at the State University of New York in Cortland, N.Y., with the goal of coming up with a plan to halt or at least slow the exodus.

headline: $10 Million Homes
Video: A Boomtown Revisited
text: The second video chronicling Nick’s journey across China is from our first stop on the Chinese Mainland. Dongguan about 50 miles north of Hong Kong and Nick had first visited here 20 years ago. He later returned to profile a communist party official.

headline: Two Hedge-Fund Heavies Host Obama
text: Presidential candidates in both parties have been wooing the Wall Street set in a big way this election season. Last Friday, it was the turn of Democrat Barack Obama, who touched down in Greenwich, Conn., the unofficial hub of the hedge fund set, for a pair of fundraisers. The first was co-hosted by George Soros, the financier and former hedge fund manager, and Paul Tudor Jones, who runs the giant hedge fund Tudor Investment Corporation. That event, held in Mr. Jones’s $25 million waterfront mansion — which Vanity Fair’s Nina Munk has described as a “a cross between Tara and a national monument” — collected $2,300 from each of the approximately 300 attendees, the Greenwich Time reported.

headline: The Inside-Out Lamburger
text: Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, grills a very un-American burger.

headline: Looking for In-Laws
text: Continuing his journey across China, Nicholas D. Kristof visits his wife's ancestral village.

headline: The Road From Yellow to Green Taxis
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s announcement today that the entire fleet of New York City taxicabs — more than 13,000 vehicles — will become all-hybrid by 2012 marks a reversal of his administration’s earlier slowness in embracing the issue.

headline: The Clinton Chronicles
text: Just as the presidential primaries are moving up on the calendar, so, too, are the publication dates of books about the race. And Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign may be most affected, as The Time’s Motoko Rich writes:

headline: CBS Buys Wallstrip, Going Long on Finance Humor
text: Wallstrip, the offbeat financial Web show whose host has been known to frolic with hogs for a segment on pork producer Premium Standard Farms, has found a home with Big Media. CBS on Tuesday confirmed that it bought the quirky start-up, whose backers include venture investor Fred Wilson, for an undisclosed price.

headline: The Buyout Boom, Now Even Boomier
text: The explosive growth of private equity deals is a well-documented trend by now, but some new numbers from Thomson Financial underscore just how enormous the volume of buyouts has become. Consider this: So far this year, the volume of global announced deals involving private equity firms is $447 billion, more than double the volume from the same period in 2006 — a year that was no slouch was far as buyouts were concerned. In the United States, the rise has been even sharper. At $281 billion, U.S. private equity deals have more than tripled from a year ago, boosted by the recent buyouts of Alltel, First Data and others.

headline: New Complaints in Gay-Bias Suit Against Law Firm
text: In the latest twist in a legal battle that’s starting to resemble a corkscrew, Aaron Charney, the former Sullivan & Cromwell associate who has sued the law firm alleging gay bias, added several charges to his complaint Monday. To his initial allegations of discrimination based on sexual orientation, Mr. Charney has added claims of emotional distress and conspiracy, according to the New York Law Journal. Before his suit caused a stir in legal circles, Mr. Charney had worked in the mergers and acquisitions group at one of the leading firms that advises in such deals.

headline: Google Trends: Hot or Not?
text: The 44th hottest trend in Google search right now is the phrase “Google Hot Trends.”

headline: The View From Muslim-Americans
text: The Pew Center for the People and the Press has released results from a new poll of Muslim Americans’ attitudes on the United States. Good news, according to the Dallas Morning News’s headline: “Poll: Most Muslim-Americans reject suicide bombings”

headline: Vive la Tin Snail
text: As French as the Eiffel Tower, or a smoke-filled bistro, the cheap and cheery Citroën 2CV was originally built to suit the basic transportation needs of country-dwellers. Somewhere along the way, and during its epic production run of 1948-90, the simple 2CV became a symbol of Gallic coolness. The car has a cultlike following and is affectionately known by a variety of nicknames, including “the tin snail,” “the duck,” or “the flying ragtop” because of its foldable canvas roof.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Tell Matt Where to Go in Georgia and Alabama
text: For the next 12 weeks, Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, will be on the road from New York City to Seattle. To make his journey a success, he needs your help. His next stops are in Georgia and Alabama.

headline: Rudy+John=Friends 4Ever
text: The feud between Senator John McCain and former Gov. Mitt Romney is heating up, but it seems the McCain-Giuliani Mutual Admiration Society is as strong as ever. While Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mr. McCain share a reputation for tough talk, they only seem to have the kindest of words for one another. Let’s take a look at a few examples:

headline: The Finer Points of the Immigration Bill
text: Julia Preston, The New York Times reporter who answered some immigration questions last week, today wrote an article that outlines the immigration bill before the Senate.

headline: Need-Blind Immigration
text: Readers respond to David Brooks’s May 22 column, “America’s Admissions System.”

headline: Income Gap? More of a Chasm
text: Readers respond to Bob Herbert’s May 22 column, “American Cities and the Great Divide.“

headline: New York City Taxis to Be Slightly Less Filthy
text: Our colleagues over at The Empire Zone are all over this story about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan, announced today, to replace New York City’s entire taxi fleet with hybrid vehicles in the next five years. The Times’s Sewell Chan writes:

headline: The Frugal Traveler Hits the Road
text: Matt Gross packs up the 1989 Volvo station wagon he bought on Craigslist and heads out for a three-month trip across the continental U.S.

headline: Modern Art and Old Rome (1): Schnabel
text: Of course everyone comes here to see the old stones. But this month you can take in Roman history and terrific modern art exhibits in one go. Check out the Julian Schnabel exhibit that just opened in Palazzo Venezia, a grand decaying building that was the first great Renaissance palace in Rome, and later served as a residence for Italian Dictator Benito Mussolini. Schnabel’s humongous bright abstract paintings are literally leaned up against the chipping frescos of the palace’s cave-like chandeliered rooms. The contrast is perfect. In another room, Schnabel’s large glossy signature portraits are hung over sullied frescos of Roman seals and columns.

headline: That Other Kentucky Horserace
text: Yes, the Preakness Stakes outdid the Kentucky Derby in terms of excitement this year with Curlin’s come-from-behind victory. Then again, we’re just as happy to watch another horserace in Kentucky today, this one featuring an impressive story of political recovery—even if it’s only temporary.

headline: ‘A Song, and a Dance’
text: The Senate Republicans gathered today at a news conference with law enforcement officers from around the state to demand that Gov. Eliot Spitzer push the Assembly to pass a bill reinstating the death penalty for cop killers. Afterward, Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, said that he had already spoken “very directly” to his Assembly counterpart, Speaker Sheldon Silver, about moving a death penalty bill to the Assembly floor for a vote.

headline: Giuliani’s Touchdown in Albany
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani swung by Albany today to receive the support of a wide swath of New York state senators and members of the assembly. Well, not so much Albany — he flew into a private air terminal, run by the company Million Air, at Albany’s airport, received the endorsements and some enthusiastic praise, then got back on his jet and flew off again.Among other things, the former New York City mayor said the Democratic candidates running for president did not understand the threat of Islamic terrorism and that state Republicans would find a way to retake control of the Assembly, a task that would require them to add a couple of dozen seats to the 40-odd controlled by the Republicans today.

headline: Brooklyn’s Sweetest Landmark?
text: The city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission voted today to schedule a hearing on whether to designate the former Domino sugar processing plant in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn as a landmark. The decision today, which was made in a unanimous vote, is the first of three steps required to make a building a landmark in New York City. Next, the commission will hold a hearing, then a final vote.

headline: The Dynasty Continues
text: One of the great privileges of this job is the annual media game at Yankee Stadium and Fenway Park. Once a year, early in the morning, the Yankees and the Red Sox open their doors to let the New York media take on the Boston media. It’s real hardball: umpires, scoreboards, music, a post-game food spread, the works. Everything but those annoying writers asking us questions after the game.

headline: Glavine Not Looking Too Far Ahead
text: In the chat that he inevitably has with Atlanta/New York reporters on the first day of a series down here, Tom Glavine said that victory No. 300 “seems much more in reach than it did before.”

headline: Bush Wars: The Final Frontier
text: With the title of his 1980 book, the journalist Sidney Blumenthal coined a term that has entered the political lexicon: “The Permanent Campaign.” The phrase denotes the blurring of the line in modern times between campaigning and governing. Presidents, of course, have always made decisions with an eye on their popularity. But with the advent of television, polling, and professional consultants, presidents of the 1970s and ’80s—Nixon, Carter, and Reagan in particular—upped the ante by devoting the full arsenal of modern electioneering tools not just to winning office but to holding office as well.Recently, the permanent campaign has added yet another stage—a final frontier. This is the fight for history, centered on the presidents’ libraries. The presidential libraries date from 1939, when Franklin Delano Roosevelt conceived his as a repository for his public papers, to be built with private funds and run by public officials. Since then, chief executives have sought to outdo their predecessors by entombing their archives in extravagant, self-memorializing shrines. These museums extend the permanent campaign by utilizing the same public relations techniques as a race for the White House—and lately requiring comparable fundraising efforts to boot.

headline: U.S. Championship, Round 8: Onischuk and Shabalov Retain Lead
text: Alexander Onischuk and Alexander Shabalov drew their games today but retained their lead in the Frank Berry U.S. Championship in Stillwater, Okla. Three grandmasters — Sergey Kudrin, Gregory Kaidanov and Yury Shulman, last year’s runner-up — trailed by half a point with only one round to go. All the games can be seen live or replayed here at Monroi.com.

headline: Move Over Youngsters
text: Oh, so you want red wine? How does ’29 sound, as in 1929? That’s right, and I’m talking Beaujolais. You know, that light, fruity inconsequential red that’s best drunk within a couple of years. Now let’s move onto something serious.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Maryland and North Caro
text: The Frugal Traveler visits a classic diner in Baltimore and explores two sides of Latino culture in North Carolina.

headline: Israelis Don’t Want Gaza to Be Their Next Lebanon
text: JERUSALEM, May 22  For the government of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, badly battered by last summer’s inconclusive war against the rockets of Hezbollah, launched from Lebanon, the rocket fire from the Gaza Strip seems a similarly intractable problem with no easy, popular response.

headline: Triplex Penthouse at the Plaza Hotel Set to Sell for $56 Million
text: In an era of ever more expensive apartments in Manhattan, a triplex penthouse condominium in the Plaza Hotel has gone into contract for $56 million, in what would quite likely be the most expensive Manhattan apartment sale to date when it closes later this year, according to several real estate executives briefed on the transaction.

headline: Bush Says Al Qaeda Seeks Haven in Iraq
text: NEW LONDON, Conn., May 23 — President Bush, addressing head-on the criticism that Iraq has turned into another Vietnam, argued today that withdrawing from Iraq would be dangerous because, unlike the enemy in Vietnam, terrorists in Iraq have the capability and desire to strike Americans at home.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the Inside Art column in Weekend on May 4 about the entry of Merchandise Mart Properties, a Chicago company, into the art business misstated the name of one of the company’s buildings in New York. It is the Architects & Designers Building on East 58th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, not the Design & Decoration Building. (A building called the Decoration & Design Building, on Third Avenue between 58th and 59th Streets, is owned by the Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation.)

headline: Mayor Plans an All-Hybrid Taxi Fleet
text: The spacious but gas-guzzling Ford Crown Victoria, long the emblematic vehicle of the city’s yellow cab fleet, would be replaced by cleaner, more fuel-efficient hybrid vehicles under a five-year plan proposed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday.

headline: Propping Up the General
text: It seems the more unpopular Pakistan’s military dictator, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, becomes at home and the less he is willing to fight the Taliban, the more the Bush administration clings to him.

headline: Action Hero Breaks Summer’s Fantasy Spell
text: LOS ANGELES, May 22 — When last seen, in 1995, the New York super-cop John McClane, alter ego of the actor Bruce Willis, was performing barehanded bomb disposal on a downtown train and parrying racist attitude from his partner, Samuel L. Jackson, as he put away a batch of Germanic baddies led by the distinctly British Jeremy Irons.

headline: Hedge Fund Figure Leaves Merrill Lynch
text: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that Ben Weston, the chief of its hedge fund development and management group, left the firm after two years.

headline: Normal Relations With Hamas? (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Frustrated Pettitte Stews About His Missed Chances
text: The Yankees could not have asked for much more from Andy Pettitte than what they have gotten so far. Pettitte’s earned run average, 2.83, ranked ninth in the American League going into last night’s games, and his body has held up in a season full of injuries to Yankees starters.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about a recent migration of Orthodox Jews to Waterbury, Conn., a struggling and heavily Roman Catholic city, misidentified the New York county that is home to the town of Kiryas Joel, another Orthodox enclave. It is Orange, not Rockland.

headline: The Vineyard, the Barrel and Full Disclosure
text: THE natural, pastoral image of wine is one of its greatest marketing strengths. You’ve seen the ads — all about meadows and rolling hills and sunny skies and convivial companions. The production of wine, too, connotes an agrarian world of picturesque vineyards, wooden barrels and sage craftsmen.

headline: Pass the Clam Dip
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Female Shark Reproduced Without Male DNA, Scientists Say
text: A hammerhead shark that gave birth in a Nebraska aquarium reproduced without mating, a genetic analysis shows.

headline: What You Get for ... $10 Million
text: Miami Beach, Fla.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Understand the South, Y’all, Even the Puzzling Parts
text: Ever since Roy Blount Jr. packed his bags and left the South nearly 40 years ago, he has been stuck with the job of explaining himself and his people to Northeastern liberals. It hasn’t been easy getting past the redneck, racist, raving fundamentalist stereotypes, patiently explaining that “y’all” is always plural and insisting that, amazingly enough, he does not really care about car racing.

headline: China Arrests 28 on ‘Instigating Riots’ Charges
text: BEIJING, May 23 — Police in southwestern China arrested 28 people on charges that they instigated riots last weekend over family planning controls. But the government also dispatched officials to the region to “deal with complaints” about the area’s strict measures to enforce birth control measures, reports in state-run news media said today.

headline: Letters
text: In Defense of Truffle Oil

headline: For the Love of a Good Burger
text: I’M sure you know how to make a burger. But do you make a burger you love, one that people notice, one that draws raves?

headline: Unflinching Indulgences From Belgium
text: IT’S time for a quiz. A diagnostic test, really. This one is best taken on an empty stomach, with a napkin and a defibrillator at hand.

headline: A Voyage to Olympus for Young Mortals
text: The Cyclops, hairy and forbidding, arrived last week. Aristotle, literally a talking head, took his place early this month. The Trojan horse, 13 feet tall, came in April. But Odysseus — the voyaging warrior and undisputed hero of this scene — won’t make his grand entrance until Friday.

headline: Project’s Foes Shown Door in Brooklyn
text: The letter arrived in Marilyn Oliva’s mailbox yesterday from the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz. It thanked her for her dedication to the community as a member of Community Board 6, but informed her that her services were no longer needed.

headline: Recipe: Quick Basque Rillettes Sandwich
text: 1/2 red bell pepper, seeded, ribs removed

headline: Alcan Rejects a Hostile Bid From Alcoa
text: OTTAWA, May 22  The Canadian aluminum producer Alcan rejected a $27.4 billion hostile bid from a rival, Alcoa, on Tuesday, calling the offer inadequate. Alcan said that it was in talks with other companies and added that it was considering the possibility of turning the tables with a counterbid for Alcoa.

headline: Trenton: Troopers’ Union Chief Suspended
text: The state police yesterday suspended the head of the troopers’ union, Detective David Jones, for five days because he revealed a radio talk show host’s personal details to reporters this month, the union announced. The suspension came after an investigation by the state attorney general. On May 3, Detective Jones showed reporters a piece of paper containing the home address of the host, Craig Carton  half of the team known as the Jersey Guys  along with Mr. Carton’s license plate number and the make and model of his car, the investigation found. The detective’s actions came after Mr. Carton and his co-host disclosed Web postings by state troopers that threatened a “ticket blitz” in response to criticism of troopers’ role in a car crash involving Gov. Jon S. Corzine in April. Mr. Jones did not use law enforcement databases to obtain Mr. Carton’s information, according to the attorney general’s office.

headline: Louisiana Court Backs Death in Child Rape
text: The Louisiana Supreme Court yesterday upheld the death sentence of a man convicted of raping an 8-year-old girl. Legal experts say the man, Patrick Kennedy, is the only inmate on death row in the United States who was not convicted of committing or participating in a killing.

headline: Brooklyn: Probation for Fake Veterinarian
text: A man charged with operating on animals without a license was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to probation and mandatory psychiatric treatment. The man, Steven Vassall, 29, was accused of botching surgery on a Boston terrier. His case drew worldwide publicity for the involvement of a so-called undercover cat named Fred, used in a sting operation by the district attorney’s office. Mr. Vassall was sentenced after pleading guilty to scheming to defraud and to the unauthorized practice of veterinary medicine. Under the terms of a plea bargain, he must attend an outpatient mental health program five days a week and refrain from involvement in nursing or animal care.

headline: Ex-Writer Guilty of Kidnapping and Sex Attack
text: A former fashion writer was convicted today of a bizarre crime in which he posed as a firefighter and tied up and sexually abused a Manhattan woman he barely knew.

headline: Scores for Yonkers Students Drop on State English Test
text: Of New York State’s five largest school systems, Yonkers was the only one whose students performed worse this year than last on the state’s standardized English tests even as test scores rose statewide, according to data released yesterday.

headline: Ex-Gonzales Aide Testifies She ‘Crossed the Line’
text: WASHINGTON, May 23 — The Justice Department’s former liaison to the White House testified before Congress today that she improperly weighed political factors in considering applicants for career positions in the department, and she said she was sorry.

headline: Corrections
text: Editors’ Note

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Monday about Anthony Brooks, a British undercover agent in France in World War II, misidentified a German armored division he sabotaged, and its commander at the time. It was the Second SS Panzer-Division, not the Second Panzer Division. It was commanded by Heinz Lammerding — not Heinz Guderian, who had been promoted to another job.

headline: Atlanta Plans to Overhaul Narcotics Unit
text: ATLANTA May 22  Chief Richard J. Pennington announced 140 personnel changes in the Atlanta Police Department on Tuesday, including an overhaul of the narcotics unit, which has been under scrutiny since November, when an elderly woman was shot and killed in a botched drug raid.

headline: Google Investing in Company Started by Co-Founder’s Wife
text: SAN FRANCISCO, MAY 22  In Silicon Valley’s version of “The Bachelor,” Anne Wojcicki not only landed one of America’s richest men, Sergey Brin, a co-founder of Google, but she also got her husband’s company to finance her start-up.

headline: Bombing Kills Six in Turkish Capital’s Shopping District
text: DENIZLI, Turkey, May 22 — A powerful explosion tore into a shopping district in Ankara on Tuesday, killing six people and wounding more than 70 in the most lethal attack in this country in months, Turkish officials said.

headline: Home Depot to Investors: Mea Culpa
text: It was, as even Home Depot executives will concede, a 37-minute fiasco.

headline: Shifting Madison Square Garden
text: For more than 40 years, New Yorkers and their visitors have mourned the replacement of one of the city’s grand Beaux-Arts palaces with today’s dreary Penn Station. Now, an appealing proposal for a new train station and development of the area gives Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Mayor Michael Bloomberg the best opportunity in a very long time to correct this historic architectural blunder.

headline: Senate Votes to Keep Temporary Worker Program
text: WASHINGTON, May 22  A comprehensive immigration bill survived a significant test on Tuesday as the Senate voted to keep a provision that would let hundreds of thousands of temporary foreign workers enter the country each year.

headline: Developing Ports of Many Modes
text: For decades, New Jersey developers have been recycling worn-out warehouses near the Hudson River into chic condos and fashionable retail centers. In cities like Hoboken, Jersey City and Weehawken, the value of a view of the Manhattan skyline across a milewide stretch of water overwhelms a site’s value as a functional place to store and repackage goods.

headline: Nominee to Head Consumer Agency Withdraws
text: WASHINGTON, May 23 — President Bush’s nominee to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission withdrew his name from consideration today, as a growing number of senators questioned both his suitability and a $150,000 departure payment that the National Association of Manufacturers was preparing to pay him. The nominee, Michael E. Baroody, is a senior lobbyist for the association.

headline: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
For Liverpool Player, a Detour Leads Right to the Big Game
text: One of the most important players on the field for today’s European Champions League final between Liverpool and A.C. Milan began the season in Brazil, moved to a struggling English Premier League team in a controversial transfer deal and will find himself marking Kaká, one of the game’s most dynamic and explosive players, in the match in Athens.

headline: To Preserve a House, a Plan to Move It
text: It seemed destined for the wrecking ball, like so many other midcentury buildings by the architect Paul Rudolph.

headline: Furious Street Battles Remind Lebanon of Its Past
text: NAHR AL BARED REFUGEE CAMP, Lebanon, May 22  The stark reality of the three-day battle in this seaside refugee camp became apparent Tuesday on a drive through the area during a brief but dangerous lull in the fighting.

headline: Russia: Mine Officials Who Turned a Blind Eye to Safety Are Fired
text: The authorities dismissed five mine safety officials for allowing a Siberian coal mine to “break safety rules for the benefit of profit,” an action they said led to an explosion in March that killed 108 miners, the biggest mine disaster in Russia’s recent history. An investigation showed that the mine’s managers deliberately disabled a methane gas detector. A buildup of methane, sparked by a short circuit, caused the blast. The dismissals, reported by the Interfax news agency, were an exception to the usual blanket impunity enjoyed by government officials.

headline: Finding Poetry in the Position Paper
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton weighed in on universal pre-K this week. Senator John McCain outlined his views on ethics in government. Next week, Senator Barack Obama is expected to detail his proposals for expanding health coverage.

headline: Demand and Costs Rise for Best Cuts
text: AT $42, a nicely charred 16-ounce slab of prime boneless strip loin might not seem like much of a bargain now, but it could soon.

headline: Bubonic Plague Kills a Monkey at the Denver Zoo
text: DENVER, May 22  The death of a monkey at the Denver Zoo from bubonic plague has prompted officials to change the habitats of some zoo animals and renew efforts to keep visitors from feeding the urban wildlife here.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: An article in Business Day on May 15 reported that law enforcement authorities in Switzerland had begun a criminal investigation into possible money laundering at BAE Systems, the British military contractor. It noted a report in The Guardian, a British daily, that said Swiss investigators could examine accounts held by Wafic Said, a Syrian financier who helped broker a $79 billion arms contract between BAE Systems and Saudi Arabia two decades ago. Mr. Said could not be reached by The Times before the article was published.

headline: Laughing and Crying
text: First I had to laugh. Then I had to cry.

headline: Tolerating the New Tunes, but Exulting in the Old
text: A few minutes into its sold-out concert at the Beacon Theater on Monday night, Steely Dan uncorked a song of recent vintage. It was “Godwhacker,” from the band’s 2003 album, “Everything Must Go” (Reprise), and the lyrics blithely gestured toward a tale of vengeance, pursuit and, well, deicide. When the chorus arrived, Donald Fagen and a pair of backup singers offered a cryptic admonition:

headline: Middletown: Child Bitten by Coyote
text: Police officers and state wildlife officials set traps yesterday to catch a coyote that bit a 5-year-old boy in the face and neck on Monday night, the second time in two months that a coyote had attacked a child in Middletown. The boy, Brayden Gazette, required 46 stitches and rabies shots. Police officers fired a shotgun at the coyote, but could not tell if they had hit it, said Robert M. Czech, the township administrator. On April 6, a 20-month-old boy was bitten by a coyote in another section of the township, but was not seriously injured.

headline: Canada: Nortel Settles Accounting Fraud Investigation
text: Nortel Networks said it would pay 1 million Canadian dollars ($921,000) as part of a settlement with the Ontario Securities Commission. The payment is not a fine. The company called it a contribution toward the cost of the commission’s investigation into accounting irregularities at the company from 2000 to 2003. Nortel, the communications equipment maker, acknowledged in the agreement that its senior executives had improperly altered accounting policies and provisions to improve the company’s apparent financial performance. Under the agreement, the company must give the commission special quarterly and annual reports on efforts to improve its accounting controls. Nortel fired its chief executive, Frank A. Dunn, and two other executives over the bookkeeping issues in 2004. The former executives face separate charges by the Ontario regulator. The Securities and Exchange Commission has also charged the three as well as other former Nortel employees. Law enforcement officials in both Canada and the United States are also investigating the company.

headline: How to Win the Energy War
text: With gas prices hitting yet another all-time high, consider this: while history is littered with examples of countries that were forced to change their domestic and foreign policies because of the lack of a natural resource, there are very few notable instances of nations that had the ability to eliminate such a vulnerability but didn’t. America’s current energy condition, however, is a spectacular example of such a failure. Consider four facts:

headline: Landis’s Character Is the Focus of Questioning
text: MALIBU, Calif., May 22  One of the most prominent doping cases in sports history is coming down to a crank call, a black suit and a beer or two.

headline: 10 Horses Killed in Rockland County Barn Fire
text: CHESTNUT RIDGE, N.Y., May 23  Ten horses died in a barn fire here early this morning and two were rescued by the barn’s owner, the police said.

headline: Summery, Smoky and Spicy: Nudging Spinach Dip Upward
text: UPON accepting an invitation to a barbecue several years ago, I asked the hostess if I could bring anything. “Sure,” she said. “How about spinach dip? It’s easy and everyone loves it.”

headline: The Few, the Proud, the Dartmouth-Bound
text: When he first met James Wright, the president of Dartmouth College, two years ago, Samuel Crist was in a hospital bed at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., recuperating from gunshot wounds from a firefight in Falluja, Iraq.

headline: Queens: Man Charged in Sex Attack
text: A Jamaica man has been charged with holding an acquaintance captive in his family’s garage and sexually assaulting her, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Joseph Burrell, 44, of 171st Street, was arraigned last weekend on charges of attempted rape, criminal sexual acts and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Burrell lured a 42-year-old woman to his family’s furnished garage by inviting her to a barbecue last Wednesday and attacked her, beating her and smashing a glass object on her, then tried to rape and sodomize her.

headline: Romance Over, Union Chief Has Corzine’s Number
text: When contract negotiations between Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s administration and New Jersey’s seven major state employee unions reached a standstill last fall, one union president, Carla Katz, sent a message to the governor’s private e-mail address with a personal appeal to revive the talks.

headline: India: Viacom Forms Joint Media Venture
text: Viacom and an Indian media company, the TV18 Group, said they would jointly create Viacom-18, a television, film and digital media company. Viacom-18 will start a Hindi-language entertainment channel later this year, and Viacom’s MTV Networks, which is already present in India, will become part of the joint venture. Viacom’s movie studios, DreamWorks and Paramount Pictures, will look for opportunities in India over the next few months, Viacom said. "India is one of Viacom’s priority markets for expansion internationally," Philippe P. Dauman, above, the president and chief executive of Viacom, said during a news conference in Mumbai.

headline: A Federal Failure at the Ground Zero Cleanup (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gay and Dissident Bishops Excluded From ’08 Meeting
text: The archbishop of Canterbury sent out more than 800 invitations yesterday to a once-a-decade global gathering of Anglican bishops. But he did not invite the openly gay Episcopal bishop of New Hampshire and the bishop in Virginia who heads a conservative cluster of disaffected American churches affiliated with the archbishop of Nigeria.

headline: Court Upholds Suspension of Student in Video Case
text: SEATTLE, May 22  Gregory Requa is not the annoying young man caught on camera making rabbit ears and thrusting his hips behind Joyce Mong’s back. Nor is he the student who admitted to secretly filming Ms. Mong’s English class at Kentridge High School to mock its clutter, her hygiene and to capture the teacher at unbecoming angles.

headline: Plaintiffs Gain in Effort to See Police Spy Reports
text: Civil liberties lawyers overcame major hurdles yesterday in their efforts to force the city to release raw intelligence reports detailing the Police Department’s surveillance and infiltration of protest groups leading to the 2004 Republican National Convention.

headline: Insurers Settle Ground Zero Damage Claims
text: The Spitzer administration announced the settlement of all insurance claims at ground zero today, ensuring that $4.55 billion will be available for rebuilding the World Trade Center site.

headline: Stanley Miller, Who Examined Origins of Life, Dies at 77
text: Stanley L. Miller, a scientist whose spectacular discovery as a young graduate student pioneered the study of the origin of life on earth, died Sunday at a hospital near his home in National City, Calif. He was 77.

headline: Ethiopia Releases Detained Times Journalists
text: Three journalists for The New York Times were arrested by the Ethiopian military on May 16 in the Ogaden region of the country, held for five days and interrogated at gunpoint, and then released Monday without any charges being lodged against them, The Times said yesterday.

headline: The Vegans and Their Children (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: 3 Global Financial Institutions’ Roles Questioned
text: WASHINGTON, May 22  The crisis has ended over Paul D. Wolfowitz, the president of the World Bank who resigned last week. But the bank’s identity crisis has just begun.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article yesterday about efforts by Brett Myers, a pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, to change his life since being charged with assaulting his wife referred incorrectly to the timing of the alleged altercation. It was last June, not August. (A court date in the case had been scheduled for August.)

headline: ESPN’s Nice Guys May End Up Finishing First
text: The first time Mike Greenberg, a self-titled sportscasting metrosexual, met his ESPN Radio partner, Mike Golic, he said to himself, “Will you look at this big, fat, disgusting slob.”

headline: New York Eighth Graders Show Gains in Reading
text: The number of eighth graders reading at grade level or above in New York State climbed impressively this year for the first time since 1999, when the state adopted tougher educational standards and its modern testing system, according to scores released yesterday from the annual statewide English exam.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in some copies on Saturday about an open house at the Islamic Center of South Jersey in Palmyra, the mosque where four of the six men accused of plotting to kill soldiers at Fort Dix had worshiped, misstated the date of their arrests. It was May 7, not May 10.

headline: Edwards to Discuss Diplomacy and U.S. Military Policy
text: John Edwards, the Democratic presidential candidate, plans today to outline his views on military policy, with a call for greater international strategic partnerships, more aggressive use of diplomacy in place of armed intervention and the creation of a 10,000-member reserve corps to help stabilize troubled nations.

headline: Picture a Pollock Painted by Harps
text: In an alternate universe where the avant-garde works of the 1950s and ’60s found a huge and enthusiastic audience, the program Petr Kotik conducted on Monday at Zankel Hall might have been a pops concert.

headline: Veteran Facing Deportation Wins Hearing for Freedom
text: NEWARK, May 22 — A veteran of the Persian Gulf war of 1991 who has been in custody for three years while United States immigration officials have tried to deport him has been granted a hearing to determine if he is being held legally.

headline: Democrats Find Ethics Overhaul Elusive in House
