text: WASHINGTON, May 22  House Democratic leaders pushing a promised lobbying overhaul are facing resistance from balky lawmakers and fending off accusations that a prominent member is flouting new ethics rules.

headline: Corzine Weighs New Plan to Retain State Toll Roads
text: PRINCETON, N.J., May 22  Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey said Tuesday that he was considering a plan that could generate billions of dollars from such state assets as toll roads without ceding control to private companies.

headline: A Staple From Quebec, Embarrassing but Adored
text: DURING the 2000 presidential campaign, the candidate from Texas fielded a question from Canada: “Prime Minister Jean Poutine said you look like the man who should lead the free world into the 21st century. What do you think about that?”

headline: U.S. Trying to Identify Body Found in Iraq
text: MAHMUDIYA, Iraq, May 23 — The American military started examining a body found in the Euphrates River on Wednesday that Iraqi authorities and local residents believe is one of three American soldiers seized in an ambush on May 12.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Buy Real Estate Trust
text: Morgan Stanley agreed yesterday to buy the Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, an investment trust founded by the Texas billionaire Richard Rainwater, for $2.78 billion.

headline: Hague Court Inquiry Focuses on Rapes
text: DAKAR, Senegal, May 22 — The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague said Tuesday that he would investigate human rights violations committed during a brutal crackdown after a coup attempt in the Central African Republic in 2002 and 2003.

headline: Demotions a Source of Motivation for Youkilis
text: With his shaved head hidden under his helmet but his bushy beard exposed, Kevin Youkilis of the Red Sox dug his feet deep in the batter’s box against Mike Mussina of the Yankees in the first inning of last night’s game at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Clinton Staff Memo Urged Skipping Iowa
text: WASHINGTON, May 23 — In an indication of how the shifting calendar is forcing the presidential candidates to rethink their strategies, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign considered — and rejected — a plan to stop competing in Iowa, the traditional kickoff state in the nominating process, and to concentrate instead on later states including the 20 that will vote on a single day in early February.

headline: Guatemala: Adoption Protocol Endorsed
text: Lawmakers endorsed an international adoption protocol under pressure from the United States, which has said it will cease allowing Guatemalan children to be adopted by American parents unless reforms are made in Guatemala’s largely privatized system. That system has been heavily criticized by international human rights organizations for the high cost charged to adoptive parents and for payments that are sometimes made to girls and women who are putting their children up for adoption. But real changes will not come until Congress passes a law implementing the requirements of the protocol, called the Hague Convention on Intercountry Adoption. The treaty calls for counties to set up a central adoption authority, which has been controversial in Guatemala because of the political clout of private attorneys who now manage adoptions.

headline: Wall-to-Wall Books, and All of Them for the Landlord
text: The line outside the Gotham Book Mart in Midtown snaked down the block yesterday morning. Several dozen eager bargain hunters, book dealers, art collectors and former employees of the storied shop waited to bid on a piece of literary history.

headline: Iran Isolates Jailed U.S. Scholar Charged With Revolution Plot
text: Swiss diplomats seeking to visit Haleh Esfandiari, a leading Iranian-American academic jailed in Iran, have not been given access to her, the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars said yesterday.

headline: Germany: Investor Confidence on the Rise
text: German investor confidence rose to an 11-month high in May as company profits surged and economists raised their forecasts for growth this year. The Center for European Economic Research in Mannheim said its index of investor and analyst expectations increased to 24, the highest since June, from 16.5 in April. The center, known by the German acronym ZEW, said a gauge of investors’ assessment of the current situation rose to a record 88 from 76.9 last month.

headline: American Express or Visas?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Baghdad Truck Bomb Kills 25 and Wounds 100 Others
text: BAGHDAD, May 22  A truck laden with explosives detonated near a market in southwestern Baghdad on Tuesday, killing 25 people and wounding more than 100 in the latest setback for the American-led effort to stabilize this capital city.

headline: It’s Not That the Boss Seems Distant. It’s Just That He Doesn’t Exist.
text: To describe “The Boss of It All,” Lars von Trier’s acidic corporate comedy, as “ ‘The Office’ Viewed Through the Looking Glass” only scratches the surface of the newest film from one of the foremost tricksters of world cinema. At the outset Mr. von Trier, shown standing behind a window, disingenuously announces that the movie is “a comedy and harmless as such: no preaching or swaying of opinion.”

headline: Nascar Plans to Use New Car Full Time in ’08
text: Nascar will use the Car of Tomorrow in all 36 Nextel Cup races next season after officials announced yesterday that they had decided to scrap plans to phase in the new racecar over three years.

headline: Fire in Baltimore Row House Kills 6 People and Injures 7
text: BALTIMORE, May 22  A fire tore through an East Baltimore row house Tuesday morning, killing six people, including three children, and injuring seven others, the authorities said.

headline: ‘60 Minutes’ Creator Takes on Rockettes
text: The “Radio City Christmas Spectacular,” featuring the Rockettes, Santa Claus and a parade of wooden soldiers, will be shown almost in its entirety in a prime-time special on NBC in early December, in what Radio City and the network said yesterday was the first such broadcast in the show’s 75-year history.

headline: Dining Briefs
text: NEW PLACES

headline: To Sleep, Nay, Perchance to Stay Wide Awake
text: Not sleeping is unpleasantly hallucinatory  a perpetually interrupted story suffused with nasty little phantasms and blurs and set to a cloying medley of half-remembered music. “Wide Awake,” the documentary about insomnia on HBO tonight, is true to this experience.

headline: Savannah Adds to the Master Plan of 1733
text: SAVANNAH, Ga.  As one of the oldest planned cities in the country, Savannah is known for compact, walkable streets and beautifully landscaped historic squares. Designed by the city’s founder, James Oglethorpe, in 1733, it has remained largely intact even as electricity and cars were introduced, though buildings have changed uses over time.

headline: Helped by Imports, Busch Raises Forecast
text: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said yesterday that profit would rise more than forecast this year on higher sales of imported beers and fewer discounts of Bud Light and Michelob.

headline: Trying to Find the Upside After a Scandal
text: FOR decades, the Marsh & McLennan Companies relied on word of mouth and personal relationships to maintain a client roster of the biggest corporations and to bring in new business. And it grew into the world’s largest insurance broker.

headline: N.F.L. Welcomes Whistle-Blowers on Concussions
text: NASHVILLE, May 22  After the 2011 Super Bowl was awarded to Arlington, Tex., on Tuesday, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell addressed a variety of issues, including the handling and treatment of concussions.

headline: NBC’s ‘Dateline,’ Its Ratings in Decline, Releases Its Longtime Anchor
text: With an eye toward costs, NBC News yesterday released one of its longtime news anchors, Stone Phillips, announcing that he was leaving the network and would no longer appear on the newsmagazine program “Dateline.”

headline: Portland Wins Lottery and Can Pick the Prize
text: SECAUCUS, N.J., May 22 — It was a bad night to be one of the N.B.A.’s worst teams. The league held its draft lottery Tuesday, and the three teams that finished with the worst records were bumped out of the draft’s top spots.

headline: Tracking an Online Trend, and a Route to Suicide
text: SEOUL, South Korea, May 22  From their nondescript sixth-floor office, Kim Hee-joo and five other social workers troll the Internet to combat a disturbing trend in South Korea: people using the Web to trade tips about suicide and, in some cases, to form suicide pacts.

headline: Marian Radke-Yarrow, Child Psychology Researcher, Dies at 89
text: Marian Radke-Yarrow, a researcher in child psychology who conducted many influential studies on a range of sensitive issues  including prejudice among elementary school pupils, depression in very young children and indications of altruistic impulses even in 1-year-olds  died on Saturday at her home in Bethesda, Md. She was 89.

headline: Court Says Paramilitary Commander Must Be Tried in U.S. Before Returning to Haiti
text: Facing deportation to Haiti, where he is wanted for murder, the onetime commander of a paramilitary group was instead ordered in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday to stand trial on charges of grand larceny.

headline: Low-Maintenance Yards
text: When landscaping his second home in Santa Fe, N.M., Brad Bealmear knew that a lush green lawn wasn’t a feasible option for a harsh desert environment. Inspired by the expansive views of pinon and juniper trees surrounding his three-bedroom house, he planted native vegetation and brought in drought-resistant shrubs like chamisa. “Water is getting more expensive and more scarce,” Mr. Bealmear said. “But now we don’t have to worry about the yard. It’s low maintenance.”

headline: As Comrades Search, Fatal Bomb Wreaks Havoc
text: MAHMUDIYA, Iraq, May 22 — The ground exploded under an ashen sky at dawn. Dust, dirt, blood and military equipment filled the air, clearing after several seconds to reveal a frenzied scene of horror.

headline: Antimissile Test Comes Amid Financing Debate
text: WASHINGTON, May 22  With Congress considering cutting the Pentagon’s budget for missile defenses and Europe on edge over Bush administration proposals to deploy the system to the continent, much is riding on a test scheduled in the next few days of the antimissile shield based in California and Alaska.

headline: Parent of Outback Chain Accepts Higher Bid
text: OSI Restaurant Partners, owner of the Outback Steakhouse chain, has agreed to a higher $3.1 billion takeover offer from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and Catterton Partners.

headline: To Cut the Mustard, and More
text: A SUNNY Sunday in spring, and the outdoors beckoned. Armed with a picnic, my husband and I headed for the Cloisters and Fort Tryon Park.

headline: Armstrong Strategy, but He Isn’t Armstrong
text: Floyd Landis demanded an open hearing to dupe the public with his quaint props, with a symbolic yellow tie under his shirt collar, with his mother in the courtroom wearing a bonnet, with his father all but ready to churn butter for the jury.

headline: Wine Calendar
text: Dinner, With Commentary

headline: Reorganizing the Schools (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Calendar
text: All About Cheese

headline: Intel to Form a Flash Memory Venture With a Swiss Company
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 22  In a move to shed an unprofitable business as its turnaround gains traction, the Intel Corporation announced Tuesday that it would join with STMicroelectronics, a Swiss semiconductor maker, to form a new company to sell flash memory chips.

headline: Illinois: Teller Is Killed in Bank Robbery
text: Three masked men stormed a community bank on the South Side of Chicago and shot three people, before fleeing with a “small amount” of money, the police said. A 23-year-old male bank teller died later of his wound. A 48-year-old security guard at the bank and a 73-year-old customer were in critical condition at a local hospital, said Monique Bond, a police spokeswoman. The robbery occurred around 9:30 a.m., when the three masked men entered the Illinois Service Federal Savings & Loan, disarmed one security guard, exchanged gunfire with a second guard, wounding him, and shot the two other victims, the police said. The robbers remain at large.

headline: Europeans Approve Vivendi Deal for BMG
text: European regulators approved the estimated $2.1 billion purchase by Vivendi of the Bertelsmann music publishing unit yesterday, a deal that will give Vivendi unmatched market power in determining how much performers and songwriters earn from their creations.

headline: Tavárez Treats Himself With a Victory
text: Julián Tavárez had a very happy birthday yesterday. On the day he turned 34, he earned his 34th career victory as a starter in the Red Sox’ 7-3 win over the Yankees last night at Yankee Stadium.

headline: 12 Guilty in Serbian Premier’s Death
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo, May 23 — A Serbian court found two former paramilitary police officers guilty of the assassination of Zoran Djindjic, the pro-reform prime minister who was gunned down in Belgrade in March 2003.

headline: A Chef to the Few Heeds the Call of the Many
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: For Drug Makers, a Downside to Full Disclosure
text: When GlaxoSmithKline settled a lawsuit three years ago with the

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL And the next Idol is ... ? Jordin Sparks, above left, and Blake Lewis learn who will walk away with the title in tonight’s two-hour season finale, broadcast live from the Kodak Theater in Los Angeles. An “American Idol Red Carpet Special,” at 7:30, focuses on the action outside the theater. Meanwhile, Melinda Doolittle fans  including Simon Cowell  will be left to wonder what might have been.

headline: Letter From California: Some Thoughts on Living the Combustible Life
text: Recently, I flew from Denver to Ontario, Calif. The next-to-last leg of that flight is mostly over desert, and at night the desert floor means darkness. Then we came over the mountains, and in the distance I could see a dim line of lights slowly rising to fill the horizon, the leading edge of the luminosity that is Southern California at night. Before long we were descending, wheels down, over a district of low, flat buildings, enormous in scale, their parking lots and loading bays gleaming under mercury and sodium lamps.

headline: CBS Buying Wallstrip, a Web Finance Site
text: CBS has bought Wallstrip, an online company whose Web site mixes finance with humor, to add to its daily financial news Web broadcast. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: F.A.A. Warns of Increasing Flight Delays
text: HERNDON, Va., May 23 — Although airlines experienced their worst flight delays ever last summer, this year so far looks even worse, Federal Aviation Administration officials said today. But government and airline executives said they hoped that innovations in air traffic software would minimize delays caused by weather.

headline: Kazakhstan: President Ends Term Limit for Himself
text: President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev signed several constitutional amendments put forward by Parliament, including an exemption for himself from a provision limiting presidents to serving two terms, effectively clearing the way for him to become president for life. Political opposition groups objected to the provision as the beginning of a Soviet-style personality cult for Mr. Nazarbayev, who came to power in 1989 and whose current seven-year term expires in 2012. Mr. Nazarbayev also signed off on constitutional changes that expand Parliament’s responsibilities, including a greater role in choosing the prime minister.

headline: Haiti: Switzerland to Return ‘Baby Doc’ Funds
text: Switzerland will return $6.2 million next month that it seized in bank accounts of the dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, known as Baby Doc, Swiss officials said. A large part of the money is to be given to Haiti for humanitarian projects. The officials said the remainder would be returned to Mr. Duvalier, who was overthrown in 1986 and lives in exile in France.

headline: Brooklyn: Healthful Food Plan for the Poor
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Christine Quinn announced a new effort yesterday aimed at improving poor New Yorkers’ access to healthful food. With a $500,000 grant from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation, city officials are bringing together public and private groups to recommend ways to increase healthful eating and physical activity. In addition, the Human Resources Administration, the city’s welfare agency, is expanding a pilot program that allows food stamp offices to process electronic applications taken at food pantries and soup kitchens. Two organizations in Queens will be added to the program, with Manhattan groups to follow, city officials said.

headline: For Sosa, Atlanta Is No Place Like Home
text: ATLANTA, May 22 — As any good host would, the Atlanta Braves welcomed Jorge Sosa back to town by offering all the comforts of home. For Sosa, that sort of hospitality meant getting hit and hit hard, just as he did before the Braves dumped him nearly 10 months ago.

headline: California Wants Strict Auto Emission Rules
text: ARLINGTON, Va., May 22  Officials from California demanded on Tuesday that federal regulators allow the state to impose the strictest automobile and light truck emissions rules in the nation. They said that new regulations were needed to lessen the threat of global warming and threatened to sue if the government did not allow them to go forward.

headline: And Now for a Chocolate Break at Bendel’s
text: Alison Nelson, above, who opened the Chocolate Bar in Greenwich Village five years ago, has added another location, her third, in the Henri Bendel store on Fifth Avenue (56th Street). This airy cafe on the third floor, done in blue, chocolate-brown and ivory, has a bar, banquette seating and a table on the balcony. Boxes of chocolate bars and truffles line the shelves.

headline: Finally, Exit From New York
text: As the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge faded in my rearview mirror last Thursday afternoon, I had only one thought in my head: Finally! I had woken up late, had spent way too long packing for this road trip and had been sitting in Brooklyn traffic. Typical. Now, however, my Volvo was zipping over what was once the world’s longest suspension bridge, heading west, and nothing could stop me.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about spousal rights, gave an incorrect name for the federal office that tallied the number of rights and responsibilities connected to marriage. It is the Government Accountability Office, not the Government Accounting Office.

headline: Delgado Doesn’t Know How to Fix His Problem
text: ATLANTA, May 22  Carlos Delgado’s name was in the starting lineup Tuesday night for the 41st time this season. Not once in the previous 40, Delgado said, had he felt comfortable at the plate.

headline: Troubled Lender Sells Division and Brings in New Leadership
text: The Fremont General Corporation, a financial services company caught up in the subprime mortgage lending mess, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its commercial real estate unit for $1.9 billion and bring in new managers.

headline: British Police Seek 3 Missing Terrorist Suspects
text: LONDON, May 23 — Britain’s counterterrorism police today took the highly unusual step of issuing a public appeal for information about three suspected terrorists said to have absconded from a form of house arrest known as control orders.

headline: Pope Softens Remarks on Conversion of Natives
text: ROME, May 23 — Pope Benedict XVI tried today to quell anger in South America over his recent comments on the conversion of native populations there, acknowledging today that “unjustifiable crimes” were committed in the European conquest of the continent five centuries ago.

headline: Trial to Begin in Fire That Burned Houdini Papers
text: CINCINNATI, May 22  A private collection of Harry Houdini memorabilia was largely destroyed in a house fire that the police said was started when a burglar tried to light his crack pipe. The suspect in the case is scheduled to go on trial on Friday.

headline: Immigration Raid Leaves Sense of Dread in Hispanic Students
text: WILLMAR, Minn.

headline: Post at Luxury Hotel Awaits Ex-Mayor at End of Prison Term
text: BOSTON, May 22  When he gets out of federal prison next week, Vincent A. Cianci Jr., the former mayor of Providence, R.I., who was convicted of corruption, will not exactly be slumming it.

headline: Food Safety Joins Issues at U.S.-China Talks
text: WASHINGTON, May 22 — Teams of cabinet members from China and the United States held a day of talks Tuesday to reduce economic tensions but ran into familiar disagreements over trade, currency issues and at least one new concern, the safety of Chinese food exports.

headline: Democrats Pull Troop Deadline From Iraq Bill
text: WASHINGTON, May 22 — Congressional Democrats relented Tuesday on their insistence that a war spending measure set a date for withdrawing American combat troops from Iraq. Instead, they moved toward a deal with President Bush that would impose new conditions on the Iraqi government.

headline: Recipe: The Best Spinach Dip With Chipotle and Lime
text: 2 10-ounce packages frozen spinach, thawed and drained

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A brief article in Science Times on May 1 about research on migraines and mental decline referred incorrectly to the subjects of the study. The researchers looked at men and women, not just women. In addition, among the approximately 1,400 subjects studied over 12 years, more than 200 of them had a history of migraines  not about 20 of them.

headline: As Refugees Flee, Lebanese Army Vows to Crush Militants
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon May 23—The stream of Palestinians flowing out of the Nahr al Bared refugee camp on the outskirts of Tripoli continued today, as the Lebanese army reinforced its positions and vowed to crush the militants inside the camp.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Saturday about the Cavaliers’ victory against the Nets to win their playoff series misstated the age of LeBron James of Cleveland. He is 22, not 24.

headline: Debate Raging, Mexico Adds to Consulates in U.S.
text: On the surface, there was nothing extraordinary about a certain government office in Little Rock, Ark., the other day as paperwork was signed, names were called, fees were paid, waits were endured and computer keyboards went tap, tap, tap.

headline: Harsh Realities in a World of Fantasy
text: CANNES, France, May 22 — Sleaze rarely looks as lovely and plays with such sentiment as it does in Abel Ferrara’s “Go Go Tales,” a down-and-dirty story about a nightclub owner and the beauties and beasts who work for him. The film, which unfortunately, if unsurprisingly, is screening out of competition, is easily Mr. Ferrara’s best since “The Funeral” (1996) and welcome news for his hard-core, patient admirers. (Its commitment to female pulchritude comes unadorned by self-consciously belabored art and ideas.) An obvious homage to John Cassavetes’s underbelly classic “The Killing of a Chinese Bookie” (1976), “Go Go Tales” also works rather poignantly as a metaphor for the down-and-dirty independence that Mr. Ferrara has pursued his entire filmmaking career.

headline: Living History in St. Petersburg
text: As an American expatriate in St. Petersburg, one of the most romantic, historic and difficult cities in Russia, Lisa Kreutz zeroed in on one of its most prestigious areas when she bought an apartment in 2003.

headline: Roy De Forest, 77, Painter of Colorful, Comic Scenes, Dies
text: Roy De Forest, a Bay Area artist whose paintings depicted a comical, crowded frontier land of people and animals in patchworks of scorched, textured color, died on Friday in Vallejo, Calif. He was 77 and lived in nearby Port Costa.

headline: Giuliani Above the Fray as McCain and Romney Skirmish
text: The contrast could hardly be more striking. Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney have been mixing it up on the trail with increasing intensity ever since their feisty exchange at the last Republican debate. This week their arguments over immigration prompted Mr. McCain to suggest acidly that Mr. Romney’s solution might be “to get out his small-varmint gun and drive those Guatemalans off his lawn.”

headline: Yankees Stumble and Lose Momentum
text: There were two wide cardboard boxes stacked on top of each other by the empty locker at the back of the Yankees’ clubhouse yesterday. Written on the top box, in red marker, was, “Attn Rob Cucuzza/Rocket.”

headline: Search Continues Off Jersey Shore for Missing Fisherman
text: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J., May 22  Another brass plaque will soon be added to the wooden railing surrounding the fishermen’s memorial here, inscribed with the names of one, and probably two, commercial fishermen.

headline: Correction: Who’s Watching What We Eat?
text: An article last Wednesday about criticism of the Food and Drug Administration’s efforts to protect food safety misstated the agency’s explanation for the cause of a recent contamination outbreak. It believes melamine, a chemical used in fertilizers and plastics that has tainted pet food and animal feed, was in wheat flour imported from China  not in wheat gluten or rice protein. (The agency’s initial assessment was based on the fact that the flour was mislabeled as wheat gluten or rice protein.)

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on May 8 about a study showing how meditation affects attention referred incorrectly to one group that was studied. The 17 volunteers who meditated for 10 to 12 hours a day as part of the research did have previous meditation experience; they were not new to meditation.

headline: Attack Not Disputed at Trial, Just Intent of the Attacker
text: The prosecution and the defense offered contradictory versions yesterday of why  but not whether  a former fashion writer had dressed as a firefighter, tied up a woman he barely knew and sexually molested her in her Chelsea apartment on the night of Oct. 31, 2005.

headline: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
text: When Institutional Investor’s Alpha magazine released its annual list of the highest paid hedge fund managers last month, it allowed the rest of us to play an entertaining little parlor game: what could you buy if you made as much money as those guys?

headline: Wie Planning to Resume Her Career Next Week
text: Michelle Wie spent yesterday at RiverTowne Country Club in Mount Pleasant, S.C., an old shrimp boat town on Charleston Harbor and the site of next week’s L.P.G.A. Ginn Tribute.

headline: Pilot Strays Near Shuttle
text: A private pilot was chased by a NASA helicopter after his plane flew near the space shuttle Atlantis as the shuttle sat on its launching pad. The incident prompted an F.B.I. investigation, federal authorities said. The pilot, Michael Dunn, 41, of Port St. Lucie, Fla., became disoriented and drifted into restricted airspace above the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, said Chris Bonner, and F.B.I. special agent. The plane, a 50-year-old Aeronca Champ, lacked a radio or working transponder, Mr. Bonner said. He said the F.B.I. decided not to pursue criminal charges after questioning Mr. Dunn.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,415 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:

headline: The 300th Birthday of the Man Who Organized All of Nature
text: As a warm-up to a birthday celebration, it was sedate, and also spartan.

headline: During His Funeral, Falwell Is Praised for Activist Style
text: LYNCHBURG, Va., May 22  The Rev. Jerry Falwell was eulogized Tuesday as a daring critic of American life, called by God to his role as a clergyman and political activist.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Russia Scuttles Export

headline: Buffalo: Murder Suspect Dies
text: A man charged with the murder of two women whose remains were found inside sealed barrels on March 31 died on Saturday, four days after being taken to the Erie County Medical Center for a mental health evaluation, the Erie County Sheriff’s Office said yesterday. Hours before he was stricken on May 15, the man, Robert J. Henchen, 42, of Colden, pleaded not guilty to charges of killing Geraldine Jackson, 87, and Nancy Phelps, 69, both of whom disappeared months before their remains were found. According to his lawyer, Mr. Henchen suffered “a cardiac incident.” But the cause of his death remained under investigation yesterday, the Sheriff’s Department said. He had been hospitalized because of odd behavior, including refusal to wear clothes, at the Erie County jail, said Undersheriff Richard T. Donovan.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture in Weekend on Friday with an article about the fall prime-time schedules for Fox and CW was published in error. It showed a scene from “Supernatural,” which will be entering its third season on CW  not “Reaper,” a new show on that network.

headline: Defibrillators Lift Medtronic’s Profit
text: Medtronic, the biggest maker of electronic heart devices, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 9.7 percent on higher sales of implantable defibrillators, the company’s top product.

headline: Everything and the Kitchen Sink: The Memoir of a Dishwasher
text: Until just recently, Pete Jordan hadn’t washed a dish professionally in seven years. Now an author, Mr. Jordan used to be a paid dishwasher, following in the steps of literary plongeurs like Theodore Dreiser and George Orwell, who, recalling his time behind the sink in Paris, once wrote:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music review on Saturday about a performance of Rameau’s “Castor et Pollux” at the French Institute Alliance Française in New York, misspelled part of the name of the group that performed. It is L’Opéra Français de New York, not Française.

headline: Palestinian Rivals Meet to Discuss Cease-Fire
text: TEL AVIV, May 23 — The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, held a private meeting Tuesday night in Gaza with the Palestinian prime minister, Ismail Haniya, to try to secure the cease-fire between their rival factions, and to discuss how to calm down an escalating conflict with Israel, Mr. Haniya’s spokesman said today.

headline: Sports Briefing
text: pro football

headline: Russian Is Accused of Poisoning Ex-K.G.B. Agent
text: LONDON, May 22  The British authorities on Tuesday accused a Russian businessman, Andrei K. Lugovoi, of murdering Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. agent and foe of the Kremlin poisoned six months ago in London with a radioactive isotope, polonium 210.

headline: For Yanks and Red Sox, It’s Money Well Wasted
text: For nearly a century, the Boston Red Sox and the Yankees have made each other crazy. Lately, it may be more true than ever.

headline: The Hollow Promise Reform Act
text: The House’s new Democratic majority is flirting with disaster as it guts key provisions of the strict lobbying reform it promised voters last November. Rebellious lawmakers, worried about their own career path, fought their leaders to defeat tighter restrictions on the sleazy, revolving-door culture by which members of Congress move on from an apprenticeship of merely serving the people to real Washington money as insider lobbyists.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A brief article in Science Times yesterday about a study showing that alcohol consumption can lower the risk of one type of kidney cancer misstated the publication date. It appeared in the May 16 issue of The Journal of the National Cancer Institute; it is not scheduled to be published in the June 16 issue.

headline: A Policewoman Looks Back on the Craziest of Love Duets
text: The policewoman who guarded the hospital room, Margaret Powers, had come prepared. “I happened to have brought a pack of cards,” Mrs. Powers recalled. She introduced herself to the woman in the bed, Linda Riss, whose eyes were bandaged. Lye had been thrown in her face. A jealous ex-boyfriend was responsible, and he was still at large. She was 22. The policewoman was 10 years older.

headline: Book Ads: The Golden Age, 1962-1973
36 Hours in Moscow
text: A weekend in a metropolitan city that has maintained its brash and flashy side.

headline: Democrats Pull Troop Deadline From Iraq Bill
text: For the first time since taking power in Congress, the Democrats yesterday publicly agreed to allow a vote on Iraq war financing without a timetable for troop withdrawal. The move apparently ended a legislative battle with President Bush, who had refused to accept time constraints.

headline: High Art
text: La Paz, Bolivia, might be the Pop Art capital of South America.

headline: Clinton Campaign Memo on Iowa
text: The following is the text of a Clinton campaign memo obtained by The New York Times.

headline: The Unknown
text: Images from "Mythic Creatures: Dragons, Unicorns and Mermaids" at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Star moves
text: Following a years-long search, Mike Myers, the star of the “Austin Powers” and “Wayne’s World” movies, has finally found his perfect pad in New York’s SoHo district, according to “The New York Post.” The celebrity has just purchased a newly constructed penthouse at 72 Mercer Street for $7.95 million. Measuring just over 4,200 square feet, the apartment includes three bedrooms, six bathrooms, a living area with 15-foot ceilings, and a 1,368-square-foot rooftop terrace.

headline: A Different Museum
text: Additional images from the Creation Museum in Petersburg, Ky.

headline: Photos: Milan Champion of Europe
text: Two years after losing a three-goal lead to Liverpool in the 2005 Champions League final, A.C. Milan defeated the England side to win its seventh European Cup title.

headline: Onex to Unload More of Spirit in Offering
text: Canadian buyout firm Onex said Tuesday it plans to sell another billion-dollar share of its stake in Spirit AeroSystems Holdings. Nigel Wright, managing director of Onex, said the sale will come through a secondary offering of about 31.5 million Class A shares at $33.50 each.

headline: It’s True: Guy Kawasaki Starts Rumor Site
text: The proliferation of cheap software is allowing entrepreneurs to take bigger risks when starting a company with an unproven, or non-existent business model. In the latest such example, Garage Technology Ventures investor Guy Kawasaki, best known for his early Apple evangelism, recently launched Truerumors.com, a forum to post rumors and comments via phone call, text message, or email.

headline: Jury Gets a Taste of Black’s Unusual Rhetoric
text: Conrad Black, the former chairman of Hollinger, expressed a desire to “blow the asses off” investors who complained of boardroom extravagance shortly before what was expected to be a contentious annual shareholder meeting in 2002, according to an e-mail presented Tuesday in a Chicago court.

headline: MuleSource Takes $12.5 Million in New Funding
text: MuleSource, a provider of open-source business software, said Tuesday that it had raised $12.5 million in its second round of venture funding, adding to an initial $4 million it raised last fall. This latest round was led by Lightspeed Venture Partners.

headline: No Rival Bids Emerge for First Data
text: Private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts can go ahead with its $29 billion takeover of First Data without worrying about another suitor. First Data, one of the nation’s largest credit-card processing companies, said Tuesday that a period for soliciting competing bids passed without any other takeover proposals.

headline: Wall Street Bonuses May Break Record (Again)
text: Wall Street appears to be gearing up for another year of fat bonuses, according to a forecast released Tuesday. Less than halfway through 2007, an executive recruiting firm, Johnson Associates, is predicting that year-end bonuses for investment bankers could exceed last year’s total by 10 percent to 15 percent in most areas.

headline: Dress Codes: Shorts
text: Raising cuffs without raising eyebrows.

headline: Hedge Fund Suit Tests Use of ‘Big Boy’ Letters
text: The use of “big boy letters” — which often appear in deals where one party has confidential information about a stock or bond — is about to face its first significant legal challenge in the form of a lawsuit filed by R2, a Texas hedge fund.

headline: Former Chief of EMI Said to Prepare Rival Bid
text: It took EMI Group years to reach a consensual takeover agreement, but another bidder may emerge much, much sooner. The New York Post reported Wednesday that at around 12:30 p.m. Tuesday — exactly 24 hours after EMI agreed to be acquired by Terra Firma Capital Partners for 265 pence per share — private equity firm Corvus Capital and former EMI chief executive Jim Fifield were in the final stages of preparing a bid of 278 pence per share for the British music company.

headline: Fine Points | Keeping Time in Cool Comfort
text: Opening Ceremony in Manhattan introduces its shoe collection that includes suede, canvas and leather jazz shoe styles for men and women.

headline: The Meaning of ‘I’ll Be Back’
text: Angelina Jolie may be going on sabbatical, Rambo is back with a bloody trailer at the Cannes film festival, but what about everyone’s favorite action hero-turned-governor?

headline: Intel to Form a Flash-Memory Venture
text: In a move to shed an unprofitable business as its turnaround gains traction, Intel said Tuesday it would join with STMicroelectronics, a Swiss semiconductor maker, to form a new company to sell flash memory chips. Flash memory is used in cellphones, digital music players and digital cameras and is considered one of the most erratic segments of the semiconductor market.

headline: Hedge Fund Executive Leaves Merrill Lynch
text: Merrill Lynch said yesterday that Ben Weston, the chief of its hedge fund development and management group, left the firm after two years.

headline: Outback Steakhouse Accepts Higher Bid
text: OSI Restaurant Partners, owner of the Outback Steakhouse chain, has agreed to a higher $3.1 billion takeover offer from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and Catterton Partners.

headline: Luxury Chiang Mai, a bit guiltily
text: Traveling in Southeast Asia, as in most parts of the developing world, often involves being confronted with jarring contrasts between rich and poor, visitor and local. And the more remote the area, the bigger the disparity.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Buy Real Estate Trust
text: Morgan Stanley agreed Tuesday to buy Crescent Real Estate Equities, an investment trust founded by the Texas billionaire Richard Rainwater, for $2.78 billion. At $22.80 a share, the offer is 5.5 percent more than Crescent’s closing price Tuesday of $21.62. The total value of the transaction is $6.5 billion including debt, Fort Worth-based Crescent said.

headline: ...And Do You Take This (Buff) Woman?
text: Determined brides have found one way to cut corners by trying to get in shape for less than $20. Ashley Miller, personal trainer, tests wedding workout DVDs.

headline: MGM Mirage Forms Independent Board to Study Kerkorian Offer
text: The casino giant MGM Mirage said Tuesday night that its board had formed an independent committee to study an offer by the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian to buy two MGM Mirage properties and perhaps restructure the company.

headline: Europeans Approve Vivendi Deal for BMG
text: European regulators approved the estimated $2.1 billion purchase by Vivendi of the Bertelsmann music publishing unit yesterday, a deal that will give Vivendi unmatched market power in determining how much performers and songwriters earn from their creations.

headline: Sallie Mae Says Chief Is Resigning
text: SLM, the student lender commonly known as Sallie Mae, said Tuesday that its vice chairman and chief executive, Thomas J. Fitzpatrick, was resigning to pursue other interests. The move comes after SLM agreed last month to be sold to a consortium led by a private equity firm, J.C. Flowers & Company.

headline: Chinese Bookstore Chain Prices I.P.O. Amid Strong Demand
text: Sichuan Xinhua Winshare Chainstore, which will be the first bookstore operator to list in Hong Kong, has priced its initial public offering at the top of the range for a total deal size of 2.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($274 million).

headline: Firms Sell Formica for $700 Million
text: Cerberus Capital Management and Oaktree Capital Management will sell the Formica Corporation, the countertop maker they acquired out of bankruptcy protection, for $700 million to a New Zealand manufacturing company, Fletcher Building.

headline: House Votes to Tighten Reins on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
text: Legislation to tighten federal oversight of the two biggest buyers of home mortgages, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, cleared the House on Tuesday. But the bill could lose the support of the Bush administration because of a provision trimming the authority of federal regulators.

headline: Bloomberg for Governor?
text: More New York City residents would support Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg if he were to run for governor than if he were to run for president, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released this morning.

headline: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
text: When Institutional Investor’s Alpha magazine released its annual list of the highest paid hedge fund managers last month, the eye-popping sums caused grumblings among some investors about the high fees that hedge fund managers are collecting.

headline: Home Depot Plans Kinder, Gentler Shareholder Meeting
text: It was, as even Home Depot executives will concede, a 37-minute fiasco. In a basement hotel ballroom in Delaware, with the board nowhere in sight and huge timers on stage to cut off angry investors, Home Depot held a hasty annual meeting last year that attendees alternately described as “appalling” and “arrogant.”

headline: The Difficulty of Death
text: In a movie culture filled with fake death and callous killing, "Dying at Grace" is not just a shock to the system; it's an accusation. Filmed over 14 weeks in the winter of 2002, in the palliative care ward of the Salvation Army Toronto Grace Health Center, Allan King's wrenching record of five real deaths is a potent reminder of the fearful gap between fiction and reality.

headline: Payless Adds Stride Rite to Its Closet
text: Payless ShoeSource said Tuesday it is buying shoe company Stride Rite for about $800 million as a way to grab a bigger share of the fast-growing branded and children’s footwear sectors.

headline: Boards Feel the Heat as Investor Activists Speak Up
text: In Europe, the occasional activist has stirred up a revolt at an annual general meeting, led a no-confidence vote against management and even taken executives to court. Those have been the extreme cases.

headline: Google Backs Firm Started by Co-Founder’s Wife
text: In what The New York Times describes as Silicon Valley’s version of “The Bachelor,” Anne Wojcicki not only landed one of America’s richest men, Sergey Brin, a co-founder of Google, but she also got her husband’s company to finance her start-up. Google said Tuesday that it invested $3.9 million this month in 23andMe, the biotech company co-founded last year by Ms. Wojcicki, a former health care industry analyst, The New York Times reported.

headline: Oaktree Raises $800 Million in Landmark Offering
text: Oaktree Capital Management, an investment firm that oversees about $40 billion in assets, became the first company to list on a new market created by Goldman Sachs as a way for private firms to raise money without going public. Oaktree raised more than $800 million selling a stake of about 14 percent to fewer than 50 other large investors, The Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: Hertz Backers Plan $1 Billion Offering
text: Hertz Global Holdings said Clayton Dubilier & Rice, Merrill Lynch and the Carlyle Group plan to sell shares valued at almost $1 billion after the stock gained 40 percent since its initial offering in November.

headline: Norilsk Raises Bid for LionOre Mining
text: Norilsk Nickel on Wednesday raised its bid for LionOre Mining International to 27.50 Canadian dollars a share, valuing the Canadian miner at about 6.8 billion Canadian dollars ($6.3 billion). The Russian company’s revised bid for LionOre, the world’s 10th-largest nickel producer, was 10 percent higher than a rival offer from Xstrata, which last week made a bid of 25 Canadian dollars a share, valuing LionOre at 6.2 billion Canadian dollars.

headline: An Imperfect Construction
text: In "9 Star Hotel," the Israeli filmmaker Ido Haar draws us into the precarious world of young Palestinian construction workers scrabbling to survive in and around the Israeli city of Modiin. Irregularly and illegally employed, the men hide in the wooded hills above the city, sleeping in shelters made from scraps of Sheetrock and constantly on the alert for Israeli security forces.

headline: Alcan Spurns Hostile Bid and Talks to White Knights
text: The Canadian aluminum producer Alcan rejected a $27.4 billion hostile bid from a rival, Alcoa, on Tuesday, calling the offer inadequate. Alcan said that it was in talks with other companies — The Globe and Mail newspaper reported that one of them is the Australian mining giant BHP Billiton — and added that it was considering the possibility of turning the tables with a counterbid for Alcoa.

headline: The Color of Dissent
text: In the documentary "Orange Winter" orange blooms throughout Kiev, Ukraine, the epicenter of dissent over that country's stolen 2004 presidential elections. Outraged Ukrainians adopted the color that winter to express support for the pro-Western presidential candidate, Viktor A. Yushchenko, who was poisoned with dioxin by unknown enemies to protect his establishment-supported rival, Viktor F. Yanukovich.

headline: 2008: Beautyshop Appeal
text: During a speech before the Council on Foreign Relations today, John Edwards plans to call for “greater international strategic partnerships, more aggressive use of diplomacy in place of armed intervention and the creation of a 10,000-member reserve corps to help stabilize troubled nations,” reports The Times’s Leslie Wayne.

headline: Republican Donors, Undaunted
text: Greg Giroux of CQPolitics has a party fundraising update that shows winning isn’t everything, at least not in politics:The Democratic victories in last November’s elections have not — at least not at this early juncture of the 2007-08 cycle — reversed the fundraising advantage the Republican National Committee (R.N.C.) has long held over the Democratic National Committee (D.N.C.).The R.N.C. reported raising $7.4 million in April, compared with $4 million for the D.N.C., according to campaign reports filed late last week with the Federal Election Commission (F.E.C.). That continues a trend: The R.N.C. has outraised the D.N.C. every month this calendar year.The R.N.C. raised $33 million in the first four months of this year and had $14.2 million in cash on hand; the committee was debt-free as May began. The D.N.C. has raised $19.7 million this year and had available cash of $6.1 million, with debts of $3 million.The D.N.C. has lower cash on hand than the R.N.C. because it has spent a greater percentage of its receipts — in part because the D.N.C. pays salaries for party personnel in all 50 states. The D.N.C., which has vowed to be more competitive in traditionally Republican-leaning states and districts, spent about $921,000 on staff salaries in April.

headline: Video: Looking for In-Laws
text: In the latest video from China, Nick tries to track down his wife’s relatives. Sheryl WuDunn’s ancestors, like many other Chinese-Americans, hailed from the Taishan region of southeastern China. There’s an audio slide show from Nick’s last visit in 2003 and a related column with a very provocative headline.

headline: Statue Watch: Bill Clinton Edition
text: Inside the United Nations, the subject of what Kosovo can and can’t do is a subject of great debate. It cannot supervise the Serbian province indefinitely, yet plans for effective independence have been hitting hurdles for months.

headline: Oilman Tops Hedgie for Manhattan Real-Estate Crown
text: In what may be a sign of the times, oil has trumped hedge funds in New York’s contest for real-estate bragging rights. The New York Times, picking up on a story on The New York Observer’s blog, reported Wednesday that an unnamed “London-based businessman in the oil business” has agreed to pay $56 million for a triplex penthouse condominium at New York’s Plaza Hotel. If the deal closes, it is likely to be the most expensive sale ever of an apartment in Manhattan. It would also break the record set by Daniel Loeb, the head of the hedge fund Third Point Capital, who is known for his exquisitely barbed letters to corporate managers.

headline: Finding Poetry in the Position Paper
text: While they often don’t get the attention of a verbal gaffe captured on YouTube, a candidate’s campaign platform and their issue positions tend to matter — a lot.

headline: The Fertile Territory Beyond Our Own
text: We New Yorkers like to think we live in the best restaurant city in the country, and I’ve not seen any compelling evidence to date that we don’t.

headline: Tracking Illnesses Online
text: A couple weeks ago, I wrote about my desire to see a “Web 2.0” site where people could report the details of their illnesses. At a glance, you’d be able to see the clouds of color-coded flu bugs or GI bugs moving through your area or even your town. When you got sick, at least you’d know what kind of duration and intensity you could expect.

headline: Blogroll Update
text: We’ve updated our blogroll to include some of the newsier neighborhood blogs from the five boroughs, especially Brooklyn, which seems to be New York City’s blogtopia. Or blogistan.Thanks in particular go to Louise Crawford of Only the Blog Knows Brooklyn, who pointed out that we had not paid enough attention to the list lately.

headline: New Ads From Dodd and Romney
text: In a new ad out today, Senator Christopher J. Dodd names names, but in his new ad, Mitt Romney declines to name a place.

headline: The Perfect Paris Lunch (3 star)
text: My wife’s aunt was in town for her birthday last week, and to mark the occasion she wanted to treat us all to a 3-star restaurant. We had read a while ago that Yannick Alléno of Le Meurice just got his third Michelin star this year, and my aunt-in-law liked the idea of a lunch in old-style French elegance.

headline: Big Tool Deal in the Works?
text: Illinois Tool Works makes everything from self-drilling screws to commercial meat slicers. But is the 95-year-old industrial conglomerate interested in making a deal? That is what many investors seemed to be wondering Tuesday, as trading in the company’s stock and options ratcheted up quite a bit. Shares of the company, which has a market capitalization of more than $29 billion, spiked as much as 6 percent in morning trading Tuesday amid what Jon Najarian, co-founder of OptionMonster, described as “way above normal” trading volume.

headline: Britain delays home sales packet
text: Britain has delayed the requirement that anyone selling a home must provide a packet of information about the property after surveyors mounted a legal challenge, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Same Institute, Different Drummer
text: Ah, how times have changed. After Fernando Ferrer, the former Bronx borough president, lost the Democratic primary for mayor in 2001, he found a safe harbor as president of the Drum Major Institute, a liberal policy group.

headline: The State Assembly’s Error Message
text: Normally, the New York State Assembly has a lovely little Web site with links to lawmakers’ home pages, a search function for legislation and more.

headline: Diamonds are for luck
text: The last time that McLaren Mercedes drivers carried diamonds around like this in Monaco, in 2005, they finished first and fifth in the race. Obviously the team has no objections to doing all it can to facilitate its sponsor, the Steinmetz diamond company, in its efforts to show off the diamonds again.

headline: When Labor and Private Equity Shake Hands
text: Who says buyout firms and unions can’t be friends?

headline: Roaming for Less, in Europe
text: The European Union placed caps today on mobile-phone roaming charges within its 27 member states, answering a groundswell of complaints that would be easily recognizable to anyone with a cell phone and any semblance of a victim’s complex.

headline: Modern Art and Old Rome (2):Chagall
text: If you are shopping on Via Corso or heading back to town from the Coloseum or the Imperial Forum, stop at the wonderful temporary Chagall retrospective exhibit in the Museo Del Risorgimento. The museum is entered through the back side of Rome’s ugliest monument, Il Vittoriano, a bright white late 19th Century creation to commemorate Italian unification. (For those who have just done the Schnabel exhibit, Il Vittoriano is the bright white monstrosity right across Piazza Venezia.) The Chagalls could be better organized and displayed, but there are dozens of terrific paintings spanning 6 decades of the artist’s work. Particularly interesting for those in Rome who are overdosed on traditional religious art, are Chagall’s unconventional renderings of the Bible, in which Jesus is shown with all the trappings of Judaism (notice the Torah), placed in what looks like Chagall’s birthplace in a village in Russia. To finish your visit, head upstairs to the museum’s outdoor cafe, on a terrace overlooking the ruins of the Imperial Forum. The coffee is excellent. The sangria not bad. Most important, the terrace has one of the best panoramas of Rome, with excellent signs that help you make sense of the forest of spires and arches you are seeing. Just FYI this outing is very kid-friendly; I did this one with my 15-year-old, who loved both the art and the view.

headline: Vlasic Ads
text: The stork that has represented the Vlasic line of pickles since 1974 is returning to television advertising for the first time in many years.

headline: Vlasic Ads
text: The stork that has represented the Vlasic line of pickles since 1974 is returning to television advertising for the first time in many years.

headline: Blodget’s Fateful Amazon Call Comes True Again
text: Henry Blodget, the former Internet analyst, is taking some pride from a little-noticed milestone: For the first time since he agreed to be barred from the securities industry, shares of Amazon have risen back above $400.

headline: Testing, 3-4-5, Testing, 6-7-8 …
text: New York has reported results of English tests in Grades 3-8 taken in all public schools this spring. The tests show that the number of students passing in earlier grades dropped from 2006 levels in most places, but rose compared with last year in middle school grades. The Times unveiled an online tool today that allows readers to look up results by school.

headline: The Saga of ‘Toto’ Constant
text: A Brooklyn judge’s decision yesterday to hold Emmanuel Constant — a onetime paramilitary leader and C.I.A. informer — for further jail time on grand larceny charges underscores the sad and bizarre aspects of a complex legal case that spans Haiti and the United States and has caught the attention of human and civil rights advocates in both countries.

headline: Microsoft: We Don’t Need Yahoo
text: With an agreement to buy aQuantive under its belt, Microsoft is playing down rumors — in the air for at least a year, most recently stoked by the New York Post — that it might try to buy Yahoo. “We have all of the pieces we need to move forward” in the online-advertising business, Yusuf Mehdi, Microsoft’s chief advertising strategist, said Wednesday at a Goldman Sachs  Internet conference in Las Vegas.

headline: Clinton Staff Memo Urges Shunning Iowa
text: A senior official in the campaign for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wrote an internal memorandum to the campaign advising Mrs. Clinton not to participate in the Iowa caucuses, arguing that she probably could not win them and that she would be better off spending her time and campaign money in places more hospitable to her campaign.

headline: Settlement a Boon for Ground Zero
text: The Spitzer administration and a group of major insurers announced a settlement this afternoon of insurance claims at ground zero, ensuring that $4.55 billion will be available for rebuilding the World Trade Center site — about half of what is needed. The settlement provides about $870 million to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the land at ground zero and built the trade center, and $1.13 billion to the developer Larry A. Silverstein, who is to build large office towers on Church Street, between Vesey and Liberty Streets.

headline: You Should Hear His ‘Ed Sullivan’
text: (mp3)

headline: A War Phrase That Pays Less and Less
text: Britain and the House budget committee deserted the “war on terror” last month, and now candidates for the White House are starting to weigh in.

headline: We Respond to Questions About the Layout of the House
text: Dear Readers:

headline: Hands Across the Complex
text: It has been 21 years since Hands Across America, when on May 25, 1986, some five million people joined hands in a line to Long Beach, Calif., from New York to raise money to fight hunger and homelessness.

headline: So What Was Wrong With the Original Idea?
text: Beyond telling our architect, Greg Huddy, that the latest version of the house was too big and too expensive, I didn’t have any ideas on how to fix it.

headline: The Peregrine Chicks of Throgs Neck
text: It is a tale that would have been warm enough to touch the heart of Robert Moses — well, maybe not. According to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a population of tiny peregrine falcons was recently born atop the Throgs Neck Bridge, the suspension span that connects the Bronx and Queens and opened in 1961 under Moses’s supervision.

headline: Et tu, Senator Kerry?
text: The New Republic’s Michael Crowley has read retired-and-still-eight-time-loser Democratic strategist Bob Shrum’s new memoir, “No Excuses: Concessions of a Serial Campaigner,” so you don’t have to. “[N]o one comes in for rougher treatment in this book than Shrum’s former client, John Edwards,” Crowley writes, who says Edwards is portrayed as an intellectual lightweight and “a hyper-ambitious phony.”

headline: Apple iPhone Commercial
text: An ad for the launch of Apple's iPhone.

headline: Avon Commercial
text: An ad for Avon.

headline: A New Silent Majority
text: Something seems a little out of whack between the mainstream media and the American people. Take the arguments of the past few days over former President Jimmy Carter’s remarks about the Bush administration and the consequences of its particular brand of foreign policy. Carter didn’t attack President Bush personally, but said that “as far as the adverse impact on the nation around the world, this administration has been the worst in history,” which can’t really be too far out of line with what many Americans think.

headline: Dreaming of Citywide Broadband
text: The city’s Broadband Advisory Committee, created in 2005, includes representatives of the City Council and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg who are trying to find ways to broaden Internet access across the five boroughs. The committee held a public hearing yesterday at Borough Hall in Brooklyn, led by Councilwoman Gale A. Brewer, a Democrat from Manhattan.

headline: It’s a Boy for Mary Cheney
text: For such a little guy Samuel David Cheney, weighing in at 8 lbs., 6 oz., sure prompted a hefty debate in the run-up to his birth in Washington this morning. He’s the son of Mary Cheney, and his grandfather is Vice President Dick Cheney.

headline: Giuliani Takes on Edwards
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani found a useful foil in Ron Paul during the recent Republican debate, and now he’s taking on a Democrat — John Edwards — to make his points on the national security front during an appearance today in New Hampshire.

headline: Next Year’s Budget, This Year
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer, in a speech tonight to the Citizens Budget Commission, plans to announce that he will move up the budget calendar by a couple of months to try to ease the state’s tight negotiating timetable.

headline: A Life in Rim Shots
text: What does it take to be a comedy writer? Some people ask because they want to be one and some (the more fortunate ones) because they merely want to know.

headline: Delgado Dropped to Sixth
text: Carlos Delgado’s struggles have cost him his hold on the cleanup spot in the lineup. Willie Randolph dropped him to sixth, replacing him with David Wright, marking the first time Delgado has started a game and hit that low since May 14, 1997, when he played with Toronto.

headline: “In Darfur”
text: My assistant, Winter Miller, who keeps order as I go gallivanting around the globe, wrote a terrific play called “In Darfur” — about the ethical issues that arise in reporting in a hellhole like Darfur. It was inspired in part by a trip to the Chad-Darfur border a year ago in which she accompanied me through burned-out villages

headline: U.S. Championship, Final: Shabalov Wins
text: Alexander Shabalov beat Sergey Kudrin in the last round of the Frank K. Berry U.S. Championship in Stillwater, Okla., to win the tournament and claim the title of U.S. champion. Alexander Onischuk, last year’s champion, had a chance to tie for first, but he was held to a draw in the last round by Boris Gulko. Onischuk finished second and Gregory Kaidanov, Yury Shulman Julio Becerra finished in a tie for third. The games can be replayed here at Monroi.com.

headline: E-Mail on My Cellphone
text: Who needs a BlackBerry or a Treo? David Pogue reviews three free services that send your e-mail to any cellphone.

headline: You Want Yankee News? Tonight’s Your Night

headline: Your Comments on My China Trade Column
text: My Thursday column takes on China-bashing protectionists but also notes that China is going to face difficult transitions ahead. I tend to think there’s a bit too much China exuberance right now and that most people don’t adequately allow for the challenges ahead.

text: Nicholas D. Kristof visits a sweatshop in the heart of China's manufacturing region.

text: George Steinbrenner and the Boy Scouts of America would have been proud.

text: When Eric Dimenstein, a booker, first approached Conor Oberst — the heartthrob singer-songwriter better known as Bright Eyes — with the idea of playing seven shows at Town Hall, Mr. Oberst reacted like any up-from-the-underground indie rocker: he blanched.

headline: In Trinidad, Outdoor Life, Inner Desires
text: “There’s no hidin’ place down here,” Sophia Adams sings in “Moon on a Rainbow Shawl,” and she’s right. For Sophia and her neighbors in a crowded, cacophonous yard in Port of Spain, Trinidad, life is lived in public, and passing judgment on one another is as natural as singing.

headline: As Law Is Renegotiated, Immigrant Families Are on Edge
text: Amir Nikpouri was struck by love at a family gathering on the first trip he had made in many years to his home country, Iran.

headline: Refugees Pour Out of Camp in Lebanon
text: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, May 23  The stream of Palestinians flowing out of the Nahr al Bared refugee camp on this city’s outskirts continued Wednesday, as the Lebanese Army reinforced its positions and vowed to crush the militants inside.

headline: Study Finds Hurricanes Frequent in Some Cooler Periods
text: Over the last 5,000 years, the eastern Caribbean has experienced several periods, lasting centuries, in which strong hurricanes occurred frequently even though ocean temperatures were cooler than those measured today, according to a new study.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,418 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:

headline: Kenneth Sokoloff, 54, Economist, Is Dead
text: Kenneth L. Sokoloff, an economic historian who was a leading expert on the role the United States patent system played in technological and productivity advances in the 19th century, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 54.

text: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

headline: Bush Wants Tougher Sanctions on Iran
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 — President George W. Bush said today that he would seek tougher sanctions against Iran for defiantly pursuing a uranium-enrichment program that Western governments believe is intended to help develop nuclear weapons.

headline: Mine Blast Kills at Least 38 in Siberia
text: MOSCOW, May 24 — A gas explosion in a coal mine killed at least 38 people early this morning in a part of Siberia notorious for mine accidents, opening fresh wounds in a community scarred by an accident two months ago that claimed more than 100 lives.

headline: War Spending Bill Without Timetable Clears Congress
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 — Congress voted tonight to meet President Bush’s demand for almost $100 billion to pay for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan through September, providing a momentary truce in a bitter struggle over war policy.

headline: Sticking With the Basics to Stay on the Right Track
text: JOHNNY G’s original Spinning program includes five moves: standing flat, which means standing on the pedals and slightly increasing the resistance; seated flat, which means pedaling during warm-up and cool down; seated climb, which means sitting on the bike with an elevated resistance; standing climb, which means standing out of the saddle with resistance even higher; and jumps, which means moving up and out of the seat.

headline: Canada: Profit Up at Bank
text: The Bank of Montreal said second-quarter profit rose 3 percent as higher fees from mutual funds and stock sales offset a big loss in commodities trading. Net income climbed to 671 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from 651 million Canadian dollars a year earlier, the bank said. Record mutual fund sales and rising demand for loans contributed to a 24 percent increase in consumer banking profit, countering the commodities losses, which were related to natural gas trading. The bank said on May 17 that it would report a pretax trading loss of 680 million Canadian dollars. Bank of Montreal said profit was 1.31 Canadian dollars a share excluding the trading loss and other one-time items, an increase of 3.1 percent from a year ago. Revenue in the quarter, which ended April 30, rose 2.7 percent, to 2.57 billion Canadian dollars from 2.5 billion Canadian dollars.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on May 16 about clashes in Gaza between the military wing of Hamas and forces loyal to Hamas’s rival, Fatah, misidentified the affiliation of seven men who were killed in a jeep and whose weapons were stolen in the attack. They were members of the pro-Fatah National Security Forces, not the Presidential Guard.

headline: A Predator Preys Mostly on Our Minds
text: MIDDLETOWN, N.J.

headline: Yankees Likely to Cut Ties With Pavano
text: The Yankees all but closed a maddening chapter of their recent history yesterday by admitting that Carl Pavano has probably thrown his last pitch for the team. Doctors have determined that Pavano has a damaged elbow ligament, and Pavano has decided to undergo reconstructive surgery.

headline: When They Say You Are a Spammer
text: About a year ago, Scott Madlener, a marketing executive, e-mailed a client several times but his messages were not getting through.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column yesterday about a free folk music series on Governors Island this summer erroneously included a deceased singer among the performers. The concert called “Harry Chapin: A Celebration in Song” will be performed by friends and family members of Mr. Chapin, who died in 1981.

headline: Bronx: Inmate Charged in Murder Plot
text: An inmate at Rikers Island was arraigned yesterday on charges that he tried to arrange the murder of a 31-year-old Queens woman who is scheduled to testify against him, prosecutors said. The inmate, Ashumba Bryan, 29, of Brooklyn, was charged with conspiracy to commit murder, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Bryan is awaiting trial on charges of attacking and robbing the woman in October 2005  beating her and throwing her out of her moving car, prosecutors said. Mr. Brown said Mr. Bryan was captured on audiotape in April trying to arrange the woman’s murder for $10,000 to prevent her from testifying.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article last Thursday about concerns in Congress over broadcasts of Islamic militant views by Al Hurra, an American government-financed television network in the Middle East, referred incorrectly to the timing of the appointment of the network’s new vice president for news, Larry Register. Mr. Register was already on the job when Al Hurra broadcast a speech by Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, in December; he was not hired to make sure such broadcasts did not recur. The article also misstated the length of Sheik Nasrallah’s broadcast speech; it was 67 minutes, not 30 minutes.

headline: Real People Meet Real Design
text: MARK CRISPIN MILLER squinted into the hanging, eyeball-high tunnel made by the decorative smashed-glass panels of Yorgos Papadapoulos, a Greek Cypriot living in London and showing at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair last Saturday, and worried aloud. “I think these defy the broken-window doctrine of policing,” he said. “You’d be tempted to run amok in your own house. Who knows where that would lead?”

headline: Getting a Chance to Fill Up Before the Price Goes Up
text: DETROIT, May 23  A Michigan-based retail chain is trying to help customers save money by warning them several hours beforehand about price increases at its gasoline stations.

headline: Top of Throgs Neck Bridge Is Home to Family of Falcons
text: There’s plenty of room for a growing family, and the views can’t be beat.

text: To the Editor:

headline: A Rose-Colored Reality Where Everyone Wins
text: There are no sore losers on reality television.

headline: Currency’s Rise Stokes Concern in India
text: NEW DELHI, May 23 — Concerned that the rising value of the Indian rupee is threatening to limit the country’s economic growth, especially in the lucrative outsourcing industry, monetary policy experts here have started putting pressure on the Reserve Bank of India to stem the rupee’s rise.

headline: Senate Narrowly Rejects Changes in Immigration Bill
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 — - The Senate narrowly rejected two proposals today that would have upset the delicate compromise embodied in a bipartisan bill to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws.

headline: S.E.C. Revises Its Standards for Corporate Audits
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new guidelines yesterday that try to balance the need for tighter financial controls with the cost of complying with them. It said the new procedures will make it less costly for smaller companies to assess the state of their internal financial controls.

headline: Brazil: Minister Quits Under Cloud
text: In a widening corruption scandal, the sixth to strike the government of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva since he took office in 2003, the minister of mines and energy, Silas Rondeau, resigned. Citing wiretapping and videotape evidence, the police say he accepted a $50,000 bribe from a construction company in return for preferential treatment in the awarding of contracts for a rural electric program.

headline: City to Pay $2 Million to Parents of Man Fatally Shot by an Officer
text: The city agreed yesterday to pay $2 million to the parents of a young man killed in a Brooklyn stairwell, ending a three-year effort to account for the damage done by a single bullet fired by a police officer.

headline: From Israel, N.B.A. Is Still a Long Shot
text: Yotam Halperin’s bid to become the first Israeli player in the N.B.A., as described in the October 2006 issue of PLAY, has remained in limbo since he returned to Israel and his team there, Maccabi Tel Aviv. The news media’s attention on his N.B.A. quest wore on him, his agent says, and he struggled through the first half of the season in the Israeli league. But in the second half he turned things around and led Tel Aviv to the playoffs, where the team is still alive. The Seattle SuperSonics chose Halperin in the second round of the 2006 draft and still own his N.B.A. rights, but will likely not make a decision about his future until June, according to the agent, Jason Levien. For now, Halperin is keeping his thoughts on an N.B.A. career to himself. “There was so much media hype and attention about him playing in the N.B.A. that he is not talking to the media about it right now,” Levien said. “He just doesn’t want to talk about it.”

headline: Turkey Vows to Pursue Militant Kurds Into Iraq
text: ISTANBUL, May 23  Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said in sharp language on Wednesday that Turkey would move against Kurdish militants in northern Iraq if necessary, hours after the Turkish authorities said they had identified the suicide bomber in an attack on Tuesday in Ankara as a man from a predominantly Kurdish city.

headline: Prisoner of Her Desires
text: Brussels

headline: Truth, Cynicism and the Baseball Way
text: So, Major League Baseball, in its current truth and candor phase, wants to finally dig into the seedy depths of its Steroid Era and reveal who injected what, when they did so and in what dosages. Right. Let’s review the current Jason Giambi tempest for what it is: baseball business as usual, which is to say, cynicism as usual.

headline: An Owner Gets a Title, but Not His Wish
text: Now that he is no longer prime minister of Italy, Silvio Berlusconi has more time to focus on the truly important things in life — that is to say, the starting formation for his A.C. Milan soccer team.

headline: Rethinking Old Age
text: At some point in life, you can’t live on your own anymore. We don’t like thinking about it, but after retirement age, about half of us eventually move into a nursing home, usually around age 80. It remains your most likely final address outside of a hospital.

headline: Crazy, He Calls Me (and Terrified, I Agree)
text: There is a case to be made that “Gaslight,” Patrick Hamilton’s 1938 play, currently the subject of an excellent revival at the Irish Repertory Theater, is the seed from which the Lifetime television channel eventually grew. It established the blueprint for a kind of domestic-peril thriller that has defined that channel’s identity and purpose. Every time an actress like Lisa Rinna or Heather Locklear portrays the sort of wife who discovers that the greatest threat to her mental and physical safety is the man sitting in her breakfast nook, Mr. Hamilton’s estate ought to receive some type of remuneration.

headline: After Gains in the North, Sinn Fein Seeks a Louder Voice in Ireland
text: DUBLIN, May 23  Weeks after its return to Northern Ireland’s power-sharing government, Sinn Fein, the political affiliate of the Irish Republican Army, is trying to extend its influence in the Irish Republic, pursuing its goal of a united Ireland.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A map with a front-page article on Monday about a clash between Lebanese troops and Islamic militants at a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon misidentified the city shown south of Beirut, the capital. It is Sidon  not Tyre, which is about 25 miles south of Sidon. A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/world/middleeast

headline: Pérez, Using His Full Repertory, Baffles the Braves Again
text: ATLANTA, May 23 — After years of experimenting, the Mets have discovered the one ingredient they need to defeat the Braves. His name is Oliver Pérez. The Mets have defeated the Braves three times this season. Pérez has won all three games, including a 3-0 victory Wednesday night at Turner Field that ensured the Mets will leave town atop the National League East.

headline: Morgan Library Chooses Familiar Face for Its Next Chief
text: Four months after Charles E. Pierce Jr. announced plans to retire as director of the Morgan Library & Museum, the institution’s board has named a familiar face as his successor: William M. Griswold, who was a curator at the Morgan for six years and is now director and president of the Minneapolis Institute of Arts. He assumes the post in early 2008.

headline: With a New Sock, the Red Sox Add Some Distance
text: In 2004 Curt Schilling’s bloodied socks — the ones he wore that October while he conquered the Yankees and the St. Louis Cardinals on the way to Boston’s first World Series championship in 86 seasons — were the symbol of the Red Sox.

headline: A House on the Hudson With a Japanese Soul
text: GERMANTOWN, N.Y.

headline: Candidate to Lead Consumer Agency Withdraws
text: WASHINGTON, May 23 — A senior lobbyist at the National Association of Manufacturers withdrew his nomination to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission on Wednesday as a growing number of senators questioned both his suitability and a $150,000 departure payment that the association was preparing to give him.

headline: Pirates and Sanctions
text: DONGGUAN, China

headline: Manhattan: Cancer Screening Awareness
text: A group of the city’s most powerful women gathered outside City Hall yesterday to promote regular breast cancer screening through mammograms, whose use has been steadily decreasing. The group, which included First Deputy Mayor Patricia E. Harris; the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn; and the public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, announced a public awareness campaign, assisted by Macy’s, to inform women about how and when to schedule exams. Ms. Harris said fewer women were receiving regular mammograms than in the past. According to a study recently published in the medical journal Cancer, the decline could be a result of a shortage of available testing, questions about the effectiveness of the exam and higher patient co-payments.

headline: Lead Lawyer for Landis Describes Errors by Lab
text: MALIBU, Calif., May 23 — For nine days, lawyers from the United States Anti-Doping Agency sat next to a wooden easel that displayed Floyd Landis’s drug-test results.

headline: Free Software to Play DVDs
text: Q. I would like to watch DVDs on my computer with a program that works better than Windows Media Player. Are there any free ones available?

headline: ‘The Apprentice: Omaha Edition,’ Starring Warren Buffett
text: A number of years ago, in a moment of professional weakness, I bought exactly one share of Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway (the Class B share, mind you, not the $100,000 kind).
