text: A performance by the Adamas String Quartet as part of the Juilliard String Quartet Seminar recital.

headline: The Akademos Quartet
text: A performance by the Akademos Quartet at Carnegie Hall as part of the Emerson String Quartet's "Perspectives" series.

headline: The Calder Quartet
text: A performance from the Calder Quartet as part of the Juilliard String Quartet recital.

headline: Jasper String Quartet
text: A performance from the Jasper String Quartet as part of the Juilliard String Quartet recital.

headline: Le Musiche Quartet
text: A performance by Le Musiche Quartet at Carnegie Hall, as part of the Emerson String Quartet Young Artists Concert.

headline: A Perfect Night for a Pitching Duel
text: The game-time temperature here was 79 degrees. There’s hardly a cloud in the sky. And on the field are the top two teams in the National League East, only one and a half games separating them, and two of the best pitchers of this era, Tom Glavine and John Smoltz, are pitching. Glavine is five victories from 300, and Smoltz can notch No. 200 tonight. And yet I can see sections on the lower bowl that have a handful of fans, and the upper decks aren’t much better.

headline: At Women’s Team Championship, China Is Flexing Its Muscle
text: If anyone had doubts about how far the Chinese women have come, they are being dispelled at the First Women’s Team Championship in Yekaterinburg, Russia. After five rounds, the Chinese women lead with 9 points out of a possible 10 (two points are awarded for a victory, one for a tie), followed by Russia with 8 and the Ukraine with 7. The tournament began on May 19 and runs through May 30. The official Web site is  here.

headline: Americans Support Immigration Change
text: Julia Preston reports on a nationwide New York Times/CBS News poll addressing immigration reform.

headline: A Slogan for Gore? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Not on Every Map, but a Desirable Location Anyway
text: KAY STEVENS remembers when there was no Lake Oconee, only a river running through pineland and dairy farms in the Georgia Piedmont. “The busiest day of the week was Thursday,” she said, “when people were going to the cow sale.”

headline: Chinese Officials Extol Benefits of U.S. Relations
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 — Chinese leaders traveled from the White House to Capitol Hill on Thursday, trying to persuade skeptics of the benefits of the Chinese-American relationship. But they appeared to make little headway in quelling Congressional anger over China’s economic practices.

headline: Immigrants and Politics
text: A piece of advice for progressives trying to figure out where they stand on immigration reform: it’s the political economy, stupid. Analyzing the direct economic gains and losses from proposed reform isn’t enough. You also have to think about how the reform would affect the future political environment.

headline: For Daredevil Skiing, the Season Is Now
text: AS ski season vanishes to slush in much of the country, it’s only just beginning at Tuckerman Ravine in New Hampshire. Tens of thousands of skiers, boarders and adventurers from all over the world start arriving there in late April, and work and worry the snowy proving ground until at least June and sometimes into July.

headline: Shiite Cleric Resurfaces With Anti-U.S. Sermon
text: BAGHDAD, May 25 — The populist Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr appeared in public for the first time in months on Friday, delivering a fiercely anti-American sermon and offering himself in a new guise as a nationalist intent on bridging the divide between Iraq’s warring communities of Shiites and Sunnis.

headline: Apologetic, Home Depot Tries to Move Beyond Nardelli’s Shadow
text: ATLANTA, May 24  For two hours, Home Depot executives did not utter his name.

headline: Klein to Overhaul Alternative Schools Programs to Deter Potential Dropouts
text: With half of New York City’s students failing to graduate on time, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced yesterday that the city planned to shut down some schools and programs for the most troubled students and to bolster others.

headline: Kelly Resists Tradition, and Mayor, on Police Pay
text: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly is so frustrated by his department’s problems with attracting recruits that he took a surprising slap this week at a time-honored city tradition — one supported by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Algeria’s Women Quietly Advance in Careers and Society
text: ALGIERS, May 25 — In this tradition-bound nation scarred by a brutal Islamist-led civil war that killed more than 100,000, a quiet revolution is under way: women are emerging as an economic and political force unheard of in the rest of the Arab world.

headline: Green Cards and Ph.D.’s (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Time Travel
text: “Masterworks of Six Centuries” continues through June 15 at these Manhattan galleries:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,422 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:

headline: Netherlands: Russia Wins a Yukos Round
text: Russia won an incremental victory in the legal struggle for what remains of the foreign subsidiaries of Yukos. A Dutch court approved a request by the Russian bankruptcy administrator, Eduard K. Rebgun, to represent Yukos in court in the Netherlands. While most of Yukos’s assets have been unraveled and sold at auction, a company bank account in the Netherlands holding about $1 billion from the sale of a Lithuanian refinery is still in dispute. A Dutch court has yet to rule on Mr. Rebgun’s claim to the property, according to a statement by Yukos shareholders. The money is also claimed by Yukos shareholders and creditors.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about “Gods, Myths and Mortals: Discover Ancient Greece,” an exhibition that opens today at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan, misspelled the name of the Cyclops who captured Odysseus and is depicted in the exhibition. He is Polyphemus, not Polymephus.

headline: Harvey Weinstein, 82, Kidnapping Victim Who Kept His Cool, Dies
text: Harvey J. Weinstein, a formal wear manufacturer whose kidnapping and survival after 12 days in a barrel-shaped pit near the Hudson River in Manhattan made headlines around the country in August 1993, died on May 13 at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Capitalist Roaders (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: F.B.I. Seizes Air Ambulance Company’s Files
text: Justice Department investigators have seized records from the headquarters of a large operator of medical helicopters as part of an investigation, apparently into possible health care fraud.

headline: Congress Passes Increase in the Minimum Wage
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 — Congress handed a major victory to low-income workers on Thursday night by approving the first increase in the federal minimum wage rate in a decade.

headline: Facebook Expands Into MySpace’s Territory
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 — With an ambitious strategy for expansion, Facebook is getting in MySpace’s face.

headline: Off the Back of a Truck, and Healthy
text: TROY, N.Y.

headline: Home Depot Chief Offers Apology to Shareholders
text: ATLANTA, May 24 — First, there was an apology.

headline: A Partisan in the Halls of Justice (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lawmakers in New Jersey Advance Bill on Paid Leave
text: TRENTON, May 24 — Employees of many New Jersey businesses would be entitled to up to 10 weeks of family leave with partial pay for a new baby, a difficult pregnancy or an ill parent or spouse, under a measure approved on Thursday by a Senate committee.

headline: Iraqi Shiite Cleric Reportedly Ends a Sojourn in Iran
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 — The powerful Iraqi cleric Moktada al- Sadr has quietly returned to southern Iraq after a four-month sojourn in Iran, according to American intelligence reports.

headline: A Death Tied to 9/11 Dust Is Not Cause for Alarm to Others, Experts Say
text: When the New York City medical examiner decided last week that Felicia Dunn-Jones’s death was directly linked to the dust of the destroyed twin towers, making her the 2,750th victim of the attack on Sept. 11, Mrs. Dunn-Jones’s husband, Joseph, was relieved beyond words.

headline: Selig Weighs Whether to Sanction Giambi
text: Commissioner Bud Selig has received a report from the three lawyers who met with the Yankees’ Jason Giambi on Wednesday regarding his tacit comments about steroid use. Giambi told USA Today last week, “I was wrong for doing that stuff” in an article focused on steroids.

headline: Young People Arrested When They Gathered to Attend a Wake Ask for an Apology
text: The arrests of about 30 young people on the way to a friend’s wake on Monday have set off a wave of anger in Bushwick, Brooklyn, with more than 50 teenagers assembling yesterday to demand an apology, and their teachers saying that the police had unfairly made a target of the arrested youths  some as young as 13.

headline: Three Women With One Goal at Indy
text: INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 — Women will drive 3 of the 33 cars in the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday, a first for an event that dates to 1911. Danica Patrick, one of the three women, sounded as if she would be more excited about this moment if it accompanied a big head start.

headline: Albany: Interim SUNY Chancellor Nominee
text: The State University of New York nominated John B. Clark yesterday to be interim chancellor of its 64-campus system starting June 1. The current chancellor, John R. Ryan, announced in March that he would step down at the end of May. Dr. Clark, who worked on Wall Street for 17 years and has a doctorate from Teachers College at Columbia University, is currently interim president of the State University College of Technology at Alfred. This will be his sixth interim post at SUNY, including three other campus presidencies. SUNY said that if Dr. Clark is approved by its board on May 31, he will remain through Dec. 31, or until its trustees conclude a national search for a permanent chancellor. Dr. Clark, 56, will earn $340,000, but will not be a candidate for permanent chancellor, the university said.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: In a Crowded Anime Dreamscape, a Mysterious Pixie
text: In “Paprika,” a gorgeous riot of future-shock ideas and brightly animated imagery, the doors of perception never close. A mind-twisting, eye-tickling wonder, this anime from the Japanese director Satoshi Kon bears little relation to the greasy, sticky kid stuff that Hollywood churns out, those fatuous fables with wisecracking woodland creatures selling lessons in how to be a good child so you can grow up to be a good citizen. Model behavior isn’t on the menu in “Paprika,” and neither are dinky songs and visuals. Here, when a woman sprouts a pair of wings, she doesn’t only flit about like Tinker Bell; she’s also pinned captive to a table, a man’s hand slithering under her skin.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article yesterday about the end of the arbitration hearing between the cyclist Floyd Landis and the United States Anti-Doping Agency referred imprecisely in some copies to Landis’s potential place in Tour de France history. He could become the first champion in the Tour’s 103-year history to be stripped of the title for a doping violation, not the first to be stripped of the title.

headline: Ukrainian Political Crisis Escalates
text: MOSCOW, May 25 -- President Viktor A. Yushchenko issued a decree today putting Ukraine’s interior troops under presidential command, but the Interior Ministry, joined by Prime Minister Viktor A. Yanukovich, declared the move unconstitutional and defied it.

headline: U.S. Growth Expected to Cool, Falling Below Pace in Europe
text: FRANKFURT, May 24 —Economic growth in Europe and Japan is expected to outpace that in the United States this year for the first time since 2001, as a slowdown in the American housing market curbs growth, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Thursday.

headline: For New York, Big Job Growth in Home Care
text: New York City’s economy has been booming, with unemployment dropping to historic lows and Wall Street getting most of the credit. But the typical new worker in the city is not a pinstriped investment banker or a corporate lawyer. She is a home health aide like Vivienne P. Smith.

headline: Documents From Sallie Mae Add to Questions About Timing of $18 Million Stock Sale
text: An internal document from Sallie Mae, the nation’s largest student lender, showed that the company sought a meeting with President Bush’s budget office about two months before the company’s chairman, Albert L. Lord, sold more than $18 million in shares.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on May 16 about Robert S. Oelman, former chief executive of NCR, referred incorrectly to Mr. Oelman’s support of Nelson Rockefeller’s efforts to become president. Mr. Rockefeller asked Mr. Oelman to head up his Ohio campaign in 1968  but not in 1972, when Mr. Rockefeller decided against seeking the presidency and instead supported President Nixon’s re-election.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: ‘Star Wars,’ the Way You Like It

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN.

headline: China’s Leaders Confront Their Manic Market
College Considers a Plan to Sell Its Art Collection
text: Short on funds and fearful of losing its accreditation, Randolph-Macon Woman’s College in Lynchburg, Va., is exploring the possibility of saving itself by sharing its most valuable asset: a world-class collection of American art. Worth more than $100 million, it includes paintings by George Bellows, Edward Hopper, William Merritt Chase and Georgia O’Keeffe.

headline: New Haven: No Bail in Terror Case
text: A federal judge yesterday denied bail to a former Navy sailor held since March on charges that he provided classified information to the owner of a Web site that supported terrorist causes. Prosecutors charge that in 2001, Hassan Abujihaad, 31, of Phoenix, then a signalman aboard the guided missile destroyer Benfold, sent a document detailing the planned movements and vulnerabilities of a group of ships in the Persian Gulf to Babar Ahmad, the owner of the Web site, who ran it in Britain through an Internet hosting company in Connecticut. Mr. Ahmad has been indicted and is awaiting extradition. In denying bail for Mr. Abujihaad, Judge Mark Kravitz of Federal District Court cited the fact that Mr. Abujihaad has a fiancée in Morocco and is said to have discussed plans to buy two assault rifles in the months before his arrest. A trial is scheduled for the fall.

headline: In This Clash, Both Sides Are Good
text: Few things are more routine in this city than fights over property. But how many of them have people talking about nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, X-ray crystallography or something called cryoelectron microscopy?

headline: Senators Accuse Bush of Ignoring Warnings on Iraq
text: WASHINGTON, May 25 — Democrats on a deeply divided Senate Intelligence Committee accused the Bush administration today of ignoring warnings in 2003 from the nation’s spy agencies that a post-war Iraq could face violence and division and that an invasion could strengthen the hand of Al Qaeda and Iran.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Monday about the efforts of three women in Atlanta to combat mortgage fraud misstated the location of one woman’s neighborhood. Smoke Rise is east of Atlanta, not west.

headline: Ireland Votes on Whether to Give the Prime Minister a Third Term
text: DUBLIN, May 24 — Irish voters went to the polls on Thursday in a national ballot that will decide whether Prime Minister Bertie Ahern secures a third successive term after 10 years in office.

headline: Where the Road to Renaming Does Not Run Smooth
text: DURBAN, South Africa, May 18 — None of South Africa’s big cities are so redolent of colonialism as this old seaport, namesake of a British major general and headquarters, in the early 1800s, of a British colony at Africa’s southern tip. Durban’s baroque city hall is said to be a clone of Belfast’s. From Brighton Beach to Victoria Market, allusions to colonial dominance are inescapable.

headline: Get Moving on Traffic Relief
text: Congestion pricing, a system of charging drivers for traveling on a city’s most-crowded streets, is a proven success that New York City is right to want to emulate. It has worked in Stockholm and London, where skepticism gave way to resounding support. Residents of both cities were turned around by the unclogged streets, quicker commutes, better public transportation and cleaner air. Now that Mayor Michael Bloomberg wants to give congestion pricing a try, state leaders, starting with Gov. Eliot Spitzer, should get on board.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10:30 P.M. (AMC) 2007 TAURUS WORLD STUNT AWARDS This annual ceremony honors Hollywood’s action heroes: the men and women who take the falls — and the bullets, bruises and broken bones — for film stars. Awards will be given for hardest hit and best fight, fire, high work, specialty stunt and work with a vehicle. Nominees include Tony Angelotti, who was seriously injured while doubling for Johnny Depp in the third “Pirates of the Caribbean” installment. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California will present a lifetime achievement award to Burt Reynolds; Jeannie Epper will be recognized as the godmother of stuntwomen. Dwayne Johnson (the Rock), above, will make a dramatic entrance as host. And since no stunt awards ceremony is complete without a little action, the ceremony will feature a parkour demonstration, a sword fight and a fashion show where the models aren’t just hot: they’re on fire.

headline: Gone With the Windmill Farms, or, a Cape Cod Cautionary Tale
text: Every so often a purely local dispute rises above its station and assumes national importance. This was the case with the Cape Wind project, a proposed wind farm that seemed to have everything going for it: It would deliver badly needed additional electric power to energy-hungry New England, reduce utility bills for everyone and cut down on air pollution. There was just one little problem. The spinning windmills would be located in Nantucket Sound, within view of some very expensive homes and some very wealthy and powerful citizens.

headline: People
text: People

headline: A Month of Coming-Out Parties
text: IT can be said that all of today’s gay rights — from those that allow marriage to those that protect from hate crimes — can be traced to a few tense days in June 1969. That’s when a group of patrons at the Stonewall Inn, an unlicensed gay bar in Greenwich Village, grew fed up with one too many raids on the club. They fought back against the police, setting off the Stonewall riots and spawning the modern gay rights movement.

headline: Topics That Make Money Managers Get All Sentimental
text: IT takes all kinds of investors to make a market, or so it seemed at a conference this week of the crème de la crème of money managers. Typically a reclusive bunch, the managers agreed to offer up a few of their investment ideas to a roomful of attentive money managers in an effort to raise money for pediatric cancer and other childhood diseases.

headline: Custom Stamps as a Status Symbol
text: MADISON AVENUE used to have high hopes for the lowly postage stamp. For decades, advertisers imagined that if only the legal barriers against commercial images on postage stamps came down, they could do great things on envelopes.

headline: Israel Seizes 33 Palestinians in Crackdown
text: JERUSALEM, May 24 — Israel stepped up its campaign against Hamas on Thursday, arresting 33 prominent West Bank Palestinians in early morning raids, including a cabinet minister, three legislators and three mayors, and accusing them of “terrorist activity,” army officials said.

headline: In Three Visions of Balanchine, Charm, Romance and Drama
text: We could waste time about whether New York City Ballet’s new triple bill should really be labeled “Essential Balanchine.” Although “Walpurgisnacht Ballet,” which opens the program, is certainly intoxicating, most Balanchinaholics would surely count at least 25 other ballets by the master as more essential than this one. No matter: it, and more indubitably the two that follow, plunge us deep into the essential Balanchine experience, which is one of transformation. Those onstage are seen to change, the place they inhabit is felt to change, and ultimately we know that we too are changed, we know not how.

headline: Senate Votes to Keep Plan to Make Immigrants Legal
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 — The Senate on Thursday turned aside the most significant challenge to the comprehensive immigration bill now under debate, voting 66 to 29 to keep a provision that offers legal status to most of the nation’s 12 million illegal immigrants.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 18 through May 23 with 1,125 adults throughout the United States.

headline: Nascar’s Rules Tested by Tests on New Car
text: CONCORD, N.C., May 24  Hendrick Motorsports drivers have won all five Nextel Cup races involving the Nascar-designed Car of Tomorrow. Around the garage, there is no secret to their success: The team has tested the car at various tracks as much as or more than any other team, gathering information that has translated into victories.

headline: Those Tired, Those Poor: A Journey as Important as Its Destination
text: In its basic outline the story told in “Golden Door,” Emanuele Crialese’s beautiful dream of a film, is hardly unfamiliar. Some version of this immigrant’s tale — setting out from the old country, crossing the Atlantic in steerage, arriving at Ellis Island — is part of the family history of millions of Americans. But what makes Mr. Crialese’s telling unusual, apart from the gorgeousness of his wide-screen compositions, is that his emphasis is on departure and transition, rather than arrival.

headline: Art in Review
text: FRANCESCO CLEMENTE Works, 1971-1979  Deitch Projects 76 Grand Street, SoHo Through June 2

headline: After 7 Years in Prison, Muslim Cleric Is Deported From Britain
text: LONDON, May 25 — The British authorities, grappling with ways to contain suspected terrorists, deported today a Jamaican-born Muslim preacher and convert to Islam accused of influencing one of the attackers in the London bombings of July 2005.

headline: Lighting the Way
text: Sometimes thinking small can get things done. To bring artificial light to an isolated village or refugee camp could require building an enormous hydroelectric dam, followed by laying hundreds of miles of cable. Or it could take the donation of a $10 solar flashlight.

headline: Coming Soon to Wal-Mart: 2 Dell PCs
text: Dell, in a first step toward transforming its ailing strategy of selling direct to consumers, said yesterday that it planned to offer computers at Wal-Mart Stores, starting in June.

headline: Alcohol, Drugs and Abortion (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about a lawsuit over a sale of corporate bonds referred incorrectly to the current status of the Citigroup business that sold the bonds. That business is now owned by Legg Mason; it is not a part of the Smith Barney unit of Citigroup. (Citigroup and its affiliates are defendants in the lawsuit; Legg Mason is not.)

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Closer to Reform
text: With their credibility on the line, House Democrats did the right thing yesterday by mandating disclosure of the lobbying industry’s power to purchase Capitol influence with richly bundled campaign donations to pliable lawmakers.

headline: Japan: Consumer Prices Slow
text: Consumer prices fell at a slower pace in April, the government reported. Core consumer prices, which exclude fresh food, declined 0.1 percent from a year earlier. The measure of inflation fell 0.3 percent in March, the steepest drop in two years, matching the median estimate of 44 economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. Core prices in Tokyo, a harbinger of nationwide prices, were unchanged for a second month, also in line with economists’ expectations.

headline: When Art Meets Science, Things Don’t Go Very Well
text: Carl Djerassi probably doesn’t want to hear this, since he has written that he consciously reduces the amount of science in his plays to make them more commercial, but: There’s not enough science in his play “Phallacy,” which is receiving its American premiere at the Cherry Lane Theater.

headline: Ann Taylor and Gap Say Earnings Fell in the Quarter
text: Gap Inc., the largest United States clothing retailer, reported its seventh consecutive quarterly decline in profit yesterday, and the women’s apparel retailer Ann Taylor Stores also reported lower first-quarter profit.

headline: G.M. Details Delphi Exposure, Gets S.E.C. Request
text: DETROIT, May 24 — General Motors said today that it expects to take a $1 billion charge in the second quarter and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at the Delphi Corporation, its former parts division.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Ignoring the Warnings, Again?
text: The latest findings on Avandia, a top-selling diabetes drug, raise concerns both about its safety and about the way the manufacturer and the Food and Drug Administration have responded to signs of danger. It would be rash to make definitive judgments until the F.D.A. completes a detailed analysis. But the handling of this case bears disturbing resemblances to the Vioxx debacle, in which early warning signs were ignored by its manufacturer until the evidence of serious harm became inescapable and the drug was pulled from the market.

headline: From the Edge of Madness to Fighting’s Mainstream
text: Mixed martial arts was, in its recent outlaw years, the criminal element of sports, called “human cockfighting” by Senator John McCain and written into legal exile in New York by a stroke of former Gov. George E. Pataki’s pen.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about Wynn Handman, an acting teacher and director in New York who was honored on Monday for his 85th birthday by students and protégés, misspelled the given name of one former student and misstated the name of a drama program for high school students produced by American Place Theater, which Mr. Handman founded. The former student is the actress Allison Janney, not Alison, and the program is Literature to Life, not Literacy for Life.

headline: Poll Shows View of Iraq War Is Most Negative Since Start
text: Americans now view the war in Iraq more negatively than at any time since the invasion more than four years ago, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: In Need of Income, Cemeteries Are Seeking Breathing Clientele
text: PHILADELPHIA — The dinner was first-class, with butlers serving hors d’oeuvres and the strains of “Blue Danube” tastefully muffling the festive din. This nine-course re-creation of the last supper aboard an ill-fated ocean liner was the culmination of Titanic Day at Laurel Hill Cemetery, one of a growing number of historic cemeteries to rebrand themselves as destination necropolises for weekend tourists.

headline: Israel Strikes Near Palestinian Leader’s Home
text: JERUSALEM, May 25 — The Israeli army continued its air campaign against the Hamas infrastructure in the Gaza Strip late Thursday and today, striking at least eight different locations, an army spokesman said.

headline: Starring New York, City of Grit and Glamour
text: To walk through the main concourse at Grand Central Terminal is to step onto a real-life movie set. Cary Grant passes through it while escaping his would-be killers in “North by Northwest.” Jim Carrey grabs Kate Winslet’s hand and dashes across it in “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind,” watching people vanish one by one as his memory is erased. Most tellingly, it is the site of a pivotal moment in “The Fisher King,” when Robin Williams, as a pure-hearted, emotionally unbalanced man, spots the quite plain woman of his dreams heading for her train. Suddenly everyone in the room breaks into a waltz, as this grimy, everyday place becomes a scene of glittering romance.

headline: Bush Reaffirms His Support for Gonzales
text: WASHINGTON, May 24  President Bush said Thursday that he would correct any problems uncovered in the investigations of last year’s dismissals of federal prosecutors, but he added that nothing had undermined his support for Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales.

headline: Clinton Revisits Health Care and Affordability
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who endured a major political setback as first lady when she tried to promote universal health care, revived that crusade yesterday but in a more measured way, offering a plan to reduce costs, through programs like disease prevention, to make universal coverage affordable.

headline: The Shushing of the Boos
text: CANNES, France, May 24 — Whether because of happenstance or hard work, the 60th Cannes Film Festival has presented attendees with an embarrassment of riches. The competition lineup has been notably strong, on occasion galvanizing, resulting in more cheers from the international press than jeers (a beloved tradition) than I’ve heard in the past decade. The knives have come out for a few films — the very presence of Quentin Tarantino’s extended-play version of “Death Proof” in the main competition proved an affront to some — but this has been a week in which it has been blissfully easy to confirm your love for cinema, not your pessimism about the state of a beloved art.

headline: Take Me Out to the Baggage Check
text: Zeljko Bibic was headed into Yankee Stadium on Wednesday with a Tumi bag slung over his shoulder and his son, Nikola, at his side. Not so fast, he was told at the gate. The bag was too large to be permitted inside.

headline: EGL Accepts Buyout Offer From Apollo
text: The logistics company EGL has ended its buyout agreement with its chief, James R. Crane, and has accepted a higher offer from Ceva Logistics, which is owned by Apollo Management.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A caption for a comic-book illustration yesterday with a sports article about the attention that Kelly Kulick received as the first woman to earn a season-long exemption on the Professional Bowlers Association Tour, including a role in a Spider-Man comic, misidentified the character shown in the illustration. It was Miss Arrow  not Kulick’s bowler-turned-action hero character. (An illustration showing Kulick’s character can be found at nytimes.com/sports.)

headline: Rookie Reliever Shows Versatility and Wins Respect
text: ATLANTA, May 24  The other night, Billy Wagner responded to a radio reporter’s request for an interview by calling out Joe Smith’s name.

headline: Exploring the Nature of the Unnatural
text: They lure children into dank swamps and devour them. They live in caves or among high rocks or deep in dense forests. They are covered with scales or thick fur. They have hands at the ends of their tails or a single glaring eye. They exhale fire, cause hurricanes with their wings or feast on human eyes, teeth and nails. They might also whimsically help the unwitting, but they are almost all mercurial, unreliable, tricksters.

headline: Young String Quartets, Learning From the Masters
text: On Tuesday and Wednesday I heard seven young string quartets coached by two eminent ensembles play music by three composers in two different halls. Five of the seven were all female. The overall demographic was 5 men and 23 women, three of whom showed signs of imminent motherhood. I have no idea what all this means and pass it on without comment.

headline: Immigration Bill Provisions Gain Wide Support in Poll
text: As opponents from the right and left challenge an immigration bill before Congress, there is broad support among Americans — Democrats, Republicans and independents alike — for the major provisions in the legislation, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: In Market, Hopes for Health and Urban Renewal
text: PHILADELPHIA — It seems that anyone you talk to in the streets around Progress Plaza, a tattered shopping center in a mainly black, poor part of North Philadelphia, is excited.

headline: New Effort to Continue Espionage Case
text: Federal prosecutors have offered to provide more classified information in open court to keep alive their prosecution of two former pro-Israel lobbyists charged with violating the Espionage Act. The lobbyists, who had been with the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, are charged with illegally giving national security information to Israeli officials and reporters. Citing national security concerns, the prosecutors had tried to close from public scrutiny a substantial part of the information to be used at trial. But Judge T. S. Ellis III of Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., ruled in April that the government’s proposal would not afford a fair trial to the two defendants, Steven J. Rosen and Keith Weissman. The prosecutors’ new proposal was filed under seal, but other government documents said it would allow “greater public disclosure of a significant amount of classified information.”

headline: At Cannes This Year, the Bankers May Outnumber the Movie Stars
text: CANNES, France, May 24 — One morning more than a decade ago, John W. Miller found himself trying to explain the Cannes Film Festival in a conference call to his colleagues at Chemical Bank.

headline: Poor Decisions? Knicks Deserve a Mulligan
text: As the N.B.A. playoffs grind forth, Madison Square Garden is dark once again.

headline: Iraq Presents Graduating Class at West Point With New Challenges
text: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 22 — The graduating cadets of the United States Military Academy spent their final days here like scores of seniors, or firsties, before them: packing foot lockers and showing their mothers around gray buildings and sweeping lawns. All smiles. Even the lone cadet marching in full uniform in a parking lot under the hot sun — a form of punishment called “walking the area” — flashed a grin when a friend passed.

headline: Ukraine Fires Prosecutor
text: MOSCOW, May 24  President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine dismissed the chief prosecutor on Thursday, news agencies reported.

headline: Coca-Cola Is Said to Buy Vitaminwater
text: Directors of the Coca-Cola Company last night approved the purchase of Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.2 billion in cash and Coke stock, according to an executive involved in the negotiations.

headline: Ensuring Food Safety (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Mission for Memorial Day: Always Remember
text: IF you traveled on one of the nation’s Interstates in these last few days before Memorial Day, you might have encountered an unusual sight: bikers by the dozens stretched half a mile down the highway, their motorcycles flying military banners and spewing exhaust.

headline: Risky Bets on Winning Tax Fights
text: Death may still be certain, but taxes are something else entirely.

headline: Mayor Has New Plan to Cite Drivers Who Block the Box
text: Ticketing drivers who block intersections would become much easier under a plan announced yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as part of a broader attack on traffic congestion.

headline: U.S. Casualties May Spike This Summer, Bush Warns
text: WASHINGTON, May 24  President Bush warned Thursday that casualties in Iraq could increase over the summer as the United States completes its troop buildup there.

headline: Rooftop Blaze on 34th Street Draws 100 Firefighters to Scene
text: More than 100 firefighters responded to a blaze yesterday atop a mixed-use building on West 34th Street. Investigators had not determined a cause last night.

headline: Slim for Summer: Good Reading, but Less (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Investigation Is Said to Open on Dow Chemical
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into whether two senior executives at Dow Chemical secretly tried to put the company into play as well as into the unusual trading in its stock that may have resulted, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Search for Vein Delays Execution of Ohio Inmate by 90 Minutes
text: LUCASVILLE, Ohio, May 24 (AP)  An overweight inmate was executed by injection on Thursday after a delay of about 90 minutes while prison medical workers struggled to find suitable veins in his arms.

headline: Bronx: Man Wounded in Shootout With Police
text: A man was shot in the shoulder during a gunfight with plainclothes officers in the Bronx early yesterday, the police said. Charges were pending against the man, Ron Tribble, 21, who was treated at St. Barnabas Hospital and released, the police said. The confrontation began at 173rd Street and Webster Avenue shortly before 4 a.m., the police said, when Mr. Tribble and another man flagged down an unmarked car carrying three plainclothes officers, possibly believing the car was a livery cab. After an officer rolled down his window, Mr. Tribble ran, the police said. The officers chased Mr. Tribble, and two of them fired after they saw him readying a gun to fire, the police said. After firing at the officers, Mr. Tribble jumped a fence, and was later found hiding in a yard, the police said.

headline: House Votes to Lift Veil Over Lobbyists’ Donations
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 — The House voted Thursday to drag into public view the role that registered lobbyists play in soliciting and collecting contributions for political campaigns, exposing for the first time one of the most effective ways that influence-seekers ingratiate themselves with lawmakers and presidents.

headline: Brian Leetch Retires From Hockey
text: Brian Leetch said he knew months ago that he had no comeback left in him. After sitting out the entire season, he finally announced his retirement yesterday, officially ending the 18-year career of arguably the best American-born player in N.H.L. history.

headline: At Least Give Giambi Some Credit
text: Imagine if Jason Giambi had gone to the House Government Reform Committee hearing in March 2005 and said what he told a USA Today reporter last week.

headline: The Catholic Boom
text: The pope and many others speak for the thoroughly religious. Christopher Hitchens has the latest best seller on behalf of the antireligious. But who speaks for the quasi-religious?

headline: At Friend’s Expense, Smoltz Claims No. 200
text: ATLANTA, May 24 — It may come as soon as this weekend, via telephone call or text message. Or after a competitive 18 holes in November. But there will surely come a time when John Smoltz and Tom Glavine will reflect on all that went on at Turner Field and share a good laugh. That is what friends do.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Public Lives column last Friday, about David Chang, the owner of the Momofuku restaurants in the East Village and the winner of this year’s James Beard Foundation award for best new chef, referred imprecisely to the Japanese name for another restaurant he plans to open, Ko. It is more accurately translated as “child” than “son of.”

headline: The Tuscany Life, in Croatia
text: FOR vacation-home buyers who want the feel of Tuscany but at lower prices, the peninsula of Istria in northern Croatia is proving to be a popular choice.

headline: No Segways Needed (1 Letter)
text: To The Editor:

headline: Congress Passes War Funds Bill, Ending Impasse
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 — Congress voted Thursday to meet President Bush’s demand for almost $100 billion to pay for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan through September, providing a momentary truce in a bitter struggle over war policy.

headline: WFNY Drops Talk Format and Returns to Rock, Citing Profits
text: New York City regained a rock radio station yesterday afternoon when WFNY-FM (92.3) largely abandoned the low-rated all-talk format it adopted in January 2006. The revamped station heralded its new format just after 5 p.m. when it played “All Apologies,” by Nirvana.

headline: U.S. Opens a Sheltered Path to Asylum for Some Iraqis
text: An obscure program that bypasses the State Department’s normal immigration procedures has granted a form of temporary asylum to a former minister who led Iraq’s troubled Health Ministry and to more than 100 other Iraqi professionals, witnesses of potential crimes by Americans, and children wounded in the conflict.

headline: On the Edge, a Man Finds Hope in a Mystery Woman
text: While watching Luc Besson’s comedy “Angel-A,” in which a leggy blond angel descends from on high to save the soul of a petty criminal who barely comes up to her shoulders, I had an unpleasant thought: if Hollywood got its hands on the story, Uma Thurman and Danny DeVito would be cast as the odd couple. Not much charm there. Or worse: Daryl Hannah and Pauly Shore.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Erin Go Faster
text: Princeton, N.J.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: For the Record
text: In the May 23 Editorial Observer about fires in California: John Cheever’s journal mentioned burning ghats, not burning gnats. Ghats are stairs from temples to the Ganges River in India, where Hindus traditionally construct funeral pyres. Gnats, of course, are tiny insects.

headline: Rooms Without Walls
text: WHO Carrie Wilhite, 40, a stay-at-home mother from Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., shown at rear with her husband, Brad, 42, an investment banker, as their three children play with two friends.

headline: Macedonian Is New Assembly President
text: Srgjan Kerim, a former foreign minister of Macedonia who has served as his country’s ambassador to Germany, Switzerland and Lichtenstein, and the United Nations, was elected president of the General Assembly for the 62nd session of the 192-member body, which begins in September. The post rotates by regions, and Mr. Kerim’s candidacy was put forward by the Eastern European group. He succeeds Haya Rashed al-Khalifa of Bahrain.

headline: Trump & Co. Hits Chicago to Drum Up Apartment Sales
text: CHICAGO, May 24 — It was a jarring sight for those going about their business in the low-key bustle of downtown on Thursday: Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, and his glamorous grown children stepping off Michigan Avenue surrounded by a swirling sea of camera crews he had summoned.

headline: For Slain Soldier’s Family, 2 Awful Nightmares, One Real
text: LOS ANGELES, May 24 — For the family and friends of Pfc. Joseph J. Anzack Jr., found dead Wednesday in Iraq nearly two weeks after being captured with two other soldiers in an ambush, the anguish came with a devastating twist: This was the second time in just four weeks that they had gotten word he was dead.

headline: Spain Voting Seen as Test for Premier and His Rival
text: MADRID, May 24  Spaniards go to the polls on Sunday to elect local and regional officials who are responsible for such services as garbage collection, schools and running the village fiestas. But the way the campaign is being run, it feels like an election for the next prime minister.

headline: Iraqi Tribal Leader Is Killed, and Mourners Are Attacked
text: BAGHDAD, May 24  The growing confrontation between tribal leaders in Anbar Province and Al Qaeda took a violent turn on Thursday when a suicide bomber drove into a crowd gathering for a funeral procession in the volatile city of Falluja, killing at least 27 people and wounding dozens of others.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about former President Jimmy Carter’s recent criticisms of the Bush administration, and his subsequent explanation of his remarks, imprecisely described a question that Mr. Carter was asked during an interview with The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette. He was asked: “Which president was worse, George W. Bush or Richard Nixon?” He answered that the Bush administration was “the worst in history” for the adverse impact he said its policies had on the way the United States is viewed around the world. He was not asked, as he later told NBC’s “Today” show, to compare Mr. Bush’s foreign policy with Mr. Nixon’s.

headline: A Defender of the Controversial, and Now of Imus
text: THAT persistent rumble, somewhere between stentorian and strangulated, is the sound of the lawyer Martin Garbus clearing his throat. He’s a bit under the weather. “Don’t get too close to me,” he says. It is a well-intentioned warning, not censure. Not from him.

headline: 38 Die in Methane Blast at a Coal Mine in Siberia
text: MOSCOW, May 24  A methane explosion in a coal mine killed at least 38 people early Thursday, opening fresh wounds in a Siberian region notorious for mine accidents, where more than 100 miners died in a blast two months ago.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Douglas Holmes, Researcher Best Known for Work on Aging, Dies at 73
text: Douglas Holmes, a noted social psychologist who spent his career investigating means of improving social services for people at both ends of the life cycle  children and the elderly  died on Wednesday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 73 and also had a home in Manhattan.

headline: Dell, in Shift, Will Offer PCs at Wal-Mart
text: Dell, in a first step toward transforming its ailing model of selling direct to consumers, said today that it would offer computers at Wal-Mart stores starting in June.

headline: Matchmaking: Old Masters Meet Their Modern Soul Mates
text: A six-gallery “art walk” is in full stride on the Upper East Side, covering some 600 years of endeavor from exquisite medieval “gold-ground” paintings to rambunctious 20th-century Conceptual photographs. In “Masterworks of Six Centuries” each participating gallery explores a theme, so that at the end of the three-block stroll you may have earned a pocket briefing in art history and a sense of time well spent.

headline: Brotherly Art: The Clarks Who Collected
text: In the art world this is a collectors’ moment. The market keeps climbing, new galleries continue to open, and records are regularly broken at auctions. Perfect timing then for a museum show highlighting the life and times of collectors.

headline: Westport: Ex-Selectwoman Nominated for Bank
text: President Bush has nominated Diane G. Farrell to become a director of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, the White House said yesterday. Ms. Farrell, left, a Democrat, is a former first selectwoman of Westport and last year ran unsuccessfully against Representative Christopher Shays for a congressional seat. If approved by the Senate, Ms. Farrell would serve the remainder of a four-year term expiring on Jan. 20, 2011, the White House said.

headline: 150 Years of Gathering Mostly American Treasures
text: Some of New York’s best-known art galleries began as antiques shops, among them James Graham & Sons, which is celebrating its 150th anniversary this week. It is thought to be the oldest gallery in the city owned by one family.

headline: Senator Says F.D.A. Was Lax on Label for Avandia
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 (Bloomberg)  Federal regulators did not act on a recommendation from their safety reviewers several months ago that GlaxoSmithKline’s diabetes drug Avandia should carry the strongest possible caution about heart attacks, Senator Charles Grassley said Thursday in a statement.

headline: Inhabiting the Tortured Soul of a Tennyson Narrator
text: The name Tennyson evokes for me my grandmother’s leatherbound book of his collected poems with the name stamped on the front in gold, its thin pages heavy with columns of florid verse: an object more admirable than beloved. There are wonderful things in it, but a little goes a long way.

headline: Correction: A Renaissance of Charm in a Hub of the Surfing World
text: A picture with the Havens column last Friday about San Clemente, Calif., was published in error. The house shown in the photograph was recently sold; it was not a two-bedroom house priced at $2,687,500.

headline: There’s an Allegory in Those Hills
text: Oh no, oh no, oh no. “Setting the Indian on the course to civilization best ensures his survival,” says President Ulysses S. Grant (Fred Thompson!), expositorily, on HBO on Sunday night. Gag.

headline: Congress Putting Long-Term Care Under Scrutiny
text: A Congressional committee yesterday began looking into business practices in the long-term care insurance industry.

headline: Instant Star, Just Add Hype
text: America voted and the new American idol is the dewy-eyed Jordin Sparks. A 17-year-old girl with a big voice and a melting smile, she sings more from the adolescent heart than from the grown-up head.

headline: P. M. Kaiser, 93, Diplomat for Democratic Presidents, Is Dead
text: WASHINGTON, May 24 — Philip M. Kaiser, a former ambassador to Austria, Hungary and Senegal who served as a diplomat or political appointee under every Democratic president from Harry S. Truman to Jimmy Carter, died Thursday in Washington. He was 93.

headline: G.M. Expects to Take a $1 Billion Charge for Delphi Costs
text: DETROIT, May 24 — General Motors said on Thursday that it expected to take a $1 billion charge in the second quarter and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at the Delphi Corporation, its former parts division.

headline: Through Rose-Colored Granny Glasses
text: Tear gas, pot and patchouli were the scents of the 1960s. You can almost detect the last two, spicy and pungent, wafting through “Summer of Love: Art of the Psychedelic Era” at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: Summer Weekends: Get Out and Go
text: MEMORIAL DAY triggers a series of inexorable actions. Beach romances fly off bookshelves. White pants and Hawaiian shirts tumble out of closets. Pools are opened, rooftop parties commence and patio umbrellas are unfurled in a backyard chorus of cranks and squeaks.

headline: Queens: Man Sentenced for Nightclub Shooting
text: A Brooklyn man who opened fire at a Queens nightclub in 2004, killing one person and wounding two others, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 75 years to life in prison, prosecutors said. The man, Moises Valerio, 32, of Hull Street in East New York, was convicted on May 4, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Valerio, angry at being ejected from Club Phenomenon in Woodside on May 22, 2004, grabbed a gun from his car, returned to the club and fired on the club’s security officers. One, Francisco Rosa, 35, an off-duty state court officer, was killed.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Albany: More Oversight for Authorities
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer released a proposal yesterday to overhaul and provide more monitoring of the state’s hundreds of public authorities, after weeks of negotiation with legislative leaders. But Mr. Spitzer’s legislation still differs significantly from proposals in the State Senate and Assembly, which seek greater scrutiny for authorities, including requiring the comptroller to approve all authority contracts and establishing an authority budget office that has the power to subpoena authorities for financial documents.

headline: Theater Listings
text: THEATER

headline: 2nd Ave. Subway’s Photo Op Cost the M.T.A. $89,000
text: How much is a little publicity worth?

headline: Support Riders in Tour Admit Taking EPO
text: FRANKFURT, May 24 — Professional cycling sustained another blow to its credibility Thursday when two German riders admitted in an emotional, nationally televised news conference that they took performance-enhancing drugs while supporting the winning riders in two Tours de France.

headline: H.I.V. Testing Bill Starts ‘War’ Among Assembly Democrats
text: ALBANY, May 24 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer and a majority of state lawmakers are backing a bill requiring H.I.V. testing of suspects indicted on rape charges. Nevertheless, its chances of passage are unclear, as the legislation is the subject of contentious debate in the Assembly.

headline: O’Donnell Leaving ‘The View’ 3 Weeks Early
text: Rosie O’Donnell, who was scheduled to leave the cast of “The View” on June 22, will not return to the talk show at all after the Memorial Day weekend, ABC announced this afternoon on the Web site of its news division.

headline: Senate Panel Approves Rule to State Cost of Spy Efforts
text: WASHINGTON, May 24  In a move to reduce secrecy around the nation’s spy agencies, the Senate Intelligence Committee has approved a measure to make public the total amount spent on spying and to direct the Central Intelligence Agency to release an internal report examining its failure to prevent the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: Good or Bad, It All Goes Back to Cashman
text: Brian Cashman’s tenure with the Yankees stretches back more than half his life. Cashman, the general manager, started as an intern in the scouting department in 1986, when he was 19. He understands that to lose in New York, with a team built to win, is to invite blame on the architect.

headline: A Hybrid Beat With Roots in Both Cuba and Boston
text: Rhythm is an earthy but flexible property for the drummer Francisco Mela. At the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night he created a flickering sort of pulse, animated by both the thrum of Afro-Cuban folk music and the thrust of contemporary post-bop. His band, a quintet, wasn’t playing anything recognizable as Latin jazz. What it was after was a hybrid as natural as Mr. Mela’s propulsion, which generally flowed.

headline: Bronx: Ex-School Worker Charged
text: A former accounting assistant at the Riverdale Country School was indicted yesterday on charges of stealing more than $500,000 by skimming cash from school fund-raisers and the cafeteria, prosecutors said. The suspect, Eileen Koranteng, 50, of Peekskill, was charged with grand larceny and forgery, the Bronx district attorney’s office said. Ms. Koranteng was an employee at the school from 1997 until 2006. In July 2001, she began embezzling tuition payments and other school money totaling $508,000, prosecutors said.

headline: More Than Ever, It Pays to Be the Top Executive
text: Like most companies, Office Depot has long made sure that its chief executive was the highest-paid employee. Ten years ago, the $2.2 million pay package of its chief was more than double that of his No. 2. The fifth-ranked executive received less than one-third.

headline: Denmark: Offer for Insurer’s Shares
text: The Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group, a British nonlife insurer, offered 6.4 billion kroner ($1.2 billion) to buy the stock it does not already own in Codan, a nonlife insurer in Denmark. Royal and Sun bid 605 kroner apiece for the shares, a premium of 15 percent over the closing price Wednesday of 525 kroner. Royal and Sun completed the sale of operations in the United States in March to focus on British and Scandinavian businesses and on emerging markets.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about former President Jimmy Carter’s recent criticisms of the Bush administration, and his subsequent explanation of his remarks, imprecisely described a question that Mr. Carter was asked during an interview with The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette. He was asked: “Which president was worse, George W. Bush or Richard Nixon?” He answered that the Bush administration was “the worst in history” for the adverse impact he said its policies had on the way the United States is viewed around the world. He was not asked, as he later told NBC’s “Today” show, to compare Mr. Bush’s foreign policy with Mr. Nixon’s. (Go to Article)

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about “Long Time Leaving,” by Roy Blount Jr., a collection of essays on Southern topics, misstated the title of a movie discussed in the book. The movie, based on a novel by the same name, is “Raintree County,” not “Raintree Country.”

headline: Despite Gas Prices, Drivers Are Hitting the Road
text: Despite near-record gasoline prices, more Americans than ever were expected to travel on the long Memorial Day weekend, most of them by motor vehicle.

headline: Openness Sought in British Terror Trials
text: FLORENCE, Italy, May 24 — The head of British counterterrorism at Scotland Yard on Thursday criticized what he called excessive secrecy in Britain’s terrorism trials, and he called for changes that would permit freer reporting and wider discussion of the issue.

headline: Two Country Houses and One Romance, Made in Connecticut
text: IN the movies, love always seems to find its way: opposites attract, the hard-working guy marries the girl next door, and coincidence has a way of intervening at just the right moment. Life doesn’t always imitate art, as Lucille Masone Smith knows, having spent a career helping to create the artifice of film. But sometimes it comes surprisingly close.

headline: Needing Cash, Cemeteries Seek Breathing Clients
text: Historic cemeteries, desperate for money to pay for badly needed restorations, are reaching out to the public in ever more unusual ways, with dog parades, bird-watching lectures, Sunday jazz concerts, Halloween parties and other events.

headline: Welcome Home
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: The Faces of Apatow
text: Scenes from the evolution of Judd Apatow's life and work over the years.

headline: Gravity Defying
text: Sexy sofas, not-so-precious metals, homey handwork. At this year’s Milan Furniture Fair, design lightens up. Seriously.

headline: If the Elevator Is Broken, Is a Rent Rebate in Order?
text: Q Our building is a mix of rent-stabilized and free-market apartments. We have two very old and very slow elevators, one of which has been inoperable for almost three weeks. We have received word from the management company that the elevator needs to be replaced and that this will probably take two months or more.

headline: Murder and Mistrust
text: Charged with fighting crime in streets saturated with drugs and guns, Newark's police force faces a lack of equipment and cooperation from the public.

headline: Pulse | Light as the Breeze
text:
Summer promises to be
fashionably full of holes,
with eyelet showing up as
the latest retail confection.

headline: Magnificent mansion
text: Exterior

headline: A Closer Vision
text: Additional images of the Netherlands Institute for Sound and Vision.

headline: A Century-Old Trade
text: Delivery men called dabbawallas transport home-cooked meals to workplaces all over Mumbai, India, with near-clockwork precision.

headline: The Harlem Valley Rail Trail
text: A century and a half ago, it was the northern route of the New York and Harlem Railroad. Today, it is the Harlem Valley Rail Trail, where bicyclists of all skill levels can pedal through the cool forests and sweet-scented farmlands of the Taconic Hills. There is bicycling now on 4- and 12-mile public stretches of paved rail bed, united by country roads where riding is fairly easy. When it is eventually completed, the trail will stretch 46 miles from Wassaic in Dutchess County to Chatham in Columbia County.

headline: Midsize Matchups: How Some of the Newest Family Sedans Compare
Old-Time Farming and Baseball
text: Old Bethpage Village Restoration (www.nassaucountyny.gov/agencies/parks) is a 165-acre village and working farm that recreates a 19th-century Long Island hamlet, assembled from more than 50 period homes and commercial structures from surrounding towns. Children can churn butter or scribble on a slate in the one-room schoolhouse, pet farm animals and buy penny candy in the Layton General Store (1866).

headline: Museum Row, for Children
text: It's totally hands-on at the Cradle of Aviation (www.cradleofaviation.org), one of a trio of family-oriented museums in Garden City. The aviation museum offers children a chance to climb into a jet simulator and experience G-force. An IMAX theater has eye-popping programs like "Hurricane on the Bayou," which simulates the fury of Hurricane Katrina, and "Magnificent Desolation: Walking on the Moon," which relates the sensation experienced by the 12 men who have set foot on the moon's surface. Over the summer, there are aerospace minicamps devoted to weekly themes like astronomy or space exploration.

headline: Down the Brandywine
text: The placid waters of Brandywine Creek provide a welcome respite from life's pressures. On a hot day, nothing beats floating downstream Huck Finn style and dangling your toes in the water as cows moo and blue skies peek through a canopy of oak and maple trees. The Northbrook Canoe Company (northbrookcanoe.com) near West Chester, Pa., rents canoes (beginning at $35), kayaks ($25) and inner tubes ($15). There are seven routes on the meandering west branch of the Brandywine. The shortest trip is an hour, and more ambitious paddlers can journey six and a half hours and end up in Delaware. Paddlers often spot trout and minnows, as well as birds, frogs, turtles and, on rare occasions, foxes. While toweling off back at headquarters, you can order cheeseburgers, hot dogs and chicken nuggets from the Food Shack. There's a picnic grove for those who prefer to pack a lunch.

headline: Dow Faces S.E.C. Inquiry Into Deal Talks and Trades
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an inquiry into whether two senior executives at Dow Chemical secretly tried to put the company into play and into the unusual trading in its stock that may have resulted, according to The New York Times.

headline: A Treasure in a Barn
Lighthouse Trail
text: You can get a lofty view of New Jersey's rich maritime history by visiting the lighthouses that dot the shoreline from Sandy Hook Lighthouse overlooking Lower New York Bay to Cape May at the southern tip of the state. Eleven lighthouses are open to the public, and New Jersey Tourism (www.visitnj.org) issues a free 17-page booklet outlining their history.

headline: Russia Wins a Yukos Round
text: Russia won an incremental victory in the legal struggle for what remains of the foreign subsidiaries of Yukos. A Dutch court approved a request by the Russian bankruptcy administrator, Eduard K. Rebgun, to represent Yukos in court in the Netherlands.

headline: Lancaster County Farm Stays
text: Here's your chance to don some overalls and be a farmer for a weekend. More than 30 working farms in Lancaster County, Pa., participate in a farm stay program (www.padutchcountry.com), many in the heart of Amish country, where you can skip across wooden bridges, wave to kids in buggies and spot one-room schoolhouses as you drive through fertile farmlands.

headline: UBS Researchers Say Banks May Be in for a Merger Binge
text: Expectations of a spate of bank mergers are “the highest since the turn of the millennium,” according to UBS research analyst Philip Finch.

headline: Appeals Court Upholds Convictions in Adelphia Fraud Case
text: A federal appeals court upheld the criminal convictions yesterday of the founder of Adelphia Communications, John J. Rigas, and his son Timothy, who both face lengthy prison terms for concealing loans and stealing millions from the cable television provider.

headline: Apologetic, Home Depot Tries to Move Beyond Nardelli’s Shadow
text: At Home Depot‘s annual meeting yesterday, investors and management went back and forth on a range of issues as the specter of Robert L. Nardelli, the company’s ousted chief executive, continued to haunt the proceedings.

headline: Fifield Is Still Interested in EMI, Even If Corvus Isn’t
text: Jim Fifield, a former executive of the EMI Group, is still interested in making a bid for the company, which received a takeover offer from Terra Firma Capital Partners this week.

headline: Fidelity Starts $500 Million Buyout Fund
text: Fidelity Equity Partners, an arm of Fidelity Investments, has opened a $500 million buyout fund. The new private equity shop, which officially and quietly started operating in January, is funded internally and the vehicle’s limited partners are Fidelity shareholders.

headline: UBS to Dispose of $3.3 Billion Julius Baer Stake
text: UBS, the world’s biggest money manager, plans to sell its 4.1 billion-Swiss franc ($3.3 billion) stake in bank Julius Baer Holding and use the proceeds to buy back shares.

headline: Are Online Ad Firms Worth Top Dollar?
text: The recent frenzy of deals for online advertising firms — Google‘s $3.1 billion deal for DoubleClick, WPP‘s $649 million purchase of 24/7 Real Media, Microsoft‘s $6 billion move on aQuantive — has some industry observers wondering if a whiff of desperation isn’t in the air.

headline: Dinosaur and Other Bones
text: A bronze torosaurus, standing two stories high and 21 feet long, guards the entrance to the Peabody Museum of Natural History (www.peabody.yale.edu) at Yale University in New Haven. The torosaurus has friends there, too. Poised in the museum’s great hall are full-size skeletons of a brontosaurus and stegosaurus and the head of a triceratops. Also notable are the 110-foot long “Age of Reptiles” mural and its companion, the 60-foot-long “Age of Mammals” by Rudolph F. Zallinger, whose work is being celebrated there his year. The Discovery Room has hands-on specimens like real dinosaur teeth, as well as live snakes and poison dart frogs that visitors distinctly do not touch. An exhibit called “Fossils Fragments: The Riddle of Human Origins” features a skeleton of one of the early members of our genus, Homo, discovered in Kenya. The many questions about evolution that are posed here will probably fuel a family discussion all the way home.

headline: Powowing
text: Visitors can experience life in a coastal Pequot village of the 16th century and learn to speak a few Algonquin phrases at the tribally owned Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center (www.pequotmuseum.org) in eastern Connecticut. The 85,000-square-foot museum claims to have more exhibition space than any other American Indian center in the country. There are computer-interactive exhibits, dioramas, a children's library, documentary films and live events. The surrounding countryside can be viewed from an 18-story tower and observation deck. A current exhibition, "Fifty Years of Powwow," intersperses photographs with displays of Native American dance regalia.

headline: Stock Picks From Hedge-Fund Stars
text: When some of the biggest — and most reclusive — names in hedge-fund land took the podium this week at a charity event, they offered attendees more than just some inspiring words: They gave investment advice.

headline: Christianity in China
text: Continuing his journey across China, Nicholas Kristof visits a house church in Shandong province.

headline: Sharper Image Jumps on Buyout Speculation
text: A Buyout firm, Sun Capital Partners, has doubled its stake in Sharper Image, raising the prospect that the ailing specialty retailer might be taken private as it tries to bounce back. Sharper Image’s stock rose 15 percent Thursday after it said in a regulatory filing that an affiliate of Sun Capital had paid $13.78 million for 1.49 million shares held in a trust set up by the company’s founder and former chief executive, Richard Thanheimer.

headline: Royal and Sun Makes Offer for Remaining Codan Stake
text: The Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group, a British nonlife insurer, offered 6.4 billion kroner ($1.2 billion) to buy the stock it does not already own in Codan, a nonlife insurer in Denmark.

headline: LionOre Mining Favors Norilsk Offer
text: LionOre Mining International, the nickel producer, said that the takeover offer of $6.8 billion Canadian dollars ($6.3 billion) from Norilsk Nickel of Russia was superior to a rival offer by Xstrata of Switzerland. Xstrata’s most recent bid was for $6.2 billion Canadian dollars. Both companies have now made two offers for LionOre. Under the terms of an agreement signed with LionOre, Xstrata has until June 1 to match Norilsk’s offer.

headline: Iberia to Consider Takeover Bid
text: The Spanish airline Iberia said that it had received information on a takeover bid led by the private equity group Texas Pacific Group and that its board would study the offer at its next meeting.

headline: EGL Chooses Apollo Over Its Founder
text: The logistics company EGL has ended its buyout agreement with its chief, James R. Crane, and has accepted a higher offer from Ceva Logistics, which is owned by the private equity firm Apollo Management.

headline: G.M. Expects $1 Billion Charge for Delphi Costs
text: General Motors said Thursday that it expected to take a $1 billion charge in the second quarter and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at Delphi, its former parts division. The company also said that it had received a new request for accounting documents from the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has been investigating G.M.’s accounting practices for nearly two years.

headline: Gambling Web Site Pleads Guilty in U.S. Case
text: An Internet gambling site, BetonSports, pleaded guilty Thursday to federal racketeering charges and agreed to cooperate in a case against the company’s founder and other defendants, a prosecutor said. BetonSports admitted a “pattern of racketeering acts,” including mail and wire fraud, operating an illegal gambling business and money laundering, a statement from the United States attorney in St. Louis, Catherine L. Hanaway, said.

headline: I’d Like to Sell the World a Coke
Morgan Stanley Fund Said to Approach $8 Billion
text: Morgan Stanley is reportedly close to completing fundraising for an $8 billion real estate investment fund, The Financial Times reported. It would be the securities firm’s largest real estate fund to date. The newspaper said that 40 percent of the investment bank’s sixth real estate fund will be invested in Japan. The fund is expected to close as early as next month amid strong demand from mostly non-Japanese investors, the Financial Times said.

headline: Greenlight Capital Re Rises in Market Debut
text: Stock in Greenlight Capital Re, a reinsurance company, jumped more than 20 percent in its market opening Thursday as the its ties to hedge fund manager David Einhorn seemed to be a draw for investors, MarketWatch reported. The company’s shares were up 21 percent at $23.03 during afternoon trading Thursday. Greenlight Capital raised $195 million in the initial public offering.

headline: Sallie Mae Documents Add to Questions About Stock Sale
text: An internal document from Sallie Mae, the nation’s largest student lender, showed that the company sought a meeting with President Bush’s budget office about two months before the company’s chairman, Albert L. Lord, sold more than $18 million in shares. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the House education committee are investigating whether Mr. Lord had inside information about the president’s budget proposal, which was released in February and called for cuts in subsidies for companies participating in the federally guaranteed student loan program.

headline: Take My Television – Please!
text: My business of green column today is about the growing options here in Europe for disposing of unwanted electronic equipment in an eco-friendly manner. The European Union as well as a number of electronics companies like Dell and Nokia are pioneering new thinking in the field.

headline: More Than Ever, It Pays to Be the Top Executive
text: As executive pay has surged in most American companies, attention has focused on the growing gap between the earnings of top executives and the average wage of workers in cubicles or on the shop floor. But, notes The New York Times, little noticed, is how much the gap has also widened between the summit and the next few echelons down.

headline: Consortium Sets New Deadline for ABN Amro Bid Decision
text: A consortium of banks led by the Royal Bank of Scotland has pushed back the date by which it will decide whether to bid for ABN Amro, not for any complex strategic reason, but because, as it turns out, the date it chose falls around a holiday.

headline: Tribune Debt Deal Not as Sweet as Expected
text: Tribune, which last month agreed to go private in an $8.2 billion deal with the real-estate mogul Samuel Zell, completed a tender offer for half its shares, but the media company had to agree to difficult borrowing terms, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: G.E. to Double Down on Clean Tech Investments
text: General Electric plans to double its clean technology venture capital investments from $25 million this year to $50 million a year by 2008. G.E. plans to make investments across the clean-tech sector including solar, biofuels and batteries. In January, G.E. led a $40 million investment round in A123Systems, a company developing lithium ion batteries for plug-in hybrid vehicles.

headline: Upper Deck’s Topps Bid: Sneaky or Sincere?
text: Is Upper Deck‘s bid for venerable bubble gum and card maker Topps really a back-door move to spy on its rival?

headline: Biolex Swallows $30 Million from V.C.s
text: Biolex Therapeutics, a privately held biopharmaceutical company, announced the closing of a $30 million Series C financing. The financing was led by Investor Growth Capital of New York and included the participation of two other new investors, JP Morgan Securities and Easton Capital.

headline: 2008: Supplemental Cases
text: Congressional passage of a war spending bill, which does not set a withdrawal timeline but requires the Iraqi government to meet a series of benchmarks to continue receiving aid, is drawing a forceful reaction, especially on the Democratic side.

headline: Nasdaq in $3.7 Billion Deal for Sweden’s OMX
text: Robert Greifeld can breathe a little easier. The chief executive officer of the Nasdaq Stock Market, who has been trying for at least 14 months to buy a European exchange, has finally gotten his deal with an agreement to buy Sweden’s OMX for 25.1 billion Swedish kronor ($3.7 billion).

headline: In Cannes, Bankers May Outnumber Movie Stars
text: Amid the glamour and the French Riviera sun, more and more Wall Street banks, private equity firms and hedge funds are coming to the 12-day Cannes festival – the world’s largest international film market – to try to arrange and finance entertainment deals. Merrill Lynch, Citigroup, and JPMorgan Chase, as well as hedge funds like Atticus Capital and various companies backed by the likes of Providence Equity Partners and the Texas Pacific Group, are all here this year, competing for deals.

headline: The Lies People Tell
text: The Portuguese filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira's "Magic Mirror," a dreamy satire about class, is centered on a rich woman named Alfreda (Leonor Silveira), who has been praying for a sighting of the Virgin Mary her whole life and is baffled and annoyed that it hasn't happened.

headline: test
Movie Memories and Gender Confusion
text: A gentler, more wistful Henry Jaglom wrote and directed "Hollywood Dreams," his 15th and perhaps most accessible film. Filled with movie memories and gender confusion, the story shows one of our most polarizing independent filmmakers in a nostalgic mood, musing over the burdens of fame and the price of success — which would be love, as if you didn't know.

headline: A Smoggy Start to a Long Weekend
text: As New Yorkers prepare for the Memorial Day weekend, they can look forward to the usual routines: schools letting out, lazy summer weekends and frequent ozone warnings.

headline: This Land: A Soldier's Story
text: Dan Barry reports on the death of Sgt. James E. Dean, who was shot by a Maryland police sniper three weeks before his redeployment to Iraq.

headline: A Study of Male Family Dynamics
text: There's bad news for absentee dads: It is apparently no longer sufficient to buy your grown child a car as penance for missing all those Little League games. The outsize guilt trip that Carl Lee (John Heard) imposes on himself for being a lousy parent hurts the credibility of "Steel City," an otherwise absorbing study of male family dynamics written and directed by Brian Jun.

headline: He’s Back
text: So it seems that Moktada al-Sadr, the firebrand anti-American cleric at the center of radical Shiite politics and armed violence in Iraq, is back from a four-month hole-up in Iran, and is leading Friday prayers today at the mosque in Kufa, near Mr. Sadr’s base in Najaf.

headline: Tales of the Somewhat Surprising
text: Mark Noonan at Blogs for Bush is (somewhat surprisingly) pleased that the Democratic House passed a law against gasoline price gouging.

headline: The Personal Within the Political
text: "Amu," the ambitious debut feature by Shonali Bose, wears its political heart on its sleeve and is unafraid to tackle big topics: identity, history, truth, injustice.

headline: MGM Mirage Sets Advisers for Kerkorian Talks
text: Negotiations with your own controlling investor are bound to be complicated. To help navigate its talks with majority shareholder Kirk Kerkorian, MGM Mirage has enlisted some help. The casino company said Friday that a special transaction committee of independent directors has hired UBS and the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges as advisers as it considers the recent proposal from Mr. Kerkorian’s investment firm, Tracinda.

headline: Giuliani’s Yankees Chair
text: Yankee fan extraordinaire Rudolph W. Giuliani might be getting accustomed to answering questions about the team paraphernalia he owns.

headline: McCain on Clinton, Obama War Votes
text: This didn’t take long. Senator John McCain of Arizona just took a break from his week of skirmishing with fellow Republican Mitt Romney to issue a statement denouncing two of the leading Democratic candidates, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, for their votes against the Iraq war funding bill.

headline: Talking Turkey: A Reader Nominates OnStar
text: And now, a note from reader Steve B:

headline: Bias Attack or Juvenile Brawl?
text: [Update, 7 p.m.: The police have come down on the side of calling the attack on a Sikh student in Queens a hate crime. At a press briefing following a promotions ceremony at police headquarters this morning, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said investigators deemed the attack a hate crime because the Pakistani students’ remarks were religiously biased.

headline: Gore Sees No Reason to Run
text: At times provocative, at other times surprising – yet still not a candidate for president – former Vice President Al Gore spoke and took questions on the state of American politics and his new book, “The Assault on Reason,” at Manhattan’s 92nd St. Y last night.

headline: Algerian Women’s Growing Participation in Society
text: In a tradition-bound nation, women are emerging as an economic and political force unheard of in the rest of the Arab world.

headline: Not a Mother’s Milk
text: On several occasions over the last few years, I’ve run across the phrase “milk-fed” in relation to a bird.

headline: Coca-Cola Pulls Out the Stops for Glaceau Deal
text: The Coca-Cola Company said Friday it would buy Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.1 billion.
