It would be Coke’s largest acquisition ever, and the price tag is more than the amount of cash Coke had on hand at the end of last quarter, meaning it will need to use debt to finance the all-cash deal. Shareholders seemed to find the deal refreshing: They bid up Coke shares by 1.4 percent in late-morning trading.

headline: For New M.B.A.’s, Diplomas and Deal Wisdom
text: Stephen M. Case has been making a lot of public apologies lately. Less than a year ago, in an interview with TV talk-show host Charlie Rose, the co-founder of America Online conceded that he was “sorry” for advocating the ill-fated 2000 merger of AOL and Time Warner.

headline: California Freeway Rebuilt in a New York Minute
text: Your blogger has the good fortune to have three close relatives in the civil engineering profession, and thus ample opportunity to watch a civil engineer’s mind at work and play, often at the same time.

headline: Friday off in Monaco – sort of
text: As most fans know, nothing much happens in Monaco on Friday. This morning, however, the GP2 series held its qualifying session, and I just had to draw attention to this. I recommend watching the GP2 race tomorrow if you have access to it on television, or here at the track. Thanks to an oil slick on the track the last seven minutes of the qualifying session were useless. The session had been stopped to clean up the oil, but seven minutes was not enough time for the 26 cars to get a good shot at setting a good lap time. The result is that the grid has been hugely shaken up, and some of the usual last-place starters are now at the front. The championship leader, Timo Glock, starts eighth, and Bruno Senna starts ninth. This promises a great race.

headline: Plenty of Homes for Sale
text: There are now more than 4 million single-family homes for sale in the United States, and that is a record. As recently as the end of 2005, the figure was fewer than than 3 million.

headline: The What Ifs
text: The other day, a colleague asked me what Paul and I refer to as “The Question”: “Aren’t you guys worried about building a house in the middle of hurricane territory?” Her query was no doubt prompted by NOAA’s cheerful prediction that the 2007 hurricane season — which runs from June 1 to Nov. 30 — will be above average, with 13 to 17 named storms. (The average is 9.6.)

headline: Napa Name Recognition
text: This week Napa Valley became the first American wine region to receive protection for its name by the European Union.

headline: Tour de France Champion Admits Doping
text: One of the safes hanging over Floyd Landis’s head as he fights doping allegations is the prospect of becoming the first Tour de France winner to be stripped of the title for doping. Today, another candidate volunteered.

headline: The Clinton-Obama Two-Step
text: There was no real suspense about whether the Iraq spending bill would pass the Senate last night. But in the final minutes, everyone was waiting to see how the two main contenders for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama, would vote.

headline: Immigration Poll Interviews
text: As the debate over new immigration legislation rages around the country and in Congress, The Times and CBS News published a new poll on the issue at the end of this week.

headline: McCain Gives Obama ‘Flak’
text: The oldest presidential candidate isn’t cutting the youngest any slack over the latter’s no vote on the Iraq funding supplemental bill.

headline: The Olympics' First Losers
text: Nicholas D. Kristof visits a woman who says she may be jailed during the Beijing Games. The encampment for petitioners like her was already demolished in preparation for the Olympics.

headline: Goldman Alum Keeps the Hedge in Hedge Fund
text: When Dinakar Singh isn’t giving investment tips at charity events, the former head of Goldman Sachs‘s proprietary equities trading desk runs a long/short-oriented hedge fund.

headline: Blogtalk: Holiday Reading
text: The fire on the West Side yesterday means Coach employees can start the holiday weekend early. No more smoking on the roof, though. [Fashionista]

headline: Immigration Nation
text: “Here’s what happens when you poll people on a complex, emotional issue the vagaries of which they know little about,” writes Allahpundit at Hot Air who, having already parsed the views of Muslim Americans, now dissects The New York Times/CBS News expansive poll on attitudes toward immigration reform.

headline: Governor vs. Game Warden in South Dakota
text: Suppose you were a game warden for the federal Fish and Wildlife Service. A big part of your job would be tramping the woods and marshes to check up on hunters — strangers with loaded guns who shoot things for recreation – and then writing them up when you find them breaking the law.

headline: 2008: Times/CBS News Poll Results
text: The latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News poll included at look at how the top 2008 Democratic and Republican candidates are faring.

headline: U.S. Troops Train for Paralympics
text: Retired and active duty troops attended the 2007 Paralympic Military Sports Camp in Colorado and discovered unknown athletic talent.

headline: An Opening Gambit With an Odd Acronym
text: When the legendary basketball coach Bobby Knight was pushed out of Indiana University, Texas Tech University in Lubbock jumped to welcome him, in hopes of raising the school’s national profile. Perhaps that move did not reap enough public attention (or maybe it was not the right kind), because the school is now trying another visibility-building leap in a different kind of competitive endeavor: Chess.

headline: A Benefit for The Kitchen
text: Melena Ryzik of The Times attends a benefit gala held at the Puck Building for the performance space The Kitchen.

headline: About Kalmykia, Home of the Candidates Matches
text: Tomorrow is the opening ceremony for the candidates matches that will determine four participants for the world championship tournament in September and October in Mexico City. The matches, like so many other recent events (including last year’s title contest between Veselin Topalov and Vladimir Kramnik), are taking place in Elista, the capital of Kalmykia, a Russian republic on the Caspian Sea. Why Kalmykia? It is the home of Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, the president of the World Chess Federation, who is also the president of Kalmykia. Ilyumzhinov is providing $320,000 of the $480,000 prize fund for the matches and the federation is providing the rest.

headline: Video: Christianity in China
text: On an architectural level, this house church in Shandong province is far from the awe-inspiring splendor of Notre Dame or St. Peter’s Cathedral. But, as Nick reports in his latest video from his journey, house churches are sweeping across China.

headline: Deciding Whether a Window Shade Is Open or Closed
text: On a recent trans-Atlantic flight with Air France, I was asked to pull down my window shade by the stewardess. I refused, as it was daytime and I had no desire to sleep. She insisted, but I held my ground and told her to take the matter up with the captain. She left me alone after that. Was I within my rights to keep my window shade open? Can flight attendants order passengers to close their shades?

headline: Down and Out in Roslyn, Long Island
text: The Roslyn Village Motel, a $175 per week flophouse, is an unusual sight among the glitter and wealth of the North Shore town's "miracle mile."

headline: Green-Wood Remembers Civil War Dead
text: A volunteer effort at Brooklyn's historic Green-Wood Cemetery honors nearly 3,000 Civil War veterans buried there with new gravestones.

headline: Tools for Better Living
text: An exhibit at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum in New York features inventions designed to help the world's poor move out of poverty.

headline: Say Amen, Everybody, 15 Years Down the Line
text: When Wynton Marsalis unveiled his sanctified long-form composition “In This House, on This Morning” 15 years ago, it marked a breakthrough for him as well as for Jazz at Lincoln Center, where he had recently begun his tenure as artistic director. So it might be tempting to view the piece’s revival this week as an act of misty nostalgia, the equivalent of dusting off a scrapbook, or a treasured hymnal, and gingerly turning pages.

headline: As Condos Rise in South Florida, Nervous Investors Try to Flee
text: MIAMI, May 25 — As dozens of condominium towers conceived during Florida’s real estate boom near completion, investors who snatched up units in the preconstruction phase in hopes of turning a quick profit are increasingly trying to break contracts, even walking away from fat deposits.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about “Pearl Harbor,” by Newt Gingrich and William R. Forstchen, misstated the phrase that President Franklin D. Roosevelt used in referring to Dec. 7, 1941, the day of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. He called it “a date which will live in infamy,” not a “day” that will live in infamy.

headline: Arrested While Grieving
text: No one is paying much attention, but parts of New York City are like a police state for young men, women and children who happen to be black or Hispanic. They are routinely stopped, searched, harassed, intimidated, humiliated and, in many cases, arrested for no good reason.

headline: For the Love of the College Game
text: LAS VEGAS, May 25 — When Tony Gwynn’s cellphone rings after midnight, he immediately has to wonder if someone got hurt, got busted, or got soaked.

headline: Russia and Britain Spar Over Poison Case
text: The top prosecutors of Russia and Britain quarreled over a British demand to extradite a former K.G.B. security officer accused of poisoning Alexander V. Litvinenko in London last November. After a meeting of justice officials from the Group of 8 countries in Munich, Russia’s prosecutor general, Yuri Y. Chaika, said the suspect, Andrei K. Lugovoi, could face trial in Russia, provided the British provide “evidence proving Lugovoi’s guilt,” but he reiterated Russia’s refusal to extradite him. The British attorney general, Peter Goldsmith, responded that British justice should decide the matter. “This murder was committed on U.K. soil,” he said in a statement. “The evidence is in the U.K. A U.K. citizen was killed and other people put at risk. And it is therefore right a suspect should face justice in a U.K. court.”

headline: Battle Over Control of Troops Escalates Political Crisis in Ukraine
text: MOSCOW, May 25  President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine issued a decree on Friday putting Interior Ministry troops under his command, but the ministry, joined by Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, declared the move unconstitutional and defied it.

headline: What’s on Saturday Night
text: 8 P.M. (Hallmark) PANDEMIC (2007) Tiffani Thiessen, left, plays a very good-looking epidemiologist and team leader from the Centers for Disease Control in this three-hour movie about the riptide virus, a fictional deadly bird flu carried from Australia to California by an infected surfer on an airliner. Vincent Spano plays an F.B.I. agent in charge of a drug lord aboard the toxic plane. Eric Roberts is the mayor of Los Angeles. And — step aside, Arnold — Faye Dunaway is the governor of California, who responds to incipient mass hysteria in her state by imposing martial law.

headline: Clemens Will Make Another Start in the Minors
text: Roger Clemens will start for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre on Monday, General Manager Brian Cashman said yesterday. But Cashman kept his options open when addressing the question that every Yankees fan wants answered: When will Clemens join the team?

headline: The High Price of Creating Free Ads
text: From an advertiser’s perspective, it sounds so easy: invite the public to create commercials for your brand, hold a contest to pick the best one and sit back while average Americans do the creative work.

headline: Speaking Up in Fresh Air at Home Depot
text: The dirty little secret of this year’s Home Depot annual meeting were the timers.

headline: A Say in How I Go (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Coke Takes $4 Billion Step Away From Carbonation
text: If you set up a lemonade stand this weekend, you might consider stirring in something a little different.

headline: Shiite Cleric Ends Absence From Iraq With Fiery Speech
text: BAGHDAD, May 25 — The populist Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr appeared in public for the first time in months on Friday after what American officials have described as a lengthy period of refuge in Iran. He delivered a fiercely anti-American sermon and offered himself in a new guise as a nationalist intent on bridging the divide between Iraq’s warring communities of Shiites and Sunnis.

headline: Traffic Agents Talk About the Prospect of New Ticket-Writing Powers
text: The traffic light at Fifth and Flatbush Avenues in Brooklyn changed. Thomas Carlton, a traffic enforcement agent, went into action, herding three stragglers — cars driven by people oblivious to the idea that an intersection is not the place to be during a red light.

headline: ‘I Should Be Dead’
text: New Jersey’s Gov. Jon Corzine has started to make up for one of the worst mistakes in his life  failing to wear a seat belt  with a new public service commercial just in time for the Memorial Day weekend. As every driver who ever forgets to buckle up probably knows by now, Mr. Corzine’s arrogant dismissal of that basic auto-safety rule nearly cost him his life in a highway crash on April 12.

headline: Two Failures Do Not End Dreams of a Rochester-to-Toronto Ferry
text: ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 23 — Two years ago, this city of 190,000 people — with more per-capita murders, high school dropouts and children living in poverty than any other in the state — paid $32 million for a high-speed ferry. It was considered a way to help revive the local economy by shuttling thousands of passengers a day to and from Canada, across Lake Ontario.

headline: For Plumbers, a Rush Before Toes Reach the Sand
text: OCEAN BEACH, N.Y. — The Pressman family’s summer house lurched back to life the other day, as it does every year at this time, but not without protest. The upstairs faucet hissed like a cobra and the water heater emitted deep, intestinal burps. A burner on the stove clicked, clicked, clicked, then burst into a blue ring of flame. The answering machine awoke and delivered its news: two calls since Columbus Day.

headline: Within 25 Miles of New York, Iran Offers a Congenial Glow
text: UNITED NATIONS

headline: Nine Buildings Are Evacuated After Leak
text: Two people were hospitalized and dozens more were evacuated from nine residential buildings in Brooklyn last night after an overloaded electrical system caused a carbon monoxide leak, the Fire Department said.

headline: Test of Drug for Diabetes in Jeopardy
text: A large clinical study meant to test the heart safety of the diabetes treatment Avandia may be in jeopardy as a result of recent reports of the drug’s risks, according to an executive for its maker, GlaxoSmithKline.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about a New York Times/CBS News poll that measured opinion about the Iraq war misstated the date of the first Times/CBS News poll that included a question about whether the United States did the right thing in taking military action in Iraq. It was December 2003, not January 2003. (The war did not begin until March 2003.)

headline: China Makes a U.S. Deal, but It’s Not With Washington
text: THE United States and China ended talks with unfinished business, as China took a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group. The Tracinda Corporation of Kirk Kerkorian sought to buy two Las Vegas properties for an estimated $12 billion, and Coca-Cola moved to broaden its noncarbonated beverage portfolio with a $4.1 billion deal.

headline: Holiday on Monday: Memorial Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about plans for 3-D movies using new technology referred incorrectly to the showing of 3-D movies on DVDs. Such films can in fact be shown on DVDs, and have been.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Schedule information on Thursday with a theater review of “Gaslight,” at the Irish Repertory Theater in Chelsea, misstated the box office telephone number. It is (212) 727-2737.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Paying the Price

headline: Heaven, Hell and Purgatory, Encased in Glass
text: HILVERSUM, the Netherlands — It’s almost daunting to note how many young architectural talents are flourishing today in the Netherlands. If Rem Koolhaas, the profession’s reigning intellectual prince, casts a long shadow, it’s clear that plenty of emerging architects have managed to assert strong creative voices of their own.

headline: In a Seat Belt Ad, Seeing Corzine as Contrite, or Calculating
text: PRINCETON, N.J., May 25 — Gov. Jon S. Corzine is really, really sorry that he was not wearing a seat belt when the sport utility vehicle he was riding in hurtled into a guardrail on the Garden State Parkway.

headline: Some Union Local Members Call for Using Mail Ballots
text: Larry Davis says it is ridiculous that only 2 percent of the 27,000 members in his union local  the largest in the umbrella union, District Council 37  voted in the local’s last election.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the Metro Briefing column on May 17 included incorrect information from the New York City Department of Education about the number of charter schools that are overseen by the department, New York State and the State University of New York. The department oversees 31 such schools, not 38. The state and SUNY oversee a total of 27, not 20.

headline: Lawmakers in Colombia Urge Firing of Mediator
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 25 — When allegations emerged this month that outlawed Colombian paramilitaries had thrown whiskey-soaked parties with prostitutes in an area set aside for peace talks, Colombia’s Congress expressed shock.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Philip M. Kaiser, a former ambassador to Austria, Hungary and Senegal, gave an incorrect year in some copies for the beginning of his service as ambassador to Senegal. It was 1961, not 1962. The byline also misspelled the given name of the writer in some copies. He is Steven R. Weisman, not Stephen.

headline: Two Social Ethicists and the National Landscape
text: In January, Gary Dorrien was installed as the Reinhold Niebuhr professor of social ethics at Union Theological Seminary in New York City. Niebuhr, who taught social ethics at Union from 1928 to 1961, was the most prominent and influential American theologian of the last hundred years. His evolving notion of “Christian realism” shaped the outlook of Depression-era radicals, World War II interventionists, anti-Communist cold warriors and early civil rights militants. He lectured across the country on a weekly basis, as does Dr. Dorrien, who, like Niebuhr, often arrives at his last class on Thursday “with my bags packed.”

headline: Hernández Finds Warm Welcome Back Home
text: MIAMI, May 25 — For the first 15 minutes of his first day back with the Mets, Orlando Hernández sat at a computer sorting out all the tickets he had reserved for friends and family. This is home for him. He trains here. He plays golf here. He also pitches his best here and, making his first start since a monthlong stay on the disabled list, Hernández joined in the Marlins’ celebration of Cuban Heritage Night by allowing only two hits over six scoreless innings as the Mets defeated the Marlins, 6-2, at Dolphin Stadium.

headline: Official Fired by Wal-Mart Fights Back
text: After Wal-Mart Stores fired a top advertising executive, Julie Roehm, six months ago, the company accused her of violating a wide range of its strict ethics policies.

headline: Feeling Well, Martínez Pays Mets a Visit
text: MIAMI, May 25 — In about the time it took for the clubhouse doors to open and shut in his wake, Pedro Martínez cracked wise about his teammates’ buzz cuts, shook roughly a dozen hands, hugged about five teammates, a trainer and a clubhouse attendant, and poured a drink for one of his thirsty sons. There is hardly anyone else in baseball who can make an entrance like Martínez, and he quickly backed that up with his trademark candor and ferocious confidence.

headline: Adopting the Hollywood Model for Comic Books, Producers and All
text: Hollywood has never been shy about poaching ideas from comic books, whether it’s the “Adventures of Superman” television series that inspired a generation of young cape-wearers in the mid-1950s or this month’s “Spider-Man 3,” which has earned nearly $300 million at the box office in just three weeks.

headline: When a Scam Is a Phone Call Away (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hate Crime Is Charged in Attack on Sikh Boy
text: A teenager was charged with felony hate crimes yesterday, a day after he forced a 15-year-old Sikh schoolmate into a boys’ bathroom in Queens, tore off his turban and sheared his hair, the authorities said.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,430 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of following Americans yesterday:

headline: Activists at the Boardroom Door
text: SHAREHOLDER activism, which its proponents say is intended to make corporations more accountable, ethical, profitable and transparent, is “threatening the future of American business.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about the presidential campaign of Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, and how it could be affected by the battle over immigration, referred incorrectly in some copies to his state’s Hispanic population. New Mexico has the highest percentage of Hispanics in the country; it does not have the highest percentage of Hispanic immigrants in the country.

headline: Wait a Few Months Before You Believe the Numbers
text: IT is the newest economic statistics that usually get all the attention as investors and analysts try to gauge the health of the economy.

headline: Senate Democrats Say Bush Ignored Spy Agencies’ Prewar Warnings of Iraq Perils
text: WASHINGTON, May 25 — Democrats on a deeply divided Senate Intelligence Committee on Friday accused the Bush administration of ignoring preinvasion warnings from the nation’s spy agencies that a war in Iraq could be followed by violence and division and that it could strengthen the hands of Al Qaeda and of Iran.

headline: O’Donnell Departs ‘The View’ Weeks Early
text: Rosie O’Donnell, who was scheduled to leave the cast of “The View” on June 20, will not return to the talk show after the Memorial Day weekend, ABC announced yesterday.

headline: Face-Off Expert Is an Unlikely Star at Delaware
text: BALTIMORE, May 25 — The journey from obscure blue-collar player to one of the brightest stars of the N.C.A.A. men’s lacrosse tournament began in Alex Smith’s basement.

headline: Breaking the Silence on Finance
text: Money is known as “the last taboo” for a reason. We are more likely to know about our friends taking antidepressants than we are to know how they are stressing over their mortgage payment and Visa bill (or for that matter, about the help they are getting from generous parents or an inheritance).

headline: Sitting in Favorite Seat, Unser Tries to Start Fresh
text: INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 — Late Sunday morning, Al Unser Jr. will strap himself into a red, white and blue Indy car owned by A. J. Foyt, another multiple winner of the Indianapolis 500. He will fire the engine and speed away, thrilled to be part of the pack.

headline: One-Stop Car Insurance Service, Body Work Included
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Several insurance companies have decided their old strategy for handling car-damage claims is in need of repair.

headline: California: Ex-Executive at Red Cross Pleads Guilty
text: A former Red Cross executive in Orange County has pleaded guilty to federal charges that she embezzled at least $110,000 of the organization’s money. The woman, Karen Shuerger, 58, pleaded guilty to four of five charges Wednesday and will be sentenced this summer. Investigators are still trying to determine how much money was involved. Ms. Shuerger, who now lives in Henderson, Nev., resigned in October 2005 as assistant director of accounting. Red Cross officials then discovered the misappropriated money, spent largely on vacation spots, and said they had since put in place better monitoring of finances.

headline: Arizona: Body Found in Duct at School
text: The body of a man was discovered in a ventilation shaft above the cafeteria of a Phoenix elementary school after a parent noticed a foul odor coming from the school, Sgt. Andy Hill said. A maintenance worker climbed to the roof and found the body, Sergeant Hill said. The police in Phoenix, where temperatures have hovered around 100 degrees for the past week, believe that the man was trying to break in to the school, and they are investigating how long the body had been in the air duct and the cause of death. “We have an adult male who took the top off and forced his way into the vent and died,” the sergeant said. School officials evacuated about 850 students and closed the school on what was a regularly scheduled early release day.

headline: Existing Home Sales and Prices Fall in April
text: By all measures, April was a bad month for anyone with a “for sale” sign in the front yard.

headline: Coca-Cola Agrees to Buy Vitaminwater
text: The Coca-Cola Company announced today that it will buy Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.2 billion in cash.

headline: And Gas Saver Makes Three Cars in the Driveway
text: DETROIT, May 25 — With gas prices well over $3 a gallon nationwide, many drivers are lining up to buy small cars.

headline: Ensuring Progress at Ground Zero
text: Visitors to the former World Trade Center site last year witnessed the idle construction equipment and saw only the faintest of markings where the twin towers once stood. Ground zero was a sad place made even sadder by a lack of progress.

headline: E.U. Probes Google Over Data Retention Policy
text: BERLIN, May 25  Google has been warned that it may be violating European Union privacy laws by storing search data from its users for up to two years, the latest example of a United States technology giant whose practices face a collision with European standards.

headline: Nasdaq Agrees to Buy OMX, Operator of 7 Stock Exchanges in Europe
text: LONDON, May 25 — It was third time lucky for Robert Greifeld, the chief executive of Nasdaq, who succeeded after failing twice to expand into Europe.

headline: Needed: Fiscal Restraint (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Britain Deports Man Accused of Ties to Attacker in ’05 Bombing
text: LONDON, May 25 — The British authorities, grappling with ways to contain suspected terrorists, on Friday deported a Jamaican-born Muslim preacher and convert to Islam accused of influencing one of the attackers in the London bombings of July 2005.

headline: Russia Putting on a Davos-Style Economic Forum to Showcase Its Growth
text: MOSCOW, May 25  The Kremlin is hoping it can put the focus on gains in the Russian economy at a forum for business leaders next month in St. Petersburg, highlighting growth that has been overshadowed by negative political news from Russia.

headline: Answering a Question Finally Asked
text: Last week, a few minutes before a Senate hearing began on Capitol Hill, as chairs were still sliding along the floor, two men stood before a witness table and shook hands.

headline: U.S. Military Leader in Iraq Talks of ‘Thinning the Lines’
text: BAGHDAD, May 25 — Since taking over in December as the American ground commander in Iraq, Lt. Gen. Raymond T. Odierno has urged patience to those seeking quick progress. He has privately pushed to extend the current American troop buildup into next year, and he said Thursday that whenever an American pullback does come, no one should expect it to be rapid.

headline: U.S. Rebuffs Germany on Greenhouse Gas Cuts
text: WASHINGTON, May 25  The United States has rejected Germany’s proposal for deep long-term cuts in greenhouse gas emissions, setting the stage for a battle that will pit President Bush against his European allies at next month’s meeting of the world’s richest countries.

headline: Back From Europe, the Philharmonic Displays Its Skills and Nonchalance
text: On Thursday night Glenn Dicterow, the New York Philharmonic’s concertmaster, was a fine emblem of the orchestra. He played with a singing tone and a degree of ease — nay, insouciance — that bordered on downright carelessness.

headline: Haitian Refugees (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Katrina Health Care System
text: This is my fourth week as a guest columnist. Let’s take a look at the health care news that’s transpired in that time.

headline: A ‘Wrong’ Play That Ended Up as One That Was Just Right
text: The world’s most successful single-session charity bridge event had its 44th running 11 days ago at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan, with most of the top New-York-area players competing. Organized by Marion Madoff and Marci Miron, it raised $120,000 for the U.J.A.-Federation of New York. It was a pro-am, the winners being Aaron Silverstein and Helaine Hausman, ahead of Jacqui Mitchell and Lynne Tarnapol, all of New York.

headline: Clinton and Obama Face G.O.P. Attacks for War Vote
text: The decision by two of the leading Democratic presidential candidates to vote against a bill providing more money for the war in Iraq because it did not set a timetable to withdraw the troops reverberated on the campaign trail yesterday, underscoring the deep divisions over the war between Democrats and Republicans.

headline: In Utah, Hoping Small Egos Have More to Prove
text: SALT LAKE CITY, May 25 — The résumé, newly revised, says Carlos Boozer is a certified star. He has the requisite statistics, an All-Star Game appearance and, as of this week, a spot on the United States Olympic team.

headline: Employees Ran Loan Scheme, Bank Reports
text: Shares of the Sterling Financial Corporation, the Pennsylvania-based bank, fell 38 percent yesterday after it said that officers and employees at a subsidiary ran a “sophisticated loan scheme” that would cost as much as $165 million and that might force the sale of the company.

headline: New Jersey Congressman Chases Down Man the Police Say Tried to Rob Him
text: WASHINGTON, May 25 — You can take the kid out of the ’hood, but you can’t take the ’hood out of the kid — even if the ’hood is the upscale neighborhood of Georgetown and the kid is a congressman from one of the wealthier swaths of New Jersey.

headline: In the Midst of Desire and Frustration, Questions of What Might Have Been
text: NEW HAVEN, May 23 — A lone tree, denuded of greenery and casting a spindly shadow on the gray wall behind it, sets the stark, melancholy tone for Gordon Edelstein’s new production of “Uncle Vanya” at the Long Wharf Theater.

headline: Gulf Region Gains Help in New Law on War Funds
text: State and local governments in Gulf Coast areas devastated by the 2005 hurricanes will no longer be required to pay 10 percent of the cost of repairing their roads, schools and other public works, under a provision of the emergency war spending bill approved by Congress on Thursday night.

headline: Catholic Upward Mobility (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about a New York Times/CBS News poll that measured opinion about the Iraq war misstated the date of the first Times/CBS News poll that included a question about whether the United States did the right thing in taking military action in Iraq. It was December 2003, not January 2003. (The war did not begin until March 2003.) (Go to Article)

headline: Alcohol-Related Auto Deaths Rise, Report Finds
text: WASHINGTON, May 25  The number of motor vehicle deaths dropped very slightly last year, the Transportation Department estimated on Friday, but deaths in alcohol-related crashes rose slightly, reaching 41 percent of the total.

headline: Winning on Iraq, Bush Turns to Immigration
text: WASHINGTON, May 25  Having won his fight with Congressional Democrats on an Iraq war spending bill, President Bush is now waging an equally aggressive battle with Republicans, as he tries to persuade them to support an immigration bill that he hopes will be a signature domestic achievement.

headline: World View Podcast
text: Greg Winter and Carlotta Gall discuss Pakistan.

headline: Radical Environmentalist Gets 9-Year Term
text: EUGENE, Ore., May 25 — By the time Chelsea D. Gerlach was 16, she was putting her passion for the environment into action.

headline: No Relief in Sight for the Yankees
text: Poor relief pitching by the Yankees was one obvious reason the Los Angeles Angels won, 10-6, at Yankee Stadium last night. Tyler Clippard, the rookie right-hander making his second major-league start, was removed after only four innings by Manager Joe Torre, a curious decision that backfired.

headline: Boss’s Point Made and Taken
text: George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, has rarely made public statements in recent years without the filter of his public relations firm.

headline: Eco-Friendly Cities (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Israel Hits Hamas Posts in Gaza With Airstrikes
text: JERUSALEM, May 25 — The Israeli Army continued its airstrikes against the Hamas infrastructure in the Gaza Strip late on Thursday and Friday, hitting at least eight different locations and taking aim at a rocket-launching cell, an army spokesman said.

headline: CBS Has a Crush on Wallstrip
text: WHY would CBS want to buy the stocks-oriented video blog Wallstrip? After all, the network exited the online-business-news business when Dow Jones purchased MarketWatch.com in 2004. Is this just a case of a stodgy old-media company trying to hang out online with the cool kids? And anyway, couldn’t the network just create its own similar service if it wanted to?

headline: Israel Bombs Hamas Buildings in Gaza, Killing 5
text: JERUSALEM, May 26 — Israel bombed a series of Hamas buildings in Gaza today, killing at least five Palestinians and wounding six, and arrested another Palestinian cabinet minister, Wasfi Kahaba, a member of Hamas, at his home in the occupied West Bank.

headline: So Much to Do, So Little Time
text: OCEAN BEACH, N.Y. — The Pressman family’s summer house lurched back to life the other day, as it does every year at this time, but not without protest. The upstairs faucet hissed like a cobra and the hot water heater emitted deep, intestinal burps. A burner on the stove clicked, clicked, clicked, then burst into a blue ring of flame. The answering machine awoke and delivered its news: two calls since Columbus Day.

headline: Turkey’s President Vetoes Bill Allowing Direct Elections
text: ISTANBUL, May 25 — President Ahmet Necdet Sezer on Friday vetoed a bill that would allow the Turkish president to be elected in a national ballot, instead of by Parliament, as is currently the case.

headline: An Impasse in Italian Talks Over Return of Artifacts
text: ROME, May 25 — After months of intense discussions, negotiations between a New York antiquities collector and the Italian government have bogged down over a demand that she never be pursued by Italy again, several people close to the talks say.

headline: North Korea: Short-Range Missiles Fired
text: North Korea test-fired several short-range missiles from its eastern coast into the Sea of Japan. The tests, believed to be part of annual drills, did not constitute a “grave issue for Japan’s security,” Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said. The launchings occurred even as American officials continued to try to obtain the release of North Korean funds from a bank in Macao, a critical step in February’s nuclear agreement.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about economic talks between China and the United States misstated the American trade deficit in 2006, a contentious issue between the two countries. The total deficit was $765 billion last year  not $232 billion, which is the amount of America’s trade deficit with China.

headline: Budget Battle Lines
text: The federal budget for 2008, agreed to last week by the House and Senate, puts Congress in good shape to move forward responsibly on many of the nation’s pressing needs. But the Bush administration seems determined to stand in the way.

headline: A Quiet Revolution in Algeria: Gains by Women
text: ALGIERS, May 25 — In this tradition-bound nation scarred by a brutal Islamist-led civil war that killed more than 100,000, a quiet revolution is under way: women are emerging as an economic and political force unheard of in the rest of the Arab world.

headline: Danish Cyclist Admits Doping in Tour Victory
text: Bjarne Riis, a former Danish cyclist who won the 1996 Tour de France, admitted yesterday that he used several banned drugs, including EPO, steroids and human growth hormone, while competing in the 1990s, becoming the first champion of the sport’s most prestigious competition to confess to doping.

headline: Education Grants (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Protesters Barred From Cheney’s West Point Speech
text: WHITE PLAINS, May 25 (AP) — A federal appeals court on Friday denied an organization permission to stage an antiwar demonstration on Saturday on the grounds of the United States Military Academy at West Point, where Vice President Dick Cheney is to deliver the commencement address.

headline: Harold Froehlich, 84, Dies; Designed Deep-Sea Minisub
text: Harold E. Froehlich, a resourceful engineer who applied the principles of aeronautics and balloons to help design the Alvin, the deep-diving exploratory submarine used to recover a misplaced hydrogen bomb in the 1960s and to explore the Titanic wreck, died on May 19 in Maplewood, Minn. He was 84.

headline: Nasdaq to Buy Operator of Nordic Exchanges
text: LONDON, May 25 — It was third time lucky for Robert Greifeld, the chief executive of Nasdaq, who succeeded after failing twice to expand into Europe.

headline: Sales of Existing Homes Fell in April
text: By all measures, April was a bad month for anyone with a “For Sale” sign in the front yard.

headline: Ireland: Ahern on Course for a Third Term
text: Bertie Ahern, who presided over Ireland’s transformation into one of Europe’s most successful and competitive economies during his 10 years as prime minister, appeared headed for a third term, according to preliminary results from parliamentary elections on Thursday. But while the numbers indicated that his centrist Fianna Fail party would have the most seats in Parliament, the question awaiting the final count, which could extend through the weekend, was which other parties might join a coalition government and give Mr. Ahern a majority.

headline: My Life as a Diplomat
text: Cape Town

headline: Missile Defense Test Is Halted After the Target Rocket Fails
text: WASHINGTON, May 25  A highly anticipated test of a new Pentagon system to defend against long-range ballistic missiles was halted early on Friday because the target rocket fell far short of the designated interceptor range in the Pacific, officials announced.

headline: A Say on Executive Pay
text: Executives have always been paid at the top of the corporate scale, but as the gap between them and average workers widens into a chasm, more people have begun to ask how much is too much.

headline: Djokovic Is on the Rise, Just as He Expects to Be
text: There is something ominously methodical about Novak Djokovic at work, despite his lively mind and tendency to call for the trainer in times of duress.

headline: Drought Allows Florida to Clean Bottom of Lake Okeechobee
text: MIAMI, May 25 — The severe drought in South Florida had an upside for state water management officials who took advantage of the low water levels in Lake Okeechobee and began giving the lake bed a good cleaning.

headline: Here, It’s Root, Root, Root for Beer Permit
text: NEWARK, May 25 — It’s like a hot beach without a blanket, or a barbecue sadly bereft of sizzling meat. On Friday night, the minor-league Newark Bears gave fans one summertime treat — a baseball game on a balmy evening — without another:

headline: In Nascar, Two Old Hands Reach Out for Some Help
text: CONCORD, N.C., May 24  Nascar will always be a sport of legendary names, but its history can be told in numbers, too. There is No. 3, linked forever to the driver Dale Earnhardt, and No. 43, the domain of Richard Petty and the signature car number of Petty Enterprises.

headline: Shake-Up of Board Is Defended
text: The Brooklyn borough president yesterday defended his removal of nine members from a community board that had criticized Atlantic Yards, the $4 billion high-rise-cum-arena project that he has called the future of the borough.

headline: Cavs Refuse to Assign Blame for a Noncall
text: CLEVELAND, May 25  LeBron James and his Cleveland Cavaliers coach, Mike Brown, held their tongues Thursday night after a controversial noncall at the end of Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals. A day later, reflecting on the 79-76 loss and their 0-2 deficit to the Detroit Pistons, James and Brown were only slightly less restrained.

headline: To Sell Brooklyn, Borough Leader Took Free Trip on Cruise Ship
text: When the Queen Mary 2 made Brooklyn its New York home port, Marty Markowitz, the borough’s president and most tireless booster, fairly burst with pride.

headline: Suit Sheds Light on Clintons’ Ties to a Benefactor
text: When former President Bill Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took a family vacation in January 2002 to Acapulco, Mexico, one of their longtime supporters, Vinod Gupta, provided his company’s private jet to fly them there.

headline: An Eye-Opening Flight That Might Knock You Out
text: My trip from the Hamptons to New York City was smooth and scenic and took about 12 minutes.

headline: In Maine, Catching Salmon the Old-Fashioned Way
text: LOVELL, Me. — Anyone who thinks the market price for lobster or Chilean sea bass seems high should talk to my father, who paid $6,800 for a single fish recently.

headline: Medicare Plans to Deny Coverage of Artificial Disks
text: Government regulators said yesterday that Medicare, the federal insurance program, planned to deny coverage for artificial disks implanted in the lower spines of older patients.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Tough 5 Months, but Democrats Cite Successes
text: WASHINGTON, May 25 — After five months in power, Congressional Democrats headed home for their Memorial Day recess with only a few signature accomplishments on the domestic front, notably an increase in the minimum wage, and the prospect of returning to a renewed struggle with the Bush administration over the war in Iraq.

headline: From the Green Zone to the Spin Zone (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fox’s Library: Tribute to Democracy or Ego?
text: SAN CRISTÓBAL, Mexico, May 25 — Swept into office in 2000 in Mexico’s first real democratic election, former President Vicente Fox is breaking ground again, this time on a library devoted to his often stormy tenure.

headline: Festival Distinguished by Its Strong Actresses
text: CANNES, France, May 25 — The critics in Cannes are a notoriously contentious bunch, but something close to a consensus has formed that this festival has new vitality at 60. Some years, a disappointing lineup in the main competition sends impatient crowds to the sidebar programs, but this year the big show is receiving most of the attention and acclaim.

headline: White House Is Said to Debate ’08 Cut in Iraq Combat Forces by 50%
text: WASHINGTON, May 25 — The Bush administration is developing what are described as concepts for reducing American combat forces in Iraq by as much as half next year, according to senior administration officials in the midst of the internal debate.

headline: Fans Tolerate Doping, and Media Remain Riveted
text: Last season, baseball fans reveled in the outfield acrobatics of Gary Matthews Jr. Matthews was one of the most exciting center fielders in baseball.

headline: Libby Prosecutor Asks for No Leniency in Sentence
text: WASHINGTON, May 25  The prosecutor who in March won the conviction of I. Lewis Libby Jr. on four felony counts in the C.I.A. leak case asked a federal judge on Friday to sentence him to 30 to 37 months in jail.

headline: A World of Glacial Movements, Tense With Emotions
text: Like snails, like glaciers, Eiko and Koma move slowly, so slowly, and yet even in stillness their bodies seem at all points suffused with meaning and, more particularly, feeling. The mind doesn’t go into slow motion while watching them. They keep us in a state of almost continuous suspense, so that we’re returned to that most basically pleasurable of theater sensations: wanting to know what will happen next.

headline: Green Breaks Foot With a Foul Ball
text: MIAMI, May 25 — The Mets lost Shawn Green for an undetermined amount of time Friday night when he broke his right foot during the fifth inning of their 6-2 victory against the Florida Marlins.

headline: Consolidating the Banks of Europe
text: The European banking market is in the midst of a merger wave spurred by a quest for earnings growth and the fear of falling behind. At the forefront of the acquirers is Alessandro Profumo, chief executive of UniCredit, Italy’s largest bank, which last week agreed to buy a rival, Capitalia, for 21.8 billion euros ($29 billion).

headline: U.S. and Iraqi Forces Clash With Militia in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD, May 26 — American, British and Iraqi forces battled fighters from the Mahdi Army militia in Baghdad and the southern port city of Basra today, a day after the militia’s leader, the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, came out of hiding and reiterated his calls for the withdrawal of foreign troops.

headline: A Stadium Seat, an Investigative Columnist and a Younger, Angrier Giuliani
text: Perhaps the presidential candidate and Yankee fan extraordinaire Rudolph W. Giuliani has become accustomed to answering questions about the team paraphernalia he owns.

headline: Dissecting the Game, Skill by Skill
text: A combination of skills — from shotmaking to mental toughness — is required to win a Grand Slam event like the French Open, which begins tomorrow. But the individual strengths of players can make a difference at key moments in a match.

headline: Human-Trafficking Bill (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Last of the Last: 3 Horses in a Stable of Empty Stalls
text: Brutus sleeps in a back corner, in a stall with a window view of the neighbors’ courtyard. Only in New York, perhaps, can you find yourself living in an apartment next to a horse. Tugger and Monte have two wooden stalls close to each other, away from the windows, near the old ramp that leads downstairs.

headline: Panel Wants to Hear From Justice Official
text: The House Judiciary Committee chairman asked Paul J. McNulty, the deputy attorney general, to appear before the panel to respond to accusations by Monica M. Goodling, a former Justice Department aide, in her testimony to the panel earlier this week. Ms. Goodling said Mr. McNulty failed to testify fully when he appeared in February before a Senate panel and knew more than he had acknowledged about the extent of White House involvement in last year’s dismissal of federal prosecutors. The chairman, Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said in a letter to the Justice Department that the testimony was “clearly necessary.”

headline: Nintendo, Once Down, Devises Its Comeback
text: SEATTLE, May 23 — Reggie Fils-Aime, president and chief operating officer of Nintendo of America, is certainly the game industry’s man of the moment, at least in the United States. Mr. Fils-Aime and his crew staged a day of media events here this week amid one of the most remarkable turnabouts in fortune gamers have seen since Atari went belly up two decades ago.

headline: Various Ways to Invest Buffett’s Way
text: WARREN E. BUFFETT created his immense fortune by investing with Main Street, not Wall Street, in mind.

headline: Sallie Mae Chairman’s Payout Is Tallied

I suppose the only new insight that I can bring to it is simply to describe the outcry, the roar, the laughter that erupted in the media center when Kimi Raikkonen parked his Ferrari in the Rascasse corner at exactly the same spot where Michael Schumacher parked his during qualifying last year on this day in Monaco.

headline: Which Carbon Diet Works Better?
text: Attention, global-warming wonks. Ronald Bailey has a must-read (and surprisingly readable, given the subject) post at Reason analyzing ways to slow emissions of greenhouse gases. He compares the favorite appraoch of economists, a carbon tax, with the favorite approach on Capitol Hill and the presidential campaign trail, a carbon market that would put a cap on emissions and allow companies to buy and sell emission permits. You can guess which approach looks better, but it’s worth learning exactly why.

headline: China’s ‘Genocide Olympics’
text: As I travel around China, I’ve been asking about Darfur. Most ordinary people seem unaware of it – and unaware of Chinese support for the Sudanese regime as it conducts genocide in Darfur. But government and Communist Party officials are acutely aware of the situation and deeply sensitive to it. The campaign to tie Darfur to the Olympics is working.

headline: Video: The Olympics’ First Losers
text: There’s a new video from Nick’s journey across China. He visited a petitioner who’s in Beijing trying to get party officials to help her with injustices her family suffered after a mining accident. These petitioners, who come from all across China seeking redress for injustices, are already feeling the squeeze from authorities who are afraid that such people will mar Beijing’s image during the Olympics. The government destroyed the “petitioners’ village” where they lived in Beijing, and the authorities are sending more of them into detention centers or back to their home villages.

headline: Inside the List
text: LEONARD’S FINAL FOUR: What’s Elmore Leonard’s best novel? In the right bar, that question could start a rumble. But Mark Reiter tackles it with elegance and wit in his recent book “The Enlightened Bracketologist: The Final Four of Everything,” which he wrote with Richard Sandomir and Nigel Holmes. According to Reiter, the novels that make it to Leonard’s final four are “Hombre” (1961), “Swag” (1976), “LaBrava” (1983) and “Killshot” (1989). It’s hard to quibble with that list. “LaBrava” got there by defeating, in the second round, “Get Shorty.” (Reiter calls this “an ironic matchup, since Leonard wrote ‘Get Shorty’ to get back at Dustin Hoffman for torturing him during the writing of the ‘LaBrava’ screenplay.”) The final matchup, in Reiter’s bracket, is between “Swag” and “Killshot.” I’ll let Reiter describe which book wins: “ ‘Swag’ is great because you root for the crooks. ‘Killshot’ goes it one better with Leonard’s best-ever opening chapter, a cast of kinky characters who are both menacing and sympathetic, and the rarity of a happily married couple as the novel’s action heroes. Even the blunt title is perfect.” Leonard’s new novel, “Up in Honey’s Room,” is at No. 15.

headline: Victim of Climate Change, a Town Seeks a Lifeline

And then, with a rumble down a gravel strip, the planes are gone, the outside world recedes and this subarctic outpost steels itself once again to face the frontier of climate change.

headline: Early Arrivals and Late Departures Get Harder

But it’s not as easy as it used to be. During the travel slump after 9/11, when hotels had plenty of rooms available, it was often possible to arrive at almost any hour and get into a room, and a polite request to the front desk was usually all it took to extend your stay.

headline: Tribal Loyalties

Taking a page from the city’s new get-tough anticrime playbook, Capt. headline: Before the Lights Went Out
text: Any book whose acknowledgments begin “I am extremely grateful to Her Majesty the Queen” would seem to promise pretty rarefied reading, but Juliet Nicolson’s brief new social study of England in the summer of 1911 proves sharp and rangy, making room for the lower orders along with the royals and the gentry. All of them were caught up that season in a prolonged and oppressive heat wave that only the cheetahs in the Regent’s Park zoo found delightful. As the sweltering continued, some of the more thoughtful inhabitants of the class-bound island nation began to wonder if the real problem might not be the heat but the rigidity.

headline: Faust and the Exploding Angel
text: A METAPHOR for the high cost of overweening desire, Faust is the story of a man who sells out by trading his soul to the Devil for wealth, love, knowledge or power. Even those who do not believe in Satan can recognize how neatly the plot illustrates the dilemma inherent in temptations of all kinds. Adapted in countless novels, poems, films, paintings, dances, dramas and operas, the Faust plot provides a renewable resource for contemplating moral compromise.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) BURY MY HEART AT WOUNDED KNEE Dee Brown’s 1971 epic history of the displacement and decline of the American Indian has gained a new character in this adaptation, the better to attract a wide audience. At the story’s heart now is Charles Eastman (Adam Beach), a Dartmouth-educated part-Sioux doctor who is shown at the Battle of the Little Bighorn but in real life was nowhere near it. Anna Paquin plays Elaine Goodall, the white schoolteacher Eastman marries; Aidan Quinn portrays Senator Henry Dawes, who sponsored the General Allotment Act of 1887, which authorized the government to survey and divide tribal lands; and August Schellenberg, above, is Sitting Bull, the Lakota chief who refused to budge.

headline: Vice
text: “I leave to my actions to speak for themselves,” Aaron Burr once wrote, “and to my character to confound the fictions of slander.” His faith was ill placed, at least according to Nancy Isenberg, who in her fascinating new biography, “Fallen Founder,” argues that Burr has been misunderstood, and underappreciated, for two centuries. The Burr you know — for killing Alexander Hamilton in a duel in Weehawken, N.J. — is the bad boy of the early American Republic: rash, dissipated, self-interested and, by the end of his life, half-mad. But the Burr Isenberg knows is witty, wise and very, very sexy.

headline: As the Clock Winds Down
text: With less than two weeks to go in the legislative session, little of substance has been passed and the Democrats and Republicans seem far apart in their proposals and their willingness to listen to each other. The big issues involving taxes, health care and education remain unsettled.

headline: Race Resumes After Rain Delay
text: INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 — Rain delayed the 91st running of the Indianapolis 500 for more than three hours on Sunday, with Tony Kanaan taking the lead from his teammate, Marco Andretti, just before the race was red-flagged after 113 of 200 laps.

headline: They Came, They Toured, They Offended
text: EVERY summer, people all over the world become acquainted again with a deep truth spoken by the philosopher-tourist Steve Martin.

headline: Susan Sloan, David Frisco Jr.
text: Susan Jane Sloan, an architectural designer, and David Anthony Frisco Jr., a graphic designer, are to be married today at the Brookstown Inn in Winston-Salem, N.C. Rabbi Andrew Ettin is to officiate.

headline: Melissa Kujawski, Andrew Rosen
text: Dr. Melissa Henrie Kujawski, a daughter of Elizabeth Szancer Kujawski of Manhattan and Nathan Kujawski of Flushing, Queens, is to be married this evening to Andrew Phillip Rosen, the son of Arlene and Carl Rosen of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Marcelo Bronstein is to officiate at the Tribeca Rooftop, an events space in Manhattan.

headline: Cleaning Up the Clean Water Act
text: A series of murky Supreme Court decisions have left the agencies responsible for enforcing the Clean Water Act in a state of confused paralysis, exposing millions of acres of wetlands and thousands of miles of streams to illegal and destructive development. Companion bills in the House and Senate would solve this problem by reaffirming the broad protections intended by Congress when it passed the law nearly 35 years ago. These bills deserve prompt passage.

headline: Season in the Sun
text: “Corsica is not — how shall I say it — is not well known for its allegiance to the laws of the continent,” the owner of a seaside Corsican auberge tells a young American without working papers, proposing to let him do odd jobs in exchange for room and board and “a little something at the end of the season.” This is precisely what John Hanson Mitchell, trying to deflect the insistent letters from his draft board, is eager to hear. But he’s not alone. Just about everyone in his memoir of the Rose Café in the summer of 1962 is a fugitive of some sort: political refugees, con men, Gypsies, aged members of the underground with “long-distance eyes” — even a shy deliveryman whose father, a scruffy old donkey herder , may, it is whispered, be a mazzeri, a Corsican version of a zombie .

headline: Queen of Hearts
text: Lovely to look at and ornery to handle, artichokes are — like roast turkey and hand-wrapped tamales — ideal ritual food. The rites that artichokes serve, of course, are spring’s, the annual cleaning and regreening of the palate after the long winter. (Even in their oddball alcoholic form — the Italian digestivo Cynar — artichokes serve as a quasi-medicinal cleanser.) Other greens and tender young herbs are there as part of the vernal celebration, but artichokes are almost alchemical in their appeal. What other food would you forgive for pricking your fingertips, overflowing your compost bucket and killing your best wines? The artichoke makes up for all this, of course, with its distinctive flavor — a nutty, herbal fusion with an everlasting finish.

headline: With Marco and Michael, Andrettis Hope Luck Turns at Indy
text: INDIANAPOLIS, May 26 — Marco Andretti was a rookie, and still a teenager, when he nearly won the Indianapolis 500 last May. He drove a nearly flawless race, even when he lost the lead to Sam Hornish Jr. at the end and finished second, drawing raves from his father and grandfather, who also lug an often burdensome last name that suggests speed.

headline: Sister Acts
text: The 13th century was a very long time ago. But you’d never know it from Nancy Goldstone’s breezy account of the careers of four sisters — Marguerite, Eleanor, Sanchia and Beatrice — born to Raymond Berenger V, the Count of Provence, and his wife, Beatrice of Savoy. Some might call that a victory. After all, making the past accessible to present-day readers is the goal of any popular historian. But Goldstone’s method raises some questions. “Four Queens,” she explains, is the story of “a family of four sisters who had risen from near obscurity to become the most celebrated and powerful women of their time.” But just how obscure was this family?

headline: Hilary Rubin, Alexander Teeman
text: Hilary Michelle Rubin, a daughter of Maureen and Alan I. Rubin of Los Angeles, is to be married today to Alexander Stephen Teeman, a son of Ellen and Martin A. Teeman of Katonah, N.Y. Rabbi Charles J. Davidson is to officiate at the Puck Building in New York.

headline: Interpreting Steinbrennerisms as Losses Weigh on Job Security
text: The Yankees have a funny way of coming back against the Boston Red Sox. Instead of mounting a long winning streak, they lose games. Maybe the Yankees think they can fool the Red Sox and lull them into a false sense of security.

headline: Naomi Giges, Timothy Downey
text: Naomi Elin Giges and Timothy Robert Downey are to be married this evening at Fresh, a restaurant in New York. The Rev. Elissa C. Giges, an interfaith minister and an aunt of the bride, is to officiate.

headline: Daring to Disagree, and Sent to an Asylum
text: Few more horrific human warehouses ever existed than the Insane Asylum at the Illinois State Hospital at Jacksonville, circa 1860. With screams punctuating the night, the smell of human waste overwhelming, and abuse of patients a daily occurrence, any poor soul who chanced to enter sane did not stay so for long.

headline: Passing Off Puts James in a Debate Over Style
text: CLEVELAND, May 26 — LeBron James walked into the Cleveland Cavaliers’ locker room Friday wearing black sunglasses as if to shield himself from the lightning storm of debate around him.

headline: War Without End
text: Never mind how badly the war is going in Iraq. President Bush has been swaggering around like a victorious general because he cowed a wobbly coalition of Democrats into dropping their attempt to impose a time limit on his disastrous misadventure.

headline: A Monthly Wild Card: Job Numbers
text: PREDICTING which way stocks will move is no easy feat, but it has been a snap compared with forecasting changes in employment. Job creation was far stronger than expected in March, then far weaker last month. Stocks, meanwhile, have moved almost relentlessly higher.

headline: Bill Fills Niche, or at Least Gift Shop Shelf
text: CARSON CITY, Nev., May 24  Among the 573 Senate bills the Nevada Legislature plowed through this week, one stood out for its sheer jocularity.

headline: Doubts Grow as G.I.’s in Iraq Find Allies in Enemy Ranks
text: BAGHDAD — Staff Sgt. David Safstrom does not regret his previous tours in Iraq, not even a difficult second stint when two comrades were killed while trying to capture insurgents.

headline: Altima Coupe: Fewer Doors, More Drama
text: IT was a Rodgers and Hammerstein moment: Across a crowded room, I saw a stranger. And somehow I knew, even then, I wanted to see this stranger again and again.

headline: Judd Apatow’s Family Values
text: For his second film, Judd Apatow chose locations that gave him a chance at making it home to Pacific Palisades in time for dinner. That meant much of “Knocked Up,” Apatow’s follow-up to “The 40-Year-Old Virgin,” was shot in the summer cauldron of suburban Los Angeles. While the set had a cozy family feel to it — the cast consisted of Apatow regulars, including his wife, Leslie Mann — 12-hour days in Northridge began dragging interminably. The curious appearance one day of Joey Buttafuoco (of Amy Fisher fame) manning a craft-services ice-cream truck only momentarily lifted the torpor.

text: FILM

headline: America the Generous: A Lost Story of Citizenship
text: When people bicker over immigration, it’s often not long before the topic turns to My Family Came Here Legally. People whose roots go to Ellis Island or deeper like to say that. It fills their family trees with hard-working people who were poor but played by the rules, who got with the American program. It draws a bright line between upstanding Americans and those shadowy illegal workers hiding one big secret and who knows how many others.

As their voices filled the ornate Roman Catholic church, Mary Help of Christians on East 12th Street, a white-haired congregant named Josephine Ruta strode with purpose toward the altar. With a wave of her hand, she summoned the pastor, the Rev. Mark Hyde, and informed him that she wanted to sing a song.

text: TRENTON, May 25  Sometime next month, the New Jersey Legislature is expected to end the state’s well-worn  some would say worn-out  practice of holding more than one elective office at a time.

headline: The Crash That Passed Us By
text: SPRING — the season for house selling — is here, and the national picture continues to be bleak at best. The national data released so far this year have been extremely weak and worrisome.

headline: A Star’s (Pre-Celebrity) Turn on the Soccer Field
text: GRACIE” is first and foremost a family film. But not in the usual kid-tested, mother-approved, focus-grouped to the whole family way. Based loosely on the struggles of the actress Elisabeth Shue to play soccer on boys’ teams in her hometown, South Orange, “Gracie” is a “Bend It Like Beckham”-esque tale conceived, produced, directed and starring sundry members of the Shue family.

headline: Burning Love
text: About two months after we met, I said to my future wife, “I think we should live together.”

headline: A High-End Remote for a High-Tech Life
text: COUCH potatoes who don’t like the clutter of four or five remote controls can buy a single version to rule the television, cable box, DVD player, stereo and even the lighting system. Most of these devices use clickers or buttons the way standard remotes do, but a few luxury versions use colorful touch screens as control panels.

headline: Jazz Proves That the Spurs Are Only Human
text: SALT LAKE CITY, May 26 — Tim Duncan is not prone to wild emotional swings, only minute degrees of change ranging from stoic and modestly pleased to stoic and mildly annoyed. His brisk walk to the bench late Saturday night provided the only visual clue to the state of his psyche.

headline: The Curtains, the Dog, the Remark
text: IT was Memorial Day weekend, the official start to the summer season, and although the stores were boasting sales even more spectacular than the week before, I was determined to do anything but shop. But there I was walking along Avenue of the Americas with my boyfriend, Steve, headed toward Bed, Bath & Beyond. I had agreed to go into Manhattan from Prospect Heights to stroll around Union Square and the Flatiron district. When Steve suggested that we stop into the store for bedroom curtains, I reluctantly said yes.

Then, as the pedestrian traffic thickened, I heard the sharp, clear notes of a brass band and clambered out of the cab into a mob of celebrants.

headline: A Hard Bloke
text: “We have a new boy starting next month,” announces Raymond Blanc, the esteemed chef-owner of a British countryside restaurant called Le Manoir aux Quat’Saisons, about a third of the way into “The Devil in the Kitchen,” Marco Pierre White’s memoir. “His name is Marco White and he has worked for Albert Roux, Pierre Koffman and Nico Ladenis. None of them could break him.”

headline: Christina Pollak, Matthew Devlin

headline: In Search of Graham Greene’s Capri
text: LET'S free associate. If I say Capri, what comes to mind? Glamour, gorgeous views, ritzy shopping — the uninterrupted leisure of la dolce vita. And what if I say Graham Greene? Troubled faith, espionage, unforgiving, “cinematic” realism, seedy characters in sordid places. “Greeneland” can be thrilling on the page, but not many of us would want to go there on vacation.

headline: Observances on Long Island
text: Following is a list of some of the Memorial Day parades and ceremonies across Long Island.

headline: Correction: It’s All About My Mother
text: A Style picture layout on May 13, featuring women wearing their mothers’ clothing or clothing like it, misstated the price and store location of the Balenciaga by Nicolas Ghesquiere dress worn by Sharmila Desai. It costs $2,975, not $1,325, and is available at the Balenciaga boutique, 542 West 22nd Street, not at Blake, Chicago.

headline: Prisoner of War
text: Twenty years ago last month, Primo Levi plunged headlong into the stairwell of the apartment building in Turin where he had been born and to which he had returned after liberation from Auschwitz. At the time, there was a great deal of debate about the nature and meaning of his death: was it an accident or a suicide, illness or cosmic despair? But it is surely the way he lived and wrote in the four decades after the war that matter most. If the ancient Greeks were right that it is the manner of one’s death as much as the substance of one’s life that determines its ultimate meaning, then much of European Jewry, not to mention European culture, would need to be written off as an abject failure.

headline: A Dosa a Day? Why Not?
text: By the time the footlong dosa, a stuffed South Indian crepe, is delivered across the copper counter at the Hampton Chutney Company, you may wonder how you’ll finish eating something that is long enough to carry under your arm. Gary MacGurn, who with his wife, Isabel, owns the 10-year-old business in Amagansett, as well as two Manhattan outposts, says it’s easy. When he first opened, he said, “I found I could eat a dosa every day, and I still do.”

text: To Catch a Brooklyn Bass

Yesterday, the couple had a paebaek, a traditional Korean ceremony, at the River Room of Harlem, a restaurant.

headline: The Old Ballgame, Recreated in Color
text: HE roots for Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez and the rest of the team at least once a week, but after a few innings Graig Kreindler often feels compelled to flip off the TV and head downstairs to his basement painting studio in Airmont, N.Y. There, on the easel before him, he encounters a different breed of Yankee: Mantle. DiMaggio. Gehrig. Ruth.

headline: Bombs Kill 2 G.I.’s in Iraq as Death Toll Near Year’s High
text: BAGHDAD, May 27 — Two more American soldiers have died from roadside bombs, the American military said Sunday, as American forces decided to run DNA tests on a body that could be that of one of the remaining two missing soldiers seized in an ambush on May 12 south of Baghdad.

headline: Terri Landon, Jay Bacow
text: Terri Marissa Landon, the daughter of Marlene Landon and Leonard Landon of New York, is to be married today to Jay Fleet Bacow, a son of Adele Fleet Bacow and Lawrence S. Bacow of Medford, Mass. Rabbi Jeffrey Summit, the executive director of Tufts Hillel, is to officiate at Tufts University in Medford, of which the bridegroom’s father is the president.

headline: State Program Wrestles With Problem of Linking Local Produce to Chefs
text: NO one has to convince David Zemelsky of the value of selling locally grown produce to Connecticut restaurants. That has been the cornerstone of Star Light Gardens, the organic greens and heirloom tomato operation he opened in Durham eight years ago.

headline: The Many Tribes of YouTube
text: WHAT do you think of the latest video on YouTube? Wait. Don’t answer that, or at least don’t answer with words. Because almost the instant you start to talk about one of the beautiful, puzzling videos that pervade the site that Google acquired last fall for $1.65 billion, you reveal that you’re missing the point. Really the only authentic response to a YouTube video is another YouTube video — the so-called “video response.”
