headline: Bankers Behaving Badly
text: Some years ago, a New Yorker cartoon depicted a middle-aged, big-haired, overweight and badly dressed woman striding energetically down the street, with Manhattan’s skyline in the background. Her too-snug T-shirt displayed the large black initials “DKNJ.” The caption beneath read simply, “Donna Karan’s nightmare.”

headline: The List: 33 Architectural Favorites in New York
text: IN a survey conducted by Harris Interactive for the American Institute of Architects, 33 of the 150 examples of America’s favorite structures are in New York City. Here is a list of New York’s honorees, with their rankings in the survey.

headline: A Barbaric Relic
text: It is amazing what legislators will resort to when they want to avoid taking a stand on a controversial matter, even when they know it is the right thing to do.

headline: A Sleeping Beauty Since ’62, Rare Bugatti Awaits Its Comeback
text: AMONG serious collectors, there are few mysteries; with only occasional exceptions, cars of particular significance have all been deeply researched and their histories well-documented. A Duesenberg or Ferrari expert knows when an important example will be coming to auction and can typically recite its ownership history in numbing detail, referring to the car not by something as vague as a model name but by its exact chassis number.

headline: In the Dressing Room, Relationships Laid Bare
text: MY girlfriend had grown tired of seeing me in my habitual attire — baggy khakis with fraying ends, threadbare sweaters I’d probably owned since college, an old tweed sports coat — and resolved to expose me to the possibilities of style.

headline: Ahern, Short of Election Majority, Vows to Form a New Coalition
text: DUBLIN, May 26 — Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, who has led Ireland since 1997, said Saturday that he was confident of forming a new coalition government and securing a third term as complete results of a national ballot showed his party winning the largest share of seats in Parliament but falling five seats short of a majority.

headline: No Place to Park, but Plenty of Blame
text: Parking, that most coveted urban commodity, has turned a typically serene corner of the Bronx into a battleground.

headline: Poland’s Second City Is First Choice for the Young
text: TO find Pauza, an artsy pub in the medieval heart of Krakow, slip past the rowdy British lads at the greasy kebab stands, step over the inebriated young woman splayed on the shiny cobblestones, and wait. A clique of trendy young Poles will clear a path to a soot-stained building on Ulica Florianska; follow them up a dark stairwell and open the unmarked wooden door.

headline: The Week in Westchester
text: Still No Answer on Dobbs Ferry Election Date

headline: Clueless
text: Of all the people who deserve some blame for the debacle in Iraq, don’t forget the American public. Today, about two-thirds of Americans oppose the war. But back in March 2003, when United States troops stormed into Iraq, nearly three out of four Americans supported the invasion. Doves say that the public was suckered into war by a deceitful White House, and hawks say that the press has since led the public to lose its nerve — but the two sides implicitly agree that the public has been dangerously unsure, or easily propagandized, or ignorant.

headline: Fola Popoola and Alvin May II
text: Folasade Adetokunbo Popoola, the daughter of Lillie Popoola and Dr. Dapo Popoola of Rolling Hills, Calif., is to be married today to Dr. Alvin Sol May II, a son of Diane May and Mr. May Sr. of Oakland, Calif. The Rev. Jim Welch, an evangelical minister, is to officiate at a private estate in Malibu, Calif.

headline: Penske and Dodge Seek Breakthrough at Lowe’s
text: CONCORD, N.C., May 26  The racecar owner Roger Penske has pulled off one of the most unusual doubles in motorsports. He will have drivers on the pole Sunday in the Indianapolis 500, with Hélio Castroneves, and the Coca-Cola 600 Nascar race, with Ryan Newman.

headline: State Reading Scores Jump for Roosevelt 8th Graders
text: THE school district in Roosevelt had had little but bad news in recent years. A state takeover in 2002 because of financial problems and poor student performance has been followed by worse performance and more financial problems, culminating in the resignation of the state-appointed superintendent, Ronald O. Ross.

headline: The Dogged Approach
text: Q: Although you’re a former intelligence officer with the Israeli Army, your new book, “The Loved Dog,” which has zipped to the top of best-seller lists, advocates a nonmilitary, totally indulgent approach to dog training. Why do you say indulgent? Indulgence sounds a little bit L.A., and I am not about painting your dog’s toenails pink. I am more about connecting with your dog and respecting your dog.

headline: A Hip-Hop Hurricane and Other Phenomena
text: Hurricane Chris

headline: Over Here
text: Washington

headline: Perpetual-Motion Maestro
text: JAMES LEVINE could hardly wait to show off his physical agility. A year ago he missed four months of work after tripping on the stage at Symphony Hall in Boston during a concert with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, severely injuring his right shoulder.

headline: After Forest Fires, Resiliency and Growth
text: WHILE television sets across the country were showing forests ablaze and firefighters frantically dousing flames during the weeklong inferno that burned more than 17,000 acres in the New Jersey Pinelands, a few more subtle events were happening far from the cameras’ lenses.

headline: Appeals Court Affirms an Eviction
text: A RECENT New York appeals court ruling provides vivid evidence that even an experienced real estate lawyer is no match for the power of a co-op corporation to control the quality of life in its building.

headline: Sturm und Drang Over a Memorial to Heinrich Heine
text: NOWHERE are the tensions between art and politics drawn more sharply than in the strange case of the Heine Memorial, intended in 1899 for one of the most prominent sites in Manhattan but finally unveiled in the Bronx, where it stands at 161st Street and the Grand Concourse.

headline: From a Bad Marriage, Pretty Babies
text: AS Daimler and Chrysler negotiate their separation, the sedan widely regarded as the best design to come from their marriage, the Chrysler 300, might imagine itself in a movie moment: She is a lovely daughter at the prom. In a bittersweet scene, the divorcing mom and dad are ruefully proud: “At least our marriage produced her!”

headline: Lens Solution Is Pulled Over Link to Infection
text: A contact lens solution manufacturer voluntarily withdrew one of its products yesterday after federal health officials said an investigation had linked it to a rare but potentially blinding eye infection.

headline: Tuscan Summer: Food, Wine and Music Galore
text: Tuscany will be alive this summer with classical music, lots of it. Three music festivals will be inaugurated this year near Siena, an area that already has three other summer festivals.

headline: Up Front
text: In the 1980s and ’90s, Steven Pinker established himself as one of his generation’s leading experimental psychologists. But with the publication, in 1994, of “The Language Instinct,” his study of the biological sources of speech, Pinker attracted nonspecialist readers. He enlarged his following with “How the Mind Works” and “The Blank Slate: The Modern Denial of Human Nature,” books that bring the psychological perspective to bear on art, politics and morality, among other subjects.

headline: Red Carpets Through History
text: THE Cannes Film Festival presents its awards today, bringing out the brightest stars in the Hollywood and international firmaments for a red-carpet barrage of photos, speculation on the winners and generally profound discourse. But was the pre-show interview always this glamorous?

headline: A Tour With Head Tilted Up
text: TO see 25 of America's 150 favorite architectural structures in a day, you could hire a private plane and try to spot the Sears Tower, the St. Louis Arch, the Milwaukee Art Museum and 22 more from the air as you cross the country.

headline: And You Call That a Blockbuster
text: Hollywood may turn out a slew of blockbuster movies this summer, but will they measure up against the blockbusters of the past?

headline: How ‘Idol’ Helped One Sitcom Cheat Death
text: WHEN Fox Broadcasting introduced its comedy series “ ’Til Death” to potential advertisers one year ago, the show and its star, Brad Garrett, were immediately the subject of cocktail-party chatter.

headline: Bush’s Fleurs du Mal
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Just So Stories
text: Avant-garde fiction in America can seem something of an oxymoron, operating less as a forward movement than as a separatist cult that neither desires nor expects to have any influence on mainstream literature. But the absence of influence is also the presence of freedom, a characteristic easily discernible in the work of Lydia Davis. Known for her translations from the French, especially for her version of “Swann’s Way,” the first volume of Proust’s monumental modernist novel, Davis seems to work on the margins as a writer. Her spare, elliptical short fiction is critically acclaimed, but it forms a challenging body of work, dispensing with straightforward narrative in favor of a microscopic examination of language and thought.

headline: Christina Calcagni, August Sack VI
text: Christina Beck Calcagni, a daughter of Patricia Belle Dantzler Calcagni and Stephen M. Calcagni of Roxbury, Conn., was married yesterday in Chestnut Hill, Mass., to August Albert Sack VI, the son of Mr. Sack IV of Wainscott, N.Y., and the late Susan Van Wyck Sack. The Rev. William McInnes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius of Loyola on the campus of Boston College, from which the bride graduated.

headline: Because We’re Not There Yet
text: THE 1950s are considered the golden age of the automobile. Sales climbed. Fins, after-burner taillights and other jet-age accoutrements appeared on family cars. Drive-in restaurants, movies and even churches and funeral parlors became part of the landscape.

headline: 36 Hours in Moscow
text: OLD-TIMERS always marvel about how much Moscow has changed since the stultifying days of the Soviet Union. That's ancient history. What's really worth marveling about is how much the city has changed in the last year or two. Few places in the world have undergone such a rapid, dizzying and cacophonic transformation as Moscow, and it shows no sign of abating. The gangster Moscow of the 1990s has given way to something tamer, more metropolitan, perhaps, but it is still brash and flashy. The city, like Russia itself, seems to be in search of its identity — embracing the past, though often ironically, while plunging full-speed ahead. What the future holds is uncertain, but meantime, Muscovites are indulging in what an energy-fueled boom has bestowed on them.

headline: Shellen Wu, Steven Chin
text: Shellen Xiao Wu, the daughter of Xiang Fan He and Heng Lin Wu of Setauket, N.Y., is to be married today to Steven Coffee Chin, the son of Chui Fong Chin and Woon Ping Chin of New York. The Rev. William C. F. Yip, a cousin of the bridegroom and a nondenominational Protestant minister, is to officiate at Beach Club Estate, a caterer in Ronkonkoma, N.Y.

headline: The Unintended Consequences of Hyperhydration
text: It’s easy to find, in the mightily expanding iconography of American waste, the monumental (a ziggurat of flattened cars), the sinister (ocher sludge foaming on a riverbank) and the sublime (a plastic bag fluttering in a Japanese maple). The empty bottle and crushed aluminum can are none of these. They are almost too commonplace to notice, too dreary to evoke anything at all. Foundered on a roadside or slumped in a bag of spent Chinese takeout, the can without its Mountain Dew and the bottle without its Bud are unremarkable things. They’re just trash: something we once wanted and now can’t be bothered with.

headline: In One Town, Intersections of Sacrifice
text: Carlstadt, N.J.

headline: Comings and Goings
text: The approaching hurricane season doesn’t seem to be intimidating the Mexico Tourism Board (www.visitmexico.com). On May 17, it announced the opening of a new terminal at the Cancún International Airport, its third. It also announced preliminary plans for a new international airport down the coast in Tulum. ... Think you’ve done everything in Venice? Think again. How about enjoying an opera al fresco under the cypress trees on San Giorgio Maggiore island? The newly reopened Teatro Verde, a 1,500-seat open-air theater built in 1954 (below), has just undergone a $3.3 million refurbishment. For the next five years, the Teatro Verde (www.teatro-verde.de), accessible by boat from St. Mark’s Square, will be the summer home for productions of Johann Strauss’s “Night in Venice.” Tickets start at 59 euros, about $81 at $1.38 to the euro. ...Last Thursday, JetBlue began direct flights to Nantucket from Kennedy Airport in New York to Nantucket, and starting June 14, Delta will offer the same. Travelers who want to take advantage of the new flights before the high season might be interested in several deals, all valid through June 21. For example, the Wauwinet (www.wauwinet.com), which recently opened a new spa, has rates starting at $260. Travelers with dogs might be interested in Harbor House Village (www.harborhousevillage.com, see special packages), which has a new, adjoining Woof Hotel with 12 pooch-friendly rooms. Starting rates are $117. Other preseason starting rates include $235 at the White Elephant (www.whiteelephanthotel.com) and $109 at the Jared Coffin House (www.jaredcoffinhouse.com). ... The Hyatt Regency Maui Resort and Spa (www.maui.hyatt.com) is offering a Kids Eat Free special. The promotion applies to families with children 12 and under who stay at least four nights there from June 11 to Aug. 25. For each paid adult meal, one free children’s meal will be provided — whether it’s breakfast, lunch or dinner — at four of the resort’s restaurants; nightly room rates start at $414.

headline: Give Me a Home Where the Lizards Can Roam
text: Larchmont

headline: Danbury’s Freedom Fighters
text: In a fitting Memorial Day tribute, Danbury unveiled a monument yesterday to the 90 African-Americans from the city who fought in the Civil War, making it one of the few memorials in the state to mention the important role of black Americans in fighting for their freedom.

headline: U.S. and British Airstrikes Hit Iraqi Militia
text: BAGHDAD, May 26 — American, British and Iraqi forces battled fighters from the Mahdi Army militia in Baghdad and the southern port city of Basra on Saturday, with commanders resorting to airstrikes to suppress the militia in both cities, officials said.

headline: South Korea Joins Rush to Build Ever Taller Buildings
text: INCHEON, South Korea — On a stretch of reclaimed land, near where Gen. Douglas MacArthur’s forces came ashore during the Korean War, this city will build a towering monument to its rising ambitions: twin skyscrapers reaching 2,013 feet into the sky, higher than the tallest building in the world today.

headline: A Handful of Soldiers, on Patrol
text: MAHMUDIYA, Iraq

headline: Rebecca Kristol, Elliot Silver
text: Rebecca Louise Kristol, a daughter of Susan S. Kristol and William Kristol of McLean, Va., is to be married today to Elliot Adam Silver, a son of Dr. Orli R. Etingin and Dr. Jonathan S. Silver of New York. Rabbi David Kalender is to officiate at the National Building Museum in Washington.

headline: For Idle Cabbies, a Healthy Way to Wait
text: Tanvir Ahmad, a 53-year-old taxi driver, was walking the perimeter of the four-acre lot that is reserved for cabs waiting for business at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: Mets’ Green Still Hoping to Avoid Disabled List
text: MIAMI, May 26 — A day after fracturing a bone in his right foot, Shawn Green said he remained hopeful that he would not need to go on the disabled list. But Green will not know for sure until Tuesday, when doctors in New York are scheduled to perform additional tests.

headline: Where Every Generation Is First-Generation
text: Last June, Seyran Ates, a lawyer, was waiting for a U-Bahn train in Berlin’s Mockernbrucke subway station with a client for whom she had secured a divorce when the client’s husband stormed onto the platform. He began beating up his ex-wife. Then he turned on Ates. Ates recalls seeing a number of men standing around, watching it all happen, as she danced from side to side with her attaché case, trying to fend off his heavy punches and kicks. It was not the first time she had been attacked in the line of duty.

headline: Baby Boomers Are Cashing In. So What?
text: WILL stocks suffer a multidecade bear market as the baby-boom generation sells its shares to support its retirement? Some have predicted such an outcome, but a new study — which projects huge growth in 401(k) assets in future decades — paints a far more sanguine picture.

headline: Native Son
text: Fifteen is a terrible age for a boy, especially a boy with no parents, a trail of abusive foster homes, a predilection for arson and a face so full of acne even his friends call him Zits.

headline: Correction: The Week Ahead: May 20 - 26
text: The Art entry last Sunday in the Week Ahead report misspelled the name of the school of art that includes Neo Rauch, whose work is the subject of a Met show. It is the New Leipzig School, not Liepzig.

headline: Correction: Evening Hours
text: A picture caption with the Evening Hours column on May 13 misidentified a couple at the Mount Sinai Hospital Crystal Ball on May 3. They are Louise and Edgar Cullman — not Elle and Edgar Cullman Jr., who are the son and daughter-in law of Louise and Edgar.

headline: Stocks Fall in a Week of Cloudy Economic News
text: After weeks of gains, the broad stock market gave up ground last week, while trading volumes declined in advance of the Memorial Day weekend.

headline: For an Airport With a Past, a Future of Soccer Balls?
text: Hopewell Township

headline: Not Going by Car? Get Directions, Anyway
text: Driving in a new city is never easy, particularly if you prefer sightseeing to map reading. But surfacing from a subway miles from your target destination can also be frustrating.

headline: Thea Spyer and Edith Windsor
text: Thea Clara Spyer and Edith Schlain Windsor were married in Toronto on Tuesday. Justice Harvey Brownstone of the North Toronto Family Court officiated at the Sheraton Gateway Hotel.

headline: A Pause to Refresh a Weary Dogmatist
text: CHARMING, modest and funny are not words usually associated with Lars von Trier, but they are exactly right for his playful new comedy, “The Boss of It All.” Made in just five weeks, and set mostly in an office building, the film follows a doofus actor hired to masquerade as the owner of a company whose employees have never set eyes on him. Such an engaging film is not what anyone would expect from this Danish director whose international breakthrough came in 1996 with the glorious but emotionally grueling “Breaking the Waves” and who more recently made two bleak, stylized films set in Depression-era America, “Dogville” (2003) and “Manderlay” (2005).

headline: Now, Nassau Reconsiders Redistricting
text: SUFFOLK COUNTY has created a nonpartisan commission to redraw legislative districts after the 2010 census. Now it may be Nassau County’s turn.

headline: In Just 20 Seconds, a Guitar to Go
text: AN airline pilot’s life can be a lonely one. Countless nights are spent in austere hotels, far from friends and family, with nothing but room service and cable television to ease the monotony.

headline: Bullets in the Beer? Eliot Ness Must Be Back
text: A TRUCK armed with a huge battering ram speeds along a dark, rain-slicked Chicago street, then smashes through the seemingly impenetrable doors of an illegal brewery. Mobsters scatter as federal agents invade. Guns erupt. Bullets splinter vats of beer, flooding the floor. Bodies sprawl in frothy pools. And the gangbuster Eliot Ness notches another victory against the notorious Al Capone.

headline: Asked to Serve Again, a Soldier Goes Down Fighting
text: HOLLYWOOD, Md.

headline: Kimberly Kissam, David Lucchino
text: Kimberly Elizabeth Kissam, a daughter of Nancy L. Kissam and the late James B. Kissam of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married yesterday to David Lawrence Lucchino, a son of Roberta F. Lucchino and Judge Frank J. Lucchino of Pittsburgh. The Rev. Shannan R. Vance-Ocampo, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Country Club in Brookline, Mass.

headline: An Early Detour for Tour de France
text: In which country will the Tour de France start this year? It may sound like a trick question, but there have been five occasions in the race’s 104-year history when the route began outside France: in Amsterdam, Brussels, Berlin, Luxembourg and Dublin. This year, the race will start in London on July 7 with the prologue — a 4.9-mile time trial that starts by Trafalgar Square passes Big Ben, the Houses of Parliament, Westminster Abbey and Buckingham Palace.

headline: An Ever-So-Tactful Auf Wiedersehen
text: Since DaimlerChrysler agreed to sell off its money-losing Chrysler division, Chrysler executives have had to tread a fine line in expressing their reactions to the automaker’s return to American ownership. After all, their old bosses in Germany will still be, in a sense, nearly 20 percent their new bosses. The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management will own the other 80 percent of Chrysler.

headline: Happy Campers
text: Whether or not a book can be judged by its cover, that’s sometimes where it begins. The cover of “My Holocaust” resembles a child’s board game, like Chutes and Ladders but with sprigs of barbed wire and playful figurines in striped prisoner’s garb. A cattle car sits near an ice cream truck. Hanging from colorful striped poles are the words “Auschwitz” and “Birkenau.” The concentration camp gate, where the “Arbeit Macht Frei” always went, now says “A Novel.”

headline: Learning to Dance, One Chunk at a Time
text: LAST month in a studio at American Ballet Theater, Angel Corella was studying the former Ballet Theater star Gelsey Kirkland as she showed him sequences from the second act of “The Sleeping Beauty,” a new production set to have its premiere this week at the Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: To Love and to Cherish for All Eternity, or Not
text: I am no stranger to divorce. I am a two-time loser, having severed my unions with both the man I married when I was too young to know better and the man I wed when I was too work-obsessed to pay attention.

headline: The Clear Blue Sky
text: No matter where you stood in the city, the air was thick after the towers fell: literally thick with the soot and stench of incinerated flesh that turned terror into a condition as inescapable as the weather. All bets were off. New Yorkers who always know where they’re going didn’t know where to go. Cab drivers named Muhammad were now feared as the enemy within; strangers on the street were improbably embraced like family under a canopy of fliers for the missing. Such, for a while anyway, was the “new normal,” though the old normal began to reassert itself almost as soon as that facile catchphrase was coined. Today 9/11 carries so many burdens — of interpretation, of sentimentality, of politics, of war — that sometimes it’s hard to find the rubble of the actual event beneath the layers of edifice we’ve built on top of it. (Or built on top of all of it except ground zero.)

headline: Remembering Soldiers, by Forgetting About Britney and Paris
text: LONG BEACH, N.Y.

headline: Chávez’s Move Against Critic Highlights Shift in Media
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 26 — Arturo Sarmiento speaks upper-crust English polished at Sandhurst, Britain’s aristocratic military school. He made fortunes trading oil and importing whiskey. Now Mr. Sarmiento, just 35 and a staunch supporter of President Hugo Chávez, owns an expanding television network here.

headline: Hollywood on the Lackawanna?
text: SCRANTON, Pa.

headline: Yes, Mold Is Gross. But Is It Dangerous?; Choose Preservation Over Politics; Selecting Books for Children (4 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Artsy Spin on the Grand Tour
text: BASEL, Kassel or Venice? On a recent Thursday night, art collectors and hangers-on were mapping their summer travel plans over plastic glasses of wine at several art openings in New York City's Chelsea gallery district. Just ask David Maupin, co-owner of the Lehmann Maupin Gallery. He's heading to all three.

headline: Maybe Sanjaya Was Channeling Her
text: BABY boomers will recall the brief but spectacular career of one Mrs. Miller, a matronly soul whose pitiful recordings of rock hits like “Monday, Monday” and “Downtown” became joke best sellers in the late 1960s. Well, she was just a piker compared to Florence Foster Jenkins, whose tune-free singing in the ’30s mangled not only pop songs but also the music of Mozart, Verdi and Gounod.

headline: Rebecca Antar, Matthew Novick
text: Rebecca Miriam Antar and Matthew Charles Novick are to be married today by Rabbi Michael S. Friedman at the Glen Cove Mansion in Glen Cove, N.Y.

headline: Pinpointing the Plays That Really Swing a Game
text: Jeff Ma is best known as a card counter, a member of the rogue blackjack team from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the 1990s that won millions of dollars. Then its elaborate and reckless — if legal — schemes were discovered, and casinos barred Ma and his group from their tables.

headline: Scam Artists
text: “Fakes and Forgeries: The Art of Deception,” at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich, Conn., brings together more than 60 examples of creative duplicity, from Cycladic and Egyptian sculpture to Renaissance and modern paintings, works on paper and decorative arts. Among them are pieces that constitute some of history’s more esteemed feats of artistic deceit, including paintings by the great Dutch forger Han van Meegeren that fooled old master experts for decades.

headline: The Alchemist’s Moment: The Reclusive Mr. Polke
text: Cologne, Germany

headline: Blood and Crashes? Sounds Like Lynch
text: Regina, Saskatchewan

headline: Jennifer Maskell, Mark Carney
text: Jennifer Lynn Maskell, the daughter of Patricia Maskell and Stephen J. Maskell of McLean, Va., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Francis Carney, the son of Suga Carney and Joseph P. Carney of Fairfax, Va. The Rev. William J. Donnelly, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the King Family Vineyards in Crozet, Va.

headline: Grade-School Girls, Grown-Up Gossip
text: WHEN Britney Spears shaved off her signature blond locks, Alexis Gursky, 9, found herself wondering not why Ms. Spears picked up a razor in the first place, but why she did not do more with the hair she shaved off.

headline: How Confidential Are Applications?
text: Q Are there any laws in New York that govern how a co-op board handles buyers’ private financial information?

headline: Darling Likes Being No. 2 on Bonds’s List
text: Twenty-one years later, Ron Darling still remembers the pitch that he threw to a young, lean rookie on the Pittsburgh Pirates.

headline: ‘Doors Open’
text: Chapter 3: The Auction House

headline: ‘Middle School Syndrome’ Undergoes a Reversal
text: SCORES on state tests at Westlake Middle School were disappointing for years, and school officials had largely written them off as “middle school syndrome,” a mysterious decline in achievement between elementary school and eighth grade that seemed to afflict most schools in the state.

headline: Grooming a Handwriting Champion
text: MELVILLE, N.Y.

headline: New York’s Powerful Ghosts
text: New York State government has two parts, one public and one carefully tucked out of sight.

headline: 6 Attacks in City Leave 4 Dead and 2 Critically Wounded
text: Four men have been killed and two others critically wounded in a spate of unrelated attacks throughout the city since late Friday, the police said.

headline: Lisa Schorr, Alexander Kaplan
text: Lisa Schorr, the daughter of Lisbeth B. Schorr and Daniel Schorr of Washington, is to be married today in Washington to Alexander Isaac Kaplan, the son of Phyllis Kaplan and Edward Kaplan of Memphis. Rabbi David Saperstein is to officiate at Evermay, a Federal-era house.

headline: All Hail the Green Cabs
text: By doubling mileage requirements for city taxicabs, Mayor Michael Bloomberg seems to have locked in one piece of a potentially historic environmental legacy — not the most ambitious piece, but a significant one nonetheless. His action will transform New York’s taxi fleet from the most polluting in the nation to one of the cleanest, and do so in five years, making the city a leader as municipalities compete to cut carbon emissions.

headline: Seeking Signs of Literary Life in Iran
text: When I moved to Iran in 2000 to work as a journalist, I aspired to belong to a literary circle not unlike that of the engaged women of Azar Nafisi’s “Reading Lolita in Tehran,” who found relief from their authoritarian society in the imaginative world of novels. That bookstores did not exist as such — there were only bookstore/stationery stores, or bookstore/toy stores — was the first sign my plan might not work. I initially mistook Tehran’s most popular bookstore, with its windows full of weathered copper pots and other bric-a-brac, for an antique shop. Inside, the floor space dedicated to books was roughly a quarter of that taken up by kilims, cactuses and Lego sets. “I’m embarrassed to call myself a bookseller,” one store owner told me recently, gazing at the wall of Hello Kitty accessories that dominated his shop. In the hour we spent talking, customers came in to buy watch batteries, a condolence card, wrapping paper and a compass. Not a single person bought a book.

headline: Bill Adds Fuel to Flames in a Divided Border State
text: PHOENIX, May 23 — Here in Arizona, where fighting over immigration comes as naturally as the desert heat, the Senate bill to overhaul immigration laws has ignited a particularly ardent round of fire breathing.

headline: It’s Spring. Somebody Tell the Buyers.
text: IT’S spring, the traditional time for hope and growth in residential real estate sales. But beyond the borders of New York City, there are indications that a wintry chill besets the market in much of the region.

headline: To Smoke or Not? Thereby Hangs a Tale
text: CLAUDIA ELMHIRST can’t wait to read a novel again. When she’s memorizing lines, the British actress doesn’t touch a book, though that usually means only a few weeks of burying herself in a script. Since February of 2006, however, she has been immersed in “Intimate Exchanges,” a 750-page epic by Alan Ayckbourn that asks 2 actors to play 10 characters in 8 interconnected plays. Each play has two possible endings, and Ms. Elmhirst and her co-star, Bill Champion, have committed every variation to memory.

headline: Out of Retirement and Into Uncertainty
text: THINK of retirement and a picture emerges of a grand send-off at the office, followed by travel, hobbies, grandchildren, and a pension and a Social Security check to pay for it all. But after awhile, the retirement fund may start to feel a little skimpy, or the golf course a little dull — or both — and the concept of returning to work becomes, well, more than a concept.

headline: When the Desert Calls
text: ALAINA DEMARTINI decided to trade the San Francisco chill and fog for palm trees and bright stars in an open sky. So last year, she and her husband, David, a retired electrician, moved to the house in Palm Springs, Calif., that they bought as a second home five years ago.

headline: My Year of Vegetables
text: A few years ago, the novelist Barbara Kingsolver packed her husband and two daughters into a car and left their home in Tucson for good, resettling on a farm in southern Appalachia. Their intention was to spend a year of their new rural life eating only what they could grow themselves or buy from local suppliers. The plan was no whim. Kingsolver and her husband, Steven L. Hopp, a biologist who teaches environmental studies, had been raising fruit and vegetables at Hopp’s farm every summer since they met.

headline: Bread and Pastries, Freshly Baked
text: Mozzicato de Pasquale claims to have served generations of customers, and considering that the de Pasquale part of the business (which was bought by the Mozzicato family in 1975) has been baking bread for Hartford residents since 1908, that is no idle boast. The bakery turns out fresh loaves of Tuscan and rye bread, but good as they are, those are just a bit of crust in a wide range of baked goods that have made Mozzicato a much loved establishment.

headline: Good News for Middle Schoolers
text: New York moved to the forefront of the state school reform movement when it raised standards for both students and teachers and instituted rigorous tests during the late 1990s. Test scores have risen since then. But the latest reading scores offer the most hopeful sign yet that the reforms are having an impact — not just in the early grades but also in the notoriously troubled middle school years.

headline: Familiar Aches Put Damon on Bench
text: The Yankees played most of yesterday’s 3-1 loss against the Los Angeles Angels without Johnny Damon, their regular center fielder and leadoff batter. Damon left Friday night’s game in the seventh inning with sore calves and pain in his right Achilles’ tendon.

headline: New Jersey Man Back Home After 3-Nation African Ordeal
text: A 24-year-old New Jersey man who traveled to Somalia to help establish an Islamic state there but was instead imprisoned by three different nations, was released Friday and returned home yesterday, his father said.

headline: The New Tributes, and an Old Triangle
text: HAVE all the great songs already been written? That might justify the latest outpouring of tributes and tribute albums: remakes, with and without conceptual overlay, of material that other musicians admire but aren’t afraid to transform. In the age of the sample, the remix and countless YouTube parodies, entire songs and sometimes entire albums are still being recycled and reclaimed, and musicians are presenting themselves as critics, curators and — above all — fans.

headline: Creeping Equality, a Bit of Fraternity and a Slick of Asterisks at Indy
text: Weary of being ignored by disc jockeys with man crushes on groups like Aerosmith, Sarah McLachlan and her star crew of femme rockers took the American stage in their own hands as they led a celebration of ovulation in the late ’90s.

headline: Working Out the Kinks, for a Price
text: IT’S mid-May and, at the rehearsal studios at 890 Broadway, 25 actors are presenting the Broadway-bound musical “Cry-Baby” to an invited audience of about 150. The cast, clad largely in street clothes, performs the show aided by little more than three musicians, five wooden platforms, several tables and some cardboard-cutout-style props.

headline: Saluting a Maker (Not a Taker) of Photographs
text: Since his death in 1984, Ansel Adams has earned an almost slavish devotion among photography fans. It is easy to see why.

headline: Crashing the Finals Party: The Rowdy Ducks
text: The veteran defenseman Sean O’Donnell spoke up during last week’s semifinals, complaining of dirty play and a lack of respect for opponents on N.H.L. rinks.

headline: Take This Job and Love It
text: EVERY few months on Rider Diaries, an online forum for New York transit buffs, someone posts a message with a subject line like “I’VE BEEN CALLED!!!!” That particular exclamation appeared in October 2005; its writer, a skinny 20-year-old named Jason Brown, crowed that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had “finally reached my number.”

headline: To See You Again
text: Ailsa Kelman, the heroine of Margaret Drabble’s 17th novel, first appears in a dress in which she “gleamed and rippled with smooth muscle, like a fish.” This costume choice is “a happy accident” because Ailsa has been asked to announce, in front of a large London gathering and an even larger television audience, the winner of the Plunkett Prize “for a general science book with a vaguely defined ecological or environmental message” — which turns out to be “Hermaphrodite: Sea Change and Sex Change,” a study of gender-bending in diverse marine species. While she reads the citation in the hall of a natural history museum, beneath a giant fiberglass manta ray, “the jaws of sharks, fixed in the gape of their everlasting grins,” display “their triple rows of teeth.”

headline: That Grouper on the Menu? Turns Out It Was a Fish Tale
text: MADEIRA BEACH, Fla., May 23  On the weathered deck of Dockside Dave’s, a table of tourists waits for the sandwich that has long been as much a part of the beach experience here as the sunshine. Then it arrives, a half pound of fried filet of grouper, fresh from the dock, topped with lettuce, a slice of fresh tomato and splayed on an open bun.

headline: With Tayshaun Prince
text: Forward Tayshaun Prince is averaging 15.2 points in the playoffs for the Detroit Pistons, who hold a two-games-to-none lead over the Cleveland Cavaliers in the Eastern Conference finals. The 6-foot-9 Prince has a remarkable arm span of 7-2. Among his teammates he is known as the go-to guy for league news, current events and even celebrity gossip. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

headline: Letters
text: Congress and Private Equity

headline: Correction: My Dear Fellow Species
text: An article last Sunday excerpting the letters of Charles Darwin misstated the age of “The Origin of Species.” It will be 150 years old in 2009, not next year.

headline: The Gospel of Dobson
text: James Dobson is the Christian right’s most powerful leader. While the Moral Majority and the Christian Coalition have crumbled, Dobson’s organization, Focus on the Family, has prospered. His multimillion-dollar-a-year media empire includes a daily radio show, with him as the host, that reaches millions of listeners, as well as a rapid-response telephone and letter-writing operation.

headline: ‘Sicko,’ Castro and the ‘120 Years Club’
text: CUBA works hard to jam American TV signals and keep out decadent Hollywood films. But it’s a good bet that Fidel Castro’s government will turn a blind eye to bootleg copies of “Sicko,” Michael Moore’s newest movie, if they show up on the streets of Havana.

headline: Dress Whites
text: It isn’t even summer, and the white shirt and shirtdress are in abundance on the streets of Manhattan. There was even a canopy of hundreds of white shirts on Little West 12th Street in the meatpacking district. At evening parties, long white shirtdresses were reminiscent of Renoir portraits. The parks were punctuated with white dandelion heads, and the streets were flooded with sailors in town for Fleet Week.

headline: Scattershot Décor, Sure-Shot Restaurateur
text: THE sign outside the restaurant reads “Michael Anthony’s Food Bar, Ordinary to the Extraordinary.” The ordinary is the location and the décor; the extraordinary, the food.

headline: Operation Freedom From Iraqis
text: WHEN all else fails, those pious Americans who conceived and directed the Iraq war fall back on moral self-congratulation: at least we brought liberty and democracy to an oppressed people. But that last-ditch rationalization has now become America’s sorriest self-delusion in this tragedy.

headline: Bear Sightings Rising in Residential Areas
text: SIGHTINGS of black bears in highly populated areas in Connecticut are up sharply this spring, according to the State Department of Environmental Protection.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Arts & Leisure

headline: Correction: In Search of the Man Who May Have Created Jazz
text: An article on April 22 about twin film projects on the cornetist Charles (Buddy) Bolden included incomplete information about the writers from Dan Pritzker, the director of “Bolden,” one of the productions. In addition to Mr. Pritzker and Derick and Steven Martini, David Rothschild collaborated on the screenplay.

headline: Correction: Housing Plan Turns Disney Grumpy
text: The National Perspectives article last Sunday, about a plan to build 1,500 apartments on a site in Anaheim, Calif., zoned for tourist facilities, misstated the corporate affiliation of Discovery Cove in Orlando, Fla., which was cited as a boutique attraction of the sort that the Walt Disney Company might decide to add in Anaheim. It is owned by the Anheuser-Busch Companies, not Disney.

headline: One Hudson Morning
text: The Hudson that you see from the skiff of a commercial shad fisherman is not the river so familiar from the window of the Metro-North train, the waterfront condominium balcony, or even the shiny deck of a sportfishing boat. The river from those places offers itself to you for passive pleasure; you can give yourself over to indolence and dreams as you wait for the vista and the light to shift, or for a fish to take the lure.

headline: Syrian President’s Fortunes Revive for Election

headline: The Quiet Americans
text: Since my daughter is graduating from college today, I am thinking a lot about the class of 2007 and the world they are about to enter. I’m not sure what they call this generation. Is it generation “X” or “Y” or “Zero” or “Me”? Having taken part in two other commencements this season, though, and knowing enough about what my own daughter’s friends are doing, I can say there is something quietly impressive about this cohort. In fact, if I were giving them a label I’d call them the “Quiet Americans” — not in the cynical way Graham Greene meant it, but in a very positive sense.

headline: A Slice of Relaxed Life, Sandwiched by Parks

The wide sidewalks still have a pleasant buzz, but instead of backpacks, the accessory of choice seems to be strollers.

headline: Fighting Off Foreclosure
text: SHERRI CAUGHMAN prides herself on being the kind of conscientious New Yorker who does her homework before making any major purchases. So when Ms. Caughman, 44, a supervisor in the city’s food-stamp program, decided last November to buy a two-family house in Jamaica, Queens, she took a class on buying real estate, researched the property through city records and vetted the terms of her mortgage with her former sister-in-law, a real estate broker.

headline: Thought Crimes
text: Amoebic dysentery, maggots, sadistic guards, a reeking latrine pail — these are the constants in Karen Connelly’s tale of political prisoners in Burma, a novel that, at least initially, makes you wonder who will read on, through scenes featuring little more than truncheons and gruel, to puzzle over the unexpected, alien detail — a white pen — at the center of the plot. And who will care about the novel’s main characters, a 12-year-old orphan who kills rats for a living and a skeletal dissident in solitary confinement, reduced to eating the lizards he traps inside his cell?

headline: In Zimbabwe, Police Raid Youth Conclave

headline: Crossing Cultures
text: On a journalistic quest, I once visited Jaffa looking for the childhood home of Sabri al-Banna — a k a Abu Nidal, the most infamous of Palestinian terrorists. Stymied in my search, I stopped into Fakhri Geday’s pharmacy. The aging proprietor had grown up in Jaffa before 1948, when most Arab residents of “the Bride of Palestine” fled during the Jewish conquest. Geday politely gave me directions to the old al-Banna mansion, now an Israeli military courthouse. It was a diorama of displacement.

headline: A Tiffany (Girl) in the Family
text: Tiffany floor lamps tend to dominate a room, and the one beside Paul Baur’s fireplace is no exception. Its glass shade is a dense, intricate patchwork of green tendrils, cobalt lozenges and garnet stripes, perched atop a thick, vinelike copper stand. When Mr. Baur, 91, flips five switches to light the cluster of bulbs inside, the lamp glows like a scoop of embers.

headline: Standardizing the Standards
text: “I know you’re restless today, but I need to see you sitting at your desks. Angel, that means you, too!” In the second-grade classroom at the Washington school where I volunteer, the teacher turned to me and said with a sigh, “It’s testing week.” In fact, her class wasn’t suffering through the standardized ordeal, just tiptoeing around while others did. The “adequate yearly progress” (A.Y.P.) assessments mandated by the No Child Left Behind legislation, which was enacted in 2002 with high hopes of closing the achievement gap for minorities, don’t kick in until third grade. But when it comes to tests, N.C.L.B. is fulfilling its inclusive mission all too well: nobody — not even kids too young to be filling in the bubbles yet — escapes the atmosphere of exam-induced edginess.

headline: One Day in Baghdad
text: When the alarm goes off at 0730 hours, I roll from my cot and, as routinely as finding socks back home, strap on uniform, armor, pads, grenades, a 9-millimeter Beretta, assorted mayhem and hurt. Routine is not so comforting in Iraq, I think. But this day is so far like almost every other. I joined the Army with my G.E.D. and a desire to see life beyond Syracuse. I signed just before 9/11 and was shipped to boot camp after the towers fell.

headline: A Star at the Zoo
text: If you thought only children were interested in zoos, then visit Berlin’s city zoo, located in the heart of old west Berlin. Since March, when a little polar bear called Knut was born, the Zoo has become a major attraction, for young and old. In the past 3 months, a staggering 700,000 people have visited the Zoo — to see Knut. The Zoo’s management is delighted. Not just because of the added revenues. It costs Euro 11 a shot to enter. Shares in the Zoo have soared.

headline: Editor’s Choice
text: THE ATOMIC BAZAAR: The Rise of the Nuclear Poor, by William Langewiesche. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) A journalist travels the globe to discover how hard, or easy, it is to gain possession of nuclear weapons or technology.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE ROAD, by Cormac McCarthy. (Vintage International, $14.95.) In this Pulitzer Prize-winning novel , a man and his young son travel across the wretched landscape of a post-apocalyptic world. A nuclear holocaust has reduced everything to ash — clocks stopped at 1:17; the sky opened with “a long shear of light and then a series of low concussions” — and the survivors must kill or be killed (and eaten). As winter approaches, McCarthy’s unnamed heroes scavenge their way south to the Gulf Coast, encountering all manner of perils and remnants of the lost world. In the Book Review, William Kennedy called this terrifying parable “consistently brilliant in its imagining of the posthumous condition of nature and civilization.”

headline: Correction: A Tale of Two Cities

Although Moses proposed early versions of what would become the Westway superhighway, and although he did not agree with some Westway opponents' view that money for the proposal should be diverted to public transit, he spoke against Westway after he had lost his last public authority chairmanship.

headline: Correction: Trees They Want, but No Boys Allowed

Mr. Benepe said that trees reduce — not produce — carbon dioxide in the air by absorbing it. (Trees do emit some carbon dioxide the same way that animals do, but the emission is far outweighed by the absorption that occurs during photosynthesis.)
