headline: ‘The Perfect Summer: England 1911, Just Before the Storm’
text: On the first day of May 1911 temperatures throughout England began to rise, and everyone agreed that the world was becoming exceedingly beautiful. The cold weather of April had held back the flowering of many of the spring bulbs, and with the warmth of the first week of summer there had been a sudden burst of growth. The verges of the country lanes were frothing with cow parsley while late primroses still dotted the roadside banks. Top-hatted men strolling in the London parks had decided it was warm enough to abandon their scarves. Straw-bonneted women had gathered up country bluebells to sell in wilting bunches on street corners in the smarter parts of London, and window boxes were already spilling over with scarlet geraniums and marguerites. Tiny pink flowers covered the branches that would later produce crab apples, while the ocean of white blossoms produced by other fruit trees had prompted Country Life to declare that 'few people can remember any parallel to its profusion.' England was plump with promise.

headline: ‘The Occupation of Iraq’
text: Conflicts and wars fought on its territory have always been the lot of Iraq. It has had the geographic misfortune of lying across the fault lines of civilisations and empires, and its peoples have suffered the waves of conquerors and battles fought over its lands. The ebb and flow of powers that controlled its destiny always left behind a residue that helped to form the profile of the modern Iraqi. But these were not accretions that melded together to form a common sense of nationhood. The shared history and experiences of Iraqis did not give rise to unifying national myths. The legacy of pre-Islamic civilisations - of Sumer, Babylon and Nineveh - was not one that could be readily adapted to the formation of national identity. The pride that came from knowing that Iraq was the land that gave humanity settled agriculture, its first cities and the alphabet, was not internalised. Iraq's ancient history featured only on the periphery of the identity of Muslim Iraqis. Various modern governments have tried to make the connection and continuity with this heritage - sometimes ludicrously, as when Saddam Hussein appropriated the heritage of the lawmaker Hammurrabi and stuck his name on the (rebuilt) walls of Babylon. But it was never pursued with the intent of forming a national consciousness.

headline: ‘The Canon’
text: When the second of her two children turned thirteen, my sister decided that it finally was time to let their membership lapse in two familiar family haunts: the science museum and the zoo. These were kiddie places, she told me. Her children now had more mature tastes. They liked refined forms of entertainment - art museums, the theater, ballet. Isn't that something? My sister's children's bodies were lengthening, and so were their attention spans. They could sit for hours at a performance of Macbeth without so much as checking the seat bottom for fossilized wads of gum. No more of this mad pinball pinging from one hands-on science exhibit to the next, pounding on knobs to make artificial earthquakes, or cranking gears to see Newton's laws in motion, or something like that; who bothers to read the explanatory placards anyway? And, oops, hmm, hey, Mom, this thing seems to have stopped working! No more aping the gorillas or arguing over the structural basis of a polar bear's white coat or wondering about the weird goatee of drool gathering on the dromedary's chin. Sigh. How winged are the slippers of time, how immutably forward point their dainty steel-tipped toe boxes. And how common is this middle-class rite of passage into adulthood: from mangabeys to Modigliani, T. rex to Oedipus Rex.

headline: ‘The Lizard Cage’
text: The boy was twelve years old when he entered the Hsayadaw's monastery school. As the newest novice, his became the smoothest bare head; he was given dark ochre robes and taught how to wear them. With his scavenger's eye for opportunity, he saw how lucky he was. The men here gave him food, and a mat to sleep on beneath a wooden roof. He saw also that the school was a poor place, but the monks who ran it were generous with what little they had.

headline: ‘Animal, Vegetable, Miracle’
text: This story about good food begins in a quick-stop convenience market. It was our family's last day in Arizona, where I'd lived half my life and raised two kids for the whole of theirs. Now we were moving away forever, taking our nostalgic inventory of the things we would never see again: the bush where the roadrunner built a nest and fed lizards to her weird-looking babies; the tree Camille crashed into learning to ride a bike; the exact spot where Lily touched a dead snake. Our driveway was just the first tributary on a memory river sweeping us out.

headline: ‘The Last Tycoons’
text: Even among the great Wall Street firms-Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and Merrill Lynch-Lazard Frères & Co. stood apart, explicitly priding itself on being different from, and superior to, its competitors. For 157 years, Lazard had punched above its weight. Unlike other Wall Street banks, it competed with intellectual rather than financial capital and through a hard-won tradition of privacy and independence. Its strategy, put simply, was to offer clients the wisdom of its Great Men, the finest and most experienced collection of investment bankers the world had ever known. They risked no capital, offering only the raw Darwinian power of their ideas. The better the idea, and the insights and tactics required to achieve the result contemplated by it, the greater was Lazard's currency as a valued and trusted adviser-and the larger were the piles of money the Great Men hauled out of the firm and into their swelling bank accounts. The lucky few men-yes, always men-at Wall Street's summit have always been portrayed as ambitious and brilliant on the one hand and unscrupulous and ruthless on the other. But the secret history of Lazard Frères & Co., the world's most elite and enigmatic investment bank, twists parts of this conventional wisdom into knots of unfathomable complexity. The Great Men chronicled herein amassed huge fortunes-to be sure-but they refused to admit to anyone, least of all to themselves, that their pursuit of these riches led to relentless infighting. Instead they spoke, without irony, of being part of a Florentine guild and of advice whispered to heads of state and to CEOs of the world's most powerful corporations, while all the time attempting to preserve the mythical special idea that was Lazard. They also, to a person, craved an equally elusive chimera: the assurance that somehow, despite everything, they alone had remained virtuous.

headline: ‘The Sea Lady’
text: The winning book was about fish, and to present it, she appeared to have dressed herself as a mermaid, in silver sequinned scales. Her bodice was close-fitting, and the metallic skirt clung to her solid hips before it flared out below the knees, concealing what might once have been her tail. Her bared brown shoulders and womanly bosom rose powerfully, as she drew in her breath and gazed across the heads of the seated diners at the distant autocue. She gleamed and rippled with smooth muscle, like a fish. She was boldly dressed, for a woman in her sixties, but she came of a bold generation, and she seemed confident that the shadowy shoals of her cohort were gathered around her in massed support as she flaunted herself upon the podium. She felt the dominion. It pumped through her, filling her with the adrenalin of exposure. She was ready for her leap.

headline: ‘Falling Man’
text: It was not a street anymore but a world, a time and space of falling ash and near night. He was walking north through rubble and mud and there were people running past holding towels to their faces or jackets over their heads. They had handkerchiefs pressed to their mouths. They had shoes in their hands, a woman with a shoe in each hand, running past him. They ran and fell, some of them, confused and ungainly, with debris coming down around them, and there were people taking shelter under cars.

headline: Decisions, Decisions, Decisions
text: It is days like today that the Mets wish their Class AAA affiliate was still in Norfolk, Va., and not in New Orleans. With Carlos Gomez (hamstring) and Shawn Green (broken foot) unavailable today, the Mets wanted to fly in Ben Johnson, who could be activated if they chose to disable Green before the game.

headline: Sunday Sampler Platter
text: Gov. Bill Richardson followed up the formal announcement of his presidential bid with his turn among the candidates for a grilling by Tim Russert on NBC’s “Meet the Press.” While acknowledging that he didn’t have the “celebrity” status or the money of some of his top Democratic rivals, he called himself “the insurgent candidate’’ who could bring the country together because of his experiences as a lawmaker, a governor (of New Mexico) and as a former United Nations ambassador and member of the Clinton cabinet.

headline: Barack Obama's Basketball Family
text: From 2007: Craig Robinson, basketball coach at Brown University - and Barack Obama’s brother-in-law - talks about Mr. Obama’s game and its impact on his political career.

headline: Candidates Matches Begin With Two Victories and Six Draws
text: There was a great deal of gritty, fighting chess as eight matches to select candidates for the world championship got underway today in Elista, Kalmykia. The winners of the matches will play each other to determine which four will qualify for a championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

headline: Stretching Executive Power in Wartime
text: “The Constitution has never greatly bothered any wartime president,” wrote Francis Biddle, F.D.R.’s attorney general during World War II. Biddle was writing about Roosevelt’s shameful 1942 decision to evacuate Japanese-Americans from the Pacific Coast and place them in internment camps. But Biddle’s comment applies to all presidents in times of crisis. National survival or, perhaps more accurately, the president’s perception of national survival always takes precedence. George W. Bush has been no exception.

headline: ‘Clearly Anti-Competitive’
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer vetoed his fourth bill last week, rejecting an extension of a law limiting the number of check-cashing facilities in any one area. Since 1994, new check-cashing facilities have been banned within three-tenths of a mile of an existing one. This year, the Legislature voted to extend a 2002 law that broadened this prohibition to other financial institutions that open branches mainly devoted to check cashing, including banks and credit unions.

headline: Sticking Points on Authorities Bill
text: A battle looms this week between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Legislature over the details of a bill that would bring new levels of disclosure and oversight to the state’s hundreds of public authorities. Though there is broad agreement on a number of issues, the Legislature favors allowing the state comptroller to approve all authority contracts and giving subpoena power to the office that monitors authorities’ finances. The Spitzer administration, in private talks with lawmakers, balked at those positions.

headline: Drop and Give the Vending Machine 20
text: Watch those vending machines, school hall monitors. A new regulation proposed by the governor says that before students are allowed to buy Gatorade or other sports drinks, they must have “engaged in vigorous athletic activity lasting for more than one hour.” The requirement is included in Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s array of proposals aimed at making food served and sold in schools healthier.

headline: Resistance on DNA Collection
text: Assembly Democrats are resisting Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s proposal to expand DNA collection to all misdemeanor convictions without taking more steps that they say will protect the wrongfully accused.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 6 A.M. (TCM) COMMAND DECISION (1948) Turner Classic Movies salutes the armed forces with a Memorial Day marathon starring some A-list heroes, beginning with Clark Gable in this colorized World War II drama about a general who must battle his own government to send his planes deeper into Germany. The tribute continues with Humphrey Bogart in “Action in the North Atlantic” (1943), at 8; “From Here to Eternity” (1953), the Oscar-winning romance with Montgomery Clift, Donna Reed and, above, Deborah Kerr and Burt Lancaster, at 10:30; “Sergeant York” (1941), the Gary Cooper classic, at 12:30 p.m.; Michael Caine and Laurence Olivier in “The Battle of Britain” (1969), at 3; “Where Eagles Dare” (1969), starring Richard Burton and Clint Eastwood as fearless fliers, at 5:15; “A Soldier’s Story” (1984), in which Howard E. Rollins Jr. plays an African-American officer assigned to investigate a racially charged murder, at 8; the William Holden classics “Stalag 17” (1953), at 10, and “The Bridge on the River Kwai,” at 12:15 a.m.; and “Wake Island” (1942), with Brian Donlevy as a Marine major trying to keep the Japanese off his island base, at 3. Day breaks on a more melodic note with Tab Hunter and Frankie Avalon in “Operation Bikini” (1963) at 4:30.

headline: Morning Fire Kills Three in a Home in New Jersey
text: An early-morning fire tore through a home in Spotswood, N.J., yesterday, killing three people inside, including a man and woman who were to be married in a few days, officials and neighbors said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about a decision by a New Hampshire legislative panel to reject a seat belt law misstated the state’s rate of seat belt use and referred imprecisely to its rank in the nation. The rate is 63.5 percent, not 49.6 percent. New Hampshire and Wyoming  not just New Hampshire  rank last.

headline: The Scent of a Man, Bought by a Woman
text: It is an industry rule of thumb that women’s perfumes account for two-thirds of annual sales of “prestige” fragrances — that is, high-end fragrances sold in department stores or boutiques, rather than drugstores.

headline: African Energy Celebrated Ebulliently and Symbolically
text: DanceAfrica is always a trip, not only through African nations and their cultures but also into another world that proudly claims those cultures as its own. Chuck Davis, who founded this yearly festival 30 years ago, was the perfect towering, irrepressible guide, easing everyone into chanting, hugging and shaking hands during Friday night’s show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on the Street Scene page of Business Day on Friday about the presence of financial firms at the Cannes Film Festival referred incorrectly to the role of the studio Summit Entertainment in the film “Pompeii.” While Summit negotiated financing for the film, it did not invest in it.

headline: In Queens, Classes in Mandarin Are Also Lessons in Adaptation
text: Something extraordinary happened to Maria Farren of Flushing, Queens, on a recent trip to the grocery store. From the familiar background chatter of people speaking Chinese, a syllable leapt out from nowhere. It was not that she understood the word — she didn’t — but the sound was familiar. That was enough of a surprise that she paused in mid-aisle.

headline: In Fierce Competition, Google Finds Novel Ways to Feed Hiring Machine
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — On a spring Saturday, about 90 students from Stanford and as many from the University of California, Berkeley, converged on Google’s corporate campus for a day of spirited team competition over mind-bending puzzles, Lego building problems and video games.

headline: Militants Widen Reach as Terror Seeps Out of Iraq
text: When Muhammad al-Darsi got out of prison in Libya last year after serving time for militant activities, he had one goal: killing Americans in Iraq.

headline: Looking Ahead
text: A DAY OFF All banks and stock markets in the United States are closed today in observance of the Memorial Day holiday. They will reopen on Tuesday.

headline: Irish Classic Is Still a Hit (in Calfskin, Not Paperback)
text: DUBLIN, May 27 — For a manuscript written 1,200 years ago and revered as a wonder of the Western world practically ever since, little is known about the Book of Kells and its splendidly illustrated Gospels in Latin. But the book may be about to surrender a few of its many secrets.

headline: A Divide That Begins in Little League
text: As the nation continues to celebrate the desegregation of Major League Baseball in 1947, the enduring question is why African-Americans have all but vanished from the baseball landscape.

headline: Giants Look to 2 Intriguing Pitchers
text: The San Francisco Giants will be in town on Tuesday night, and that means that Barry Bonds and his controversial pursuit of home run supremacy will take center stage at Shea Stadium. But anyone spending too much time jeering him in left field may miss the Giants’ two intriguing pitching attractions, Tim Lincecum and Barry Zito, who are scheduled to start the first two games of this series with the Mets.

headline: Sometimes It’s Over Even When It Ain’t
text: Without realizing it, about half a century ago Yogi Berra, baseball’s old philosopher, described the perilous situation of these Yankees. Asked about the shadows in left field at Yankee Stadium when all World Series games were played in the afternoon, he shrugged.

headline: How Baseball Moved Its 24-Hour Channel Into Scoring Position
text: Major League Baseball plotted for two decades to create a 24-hour channel, and last month it got its way after months of tortuous negotiations with DirecTV and cable operators.

headline: The Educated Giant
text: Taishan, China

headline: At BET, Fighting the Rerun
text: Last week, executives from Black Entertainment Television walked through the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, laying out the plans for the annual BET Music Awards on June 26. The broadcast has become the highest-rated award show on cable, topping the MTV Music Awards, ESPN’s ESPY Awards and the Nickelodeon Kids’ Choice Awards.

headline: Honoring an Avant-Garde Eminence of the Saxophone
text: “I didn’t expect to blossom like I did,” the saxophonist Sam Rivers said at the Miller Theater on Friday, reflecting on his 60-year career. His quip sent ripples of appreciative laughter through the crowd, which was generously stocked with musicians, and generally skewed toward extreme jazz erudition.

headline: Sosa Rebounds as Mets Sweep Marlins
text: MIAMI, May 27 — They know that last season was last season, and this year is this year, but the Mets find it instructive to recall their electric start in 2006 and compare it with how things stand after the first 49 games of 2007.

headline: Plunge in CD Sales Shakes Up Big Labels
text: “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band,” the Beatles album often cited as the greatest pop recording in music history, received a thoroughly modern 40th-anniversary salute last week when singers on “American Idol” belted out their own versions of its songs live on the show’s season finale.

headline: Demme’s Tales of Ordinary Heroes in New Orleans
text: Victims and despair were what Jonathan Demme expected to find when he headed to New Orleans with his camera. Instead, he said, he discovered tough-minded heroes, who became the stars of his unadorned film “Right to Return: New Home Movies from the Lower Ninth Ward.” Beginning tonight Tavis Smiley will turn over the entire week of his PBS program, “The Tavis Smiley Show,” to broadcast parts of the film.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page headline on Saturday about concepts being developed by the Bush administration to reduce United States combat forces in Iraq by as much as half next year referred imprecisely to the overall effect on troop levels. As the story indicated, removing half of the 20 combat brigades now in Iraq by the end of 2008, one of the ideas under consideration, would cut the total number of troops there by about one-third, from 146,000 to roughly 100,000, not by 50 percent. That is because many of the troops that would remain in Iraq are in training or support units, not in combat forces.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Thursday about an announcement by Silverio A. Vega, the Cuban-born mayor of West New York, N.J., that the annual Cuban Parade of New Jersey would not be allowed to pass through his town gave the incorrect date in some copies for Mr. Vega’s news conference. It was last Monday, not Wednesday.

headline: Charles Nelson Reilly, Tony-Winning Comic Actor, Dies at 76
text: Charles Nelson Reilly, who acted and directed on Broadway but came to be best known for his campy television appearances on talk shows and “Match Game,” died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 76 and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: NBC Said to Be in Talks to Remove Program Chief
text: NBC Universal is in talks to sever its ties with Kevin Reilly, the president of its entertainment division and the network’s chief programmer, just three months after extending his contract for three years, several executives informed of the discussions said yesterday.

headline: Dance, Gallerina, Dance: A Gimlet-Eyed Look Through an Art World Keyhole
text: The heroine of Danielle Ganek’s captivatingly titled novel “Lulu Meets God and Doubts Him” is a gallerina. That is, she works at a Chelsea art gallery as part of the décor. The rest of the setting includes a concrete desk, a stainless-steel slab used as a counter, one calla lily in a vase and a white leather guest book where visitors can leave their addresses so the gallery can send them helpful bulletins. In a friendlier art world perhaps the gallery would.

headline: Manhattan: Man Fatally Shot
text: A 27-year-old man was shot in the back and killed early yesterday in an East Harlem apartment, the police said. The man, identified as Delvon Hairston, of 2370 Second Avenue, was shot at about 12:20 a.m. in an apartment at 2390 Second Avenue, the police said. He was taken to North General Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Investigators were seeking three suspects yesterday, the police said.

headline: Centereach: Mother Charged With Snorting Heroin Near Her Son
text: A woman was arrested at a Wal-Mart store on Saturday after she was caught snorting heroin while pushing her 3-year-old son in a shopping cart, the Suffolk County police said. The woman, Stacy Roe, 35, of Farmingville, was arrested and charged with endangering the welfare of a child and criminal possession of a controlled substance. She was seen on surveillance video snorting a substance through a straw while pushing the cart inside the store at 6:10 p.m., the police said. When the police confronted her, she admitted she had just snorted heroin and said she had a bag of the substance in her wallet, the police said. The woman told officers she was shopping for a toy train for her son, the police said. The child was removed and placed in the custody of his father, and the case was referred to Child Protective Services, the police said. Ms. Roe was ordered to be in court on July 17.

headline: Northwestern Keeps Its Hold on Title
text: PHILADELPHIA, May 27  After an unexpected start and unaccustomed frailty on defense, Northwestern recovered Sunday night to deliver a familiar result, winning its third consecutive N.C.A.A. championship in women’s lacrosse.

headline: In Cannes, a Romanian Takes Home the Fronds
text: CANNES, France, May 27 — The message from the Cannes Film Festival juries was clear: Romania rules.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on April 26 about the restricted activities of city councilmen chosen in municipal elections in Saudi Arabia two years ago attributed an erroneous distinction to those elections. While they were the first in which all men outside the military could vote (women are not allowed to vote), the elections were not the first ever held in Saudi Arabia. (A far more limited form of voting was introduced in Mecca in 1925, which lasted for roughly a decade. In later years, until the 1960s, some councilmen were elected in selected cities by small groups of voters.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message the day the article ran; this correction was delayed for research.

headline: Year After Scandal, a Sport Thrives
text: BALTIMORE, May 27 — Jim Jennings, the commissioner of the National Lacrosse League, remembers sitting in a meeting with a potential advertiser about a year ago.

headline: Memorial Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: 3 Afghan Employees of French Aid Group Freed by the Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 27  Three Afghan employees of a French aid organization, who had been held hostage for seven weeks by Taliban insurgents, were freed unharmed after local residents intervened, the governor of Nimruz Province, Ghulam Dastagir Azad, said Sunday.

headline: In Ruse, Vancouver Officer Poses as Reporter to Arrest Protester
text: David Cunningham, a prominent protester who heads the Anti-Poverty Committee in Vancouver, British Columbia, recently received a call from someone who said he was a reporter, Peter MacKay, from the free daily 24 Hours Vancouver.

headline: Fans of Canceled ‘Jericho’ Mobilize With a Very Literal Protest
text: Soon after CBS said this month that it had canceled the drama series “Jericho,” angry fans started sending individual bags of nuts to executives at the network’s offices in New York and Los Angeles as a protest.

headline: An Even Better Farm Bill
text: For years, reform-minded legislators have been trying to rid the country of a farm subsidy program that lavishes huge amounts of money on relatively few producers, compromises the environment, penalizes third-world farmers and fouls up trade negotiations. With the farm bill set to expire this year, the Bush administration has already proposed several excellent reforms. Now legislators in both houses are offering another approach that actually improves on the administration’s.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on May 15 about a study by ACT, the Iowa testing organization, on the effectiveness of college preparatory courses, misstated a finding of the report. In analyzing about 1.2 million high students who took the ACT college admissions test before graduating last June, the study found that 26 percent of those who took the core curriculum were college ready; it did not find that 26 percent of all students tested were college-ready.

headline: Wealthy Enclave Offers Windfall for Candidates
text: GREENWICH, Conn., May 25 — Senator John McCain made his pitch to this gilded shoreline suburb back in April. Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts came on May 7, followed one night later by former President Bill Clinton on behalf of his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Last weekend, it was back-to-back appearances by Senator Barack Obama, topped off on Sunday with a visit from Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor.

headline: Alone in a City’s AIDS Battle, Hoping for Backup
text: WASHINGTON, May 28 — The nation’s capital is the only city in the country barred by federal law from using local tax money to finance needle exchange programs. It is also the city with the fastest-growing number of new AIDS cases.

headline: Trying to Make Move for the Lead, Patrick Runs Out of Time
text: INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 — Danica Patrick, who caused a stir two years ago by becoming the first woman to lead the Indianapolis 500, did not lead a lap Sunday and finished eighth in the race for the second consecutive year. She was not pleased.

headline: What the History of Memorial Day Teaches About Honoring the War Dead
text: Memorial Day got its start after the Civil War, when freed slaves and abolitionists gathered in Charleston, S.C., to honor Union soldiers who gave their lives to battle slavery. The holiday was so closely associated with the Union side, and with the fight for emancipation, that Southern states quickly established their own rival Confederate Memorial Day.

headline: From Realm of Pure Dance to Enchanted Fairyland
text: What conjunction of the stars determined that Bach and Handel were both born in 1685, Verdi and Wagner in 1813, and George Balanchine and Frederick Ashton in 1904? Impossible to imagine Western classical music without the first pair, Romantic opera without the second, modern classical ballet without the third. Balanchine, working principally in New York from 1934, and Ashton, working mainly in London from 1926, achieved their finest works when moving in separate orbits, but their paths often crossed over the decades.

headline: Living on Iraq Time
text: York, Pa.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Little Older and a Bit Creakier, Skaters Boogie on in Central Park
text: With blasts of disco, tight, flashy costumes and acrobatic flourishes, the skate dancers took over a paved oval in Central Park as rebels. Now, 30 years later, they are part of its establishment, and some of the heavily padded knees are a bit creaky.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,432 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Saturday:

headline: Cost Put a Stroke Treatment Out of Reach, Then Technology Made It Possible
text: Doctors at Martha’s Vineyard Hospital, the only hospital on the small island off Massachusetts, knew only one drug had been shown to work for stroke, tPA. But, until they adopted a new telemedicine system for hospitals like theirs, they had not been giving it to the 25 or so stroke patients they cared for each year.

headline: Militant Hints at Resolution in Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 27 — As negotiations continued Sunday over the standoff between Lebanese troops and Fatah al Islam militants holed up in a Palestinian refugee camp in northern Lebanon, a spokesman for the militant group signaled that a compromise could be possible to ease the two-week-old siege.

headline: A Twosome Reminiscent of the Stockton-Malone Era
text: SALT LAKE CITY, May 27  Outside Energy Solutions Arena, a pair of towering bronze statues cast expansive shadows. Karl Malone, all chiseled muscle, seems to be driving toward the clouds. John Stockton, his gaze fixed in a state of eternal determination, is in midpass.

headline: Mr. Spitzer’s DNA Proposal
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is right to want to expand New York State’s use of DNA evidence to solve crimes and exonerate the innocent. But, disappointingly, his proposed plan includes an unrelated — and unworthy — new provision that would seriously undermine his declared goal of minimizing injustice.

headline: Facing Inquiry, Japanese Official Commits Suicide
text: TOKYO, May 28 — Japan’s agriculture minister, Toshikatsu Matsuoka, killed himself on Monday, just hours before he was to face parliamentary questioning about a political finance scandal, government officials said.

headline: Less Than 500 Is Just Fine With Franchitti
text: INDIANAPOLIS, May 27 — The actress Ashley Judd, her long hair matted by the third rain shower of a long day, ran barefoot down pit road Sunday night to greet her husband, Dario Franchitti, the lesser known of the celebrity couple.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page headline on Saturday about concepts being developed by the Bush administration to reduce United States combat forces in Iraq by as much as half next year referred imprecisely to the overall effect on troop levels. As the story indicated, removing half of the 20 combat brigades now in Iraq by the end of 2008, one of the ideas under consideration, would cut the total number of troops there by about one-third, from 146,000 to roughly 100,000, not by 50 percent. That is because many of the troops that would remain in Iraq are in training or support units, not in combat forces. (Go to Article)

headline: Roadside Bombings Kill 2 More G.I.’s in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, May 27 — Two more American soldiers have died from roadside bombs, the American military said Sunday, as American forces decided to run DNA tests on a body that could be that of one of the remaining two missing soldiers seized in an ambush on May 12 south of Baghdad.

headline: 3 Magazines Are Accused of Retouching Celebrity Photos to Excess
text: While the situation was certainly not as emotionally charged as when Time magazine darkened O. J. Simpson’s mug shot on its cover a decade ago, three magazines were defending themselves against accusations last week that they had doctored their covers — and one retouched celebrity cried foul.

headline: James Changes Everything for the Cavaliers
text: CLEVELAND, May 27  Drenched in sweat and his jaw clenched in pure resolve, LeBron James walked off the court without seeing or hearing anybody but himself.

headline: Seeking More Controls on Expanded DNA Database
text: ALBANY  Assembly Democrats are resisting Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s proposal to expand DNA collection to all misdemeanor convictions without taking more steps that they say will protect the wrongfully accused.

headline: Not to See the Fallen Is No Favor
text: On this Memorial Day, thousands of United States men and women are engaged in untold acts of bravery and drudgery on behalf of what our leaders have defined as vital American interests in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: New CDs
text: R. KELLY “Double Up” (Jive/Zomba)

headline: Scientists Explore Genetic Risk of Breast Cancer
text: In a long-delayed harvest from the human genome project, researchers say they have found six new sites of variation in the genome that increase the risk of breast cancer.

headline: Mears Becomes Fourth Hendrick Driver to Win
text: CONCORD, N.C., May 27 — Rick Mears won the Indy 500 four times in his career, and perhaps it was inevitable that his nephew Casey Mears would make it to victory lane on Memorial Day weekend someday, too.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Lindsay Lohan Arrested in Car Crash

headline: A Devil in the Details, but Not the Constitution
text: WASHINGTON, May 27  When people think, if they ever do, about a Supreme Court justice’s daily routine, many undoubtedly envision a life spent contemplating the great issues: due process, equal protection and other resonant constitutional concepts.

headline: Fixing the Alternative Tax
text: When lawmakers return from their Memorial Day recess, fixing the alternative minimum tax, once and for all, should be at the top of their agenda.

headline: Davydenko Takes First Round in French Open
text: PARIS, May 28 — Seconds after his match ended today, Nikolay Davydenko wrapped himself in a fuzzy blue towel and ran off the court as the rain began to pour, yet again, at the French Open.

headline: Indar Jit Rikhye, 86, U.N. Adviser and Peacekeeper Trainer, Is Dead
text: UNITED NATIONS, May 25 — Indar Jit Rikhye, a major general in the Indian Army who was a key military adviser to United Nations peacekeepers around the world and then founding president of a research institute devoted to training peacekeepers, died May 21 in Charlottesville, Va. He was 86.

headline: Trust and Betrayal
text: “In this place where valor sleeps, we are reminded why America has always gone to war reluctantly, because we know the costs of war.” That’s what President Bush said last year, in a Memorial Day ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary by The Associated Press on Wednesday about Ben Weisman, a songwriter, included erroneous information from a family member about his illnesses before his death. He suffered a stroke and had pneumonia; he did not have Alzheimer’s disease. The obituary also erroneously included a group among the performers for whom he wrote songs. He did not write for the Beatles.

headline: Silence Speaks Volumes at Intersection of Views on Iraq War
text: LEWES, Del. — No one talks, but a lot is said at the intersection of Savannah Road and Kings Highway.

headline: The Education Dept. on the Loan Scandal (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Rise of a Junior Senator From Ottawa
text: OTTAWA, May 25 — As he has moved through the playoffs and closer to the stage that traditionally magnifies the feats of N.H.L. goaltenders, Ray Emery has treated that tradition with a shrug and an amused smile.

headline: Bush Pays Tribute to Fallen U.S. Troops
text: ARLINGTON, Va., May 28 — President Bush used his traditional Memorial Day address at Arlington National Cemetery today to speak directly, in deeply personal terms, to the families of soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan, assuring them that Americans “will never forget the terrible loss you have suffered.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about an exhibition of work by Eva Rothschild, at 303 Gallery in Chelsea, misidentified the gallery that represents Liz Larner, a sculptor whose creations Ms. Rothschild’s works were said to resemble. Her principal dealers are the Tanya Bonakdar Gallery in New York and Regen Projects in Los Angeles  not 303 Gallery, which she left in 2004.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A brief report in the Circuits pages of Business Day on May 17 about a low-cost camcorder called the Flip Video referred incorrectly to its retail availability. Although CVS, Rite Aid and Wolf Camera are among the locations where video from the cameras can be processed into DVDs, those stores do not sell the cameras.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article last Monday about a further decline in India’s electricity supply, even as its economy has expanded, incorrectly compared the per-capita annual energy consumption between India and the United States. The typical Indian consumes about one-fifteenth as much energy per year as the typical American  not one-fifth.

headline: Officers and Counterprotesters Disrupt Gay Rights Rally in Russia
text: MOSCOW, May 27  Police officers and riot troops quashed a gay rights rally in Moscow on Sunday, detaining organizers as well as at least two European lawmakers, while members of Orthodox Christian and nationalist groups badgered the demonstrators with insults, eggs and fists.

headline: A Queen’s Announced Presence Helps Place Another Queen
text: In chess there are prodigies. Of the top 20 teenagers, 18 are grandmasters. In bridge we very rarely have a prodigy. This is partly because our game is not a pure computational exercise; there are hidden cards. There is also a psychological side to the game. You must cooperate well with your partner, and you must be able to read your opponents.

headline: Israeli Labor Party Voting to Choose New Leader
text: JERUSALEM, May 28 — Initial results did not point to a clear victor in the race for the leadership of the Israeli Labor Party on Monday, but they left no doubt that Defense Minister Amir Peretz would lose the party chairmanship.

headline: China Disputes Defense Assessment
text: BEIJING, May 27  A Pentagon report that voiced concerns about China’s buildup of land- and sea-based ballistic missiles “misleads international opinion” and tries to spread false fears of a China threat, Chinese state news media said Sunday.

headline: WABC-TV Is Knocked Off Air After Fire at Lincoln Center Studios
text: WABC-TV was knocked off the air just before its 11 p.m. newscast last night after a spotlight exploded and caused a fire at its Lincoln Center headquarters, according to a station official.

headline: Biodiesel Makers See Opportunity as New York Seeks Greener Future
text: On an industrial strip of land hemming Newtown Creek, pipelines snake low to the ground, connecting an array of giant beige oil tanks.

headline: No Tax Increase in Budget (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Allies Turn Foe, Disillusion Rises in Some G.I.’s
text: BAGHDAD — Staff Sgt. David Safstrom does not regret his previous tours in Iraq, not even a difficult second stint when two comrades were killed while trying to capture insurgents.

headline: Vintage Mussina Is Not Enough to Avoid Sweep
text: The Yankees were getting a vintage performance from Mike Mussina, a big afternoon from an .037 hitter and were leading a first-place team in the Los Angeles Angels. During a season in which little has gone right, nothing was going wrong on a beautiful late spring afternoon at Yankee Stadium. Perhaps that was more than anybody had a right to expect.

headline: Libya Court Clears 6 of Slander in H.I.V. Case
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria, May 27  A Libyan court on Sunday acquitted five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor on charges of slander.

headline: Makers of Comedy Film Aim for Religious Audience
text: More important than the lesson Mel Gibson taught Hollywood about drunken anti-Semitic tirades (that they’re bad for publicity) is the one gleaned from his 2004 film “The Passion of the Christ.” The movie demonstrated just how many evangelical moviegoers there are and how much money can be made from them.

headline: Brooklyn: Man Shot Dead in Street
text: A 22-year-old man was fatally shot yesterday afternoon on a street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. The victim, Christopher Darns, of Brooklyn, was shot at 3:10 p.m. in front of 866 Madison Street, the police said. There have been no arrests, the police said.

headline: In Rare Talks, U.S. and Iran Discuss Iraq
text: BAGHDAD, May 28 — The United States and Iran held rare, face-to-face talks in Baghdad on Monday, adhering to an agenda that focused strictly on the war in Iraq and on ways the two bitter adversaries could help to improve conditions here.

headline: Counting TV Time for Sponsor Logos in Sports Contests
text: VALENCIA, Spain, May 24 — When the sleek yacht of the Luna Rossa team sailed away with a victory in the America’s Cup semifinals on a sunny weekend in the Mediterranean, there were two vital results.

headline: With Tuition Waiver, Maine Invests in Its ‘First People’
text: ORONO, Me.  By the time she was 32, Karen Carrion was living in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., working for a concert promoter and looking for a change. She had never attended college and considered it out of the question because of the cost.

headline: Robbins and His Corps, Stripped of Storytelling
text: “Make more,” Balanchine said (or so the story goes) when Jerome Robbins showed him an unfinished version of “Dances at a Gathering.” “Make it like peanuts. Keep eating.” (Another version of this story, starring popcorn, is also told.) In its finished form, the 1969 “Dances at a Gathering” is an hour long, and on a good day that’s still too few peanuts.

headline: Steps Toward Reducing Risk
text: Dr. Walter J. Koroshetz, deputy director of the National Institute on Neurological Disorders and Stroke, lists five things everyone should know about strokes:

headline: The Abortion Issue: Who Decides? (5 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Feeding Lawyers’ Souls, but Not Their Wallets
text: Last month, the federal appeals court in New York gave the civil rights bar a collective heart attack.

headline: Manhasset: Body of Man Found
text: The body of an unidentified man was found face down in a wooded area at 1:15 a.m. yesterday, the Nassau County police said. The police, responding to a 911 call, found the man, believed to be about 27, about 50 feet from Community Drive on the east side. The case was being investigated and an autopsy was to be performed to determine the cause of death, the police said.

headline: OMG! Cute Boys, Kissing Tips and Lots of Pics, as Magazines Find a Niche
text: Above the neon-orange lettering that promotes the issue’s “love blogs” and other content, Zac, Corbin and Miley smile winningly on the cover for the May/June issue of J-14.

headline: Millions of Addresses and Thousands of Sites, All Leading to One
text: THINK you have a good handle on the Internet economy? Try this one.

headline: Mexican Police Hold Suspect in Killing
text: MEXICO CITY, May 27 — The police in the northern state of Nuevo León have detained a suspect in the killing of an organizer for an American union that represents Mexican guest workers in the United States. But the union said Sunday that it did not believe the police account of the killing.

headline: Olmert Warns Hamas, as Rocket Kills Civilian
text: JERUSALEM, May 27 — An Israeli man died from a Qassam rocket launched from Gaza on Sunday, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert vowed to continue Israel’s military assault on Hamas as an effort to stop the rocket fire, warning that “no one involved in terror is immune.”

headline: China Seeks Extradition Pacts in Spite of Death Penalty
text: BEIJING, May 28 — China has called on Western countries to put aside fears about its death penalty and sign extradition treaties, state media reported today, as the Communist Party seeks the return of suspected corrupt officials and criminals who have fled overseas.

headline: Outbreak of Eye Infections Puzzles Officials
text: Health officials and eye doctors are puzzled by an outbreak of a rare but potentially blinding eye infection that led the manufacturer of a contact lens cleaning solution to withdraw one of its products this weekend.

headline: Dear Diary
text: DEAR Diary:

headline: Tableau of History: Generations Link Arms at Ballet Theater Reunion
text: It was a day of squealed greetings and murmured conversations about the past, a day for the exchange of career news and family photographs. Curtains went up late at two performances. The problem was that few of the 300 or so former American Ballet Theater dancers who converged on New York City from around the country for an alumni reunion on Saturday could tear themselves away from one another to take their seats.

headline: Judging a Diet Book’s User by Its Bright Pink Cover
text: After Jay Jacobs shed 30 pounds with the help of “The Beck Diet Solution” by Judith S. Beck, he decided to shed something else: the book’s bright pink cover.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on May 18 about a reported robbery attempt at the country estate in South Kent, Conn., owned by the socialite Anne Bass, misstated the year that she arranged for a herd of 130 Randall cattle to live on her land. It was 2004, not 2005. The article also referred imprecisely to the herd’s ownership. Of the roughly 180 cattle that are now in the herd, Mrs. Bass owns about 40  not the entire herd  according to the cattle manager, Cynthia Creech, who owns the rest.

headline: An Aggressive Telecom Investor Looks East and West for Quarry
text: PARIS, May 27 — Though far from a household name in telecommunications, Altimo likes to compare its aspirations to Vodafone, the world’s largest cellphone network, which owns pieces of phone companies from the East Coast to England to India.

headline: Lost Chances for Survival, Before and After Stroke
text: Dr. Diana Fite, a 53-year-old emergency medicine specialist in Houston, knew her blood pressure readings had been dangerously high for five years. But she convinced herself that those measurements, about 200 over 120, did not reflect her actual blood pressure. Anyway, she was too young to take medication. She would worry about her blood pressure when she got older.

headline: Williams Struggles, but Survives First Round
text: PARIS, May 27 — At the start of her first-round match at the French Open, Serena Williams’s mood was as gloomy as the gray sky above.

headline: A Pistons Star Is Finding His Motivation
text: CLEVELAND, May 27 — This time, the absence of a guarantee coming out of Rasheed Wallace’s mouth may just be more telling.

headline: Hockey in the Garden: A New York State of Ice (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: 27 Years After It Was Awarded, a Pulitzer Prize Is Acknowledged
text: Often the writing and photography that win Pulitzer Prizes require heroic efforts on the part of journalists. For one recipient this year, the process of receiving the award also took an enormous effort.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on April 25 about Warren E. Avis, founder of the chain of car-rental agencies, misstated the year of an interview in which Mr. Avis discussed the difficulties he faced over his idea to open such agencies at airports. It was 1985, not 1987. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on May 20.

headline: A Well-Chronicled Coming-of-Age Reaches the Orchestra Phase
text: No songwriter gleans more from his growing pains than Conor Oberst, the leader of Bright Eyes. Since he was a teenager, he has been recording richly self-conscious songs that blurt out his uncertainties and frazzled ideals, his misfires and his triumphs, his mistakes and his recoveries, his confessions and his hallucinatory tangents. His music regularly touches down in folk-rock, but doesn’t feel compelled to stay there.

headline: Iraq Ministry Fires Worker for Illegal Eviction Attempt
text: The Iraqi Finance Ministry said yesterday that it had fired a ministry employee who tried in March to evict a Sunni Arab widow and her family from their home in a mostly Shiite neighborhood of western Baghdad. The woman refused to move and was shot dead the day after being visited by two Shiite men identifying themselves as Finance Ministry guards.

headline: 2004 Crash in Afghanistan Highlights Gaps in U.S. Control Over Flights
text: WASHINGTON, May 27  Carrying three soldiers and two pallets of mortar shells through the Hindu Kush mountains of Afghanistan, the twin-engine turboprop was on a military mission.

headline: Venezuela Police Repel Protests Over TV Network’s Closing
text: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 27 — With little more than an hour to go late Sunday until this country’s oldest television network was to be taken off the air after 53 years of broadcasting, the police dispersed thousands of protesters by firing tear gas into demonstrations against the measure.

headline: A Plan to Sail Between Old and New Worlds, as Adventurers Did, in Theory
text: JERSEY CITY, May 25 — Dominique Görlitz is certain that 14,000 years ago Old World adventurers crossed the Atlantic regularly.

headline: Conservatives and Socialists Split Local Elections in Spain
text: MADRID, May 27  Spain’s ruling Socialists and their conservative opposition won virtually equal support in local elections on Sunday, setting the stage for a fierce contest for next year’s general election.

headline: Rows of New Markers, and Untold Sacrifice by Civil War Soldiers
text: Conrad Joachim, a German immigrant, marched off to war from his home on Greenwich Street in Manhattan on May 13, 1862, enlisting as an assistant surgeon in the 15th New York Heavy Artillery. Charles Joachim, whom historians believe to be his son, had already joined the same unit.

headline: Studio Fire Knocks WABC-TV Off Air
text: WABC-TV was knocked off the air just before its 11 p.m. newscast last night after a spotlight exploded and caused a fire at its Lincoln Center headquarters, according to a station official.

headline: Gesture and Light
text: Images from "Georges Rouault" at Mitchell-Innes & Nash.

headline: Count ’em… 460 Hong Kong handover events
text: Hyperactive, hyper-organized Hong Kong has planned a whopping 460 events to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the handover from British to Chinese rule on July 1, 1997.

headline: Munitions in Mozambique
text: Some residents fear that a munitions depot in Maputo, Mozambique, will explode due to government neglect.

headline: A Day of Remembrance
text: On this day, to fallen soldiers of all wars with chronicles of fallout from the war in Iraq, the everpresent reminder that Memorial Day transcends generations.

headline: A (nearly) free lunch with perfect ambience
text: Rome of course has its share of decent lunch places, but it’s hard to sit down in a restaurant here for under 20 Euro and there’s little appealing outdoor dining, despite this city’s extraordinary weather. So here is my suggestion from this gorgeous spring day: There are myriad bread bakeries offering cheap delicious sandwiches (panini) consisting of meats, local cheeses, fresh vegetables, and more — all on warm fresh-baked Italian flat breads. Have a picnic!

headline: FIA gives a bit of attention to McLaren
text: So the FIA has decided to investigate this story about McLaren giving team orders to “fix” the race results in Monaco. I would laugh this off were it not for the fact that I have not yet seen the FIA do anything to help McLaren. So I worry that the FIA might do something that resembles fixing the championship – if McLaren were to be disqualified, Ferrari would win…65 seconds behind. On the other hand, knowing that the FIA could never do such a thing, I ultimately do not worry about it.

headline: Pregame in Toronto
text: It’s four hours or so before game time, and many of the Yankees are out on the field at Rogers Center, taking early batting practice, as they do before the first game of every road series. No sign of Joe Torre, but Reggie Jackson is behind the batting cage. Mariano Rivera is horsing around in center field, where he’d probably be a heck of a player.

headline: Candidates Matches: Three Decisive Games, Including One Upset
text: Three of the eight games on Day 2 of the candidates matches ended decisively, with one of the favorites, Judit Polgar of Hungary, losing to fall behind 0.5 to 1.5. The matches are taking place in Elista, Kalmykia, to select four qualifiers for a world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

headline: The Rudolph Giuliani Temperament
text: Michael Powell, who started covering Rudolph Giuliani 15 years ago, talks about how the candidate has changed, or not, as he runs for president.

headline: Kazakhstan Issues Warrant for President’s Son-in-Law
text: MOSCOW, May 28  The authorities in Kazakhstan announced Monday that they had issued an international arrest warrant for Rakhat Aliyev, the son-in-law of President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev and one of the Central Asian oil state’s most powerful and loathed men.

headline: The Redolence of Spring? Call It Essence of Nitrogen
text: Right now, my kitchen is suffused with that vivid fragrance familiar to suburban homeowners everywhere, and to any apartment dwellers who have ever played inadvertent hosts to rodents — the smell of an animal corpse busily decomposing somewhere out of reach.

headline: Effective, Yes, but Is It Safe? A Drug’s Risks
text: People with diabetes have too much sugar in their blood, so a drug that lowers blood sugar ought to be a good treatment, right?

headline: Chief Justice of Pakistan Says Musharraf Pressed Him to resign
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 29 — Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, the suspended chief justice of Pakistan, said today in a signed affidavit to the Supreme Court that on March 9, he was detained all afternoon against his will at the Army House in Rawalpindi, and was pressed to resign by the president of Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, and by four senior military and intelligence chiefs, most of them in uniform.

headline: Zoellick to Be Named to Lead World Bank
text: WASHINGTON, May 29 — Robert B. Zoellick, a former deputy secretary of state and top trade envoy under President Bush, is expected to be named president of the World Bank, administration officials and others said today.

headline: A Rival Bidder for ABN Amro Is on the Spot
text: LONDON, May 28  The takeover battle for the Dutch bank ABN Amro may gain momentum on Tuesday when a bidding consortium led by the Royal Bank of Scotland is expected to give some insight as to whether it will go ahead with a rival offer.

headline: Avaya Is Said to Be Exploring a Sale of All or Some of Itself
text: The telecommunications company Avaya is in negotiations to sell a part or all of itself, in what may be the latest round of deal making in its industry, executives briefed on the negotiations said last night.

headline: Rise in Violence in North Shows Afghanistan’s Fragility
text: KABUL, Afghanistan, May 28 — Angry supporters of Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, the ethnic Uzbek strongman, clashed with the police in the northern town of Shiberghan on Monday, leaving at least seven people dead and 34 wounded, officials said. The government sent army units to the area, anticipating further unrest.

headline: Telepresence TV
text: High-end videoconferencing — the magical ability to be two places at once — has had a bumpy past, plagued by jerky gestures, out-of-sync lips and sound and cumbersome equipment. Few executives liked what they saw, including unflattering pictures of themselves, and most thought the business tool was not worth the price.

headline: Making Sense of a Mountain of Evidence
text: Federal authorities have investigated Barry Bonds on the suspicion that he perjured himself and laundered money, but Bonds has not been convicted of either act or even been indicted. Baseball officials suspect that Bonds used steroids, but he has never tested positive.

headline: Bush Takes On Opponents of Immigration Deal
text: GLYNCO, Ga., May 29 — President Bush today accused opponents of his proposed immigration measure of fear-mongering to defeat it in Congress, and took on his own conservative political base as he did so.

headline: Car Crashes Into a Restaurant, Injuring Six
text: An out-of-control car crashed through the front window of a Popeyes restaurant in Hamilton Heights yesterday, injuring four customers, shattering glass and smashing benches and tables. The two people in the car were also hurt, but none of the injuries were serious, the police said.

headline: Mets’ Lineup Is Preparing for Mastery and Mystery
text: The San Francisco Giants are in town tonight, which means that Barry Bonds and his pursuit of home run supremacy will take center stage at Shea Stadium. But anyone spending too much time jeering him in left field may miss the Giants’ two intriguing pitching attractions, Tim Lincecum and Barry Zito, who are scheduled to start the first two games of the series.

headline: China Sentences Former Drug Regulator to Death
text: SHANGHAI, May 29  The former director of China’s top food and drug safety agency was sentenced to death on Tuesday after pleading guilty to corruption and accepting bribes, the state-controlled news media said.

headline: Moral Rights or the Outraged Heir: Real-Life Drama at House of Molière
text: PARIS, May 28 — Since Bernard-Marie Koltès died in 1989 at 41, his reputation as a playwright has continued to grow. In February, for the first time, one of his plays, “Le Retour au Désert,” entered the repertory of the Comédie-Française, the historic Paris theater popularly known as the House of Molière.

headline: Roddick and Blake Crash Out of French Open
text: PARIS, May 29 — To figure out how Andy Roddick was faring in his first-round match at the French Open today, spectators did not have to see the score.

headline: Words Fail Yankees as Skid Reaches 4 Games
text: TORONTO, May 28 — The season has defied all the Yankees’ predictions. They were supposed to hit, and they cannot. They were supposed to develop pitchers in the minors, and they are force-feeding them in the majors.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary and picture caption on May 17 about Yolanda King, an actor and the daughter of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., misstated the name of a surviving brother. He is Martin Luther King III, not II.

headline: In India, Grandma Cooks, They Deliver
text: MUMBAI, India — Gaurav Bamania, a hedge fund analyst who works in one of the many downtown office towers that now dominate the skyline of India’s financial capital, could easily eat lunch at one of the city’s better restaurants. Instead, Mr. Bamania, 26, follows a practice dating back over a century to the early years of British rule: he has a hot meal, lovingly cooked at home by his grandmother, and delivered to his desk every workday.

headline: Hillary’s War
text: On a Thursday afternoon in early May, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton rose before a nearly empty Senate chamber and proposed that Congress undo one of the most significant acts in its recent history: the authorization of the Iraq war. In remarks lasting just two minutes, she spoke bluntly: The “authorization to use force has run its course, and it is time to reverse the failed policies of President Bush and to end this war as soon as possible.” She added, “If the president will not bring himself to accept reality, it is time for Congress to bring reality to him.”

headline: Twenty Questions Even a Caveman Can Ask
text: IT is time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing, the media and popular culture.

headline: Not a Noise You Want to Hear at 18,000 Feet
text: LIKE most business travelers who fly a lot, Wade Cornett is accustomed to routine changes in sounds on an airplane — the whine of engines on a climb, the whump of the landing gear, the rattle of the airframe in turbulence.

headline: From Donald Trump to Eliot Spitzer: Still Battling Over a Wasteful Law
text: For churning up long-lost files, dusty tchotchkes and fading personal memories, nothing beats packing up your belongings for a big move.

headline: Small Incidents Are Creating a Big Problem With the N.Y.P.D.
text: These are small incidents, but they are accumulating by the tens of thousands, and someday New Yorkers are going to be shocked by the power of the anger that these seemingly insignificant incidents have generated.

headline: Lens Solution Recall Is Blow to Company’s Stock
text: Shares of Advanced Medical Optics plunged in trading today as investors reacted to a recall of one of the company’s best-selling contact lens cleaning solutions over health concerns.

headline: An Implant for the Heart Gets a Jolt From Above
text: DENVER — Implanted stimulators halt thousands of cardiac arrests annually by delivering sharp jolts of electricity to weakened hearts that have begun beating dangerously rapidly or erratically.

headline: Thinning of Veterans’ Ranks Leaves Breach in Collective Memory
text: On yet another Memorial Day in New York, more old soldiers faded away.

headline: Oh, Gosh. First, I’d Like to Thank All the Actual People.
text: LAS VEGAS, May 28 — Johnny Depp and Tina Turner meandered slowly through the crowded casino, their progress hindered not by screaming fans or paparazzi but by a pair of Marilyn Monroes up ahead offering each other flamboyant hellos.

headline: With Billups Misfiring, the Pistons Start to See Signs of a Slowdown
text: CLEVELAND, May 28  Chauncey Billups says he has never been in a rut like this, one that has jolted him into uncharacteristic turnovers and strangely passive play.

headline: Corrections
text: A chart last Tuesday in Science Times, with the Personal Health column about jet lag, omitted the recommended dose of melatonin for changing the body clock. The dose should be a half-milligram or less — preferably 300 micrograms — except at bedtime, when 3 milligrams is acceptable. A corrected chart is online. (Go to Article)

headline: For Babies and Language, Seeing Is Believing, Even Without Hearing
text: As any new parent will attest, babies are amazing. And to the list of remarkable things infants can do, here’s a new one: they can distinguish one language from another just by the sight of a talking face, not sound.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about a blackout at WABC-TV in New York on Sunday night because of a fire at its Lincoln Center headquarters misspelled the surname of the news director. He is Kenny Plotnik, not Plotnick.

headline: Fears Linger in Mozambique Over Unexploded Weapons
text: MAPUTO, Mozambique — One recent steamy morning, in a field on the outskirts of this capital, seven soldiers under the watchful eye of a military engineer took turns digging a hole deep enough to stand in. A suspicious depression in the sand suggested that a rocket or artillery shell might be buried there.

headline: Bryant’s Bid for West Seems to Be Long Shot
text: In the summer of 1996, Jerry West orchestrated a series of moves that brought Kobe Bryant and Shaquille O’Neal to Los Angeles and put the Lakers on the path to three consecutive N.B.A. championships. Eleven years later, Bryant is trying to return the favor, hoping to recapture the Lakers’ lost magic.

text: Men who drink a lot of coffee may lower their risk of developing the painful inflammatory disease gout, researchers say.

headline: In Long Island Standoff, Ex-Convict Kills a Hostage and Then Himself
text: A drunken ex-convict killed a 59-year-old acquaintance by cutting her throat and sexually assaulted one of her grandchildren during a 14-hour standoff on Long Island that ended when he fatally shot himself yesterday afternoon, the police said.

headline: To Temper Image, Giuliani Trades Growl for Smile
text: ATLANTA — Oh, baby, here it comes. The gray-haired woman raises her hand and compliments His Honor for his Sept. 11 bravery. Then she asks him:

headline: Efficiency, Not Just Alternatives, Is Promoted as an Energy Saver
text: WATERBURY, Vt. — Green Mountain Coffee Roasters makes a lot of money selling individual servings of ground coffee in white cups that are churned out by the millions from a hissing, clanking production line here. But it recently found a way to generate even greater profits from the operation that will require only a modest investment.

headline: Opposites Who Attack Share Power in Albany
text: ALBANY, May 25 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer sees the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, as an old-school politician who treats the Senate like his personal kingdom.

headline: Players Not Yet Mature, Sounding Old and Young
text: It is always a question whether the talented young should be turned into little adults, wise before their time, or allowed to dawdle a while and just be children. The New York Youth Symphony, whose members range in age from 12 to 22, sounded both old and young at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon. In the right music its strings sections are startlingly beautiful, with a sheen and trueness a lot of grown-up orchestras would envy. Brass and winds showed a simpler kind of enthusiasm and forwardness.

headline: 2 Flights Carried Man With Deadly TB
text: WASHINGTON, May 29 — Public health officials today urged the passengers and crew of two recent trans-Atlantic flights to get checked for tuberculosis, after learning that a man with an exceptionally deadly and drug-resistant form of the disease had flown on the planes.

headline: Make a Bad Bill Better
text: The great immigration struggle of 2007 has moved from the Senate chamber in Washington to the continent at large. With Congress taking the week off, it’s time for constituents to weigh in. You can be sure of this much: The debate will get louder before it gets better.

headline: British Library, You’ve Got Mail, and It’s Not Spam
text: In the collection of the British Library there are two Gutenberg Bibles, two copies of Magna Carta, five copies of Shakespeare’s First Folio and now something new: your e-mail messages.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on May 18 about a Tacoma, Wash., woman who lost her belongings because of a fraudulent advertisement on the Web site Craigslist misspelled her surname in one reference. She is Laurie Raye, not Ray.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 10 P.M. (CBS) FLASHPOINT: KIMBERLY DOZIER AND THE ARMY’S FOURTH I.D. — A STORY OF BRAVERY, RECOVERY AND LIVES FOREVER CHANGED The title just about says it all. A year ago today Ms. Dozier, a CBS News correspondent, was nearly killed by a roadside bomb in Baghdad after she and her crew left their armored vehicle to report a story about American soldiers working with Iraqi security forces. Her colleagues Paul Douglas, a cameraman, and James Brolan, a soundman, as well as Capt. James A. Funkhouser of the Army and his Iraqi translator, died. Ms. Dozier, above right, was given a 50-50 chance of survival; after 25 operations she returned to television two days ago on “CBS News Sunday Morning.” This hourlong special, with Katie Couric, above left, as anchor, follows Ms. Dozier as she reconnects with some of the people who were injured alongside her on that Memorial Day blast, and remembers the lives that were lost.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Friday about efforts by Chinese officials to convince skeptics in Washington that there are benefits to Chinese-American economic relations, misspelled the surname of a Chinese finance ministry official. He is Zhu Guangyao, not Xhu.

headline: Davydenko and Venus Williams Beat Opponents and Rain
text: PARIS, May 28  Seconds after his match ended Monday, Nikolay Davydenko of Russia wrapped himself in a fuzzy blue towel and ran off the court as the rain began to pour, yet again, at the French Open.

headline: Prognosis: Prolonged Use of Antibiotics After Lyme May Not Help
text: People who have had Lyme disease sometimes have symptoms long after the illness seems to have been cured. To ease their discomfort, some doctors prescribe antibiotics for months or even years.

headline: Seeing Frustration in Yanks, Torre Lends Some Perspective
text: TORONTO, May 28  Like all teams, the Yankees would rather not let people know when they hold team meetings. There is a reason, after all, they meet after reporters leave the clubhouse.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a film review on Wednesday about “9 Star Hotel” misspelled the name of the character who scavenges for garbage. He is Ahmad, not Ahmed.

headline: ‘Pirates’ Haul So Far Estimated at $401 Million
text: LOS ANGELES, May 28 — The Memorial Day weekend affirmed the muscle of the international movie market as “Pirates of the Caribbean: At World’s End,” the third installment of Disney’s blockbuster series, set new industry benchmarks with an aggressive release in more than 10,000 theaters in 104 countries.

headline: In Canada, Fretting Over Foreign Takeovers
text: OTTAWA, May 28  A recent series of acquisitions of Canadian corporations has prompted a growing public debate over foreign control.

headline: A Woman’s Lot in Kabul, Lower Than a House Cat’s
text: It’s not that hard to understand why Khaled Hosseini’s first novel, “The Kite Runner” (2003), became such a huge best seller, based largely on word of mouth and its popularity among book clubs and reading groups. The novel read like a kind of modern-day variation on Conrad’s “Lord Jim,” in which the hero spends his life atoning for an act of cowardice and betrayal committed in his youth. It not only gave readers an intimate look at Afghanistan and the difficulties of life there, but it also showed off its author’s accessible and very old-fashioned storytelling talents: his taste for melodramatic plotlines; sharply drawn, black-and-white characters; and elemental boldfaced emotions.

headline: Clemens Surges Toward the Majors
text: MOOSIC, Pa., May 28 — It may be too late for the Yankees, but help appears to be on the way. Roger Clemens is ready.

headline: The Lure of Seeing a Hushed City at Water Level
text: For years, a small, secretive group of people, most of them men, spent their off hours paddling just above the surface of the city’s dirty rivers in kayaks. They rowed to their own music, often alone, and few paid much attention.

headline: Genome Researchers Find New Indicators of Breast Cancer Risk
text: In a long-delayed harvest from the human genome project, researchers say they have found six new sites of variation in the genome that increase the risk of breast cancer.

headline: Lottery Numbers
After Build-A-Bear, Build-A-Toy-Car
text: Lucky for one entrepreneur, the founder of the stuff-and-outfit your own plush animal phenomenon known as Build-A-Bear Workshop never got far on her idea to pursue a build-a-car concept.

headline: Desperate Iraqi Refugees Turn to Sex Trade in Syria
text: MARABA, Syria — Back home in Iraq, Umm Hiba’s daughter was a devout schoolgirl, modest in her dress and serious about her studies. Hiba, who is now 16, wore the hijab, or Islamic head scarf, and rose early each day to say the dawn prayer before classes.

headline: Beneath the Speeding Cyclone, a Look Back in Time
text: Headless bodies paraded down Surf Avenue in Coney Island all afternoon Saturday, past the half-closed gate of the little shack under the Cyclone where Charles Denson was hanging banners and photos on the white walls.

headline: Text of President Bush’s Speech on Sudan
text: Here is the text of President Bush’s remarks this morning announcing harsher sanctions against Sudan, as released by his press office. Mr. Bush spoke in the Diplomatic Reception Room of the White House for about six minutes, beginning at 8:01 a.m. Eastern time.

headline: The Brain: Malleable, Capable, Vulnerable
text: In bookstores, the science aisle generally lies well away from the self-help section, with hard reality on one set of shelves and wishful thinking on the other. But Norman Doidge’s fascinating synopsis of the current revolution in neuroscience straddles this gap: the age-old distinction between the brain and the mind is crumbling fast as the power of positive thinking finally gains scientific credibility.

headline: Duke’s Comeback Season Ends Short of the Title
text: BALTIMORE, May 28 — His eyes red from crying and the eye black on his cheeks smudged from sweat and tears, the Duke senior Matt Danowski did his best to maintain his composure.

headline: Selig Cannot Look Away This Time
text: The sports journalist roots for drama, for the story to unfold in the most theatrical of settings. For the purposes of the ensuing discussion, that means for Barry Bonds to somehow make it to Milwaukee by June 18 within striking distance of Hank Aaron.

headline: Stuck in the Security Line? Try These Exercises
text: My assistant is the loneliest person on earth. I travel about four days a week. Last year alone, I logged 140,000 miles in the air, all within the continental United States.

headline: For the Tiniest Babies, the Closest Thing to a Cocoon
text: Kimberli Johnson’s baby was born much too soon, trading the serenity of the womb after 24 weeks of gestation for the chaotic world of a neonatal intensive care unit.

headline: Big Landlord Close to Deal for a REIT in New York
text: The real estate company that bought two prominent apartment complexes on Manhattan’s Lower East Side is trying to make another major acquisition in the New York market.

headline: Finding Some Calm After Living With ‘the Shakes’
text: As Sandy Kamen Wisniewski remembers, her hands always shook. She hid them in long sleeves and pockets and wrote only in block letters in school because at least that was readable. The tremor became much worse as she entered her teenage years, and if she was upset or under stress, it grew so bad she cringed with embarrassment and decided that it must all be psychological.

headline: Letters
text: The Variable Tales of Life

headline: Ducks Put Ottawa in Unfamiliar Spot: Behind in a Series
text: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 28 — When all the hybrids and convertibles rolled into the Honda Center parking lot Monday, they were confronted with a motor home draped in a gigantic Canadian flag.

headline: With Hurricanes in the Lab, They Can Blow the House Down
text: Over the years, many people have tried to simulate the winds of hurricanes and measure the effects.

headline: Obama Offers Health Care Plan
text: IOWA CITY, Iowa, May 29 — Senator Barack Obama proposed a major overhaul of the nation’s health care system today, aimed at covering the nearly 45 million uninsured Americans, reducing premium costs for everyone else, and breaking what he asserted was “the stranglehold” that the biggest drug and insurance companies have on the health care market.

headline: Forget Ethics, Remember Politics
text: The Bush administration’s never-ending push to turn federal agencies into favor-filled partisan clubhouses has just been confirmed in red-handed detail at the General Services Administration, the government’s main housekeeping agency. Investigators found that Lurita Doan, the Bush appointee running the agency, violated the Hatch Act, which forbids federal workers from politicking on the job.

headline: Change on Immigration Turns Senator Kyl Into Lightning Rod
text: WASHINGTON, May 25 — Angry calls poured into Senator Jon Kyl’s office this week by the thousands, expressing outrage beyond anything he said he had witnessed in his 20-year political career. The callers were inflamed by Mr. Kyl’s role in shaping the bipartisan immigration compromise announced May 17, which lawmakers continue to debate.

headline: Will Warming Lead to a Rise in Hurricanes?
text: When people worry about the effects of global warming, they worry more about hurricanes than anything else. In surveys, almost three-quarters of Americans say there will be more and stronger hurricanes in a warming world. By contrast, fewer than one-quarter worry about increased coastal flooding.

headline: At Risk: Where Smokers Congregate Outside Bars, a Cloud Hovers
text: Now that smokers have been pushed out of many bars and restaurants to mill about the door, is it time to send them packing altogether?

headline: Google Deal Said to Bring U.S. Scrutiny
text: The Federal Trade Commission has opened a preliminary antitrust investigation into Google’s planned $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising company DoubleClick, an industry executive briefed on the agency’s plans said yesterday.

headline: A Bridge Restores a Lifeline to a Battered Town
text: BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., May 24 — Sometimes a bridge is more than just a bridge. The new span across the copper-colored St. Louis Bay connects today’s diminished reality to memories of a more generous past, a hopeful link to the return of better days.

headline: Justices Limit Discrimination Suits Over Pay
text: WASHINGTON, May 29 — The Supreme Court made it harder today for many workers to sue their employers for discrimination in pay, insisting in a 5-to-4 decision on a tight timeframe to file such cases. Dissenters said the ruling ignored workplace realities.

headline: Neither Fire Nor Water Blocks ABC Early Morning Newscast
text: Hours after a fire knocked WABC-TV off the air Sunday night, sending camera crews and journalists fleeing the station’s Lincoln Square studios, the news crew pressed through the mess and produced what some called a miracle: a 5 a.m. newscast yesterday.

headline: Mother and Three Daughters Found Dead in Texas
text: A mother and three of her daughters were found dead today, hanging in a bedroom closet of a mobile home in Hudson Oak, Texas, about 25 miles west of Fort Worth, according to broadcast reports and Web news sites.

headline: With or Without a Petty, a Team Moves Ahead
text: CONCORD, N.C., May 28  Kyle Petty is long past the time in his Nascar career for celebrating top-five finishes or eyeing Nextel Cup championships. Petty will be 47 on Saturday, and in 29 years behind the wheel of a stock car he has been through all of that too many times.

headline: 5 British Civilians Abducted in Iraq
