text: BAGHDAD, May 29 — Gunmen wearing police commando uniforms abducted five British civilians from a Finance Ministry complex on Tuesday, British officials said, seizing a business consultant and his four bodyguards in an attack that revived questions about links between official security forces and criminal militias.

headline: Memo Pad
text: FEWER TRAVELING TO EUROPE Passenger traffic from the United States to Europe last year was just short of 13 million and the 2000 record of 13.1 million, said Donald N. Martin & Company, quoting new Commerce Department data. European destinations, however, are losing overall market share. In 2006, visits from the United States to all foreign destinations (excluding Canada and Mexico) were up 12.2 percent over the year 2000, to 30.3 million. Last year, Europe’s share of total overseas traffic from the United States was 43.1 percent, compared with 48.9 percent in 2000.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music review on Thursday about the International Contemporary Ensemble, at P.S. 122, misstated the surname of the sound engineer. He is Ryan Streber, not Steber.

headline: Los Angeles Mayor Expected to Endorse Clinton
text: Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles, one of the most influential Democrats in California, will endorse Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York for president on Tuesday, according to two Democrats close to Mrs. Clinton’s presidential campaign.

headline: Barak in Israeli Labor Party Runoff
text: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, May 29 — After the final count of votes in Israel early today, no clear victor emerged for the leadership of the Labor Party, ensuring a second-round runoff between the former Labor prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the former Shin Bet security agency chief, Ami Ayalon.

headline: Russia Seeks Meeting With U.S. and Europe on Arms
text: MOSCOW, May 28  Russia called Monday for an emergency meeting with the United States and European countries to discuss the future of a conventional arms treaty in Europe, which President Vladimir V. Putin suspended last month and has threatened to withdraw from altogether.

headline: The Crime Rate Drops, and a City Credits Its Embrace of Surveillance Technology
text: EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 28 — Detective Robert Harris starts patrolling the raw streets of this worn-down city before he even leaves the parking lot at Police Headquarters.

headline: Hybrid Yellow Cabs: Don’t Forget the Disabled (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tod H. Mikuriya, 73, Dies; Backed Medical Marijuana
text: Dr. Tod H. Mikuriya, a California psychiatrist who was widely regarded as the grandfather of the medical marijuana movement in the United States, died on May 20 at his home in Berkeley. He was 73.

headline: U.S. and Iranian Officials Meet in Baghdad, but Talks Yield No Breakthroughs
text: BAGHDAD, May 28 — The United States and Iran held rare face-to-face talks in Baghdad on Monday, adhering to an agenda that focused strictly on the war in Iraq and on ways the two bitter adversaries could help improve conditions here.

headline: Lawmakers Push for Big Subsidies for Coal Process
text: WASHINGTON, May 28 — Even as Congressional leaders draft legislation to reduce greenhouse gases linked to global warming, a powerful roster of Democrats and Republicans is pushing to subsidize coal as the king of alternative fuels.

headline: An Assault in Iraq, a Stage Hit in London
text: LONDON, May 28 — Soon after Falluja became a symbol of the horrific violence and aggressive American tactics in Iraq, the theater director Jonathan Holmes listened to a group of British generals and journalists conduct a post-mortem on what had happened during the assault on that town.

headline: Bush Focuses on Soldiers’ Families in Memorial Day Speech
text: ARLINGTON, Va., May 28  President Bush used his traditional Memorial Day address at Arlington National Cemetery on Monday to speak directly, in deeply personal terms, to the families of soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan, assuring them that Americans “will never forget the terrible loss you have suffered.”

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: As the advertising awards season nears a peak, what follows is a special edition of Webdenda, recapping some of the recent winners of industry honors. The regular listing of people and accounts will return next week.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A caption on June 8, 1944, with a photograph of Army officers at mess on the Pacific front, misspelled the given name of the first officer seated at the left side of the table. He was Col. Girard B. Troland of New London, Conn. — not Gerand. The error was called to the attention of the editors by his grandson yesterday.

headline: Uranium Windfall Opens Choices for the Energy Dept.
text: WASHINGTON, May 28  The government accumulated vast quantities of uranium when prices were very low and no one else wanted it. But now that uranium prices have increased tenfold, the government has a precious commodity  and some tough questions  on its hands.

headline: Vatican City: Pope Restores Muslim Office
text: Pope Benedict XVI signaled a renewed emphasis on relations between Catholics and Muslims, a year after the Vatican seemed to sideline the issue by eliminating a separate office for dialogue with other faiths. The Vatican’s second-in-command, Secretary of State Tarcisio Bertone, told the newspaper La Stampa that the Pontifical Council for Interreligious Dialogue would again become a “separate department.” The council’s collapse, in March 2006, into another Vatican department came up against heavy criticism, especially after a speech by the pope a few months later that many Muslims charged was hostile to Islam.

headline: Bach’s Songs of Innocence and Experience, All in a Day
text: A year ago the Ukrainian pianist Konstantin Lifschitz made a powerful impression on a Town Hall audience with a complete traversal of Shostakovich’s 24 Preludes and Fugues, presented in afternoon and evening installments. How to top that feat? If you’re Mr. Lifschitz, you turn to Shostakovich’s inspiration, Bach’s “Well-Tempered Clavier,” as he did in a Sunday double-header that concluded the Free for All at Town Hall season.

headline: In China, a Stake in Blackstone Stirs Uncertainty
text: HONG KONG, May 28 — From Washington, the Chinese government’s purchase of a $3 billion nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group looks like a shrewd alliance with a politically connected American private equity fund loaded with financial expertise.

headline: Correction
text: A chart last Tuesday in Science Times, with the Personal Health column about jet lag, omitted the recommended dose of melatonin for changing the body clock. The dose should be a half-milligram or less — preferably 300 micrograms — except at bedtime, when 3 milligrams is acceptable.

headline: Special Operations: High Profile, but in Shadow
text: WASHINGTON, May 28 — Every night in Iraq, American Special Operations forces carry out as many as a dozen raids aimed at terrorist leaders allied with Al Qaeda, other insurgent fighters and militia targets. Their after-action reports are the first thing that Gen. David H. Petraeus, the senior American commander in Baghdad, reads the next day.

headline: Barak in Runoff to Lead Israeli Labor Party
text: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, May 29 — With 99 percent of the vote counted in Israel early Tuesday, no clear victor had emerged for the leadership of the Labor Party, ensuring a runoff between the former Labor prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the former Shin Bet security agency chief, Ami Ayalon.

headline: Getting to a Colombia Trade Deal
text: Free trade agreements with Peru and Panama now seem headed toward Congressional approval, after the Bush administration agreed to incorporate the basic labor standards long insisted upon by House Democrats. But a separate trade pact with Colombia rightly remains in legislative limbo over a much starker labor problem. Colombia leads the world in the killing of labor activists.

headline: Spurs Take Control as Jazz Starts to Lose It
text: SALT LAKE CITY, May 28 — Jerry Sloan’s final gestures in a losing effort Monday night were a pointed finger, an angry outburst and a swift march to the Utah Jazz locker room. He disappeared from the court 2 minutes 34 seconds before the final buzzer. The Jazz may soon be gone as well.

headline: Bush Tightens Penalties Against Sudan
text: WASHINGTON, May 29 — President Bush announced today that he is imposing stiff economic sanctions against Sudan and that he will press the United Nations for additional action to end the violence in Darfur.

headline: Alone in a City’s AIDS Battle, Hoping for Backup
text: WASHINGTON, May 28 — The nation’s capital is the only city in the country barred by federal law from using local tax money to finance needle exchange programs. It is also the city with the fastest-growing number of new AIDS cases.

headline: Romeo and Juliet Double-Date With Peter and the Nurse
text: Language as finely and as fiercely wrought as Shakespeare’s can withstand and even prosper while considerable violence is being done to it.

headline: Can Science Outwit Storms Like Katrina?
text: Stand atop any levee in the New Orleans area, and one question will offer itself, unbidden, to the mind: Is this pile of dirt tall enough to stand up to the next storm?

headline: China Urges Western Nations to Enter Extradition Treaties
text: BEIJING, May 28  China has called for Western countries to put aside their fears that its justice system is unfair and sign extradition treaties, state news media reported Monday, as the Communist Party seeks the return of suspected corrupt officials and criminals who have fled overseas.

headline: Flying Above the Traffic but Below Expectations
text: It has been the dream of New Yorkers for as long as there has been traffic on the Van Wyck: whizzing by helicopter from Manhattan to the airport to avoid being at the mercy of the city’s highways and clogged crosstown streets.

headline: A Labor Shortage? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Design That Solves Problems for the World’s Poor
text: “A billion customers in the world,” Dr. Paul Polak told a crowd of inventors recently, “are waiting for a $2 pair of eyeglasses, a $10 solar lantern and a $100 house.”

headline: Nature’s Tricks Help Moths Say ‘Don’t Eat Me’
text: The gaudy swirls of color on a butterfly’s wing, the rococo curlicues on its riotously dressed caterpillars, may seem to be delightful examples of nature’s artistry. But that is to miss nature’s point.

headline: Turning Grease to Fuel, and Despair to Hope
text: The back entrance to Barbounia, a restaurant on Park Avenue South, was open and Joseph Presswood dragged out a 55-gallon barrel of cooking oil. He plunged a vacuum hose into the grease as Edgar Rivera flipped on a switch. Thick brown liquid bubbled up through the hose to a container in a truck parked on 20th Street.

headline: Mayor Assails Bill in Congress on Immigration
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in unusually pointed and broad language, criticized Congress yesterday for parts of a comprehensive immigration bill now being debated in the Senate.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the addition of Mexican consulates in the United States misspelled the surname of the lead demographer for the Urban Institute, which conducted a study on illegal immigrants in Arkansas, where a new consulate has opened. He is Randy Capps, not Kapps.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article and picture caption on Wednesday about an International Criminal Court investigation of atrocities committed in the Central African Republic in 2002 and 2003 misspelled the surname of a general who seized power there in 2003 and remains president. He is François Bozize, not Boizize.

headline: Revisiting Rouault’s Stained-Glass World
text: You wouldn’t call it a full-fledged revival, but Georges Rouault is back in our sights. A few months ago some of his work was at the Metropolitan Museum in a show about his wily dealer, Ambroise Vollard. Now a couple of dozen pictures are at Mitchell-Innes & Nash.

headline: Spain Arrests 16 North Africans Accused of Recruiting Militants
text: MADRID, May 28 The police on Monday arrested 16 men, most of them Moroccans, suspected of recruiting volunteers to fight in Iraq and other countries and spreading propaganda calling for Islamic jihad.

headline: Danger: Playground Ahead
text: San Francisco

headline: Japan Cabinet Minister, Facing Scandal, Hangs Himself
text: TOKYO, May 28 — Japan’s agriculture minister, Toshikatsu Matsuoka, killed himself on Monday, just hours before he was to face parliamentary questioning about a political finance scandal, government officials said.

headline: Break a Confidence? Never. Well, Hardly Ever.
text: Anyone who has ever worked in a hospital can attest that doctors are purveyors of information: dry facts, clinical data, medical wisdom. When I was an intern, my hospital had a separate computer system for laboratory results, another for vital signs and nursing notes, and another for medical records. Clinical medicine, it seemed then, wasn’t about patient care as much as about data management.

headline: Recall Slows Company’s Plan to Grow in Eye Care
text: On Thursday, James V. Mazzo, the chief executive of Advanced Medical Optics, appeared to be a step closer to his goal of offering a full suite of products in the eye care market, as his company weighed a takeover bid for its significantly bigger rival Bausch & Lomb.

headline: Digital Fears Emerge After Data Siege in Estonia
text: TALLINN, Estonia, May 24 — When Estonian authorities began removing a bronze statue of a World War II-era Soviet soldier from a park in this bustling Baltic seaport last month, they expected violent street protests by Estonians of Russian descent.

headline: Hazards: Obese Employees More Likely to Be Injured on the Job
text: Companies often encourage their employees to keep their weight down as a matter of improving overall health and medical costs.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article on May 20 about a player from Israel who was selected by the Liberty in the W.N.B.A. draft in April misspelled her given name in some copies. As the article noted elsewhere, she is Shay Doron, not Shea.

headline: Andy Roddick Crashes Out of French Open
text: PARIS, May 29 — To figure out how Andy Roddick was faring in his first-round match of the French Open tennis tournament today, spectators did not have to see the score.

headline: Venezuela: Government Sets Sights on Globovisión and CNN
text: The government lashed out at Globovisión, the country’s only remaining television channel that is critical of its policies, accusing it of manipulating images to incite an assassination attempt against President Hugo Chávez. Willian Lara, the communications minister, called for an investigation of Globovisión, a 24-hour news channel, saying semioticians hired by the government had determined that video run by the channel of an assassination attempt in 1981 against Pope John Paul II could be interpreted as hostile to Mr. Chávez. Mr. Lara, who also denounced CNN’s coverage of Venezuela, made his claims as the police dispersed protests for a second day against a decision forcing the dissident network RCTV off the air on Sunday.

headline: James Beck, 77, Art Scholar and Critic of Conservation, Is Dead
text: James Beck, a Columbia University art historian who became well known as a critic of what he viewed as the ruinous conservation of world masterpieces, including Michelangelo’s Sistine Chapel ceiling, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with a sports article on May 20 about the graduation ceremony at Fordham University in which Mets Manager Willie Randolph received an honorary doctorate misspelled, in some copies, the given name and surname of the faculty member who sponsored Randolph for the degree and who was shown with him. She is Maryanne Kowaleski, not Maryann Howaleski.

headline: Bush to Tighten Fiscal Penalties Against Sudan
text: Ahead of a meeting of the Group of 8, President Bush will announce today that he is imposing stiff economic sanctions against Sudan — including penalties against two senior government officials and a rebel leader. He will also press the United Nations for additional actions to end the violence in Darfur, according to senior administration officials.

headline: What Kind of Team is Clemens Joining?
text: The good news for the Yankees is that Roger Clemens is probably through with the minor leagues. He went six innings for Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre, allowing two hits and no runs.

headline: On the North Korean Border
text: How crazy is the situation in North Korea? North Koreans are escaping to China in search of freedom.

headline: UK house price growth slows
text: House price growth in England appears to be slowing — at long last. A new survey from Hometrack, a leading property Web site, shows that house prices rose by 0.6 percent in May from April, a slight dip from the previous month’s growth of 0.7 percent. Annual house price inflation also declined from 6.8 percent to 6.7 percent in May.

headline: Differentiating Between Aneurysms and Stroke
text: What is the difference between an aneurysm and a hemorrhagic stroke? – Lynn Bechtold

headline: Seeing a Stroke Using M.R.I.s
text: Do strokes always show-up on M.R.I.s? – Janell Fowell

headline: Trying to Cut Cost Barriers
text: Would it be practical to cut diagnostic costs, and so expand the reach of effective care, by placing M.R.I. machines in more locations and sending the scans electronically to be read by neurologists at regional centers – – or overseas for that matter? – Irv Federer The cost of M.R.I. is not related to reading the scans. In fact, acute stroke damage on a high quality-diffusion M.R.I. is one of the easiest things for a doctor to pick out. The cost is in the M.R.I. machines themselves, with their multi-million dollar price tags, and upkeep and staffing costs. M.R.I. scanning also takes more time to perform and many people — such as those with pacemakers, claustrophobia, confusion with inability to hold still — can not undergo M.R.I. scans. – Dr. Koroshetz

headline: What’s Next for Stroke Treatment?
text: Are any new therapeutic advances on the immediate horizon that may improve the efficacy of acute stroke care with fewer side effects than tPA? – Paul Roberts

headline: Different Types of Aspirin
text: Are coated and uncoated aspirin equally effective at helping to prevent strokes? – Joel

headline: Can Bumps to the Head Cause Stroke Later On?
text: Can significant bumps to the head increase your chances later in life for a stroke or aneurysm? – Julie

headline: Is Dizziness a Warning Sign for Stroke?
text: Is mild to severe dizziness considered a possible warning sign for stroke? – John

headline: Diagnosing a Stroke
text: In the emergency room, how do doctors diagnose the type of stroke – ischemic or hemorraghic – and decide whether tPA would be useful? – John Niesyn

headline: Evaluating Your Local Hospital
text: How can one evaluate a local hospital ER’s stroke diagnosis and treatment standards and protocols? – Don Porter

headline: The Dangers of tPA
text: If tPA causes bleeding in the brains of 6 percent of people who get it, it does not seem like such a great drug. Would you ever give it to someone who seems to be having a relatively mild stroke? If so, why? – Donna

headline: Is Damage Cause by High Blood Pressure Reversible?
text: Can people reverse the possible damage caused from years of high blood pressure? That is, if they lose weight and control their blood pressure, will the buildup in their blood vessels decrease and return to normal? – Maureen Aldakheel

headline: The Risks Associated With Valve Replacement
text: Why does aortic valve replacement increase risk for stroke? – Mark Gordetsky

headline: Different Symptoms for Different Sexes?
text: What are some of the key differences of stroke symptoms, if any, between men and women? – Sandra Holtzman

headline: The Chances of a Second Stroke
text: Does having one stroke increase your chances of having a second? – Edward Yes. Overall, the highest risk factor for stroke is having had a previous stroke. This is why so much research has gone into reducing this risk. A stroke prevention plan between patient and their neurologist is essential in persons with a history of stroke. – Dr. Koroshetz

headline: The Role of Cholesterol in Causing Stroke
text: The article says high cholesterol is a risk factor. Could you detail what you mean by high cholesterol? High numbers overall or just high LDL? Or both? How high is too high? – Laura

headline: Latest property viewing gimmick: blindfolding
text: Landing in my inbox this week was an email from Hajar Ali, founder of UrbaneSpaces www.urbanespaces.com, a real estate firm in Singapore specializing in unique properties.

headline: What You Get for $300,000
Pattern Recognition
text: Evolution provides warning labels for moths in all kinds of patterns.

headline: New Contract for Broadway Musicians
text: Local 802, the union representing Broadway musicians, has agreed on a three-year contract with Broadway producers, a deal that was overwhelmingly approved by its members.

headline: Living the Athenian Lifestyle
text: Tour Nicholas Pisaris's loft-style apartment in the Psyrri section of Athens.

headline: Tishman Speyer Close to Deal for a REIT in New York
text: The real estate company that bought two prominent apartment complexes on Manhattan’s Lower East Side is trying to make another major acquisition in the New York market. The company, Tishman Speyer Properties, has joined with Lehman Brothers and was close to a deal Sunday night to buy Archstone-Smith Trust, the second-largest public apartment owner in terms of market cap and asset value, for more than $20 billion, The New York Times reported.

headline: JPMorgan Back on Board in Nasdaq’s Latest Exchange Deal
text: JPMorgan Chase has picked up its first advisory mandate from the Nasdaq Stock Market since standing down as financial adviser on the exchange’s hostile bid for the London Stock Exchange to avoid a conflict of interest.

headline: Calpers Backs Shareholder Rights Bill at UnitedHealth
text: In a showdown over shareholders’ rights to be decided Tuesday, the largest public pension fund in the nation is fighting to give investors the power to nominate directors at UnitedHealth Group, the biggest company entangled in the stock-option backdating scandal.

headline: Australia’s Healthscope Bids for Symbion
text: Healthscope, a private hospital operator in Australia, said Tuesday it had offered 2.86 billion Australian dollars ($2.34 billion) for Symbion Health, an acquisition that would make it the country’s largest pathology services provider.

headline: LDK Solar to Bow Amid Strong Investor Interest
text: LDK Solar, a Chinese producer of solar cells, tops a calendar of three initial public offerings for the shortened Memorial Day week. Joining the LDK Solar offering are two biopharmaceutical deals with the three expected to raise $537.4 million. Morgan Stanley is the book-runner for all three.

headline: 2004’s ‘Dewey Defeats Truman’
text: Correction Appended

headline: Is Ford Gearing Up to Sell Volvo?
text: After unloading its Aston Martin brand in March for $925 million, Ford Motor might be gearing up to sell another unit in its luxury division. According to reports, the money-losing car maker is planning to sell Volvo, possibly to BMW of Germany.

headline: Pole Vaulting to a New Crowd
text: Allison Stokke, the 18-year-old high school pole vaulter whose face launched thousands of searches in the past month, was introduced today to a whole new crowd: readers of The Washington Post. A story that chronicles how she struggled with the unwanted attention was played at the most prominent spot on the Web site — the top section of the home page — with a picture of her looking quite serious. Judging by her top ranking on the “most viewed articles” list, her appeal stretches beyond her almost completely male fan base.

headline: For Shareholders, a C.E.O.’s Political Largesse Proves Too Much
text: The generosity of the chief executive officer of InfoUSA toward the Clintons has proved so controversial within his firm, a major provider of database-processing services, that it has prompted a shareholder lawsuit complaining that hiring the former president was a “waste of corporate assets.”

headline: Former Citigroup Executives to Launch Asia Hedge Fund
text: Three recently departed executives of Citigroup‘s Global Special Situations Group have announced plans to open a Hong-Kong based hedge fund.

headline: In Canada, New Concern Over Foreign Takeovers
text: A recent series of acquisitions or potential acquisitions of Canadian corporations has prompted a growing public debate over foreign control. On Monday, in the latest sign that the takeovers had become a growing political issue, the opposition Liberal Party said that it wanted to freeze foreign takeovers of Canadian companies for three months to allow a review of investment laws.

headline: South Korea Examines Credit Suisse Transaction
text: South Korea’s financial regulators are looking into whether Credit Suisse violated disclosure rules in its purchase of shares in a small domestic building material company. Credit Suisse said in a public disclosure on Friday that it bought a 5.2 percent stake in Byucksan in mid-December for about 5 billion won ($5.4 million), but gradually sold a 4.3 percent stake for about 4.3 billion won.

headline: Apax Ditches V.C. Investments for Latest Fund
text: The British private equity firm Apax Partners will not earmark any of the new fund it is raising for venture capital investment, according to Electronicsweekly.com, instead funneling the cash it raised for such purposes into private equity buyouts.

headline: Brazil’s JBS Beefs Up with Swift Deal, Report Says
text: JBS, Latin America’s biggest meat producer, agreed to buy closely held Swift & Company for $1.4 billion, gaining control of the third-largest seller of beef and pork in the United States, from HM Capital Partners, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Europe Closes the I.P.O. Gap With the U.S.
text: For the first time since World War II, bankers in Europe are on the verge of earning more from initial public offerings than their counterparts in the United States, prompting Bloomberg News to state that “the lights may be going out on Wall Street.”

headline: Spitzer Said to Form Panel on Wall St. Rules
text: New York Governor Eliot Spitzer, who, when he was attorney general, aggressively policed the financial services industry, is forming a committee of Wall Street chief executives, lawyers, consumer groups and regulators to modernize financial-services regulation in New York State, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager’s Comments Irk Macquarie
text: At a charity event in New York last week, during which some of the biggest names in hedge funds offered investment advice, James Chanos, the short seller who catapulted to fame by questioning Enron, offered the Macquarie Bank, the Australian financial group, as a stock that might be in for a fall. He even drew some comparisons between Enron and Macquarie, which has raised a lot of big investment funds that it used to buy assets and sell them to related entities.

headline: Tech Retailer CDW Said to Consider Buyout
text: CDW, a computer reseller with a market capitalization of about $6 billion, is in talks with private equity firms about a possible buyout, The Wall Street Journal reported. Madison Dearborn Partners is considered to be in the lead to buy the company, the Journal said.

headline: Presidential Candidates Flock to Hedge-Fund Enclave
text: Senator John McCain did it. Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts did it. President Bill Clinton, on behalf of his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, did it. They all made recent pilgrimages to Greenwich, the leafy Connecticut suburb that is home to an inordinate number of hedge funds and, increasingly, a required stop on the presidential fund-raising tour, The New York Times reports.

headline: Morgan Stanley Analyst Defects to Hedge Fund
text: A well-known property analyst at Morgan Stanley in Hong Kong has left the Wall Street firm for an alternative investment manager based in the United States, joining an industry-wide migration in recent years.

headline: URS Buys Washington Group for $2.6 Billion
text: URS, a construction design and engineering company based in San Francisco, agreedj to buy Washington Group International, a rival based in Boise, Idaho, for $2.6 billion, to create one of the country’s largest engineering and construction companies, the companies said Monday.

headline: To Lure Top Talent, Google Finds Novel Ways to Recruit
text: As competition for top recruits in engineering and other fields intensifies, companies like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo frequently find themselves going after the same candidates, as well as running up against myriad Silicon Valley start-up companies that have been pumped up with venture capital in recent years.

headline: Investors Worry as K.K.R. and CVC Pull Out of Coles Bid
text: Two private equity firms have pulled out of a consortium bidding for the Coles Group, the Australian retailer, pushing its shares down sharply as investors worried about the state of the company’s financial health.

headline: Are Warner and Cerberus Planning a Suprise Attack on EMI?
text: Is Warner Music Group teaming up with Cerberus Capital Management for an 11th-hour surprise bid for the rival music outfit EMI Group? The Sunday Telegraph reported that Warner and the private equity firm have explored a novel two-stage bid for EMI to rival the $4.7 billion recommended offer from Terra Firma, an investment vehicle controlled by the British financier Guy Hands.

headline: Silicon Valley Wide-Eyed Over a Bride
text: Silicon Valley is aflutter with the news that Anne Wojcicki, a 33-year-old former health care investment analyst, this month married a handsome young computer scientist, who just happens to be one of America’s richest men.

headline: Google Deal Said to Bring U.S. Scrutiny
text: The Federal Trade Commission has opened a preliminary antitrust investigation into Google‘s planned $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising company DoubleClick, according to The New York Times.

headline: Avaya Is Said to Be Exploring a Sale
text: The telecommunications company Avaya is in negotiations to sell a part or all of itself, in what may be the latest round of deal making in its industry, The New York Times reported.

headline: In China, a Stake in Blackstone Stirs Uncertainty
text: From Washington, the Chinese government’s purchase of a $3 billion nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group looks like a shrewd alliance with a politically connected American private equity fund loaded with financial expertise.

headline: For John Mack, a Bid to Regain Lost Ground
text: As John J. Mack finds himself two years into his campaign to raise Morgan Stanley‘s metabolism, The Wall Street Journal takes a look at some of the bank’s missteps and successes in its bid to regain lost ground.

headline: Rival Bidders Offer $95.5 Billion for ABN Amro
text: The takeover battle for the Dutch bank ABN Amro gained momentum Tuesday when a consortium led by the Royal Bank of Scotland, which has openly coveted ABM Amro for weeks, formally offered 71.1 billion euros ($95.6 billion) for it. The proposal trumped ABN’s agreed deal with Barclays, already the largest banking takeover.

headline: The Newest Bears on Private Equity: Buyout Firms
text: Is the private equity party about to end? Cassandras have sounded warnings for months now — but their ranks are beginning to fill with some big names from the buyout world, the Wall Street Journal reported Monday.

headline: Candidates on a Plane
text: Imagine that the top presidential candidates are all at an airport, trying to get on a flight. There is one seat left on the plane, and there are six people ahead of them in line. What does each of the candidates do?

headline: BA Shares Rise as Buyout Rumors Mount
text: Shares of British Airways, Europe’s third-largest airline, rose the most in almost a year on speculation the carrier might attract a private-equity bid, Bloomberg News reported Monday. Shares of the airline advanced as much as 22.5 pence, or 4.9 percent, to 483.5 pence, the biggest gain since June 15, 2006 at midday.

headline: 2008: The Changes in Giuliani
text: As he travels around the country seeking the G.O.P. nomination, Rudolph W. Giuliani has offered a calmer side to his personality than what he often displayed while mayor of New York. The Times’s Michael Powell looks back on his political journey:

headline: Karen Kilimnik in View
text: Additional images from the Karen Kilimnik survey at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia.

headline: Bradley Pharmaceuticals’ C.E.O. Makes Buyout Offer
text: The chief executive of Bradley Pharmaceuticals has bid $21.50 a share to buy the company, valuing it at about $363 million, the company said in a regulatory filing. The chief executive, Daniel Glassman would remain in his position and would retain the current top management, the company said.

headline: Fort Dix Tipster Steps Forward
text: The man applauded by an F.B.I. agent as the “unsung hero” of Fort Dix case stepped into the spotlight today on CNN.

headline: ‘Sicko’ and the Race
text: The presidential race was consumed last week with discussion of the immigration bill and financing of the Iraq war. This week, health care may take center stage, with Senator Barack Obama planning to release his long-awaited health care proposal today.

headline: Options for Reimbursement When a Tour Falls Through
text: With overseas travel agencies offering more prepaid tours, is there any insurance policy or credit card coverage for refunds in the event you show up and find the travel agency is no longer in business or unable to provide the promised itinerary?

headline: Peace Victim
text: — Tobin Harshaw

headline: Archstone-Smith Agrees to $22 Billion Takeover
text: Too big for a deal? Not these days.

headline: Remarks of Senator Barack Obama
text: The following is the prepared text of Senator Obama's speech on health care, as provided by his campaign.

headline: Housing Price Rebound?
text: The latest housing price numbers have a tinge of hope — at least in some bubbly markets. The Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller indexes for March, out today, actually went up in the Boston and San Francisco regions. In each case, the bounce came after nine consecutive monthly declines. And the Portland and Seattle markets, which had shown signs of slipping although their year-over-year gains remained substantial, each showed improving month-over-month numbers.

headline: Who Might Take the Wheel at Volvo?
text: Volvo has had plenty of admirers over the years, and we are not just talking about affluent Northeasterners who like its sensibly Swedish version of luxury. Renault of France and Fiat of Italy have, at various times, considered buying or merging with Volvo. With reports percolating that Ford Motor Company might put the business up for sale — it is part of Ford’s Premier Automotive Group, which has already sold Aston Martin — attention naturally turns to who else might cast an eye Volvo’s way.

headline: Potential New Bidders for Alcan Arise, as Does Politicians’ Ire
text: As reports surface that more bidders might jump into the fray for Alcan, Canadian politicians are calling for greater protections against takeovers by foreign companies.

headline: Obama’s Health Plan
text: Fresh off campaign stops in New Hampshire over the weekend, Senator Barack Obama traveled to the University of Iowa to outline his own plan to try to provide health insurance coverage for everyone.

headline: Why People Hate, and Love, Jim Cramer
text: Jim Cramer wants to know why he has become “a polarizing figure” since he started his CNBC stock-picking show, “Mad Money,” in which he yells and sweats a lot, throws things, and sometimes wears a diaper or jumps into a pile of lettuce “to illustrate,” he cheekily writes, “the finer points of investing.”

headline: The Animated Life: L'Eau Life
text: A short animated film by artist Jeff Scher. Part of Sightlines, an Op-Ed visual series.

headline: Lofty Goals in Higher Education
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer signed an executive order today creating a commission to look at overhauling the State University of New York system. The goal is a lofty one: to put SUNY on par with elite public university systems in states like California. But it would also be expensive to accomplish that, and the governor would only say that “how funding will fit into this I remain to wait and see.”

headline: Tuesday Motorsports
text: The Indy 500 gave us one of the better feel-good stories in recent IndyCar memory when Dario Franchitti won a rain-shortened race, and the camera found his wife, Ashley Judd, running down the pits, barefoot and wet.

headline: Clinton Sees ‘Rising Pessimism’
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination, pledged in a speech in Manchester, N.H., this morning to reduce corporate tax breaks and eliminate incentives for companies that move overseas in order to combat “rising inequality and rising pessimism in our workforce.”

headline: Look before you leap
text: “Blind Light,” an exhibit of the work of the British sculptor Antony Gormley, has drawn mixed reviews from the critics. Some observers have found deep meanings in installations like an enormous glass cube filled with a hazy vapor. Others are simply confused.

headline: Is Someone Browsing Kroger’s Aisles?
text: Options traders are on a shopping spree with Kroger, the grocery chain. Trading in the company’s options skyrocketed Tuesday, a development that OptionMonster.com’s Jon Najarian chalked up to fresh speculation about a possible buyout of the company.

headline: Retailers Turn Up on Citi’s Buyout List
text: Two decades ago, a favorable environment for junk-bond financing helped fuel a wave of leveraged buyouts. Citi’s equity strategists say they are feeling a bit of a flashback these days, as yields on risky debt are relatively low, making it cheaper to borrow money to take companies private. The atmosphere “is reminiscent of the L.B.O. heyday back in the latter 1980’s,” they wrote in a report published Tuesday. Citi’s analysts compared companies’ cash flows with junk-bond yields and found that certain sectors look especially ripe for buyouts: These included the commercial services industry (which includes waste management, employment services, etc.) and retailing.

headline: On Gay Marriage, Poll Shows a State Split
text: Forty-seven percent of New Yorkers oppose gay marriage, while 43 percent support the idea, according to a new poll from Siena College.

headline: From the Banking World, More Bitter Beach Reading
text: Bankers can be forgiven for being very careful about what they say around the office. Acid-laced books, both fictional and nonfictional, written by former employees of investment banks, seem to have replaced drug-strewn memoirs as the current era’s “it” genre.

headline: Fashion Oligarchs
text: I’m mildly curious about what people wear (and don’t wear) at the Cannes Film Festival, and I’m thinking that next year I ought to go and see for myself, and maybe combine the trip with the Grand Prix at Monaco, just to see a different kind of action. I’d go for the simple reason that I don’t know what to expect from those events, and not from any illusion that I can compete with Hello! for fawning reportage of the latest sequined coated babe. It ain’t gonna happen. Nonetheless, I will have to deal with the expectation that this is what “most people” want to read. “To write what you are interested in writing, and to succeed in getting editors to pay for it, is a feat that may require pretty close calculation and a good deal of ingenuity. You have to learn to load solid matter into notices of ephemeral happenings; you have to develop a resourcefulness at pursing a line of thought through pieces on miscellaneous and more or less fortuitous subjects; and you have to acquire a technique of slipping over on the routine of editors the deeper independent work which their over-anxious intentness on the fashions of the month or the week have conditioned them automatically to reject.” This is from Edmund Wilson, in a 2005 piece by Louis Menand, and I keep its essence in the back of my head. Very often writers don’t know what they want to say about subject, only that something deserves to be written which hasn’t been sufficiently said.

headline: Charles Nelson Reilly, Master Thespian
text: Charles Nelson Reilly appeared on “Match Game” prefamous. As a kid I believed he must have been very, very famous before I was lucky enough to catch him cooling his heels in the afterschool hours.

headline: Congestion Pricing? It’s ‘Complicated’
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer had this to say today when asked about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan:

headline: A Shocking Confession in Russia
text: An 18-year-old art student has told police that he killed more than 30 people in Moscow, according to reports in Russian newspapers.

headline: The Face of Ultimate Fighting
text: What does an organization called Ultimate Fighting Championship do when its ultimate fighter is badly beaten in front of tons of adoring fans?

headline: What to Cut Back?
text: In order to cut back the size of the house, we had to lose something — but what?

headline: ‘What Can They Do to Me?’
text: It is the question that every presidential candidate must have a good answer to: Why do you want the job?

headline: Let’s Talk About Sects
text: The conservative editorial cartoonist Allen Forkum offers some illustrated commentary, followed by the more literal kind:

headline: China Sweeps to Victory at the Women’s Team Championship
text: The Chinese women won the First Women’s Team Championship with an undefeated score in nine matches. The only blemish on their record was a tie against Georgia (formerly of the Soviet Union), who were led by former women’s world champion Maia Chiburdanidze. The championship, which was held in Yekaterinburg, Russia, began on May 19. The official Web site is here.

headline: Cabbages and Condoms, a Winning Idea
text: Mechai Viravaidya was recognized by The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation today with a $1 million award for confronting “taboo subjects like sex and HIV/AIDS directly in order to save lives,” the foundation said.

headline: A Doodle Is Worth $2,000
text: Senator Barack Obama: activist, author, presidential candidate … artist?

headline: U.S. Attorney Charges Pakistani Banker with Insider Trading
text: Federal prosecutors on Tuesday charged a high-profile investment banker in Pakistan with taking part in a $7.5 million insider-trading scheme that they say was run by a former Credit Suisse banker. In a new complaint filed in federal district court in Manhattan, the United States attorney’s office accused Ajaz Rahim, the former head of Faysal Bank Limited, of profiting from confidential information fed to him by Hafiz Mohammed Zubair Naseem, at the time a junior associate in Credit Suisse’s energy team.

headline: The Soft-Shell Crab Poor-Boy
text: Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, cooks a New Orleans favorite. (Warning: Contains images of violence to crabs.)

headline: All Bonds, All The Time
text: Barry Bonds, perhaps one of the most polarizing players in the history of baseball, will be sitting on the bench for the opener of the Giants’ three-game series at Shea Stadium. The Giants like giving Bonds two consecutive days of rest, and with an off day yesterday and a lefthander, Oliver Perez, starting for the Mets tonight, benching him was the natural move.

headline: Chain Reactions
text: The political party that claimed it would restore “honor and dignity to the White House” has done nothing of the sort. Having on false pretenses led us into the disaster of Iraq, the administration and its supporters are now beginning – cravenly and shamefully – to shift blame onto the Iraqi people. The administration continues to hold hundreds of people without charges in secret prisons around the world, while arguing that torture is O.K. and that President Bush can disregard the laws he doesn’t like. I haven’t even mentioned illegal spying or efforts to keep scientists quiet if they’re saying the wrong thing.

headline: Candidates Matches: Two Grab Big Leads
text: Gata Kamsky of the United States and Peter Leko of Hungary took overwhelming leads of 2.5 to 0.5 over their opponents in the candidates matches taking place in Elista, Kalmykia. The matches are to select four qualifiers for the world championship tournament in Mexico City in September and October. The games can be replayed here at the official Web site for the matches.

headline: 2008: P.M. Postscripts
text: Former Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney said today in New Hampshire that he would donate to charity at least a part if not more of his presidential salary (should he win) — given that he’s the wealthiest among the candidates.

headline: Who Pays to Play?
text: Taxpayers are helping to pay for corporate executives to travel to a destination golf resort in the hard-luck town of Bandon, Ore.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Tell Matt Where to Go in Tennessee and Kentucky
text: Next stops on the Frugal Traveler’s itinerary are Tennessee and Kentucky. Have you been or do you live near by? Share a suggestion what Matt should see, eat and do on his way through these states.

headline: It’s Zoellick
text: Without a mention of the most eye-grabbing names to lead the World Bank (Tony Blair and Bill Frist, anyone?), the White House has picked a man who has plenty of appropriate experience in Republican government, respect abroad and ties to President Bush that date back to the early days of his 2000 campaign, when a group led by Condoleezza Rice known as “the Vulcans” advised a candidate inexperienced on foreign policy.

headline: ‘Aberration,’ Says L.A.P.D. Chief
text: Commissioner William J. Bratton of the Los Angeles Police Department faced off with his overseers today on the immigration protest gone awry on May Day. At the time, he called it “worst incident of this type I have ever encountered in 37 years” in law enforcement.

headline: CDW Agrees to $7.3 Billion Buyout by Madison Dearborn
text: CDW, a technology products retailer aimed at business, said late Tuesday that it has agreed to sell itself to Madison Dearborn Partners for about $7.3 billion in cash. In a statement Tuesday, CDW said that the deal values the company at $87.75 a share, or a 16.3 percent premium over its closing stock price on Friday.

headline: Frugal Traveler: Armuchee, Ga.
text: The Frugal Traveler arrives in Armuchee, Ga., just in time for the Armuchee Bluegrass Festival.

headline: Interrogation Methods Are Criticized
text: WASHINGTON, May 29 — As the Bush administration completes secret new rules governing interrogations, a group of experts advising the intelligence agencies are arguing that the harsh techniques used since the 2001 terrorist attacks are outmoded, amateurish and unreliable.

headline: What’s on Tonight
text: 8 P.M. (22, 26) CRAFT IN AMERICA Three hourlong specials consider the significance of the craft movement in the United States and its impact on the nation’s cultural heritage, starting with “Memory,” in which the basketmakers Mary Jackson, above, and Pat Courtney Gold; the woodworker Sam Maloof; and other artisans place their work within craft’s larger historical context. At 9, “Landscape” examines the relationship between artists like the jewelers Kit Carson and Jan Yager and their physical environments. And “Community,” at 10, honors the connection between artisans and where they live.

headline: From Jail, a Panhandler Fights New York’s Loitering Law as a Violation of Free Speech
text: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 29 — A homeless panhandler arrested here six months ago on loitering charges is contending in court that a state law banning begging violates his right to free speech. The man, Eric Hoffstead, started living on the streets about a year ago and was arrested after asking a police officer for a dollar; he urged his court-appointed lawyer to challenge the arrest after reading a newspaper article about a similar case.

headline: Bush Seeks to Double Spending for AIDS Program
text: WASHINGTON, May 30 — President Bush asked Congress today to double the amount the United States spends to fight “this modern-day plague” of AIDS in developing countries. He proposed spending $30 billion over a five-year period beginning in September 2008.

headline: Recipe: Fettuccine With Mushroom Ragù
text: Time: 40 minutes

headline: Rising Star in Israel Hits the Fast Track of English Soccer
text: Ben Sahar did not play a big role in Chelsea’s run to the English F.A. Cup title. He did not play a part in Chelsea’s second-place finish in the Premier League. And Sahar did not step on to the field once as Chelsea advanced to the semifinals of the European Champions League.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of editing errors, the Critic’s Choice column yesterday, about a new box set of DVDs of Katharine Hepburn films, referred incorrectly to a brother of Hepburn who committed suicide, and it misstated his date of birth, part of which Hepburn said for years was her own birthday. He was an older brother, not younger, and was born on Nov. 8, 1905 — not 1909. (Katharine Hepburn, whose centenary was May 12 this year, claimed for years that she was two years younger than she actually was and that her birthday was Nov. 8.)

headline: Summer’s for Soft-Shells, With a New Orleans Riff
text: THERE may be no bad way to prepare soft-shell crabs. They contain so much moisture they’re just about impossible to overcook, and they cook so quickly they’re hard to undercook.

headline: Ex-Chief of China Food and Drug Unit Sentenced to Death for Graft
text: SHANGHAI, May 29 — The former director of China’s top food and drug safety agency was sentenced to death on Tuesday after pleading guilty to corruption and accepting bribes, the state-controlled news media reported.

headline: A Concert Greets the Summer While Giving a Nod to the Past
text: The New York Philharmonic has established a tradition of playing a free concert at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on Memorial Day, partly to commemorate the holiday itself — perhaps more acutely now, in wartime — and to inaugurate the summer, when the orchestra also performs free in the parks. On Monday Xian Zhang, the Philharmonic’s associate conductor, brought those impulses together in a program that began with Dvorak’s ebullient “Carnival” Overture and then settled into Brahms’s more solemn, philosophical but ultimately triumphant First Symphony.

headline: Ending Our Tobacco Addiction
text: The sharp decline in the prevalence of smoking over the past four decades has been a towering public health achievement. In 1964, some 42 percent of adults in the United States smoked cigarettes. Today, only 21 percent do. But as an expert panel assembled by the Institute of Medicine warned last week, the downward trend shows signs of slowing while the death toll from cigarette smoking remains disturbingly high.

headline: Man Posed as Yale Aide in Swindle of Irish Immigrants, Authorities Say
text: NEW HAVEN, May 29 — It sounded good enough to be a dream come true, yet practical enough to be possible. The illegal Irish immigrants were eager to get their papers, and someone at Yale Law School was eager to help them.

headline: Saffron Power: Yellow, Yet Not Necessarily Mellow
text: AT a symposium on Spanish cuisine last November, I anticipated two days of deconstructed, itsy-bitsy food, the hallmark of molecular cuisine that has captivated top chefs worldwide.

headline: An Earthy Mushroom Pasta Sauce With Piquant Cheese for an Earthy, Truffly Wine
text: WHETHER they hail from Alba or Asti, barberas tend to share an earthy profile, striking fruity chords with notes of black truffle. Mushrooms, I thought, as I tasted. And pasta. Perhaps even a beefy red sauce.

headline: Pink or Blue? These Bundles of Joy Are Always Green
text: Editor’s Note: In Advertising comes to you today because of the Memorial Day holiday yesterday. Look for In Advertising next week on June 4, its usual publication day, Monday.

headline: Recipe: Roasted Poussin With Braised Hearts of Romaine, Parmesan and Anchovy
text: Adapted from the Modern

headline: Boeing Makes a $2.4 Billion Sale of 787s in Russia
text: MOSCOW, May 29 — Boeing sold 15 of its next-generation 787 jets to a private Russian airline today in a deal valued at about $2.4 billion, Boeing’s largest sale in the former Soviet Union.

headline: NBC, in Shake-Up, Names Outsider to a Top Position
text: NBC Universal shook up its entertainment operations yesterday, hiring one of the hottest young production talents in television, Ben Silverman, as a co-chairman of both the entertainment division and its television studio.

headline: Ex-Trade Envoy Is Bush’s Choice for World Bank
text: WASHINGTON, May 29 — President Bush has chosen Robert B. Zoellick, a senior diplomat and trade envoy who became a top Goldman Sachs executive last year, to lead the World Bank and try to heal the bitter rifts left by the ouster of Paul D. Wolfowitz, the administration said Tuesday.

headline: Russia Hails Test of a New Missile It Says Can Pierce Defense Shields
text: MOSCOW, May 29  Russia held a test launching of a new intercontinental ballistic missile on Tuesday and said it had successfully fired the weapon almost entirely across its northern airspace to the Russian Far East.

headline: Recipe: Saffron Almond Meringues
text: Adapted from María José San Román

headline: At Murder Trial, Prosecutors Doubt Police and Each Other
text: “Curiouser and curiouser,” cried the judge, Gustin L. Reichbach, channeling “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” as he surveyed the spectacle in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday.

headline: Bronx: Four Injured by Gunfire
text: Four teenagers were seriously wounded early yesterday when a gunman walked into a fast-food restaurant on Archer Street and opened fire, the police said. The shooting occurred just after midnight near Taylor Avenue, the police said. The police did not provide a motive for the shooting. The victims were a 17-year-old boy who was hit in the chest, wrist and leg; an 18-year-old woman hit in the leg; a 19-year-old man hit in the leg; and another 19-year-old man who was struck in both legs, the police said. The police did not identify the victims. No arrests had been made yesterday evening, the police said.

headline: Sheehan Says She’s Quitting as Face of Peace Movement
text: Cindy Sheehan, the antiwar activist who spent the last two years trying to confront President Bush, courting controversy and traveling around the world in protest of the war in Iraq, says she will now try a final tactic: silence.

headline: Young Runner to Go After Family High School Record
text: In 1973, Matt Centrowitz of Power Memorial High School in Manhattan ran a mile in 4 minutes 2.7 seconds. On Saturday, his son, Matthew, will go after the family high school record. Officials of the Reebok Grand Prix announced yesterday that Matthew, an 18-year-old high school senior from Annapolis, Md., would run the mile in their meet Saturday at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island in New York. A month ago, the younger Centrowitz set a Penn Relays high school record of 4:08.38 for the mile. Last weekend, he ran 4:04.09 for 1,600 meters, the equivalent of 4:05.5 for the mile. His father, the track coach at American University, had a career best of 3:54.94 for the mile. The son is bound for the University of Oregon, his father’s alma mater.

headline: Palestinian and Israeli Leaders to Meet Next Week, as Tensions Remain High
text: JERUSALEM, May 29  Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, and Ehud Olmert, Israel’s prime minister, will meet next week, their offices said Tuesday, in a continuation of a Washington-sponsored dialogue that will inevitably focus on another round of Israeli-Palestinian warfare.

headline: Oil May Allow Sudan to Escape Sanctions’ Pain
text: The Bush administration’s new sanctions against Sudan aim to squeeze the country’s economy by freezing Sudanese companies out of American financial institutions and curtailing their dollar transactions.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the position of Greenwich, Conn., as a must stop on the campaign fund-raising trail misidentified the birthplace of former President George Bush. He was born in Milton, Mass. — not Greenwich, where President Bush outraised Democrats in the 2004 campaign.

headline: Obama Calls for Wider and Less Costly Health Care Coverage
text: IOWA CITY, May 29 — Senator Barack Obama proposed a major overhaul of the nation’s health care system on Tuesday, aimed at covering the nearly 45 million uninsured Americans and reducing premium costs for everyone else.

headline: Spitzer Names a Panel to Improve Universities in New York
text: ALBANY, May 29  Gov. Eliot Spitzer named a commission on Tuesday to recommend how to overhaul higher education in New York, saying he wanted to improve the reputation of the state’s public universities.

headline: Gingrich Lambastes President and Rove
text: WASHINGTON, May 29 — President Bush has presided over a Republican Party in “collapse,” and Karl Rove’s strategy in the 2004 presidential election was “maniacally dumb” for focusing so heavily on the conservative base.

headline: Bush to Meet Putin in July
text: WASHINGTON, May 30 — President Bush will be host to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Bush family’s oceanside home in Kennebunkport, Me., on July 1 and 2, where the two leaders are to discuss several issues that have curdled relations between Washington and Moscow.

headline: TB Patient Is Isolated After Taking Two Flights
text: Federal and international officials are tracking down passengers and crew members on two trans-Atlantic flights earlier this month who may have been exposed to a man infected with an exceptionally dangerous form of tuberculosis.

headline: In a Switch, China Triples the Tax on Stock Trades
text: HONG KONG, Wednesday, May 30 — In an abrupt reversal, China’s finance ministry announced early Wednesday morning that it would triple the tax on stock trades, a move aimed at braking what many business executives and economists inside and outside China now see as a stock market bubble.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about a decision by the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, to remove at least five members of Community Board 6 who oppose the Atlantic Yards development project — which Mr. Markowitz supports — misstated the reason for the absence of a response by Mr. Markowitz. At the time the article was being reported, Mr. Markowitz could not be reached by his aides because he was on a ship at sea, had no telephone access and was not regularly checking his e-mail messages. He did not “refuse” to comment. (Go to Article)

headline: End-of-Days Fidelity for ‘Jericho’
text: The problem with the proposition that television is an art is that art is meant to be deathless, while television shows are always being canceled.

headline: Bush Names Ex-Trade Envoy to Run World Bank
text: WASHINGTON, May 30 — President Bush announced today that he had chosen Robert B. Zoellick, a senior diplomat and trade envoy, to lead the World Bank, where one of his first tasks will be to try to heal the bitter rifts left by the ouster of the bank’s current president, Paul D. Wolfowitz.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Saturday about a clinical study that tests the risk of the diabetes treatment Avandia on the heart misspelled the surname of the F.D.A. spokeswoman who cautioned about misinterpreting data from early findings. She is Julie Zawisza, not Zawisa.

headline: U.S. Raising Visa Fees 66% on Average, to Advocates’ Dismay
text: The federal agency that handles immigration visas confirmed yesterday that it would raise its fees by an average of 66 percent starting July 30. The step made final an increase first proposed in January, and drew a new outcry from immigration lawyers and advocacy groups.

headline: Don’t Restrict Innovation (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Notion From 9/11 Is Kept Alive
text: The first day of the post-Rosie O’Donnell era on “The View” television show has come and gone, and by any fair accounting, an often useful provocateur has left the building.

headline: Iran Arrests Grandma
text: Man, was I wrong about Iran.

headline: Boeing Sells 15 Dreamliners to Russian Airline
text: MOSCOW, May 29 — The Boeing Company sold 15 of its next-generation 787 jets to a private Russian airline on Tuesday in a deal valued at about $2.4 billion, Boeing’s largest sale in the former Soviet Union.

headline: Up for Auction, Thorpe’s Letters Make the Past Come Alive
text: Jim Thorpe’s life after his peak as an Olympic champion and amateur and professional football player until his exit from sports in 1928 has hardly been examined by mainstream historians. But a glimpse of his story and sports performances can be found in private correspondence recently released by his family.

headline: Take Note: Computing Takes Up Pen, Again
text: SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 — For more than two decades, the dream of controlling a computer with a pen has seduced and, more often than not, frustrated some of the biggest luminaries in the technology pantheon, including Bill Gates and Steve Jobs.

headline: A Bush Brother Spreads His Vision of Computerized Teaching Programs
text: SPOTSYLVANIA, Va.

headline: The Cartridge, Updated, Catches Up to Data
text: If you’ve ever felt as though you can’t keep up with the pace of life, well, it could have been worse. You could have been a computer disk.

headline: Some Hitherto Staunch G.O.P. Voters Souring on Iraq
text: WILMETTE, Ill., May 29 — Through four elections, Debbie Thompson has supported Representative Mark Steven Kirk, a Republican and staunch backer of the Bush administration’s policies in Iraq.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Books of The Times review yesterday, about “A Thousand Splendid Suns,” by Khaled Hosseini, misspelled a character’s name. She is Laila, not Lila.

headline: A Crowd-Pleaser of a Trip and a Book to Try at Home
text: The Farmers’ Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., has a sure crowd-pleasing exhibition on view until the end of October: “Ice Cream: Our Cool Obsession.” There are photographs, historical artifacts like antique ice cream machines and old trucks, and a retro ice cream parlor serving treats. The history of the confection, starting with water ices in ancient times, is explored.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about elections in Ireland referred incorrectly to televised endorsements for Bertie Ahern’s campaign for re-election as prime minister. The broadcasts had Prime Minister Tony Blair and former President Bill Clinton praising Mr. Ahern’s role in negotiations that led to the 1998 Good Friday peace accords in Northern Ireland. The endorsements did not praise Mr. Clinton’s role in the talks.

headline: Setting the Rent
text: Setting the weekly rental rates for vacation homes on Kiawah Island, S.C., is a balancing exercise for Jeanette Lawson. “I look at last year’s rates,” she said. “What did I ask, and how did it rent? If it rented too quickly, maybe I had it priced too low.”

headline: Downtown Landmark Makes a High-End Play
text: In a leap of faith in the Lower Manhattan office market, a group of real estate developers is creating what would be the financial district’s first office tower with a country club’s exclusivity — and perhaps its extraordinary membership fees — in the Woolworth Building.

headline: New Buildings Are Proposed Among Projects
text: Facing a $225 million budget gap, the City Housing Authority is planning to sharply reduce its staff and sell vacant land in its projects for development into housing, much of it for middle-income residents, officials said yesterday.

headline: Trenton: Eight Indicted in Doughnut Shop Robberies
text: Eight people have been indicted on charges of robbing 97 small businesses in New Jersey and southeastern Pennsylvania, including a large number of doughnut shops, prosecutors said yesterday. Members of the group were charged with traveling to the businesses in rental cars, breaking in after they had closed and using crowbars to pry open cash registers, said Attorney General Stuart Rabner. In some cases, they also stole safes. Mr. Rabner said 50 police departments participated in the investigation.

headline: Recipe: Papas Bravas
text: Adapted from María José San Román

headline: Russia: Court Grants Amnesty to Beslan Siege Police
text: A federal court granted amnesty to three policemen accused of negligence in failing to prevent a Chechen terrorist group from seizing a public school and more than 1,100 hostages in Beslan in 2004. Their trial, which began last year, had been seen as another chance to expose official bungling of the three-day siege, in which 333 people died, 186 of them children, and to turn up more information about lingering mysteries. Survivors and relatives, who accuse the government of a whitewash, reacted with dismay, shouting and rushing the judge, who was forced from the courtroom in North Ossetia before finishing reading his decision, according to local reports.

headline: Fred Thompson Moves Toward a Run for President
text: WASHINGTON, May 30 — Former Senator Fred D. Thompson of Tennessee shook up the Republican presidential field today by making clear that he is likely to run for the White House.

headline: Weis’s N.F.L. Friendships Led Browns to Quinn
text: BEREA, Ohio  When the Cleveland Browns’ general manager, Phil Savage, visited Notre Dame to watch a football practice last August, he was offered a special vantage point: Charlie Weis’s guest-of-honor chair.

headline: How We’re Animalistic — in Good Ways and Bad
text: The odd thing is that conservatives wear pinstriped suits. They love the ancients so much that they really should be walking around in togas. The main contribution of the Greeks to modern American politics may have been Michael Dukakis, who once climbed the Acropolis in wingtips.

headline: From a Pennsylvania Garden Patch, Down-Home Crocus Taste
text: YOU wouldn’t think of saffron as a down-home flavoring. But in parts of Pennsylvania Dutch country, any respectable cook making the local specialty, chicken pot pie — really more of a stew than a pie — always uses a pinch of saffron.

headline: TB Patient Was Advised Not to Fly
text: A man who may have exposed passengers and crew members on two trans-Atlantic flights earlier this month to a highly drug-resistant form of tuberculosis knew he was infected, and had been advised by health officials not to travel overseas.

headline: Recipe: Pennsylvania Dutch Chicken Pot Pie
text: Time: 2 hours

headline: Security Council to Vote on Court to Try Suspects in Beirut Slaying
text: UNITED NATIONS, May 29  The United States and its European allies, acting despite opposition from Russia, scheduled a vote for Wednesday on a binding Security Council resolution establishing an international court to try those suspected of killing Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Death Shapes a Reality Show

headline: Fighting the Tide, a Few Restaurants Tilt to Tap Water
text: DON’T bother asking for Fiji, San Pellegrino or any other designer water at either Incanto, a restaurant that opened in San Francisco in 2002, or at Poggio, which opened in Sausalito, Calif., two years later.

headline: Recipe: Vegetable Paella With Wild Mushrooms
text: Adapted from María José San Román

headline: No More Excuses on Darfur
text: Behind-the-scenes diplomacy has done nothing to stop the slaughter of innocents in Darfur. For months, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations and other international leaders have been claiming that Sudan’s president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, was ready to halt further attacks by the Sudanese armed forces and its janjaweed militia allies and accept a robust international protective force. Instead, Mr. Bashir and his henchmen have used those months to kill still more people and drive others from their homes.

headline: Brooklyn: Woman Fatally Stabbed
text: A 45-year-old woman was found dead in her home at 247 Malcolm X Boulevard in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday, the police said. She had been stabbed several times in the neck. The woman, who was not identified, was found by police officers shortly after 11:30 a.m. No arrests had been made yesterday evening, the police said.

headline: In Her Time Away From Golf, Wie Enjoys Being 17 Years Old
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C., May 29  For Michelle Wie, the last four months away from golf have been a rest, a reality check and a chance to enjoy her last taste of high school without cramming it into her normally frantic schedule.

headline: New York Is Top State in Dollars Per Student
text: New York again leads all other states in school spending per pupil, according to the latest census figures.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Sunday about early and absentee voting in next year’s presidential primaries misidentified the academic affiliation of Paul Gronke, a professor of political science who is an expert on early voting. He is at Reed College in Portland, Ore., not the University of Oregon.

headline: Scattered Stories, Shaken and Stirred
text: PHILADELPHIA — Karen Kilimnik has gotten the survey that her strange, still difficult achievement deserves. For one thing, her show at the Institute of Contemporary Art is appropriately strange itself, beginning with a barren, seemingly empty, party’s-over gallery. It goes deep into her woman-child imagination, touching an all-too-American sense of emptiness. It also makes her efforts in installation art, which encompass materials as various as glitter, fake snow and blood, stuffed animals, ballet shoes and piles of party drugs, feel of a piece with her painting, photography, video and drawing.

headline: Life in the Sprawling Suburbs, if You Can Really Call It Living
text: “In some ways a suburban city can be understood as an intolerant city.” If that loaded quotation from the Calgary-based architect Marc Boutin doesn’t tell you exactly where “Radiant City” stands on the issue of suburban sprawl, the filmmakers have plenty more just like it.

headline: Parren Mitchell, 85, Congressman and Rights Leader, Dies
text: Parren J. Mitchell, who as the first black elected to Congress from Maryland led the Congressional Black Caucus and spearheaded programs to aid minority-owned business, an effort he viewed as the second phase of the civil rights movement, died on Monday in Baltimore. He was 85.

headline: Suicide Poses Old Threat to Japan’s New Leader
text: TOKYO, May 29  When Prime Minister Shinzo Abe took office last fall, he was a popular leader vowing to end what he called Japan’s “postwar regime.” But the suicide of the agricultural minister this week threatens his administration with one of the oldest problems in Japanese politics: money scandals.

headline: Earl Ubell, Science Reporter, Dies at 80
text: Earl Ubell, a science reporter and editor familiar to generations of New Yorkers for his wide-ranging reports in the old New York Herald Tribune and on WCBS-TV, died on Tuesday in a nursing home in Englewood, N.J. He was 80 and had been a resident of Hackensack, N.J.

headline: Pondering Some Old, Familiar Questions on the Road Across Country
text: The tires whine, and sometimes they moan. Sometimes they send up a whistle I don’t even hear until it stops. Now and then the asphalt runs smooth and true. But mostly the interstate is a series of discontinuities  a sharp thump as we hit a shallow overpass, a few miles partly paved with recycled rubber, a long sequence in western Nebraska where the tires make the sound of the special effects in Walter Mitty’s mind. And then there is Omaha, where the freeway looks smooth but is really a dozen heavily corrugated miles that must drive the truckers insane.

headline: Bonds Sits One Out as the Beat Goes On
text: Barry Bonds of the San Francisco Giants did more singing than playing at Shea Stadium yesterday. He rolled into the clubhouse with a digital music player on his arm and headphones over his ears. Soon after his arrival, the Giants announced that Bonds was not starting and not talking.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about a legal immigrant and Persian Gulf war veteran who has been detained in a New Jersey jail for three years while immigration authorities try to deport him for a firearms conviction misstated his surname at one point in some copies. He is Warren Joseph, not “Mr. Warren.”

headline: Pretty Faces With Plenty of Troubles, and Secrets
text: “Hidden Palms,” the new series from Kevin Williamson making its debut tonight on CW, may be the first teenage soap opera visually dedicated to mid-20th-century Modernism. Remove the sex, sociopathology and possible filicide, and you will still be left with a quite inspiring home design show.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A headline on a report in The Caucus yesterday, about The New York Post’s error in reporting that Senator John Kerry had chosen Richard A. Gephardt as his running mate in 2004, misstated the famous headline in The Chicago Daily Tribune in 1948 when the paper declared the wrong winner in the presidential race. The headline was “Dewey Defeats Truman,” not “Dewey Beats Truman.” (Go to Article)

headline: Don’t Point That Menu at My Child, Please
text: IT seems like such a wonderful concept when you encounter it for the first time as a parent. You go to a restaurant as a family, are seated and given menus, and the waitress cheerfully turns to your children and exclaims, “And these are for you!” Their own special menus — kids’ menus! Sometimes these are little laminated things, peewee facsimiles of what Mom and Dad are holding. Sometimes these are placemats that not only tell you what foods are available but also contain mazes and word-search puzzles.

headline: Digging Deeper Into Darfur
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Experts Say Decision on Pay Reorders Legal Landscape
text: Yesterday’s Supreme Court ruling limiting the ability of workers to sue companies for pay discrimination will reorder the legal landscape for employees and employers, workplace experts said.

headline: Europe Pushes to Get Fuel From Fields
text: ARDEA, Italy — The previous growing season, this lush coastal field near Rome was filled with rows of delicate durum wheat, used to make high-quality pasta. Today it overflows with rapeseed, a tall, gnarled weedlike plant bursting with coarse yellow flowers that has become a new manna for European farmers: rapeseed can be turned into biofuel.

headline: Rice Rejects Link of Iran Arrests and Captures of Guards in Iraq
text: BERLIN, May 29  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice on Tuesday rejected linking Iran’s charges against three Iranian-Americans in Tehran to the Bush administration’s capture of members of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard in Iraq.

headline: Telling India’s Modern Women They Have Power, Even Over Their Skin Tone
text: NEW DELHI, May 29 — The modern Indian woman is independent, in charge — and does not have to live with her dark skin.

headline: Stuck in the Middle With You
text: Even as abortion, the environment and immigration -- some of the perennials in politics -- are being used by interest groups to raise the decibel level and galvanize the left and the right, some of the presidential candidates are playing to the middle. Perhaps they’ve been reading the poll numbers.

headline: A Garden in Miami, a Loft in Athens
text: For Nicholas Pisaris, an international negotiator and corporate lawyer, life is a tale of two cities. He divides his year between a home hidden in an orchid-filled garden in Miami’s historic Coconut Grove and a loft apartment with the Acropolis on the skyline.

headline: Malaysian Court Refuses to Recognize Woman’s Conversion to Christianity
text: PUTRAJAYA, Malaysia, May 30 — In a controversial victory for Islamic law over secularism, Malaysia’s highest court today refused to recognize the conversion of a Muslim-born woman to Christianity, ruling that the matter was beyond the jurisdiction of the country’s civil courts and should be handled by religious authorities.

headline: Group Makes $95.6 Billion Bid for ABN Amro
text: LONDON, May 29  The Royal Bank of Scotland Group and two other European banks made a formal $95.6 billion bid today for ABN Amro, the Dutch bank at the center of a bidding war with Barclays in the richest banking takeover.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening Soon

headline: Georgia, Alabama and a Bit of Gold Fever
text: IN retrospect, the warning signs were obvious. My heart thudded uncontrollably as I cruised along South Carolina’s verdant, rustic Route 72, and I was gripped by waves of boundless enthusiasm and irrational exuberance. Sweat beaded on my forehead and down my back — was the air-conditioning failing, or was my health? By the time I crossed into Georgia, I’d diagnosed my problem: I had gold fever — and I’d caught it from you, my readers.

headline: In First for Britain, U.S. Citizen Is Extradited on Terror Charges
text: An American citizen extradited over the weekend from England pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of conspiring to send money and military gear to associates of Al Qaeda, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Summer Breezes in, Sipping Barbera
text: WHAT’S that noise? Sort of like a whoosh, a collective exhale, a sigh of relaxation? Is it a signal that summer may finally be upon us?

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,449 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: Yankees Find a New Way to Lose
text: TORONTO, May 29 — The Yankees took infield practice before Tuesday’s game, a rare in-season crash course in fundamentals. One play they did not simulate was a runner stealing home.

headline: Lens Fluid Maker Says Link to Infection Unsolved
text: Advanced Medical Optics said yesterday morning that it had no explanation yet of why its leading contact lens care product might be contributing to an outbreak of eye infections. And it said it would be next week before it could provide Wall Street with an estimate of the financial impact of its global recall of the lens cleaner.

headline: Gunmen in Police Uniforms Kidnap 5 British Civilians
