text: BAGHDAD, May 29 — Gunmen wearing police commando uniforms abducted five British civilians from a Finance Ministry complex on Tuesday, British officials said. They seized a business consultant and his four bodyguards in an attack that revived questions about links between official security forces and criminal militias.

headline: Los Angeles Police Chief Notes Failures of Command at Rally
text: LOS ANGELES, May 29 — The clash between the police and demonstrators and journalists at an immigration rights rally on May 1 demonstrated a “command and control breakdown” so severe that at times officers did not know who was in charge, Chief William J. Bratton of the police said Tuesday.

headline: Pakistan’s Suspended Justice Tells of Facing Down Musharraf
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 29  Pakistan’s suspended chief justice, challenging his dismissal, said in an affidavit on Tuesday that he had been detained for several hours on March 9 and pressed to resign by the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, as well as senior military and intelligence officials.

headline: Overhaul of Immigration Law Could Reshape New York
text: Few places in the United States could be more deeply affected by the proposed overhaul of legal immigration than New York, say scholars and demographers of immigration.

headline: Physician, Upgrade Thyself
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Arts Space in Brooklyn to Get New Digs
text: In a move that has greater symbolic significance than mere real estate hopscotch, Galapagos Art Space, the pioneering bar and performing arts space that helped put Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on the cultural map, is moving a few neighborhoods down the East River, to Dumbo.

headline: Azerbaijan: BP Denies Playing Role in Coup Attempts
text: An executive of the energy company BP felt compelled to hold a news conference in Baku, the capital of oil-rich Azerbaijan, to deny allegations that the company had tried to stage coups in 1992 and 1993. The executive, Bill Schrader, the country president for BP, said such an action would “contradict corporate philosophy,” according to a report by the Interfax news agency. Mr. Schrader was responding to articles in Azeri newspapers and the British tabloid Daily Mail citing accusations of a former BP employee.

headline: A Rocky Start for Nevada’s New Governor
text: CARSON CITY, Nev., May 24 — Life these days for Gov. Jim Gibbons of Nevada might kindly be described as suboptimal.

headline: Scottish-Led Group Bids $95.6 Billion for ABN Amro
text: LONDON, May 29  The Royal Bank of Scotland Group and two other European banks made a formal $95.6 billion bid Tuesday for ABN Amro of the Netherlands, challenging Barclays in what would be the richest banking takeover.

headline: An Uprising Squelched and a Budget in Place, Texas Legislators Head Home to Recover
text: HOUSTON, May 29  Bidding farewell to a raucous legislative session he branded “the good, the bad and the ugly,” Gov. Rick Perry commended Texas lawmakers in Austin on Tuesday for passing a last-minute budget that cut school property taxes and expanded financing for health care, education and border security.

headline: The Rise of Globalization, a Story of Human Desires
text: Globalization has a bad image problem. It is a conceptual tar baby to which every perceived ill in the world attaches: depressed commodity prices, Asian sweat shops, child labor, fast-food imperialism, American cultural hegemony, outsourcing and global warming. A low point for the world’s most unstoppable trend came on Sept. 10, 2003, when Lee Kyung-hae, a distraught Korean farmer protesting at the World Trade Organization summit in Cancún, Mexico, plunged a knife into his own heart after shouting “Death to W.T.O.”

headline: Down to Last Out, the Mets Aren’t Down at All
text: The scorecard from last night’s Mets-San Francisco Giants game featured a bunch of Ks, a few HRs and some on-the-fly notations that, in the end, did little justice to what actually played out on the Shea Stadium grass last night.

headline: U.S. Seeks to Break Deadlock in North Korea Talks
text: BEIJING, May 30 — Arms control negotiators from the United States and China met here today in an effort to revive a stalled agreement under which North Korea would begin to dismantle its nuclear weapons program.

headline: New Jersey Public Advocate Seeks Stronger Eminent Domain Protections for Property Owners
text: TRENTON, May 29 — The New Jersey public advocate urged the Legislature on Tuesday to adopt a law that would make the use of eminent domain more equitable, while preserving it as a valuable redevelopment tool for many hard-pressed cities.

headline: Brooklyn: Man Sought in Brother’s Killing
text: A 46-year-old Brooklyn man was found shot to death in his apartment yesterday afternoon, and his brother was being sought as the leading suspect, the police said. The victim, whose name had not been released pending family notification, was shot several times in the torso. His body was found shortly after 3 p.m. in the apartment at 109 Butler Street in Boerum Hill.

headline: Russia to Issue Visas to Georgians
text: Russia resumed accepting visa applications from Georgian citizens, a step toward easing tensions that have strained relations between the countries after Georgia chose to align closely with the West. Russia also suggested the possibility of a meeting between President Vladimir V. Putin and his Georgian counterpart, Mikheil Saakashvili. Disputes remain. Russia has not lifted its import ban of Georgian wine and mineral water, or its block against direct postal service and air traffic with Georgia.

headline: The Pope’s Language Lesson
text: Vatican City

headline: Go, Eat, You Never Know
text: THEY come around every few years, these rumors that Katz’s Delicatessen is about to close or move or somehow betray itself and those of us who care about it, and our response is always the same.

headline: With Financial Tactic, Corzine Would Keep Turnpike Public, Toll Increases and All
text: Who knew that the New Jersey Turnpike, the state’s congested artery that commuters love to hate, was so beloved?

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A television column on May 19 about the prime-time fall schedules at the major television networks misspelled the surname of the star of a new Fox drama, “Canterbury’s Law.” She is Julianna Margulies, not Marguiles.

headline: Is Wal-Mart Too Cheap for Its Own Good?
text: Low prices, it turns out, can be bad for business.

headline: Truth, Fiction and Lou Dobbs
text: The whole controversy involving Lou Dobbs and leprosy started with a “60 Minutes” segment a few weeks ago.

headline: Losses All Around for American Men
text: PARIS, May 29  To figure out how Andy Roddick was faring in his first-round match Tuesday at the French Open, spectators did not have to see the score.

headline: China Triples Tax on Stock Trades
text: HONG KONG, May 30 — Chinese stocks plunged today after China’s finance ministry announced early this morning that it would triple the tax on stock trades, a move aimed at braking what many business executives and economists inside and outside China now see as a stock market bubble.

headline: Agreeing to Code of Conduct on Student Loans
text: Wells Fargo, one of the largest companies in the student loan business, has agreed to follow a code of conduct developed by the New York attorney general’s office governing relationships between lenders and universities. The code, which came as a result of a continuing investigation by the attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, prohibits practices including giving a university money or other incentives in exchange for steering students to a particular lender. Mr. Cuomo’s investigation identified instances in which loan companies paid universities based on the amounts borrowed by students, as well as questionable ties between financial aid administrators and lenders. The latest agreement means that the five largest student loan companies in the country have agreed to follow the code.

headline: Woman Accused of Killing Companion With an S.U.V.
text: A Brooklyn woman was charged with murder yesterday after she ran over her companion with her Nissan Pathfinder while he was riding a bicycle, then put the vehicle in reverse and struck him again, the police said.

headline: Having a Snack? Make It a Holiday
text: WE are, each and every one of us, standing together on the threshold of National Surimi Seafood Month. June is also the month to celebrate papayas, iced tea, frozen yogurt, candy, soul food, steakhouses and applesauce cake. And whether you eat turkeys or simply admire them, prepare to party. June is Turkey Lovers’ Month, too.

headline: Sadness in Our Hearts (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: James Takes Game Into His Hands in Fourth Quarter
text: CLEVELAND, May 29 — LeBron James was on the free-throw line with four seconds remaining in Game 4, his Cleveland Cavaliers holding a 2-point lead after a nail-biting finish worthy of whatever remained at the tip of James’s fingers.

headline: Shots Kill One and Hurt One at Party on S.I.
text: A shotgun-toting partygoer shot and killed a 17-year-old youth and injured a 15-year-old boy early yesterday during a gathering at a Staten Island housing complex, the police said.

headline: NBC Brings In Programming Help
text: NBC Universal shook up its entertainment operations today by hiring one of the hottest young production talents in television, Ben Silverman, as a chairman of both its entertainment division and its television studio.

headline: The Concerts Found Onstage While Everyone Else Takes a Break
text: For seven years, Christopher DeLaurenti went to orchestral concerts wired, wearing a leather vest with microphones nestled in the shoulders and cables running down the back. Come intermission, when the audience wandered out, Mr. DeLaurenti perked up.

headline: Now, Spitzer Is Warming to Wall St.
text: As attorney general of New York, Eliot Spitzer made a name for himself as a tough cop willing to take on deep-pocketed industries like Wall Street and insurance. Now, as governor, he may be making life a little easier for them in an effort to keep financial services in New York competitive in the global market.

headline: Clemens Slotted to Face White Sox
text: TORONTO, May 29 — The Yankees would be strutting a little more about the arrival of Roger Clemens if they were closer to first place. As it stands, they expect to put Clemens in their rotation on Monday in Chicago, with tempered expectations.

headline: Should British Academics, or Rock Bands, Boycott Israel?
text: LONDON, May 29 — In what has become an annual rite, British college teachers will debate Wednesday whether they should punish their Israeli colleagues, in solidarity with Palestinians calling for boycotts, and whether it would be anti-Semitic to do so.

headline: Correction
text: An article last Wednesday about a decision by the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, to remove at least five members of Community Board 6 who oppose the Atlantic Yards development project — which Mr. Markowitz supports — misstated the reason for the absence of a response by Mr. Markowitz. At the time the article was being reported, Mr. Markowitz could not be reached by his aides because he was on a ship at sea, had no telephone access and was not regularly checking his e-mail messages. He did not “refuse” to comment.

headline: Clinton Secures Endorsement of the Mayor of Los Angeles
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former President Bill Clinton have delivered another one-two punch that reflects their combined political power: corralling the endorsement of Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa of Los Angeles, one of the most powerful Democrats in California and among the most influential Hispanics in the nation.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A caption with an article on May 15 about the trial of Jose Padilla, who is charged with conspiring to support terrorism, incorrectly rendered the name of his mother, who was shown outside federal court in Miami. She is Estela Ortega-Lebron, not Estrela Ortega. The article also misstated the year of his transfer from military custody to civilian custody. It was 2006, not 2005.

headline: Gretchen Wyler, 75, Actress and Advocate for Animals, Dies
text: Gretchen Wyler, an actress in Broadway musicals in the 1950s and ’60s who became known in later years as an animal-rights advocate, died on Sunday at her home in Camarillo, Calif. She was 75.

headline: Young Optimists (Up to a Point) (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Justices’ Ruling Limits Suits on Pay Disparity
text: WASHINGTON, May 29 — The Supreme Court on Tuesday made it harder for many workers to sue their employers for discrimination in pay, insisting in a 5-to-4 decision on a tight time frame to file such cases. The dissenters said the ruling ignored workplace realities.

headline: What Happens if We Leave Iraq? (7 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Albany Leaders Agree to Extend Law Protecting Loft Tenants
text: ALBANY, May 29  Leaders of the State Assembly and Senate agreed on Tuesday to an extension of the loft law, which protects tenants who live in old commercial lofts from eviction, two days before the legislation was set to expire.

headline: Immigrants and Prison
text: Near the start of his Nov. 4, 2003, program on CNN, Lou Dobbs said, “One-third of the inmates now serving time in federal prisons come from some other country — one-third.” Later, he offered more details: “Coming up, we’re going to take a further look at the impact of illegal aliens. And it is an expensive proposition, particularly in our nation’s prisons. Illegal aliens, those citizens — noncitizens taking up a third of the cells in our federal penitentiaries.”

headline: Hewlett-Packard Stakes a Claim as an Information Manager
text: Vyomesh Joshi does not think of those trillions of pages crowding the Internet as the screen images they are. He sees them as the printouts they could be.

headline: Does the Man Who Put the Fire in ‘Fired!’ Still Have It?
text: If Brian Cashman is “on a big hook,” as George Steinbrenner said last week in one of those interviews he rarely grants, would the Boss fire him?

headline: All the Right Moves to Annoy the Jazz
text: SALT LAKE CITY, May 29 — Manu Ginóbili bumped and flailed, Tim Duncan coolly pivoted in the post and Tony Parker darted through every gap. After a dozen minutes of flapping arms, precise footwork and boundless energy, the Utah Jazz was flustered, and just about finished.

headline: Iran’s Giant Shoe Box of Faded Photographs, Full of the Unexpected
text: TEHRAN, May 29 — When Shadi Ghadirian was 21, she got a student job printing old photographs at the small photography museum here. She was so drawn by the 19th-century pictures of women with thick black eyebrows wearing head scarves and short skirts over baggy pants that two years later, in 2000, she began incorporating the imagery into her own photography.

headline: Equity Firm to Acquire Net Retailer
text: The CDW Corporation, a leading online computer reseller, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell itself to Madison Dearborn Partners for $7.3 billion in cash, the latest big acquisition by a private equity firm.

headline: Thai Court Clears One Party but Convicts Another
text: BANGKOK, May 30 — A Thai constitutional court found today that members of one of the country’s major political parties violated the country’s voting laws in elections last year, raising the prospect that it may be dissolved. A few hours earlier, the other major party was acquitted by the same court.

headline: Bush Takes On Conservatives Over Immigration
text: GLYNCO, Ga., May 29 — President Bush took on parts of his conservative base on Tuesday by accusing opponents of his proposed immigration measure of fear-mongering to defeat its passage in Congress.

headline: Convictions of Samsung Executives Upheld
text: SEOUL, South Korea, May 29 — An appeals court on Tuesday upheld the conviction of two senior executives at the Samsung Group on charges that they helped the only son of its reclusive chairman, Lee Kun Hee, inherit control of Samsung, the country’s largest conglomerate.

headline: The Coal Trap
text: There is a rule for judging solutions to the twin problems of energy dependence and global warming: A policy designed to solve one problem should not make the other worse. But that is a likely outcome of the many “energy independence” bills circulating in Congress that aim to build a whole new generation of coal-to-liquid plants to convert coal into automotive fuel.

headline: Mother Hangs 4 Daughters and Herself, Police Say
text: HUDSON OAKS, Tex., May 29 — A woman who was said to be struggling with depression apparently hanged her four young daughters in their North Texas mobile home early Tuesday morning before hanging herself, the authorities said.

headline: Deal for Big REIT Startles Some Experts
text: First real estate specialists were surprised by the deal. Then they were surprised by the price.

headline: Tishman Speyer in Deal for Big REIT
text: Tishman Speyer Properties, the real estate company that bought two prominent apartment complexes on Manhattan’s Lower East Side, has joined with the investment bank Lehman Brothers to buy Archstone-Smith Trust, the second-largest public apartment owner in terms of market capitalization and asset value, for $13.5 billion, the companies said today.

headline: At the Ensemble Studio Theater, the Show Must Go On
text: The auditorium at John Jay College was packed, with 600 people gathered for a three-hour memorial service featuring three dozen speakers. Curt Dempster, the founder and artistic director of the Ensemble Studio Theater, was remembered as an idiosyncratic and prickly visionary, someone who not only kept the theater alive for 35 years in its ramshackle 74-seat home on West 52nd Street but also, at times, seemed indistinguishable from it.

headline: Three Menus and a Few Sure Things
text: DOES the trolley still run down Eighth Avenue?”

headline: Touch Screen in a Table Is the Latest Wrinkle in Computers
text: Having just tried its hand at developing a digital music player, Microsoft is working on something new: digital furniture.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts yesterday about the impact of plunging CD sales on big music companies and the companies’ efforts to sell more recordings misidentified the electronic file format in which Apple’s iTunes will sell EMI’s music catalog without protection against copying. It is AAC, not MP3.

headline: Reading to a Partner That Listens on Command
text: WESTPORT, Conn. — Sofia Weinberg, 9, carefully chose a popular picture book from a table one recent afternoon, then waited in line for her turn to read to Sandy at the Westport Public Library. Within minutes, Sofia and Sandy were snuggling together on a pale blue blanket, poring over the book, “Martha Speaks.” Sofia pronounced each word carefully, yet softly. And Sandy listened attentively, occasionally panting from the heat of the day.

headline: In North Iraq, Sunni Arabs Drive Out Kurds
text: MOSUL, Iraq — The letter tossed into Mustafa Abu Bakr Muhammad’s front yard got right to the point.

headline: At Midday, You See All Types
text: IN the rest of the country “I love you” may be the three sweetest words in the English language, but in New York nothing beats, “My lunch canceled.”

headline: Mexico: Migrant Jumps to His Death in Immigration Sweep
text: A raid by the authorities on a train carrying undocumented Central American immigrants in southern Mexico ended in tragedy on Monday as a man jumped to his death from a moving rail car and a boy had his leg severed by the train’s wheels. “We were all on top of the train when the police began chasing us,” the boy, Luis Carlos Hernández, 14, from Honduras, told The Associated Press from a hospital in Veracruz, where he was recovering from an amputated right leg. The unidentified man who jumped fell onto the tracks and was decapitated, officials said.

headline: Raids in Baghdad Follow Kidnappings
text: BAGHDAD, May 30 — American and Iraqi troops raided Baghdad’s Sadr City neighborhood on Wednesday, looking for five British citizens abducted a day earlier from a nearby government building, military and diplomatic officials said.

headline: Prosecutors Accuse Banker of Fraud and Conspiracy
text: Federal prosecutors charged a high-level investment banker in Pakistan yesterday with earning more than $7.5 million in illegal profit from an insider-trading scheme that they say was run by a former Credit Suisse banker.

headline: Bumped Fliers and No Plan B
text: PHOENIX — The summer travel season is under way, and so many planes are expected to be full that, if you are bumped, you could end up waiting days for a seat on another flight to the same destination.

headline: The Bonds Paradox: Headphones, Head Games
text: With his unmistakable head bobbing to a beat, an amused Barry Bonds swept through a thicket of news media in the Giants’ clubhouse as if the music piping through his Bose headphones were more Doris Day than the latest iPod download: “Que Será Será (Whatever Will Be, Will Be).”

headline: Waiting for Steinbrenner as Free Fall Continues
text: Between innings here in Toronto, the Blue Jays sometimes run a skit on their scoreboard that’s a take-off on the George Steinbrenner character from Seinfeld. “The Big Stein” is shown from the back, in a wood-paneled office, barking orders at the Blue Jays’ mascot.

headline: Don’t Point That Menu at My Child, Please
text: In his early days as a parent he regarded children’s menus as a great thing, David Kamp writes in today’s Dining section, but he has come to conclude that the kids’ menu is regressive, encouraging youngsters to believe that there is a rigidly delineated “kids’ cuisine.”

headline: Lost City of the Incas
text: Choquequirao, a sister city of similar significance to Machu Picchu, is harder to reach, but still sufficiently free of tourists.

headline: London’s sustainable luxury
text: Clareville

headline: Kobe Bryant Asks to be Traded
text: Kobe Bryant, the NBA's most dazzling player and the star of three straight championships for the Los Angeles Lakers, has asked to be traded.

headline: Splash!
text: You look better in less if you're in pretty good shape. And if you're not, who cares?

headline: Looking at Anselm Kiefer
text: Additional images from the Anselm Kiefer exhibition at the Grand Palais in Paris.

headline: Fred D. Thompson, in His Own Words
text: A look at what Fred D. Thompson has said on the issues:

headline: VeriSign’s Chief Executive Resigns Abruptly
text: VeriSign, which manages the dot-com and dot-net domain names registry, said on Tuesday that its chief executive, Stratton D. Sclavos, had resigned for undisclosed reasons. Analysts were startled by the abrupt departure. The company gave little information about the reason for Mr. Sclavos’s departure after 12 years as chief executive.

headline: I.B.M. Borrows $11.5 Billion to Buy Back Stock
text: I.B.M. disclosed Tuesday that it was taking on $11.5 billion in debt to finance an acceleration of its stock repurchase plan, which the company believes is one of the largest such steps ever.

headline: Convictions of Samsung Executives Upheld
text: An appeals court on Tuesday upheld the conviction of two senior executives at the Samsung Group on charges that they helped the only son of its reclusive chairman, Lee Kun Hee, inherit control of Samsung, the country’s largest conglomerate.

headline: Are Online Ad Firms Overpriced?
text: The debate continues: Are the recent deals involving online-advertising firms — Google–Doubleclick, Microsoft–aQuantive, WPP–24/7 Real Media — signs of a bubble, or wise, strategic, long-term plays?

headline: India Prepares for Its Biggest I.P.O.
text: A real estate developer, DLF, on Tuesday kicked off the sales effort for an initial public offering to raise $2.4 billion, the largest yet in India.

headline: Has a Management Buyout Bid Put Bradley’s in Play?
text: Bradley Pharmaceuticals‘ founder and chief executive wants to take his company private, but he may have inadvertently put it into play on Tuesday with a $352.6 million bid, Forbes says. Bradley’s stock soared 21.2 percent Tuesday, rising $3.91, to $22.35, a premium to the $21.50 offered by the company’s chief executive, Daniel Glassman.

headline: More Defections from Coles Consortium Are Rumored
text: The private equity consortium bidding for the Australian retailer Coles Group, responding to rumors that two more members had pulled out, said on Wednesday it could not confirm whether all four participants were still in the group.

headline: Viacom Said to Sell Famous Music to Sony
text: Viacom has agreed to sell its Famous Music publishing business to Sony/ATV Music Publishing for about $370 million, the Wall Street Journal reported, adding that a deal may be announced Wednesday.

headline: Proxy Firm Deals Blow to Biomet Buyout, Report Says
text: In the latest example of resistance to private equity buyouts, the deal for the medical-device maker Biomet got a thumb downs from the influential proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services, which recommended Biomet holders vote down a $10.9 billion private-equity deal for the company, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Now, Spitzer Is Warming to Wall Street
text: As attorney general of New York, Eliot Spitzer made a name for himself as a tough cop willing to take on deep-pocketed industries like Wall Street and insurance. Now, writes The New York Times’s Jenny Anderson, as governor, he may be making life a little easier for them in an effort to keep financial services in New York competitive in the global market.

headline: Is Russia the Next V.C. Hot Spot?
text: Thanks in part to such increasingly global and sophisticated management, tech startups in Russia are coming of age, according to BusinessWeek. Indeed, after years of promise and potential, Russia finally looks poised to become the next hot destination for foreign V.C. investment.

headline: An Unofficial Fan Club No More
text: The Web site dedicated to the pole vaulting internet star has closed down, apparently bowing to her complaints lodged from the front page of The Washington Post on Tuesday. Renaming itself the “Former Unofficial Allison Stokke Fan Page,” the site left a message for her:

headline: Black’s New York Pad Worth Triple What He Paid, Witness Says
text: A New York real estate appraiser testified Tuesday in the federal fraud trial of Conrad Black that the Manhattan apartment bought by the former media baron in 2000 had a market value nearly three times the $3 million he paid the newspaper company for it.

headline: Airband Snags $12.5 Million in venture capital
text: Airband Communications said Tuesday that it had received $12.5 million in its latest round of venture funding. M/C Venture Partners of Boston was the lead investor in Dallas-based Airband, which provides wireless broadband networks for businesses.

headline: CBS Said to Buy Last.fm for $280 Million
text: CBS is buying a popular social-networking Website organized around musical tastes for $280 million, combining a traditional broadcast giant with an early leader in online radio, according to the Los Angeles Times. CBS is expected to announce today that it has acquired London-based Last.fm, which claims more than 15 million monthly users, including more than 4 million in the United States, the report said.

headline: Dynegy Sells Plant to Gates-Backed Venture
text: A joint venture between Cascade Investments, a private equity firm controlled by Microsoft‘s chairman, Bill Gates, and PNM Resources will buy a gas-fired power plant in Texas from Dynegy for $467.5 million.

headline: Scrutiny Aside, Google’s DoubleClick Deal Is Likely to Pass Muster
text: There was little doubt that the Federal Trade Commission would thoroughly investigate Google‘s planned purchase of DoubleClick, but, says BusinessWeek, there’s even less doubt that the FTC will eventually sign off on the $3.1 billion deal for the online advertiser.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Backs Rival Start-Up
text: Deutsche Telekom said it was backing Web telephone-calling start-up Jajah, embracing a technology that undercuts rates for the German telecommunication giant’s established long-distance and mobile phone businesses.

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald Brings Together Brokers in $1.3 Billion Move
text: Cantor Fitzgerald agreed to sell BGC Partners to its listed ESpeed unit for $1.3 billion in stock, combining the voice and electronic bond trading divisions a month after rejecting a takeover offer for ESpeed.

headline: British Want Their Hedge Fund Access
text: The British want more hedge fund access, and that might suit the Financial Services Authority just fine. Just 10 percent of the public in Britain think the asset class should be the sole domain of the professional investor, with the majority favoring wider access, according to a study commissioned by F&C.

headline: More Pain at Goldman’s Flagship Hedge Fund
text: It often seems as if Goldman Sachs, the highly profitable securities firm, knows how to pluck money from thin air. But the firm is losing its touch with Global Alpha, its flagship hedge fund, which manages money for some of Goldman’s wealthiest clients and employees.

headline: Backing Up Your Files
text: David Pogue reviews three removable cartridge systems.

headline: Kravis Seeks to Allay Canada’s Fears on BCE Bid
text: Amid rising political tension in Canada over a recent spate of foreign takeovers, Henry R. Kravis, co-founder of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, sought Tuesday to play down the level of his firm’s involvement in the bidding war for BCE and offer reassurances he was not masterminding the acquisition of the country’s biggest telephone company.

headline: The World Bank and the Goldman Connection
text: Though Tuesday’s nomination of Robert B. Zoellick as the new president of the World Bank is newsworthy in its own right, there’s a Wall Street angle as well: It marks yet another top political post for a Goldman Sachs alumnus.

headline: Jihadists Fill Palestinian Power Vacuum
text: A standoff between the Lebanese Army and Islamists has focused attention on a jihadist element.

headline: ICE Sweetens CBOT Offer With Settlement Deal
text: IntercontinentalExchange, hoping to bolster its unsolicited bid for the Chicago Board of Trade, said Wednesday it had reached a deal with the Chicago Board Options Exchange to settle a longstanding dispute over trading rights at the CBOT. The deal applies only if ICE merges with CBOT.

headline: 2008: Looking Back on War Votes
text: The New York Times Magazine preview now available is itself a preview of a new book by Jeff Gerth and Don Van Natta Jr., former and current Timesmen, respectively. Their full book, “Her Way: The Hopes and Ambitions of Hillary Rodham Clinton,” will be published by Little, Brown next week. In the adapted article, the investigative reporters examine Mrs. Clinton’s Oct. 11, 2002 vote authorizing the use of force in Iraq—calling into question whether she read the national intelligence estimate—and the subsequent political fallout and shifts on the issue.

headline: Commenting on the Commentators
text: Funny thing happened on the way to last weekend’s Super Sunday of auto racing telecasts. The announcing crews seemed as if they had been switched in the delivery room.

headline: Leak Prosecutor Says Plame Was Covert
text: Valerie Plame Wilson’s covert status at the C.I.A. is old news for many observers of the inquiry into the leaking of her identity. One side of the political divide argued that she was actually on desk duty at Langley at the time of Robert Novak’s infamous column naming her, which would mean that the leaking of her identity was, if not exactly nice, not illegal either. The other side, and Ms. Wilson herself, said the opposite.

headline: It’s Not Paranoia If They’re Really Out to Get You
text: — Tobin Harshaw

headline: FIA exonerates McLaren and clarifies team orders
text: The FIA has obviously decided to waste no time in keeping anyone in suspense on this McLaren team orders situation by coming to an immediate, categoric and very clear decision on the affair. In fact, it has taken the opportunity to very clearly lay out a policy, it seems to me, that sets a precedent for what is and is not acceptable in the way of team orders. In fact, retrospectively, I suspect that one of the reasons the FIA jumped on this problem was certainly to clear the air over accusations against McLaren and to take this as an opportunity to wipe out any possibility of suspicions.

headline: Stuck in the Middle With You
text: There is far more nuance in the public’s views of social issues than suggested by the characterization of the country as a divide of red states and blue states.

headline: Ernst & Young Won’t Face Criminal Charges
text: Update: A grand jury in Manhattan indicted four Ernst & Young employees on charges including conspiracy to defraud the Internal Revenue Service, tax evasion, making false statements to the I.R.S., and impeding and impairing the lawful functioning of the I.R.S. See the updated story by The New York Times here.

headline: Thompson’s on the Move Toward a Run
text: We’ve now confirmed that former Tennessee Senator Fred Thompson is taking formal steps toward a presidential bid, through the formation next week of a “testing-the-waters” committee that will allow him to do some fundraising.

headline: Evercore Bulks Up With Two Bankers
text: Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, has wooed two investment bankers away from bulge-bracket firms in what might be the start of an aggressive expansion strategy. The firm, which went public less than a year ago, said Tuesday it had hired Francois Maisonrouge, who had been a managing director and chair of life sciences at Credit Suisse, and Mark Vander Ploeg, who was previously a vice chairman of investment banking at Merrill Lynch. Both join Evercore as senior managing directors.

headline: Hedge Fund Signals Support for Clear Channel Deal
text: In their tortured quest to take Clear Channel Communications private, the radio giant’s two bidders have locked up a key constituent. One of the company’s largest shareholders disclosed Wednesday that it would approve the latest version of the deal, which has dragged amid resistance from some investors.

headline: A Victory for Hamas
text: Steven R. Weisman discusses the Palestinian elections and the Bush administration's strategy of promoting victory in the Middle East.

headline: The U.S. Reaction
text: Steven R. Weisman discusses President Bush's reaction to the Hamas victory in the Palestinian elections.

headline: REIT on the Money?
text: There’s a lot of real estate speculation on Wall Street.

headline: Training Elite Troops
text: Thom Shanker reports on the training progress of elite Iraqi and Afghani soldiers. (Produced by Matthew Orr)

headline: Reader Responses
text: The following are excerpts of reader responses to David Leonhardt's May 30 column on Lou Dobbs:

headline: Hussein's Frantic Flight
text: Michael R. Gordon reports that even as the U.S. invaded, Saddam Hussein saw Iraqi unrest as the top threat.

headline: Saddam's Defenses
text: Michael R. Gordon reports that even as the U.S. invaded, Saddam Hussein saw Iraqi unrest as the top threat.

headline: The Weapons Question
text: Michael R. Gordon reports that even as the U.S. invaded, Saddam Hussein saw Iraqi unrest as the top threat.

headline: Steps to Avoid War
text: Michael R. Gordon reports that even as the U.S. invaded, Saddam Hussein saw Iraqi unrest as the top threat.

headline: Book Sourcing
text: Michael R. Gordon explains his reporting for a series of articles adapted from his book, "Cobra II: The Inside Story of the invasion and Occupation of Iraq."

headline: Inadvertent Assistance
text: Michael R. Gordon reports on disagreements within the U.S. command about the Iraqi military threat.

headline: Enough Troops?
text: Michael R. Gordon reports on disagreements within the U.S. command about the Iraqi military threat.

headline: Strategic Differences
text: Michael R. Gordon reports on disagreements within the U.S. command about the Iraqi military threat.

headline: U.S. Divided on Iraq Plan
text: Michael R. Gordon reports on disagreements within the U.S. command about the Iraqi military threat.

headline: Nanjing Massacre
text: The Times's Howard French reports how China continues to unveil layers of its horrid history with neighboring Japan. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: Back in the Streets
text: Craig Smith, the European correspondent for The Times, explains how the current protests in France are related to last year's riots.

headline: Diseases on the Brink: Polio
text: The Times's Celia W. Dugger and Donald G. McNeil Jr. discuss five diseases on the brink of eradication. (Producer: Kassie Bracken)

headline: Jimmy Carter: Eradicating Trachoma
text: As part of a Times series on diseases on the brink of eradication, former President Jimmy Carter discusses The Carter Center's work to combat Trachoma in Ethiopia. (Producer: Craig Duff)

headline: Shanghai Journal: At the Dump
text: Howard W. French explores the mess when scavengers sift through the trash at Shanghai's largest dump.(Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: A Disease's Hidden Agony
text: Times reporter Donald G. McNeil Jr. discusses the eradication efforts for lymphatic filariasis. (Producer: Kassie Bracken)

headline: France Drops Labor Law
text: President Jacques Chirac announced that a contested labor law would be rescinded, handing a victory to student groups and labor unions. (Produced by Naka Nathaniel and Ursula Pawlowski)

headline: Iran's Nuclear Status
text: The Times's David Sanger reports that the White House and international community must now decide how to respond.  (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: ‘L’Eau Life’
text: L’eau Life began as an experiment in animating water in motion with water color.

headline: Nuclear Jihad: Khan's Clients
text: Top international officials discuss what the transfer of technology by Khan to rogue states means for international security. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

headline: Nuclear Jihad: Khan's Flights
text: Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf discusses how he first began to suspect Khan was up to no good after he became Army Chief of Staff in 1998. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

headline: Nuclear Jihad: The CIA
text: CIA veteran Art Brown, experts and reporter David Sanger discuss the victories and failures of the US intelligence community in tracking and stopping AQ Khan. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

headline: Nuclear Jihad: AQ Khan
text: Pakistani leaders, experts, reporters and acquaintances of AQ Khan help us understand who he was and how he was able to do what he did. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

headline: Nuclear Jihad: Making a Bomb
text: New York Times reporters William Broad and David Sanger and Harvard's Matthew Bunn explain some of the science involved in making a nuclear bomb. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

headline: Nuclear Jihad: Black Market
text: A former intelligence officer, experts and Mohamed ElBaradei of the IAEA discuss the threat of others filling the void left by the Khan network. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

headline: Nuclear Jihad: Khan's Legacy
text: Top US and UN Officials, experts and reporter David Sanger explain that today's nuclear reality might be even more dangerous than during the Cold War. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

headline: Nuclear Jihad: Terror
text: The State Department Official for Arms Control and other experts discuss the threat of nuclear attacks by terrorists and what is being done to prevent them. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

headline: Nuclear Jihad: Iran
text: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, a former defense intelligence officer and David Sanger of the New York Times discuss the question of a nuclear-armed Iran. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

headline: Nuclear Jihad:  Pakistan's Weapons
text: Pakistani leaders, a CIA veteran, experts and reporter David Sanger discuss the threat of Pakistan's nuclear weapons falling into the wrong hands. (Producer: Jason Maloney)

headline: Preview: Nuclear Jihad Documentary
text: Nuclear Jihad airs Monday, April 17, at 8pm on the Discovery Times channel. (Video courtesy Discovery Times Channel/CBC)

headline: Chinese President Meets With Bush
text: President Bush and President Hu Jintao of China broke little new ground on a host of issues, The Times's David E. Sanger reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: Preparing for War: A Mock Iraq
text: The Times's Dexter Filkins reports on the national training facility in Fort Irwin, Calif., where U.S. soldiers simulate guerilla warfare.

headline: Video: Russia Rebuilds Grozny
text: Kyle Crichton of the Foreign desk discusses the current rebuilding efforts in Grozny, Chechnya's capital.

headline: Cheney's Remarks About Russia
text: Vice President Dick Cheney's remarks appeared to lay down new markers for a relationship that has become strained.

headline: How to Help Struggling Palestinians
text: The Times's correspondent Steven R. Weisman reports from the UN that the European Union and the United States differ on how to aid the Palestinian people. Producer: Emily Hager

headline: Baghdad Force to Be Unified
text: Dexter Filkins reports that senior Iraqi leaders are preparing a restructuring of Baghdad's security brigades.

headline: Universities in Crisis
text: The value of a bachelor's degree is plummeting in France's archaic state-owned university system. (Producer: Emily B. Hager)

headline: Religion Returns to Chechnya
text: The Times's C.J. Chivers reports on the revival of a dance ritual among  Chechnya's Sufi Muslims, a sect that is also erecting the region's largest mosque.    Producer: Adam B. Ellick

headline: Tracking the Spread of HIV
text: A U.N. report indicates that the number of people infected with H.I.V. may have stabilized globally since the 1990s, but the disease is still proliferating in several individual countries.

headline: Intense Hunt Ends in Zarqawi's Death
text: The death of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, Al Qaeda's leader in Iraq, came after intense detective work by the American military, The Times's Mark Mazzetti reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: Good News for Bush on Zarqawi
text: The killing of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi is the best news for the White House on Iraq in months or years, The Times's Jim Rutenberg reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: Zarqawi's Death May Spur Violence
text: Commanders at the Pentagon predict that Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's death will cause an upsurge in violence in Iraq in coming days, The Times's Thom Shanker reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: Uprising in Uzbekistan
text: C.J. Chivers examines newly available videotape of the May 2005 uprising in Uzbekistan. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: The U.N. Condemns Missile Tests
text: All 15 members of the United Nations Security Council agree to condemn North Korea for firing test missiles into the Sea of Japan. (Producer: Emily B. Hager)

headline: Chechen Rebel Chief Is Killed
text: Shamil Basayev claimed responsibility for some of Russia's worst terror attacks, including the Beslan school siege.

headline: Bush and Putin's Relationship
text: As President Bush prepares to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday in Russia, his embrace of the Russian leader has turned chilly. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: U.N. Slowly Tackles Lebanon Crisis
text: The United Nations Security Council meets for the third time to discuss solutions to the Lebanon crisis. (Producer: Shayla Harris)

headline: Staying Put
text: As Lebanese and foreigners were forced to flee, Israelis in the northern part of their country stayed put as Hezbollah's missiles continued to fall.

headline: The West Bank Question
text: With daily rocket fire coming from Lebanon and Gaza, Israel's premier can expect greater resistance in pursuing any plan to withdraw. (Produced by Naka Nathaniel)

headline: Arab Nations Hesitant on Cease-Fire
text: Surprisingly, some Arab countries do not seem to be in a hurry to demand a cease-fire in the Middle East conflict, The Times's Helene C. Cooper reports. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: Bomb Shelter Wedding
text: What happens when you get married in a town evacuated because of bombardment? The press outnumbers the guests. (Produced by Naka Nathaniel)

headline: Not Choosing Sides
text: Arab Israelis in Nazareth are caught in the middle of the conflict after a Hezbollah rocket killed two children. (Producer: Naka Nathaniel)

headline: Small Bites in Barcelona
text: A tour of five Catalonian restaurants in Barcelona, Spain.

headline: Kobe Bryant’s Delicate Dance Ends
text: [UPDATE, 4:55 PM ET: Kobe Bryant did away with all the diplomacy this afternoon, demanding a trade during a radio interview in New York. Asked if there was anything the Lakers could do to keep him, he responded: “No, bro.” More on what he said and the possible deals that would send him away at TrueHoops.]

headline: United Nations Calls for Cease-Fire
text: The Times's Warren Hoge details today's United Nations call for a cease-fire. (Producer: Adam B. Ellick)

headline: Getting Ready to Go In
text: A small apple orchard away from the Lebanese border, Israeli troops prepared on Friday to secure an area in Lebanon being used by Hezbollah to launch rockets into northern Israel.

headline: Rattling the Border
text: For an eleventh day, the Israeli-Lebanese border shook with their  rocket fire and artillery shells.

headline: Smoke and Tears
text: July 23 - Nearly a hundred Hezbollah missiles fell into northern Israel on Sunday setting off brush fires that blanketed the town of Kiryat Shmona in smoke.

headline: A Long, Difficult Summer
text: One debate is whether democratization is spreading, or whether other countries believe the United States is tied down. (Producer: John Files)

headline: Historic Elections in Congo
text: Voters in the Democratic Republic of the Congo are heading to the polls for a historic presidential election.  It is the first in 46 years. (Producers: Emily B. Hager and Courtenay Morris)

headline: Rocket Fire on the Border
text: Jerusalem bureau chief Steven Erlanger reports on rocket fire along the border between Israel and Lebanon.  (Producers: Emily B. Hager and Michael Kamber)

headline: Israel's Targets in Gaza
text: The Times's Greg Myre reports from the Gaza Strip that Israeli forces are using a new tactic against the Palestinians. (Producers: Emily B. Hager and Michael Kamber)

headline: Israel's Campaign in the Gaza Strip
text: The Times's Greg Myre reports from the Gaza Strip on Israel's latest incursion into Palestinian Territory. (Producer: Michael Kamber and Emily B. Hager)

headline: Aid Convoy in Lebanon
text: Archie Tse travels with a group delivering aid to southern Lebanon. (Produced by Archie Tse and Jigar Mehta)

headline: Bombing in Beirut
text: Hassan M. Fattah reports on the bombing of a neighborhood in southern Beirut on Thursday, Aug. 3. (Produced by Archie Tse)

headline: Missile Attacks in Lebanon
text: Hassan M. Fattah reports from Quzai, a fishing village south of Beirut, where rockets fell on Friday, Aug. 4, and destroyed much of the fleet. (Produced by: Archie Tse)

headline: The Battle for Baghdad
text: The Times's Dexter Filkins chronicles the recent violence in Baghdad and the responses of the American and Iraqi governments. (Producer: Kassie Bracken)

headline: Deadly Hezbollah Strike in Israel
text: The Times's Richard A. Oppel Jr. reports from Kfar Giladi, Israel, where a Hezbollah rocket attack on Sunday, Aug. 6, killed 12 army reservists. (Producer: Michael Kamber)

headline: Surviving in Bourj al-Barajneh
text: Archie Tse reports from Bourj al-Barajneh, a Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon.  (Produced by: Emily B. Hager and Archie Tse)

headline: Shelling in Northern Israel
text: Richard A. Oppel Jr. reports on an Arab Israeli family under siege from Hezbollah attacks in northern Israel. (Produced by Michael Kamber)

headline: American Airlines Flight 115
text: Passengers arriving from Heathrow airport in London described their journey to New York.(Produced by Kassie Bracken, Jigar Mehta and Matthew Orr)

headline: Investigating the Terror Plot
text: British officials had been the suspects for months, officials said. (Produced by Emily Hager)

headline: Iraqi Reconstruction Projects
text: James Glanz travels to two small Iraqi towns and reports on the reconstruction negotiations between Iraqi shieks and U.S. military officials. (Producer: Kassie Bracken)

headline: Beirut, After the Cease-Fire
text: The Times's Archie Tse reports from a park in central Beirut where refugees began departing for their homes on Monday.

headline: Israel, After the Cease-Fire
text: Greg Myre reports from Northern Israel on the aftermath of the cease-fire. (Producers: Michael Kamber and Jigar Mehta)

headline: Iraq's Economy
text: The Times's Damien Cave highlights Iraq's skyrocketing inflation by visiting a gas station in Baghdad. Producer: Adam B. Ellick

headline: Bounty for Edwards?
text: The movie “Pirates of the Caribbean” may be hauling in cash at the box office this summer, but Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards may benefit from a real-life sunken treasure found in a 17th century shipwreck. Tampa-based Odyssey Marine Exploration recently announced finding what could be the richest shipwreck ever – a 350-year old sunken ship containing 500,000 gold and silver Colonial-era coins worth hundreds of millions of dollars in the Atlantic off the English coast.

headline:
A Grape That Gets Around,
But Still Gets Overlooked
text: I spend a lot of time thinking about all sorts of wines, but I confess I haven’t thought much recently about pinot gris. For whatever reason, it’s a wine that I’ve largely ignored, except in its Italian manifestation, pinot grigio, which I wrote about last summer. But recently I’ve had some delicious pinot gris wines, all from different places, and I’ve wondered whether it’s just me who lost track of what can be a compelling category of wines.

headline: Investment Bankers and The China Syndrome
text: After the Lenovo Group acquired I.B.M.‘s personal-computer division two years ago, many investment bankers started to believe that Chinese companies would soon increase their overseas acquisitions. And they have — but not by much, Reuters reports. The analysis of China’s buying habits comes amid a steep selloff in the Chinese stock markets, volatility that could make it even harder for Chinese firms to broker cross-border deals.

headline: Paris, via New York, comes to Berlin
text: The posters said it all: “The most beautiful French are coming from New York to Berlin.” Its true! The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York has lent a fabulous collection of its 19th century French artists to the Neue Nationalgalerie in Berlin. Starting June 1, and lasting until October 7, more than 150 works are on display. They range from Ingres and Corot, Courbet and Manet to Degas, Pissarro, Monet and Cezanne. Its a very, very big exhibition of French Impressionists. MOMA has also lent Berlin sculpturs by Rodin and Maillol. The Nationalgalerie, located close to Berlin’s famed Philharmonie, home to one of the world’s great orchestras, has had a great relationship with MOMA. Just a warning. Its coming up to the holiday season. Berlin is becoming one of the big tourist attractions. The queues will be long. Check out the museum website for special offers or how to book tickets in advance. Also Tel (00 49) 30 226 2651, or EMail: nng@smb.spk-berlin.de

headline: Dragon boating revelry
text: Hong Kong’s annual dragon boat races combine a fast, furious sport, ancient Chinese lore and an all-out carnival atmosphere.There will be races all month (more info below), but the Stanley races, which take place June 19, are the biggest and most popular. More than 200 teams compete from 8 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. But the party — on hired junks and yachts ringing the bay, and at packed seaside pubs and restaurants — goes on late into the night.Dragon boating is a little like Western rowing, only spiced up with the chaos of a Chinatown street festival. Up to 20 paddlers cram, in pairs, into long, narrow wooden boats that — to the delight of onlookers — are apt to tipping over at the hands of the unskilled. The front is adorned with a colorful, ornate dragon’s head. This is also where the drummer sits, to beat out time for the rowers to row to. And what’s there not to love about a sport with a designated drummer? At the back is the steerer, like a coxswain.The races are short — sprints, actually — done in heats. It’s simple enough that everyone from the little kids playing on the beach to the drunk guys on their yachts can follow the action.

headline: No Gagging the Gags
text: Talking about comedy writing last time, I omitted an interesting phenomenon thereto: the fact that the gag-writer’s brain often works independently of his conscious mind. Sometimes alarmingly so. Because the topical joke-writer’s livelihood depends on his ability to crank out — if the show is on daily — good, current stuff, fast and for immediate use. And after a great deal of this, there’s something that develops and takes on a life of its own.

This isn’t the first time Nick has examined the issue — he wrote a column from the region in Dec. 2004. , but you don’t get a very accurate picture of what’s going on inside North Korea when you’re in the company of government officials.

headline: Your Comments on my China Religion Column
text: O.K., so the Thursday column is actually about more than China and religion. In a larger sense it’s about the emergence of a bit more personal space, a bit more rule of law, and the hope that China will follow Taiwan and South Korea toward greater pluralism and freedom. But the most striking manifestation of that trend for now is the boom in religion in China, and the way most people in most of the country can worship freely most of the time. And I agree with Li Baiguang that in 20 or 30 years China could have several hundred million Christians, making it the largest Christian country in the world. In most of the world, economic development has eroded religious faith, but in China it’s working the other way and there’s a considerable parallel with South Korea and its embrace of Christianity in the 20th century.

headline: Spoleto Festival U.S.A.: An Italian Ghost in Charleston
text: Charleston, S.C., – There is a ghost at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. here, and it is not part of any stage production. The composer Gian Carlo Menotti, who founded the festival in 1977 as an offshoot of his Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, threatened for years, loudly and acrimoniously, to split with the American festival, and he finally did so in 1993. But Mr. Menotti, who died in February at 95, will be honored in a free concert tomorrow morning, and he has figured prominently in conversation during the festival’s early days.

headline: Canada: Clothing Maker Moves Operations
text: Gildan Activewear, a maker of clothing like T-shirts, tank tops and golf shirts, said it would close two sock plants in North Carolina and lay off 520 employees as part of its plan to shift production to lower-cost factories in other countries. The North Carolina factories will close by the end of August, leaving one American plant, in Hillsville, Va., for making socks. Gildan is based in Montreal.

headline: Coca-Cola and PepsiCo Agree to Curb Animal Tests

headline: Lottery Numbers
Evening in Bryant Park a Nice Change for Yankee Fans
text: Bryant Park had the feel of Yankee Stadium last night. Vendors sold hot dogs, peanuts and Cracker Jacks. Thousands of fans, many in Yankees hats and T-shirts, covered the grass. They even sang the national anthem. The only thing missing was the Yankees. But that did not seem to matter. Their game against the Blue Jays in Toronto was being shown live on a large television screen.

headline: Louisiana Sets Deadline for Storm Damage Claims
text: The Road Home, the Louisiana grant program for homeowners who lost their houses to Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, is expected to cost far more than the $7.5 billion provided by the federal government, in part because many more families have applied than officials had anticipated.

headline: Justice Department Investigation Broadens
text: An internal investigation at the Justice Department into whether politics influenced hiring practices is being expanded after last week’s testimony by a former senior aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales. The department’s inspector general and the top lawyer at the agency’s Office of Professional Responsibility notified the chairmen of the Senate and House Judiciary Committees in a letter that “we have expanded the scope of our investigation.” The inquiry by the two internal units will widen to examine accusations of wrongdoing by the aide, Monica M. Goodling, who said in House testimony last week that she had “crossed the line,” allowing partisan considerations to affect hiring for lower-level civil service jobs.

headline: TB Patient Is Related to C.D.C. Expert on Disease
text: The man infected with a dangerous and hard-to-treat form of tuberculosis, who potentially exposed several hundred airline passengers to the disease, is the son-in-law of a microbiologist who studies tuberculosis at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.

text: The stock market yesterday clawed back to where it was seven years ago during the heady days of technology and the Internet boom — and it had to overcome an overnight sell-off in China to get there.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,454 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: What I Think About Evolution
text: Washington

headline: Royal Opera Steps Into New Act: DVD Maker
text: In opera’s latest expansion into the world of video, the Royal Opera House at Covent Garden in London said yesterday that it had bought a leading maker and producer of performance DVDs, Opus Arte.

headline: Sam Kagel, 98, Mediator of 1982 N.F.L. Strike, Is Dead
text: Sam Kagel, a mediator and arbitrator whose career settling labor disputes ranged from the rowdy San Francisco docks of the 1930s to the N.F.L. fields of the early 1980s, died on May 21 in San Francisco. He was 98.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A film review last Thursday about “Pirates of the Caribbean: At World’s End” misstated a word in a line spoken by the character Lord Beckett early in the film. He says, “The immaterial has become immaterial,” not that it has become “material.” The review also misidentified the site of a meeting of the Pirate Brethren Court. It is Shipwreck Cove, not Singapore.

headline: Colleagues Honor Slain Russian Journalist With a Book and Demand Justice
text: MOSCOW, May 30  The independent Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta on Wednesday officially began sales of a bound collection of articles and commentary by Anna Politkovskaya, its special correspondent who was killed last year, and renewed its demand for an honest investigation of the crime.

headline: Manhattan: Examination of Flight Delays
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has set up a task force to find ways to reduce flight delays at the region’s three main airports, authority officials said yesterday. The group will include airline executives and federal, state and city government officials. The Port Authority, which operates Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports in Queens and Newark Liberty International Airport, will lead the group.

headline: Housing Plan Puts Idea of East New York’s Revival to the Test
text: As locations go, things do not get much more impressive than Block 4375, Lot 1 in East New York, Brooklyn.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption in some copies on Tuesday with a sports article about Anaheim’s victory against Ottawa in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals misidentified the Ducks’ player in front of the Senators’ net when his team tied the score in the third period. It was Brad May  not Ryan Getzlaf, who scored the goal but who was not in the picture.

headline: For This Bus You Must Be Just the Ticket
text: A TRIP aboard the jitney, the luxury coach to the Hamptons, calls for a style blend of the buoyant and sleek. Beachbound New Yorkers lining up for the bus at 69th Street and Lexington Avenue last Friday to kick off Memorial Day weekend pulled off the mix, wearing tiny shorts or billowy sundresses with jeweled maharini sandals and matching gem-tone nail lacquer. Others were ultracasual in Pocahontas-style moccasins — the new Uggs — and carried a requisite status bag. These ranged from outsize canvas carryalls to pony-skin wheelies, Goyard logo totes and even a white leather Saint Laurent Muse.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article yesterday about Congressional districts where Republican supporters of the war are taking political heat referred incorrectly to a House resolution on the president’s decision to increase troops in Iraq, a decision opposed by Representative Mark Steven Kirk, Republican of Illinois. The resolution opposed the president’s plan, it did not back it.

headline: Newark: Transit Fares to Increase
text: A fare increase averaging 9.6 percent will take effect on New Jersey Transit trains and buses tomorrow. The increase, approved in April, will be the third since 2002. The income will help the agency close a $60 million budget gap and expand service, New Jersey Transit said. Train and interstate bus tickets will increase by 9.9 percent, while the price of tickets for a single one-zone bus and for local light-rail service will rise by 8 percent, to $1.35 from $1.25. Each weekday, New Jersey Transit serves 857,000 riders, a record high, the agency said.

headline: An Answer to Help Clear His Fog
text: For the past seven years, Mel Renfro, a former star defensive back for the Dallas Cowboys and a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame, has wondered why he wakes up most mornings with a malaise that seems only to be getting worse. Last week he got a clearer idea, and reassurance that he is not alone.

headline: Pakistan: 4 Arrested in Killing of Judge’s Aide
text: The police arrested four men in the killing of Syed Hammad Raza, who worked as the chief of staff to Pakistan’s suspended chief justice. The interior minister, Aftab Ahmed Khan Sherpao, said the four belonged to a gang of robbers from Kashmir and shot Mr. Raza when they broke into his house in Islamabad on May 14. The police, who said they had recovered the gun used in the shooting and a stolen watch, maintained from the start that the killing was robbery-related. Mr. Raza’s wife denied there had been a robbery attempt and termed the shooting politically motivated because of Mr. Raza’s close association with the suspended justice, Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry.

headline: Calendar
text: Growing Roses

headline: New York City Expands Test Program in Schools
text: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced yesterday that the city school system would spend $80 million over five years on a battery of new standardized tests to begin this fall for most of New York City’s 1.1 million public school students.

headline: Time Wasted? Perhaps It’s Well Spent
text: WASTING time gets a bad rap. We pester our children not to do it; we take pride in the multitasking that ensures we never do it; and we bristle at our fellow workers, shop clerks and just about anyone else who slows us down by doing it.

headline: California: Whales Presumed at Sea
text: Two humpback whales may have found their way back into the Pacific Ocean through San Francisco Bay after wandering off their migration path for more than two weeks. The mother and her calf have not been seen since sunset Tuesday, when they were spotted swimming in the bay. They may have slipped under the Golden Gate Bridge overnight and into open sea, said Bernadette Fees, a deputy director with the California Department of Fish and Game. The whales attracted crowds to the banks of the Sacramento River as they meandered upstream starting about May 13.

headline: From Hitmaker to Defendant, a Long and Winding Road
text: In December 2002 the British journalist Mick Brown was driven by Phil Spector’s chauffeur in Phil Spector’s white Rolls-Royce to Phil Spector’s gloomy castle in Alhambra, Calif., for a spooky interview with Phil Spector, who wore black silk pajamas and made a grand entrance to the strains of Handel.

headline: Palm to Sell Device That Won’t Fit in the Palm
text: CARLSBAD, Calif., May 30  Fifteen years after pioneering personal computers that nestled comfortably in a user’s hand, Palm reversed itself Wednesday and said that it would begin selling a two-handed laptop-size machine called the Foleo.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Tuesday about a push by lawmakers to pass subsidies for coal misidentified the state represented by the Republican Senator Larry E. Craig, who is a supporter of the coal-to-liquid fuel concept. It is Idaho, not Wyoming.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. Can I use bold color in a small space?

headline: The Yankees Try Anything in a Search for an Identity
text: TORONTO, May 30 — The Yankees were not required to come to the ballpark Wednesday until an hour before the game, and they canceled batting practice in an effort to relax. “We’re going to padlock the batting cage,” Manager Joe Torre said.

headline: Loitering Arrest of Panhandler Is Dismissed as Unlawful
text: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 30  A homeless panhandler arrested for loitering after asking a police officer for a dollar won a legal battle on Wednesday when a City Court judge dismissed the charge, finding the arrest unconstitutional.

headline: Swimmers Who Avoid the Deep Have a New Camcorder Choice
text: Aspiring Cousteaus can now record all of their undersea adventures on video, provided their adventures don’t take them deeper than five feet.

headline: Israel: Peres Seeks a Chance to Serve Again
text: Shimon Peres, a leading figure of Israeli political life, said he would again ask Parliament to elect him president, a symbolic and largely powerless post. Mr. Peres, 83, is supported by his latest party, the centrist Kadima, but he may not win the secret ballot on June 13. In a shock, Mr. Peres, left, lost in the last election, in July 2000, to Moshe Katsav, 61, a relatively unknown Likud politician who is ending his term accused of rape and sexual misconduct. Other candidates are Colette Avital from the Labor Party and Reuven Rivlin of Likud. “The president does not have much authority,” Mr. Peres said. “But he does have the authority to do good deeds.”

headline: U.S. and Iraqi Forces Seek Abducted Britons in Raid
text: BAGHDAD, May 30 — American and Iraqi troops raided Baghdad’s Sadr City neighborhood on Wednesday, looking for five British citizens abducted a day earlier from a nearby government building, military and diplomatic officials said.

headline: China: U.S. Envoy in Talks About North Korea
text: Assistant Secretary of State Christopher R. Hill arrived in Beijing to work with Vice Foreign Minister Wu Dawei on reviving the stalled agreement under which North Korea would begin to dismantle its nuclear program. Mr. Hill maintained that the impasse was a technical matter and that North Korea remained committed to the deal. He declined to give any details of the talks.

headline: The Continuing Saga of SIPP
text: A year ago, the Bush administration decided to kill what is arguably the single most important survey on the effects of government programs on Americans’ lives. In a rare and welcome reversal, the administration has heeded the protest of policy experts and Congress and has decided to continue the project, known as SIPP, or Survey of Income and Program Participation.

headline: Melamine From U.S. Put in Feed
text: Ever since pet food contaminated with an industrial chemical was traced to shipments of wheat flour from China, American officials have concentrated on cracking down on imports.

headline: Southern Gothic: Ghosts Welcome
text: BATCHELOR, La.

headline: About Online Surveys, Traditional Pollsters Are: (C) Somewhat Disappointed
text: PARIS, May 27 — To traditional pollsters, a random survey adjusted to reflect the general population is the only way to measure public opinion properly.

headline: New York City Police Seek Trust Among Immigrants
text: Sidique Wai slipped into a mosque in Harlem as afternoon prayers broke, a wisp of a man swimming upstream against the crush of robed worshipers spilling out. He stepped out of his shoes and walked briskly to the front of the prayer room. A microphone was pressed into his outstretched hand.

headline: Rice Clashes With Russian on Kosovo and Missiles
text: POTSDAM, Germany, May 30  The United States and Russia, with relations between them at their most contentious since the collapse of the Soviet Union, openly sparred here on Wednesday at a meeting of foreign ministers of the Group of 8 industrialized nations.

headline: Thai Court Disbands Former Prime Minister’s Political Party
text: BANGKOK May 30  A constitutional court on Wednesday banned the political party of former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra after finding it guilty of election fraud in a ruling that could throw Thai politics into disarray.

headline: Big Disparities in Judging of Asylum Cases
text: Asylum seekers in the United States face broad disparities in the nation’s 54 immigration courts, with the outcome of cases influenced by things like the location of the court and the sex and professional background of judges, a new study has found.

headline: Small Business Not as Usual
text: Hannah Kain, a small-business owner in Fremont, Calif., started her packaging services business, ALOM Technologies, in 1997 with a $250,000 Small Business Administration loan. In 2000, her 70-employee company was singled out as an entrepreneurial success by the agency, complete with a ceremony in San Francisco.

headline: F.D.A. Still Unsettled in Wake of New Questions
text: ROCKVILLE, Md., May 30  When Dr. Andrew C. von Eschenbach took over the Food and Drug Administration in 2005, the agency had a crisis over drug approvals that had missed or ignored dangerous side effects in Vioxx, antidepressants and other prominent medications.

headline: Albany Close to Agreement to Ease Ticket Resale Limits
text: ALBANY, May 30 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer and state lawmakers are close to reaching agreement on dismantling laws that limit the resale of tickets to musicals, plays, concerts and sports events, but concerns raised recently by the Yankees and Mets appear to have held up a final deal.

headline: New Yorkers Slip in Survey on Spending
text: New Yorkers earn and spend much more than most other Americans do, but they no longer spend more than the residents of Chicago and Los Angeles, according to federal data released yesterday.

headline: If a Sofa Doesn’t Fit, They’ll Make It Fit
text: I GET calls at all hours of the night,” Shlomi Gal-On said recently, describing the vagaries of his work. “Usually there are tears involved.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a deadly clash between the police and supporters of Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, an ethnic Uzbek strongman in northern Afghanistan, referred incorrectly to Rais Qurban, deputy leader of a pro-Dostum youth movement. Mr. Qurban was one of the people reportedly killed; he was not the resident who said he thought that Rais Qurban had been killed.

headline: Valerie Wilson Sues C.I.A. Over Memoir
text: Valerie Wilson, the former Central Intelligence Agency operative at the heart of an investigation that reached into the White House, sued the agency in federal court in New York today over its refusal to allow her to publish a memoir that would discuss how long she worked for it.

headline: An Age of Reason, From Al Gore (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Four Charged in Tax Shelter Case
text: Four current and former partners of the accounting firm Ernst & Young have been charged with tax fraud conspiracy over their work on questionable tax shelters.

headline: New Jersey: Republicans File Suit Against Corzine
text: New Jersey Republicans filed a lawsuit today charging that Gov. Jon S. Corzine was violating the state’s open records act by refusing to release e-mail messages he exchanged with his ex-girlfriend, the president of a state employees union, during recent contract negotiations. Lawyers for the governor say that the e-mails between Mr. Corzine and Carla Katz, president of the communications Workers of America Local 1034, are protected by gubernatorial privilege. Mr. Corzine’s attorneys also point out that a state ethics panel has reviewed the e-mails and concluded that the governor acted appropriately. But Mark Sheridan, a lawyer for the state Republican committee, said that the public records law requires Mr. Corzine to disclose any e-mails that discuss the contract negotiations because they involve state business.

headline: U.S. Troops Raid Sadr City in Search for 5 Britons
text: BAGHDAD, May 31 — The search for five British civilians kidnapped from an Iraqi government building intensified Thursday, with American troops conducting raids in Sadr City and the Iraqi government pledging its support for an investigation.

headline: U.N. Approves Court to Prosecute Hariri Killing
text: UNITED NATIONS, May 30  A divided Security Council approved a resolution on Wednesday establishing an international tribunal to prosecute suspects in the assassination of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister.

headline: The Makeup Artist Presses the Flesh
text: WITH the chiseled looks of an Italian model and the charm of a politician on the campaign trail, Vincent Longo, the makeup artist, coasted onto the makeup floor at Barneys New York this month for his first personal appearance in two years.

headline: Mocking Stars and Beer Ads. Yawn.
text: The humor site FunnyOrDie.com, which first appeared in April, is exactly where venerable, broad, obvious, stable venture capital belongs. There is nothing there to frighten viewers or the tech market. Like, for example, a joke you haven’t heard.

headline: Manufacturer of Risky Drug to Sell Shares
text: Is a pharmaceutical company whose biggest-selling drug is considered as dangerous as heroin or LSD a good investment?

headline: It’s Time for Would-Be Champions to Get Their Signals Straight
text: The trials to select three United States world championship teams begin tomorrow in the Hyatt Regency Woodfield hotel in Schaumburg, Ill., with sponsorship from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

headline: British Academics’ Union Endorses Israel Boycott
text: LONDON, May 30  The main union representing 120,000 British college teachers voted Wednesday to endorse a Palestinian trades’ union call for a boycott of Israeli academic institutions.

headline: The Obama Health Plan
text: As a surgeon, I’ve worked with the veterans’ health system, Medicare, Medicaid and private insurance companies. I’ve seen health care in Canada, Britain, Switzerland and the Netherlands. And I was in the Clinton administration when our plan for universal coverage failed. So, with a new health reform debate under way, what I want to tell you in my last guest column is this:

headline: Jihadist Groups Fill a Palestinian Power Vacuum
text: JERUSALEM, May 30 — It was 2 a.m. when masked gunmen raided Al Wafa Net in the Khan Yunis camp in Gaza where 17 young men were surfing the Internet.

headline: Oral Dissents Give Ginsburg a New Voice on Court
text: WASHINGTON, May 30  Whatever else may be said about the Supreme Court’s current term, which ends in about a month, it will be remembered as the time when Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg found her voice, and used it.

headline: Speak Whale to Me
text: Cold Spring, N.Y.

headline: Suit Over C.I.A. Program
text: The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit against a Boeing subsidiary, alleging that the company provided flight plans for Central Intelligence Agency aircraft transporting terrorism suspects to overseas prisons where they say they were tortured. The latest of several legal challenges to the agency’s program of extraordinary rendition, the practice of seizing suspects and delivering them to security services in other countries, was filed in federal court in Northern California against the subsidiary, Jeppesen Dataplan, which provides flight plans, overflight permits and other services. The A.C.L.U.’s plaintiffs are Binyam Mohamed, an Ethiopian, and Abou Elkassim Britel, an Italian, who were allegedly taken to Morocco; and Ahmed Agiza, an Egyptian taken to Egypt. A Boeing spokesman declined to comment on the lawsuit or to confirm that the C.I.A. is a customer.

headline: Asbestos Award Upheld
text: A federal appeals court in Atlanta upheld a ruling yesterday awarding New York City more than $40 million from the trust for a bankrupt Florida-based asbestos company, the latest development in litigation that has lasted more than two decades. The company, the Celotex Corporation of Tampa, was among the companies sued by the city starting in 1985 to reclaim expenses incurred in removing asbestos from city-owned buildings. Celotex later filed for bankruptcy. New York City filed more than 740 claims in the case, but the Celotex trustees refused to pay some of them, arguing they were wrongly decided. Two judges and a federal court in Florida previously ruled in the city’s favor, most recently in April 2005. Yesterday, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, upheld the lower court rulings, bringing the total payments from Celotex, including $11 million from previous claims, to more than $55 million.

headline: Manhattan: Man Sought in Taxi Robberies
text: The police said yesterday that they were seeking a man who had robbed eight taxi drivers since May 17. In one case, the man showed a gun to the driver before demanding money, the police said. The robberies have occurred at various spots in Manhattan, all at night or in early morning, the police said. The suspect is described as a black man, 30 to 40, 6 feet 1 inch to 6 feet 3 inches tall, with a muscular build and a mustache and wearing a baseball cap. Drivers have been alerted to the robberies and urged to take precautions, said Matthew W. Daus, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

headline: Reyes Keeps On Playing Those Mind Games
text: José Reyes watched the highlights of Tuesday night’s bizarre 12th inning, and the memories came flooding back. Even two years later, they were still fresh.

headline: From Nike, Beat-Up Chic
text: THE prevailing mentality among sneaker enthusiasts, which doesn’t seem like a lot of fun, is never to wear the most coveted shoes for fear of a smudge. So a new collection of Nikes that look intentionally distressed could be seen as a reaction against the cult of the pristine.

headline: A Clean Start at the World Bank
